https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/05/busin.snippet: General Motors Corp has a deal for investors who own more than $363 million in two issues of its preferred stock; it wants to pay them higher rate of interest; proposal could cost GM an additional $2.7 million a year in payments to investors, but ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/05/busin.main_headline: Investors Get a G.M. Windfall, And G.M. Does All Right, Too
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/05/busin.print_headline: Investors Get a G.M. Windfall, And G.M. Does All Right, Too
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/05/busin.body_text: **********The General Motors Corporation has a deal for investors who own the more than $363 million in two issues of its preferred stock. It wants to pay them a higher rate of interest. **********G.M.'s proposal, announced this week, could cost the auto maker an additional $2.7 million a year in payments to investors. **********What's the catch? For the investor, there is none. The loser is Uncle Sam. For the newly offered securities would provide a tax break for General Motors. While it will pay investors more, it will end up at least $9 million richer after taxes. **********Such tactics have been available for years, but President Clinton has proposed closing that particular angle, and many expect Congress to include that proposal in this year's tax-cut bill. But it appears that the General Motors security would escape the Clinton bill because it is designed to fall at the edge of the arbitrary line set by President Clinton. **********In so doing, Merrill Lynch, which created the security for General Motors, illustrated the great difficulty for tax code writers in closing what they see as loopholes. New provisions in the tax code simply inspire new wrinkles on Wall Street. **********G.M. gets the tax break because while the new securities look and feel much like preferred stock -- the misleading name for the security is Trust Originated Preferred Securities -- they are actually counted as debt when General Motors files its tax return. And tax laws provide that interest paid on debt is deductible from a corporation's taxable income, while interest paid on preferred stock is not. **********Thanks to the unusual way the debt is structured, it will not show up as debt on General Motor's balance sheet. Instead, it will show up as a ''minority interest,'' a sort of semi-liability that usually appears when a subsidiary is only partly owned. **********And because G.M. will have a right to defer interest payments for up to five years, the bond rating agencies view such ''debt'' as being more like equity, and therefore give it little weight in deciding whether a given level of debt means a company's bond rating should be lowered. For G.M., the securities seem to be the best of both worlds -- the tax deduction of interest on debt with none of the negative balance sheet connotations of having too much debt. **********The Clinton proposal goes after that as follows: It provides that companies cannot deduct the interest as tax-deductible debt if the security is not shown as debt on the balance sheet and if its original maturity is at least 15 years. When it was proposed, that covered any such security, since they typically are issued with terms of 20 to 30 years. **********But the General Motors new security has a different tact. It is to be issued on July 2, and will mature on July 1, 2012. ''That's 14 years and 364 days,'' said Robert Willens, a tax expert at Lehman Brothers. ''This appears to be the first security of this type to be planned to come in under 15 years.'' **********The proposed effective date for the Clinton proposal is the date of the first action by a Congressional committee on the proposal, which could happen within the next few weeks. Other issues of similar securities this year have relied on getting in before the effective date, but it appears that General Motors was concerned about how long it would take to get an exchange offer done, and opted for the maturity provision. **********G.M. is actually offering two securities. In exchange for its Series D preferred, which pays an annual interest rate of 7.92 percent, it is offering a Series D Trust Originated Preferred Security paying an annual rate of 8.67 percent. For Series G preferred, which pays 9.12 percent a year, it is offering a Series G trust security, paying 9.87 percent. **********Because G.M. promised the original holders of the preferred that they would be listed on the New York Stock Exchange, it is offering to acquire only 90 percent of both issues, thereby leaving enough outstanding to maintain the Big Board listing. **********For holders considering the exchange, one argument against doing it is that the exchange will be a taxable event, providing a capital gain based on the value of the new security compared with the original cost of the preferred for the investor. And while call provisions on the two are similar, the new security has a provision allowing it to be immediately paid off if Congress changes the tax law in a way that would take away the tax break for that security. Changing the maturity requirement in the Clinton proposal could accomplish that. **********And for any corporate holders of the preferred, an exchange would be unwise because they would lose the dividend received deduction that reduces their corporate income tax. That consideration does not apply to individual investors, who own most of these securities. **********Otherwise, this is a case of G.M. offering to pay more than it is now paying. Effectively, investors are being offered an extra three-quarters of a percentage point a year to give G.M. a tax savings.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/01/world.snippet: Albania, poorest country in Europe, is sorting out devastating consequences of flim-flam schemes that have cost tens of thousands of desperately poor people their tiny savings; pyramid schemes have flourished in former Communist countries, but esp...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/01/world.main_headline: In a Poor Land, a Classic Swindle Leaves Rage and Emptier Pockets
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/01/world.print_headline: In a Poor Land, a Classic Swindle Leaves Rage and Emptier Pockets
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/01/world.body_text: **********Life was hard enough for Shpresa Rinxhi before she and her husband  scraped together $500 and put it into one of the most dizzying of Albania's dream machines, a so-called charity foundation that was promising a quick 300 percent return on their money. **********Together with their three children, the Rinxhis (pronounced REEN-jee) live in one room in a former workers hostel, cooking their dinners on a stove in the corridor, sharing a bathroom with eight other families. On his $60 a month salary from a state-owned cement plant, and the $2 a day she earns at their fruit and vegetable stand, the couple saw the promises of a fund called Xhaferri (pronounced jah-FEH-ree) as their only chance for a better life. And so, like hundreds of thousands of other Albanians, they chose to believe. **********If they had any doubts, those were washed away by the arrival here last November of Rrapush Xhaferri himself, a former army officer who had paraded his wealth by sponsoring a Miss Albania contest and hiring a highly paid Brazilian coach for his local soccer team. **********''He told us, 'Don't be afraid. The water in the sea will dry up before I run out of money,' '' recalled Edward Prushi, 32, an unemployed gym teacher who himself entrusted Xhaferri with the $1,000 he had saved during a stint as a construction worker in Greece, only to see it disappear into the sink-hole of a classic pyramid scheme. **********Now Albania, the poorest country in Europe, which six years ago emerged from the almost total isolation imposed by a harsh Communist regime, is sorting out the devastating consequences of the latest series of flim-flam schemes to hit Eastern Europe in the post-Communist era. **********Other countries new to the wilds of free markets -- Romania, Russia and Bulgaria, among others -- have seen similar schemes preying on  gullibility, ignorance and desperation, leaving the clients dazzled by the novel dream of getting rich. **********But the pyramid schemes in Albania -- there were at least 10 by some accounts, the largest of which remain nominally in operation -- lasted longer than anywhere else, in some cases for two years. **********By most estimates, the amount taken in from Albanians by various pyramid schemes was almost $1 billion, roughly three times the size of the national budget deficit. The investment schemes have touched almost every family in Albania. **********The prolonged success of the  funds, and their ability in the short term to deliver on the most fantastic of promises, was what led even cautious Albanians to take a risk. **********''The only people who did not lose money were those who couldn't put their hands on any,'' said Mr. Prushi. ''There were people who sold their houses, others sold their cows, and now their children don't even have milk.'' **********Mrs. Rinxhi reached for the cigarettes she started smoking again when the crisis began, her eyes filling with tears. ''We are in a terrible situation,'' she said. ''It can't be worse.'' **********Today Mr. Xhaferri is in jail, his fund seized by the Government; Marta, the woman who ran the local Xhaferri office, collecting wads of leks -- the Albanian currency -- from people who spent hours waiting in line, has disappeared. And the people of Fushe-Kruja, a shabby, dusty town of 25,000, responded last weekend by joining the rest of the country in street demonstrations, which, in some places have turned into near-riots. **********Thrown on the defensive, the center-right Government of President Sali Berisha has promised to restore at least some of the missing money to the people on Nov. 5, to be distributed through savings account passbooks and options to bid on state property. The Government has also lashed out at its already feeble opposition and has blamed opponents for fomenting the violence last weekend. **********But here, where the demonstrations were peaceful, residents insist that the Government is to blame for the catastrophe that has befallen them. Like many others, they are waiting to see if President Berisha fulfills his promise. ''We want our money,'' said Mr. Prushi. ''We don't want pieces of paper.'' **********Fushe-Kruja, like many small towns in this nation of 3.5 million,  was a relative late-comer to the national craze, which by October of last year had reached frenzied levels. By then funds like Xhaferri were stepping up efforts to collect more money, opening new offices, promising ever higher rates of return over ever shorter periods of time -- all signs that the bubble was about to burst. **********But when Mr. Xhaferri came here, nobody really wanted to ask him hard questions, like how he could promise to triple their money in three months in a country with meager investments and 20 percent unemployment. **********''We didn't ask anything about him,'' said Mr. Prushi. ''People were getting their money, and that was enough for us.'' **********But the longevity of the schemes is also seen as evidence that the Albanian Government tolerated, perhaps even encouraged the funds, despite repeated warnings from inside and outside the country, from the governor of the central bank to the International Monetary Fund. **********President Berisha, at a news conference this week, denied any Government involvement, and wrote off Albania's early laissez-faire approach as a sign of its commitment to free-market capitalism. **********''In a free and democratic society,'' said the president, ''borrowing is one of the inalienable rights of human beings. The Government will never dictate when to lend, when to borrow.'' **********Whether the Government was complicit in the schemes is still unclear, but it is certain that Mr. Berisha's Democratic Party -- with the endorsements of some of the biggest funds -- won national elections last May in a vote that international observers said was tainted by ballot-rigging and intimidation, and local elections last October. ''Vote Democratic Party and everyone wins,'' was one slogan that implicitly linked the party's success with the survival of the pyramid schemes. **********By last October, a year after the I.M.F. first registered its concern about Albania's free-wheeling ''informal market,'' the warnings had become increasingly urgent. According to Western financial experts, the I.M.F., at its annual meeting in Washington, was urging the Albanian Government to take immediate action. **********Shortly afterwards, Finance Minister Ridvan Bode went on the Government-run television network to warn people that the Government might have to investigate the funds. But his warning was drowned out by assurances -- also broadcast on Albania's tightly controlled official networks -- by some of the top fund managers that there was nothing to worry about. **********In the same period, Mr. Berisha, answering accusations about the thriving arms and drugs traffic that has spilled across Albania's borders and which many believe has helped fuel the pyramid schemes, reassured the people that ''Albanian money was the cleanest in the world.'' To many, that sounded very much like the Government's seal of approval. **********''That made us very sure,'' sad Haxhire Kadiu, a neighbor of the Rinxhis. ''Since these funds were approved and licensed by the Government, we believed them. Otherwise, why didn't they do anything to stop them?'' **********As the schemes grew bigger and bigger, their effect on the economy became more and more dangerous. Not only were people investing the little money they had, but many began to live off the interest payments that they continued to get as recently as last November. **********The Government's paralysis was obvious to all. ''You don't stop pyramid schemes and put hungry people on the streets a month before elections,'' noted one Western diplomat. **********The first sign of collapse came in November when a fund run by a 30-year-old former shoe factory worker, a woman widely known as Sude the Gypsy, stopped making payments. **********On Nov. 26 the manager of a smaller fund vanished with $13 million. By mid-January, Sude had declared bankruptcy, triggering the first street demonstrations. On Jan. 26, the state seized the $255 million held in state banks by Xhaferri and another fund, Populli, just two weeks before most families in Fushe-Kruja were due to get their money back, including profits. **********But the unanswered question is what will happen next, particularly with some of the larger investment funds, which many believe the Government could bail out, at some cost to the economy. **********''There are other schemes out there that are not solvent, and that is a major concern,'' said a Western financial expert. ''The Government faces a very, very difficult problem in trying to minimize the damage.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/08/world.snippet: Memorial to Holocaust victims, and two museums dedicated to Jewish life and culture, will open in Salonika, Greece, more than 50 years since Nazis wiped out all traces of city's Jewish past; all but one of its 36 synagogues were destroyed, and all...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/08/world.main_headline: Silence Ends, and Jewish Ghosts Are Remembered
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/08/world.print_headline: Silence Ends, and Jewish Ghosts Are Remembered
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/08/world.body_text: **********It has been more than 50 years since Nazi occupiers wiped out all traces of this port city's rich Jewish past. All but one of its 36 synagogues were destroyed, and all but a few thousand of a pre- war population of 56,000 Jews were killed in Nazi death camps. **********The war ended, and the survivors returned -- only to find that all traces of their tragedy, too, had somehow vanished. As at Babi Yar, the notorious Nazi mass grave in Ukraine where Soviet authorities for decades refused to acknowledge that most of the victims were Jews, Salonika has been slow to recognize that its large and vibrant Jewish community was singled out for annihilation. **********''There was such an unbearable silence about the Jews of Salonika,'' said Andreas Sefiha, the 69-year-old president of the city's Jewish community, who as a boy of 13 had managed to escape the occupied city in 1943 before the trains started leaving for Auschwitz. ''It was sometimes as if we had never existed. For my generation, it was like a second death.'' **********As Salonika, Greece's second-largest city, celebrates its turn this year as the European Union's cultural capital, the city is at last coming to terms with its own history. Its first monument to the victims of the Holocaust is to be erected soon in a downtown square, and two new museums dedicated to Jewish life and culture over the last five centuries are due to open this spring. **********Doing right by this Balkan city's past was ''one of the most difficult tasks'' that Panos Theodoridis, a writer and architectural restorer, said he confronted when he became the fourth artistic director of the organization in charge of events for the cultural-capital role. **********''People here tend to forget that this city was multinational right from the beginning,'' he said. ''Now it is time to pay homage to all those who formed the city's character.'' **********Mr. Sefiha, who took a leave from his family's machine-building business to devote his energies to a Jewish community that now numbers a mere 1,150, considers the establishment of the museums and the monument a belated act of justice. **********''I think after we have the monument, more people will be interested to know the history of this town -- why it is necessary to have a monument at all,'' he said. **********To the discomfort of local Greek nationalists, it is a history that was largely Jewish during the 500 years of Ottoman Turkish occupation, with strong influences of Armenians and the Turks themselves. The first great wave of Sephardic Jews came here in the late 15th century, expelled from Spain and Portugal. **********In time, the community grew with the arrivals of Ashkenazi Jews from Eastern Europe, until, by the late 19th century, Jews made up two-thirds of the population of this flourishing port city. **********Business was conducted either in French or Ladino, the Judeo-Hispanic language spoken by the Sephardim, and shops and offices closed on Saturday for the Jewish Sabbath. **********All evidence of this past is virtually gone now, and not only because of the Nazis. There were fires and earthquakes but also a local strain of Greek nationalism, fueled by the arrival in 1923 of about 160,000 ethnic Greeks transferred here from the Turkish mainland. **********Greece, a country where more than 95 percent of the population is Orthodox Christian, is still suspicious of its minorities, religious and ethnic, and still reluctant to grant them their place in history. Not only has Salonika never commemorated its Holocaust victims, but its children also find scant reference to the city's multicultural past in their school textbooks. **********''Nothing appears in the books -- no mention at all,'' said Mr. Sefiha. ''But I am sure one day people will write again the story of this town in a more objective way. '' **********The Jewish contribution to the city's past is not the only historical memory to have fallen victim here to a collective amnesia. In local guidebooks, and even in literature printed for this year's international cultural events, the five centuries of Ottoman rule are referred to euphemistically as the ''post-Byzantine'' period, a reflection of the strong anti-Turkish sentiment that is part of Greek consciousness. **********And yet, curiously enough, this was not always so. In the 1930's, in a gesture of good will to the modern secular Turkish state founded by Mustafa Kemal Ataturk, the local city council offered him as a gift the house where he had been born -- a modest, pleasant building with a garden, which has survived as one of the few examples of Turkish middle-class life in a city that was once the second largest in the Ottoman Empire. **********The house -- now attached to the heavily guarded Turkish Consulate -- is now not only forgotten, but deliberately ignored by local authorities, who never include it in any list of local historical attractions. **********Few Greeks are even aware that Ataturk was born in Salonika or that this was where the Young Turks began the revolution that eventually brought down the Ottoman Empire. The street along the side of the house, which was once called Ataturk Street, was long ago renamed. **********Place names are still a sensitive issue in this corner of the Balkans. Local sentiment is still strongly opposed to the idea that the name Macedonia -- the kingdom of Alexander the Great, the region's most illustrious native son -- be shared with the newly independent state next door, once one of the Yugoslav republics. Known as Macedonia to most of the rest of the world, here in northern Greece it is referred to elliptically as the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia (Fyrom for short, the temporary name used officially by the United Nations and foreign governments), and its people are called Skopjians, after the country's capital, Skopje. **********Under international pressure, Greece finally lifted its economic embargo against independent Macedonia in September 1995, but the dispute over the name -- now being negotiated in New York under the auspices of a United Nations mediator, Cyrus Vance -- still looms large, blocking a complete normalization of relations. **********Greek traders bringing goods south from Macedonia into Greece still have to snip off the ''Made in Macedonia'' labels and replace them with the more mysterious ''Made in Fryom.'' Macedonian bank and customs documents have to be retyped, just as televisions made in Turkey are refitted for trade here with labels reading ''Made in China.'' **********Such torturing of history, and reality, makes for a heavy burden, one that many here hope will be shed as this city -- and the turbulent region that it borders -- moves closer to modern European standards. **********''It is impossible to live within the European Union without being really European,'' said Mr. Sefiha. ''Greece still has to make a lot of steps in this direction.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/08/busin.snippet: Developments in takeover and legal battles between True North Communications and Publicis SA concerning True North's proposed acquisition of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt discussed(S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/08/busin.main_headline: True North Pushes Fight With Publicis
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/08/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; True North Pushes Fight With Publicis
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/08/busin.body_text: **********There have been further developments in the takeover and legal battles between True North Communications and Publicis S. A. concerning True North's proposed acquisition of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt. **********True North, in a letter sent Friday, urged that shareholders ''not act hastily'' on a hostile tender offer from Publicis for 9.62 million shares of True North stock at $28 a share, which would give Publicis control of True North. **********The letter said that the True North board would ''carefully consider Publicis's offer and report its recommendations to True North shareholders at the earliest practicable time.'' **********And Publicis Communication, the advertising unit of Publicis, filed a request on Friday to amend a suit filed Nov. 26 seeking to derail the Bozell, Jacobs acquisition. The request was filed in Federal District Court in Illinois. Publicis wants to add Bozell, Jacobs as a defendant and wants True North to change its anti-takeover provisions. Those provisions include a ''poison pill'' that complicates hostile efforts to acquire more than 25 percent of True North stock; Publicis now owns 18.4 percent and seeks to reach 50.1 percent through its tender offer. **********In one portion of the request to amend the suit, Publicis also contended that True North ''used a private investigator'' between September 1995 and February 1996 to investigate Maurice Levy, chairman and chief executive of Publicis.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/07/news/.main_headline: For Malaysia, Can One 'National Card' Do It All?
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/07/news/.print_headline: For Malaysia, Can One 'National Card' Do It All?
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/07/news/.body_text: **********KUALA LUMPUR—                     If the Malaysian government has its way, every person over 12 years old in this country of 20 million will soon have a piece of silicon in his pocket. **********Bidding is under way for a project that will produce the ultimate "national card" — a card with identification, driver's license, medical information and immigration status all crammed onto one computer chip. The card will also feature an electronic purse, replacing cash for small purchases. **********Similar plans for national cards exist in other countries — Singapore is working on a national card project, and South Korea is considering using chips in driver's licenses. **********But the people involved in Malaysia's one-citizen, one-chip project say it is the most ambitious plan by any country to combine government services on one card. **********Planners bill the project — part of the country's drive into the global multimedia industry — as a practical way to make government more efficient. The immigration portion of the chip will speed up border formalities, they say, and the health card will store medical information to improve diagnosis and emergency care. The electronic purse will eliminate the need for cash when buying things like a newspaper or a cup of coffee. **********The project, estimated to cost at least $800 million to launch, is being pushed by Prime Minister Mahathir bin Mohamad, who at age 71 has his own World Wide Web page (http://www.smpke.jpm.my/jaring/pm/pm.html). **********For years, officials in Malaysia — where citizens over age 12 already carry a paper national identity card — have been studying plans to streamline and harmonize government services, and now the effort seems embodied in the card project. The plan will, for example, require the police, doctors and newsstand vendors to have compatible chip-reading equipment, but each would have the ability to access only certain portions of the chip. The police will be able to store such data as traffic infractions on the card, and a newspaper vendor will be able to debit the card for the cost of a magazine. **********The project, if successful, would offer Malaysia the opportunity to export the system to other countries. "It's just going to put Malaysia so far ahead of the other countries that they're going to broker that into an intellectual-services industry," said Bob Hepple a smart-card specialist at Visa International, one of the bidders in the project. **********But given the scope of the plan, and the country's current financial situation, the "if" in the project looms large. **********"Politely, I would say it's going to be a challenge," said Alex Tan of Hypercom International, another company bidding for a role in the project. **********Tests are scheduled to begin next year, and residents of metropolitan Kuala Lumpur are due to be issued their cards before 2000. **********But already the card's planners have had to climb down from initial plans to include credit and debit card facilities in the first phase of the project, which would have created what one industry analyst called a "Chase Manhattan driver's license." **********Kuala Lumpur now plans to follow what is euphemistically called a "two-card approach." The government card would eventually be merged with a national payment card — a plan that skeptics say may never happen. **********Of more immediate concern to planners is the security of the card. Mr. Hepple of Visa offered this scenario: A person parks his car in the middle of Kuala Lumpur and pays the parking fee with the electronic purse function of his card. **********"Are people going to be comfortable that their name and address are available to that parking meter?" Mr. Hepple asked. "Is that parking meter going to break the law, decide that, 'O.K., this guy is obviously rich because he has a car. And he's not at home, so we can go and burgle his house?"' **********Chip designers and card manufacturers say there is always a technical answer to security concerns. "Data are put in separate compartments and guarded by secret keys," said Raphael Auphan, general manager in Malaysia for Gemplus, a leading smart-card company based in France. "Only certain devices can access the different compartments." **********But experts say they also wonder whether putting that much data on one piece of silicon is a good idea. **********"This would never go over in Germany or the U.S. or the Scandinavian countries," said a Malaysian official involved in the project. "In Malaysia, it's different. The minute we're born we already have a number. That's where the cultural differences come into play." **********Even with the Western countries seemingly out of the picture, the official said he was little concerned about room for growth outside of Malaysia, noting that expansion of the card system into the nine-member Association of South East Asian Nations, or ASEAN, might be the next step. **********"We are thinking about whether we should have an ASEAN-wide standard so that the card that is issued in Malaysia or Singapore or Indonesia can be used region-wide," the official said. **********"But we have to prove that it can work first in Malaysia."

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/30/busin.body_text: **********America Online to Give Refunds and Credits **********America Online agreed to give millions of dollars worth of credits and refunds as compensation for the network traffic jams that have been frustrating its customers. **********Threats of lawsuits by many states and an outcry from subscribers had clouded the company's prospects, and the announcement lifted the stock sharply even though the deal could be costly. $(Page A1.$) **********Ford Profits Increase **********Ford Motor reported higher earnings for the fourth quarter and all of 1996, despite continued losses in the European and Latin American divisions. $(D4.$) **********Strong Quarter for Philip Morris **********Philip Morris announced strong fourth-quarter earnings, powered by robust international tobacco profits and the better-than-expected performance of Marlboro cigarettes in the United States. $(D2.$) **********Late Surge Lifts the Dow **********A weeklong stock decline ended with a rally fueled by late buying. The Dow industrials rose 84.66 points; other indexes were up significantly less or declined. $(D8.$) **********Inflation-Indexed Bonds Do Well **********The Treasury's first auction of inflation-indexed securities went better than expected, with strong interest from institutional investors. The prices of other Treasury securities rose, with the 30-year bond yield falling to 6.90 percent from 6.92.$(D18.$) **********While the inflation-indexed bonds are seen by Wall Street as another way to make a buck, economists' pulses are racing over other uses. Peter Passell: Economic Scene. $(D2.$) **********Orders for Durable Goods Decline **********Unexpectedly, factory orders for big-ticket goods fell 1.7 percent in December, indicating that economic growth could be more restrained than many analysts believe. $(D4.$) **********No Jubilation Over Weaker Yen **********For Japanese exporters, the trouble should be over. ITT reiterated that it would probably take up to 10 business days to consider the offer. $(D4.$) **********Chiron Shuffling Its Top Ranks **********Chiron, a growing biotechnology company that has suffered setbacks in the last year, said it would seek a new president and chief executive to succeed Edward E. Penhoet, who will become vice chairman. $(D4.$) **********Trade Boom Bypasses Caribbean **********Caribbean economies are reeling from the effects of the North American Free Trade Agreement, which has lifted trade among the United States, Canada and Mexico but made it harder for smaller nations to compete. $(A1.$) **********A New Role For Kravis **********Henry R. Kravis, best known for multibillion-dollar deals as a founding partner in Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, has taken an interest in deal-making at a less rarefied level. He is chairman of the New York City Investment Fund, which incorporated last fall with the intention of creating jobs in New York, especially in poor and minority neighborhoods. $(B1.$) **********F.A.A. to Provide Safety Data **********The F.A.A. said it would release information on airline safety over the World Wide Web but that it would not rank carriers. $(B6.$)

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/29/world.snippet: Beoing Co, largest US exporter, begins lobbying blitz in Congress, along with host of other American corporations, for vote to renew China's most-favored-nation trade status; says if US makes misstep, China will do more business with Airbus Indust...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/29/world.main_headline: Boeing and Other Concerns Lobby Congress for China
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/29/world.print_headline: Boeing and Other Concerns Lobby Congress for China
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/29/world.body_text: **********Even though the annual Congressional vote on renewing China's most-favored-nation trading status is still several months away, the Boeing  Company has begun its lobbying blitz in Congress, along with a host of other American corporations that have billions to lose if the anti-China mood rolling through Washington vents itself in some form of trade action. **********Boeing -- America's largest exporter -- is repeating its familiarpitch: that if Washington makes a misstep, China will simply do more business with Airbus Industrie, the European aircraft consortium. At stake, they argue, is a $4 billion order for 100 planes that Airbus is already negotiating in Beijing this week, in preparation for a visit to China next month by President Jacques Chirac of France. **********Airbus's best negotiating card may be France's decision two weeks ago to vote against a resolution at the United Nations Human Rights conference in Geneva condemning Beijing. The United States supported the resolution, which failed. **********''When President Chirac arrives in Beijing in a few weeks, I am sure that he will be rewarded for that stance,'' said Larry S. Dickenson, Boeing's vice president for international sales. **********Every year Congress has threatened to revoke China's privileges, which simply amount to the normal trading preferences that the United States extends to virtually every country in the world, save Cuba, North Korea and a few other rogue  nations. And every year for 15 years, Congress has voted to renew China's most-favored-nation status. Last year the vote was overwhelming. **********This time, though, the politics of trade with China has changed. For the first time, the Christian right has entered the fray, arguing that renewal of the trade privileges has become a moral issue. ''The recent campaign-funding scandals have shown us that Beijing, while loudly protesting against our meddling in their internal affairs, is fully willing to meddle in our internal affairs,'' Gary Bauer, the president of the Family Research Council, a conservative group, said in this week's issue of Slate magazine. **********''Companies controlled by China's People's Liberation Army stand accused of smuggling arms to L.A. street gangs,'' he said. ''This should send a chill down every American spine. Can anyone believe that China's rulers would go on placidly trading with us if we had armed China's student democracy movement?'' **********The involvement of groups like Mr. Bauer's has created an odd alliance in Congress: labor union champions and liberals who have long complained that American jobs are being sacrificed to China find themselves  joining forces with conservatives who describe China as a current economic threat and a future military threat. **********''We've never seen anything quite like this,'' said a White House official who declined to speak for attribution. ''This is driving a real wedge that leaves us with only the moderate Democrats and the moderate Republicans.'' **********But interviews with several executives involved in the lobbying effort suggest that while the politics has  changed this year, the lobbying effort by major businesses has yet to adjust. Executives say they are confounded about how to deal with the allegations that China was seeking to influence the 1996 election here. **********''We don't want to discuss it publicly,'' said a senior executive of Ford Motor Company, whose written appeal to Congress points out that the Chinese auto industry is expected to become the ''third- or fourth-largest in the world'' by 2010, and argues that ''it is time that U.S. manufacturers establish a strong, competitive presence in China.'' **********''Whatever we say, we are either going to anger the Administration, the Republicans or the Chinese,'' the executive said. **********What is clear is that American business has given up any hope of winning ''permanent'' most-favored-nation status for China, which would end the annual debate over trade and China's human rights record. **********Instead, it is focusing on insuring that negotiations between China and the United States over China's entry to the World Trade Organization, the club of trading nations, do not collapse under the weight of the Congressional mood this year. **********''If we lose the opportunity to get China into a rule-based organization like the W.T.O. now,'' said Mr. Dickenson of Boeing, ''it will take us another five years to get back to the spot we're at today.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/04/world.snippet: British tabloids are keeping low profile in wake of death of Diana, Princess of Wales, to reduce public outrage over their usual frenzied coverage of her; have shifted to kinder tone in discussing her relationship with Emad Mohamed al-Fayed, who d...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/04/world.body_text: **********Three days after the death of Diana, Princess of Wales, in a car crash in Paris, editors and ombudsmen of Britain's tabloids are uncharacteristically silent. They are keeping a low profile to reduce public outrage over their usual frenzied coverage of the Princess. **********Some critics have suggested the sensational type of coverage the tabloids gave Diana contributed to her death since the fatal car crash occurred as she was being followed by several paparazzi, who sell their photographs to tabloids. **********A tone of remorse, mixed with attempts to place responsibility elsewhere, surfaced in page after page of British dailies. Only a few days ago they had been cashing in on Diana and her relationship with Emad Mohamed al-Fayed, a sometime film producer and the Harrods department store heir whom the tabloids often referred to as an ''Egyptian playboy.'' He was also killed in the crash. **********Since Monday, those tabloids have overflowed with kind, sober pictures of the couple. Gone were the bathing suits, bare skin and the grainy pictures of the couple during their vacations on Mediterranean beaches. **********Now Mr. Fayed, known as Dodi, is described as Diana's ''true love,'' the man who made her truly happy. And  The Sun, Britain's largest circulation daily, asserted today that in the last few weeks Prince Charles had been writing Diana, his former wife, affectionate letters. **********Alan Rusbridger, editor of The Guardian, a respected broadsheet, said of the tabloid editors: ''They have been on their best behavior. The fact that tabloid editors have made no public appearances at all indicates they are guilt-ridden.'' **********In an editorial on Monday, The Sun sought to diminish public pressure for new laws to rein in the tabloids.  ''Diana died in France,'' it said, ''a country which has the toughest privacy laws imaginable -- and the wildest of the paparazzi,'' who the editorial added, ''sell their pictures to a world market of newspapers, magazines and TV stations.'' **********Paul McCann, media editor of The Independent, another broadsheet, said of the tabloids' coverage of the Princess's death, ''Their message is don't blame the press and let us not jump to conclusions.'' **********''Almost every single tabloid was caught on Sunday, the day she died, with sarcastic and voyeuristic stories about her and Dodi,'' he said. **********Ombudsmen for five national and Sunday papers, mostly tabloids, refused comment about their editorial policy in response to telephone calls. **********The Press Complaints Commission, an informal body of self-regulation for the British press, began consulting its members on Tuesday to find new ways of curtailing intrusions into private lives by tabloids. **********''I think we have learned the enormous antipathy toward the press in the immediate aftermath of these events,'' Andrew Hutchinson, editor of The Daily Telegraph, another broadsheet, said in an interview. ''I am sure something will come out of it. Certainly in the medium term, newspapers will be careful about the sort of photographs they use. Whether this will go on in the long term remains to be seen.'' **********Some Government officials, like Foreign Secretary Robin Cook, had gone further, suggesting that voluntary understandings might not be sufficient. **********''She was regarded with such love and affection by the British people,'' Mr. Cook said of Diana. ''And this week we will have to reflect on whether that love and affection of the British people was truly reflected in the behavior of the British press towards her.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/18/busin.main_headline: Amex Specialists to Cover Options Losses
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/18/busin.print_headline: Amex Specialists to Cover Options Losses
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/18/busin.body_text: **********Specialists at the American Stock Exchange will pay for losses incurred when options trading was halted Tuesday, exchange officials said yesterday. **********The trading halt may have forced some investors to pay thousands of dollars more for options, which are used to bet on the direction of a stock or index. **********The American Stock Exchange halted trading in equity options and index options two hours early Tuesday when new software to increase options trading capacity failed. **********The exchange told customers that ''if they had orders in and they felt they were due an execution, to come in and request it and we would honor it,'' said Andy Schwartz, a member of the exchange's board of governors and senior partner at AGS Specialist Partners. **********Mr. Schwartz said the exchange would pay any losses. Joseph Stefanelli, executive vice president in charge of derivatives, later said the specialists who make options markets were responsible, not the exchangeas an institution. **********''We may, because of the specialists stepping up to the plate and doing the right thing, try to help them out if they have sustained some losses, but we have no policy on that,'' Mr. Stefanelli said. **********The shutdown may have been costly for some investors because stock prices soared while options trading was down; the Dow Jones industrial average gained 174.78 points.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/09/news/.main_headline: Facing U.S. Boycott, Drugmaker Returns Pill Rights to Creator : Opponents Of Abortion Force Shift By Hoechst
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/09/news/.print_headline: Facing U.S. Boycott, Drugmaker Returns Pill Rights to Creator : Opponents Of Abortion Force Shift By Hoechst
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/09/news/.body_text: **********WASHINGTON—                     Concerned that its image might be tarnished by high-profile pressure from American anti-abortion groups, the German pharmaceutical company that makes the RU-486 abortion pill said Tuesday it was transferring its patent rights to a creator of the drug. **********Hoechst of Germany said that its wholly owned French subsidiary, Roussel Uclaf, had signed an agreement to transfer rights to the drug without remuneration to a new French company, Exelgyn, being formed by Edouard Sakiz, 71, who was chief executive of Roussel Uclaf until 1993. **********Roussel Uclaf said it could find no buyer for the drug, which is now legally available in France, Sweden and Britain. **********U.S. anti-abortion groups reacted to the decision by noting that Hoechst's retreat would not necessarily limit availability of the drug. **********Hoechst, the fourth-largest drug manufacturer in the world, said there would be no interruption in availability of the drug in the three countries where it is marketed. Plans by a nonprofit group, the Population Council, to produce it in the United States by late this year were unaffected by the announcement Tuesday. **********Hoechst acknowledged that the heat of the debate over RU-486 in the United States was an important factor in its decision. The decision came a week after anti-abortion groups in the United States started a major campaign against a new antihistamine, Allegra, or fexofenadine, which Hoechst is counting on for substantial profits. **********"We didn't want to take the risk of boycotts, especially in the U.S.," said Catherine Euvrard, a company spokeswoman in Paris. She called the drug a "hot potato" and added, "This product can no longer be part of the strategy of an international company." **********The move will have greater symbolic than economic impact on the company. Profits from the drug's sales were $3.44 million last year, an almost negligible portion of the company's $7.5 billion in revenue. But Hoechst spent millions of dollars to develop the drug. **********Dr. Sakiz told the French newspaper Le Monde: "It's clear that in accepting, I'm going to become an easy target. It's true there's a risk that some people might consider me Satan. But I also believe we cannot abandon such an important molecular product that has so much promise." **********Proponents have vaunted RU-486 as a way to make abortion more readily available to women, particularly those who live far from clinics and might otherwise be unable to obtain it. Itsdetractors say the procedure is not as safe, simple or certain as proponents say. **********Hoechst has done little to market the abortion drug in recent years. But Ms. Euvrard said that Hoechst hoped that Dr. Sakiz would be "more proactive" in promoting it. **********She said that during a transition period, Hoechst would continue manufacturing the drug, while "doing everything it can" to help Dr. Sakiz set up his company, including providing stock of the drug's active ingredient. **********Dr. Sakiz will have the rights to drug distribution in every country but the United States, but Ms. Euvrard said the standards Hoechst has applied for selling RU-486 would continue to apply: Abortion must be legal in the target country; there must be a formal request from the country's government; there must be "a certain degree of consensus on abortion" in the country; high-quality medical centers must be available to ensure proper follow-up for women using the drug; distribution channels must be secure, to ensure that no black market in the drug emerges; and the drug prostaglandin, which is used in the procedure, must be available. **********One of the anti-abortion groups calling for the boycott of Hoechst's allergy drug, the Family Research Council, took out a full-page in USA Today against Allegra. A spokeswoman, Kristi Hamrick, said of Tuesday's announcement, "We're certainly going to have to evaluate this change." **********She said her group would continue to campaign against RU-486. **********The Planned Parenthood Federation of America, a group that advocates birth control and provides abortion services, denied that Hoechst's transfer of RU-486 could be viewed as a moral victory for abortion foes. **********"The fact is," said Margaret Conway, a Planned Parenthood vice president, "the opponents of medical abortion are the same extremists who want to outlaw all abortions, and that's simply not going to happen." **********The Population Council, which hopes to begin producing RU-486 in the United States by the end of the year, was measured in its own reaction to Tuesday's news. **********A spokeswoman, Sandra Waldman, said that Hoechst's shifting of patent rights outside the United States was not unlike the process in 1994 by which U.S. rights were granted to the Population Council. **********Roussel gave up trying to sell RU-486, or Mifepristone, in the United States because of opposition from abortion protesters. **********The council is now in the process of providing information on labeling and manufacture to the U.S. Food and Drug Administration. Final approval is expected to be granted later this year. **********The council has found a manufacturer for the drug, but the debate in the United States is so sensitive that it refuses to name, or even characterize, the company. The U.S. market for the pill has been estimated at $100 million annually **********RU-486 works by blocking the action of progesterone, a natural hormone essential for maintaining pregnancy. The drug must be given within three weeks after the first missed menstrual cycle.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/08/busin.snippet: After years of pouring billions of dollars into Hollywood film and television productions, European broadcasters are voicing outrage at the tactics a number of American studios are using to squeeze additional revenue out of non-U.S. buyers..For Eu...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/08/busin.main_headline: MEDIA MARKETS : Europeans Revolt at U.S. Studio Tactics
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/08/busin.print_headline: MEDIA MARKETS : Europeans Revolt at U.S. Studio Tactics
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/08/busin.body_text: **********After years of pouring billions of dollars into Hollywood film and television productions, European broadcasters are voicing outrage at the tactics a number of American studios are using to squeeze additional revenue out of non-U.S. buyers. **********For European viewers, the higher prices demanded by the Hollywood studios are often passed along as increased costs for digital pay-television packages, the broadcasters say. "It's an emotional issue for broadcasters," said James McNamara, president of Universal Television Enterprises. **********Ongoing disputes involving Viacom Inc.'s Paramount Pictures Corp., Kirch Group of Germany, Mediaset SpA, owned by the Italian media executive Silvio Berlusconi, France's Television Par Satellite digital network and others threaten future contracts. **********Past partnerships between American studios and European broadcasters have contributed more than $10 billion to Hollywood films and television series in the past two years, according to industry sources. **********European broadcasters once could pick and choose individual episodes of series, said Harry Evans Sloan, chairman and chief executive officer of the Luxembourg-based Scandinavian Broadcasting System Inc. **********"Now the major studios say you have to take entire series you haven't seen and others that have run for years that you don't want," he said. **********The Europeans are hitting back where it hurts, producing their own telefilms and series and turning away from U.S. programs, they say. **********"The prices have become so high for American series and films that it has encouraged a boom in German production, teaching us that German product draws more audiences," said Helmut Thoma, managing director of RTL Plus GmbH. **********"The big advantage of U.S. product was that it used to be affordable by comparison to producing in Germany. Now with the higher prices, it no longer makes sense," he said. **********Irate at being denied Paramount films it thought it had paid for, Italy's Mediaset is threatening to cancel future contracts. **********"Next year there may be no deals," Giovanni Stabilini, Mediaset's senior vice president for acquisitions, said at Mipcom, an international television conference that closed here last week. "Paramount loses its European locomotive if this practice continues." **********A spokesman for Kirch Group was equally incensed over Paramount's failure to provide films for which the German broadcaster thought it had contracts. In what are known in the media trade as "output deals," European broadcasters paid American studios large sums for their total output over periods ranging from three to 10 years, largely to guarantee that they would have the rights to hit films as lures for pay digital-television packages. **********In the first four months of 1996 alone, Kirch Group paid $3.5 billion for rights to films from Paramount, the Columbia-Tristar unit of Sony Entertainment Pictures Inc. and Discovery Communications Inc., the documentary network based in Bethesda, Maryland. **********Instead, Kirch, Mediaset and others who had contracted with Paramount discovered in recent weeks that overseas rights to major studio releases such as "Air Force One" and "Face/Off" had been sold to Buena Vista International, a branch of Walt Disney Co. The broadcasters will have to negotiate additional payments to acquire rights to Paramount's hit films, according to Mr. Stabilini. **********Gary Marenzi, president of Paramount's international television group, defended the studio, asserting that this was common practice. **********"We are not trying to avoid our obligations," he said. Mr. Marenzi declined to comment on the practice of linking series to hit films. **********Mediaset's Mr. Stabilini and RTL's Mr. Thoma, however, said depriving broadcasters of hit films may set a dangerous precedent. **********"This practice undermines the whole concept of the 'output deal,' which is structured on purpose specifically to obtain these locomotive feature films for TV," Mr. Thoma said. "All the other stuff — the series, the sitcoms and so on — are not successful, in Germany at any rate. Everyone is rethinking the whole situation." **********Meanwhile, independent producers complain that they are being shut out of overseas markets by the major studios. **********"When we go to some European stations, they say we've already got all these American programs that we had to take just to get 'Lost World,"' said Todd Leavitt, chairman of the television group of Alliance Communications Corp., based in Toronto. "We're being locked out." **********The industry is also seeing increasing conflict over producers holding back programs from broadcasters to supply their own channels. **********Children's programming, for instance, once destined for free television networks, is now being snapped up by pay networks such as Viacom's Nickelodeon, Time Warner's Cartoon Network and News Corp.'s Fox Kids, said Ronald Weinberg, president of Cinar Films Inc., a Canadian producer of children's films and television series.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/15/busin.snippet: The United States revived efforts Monday to liberalize global trade in financial services by presenting a fresh offer to open its banking and insurance markets to foreign operators and pressing rapidly developing countries in Asia and Latin Americ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/15/busin.body_text: **********The United States revived efforts Monday to liberalize global trade in financial services by presenting a fresh offer to open its banking and insurance markets to foreign operators and pressing rapidly developing countries in Asia and Latin America to follow suit. **********Washington's offer to put banks and insurers from other countries on the same footing in the U.S. market as their big American competitors is conditional on winning market-opening commitments from a substantial number of other countries, Jeffrey Lang, the deputy U.S. trade representative, said. **********"Major emerging markets in Asia and Latin America are absolutely critical" to reaching an agreement by a December deadline, said Mr. Lang, who made his comments before American officials formally presented the U.S. offer at the World Trade Organization in Geneva. **********Mr. Lang declined to specify individual targets, but U.S. and European officials have mentioned South Korea, Thailand, Malaysia, India and Brazil as being at the top of their lists. Malaysia, for example, has offered to allow foreigners to buy as much as 40 percent of local financial-service companies, a move that could actually require the insurer American International Group Inc. to get rid of half of its 80 percent holding in a Malaysian insurer. **********The American offer, which followed similar moves by the European Union and Japan in the past two weeks, was welcomed by WTO officials because the huge U.S. market makes Washington's participation vital to an accord. A U.S. decision to withdraw from a previous round of negotiations in 1995 torpedoed an accord then, although many countries have made interim commitments that run until the end of this year. **********"Without them, there is no deal," one official said, referring to the United States. **********WTO members had set a deadline of Monday for presenting offers. Negotiators will meet Thursday in Geneva to discuss them. **********Mr. Lang said he was encouraged by signs that developing countries increasingly regarded opening their own markets as essential to tapping global capital markets to finance their growth. WTO officials agreed, saying that neither Thailand nor the Philippines had shown signs of backtracking in the talks despite recent financial turmoil that forced them to devalue their currencies. **********Under the new offer, the United States would open up its financial-services markets to new investment from non-U.S. companies, instead of only to companies that have established U.S. subsidiaries as at present. Unlike the U.S. offer of 1995, the new proposal also makes non-U.S. companies eligible to benefit from any future financial-services deregulation in the United States. **********Non-U.S. companies would have the same opportunities to conduct interstate banking as their American counterparts, and they no longer would have to pay special fees for supervisory examinations.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/08/world.snippet: Michael Manley, who dominated Jamaican politics for a generation and became one of most eloquent spokesmen for third-world causes, dies at 72; political career reviewed; photo (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/08/world.main_headline: Michael Manley, Ex-Premier of Jamaica, Is Dead at 72
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/08/world.print_headline: Michael Manley, Ex-Premier of Jamaica, Is Dead at 72
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/08/world.body_text: **********Michael Manley, who dominated Jamaican politics for a generation and became one of the most eloquent spokesmen for third-world causes, died Thursday night at his home outside Kingston. He was 72 and had long suffered from prostate cancer. **********In a political career that began under British colonial rule in the 1950's and ended only when declining health forced him to step down as Prime Minister in 1992, Mr. Manley championed issues ranging from Caribbean solidarity to the reordering of the global economy. **********He was born to wealth and privilege but made his mark as an advocate for the impoverished and underprivileged, in Jamaica and throughout the developing world. **********''Gross maldistribution of the world's wealth and food is no longer a moral offense only,'' Mr. Manley wrote in an article for The New York Times in 1975 that was a typical expression of his political views. ''It now represents the greatest practical threat to peace and to any desirable development of mankind.'' **********Prime Minister P. J. Patterson, Mr. Manley's protege, described his predecessor as a ''colossal figure,'' and Jamaicans began lining up before dawn yesterday outside the Prime Minister's official residence to offer their condolences. **********Michael Norman Manley was born in Kingston on Dec. 10, 1924, into one of the island's most notable families. His father, Norman Washington Manley, was an Oxford-trained lawyer and orator who was to lead Jamaica to independence as Prime Minister from 1955 to 1962. His English-born mother, Edna Swithenbank Manley, was a prominent sculptor. **********From birth, Mr. Manley was raised in an atmosphere that combined political and artistic ferment. Norman Manley founded the People's National Party, which would eventually serve as the vehicle to power for both father and son, in 1938, while Edna Manley became the focal point of a lively circle of artists, poets and musicians who made the Manley estate, Drumblair, their second home. **********Though Mr. Manley later said he considered himself ''the most privileged man in Jamaica'' because of that upbringing, he enlisted in the Royal Canadian Air Force as an 18-year-old, in part to establish an identity independent of his glittering parents. He served a year and a half but did not see combat. **********Once World War II ended, he enrolled at the London School of Economics, where he was exposed to the democratic brand of socialism espoused by Harold Laski, who became his intellectual mentor. **********After his return to Jamaica in December 1951, Mr. Manley quickly became involved in the trade union movement, focusing his efforts on improving salaries and living conditions for the island's sugar and bauxite workers. In 1962, when Jamaica achieved independence from Britain, he was appointed to the Senate; five years later, he was elected to Parliament and became vice president of the party his father was still leading. **********In 1969, Norman Manley died, and Michael Manley succeeded him as president of the People's National Party. Tall, handsome, charismatic and a spellbinding orator who enthralled large crowds on the campaign trail, Mr. Manley won a landslide victory in the general election that followed in 1972, becoming Jamaica's fourth Prime Minister. **********Once in office, Mr. Manley set out to reduce what he called the ''irrational and dangerous'' economic inequalities and class divisions that defined Jamaican society. He expanded the health and education systems, organized job training programs for the young and the unemployed, fostered racial pride and tried to encourage agricultural self-sufficiency through state farms. **********That same year, Mr. Manley addressed the United Nations and chastised what he called ''the misplaced priorities'' of its members, ''especially the most powerful and wealthy ones.'' Along with Prime Minister Indira Ghandi of India and President Julius K. Nyerere of Tanzania, Mr. Manley became one of the most outspoken advocates of what he called a new international economic order for developing nations. **********''The point is that now some two-thirds of mankind have been reduced to a peripheral status in political, economic and even social terms,'' he wrote. The solution, he argued, was a redistribution of the world's wealth, with the poor countries that ''own the resources and provide the essential infrastructure and the labor force'' getting a larger share. To do that, he argued in one memorable phrase, capitalism should be demolished ''brick by brick.'' **********At home, he tried to put theory into practice by raising royalties on exports of bauxite, the ore from which aluminum is made, and acquiring a controlling share of American and Canadian bauxite companies. He was successful on both counts, but in doing so antagonized the Nixon and Ford Administrations. **********Mr. Manley also sought a much closer relationship with Cuba, which further strained his ties with the United States. He imported hundreds of Cuban doctors, teachers and construction workers and invited Fidel Castro, whom he described as ''a man of extraordinary political sophistication,'' to visit Jamaica. **********Later, Mr. Manley said that even though the United States ''overreacted'' to his friendship with Mr. Castro, he too bore part of the blame for the deterioration of Jamaica's relationship with Washington. ''We became defiant about it, and that was a mistake,'' he said in 1988. **********Though of mixed racial background, Mr. Manley also became one of most forceful boosters and benefactors of the Black Power movement that swept the Caribbean. **********''An epoch of brainwashing in white-oriented society has left scars which, however unconscious, mar the inner assurance with which black people accept their own forms of beauty and excellence,'' he proclaimed in 1969. **********In his 1972 election campaign, Mr. Manley often wore African garb and carried the ''Rod of Joshua,'' an ebony-and-ivory staff said to have been given to him by Emperor Haile Selassie of Ethiopia, as a symbol of moral authority and black pride. That helped win him the support of the Rastafarian movement and other black nationalists initially suspicious of his cosmopolitan, mulatto background. **********As Prime Minister, Mr. Manley encouraged and subsidized Afro-Caribbean forms of cultural expression like reggae music, which became a global phenomenon during his tenure, persisting even when the lyrics of some songs criticized his policies. ''If anybody is going to protest against me, at least I want them to do so with style,'' he once said, with characteristic good humor. **********After more than 100 people were killed in outbreaks of gang and political violence in 1976, Mr. Manley, attributing the clashes to right-wing opponents, imposed a state of emergency. He won another resounding victory at the polls that year, but his second term was marked by increasing polarization and a sharp economic decline, which forced him to seek loans from his ideological adversaries at the International Monetary Fund. **********In 1980 he was decisively defeated by a conservative, Edward P. G. Seaga of the Jamaica Labor Party, after a campaign in which an estimated 700 people were killed. His party boycotted the election called in 1983, complaining that promised electoral reforms had not been carried out, and it was not represented in Parliament for the next six years. Mr. Manley spent much of that time working on behalf of the Socialist International. **********But he was returned to power early in 1989, after promising not to repeat the errors of his first period in office. He patched up his ties with the private sector and with the United States, saying at a news conference just after he was elected that ''to allow ourselves to slide into an unnecessary state of tension'' with Washington was a blunder ''that can never happen again.'' **********''I kept thinking that you could make the world economy submit to a system of political management to safeguard against injustice and inequity,'' Mr. Manley said in another interview that year, analyzing his earlier outlook. ''I didn't realize the forces of production are too powerful, and their inherent logic too irresistible, to be made subservient to political barriers on a permanent basis.'' **********As a result of his change of heart, Mr. Manley largely pursued orthodox free-market economic policies during his second stint in office. He let the Jamaican dollar float, removed price controls and subsidies, sped up the privatization of state-owned enterprises and relaxed restrictions on foreign investment, all of which won him praise from the United States. **********''He has set a great example, and I admire his stance,'' President George Bush said. Nevertheless, Mr. Manley continued to assert that he was a socialist, arguing that ''socialism is about equality'' and vowing never to give up his commitment to economic and racial justice. **********In 1992 he announced that he would step down for health reasons. He had undergone five operations for prostate cancer, diverticulitis and pneumonia, in which part of his lung and colon had been removed. In retirement he spent most of his time growing coffee and flowers on his farm outside Kingston or following sports, especially cricket, which he deeply loved. **********Mr. Manley, who began his career as a journalist, first with the BBC and The Observer in London and later with newspapers in Kingston, was also the author of seven books and many essays and articles. His books ranged from a collection of his speeches and political volumes like ''Poverty of the Nations: Reflections on Underdevelopment and the World Economy'' to ''A History of West Indies Cricket.'' **********His body is to lie in state at the National Arena in Kingston next Friday and Saturday, the Government announced yesterday, and after a state funeral on March 16 will be buried at National Heroes' Park. **********Mr. Manley is survived by his fifth wife, Glynne Ewert, and five children: Rachel, Joseph, Sarah, Natasha and David.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/18/world.snippet: Some 1,100 Zapatista rebels in black masks have been visiting Mexico City, reawakening public sympathy for their lagging effort to defend Mexico's Indians from their Chiapas state strongholds; make no progress toward reopening peace talks with Gov...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/18/world.main_headline: Rebels' Journey Leaves Mexico Confused About Their Role
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/18/world.print_headline: Rebels' Journey Leaves Mexico Confused About Their Role
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/18/world.body_text: **********In the fourth year since the Zapatista rebels began a quixotic uprising from southern jungles, their movement has become the equivalent for the Government of a bad elbow, causing no actual trauma but making the nation feel that it is not really well. **********Some 1,100 Zapatista militants in black face masks spent the last five days in Mexico City, their first visit to the capital since their ragged army burst into view on Jan. 1, 1994. Their sojourn, which ends today, served to reawaken public sympathy for their lagging cause and rekindle the rebels' determination to pursue their defense of Mexico's Indians from their strongholds in the state of Chiapas. **********But the Zapatistas' stay produced no progress toward reopening peace talks with the Government that lapsed a year ago. The Government allowed them to move about freely but offered no new negotiating proposals. The Zapatistas only created confusion over whether they want to continue as a guerrilla army, albeit a feeble one, or lay down arms. **********Zapatista leaders had said the purpose of their long march to the capital was to inaugurate a new civilian front to serve as a landing pad for rebels who want to put down their weapons. But on Saturday the rebels read a communique from Subcommander Marcos, their highest non-Indian leader and chief strategist, saying they would not join the new front, even though it bears the Zapatista name. **********''The Government uses the lie of a peace which means nothing more than surrender and punishment for us,'' Subcommander Marcos wrote. He accused the Government of failing to comply with partial peace accords signed in February 1996, and of stepping up army surveillance in their communities in Chiapas. **********More than 2,000 delegates from civilian support groups across Mexico went ahead and formed the political front, with the rebels from Chiapas standing by as ''observers.'' Leaders of the new organization were adamant that it would not be a political party but were hard pressed to explain exactly what it would do. **********The Government, which welcomed the Zapatistas' visit as a sign that they are moving toward peaceful means of protest, once again rejected their demands for greater autonomy for Indians as dangerously separatist. **********''The solution to the conflict in Chiapas cannot go against the unity and cohesion of Mexico,'' Interior Minister Emilio Chuayffet warned. **********The only forward movement came from the Congress, where the opposition now controls the lower house. Porfirio Munoz Ledo, the leader of that chamber, said he plans to introduce a bill this week that would translate the 1996 accords into law. **********At least one important by-product of the visit was the education of the militants themselves. At first the Zapatistas set up tight security perimeters everywhere they went, using sympathizers standing shoulder to shoulder. They remained aloof from supporters and bullied the clamoring press. **********By Tuesday they had abandoned their fears and military discipline and put on an easygoing rap session and soccer match with students on the campus of the national university. **********A Chol Indian from a Chiapas jungle hamlet, who mixed happily with the students, said: ''I have been able to see with my own eyes that people support us. We were not crazy or disoriented just because we have been off in the jungle.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/26/busin.snippet: *Unilever enrolls film maker David Lynch to direct television advertising campaign for new home pregnancy test, Clear Blue Easy One Minute; commercials for test offer toned-down version of Lynch's notoriously offbeat trademark style, which incorpo...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/26/busin.main_headline: The offbeat film maker David Lynch directs a campaign for Unilever's home pregnancy test.
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/26/busin.print_headline: The offbeat film maker David Lynch directs a campaign for Unilever's home pregnancy test.
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/26/busin.body_text: **********AS if pregnancy were not a surreal enough topic on its own, Unilever has enrolled the notoriously offbeat film maker David Lynch to direct a television campaign for a new home pregnancy test. **********The commercials for the test, Clear Blue Easy One Minute, offer a toned-down version of Mr. Lynch's trademark style of dreamlike sequences and irrational events, which he has displayed in films like ''Blue Velvet'' and the television series ''Twin Peaks.'' **********In the spots, by Ogilvy & Mather in New York, a woman stands in her bathroom and watches the crucial minute tick past. As she waits to learn whether she is pregnant, the numbers on the watch face turn into ''yes'' and ''no.'' Then the ''hot'' and ''cold'' labels on her sink faucets, and even drops of water falling from the spigot, do the same. **********''When you're waiting to find out if you're pregnant or not, nothing else in the world matters until you know,'' an announcer says as the woman waits. As the spots close, we see the woman smile mischievously when she gets her answer, though we never learn whether she is expecting. **********''When we went to consumers in the storyboard stage, they told us the basic idea totally captured the way that women feel when they think they're pregnant,'' said Natasha Kavanagh, the management supervisor for the campaign at Ogilvy & Mather, part of the WPP Group. **********''This is a very different kind of advertising than is typically done for this category,'' she added, ''which tends to be rather uninteresting and predictable.'' **********The Clear Blue line of products, which also includes Clear Plan Easy, an ovulation test, is made by Unipath Diagnostics, an American subsidiary of Unilever that markets women's health products. The $7 million campaign for the one-minute test, which consists of three commercials -- one 30 seconds long and two 15 seconds long -- will run nationally starting on Monday. It has run in local markets, including Chicago; Little Rock, Ark., and Tampa, Fla., since June 12. **********Mr. Lynch, who declined to be interviewed for this article, apparently expressed interest in the campaign early, when the agency was showing the storyboards for the spots to several directors. At first, his interest surprised both Unilever and Ogilvy & Mather. **********''Given how edgy some of his work is, it's questionable whether he would've been our first choice,'' said Alastair Paton, general manager of Unipath. ''We chose David not on the basis of his reputation, but on his interpretation of what the story- boards meant to him.'' **********In the last nine years, Mr. Lynch has directed commercials for 10 other campaigns, ranging from spots for Opium perfume by Yves Saint Laurent to public service announcements for the American Cancer Society to spots for Alka-Seltzer Plus. In addition to ''Blue Velvet,'' released in 1986, his film credits include his 1976 debut, ''Eraserhead,'' and ''The Elephant Man'' in 1980, ''Wild at Heart'' in 1990 and ''Lost Highway'' last year. The television show ''Twin Peaks'' achieved widespread popularity during its run on ABC in 1990 and 1991, and its look is considered to have influenced current series like ''The X-Files.'' **********David Cohen, executive producer of the commercials, said that Mr. Lynch was attracted to the campaign for reasons more mundane than one might expect from the creator of characters like Frank Booth, the sadistic, irrational man portrayed by Dennis Hopper in ''Blue Velvet.'' **********Mr. Lynch believed the spots ''had a solid concept,'' Mr. Cohen said, ''and they were nicely thought through in graphics and in terms of telling the story.'' **********Clear Blue Easy holds a 6 percent share of the $206 million market for home pregnancy tests in the United States. The leading test, with 23 percent, is E.P.T., made by the Warner-Lambert Company. Commercials for E.P.T., by J. Walter Thompson New York, another unit of WPP, show women talking about getting wrong results with home pregnancy tests and assert that E.P.T. is highly accurate and easy to use. **********''The ads feature women sharing their real-life experiences,'' said Jeffrey Baum, a spokesman for Warner-Lambert in Morris Plains, N.J., ''and we found that consumers can relate.'' **********With the commercials by Mr. Lynch, Unipath says it wants to add more depth to its campaign. **********The idea ''required an understanding of female psychology and the nervous excitement that someone feels when they think they're pregnant,'' Mr. Paton said. ''We looked at the emotional process involved.''
