https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/28/world.main_headline: East German Ex-Spymaster Found Guilty, but Goes Free
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/28/world.print_headline: East German Ex-Spymaster Found Guilty, but Goes Free
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/28/world.body_text: **********Markus Wolf, the former East German spymaster who undermined and outsmarted his adversaries for decades during the cold war, was found guilty today on three counts of kidnapping dating from the 1950's and 1960's, but was given a two-year suspended sentence that allowed him to go free. **********His trial in Dusseldorf represented one of few conclusive attempts by the reunified Germany to bring the onetime Communist leadership to book for deeds that grew from and cemented the country's division. **********Mr. Wolf, 74, had dismissed the hearings as a political show trial.  The suspended sentence gave him his liberty in a glare of free publicity just days before the June 1 publication of his memoirs in 14 countries including the United States. **********In the weeks before the verdict today, pre-publication serialization of the memoirs has infuriated many politicians here by accusing the late Herbert Wehner -- a towering Social Democrat in West German politics -- of maintaining conspiratorial links to the erstwhile East German authorities. **********But, from a cinematic viewpoint, the memoirs' most striking picture is of two C.I.A. operatives arriving at his country home outside Berlin in 1990 -- a few months after the fall of the Berlin wall -- laden with pralines and flowers and offering him a new identity in California and a large amount of money in return for the names of his agents. **********Today's verdict followed six years of efforts by German federal prosecutors to punish Mr. Wolf for his role as head of East Germany's foreign intelligence department -- a position that once earned him the sobriquet of ''the man without a face'' among Western intelligence operatives who, for years, did not know what he looked like. **********In 1993 -- two years after he gave himself up to the German authorities -- the same Dusseldorf court convicted Mr. Wolf on treason charges and ordered him jailed for six years. But the verdict was overturned in 1995 after Germany's highest court ruled that former East German intelligence officials could not be accused as traitors for espionage activities in their own country. **********Last January prosecutors invoked East German law to charge Mr. Wolf with kidnapping, coercion and causing bodily harm -- offenses subject to a statute of limitations for former West German spies but not for their East German counterparts. **********The case has provoked debate between easterners and westerners over the same issue that troubles other countries, from South Africa today to Germany a half-century ago: How should figures from the past be dealt with when repressive regimes give way to democratic successors? **********Mr. Wolf and his supporters -- some of whom crammed the Dusseldorf courtroom today to greet him with applause and roses -- maintain that he has been tried as an emblem of a defeated regime by vengeful people who still cannot come to terms with his ability to hoodwink them. **********But the presiding judge in Dusseldorf, Ina Obst-Ollers, argued today, ''I want to set it straight that he was not convicted because he was a Stasi symbol.'' Stasi is the shortening of the German state security apparatus in which Mr. Wolf worked. ''He was accused of concrete crimes.'' **********Those crimes included the abduction of a Stasi defector from Austria in 1962, the 1955 kidnapping of a German translator working for the United States authorities in West Berlin and the 1959 detention of an East German typesetter who had worked for the Gestapo in occupied Norway during World War II. **********The prosecution, which dropped separate treason charges three weeks ago to speed up the hearings, had demanded a jail term of three and a half years, and defense lawyers depicted the two-year suspended sentence as a victory. **********''I should be able to live with this judgment if I did not believe it was a violation of the law and the Constitution,'' Mr. Wolf said. He betrayed no emotion as the verdict was read. Both defense and prosecution now have one week to consider appeals. **********Mr. Wolf was head of East Germany's foreign intelligence agency from 1953 to 1986, running a network of some 4,000 agents. Possibly the most illustrious of those was Gunter Guillaume, infiltrated into the personal office of former Chancellor Willy Brandt. The unmasking of Mr. Guillaume in 1974 brought down Mr. Brandt's Government. **********In his memoirs, however, Mr. Wolf chronicles what United States and other Western intelligence services long suspected about West Germany in the cold war, namely that many of its officials maintained clandestine contacts with the Communist East and passed on classified information about United States and NATO intentions. The memoirs are being published in Germany as ''Spy Chief in the Secret War,'' by List Verlag, a unit of Axel Springer Verlag, and in the United States as ''Man Without a Face,'' by Times Books/Random House, a unit of Advance Publications. **********So keen was American intelligence to find out the extent of his knowledge, Mr. Wolf says in the memoirs, that, in May 1990, Gardner Hathaway, the just-retired assistant C.I.A. director for counterintelligence, and another agent appeared at his door with an offer from the then-C.I.A. chief, William Webster. **********Seeking to lure the East German with a ''seven-figure sum'' and a home in California, Mr. Hathaway reportedly told Mr. Wolf, ''California is very beautiful, great weather.'' **********''Siberia isn't bad, either,'' Mr. Wolf said he replied.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/15/busin.body_text: **********The Federal National Mortgage Association met analysts' expectations for the fourth quarter with a sharp jump in earnings. **********And the company provided a clear sign that it has learned to manage earnings growth in diverse interest environments, analysts said yesterday, with a 15 percent year-over-year increase in earnings for 1996 -- a year that saw mortgage rates climb more than 100 basis points and then fall another 70 basis points. **********Fannie Mae is a Government-sponsored enterprise created to buy loans from primary lenders to return funds to the mortgage market. **********Fannie Mae reported fourth-quarter earnings of $712.1 million, or 65 cents a share. But the pace of any recovery will be plodding, economists w...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/07/busin.body_text: **********Germany's economy, which slowed to a standstill in recent months, appears set to resume a course of subdued growth, according to a raft of employment and economic data released Thursday. **********But the pace of any recovery will be plodding, economists warned, meaning that any gains in economic output this year will not significantly remedy Germany's record unemployment, which worsened again in February. **********High unemployment, which pollsters say has led Germans to lose confidence and see themselves living in a time of upheaval and uncertainty, will keep consumer demand muted and contribute to the sluggish economic pace, economists said. **********The Federal Labor Office reported that another 5,000 Germans lost their jobs in February, bringing the seasonally adjusted total to 4.32 million, a rise that was surprisingly less threatening than many had feared. The seasonally adjusted unemployment rate was unchanged from January at 11.3 percent. **********Unadjusted for seasonal factors, the jobless total increased 14,000 to 4.67 million, with the unadjusted quota similarly unchanged at 12.2 percent. **********The rise of 5,000 in February was slight compared with the shock increase of 145,000 in January. Coupled with other figures announced on Thursday, the jobs report showed a hopeful break in the clouds, analysts commented. **********"The latest economic indicators suggest that the growth pause should be overcome in the months ahead," said Holger Fahrinkrug, analyst at UBS. **********Any economic revival follows a half-year of stagnation, according to the annual spring survey of business sentiment by the German Chamber of Industry and Commerce. Based on a poll of 25,000 member companies, the federation warned that the economy remained at a standstill during the first quarter after growth stopped in the last three months of 1996. **********The economy also will have to do without a rate stimulus. The Bundesbank kept its interest rates unchanged at a meeting of its board Thursday.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/16/world.snippet: Albania, along with violent political turmoil, is also experiencing deep social and cultural upheavals as peasants desert infertile rural regions and traditional culture for Tirana and modern way of life; ever-widening encampments of squatters hav...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/16/world.main_headline: In a Land Adrift, the Albanian People Drift Too
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/16/world.print_headline: In a Land Adrift, the Albanian People Drift Too
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/16/world.body_text: **********Following the custom of her clan, Miranda Cara, a young woman from the remote northern mountains of Albania, has been creating her dowry, embroidering pillowcases and tablecloths with colorful needlework. **********But for the past several years, Miss Cara, 20, a petite figure with deep brown eyes and long dark hair, has had less time for sewing or dreaming of a wedding than she did when she was younger. She moved with her family to the outskirts of this dusty capital, among the hundreds of thousands of internal migrants who have deserted the infertile rural regions of Europe's poorest country for the lure of the city. **********She said she prefers her tedious low-paying factory job to being married off by her parents to a man they would choose and whom she would be obliged to serve for the rest of her life. **********In male-dominated Albania, a dowry is not a sign of wealth but rather a sign of servitude. Until recently, the bride's parents put a bullet inside the dowry box to show that if their daughter was not dutiful, the husband could shoot her. Bullets are no longer de rigueur, but the attitude prevails. **********This has created a clash between  traditional culture, which is gradually fading, and an aspiration for a modern way of life. **********''In my rural society, it is unimaginable to send daughters to work,'' Miss Cara said. ''They are all trying to get their daughters married,'' she added, relaxing after eight hours on a tiring assembly line. ''There, society has its rules and if you step over them, you are an outsider.'' **********Tirana was once off-limits to peasants, who were forbidden by the rigid Communist system to move from their villages. But the city's population has more than doubled -- to about 500,000 -- in the last five years. That has created deep social and cultural upheavals along with Albania's violent political turmoil. **********Ever-widening encampments of squatters have circled the city, where the horse-drawn buggies of the countryside compete with the shiny new Mercedes-Benz cars of young drug runners. Everyone has been drawn by the economic free-for-all, which includes legitimate industries as well as drug smuggling. People like Miss Cara move to the city for jobs that pay $35 a month in light industries that make cheap goods for export to Italy. Albania's average wage is about $60, by far the skimpiest in Europe, but even with a small salary by Albanian standards, Miss Cara considers herself lucky to have a real job. **********Her father, Han, a 55-year-old former copper miner who began working at age 13, sold the family apartment in Kukes, a historic Muslim town, and packed the family onto a bus for the nine-hour journey over winding roads to the capital. **********''It was cold, there was no work and when you see everyone leaving, you leave too,'' said Mr. Cara, who lost his job in the mines and whose wife, Naile, had been laid off as a hotel cook. **********They brought with them a 20-year-old wood-burning stove, a few pieces of furniture, a little cash from the sale of their apartment and five nearly adult children. Since arriving in the flatland around Tirana, the Cara family has gone through profound change. **********They settled in a makeshift hut on  land, which, like other squatters, they did not buy. They then built their three-room house, sifting the sand for the cement and laying the cinder blocks. With their new neighbors, they banded together to protest a lack of running water and electricity. **********During their protests, the community fought the police, then kidnapped a prominent politician, a move that led to a settlement. They were granted electricity, but they get  water only sporadically. **********The eldest daughter, Ferite, 24, fled to the Italian city of Turin, a center for Albanian prostitutes, and returned recently sporting peroxided permed hair, a micro-mini skirt, platform shoes, heavy makeup and an armload of costume jewelry. Her outfit contrasted sharply with her mother's mountain attire -- dark, wide-legged pantaloons covered by a long skirt, blouse and a head scarf, signifying her Muslim religion. **********Miranda Cara said that on visits home, Ferite, flush with money, has been dismissive of the factory job of which Miranda is so proud. **********But Miss Cara said the most profound aspect of her work had been the independence to hold down her own job. She joins together plastic pieces of tiny toys that are exported to Italy to be packaged with chocolate bonbons and then exported to the world. **********''In order to get the $35 a month you have to meet a target of handling a lot of toys a day,'' she said. ''It is boring. There are no women at the plant over the age of 40. You have to be speedy but I have nimble fingers and I can do it.'' **********Because of their poverty, the Cara family did not invest in the pyramid schemes that defaulted earlier this year and left much of the Albanian population without their savings. But they have been hurt by the economic collapse that followed. Prices have soared, and Miss Cara's salary is not worth what it used to be. She can pay  for her bus fare to work and for her contribution to the family for food but no extras. Plans for extensions to the house have been jettisoned. **********One of her brothers recently married a cousin from a mountain region  -- a union arranged by both sets of parents. Spent cartridge shells were strewn outside the house, remnants of a celebratory shooting spree that accompanies many Albanian weddings. **********An early marriage is still expected of her, but Miss Cara is looking beyond that and beyond the assembly line. Armed with her high school diploma, she now dreams of going to the university and of becoming a historian. **********''The mountains are beautiful,'' she said. ''The snow is so pure that you can bring it inside in a tub, put it on a fire and wash your clothes in it. But for me, that is the past.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/10/world.snippet: Government of Kenyan Pres Daniel arap Moi faces battle over constitutional reforms that threatens to overshadow, or even derail, Presidential elections later in 1997; calls from opposition to revamp Constitution to give President less power have c...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/10/world.main_headline: Kenyan President Is Facing a Growing Chorus of Discontent
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/10/world.print_headline: Kenyan President Is Facing a Growing Chorus of Discontent
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/10/world.body_text: **********With opposition leaders threatening more violent protests like the one that rocked this capital recently, a protracted battle over constitutional reform is looming in Kenya, threatening to overshadow or even derail presidential elections later this year. **********Eight months ago, President Daniel arap Moi's political position appeared unassailable. Opposition leaders were splintered along ethnic  lines, unable to find a single candidate to challenge the man who has ruled Kenya for 19 years. With his political enemies divided, it looked as if the President would win re-election easily. **********But now it appears that calls for revamping the Constitution to give the President less power have caught fire with the beleaguered Kenyan middle class, who are weary of the East African nation's steadily declining economy and the rampant corruption in the administration. **********What remains unclear is whether the opposition can harness that anti-Government sentiment and rally behind a candidate capable of winning the election, diplomats said. **********''We are seeing a groundswell of frustration and anger against the current Government,'' a diplomat said, speaking on the condition of anonymity. ''But I haven't seen the opposition offer an alternative yet.'' **********A confluence of political interests have fueled the current tide of popular opinion against Mr. Moi, diplomats say. Several influential church leaders have joined with human rights advocates and charity directors in calling not only for a new Constitution but also for the repeal of colonial-era laws giving the Government sweeping powers to detain people, break up demonstrations and harass opposition groups. **********Opposition politicians who have joined the reform movement have long complained that the electoral rules under the current Constitution give them almost no chance of winning an election against Mr. Moi. **********The Constitution requires a president to garner at least a quarter of the vote in five of Kenya's eight districts. This dilutes the power of the two largest tribes -- the Luo and the Kikuyu -- who are concentrated in two heavily populated districts.  The election rules also do not require a president to get a majority of the votes cast, which means a member of a minority tribe like Mr. Moi can win as long as he hammers together a plurality of smaller groups. **********The reformers have been pushing for an amendment requiring a winning candidate to get at least half of all the votes cast, which would help candidates from the larger tribes. **********The opposition has also said the Constitution should allow coalition governments. Kenya has a winner-take-all system, giving Mr. Moi all the Cabinet seats and power even though his party can at best garner only about 40 percent of the vote. A change would open the door for other opposition leaders who cannot get a majority to still form a government with other opposition parties. **********On May 31, Mr. Moi showed he was willing to take a hard line against the reformers. Riot police crushed a protest by about 1,000 people with tear gas and rubber bullets, setting off two days of looting and unrest. **********On June 1, the President promised to consider repealing the Public Order Act, which allows troops to use force to break up unlicensed protests. But even as he made the announcement, his soldiers kept several opposition leaders, who had promised a second protest, under house arrest in the capital. **********''It's going to be a very rough summer,'' one diplomat said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/12/world.snippet: China says it vetoed United Nations resolution to send peacekeepers to Guatamela because of Guatemala's longstanding diplomatic recognition of Taiwan, which China regards as renegade province; has signaled that it might reconsider veto if Guatemal...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/12/world.main_headline: China Asserts Taiwan's Ties To Guatemala Led to Veto
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/12/world.print_headline: China Asserts Taiwan's Ties To Guatemala Led to Veto
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/12/world.body_text: **********China said today that its decision to veto a United Nations resolution that would have sent peacekeepers to Guatemala was justified by Guatemala's longstanding diplomatic recognition of Taiwan, an affront to Chinese sovereignty over the island it regards as a renegade province. **********''Guatemala cannot expect on the one hand to do something that harms the sovereignty and territorial integrity of China while on the other hand requesting China to cooperate in peacekeeping,'' said Shen Guofang, the Chinese Government spokesman. His remarks were carried by the New China News Agency. **********''We had no choice,'' Mr. Shen said of the veto cast Friday night in the Security Council, noting that China had no objection to the principle of sending United Nations monitors to help carry out the peace accord that is ending 36 years of civil war in Guatemala. He said Guatemala was responsible for China's decision to use its authority as one of the five permanent members of the Security Council to scuttle a resolution supported by a majority of the 15-member Council. **********Diplomats in New York indicated that China had signaled that it might be willing to reconsider its veto in exchange for Guatemala's downgrading its relations with Taiwan and ceasing its support for Taiwan's re-entry into the United Nations. **********Guatemala and more than two dozen other countries, mostly in Latin America, the Caribbean and Africa, extend formal diplomatic recognition to Taiwan as the Republic of China, the political descendant of Chiang Kai-shek's government that fled the mainland in 1949 after defeat by Mao Zedong's Communists. **********China's veto marked the first time in 24 years that Beijing had used its no vote in a matter outside the selection of the Secretary General and thus reflects a hardening of political attitudes in the Communist Party leadership here to confront Taiwan in a year when Hong Kong will return to Chinese rule after 150 years as a British colony. **********The return of Hong Kong, Macau and Taiwan to Chinese sovereignty has been a longstanding objective of China's Communist rulers. **********Beijing considers any recognition of Taiwan to be a boost to pro-independence forces there that have supported President Lee Teng-hui's drive to raise Taiwan's international standing as a sovereign political entity. President Lee says he opposes Taiwan independence and he pays lip service to his party's goal of reunification with the mainland, but as the first native-born Taiwanese President, Mr. Lee has also pursued a path of a strong, independent image. **********In Taiwan, Foreign Minister John Chang sharply rebuked Beijing's veto. ''It is extremely insensible and unreasonable for Communist China to mingle relations across'' the Taiwan Strait with a ''regional peacekeeping mission'' of the United Nations,'' he said. Mr. Chang attended the ceremony in which the peace accords were signed on Dec. 29. **********Taiwan lost its seat in the United Nations in 1971 and, under President Lee, has campaigned to re-enter it and has often called on Guatemala's support to do so. China's veto was cast as Taiwan's Prime Minister, Lien Chan, was visiting Nicaragua, another of the dwindling roster of Taiwan's diplomatic allies. In a blow last month, South Africa said it would be switching its diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing. **********The Vatican also remains in Taiwan's camp, and the Taiwanese Prime Minister was scheduled to make a swing through Europe to visit Pope John Paul II before heading to Africa to shore up Taiwan's support after the defection of South Africa. A sign of Beijing's determination to counter every Taiwan move aggressively was the announcement that the Chinese Foreign Minister, Qian Qichen, left on  Friday for an 11-day tour of European and African capitals. **********Under the terms of the Guatemala peace accord, the Guatemalan Army would pull back its combat units to prearranged locations while the rebel forces of the Guatemalan National Revolutionary Unit were to assemble at eight separate locations to disarm. The 155 United Nations peacekeepers were to have verified the disarming process.                     -------------------- **********Guatemala Seeking O.A.S. Role **********GUATEMALA CITY, Jan. 11 (AP) -- Guatemala is pursuing other options for obtaining peace monitors, officials here said today. **********Foreign Minister Eduardo Stein Barillas said getting observers through the Washington-based Organization of American States can be done ''in a matter of hours,'' and that the O.A.S. Secretary General, Cesar Gaviria, began consultations on that possibility in Managua, Nicaragua, hours after the United Nations veto. **********Another option would be a direct appeal to the United Nations General Assembly, but Mr. Stein said that would take around 90 days and unnecessarily delay the process.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/04/world.snippet: Clinton Administration officials say China is not ready to become member of World Trade Organization because of its unwillingness to open markets to foreign competitors; both US and European negotiators at recent talks in Beijing and Geneva say Ch...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/04/world.main_headline: U.S. OFFICIALS SAY CHINA IS NOT READY FOR TRADE GROUP
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/04/world.print_headline: U.S. OFFICIALS SAY CHINA IS NOT READY FOR TRADE GROUP
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/04/world.body_text: **********After several months of slogging negotiations, Clinton Administration officials say they now doubt that they will reach broad agreement this year to admit China to the World Trade Organization, an accord they once hoped would be the centerpiece of President Jiang Zemin's state visit to Washington in October. **********American officials had hoped that during talks in Beijing and Geneva that concluded on Friday, China would make a comprehensive offer to open its markets and allow foreign competitors to take on state-owned Chinese industries, which employ a majority of China's urban population. **********But instead, officials from the United States and Europe said, China's negotiators offered piecemeal concessions. Now American officials are questioning whether Mr. Jiang, who is assembling a leadership team that will be formally endorsed at a major party congress just before his visit here, is ready to take the politically difficult steps required for his country to join the club of trading nations. Now, 131 countries and regions are members of the World Trade Organization -- with the notable exceptions of g China and Russia -- and Beijing has sharply criticized the West for setting conditions that it believes bar it from entry. **********American officials say that China is unwilling to make large-scale concessions that would allow, for example, foreign companies to sell stock, deliver packages commercially and sell telecommunications services across the breadth of China. Currently, a number of companies are permitted to do these things, but only on an experimental basis in some cities. **********''China's offers were tepid,'' said Charlene Barshefsky, the United States trade representative who has supervised the delicate negotiations. ''This was a view shared by a number of our trading partners,'' she said, even Japan and Europe, which have pressed for quicker admission for China under relaxed rules. ''If China wishes its hopes to enter the W.T.O. to be a key element of the meeting with President Clinton, it must move quite rapidly now,'' she said. ''But there is no indication at this juncture that China intends to move meaningfully forward.'' **********Some of the comments made by Ms. Barshefsky's negotiating team and their Chinese counterparts in recent days were clearly part of the posturing that accompanies the complex economic negotiations that have become the 1990's successors to arms control talks. But the negotiations over market openings in China are particularly fraught with high-level politics in both capitals. **********Chinese leaders have to weigh whether it is worth surrendering further control over the nation's economy to market forces in order to meet the entrance requirements for the World Trade Organization. And they have to consider the potential political costs if open competition -- and a phasing out of subsidies to state-run industries -- results in waves of unemployment. **********In Washington, the current investigations into China's possible role in the 1996 Presidential and congressional campaigns have also lurked in the background. Several months ago, Chinese officials warned that they would not make a comprehensive trade offer if they believed that President Clinton could not enter serious negotiations that would also require concessions on the American side. **********''They are worried that any American concession to China would result in someone charging that the Chinese were getting a favor for their contributions, even if they didn't make any contributions,'' one senior American official said recently. ''And they may be right -- this is not a time when Clinton can make many horse trades.'' **********China's intentions may also become clearer in a series of high-level visits by American officials to Beijing over the next several months. Administration officials say President Clinton's national security adviser, Samuel R. Berger, is considering a trip there later this month, if the latest Middle East crisis recedes. Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin is planning his first trip there in late September, and that may turn out to be the last chance to settle on agreements that could be finalized during Mr. Jiang's state visit, the first by a top Chinese leader since the 1989 military crackdown on pro-democracy protests in Tiananmen Square. **********But Ms. Barshefsky said she had no immediate plans to travel to China, despite an announcement by China's chief negotiator, Long Yongtu, that she was coming to Beijing soon. Her direct participation in the talks would be the surest sign that a deal was nearing. **********Negotiators who have sat at the table with the Chinese for several weeks report that there has been modest progress. For example, the Chinese promised not to provide export subsidies for agricultural products. Although China offers no such subsidies now, American officials are concerned that as China's market opens, farmers will press the Government to help them send their products abroad. **********China also agreed to eliminate import quotas for cars and minibuses -- which have kept American and Japanese makers from making vehicles in their existing factories and shipping them to China -- over 8 years instead of the 15 years they first offered. Currently, American auto manufacturers seeking to sell cars in China must enter joint ventures to build cars there, and agree to transfer significant manufacturing technology to their Chinese partners. While several carmakers have entered such arrangements, others have balked, saying China's demands are too high. **********Chinese negotiators have also agreed to abolish quotas on the importation of other items as soon as the country is admitted to the World Trade Organization, and reduce tariffs on a range of goods, although American officials say the cuts are still insufficient. **********At a meeting last month, President Clinton's economic advisers generally agreed that the most that could now be hoped for from Mr. Clinton's summit meeting with Mr. Jiang is a commitment to keep talking -- rather than a real accord.

The Duke Energy Power Services unit and the closely held United American formed a partnership to buy a 50 percent stake in the Houston-based American Ref-Fuel. Browning-Ferris Industries owns the other half. Duke, based in Charlotte, N.C., and United American, of Woodcliff Lake, N.J., announced the purchase on Oct. 13 without disclosing a purchase price. https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/25/world.snippet: China charges that Repr Frank R Wolf, who recently traveled to Tibet and accused Chinese authorities of strangling traditional culture in Himalayan region, deliberately tried to stir up trouble and lied about true conditions in Tibet; Wolf says he...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/25/world.main_headline: China Faults U.S. Official Over Tibet Trip
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/25/world.print_headline: China Faults U.S. Official Over Tibet Trip
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/25/world.body_text: **********With Tibet emerging as a potentially serious obstacle in United States-China relations, Beijing issued a tartly worded attack today on a Congressman who recently traveled to Tibet and accused the Chinese authorities of strangling traditional culture in the Himalayan region. **********In a long statement from the New China News Agency, a senior official from Tibet accused the Congressman, Representative Frank R. Wolf, Republican of Virginia, of deliberately trying to stir up trouble and lie about true conditions in Tibet. **********''All people with a sense of justice, including the Tibetan people, are enraged by his actions,'' said the official, Raidi, who heads the local legislature in Tibet and uses one name. **********Mr. Wolf, who traveled to Tibet from Aug. 9 to 13 as a tourist without telling the authorities he was a Congressman, told reporters in Washington last week that he saw evidence of religious persecution and the obliteration of Tibetan culture and language by an influx of Chinese traders and merchants. **********In response to those assertions, Mr. Raidi listed a series of statistics to show that Tibet's economy, agricultural output and foreign trade were all growing fast, and he insisted that 46,000 monks and nuns can worship freely. **********But he defended the Government's tight control of unauthorized religious activities, which Chinese leaders often suspect of advocating independence for Tibet. **********''The reason to crack down on activities by separatists who are acting under cover of religion is to protect the majority of the religious believers and insure that the religious activities are carried out in line with the doctrines,'' Mr. Raidi said. **********''In line with the doctrines,'' as Mr. Raidi did not have to elaborate, means religious worship that submits to the authority of Communist Party officials, who generally ban any organized activity they themselves do not control. **********Today's outburst came as Washington and Beijing prepare for a summit meeting in late October, when President Jiang Zemin travels to the United States to meet President Clinton, and each side is eager to bridge disagreements over human rights and nuclear nonproliferation. **********However, concern over conditions in Tibet has been growing in Congress. Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright recently agreed to name a special coordinator within the State Department to monitor conditions there and to urge China to negotiate with the Dalai Lama, the spiritual leader of Tibet who was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in 1989 for peacefully campaigning for greater autonomy in his homeland. **********Mr. Raidi, reflecting Beijing's frustration at being unable to limit the moral authority of the Dalai Lama, denounced the religious leader as a tool of imperialist forces trying to undermine China. **********''He never concerned himself with the real life of the Tibetan people, and did nothing beneficial for Tibet,'' Mr. Raidi was quoted as saying. ''The Tibetan people, thus far, are aware of his separatist theory and have long abandoned him.'' **********Over the weekend, the New China News Agency also issued a series of statements quoting scholars who defended China's right to rule Tibet. **********One argued that Tibetan culture can coexist alongside Chinese culture just as Eskimo culture can in Alaska, which like Tibet is a spacious and remote area where the culture of a minority population lives under a higher sovereign. **********Mr. Wolf, a champion of religious freedom, said he had urged the Clinton Administration to press Mr. Jiang for the release of what human rights organizations estimate to be 700 prisoners of conscience in Tibet. He also argued that urgent action was needed to save Tibetan culture from being overwhelmed by Chinese settlers, who he said outnumbered ethnic Tibetans in Lhasa, Tibet's capital, by about 160,000 to 100,000. **********Mr. Raidi, in response, argued that Chinese residents account for less than 3 percent of the official population in all of Tibet. He did not offer statistics for Lhasa, and it is possible that many Chinese businessmen are counted as temporary residents and do not appear in official tallies, the same as thousands of military personnel stationed there. **********In his defense of Chinese rule, Mr. Raidi argued that Tibet had carried out democratic reforms beginning in 1959, the year the Dalai Lama escaped to exile in India after an uprising that might have led to his arrest. **********Yet in the 1960's and 1970's, even official Chinese accounts concede, zealous Chinese officials and rogue factions of Red Guards destroyed thousands of temples, banned virtually all religious worship and imprisoned untold thousands of monks and nuns. **********At the time, the Government insisted that Tibet was a happy place of progress, much as Mr. Raidi's statement today did. Today's statement was also notable for its strong nationalist tone. **********''Under the leadership of the Communist Party of China, Tibet experienced the most profound changes in its history during the last 40 years, particularly after the democratic reform,'' Mr. Raidi was quoted as saying.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/28/busin.snippet: Outlook for investing in Friendly Ice Cream Corp's planned offering of 67 percent of company stock discussed; offering is part of Friendly's three-pronged effort to refinance its large debt; table; photo (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/28/busin.main_headline: I Scream. You Scream. Will Wall St. Scream?
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/28/busin.print_headline: AT THE GATE; I Scream. You Scream. Will Wall St. Scream?
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/28/busin.body_text: **********FOR ice cream lovers in the Northeast, Friendly's restaurants have long been synonymous with tasty treats, from the company's signature shakes to its sundaes studded with bits of candy bars. **********But are investors willing to treat themselves to shares of the company's stock? **********Sometime next month, Friendly's parent, the Friendly Ice Cream Corporation of Wilbraham, Mass., wants to sell five million shares -- or 67 percent of its company -- for $19 to $21 apiece. **********Prospective investors may find the company's history attractive. Founded in 1935, Friendly's has long been an industry leader, offering innovations like, in 1951, half-gallons of ice cream that consumers could take home. Today, Friendly's is continuing efforts to fashion itself into a full-service family restaurant chain and to capitalize on its special allure for the sweet-toothed. **********But in recent years Friendly's has found  itself in a sticky mess. One reason is its debt. **********Due in large part to a leveraged buyout in 1988 by the Restaurant Company, an investor group, Friendly's carries a very heavy burden of long-term debt -- $386 million as of June. In 1996 alone, the debt cost the company $44.1 million in interest expense, contributing to a $7.8 million loss that represented the fifth consecutive year in which Friendly's had negative earnings. **********Indeed, the impending public offering is part of a three-pronged effort by Friendly's to refinance its large debt. The company hopes to raise $100 million, with more money coming from a new, $140 million credit facility, which includes a term loan and a letter of credit. And if the stock offering is successful, Friendly's plans to sell $200 million in 10-year notes. All told, it intends to use up to $362 million of the money it raises to straighten out its balance sheet. **********Industry analysts applaud the refinancing effort. But they still wonder whether the company can outrun growing competition from a host of other, expanding restaurant chains. **********True, Friendly's is still the leading full-service restaurant operator in the Northeast, where about 80 percent of its nearly 700 restaurants and franchises are located.  And so far, the company has only one big, established competitor there, Brigham's Inc. But on the way is Cracker Barrel Old Country Store Inc., whose specialty is running restaurant-gift shops on interstate highways mostly in the South. Its entrance into  New England is a worrisome sign for Friendly's, given that Cracker Barrel is growing at a rate of 20 percent a year. **********Also invading Friendly's stronghold are other family dining chains like Outback Steakhouse, Olive Garden and Ruby Tuesday. Analysts say many of those chains can expand rapidly because they have little debt. **********To be sure, Friendly's, which declined to comment because it is not allowed to discuss its financial status in the period leading up to the offering, has been moving in the right direction. By sprucing up its restaurants, closing unproductive ones and offering higher-priced dishes like a steak entree, the company has raised its average revenue per restaurant by a healthy 29 percent during the last 10 years. But that rate lags behind the gains of nearly every other large restaurant chain. **********Its revenues from sales to supermarkets and institutions, which totaled just $1.4 million in 1989, have also improved. Because Friendly's has been pushing its treats in those precincts -- more than 5,000 supermarkets now carry its frozen desserts -- nonrestaurant revenues have jumped to $57.7 million for the 12 months ended in June, or nearly 10 percent of its total revenues of $665 million. **********Industry analysts are not surprised by these gains. **********''This company has an extremely powerful signature -- its ice cream,'' said Malcom  M. Knapp, a restaurant consultant in Manhattan. ''They look at their treat business as their special edge.'' **********To exploit that strength, Friendly's has stepped up efforts to link sales of its frozen treats with sales of its lunch and dinner entrees. The company has also been opening ice cream stores overseas -- in Britain and South Korea, for example -- as well as selling its treats in new domestic settings like stadiums and amusement parks. **********Because of the company's strong brand name, David Menlow, president of IPO Financial Network in Springfield, N.J., said Friendly's stock was likely to be well-received, opening at $1 to $2 over its offering price. ''Name-brand companies are garnering the most attention in this I.P.O. market,'' he explained. **********But like other analysts, Mr. Menlow questioned whether Friendly's stock would be able to sustain a premium over the long haul. **********In general, restaurant stocks have had a tough time over the last few years because of concerns over escalating competition in the industry. David Trossman, an analyst at BT Alex. Brown, said the 35 restaurant stocks in his company's index had gained an average of 7.1 percent since the beginning of the year. During the same time, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index has appreciated more than 28 percent. **********Given the intense rivalries, Mr. Trossman said, ''the Street likes one of two things -- either a new restaurant concept that has very rapid growth potential, or some reason to believe that returns on a given base of restaurants will go up dramatically.'' **********Friendly's has yet to prove itself on either score. It is staying on top of food trends, like the wrap sandwich, but that effort hardly qualifies as a new concept. And its 1996 revenues grew in large part because of the introduction of higher-priced foods. Strong competition within the industry, however, limits how much farther Friendly's can push up prices. **********Friendly's seems to be having trouble carving out new territory, too. True, in July it entered into an agreement with Davco Restaurants -- the largest franchisee for Wendy's International -- under which Davco has bought rights to 34 existing Friendly's sites and has agreed to open 100 more during the next 10 years in the mid-Atlantic region. **********But no one knows how that long-term deal will work out. And, according to Mr. Knapp, efforts by Friendly's to expand into the Midwest have run into competition from companies like Denny's, Shoney's and Bob Evans Farms, which are established there. **********And while the company's newer restaurants are generating more than $1 million in revenue annually, the average revenue for all of its locations was $855,000 for the 12 months ended in June. The average Denny's or Shoney's restaurant now generates $1.2 million to $1.7 million a year, and often more, while the average Cracker Barrel brings in about $4 million, according to industry figures. **********And then there's that high dose of debt that Friendly's investors will be asked to swallow. In a recent report, Mark S. Basham, an analyst at Standard & Poor's, argued that the debt creates such large financial risks that the offering price should be lowered. And by a large sum: from its current $20 a share to $15, or less.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/23/world.snippet: Six senior Bosnia Serb police commanders defy hard-line leadership in Pale to report for work at central police headquarters in Banja Luka for the first time since British troops seized the six police facilities in the city and ousted officers loy...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/23/world.main_headline: 6 Officers In Serb Police Back on Job In Bosnia
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/23/world.print_headline: 6 Officers In Serb Police Back on Job In Bosnia
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/23/world.body_text: **********Six senior Bosnian Serb police commanders walked into the central police headquarters to work today for the first time since British troops seized the six police facilities in this city and ousted officers loyal to the Bosnian Serb leader, Radovan Karadzic. **********''We are nervous,'' said the new chief, who asked to remain unidentified. ''Things are tense. This is not an easy situation for us.'' **********The officers, who defied the hard-line leadership in Pale by appearing for work today, spent the morning with American police officials from the United Nations International Police Task Force to begin what the officials term the ''restructuring'' of the city's 600-strong police force, although other people say the word ''purge,'' however, would probably be more accurate. **********All police supporters of Dr. Karadzic, an indicted war-crimes suspect who wields most of the power in the Serbian-governed portion of Bosnia although he holds no official office, will be dismissed, they said. And only officers loyal to his successor and rival, the Bosnian Serb President, Biljana Plavsic, will be reinstated. **********The seizure of the police stations, carried out on Tuesday by some 350 British troops who are with the 31,000-member peacekeeping force led by NATO, has effectively turned Banja Luka into a separatist enclave dominated by an administration that supports Ms. Plavsic. It has deeply  angered the leadership in Pale, the stronghold of Dr. Karadzic and his hard-line supporters. **********The Bosnian Serb representative of the country's three-member Presidency, Momcilo Krajisnik, a close ally of Dr. Karadzic, said that all police who returned to work would be in defiance of the legal authority.  And he issued a dark threat, saying that after today he could not be responsible for any ''incidents'' that might occur. **********A group of police officers loyal to the leadership in Pale tried briefly to occupy a small police station outside Banja Luka on Thursday, but were turned back by the police inside. And heavily armed British troops wearing flak jackets and backed by armored vehicles have surrounded the city's police centers and carefully check all visitors. Many NATO officials say they fear Dr. Karadzic and his supporters may resort to violence in an effort to intimidate Ms. Plavsic's supporters. **********''We have about 400 of the city's police who have signed a list saying they are willing to return to work,'' said Henry E. Williams, a police officer from Citrus County, Florida, who heads the United Nations police monitoring force in the Bosnian Serb sector. ''Now we are just waiting to see if they will really return. This is all pretty intense. There is still an air of uncertainly. Our goal, in the end, is to integrate the police forces in all of Bosnia, but we have to crawl before we can walk.'' **********The return of the police today, who were part of a force of about 50,000 officers paid by Dr. Karadzic and directly under his control, signals a willingness by at least a small number of Bosnian Serb police officers to defy Dr. Karadzic and begin to conform to the detailed dictates of the Dayton peace accord. The accord includes an eventual integration of the police forces in the Muslim and Croat areas in the rest of Bosnia. **********''Today is the first day a few of us make a move to end our isolation from the rest of the world,'' said a senior police commander, who asked to remain unidentified. ''It is the first attempt to build a real democratic system. And it means that in Banja Luka we have accepted that those Muslims and Croats who were expelled from the city have the right to return. If all this works, it will be momentous.'' **********Roy Benifield, a retired police officer from Buford, Georgia, ran through the restructuring process with the six returning police inspectors as they downed cups of thick Turkish coffee and chain-smoked  American cigarettes. **********''All new police officers will go through courses on codes of conduct, respect for human rights and basic police procedures,'' he said. ''There will be a written exam and a psychological test. Before anyone is certified to work we will do background checks and every candidate will have his name be published in the paper so we can investigate any complaints about any officer.'' He also said that the officers will have to be cleared by the international war-crimes tribunal in The Hague. **********The abrupt arrival of the United Nations police monitors and the swift transition of authority seemed to stun many of the Serbian police commanders in the room. The Bosnian Serb police, who have been accused by United Nations officials of repeated human-rights violations and involvement in the smuggling of cigarettes and gasoline, have often been seen as hindering a return to the rule of law, often in cooperation with their wartime enemies. **********''The police in the Serb enclave work closely with the Croat and Muslim mafias,'' said a senior Western diplomat. ''Cars are stolen in the Muslim part of Bosnia and delivered to Serb police officials on the partition lines for sale. Because there is no cooperation between the Serb police and their Muslim and Croat counterparts there is never any investigation into what happened.'' **********The six inspectors huddled together over the table during a recess in the morning's meeting. **********''I didn't think I'd have to go to any more courses before my retirement,'' said an older inspector with more than twenty years in the police.  ''Now we have this retired American cop coming to teach us how to be police. I guess when we finish we can go to Angola and teach them.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/17/busin.snippet: Ireland and things Irish have outsized presence on World Wide Web; wide variety of Celtic-themed sites help link Ireland with vast Irish population abroad; table; photo (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/17/busin.main_headline: Hyperlinks to Irish Auld Sod Update St. Patrick
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/17/busin.print_headline: Hyperlinks to Irish Auld Sod Update St. Patrick
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/17/busin.body_text: **********What would St. Patrick make of his day? The fifth-century kidnapee-turned-cowherd-turned-missionary, the first to convert anyone outside the Roman Empire to Christianity and a big believer in the ascetic hermit-monk approach to life, would probably be just as disgusted with today's plastic shamrocks, green beer and ''kiss me'' buttons as he was with the bacchanalian excesses of the comfortable classes in his own time. **********But seeing the full text of his ''Confessio'' on the World Wide Web, in English translation, with a map, helpful hypertext subheadings and links to his life story, well, that might warm his crosier. **********Patrick was a scholar and teacher as well as a proselytizer. Perhaps his most important legacy was the sowing of literacy, learning and faith in a place where it could survive the Dark Ages mostly intact. Thanks to Patrick and the saints-to-be whom he taught or inspired, the greatest intellectual achievements of Western civilization were safely backed up and archived off site in Ireland while the original Vandals hacked into and crashed the Roman Empire. **********The Internet, with its global cross-linking of vast stores of human knowledge, can be seen as a mammoth electronic recap of his achievement. If Patrick were still the bishop of Armagh and Primate of All Ireland today, it would be perfectly in character for him to have a home page on the Web. (His latest direct successor, Archbishop Sean Brady, does, in a way: he is featured on the site of the neighboring Catholic Diocese of Kilmore.) **********For an island of only about five million people (in the Republic and the North combined), Ireland and things Irish have an outsized Web presence. The country seems to produce more than its share of innovative Web design talent. And a wide variety of Celtic-themed sites help link the auld sod with its vast diaspora of 50 million or more people. **********Several comprehensive omnibus sites are available on the Web. The oldest and most sophisticated, Paddynet, features a huge searchable Green Pages of Irish-related links, an elaborate chat ''hotel,'' message boards and links to Shop Ireland, offering on-line shopping for all manner of Irish goods. **********Newer and still building are Irlnet (the name comes from the three-letter nationality code displayed on Irish cars) and Every Celtic Thing on the Web, which are more culturally oriented and a bit less commercial. Ireland Online's well-established home page is designed as an all-purpose starting point for Web surfing in general. **********Irish culture is enjoying a worldwide boom in popular attention at the moment, epitomized by two thriving touring stage shows that feature Irish step dancing, ''Riverdance'' and ''Lord of the Dance.'' There is an official ''Riverdance'' Web site that is slick and long on merchandising, much like a Hollywood movie site; the unofficial ''Lord of the Dance'' sites are a bit homier. **********Traditional Irish music is also in the ascendant, led by the Chieftains, the multiple-Grammy-winning warhorses, about whom there are a number of sites sponsored by record companies and fans. An encyclopedic resource for Celtic music -- from the New Age-tinged Clannad to the harp airs of O'Carolan to rockers like U2 and Sinead O'Connor -- is Ceolas, hosted by Stanford University. **********The popular ''Thistle and Shamrock'' radio program, heard on National Public Radio affiliates nationwide, has a companion site. And Green Linnet, which has long been to Irish music what Sun Records was to rhythm and blues, maintains an informative showcase for its artists. **********Centuries of suppression by the English nearly extinguished the Gaelic tongue, but it is still spoken as a first language in rural areas of western Ireland. The Internet is full of resources for students of Irish and its sister tongues, which still barely survive in Scotland and the Isle of Man, Brittany and Wales. A good starting point can be found at the Gaelic site hosted by the University of North Carolina. **********The Irish abroad can stay in touch with news of Roisin Dubh (a Gaelic nickname for Ireland) through the web sites of The Irish Times, one of the best overseas newspaper sites on the Web, and RTE, the Irish counterpart to the BBC. **********Those of Irish descent can get help researching their roots on the Internet. The Irish National Archives offers indexes of important census, tax and other records, though not the records themselves, and the genealogical centers of many Irish county have presences on the Web. **********At the risk of reinforcing a pernicious stereotype, the Irish site with the widest appeal may be the sharp, elaborate Web site of the brewer and distiller, Guinness P.L.C. Visitors can tour the historic brewery at St. James's Gate, Dublin, and learn about the brewing process, the proper way to pull a pint, and the real purpose of the plastic widget in the bottom of a can of stout.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/30/busin.body_text: **********THE GREENSPAN WATCH **********The Fed Finally Does It **********Rarely has anything been so feared, anticipated, talked about, second-guessed, analyzed -- without actually happening. For months, as the economy and the stock market kept whooping it up, all eyes have been on Alan Greenspan. Will he raise rates this time? When will he do it? Why didn't he do it? How did he sleep last night? What did that twitch mean? As the months dragged on, it started to seem that the Federal Reserve would never do it, so when it finally did nudge interest rates higher last week, it was an odd jolt. Apparently Mr. Greenspan wearied of hearing inflation's menacing footsteps around every corner and threw a punch before it even appeared. But the blow, soft as it was, will be felt all through the economy by lifting borrowing rates. And while most economists said the move was about right, some critics, arguing that inflation was extinct, said the move would hurt workers unnecessarily. **********THE BULL MARKET **********Could It Be Over? **********So when stock prices tumbled on Thursday, a full day after the Fed acted, was it a delayed reaction? Don't be silly. Investors' reaction isn't always wise, but it's always instant. No, they're already speculating about the next Fed rate increase, which suddenly seemed more likely -- especially after various economic reports showed the kind of strength that could revive inflation. And the 30-year Treasury bond yield crept above 7 percent, a suddenly enticing alternative to stocks. Yes, the numbers looked scary -- the Dow off 216 at one point, before closing down 140. But remember that at these lofty levels, that's just a 2 percent drop. A decade ago, a 2 percent decline would have been about 40 points. Then again, those same lofty levels mean the Dow has an awfully long way to fall. So will the market crash tomorrow? The answer is a definite maybe. **********GAS AND ELECTRIC **********Cleaner Cars: A Compromise **********General Motors has sold only a few dozen electric cars a month since introducing them in December. No surprise, really. The cars' short range is limiting enough, and who needs to add ''Be sure to plug in the car, Honey'' to lives already strewn with to-do lists? Both drawbacks, though, vanish with the ''hybrid'' car -- gasoline engine plus electric motor. The gas engine either propels the car or charges the battery. No limits, no plugs and a lot less pollution than a gas-only vehicle. And last week Toyota said it would be the first to offer hybrids to a mass market -- for now, though, just a Japanese mass market; it has no immediate plans to sell here. Not only is this a workable compromise on the pollution front, but the price is far less shocking -- less than $20,000, versus $34,000 for G.M.'s electric. **********INVESTMENTS, POOR **********The Perils of Gold Fever **********Gold does strange things to people. Always has. Look at Charlie Chaplin in ''The Gold Rush,'' or Humphrey Bogart in ''Treasure of Sierra Madre.'' History is littered with gold-plated craziness, and investors are by no means immune. When Bre-X Minerals said it had found one of the world's richest gold deposits, in the wilds of Indonesia, investors went wild, turning this little Canadian company, with not much going for it beyond those gold stars in its eyes, into a $1 billion-plus concern. Big-name mutual funds put serious money into the company. And yes, if you'd bought Bre-X stock in early 1995 and sold it last year, you'd have struck serious gold indeed, as the share price went from pennies to $20. Last week, though, just as the gold was scattered to the avenging wind at the end of ''Treasure of Sierra Madre,'' the Bre-X dream got a blast of reality. The company acknowledged that the gold find was probably not nearly what it seemed, and the shares plunged more than 80 percent in a day. **********ACQUISITIONS, DOOMED **********A Costly Gulp of Snapple **********William D. Smithburg, chairman and chief executive of Quaker Oats, has been denied a bonus the last two years. But before the pity wells up in your heart and you mail him that $17 in the cookie jar, consider his imaginative use of stockholders' money. In 1994, Snapple was all the rage, and Quaker was so desperate to acquire it that it paid a price that made jaws drop: $1.7 billion. But Snapple didn't become the next Coke -- Quaker must have expected that it would -- and last week Quaker essentially acknowledged its costly mistake, selling Snapple for a mere $300 million. In other words, nearly $2 million of its investment was wiped out every single day it owned Snapple. Gently, now: put the lid back on the cookie jar. **********UPS AND DOWNS **********A 'Good Time,' Fortune or No **********In 1935, James Ryder, a day laborer, borrowed $100, bought a used Model A truck and soon afterward started a truck-leasing business. Then comes the old rags-to-riches tale: Ryder System was grossing $1.5 million a year by 1946, and when Mr. Ryder quit in 1978 -- in a battle over control of what had become a giant -- he had a $20 million fortune. There the tale loops back again, though, as Mr. Ryder sank his nest egg into the creation of a rival company, Jartran, which within a few years was in bankruptcy. But Mr. Ryder, who died last week at 83, had no regrets. ''I had a good time,'' he said. **********HUMAN CAPITAL **********Today's Widgets: Prisoners **********The debate in Fallsburg, N.Y., revolves around a very modern economic quandary. This struggling Catskills town badly needs new businesses, and the Corrections Corporation of America has bought 185 acres here and wants to build one of its private prisons. Town officials love the idea because a private prison would be taxable property; the prison guards' union hates it because private prisons often hire nonunion workers. Sound familiar? When a business is booming -- and the business of locking people up is certainly booming -- someone will come along and try to do it for less, turn out widgets more efficiently. What's unusual, to put it mildly, is that the widgets this time are human beings. **********BOOK MADNESS **********Have Circus, Will Publish **********What a strange business book publishing is. Here, often, is how a best seller is made: The media, ever on the prowl for a ''hot story,'' latch onto a book and create a circus of publicity; a shopper sees the book, remembers the media circus and buys it. Perhaps, along the way, someone reads the book -- perhaps even likes it -- but that's beside the point. It's irrelevant whether it's literature or, well, just words. Case in point: A buzz begins about a 98-year-old Kansas woman named Jessie Lee Brown Foveaux, who has written a memoir, and publishers -- possibly remembering the hit ''Having Our Say'' -- claw at each others' tweeds to try to buy it. When the dust settled recently, Warner Books had paid more than $1 million for Mrs. Foveaux's book. Yes, yes, maybe the book's good -- maybe it's not, as a Simon & Schuster executive put it, ''so boring it was unbelievable.'' But that's not the point. Good books don't automatically become best sellers; circuses do. **********TV VIOLENCE **********Don't Touch That Dial! Please? **********Television violence is not about to go away -- at least it hasn't so far, according to a study out last week, and it's still ''sanitized and glamorized,'' with punishment rare. So for those who want to shield children, the question remains: How? Those new ratings don't look promising, the study says, because the old ''forbidden-fruit syndrome'' kicks in. If a show is rated TV-M (mature audiences only), a teen-ager will say, ''Bring it on!'' And anything with a Y (all children) will elicit a resounding ''Yuk!'' So it's really simple: just label the nastiest stuff Y, and the kids won't go near it.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/20/busin.body_text: **********Stepping up the pressure on potential witnesses in the criminal investigation of the Columbia/ HCA Healthcare Corporation, Federal agents have been making nighttime visits to the homes of some company employees in Florida, trying to persuade them to cooperate with the inquiry and provide evidence to the Government. **********In addition, agents have served more subpoenas in Florida, increasing the number of executives compelled to appear before one of the grand juries investigating the unfolding scandal at the company. Many of the Columbia employees who have been subpoenaed hold jobs directly related to hospital finances or reimbursement from Federal programs like Medicare. **********The use of the home visits, some of which have taken place in recent days, is a sign that Federal officials are maintaining their aggressive stance in the widespread Columbia inquiry even as the company says it wants to cooperate. Such visits are a standard technique used by law enforcement officials when they suspect a witness might cooperate if approached outside the office. It is also used when officials are hoping to keep potential witnesses anxious and to persuade them to talk. **********''Historically, this tactic is used to scare a potential witness into immediate cooperation,'' said Gerald B. Lefcourt, a prominent criminal defense lawyer in New York. ''It's a standard tactic, and it probably works more times than anyone would like to admit.'' **********The home visits in the Columbia case are not the first in the investigation. Still, some of the earlier ones were decidedly different, with Federal investigators secretly meeting at the homes of cooperating witnesses who work for Columbia to avoid the suspicions of co-workers. **********Victor Campbell, a spokesman for the company, said he was unaware of any visits to executives in Florida. But Columbia has been prepared for such an event: weeks ago, in a move that is somewhat standard for a company under investigation, it sent out a memorandum to employees informing them of their rights if they were contacted at home by the Government. **********At least some of the questions asked by the agents were said to pertain to activities at Columbia's Fawcett Memorial Hospital in Port Charlotte, Fla. Fawcett is at the center of the first indictment handed up in the case against three Columbia executives. The men are charged with inflating the costs that Fawcett reported to Federal health programs like Medicare in order to illegally increase the hospital's reimbursement. **********Today, the three executives pleaded not guilty to the charges in Federal District Court here. **********The three executives -- Jay A. Jarrell, chief executive of Columbia's southwest Florida division; Michael T. Neeb, chief financial officer of its Jacksonville, Fla., division, and Robert W. Whiteside, a reimbursement director at the company's headquarters in Nashville -- said little in the short arraignment before United States Magistrate George T. Swartz. **********It was the executives' first appearance in court since the indictment against them was unsealed in late July. The indictment was handed up under seal on June 25, weeks before Federal agents conducted a sweeping raid on Columbia's hospitals and offices in a number of states. **********During today's hearing, Kathleen Haley, the assistant United States attorney in the case, asked if Columbia was paying the legal fees of the three executives, and raised questions about whether that would present a conflict of interest for their lawyers. **********Columbia itself is a target of the investigation, raising the possibility that its defense might conflict with that of the three executives. **********Under questioning from the magistrate, the executives' lawyers did not disclose whether they were being paid by the company, which is a frequent practice in cases in which executives are indicted for actions taken on behalf of a company. But the lawyers denied there was any conflict of interest even if Columbia was paying the bills. **********''There is nothing unusual or improper with a corporation paying'' for executives' legal bills, said Peter F. George, a lawyer for Mr. Jarrell. ''This is permitted by law and by the ethics of our profession.'' **********The issue was resolved after the executives agreed to waive any potential conflict stemming from Columbia's payment of legal bills that might arise later in the case.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/28/busin.body_text: **********Dow Plunges 554 Points; Exchanges Close Early **********Stocks tumbled around the world, and on Wall Street, markets were forced to end trading earlier than planned. **********The Dow industrials lost 554.26 points, or 7.2 percent, closing at 7,161.15, but no one knew just how far stocks might have skidded had not market rules -- adopted in the wake of the crash 10 years ago -- required markets to close at 3:30 P.M., half an hour early. The Dow's drop in percentage terms was the biggest ever in terms of points, but only about a third as large as the 22.6 percent on Oct. 19, 1987, in percentage terms. [Page A1.] **********While mutual fund companies said some individual investors sought redemptions, there were few signs of panic. And for some longtime market gurus, amid the pain of the market's plunge came relief that Wall Street finally had a ''correction.'' [A1.] **********Many investors headed for the safety of Treasuries, lifting bond prices and driving the yield on the 30-year issue down to a 20-month low, 6.14 percent, from 6.27 percent. [D6.] **********Oxford Health Warns of Problems **********The day's biggest decliner was Oxford Health, the big health maintenance organization, whose stock fell more than 60 percent after it said that it had been losing money because it fell behind in sending bills to customers and underestimated how much it owed doctors and hospitals. [A1.] **********Rate Rise for Satellite Broadcasters **********The rates that satellite broadcast companies, like DirecTV, Primestar and Echostar, pay to transmit network television signals would quadruple under a Copyright Office ruling. Owners of programming, like the networks, Hollywood studios and major sports leagues, would benefit. [D10.] **********Two Companies to Sell Assets **********Louisiana-Pacific said it would sell assets worth more than $1 billion and cut 3,500 jobs, reflecting problems widespread in the paper industry. Stone Container announced plans to sell its wood-pulp businesses to focus on corrugated containers and cut $1.5 billion from its $4 billion debt. [D7.] **********Strategic Moves by 2 Bells **********U S West announced a plan to split into separate telephone and cable television companies, while another Bell, Ameritech, said it had agreed to buy control of a European telephone carrier for more than $3 billion. Market Place. [D12.] **********Westinghouse Said to Seek Sale **********Westinghouse is negotiating to sell its power-generation units, ending its role as an industrial manufacturer, people associated with the talks said. A sale could be worth as much as $4 billion. [D2.] **********Britain to Delay Joining Euro **********The British Government, in an effort to end weeks of damaging political and financial uncertainties, ruled out early entry into the planned European single currency but said that signing up for monetary union was a long-range ambition. [A11.] **********Rolls-Royce For Sale **********Rolls-Royce Motor Cars, whose hood ornament is a symbol of British elegance, will be sold by Vickers, the defense and engineering company that purchased it eight years ago. [D5.] **********Scientific Computing Standard Due **********A group of developers of the fastest hardware and software for scientific and engineering computing plans to announce a technical standard to allow complex programs to operate on different types of computers, using either the Unix or Windows NT operating system. [D2.] **********U.S. May Intervene With Railroad **********The Government warned that it might step in to help resolve problems that have snarled grain shipments by Union Pacific. [A17.]

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/12/busin.body_text: **********Stocks were mixed yesterday, as the market's two main indexes were the only ones that managed to regain some ground after Friday's sharp losses. **********The Dow Jones industrial average jumped 30.89 points, to 8,062.11, rebounding from the Friday selloff that took most of the market's major indexes down 1.5 percent or more. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index also rose yesterday, adding 3.46 points, to 937. **********But the Nasdaq composite index finished lower, down 11.78 points, to 1,586.74, and indexes of smaller-company stocks also declined. **********On the New York Stock Exchange, declining stocks slightly outnumbered those  advancing, and volume was moderate.  Telephone companies, oil stocks and banks had gains. Technology, drug and health care stocks languished. **********The plunge on Friday brought losses to  stocks, Treasury securities and the dollar, as equities seemed to follow Treasuries lower and the dollar's selloff served as a catalyst for further slides in bond prices. **********But the markets seemed to regain their composure yesterday, analysts said, as long-term investors returned to seek out lower-priced securities. **********While the bond market closed little changed yesterday, a rally in the afternoon prevented larger losses. The yield on the 30-year bond rose to 6.64 percent, from 6.63 percent Friday. **********That afternoon bond rally, said Larry Rice, chief investment officer at Josephthal, Lyon & Ross, led to the turnaround in the Dow, which had been down as much as 66 points in the early afternoon. ''Bonds rallied, plain and simple,'' he said. **********The dollar also rebounded, rising 1 percent against the Japanese yen and slightly less than 1 percent against the German mark. **********A healthy American economy -- with brighter growth prospects than that of the major economies of Europe or of Japan -- coupled with relatively low interest rates, helped strengthen the dollar, said Craig McCauley, executive vice president of global investment management at the Bankers Trust Company. **********Even though there was no rebound across the board in the stock market, some analysts were still surprised that even a modest recovery had occurred. ''I thought the market would have a bad day, and it didn't,'' said Robert Stovall, president of Stovall/Twenty-First Advisers Inc. ''I was pretty impressed with the zeal to buy stocks.'' **********Yesterday's modest turnaround, he said, was a sign of the continued influence of the underlying factors that have been supporting the stock market all year, including the strong flow of cash into mutual funds. **********Still, some analysts expect that equities will at best just meander this week, as several important economic reports are released. **********''There's an awful lot of numbers coming out this week,'' said Jim Benning, a vice president and trader at BT Brokerage in New York. ''Any one of these numbers could really push the market either way.'' **********The Labor Department will release the Producer Price Index for July tomorrow, and the Consumer Price Index comes out on Thursday. **********But the July retail sales report scheduled for release tomorrow is probably the week's most important number. It will provide the first indication of consumer buying for the second half of the year. It is the uncertainty about the pace of economy in the second half that led to last week's selloffs in stocks and bonds. **********In the stock market yesterday, Chevron rose 2 3/8, to 80 1/16. Mobil  gained 3 11/16, to 76 9/16. Royal Dutch/ Shell picked up 1 1/16, to 54 3/4. **********The Fort Howard Corporation, a maker of napkins, paper towels and other tissue products, rose 2 7/8, to 60 3/8, on Nasdaq. Fort Howard is being acquired by the James River Corporation for $6.3 billion and it was announced yesterday that the new company, to be called the Fort James Corporation, will become a component of the S.& P. 500 index.  James River rose 1 7/16, to 43 15/16. **********Ascend Communications was the most active issue, with more than 24 million shares trading on the Nasdaq market. The shares fell 4 3/4, to 44 11/16. A regulatory filing by the company  disclosed that July revenue had sharply lagged behind analysts' expectations for Ascend, a computer networking company. **********Coca-Cola fell 15/16, to 61 3/4, yesterday, the third consecutive session in which Coke posted a decline. The stock traded as low as 59 5/8. Coke lost 3 7/8 on Friday, leading the Dow lower, after it said its third-quarter earnings would fall below analysts' expectations. **********ON THE WEB **********The latest stock and mutual fund quotations, along with news updates, are available on the Internet from The New York Times on the Web: www.nytimes.com

The president of Mitsubishi Motors, Takemune Kimura, said he regretted the executives' arrests. He said that the three paid 23.5 million yen ($194,000) to the gangsters but that top executives at the auto maker were unaware of the transactions. **********The executives are Atsushi Ueba, 56, former head of the company's general affairs department, and two department members, Yuichi Ueki, 43, and Shoichi Shima, 38.
