https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/02/busin.body_text: **********After a year of historic legislation, heated litigation and no fewer than four multibillion-dollar mergers, even the most confident are reluctant to venture an opinion about what changes 1997 will bring to the roiling telecommunications industry. **********''It's hard to predict 100-year floods,'' said Pierce J. Roberts Jr., an investment banker at Bear, Stearns & Company who has advised the Nynex Corporation on its planned $22 billion merger with the Bell Atlantic Corporation, last April. **********With deregulation now the law of the land, most experts believe that the telephone business can only become more competitive this year. The tougher economic realities that competition will bring also suggest that more phone companies will pursue mergers or takeovers. **********But the onset of competition will be a messy, hard-fought process -- with the long-distance and local carriers haggling over every nuance of the rules of engagement. And those detours into court could further delay the free-market free-for-all that the Telecommunications Act of 1996 was meant to uncork. **********''Our early experience is that it takes a long time to get even a modest, controlled rollout of competition,'' John D. Zeglis, general counsel of the AT&T Corporation, said. Already, the GTE Corporation and other local phone companies have persuaded a Federal appeals court to suspend new Government regulations on how the local phone companies must open up their local networks to AT&T and other rivals. GTE contends that the Federal Communications Commission has no jurisdiction to set these so-called interconnection rules. **********The next phase of rule-making -- in which the F.C.C. will revamp the web of subsidies that guarantee universal telephone service -- could ignite fresh legal challenges. **********''This could be as contentious, or even more contentious, than the interconnection rules, since universal service is about real money,'' said Scott Cleland, managing director of the Schwab Washington Research Group, a consulting firm. **********Among other things, the Clinton Administration is pushing for the phone companies to pledge to wire the nation's schools and hospitals for high-speed access to the Internet -- an ambitious program that could add $2.25 billion to the cost of providing universal phone service. **********The trouble is that under the new rules the 50 states will be responsible for collecting the subsidies that guarantee universal service. So if the F.C.C. were to make such a provision part of the new universal service regulations, Mr. Cleland predicted that at least one state government would immediately challenge the rules in court. **********New kinds of competition will not necessarily wait for all these court cases to be settled. AT&T is already offering local phone service to a small number of customers in Sacramento, Calif., Mr. Zeglis said. And the Ameritech Corporation, which offers local service in five Midwestern states, plans to file for permission to offer long distance next week. **********''We can start competing in spite of the court case,'' said Richard C. Notebaert, chairman of Ameritech, which has signed interconnection agreements with about a dozen would-be competitors, including the MFS Communications Company and Time Warner Inc. **********As the long-distance and local carriers invade each other's markets, they will probably continue to seek partners -- extending a wave of consolidation that began last year with the back-to-back mergers of Bell Atlantic with Nynex and SBC Communications Inc. with Pacific Telesis Group. **********''You'll see more mergers because you've still got several companies hanging out there,'' said Alex J. Mandl, the former president of AT&T, who stunned the industry last August when he left to take over an obscure wireless company, Associated Communications. **********Some of the most obvious pairings, like the two Bell deals, were done in 1996. Even the takeover of the MCI Communications Corporation by British Telecommunications P.L.C. was not completely unexpected, since British Telecommunications has owned 20 percent of MCI since 1994. **********Still, investment bankers sketched out several other deals that would put together long-distance and local carriers. GTE, which explored an alliance with MCI before the British Telecommunications merger was announced, is still eager to join forces with another major carrier, according to people familiar with the company. AT&T looms as the most obvious candidate, since its long-distance network would mesh well with GTE's sprawling local presence. **********Companies that provide alternative local phone service could also prove alluring to long-distance carriers seeking to expand into the $90 billion local phone business. The largest of these companies, Teleport Communications Group, has been rumored to be a takeover target for months. **********And while the British Telecommunications-MCI combination may raise thorny regulatory issues, analysts predict it will not be the last cross-border alliance. They suggest that Sprint could eventually be acquired by its European partners, Deutsche Telekom and France Telecom, each of which currently owns 10 percent of Sprint. **********What does all this activity portend for consumers? Experts said the rise of competition -- and even the spate of deals -- could reduce certain phone rates. Indeed, there are signs that the creation of a trans-Atlantic telephone company in British Telecommunications-MCI could erode the system of artificially inflated calling rates between the United States and Europe. **********Yet in the domestic local phone business, where the most revolutionary changes were supposed to occur, the outlook for consumers is murky. The regional Bell companies are zealously defending their local franchises. And long-distance carriers like AT&T and MCI are focusing on business customers ahead of the less profitable residential market. **********''The real disappointment of the telecom act is that there is going to be very little residential competition,'' Mr. Cleland said. **********That may be overly pessimistic. But given the raft of lawsuits that seems likely to tie up the process in the courts through this year, it is possible that this new era of telecommunications will be known for now less for its cheaper monthly bills than for its expensive wheeling and dealing.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/15/busin.body_text: **********Riser Foods Inc. agreed yesterday to be acquired by Giant Eagle Inc. for $403 million in cash and assumed debt. The transaction would create a food retailer and wholesaler with sales of $4 billion next year and stores stretching from Pittsburgh to Cleveland. The closely held Giant Eagle, a supermarket chain and wholesale distributor based in Pittsburgh, will pay $42 a share for Riser's class A and class B shares. Shares of Riser Foods, based in Bedford Heights, Ohio, closed yesterday at $41.625. Giant Eagle will also pay for outstanding stock options and assume $47 million of Riser's debt.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/02/world.snippet: Eskom, the state-owned power company, succeeds in bringing electricity to half South Africa's households, up from about a third six years ago, but there is no corresponding rise in power consumption; people are too poor to afford appliances, and a...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/02/world.main_headline: Delivering the Power to the People Is Just a First Step in South Africa
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/02/world.print_headline: Delivering the Power to the People Is Just a First Step in South Africa
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/02/world.body_text: **********On cold days, the air in many of South Africa's black townships is so dense with smoke that you can hear the clip-clop of the donkeys pulling the coal carts long before you can see them. **********Hidden in the pollution are millions of new pylons carrying electricity to even the most rundown shacks, the result of a massive electrification project that is one of the Government's few economic success stories. While President Nelson Mandela's promises of new housing, new jobs and better schools remain far behind schedule, the Government-owned power company has brought electricity to more than two million new households. Now half the households in South Africa are wired for electricity, up from about a third six years ago. **********But access to electric power does not mean that people are trading in their coal stoves for electric heaters and ranges. **********Far from it. Even though the power company arranged for lessons in how to use appliances and gave away irons, hot plates and electric kettles in some areas, a year later many are gathering dust. **********With all the promise of a better life that electrification brings, in South Africa electricity has arrived in villages and squatter camps long before paychecks and worldly ways. Power-company executives say they have come to realize that without improvements in other areas, the impact of electricity is limited. **********The power company has learned some hard lessons in the last few years. More than six years into the electrification project, company executives say they are hemorrhaging money and electricity use remains far below the levels they had counted on. On average they are subsidizing the new hookups to the tune of $84 per household per year. **********Some of the problem is simply poverty. Buying appliances has proved far beyond the reach of many South Africans. But experts say that the company, Eskom, which generates 97 percent of the country's energy and half the energy used elsewhere on the African continent, also failed to calculate the pull of habit and the choices people would make when they finally were able to flip that switch. **********''What we have seen is that electricity does not improve people's lives all alone,'' said Thula Bopela, Eskom's National Electrification Planning Manager. ''It has to be linked to roads, water, jobs and development in general.'' **********Some Eskom executives believe now that only the next generation will really embrace plug-in conveniences. **********Even the Eskom executive in charge of electrification in the huge black township of Soweto, Silos Zimu, said he has not been able to get his parents to abandon coal. ''They think it heats better,'' Mr. Zimu said. ''You cannot convince them otherwise.'' **********Televisions, not household appliances, are often people's first major purchase when electricity arrives. Unfortunately for the power company's balance sheet, television sets are expensive, so it takes people a long time to save enough money to buy one in a country where the average household income is below $3,000 a year. And they do not draw much more power than a light bulb. Often, too, people have been more interested in refrigeration during the hot months than in changing their heating and cooking techniques. In urban squatter camps and some other areas, people had often used car batteries or other means to obtain some electricity, so wiring their homes has not necessarily made a major change in their life styles. **********In rural areas, electricity must compete against other fuels, including wood and cow dung, which cost nothing but the effort of gathering them. In some areas, too, a coal stove is still a status symbol while electric appliances are considered extravagances. Another problem is that when appliances break, there is nowhere to get them repaired. In the end, many households have been using electricity for lighting only. **********Even in Soweto, this country's biggest, most sophisticated township, where a few houses sport satellite dishes and two-car garages, the coal carts still ply the streets at their laconic pace. Like summertime ice cream trucks, they blow whistles or toot horns to signal their arrival. **********In winter, Government pollution monitors say, the air quality here is among the worst in the world. It is not just coal -- there is industry upwind, people burn garbage openly and the cars kick up showers of dust on unpaved roads. But coal is a major factor. And the much-improved delivery of electricity has made hardly a dent. **********''The coal stove is a social gathering place -- you cannot sit around a radiator,'' said Jabu Sithole, a longtime Soweto resident and chairman of the local branch of the National Association for Clean Air. ''Some people also have a very deep belief that food cooked on coal tastes better.'' **********Eskom still aims to provide electricity to 300,000 new homes a year until 1999. At that point, about 72 percent of the country's 8.8 million dwellings should have electricity. **********But the company has had to drastically revise its estimates of when it would begin making money on its new customers. It had estimated that at the end of 10 years, the average connected household would be using a relatively modest 350 kilowatt-hours per month. Right now, the average stands at 86. **********The company has been revising its strategies for who will get electricity and when. In the past, decisions about who got electricity first were based on the cost of the hookup. If it was cheap to wire a township or a squatter camp because it was a high density area near the main power lines, it was done. **********Now, the agency is becoming more open to capital outlays if there is a good chance that the households at the end of the line will be large users of electricity. ''We got wise,'' Mr. Bopela, the Eskom planning manager, said, ''when we saw ourselves bleeding to death financially.'' **********Mr. Bopela said Eskom is also considering a pilot program to deliver very low-amperage electricity to areas where the people are so poor that they will undoubtedly use the electricity only for lighting. This could save as much as $250 per hookup. Upgrading later would be possible and not terribly expensive, Mr. Bopela said. **********Until now, all of Eskom's new connections have delivered enough electricity to power households outfitted with dozens of appliances, from air-conditioners to microwaves. With low average household incomes and millions of people living in one-room shacks, the decision to provide hookups with such power capacity seems in retrospect like overkill. **********''We have learned a lot,'' Mr. Bopela said. ''If we see that people are still going to use coal or paraffin and only want us for lights, then that is what we should give and nothing more.'' **********The fact that people are not using the electricity much does not mean there has been no enthusiasm for it.  Even in the poorest areas, residents have pushed hard to be hooked up. **********But in the end, many people stick with the familiar old ways. Electricity may not be more expensive than some of the other fuels, but a family can watch a monthly ration of coal being used up and calculate what it can afford. The cost of using electricity, on the other hand, often remains invisible until a family's income is spent. And recipes learned on a coal stove or open fire have to be retuned for a hot plate. **********Riverose Mcathi, who lives in the White City section of Soweto, was out on the street recently signaling ''the coal man'' to fill a tin bin by her front door. Her house, one of the thousands of identical dwellings built for blacks by the former Government decades ago, has had electricity since 1984. But she has not given up her coal stove. **********''With the coal stove you heat the house and you can put the pots on it,'' Mrs. Mcathi said. ''It is true that you can feel it in the air in the winter when people are using it a lot, but it is only for a few months and it is cheaper.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/04/busin.snippet: Excerpts from essays by children Matt Horesta, Alexander Gertel and Amy Lauren Anderson on learning about money and investing from essay contest sponsored by Stein Roe & Farnham, mutual fund company in Chicago (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/04/busin.body_text: **********Children aren't so different from you and me. They like to spend money -- whether on video games or Nikes. But more and more of them seem to be learning about saving and investing for the future from their parents and guardians. **********Stein Roe & Farnham, the mutual fund company in Chicago, recently sponsored a children's essay contest to encourage such practices. The question was: What are the most important things you have learned about money and investing, and how will this knowledge help you in the future? **********Among the more than 1,200 entrants, from grades 5 through 7, several themes emerged. A common sentiment was that banks are a place where your money grows very slowly. For all the bankers out there trying to sell mutual funds and other investments, those responses suggest a prickly image problem. **********Many children described saving as the first step on their way to financial competency. Some had innovative approaches worked out with their parents; others talked about specific formulas, like saving 10 percent of everything earned, whether from pet-sitting or doing household chores. A few said they set aside as much as half or two-thirds of their earnings or cash gifts to help build a college fund. **********Then there were a few other widely held beliefs that have sent investors of all ages down ill-chosen paths: stocks always go up; you can always sell houses for more than you paid for them, and you will do well buying a stock if you like the company's product. **********Following are excerpts from three of the essays: **********WHEN I was 6, my grandfather began to teach me about the stock market. He told me I needed to learn how to invest intelligently although at the time, I'm not sure I knew what that meant. He taught me how to read The Wall Street Journal and how to follow stocks on the New York Stock Exchange and on the Nasdaq . . . **********When my grandfather thought I was beginning to get a handle on investing, he gave me $150 to invest in a stock of my choice. Foolishly, I disregarded everything he taught me, and I invested with my heart. I chose a stock of a minor league baseball park in my state that was listed on the Nasdaq. I love to play baseball, and this park reminded me of ''Field of Dreams.'' I was sure this was a sound investment, but from the day I bought it, it has continued to lose money. And last month, there was a 1-for-10 reverse split! Today, my 48 shares are 4 shares and my investment is worth $1. What a lesson that was! **********Matt Horesta **********7th grade, Pompton Plains, N.J. **********BEFORE you invest money you have to make it. The way I do this is by using coupons at the grocery store. Every week I cut out the coupons of products we use. My mother makes a list of the items we are going to buy. Then my father and I go to the store with the coupons and the list. When we pay for the groceries, I hand the coupons to the cashier, and he or she scans them. The savings show up on the receipt. When we get home, my father adds up the savings, and I write the amount saved in a notebook. I save approximately $10 per week. (That is over $500 per year.) I put half of this savings in mutual funds, and I am able to spend the other half . . . **********Alexander Gertel **********5th grade, Mequon, Wis. **********MY grandparents have been a good example to me. They have an investment fund for each of their grandchildren. Instead of buying me an expensive ''wonder world'' for my birthday, they put money in my account. Then they buy me something smaller for my birthday, but I know that my future is growing bigger every year. I think they are very wise and love me enough to plan ahead . . . **********Amy Lauren Anderson **********5th grade, Toccoa, Ga.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/15/busin.snippet: Raytheon Co says earnings in first quarter fell 1.7 percent; net income fell to $183.4 million compared with $186.5 million a year earlier; revenue rose nearly 4 percent, to $2.9 billion from $2.79 billion; table (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/15/busin.body_text: **********The Raytheon Company said yesterday that earnings in the first quarter fell 1.7 percent, less than expected, as the military contractor's missile unit recorded its first increase in sales and pretax profit in 15 quarters. **********Net income fell to $183.4 million, or 78 cents a share, on fewer shares outstanding, compared with $186.5 million, also 78 cents, a year earlier. **********Analysts were expecting the company to earn 73 cents, based on a survey of five analysts by I.B.E.S. International Inc. **********Revenue rose nearly 4 percent, to $2.9 billion from $2.79 billion. **********The performance of the electronics unit reflected both wider profit margins and the acquisition of the Chrysler Corporation's aircraft modification and military electronics business in June, the company said. **********''They had a good quarter, but there's concern in the marketplace about the full benefit of cost savings'' to be achieved, said Roger Threlfall, an analyst with J. P. Morgan. **********Changing that perception ''is going to take more than one quarter,'' he said. **********In January, Raytheon, based in Lexington, Mass., said it would buy two military contractors for a total of $8 billion. Raytheon agreed to buy the General Motors Corporation's Hughes military business and Texas Instruments Inc.'s military electronics business. **********Given the magnitude of those transactions, the quarterly results do not grab as much attention as they might otherwise, Keith Patriquin, an analyst with Loomis, Sayles & Company, said. ''There's a lot more yet to come on what the real Raytheon is going to be,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/11/busin.main_headline: Stocks Plunge, Then Soar, As Dow Finishes Up 78.12
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/11/busin.print_headline: Stocks Plunge, Then Soar, As Dow Finishes Up 78.12
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/11/busin.body_text: **********Stock prices went on a wild ride yesterday, first plunging and then leaping. The swings came after the Government reported that jobs grew more strongly than expected last month. **********The Dow Jones industrial average  surpassed 6,700 for the first time and notched its fourth record in a week, closing at 6,703.79, up 78.12 points in heavy trading. For the week, the Dow was up 159.70 points, or about 2.4 percent. **********Other market indexes also set records. The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks rose 4.65 points, to 759.50, and the Nasdaq composite index gained 5.82 points, to 1,332.02. **********The Russell 2000 index rose for the second consecutive day, closing at a record 366.09, up 0.50 point. The New York Stock Exchange composite rose 2.18 points, at 400.76. **********Stocks tumbled at the opening of the market on the Labor Department's report on December employment, which showed higher-than-expected job growth. **********Bond prices fell even more sharply in the morning, dropping by more than a point and a half before recovering somewhat. **********The Dow was down 67 points in early trading, restricting trading on the New York Stock Exchange, but by early afternoon blue-chip stocks bounced back on what was to become a 150-point turnaround. **********''Stocks had a very, very wild day,'' said Matthew F. Alexy, chief market strategist at Credit Suisse First Boston. ''Days like this embolden investors. They see a day where the Dow comes back from what looks like a death spiral and then it goes on to make a record high.'' **********Analysts said that cash flowing in from foreign investors and larger- than-expected investments in mutual funds had helped bolster the stock market. **********There is also increasing confidence in the economy and the strength of the dollar. **********''What the stock market is beginning to reflect is that maybe we can have a strong economy without a strong rise in inflation,'' said Byron Wien, chief United States investment strategist at Morgan Stanley. 'There's a feeling out there that nothing can go wrong. It's a dangerous attitude but it's out there.'' **********Indeed, investors continue to focus on prospects for growth, despite fears of inflation that have unnerved investors in the bond market, analysts said. **********''There's a view the economy is firm,'' Mr. Alexy said. ''Right now, the equity market is saying earnings will be O.K.'' **********Mr. Wien and other analysts said that the advance in stocks was broad. Of the Dow's 30 component stocks, only 4 declined in trading yesterday, and cyclical stocks were particularly strong. **********Oil stocks again were a significant part of the rally. Shares of Texaco closed at 107 3/8, up 2 3/8. And shares of Exxon rose to 105 3/4, up 2 7/8. **********Allied Signal was one of the Dow's big gainers, rising to 70 1/2, up 2 3/8. **********Shares of General Motors closed at 61 1/8, up 1 7/8, and Caterpillar was up 1 7/8 to close at 78. **********With those gains, the Dow has risen nearly 4 percent since the beginning of the year. **********Some analysts said that despite a plunge in Japanese stocks and weakness in the bond market, investors and speculators continued to favor equities. **********''A bull market celebrates good news and ignores bad news,'' said Eric Miller, chief investment officer at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. ''There's the so-called January barometer, when people look at how the market performs. Strength encourages people, weakness discourages them. This month tends to suggest a bull market.'' **********ON THE WEB **********The latest stock and mutual fund quotations, along with news updates, are available on the Internet from The New York Times on the Web: www.nytimes.com

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/12/busin.snippet: Laura Pedersen-Pietersen article answers reader's question about Uniform Gift to Minors Act account and how to respond when parent takes back money deposited in account (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/12/busin.main_headline: How a Daughter's Account Has Divided a Family
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/12/busin.print_headline: MINDING YOUR BUSINESS; How a Daughter's Account Has Divided a Family
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/12/busin.body_text: **********Q. I'm a 25-year-old starving student in New York. Last year my parents removed $30,000 from my UGMA account because they disapprove of my life style. I got stuck with the tax bill, and a lawyer advised me that it's not worth trying to get the money back. What can I do? **********A.  Isn't it supposed to be the other way around -- students cleaning out their parents en route to a college degree? **********Heading off to the University of Michigan, I managed to smuggle out my mother's toaster oven, hot plate, tape deck, 11-inch TV and two sets of Martex sheets. Of course, the neighbors wondered why I was packing the car wearing a full-length, goose-down coat in the middle of August. **********As for recovering your money, you may want to get another lawyer. While some accountants told me that your parents have done nothing worse than take a hammer to a piggy bank that they had already filled, other experts see thievery. Under New York law, they point out, the money in your UGMA account (named for the Uniform Gift to Minors Act) was supposed to go to you at age 21, no strings attached. The age varies from state to state, from 18 to 25. **********After the child reaches the designated age, ''it would be clearly illegal for the parents or any other custodian to remove the funds for their own use, even if they've fallen into dire straits,'' said Don Young, a lawyer specializing in estate planning at the Manhattan firm of Tunick, Kupferman, Creadore & Young P.C. **********Despite this constraint, however, many wealthy parents and grandparents use UGMA accounts to give a child up to $10,000 a year. The accounts, available in all states under either the UGMA statute or a broader law known as the Uniform Transfers to Minors Act, have two attractions: The gifts are tax-free to donors, enabling them to whittle down their estates and perhaps avoid inheritance taxes. And when the child reaches age 14, the earnings are taxed at a lower rate -- usually 15 percent -- than they often would be if the parents' rate had applied. (If the earnings are less than $650, no tax applies at any age.) **********But when the taxes are due on your account's earnings, you should pay up if your parents don't. Whatever your quarrel with your folks, all the Internal Revenue Service knows is that the UGMA was in your name and, therefore, you owe the money. **********The Uniform Gift to Minors Act specifically provides that once money has been transferred to such an account, the donor cannot take it back. And any withdrawals  must directly benefit the child. While many parents set up UGMA accounts specifically to deal with soaring college costs, the law allows the custodian to make reasonable expenditures for many activities, like summer camp, music or riding lessons, orthodontics or a computer. Not included are costs that are typically the sole responsibility of parents, like utility bills or the mortgage. **********But there apparently is no such benefit with your disappearing UGMA. Nor can  your parents now claim to be retroactively reimbursing themselves for years of child-rearing expenses -- as in, ''Oops, we forgot to take out money for that S.A.T. prep course in 1989.'' **********''She should definitely attempt to recover the full value of the account,'' said David A. Baker, a lawyer in the Chicago office of McDermott, Will & Emery. ''Depending on the depositors' contract when the account was opened, she may also be able to file an action against the bank or investment firm  that released the funds to her parents after she came of age.'' **********If your parents had removed the money before you turned 21, when they still had a right of access to the account, you would most likely have found it more difficult, if not impossible, to recover it. They probably could have produced receipts to prove that the withdrawals were for your benefit. **********''The only instance when it's fairly easy to prove parental misappropriation of UGMA funds,'' Mr. Baker said, ''is when there's a divorce, and the parent found to be spending the money irresponsibly is the parent who does not have legal custody of the child.'' **********Part of the problem with parental misappropriation is that most banks and brokerage firms have no system for notifying UGMA beneficiaries when they become eligible to withdraw the money. Nor is there a mechanism to discourage or prevent the parental donors, as long as they are also custodians of the account, from tapping into the funds even after the child comes of age. **********''The system is not really set up to keep parents from raiding the accounts -- just the kids,'' said Mitchell Slater, a vice president at Merrill Lynch in Roseland, N.J., who specializes in financial planning for children. **********Terry Savage, the author of several personal-finance books, added, ''Many parents  purposely keep the accounts secret to prevent the money from being squandered.'' **********In fact, Mr. Young said, some parents leave the money parked in the accounts long after the beneficiary has come of age. He has encountered parents who use UGMA's to pay the occasional bill, too, although he  had never heard of parents' completely reclaiming an account. **********UGMA accounts can be very valuable; those of affluent families can often be well into the six figures, which can mean sizable tax savings. **********But some experts suggest that the accounts, even without their constraints, may not always be worth the effort. **********'I'm not a big fan of UGMA's,'' said Kalman A. Chany, author of ''Paying For College Without Going Broke'' (Princeton Review, $18). ''You may be jeopardizing your chances for financial aid in return for a few hundred dollars in tax savings.'' Colleges deem 35 percent of assets in a child's name to be fair game for tuition, he explained, while for parents' assets the figure is only up to 5.65 percent. **********To those who think they are too well-off to qualify for financial aid, Mr. Chany cautioned that, through divorce or downsizing, circumstances can change. **********''It's better to buy growth stocks in your own name and then, if it does not look like you'll get financial aid, start gifting the securities that have appreciated into an UGMA when your child is in high school,'' Mr. Chany said. ''He can then later sell the securities to pay for tuition, and all the capital gains will still be taxed at the child's rate.'' **********Although planners are sorting out the effects on financial-aid eligibility and other matters, new vehicles are being created for college savers, too. In the tax package this summer, for example, Congress created a so-called education I.R.A. that allows investors to escape tax on earnings used for school expenses, even after the money is withdrawn. And in the higher-education savings plans that more and more states are authorizing, earnings are taxed, but not until withdrawal. **********Mr. Young also has little use for UGMA's. ''If you set up an UGMA of which you are also the custodian, and you die before the funds are turned over to the beneficiary, then the account will be taxed as part of your estate,'' he said. **********What is the lesson in all this? If you are a parent tempted to use those UGMA dollars for something other than your child's benefit, just remember Leonard Bernstein's father. When criticized for not giving his multitalented child more encouragement, he said, ''How was I to know he would grow up to be Leonard Bernstein?''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/08/world.snippet: Union Bank of Switzerland and Swiss Bank Corp will merge, creating world's second-largest bank and world's biggest money-management company; new entity, United Bank of Switzerland, will control $592 billion in total assets; Marcel Ospel, Swiss Ban...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/08/world.main_headline: Two Swiss Banks Plan a Merger, Forming Global Financial Giant
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/08/world.print_headline: Two Swiss Banks Plan a Merger, Forming Global Financial Giant
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/08/world.body_text: **********Two banking giants, Union Bank of Switzerland and the Swiss Bank Corporation, announced early today that they planned to merge, creating the world's second largest bank. **********The proposed merger would be one of the largest corporate deals ever, and it is the latest in a recent series of deals in the global market for financial services. Banking companies in Europe, like those in the United States, have been on a buying spree to expand their markets and increase their ability to compete around the world while cutting costs. **********The companies said that the merger, which was announced at a news conference in Zurich, before the opening of European financial markets, would lead to cuts of as many as 13,000 jobs worldwide -- 7,000 of the two banks' 40,000 jobs in Switzerland, and another 6,000 among their roughly 18,000 overseas employees. The job losses are likely to fall heavily on the banks' operations in New York; both banks are among the largest foreign financial institutions in the United States. **********The combined bank is to be called United Bank of Switzerland, with corporate and consumer banking operations headquartered in Zurich, while the private banking unit will be based in Basel. It would control $592 billion in total assets, putting it behind the Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi of Japan, which controls $696 billion in assets. **********By contrast, the Chase Manhattan Corporation, the largest American banking company, with $340 billion in assets, does not even rank in the top 10 of the world's banks in terms of assets. **********A merger of Union Bank and Swiss Bank would also create the world's biggest money-management company, surpassing the mutual fund giant Fidelity Investments. **********Banking industry analysts said the deal would encourage other large financial companies around the world to pursue mergers of their own to remain competitive. **********''This will ring the bell for everybody around the world,'' said John Keefe, who runs Keefe Worldwide Information Services in New York. ''This will be a signal to the top few players that they have to increase their scale. Morgan and Citibank and Chase will have to think about what they are going to do.'' **********Some details of the merger were unclear last night, but Marcel Ospel, the tough Swiss banking executive who until now has run the Swiss Bank Corporation, which is based in Basel, was appointed as chief executive of the combined bank. Mathis Cabiallavetta, who is now chief executive of Union Bank, which is headquartered in Zurich, the Swiss banking capital, was appointed the new bank's chairman. **********The deal involves an exchange of stock. Shareholders of Union Bank, Switzerland's largest banking company, are to own 60 percent of the equity in the new bank, while shareholders of Swiss Bank, which ranks No. 3, are to own the remainder. The merger will require the approval of shareholders as well as Swiss antitrust authorities. Shareholder votes on the merger are to take place on Feb. 3 and 4. **********Rumors that the banks were about to make an announcement buoyed the stock prices of both banks in recent days. **********But the Swiss banks have been struggling in recent years, and the banks reported their first losses ever last year, as the Swiss economy was hurt by recession, and as the traditional fortresses of the Swiss in asset management and international investment banking were assailed by revitalized American institutions like Merrill Lynch, J. P. Morgan, Goldman, Sachs and others. **********Changing economic conditions around the world, as well as the slump in Switzerland, are the driving forces for the deal. The merger, though, does come at a time when Switzerland's banks, and notably Union Bank, have also come under heavy fire for their handling of the accounts of victims of the Nazis. This week, the banks got a brief respite after a three-month moratorium was announced by United States city and state financial officers who had threatened punitive action. In coming months, however, the banks are expected to face mounting pressure to reach an out-of-court settlement in New York, where they face class-action suits from Holocaust survivors and their heirs. **********Union Bank came under particular criticism earlier this year, after a security guard came across documents relating to the sale of Jewish property in Germany being shredded in the bank's basement. The guard passed them to a Swiss Jewish organization. The guard, Christoph Meili, was dismissed from his job, and later fled to the United States, where Congress accorded him and his family residence rights. **********Reports of possible mergers swirled through the world of international finance at least since last year, when an approach by Credit Suisse, the No. 2 Swiss banking group, unsuccessfully broached the idea of a merger to Union Bank. Undaunted, Credit Suisse announced earlier this year an $8.8 billion takeover of the big Winterthur Insurance Company. This regrouping, plus a surge in net profits thus far this year, as the big Swiss banks cashed in on increased earnings on securities trading on the world's bull markets, have caused Swiss bank stocks to catch fire recently, rebounding strongly after several years of weak performance. **********In addition to long-established commercial banking businesses in the United States, both Union Bank and Swiss Bank have a broad range of other financial service companies. In recent years, the Swiss Bank Corporation acquired O'Connor, a Chicago derivatives business; S. G. Warburg, a British investment bank with a sizable Wall Street presence, and Dillon Read, a venerable old-line American investment bank with blue chip clients, but with a declining market share in the main Wall Street businesses. Union Bank, for its part, has tended to acquire teams and individuals to bolster its ambitious plans for the United States. It was Mr. Ospel who, in 1995, persuaded Swiss Bank to take over Warburg. **********A merger of Union Bank and the Swiss Bank Corporation would create a mammoth money management company, with assets under management of more than one trillion Swiss francs, about $670 billion, pushing it past Fidelity Investments in the United States as the world's biggest money managing company. Union Bank's position as the world's No. 3 money manager came under assault last month, after Merrill Lynch announced it will acquire the Mercury Asset Management Group of Britain for $5.2 billion. The acquisition raised Merrill Lynch's assets to $450 billion. **********The merger is the latest move in a scramble among European banks and insurers to restructure their businesses as the introduction of a single European currency approaches. Since Switzerland, which is not a member of the 15-nation European Union, will not take part in the union, its banks are hustling to get access to the single currency area through acquisitions and cooperation accords. Thus in August, Union Bank paid $196 million to acquire Schroder Munchmeyer Hengst, a Frankfurt private bank, in a move to expand in Germany.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/18/busin.snippet: BankBoston Corp says it had trading loss in October of $20 million in securities and foreign exchange after volatility in Latin America and Asian markets (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/18/busin.body_text: **********The BankBoston Corporation reported today that it had a trading loss in October of $20 million in securities and foreign exchange after volatility in Latin American and Asian markets. **********BankBoston earned about $49 million, or 11 percent of its noninterest income in the third quarter, from the combination of trading profits, foreign exchange profits and securities gains. The bank earns about 8.5 percent of its profits from Brazil, half of the total for Latin America. **********The losses were ''partially offset by improvements in net interest revenue and fee income, which have been positively impacted by these same events,'' the bank said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. BankBoston had assets of $66.1 billion as of June 30 and is the 15th-largest bank in the country. **********BankBoston's trading loss was first reported in Barron's on Saturday. Barron's also that said BankBoston was an attractive takeover candidate. BankBoston's stock rose $2.9375, to $81.6875, on the New York Stock Exchange. **********The Chase Manhattan Corporation, the nation's largest bank, said last week that it had a net trading loss of $160 million before taxes, or $100 million after taxes, during October.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/17/busin.snippet: Robert D Campbell, former publisher of Newsweek magazine, dies at age 79 (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/17/busin.body_text: **********Robert D. Campbell, a former chairman, publisher and president of Newsweek magazine, died of complications from Parkinson's disease on Monday in Rancho Santa Fe, Calif., his son, William, said. He was 79. **********Mr. Campbell, who spent three decades with Newsweek before he retired in 1979, began his career with the magazine as an advertising salesman in California. After holding a broad range of executive posts, in 1966 he was named managing director of Newsweek International. Six years later he was appointed publisher of Newsweek. He added the title of president in 1975 and became chairman the following year. He remained a consultant to the magazine for five years after his retirement. **********Mr. Campbell was a graduate of Northwestern University, was a fighter pilot during World War II and was involved in the Berlin airlift in 1948-49. He was recalled to active duty during the Korean War and held the rank of brigadier general (retired) in the Air Force. **********Mr. Campbell is survived by his wife, the former Julia Briggs, of Rancho Santa Fe; a daughter, Julia C. Campbell, of Stratford, Conn., and a son, William D. Campbell, of Jersey City.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/15/busin.main_headline: Shell Shareholders Reject A Human Rights Initiative
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/15/busin.print_headline: Shell Shareholders Reject A Human Rights Initiative
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/15/busin.body_text: **********Filing past some 150 noisy demonstrators, shareholders of Shell Transport and Trading P.L.C. rejected a resolution today calling for greater attention to environmental and human rights policies. Operations of the giant oil company in places like Nigeria have been criticized on those grounds. **********But Shell said it had taken steps to lessen the criticism by establishing regular contacts with representatives of several groups, including Greenpeace, Amnesty International and the World Wide Fund for Nature. **********Before the annual meeting here today, held amid extraordinary security measures, Shell's management had urged a vote against the resolution. It argued that it had received the protesters' message but would not submit to an independent external review of its environmental or social programs. **********The resolution was sponsored by Pensions and Investment Research Consultants Ltd. and the Ecumenical Council for Corporate Responsibility, a church group. Voters holding 316 million of the 357 million shares rejected the resolution, the company's chairman, John S. Jennings, said. **********Shell Transport and Trading is the British arm of the Royal Dutch/Shell Group; the Dutch arm, the Royal Dutch Petroleum Company, held a separate meeting today in The Hague. **********Shell's policies, particularly in Nigeria, have come under intense public scrutiny as groups have accused the company of causing pollution problems and of having a cozy relationship with the Nigerian military Government, which is notorious for its human rights violations. **********Even though the shareholder resolution was soundly defeated, several industry executives said that pressure on oil companies to address environmental and human rights concerns would increase in time. **********''It's a trend that bears watching,'' a senior executive from another energy company, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said. ''It will open up a whole kettle of fish, the sort to thing that could affect a great deal of companies.'' **********Proponents of the resolution said that their campaign had not been a complete loss, emphasizing that greater openness on the company's record was required. ''A lot of good has come out of this resolution, even though it has been defeated,'' the Rev. Peter Barnett, a shareholder acting on behalf of a British charity that owns a block of Shell stock, said. ''I think this is the second big multinational oil corporation now paying attention to our concerns.'' **********British Petroleum already delivers an annual health, safety and environmental report, and then submits it to outside auditors, a B.P. spokesman said, adding, ''We work with a whole range of nongovernment organizations.'' **********While Shell would not go that far today, it did produce its first health, safety and environment report. **********Mr. Jennings said that Shell's board had refused to endorse the resolution because the company could not turn control of its long-term policies over to an outside group. But he added that the oil group had adopted a policy that ''explicitly recognizes Shell companies' responsibility to express support for fundamental human rights in line with the legitimate role of business.'' **********Protests against Shell intensified in 1995 after the military junta in Nigeria, a major oil producer in Shell's worldwide operations, hanged the environmentalist and playwright Ken Saro-Wiwa and eight other opposition figures. **********Mr. Saro-Wiwa and others had been consistently critical of Shell's operations in the Ogoni region of the country, arguing that the company was callous and had contributed to destroying tribal communities and the region's environment. Nigerian officials accused them of sabotage. **********Mr. Jennings said today that Shell ''is committed to reconciliation in Ogoniland,'' adding that its representatives in Nigeria had held several meetings with Ogoni leaders and had spent $36 million last year to build up basic facilities and welfare services in the Niger Delta as well as $120 million to safeguard the environment. **********Today, the stockholders of Shell's British wing approved the issuing of two new common shares for each existing share, while those of Royal Dutch Petroleum approved a 4-for-1 stock split. The company's American depository receipts will be split on a comparable basis to the British shares.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/03/world.snippet: Haaretz, Israeli newspaper, says Israeli security forces have information that 16 Palestinians involved in selling land to Jews have been marked for death, including three land dealers already killed during past month (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/03/world.main_headline: 16 Palestinians Marked for Death for Selling Land, Israelis Say
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/03/world.print_headline: 16 Palestinians Marked for Death for Selling Land, Israelis Say
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/03/world.body_text: **********Israeli security forces have information that 16 Palestinian dealers involved in selling land to Jews have been marked for death, including three land dealers already killed during the last month, an Israeli newspaper reported today. **********The report in the daily Haaretz was published the day after the Jerusalem police chief charged that a senior Palestinian security official -- later identified by Israeli television as Col. Tawfik Tarawi, chief of Palestinian General Security Service in the West Bank -- was directly involved in two of the recent slayings. **********The Palestinian Authority has denied responsibility for the killings, which have all taken place since Freih Abu Middein, its justice minister, declared on May 5 that Arabs convicted of selling land to Jews would be sentenced to death. **********Despite strong condemnation by Israel and the United States, Mr. Abu Middein has repeatedly reaffirmed the condemnation of land dealers, and neither Yasir Arafat nor any other Palestinian official has denounced the edict. At a news conference in Ramallah in the West Bank earlier this week, Mr. Abu Middein defended the death penalty as ''a question of survival and sovereignty'' and said 12 Palestinians will go on trial soon on land-selling charges. **********According to Haaretz, Israeli security officials advised various security agencies, including the service headed by Colonel Tarawi, of the  threat to the land dealers. The paper said some dealers have hired bodyguards. **********Several members of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's Government have demanded that the Government cease all negotiations with the Palestinians until the killings of land dealers stop. But since negotiations are already at a halt and show no signs of reviving under Mr. Netanyahu, the Prime Minister and his lieutenants has been limited so far to issuing denunciations. **********Mr. Netanyahu met today with security and intelligence officials to discuss how to handle the killings. A statement issued later said that the Government would ''strongly protest the matter'' to the Authority, that it would issue warrants for those suspected of involvement, and that the investigation will continue. **********The statements are not likely to deter the Palestinians, many of whom have written off any chance of making progress toward peace with Mr. Netanyahu. Though putting land dealers to death has been denounced by some Palestinians, Palestinian leaders of all leanings strongly support banning land sales to Jews. **********Last week, Bassam Eid, head of the Palestinian Human Rights Monitor and a sharp critic of the Palestinian Authority, said his group's position is that ''selling land to Jews is a national crime and should be punished by the Palestinian Authority.'' **********The Palestinian argument is that lands purchased by Jews are thereafter claimed by Israel as its sovereign territory, and therefore that any Arab who sells land is a traitor. **********The sentiment has become acute since the start of construction of a Jewish neighborhood in East Jerusalem on land that was originally purchased from Arabs. **********''I have no objection to any Israeli, a Jew, I mean, to buy a home in Gaza, under one condition, that he will live under the sovereignty of the Palestinians,'' Mr. Abu Middein told Israel Army Radio today. ''This is the main question because the land in the West Bank and particularly in Jerusalem, the Israeli Government considers any private property of the Jew, it is automatically their political sovereignty.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/02/busin.snippet: Article on some small-stock mutual funds that weathered stock market's downturn better than most (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/02/busin.main_headline: In Some Small-Stock Funds, A Haven From the Turmoil
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/02/busin.print_headline: THE MANIC MARKET: AN INVESTOR'S GUIDE; In Some Small-Stock Funds, A Haven From the Turmoil
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/02/busin.body_text: **********LOOKING for ports in a storm? Some stock mutual funds with decent long-term records performed quite acceptably during the market swoon of this summer and fall that culminated in Monday's plunge. But it was almost impossible to find a fund with a good previous record that did well during the four days of terror that ended last Monday. **********The standout funds during the swoon were the Evergreen Limited Market fund and the Bridgeway Ultra-Small Company fund. Both invest in very small companies, which weathered the downturn better than most. **********The Dow Jones industrial average peaked on Aug. 6 at 8,259.31 and then fell 13.3 percent through the panic-stricken early close on Monday. Small-stock indexes continued to climb after the Dow peaked, however, and ended on Monday about where they were in early August. **********Over all, the best-performing mutual fund over that period was a fund that buys small stocks in Britain, the DFA United Kingdom Small Company fund; it went up 14.2 percent. Alas, it had been down earlier in 1997 and has a mediocre record in recent years. (It was, however, a top performer back in the year that ended Sept. 30, 1987, just before that year's crash. Maybe this is a fund that should be monitored by those looking for signs of a new crash.) **********Energy stocks did well during much of the swoon, which is what allowed Fidelity's Select Energy Service fund to make the list of top performers. It also has a good long-term record but alone does not make for a diversified portfolio. **********The Evergreen and Bridgeway funds were joined by a newer fund, Franklin Micro Cap Value I, as good performers during the down period. All three invest in very small companies, often with market values of less than $100 million, which Wall Street is likely to ignore. **********The other funds that did well -- to no one's surprise -- were the bear funds. Rydex Ursa, which has been betting against the bull for a long time, went up 10.75 percent during the period. That did not, however, erase its losses so far in 1997. Lighthouse Growth, which plans to change its name to Lighthouse Contrarian, also did well. It, too, has been shorting a lot of stocks. **********''We've felt the stock market was getting to be a speculative bubble,'' said Kevin Duffy, the fund's manager. The Lighthouse fund had, however, done little more than break even in 1997 through Aug. 6. **********And what funds sank in the tempest-tossed seas? **********This panic began in Asia, and it should come as no surprise that foreign funds dominated the losers' list for both periods. Asian funds did the worst for the post-August swoon, and Latin American funds fared the worst in the four terrible days. For most of the summer, Latin markets had ignored the Asian troubles, but the worldwide panic hit them hard at the end. **********Among American funds, some of the biggest winners when the market was soaring ranked among the worst performers when the bull ran into trouble. Technology funds were the big losers for the August-to-October period, while the four-day crunch saw carnage as well among some aggressive-growth funds. **********And the lessons for the future? They are murky, indeed. **********Funds that do well in bear markets are unlikely to have been leaders in bull markets. Historically, small stocks tend to do worse than big ones in bear markets, but that did not happen when this market fell apart. There is no guarantee that pattern will repeat itself.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/23/world.snippet: Tensions and violence in Chiapas Indian hamlet of San Pedro Nixtalucum is linked, at least in part, to edgy, undeclared truce between Mexican Government and Zapatista rebels; rebels are penned up in jungle strongholds by troops and have lost nearl...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/23/world.main_headline: Out of Spotlight, Violence Tears at Mexican State
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/23/world.print_headline: Out of Spotlight, Violence Tears at Mexican State
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/23/world.body_text: **********The dispute started with the indiscretion of two peeping Toms who crouched in the shade of a coffee tree to watch a woman bathing. **********But by the time the violence here subsided two days later, four villagers were shot dead, six state police officers were beaten, 27 people landed in jail and nearly 400 people, including many children, were forced to flee into the forest. **********San Pedro Nixtalucum is one of hundreds of Indian hamlets clinging to steep mountain slopes in the humid uplands of the state of Chiapas. It is a long way from the low-lying Chiapas jungles where Zapatista guerrillas staged an uprising in 1994. **********But the violence that followed a simple quarrel over an offense to a woman's modesty had much to do with the Zapatista rebellion. It was one of many violent incidents in Chiapas this year that revealed the costs of the Government's strategy of postponing the peace with the rebels. **********More than three years after the Zapatistas seized a Chiapas city to draw attention to the exploitation of the region's Indians, the guerrillas and the Government have settled into an edgy, undeclared truce, with the rebels penned up in their jungle strongholds by Government troops. Peace talks stalled last September. **********The rebels have lost nearly all their political momentum. As the peace talks faltered over deep differences between President Ernesto Zedillo and Zapatista leaders, the guerrillas' international limelight faded while the army reinforced its control across the state, setting up garrisons in the most remote corners. **********While making no concessions to the rebels, the Government poured  resources into non-Zapatista communities for new road, health and school projects. This won the showdown for Mr. Zedillo, but at a price. Across Chiapas the lack of peace has aggravated age-old village disputes and deepened new rifts, bringing back the explosive tensions that existed before the Zapatista revolt. **********''We are beginning to see desperation in the Indian communities,'' said Bishop Raul Vera Lopez, a leader of the Roman Catholic diocese that includes most of the Indian regions of Chiapas. ''We see a harder line from the army and the police, and we don't see signs that the Government really wants a negotiated solution.'' **********The inhabitants of San Pedro are Tzotzil Indians who declare their identity by scarlet designs embroidered on their clothes. They grow coffee and corn using hoes much like those their Mayan ancestors used more than a millennium ago. **********San Pedro was one of many highland villages rocked by the Zapatista rebellion. A pro-Zapatista faction rejected the decades-old rule of village leaders allied with the Government's Institutional Revolutionary Party, or PRI, setting up a parallel government with its own mayor and justice of the peace -- even a two-man police force. **********When the wife of a Presbyterian pastor, Nicolas Gomez Perez, caught two village policemen from the pro-Government faction spying on her while she washed herself in a coffee grove in March, he appealed to the opposition authorities ''to make justice'' for him, opposition leaders recounted in interviews at a muddy campsite across a valley from San Pedro where they sought refuge after the incident. **********The pastor's complaint prompted a melee between rival camps armed with rocks and wooden clubs. But villagers on both sides said they were about to sign a peace pact when state police and army troops stormed in on March 14. Four opposition villagers were killed by the troops. **********The opposition group attacked the police with clubs in a failed attempt to block the arrest of 27 villagers from their side. The remaining opposition members gathered their families and fled through the forests to a friendly hamlet. $(On May 17, the Zapatistas mobilized several thousand Indian sympathizers to escort the displaced back to their homes.$) **********In San Pedro, state police officers who set up a sandbag bivouac in the town square whiled away their time playing basketball with the children. Residents waited before a shaky wooden table outside the PRI mayor's office to sign up with a representative of a state farm program to receive free fertilizer. None of the opposition residents would get fertilizer because they were all camped on the knoll across the valley. **********''The Government wants the Indians to fight among themselves so it can bring troops into our communities and break up our organizations,''  said Santos Perez Perez, a pro-Zapatista leader from San Pedro. **********At least 20 people have been killed  this year in other violence in Indian communities outside the Zapatista-controlled zone, and thousands of peasants were displaced from their homes. There are signs that both pro-  and anti-Zapatista civilian groups are arming themselves with guns. **********On one hand, PRI followers have formed two armed anti-Zapatista vigilante groups. One, called Justice and Peace, has been implicated in 11 killings. Last August its mobs attacked a convoy carrying observers from Human Rights Watch, an American monitoring group, and in February they shot and wounded a Mexican human rights observer. **********But many shooting victims have been PRI followers and state police officers. On March 7 two policemen were killed by Indians who had illegally invaded land. **********However, in April, a Human Rights Watch report concluded that state authorities contributed to the frictions by swiftly prosecuting crimes in which PRI followers were victims but failing to pursue crimes against Government opponents. **********The authorities are clamping down on the many foreigners the Zapatista movement has attracted to Chiapas.  This month the Government ordered the expulsion of 12 who joined a march by displaced Indians demanding to be returned to their homes. **********Acknowledging the need for detente, Gov. Julio Cesar Ruiz Ferro of Chiapas set up a commission to mediate Indian disputes. But many Indian leaders distrust the Governor, who is from the PRI. They refused to work with the commission until more than 80 prisoners they regard as political detainees are freed.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/07/world.snippet: Turkish Government may free 36-year-old Leyla Zana, country's most prominent political prisoner, before visit of Prime Min Mesut Yilmaz to US; Zana, former member of Parliament convicted of supporting Kurdish terrorism and sentenced to 15-year jai...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/07/world.main_headline: Turkey May Free Activist Before Prime Minister Visits U.S.
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/07/world.print_headline: Turkey May Free Activist Before Prime Minister Visits U.S.
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/07/world.body_text: **********Less than two weeks before Prime Minister Mesut Yilmaz's planned visit to Washington, the Turkish Government seems to be moving toward freeing the country's most prominent prisoner, but she says she will not accept a pardon. **********The prisoner, Leyla Zana, 36, was a member of Parliament in 1994 when she was convicted of supporting Kurdish terrorism and sentenced to a 15-year jail term. Since then her case has often been cited by critics of Turkey's human-rights record. **********According to reports published in several Turkish newspapers, Prime Minister Yilmaz would like to see Ms. Zana freed before he arrives in the United States on Dec. 17 to meet with President Clinton. **********But this week, Ms. Zana wrote letters to Mr. Yilmaz and Mr. Clinton saying she is determined to stay in jail until laws that ban separatist speech are repealed. ''Being in prison is an inevitable, unavoidable and necessary price to be paid for peace, brotherhood and a democratic Turkey,'' she wrote to President Clinton. **********In her letter to Mr. Yilmaz, Ms. Zana reminded him that he had voted for the bill lifting her parliamentary immunity in 1994 so she could be prosecuted. She urged him ''to solve the Kurdish problem with dialogue and create a democratic Turkey that is at peace with its own people.'' **********The Government is reportedly seeking to arrange Ms. Zana's release by temporarily suspending her sentence for health reasons. The same formula was recently used to free a blind lawyer, Esber Yagmurdereli, whose cause was supported by several European governments. Like Ms. Zana, Mr. Yagmurdereli had said he did not want to be freed until the laws under which he was imprisoned were repealed. **********The warden of the Ankara prison in which Ms. Zana is being held has said her health problems are not serious enough to require her release. But Minister of Justice Oltan Sungurlu has said he will submit her case to a board that considers medical discharges from prison. **********''Postponing a sentence for health reasons does not depend on an application from the person concerned,'' Mr. Sungurlu said. **********In her letters to Prime Minister Yilmaz and President Clinton, Ms. Zana said she suffered from ''no illness that would justify or necessitate a release from prison.'' She has reportedly been treated for digestive problems and a bone ailment. **********Ms. Zana is widely known in Europe as a symbol of Kurdish nationalists who are working for an autonomous or independent state in southeastern Turkey. Dozens of private groups and many officials have supported her cause, and they have been so effective that in several countries she is one of the best-known living citizens of Turkey. Partly through their efforts, she has won a series of prizes and has been nominated for the Nobel Peace Prize. **********But many Turkish officials say that support for Ms. Zana is based on misguided idealism and ignorance of what they call her militant commitment to separatism and clandestine support for terror. They say her political party, which is now banned, was a front for separatist guerrillas. **********This week in Washington, Foreign Minister Ismail Cem asserted that critics of Turkey were using a double standard in criticizing human-rights policies here. ''Spain just sentenced 26 politicians for their links to E.T.A.,'' Mr. Cem said, referring to the Basque guerrilla group. ''Does this mean that Spain will now be thrown out of the European Union?''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/08/busin.snippet: Stock of Voxware Inc gains 22 percent after Microsoft Corp licenses its voice and audio compression technologies; terms undisclosed; stock gains 87.5 cents, to close at $4.875 (S)

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/08/busin.body_text: **********The stock of Voxware Inc. of Princeton, N.J., gained 22 percent yesterday after the Microsoft Corporation, the software giant, licensed its voice and audio compression technologies. Terms were not disclosed. Microsoft plans to embed Voxware's technologies in Microsoft Netshow 2.0, a system for broadcasting live audio, video and multimedia on the Internet and corporate computer networks. Voxware's products allow the transmission of high-quality speech and sound over computer networks. Its stock gained 87.5 cents to close at $4.875.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/03/world.main_headline: Photo of Youth Held In Japan Beheading Sets Off Ethics Furor
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/03/world.print_headline: Photo of Youth Held In Japan Beheading Sets Off Ethics Furor
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/03/world.body_text: **********The arrest of a 14-year-old boy on charges of strangling and beheading a neighbor has already set off a round of soul-searching in Japan, and today the case provoked a furor over journalistic ethics after a weekly magazine published the boy's photo. **********The boy is accused of the most gruesome murder in memory in Japan, one that has shaken the nation. But Japan is also enormously protective of the rights of children to privacy, even when they are accused of horrific crimes, and so the magazine's action set off a firestorm and a new episode of national soul-searching. **********Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto denounced the magazine, Focus, and the Government said it had begun an investigation into the affair. **********''The police and almost all of the press have been very careful to protect the privacy of the boy and his family,'' Mr. Hashimoto said. ''What kind of advantage is the publisher looking for by carrying this photo?'' **********Focus did not publish the name of the boy, a ninth grader, and although his name is well known in journalistic circles it has not been reported by any Japanese publication. The boy was arrested on Saturday and, the police said, promptly confessed to strangling his 11-year-old neighbor, Jun Hase, and then cutting off Jun's head with a saw and placing it on the gate to a nearby school. **********The boy is also said to have confessed to attacking two school girls earlier this year, killing one and seriously wounding the other. **********The obsession with privacy is a bit of a paradox because Japan traditionally had little concern for either privacy or personal space. Indeed, the Japanese language sometimes expresses the concept with an import from English: ''puraibashi.''
