https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/13/busin.snippet: It has quickly become a cliché to suggest that angry French voters did more than dump their center-right government in this month's election: They also recorded a protest vote against globalization. The French left's victory, it is said, was a hea...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/13/busin.body_text: **********It has quickly become a cliché to suggest that angry French voters did more than dump their center-right government in this month's election: They also recorded a protest vote against globalization. The French left's victory, it is said, was a heartfelt cry for an alternative to the remorseless spread of economic liberalization and its damaging social consequences for advanced industrial countries. **********As an explanation of voting behavior, the theory is clearly defective. President Jacques Chirac and the outgoing government were deeply unpopular for many reasons — including arrogance, incompetence, appalling political judgment and broken promises — that had nothing to do with the global economy. **********Many voters in the world's fourth-largest trading power, including the skilled, the well-educated and the growing numbers involved in international commerce, stand to gain from globalization. As in other industrial countries, it is the unskilled and the less educated who are more likely to suffer and most inclined to attribute their ills to the global economy. **********But that does not mean that globalization itself is their enemy. France's horrifying unemployment — a main reason for the center-right's demise — is not the fault of globalization but of France's failure to adapt to it. **********The difficulty is that while many economists know this, it is not necessarily obvious to everyone else. On the contrary, to many people in industrial countries, it seems to stand to reason that if vast numbers of low-wage workers in developing countries enter the labor force in a world without economic barriers, jobs and incomes in the richer countries must be under threat. **********Numerous economic studies now show that this is a false picture of how the world works. Counterintuitive though it may be, much recent research suggests that low-wage imports are not generally the main threat to jobs in Europe, nor are they the principal cause of growing wage inequality in the United States. **********Cheap imports of labor-intensive products are not depressing prices of competing goods made in industrial nations — and they represent only a small proportion of the rich countries' overall economic output. **********Few economists would deny that cheap imports can cause shocks in some industrial sectors. But experience overwhelmingly shows that countries and companies benefit from increased competition. **********Despite a decline in manufacturing employment, most industrial countries are still net exporters of manufactured goods to developing countries. Relatively fewer people are employed in manufacturing because productivity has risen so much that fewer workers are needed. **********The consequent shift of jobs in industrial countries from manufacturing to services is as natural and as desirable as the move from agriculture to industry over the past century. Companies investing abroad are not, in most cases, stripping their home economies of jobs. **********The main threat to jobs and wages in the industrial countries is technological progress, as computers do more jobs that people once did. One day, relatively unskilled workers will be able to operate the new technology, but not for some years yet. **********The problem with these points, of course, is that they are economic, not political. They are coldly rational, when hostility to globalization is often emotional, moral or psychological. They are not good enough answers to many people's concerns. **********It is no good telling a fired Renault worker in Belgium that deindustrialization is on the whole a good thing. The political reaction to globalization is dictated by what people think and feel, not by what economists say — even if the economists are right. **********The challenges of globalization need political as well as economic responses. That means better leadership, especially in Europe. If people are really voting against globalization, the politicians must be doing something wrong.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/17/busin.snippet: Acclaim Entertainment Inc's new video game, Quarterback Club '98, has as its narrator Marv Albert, ex-sportscaster who pleaded guilty in September to assault charge in connection with sexual encounter; Acclaim is banking on Albert's reputation as ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/17/busin.main_headline: Can Marv Albert's Voice Lift Acclaim's Fortunes?
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/17/busin.print_headline: Can Marv Albert's Voice Lift Acclaim's Fortunes?
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/17/busin.body_text: **********Jae Min, a high school sophomore in Sunnyvale, Calif., and an avid video game enthusiast, knew exactly what new title he wanted at the local Electronics Boutique recently: Acclaim Entertainment Inc.'s NFL Quarterback Club '98 for his Nintendo 64 console. Why not the perennial leader in football video games, the Electronic Arts game bearing the likeness of John Madden, the popular sportscaster and former coach? Two words: Marv Albert. **********Mr. Albert, the former television sports announcer, does the play-by-play for the Acclaim game. Jae Min said he was unconcerned by Mr. Albert's guilty plea in September to an assault charge in connection with a sexual encounter. **********''Whatever may have happened with the trial, he's still a great sportscaster,'' he said. **********That attitude is exactly what Acclaim is banking on in the next few weeks of holiday shopping. **********The game is important to Acclaim because of financial troubles stemming from its failure to react quickly enough to the new generation of game consoles. But with new games like Turok: Dinosaur Hunter and Quarterback Club, Acclaim's fortunes are expected to improve. ''Acclaim should be profitable this quarter, but the question is, can the growth be sustainable?'' said Michael P. Wallace, an analyst at UBS Securities in New York. **********Lawrence Marcus, an analyst at BT Alex. Brown Inc. in San Francisco, said Quarterback Club ''is outselling the Madden title, and that has surprised a lot of people. So many people had written Acclaim off.'' **********Mr. Marcus estimates that at least 600,000 Quarterback Club games will be sold this year, which, at close to $60 retail and $45 wholesale a game, could mean more than $25 million for Acclaim. Over all, according to research by IDC/Link, the Nintendo 64 platform represents an estimated $2 billion in revenue for 1997, out of a total console market of $5.5 billion. **********''The hype around Mr. Albert certainly does not hurt,'' said Mr. Marcus, but he said that what drives the market is ''graphics, quality of play and licensing from important brands.'' There is no doubt that Acclaim has a key license for Nintendo 64: the National Football League signed an exclusive one-year deal with the company, allowing its game to use official team logos and colors. **********Nancy Smith, executive vice president of North American sales and distribution for Electronic Arts, said it is too early to declare either the Madden game or Quarterback Club a winner, but acknowledged that the company expects to ''minimally split the segment with our competition.'' Still, according to Mr. Marcus, the Nintendo 64 football games represent less than 5 percent of sales and 3 percent of profits for Electronic Arts, compared with one-third of both for Acclaim for this quarter. **********''In the coming year, Quarterback Club will remain an important part of our portfolio, but we hope it will be just one of several new hits,'' said Greg Fischbach, Acclaim's co-chairman and chief executive. **********There has been little concern expressed by consumers about Mr. Albert's association with the Acclaim game. A buyer of video games for a major retailer, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said that his company had not received ''even one customer complaint.'' **********Others do object. ''It sends the wrong signal to women in abusive relationships and to children,'' said Beverly Harris Elliott, executive director of the National Coalition Against Sexual Assault in Enola, Pa. **********Acclaim said that Mr. Albert, who resigned from the Madison Square Garden network and was dismissed by NBC after the guilty plea, was signed three years ago to a multi-product deal. The first game to come out was NBA Jam Extreme in 1996; Quarterback Club was the second. ''We could have dropped him in May when the indictment first came out, but we believed him,'' said Bob Picunko, marketing director for Acclaim Sports, a division of Acclaim Entertainment. **********The charges against Mr. Albert became public May 20; Acclaim had announced his participation in February and had already recorded his voice. The game was in production before the trial began; changing the voice would have cost millions of dollars because of production delays. **********While the decision to stand pat seems to be paying off, Acclaim is learning that getting people to buy the game and getting them to like it are different matters. Jae Min, the high schooler who was drawn by Mr. Albert's voice, said after playing the game, ''The announcing is of low quality and quite repetitive.'' He traded it in for Madden 64.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/03/world.snippet: Congo Republic misses UN deadline for assurances that work of investigative mission probing allegations of atrocities in eastern part of country will not be obstructed (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/03/world.main_headline: Congo Misses Deadline In U.N. Investigation
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/03/world.print_headline: Congo Misses Deadline In U.N. Investigation
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/03/world.body_text: **********The Foreign Minister of Congo has told Secretary General Kofi Annan in a telephone conversation that obstructions raised last week to the investigation of alleged killings in the eastern part of the country have been lifted, the United Nations spokesman said today. **********But the spokesman, Fred Eckhard, said that Secretary General Annan had demanded a promise in writing that the work of the investigative mission would not be blocked. Mr. Eckhard said that Mr. Annan had given the Government of President Laurent Kabila until noon today to send an assurance, but that the deadline had passed without one. **********A three-member investigating team led by a former Togo Supreme Court justice -- the second team to be selected for the mission after Mr. Kabila rejected the first -- has been held up in Kinshasa confronting new conditions imposed by other Congo ministers, who are more hard-line than the foreign minister, Bizima Karaha. **********They demanded a new mission leader and wanted the United Nations inspectors to do their work in tandem with a group from the Organization of African Unity. Visas for security guards for the United Nations team were also being denied. **********Mr. Kabila, who overthrew Mobutu Sese Seko in May and changed the name of the country from Zaire to Congo, has persuaded the United Nations to extend the mission's mandate back to 1993, which would also cover earlier Hutu atrocities against Tutsi. **********The United Nations team wants to investigate allegations that troops loyal to Mr. Kabila, then a rebel leader, were involved in the massacres of Hutu refugees from Rwanda over the last year. **********United Nations officials are concerned that valuable evidence is being removed or tampered with while investigators wait for government cooperation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/09/busin.main_headline: A Report on Jobless Claims Aids a Rally in Bond Prices
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/09/busin.print_headline: A Report on Jobless Claims Aids a Rally in Bond Prices
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/09/busin.body_text: **********Treasury prices recovered yesterday from Wednesday's selloff, helped by a report that showed initial claims for unemployment benefits remain at a five-month high. **********The data suggested that the economy might be slowing enough to keep inflation at bay and the Federal Reserve from raising interest rates. **********As a result, short-sellers, who had bet that Treasury prices would continue to fall, surged back into the market to limit their losses. Short- sellers sell borrowed securities, hoping to buy them back later at lower prices, pocketing the difference. **********But if prices begin to rise instead of fall -- as they did yesterday -- these participants have to cover their short positions and buy back the securities to limit losses. **********The price of the 30-year Treasury bond ended yesterday up 11/32  at 96 6/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 6.93 percent, from 6.96 on Wednesday. Bond prices fell sharply on Wednesday, hurt by disappointing auctions of new Treasury notes, and the yield rose 8 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point. **********''You're facing a market that has done a good job whipsawing some traders, but hasn't really generated a lot of casualties,'' said Dave Burtnick, senior fixed-income analyst with Technical Data in Boston. ''There's a growing belief that the anomaly of the week was Wednesday's negative price action, which was merely an auction trade. There has been some solid buying through the session. **********''There isn't a substantial bias to the upside from these levels,'' Mr. Burtnick continued, ''but you've clearly left the bears in a tough position going forward.'' **********In yesterday's weekly unemployment claims report, the number of workers applying for state jobless benefits for the first time held steady last week at a seasonally adjusted 347,000. Analysts had expected a decline of 13,000, to 334,000. **********Traders said bond prices were also supported by the Federal Reserve, which came into the market as a buyer. The central bank bought $733.8 million of Treasury securities for its own account in what is called a coupon pass, a move that permanently adds cash reserves to the banking system. The Fed said it bought securities with maturities ranging from 2002 to 2007. **********But the dollar continued to weaken yesterday, and that in turn limited bonds' gains. A strong dollar makes dollar-denominated investments like Treasury securities more attractive to foreign investors. **********In the corporate market, the Ford Motor Company sold $500 million of 100-year bonds through underwriters led by Bear, Stearns & Company. The bonds were priced at 98.591 to yield 7.81 percent, or about 85 basis points more than a 30-year Treasury bond. **********Rated A-1 by Moody's Investors Service and A+ by Standard & Poor's Corporation and Duff & Phelps, the bonds are noncallable by the issuer. **********The Norfolk Southern Corporation is expected to sell about $3 billion of bonds in four maturities next week. **********Analysts said that the company would sell the debt in maturities of 5, 10, 30 and 40 years. The 40-year maturity will have an option that allows the buyer to sell it back to the issuer in seven years. **********The proceeds of the debt sale will be used to pay for Norfolk's purchase of 58 percent of Conrail Inc. Last week, the CSX Corporation sold $2.5 billion of bonds to buy 42 percent of Conrail. **********Two days ago, Moody's lowered its credit rating on Norfolk one notch to Baa1, its second cut in three months. S.& P. rates Norfolk AA- with a negative outlook. **********Merrill Lynch & Company and J. P. Morgan will lead underwriters on the sale.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/13/busin.snippet: Treasury prices declines on credit markets following poor results of Treasury auction of 10-year notes; chart; graphs (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/13/busin.body_text: **********Treasury prices ended lower yesterday, following poor results at a Treasury auction of new 10-year notes. **********The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 3/32, to 97 11/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, edged up to  6.71 percent from 6.70 percent, where it had stayed the previous three session. **********The $12 billion sale of 10-year notes yesterday afternoon was met with weak demand. The bid-to-cover ratio, or the amount of bids compared with the amount of securities available, was just 1.90 to 1, down from 2.41 to 1 at the last auction of 10-year notes and the smallest since May 1995, when it was 1.67 to 1. Noncompetitive demand was considered decent and amounted to about $424 million. The average yield at auction was 6.374 percent, a little higher than expected, as some selling in the cash market pushed yields a bit higher. **********Investors seized on the auction's poor results as an excuse to sell Treasury securities before today's retail sales report for January and the final auction in the Treasury's quarterly refunding. Today, the Treasury sells $10 billion of 30-year bonds. In when-issued trading ahead of today's sale the 30-year bond was priced to yield 6.64 percent. **********Traders note that the 37 primary securities dealers who are required to bid at the auctions often try to punch yields higher before the sale to make Treasury securities more attractive to investors and insure demand for the issue. But with a number of important economic reports coming out this week, few investors were willing to buy actively. **********Today the Government will report on retail sales in January, and tomorrow on producer prices and industrial production. Recent signs of economic growth have not driven prices higher. The market received more indications of economic strength early in the session yesterday, when the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta released its survey of business conditions within its region. The index had a strong reading of 11.1 for January, compared to a negative 18.7 reading for December. **********Gerald A. Guild, senior vice president of the taxable-fixed-income department at Advest Inc. said the trading so far this week was typical of a three-part quarterly refunding. ''The 3-year is successful, the 10-year maturity is disappointing and the balance of whether it will be a successful refunding or not hangs on the 30-year issue,'' he said. ''The short-term benchmark of success is whether or not the three issues sell above their average auction prices on settlement day, which is Feb. 18.'' **********The generally mediocre results of the Treasury refunding so far -- an auction on Tuesday of three-year notes came largely within expectations -- have left investors concerned that demand from foreign investors may be diminishing. Such fears have weighed on bond prices. https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/25/busin.snippet: Richard L Lesher says he will resign as president of United States Chamber of Commerce after 21 years in that post; Lesher, considered dean of business lobbying, created multimillion-dollar communications system whose television facilities produce...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/25/busin.main_headline: President of U.S. Chamber Will Resign After 21 Years
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/25/busin.print_headline: President of U.S. Chamber Will Resign After 21 Years
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/25/busin.body_text: **********Richard L. Lesher, the dean of business lobbying, who raised the profile of the United States Chamber of Commerce during his 21 years as its president, announced today that he was resigning. **********Mr. Lesher, who is 63, said he had been thinking of leaving his $520,000-a-year post for some time. He dismissed suggestions that the decision might reflect dissatisfaction among members or disagreements over policy following years of lagging growth in the organization, even as it has become increasingly visible as a sponsor of business television. **********''If you're going to do something else, maybe the time to do it is now,'' Mr. Lesher said, indicating that he hoped to write, do volunteer work and take on additional corporate directorships. **********Acquaintances of Mr. Lesher said they were inclined to take his statement at face value. **********''He's ready to turn it over to someone else,'' Thomas J. Donohue, head of the American Trucking Associations and a former chamber vice president, said. ''He just wants to smell the roses.'' **********Throughout a tenure dating to the Ford Administration, Mr. Lesher built a reputation for standing his staunchly conservative ground. One of his biggest confrontations came in 1982 when President Ronald Reagan wanted to raise taxes and the chamber's chairman, Paul Thayer of the LTV Corporation, supported him, along with a majority of the board. **********But Mr. Lesher opposed the idea and was ultimately successful in both withholding chamber endorsement of the tax increase and in healing the rift that had widely been thought to threaten his job. **********More recently, Mr. Lesher was at first somewhat receptive to President Clinton's plan for health care overhaul, but, under pressure from smaller chamber members, he decided in the end to oppose the plan. **********''I think we had a major role in defeating it,'' Mr. Lesher said. **********Much of Mr. Lesher's legacy involves the creation of a multimillion-dollar communications system based in the group's neo-classical limestone headquarters overlooking the White House. Its television facilities produce syndicated business programming along with training seminars and town hall meetings. **********Perhaps best known is ''It's Your Business,'' a weekly public affairs program featuring Mr. Lesher as a permanent panelist. Another is ''First Business,'' a news program for small business. **********Other initiatives include the National Chamber Litigation Center, a legal arm that represents business interests in the Federal courts, and an extensive system to track, rank and endorse members of Congress based on their voting record on business issues. **********Mr. Lesher credits Lewis Powell, a retired Justice of the Supreme Court, with helping to shape the direction the chamber has taken. Before joining the Court, Mr. Powell told a member of the chamber board that the group should become more outspoken and ended up writing a memorandum on how to do this that the group still refers to as ''the Powell memo.'' **********Most members of the chamber's board were told of Mr. Lesher's departure only at today's meeting, but a search committee has already been formed. Mr. Lesher will remain with the chamber for at least a portion of the search process. **********Though the chamber bills itself as the world's largest business federation, its growth has lagged. The $70 million annual budget, for example, is no larger than 15 years ago.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/10/busin.snippet: Edward Rothstein Technology column on Mathematica, powerful mathematical program devised by Stephen Wolfram that encourages the user to pursue the most elaborate forms of experimentation; drawing (M)

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/10/busin.print_headline: TECHNOLOGY: CONNECTIONS; Mathematica is a software program that puts joy back in the numbers game.
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/10/busin.body_text: **********REMEMBER slide rules? **********The finest ones were so exquisitely made and so fluent in their maneuverings that they seemed unearthly objects. They were also weird. The integers etched into the ruler-shaped sticks were almost fluidly spaced: distances varied eerily, stretching in one place, contracting in another. Despite its rigidity and meticulous demarcations, the slide rule created a sense of rubbery numerical space, revealing the magic latent in calculation. **********That was lost in the button-dominated universe of the calculator. But in recent years, the sensuous feel of mathematical manipulation has again become evident in an extraordinary piece of computer software: Mathematica. Since its development in 1988 by the mathematician and physicist Stephen Wolfram, it has become the kind of application that software entrepreneurs dream of. Lotus 1-2-3, with its pioneering spreadsheets, once made the business world pant for the PC; now, Mathematica has done something similar for every field that involves sophisticated manipulations of symbols and formulas. **********In its latest incarnation -- Version 3.0, introduced last year for $1,295, with a student version available for $140 -- Mathematica is a programming language, a calculator, a composite of subtle mathematical algorithms, and a program that is more powerful than any application that has yet been devised for it. **********Its nearly million lines of code turn the exotic into the elementary: It can solve quadratic equations, plot three-dimensional graphs, solve differential equations, find the billionth prime number and generate sounds that correspond to mathematical expressions of wave forms. Even to a user who has just begun to toy with its most accessible surface powers, it is uncanny. This program is a cyber-slide rule of sorts, which invites play and inventiveness, creates a kind of tactile feel for mathematical operations and encourages the most elaborate forms of experimentation. **********And, for the million users they say they have, that is what has happened. Wolfram Research has itself created add-on software used for trading analysis, financial modeling, mechanical engineering, fuzzy logic and calculus education. Wolfram's site on the World Wide Web includes a  chronicle of unexpected applications by others as well (www.wolfram.com/discovery). **********Mathematica has been used to study reproductive rates of sea lions in western Alaska and to develop a new model for derivatives trading by a securities company. Mathematica has been used to create animations of complex origami creations and to design the 75-ton steel velodrome that was used by cyclists at the 1996 Olympics in Atlanta. A newsgroup devoted to the program is archived at www.wolfram.com/cgi-bin/mathgroup. One Web site also uses Mathematica to provide a somewhat esoteric calculating service (www.integral.com): It will find the value of any definite integral -- a feat even more difficult than declining German irregular verbs, and something earlier calculus students would have happily traded in their slide rules for. **********Mathematica is also just the most sophisticated example of a different kind of mathematical work that is now developing in cyberspace: experimentation. One fascinating series of programs aimed at high school students -- the Geometer's Sketchpad from Key Curriculum Press -- even turns geometry into a laboratory science. The old compass and straightedge are replaced by on-screen tools; diagrams can be stretched and turned. (The $170 program for Windows or Macintosh -- $40 for students -- can be sampled at www.keypress.com.) **********One $25 add-on package devoted to the proofs of the Pythagorean theorem explores the ordinary right triangle with elegant constructions. The very nature of Euclidean geometry seems to change with such software. Instead of appearing to be a timeless series of diagrams bearing immutable properties, geometry evolves out of experimentation and observation. **********The computer makes this possible not simply because of its powers of calculation but because of its powers of simulation, its ability to give an idea visible shape. That is one reason Web math is flourishing. An E-zine of visual mathematics is being developed (www.maa.org/news/cvm.html). Mathematical Web sites range from the recreational (www.math.ucalgary.ca/laf/colorful.html) to the argumentative, including an essay about the growing intimacy between the Web and mathematics (http://forum.swarthmore.edu/articles/epadel) by Gene Klotz, a professor in the mathematics department of Swarthmore College. At http://forum.swarthmore.edu, a site supported by the National Science Foundation, students can post questions for ''Dr. Math,'' mailing lists are made available and links of links are accumulated. **********All of this puts a different spin on the debates that are taking place now over mathematics curriculums. The calculator has, in recent years, become a standard classroom tool, supposedly to remove the onerous difficulties of division and multiplication in favor of more grand conceptions of number. **********But the risk (apparent enough to anyone who has been around elementary schoolchildren in recent years) is that the calculator becomes a crutch. Numerical concepts start to become mere abstractions ungrounded by manipulation of the things themselves. Such manipulation is tedious but the laborious work of mathematics -- the trial and error, the stubborn quest for more elegant solutions -- is crucial for the slow accretion of abstract understanding. **********Now, with advanced software like Mathematica, educational software like Geometer's Sketchpad, and many of the sites that pepper the Web, technology is redeeming itself after years of promoting the calculator. Calculation is becoming a subtle form of play. Experimentation is joining reason. It almost feels as if the slide rule has returned.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/07/busin.snippet: Letter from Paul Wesley Knopp comments on Nov 9 essays on child care and child care workers (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/07/busin.main_headline: Quality Child Care Comes at a Price
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/07/busin.print_headline: Quality Child Care Comes at a Price
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/07/busin.body_text: **********To the Editor: **********Re ''Spoonfuls of Sugar, but Barrels of Salt'' and ''Putting the Children First'' (Voices, Nov. 9): **********The writers observe that the level of quality and professionalism among child care workers leaves working professional mothers frustrated and worried. But establishing accreditation and licensing policies would only exacerbate the shortage and costs. **********Employment agencies, for example, and other institutions that screen workers would take a cut for their services, and licensed child care workers would and should demand professional salaries. **********Furthermore, some parents will never be satisfied with the quality of care, no matter at what price. After all, in this business the roles of employer and employee are colored by jealousy, guilt and resentment. **********As do quality automobiles, furniture and clothing, quality child care costs money -- a lot of money. **********Perhaps it's not the supply of qualified child care workers that is too small but the demand for excellent nannies among parents who cannot afford them that is too great. **********No self-respecting professional in the 1990's would work for $135 a week with no benefits. Would you? **********PAUL WESLEY KNOPP **********Lincoln, Neb., Nov. 9

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/24/busin.snippet: Jerry Masucci, owner of Fania Records and promoter of salsa music, dies at age 62 (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/24/busin.body_text: **********Jerry Masucci, the owner of Fania Records and a seminal figure in the founding of New York salsa and its spread to other countries, died on Sunday in Buenos Aires, his main residence. He was 62. **********The cause was an aneurysm that developed after surgery for abdominal pain, said a friend, the pianist and band leader Larry Harlow. **********Mr. Masucci began his career as a police officer in New York. In 1960,  he graduated from New York Law School, resigned from the police force and worked briefly for a public relations firm in Havana, where he developed an interest in Latin music. **********In 1964 he met Johnny Pacheco, a Dominican flute player, and the two men began an association that was to become Fania Records. **********For the next 15 years Fania Records defined the new salsa sound. With access to Cuban music virtually shut down, Puerto Rican musicians in New York were free to develop their own sound, and they did, defining it in nationalist terms that reflected the contexts of New York and Puerto Rico. **********With the help of Mr. Pacheco, who was his musical director, and Mr. Harlow, whom he signed in 1965, Mr. Masucci began collecting the most important names in Latin music, including Willie Colon, Hector Lavoe, Celia Cruz, Ray Baretto, Joe Bataan, Pete (El Conde) Rodriguez, Ismael Miranda, Johnny Colon and musicians who made critically acclaimed  albums but never had hits. Mr. Harlow made a series of experimental recordings and Mr. Pacheco had hits with his more traditional music. **********The Fania sound under Mr. Masucci's direction was initially hard dance music, and for 10 years its recordings were extraordinarily consistent, comparable to Motown at its peak in popular music or the Blue Note label for jazz. With the Fania All-Stars, a group that toured internationally, Mr. Masucci made salsa an international music. As tastes changed among Hispanic listeners, Fania fell into decline and Mr. Masucci shut down the label. He had moved by then to Argentina, though he had homes in Paris, Uruguay, Havana and Miami. **********Over the last several years he reactivated the label as Nueva Fania, and it was beginning to mine the new Cuban revolution in music, releasing albums by groups including Paulito y Su Elite and Dan Den. **********Mr. Masucci is survived by two daughters, Darlene and Corrine; a brother, Alex, and his father, Benny.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/29/busin.snippet: Walt Disney Co puts up for sale publishing businesses acquired in 1995 purchase of Capital Cities/ABC Inc; properties include seven newspapers, consumer publications and trade magazines; sale could fetch $2 billion to $3 billion; Disney reports ne...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/29/busin.main_headline: Disney to Sell Publications Inherited With Capital Cities
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/29/busin.print_headline: Disney to Sell Publications Inherited With Capital Cities
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/29/busin.body_text: **********The Walt Disney Company announced yesterday that it was putting up for sale the publishing businesses it acquired in its 1995 purchase of Capital Cities/ABC Inc. **********The list of properties that Disney is putting on the auction block range from seven newspapers, including The Kansas City (Mo.) Star and The Fort Worth Star-Telegram, to consumer publications like Women's Wear Daily and Los Angeles magazine, to the trade magazines Institutional Investor and Automotive Industries. **********All in all, analysts said, the sale could fetch $2 billion to $3 billion. **********Disney also announced a 33 percent increase in net income in its first fiscal year 1997 quarter, which ended on Dec. 31, to $749 million, from $565 million in the similar period a year earlier, and a 7 percent gain in revenue in the same period, to $6.28 billion from $5.89 billion. The earnings were bolstered by the sale of KCAL-TV, a Los Angeles television station, for $135 million. **********The fiscal year 1996 results were restated to reflect the ABC acquisition. **********Analysts attributed the gains in large part to the strong performance of the cable TV sports channel ESPN and of Disney's theme parks. And although broadcasting did well, the company said the broadcasting business also benefited from amortization costs related to the ABC purchase. **********''The network's performance was down but the TV stations did fairly well, I believe,'' said David Londoner, who follows Disney for Schroder Wertheim & Company. **********Disney also announced that it was teaming up with the Comcast Corporation to acquire control of E! Entertainment Television, a cable programming channel, for $320 million. Comcast, which already owns 10.4 percent of E! Entertainment, will increase its stake to 50.1 percent, and Disney will own the rest as the result of the purchase of Time Warner Inc.'s 58.4 percent stake. **********Unless Disney comes up with a clever tax strategy, much of the proceeds from the planned sale of its newspapers and magazines could go to the Government in capital gains taxes. **********Disney inherited Capital Cities/ ABC's cost basis for calculating those taxes, and it is relatively low because Capital Cities had owned many of the publications for years. Indeed, last year Michael Ovitz, then Disney's president, told at least one investment banker that the company did not plan to sell the publishing operations because the tax bite would be so large. **********Apparently Disney's chairman, Michael D. Eisner, assured some key managers of that commitment. **********The newspaper industry analyst John Morton said that during a meeting with analysts last year, Philip Meeks, president of the publishing group, told his audience that Mr. Eisner had reiterated the company's decision to stay in publishing. Mr. Meeks was out of the office yesterday and did not return phone calls. **********But Wall Street was hardly surprised by the sale. ''Everyone assumed that it was not their prime focus, and that they would consider divesting those assets,'' said Harold Vogel, who follows Disney for Cowen & Company. Although Mr. Eisner is known to be uncomfortable with debt, Disney's debt levels are reasonable. And analysts generally agreed that the lack of strategic fit was a key factor for the sale, adding that Disney is likely to pay off some of its debt in any case. **********Disney no longer breaks out publishing earnings separately, but Mr. Vogel said that the publishing division was likely to bring in about $200 million in operating profits in the 1997 fiscal year, which ends in September. He added that the unit's performance has clearly improved since 1986, when it reported its high for the decade of $160 million. Typically, publishing companies sell for 10 times or 12 times cash flow, which explains why investors expect the sale to generate at least $2 billion. **********Wall Street seemed pleased with both the earnings reports and news of the pending sale: Disney's stock advanced $1 yesterday, to $72.875. **********Mr. Morton, the newspaper analyst for Morton Research, said he believed that the sale of the papers alone would bring in about $1 billion. But he cautioned that a lot of potential buyers, including Gannett, the Tribune Company and A. H. Belo, are already digesting major acquisitions, although he viewed Newhouse and Hearst as potential acquirers. **********Analysts say they will be watching to see whether Disney can find a buyer for the whole package or whether it ends up having to sell the publications piecemeal. **********Disney said yesterday that its creative content business saw profits rise 10 percent, to $719 million: broadcasting profits jumped 38 percent, to $470 million, and theme parks turned in $238 million in profits, a gain of 21 percent.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/05/busin.snippet: Comment by Howard P Greenwald on how business can preserve the ideals of affirmative action in light of California Civil Rights Initiative, referendum known as Proposition 209; says California measure may signal beginning of the end of government ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/05/busin.main_headline: How Business Can Preserve The Ideals of Affirmative Action
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/05/busin.print_headline: How Business Can Preserve The Ideals of Affirmative Action
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/05/busin.body_text: **********A FEDERAL judge's injunction last month halted at least temporarily the tidal wave that swamped affirmative action in California on Election Day. But while the California Civil Rights Initiative, the referendum known as Proposition 209, seems headed for a long legal battle, it will probably inspire similar actions in other states. **********The California measure seeks to prohibit race-based preferences in hiring, promotion and contracting at all state agencies as well as in admissions to the state's gargantuan public higher education system. **********If the measure survives the courts, fair-minded Americans must develop alternative plans. After a quarter-century of affirmative action, members of most minority groups remain grossly underrepresented in desirable jobs and professions. **********Rather than burying the ideals embodied in affirmative action, ideas like Proposition 209 must initiate a new era for progressives, using the input and wherewithal of the private sector. **********But people concerned with justice and equality must first recognize why affirmative action has incurred the public's wrath. Higher education provides some lessons: *********** Race-based policies in admissions have collided with core American beliefs. In a country that values individual achievement, such policies seem too much like privilege. It is noteworthy that large numbers of voters from all minorities supported the California initiative. *********** Emphasis on race in the content of higher education has often followed closely behind race-based admissions, contradicting the traditional belief in knowledge of universal value. Critics of the traditional approach have argued that educational institutions at all levels should include instruction in the languages and cultures of America's many ethnic groups. These critics tend to dismiss Western literature and science as the work of ''dead white men.'' **********But ethnic Americans have traditionally looked to higher education less for affirmation of their origins than for the tools to compete, including universally recognized technical and professional skills. Of special importance for today's newcomers is command of English, the language of money and power. **********What are the alternatives? **********A highly successful collaboration between the University of Southern California, private foundations and the business community illustrates a promising concept. This collaboration has enabled U.S.C. to start an aggressive outreach program to recruit members of minorities and to prepare them to compete for favored places in the American mainstream. **********I direct a graduate-level fellowship program aimed at increasing the representation of minorities as executives in California's $200 billion health care industry. Without political fanfare, this program has steadily added highly qualified individuals to a woefully limited pool. **********It is important to understand that tuition at U.S.C., a private university, is high when compared with that of state schools. The cost often discourages even those willing to face difficult academic challenges. **********Rather than imposing quota-like admission targets, the U.S.C. program seeks out highly qualified members of minorities and helps them with finances. This differs from traditional affirmative action in two ways: it never denies admission to a nonminority applicant in order to admit a minority applicant, and it  makes no special allowances for minority applicants who fail to meet basic standards. No one can accuse the university of admitting a minority applicant solely because of affirmative action. **********Our program, moreover, concentrates on building ties among diverse people rather than highlighting their differences. Students of all backgrounds are encouraged to share their perspectives. But the program concentrates on insuring that graduates attain common professional skills and values. **********Private financing from California corporations and nationally prominent organizations, like the W. K. Kellogg Foundation, has proved crucial to our program's success. Commitments by private donors to aid minorities promise more flexibility and stability than public affirmative action programs ever have. **********THE California measure may signal the beginning of the end of government affirmative action mandates. But it can also help start a new culture of affirmative action in the private sector. **********This will require corporations, first, to make financial contributions to the professional and management education of members of minorities, either in-house or in collaboration with educational institutions. Second, it will require actively inviting minority employees onto executive career ladders. Progressive members of the business community have a historic mission: to lead in reaffirming America's commitment to opportunity and to help renew the idea that diversity in the mainstream means a better life for all.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/31/busin.snippet: Worldcom Inc announces third quarter earnings of $112.4 million, compared with loss of $53 million year earlier; revenue was up 31 percent, to $1.9 billion; results, which exceed Wall Street's expectations, fail to lift company's shares above pric...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/31/busin.main_headline: Worldcom Net Tops Estimates But Stock Price Fails to Climb
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/31/busin.print_headline: Worldcom Net Tops Estimates But Stock Price Fails to Climb
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/31/busin.body_text: **********Worldcom Inc., whose unsolicited bid for the MCI Communications Corporation depends in part on the value of Worldcom stock, announced quarterly results yesterday that exceeded Wall Street's expectations. **********But the robust results, built on especially muscular growth in the telecommunications carrier's international and Internet operations, failed to lift the company's shares above a price it had set to help determine the value of its MCI bid. **********Some analysts and industry executives have wondered whether the deal-making savvy displayed by Bernard J. Ebbers, Worldcom's chief executive, as he proposed and consummated dozens of mergers in recent years is matched by a similarly impressive ability to guide a company to growth on its own. **********Mr. Ebbers said yesterday's results demonstrated that Worldcom can generate strong growth internally, and he shrugged off the recent performance of the company's stock, which has lost as much as 20 percent of its value amid the gyrations in the broader market. **********But a result of the drop for MCI shareholders is continued uncertainty about what they would actually receive from Worldcom if they decided to accept Worldcom's all-stock offer for their company rather than a competing unsolicited $28 billion all-cash bid from the GTE Corporation. **********MCI, the No. 2 long-distance telephone company, has agreed to be acquired by British Telecommunications P.L.C. for about $19 billion in stock and cash; while the higher unsolicited bids appeared to put that offer in limbo, B.T. insists that it still wants a partnership with MCI. The four companies are engaged in negotiations to determine which will ultimately win MCI's favor. **********Worldcom said that it earned $112.4 million, or 12 cents a share, in the third quarter, beating by a penny the average estimate of analysts surveyed by First Call. In the corresponding period of 1996 the company lost $53 million, or 7 cents a share. **********''This is probably the best quarter we've ever had,'' Mr. Ebbers said. **********The growth in profits came as the company's revenue leapt by 31 percent, to $1.9 billion from $1.45 billion. **********''The earnings were quite good,'' said Guy W. Woodlief, an analyst for Prudential Securities. ''They beat our revenue estimates, our operating income estimates, our earnings per share estimates.'' **********The company said that traffic on its network from continuing operations increased by 38 percent. Revenue from Internet operations increased by 111 percent, to $147.1 million. Worldcom's international unit posted an 81 percent gain in sales, to $219.9 million from $121.6 million. **********The company's shares, however, fell $1, closing at $32.9375. **********Worldcom's bid for MCI offers MCI's holders $41.50 worth of Worldcom's stock for each MCI share as long as Worldcom's shares do not fall below $34. If that happens, Worldcom would offer a set ratio of 1.2206 of its shares for each MCI shares. **********Based on yesterday's closing share price Worldcom's offer for MCI is now worth about $29 billion, rather than the previous figure of roughly $30 billion. **********MCI's shares closed at $35.5625, down 18.75 cents, in Nasdaq trading. **********Analysts attributed some of the drop of Worldcom's shares to profit taking after the stock posted a gain of $2.1875 on Wednesday. But they also conveyed a concern that Worldcom might have to offer more for MCI to keep up with GTE. That could further dilute the value of existing Worldcom shares. **********''I think there's a fear that this whole episode with MCI could go into a bidding war,'' Mr. Woodlief said, ''and though I feel quite comfortable in my belief that Worldcom would not do anything to eliminate the shareholder-value creation, there is some fear, and an unknown fear, that higher bids may be forthcoming.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/20/busin.body_text: **********The International Business Machines Corporation has agreed to buy a majority interest in Netobjects Inc., a closely held provider of software for creating World Wide Web sites on the Internet. I.B.M. said that Netobjects, based in Redwood City, Calif., would continue to be run independently, with its chairman and chief executive, Samir Arora, at the helm. Netobjects sells Netobjects Fusion, software for creating web sites that can operate on computers running the Microsoft Corporation's Windows system as well as the Macintosh system made by Apple Computer Inc.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/04/world.snippet: Pres Clinton, hoping to quell anger of major US allies, will indefinitely waive portion of Helms-Burton law that punishes foreign companies for using American property confiscated in Cuba under Castro regime; says he does not want furor in Canada,...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/04/world.main_headline: ONE KEY ELEMENT IN ANTI-CUBA LAW POSTPONED AGAIN
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/04/world.print_headline: ONE KEY ELEMENT IN ANTI-CUBA LAW POSTPONED AGAIN
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/04/world.body_text: **********Hoping to quell the anger of some of America's strongest trading partners, President Clinton said today that he intended to waive indefinitely part of a law that punishes foreign companies that use American property confiscated in Cuba nearly 40 years ago. **********The President said he did not want the furor that the law has set off in Canada, Mexico and Europe to jeopardize what he described as an emerging international effort to isolate Fidel Castro and his Communist Government. **********''We must sustain our efforts to hasten the arrival of democracy in Cuba,'' Mr. Clinton said in a statement issued by the White House as he vacationed in the Virgin Islands. ''As a result of increasing international pressure, we have never been closer to that day.'' **********The decision today suspends for another six months the provision of the law that would allow United States citizens or corporations to sue any foreign company using confiscated American property in Cuba. Mr. Clinton first suspended that provision in July after America's trading partners threatened to retaliate. **********And Mr. Clinton indicated that he would continue to suspend the provision every six months ''so long as America's friends and allies continue their stepped-up efforts'' to advocate democratic changes in Cuba. **********Although none have joined Washington's 34-year economic embargo of Cuba, the President and his aides here pointed to several steps taken by those allies in recent months, including a vote by the European Union last month urging Mr. Castro's Government to improve its record on human rights and political freedom. **********With his decision, Mr. Clinton appeared to be trying to strike a balance between the conflicting demands of Republicans in Congress and of trading partners abroad. Judging by today's reactions, he did not succeed. **********Representative Dan Burton, the Indiana Republican who sponsored the law with Senator Jesse Helms of North Carolina, condemned the President's action, saying Mr. Clinton had decided ''once again to pass up a perfect opportunity to send a strong message to the Castro dictatorship and to those who prop it up financially.'' **********At the same time, officials in Canada, Mexico and Europe remain critical of the Helms-Burton law. The European Union's envoy to the United States, Hugo Paemen of Belgium, welcomed the decision to suspend the law's most onerous provision, but said that did not resolve the underlying problem with the law itself, which Europeans say attempts to impose American foreign policy on other nations. **********Canada's International Trade Minister, Arthur Eggleton, accused the United States of ''continuing to hold this sword over the heads of other countries.'' **********Mexico was cautiously upbeat. ''The Mexican Government recognizes that the decision of President Clinton marks an effort to take into account the opinion of the international community,'' the Foreign Ministry said in a statement reported by Reuters. **********But the ministry added, ''The Mexican Government reaffirms the need to resolve any international differences via open and respectful dialogue, not via unilateral and confrontational methods.'' **********For now, the President's decision appears to avert a trade showdown, including the possibility of tit-for-tat legal retaliation from abroad. Canada and Mexico have each passed legislation that would allow anyone punished by the American law to seek damages in their courts. **********Nor did the President's decision resolve legal challenges to the law still being pressed in the World Trade Organization and under the North American Free Trade Agreement between the United States, Canada and Mexico. **********The Helms-Burton Act was passed by Congress last March to discourage foreign investments in Cuba and to promote democratic changes. **********In addition to allowing the lawsuits, the law requires the State Department to deny visas to the executives of foreign companies that use offices, factories or other properties once owned by Americans but seized after the Communist revolution that swept Mr. Castro to power in 1959. **********Mr. Clinton originally opposed the law, but he signed it after the outrage that erupted when Cuban fighter jets shot down two small planes piloted by Cuban-Americans off Cuba's coast last February. He later suspended the provision allowing the lawsuits after America's allies warned of retaliation and officials within the Administration began to fear a trade war. **********In the middle of an election year, the President's maneuvering led to accusations that he was putting off a decision while trying to cultivate support of Cuban-American voters in Florida and New Jersey, states with important electoral votes. **********In August the President appointed Stuart E. Eizenstat, the Undersecretary for International Trade at the Commerce Department, as a special envoy to try to find common ground with the allies on other political and economic steps to isolate Cuba. **********At a news conference today, Mr. Eizenstat said the controversy over the Helms-Burton Act had focused the attention of European and other nations on democracy in Cuba. He noted that the European Union's resolution last month for the first time linked economic relations with Cuba to improvements in Mr. Castro's policies on human rights. **********While such efforts appear to have had little effect on Mr. Castro's grip on power, Mr. Eizenstat and other officials said they have had a punitive impact by isolating Cuba politically and by discouraging foreign investors. **********Senator Helms denounced Mr. Clinton's decision as ''a terrible mistake.'' In singling out Mexico and Canada for what he called ''shameful Cuba policies,'' Senator Helms said: ''I cannot understand why, just as we are beginning to make progress, the President has decided to give up the very leverage that brought such progress about.'' **********Mr. Clinton said the Administration would continue to enforce other provisions of the Helms-Burton Act, including the one denying visas to executives of foreign companies. **********The State Department has already imposed that punishment on a Mexican telecommunications company, Grupo Domos, and a Canadian mining concern, Sherritt International. Mr. Eizenstat said today that 12 other companies were under investigation for violating the law. On Monday, he said, the United States notified BM Group, an Israeli company involved in sugar and citrus production in Cuba, that its executives could face visa restrictions.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/27/news/.main_headline: On Borneo, Anger at Lack Of Haze Help
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/27/news/.print_headline: On Borneo, Anger at Lack Of Haze Help
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/27/news/.body_text: **********KUCHING, Malaysia—                     The island of Borneo, with its millions of acres of rain forest, has long been touted in promotional brochures and tourist guidebooks as the lungs of the earth. **********But with Borneo now choking in haze — and thousands of residents sick from the pollution — officials on the Malaysian side of the island are increasingly angry and frustrated. The world is only watching, they say, as Borneo burns. **********"The environmentalists talk so much when we cut down trees. Where are they now?" asked George Chan Hong Nam, deputy chief minister in the state of Sarawak, charging Friday that environmentalists did not seem concerned that forests were being destroyed. He spoke as officials struggled to understand the dimensions of the environmental and health crisis they face from fires burning out of control in neighboring Indonesia. **********The frustration level among some Malaysian officials rose earlier this week when, they say, a reconnaissance team of fire experts sent by boat from the state of Sabah to try to pinpoint the fires south of the border was turned back. **********"When there is an earthquake in Los Angeles or in Kobe, the whole world comes to the rescue and most of the people are already dead," said Hamid Bugo, an undersecretary in Sarawak's state government. "But after weeks of haze —and people will die — where are the United Nations? Are they so scared of Indonesia?" **********As if in answer to those complaints, a UN agency said Friday in Geneva that it was sending an emergency evaluation team to Indonesia as well as 150,000 face masks for children affected by the smog. The World Health Organization, in its first substantial comment on the fires, called for the international community to support Asian countries that are seeking to put out the blazes. **********In Sarawak, the state of emergency was partly lifted Friday, keeping schools shut but allowing many businesses to reopen. The economic burden of closing was taking too great a toll on workers, officials said. **********"If workers do not earn enough to buy food, what's the point of running away from the haze?" asked Mr. Hamid, the Sarawak undersecretary. **********Although the air pollution index was still four times normal levels, that was a dramatic improvement from earlier in the week, when haze levels were more than 15 times normal. Plantations, factories and timber-based industries were allowed to resume work by the guidelines issued Friday, provided the pollution index stays below the 500-mark, a level considered hazardous. **********Quarries and industries involving earthworks were ordered to remain shut. **********In Kuching, one of the cities hardest hit by the haze blowing across the border, doctors reported that the rush to emergency rooms had slowed. The state's medical board said that it had treated about 1,400 patients for haze-related ailments Thursday, down from nearly 3,000 Monday. **********The figures represent only patients treated at state-run hospitals; no estimates for private hospitals were available. **********Medical experts in Sarawak are divided on the health effects from the haze. One doctor at the Normah Specialist Medical Center in Kuching said, "It's a paradox that some people go around with a mask and then take a break to smoke a cigarette." He added that living in the haze was akin to being in a smoky bar. **********But Gabriel Teo, a doctor who treats patients with respiratory problems at the same hospital, said that missed the point. **********"We are talking about subjecting the entire population to a health risk," he said. "Not everyone is a smoker, but everyone has to breathe air. And you don't live in a pub for 24 hours a day." Especially vulnerable, he said, were children and the elderly. **********"What we are seeing are just the acute effects," Dr. Teo continued. "What we don't know are the long-term effects of breathing in smoke for two months, four months or more." **********He said that physical exertion would greatly aggravate the effects of the haze, increasing by as much as five times the amount of air a person inhales. **********James Wan, public relations manager at the Rihga Royal Hotel in Miri, a city near Sarawak's border with Brunei, earlier this week described breathing the haze like this: "It's like being in the highlands during the dry season when there's a lot of mist in the morning. The difference is that the haze never goes away. **********"With mist, it's very refreshing if you breathe in. But with the haze, it's heavy when you inhale. You feel your eyes watering. And you can smell smoke."

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/22/world.snippet: Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad of Malaysia faces off with George Soros, one of the world's most formidable currency traders, at annual meeting of World Bank and International Monetary Fund in Hong Kong, as Mahathir denounces 'a group of ultra-ric...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/22/world.main_headline: Premier of Malaysia Spars With Currency Dealer
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/22/world.print_headline: Premier of Malaysia Spars With Currency Dealer
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/22/world.body_text: **********It was high noon in Hong Kong this weekend. **********Like gunfighters on a dust-blown street, one of Asia's most outspoken leaders, Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad of Malaysia, faced off against one of the world's most formidable currency speculators, George Soros. In their holsters were weapons of oratory, currency and clout. **********At stake was nothing less than Malaysia's national prestige, the future of Southeast Asian economies and, by some accounts, the very shape of the global financial system. **********Even more, the standoff pitted two worlds against one another, an Asia of growing economic might and a West convinced that free-wheeling trade -- in ideas, capital and goods -- is the best recipe for development. **********The forum was the usually somber gathering of finance ministers, bankers and economists at the annual meeting of the World Bank and International Monetary Fund. On successive evenings, Mr. Mahathir and Mr. Soros squared off, denouncing each other in vitriolic language seldom heard in such settings. **********Yet Malaysia's economy is in crisis, its currency has collapsed and blame had to be fixed. **********Lashing out at currency traders like Mr. Soros as ''morons,'' Mr. Mahathir castigated them on Saturday as ''a group of ultra-rich people.'' **********''For them wealth must come from impoverishing others,'' Mr. Mahathir said, ''from taking what others have in order to enrich themselves. Their weapon is their wealth against the poverty of others.'' **********While not mentioning Mr. Soros by name -- although in previous comments to newspapers in Malaysia, Mr. Mahathir specifically blamed Mr. Soros for orchestrating Malaysia's economic crisis -- he told the assembled bankers and economists that Mr. Soros's ilk had to be stopped. **********''I am saying that currency trading is unnecessary, unproductive and totally immoral,'' Mr. Mahathir declared. ''It should be stopped. It should be made illegal. We don't need currency trading.'' **********Then tonight, before a standing-room-only crowd, Mr. Soros fired back at the Malaysian leader. **********''Dr. Mahathir's suggestion yesterday to ban currency trading is so inappropriate that it does not deserve serious consideration,'' Mr. Soros said. **********''Interfering with the convertibility of capital at a moment like this is a recipe for disaster. Dr. Mahathir is a menace to his own country.'' **********Since July, in the churning wake of the collapse of Thailand's currency and banking system, Malaysia has foundered. Its currency, the ringgit, has plunged 20 percent against the dollar. On the heels of the tumbling ringgit, the Malaysian stock market crashed and the country's banking system began to creak. Foreign investors fled. **********For Mr. Mahathir, who has seen his country's annual per-capita output soar from $350 to $5,000 in four decades, the assault on the ringgit smacked of a conspiracy wrought by international currency traders. **********For a man who has built the world's tallest buildings and Southeast Asia's largest airport and who harbors visions of a glittering new capital, a high-tech corridor intended to rival Silicon Valley and immense hydroelectric dams, the economic train wreck has been an affront, to him personally and to Asia. **********''We like to think big,'' Mr. Mahathir said. ''But we are not going to be allowed to do this, because you don't like us to have big ideas. It is not proper. It is impudent for us to try, or even to say we are going to do it. If we even say that when we have the money we will carry on with our big projects, you will make sure we won't have the money by forcing the devaluation of the currency. **********''If the countries of Europe and of North America can be almost uniformly prosperous, we don't see why we cannot be allowed to be a little prosperous.'' **********Then tonight, 24 hours after Mr. Mahathir's broadside against Mr. Soros, currency traders and the international financial system, Mr. Soros stood behind the same lectern and declared that the problem with Malaysia was not the world, but Mr. Mahathir himself. **********''He is using me as a scapegoat to cover up his own failure,'' Mr. Soros said. ''He is playing to a domestic audience, and he couldn't get away with it if he and his ideas were subject to the discipline of an independent media inside Malaysia.'' **********Later, at a news conference, Mr. Soros elaborated on his comments. ''I want to express my sympathy for poor Malaysians who were hurt'' by the collapse of the country's currency and stock market, ''but not for Dr. Mahathir, because he's responsible.'' **********The war of words reverberated through the cavernous conference halls, startling government officials and private bankers used to more measured language. **********An Indonesian Government economist, who spoke on condition of anonymity, was angered by Mr. Mahathir's pronouncements. **********''It's very unfortunate that we are neighbors,'' the economist said. ''I know we shouldn't interfere in other countries' policies. But all I can say is that it was very interesting. As an economist there are things that I disagree with. But because of our good neighbor policy, I can't really comment on his speech.'' **********A Malaysian banker, who also insisted that he not be quoted by name, suggested that the Prime Minister was out of touch with reality. **********''There are not two ways of doing these things,'' the banker said. ''We have to get our own house in order. He really hasn't thought these things out. He's just spouting off.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/31/world.main_headline: Helms Panel Moves Swiftly to Approve Envoys and Albright Aides
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/31/world.print_headline: Helms Panel Moves Swiftly to Approve Envoys and Albright Aides
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/31/world.body_text: **********Senator Jesse Helms may be blocking William F. Weld's nomination as Ambassador to Mexico, but his committee moved swiftly today to approve nominees for a raft of positions in the State Department and at embassies around the world. **********The Senate Foreign Relations Committee, which Mr. Helms heads, voted to recommend confirmation for 19 nominations, some of which President Clinton submitted only days ago. The nominations, including some for important diplomatic posts that have been vacant for months, now move to the full Senate for consideration. **********The nominees approved today included Felix G. Rohatyn, the investment banker from New York City, as Ambassador to France; John C. Kornblum, the Assistant Secretary of State for European and Canadian Affairs, as Ambassador to Germany; James F. Collins, a special envoy to the former Soviet republics, as Ambassador to Russia, and Philip Lader, former director of the Small Business Administration and founder of the ''Renaissance Weekend'' retreats, as Ambassador to Britain. **********The flurry of nominations followed a squabble between Mr. Helms and Senator Thomas A. Daschle, the Democratic minority leader, who accused Mr. Helms last week of stalling nominations. Mr. Helms responded by criticizing Mr. Daschle on the Senate floor, saying that any delay in appointments was the White House's fault. **********In a statement, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright noted that 57 of 67 people nominated for diplomatic posts this year had already been approved by the committee. **********''This action reflects the continued excellent working relationship that has developed between the executive branch and the Senate in the handling of diplomatic nominations,'' she said in a statement that made no reference to the controversy over Mr. Helms's blocking of former Governor Weld's nomination. **********Senator Trent Lott, the Republican majority leader, has said the Senate would try to vote on some of the nominees before the recess begins on Friday. **********The committee also recommended approval for a series of nominees to be senior aides to Ms. Albright. They included Bonnie R. Cohen, a former Assistant Secretary at the Department of the Interior, to be the Under Secretary of State for Management; David Andrews, a former deputy general counsel at the Department of Health and Human Services, to be the State Department's Legal Adviser; Marc Grossman, the former Ambassador to Turkey, to be the Assistant Secretary of State for European and Canadian Affairs, and Stanley O. Roth to be Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian and Pacific Affairs. **********The committee also recommended James P. Rubin, a senior adviser to Ms. Albright, as Assistant Secretary of State for Public Affairs. Mr. Rubin will become the department's official spokesman, replacing Nicholas Burns, who is under consideration to be Ambassador to Greece.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/24/your-.snippet: THESE DAYS, you have to be a contrarian to go fishing. This ancient industry is struggling under modern constraints brought on by overfishing, which extends from the North Sea to the coast of Newfoundland and throughout the Pacific. .Environmental...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/24/your-.main_headline: In the Age of Excess, the Age-Old Fishing Industry Is Rife With Modern Woes
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/24/your-.print_headline: In the Age of Excess, the Age-Old Fishing Industry Is Rife With Modern Woes
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/24/your-.body_text: **********THESE DAYS, you have to be a contrarian to go fishing. This ancient industry is struggling under modern constraints brought on by overfishing, which extends from the North Sea to the coast of Newfoundland and throughout the Pacific. **********Environmentalists have become increasingly successful at convincing governments to impose restrictions to preserve existing fish stocks. With catches shrinking, the governments have needed little prodding to levy quotas and limits on fishing. Last month, for example, European Union fisheries ministers agreed to a plan that will require EU countries to cut the size of fishing fleets and the time they spend at sea by 30 percent for the most endangered species and by 20 percent for other overfished stocks. **********"There are still too many boats chasing too few fish," said Steven Hughes, an industry consultant in Seattle. "It's open access here, so anyone can buy a boat and go fish. What we've done is to set a quota on what can be taken." **********Many fishing businesses are family-owned, he said, but far more have gone out of business, or merged with other companies to pool their quotas and gain economies of scale. **********Similar trends are evident elsewhere in the Pacific, where quotas also are imposed and many small companies are privately owned or have been bought by huge food conglomerates. **********"There is only one listed company of reasonable size here, and it's suffering internationally from the strong New Zealand dollar and lower fish prices," said Warren Doak, who follows the industry for Merrill Lynch & Co. in Auckland, New Zealand. **********A few fishing companies in Thailand are publicly held, but an international brokerage with offices in Bangkok said that it no longer followed them because they were small. **********"We have enough trouble finding liquidity in the larger companies right now," an analyst said, referring to the slide in Thailand's stock market. **********Still, for fans of contrarian plays, there are a few fishing-related companies that look appealing to analysts. **********Christine Farkas, who follows special situations for Midland Walwyn Capital, a Toronto brokerage, has a buy ratingout on FPI Ltd., a company in Newfoundland that is also known as Fishery Products International and is a case study in survival. **********In the late 1980s, FPI's fleet of more than 50 deep-sea trawlers brought in catches as big as 66,000 tons of cod a year. Today, since the Canadian government's 1992 moratorium on cod fishing on Newfoundland's Grand Banks, only 11 trawlers remain. Last year's catch was just 8,600 tons. The company has switched to the value-added processing of fish and shellfish, much of it purchased from as far away as Russia and China and ranging from shrimp and crab for luxury restaurants to fish for sandwiches at McDonald's. **********"What drives their profits now is the margin between what they pay for raw fish and what they can get for selling it as a 'value-added' product," Ms. Farkas said. **********That spelled trouble for FPI in 1995, when high inventories and declining value-added fish prices resulted in a loss for the year. The company's shares, which had traded as high as 9.00 Canadian dollars ($6.60) slumped to a low of 4.60 dollars last summer. **********Things began to look brighter, however, as inventories decreased and the company pursued its value-added business. It returned to profitability last year, beating expectations with earnings of 37 cents a share. Ms. Farkas is projecting 50 cents a share for this year. **********Although she is estimating sales of 671 million dollars for 1997, compared with 665 million last year, "the key is the improved margins," she said. FPI's stock, which is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange, has recovered to 6.20 dollars, and Ms. Farkas has an 8-dollar target price over the next 12 months. **********A newly listed company shows where many say the fishing industry is heading. Last week, Norway Seafoods ASA debuted on the Oslo Stock Exchange. Despite its name, it operates from Russia to Argentina and off the West Coast of the United States, where it owns the Seattle-based American Seafoods Co. The company has been on an acquisition spree, buying smaller fishing concerns as well as Frionor, a brand of fish products in Europe that it plans to promote in the United States, said Andreas Tieleman, an analyst with Enskilda Securities in Oslo. **********The company, which was founded in the 1980s, has giant trawlers that catch and then process fish. It also has built the world's largest trawler, although as one Oslo-based analyst commented, "big isn't always an advantage." **********Although the company, which is aiming for $1 billion in annual sales, will clearly have a group of analysts following its stock, none of them are likely to recommend the shares before it absorbs its acquisitions. **********If the idea of investing in a company that catches and processes fish is unappealing, consider Genki Sushi Co., a Japanese chain of 120 sushi bars and restaurants. Genki is one of Japan's most popular and well-run fast-food concerns, but its sales plunged last summer after an outbreak of food poisoning in Japan, even though the source of the illness was not pinpointed. Sales continued to fall throughout the fall and winter months, and Genki's stock followed suit, bottoming at 1,162 yen ($10.20) in February, down from a peak of 2,381 yen. **********Matters were not helped by a rise in tuna prices, one of the most popular items on Genki's menu, and the generally poor performance of Tokyo's over-the-counter exchange, where the company is listed, said Mark Buffet, who follows the stock for BZW Securities. But his buy recommendation in November — reiterated last week — proved prescient when customers began to return in February. Since then, sales have rebounded, up a healthy 10 percent for the month of April. **********"It's still a very well managed company, and if there are no more problems like last summer, its earnings for this year should be up 20 percent over last year," Mr. Buffet said. **********Genki will add 20 sushi bars this year, he said. The stock has recovered to 1,700 yen, but Mr. Buffet thinks it is still undervalued. He is projecting a price of 3,000 yen over the next eight months.
