https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/06/busin.main_headline: F.C.C. to Defer Decisions on Phone Deals
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/06/busin.print_headline: F.C.C. to Defer Decisions on Phone Deals
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/06/busin.body_text: **********The Federal Communications Commission chairman, Reed E. Hundt, has informed the office of John McCain, Republican of Arizona and chairman of the Senate Commerce Committee, that the present commission does not intend to decide two highly visible matters pending before it, preferring to wait until the Senate approves its new members and chairman. **********The first is a preliminary ruling that would allow Worldcom Inc.'s unsolicited $30 billion bid for the MCI Communications Corporation to proceed. The second is a challenge from the AT&T Corporation to the BellSouth Corporation's petition to offer long-distance telephone service in South Carolina. **********Under normal circumstances, the first rulings on these issues would be made within the next week or so. But, Mr. Hundt said, ''There are two major topics that ultimately cannot be resolved by the present commission and so should not be shaped materially at their inception by the present commission. **********He added in an interview Saturday, ''A lame duck commission is not the preferable group to take those actions when we are not going to be around to finish them off.'' **********But if the confirmation of William E. Kennard, the commission's current general counsel, is delayed, Mr. Hundt said he would re-evaluate his position. **********While it appeared on Wednesday, when Mr. Kennard had his confirmation hearing before the Commerce Committee, that he would easily sail into office, a few turbulent gusts have begun to blow from the office of Senator Jesse A. Helms, Republican of North Carolina. **********Senator Helms has made it clear that he will consider trying to block Mr. Kennard's nomination unless Mr. Kennard agrees to help a businessman named Zebulon Lee secure a radio license in Asheville, N.C., according to people close to the commission and on Capitol Hill who insisted on anonymity. **********Despite the fact that Senator Helms does not sit on the Commerce Committee, the Senate's rules would allow him to block Mr. Kennard's nomination if he was determined enough. Calls to Senator Helms's office were not returned, but the Senator has in the past supported Mr. Lee's case. **********Mr. Lee has battled with the commission for almost 10 years over radio permits. His company, Orion Communications, has sued the commission. **********Brian Lee, Zebulon's oldest son, said yesterday that he spoke with members of Mr. Helms's staff last month when he was in Washington for a court proceeding involving Orion's suit against the F.C.C. ''William Kennard as general counsel of the F.C.C. was involved in taking away our license,'' Mr. Lee said. ''Why?'' **********The budget bill recently passed by Congress directs the F.C.C. to auction radio licenses whose ownership is disputed. Mr. McCain and Mr. Hundt support that plan. The Lees do not. ''After we fought and won repeatedly under one set of rules, McCain decides to change the shape of the playing field and now he has called for having the radio station auctioned off to the highest bidder,'' Brian Lee said. **********People on Capitol Hill, who insisted on anonymity, said that Senator Conrad Burns, Republican of Montana and a member of the Commerce Committee, had passed on to Mr. Kennard questions from Mr. Helms inquiring about Mr. Kennard's role in the Lee dispute. **********''What Senator McCain is hoping is that when Mr. Kennard answers Senator Helms's questions and gives Senator Helms the information that he wants, Senator Helms will let the nomination move forward expeditiously,'' said Mark Buse, the Commerce Committee's policy director. **********The committee intends to consider Mr. Kennard's nomination this Wednesday and the full Senate could vote on it as early as Wednesday. **********Mr. Hundt's act of deference appears a bit unusual -- he has not been shy in the past. And while he said he hoped not to rule on BellSouth's application, he still ridiculed the company during a speech on Friday in Philadelphia. ''When a company shows up with 20 boxes of documents and photographers and press releases about how it ought to immediately be granted its results, you wonder whether it's a circus or a serious application,'' he said. **********In response, David J. Markey, BellSouth's vice president for governmental affairs, said in a statement, ''Anyone who says BellSouth is not serious about opening its markets is not in touch with reality and doesn't understand that competitors for business customers are coming into the market daily.''

Inso shares fell $9.6875, to $11.0625, in trading of 8.9 million shares on the Nasdaq market. The stock traded as high as $63 last October. Its earnings shortfall springs from lower royalty revenue from its reference line as it faces competition from the Internet, lower demand from on-line services and slack CD-ROM sales.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/05/busin.snippet: Myriad Genetics wins patent for discovering gene it says can cause melanoma skin cancer and for method of finding if person carries the gene; Peter Meldrum, president of Myriad, says his company will have detection test ready for public use in lat...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/05/busin.main_headline: A company says it has a method of determining which people are more likely to get skin cancer.
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/05/busin.print_headline: A company says it has a method of determining which people are more likely to get skin cancer.
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/05/busin.body_text: **********The end of this century may go down as the era in which science began mass-marketing genetic tests to determine whether people are predisposed to cancers, degenerative conditions and disease. **********Now the company that created a test to detect a gene that can cause breast cancer (and has patents pending for that gene, BRC-1, and a companion, BRCA-2) is working on a similar detection method for the skin cancer melanoma. **********Myriad Genetics has won a patent for the gene it says can cause melanoma and for a method of finding if a person carries the gene. ''What we have patented is the composition of matter on the mutation of the gene that predisposes individuals to melanoma,'' said Peter Meldrum, president of Myriad in Salt Lake City. **********Cancer is caused by the unchecked division of cells. Cell division is usually controlled by genes known as suppressors. When the body wants limited cell division, it switches off those genes. If a suppressor gene is damaged, it malfunctions; the body cannot turn it back on, cell division can run amok and tumors may result. Damage to the suppressor gene can be environmental or hereditary. **********Myriad's patent is for inherent mutations to a gene called the Multiple Tumor Suppressor 1 (MTS1). The mutated gene can be passed from parent to child. **********''The gene is a homozygous deletion, meaning it is deleted on both chromosomes,'' Mr. Meldrum said, adding that the gene is a factor in 46 percent of most major cancers. **********''But it is one of a series of genes in a cascade that leads to those cancers,'' he said. ''With melanoma, it initiates that cascade of events. If a person inherits one defective copy from one parent, it puts them at a much greater risk of melanoma.'' **********Mr. Meldrum said the threat of melanoma is about 1 percent. ''But if you have a damaged copy of the gene, you have a 25 percent risk of getting melanoma by age 50 and a 53 percent chance of getting melanoma by age 80,'' he said. **********About 40,000 Americans develop melanoma each year. Mr. Meldrum said his company will have an MTS1 detection test ready for public use in late 1998. Myriad already produces a test for the BRC-1 breast cancer gene, called BRACAnalysis. It is working on another test kit to isolate the gene that can cause salt-dependent hypertension. **********A University of Utah geneticist, Lisa Cannon-Albright, and two Myriad employees, Mark Skolnick, also a geneticist, and Alexander Kamb, a molecular biologist, are the inventors listed for patent 5,624,819. **********Patents are available by number for $3 from the Patent and Trademark Office, Washington, D.C. 20231.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/29/busin.snippet: Dream of common currency in Europe is giving way to inescapable practical imperatives and forcing political leaders to address contradictions they have ignored for years; in France, center-right Government of Pres Jacques Chirac is fighting for su...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/29/busin.body_text: **********France and Germany could hardly be more different, but it is no coincidence that both countries are going through their own convulsions in the same week. **********In France, the center-right Government of President Jacques Chirac is fighting for survival after voters issued a stunning rebuke in last Sunday's first round of national elections. **********In Germany, the Government of Chancellor Helmut Kohl plans to take the extraordinary step of using an obvious accounting gimmick -- booking a quick profit by revaluing gold reserves -- to reduce a ballooning deficit. **********Behind both events is one thing: the euro, the single European currency that is scheduled to be introduce in 1999. After years of talk, the dream of a common currency is now giving way to inescapable practical imperatives and forcing political leaders to address contradictions they have ignored for years. **********Until now, Mr. Chirac and Mr. Kohl have told their countries that the euro will provide something for everybody. The euro, they said, would be as solid as the German mark, vanquishing inflation and instability across Europe. But it would also unleash unprecedented new growth by eliminating the barriers created by the Continent's current patchwork of currencies. **********Now voters in both countries are learning the other side of the story.  Because countries can participate in the euro only if they meet strict fiscal and economic benchmarks this year, French leaders have put their economy through a wringer that has crushed inflation but sent the jobless rate to 12.8 percent. **********''The French are suffering from fiscal fatigue,'' remarked Kermit L. Schoenholtz, Salomon Brothers' chief global economist in London. So when Mr. Chirac asked voters for a renewed mandate for the euro, which meant more budget cuts, he added, it was hardly surprising that they said ''no.'' **********In Germany, Europe's longtime fortress of fiscal rectitude, Chancellor Kohl has become trapped between the competing goals of reuniting Germany and uniting Europe itself. **********Rebuilding the former East Germany has proved so expensive that Mr. Kohl is now resorting to bookkeeping maneuvers to plug the Government's budget deficit that is too large by the rules for monetary union. **********Today, Germany's central bank, in a rare public clash with the Government, objected to the plan to revalue gold reserves at current market prices instead of at their original cost, and to transfer about $7 billion in profit to the Treasury this year. **********''It is basically printing money,'' said Holger Fahrinkrug, an economist for UBS Securities in Frankfurt.  ''This is money that was not there prior to the revaluation.'' **********Both events have raised new doubts about whether the euro will actually arrive on time or, if it does, whether it will be as credible a currency as advertised. Most financial and political experts still believe the answer to the first question is ''yes,'' but they warn the answer to the second question is ''no.'' **********Indeed, many analysts argue that the events this week increase the probability that the European Monetary Union will include a large number of countries. When German officials resorted to precisely the kind of financial maneuvering they have sneered at in other countries, analysts say they opened the door to bending the rules for others, like Italy, that could not meet the requirements of the Maastricht treaty. **********Lionel Jospin, the French Socialist leader who is challenging Mr. Chirac's coalition, has repeatedly said he supports the euro but does not want the criteria to introduce it to block important social programs for France. Mr. Chirac himself has repeatedly locked horns with the German Government on similar issues, insisting that political leaders be given some kind of authority over decisions by the new European Central Bank that will control monetary policy and short-term interest rates. **********The looming conflicts have been apparent for a while, but the schedule for the euro has made them impossible to duck. Under the Maastricht treaty proposing a single currency, countries will be allowed to participate in the new monetary union if they meet certain strict fiscal and economic benchmarks in 1997. **********The rules require, among other things, that a country's budget deficit in 1997 must be less than 3 percent of gross domestic product, that the inflation rate remain low and that overall government debt be less than 60 percent of gross domestic product. **********Under Mr. Chirac, France's budget deficit has shrunk sharply and is now close to the target. Because France has linked its monetary policy to Germany's, its inflation has been less than 3 percent for several years. But Mr. Chirac still needed to make a few more cuts and he was determined to proceed with his broader program of liberalizing the economy. **********By calling a snap election one year ahead of schedule and framing the vote as a referendum on the euro, he gambled on being able to stretch out his tenure by an extra year and rejuvenate his mandate with, as he said, a new ''elan.'' **********Instead, his center-right coalition won with barely 30 percent of the vote, versus 37 percent for France's left-wing parties. The real outcome will not be decided until the runoff election this Sunday, but the results so far have already shaken Mr. Chirac's control of the agenda even if his coalition retains a majority in the Parliament. **********Most analysts believe that the euro will still become reality, even if the Socialists take power. But it is also clear that regardless of who wins the French will push harder than before for ''flexibility'' of the sort that the Germans instinctively loathe. **********Philippe Seguin, speaker of the French National Assembly and one of the top candidates to become the new prime minister if Mr. Chirac retains his majority, said this week that the strict requirements of the Maastricht treaty should be relaxed. **********''I dare hope that once the euro is launched and we no longer need to convince German public opinion, we will loosen it,'' Mr. Seguin said in an interview with the magazine L'Express. ''A target of 3 percent of deficits in a period of expansion is not virtuous. In a period of austerity it is masochism.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/09/busin.snippet: Chart describing how individuals leave electronic footprints everywhere they go and with everything they do; notes digital connections and surveillance cameras have become prime source of information for law enforcement agencies; says investigatio...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/09/busin.main_headline: Tracking the Footprints on a Digital Trail
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/09/busin.print_headline: Tracking the Footprints on a Digital Trail
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/09/busin.body_text: **********On any given day, an individual leaves electronic footprints as clear as the impressions his ancestors' feet left in the forest loam. Digital connections and ubiquitous surveillance cameras have become a prime source of information for law enforcement agencies. **********For 50 years or more, since telephone surveillance became a routine police tool, technology has supplemented human intuition and analysis. Now it is not just the expensive machinery of crime labs but the mechanization of daily life --from automatic tellers to E-mail -- that offers new ways to catch lawbreakers. **********The investigations of the 1995 Oklahoma City bombing and of last week's murder of Jonathan Levin, a high school English teacher who was the son of Time Warner's chief executive, are reminders of how easy it can be to pick up an electronic trail.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/18/world.snippet: Collapse of makeshift bridge at Maccabiah Games and death of two Australian athletes has set off unusual round of painful soul-searching among Israelis about their attitudes toward order and toward death (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/18/world.main_headline: Israelis Turn Self-Critical As Mishap Kills Two
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/18/world.print_headline: Israelis Turn Self-Critical As Mishap Kills Two
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/18/world.body_text: **********The collapse of a makeshift bridge at the Maccabiah Games and the death of two Australian participants has set off an unusual round of painful soul-searching among Israelis about their attitudes toward order and toward death. **********The questioning, which began with the decision to carry on with the opening ceremony while rescuers were still at work on Monday night searching through the Yarkon River, has ranged considerably beyond the reckoning that inevitably follows when tragedy strikes at a festive event. **********''The deaths of two Australian participants, the wounding of scores more, is indicative of what Israel has come to represent,'' wrote Michael Oren, a historian who competed in the 1977 Maccabiah, expressing a sentiment heard over radio and television, in newspapers and in homes. ''Not strength and stamina, but recklessness and greed. Not rebirth, but indifference to human life.'' **********To many Israelis, as to Mr. Oren, the juxtaposition of cheers and screams, of kitsch and a cheap bridge, seemed to reflect a nation so swept up by its successes, prosperity and derring-do that it would not even pause to build a proper bridge, or to lament the loss of lives. **********The dismay seemed excessive for what was essentially an accident caused by miscalculation and a decision to carry on with the show to avoid the confusion and panic that could ensue if 50,000 spectators were abruptly told to leave. A Gallup Poll commissioned by the newspaper Maariv found that 54 percent thought the ceremony should have been canceled, and 41 agreed it should have gone on. **********But the Ramat Gan tragedy seemed to meld with reports that at least a dozen people had drowned recently on Israel's beaches and that record numbers were being killed in road accidents. And it came at a time when the Arab-Israeli peace effort appeared to have died and the nation seemed mired in endless conflicts -- with Palestinian stone throwers, with American Jews, with the Clinton Administration, between the religious and secular, between Benjamin Netanyahu and his ministers. **********''There might be a temptation to view Monday night's disaster as an isolated incident,'' Mr. Oren continued. ''But it isn't. The criminal negligence and corner-cutting that caused it is endemic to Israeli society.'' **********He added, ''To overlook the connection between all this and pitfalls in the peace process -- or, for that matter, a Prime Minister's assassination -- is to miss the rot at the core of our society.'' **********Avraham Burg, chairman of the Jewish Agency, wrote in the tabloid Yediot Ahronot: ''At such a time we have no choice but to stop for a moment, and ask ourselves a question about the cheapness of life. Why do they die on the roads? Why do they drown in the sea? Why did they die at the Maccabiah? Because something is wrong with our way of life.'' **********Many writers expressed outrage over the decision to proceed with the ceremony. The indignation was fanned by politicians, including Mr. Netanyahu and President Ezer Weizman, who tried to distance themselves from the decision. **********Mr. Netanyahu said he did not know that anyone had died, and asserted that he had issued orders that if there was a fatality, the ceremony should be stopped. Mr. Weizman initially denied reports that he had taken part in the decision to continue, then acknowledged that he had. **********Much of the debate focused on reports that the army had proposed to build the temporary bridge, but was refused because of cost, and that the police had repeatedly warned that the bridge was unsteady. To many Israelis, this appeared to reflect a pervasive shoddiness. **********''The oppressive feeling that we don't have good luck, that God is not with us, that everyone is against us, is an escape from responsibility and a disregard of reality,'' Yosef Lapid wrote in Maariv. ''Things don't go well because we do things here hurriedly and in half-haste; this one chooses the cheapest offer without checking if it is the safest one; that one employs a contractor who is willing to risk human life in order to save materials; this one signs that the bridge is usable without checking it out -- all with 'friendly negligence.' '' **********A sociologist at Tel Aviv University, Ephraim Yauchtman-Yaar, concurred in an interview with The Jerusalem Post that the Ramat Gan accident reflected a deeper problem of the society. **********''A culture has evolved where laws, rules and regulations are not respected,'' he said. This attitude, he said, had several sources -- one was in the centuries of Jewish existence in the diaspora, where rules were perceived as a tool of the enemy. Another was the informality of Jewish life, in which contacts were as important as rules in achieving an end. Finally, Mr. Yauchtman-Yaar said, ''people try to save money, and think only of the short term.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/21/busin.snippet: Dow Jones industrial average loses 57.40 points to close at 6,820.28, falling for third straight day and dropping to its lowest level in six weeks (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/21/busin.main_headline: Dow Drops for Third Day, but Technology Stocks Rally
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/21/busin.print_headline: Dow Drops for Third Day, but Technology Stocks Rally
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/21/busin.body_text: **********Continuing fears over higher interest rates rattled the stock market yesterday, even as technology stocks rallied for the first time in more than a week. **********The Dow Jones industrial average lost 57.40 points, to close at 6,820.28, falling for the third straight day, and dropping to its lowest level in six weeks. Since peaking at 7,085.16 on March 11, the Dow has lost 265 points, or 3.7 percent. For the year,  the blue-chip index is up 5.8 percent. **********Analysts said the market was led down by concerns that higher interest rates and a strong dollar could slow the economy and weaken corporate earnings. Higher interest rates could also draw some investors away from stocks and into bonds and other safe vehicles. **********''Money is being treated better in the bond market and with Treasury bills,'' said Don R. Hays, a market analyst at Wheat First Butcher & Singer. ''People are opting to put money on the sideline.'' **********That scenario became even more likely yesterday after the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, hinted again to a Congressional committee that the Fed could raise short-term interest rates at its Tuesday policy meeting. **********Mr. Greenspan's comments helped push stock prices down early in the day with bond prices. The bond market recovered, however, while stock prices continued to slump. **********The Dow was dragged down even more by news that the Liggett Group Inc., the nation's fifth-largest cigarette maker, may settle a class action lawsuit. **********Shares of Philip Morris -- the nation's largest cigarette maker -- plunged 6 1/8 points, to 115 7/8, pulling the stock down about 17 percent since its March 11 high of 139 5/8. **********The drop in shares of Philip Morris accounted for nearly half of the Dow's loss, but broader indexes also slumped. The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks fell 3.12 points yesterday, to 782.65. And the New York Stock Exchange composite index lost 1.81 points to close at 411.78. **********Technology shares, however, rebounded yesterday after a disastrous string of losses. The technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index rose 9.97, to 1,259.26, its first gain in eight sessions -- one of those rare occasions when the Nasdaq has risen without the help of Intel and Microsoft. Still, for the year, the Nasdaq is down 2.5 percent. **********Among the winners: Ascend Communications, up 4 1/2, to 50 1/4; Dell, up 3 3/4, to 66 5/8, and Gateway 2000, up 6, to 53 5/8. Intel lost  3/8, to 133 1/4, and Microsoft was down  3/4, to 96. **********That stocks had become far too expensive has been heard again and again this year, the wisdom of everyone from Mr. Greenspan, to Warren E. Buffett, the legendary investor. **********But some analysts now believe that the recent selloff in technology, as well as the less severe downturn in blue-chip stocks, may be a sign that investors are beginning to heed the warnings. **********''I think everybody was looking for an excuse to stop buying,'' said Hugh Johnson, an investment strategist at the First Albany Corporation. ''The market had gone up too fast and became overvalued. It had become difficult for portfolio managers to find stocks they felt were worth buying.'' **********The problem, however, is that many investors are worried that the Fed's move to raise short-term interest rates may be simply the first of several, analysts said. **********''The key question now is do we pull a '94 -- when it was the first of many -- or a '96, when the Fed moved in January, and then didn't do anything for 14 months?'' asked Larry Wachtel, a market analyst at Prudential Securities. **********Mr. Wachtel and others note, however, that the market has a way of ''confounding the prognosticators,'' just as it did today by buying up shares of technology stocks. **********Still, whether the Fed acts next week or not, some analysts are already seeing dark clouds looming over what had come to be known as the ''Goldilocks Economy'' -- not too hot, not too cold. **********ON THE WEB **********The latest stock and mutual fund quotations, along with news updates, are available on the Internet from The New York Times on the Web: www.nytimes.com

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/22/world.snippet: Gen Andres Rodriguez, who led coup in Paraguay in 1989 that ended more than three decades of dictatorship of Gen Alfredo Stroessner, dies at age 72; photo (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/22/world.main_headline: Andres Rodriguez Dies at 72; Overthrew Paraguay Dictator
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/22/world.print_headline: Andres Rodriguez Dies at 72; Overthrew Paraguay Dictator
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/22/world.body_text: **********Gen. Andres Rodriguez, who led a coup in Paraguay in 1989 that ended more than three decades of dictatorship by Gen. Alfredo Stroessner, died today at a New York hospital. He was 72. **********A spokesman for the Paraguayan Embassy in Washington said that Gen. Rodriguez had died of complications from liver cancer at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Hospital, where he was undergoing treatment, and that his family was at his bedside. **********General Rodriguez is considered one of Paraguay's most important modern political figures for overthrowing General Stroessner, who came to power in 1954 and won eight straight presidential elections in Paraguay, mainly through fraud and intimidation. **********On Feb. 3, 1989, General Rodriguez toppled General Stroessner in a bloody palace coup that resulted from a bitter dispute over who would succeed an ailing General Stroessner, who went into exile in Brazil. **********Shortly after the coup, General Rodriguez, who had been a bulwark of the Stroessner regime, surprised skeptics by restoring press liberties, freeing political prisoners, welcoming home exiles, and conducting open presidential elections. **********Paraguayans elected General Rodriguez, who first served as interim president, to a four-year term that ended in 1993, when businessman Juan Carlos Wasmosy became Paraguay's first democratically elected civilian President. **********While many historians credit General Rodriguez for bringing democratic rule to Paraguay, which had known only dictators since it won independence in 1811, others viewed him as an opportunist who deposed his mentor to fulfill a lifelong quest to become President. **********In Asuncion, the Paraguayan capital, residents of the landlocked country of five million people, expressed mixed emotions over General Rodriguez's death. **********''Andres Rodriguez gave Paraguay the opportunity to live in democracy,'' said Demetrio Rojas, director of Ultima Hora, a leading daily newspaper. Domingo Laino, head of the opposition Authentic Radical Liberal party, said, ''Andres Rodriguez's light will glow brighter than his shadow.'' But Florencia Lopez, a seamstress, said that the general was ''a strongman who had robbed the public till.'' **********General Rodriguez became one of the richest men in Paraguay under the military government that he toppled. After a 40-year military career with a top salary of $500 a month, he owned the nation's largest brewery, a chain of currency exchange shops, an import-export business, several ranches, and a copper wire company. **********Toward the end of General Rodriguez's career, there were persistent allegations that he was involved in cocaine trafficking from neighboring Bolivia to Europe and the United States, but such charges were never proved. **********After his retirement from the army, General Rodriguez was sworn in as a Paraguayan Senator for Life, a position that granted him immunity from attacks by political enemies, many of them former Stroessner aides angry at losing their privileges. **********Last year, General Rodriguez played a major role in ending a tense constitutional standoff between President Wasmosy and a renegade army general, Cesar Oviedo, who refused to yield power. **********General Rodriguez is survived by his wife, Nelly Reich de Rodriguez and three daughters, Dolly, Mirtha, and Martha, who reside in Paraguay.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/24/busin.snippet: Analysis of Boeing Co's concession to European Union officials--giving up exclusive 20-year contracts to supply aircraft to American, Delta and Continental airlines in return for approval of Boeing's acquisition of McDonnell Douglas Corp; says ind...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/24/busin.body_text: **********The Boeing Company's concession to European Union officials -- giving up exclusive 20-year contracts to supply aircraft to American, Delta and Continental airlines in return for approval of the acquisition of the McDonnell Douglas Corporation -- will have little practical effect for years to come, industry experts said yesterday. **********After all, the airlines, having placed orders for the next 20 years, still want the aircraft they have ordered for the foreseeable future. And there are powerful incentives to remain with one manufacturer, including reduced training costs for pilots and mechanics, and the lower costs associated with carrying inventories of spare parts for only one brand of aircraft. **********Boeing acceded to European demands that the exclusivity clauses be dropped so that Airbus Industrie, the European consortium that is Boeing's biggest rival, would not be frozen out of competition for new orders for so many years. However, Airbus or any other potential competitors to Boeing would have to offer strong incentives to airlines to complicate their fleets with new aircraft types. **********''That will be a powerful force in deterring the airlines from making any radical changes,'' said Edmund S. Greenslet, an industry analyst who runs ESG Aviation Services in Ponte Verde Beach, Fla. ''It's going to be a tough sell, but not an impossible sell.'' **********But, he added, ''For the next five years, even 10 years, I don't think it means anything.'' **********Beyond that time, though, the Boeing concession appears to be a slight positive for Airbus and the airlines that signed the agreements with Boeing, and a slight negative for Boeing itself. **********The airlines will continue to hold on to the steep discounts they received for new aircraft in return for wedding themselves to Boeing. At the same time, they are free to consider new offerings from other manufacturers before the end of their 20-year contracts. **********''Now we get the best of both worlds,'' said Gordon M. Bethune, chairman of Continental Airlines. **********In a news conference in Washington yesterday, Philip M. Condit, Boeing's chairman, said that Boeing had been reluctant to give up the exclusivity clauses, although he said that Boeing expected the change to have little impact on aircraft orders. **********''Given this agreement, we can have, if not zero impact, then minimal impact on the bottom line,'' Mr. Condit said. **********To the degree that removing the exclusivity clause on its contracts chips away at the competitive advantage of Boeing, the change benefits Airbus. **********Airbus had feared the 20-year contracts for good reason. In practical terms, by the time an airline had moved to an all-Boeing fleet after 20 years, any airline would be reluctant to start carrying the additional costs associated with bringing in new plane types. **********''Exclusive deals are not for 20 years, they are for eternity,'' Jean Pierson, managing director of Airbus, said at the recent air show in Paris. **********Now, Airbus will at least have an opportunity to make sales pitches to top airline executives, particularly when leadership at AMR's American Airlines, Delta Air Lines and Continental changes over the next two decades. **********That thinking was reflected when Airbus mounted an aggressive public relations campaign against Boeing's long-term contracts following Delta's announcement of the  Boeing deal in March. **********John J. Leahy, an Airbus senior vice president, contended at the time that the contracts deprived airline investors of a chance to get an even better deal in the future. **********''Airline managements in the future are going to wonder what their predecessors got them into,'' Mr. Leahy said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/21/busin.snippet: "If I could only do one thing, I'd privatize France Telecom tomorrow because every day it stays in government hands it loses a little bit of competitive value and a little bit of its chances to become a long-term global winner for France," the
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/21/busin.main_headline: Privatization Policy Remains Uncertain : In France, a Time for Decisions
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/21/busin.print_headline: Privatization Policy Remains Uncertain : In France, a Time for Decisions
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/21/busin.body_text: **********"If I could only do one thing, I'd privatize France Telecom tomorrow because every day it stays in government hands it loses a little bit of competitive value and a little bit of its chances to become a long-term global winner for France," the French Socialist said. **********The speaker was Jacques Delors, the man expected at the time — November 1994 — to bring the Socialists back to power by winning the French presidency six months later. **********Mr. Delors, fresh from eight years of international exposure as president of the European Commission, was convinced that privatization of high-tech companies was vital to France's chances of success in increasingly intense global competition. **********Mr. Delors withdrew from the presidential race before that view could be tested on French voters. **********But now, following this month's Socialist election victory, France Telecom's future has emerged as a test case for Prime Minister Lionel Jospin's new government as it tries to adjust its campaign platform — opposing privatization, including a planned public offering of France Telecom shares — to the demands of modernizing the French economy. **********"If the new government can't find a way at least to partially privatize France Telecom, which is the best source of revenue out there, then there's little hope of rational decisions about the other critical state-owned sectors," an influential Socialist industrialist said Friday, a day after Mr. Jospin's first major policy speech on the issue. **********However, privatization — probably the most critical question about France's economic outlook — was the issue on which Mr. Jospin left the country in limbo. **********Financial markets on Friday seemed to interpret his taciturn approach as a sign that the government may be looking for some wiggle-room in which to proceed with privatization. One Socialist industrialist said that "the longer the government puts off taking a position, the better the chances that it can distance itself in practice from its own doctrine." **********A hint of how the government might proceed with France Telecom, whose partial privatization had been scheduled to start this month by the previous government, came Friday when a government minister told the magazine Le Nouvel Observateur that "there would be no objection to selling some shares to the company's employees." **********But Claude Allegre, the minister of research and a close confidant of Mr. Jospin, denied that the government had a broader appetite for privatizations. He recalled that when a Socialist government decided to hive off France Telecom from the French post office in 1991, Mr. Jospin, a cabinet minister, publicly opposed the move. **********Mr. Allegre dismissed a suggestion that privatization in France spawned entrepreneurship, saying that "most of the top French businessmen are bureaucrats who got control of nationalized companies that were then privatized." **********But most observers believe that Mr. Jospin cannot afford to wait long. **********Selling off state-owned companies would bring in revenue to ease the nation's debt load. More importantly, the companies — including France Telecom and Air France, Airbus Industrie and Thomson-CSF, the defense-electronics giant — need to go into private hands before their main international competitors will seal strategic alliances with them. **********A common feature of these four major enterprises — in the case of Airbus, Europe's biggest single industrial operation, the French partner company is state-owned Aerospatiale — is that they operate in markets fully exposed to international competition from big private companies. **********Mr. Jospin said Thursday that there might have to be "adaptations" for such companies — a phrase that some executives interpreted Friday to mean eventual privatization. **********That would leave untouched the status of public-service industries such as the French railways or even state-owned insurance and other financial service companies — for example, the Groupe GAN insurance company with its banking subsidiaries or Credit Lyonnais SA — on the grounds that they operate mainly in domestic markets largely shielded from the outside pressures. **********Asked to interpret the distinction made by Mr. Jospin in a policy statement, Socialist officials were reluctant to venture much farther Friday than to say that any privatizations would be considered on a case-by-case basis, an approach bound to slow the process. **********France has pledged to privatize several big companies, including Air France, Credit Lyonnais and GAN, as part of a deal with the European Commission allowing Paris to provide a final round of subsidies aimed at saving the companies from bankruptcy. But Socialist officials have made it clear that they are prepared to ignore rulings from Brussels if politics force them to. **********French public opinion remains largely hostile to privatization, in contrast to general support for the idea in most of Europe. Germany is privatizing Deutsche Telekom, and Italy's Socialist government said Friday that it expected to privatize the Italian post office. In France, trade unions often see their last bastion as government-run businesses where employees have job tenure.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/06/world.snippet: Opening of Office of History by Hungary's Interior Ministry, which keeps files on Hungarians who were spied on during Communist era, is raising questions, instead of ushering in new era of candor about past; historians, citizens and members of gov...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/06/world.main_headline: Hungary Reluctant to Give Up Secrets of Its Past
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/06/world.print_headline: Hungary Reluctant to Give Up Secrets of Its Past
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/06/world.body_text: **********In the cellars of a gracious turn-of-the-century building on the banks of the Danube, shelves of dusty files -- some of them just a few pages, others more comprehensive -- are waiting to be read by Hungarians who were spied on in the Communist era. They became accessible for the first time this week. **********But rather than ushering in a new era of candor about the past, the opening of the Office of History in the Interior Ministry, eight years after the collapse of Communism, is raising questions. **********Historians, citizens and members of the junior partner in the governing coalition are asking: Why are so few files available? What has happened to the rest? **********''The process has only begun -- we have to force it open,'' said Imre Mecs, who spent six years on death row after the 1956 Hungarian uprising was crushed by Soviet forces. Mr. Mecs, who is now the chairman of the Parliamentary Defense Committee, continued: ''I feel that the past should be opened as a cleansing process. It will hurt personal feelings, but these are things we have to swallow.'' **********Mr. Mecs, who keeps a portrait in his office of Prime Minister Imre Nagy, the hero of the failed uprising who was later hanged, is a member of the Liberal Democrats. The party has led the drive for accessibility to dossiers compiled by the Communist secret police services. **********But the dominant force in the Government, the former Communist Party, led by Prime Minister Gyula Horn, has been much more reluctant. **********By the time Communism fizzled here, the Government had become the most relaxed in the Eastern bloc, and many expected that the files of the security apparatus would be more easily pried loose than elsewhere. The expectations where heightened because for the first four years of the post-Communist period the Government here was dominated by right-of-center politicians who excoriated the Communists at every turn. **********But Hungary became one of the laggards. The first Government decided to hold the files as a weapon to selectively discredit and blackmail opponents and now, Mr. Mecs said, the former Communists are nervous about how the contents of the files would reflect on them. **********By contrast, East Germany opened its state security archives almost immediately after the fall of the Berlin wall, a move that some human rights activists asserted led to indiscriminate finger-pointing. **********Before Czechoslovakia split into two countries, a swath of security files that named names were released there. Those described as secret police collaborators, though not always accurately, were denied public office. In June Czech citizens were allowed for the first time to request their personal security files. **********There are a number of reasons why the documents in the Interior Ministry's cellar are far less complete than they would like, ministry officials said. The ministry is now run by Gabor Kuncze, the leader of the Liberal Democrats. **********First, when it became clear in 1989 that Hungarian Communism was ending, the shredding machines at the secret police agencies worked overtime. ''There was a tremendous panic,'' Mr. Mecs said. His own files -- no doubt copious, he said -- are among those declared missing. **********Then, many papers that were not destroyed at the domestic intelligence agency were moved to other parts of the security apparatus, including the anti-espionage division and foreign intelligence. **********These divisions are still run by bureaucrats from the old guard, who according to a 1994 law control which documents can be released to the History Office. Anything that the intelligence agencies deem ''operational'' -- which seems to include much of the post-1956 spying -- can be kept secret by these bureaucrats, Mr. Mecs said. **********To diminish the control of intelligence officials, Mr. Mecs said he favors setting up an independent committee that would have decision-making powers over releasing pre-1989 files. Since the spy agencies were working for the Communist Party rather than the national interests, he asserted, 99 percent of the documents cannot be regarded as confidential. **********During its first week, interest in the History Office was low-key. Gyorgy Marko, the director of the office, said 63 people came in to make applications to see their files; 40 others wrote letters of request. **********Paul Lendvai, who fled Hungary in early 1957 and went on to become a well-known journalist covering Communist Eastern Europe from his base in Austria, said that after 1956, ''everybody in Hungary was more or less co-opted, even those who were sentenced to long sentences.'' A widespread fear of embarrassment accounted for the lack of enthusiasm to uncover the past, he said. **********When Mr. Lendvai tried to use his clout -- including a face-to-face appeal to Prime Minister Horn -- to get access to his files that he knew had existed, he came up empty-handed. **********In his recent autobiography, ''Blacklisted,'' Mr. Lendvai refers to his secret police files from East Germany and the Czech Republic. In them, the Hungarian security bosses were quoted as bragging about their extensive knowledge of Mr. Lendvai -- described as a ''most dangerous man.'' **********When he was honored in the Hungarian Parliament last year, Mr. Lendvai scolded the Government for allowing the security archives to be run by people who had been in charge of ''dusty lies.'' **********''I'd rather get my files than the award,'' he said. ''It is my life.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/19/world.snippet: Profile of Hong Kong waiter Pang Hon Ming; photo (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/19/world.main_headline: Reading the Tea Leaves for a Fresh Season of Life
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/19/world.print_headline: Reading the Tea Leaves for a Fresh Season of Life
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/19/world.body_text: **********Pang Hon Ming's black-slippered feet whispered across the floor as he moved toward the round table, a white plate piled with fried noodles floating on the edge of his fingers. Carefully, with chopsticks and a ladle, he filled five small bowls with noodles before setting them in front of each of the diners, regular customers. **********''Ahh, mh-goi sai'' -- ''thank you very much,'' the customers murmured. **********But Mr. Pang, the sleeves of his white jacket turned up twice over his thin arms, was already moving away from the table, a brusqueness for which the Luk Yu Teahouse is famous. **********For nearly 60 years the Luk Yu has been an institution in Hong Kong, more club than restaurant, a club of regular diners, and grumpy waiters for those who aren't. **********As the lunch hour petered out and the last diners scuttled back to their offices, Mr. Pang, 47, sagged into a chair in the back of the restaurant and poured himself a cup of tea. **********''I leave home at 5:30,'' he said, ''and I get here about 6:35 and work until 2:30 in the afternoon. Then I'm off. I start again at 6 and work until 10:30. Then I go home. I only get two days off every month, so I work 28 days a month. The law is you're supposed to get four days off a month, but most restaurants only give two.'' **********The phone rang in the little back room as he talked, and Mr. Pang picked it up and listened. ''That was a customer, a regular, who wanted some special dishes for tonight,'' he explained afterward. **********''We used to be very famous for our dim sum, but some people say it's not so good anymore. A lot of the old chefs have retired, and the next generation is not as good as the last.'' Still, the Luk Yu has a reputation for serving superb food, particularly dishes that may not appear on the menu. **********''Regular customers are important,'' Mr. Pang said. ''Down here on the ground floor, I would say there are the most regulars. There are these really old customers who can't get up the stairs anymore. So of course they're all on the ground floor. They'll ask you to save them a table, and you do. During lunch time, all the tables are taken by regular customers. That guy who just called -- he's been coming for more than 20 years.'' **********From the floor of the Luk Yu, Mr. Pang has observed the seasons of life, as reflected in the shifting clientele. **********''In the beginning, you don't care for these people,'' he confessed. ''You see people become successful over the years. You see people who fail in their business and they stop coming. In the last year or so, more mainlanders have been coming in, but they come with the regulars.'' **********Although Mr. Pang was born in China, in the Pearl River delta town of Panyu, he came here as an infant when his parents fled Communism in 1950. ''They had a little shop that wove bamboo for window shades,'' he said. ''We lived in Sham Shui Po,'' one of the poorest urban neighborhoods in Hong Kong. ''I had seven brothers and sisters, but I don't remember how old they all are. I only remember how old I am.'' **********From his first job at 16, Mr. Pang has worked nearly every day of his life -- always in restaurants. He paused briefly to marry. He has two sons, one 21, the other 26. He said he has little time for his family, though all four members live together in a small two-room apartment. **********''I can't afford to live over here,'' on Hong Kong Island, he said, where housing prices can be stratospheric. ''Twenty years ago I bought a little apartment in Kwai Chung,'' a neighborhood near Hong Kong's container terminals. The 500-square-foot place cost  about $20,000. **********One week a year, Mr. Pang and his family return to Panyu to pay respects to the grave of his grandparents. There is little time off beyond that, he said, although, like many other Hong Kongers, he finds the lure of the race track nearly irresistible. **********''I used to gamble more,'' he said. ''In 1992, I won a couple of million dollars,'' nearly $300,000. ''But I kept betting more and lost half of it again. I get these tips from customers. During 1992, we had customers who know people in the stables and lots of races were fixed.'' **********Indeed, there have been repeated scandals at Hong Kong's tracks and most people take it as a matter of faith that the races are rigged. Even so, last year Hong Kongers bet $11 billion on the horses. **********''I don't bet so much anymore,'' he said. **********Over the course of several long conversations, Mr. Pang never mentioned Hong Kong's handover to China and seemed somewhat surprised when asked about it. **********''I have no feeling about it at all,'' he said firmly. ''It's like something that's inevitable. What's the big deal? I still have to work. It has nothing to do with me. I think things will change, but I don't think China will want to destroy Hong Kong. I just hope we don't have all that crime they have up north in China.'' **********Four Destinies **********For Hong Kong's 6.3 million people, the transfer from British to Chinese rule is just one element in their lives. These articles, by Edward A. Gargan, tell the stories of four residents, from four walks of life.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/14/busin.snippet: Having distinguished themselves as first generation to leave house to work in large numbers, women in their late 50's and early 60's are now in the retirement range; while surveys show that many keep working if they are single, divorced or widowed...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/14/busin.main_headline: She's Wound Up in Her Career, but He's Ready to Wind Down
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/14/busin.print_headline: EARNING IT; She's Wound Up in Her Career, but He's Ready to Wind Down
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/14/busin.body_text: **********AFTER a career as a salesman, Ruth Cambron's husband retired, and she thought she might, too. She took a leave from her job as a health care specialist in California, and the couple traveled on cruise ships. ''That convinced me not to retire,'' Mrs. Cambron said. ''I did not want to feel useless.'' She also wanted to build her pension. And 12 years later, at 73, she still draws a paycheck -- a stalwart in the growing ranks of older women who continue to work after their husbands stop. **********Sandra Kaul, an art gallery director and consultant, is just entering those ranks. Her husband, lured by the offer of a sweetened pension, retired in June at 58, after 30 years as a college art professor in Minnesota. ''I encouraged him,'' said Ms. Kaul, who is 55. ''I knew he really wanted to stay home and paint, while I have a career to pursue.'' **********Helena Genovese, 63, stays at her job out of both necessity and desire. Her husband, a professional hypnotist, now 68, retired seven years ago, worried that if he did not ease up he might suffer a fatal heart attack, as a friend had. But his $850 in monthly retirement benefits, mostly from Social Security, is insufficient to maintain the couple's suburban life style without Ms. Genovese's $1,900-a-month salary as a manager of the parking facility at Buffalo's airport. **********''Besides, what would I do all day at home?'' she asked. ''He plays with the dog, builds model planes and visits our children. I think that if two people are home together constantly, they could end up killing each other.'' **********Having distinguished themselves as the first generation to leave the house to work in large numbers, women in their late 50's and early 60's are now in retirement range. If they are single, divorced or widowed, they often keep working, surveys show, because they lack the Social Security credits or pension savings of men their age, who earned more and worked more years. But in growing numbers, married women in this age group are also staying on the job -- breaking with the practice of sharing their husbands' retirement. **********Surveys are just beginning to catch the shift and the reasons for it. A big one is the promise of an independent pension to avoid the poverty that often comes to widows who rely on their husbands' benefits. Social Security, the main ingredient in most cases, is cut after a husband's death. **********''Older women keep working to secure their economic survival,'' said Heidi Hartmann, director of the Institute for Women's Policy Research in Washington. **********What is more, the extra income earned by the women helps maintain family living standards, particularly if a husband has been pushed out of the labor force before he had planned to retire. And there is what Mathew Greenwald, a market researcher who polls people on retirement issues, calls the sociability aspect. **********''Building friendships on the job is often more important to women than it is to men,'' he said. ''Women may want to go on working to maintain these friendships. They find the idea of being retired more isolating than men do.'' **********Whatever the reasons, women's persistence in working could have broad implications for the economy. It could, for example, relieve some of the financial pressure on the Social Security system, which will be stretched thin when the baby boomers retire. **********The statistical evidence is still sparse, but the shift appears to apply mainly to those 55 to 64 and not to those 65 and older. The number of working men and women in that older group has traditionally been relatively small, although it has crept up slightly for both sexes in the 1990's. **********The University of Michigan, which is tracking people in their 50's and 60's in a federally financed study that is just beginning to produce data, found that of 813 married women whose husbands had retired, 45 percent still worked, most of them full time. ''These are serious workers, not just women doing real estate,'' said Marjorie Honig, a Hunter College economist who helped tabulate the results. **********Labor Department surveys also suggest that married women are working in increasing numbers after their husbands stop, or at least that married women aged 55 to 64 are staying in the labor force in rising percentages while men are not. Nearly 3.5 million women in this group were in the labor force last year, or 48.6 percent of all married women 55 to 64, up from 41.3 percent in 1989 and 36.3 percent in 1980. But the percentage of married men in that age group in the labor force has fallen to 70.2 percent, from 75.4 percent in 1980. **********''Women are beginning to realize that by working just a few more years, they become eligible for good pensions,'' said Olivia Mitchell, a labor economist at the University of Pennsylvania. ''The benefit of those few extra years can be quite high.'' **********MS. GENOVESE, who took a salaried job in 1980 when the youngest of her four children was 13, came to exactly that conclusion. ''If I work three more years, I'll be eligible for a pension of $1,000 a month,'' she said. She made it clear that if her health held up, she would work indefinitely, qualifying for an even bigger pension. Her job also provides the couple's health insurance. **********Many other women are also working for bigger pensions. The Social Security Administration projects that if current trends continue, by 2015 nearly 60 percent of married women will be entitled to higher pensions upon retirement than the spousal benefit they would receive under their husbands' Social Security. That would be up from 33 percent today. And 20 percent of the women will qualify for pensions that are higher than those of their husbands, up from less than 10 percent today. **********But there is a caveat about projecting the trend forward. What Ms. Cambron, Ms. Kaul and Ms. Genovese share with many older married women is this: They took jobs and began careers relatively late in life after raising children or at least staying home until their children were in junior high school. Younger women, on the other hand, are far more likely to have careers that parallel those of their husbands. Once they reach retirement age, husband and wife, having gone through the same career cycles, may think alike about retirement. **********''The question is, will these younger people prod each other to stay on the job or will they prod each other to retire,'' said Angela O'Rand, a Duke University sociologist and retirement specialist. **********For now, however, older husbands and wives are increasingly going in separate directions. **********Six months after her husband retired, Ms. Kaul is in high career, having entered the work force only 14 years ago, once her two children became teen-agers. She is even expanding her domain, looking into using retail stores as small, makeshift art galleries for Minnesota painters. Actually, her work as the art gallery director at Bemidji State University, 100 miles north of Minneapolis, where her husband, Marlin, had taught for 30 years, is a part-time job. But Ms. Kaul has five part-time jobs, most of them as a paid consultant to various art councils and art projects in Minnesota. **********''I am in the process of proposing to the university a larger position for myself,'' she said. ''It will probably be three-quarters time. I am suggesting that we start a museum program, to manage art collections and curate them for traveling exhibitions.'' **********Still, the Kauls do not have to rely  on her income. Marlin Kaul's sweetened pension -- a lump-sum payment and $40,000 a year -- is enough for them to live comfortably. The $15,000 she brings home helps, of course, but her decision to keep working separates the Kauls from three couples who are their friends. The men, also professors at Bemidji, accepted sweetened pensions, too, and their wives have decided to retire with them. All three women had worked much longer than Ms. Kaul. **********''Two of them were in teaching careers,'' Ms. Kaul said, ''and they no longer like their jobs enough to keep doing them anymore now that their husbands are retiring.'' **********The decision also swings the other way. And when it does, a wife who continues to work sometimes ends up on Rosalind Barnett's couch. Ms. Barnett, a psychologist and senior researcher in women's issues at Brandeis University and Radcliffe College, recounts one patient's story: **********''Her husband, a lawyer who never liked what he did, lived for the day he could move to the woods in New Hampshire, and this was a nightmare for her,'' Ms. Barnett said. ''She was the director of a nonprofit organization, involved in work and community life, with a big network of people around her, and he wanted to retire to a rural life style.'' **********In the end, the husband did not retire. ''He cut back his hours,'' Ms. Barnett said, ''but he is still working as a lawyer. He is very unhappy.'' **********EVEN husbands who support their wives' decisions to keep working can take awhile to get there, as Dominic Genovese did. **********He had never cooked, and for five years after he retired he stayed out of the kitchen, which meant that his wife could not relax until she had prepared dinner. ''The stress for me did not end with the job,'' she said. And the dinner hour became later and later. ''That ticked me off,'' Mr. Genovese said, ''But cooking is something I did not think of doing. I made the bed; that took only a few minutes. And I vacuumed; I did not want to be home with dog's hair around.'' **********A life-threatening stomach ailment changed his attitude toward cooking, he said -- as did the fact that the couple's three adult sons cook. He now makes dinner four nights a week. **********Howard Aronoff, 57, of Poughkeepsie, N.Y., also cooks. His mother had taught him, and in retirement, he took over that task from his wife, although she still does the grocery shopping. Unlike Mr. Genovese, Mr. Aronoff did not willingly retire: he took a buyout in 1993 from I.B.M., where he was a senior planner, rather than risk being laid off without any payment. After briefly trying a new career as an insurance salesman, ''I drifted into retirement,'' Mr. Aronoff said. ''When people found out I was no longer at I.B.M., they looked on me as a piece of dead wood.'' **********Her husband's changed status scared his wife, Roberta, who is 53.  His earnings suddenly deflated from more than $80,000 a year to a $35,000  pension even as the couple, who were nearly finished paying for their two children's undergraduate education, were counting on the next five years to save for retirement. So she has continued in her nearly $30,000-a-year job as the manager of a dental office, a position she had held for a decade. **********''You have to sit down and work out the money issues,'' she said. ''My husband did that. He showed me, with spreadsheets, how we would get by, and that eased my mind. He found a way even to save a little.'' **********The new budget meant belt-tightening. They bought a new car for her, for example, but he still drives a 1988 model. And their daughter, now at Harvard Law School, pays her own way. ''My wife would have liked some new jewelry,'' he said, ''and I would have liked to help my children more.'' **********Sometimes a husband chooses retirement because changes at work  suddenly make the job much more difficult. William Cambron found himself in this situation in 1985, when he was 62. For years, he had been a salesman for a wholesale company that offered a line of toasters and household wares to hardware stores. As those stores lost out to big discounters like Sam's Club, the Wal-Mart unit, Mr. Cambron had to travel farther from the couple's home in Sacramento. **********''They kept widening his territory as the market dwindled, and he was tired,'' Ms. Cambron said. And so he stopped. ''He does not have a need to work. Basically, he enjoys supporting me in what I do. He even keeps my car filled with gas. I never have to do that anymore.'' **********When her husband retired, Ms. Cambron, a year younger, was only a decade into a career as a health care specialist in the California Department for the Aging. That job paid her $50,000 a year when she retired two years ago and shifted to a job monitoring nursing homes for a nonprofit organization, earning just $7,000 but working far fewer hours. Being older than 70, she is permitted to draw her full Social Security and a California state pension. They total $37,000, exceeding her husband's retirement payments by $7,000, even as she still draws a paycheck. **********''I would not be well off,'' she said, ''if I had not continued working.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/27/world.snippet: Article on Mejanes, France, focuses on farmers' efforts to save Camargue wetlands from development; map; photo (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/27/world.main_headline: France's Cowboys (Yup!) Fight for Their Range
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/27/world.print_headline: France's Cowboys (Yup!) Fight for Their Range
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/27/world.body_text: **********Spring is barely here but its energy is already surging through the Camargue, France's large southern wetlands, where the Rhone meets the Mediterranean. **********Almost everything that moves is clearly thinking about mating. The pink flamingos, poised in a few inches of water, are curving their necks in courtship displays. Teals and shovelers fidget in their showiest plumage. **********For the Camargue's people, this is the time to renew the proposition that France has real cowboys. As the days warm, they put on their Provence costumes, mount their half-wild horses and race across the great flatlands. **********That humans and beasts can live in such unusually large open spaces along France's coveted Mediterranean coast is a result of an extraordinary but, some fear, temporary truce between farmers and developers, biologists and tour operators. Under the truce, farmers may turn their old ranch houses and stables into guesthouses and riding schools, as many are doing. But for people seeking construction of new buildings, extra roads or bridges, the answer in recent years has been no. **********Part of this river delta is parkland protected by the Government, but as much as half of the 215,000-acre park is owned by farmers who grow rice or raise cattle and the tough white breed of Camargue horses. Some old-time farmers believe that the best way to protect the wetlands is not with fences and rules but by preserving the traditions of rustic country life. **********One tradition was on display on a recent Saturday at Mejanes, a hamlet on the shore of the great Vaccares lagoon. The event was a ''ferrada,''  traditionally the branding of the cattle but in this century a friendly competition in which horsemen chase young bulls. The idea is to trip up the bull with a long, blunt stick. **********This was a cheerful, bloodless event: families from far-off farms mingled and embraced, townspeople here for the day had a taste of ruggedness and most of the young bulls got away. **********''It was all right, more or less,'' said Denys Colomb de Daunant, a horse breeder and writer who at age 74 has cut back on his own riding but was turned out for the event in the customary black felt hat and patterned Provence shirt. The young people are breaking the rules, he said, grumbling that start and finish lines were not in the right places, that some of the Camargue stallions were poorly groomed. **********Guarding the traditions is what Mr. Colomb de Daunant has done much of his life, combining the care for his herds with the writing of screenplays and books set in these windy flatlands. His passion and that of others helped create the Camargue national park in 1972. But he said that he and like-minded conservationists cannot lower their guard because pressure on this oasis has been unrelenting. **********The latest threat comes from developers promoting the building of a bridge across the Rhone. ''That would put Marseilles at our doorstep,'' Mr. Colomb de Daunant said. ''We don't want any bridge. We don't need it. Only construction companies do.'' **********For all its unspoiled beauty, this is not a place created entirely by nature. The Rhone delta was once shielded from the sea only by wandering dunes. But a century ago, levees were built to stop the Rhone's meanderings and hem the powerful river into two main branches. A seawall further stabilized the land. Pumps are now used to bring seawater into the web of brackish lagoons. In the uplands, where rice and wheat are grown, the river water is channeled into irrigation canals. **********All this manipulation, though, has wrought a rich mosaic of habitats. It has also produced one of Europe's busiest breeding and feeding grounds for birds, fish and small mammals. For thousands of songbirds, waders and ducks this is a vital stopover to and from their wintering grounds in Africa. **********One of the main Mediterranean nesting sites for the spectacular pink flamingo is a secluded man-made island in a salt marsh where water levels are kept constant and chicks are safe from land-based predators. **********Biologists worry about the pollution of the Rhone and the runoff from farm fertilizers. But at last count, there were 22,000 breeding pairs of flamingos, a record number, said Pierre Andre, a park warden who was out the other day making an inventory of the local wildlife. **********On a blue alarm clock that Mr. Andre keeps in the front of his beat-up car it was 12 o'clock. ''Lunchtime,'' he said, ''I always respect that.'' **********By a hillock punctured with fox and rabbit holes, he unpacked two baguettes, a salami, a large pate and larded pork. He laid all of this out amid the rabbit droppings. **********''We may be in the wilds,'' Mr. Andre said, snapping open a big knife. ''But we must eat. We are still in France.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/21/busin.body_text: **********In a short sale, shares are borrowed from a broker and sold in hopes that prices will fall, so that they can be bought back at lower prices for a profit. If the share price rises, the short-seller faces a loss. **********Among the largest increases in short interest were Standard & Poor's depository receipts, whose value rises or falls with the S.& P. 500-stock index, most likely an expression of fear among investors that the market would continue to tumble after its decline at the end of October. On Oct. 28, the market, as measured by the Dow Jones industrial average, fell 7.2 percent, or 554 points. Short interest soared in the S.& P. receipts to 21.2 million, from 9.9 million sold in the previous period. **********Another increase reflected arbitrage activity related to a proposed $10.2 billion cash-and-stock sale of the ITT Corporation to Starwood Lodging Trust. In such a deal, arbitragers can bet on the deal going through by buying shares in the target company -- ITT -- while shorting shares in the buyer -- Starwood. Short interest in Starwood rose to 9.3 million shares from 1.2 million the previous month.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/01/your-.print_headline: Market-Opening Moves Have Yet to Bear Fruit
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/01/your-.body_text: **********SINCE PRIME Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto outlined his government's blueprint for market deregulation nearly a year ago, the financial industry has faced a brutal shakeout and the effects have been felt more strongly each day. **********Yet some of the official efforts to put Japan's markets on par with those in New York and London in terms of openness and competitiveness have not yet proved to be fruitful. **********With fanfare, the Tokyo Stock Exchange and its counterpart in Osaka each listed single-stock options in July for 20 blue-chip brands, including Toyota Motor Corp., Sony Corp. and Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi, only to find the market participants, both brokerage houses and investors, inadequately prepared to play the new game. **********Volume hit its high on the first day of trading at the Tokyo Stock Exchange, July 18, at 4,989 transactions. It has since zigzagged down the path to reach an average daily volume of less than 100, for the 10 days through Thursday. **********"There have not been enough market-making efforts on the part of brokerage firms," said Hiroshi Masuda, market analyst at Yamaichi Research Institute in Tokyo. "Business performance of brokerage firms has been poor recently, so they are not in a position to take much risk." **********He added that the latest scandals involving the top securities houses also explained the brokers' reluctance to assume counter-party positions in option trading. Nikko Securities, Daiwa Securities, and Yamaichi Securities, three of the Big Four firms whose top executives have been recently arrested in connection with the widening payoff scandal, await punishment to be meted out by the Ministry of Finance, which may include orders to suspend proprietary trading. **********While the two Japanese exchanges are expected to list new issues for options trading in November (10 in Tokyo, 20 in Osaka), analysts said that it would probably not be worth the investment for brokerage houses to expand coverage of individual stock options. **********Despite the dismal state of the options market, Mr. Masuda said that single options were potentially useful for investors. He added that market turmoil, like the turbulence that jolted the world this week, may cause investors to acknowledge the virtue of using options to hedge against declines in individual stock prices. **********Another Big Bang development led the Japan Securities Dealers Association, which has government-mandated regulatory functions, to make trading in unlisted stocks legal business of securities companies in July. **********Only eight small brokerage firms have since registered with the association as dealers, however, and the association said that it does not see an immediate, booming potential for the market. **********"At a time when the market is down," said Mitsuru Yoshikawa, director of legal and tax research at Daiwa Institute of Research, " it is difficult to find people who are interested in these small-cap stocks." **********Investors hoping for favorable changes in Japan's institutional framework will have to wait until brokerage commissions are liberalized in 1999 or when the securities transaction tax is scrapped or considerably reduced. Commissions are currently fixed at 1.15 percent of the purchase price, for trade of less than 1 million yen ($8,330). Above that, the rates differ according to the amount of trade. **********When companies are allowed to set commissions freely, Mr. Yoshikawa added, the rate could come down considerably, not just for large-lot orders but also for relatively small investments. Contrary to the trend that followed deregulation on commissions in the United States, where individual brokers' pay is often commensurate with their sales performance, Japanese sales workers are salaried, thus it is likely that transaction fees will fall even for small-lot orders, Mr. Yoshikawa said. **********The Liberal Democratic Party, the dominant party in the coalition government, has recently unveiled an economic stimulus package in which it pledged to "strive" toward removing the transaction tax, which is currently at 0.21 percent of the transaction value and is levied on every Japanese trade. Observers said it was unlikely that the taxation would remain in its current form, and that abolition or significant reduction could come as early as April. **********"It must be abolished," said Mr. Yoshikawa of Daiwa Institute of Research. "It is odd that tax is imposed on the transactions regardless of whether you made money or not." **********—
