https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/18/world.print_headline: Japan Nears Pact With U.S. On Threat to Bar Its Ships
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/18/world.body_text: **********The United States and Japan said today that they were on the verge of a shipping agreement that appeared to defuse a looming confrontation between the Coast Guard and Japanese vessels entering and leaving American harbors. **********The accord, the details of which are not final, is intended to remove the restrictions on American ships operating in Japanese ports, a source of contention for many years. But officials on both sides conceded that no matter what they put on paper over the next few days, it may not break the power of organized crime groups that are widely viewed as controlling Japan's ports. **********But to both the Americans and the Japanese, that seemed almost secondary to the daylong scramble to patch together an accord that would persuade the Federal Maritime Commission to back away from its unexpected decision on Thursday to close American ports to Japanese cargo ships. **********By early evening -- after meetings at the White House that involved the Treasury Secretary, the trade representative and the chief of staff, Erskine Bowles -- the commission decided not to order the Coast Guard to begin the embargo, which would have been the first since 1941, when oil shipments were halted. Japanese schoolchildren are still taught that the 1941 embargo precipitated the attack on Pearl Harbor. **********The commission planned the embargo after Japanese shipping companies, on orders from their Government, refused to pay $4 million in fines imposed six weeks ago in an effort to force the relaxation of port rules. Whether they will still have to pay is among the unresolved issues. **********In fact, the Administration could not seem to decide today whether this was a brewing crisis or a comic series of missteps on both sides. At one point, a senior official at the White House was even reciting the lessons of the Cuban missile crisis, which gripped Washington 35 years ago this week: before plunging into a naval embargo, it was important to make sure the other side had a graceful way out. **********What happened today was that the unexpected decision by the Maritime Commission forced both Washington and Tokyo to elevate their long-running port dispute to the highest political levels. ''Let's say it concentrated the minds,'' said Stuart Eizenstat, the Under Secretary of State for Economic Affairs, who was thrown into the talks along with the Japanese Ambassador, Kunihiko Saito. **********Mr. Saito is no newcomer to Tokyo-Washington contretemps. His previous job was Deputy Foreign Minister, the top career diplomatic post in Japan, a position that offered plenty of opportunity to defuse trade disagreements that threatened to weaken the Japanese-American alliance. But today he was careful not to declare victory. **********''I hesitate to call it a success yet, because some details are still being worked out,'' Mr. Saito said in an interview this afternoon. ''There is a limit to what the Japanese Government can do, because there are private parties involved.'' **********One of those parties -- the Japan Harbor Transportation Association -- has a stranglehold on port operations, which is the heart of the problem. For decades, its dictates on how shipping companies must operate, including requiring expensive advance clearance for every change in plans, have been the law of the waterfront. The situation is not eased by the fact that the dividing line between the association and the yakuza, Japan's organized crime groups, is murky at best. **********''There are very powerful, well organized groups on the docks,'' Mr. Eizenstat said today, weighing every word, ''with a great deal of muscle, in more ways than one.'' **********In the accord today, Japan agreed that all shipping companies will be permitted to go through the Government to deal directly with port operators. Of course, many of those operators are members of the association, but, in theory at least, foreign companies may be able to open their own terminals. **********''This new system certainly will be tested in the very near future,'' said Koji Tsuruoka, a Japanese Foreign Ministry official involved in the talks. ''It remains to be seen what happens. But we are hopeful.'' **********Mr. Tsuruoka insisted that the yakuza had been driven out of many of the ports and that its influence was diminishing. ''The question is whether the association would harass someone using the new alternative route,'' he said. Japan has ''given assurances that order will be maintained at the ports and Japanese laws will be enforced.'' **********Such assurances are something short of an ironclad commitment,  but many Japanese trade accords have been infused with the same vagueness. **********When Japan and the United States reached a landmark accord on automotive trade in 1995, they described Japan's obligations in such differing terms that it sometimes seemed as if they had sat in different negotiating rooms. That agreement seemed to work for a year or so, but in recent months it has begun to fray, with American officials saying Japan is not living up to its commitments, and Japanese officials saying they never agreed to interfere with the operations of domestic automakers. **********No one would be surprised if the same happened in this case. ''This isn't the end of the issue, it's just the next step,'' a senior Administration official said. ''But we won't be spending the weekend watching on CNN while the Coast Guard pulls up next to Japanese freighters.'' **********The American negotiators were aided by the fact that even Japanese shipping companies have long chafed at the expensive, inefficient procedures at Japanese ports, though they have never had the political clout to subvert the control of the Japan Harbor Transport Association. So in an odd way they were allied with the Americans.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/03/busin.main_headline: The Search for the Perfect Corporate Board
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/03/busin.print_headline: The Search for the Perfect Corporate Board
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/03/busin.body_text: **********ARE stockholders asking for too much? **********One might think so from the sweeping set of proposals covering the structure of corporate boards that was issued recently by one of the biggest shareholders of them all, the California Public Employees' Retirement System. **********The list was remarkable both for the self-proclaimed importance of its mission -- ''to provide a benchmark of what is 'good' corporate governance'' -- and for its specificity, addressing everything from who should sit on certain committees to compensation for directors and term limits. **********There's only one problem: hardly any companies in the country even come close to filling the bill. **********An analysis by The New York Times of data compiled by Directorship, a consulting firm in Greenwich, Conn., shows that of the 861 public companies on the Fortune 1000 list, only one, Texas Instruments Inc., meets a wide range of basic Calpers tests, including having a majority of independent directors, a separate chief executive and independent chairman and independent committees for ethics, compensation, auditing, governance and board nominations. **********Texas Instruments also meets other criteria suggested by Calpers, whose $115 billion in assets makes it the largest public pension fund in the country. The big semiconductor maker has an age limit for directors, pays a significant part of the directors' compensation in company stock and does not provide retirement benefits to board members. In addition, its directors meet regularly without the chief executive. **********The New York Times analysis also yielded no clear pattern that would link ''good'' governance to good performance, an outcome that is consistent with many other studies. **********After all, while Texas Instruments has outperformed the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index since 1990, so has the company that fails the greatest number of basic Calpers tests: the Walt Disney Company. Its board lacks a majority of outside directors, its chairman and chief executive are the same person and a number of key committees are not made up entirely of independent directors. **********When told how the company's board fared against the Calpers guidelines, executives at Disney responded with a letter discussing the company's performance, including the fact that an investment made in Disney 12 years ago has grown at an average annual rate of 28.1 percent. **********The company said its strong performance was the direct result ''of the excellent stewardship of the Disney board of directors, one of the strongest groups of its kind in U.S. business.'' **********CALPERS, which has long been active in governance issues, says it isn't thrown by the results of the analysis. Good governance, it said, should be viewed as a kind of insurance policy to help all companies weather the inevitable difficult times. **********''Should Calpers wait until companies are in the dumper before asking them to have decent corporate governance?'' said Patricia K. Macht, a spokeswoman. **********Its suggested principles, the most far-reaching of several such efforts in recent years, should be viewed as a worthy goal, Calpers executives say. **********Although Calpers stopped short of adopting the principles because it wanted to study two of the proposals further, even the draft version released in June has heightened the scrutiny of companies and their boards. The draft immediately raised Calpers's profile in an arena where it had grown relatively quiet, but it also invited quick criticism that the guidelines were too restrictive and that Calpers was perhaps growing too meddlesome. **********''The pendulum has swung too far, and Calpers is starting to overreach,'' said John M. Nash, president of the National Association of Corporate Directors, which sponsored a commission last fall that issued a more modest set of recommendations on governance. **********The growing debate over the Calpers proposals underscores the lack of consensus about what constitutes a ''perfect'' board in the first place. **********While many of Calpers's principles are universally accepted, some are viewed as counterproductive. One guideline facing further study -- a limit on the number of directors who can be older than 70 -- has drawn the most fire. **********''Age limits would cut off too many good people with too much savvy,'' said Ralph D. Ward, editor of The Corporate Board magazine and author of ''21st Century Corporate Board'' (Wiley, 1997). ''I don't really believe Calpers wants to put in anything that firm.'' **********For Calpers, though, the debate over the proposals is almost as important as getting the companies in which it invests to fall in line, said William D. Crist, president of Calpers, based in Sacramento, Calif. **********''For a very long time, the makeup of corporate boards is a subject that has been ignored, and we do believe that the issue is very important going forward into a new global economy,'' Mr. Crist said. ''The dialogue that is going on is very healthy.'' **********The dialogue promises to become even more lively should Calpers formally adopt the principles, which it is expected to do later this year. At that point, Calpers will most likely send them to perhaps 500 of the largest public companies in which it owns stock and ask for explanations about how they meet the criteria. In areas where companies come up short, Calpers will expect to hear how they plan to measure up, including offering alternative ways to meet the spirit, if not the letter, of the guidelines. **********Calpers then plans to grade the companies and publicize the results. Uncooperative companies, Calpers executives say, will be prodded with proxy votes and shareholder proposals. **********Such a strategy strikes some experts in the field as unnecessarily heavy-handed. Ira M. Millstein, a partner at Weil, Gotshal & Manges who led the commission last year that drew up governance principles for the National Association of Corporate Directors, said he had no objection to Calpers's sharing goals to which it thinks corporate America should aspire. But to then grade companies on how they measure up is not constructive, he said. **********''I don't think it's useful to put people in a bad light if they don't happen to follow what you think,'' Mr. Millstein said. **********IF nothing else, Calpers certainly has set an ambitious target for companies to meet. **********The analysis of the data compiled by Directorship showed that large numbers of companies fail some of the tests. For example, boards have for the most part purged their compensation committees of insiders because of the outcry some years back that too many executives were setting their own pay or that of their chums. Still, 77 of the 845 largest public companies that disclosed information about their compensation committee have at least one insider on the panel, which decides how well executives are paid. **********The UAL Corporation, parent of United Airlines, has two insiders on its compensation committee: Gerald Greenwald, the company's chairman, and Michael H. Glawe, chairman of United's pilot union. But John D. Kiker, a spokesman, said the company felt a need to put insiders on the committee because UAL is owned, in the main, by its employees. In addition, Mr. Greenwald routinely removes himself from committee discussions about his own compensation, Mr. Kiker said. **********Of the 140 companies that disclose information about their ethics committees, 21 have at least one insider on the panels. Disney has two insiders on its ethics committee: E. Cardon Walker and Raymond L. Watson, both former chairmen. **********With so many specific requirements -- there are 37 principles over all -- it is inevitable that many companies that have generally served their shareholders well will fail a number of the tests. **********The Calpers principles also include the recommendation that independent directors meet alone at least once a year; that the board designate a lead director when the chairman is also the chief executive and that a retiring chief executive not be allowed to continue serving on the board. **********Calpers categorizes 23 principles as ''fundamental'' and 14 as ''ideal.'' Calpers considers the age-limit proposal an ideal, which it would merely like companies to consider, as opposed to one of its fundamental criteria -- points on which it is less open to debate. **********The philosophical underpinnings of many of the guidelines are widely held notions about the wisdom of aligning the interests of board members more closely with shareholders  and otherwise making sure that boards are not too beholden to management. If there was a central message in a McKinsey & Company report from last fall that said major investors were willing to pay a premium price for companies that had good governance practices, for example, it was that directors should have a personal financial stake in running an effective board. **********Like Calpers, the commission formed last year by the National Association of Corporate Directors applauded the idea of paying directors in stock. **********One commission member, Charles Elson, a professor at the Stetson Law School in St. Petersburg, Fla., said stock ownership was the key to effective governance. Before Mr. Elson  joined the board of the Sunbeam Corporation, the company required him to buy 5,000 shares with his own money. He now owns 9,000 shares and was traveling around Mississippi last week visiting Sunbeam plants. **********''Calpers didn't tell me to do that -- my ownership led me to do that,'' he said. ''Most of this stuff makes sense.'' **********In the same vein, Russell S. Reynolds Jr., chairman of Directorship, attributes good corporate performance over the long term to ''oversight by a board of strong, independent people truly representing the long-term interests of all the shareholders.'' **********The kind of governance that is needed, however, is ''not necessarily that dictated in the recent flurry of governance guidelines,'' added Mr. Reynolds, whose firm evaluates board practices and helps recruit  directors. **********Indeed, some of Calpers's principles and what it plans to do with them have governance experts at odds over whether they would make things better or worse. **********In criticizing the proposal on age limits, Mr. Ward, editor of The Corporate Board, said that it would restrict corporate America's access to the many veteran business people who help guide fledgling companies through the difficult early years after an initial public offering. **********BUT Harvey J. Goldschmid, a professor at the Columbia University Law School, said that while  many directors remained effective after 70, age limits and term limits would be useful for companies that wanted some new and younger faces around the board-room table. **********''It solves the etiquette problem in a relatively blunt way, but for some companies, it may be the best way,'' Mr. Goldschmid said. ''It's difficult to tell directors they are no longer right for the job.'' **********The Digital Equipment Corporation, for example, has come under criticism from many investors for having five directors, more than half its board, who are at least 70, and who therefore came of age professionally well before the rise of the Internet and other milestones in the computer field. Digital has called the criticism misplaced. ''To criticize the effectiveness of anyone based on age is simply naive,'' Dan Kaferle, a Digital spokesman, said in June about the subject. **********The push to put limits on the age of board members is certainly at odds with the philosophy in countries like Britain and Japan, where gray hairs are regarded as assets for directors. The Calpers plan is more in tune with foreign practices when it comes to separating the jobs of chairman and chief executive, which companies in many other countries generally do. **********Ann Yerger, director of research for the Council of Institutional Investors, whose members include corporate, union and public pension funds like Calpers, predicted that some members would probably endorse all the Calpers principles. But, she added, a ''fair number'' of members would probably oppose at least some. **********Mr. Nash, the president of the corporate directors' association, said  Calpers had done a lot through the years to improve board performance, starting in the 1980's with its objections to, among other things, anti-takeover measures that protected incumbent managers and rewarded corporate raiders. **********But the growing scrutiny of boards may ultimately shrink the pool of capable directors, he contended. **********''Directors don't manage companies; managers manage companies,'' Mr. Nash said. ''Good directors are tired of having their reputations maligned in the public spotlight, and good people are going to say, 'I don't need this grief.' **********''I'm afraid overreaching is going to defeat the purpose,'' he added. ''And what are the next demands? I have no idea what they may be.'' **********For his part, Mr. Crist, the president of Calpers, defended the age-limit proposal as a way to guard against directors' growing too comfortable with one another. **********''Any age is arbitrary,'' Mr. Crist said. ''The point, if you do some historical research, is that a lot of corporate boards didn't replace members, and their members got older. It wasn't their age that was the problem, but that they had been talking to themselves for a very long time.'' **********MR. CRIST said Calpers would be flexible when it asks companies for report cards on how they measure up to the principles. After all, Calpers itself has reasons why it does not meet all of its criteria, including the fact that some directors have served for more than 10 years. The people who make up the membership of the California Public Employees' Retirement System do not elect all its directors -- the board also includes political appointees and officers of state agencies. **********''Moses didn't send these things down from the mountain, and we certainly don't expect all boards to toe the line precisely,'' Mr. Crist said. ''There is no simple, perfect formula. We're not in a chemistry lab here making a compound.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/28/busin.main_headline: Protecting America's shores from those Chinese crawfish.
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/28/busin.print_headline: Protecting America's shores from those Chinese crawfish.
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/28/busin.body_text: **********ANTI-DUMPING laws, remnant of an era when imports mattered little to Americans' standard of living, are intended to give domestic producers an edge over foreign rivals. And thanks to the tilted playing field, consumers pay more for everything from cement to honey. **********Few cases illustrate the point better than Louisiana's crawfish growers' suit against their Chinese competitors, likely to be decided tomorrow by the quasi-judicial United States International Trade Commission. Indeed, few so clearly make the point that the real thrust of anti-dumping laws is to limit foreign competition. ''Most anti-dumping cases are nasty,'' said Greg Rushford, publisher of the Rushford Report, a newsletter on trade policy. ''This one is super-nasty.'' **********Crawfish, freshwater crustaceans that are used in jambalaya, etouffee and all manner of other Creole dishes, used to come almost exclusively from Louisiana. Fresh whole crawfish command premium prices from local gourmets, while the frozen tail meat ends up in a thousand restaurants across the country. But since weather problems severely disrupted production in 1994 and 1995, the state has lost its market dominance. Some 80 percent of the frozen variety now come from private farmers in Jiangsu Province, China. **********Last year the Louisiana businesses that process raw crawfish persuaded the State Legislature to appropriate $350,000 to petition the Commerce Department for protection, charging that Chinese farmers were selling crawfish below cost. That might seem a bit counterproductive for the state government. ''Louisiana taxpayers are, in effect, paying a lawyer in Washington to drive up the price of their gumbo,'' Mr. Rushford noted.'' **********But it is certainly no odder than the Commerce Department's response. Because China is not a member of the World Trade Organization and is officially viewed as a ''nonmarket economy,'' the department was not required to rely on the actual cost of production to determine the ''fair'' price of crawfish grown in ponds by Chinese farmers. **********Instead, it used the cost of fish caught at sea in ''comparable'' economies with free markets -- India, Pakistan, Sri Lanka and Indonesia. Transport costs within China were estimated from a 1994 newspaper report on trucking costs in India. And for good measure, the bean counters threw in some numbers on the cost of Spanish imports of live crawfish from Portugal. **********Absurd? Of course. But legal, according to Lawrence White of New York University's Stern School of Business. ''Loony Tunes assumptions'' are built into the anti-dumping laws in order to give domestic producers maximum advantage,  said Mr. White, the former chief economist for the Justice Department's antitrust division. **********The calculations got the Commerce Department's Import Administration, which generally looks to protectionists in Congress rather than the White House for inspiration, where it wanted to go. The agency has set anti-dumping duties ranging from 85 to 201 percent of the price the Chinese charge, implying that Chinese crawfish farmers have been dumb enough to sell their product for just one-third to two-thirds of production costs. **********For the anti-dumping duties to go into effect, the International Trade Commission must also rule that Louisiana producers have been ''injured'' by Chinese sales. And while the commission is also inclined to give the benefit of the doubt to special-interest pleadings, it has historically been more willing to take the interests of consumers into account, too. **********To try to sway the commissioners, lawyers for the Chinese exporters are arguing that the anti-dumping petition was the culmination of a failed campaign by Louisiana business to run up the price of crawfish and to persuade the Chinese to cooperate in cartelizing the market. They introduced a letter from a Louisiana import company, New Phoenix/Sterling, to China's Ambassador to the United States, asking Beijing to lean on crawfish producers to limit exports to three million pounds annually. **********''As long as China is working with New Phoenix/ Sterling on the above mentioned base, Chinese crawfish can be in the market for a long time without facing the anti-dumping threat and lose the $10 million/year business,'' wrote Eugene Ji, the company's president. **********The International Trade Commission (or the courts) will have to decide whether the motives of importers are germane to the legal issue of injury. But this relatively minor trade brouhaha does neatly illustrate the core asymmetry built into America's anti-dumping laws. Ford can charge any price to grab market share from Chrysler, unless the intent is to put Chrysler out of business. But foreigners are held to a different standard -- one that puts the Commerce Department in the position of setting and enforcing minimum prices when the low-cost producer is not American. **********''The laws invite attempts to monopolize'' that would never be tolerated in a purely American industry,'' Mr. White concluded.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/20/busin.body_text: **********IPC Information Systems Inc., a maker of financial trading systems, will be acquired by Cable Systems Holding L.L.C. and its Cable Systems International Inc. unit, IPC said yesterday. IPC Information said the acquisition, which was structured as a leveraged recapitalization, was valued at $253 million, including debt. Cable Systems will purchase between 54 percent and 90 percent of IPC's outstanding shares for $21 each. Shareholders will have the option to receive $21 a share in cash or retain a portion of their equity in the recapitalized company. If Cable Systems purchases 90 percent of IPC, the total cash consideration would be $204 million. In Nasdaq trading, shares of IPC rose $1.5625, to $19.9375.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/27/busin.body_text: **********Treasury bonds rallied yesterday as the Federal Reserve entered the market as a buyer and a revised figure for gross domestic product in the second quarter showed the economy growing at a slower pace than previously reported. **********Trading was choppy with the shorter maturities outperforming the longer issues. By late in the day, the 30-year bond had gained 1 3/32  to 100 5/32 . The yield, which moves in the opposite direction of the price, dropped to 6.36 percent from 6.39 percent on Thursday. **********The Commerce Department gave its final estimate of second-quarter growth at 3.3 percent, down from the previous estimate of 3.6 percent. Another positive for the market was the University of Michigan's sentiment index for September, which showed a decrease to 106.0 from a preliminary reading of 106.8 made in midmonth. **********''In a market that continues to be dominated by a healthy dose of positive sentiment, the G.D.P. report represented pretty good news because of the small downward revision,'' said Anthony Chan, vice president and chief economist at the Banc One Investment Advisors Corporation in Columbus, Ohio. **********Reviewing the consumer index data, Mr. Chan said, ''the decline of the overall figures for September from the midmonth reading was very constructive for the market.'' He explained that ''they seemed to imply that consumption may not grow faster in the fourth quarter compared to the possibility of 3 to 3.25 percent consumption growth in the third quarter.'' **********Doug Burtnick, a fixed-income analyst at Technical Data of Boston, noted some good flows among the shorter maturities, but said the market ran into trouble trading up from lofty price levels. **********What sustained the market yesterday? Mr. Burtnick thought it might have been the purchases from small investors as they bought heavily in the short maturities, through the five-year note. ''There was also some pretty good central bank buying, in the form of a coupon pass, in both the two-year and three-year maturities,'' he said. **********In its coupon pass, the Fed bought $1.7 billion in securities maturing in two to five years, from September 1999 through August 2002. The coupon pass adds money permanently to the banking system, but does not signal any change in the central bank's monetary policy. **********''Although the Fed meets on Tuesday,'' Mr. Chan of Banc One said, ''it is quite clear that the current benign inflationary outlook is unlikely to permit policy makers to alter their current unchanged policy course. **********''However, if labor markets become even firmer and inflation begins to reveal any signs of reincarnation, I would not be surprised if they moved to conduct one more insurance tightening as early as the November meeting.'' **********The featured economic data next week will be the monthly employment report, scheduled for Friday.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/13/busin.main_headline: But This Time, Developers Are Keeping Things Simple
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/13/busin.print_headline: But This Time, Developers Are Keeping Things Simple
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/13/busin.body_text: **********They're back. The nation's real estate developers, after their crazed overbuilding in the 1980's helped ruin hundreds of banks and savings and loans, are starting to put up speculative office buildings again, breaking ground before they know who will fill most of their floors. **********The developers swear on a stack of blueprints that they will not repeat their past excesses. Instead of building sky-scraping, marble-clad, sculpture-bedecked urban spires, they are mostly constructing squat boxes, often varying in little but trim, in outlying suburbs. In other words, McOffices. **********''Underneath, it's the same building,'' one Atlanta developer, Don Childress, said without apology of the four six-story buildings he has started since he resumed office construction a year ago. **********Economic growth and new hiring are feeding the resurgence in building, but there are other reasons, too. Cost-conscious tenants like the thrifty image these surroundings convey. Though bent on squeezing more employees into less space, they often need newer buildings with more parking and the heavier utility service that technological advances demand. **********''The glamour, the grandiose styles, the palaces -- they're gone,'' said Douglas A. Tibbetts, president of the real estate arm of the Equitable Life Assurance Society, which a decade ago backed the nation's flashiest developers. ''Today, people need something that looks efficient.'' **********The resumption of office construction, though still modest, represents a turning point in a commercial real estate market that saw the worth of some buildings fall by half since the late 80's. The value of all commercial real estate now stands at $3.2 trillion. **********Office building came to a virtual standstill for several years, with a low of only 1.6 million square feet -- the equivalent of less than two 50-story buildings -- completed in the entire nation in 1994. In 1986, developers finished more space than that every five days, with most of that fifth day left for topping-out parties. In all, 139.9 million square feet of office space was completed that year, as much as if the nation's developers had built another Houston, with all its suburbs, from scratch. **********Last year, new office space was back up to 6.6 million square feet, and Cushman & Wakefield, the real estate services firm, estimates that 13 million will be completed this year, the most since 1992. **********More than three-quarters of the new buildings under construction at the end of 1996 were speculative, accounting for most of the gain, the firm reports. For much of the 90's, speculative construction essentially ceased. **********The return of building on speculation, beginning about a year and a half ago, is concentrated in -- but not confined to -- the South and Southwest. Suburban Atlanta, Phoenix and Dallas are among the hottest markets. New speculative buildings are also going up, though, in North Jersey and the suburbs of Chicago and Washington. **********About the only exceptions to the Edge City trend are a few towers planned in urban centers like Times Square in Manhattan. **********Often, the new offices are going up in metropolitan areas where the downtowns still languish and entire office towers remain shuttered and vacant. In Dallas, the downtown vacancy rate is more than 35 percent, the highest in the nation. But in the sprawling Dallas suburbs of Plano and Irving -- out where companies like E.D.S., Exxon and J. C. Penney are based -- many of the nation's largest developers and financial institutions are vying to fill the demand for more space. Tenants see the suburbs providing newer quarters, with more parking and shorter commutes. **********Nationally, rental rates have been rising as suburban vacancy rates have dropped from 21.4 percent in early 1992 to 12.9 percent at the end of last year, according to Cushman & Wakefield. Downtown office space has filled up, too, but more slowly, with vacancies falling from nearly 20 percent to 14.8 percent over the same period. **********And investors' cash is again flowing into real estate, some of it seeking havens that seem safer than a sky-scraping stock market. ''We are flush with capital,'' said Arthur J. Mirante 2d, Cushman & Wakefield's chief executive, speaking of the national trend. ''But everyone remembers what happened in the 80's.'' **********Back then, lenders pressed developers to take their money and build whatever they wanted, requiring them to put up only 5 percent of the costs, or sometimes nothing. Citicorp aimed to back the nation's top 10 developers, while Equitable financed such major builders as John C. Portman of Atlanta, the Crow family of Dallas and Donald J. Trump. **********Today, lenders demand that developers put up 20 percent of the costs. They want to see stable or rising population and employment figures and marketing studies with evidence of rental rates high enough to support new construction. They check out the reliability of contractors and architects. And then they might only do business with developers who did not default before. **********Wall Street has given hordes of individual investors the chance to buy in with real estate investment trusts, or REIT's. Some insurers are still selling off their real estate, but pension funds and REIT's are taking their places. **********Few real estate analysts or economists see any signs that another crash is imminent. Many of the savings and loans and other rash lenders are gone, and there is no prospect of the sort of tax code changes that punctured real estate values in the late 80's. Those changes undid many of the tax shelter features that had caused investors to flock to real estate earlier in the decade. **********According to Donald Ratajczak, director of the Georgia State University's Economic Forecasting Center, the long real estate cycle that bottomed out in 1992 is still on the upswing, so that any downturns at this stage will be short. **********Even so, telecommuting and corporate cost-cutting continue to constrain demand for new space. Besides, many areas still have plenty of space left over from the last binge. Some Houston buildings that were completely mothballed are only now being unlocked and leased. **********Developing offices remains a lot like playing a casino's baccarat tables, which offers plenty of cachet but the highest stakes and risks. Homes, apartments, shopping centers and warehouses have all come back first. **********To limit their risks, most developers and lenders shun overbearing high-rises that take two or three years to finish, then another few years to fully lease. Instead, they are often doing suburban structures so simple to finance and build that they might as well be inflatable. If a decade ago construction cranes towered to the upper reaches of urban skylines, this time most of them are all but hidden among suburban trees. **********Back in the 80's, Mr. Childress, a former Trammell Crow partner who founded Childress Klein Properties in Atlanta, won architectural plaudits for a Peachtree Street high-rise that featured travertine marble outside, bronze sconces and chandeliers in the lobby. **********His latest buildings, each of the same size and shape, take no more than nine months to build, so that he and his lenders, primarily the First Union and Wachovia banks, are not gambling on the market's long-term strength. **********The only stone on the facade of his Windward I building in the fringe suburb of Alpharetta, Ga., is a few narrow bands of granite around the entrance, with glass and precast concrete elsewhere. Windward II next door dispensed with the stone altogether. **********Both were started without any takers for a majority of the space, but now only a single floor in just one building is left. **********Even the few taller buildings that are going up reflect lower-rise ambitions. **********In the late 1980's, Equitable Real Estate Investment Management designed Monarch Tower, in Atlanta's Buckhead neighborhood, as a 30-story octagonal showpiece. Over the top, in more ways than one, was an illuminated dome, flanked by four smaller domes at the corners, made entirely of gleaming stainless steel, a building material even more expensive than brass. **********Finally, a few years ago, Equitable executives realized that reality had overtaken their costly plans. A different Monarch Tower was started in June 1995 and opened to its first tenants at the beginning of this year -- the first speculative project of the new wave, says Equitable, the nation's largest real estate investor. **********Instead of a 30-story octagon, the building became a 24-story box, the only flourish being 12-foot ceilings on the top floor at the request of an aluminum company's executives. **********Grant A. Grimes, the building's developer, flogs the new design the way Home Depot flogs do-it-yourself kitchen cabinets. Striding into the compact lobby, he points to some surfaces with a stucco finish and others that are nothing but whitewashed drywall. **********''In the 80's, the lobby would have huge volumes of space, massive amounts of stone -- marble, marble, marble,'' he said, waving his arms. ''They wanted that prestige. They wanted it to look horribly expensive.'' **********He lowered his arms and his voice to continue. ''In the 90's, they want it to look professional, but they don't want it to look so opulent that when they bring a client in, they say, 'I can't afford you.' '' **********When construction began, only half the space was leased, including several floors for some Equitable operations. Now, it is more than 90 percent taken, a year ahead of schedule. Equitable plans another building just across the street. **********But Equitable remains cautious in a broader sense than design. The parent company -- having, like other insurers, sold off billions in real estate -- has not put its own money in the newer projects. Though the company plans to keep much of the real estate it still has, it is discussing the sale of its real estate development, management and finance operations to the Lend Lease Corporation of Sydney, Australia. **********Some developers are even now wondering when to expect the next bust. Atlanta already faces something of an apartment glut, and developers have filed zoning requests to build millions more square feet of office space in the Buckhead area. **********''I'm absolutely a believer in the business cycle,'' Mr. Childress said, recalling that he made no profits from 1990 through mid-1993. ''When things get too good, they will be overbuilt. You have a few cows go, and then the herd starts running. It's happened all my life, so why would it change now?''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/30/busin.snippet: One Club for Art and Copy to induct Lee Clow and Jim Durfee into its Creative Hall of Fame (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/30/busin.body_text: **********The One Club for Art and Copy in New York will induct two more executives into its Creative Hall of Fame. They will join 30 members, including Leo Burnett and David Ogilvy. **********The inductees are Lee Clow, 53, chairman and chief creative officer at TBWA Chiat/Day in Venice, Calif., owned by Omnicom Group, and Jim Durfee, 69, a partner at Messner Vetere Berger McNamee Schmetterer Euro RSCG in New York, a unit of Havas Advertising. https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/17/busin.snippet: Local phone companies are stepping up advertising spending in anticipation of competition from long-distance carriers; BellSouth Mobility plans $27 million drive starring comedian Dennis Miller (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/17/busin.main_headline: BellSouth leads the way as local telephone companies step up spending on campaigns.
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/17/busin.print_headline: BellSouth leads the way as local telephone companies step up spending on campaigns.
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/17/busin.body_text: **********BELLSOUTH MOBILITY has become the latest phone company to hire a former ''Saturday Night Live'' comedian to bolster business, rolling out a $27 million advertising campaign starring Dennis Miller. **********The hip comedians have been called upon to burnish the stodgy, Ma Bell image of many phone companies and win young customers who go for cellular phones, paging services and collect calls. First David Spade and then Chris Rock hawked MCI Communications calls. Paul Reiser, the star of ''Mad About You,'' trolled for AT&T customers. And now, Mr. Miller is pitching the BellSouth Corporation, the Atlanta-based Baby Bell serving the Southeast, in addition to his work as a spokesmanfor Mars Inc.'s M&M's. **********Indeed, advertising agencies are sensing a billing bonanza as phone companies scramble for customers in the wake of Congress's overhaul of telecommunications regulations last year. Nationwide, ''you're probably seeing and feeling a more aggressive marketing posture than you've ever seen from the Bells before,'' said William C. Pate, vice president of advertising at BellSouth. **********AT&T spent $498.1 million on advertising in the first 11 months of last year, according to Competitive Media Reporting, a unit of R. C. Auletta & Company that tracks advertising spending. MCI spent $287.2 million and Sprint $236.4 million during the same period. Spending by the Baby Bells ranged from $24.2 million (U.S. West Inc.) to $60.3 million (BellSouth) during that period, Competitive Media Reporting said. **********While the advertising budgets for most of those companies were little changed from the previous year, BellSouth was an exception, raising its spending by more than 50 percent from $40.7 million in 1995. And this year, BellSouth plans to accelerate its spending to somewhere between $100 million and $150 million, mainly in the Southeast. The big outlays are a defensive move -- BellSouth wants to create loyal customers before newcomers try to steal its callers. **********''We know that the long-distance companies, when they come into the region, are going to spend a lot of money in advertising,'' Mr. Pate said. ''We are going to make sure those companies can't come in and buy our customers.'' **********BellSouth has already signed three-year sponsorship agreements with the Atlanta Braves, the Florida Marlins and a NASCAR car-racing team, which Mr. Pate called ''the things that draw Southerners.'' And it already uses a number of Southern-bred celebrities -- including Dixie Carter, Kathleen Turner and Naomi Judd -- to build loyalty. **********BellSouth is also trying to raise its stature outside of the Southeast with a year's worth of prominent ads in USA Today starting March 10. **********In its saucy ad campaign with Dennis Miller, the company is touting BellSouth Mobility, the cellular and digital calling arm of BellSouth, which has customers in Alabama, Florida, Georgia, Kentucky, Louisiana, Mississippi and Tennessee. **********The regional ad campaign was created by West Wayne Inc., the independent, Atlanta-based company formed when BellSouth's longtime advertising agency, Atlanta-based Tucker Wayne, merged with the West Group in Tampa, Fla. Three television ads began running earlier this month on prime-time shows like ''Friends,'' ''ER'' and ''Seinfeld.'' Three radio ads also began playing at the same time, and the company plans a blitz of newspaper and billboard ads across the region. **********One of the three new television commercials shows Mr. Miller in a convertible, pretending to drive along an obviously fake highway, as various backgrounds roll by. **********First cowboys on horseback gallop up to the car as Mr. Miller drives and talks on a cell phone. Then, the palm-lined boulevards of Los Angeles become the backdrop, followed by the farmlands of Minnesota. ''You are supposed to think I'm traveling cross-country,'' Mr. Miller tells viewers. ''Only BellSouth Mobility gives you a single nationwide roaming rate from sea to shining sea.'' Television and print ads use the slogan, ''BellSouth Mobility, count on it.'' **********West Wayne plans to begin showing three fresh ads with Mr. Miller in about three months. By then, even more phone company commercials will be competing on American television channels. **********''The competitive arena is growing like crazy because of deregulation,'' said Martin A. Mecdonald, executive creative director of West Wayne. Because AT&T has such a well-defined brand image, BellSouth and all the Baby Bells must show they can compete, he said, ''to make sure they don't get eaten alive.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/30/busin.snippet: Louis Cohen letter on Jonathan Fuerbringer's Mar 2 article on impact of rising value of financial assets on consumer spending (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/30/busin.body_text: **********''Are You Worth More but Enjoying It Less?'' (March 2), by Jonathan Fuerbringer, discussed the debate over the wealth effect, the theory that consumers spend more simply because the value of their financial assets has risen. The article drew varied responses from readers. **********To the Editor: **********The reason that ''wealth effect'' is not working is not so mysterious. Despite the explosion of American wealth, consumer spending is so low because business is cutting wages of employees, who spend 95 percent of their income in the consumer economy. **********In the 1990's, the dominant corporate profit strategy has been to cut labor costs, which account for two-thirds of the cost of producing products and services. This dramatically increases corporate profits, which increases stock prices. This has been done through approaches like downsizing, building an army of low-paid contingent workers, offering lower wage increases, ending cost-of-living increases, cutting health and pension benefits and outsourcing. **********In America's golden economic age, the quarter-century ending in 1973, the real wages of Americans -- including the middle class -- doubled. The secret of a successful American economy is a large, successful middle class -- because employees are also consumers. **********In another age of so-called prosperity, the 1920's, there were big increases in corporate profits but not in manufacturing employees' wages. In 1929, many people ran out of purchasing power, sales collapsed, the stock market crashed, and the country fell into the Great Depression. **********Are there any signs of this today? Absolutely. Many consumers are mired in debt  because they earn less than they spend, and personal bankruptcies are at an all-time high. **********The new explosion of wealth has had a negative effect on consumer purchasing power in the current economy. **********LOUIS COHEN **********Manhattan, March 3

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/29/world.snippet: Union Bank of Switzerland says it has duplicates of some of documents rescued from shredding by a security guard in January and that it has unearthed evidence 'possibly' related to sale of Jewish property in Berlin during Nazi era; refused for mon...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/29/world.main_headline: Latest Swiss Bank Surprise: Secrets From the Shredder
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/29/world.print_headline: Latest Swiss Bank Surprise: Secrets From the Shredder
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/29/world.body_text: **********After refusing for months to publicly discuss the content of files rescued from shredding by a security guard last winter, Switzerland's biggest bank said today that it had duplicates of some of the documents and that it had unearthed evidence ''possibly'' related to the sale of Jewish property in Berlin during the Nazi years. **********The Union Bank of Switzerland said the documents were from a small bank it acquired after the war. From the archives and from further investigation, the Union Bank said, it concluded that the smaller bank bought 31 properties in Germany, including 20 from a Swiss family and ''possibly'' 3 from Jews in the Berlin area in 1937. **********At the time, Jews faced an array of Nazi regulations forcing them to sell land and other property. The statement by the Union Bank said a German bank had acted as intermediary in those transactions. **********The disclosure was made only days after another of the country's biggest banks -- Swiss Bank Corporation -- said it had failed until recently to identify dormant accounts worth some $11 million from the Nazi era. That disclosure deepened a crisis of confidence in the banks' candor about a wartime history that critics have assailed as one of collaboration with Nazi Germany. **********On Wednesday, under growing pressure from American Jewish organizations and international investigators, Swiss banks took the unparalleled step of releasing a list of 1,756 accounts that had lain dormant since May 9, 1945 -- the day after the end of World War II in Europe. **********But when the list was published in 28 newspapers worldwide and on the Internet, it plunged the banks into new questioning, because it showed that some accounts might have been held by high-ranking Nazis and that others contained German assets that the wartime Allies had wanted handed over for postwar reparations. **********The newest disclosure had its beginnings in January when Christoph Meili, a security guard working for a private company at the Union Bank of Switzerland, came across documents being shredded in the bank's cellar and rescued some of them, which he handed over to a Jewish organization in Zurich. **********Dismissed from his job, Mr. Meili later fled to the United States, saying he felt that his life was in danger. Moves are under way in Congress to accord him and his family permanent residence rights. **********At the time, the bank declined to go into detail about the files. **********The Union Bank said at the time that the files had originated with a small bank, the Eidgenossische Bank, which was known to have had widespread business interests in Nazi Germany and which faltered at the end of the war. Union Bank of Switzerland bought it at that time. **********The bank acknowledged in January that the destruction of the files was a breach of a new law intended to preserve such files for investigation by a commission of historians. Today, it said the shredding ''was not a deliberate act on the part of the bodies responsible'' at the bank. **********The Union Bank said it had located details of 65 real estate files that Mr. Meili had saved from the shredder. It said the files had originally been held by Eidgenossische Bank. Forty-nine of them related to property maintenance, it said. **********It said it had kept duplicates of 26 of the files, and that 47 of the files rescued by Mr. Meili related to the period leading up to the end of the war, while 18 related to the postwar era. The statement said the Union Bank based its disclosures today on documents from the Eidgenossische Bank's archives and from ''additional investigations carried out at land registration offices in Germany.'' **********''In the case of three properties,'' the statement said, ''for the purpose of which a German bank in 1937 acted as intermediary and whose previous owners were possibly Jews, the minutes of the board of directors meetings and other documents are in existence.'' **********Gertrud Erismann, a spokeswoman for the Union Bank, said the bank had compiled the information it released today last March but had not released it because of official investigations relating to Mr. Meili's actions and the actions of the employee who shredded the documents. **********But with renewed attention to the issue in Switzerland, ''what we wanted to do was to really tell what's in the documents,'' Ms. Erismann said. ''We said the public has a right to know what we have.'' **********But she said the documents would not be made available for public scrutiny and would be assessed only by the historians' commission. **********Jacques Picard, a Swiss historian in Bern who is a member of the committee, said in a telephone interview that members had seen the documents and found them relevant to their investigations.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/09/busin.snippet: Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corp's plan to buy nonprofit Roger Williams Medical Center in Providence, RI, has been delayed, after state health department decides to postpone its review of the transaction (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/09/busin.body_text: **********The Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation's plan to buy a nonprofit Rhode Island hospital has been delayed, after the state health department decided to postpone its review of the transaction. **********Columbia, the nation's largest hospital chain, agreed in July to buy Roger Williams Medical Center as part of its expansion into the Northeast. Terms were not disclosed, but reports estimated the price at $41 million. **********The Providence facility would be Columbia's first hospital in the state. It already operates two surgery centers in Rhode Island. **********Columbia officials were not immediately available to comment. The state health department postponed its review of the proposed transaction until after the state's Attorney General, Jeffrey Pine, finishes his review. **********Donald Williams, the health department official overseeing the review, said the department wants to have the information from the Attorney General's review before conducting its own. **********The company, which has expanded to about 350 hospitals in 10 years mostly by acquiring nonprofit facilities, has faced increasing scrutiny from states for these transactions. The company has faced opposition in California, Michigan, Texas and Ohio as the states argue the chain is not paying enough.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/24/busin.snippet: Ralston Purina Co says that William Stiritz will step down as chief executive and names Patrick McGinnis and Patrick Mulcahy as co-chief executives to replace him (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/24/busin.main_headline: CHIEF EXECUTIVE OF RALSTON PURINA TO STEP DOWN
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/24/busin.print_headline: CHIEF EXECUTIVE OF RALSTON PURINA TO STEP DOWN
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/24/busin.body_text: **********The Ralston Purina Company said yesterday that William Stiritz would step down as chief executive and named co-chief executives to replace him in a step interpreted as a prelude to separating its battery and pet food businesses. Patrick McGinnis, who heads the company's Purina pet foods business, and Patrick Mulcahy, who heads its Energizer battery unit, will replace Mr. Stiritz, who has been chief executive since 1981. Mr. Stiritz, 62, will remain chairman after the changes become effective Oct. 1. The appointment of co-chief executives indicates the company will separate the two businesses, analysts said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/23/busin.main_headline: CONSECO IN DEAL FOR AN INSURER, WASHINGTON NATIONAL
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/23/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; CONSECO IN DEAL FOR AN INSURER, WASHINGTON NATIONAL
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/23/busin.body_text: **********Conseco Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Washington National Corporation, an insurer, for $33.25 a share, or $410 million. Conseco, based in Carmel, Ind., is a $31 billion financial-services holding company. Washington National, based in Lincolnshire, Ill., is a provider of life insurance, annuities and specialty health insurance with assets of $2.8 billion. The acquisition and the pending acquisition of the Colonial Penn Life Insurance Company are expected to give Conseco assets of $34 billion and annual premiums and revenue of $8 billion. Washington National's stock edged up 6.25 cents a share, to $32.4375, and Conseco rose 56.25 cents a share, to $47.625.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/02/busin.snippet: Internal Revenue Service, responding to stinging set of recent Senate hearings that disclosed abusive collection practices, says it will open its doors one Saturday a month so taxpayers with unresolved cases can meet face to face with agency offic...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/02/busin.main_headline: Coming Soon: Face-to-Face Help from the I.R.S.
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/02/busin.print_headline: SPENDING IT; Coming Soon: Face-to-Face Help from the I.R.S.
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/02/busin.body_text: **********LET'S say you received a notice from the Internal Revenue Service saying that you failed to pay tax on some oil-company dividends and that you owe the Government $230. You responded with a letter saying that you have never owned that stock, but the I.R.S. keeps sending bills. **********Or perhaps you own the stock and sent a check, but your I.R.S. account was never credited, or unfathomable interest or penalties were assessed. Phone calls haven't helped, and you throw up your hands. Can't someone among the 110,000 I.R.S. employees straighten out such simple mix-ups?  And can't they do so without protracted correspondence or telephone tag? **********The answer to these questions is generally yes, the I.R.S. says, at least if your case is  not too technical or too contentious. **********If you are not already the subject of a formal I.R.S. audit, and if you are just one of the hundreds of thousands of taxpayers who each year become mired in minor tax disputes that can cause emotional havoc far out of proportion to the money at stake, your friends at the I.R.S. are here to help you -- this month, in a city near you. **********Specifically, your salvation could lie with the agency's Taxpayer Advocate -- formerly called its ombudsman -- and his deputies in each district who administer the problem resolution program. **********Although this mechanism has long been in place and is used for 300,000 cases a year, it is seen by some as the agency's ''best-kept secret,'' said Lee R. Monks, the Taxpayer Advocate. **********This, however, seems certain to change. The I.R.S., responding to a stinging set of recent Senate hearings that disclosed abusive collection practices, said it would throw open its doors one Saturday a month so taxpayers with unresolved cases can meet face to face with agency officials in hopes of resolving disputes. **********The first session is scheduled for Saturday, Nov. 15, at 33 district offices staffed from 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. by officials who have a wide range of duties and expertise. The Nov. 15 sites include the district offices in Manhattan (212 436-1013), Brooklyn (718 488-3601) Newark (973 645-3886) and Hartford (860 240-4156). Thereafter, sessions will be rotated within districts (there will be one in each district each month, but the cities will change), and the hours may be modified to include, say, weekday evenings. **********Such forums are the outgrowth of a program that has sprung up in the last few years in the I.R.S. offices in Greensboro, N.C., and other cities. While the first forums were considered successful models, relatively few taxpayers showed up, perhaps, the I.R.S. says, for lack of publicity. **********This time, though, I.R.S. officials plan heavy publicity. Also, they request -- but do not insist -- that taxpayers make a telephone reservation. For other sites and reservations, taxpayers can call the I.R.S. at (800) 829-1040. **********Mr. Monks says the sessions are intended to tackle any longstanding tax problems. But he adds that he is aiming mainly to resolve cases involving uncredited payments, scrambled Social Security numbers, delayed refunds, requests for abatement of various penalties, discrepancies between returns and Form 1099's filed directly by banks and other payers, and situations in which a taxpayer faces severe hardship from impending collection. **********''We can cut through these pretty fast,'' he said, perhaps resolving a case in as little as 15 minutes. Others, of course, could take hours or may have to be resolved in other ways. **********But taxpayers should not come to sessions to ask for advice on, say, whether something is deductible or how to survive an audit. **********''This is not a day to come in and ask technical tax questions,'' Mr. Monks said. And the Taxpayer Advocate never intervenes when I.R.S. enforcers have begun a formal audit. **********Could Mr. Monks himself become a casualty of the new I.R.S. approach to taxpayer problems? Charles O. Rossotti, the new Commissioner of Internal Revenue, said during hearings in October that the Taxpayer Advocate was so important that he would select a future advocate from outside the agency to make sure the official is regarded as an independent ally of the taxpayer. **********Some tax experts have greeted the trouble-shooting sessions with what might be called skeptical enthusiasm. **********''This is something that should have begun a long time ago,'' said Richard Davis, who once worked in the chief counsel's office at the I.R.S. and is now an assistant professor of accounting at Susquehanna University in Selinsgrove, Pa. **********But he wondered about the agency's ability to bring its antiquated computer system to bear on individual cases and whether its workers would be given enough discretion to resolve disputes. No matter how good the planning, Professor Davis added, ''They're still limited by the resources they have.'' **********Gerry W. Padwe, vice president for taxation at the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants, pointed to ''continuing problems with overlapping communications'' at the I.R.S. that seem to confound the agency's most strenuous efforts. ''Before they have processed your response, the computer spits out a new notice,'' he said. **********And Claude Renshaw, professor of business at St. Mary's College in South Bend, Ind., said he doubted that the I.R.S. was capable of conducting a ''warm and fuzzy'' cut-the-red-tape program. ''I'd like to see them pull it off,'' he said. ''But up until now, they've been reluctant to do things other than through channels.'' **********But while Mr. Monks expressed confidence that the agency's computers would be able to quickly call up taxpayers' accounts and that there would be plenty of expertise and authority on hand at the Saturday sessions, he acknowledged the risk that expectations could go too high. ''We don't want to make it seem like we can work miracles,'' he said, noting that resolution does not have to mean that one side capitulates but instead can produce compromises. **********Should a taxpayer exhaust the normal remedies, there is always a last resort -- Form 911, used to apply for something called a taxpayer assistance order. Providing you can show hardship in getting necessities like food or medical care, this form would prevent the agency from getting at your pay or bank account. **********Mr. Monks said that about 32,000 people  ''dialed'' 911 each year and that about half the pleas were accepted.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/07/world.snippet: Rev Tissa Balasuriya, 72-year-old Sri Lankan priest, is excommunicated by Vatican for allegedly deviating from integrity and truth of Catholic faith; is accused of challenging such basic Roman Catholic beliefs as original sin and Immaculate Concep...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/07/world.main_headline: A Sri Lankan Priest Is Excommunicated For His 'Relativism'
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/07/world.print_headline: A Sri Lankan Priest Is Excommunicated For His 'Relativism'
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/07/world.body_text: **********The Roman Catholic Church rarely talks these days of  heresy, a verdict that carries eerie echoes of the Inquisition and ends in automatic excommunication, the harshest penalty in canon law. And so theologians took note when the Vatican's doctrinal authorities found a 72-year-old Sri Lankan priest and scholar guilty of having ''deviated from the integrity of the truth of the Catholic faith,'' and formally cast him out of the communion of the church last week. **********The harshness of the verdict promises to make the case of the Rev. Tissa Balasuriya something of a cause celebre among third-world theologians who have followed his ordeal before the Vatican authorities with both sympathy and dread. The only other public case of excommunication in recent times was against  Archbishop Marcel Lefebvre in 1988, after he continued to flout the reforms of the Second Vatican Council. **********Father Balasuriya was accused of challenging such basic Roman Catholic beliefs as original sin and the Immaculate Conception. **********Reached by telephone today in Colombo, the Sri Lankan capital, he said calls and telegrams are coming in from around the world, as well as a petition of support signed by colleagues from the Ecumenical Association of Third World Theologians. **********''They all say they will always treat me as a priest and a Catholic,'' said Father Balasuriya, who said his four-year battle with the defenders of Catholic orthodoxy has made him ''more Catholic than ever.'' **********Father Balasuriya, a member of the missionary order of the Oblates of Mary Immaculate for 51 years,  embraces views that have been labeled ''religious relativism,'' according to which no faith has a unique claim to truth, and no spiritual figure  can claim to be the only savior. **********The keepers of the faith at the Vatican have been working to put down a rising tide of ''relativism,'' recently described by one top church official as the gravest threat to dogmatic faith since Marxism. **********Father Balasuriya's defiance has set his case apart from other disputes that have pitted theologians against Joseph Cardinal Ratzinger, the formidable head of the Congregation for the Doctrine of the Faith,  which adjudicates doctrinal matters. **********The strict discipline imposed by Pope John Paul II has been exercised on the Swiss theologian Hans Kung, a professor at Tubingen University in Germany; the Rev. Charles E. Curran, who taught at Catholic University in Washington, D.C., and the school of liberation theologians from Latin America whose anti-establishment, populist views often overlapped with leftist social ideals in the 1970's and 80's. The Vatican stopped short of excommunicating Father Kung and Father Curran, and only barred them from teaching Catholic theology. **********''This is much tougher,'' Father Kung said today in a telephone interview about Father Balasuriya's case, ''perhaps because he is a third-world theologian. It is very serious for this man, and it is very unjust,  but it is the consequence of the system. This is the system as it works, and as it will work as long as Catholicism doesn't get rid of a doctrine that says that the Pope is always right.'' **********In an address to heads of doctrinal commissions from around the world in May in Guadalajara, Mexico, Cardinal Ratzinger, who is seen as Pope John Paul II's principal doctrinal watchdog, laid out the dangers of a blend of the West's secular relativism and the ''philosophical and religious intuitions of Asia, especially and surprisingly with those of the Indian subcontinent.'' **********From the marriage of those trends, he said, is born the religious relativism that is unacceptable for the Catholic Church. **********''The faith, together with its practice, either comes to us from the Lord through his church and the sacramental ministry, or it does not exist in absolute,'' Cardinal Ratzinger said. **********By excommunicating Father Balasuriya, the Vatican has sent its message in an even more forceful way. **********''They want to menace everyone else who is in this field,'' Father Kung said. ''Unfortunately it is an efficient method because now every stupid theologian in India can accuse others of defending what Father Balasuriya was saying.'' **********The case against Father Balasuriya, who is a sociologist as well as a theologian, began in 1993, when the Catholic Bishops' Conference in Sri Lanka called for an investigation into his latest book, ''Mary and Human Liberation.'' The book took a critical look at the devotion accorded  the Virgin Mary, in particular her image as a ''Mary of the capitalist, patriarchal, colonialist first world of Christendom'' whose ''perpetual virginity'' makes her ''a dehydrated figure who is not quite human.'' **********Father Balasuriya, who has been  promoting a dialogue among the island nation's religions, argued in that and other books that Christianity and Catholicism must go further to acknowledge the legitimacy of other faiths. **********He has also challenged the view that humans are born ''alienated from God,'' a challenge that his critics say contradicts the Catholic belief in original sin. **********By July 1994, the Congregation for the Doctrine of the Faith compiled an 11-page critique of Father Balasuriya's views, much of which he later dismissed as a ''misrepresentation.'' In due course, he sent off a 55-page response to which he received a one-word reply: ''Unsatisfactory.'' **********And so the exchange continued, with never, Father Balasuriya said,  an opportunity for the constructive dialogue on religious issues that he always wanted. ''There has been no face-to-face contact with the unknown officials at the congregation,'' he said in a statement issued today. **********He argued that the Vatican, halfway around the world in overwhelmingly Catholic Italy, is in no position to judge the rights and wrongs of  scholars working in multi-denominational cultures like Sri Lanka, where most people, about 69 percent, are Buddhists, about 15 percent are Hindus, and Christians and Muslims each make up less than 8 percent of the population. **********''This has raised the question of whether or not the local church should not be solving these issues, and not unknown persons in Rome, dealing in Italian,'' he said. ''Due process in the church must be clarified.'' **********Finally, in May 1996, the Vatican, clearly exasperated by the drawn-out epistolary exchange, sent Father Balasuriya a long ''profession of faith,'' which it insisted he sign ''to verify if you accept the truths'' taught by the church. Included was a paragraph explicitly acknowledging the Vatican's hard-line position against the ordination of women. **********For this and other reasons, Father Balasuriya refused to sign the specially written profession of faith, and opted instead to sign a similar one,  without the clause on women priests.  That approach was rejected by the Vatican, and after a last-minute appeal to Pope John Paul II himself, the congregation started to move slowly but inexorably toward its final judgment, officially rendered on Jan. 2 and published on Jan. 5. **********For other members of the Oblates order, the fate of Father Balasuriya has been a painful episode, pitting personal loyalties against faith. ''I love my order; the fraternal bonds are very strong,'' said the Rev. Alexandre Tache, procurator general of the order based here in Rome, ''but you have to respect the mission of the church. The Pope and the bishops have a responsibility for teaching by the Scriptures, for interpreting by tradition.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/16/world.snippet: Slovenia becomes first former Yugoslav republic to be elected to rotating seat on United Nations Security Council; others elected are Bahrain, Gambia, Brazil and Gabon (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/16/world.main_headline: U.N. Names Slovenia To Security Council
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/16/world.print_headline: U.N. Names Slovenia To Security Council
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/16/world.body_text: **********Slovenia has become the first former Yugoslav republic to be elected to a rotating seat on the Security Council. Slovenia, which joined the United Nations in 1992, will be one of three nations getting Security Council seats for the first time; the others are Bahrain and Gambia. **********Brazil and Gabon, which have served in the past, were also chosen in elections on Tuesday. **********The new members take their seats Jan. 1, replacing Chile, Egypt, Guinea-Bissau, Korea and Poland. The five other rotating members are Costa Rica, Japan, Kenya, Portugal and Sweden. Rotating members, who serve two-year terms, have no veto rights. The five permanent members, which do have veto power, are the United States, Britain, China, France and Russia.
