https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/09/busin.snippet: Indonesia asks World Bank and International Monetary Fund for help in overcoming emerging financial crisis as economic problems continue to spread through Southeast Asia; request is relatively modest one, asking two institutions to provide consult...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/09/busin.main_headline: Indonesia Asks I.M.F. and World Bank Aid
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/09/busin.print_headline: Indonesia Asks I.M.F. and World Bank Aid
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/09/busin.body_text: **********Indonesia asked the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund today for help in overcoming an emerging financial crisis as economic problems continued to spread through Southeast Asia. **********The request, for the moment, was a relatively modest one, asking the two institutions to provide consultation and assistance in stabilizing the plummeting currency, the rupiah, and reorganizing the financial industry. **********But the precise amount and form of the assistance are subject to negotiations, which will begin later this month. One possibility, proposed by Indonesia today, is that the I.M.F. could earmark a standby fund that would be intended to stabilize the Indonesian currency on world markets and ease concerns of investors and of businesses that trade with the country. Another approach would be short-term I.M.F. loans similar to those earlier to Thailand. **********In Thailand, a group of nations led by the I.M.F. put together a $17 billion bailout. The Thai currency, the baht, had been weakened by speculative attacks, and its fall of nearly 40 percent in value set off a chain reaction through the region. **********In contrast to Thailand, financial analysts continued to describe the Indonesian economy as fundamentally sound. Banks are not as overextended, debt is not as high and foreign reserves are substantial -- enough, the Government said today, to cover five months of imports. **********As recently as last month, the I.M.F. praised Indonesia for reducing spending and instituting economic changes. The spending cuts included the suspension of $13 billion in construction projects, some of them controlled by relatives of the President, and the Government affirmed today that those suspensions would remain in force. **********Although Indonesia still has about $20 billion in foreign-exchange reserves, Finance Minister Marie Muhammad said, ''In order to safeguard the situation, the Government is sounding out long-term support funds from international institutions, including the I.M.F.'' **********He said that any such assistance would be temporary, and added: ''The Government will not draw on the fund unless it is really necessary. Our approach to it will be the same as a standby loan. You only withdraw it if you need it.'' **********He also affirmed that the exchange value of the rupiah would continue to float freely but that the Government would take measures to avoid sharp drops or fluctuation. **********Today's action was a new sign of the troubles that are infecting most of the recently surging economies of the region. Currencies have plummeted, large-scale construction projects have been put on hold, stock markets are in trouble and personal spending has suddenly been scaled back in Thailand, Malaysia and the Philippines as well as Indonesia. Even the Singapore dollar, traditionally a strong and stable currency, has dipped in value. **********In Indonesia, the rupiah has fallen more than 30 percent in value against the dollar over the last two months, despite two interventions by the nation's central bank. A crisis atmosphere and talk of a possible bailout emerged after the rupiah dropped sharply over the last week. **********Indonesia's economic problems, coming five months before the expected re-election of President Suharto to a sixth five-year term, are the latest in a series of calamities there. The nation has been embarrassed by its inability to control vast, man-made forest fires that have blanketed parts of five other Asian countries with a choking smog. **********The worst drought in 50 years is parching broad areas of plantations and rice fields, bringing outbreaks of disease and causing hundreds of deaths. **********Two weeks ago, Indonesia suffered the worst air crash in its history, in which 234 were killed. Two days later, 16 people died in an earthquake. **********Economists said today that the appeal for economic assistance was aimed in good part at shoring up faith in the health and stability of the nation, the world's fourth most populous after China, India and the United States. ''This is a strategy intended to restore confidence,'' said Ng Bok Eng, a senior economist at the Daiwa Institute of Research in Jakarta. ''And it is pragmatic, realistic and achievable.'' **********The strategy, announced after a Cabinet meeting led by President Suharto, 76, included steps that appeared intended to prevent possible social unrest. ''All relevant ministers and institutions are to safeguard stocks of essential goods and to strive to maintain price stability,'' the Government said in a statement. **********Though the Indonesian economy has grown dramatically during Mr. Suharto's three-decade-plus tenure, social and economic inequalities remain sharp. If the Government does accept aid from the I.M.F., economists said, the agency could require difficult and unpopular economic measures like a cut in fuel subsidies. **********Over the last year, Indonesia has been shaken by a series of communal riots, and in a speech on Sunday, Mr. Suharto told the military to be prepared for further unrest. **********In addition to currency problems, Indonesia's economic outlook has darkened in recent months. On Tuesday, the Government announced that inflation in September had climbed to 7.1 percent, from 5.7 percent in August. **********Economists are also lowering their 1997 growth forecasts to 3 or 4 percent, down one percentage point from predictions made just a few weeks ago. **********Foreign debt by private business has also become a serious concern. Of an estimated $55 billion in private debt, at least $25 billion falls due by next summer. Economists said much of the recent fall in the rupiah had been caused by panic buying of dollars by private companies facing debt deadlines. The measures announced by the Government today did not directly address this issue.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/30/busin.snippet: Stock market rockets to its greatest gain in over five years--2.64 percent for the Dow Jones industrial average--when Employment Cost Index, key economic indicator measuring labor costs, shows no sign of inflation despite robust economy and many r...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/30/busin.main_headline: Markets Surge As Labor Costs Stay in Check
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/30/busin.print_headline: Markets Surge As Labor Costs Stay in Check
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/30/busin.body_text: **********The stock market rocketed yesterday to its greatest gain in more than five years because a key economic indicator, measuring labor costs, showed no sign of inflation despite a robust economy and many reports that skilled workers are increasingly hard to find. **********Nothing in the Employment Cost Index, the broadest measure of what employers pay for workers, suggested that rising labor costs might soon force companies to raise their prices. Wages did rise modestly, but not across the board. And outlays for benefits like health insurance and pensions were almost unchanged. **********The mild inflation report, showing a rise in employment costs of just six-tenths of 1 percent for the first quarter, took some of the steam out of the view on Wall Street that the Federal Reserve would soon feel compelled to raise interest rates again to slow the economy. **********In the bond market, interest rates fell sharply, and stock prices, which thrive on expectations of lower interest rates, shot up. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 179 points, or 2.64 percent, the largest percentage increase since Dec. 23, 1991, when it soared 3 percent. $(Page D1.$) **********''There is no question this is a better labor cost report than we had anticipated,'' said Edward McKelvey, a senior economist at Goldman,  Sachs & Company. **********For the Clinton Administration, the modest labor cost increase was unthreatening to the economy, easing off as it did from a rise of eight-tenths of a percent in the fourth quarter. ''I don't see any inflationary pressure in this report,'' said Janet L. Yellen, head of the President's Council of Economic Advisers. **********The Employment Cost Index, in effect, contradicted a different measure of labor costs that had been rising rather sharply each month since November. That measure -- average hourly earnings for production workers below the rank of supervisor -- caught the attention of Wall Street and set off alarm bells after it rose in March at an annual rate of 4 percent. The expectation was that the broader cost index, covering all workers, would finally reflect the sharply rising hourly wage measure. **********Instead, the index rose only 2.9 percent for the 12 months through March, unchanged from last year's fourth quarter, the Labor Department's Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday. The annual rate  compared with a rise of 2.8 percent in the Consumer Price Index, the best-known inflation measure, for the same period. Wages were up at an annual rate of 3.3 percent, roughly the level that prevailed through 1996. But benefit costs rose 2 percent over the last 12 months, one of the smallest increases in this decade, mostly because of so little movement in employer outlays for health insurance. **********Many Wall Street analysts had argued that employers had run out of ways to hold down health care costs, and the Employment Cost Index for the first quarter, issued yesterday, would reflect the changing circumstance. But it did not. A report issued by the General Accounting Office in February suggested that companies were still cutting back family coverage while the percent of workers covered by company plans had continued to decline. **********''If your company paid $1,000 a year ago for your health insurance,'' said Wayne Shelly, head of the division at the Bureau of Labor Statistics that compiles the Employment Cost Index, ''today it is paying $1,002.'' **********The Employment Cost Index and some other broad measures of wage increases are displaying a distinctive pattern in this seventh year of the recovery. Rather than increases across the board -- the usual pattern as unemployment fell and labor markets tightened in most previous expansions -- the biggest raises are coming at either end of the pay spectrum, with much less for the middle. **********The main beneficiaries in recent months, the data suggest, have been executives and other high-end workers and also the lowest-paid workers. The latter appears to reflect the 50-cents-an-hour increase in the minimum wage last October, to $4.75, as well as a rise in commission payments for salespeople. **********''If you are going to have an inflationary situation brought on by labor costs,'' said Alan Krueger, a Princeton labor economist and a former chief economist at the Labor Department, ''you are going to have to have wages rising for middle-income people and not just at the tails.'' **********Still, Wall Street's preoccupation with inflation could be rekindled before the week is out. Today, the Commerce Department is scheduled to issue its first report on economic growth for the first quarter. Analysts widely expect growth in the nation's gross domestic product, the total output of goods and services, to exceed 4 percent, at an annual rate, which many forecasters consider too strong to be sustained without contributing to higher inflation. And on Friday, the Bureau of Labor Statistics will report on new job creation and unemployment for April, as well as the latest monthly figure for average hourly pay. **********''What we might do,'' Mr. McKelvey, the Goldman, Sachs economist, said, ''is focus the inflation issue more sharply on what happens to economic growth rather than labor costs.'' **********For Mr. Krueger and some other labor economists, the Employment Cost Index and the median weekly wages for full-time workers -- $504 in the first quarter, up 3 percent in 12 months -- are better indicators of what is happening to wages and who is getting raises than the more popular and more rapidly rising average hourly wage for production workers. The average hourly wage statistic, they say, is distorted by overtime pay, which can drive the average higher, and by problems with the 400,000 companies surveyed to gather this statistic. **********The surveys are done by each state government and the companies they sample are not fully representative. The Labor Department, as a result, is considering changes in the way this survey is carried out. **********Productivity, the measure of how much each worker produces, also plays a role in determining when rising labor costs might force companies to raise prices. If inflation is rising at, say, 2.5 percent a year, and productivity or output is going up at 1 percent a year, as it has been in recent years, then the Employment Cost Index has to rise by more than 3.5 percent a year before employers find themselves under pressure to seek ever larger price increases. So far, it is well short of that level.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/15/busin.snippet: Auto industry is leading reversal of a European tradition of not working in August by keeping factories open or only partially shutting them down; change largely reflects growing emergence of European companies as multinational players; produced b...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/15/busin.body_text: **********Paolo Viberti, who joined Fiat, the giant Italian auto maker, in 1979, used to get August off. Fiat simply shut its big Mirafiori plant on the edge of this northern Italian industrial city. Last year, though, it kept the plant open to retool for a new sedan, the Marea, and the 40-year-old Mr. Viberti, a logistics specialist, got just two weeks off. This August is a little better. Even though the plant is partly open, he will be off three weeks. **********Mr. Viberti and his colleagues at Fiat are not the only ones who are finding themselves on the job during at least some of the dog days of August. Across Europe, there are signs that the Continent's once-sacred long summer shutdown is gradually going the way of homemade pasta and wine in the lunch pail. **********The change largely reflects the growing emergence of European companies as multinational players. Prodded by the year-round realities of the global economy, many of these companies are finding that they must keep their offices and factories operating all the time, albeit often at a slower pace. It is just one of the changes that companies are trying to make in work rules and production methods to become more competitive on the world stage. **********The shift on summer shutdowns began for the most part with car makers, but has been spreading to other industries, including electronics and food processing, that also have extensive overseas operations. **********''You have to keep producing 12 months of the year,'' said Lamberto Prati, the assistant to the president of Barilla S.p.A., the Italian group that is the world's largest pasta maker. **********Indeed, the move to a working August, while still in its early stages, is beginning to have ripple effects across the Continent. Suppliers are finding that they have to stay open, too, to keep their customers' factories humming. **********The change is also helping to transform the vacation habits of Europeans, who are moving in increasing numbers -- and often happily -- to the American-style approach of taking shorter breaks several times a year, rather than one long summer holiday. And with fewer people away in August, the pace of summer life in many company towns is picking up: instead of pulling up the sidewalks and going on their own vacations, retailers, restaurant owners and others are finding a reason to keep their businesses open. **********To be sure, despite the new pullback, a long summer break still remains a staple for millions of Europeans, as witnessed by the crowds flocking to the beaches of the Cote d'Azur in France and Italy's Adriatic coast, among others. **********Still, the change can be seen almost everywhere. East of here, in Milan, Italy's business and finance capital, the local division of Nestle, the Swiss food giant, is keeping its corporate headquarters open all summer for the first time, ending the practice of sending its 700 employees on vacation in August. In Germany, Volkswagen, which in the past shut its factories for four weeks every summer, is likewise keeping them open for the first time. **********''Everything is changing,'' Mr. Viberti said, on a coffee break between shifts at Fiat. ''Summer is now a hot time, in every sense of the word.'' **********The change is most striking in the automobile industry. Volkswagen executives say the decision to keep the company's five factories open in Germany, which in peak periods employ about 96,000 workers, is part of a strategy to create a ''breathing factory,'' in which production expands and contracts with demand, like an organism. ''Typically, you have more orders in spring, so you need the summer production,'' said Andreas Meurer, a spokesman at Volkswagen's headquarters in Wolfsburg, ''while in autumn and winter there are fewer orders. We've got strong demand now.'' **********Instead of sending workers off all at once, Volkswagen now offers a ''vacation corridor'' stretching from late June to late September in which employees can take their vacations. Rather than using the summer shutdown to retool for new models, Volkswagen will do this while production continues, Mr. Meurer said. **********Auto suppliers that never got into the habit of closing in the summer say they are delighted by the car makers' shift to year-round production, which eliminates bumps in demand. The surge that came each year when the auto industry cranked up after its summer break ''is now largely gone,'' said Ingrid Ledertheil, a spokeswoman for Dynamit Nobel Kunststoff G.m.b.H., which makes plastic components like bumpers and dashboards for the leading car makers. **********Production no longer shuts down as it once did at the big plant north of Paris where BASF, the German chemical giant, employs 1,000 people making paints for the auto industry. ''Working conditions have changed,'' said Philippe Krasnopolski, a company officer, who added that the change was forced by new manufacturing techniques. ''It's all just-in-time delivery,'' he said. **********August factory closings are occurring ''less and less in France,'' he said, though the change has not been as sharp in Italy, where BASF factories continue to close in August. **********Maurizio Magnabosco, the head of human resources at Fiat's automobile unit, says globalization is the key that has kept the doors open at his company. Fiat is a major manufacturer in South America, for example. ''Down there, it's winter,'' Mr. Magnabosco said. ''If they're working, we have to work, too.'' **********Fiat's plant near Belo Horizonte in Brazil, with a daily output of 2,600 cars, is one of the world's largest. ''It's inconceivable for that factory to be open and we here to be closed,'' he said. ''The future will move even further in this direction.'' **********As it does, it will continue to reshape the vacation habits of Europeans, many of whom seem ready for a change. ''People no longer want long vacations, but more and shorter breaks,'' said Mr. Magnabosco, a sociologist by training. **********Another change is that families are splitting up for their holidays, he said, and his own is no exception. This month, his son is visiting Ireland while his daughter will vacation in Sardinia. He and his wife will take time off later this month at their summer home on the Cote d'Azur. **********In a circular effect, the changes in vacation habits are fueling summer car sales. This month, Fiat will sell about 100,000 cars in Italy, double the number it sold in August a decade ago, as more Italians stay home and car dealerships stay open. **********Of course, not everyone is part of the movement yet. Broad swaths of European business are continuing to roll up their assembly lines this month. This year, as in years past, the German auto maker BMW closed its big factory in Munich for a month, sending 10,000 workers on vacation. In France, Renault did likewise. So widespread are the closings in France's textile industry, which provides fabric for much of European fashion, that production slumps by two-thirds in August from midwinter levels. **********In European capitals like Paris, Rome and Madrid, thousands of small stores selling everything from neckties to necklaces are closed, their owners happily sitting on Mediterranean beaches. In Rome, the closing is still so complete that newspapers publish lists of food stores that remain open to help those left behind find provisions. **********But not everyone gets to leave town. In nonmanufacturing industries, like tourism, many Europeans work longer in summer than at any time of the year. In Spain, according to estimates by Banco Santander, the largest Spanish bank, the gross domestic product during the peak tourist months of July and August is 15 percent to 20 percent higher than the yearly average. As tourists pour into Spain, bank offices remain open on Sundays to meet the demand for services. **********Even within manufacturing, the extent of summer shutdowns has always varied by industry, with car makers the most willing to close. Among major European car makers, only Mercedes-Benz, the auto division of Daimler-Benz in Germany, has never shut down in summer. With 12 factories throughout Germany, and school vacation times differing in the various regions, Mercedes says it is impossible to close down completely at any one time. **********More in the mainstream was Volkswagen's approach. In the past, at the start of the company's summer hiatus, Volkswagen chartered passenger trains to take thousands of Italian employees from its factories in Wolfsburg to their homes in Italy. Until the practice was dropped in the 1980's, when most workers had cars, the trains dropped off passengers first in northern Italy, then in Rome, and then continued on to southern ports, where the remaining workers boarded ferries to their homes on Sicily and Sardinia. **********Wolfsburg, like Fiat's Turin and other factory centers, became a ghost town as the local merchants pulled down their iron shutters and followed the car workers to the sun. Now, many of these same merchants are vying for business by boasting that they remain open all summer. In July, the big Italian supermarket chain, GS Supermercati, papered the landscape with billboards showing a fashionable young couple behind a shopping cart, and the words ''August -- a month like any other.'' **********European trade unions have generally been defenseless to stem the tide of change. At Fiat, for example, the bitter pill of shorter summer holidays was sweetened by a company pledge to hire more workers. Union resistance was also tempered by the realization that by and large  workers liked the new arrangements. Employees do not get less time off; they simply have to avoid taking it all at once in the summer. **********Marcello Crivellaro, a 30-year-old Fiat technician who does maintenance work on robots, said he would be taking only five days off in mid-August, saving most of his vacation time to visit an aunt in Argentina in November, when the weather in South America is mild. **********Mr. Viberti, the logistics specialist, said he welcomed the chance to take some time off in midwinter to pursue his great passion, skiing. **********Still, the changes are not being met with open arms everywhere. **********Asked how they were being received at Nestle, a spokesman for the company in Milan, Saverio Ripa di Meana, hesitated, then replied, ''Fairly well.'' **********''Naturally,'' he added, ''habits that you've had for 20 or 30 years are hard to give up. But it was not a coercive measure.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/28/world.snippet: Graciela Fernandez Meijide, former human rights activist, leads center-left alliance to victory against governing Peronist Party in Argentina's congressional elections; upset will make it difficult for Pres Carlos Saul Menem to continue pace of ec...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/28/world.body_text: **********The political landscape in Argentina has undergone a major transformation with the defeat of the governing Peronist Party by an alliance of opposition parties in congressional elections on Sunday. **********It was the first time in half a century that the labor-oriented political movement founded by Argentina's legendary strongman, Gen. Juan Domingo Peron, has lost a national election while in charge of the Government. **********The upset will make it difficult for President Carlos Saul Menem, whose Peronist Party lost its majority in the 257-member House of Deputies, to continue the pace of economic and social changes that have been widely applauded for producing fiscal growth and stability. **********It was also the first time that the Peronists, who have governed almost unchallenged since Mr. Menem was elected in 1989 and re-elected in 1995, have lost an election in their stronghold, the province of Buenos Aires, which accounts for about 40 percent of the electorate. **********Pollsters and political analysts said the opposition alliance, which had attacked the Government's failure to address record unemployment and rampant corruption, was well positioned to capture the presidency in 1999. **********''The overriding factor here was people's perception that this Government had been in power for a very, very long time and that it had turned a blind eye to corruption, injustice and unemployment,'' said Felipe Noguera, a political analyst for the polling company Mora, Araujo and Noguera. ''The existence of the alliance was good news for most people because it gave them a choice.'' **********Half the seats in the House of Deputies were at stake in the mid-term elections. With 98 percent of the ballots counted, the federal election board said today that the opposition alliance had won 45.8 percent of ballots cast nationwide, or 61 seats. The alliance is composed of the centrist Radical Party and the center-left Frepaso Party. **********The Peronists won 35.5 percent of the national vote, or 52 seats, losing 13 seats and their majority. The remaining lower house seats were split among minor parties. The Senate, which was not up for re-election, remains in the hands of the Peronists. **********In Buenos Aires province, the opposition captured 48.3 percent of the vote, compared with 41.3 percent for the Peronists. **********At a celebration party in downtown Buenos Aires, the leaders of the opposition alliance stood hand in hand on Sunday night presenting a unified front of victory, amid loud cheers from a large crowd. **********Clearly the heroine of the day was Graciela Fernandez Meijide, a former human rights activist who was the opposition alliance's lead congressional candidate. Mrs. Fernandez Meijide proved very popular with voters in Buenos Aires province, where she campaigned heavily on a platform of stamping out corruption and creating new jobs. **********The Menem Government has been plagued by corruption scandals in recent years, and two months ago,  Argentina's high unemployment rate of 16.1 percent led to violent protests and roadblocks across the country. **********''I want to thank every woman and man in the country who voted, even if they didn't vote for us, because whoever they voted for, they voted for justice, education and work,'' said Mrs. Fernandez Meijide, who acknowledged that she had a hard time believing the alliance had won. **********In a televised message broadcast at 9:30 P.M., President Menem conceded defeat for his party but said ''the most important victory'' of his Government was ''the existence of a strong opposition.'' He said the Peronists ''have put our country back in its rightful place'' and promised to spend his last two years in power governing with ''the same pioneering spirit.'' **********But Carlos Alvarez, a Frepaso leader who is considered the strategist behind the opposition alliance, said: ''The people no longer want a dishonest government. The age of omnipotence and arrogance is over.'' **********Until Sunday's election, Mr. Menem had control over both the Congress through his party majority,  and the judiciary through appointments. **********The biggest losers in Sunday's elections were Gov. Eduardo Duhalde of Buenos Aires and his wife,  Hilda Duhalde, who were chosen to lead the Peronist slate of congressional candidates in Buenos Aires province in direct competition with Mrs. Fernandez Meijide. **********Analysts viewed the contest in the province as a crucial test for Mr. Duhalde's quest to become the Peronist candidate for president in 1999. Mr. Duhalde, Mr. Menem's former Vice President, said that ''the father of this defeat is the Governor'' and that he would wait a few days before commenting on his political future. **********Pollsters said the elections results showed that the Peronists grossly underestimated the importance that voters had placed on issues like unemployment, corruption and a balance of power. Instead, the Peronists tried to scare voters into remaining with their party by painting dire scenarios of economic upheaval if the opposition won. **********''Those threats fell on deaf ears because we made it clear during the campaign that our economic policies would retain the stability that Argentines have enjoyed in recent years,'' said Adalberto Rodriguez Giavarini, the secretary of finance for the Buenos Aires city government, which is controlled by the Radicals. **********''One of the most pathetic things a politician can do is to ignore the cries of the people,'' he said. ''That's what the Peronists did.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/13/busin.snippet: Waverly, moderately priced home furnishings division of F Schumacher & Co, is starting campaign in effort to update its image and compete more effectively against designers like Ralph Lauren and Liz Claiborne; Lotas Minard Patton McIver to handle ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/13/busin.main_headline: F. Schumacher's Waverly is starting a campaign to update its image in home furnishings.
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/13/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; F. Schumacher's Waverly is starting a campaign to update its image in home furnishings.
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/13/busin.body_text: **********WAVERLY, the moderately priced home furnishings division of F. Schumacher & Company, is starting a campaign in an effort to update its image and compete more effectively against designers like Ralph Lauren and Liz Claiborne. **********The campaign is part of a major transformation of the 74-year-old line, which includes fabric, wallpaper, window treatments, bedding and lamps -- some produced under license. Waverly's president, Christiane Michaels, who came to the company from Westpoint Stevens in September 1996, said her goal was to ''take the wonderful name recognition Waverly had as a fabric resource and make it the premier resource for home decorating.'' **********Ms. Michaels's strategy includes modernizing and broadening product design, seeking out new licensees, redesigning packaging and store displays and increasing the number of Waverly Home stores. There are three such stores in suburban New York; two will open later this month -- in Charlotte, N.C., and Atlanta -- and another seven are scheduled to open next year. **********To promote these changes, Waverly has replaced Tarlow, Revlon's in-house ad agency, which has outside accounts and has been Waverly's agency for the last four years, with Lotas Minard Patton McIver, and it is more than doubling its advertising budget. Officials said Waverly spent $1.7 million on advertising in 1996 and a minimal amount so far this year; the budget for the new campaign is $4 million. **********The new ads will run either as single pages or in double-  and triple-page spreads starting in February in such home furnishings and life-style magazines as In Style, House & Garden, Home, Bon Appetit, Vanity Fair and People; all but In Style and House & Garden are new for the company. Ads will also appear in trade publications. **********Elegantly photographed by Oberto Gili, who photographs both fashion and home furnishings, the campaign displays two separate Waverly collections, each creating a sophisticated interior for a different room. Most ads feature one of two chic female models, chosen not only to personify each collection, but also to appeal to women, who generate 90 percent of Waverly's sales. The copy stresses the reader's ability to use Waverly products to create a unique environment, emphasizing this again in the tag line, ''Waverly, your interior design.'' Ads also list the various types of home furnishings the company makes. **********''We want to speak to female consumers instead of at them,'' said Daniel Bonini, Waverly's vice president for marketing. ''We want to tell them that they have a choice to decorate however they want to. Their home represents their personality, and Waverly can give them the resources to accomplish their goals.'' **********Waverly also hopes to use its new advertising to attract buyers younger than its traditional 34-to-55-year-old customer base, Ms. Michaels said. **********''We present an alternative to designer names,'' Ms. Michaels said, referring to ever-growing competition from clothing designers like Ralph Lauren, Tommy Hilfiger and Liz Claiborne who are migrating into home furnishings. ''Not everyone wants to decorate their home around a designer name.'' **********This is the second time that Sally Minard, a partner at Lotas Minard Patton McIver, has handled the Waverly account; she also worked on the business in the early 1980's when she was a senior vice president at Lord Geller Federico Einstein. ''It's exactly the right moment to expand Waverly's vision, to let people know it's a resource they can turn to for in-depth help,'' she said. ''There's more opportunity to make it your own.''  Several retailers that sell Waverly products echoed that assessment. **********''If you can show a person something they feel they can do, they can have, and if the product is easily accessible, then the campaign should work,'' said Neil Janovic, vice president of Janovic Plaza, a paint and wall covering merchant in Long Island City, Queens. ''They're showing a person how easy it is to bring all the products they're associated with together. This hasn't really been done before by other leaders in the wall-covering industry.'' **********Evan Cole, president of ABC Carpet and Home, the Manhattan-based home furnishings retailer that also sells Waverly products, said he applauded the company ''for going outside the envelope.'' **********''Taking the fashion point of view is a big move,'' he added. **********Roy Chefets, a senior manager in the retail consulting practice of Coopers & Lybrand, also praised the creative work of the new campaign. ''They're selling Waverly as fashion, with glamorous photographs,'' he said. ''That's how people buy things -- they dream of what they'd like to have. It's probably a fantasy, but it's nice stuff.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/04/busin.print_headline: Thais Suspend Trading In Shares of All Banks
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/04/busin.body_text: **********The Stock Exchange of Thailand suspended trading in the shares of all banks and finance companies yesterday after the Government ordered the industry to increase its reserves against bad loans. The suspension is likely to be lifted today. The move covered shares worth $29 billion, accounting for a third of the stock market's capitalization. **********The banking industry has been squeezed by high interest rates, bad debts and skittish depositors, and Thailand's central bank recently had to broker a rescue for Finance One P.L.C., the country's largest finance company. The trading suspension is the latest in a string of financial mishaps in Thailand recently, and the problems have been reflected in the benchmark SET stock market index, which has fallen more than 50 percent in the last 12 months.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/09/your-.body_text: **********Violent fires soon burn out themselves; **********Small showers last long, but sudden storms are short. **********— William Shakespeare,"Richard II." **********- **********AS HURRICANE season approaches its crest in the Caribbean, property owners are holding their breath as well as their hats. After three devastating hurricanes in the past nine years, local real estate brokers say some owners just cannot face another. **********Prospective buyers also are watching the weather. Hurricanes, like earthquakes and volcanoes, can cause real estate prices to plummet temporarily. Even the prospect of disaster can do it. **********"There are some good speculative buys right now," said Nick Bailey, managing broker at John Foster Real Estate in St. Thomas. **********Of course, most of the best deals are made after the catastrophe. In the U.S. Virgin Islands, for example, many condominiums changed ownership at fire-sale prices following Hurricane Marilyn in 1995. Houses were more robust: Local brokers reported reductions of about between 20 percent and 40 percent on homes worth between $200,000 and $500,000, less on more expensive properties and on undeveloped land. **********One thing seems certain: Return they will. "People really have very short memories," observed Michael Collins, real estate director for Fred Sands in Beverly Hills, California. After a 6.6-point earthquake struck Los Angeles in January 1994, many people fled the area, and prices in Northridge, which is situated at the center of the fault line, came down about 30 percent in six months, Mr. Collins said. "But they have recovered long since and those opportunities are now gone." **********Japanese real estate values appear less aligned to the incidence of natural disaster than in the west, perhaps because all of the country is vulnerable to earthquakes. Prices in Kobe declined after the devastating earthquake three years ago but have since performed in line with those of the country as a whole, real estate analysts at the Tokyo office of Smith Barney said. **********Prices also tend to be more stable in Europe, where Mother Nature appears to have a lighter touch than in Caribbean or Japan. The recent flooding in Germany, although described Tuesday by Chancellor Helmut Kohl as the "worst natural disaster ever faced by newly-united Germany," has not prompted a drop in prices, real estate brokers said. **********"It's easier to repair flood damage that that caused by an earthquake," Michael Creamer of Cushman & Wakefield in New York said. "All you have to deal with is a soggy house."

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/10/busin.snippet: Article on boom in buying stock options on news of split in a company's stock; photo (L)g
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/10/busin.main_headline: New Frenzy: A Split, a Beep and an Option
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/10/busin.print_headline: New Frenzy: A Split, a Beep and an Option
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/10/busin.body_text: **********CARL CZEREPAK was sitting in a barber shop last June, getting a haircut and a shave, when his beeper went off. **********The barber's phone did not work, so Mr. Czerepak rushed out to his car, not on the news of a birth or an emergency at home but on a flash bulletin from Wall Street: Caterpillar Inc. had just announced a 2-for-1 stock split. **********''I ran out with a bib on, got my cellular phone and called my broker,'' said Mr. Czerepak (pronounced SEH-re-pack), a law-enforcement officer. ''I knew Caterpillar was a blue-chip stock, so I didn't hesitate to buy.'' **********Like scores of other investors who hope to reap the rewards of the raging bull market, Mr. Czerepak has been swept up by stock split fever, the bet that once a company splits its stock, the shares will soar. **********Some academic studies have found that share prices do tend to rise on news of a stock split, though there is no clear reason they should: all a split does is take one share worth, say, $100 and turn it into two shares worth $50 each. **********Some analysts suggest that cheaper stocks are more attractive to amateur investors, who drive their prices up; others say a split is a sign that management of a company is confident about its future. Investors who have picked up on such logic from seminars, investing guides and Internet newsletters are rushing out to capitalize on it. **********The boom has created its own mini industry of advisers and seminars as well as paging services like the one Mr. Czerepak uses. And it has contributed to a surge in trading volume at securities exchanges around the country. **********But the frenzy worries some Wall Street observers, who say that stock splits are simply a meaningless division of the stock pie into smaller pieces. They fret that amateur investors are getting swept up in a speculative bubble that is bound to burst, leaving them with big losses. **********''It's a sign of the times,'' said James Grant, editor of Grant's Interest Rate Observer. ''This is a market in which pretext follows speculation, and the new pretext for speculators is that there are two shares in place of one, and that more is better than less, even though a stock split has no financial value.'' **********Adding to critics' concerns is the way many investors are playing the stock-split game -- by using call options. These options are contracts that give investors the right to buy a stock at a particular price, within a set period. They are relatively inexpensive, compared with equities, and far more volatile. And while a successful options trade can bring an investor big profits, many options become utterly worthless. **********''Of course, it is a fact that this strategy will not work forever,'' Bernard Schaeffer, president of the Investment Research Institute, wrote recently in a bulletin to his customers. He added that it is likely to end ''very, very badly for the latecomers to the game.'' **********Trading in equity options set a record in July, according to the Options Industry Council, and some of it, at least, is attributable to speculation on stock splits. **********For instance, Caterpillar announced on June 11 that it would split its stock a month later. Before the announcement, trading volume in Caterpillar options on the American Stock Exchange had averaged 927 contracts a day; but on the day of the announcement, volume hit 7,693 contracts -- an eightfold rise. **********''It's our feeling that it's happening because there are people out there with pagers,'' said Joseph B. Stefanelli, who oversees options trading at the American Stock Exchange. ''They get a call that says, 'There's been a stock split. Buy Amalgamated Garbage Pails.' '' **********In recent months, the number of investor paging services has proliferated. Among the best known are Splitalert, Splitxpress and the IQ Pager. The services can cost up to $1,500 a year. There is also an Internet site called the Right Line Split Report, which is ''devoted to the short term dramatic investment profitability of companies who have declared stock splits.'' **********Trading options, ''particularly on the split announcements, is probably the biggest thing going on Wall Street right now,'' said Kevin Tuohy, chief operating officer at Data Research Group, which runs Splitalert. **********Anthony LaPine, the chief executive at Datalink Systems, an electronic-paging company, said that in recent months Datalink received scores of calls asking for a stock-split service. In response, his company created the Splitxpress pager, which already has several hundred subscribers. He said, ''I'm led to believe that a lot of the history derives from people like Wade Cook.'' **********Indeed, the name Wade B. Cook came up repeatedly in interviews with those who use stock split pagers. Mr. Cook is an evangelizing investment guru who spreads his word through seminars, tapes and best-selling books. He is also under investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission for securities fraud, according to documents his company, the Profit Financial Corporation, filed with the agency. Mr. Cook has denied any wrongdoing. **********In a recent book, ''Wall Street Money Machine,'' Mr. Cook -- a former cab driver whose proverbs include ''God wants us to prosper'' -- has an entire chapter devoted to buying options on stock splits. He also has an Internet site that, among other things, markets his IQ Pager. And a growing number of investors are taking his advice. **********For instance, Edward Iskra of Clifton, N.J., a computer consultant, said that although trading on stock splits can be risky, he has done very well. ''I can't say I've made a mint off of it, but the returns on investment I've gotten are large versus the market.'' **********But even Mr. Cook thinks things may have gotten a little out of hand. ''Options are just the latest craze,'' he said in a telephone interview on Wednesday, adding that no more than 5 percent of investors are sophisticated enough to make what he allows can be risky trades. **********Still, earlier that day, he said, he was attending a meeting at an investment bank when his beeper sounded. Ingersoll-Rand had announced a 3-for-2 split. He tried to buy options, he said, ''but we didn't get in there in time.'' He settled for buying 1,000 shares of stock. **********It's a fast-moving market, even for those with beepers; just ask Mr. Czerepak, the law-enforcement official who had phoned his broker to buy options on Caterpillar. After less than a half-hour, Mr. Czerepak placed another call to his broker, only to find that the price of the options he owned had already risen substantially. He quickly sold them. **********''I got a hot one, and got out and made a nice profit in 20 minutes,'' he said. ''Of course, I gave the barber a nice tip.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/16/busin.snippet: Market Place: Brazilian stocks plunge 8.5 percent as nervousness about market's astronomical run-up this year edges toward desperation; analysts say three-day selloff was provoked by currency run in Philippines on July 11 and fears that Brazilian ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/16/busin.main_headline: Primed for a Selloff, Brazil Stocks Plunge on Currency Fears
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/16/busin.print_headline: Primed for a Selloff, Brazil Stocks Plunge on Currency Fears
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/16/busin.body_text: **********After pulling back sharply in the previous two sessions, Brazilian stocks plunged 8.5 percent today as nervousness about the market's astronomical run-up this year edged toward desperation. Analysts said the three-day selloff was provoked by a currency run in the Philippines on Friday and fears that the Brazilian currency could come under devaluation pressures. **********The Bovespa index of the 47 most active shares on the Sao Paulo exchange plummeted 1,081 points, to 11,617, in its steepest decline in nearly two and a half years. The drop, following declines of 3.3 percent Friday and 3.4 percent Monday, also dragged down markets in Mexico, Argentina and other Latin American countries. **********The declines were steepest in companies that had been the motor of the Bovespa's stunning 93 percent run-up this year before Friday. Most notable among them were Telebras, the telecommunications holding company whose stock had more than doubled this year, and Electrobras, the electrical utility. **********''The market here had a propensity to fall, and it was looking for a reason,'' said Maria Amalia Coutrim of Opportunity, an asset management company in Rio de Janeiro. Because the correction is so quick and steep, it could prove brief, she said, but she added that additional minor corrections would not surprise her. **********Analysts in Rio said that talk of a correction had been in the air in recent weeks, so a selloff was easily ignited. Geoffrey Dennis -- the strategist in emerging markets for HSBC James Capel, which had cautioned in mid-June that Brazil's market was ''vulnerable to bad news'' -- said in a phone interview from London today that talk of a devaluation was a wild card that could make the correction more serious than originally foreseen. **********''Whether this turns into a major crash very much depends on whether it turns into a currency crisis,'' he said. ''If this is just profit taking against a background of high prices, it will blow itself out relatively quickly and people should start buying back relatively soon. If it turns into a currency crisis, the market will have significant downside,'' with declines of 30 to 50 percent. **********Mr. Dennis said the ''currency contagion'' that forced Thailand to float its currency on July 2, with the Philippines following on Friday and Malaysia on Monday, could exert pressure for a devaluation in Brazil, though he put the odds of a move at ''less than 50-50.'' **********The analyst said part of the reason he believed Brazil might avoid a crisis was the country's $59 billion in foreign reserves. Also, because the Brazilian currency, the real, moves within an exchange rate band that gradually decreases its value by 7 percent a year, the Government has the flexibility to speed up the adjustment without floating the currency. **********Perhaps most important, President Fernando Henrique Cardoso, whose political popularity is based on his success in slaying hyperinflation, is likely to do everything feasible to avoid a large devaluation that could lead to inflationary pressures and a loss of investor confidence as he mounts his re-election campaign.  The real is now worth $1.07 -- down 7 percent in the last 12 months. **********John Mullin, Latin American equity strategist for Salomon Brothers, said the fundamentals that had made Brazil an attractive investment market would still be there after a correction. Those factors include a huge, modernizing economy with pent-up internal demand in areas like telecommunications and, thus, plenty of room for growth. **********Such considerations made Brazilian stocks one of the best buys of the first half of 1997. The Morgan Stanley Capital International Emerging Markets Index, which covers a broader basket of stocks than the Bovespa index, shows the Brazilian market with a rise of 60.3 percent this year through Friday, the world's third-best performance, after Russian stocks, which soared 151 percent, and Turkish stocks, up 60.5 percent. Elsewhere, stocks rose 59.4 percent in Hungary; 41.5 percent in Mexico; 38.7 percent in India; 31.6 percent in Taiwan; 12.2 percent in Korea; 7 percent in Hong Kong, and 2 percent in Indonesia. Thai stocks were an exception, plunging 32 percent. In the United States, leading  stock indexes rose about 23 percent over the period. **********In Brazil, industrial growth from January to May was up to 5 percent, towering over the 1.4 percent growth for all of 1996. ''Any selloff will be contained,'' Mr. Mullin predicted. **********But perhaps Salomon has been too optimistic. At the start of trading today, the firm advised buying Ericsson Telecomunicacoes. The company, a maker of telecommunications equipment affiliated with Ericsson of Sweden, had fallen by 22 percent since Friday; by day's end, it was down another 10 percent. **********A handful of Brazilian companies, like Aracruz Cellulose, Brahma, Telebras and Electrobras, trade as American depository receipts on the New York Stock Exchange. Buyers of the A.D.R.'s of Telebras, for example, paid $48 when they were first listed on the Big Board in November 1995 and have done quite well for themselves; the A.D.R.'s peaked at $169.25 last Wednesday. Today, they fell $11.25, to $135. **********But most Brazilian stocks can be acquired only by institutional investors or investors with accounts in Brazil -- and analysts warn that some of these can take time to sell. Some analysts here, like Ms. Coutrim, expect foreign investors to cash in some Brazilian holdings while they can still make a profit and move their money to Mexico. **********''In terms of fresh money, we think Mexico is more appealing than Brazil, and expect it to be the leadership for the rest of the year,'' said Jay Pelosky, Morgan Stanley's Latin American strategist. **********While the firm remains impressed with Brazil, and is interested in the second tier of closely held companies, the Mexican market promises more growth now, he said. **********Morgan Stanley just raised its forecasts for economic growth in Mexico this year to 5.2 percent from 4.3 percent. Mr. Pelosky also said the recent elections there were encouraging. ''Mexico's economy is clearly picking up steam,'' he said.
