https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/28/world.snippet: Informal survey of opinion across the country tends to support finding of public-opinion researchers that ordinary Americans are very interested in international issues that they believe directly affect their lives, including immigration and trade...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/28/world.main_headline: On Foreign Affairs, U.S. Public Is Nontraditional
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/28/world.print_headline: On Foreign Affairs, U.S. Public Is Nontraditional
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/28/world.body_text: **********In Omaha, Ronna Elmborg, a part-time waitress who relies on television to tell her what is happening outside the United States, says that she follows international news ''because eventually it will all affect us.'' Take Iraq, she said, ''That could affect us in a real hurry.'' **********In Seattle, Greg Lulay, waiting for a bus in front of Kinko's on Broadway, said he was all for paying America's debt to the United Nations not only to support the United Nations and its views of what should be done in the world ''but as an example to other nations.'' **********In Harlington, Tex., Tom Kimbriel, a police sergeant, wants to see the United States become a stronger player in international affairs. ''We were granted the power, and its our responsibility to see that the neighborhood bully doesn't take on the kid with the glasses,'' he said. ''To argue that what goes on in other countries doesn't affect the United States is very childish. Just look at what we pay for a barrel of oil.'' **********Around the United States, an informal sampling of the attitudes of people far from the centers of foreign policy-making tends to support what some public-opinion researchers have been finding: That although a declining number of Americans say they follow foreign affairs, this might be a question of definition. Actually, the researchers are finding, even ordinary Americans who ignore many military or political developments in remote parts of the world are very interested in other international issues that they believe directly affect their lives. **********Those include immigration and trade negotiations that could have an effect on their jobs or taxes, environmental issues like global warming, health threats, and drug-trafficking and other cross-border crime. They are less likely to include foreign political or military developments. **********The researchers are also finding a persistent or even widening gap between the opinions of the general public and those of the people who make, think or write about foreign policy. **********For example, the general public seems to support the United Nations and United States cooperation with other countries in times of crisis -- rather than solitary action by Washington playing the role of the world's police force. That attitude differs markedly from those of opinion leaders and policy-makers, especially in Congress. **********Two polls this fall -- one by the Washington-based Pew Research Center for the People and the Press (formerly the Times Mirror Center) and the other by the University of Maryland's Program on International Policy Attitudes reached different conclusions about the level of public interest in international events. The Pew poll concluded that Americans did not see events abroad having great effect on their lives. Polls by the University of Maryland have shown greater public concern. Both, though, found gaps between the general public's perceptions and those of opinion leaders. **********The Pew poll -- which sampled foreign-affairs experts, journalists, scholars, scientists, religious leaders, governors, mayors, Congressional aides, business executives and labor leaders and measured their views against those of the general public -- found that ''American opinion leaders see the world as a better place, where U.S. influence is enhanced.'' **********''In striking contrast,'' the poll report said, ''the American public's global view remains bleak.'' The report, ''American's Place in the World II,'' finds that opinion leaders are more assertive about American power. Only 27 percent of those polled preferred to see the United States share power equally with other major countries. But 50 percent of members of the general public polled favored an equal spread of power. **********At the independent United Nations Association of the United States, Jeffrey Laurenti, executive director of policy studies, said that this gap has been apparent for some time. A poll his organization commissioned after the 1995 Dayton peace accords, which ended the fighting in Bosnia --  when leading policy-makers were heaping abuse on the United Nations in Bosnia and had agreed on the intervention of NATO -- indicated that ''by far the largest segment plunked down for a U.N. peacekeeping force with American troops rather than a NATO operation or no response at all.'' **********In the 1997 University of Maryland survey, 74 percent of those polled said they wanted the United States to share power internationally, compared with 13 percent who prefer a pre-eminent American role in the world. **********''Support for the U.N. is higher than support for NATO,'' said Steven Kull, director of the Maryland Program on International Policy Attitudes. **********Mr. Kull believes that those in  power frequently underrate, misjudge or misuse public opinion. **********''Something the policy-makers do not understand is how idealistic the public still is,'' he said. ''When a member of Congress says, ''I'm an internationalist, I'm supportive, but my public doesn't understand it so I have to go along with them -- that is a misperception.'' **********How foreign affairs are defined makes a difference, researchers say. **********The Maryland poll, and independent polling done for the United Nations Association, a private research and support group with chapters around the country, have found that Americans are less moved by abstract concepts like ''national interests'' -- a phrase often used by those in power -- and want more attention given to global social and humanitarian issues that they might not always  describe as ''foreign affairs.'' **********Surveys find a high level of public interest in environmental destruction, health menaces that cross borders, illegal drugs, international crime and the loss of jobs to low-wage countries. **********With Congress in Washington on the verge of bankrupting the United Nations by withholding $1.5 billion in overdue assessments -- or even withdrawing from it, a measure that garnered 54 votes in the House this year, though 369 voted against it -- polls indicate that the American public has significantly more support for  the United Nations than does Congress. **********Andrew Kohut, director of the Pew center, whose poll found less concern about foreign affairs than other polls have indicated, nonetheless agrees that Americans are not hostile to the United Nations. **********''I think there is a really strong base of support for the U.N.,'' he said in an interview. In his latest poll, 64 percent of Americans polled -- opinion leaders and the general public combined -- gave the United Nations a favorable rating, although this has slipped from 74 percent in 1993, two years after the end of the Persian Gulf war. **********''Public interest in international news stories has plummeted over a decade,'' said Mr. Kohut, with the percentage of people who said they followed foreign news dropping from 80 percent in the 1980's to 20 percent in 1997. The decline was most precipitous among young people, he said. But he added that opinion surveys find that what turns them off are traditional categories of foreign news as international politics, security, war and peace. **********Mr. Kohut says that news organizations bear a share of the responsibility for driving people away. Most people receive foreign news from  television, which is carrying less of it, and what there is may be largely pictorial or pitched to strategic or military issues. **********''As the news hole for international news shrinks,'' he said, ''the proportion of conflict-driven stories increases. People say, 'How can one keep all these wars straight?' '' **********''If you look at what American people say are high priority issues to them with regard to foreign policy, it is consistently those things which have some apparent or clear relevance to their lives,'' he said. ''Jobs comes up to the top of the list. The spread of nuclear weapons is very high -- the only traditional security problem that's way up there. **********''Things like combating international drug-trafficking, insuring an adequate energy supply, improving the global environment -- these are issues that people feel affect not only the country, but affect them in their communities,'' Mr. Kohut said. **********''They have a hard time dealing with issues like 'What is the relevance of failed states, in Africa, in Bosnia?' '' he said. ''But when the American public sees the relevance of an issue such as global environmental concerns or nuclear proliferation, they are as engaged as the members of the Council on Foreign Relations.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/21/busin.snippet: Annual Burning Man festival will be held in Nevada's Black Rock Desert on Labor Day weekend; festival is paean to state of being that can be found in precincts of cyberspace, which libertarian celebrants hail for its invented identities in multi-u...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/21/busin.main_headline: Digerati are unlikely celebrants of a primitivist conflagration in the Nevada desert.
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/21/busin.print_headline: Digerati are unlikely celebrants of a primitivist conflagration in the Nevada desert.
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/21/busin.body_text: **********A NAKED couple poses on the baked desert plain, wearing black net face masks, goggles and snorkels. A bald man in blue lipstick wears a baby dress and carries a pinwheel. A man squats in ersatz tribal gear complete with a stick through his nose. Celebrants like these have come to a five-day festival in Nevada's Black Rock Desert that takes place annually on Labor Day weekend with 115-degree temperatures, parched earth and ritualistic spectacle (last year about 10,000 people arrived). **********At their center is a five-story high statue of a man, constructed of wood and lighted with neon. On the final night, the statue is set ablaze as celebrants dance in painted skin and loincloths and scream in ecstasy. **********The festival is called Burning Man and in preparation for this summer it is being commemorated in a new book containing devotional essays and photos of elaborate revelry. But despite the mock primitivism of the festival, the book is being published by Hardwired, a label usually more preoccupied with Web-ites than Luddites. And the festival itself has a promotional and inspirational World Wide Web site that is heating up in anticipation of this year's event (http://www.burningman.com). In fact, the Internet seems an unusually comfortable home for Burning Man devotees. Anthologies of sites (http:/ /www.yahoo.com/regional/u-s-states/nevada/art/burning-man-festival) have been posted; regular participants in the festival provide links to photos and archives (http:// www.nepenthes.com/Burning/burning.html) and the eyewitness accounts are provided by the alternative press (http://www.phoenixnewtimes.com/1996/091296/news1.html) as well as mainstream newspapers (http://www.sjmercury.com/west/ brnmn929.htm). **********What's going on here? After all, primal screams are usually prompted by something other than the hunger for more bandwidth, and cultic conflagrations seem to have little to do with the languages of programming like HTML and Java. Yet the association is unmistakable. Kevin Kelly, a founder of Wired magazine, has called Burning Man ''the holiday of choice for the digerati.'' Among its motorcycle freaks, urban dropouts and thrill seekers, are media professionals and technology cultists. **********Is this a form of technological slumming? An escape from venture capitalists? A novel approach to  brainstorming? **********Atavistic reactions to new technologies are not that unusual. And sometimes they seem to be in homage to otherworldly forces like the ones summoned by advanced technology. As Arthur C. Clarke once famously put it, any technology sufficiently advanced is indistinguishable from magic. Technology worship can become a form of religion. **********Some of that is surely latent in contemporary cyber-devotion; it even seeps into another book about technological communities, ''A World's Fair,'' coming in September from the MIT Press, in which Carl Malamud gives an account of his creation of an Internet-based international exhibition of sites in 1996. He reminds us of the technological temple of the first World Exhibition in London in 1851: the Crystal Palace, an extraordinary invention, covered with the largest roof ever built, its 293,655 panes of glass revealing a massive assemblage of every machine ever invented. **********Now technology worship may just be taking a slightly weirder form. One cannot look at the costumes in the new book, the painted bodies, or the elaborately bedecked cars with their Mad Max design, without thinking of machinery. People are on display, showing what they can make of themselves, proclaiming their liberation from constraints, declaring a new kind of social technology in which anything can be done or made. Technology has been displaced from metal to flesh; perhaps it is even celebrated in flame. **********This was not the original intention. The festival began in 1986 when Larry Harvey, the Burning Man impresario, held a miniature gathering on a California beach to burn a human effigy. In following years, word got around, crowds accumulated, fire marshals got upset and the festival migrated to the remote desert, where each year attendance has more than doubled. **********In the desert, the impromptu festival became a full-scale countercultural declaration of independence. ''The essence of the desert,'' says Mr. Harvey, ''is that you are free to create your own world, your own visionary reality.'' It provided a social blank slate. Mr. Kelly finds a ''deep parallel between desert and cyberspace.'' **********That idea has had much resonance. This is not really a festival like Woodstock, which was partly a Romantic paean to the natural world. At Burning Man, nature is an opponent, with unforgiving windstorms, dust, lightning, heat and drought. The festival's Web site almost boasts of the spiked branches, snakes and quicksand. Instead the paean is to technological artifice and invented identities. The paean, in fact, is to a state of being that can be found in the precincts of cyberspace, which libertarian celebrants hail for its invented identities in multi-user domains, or M.U.D.'s, and chat rooms, its sexual license and lack of restrictions, its virtual communities and fantasy games. In Mr. Harvey's words, ''Both Burning Man and the Internet make it possible to regather the tribe of mankind.'' **********Perhaps. But there also may be opposing forces at work in Burning Man; this homage is also a rejection. Technology may be celebrated, but Mr. Harvey hints that Burning Man also satisfies a religious desire that technology cannot sate. Burning Man helps reveal technology's limits. It may even be partly an exorcism. The Burning Man is Technological Man, worshiped and destroyed, a robot demolished by its masters before being rebuilt again. **********This year, the festival itself will also start to reveal the limitations it once denied. With the prospect of more than 10,000 celebrants, Mr. Harvey writes on his Web site, ''it's time to assume more responsibility for what we are.'' A ''higher level of commitment'' from participants is needed. Admission will be $75 and the celebration will be held on private property. Speeding cars will be controlled. A fee will be charged to limit access to the local hot springs. **********The libertarian spirit, organizers promise, will remain intact. But it may be that at Burning Man, as in  cyberspace, and as with technology, limitations are inseparable from possibilities, absolute freedom is an illusion, and there is never a blank slate even in the desert.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/30/busin.snippet: European Commission declares that Spanish Government has no legal right to pass law that essentially outlaws satellite digital television service owned by Madrid-based Grupo Prisa and Canal Plus of France; Spanish Government had organized rival co...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/30/busin.body_text: **********The European Commission dealt a blow to the Spanish Government last week, declaring that it had no legal right to pass a law that essentially outlawed a satellite digital television service owned by Madrid-based Grupo Prisa and Canal Plus of France. **********The ruling is a significant turning point in one of the nastiest political battles over advanced television in Europe. On May 17, the center-right Government under Jose Maria Aznar pushed a law through Parliament that outlawed the decoder and transmission system used by Canalsatellite, which debuted in February. **********The Spanish Government has organized a rival consortium called Via Digital, which has yet to start broadcasting. The alliance is owned primarily by Spanish telephone company, Telefonica, along with its largest Government-owned television network, Television Espanola, and the Mexican media conglomerate Televisa. The new law requires that all digital television ventures use a system called ''multicrypt,'' which Telefonica supports and is incompatible with Canalsatellite's system. **********''The Spanish law violates fundamental treaty rules on free movement of goods and freedom to provide services,'' the commission said, announcing its intention to open legal proceedings against the Spanish Government, which has two weeks to change the law before the commission, the executive arm of the European Union, takes the issue to the European Court in Luxembourg.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/18/world.snippet: Hopes for breakthrough in crisis in Cyprus have faded since Greek Cypriot Government announced plans to buy antiaircraft missiles and Turkey, protector of Turkish part of island, threatened to react militarily if missiles were deployed; some polit...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/18/world.main_headline: On Divided Isle of Cyprus, Missile Deal Widens Rift
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/18/world.print_headline: On Divided Isle of Cyprus, Missile Deal Widens Rift
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/18/world.body_text: **********When the Greek Cypriot Government announced on Jan. 4 that it was going ahead with a $426 million purchase of antiaircraft missiles from Russia, it raised tensions over the long-running crisis on this divided island. **********The missile contract, seen as a dangerous leap in an already overheated regional arms race, drew strong negative reaction abroad. But the most alarming reaction came when Turkey -- the protector of the Turkish part of the island -- said it would react militarily if the sophisticated S-300 missiles were deployed. **********Despite a hurried tour by a top United States diplomat, and pledges by the Government that it would wait 16 months before receiving any missile components, the mood remains uneasy. People on both sides of the buffer zone between the Greek and Turkish populations ask glumly what  happened to hopes for a breakthrough in the crisis. **********''The missiles have increased tensions,'' said Gustave Feissel, chief of the United Nations mission that monitors the buffer zone. ''And the message that they drive home is that the status quo here is unstable, untenable -- and, unless it is fixed, it is going to get worse.'' **********Some political analysts worry that stoking tensions was in fact the aim of the Greek Cypriot Government, an indication of its increasing impatience with efforts to resolve a standoff that has existed since 1974. In that year Turkish troops, reacting to a coup on Cyprus engineered by the Greek junta, invaded the island and partitioned its northern third with 35,000 troops. **********Today the Greek Cypriot population makes up 78 percent of the 730,000 residents. The Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus, which declared independence in 1983, is recognized only by Turkey. **********''We are convinced that time is running out for the Cyprus problem, after 23 years of so many initiatives and no results,'' said the Greek Cypriot Foreign Minister, Alexandros P. Michaelides. ''What has happened in the last year is a fear that the situation in Cyprus could become explosive,'' he said, adding that with the missile system, the Government, aided by Greece, could defend itself. **********Few share this view, noting instead that arming Cyprus with such missiles is mainly a challenge to Turkey. More important, the Greek Cypriots have raised the old fear of Greek dominance that has plagued Cyprus since its independence from Britain in 1960. **********''The missiles were a big mistake,'' said Mustafa Akinci, leader of the Communal Liberation Party, a small leftist party on the Turkish side. ''We wanted to hope that the leaders would sit down and find a solution to the Cyprus problem. But you can't find it with an arms race.'' **********Despite last summer's violence along the 110-mile buffer zone, when Turkish border guards killed two Greek Cypriot demonstrators, there were hopes that Greek and Turkish Cypriots could be persuaded to start the kind of intense negotiations that have brought political settlements in the Middle East. **********A key element is the approaching deadline for talks with the European Union over the admission of Cyprus as an associate member. These talks, which are to start early next year, require a resolution of Cyprus's future -- either as a federated country or as two states, forever divided by a tenuous peace. **********The Turkish Cypriot president, Rauf Denktash, has objected strenuously to the Greek Cypriots' efforts to join the European Union. ''Any entry into the European Union unilaterally destroys equality between us,'' he said, ''and then we would be finished here.'' **********The outlines for a settlement exist, in a 1992 formula that would reunite the communities in a federation backed by security guarantees. **********After the visit here by the American envoy, Carey Cavanaugh, diplomats hope for some progress on narrow confidence-building measures, including a halt to overflights by Greek and Turkish aircraft and a United Nations proposal to reduce tension along the buffer zone. **********Mr. Michaelides, the Foreign Minister, also said he expects another American approach in March, perhaps proposals for a stronger multinational security force. **********''Both sides will tell you that the overall elements for a settlement are on the table,'' said Mr. Feissel of the United Nations. ''What has been lacking is the political will to do it.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/22/busin.snippet: Indonesia, the world's fourth most populous nation and one of the heavyweight economies of Southeast Asia, has been affected by the financial crisis that began with the currency turmoil in Thailand more than three months ago. J. Soedradjat Djiwand...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/22/busin.main_headline: Q&A/ J. Soedradjat Djiwandono : A Banker Draws Lessons From Turmoil in Asia
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/22/busin.print_headline: Q&A/ J. Soedradjat Djiwandono : A Banker Draws Lessons From Turmoil in Asia
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/22/busin.body_text: **********Indonesia, the world's fourth most populous nation and one of the heavyweight economies of Southeast Asia, has been affected by the financial crisis that began with the currency turmoil in Thailand more than three months ago. J. Soedradjat Djiwandono, governor of Bank Indonesia, the central bank, talked in Hong Kong about the lessons of the crisis and his plans to beef up his country's banking supervision with Alan Friedman of the International Herald Tribune. **********Q. Since Thailand faced its crisis in the summer, your own currency has also suffered along with those of neighboring nations, and investor confidence has been shattered. What are the lessons of the financial turmoil? **********A. First of all, we realized that we are really living in the globalized economy. Before, we had only talked about it, but now it is here. When you accept the benefits of globalization, you take it for granted. Yet we only realized the risks of crisis when it happened. When you are hit by crisis it can be indiscriminate, and there is contagion. **********Maybe we in the region have all been a little bit prodigal, living beyond our means. The other lesson from what has happened is that everyone can see that economic growth cannot be sustained unless the banking sector is also sound. **********Q. Is it fair to put Indonesia in the same category with Thailand? **********A. We are all Asian neighbors, and we want to follow a good-neighbor policy. **********Q. All right, let's talk about a neighbor. Prime Minister Mahathir bin Mohamad has been attacking currency speculators as "rogues" and "criminals," and he has attacked George Soros in particular for the region's problems. Do you agree with the Malaysian prime minister's views? **********A. I don't really know who was behind the speculation, but it doesn't matter who triggers it. **********Once it happens, the players come from a variety of places, including local corporate groups that have high offshore-loan exposure and need foreign exchange to import and who sell the rupiah. There are also foreign speculators. We cannot say if the problems came from domestic or international sources. **********Q. So you wouldn't describe currency speculators as criminals? **********A. No. **********Q. There has been much talk in Bangkok and here in Hong Kong about the idea of setting up a new ASEAN rescue fund in case of financial crises. Are you in favor of this idea? **********A. This is in a preliminary stage of discussion, and in my view, surveillance would have to be part of it. You cannot just put money in without conditionality. **********Q. Your country has been praised by investors for a more market-oriented response to the crisis than Thailand's. You removed limits on majority ownership of shares by foreign investors, and you have let your currency, the rupiah, float. But Indonesia is also criticized for having let its banking system grow much too fast. How do you react to the criticism? **********A. It is true that we have so many banks, some 239 of them, which in terms of total numbers means Indonesia is overbanked. But our country is very big, and so when you look at the spread of our country, we are not overbanked. **********Q. But what steps are you taking to improve the banking system? **********A. We are making efforts on supervision. We are increasing the number of supervisory personnel. We are trying to follow the internationally accepted capital-adequacy ratios, and we want to increase it. If banks cannot meet this or reserve requirements, then they will have to be merged or acquired. **********Q. What about problem loans? How big are they? **********A. Our bad debts and nonperforming loans total 9 trillion rupiah, or around $3.3 billion, about 9 percent of total lending. **********Q. But some banks have much bigger problems than 9 percent. What do you propose to do? **********A. They will have to be merged, and if necessary in some cases we will have to liquidate some banks. **********Q. And what are your aims in the coming weeks and months? **********A. When the trouble started, we raised our one-month interest rates from 14 percent to as high as 30 percent. Now they are back to 24 percent, and we have plans to reduce rates further, toward a level of around 17 or 18 percent. We also have imposed some restrictions on foreign exchange trading, and we hope these measures will be only temporary. **********Q. There have been reports that one of your deputies treated foreign banks such as the Bank of America and Deutsche Bank very harshly, asking Deutsche Bank to stop engaging in swap deals and telling Bank of America to stop making a market in currencies out of Jakarta. What is your comment? **********A. I think this is bizarre reporting. The fact that we asked foreign banks to come in and meet with us is part of our practice. The rest is untrue.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/24/busin.snippet: Sega Enterprises says it will buy Bandai Co Ltd in stock swap valued around $1 billion, creating world's biggest toy and video-game company; new company will be called Sega Bandai; it will have $6 billion in revenue, with operations ranging from S...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/24/busin.main_headline: Sega to Acquire Bandai, Creating Toy-Video Giant
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/24/busin.print_headline: Sega to Acquire Bandai, Creating Toy-Video Giant
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/24/busin.body_text: **********Sega Enterprises, the Japanese video game maker, said today that it would buy the Bandai Company Ltd., the Japanese toy company famous for the Power Rangers, in a stock swap valued around $1 billion, creating the world's biggest toy and video-game company. **********The new company, to be called Sega Bandai, would have about $6 billion in revenue, more than Nintendo, Mattel or Hasbro. Its operations would range from Sega's video arcades, miniature theme parks and home video-game machines to Bandai's Sailor Moon dolls, and its music and video entertainment divisions. **********But Sega Bandai would be the product of two troubled companies, both suffering declining sales and profit and increased competition. The move can be seen as part of a consolidation in the world toy and game business. And while mergers like this are somewhat rare in Japan, the presidents of the two companies are considered relatively Western-style managers. **********Three years ago, when American children could not get enough of the Power Ranger action figures and Sega was giving Nintendo a run for its money, the presidents of Bandai and Sega dreamed of growing beyond toys and games into multimedia and entertainment, of becoming the next Disney. **********But Bandai announced last week that it would lose money this fiscal year, as Power Ranger sales have fallen and its new Pippin machine for browsing the Internet has been disappointing. **********Sega is now falling to a weak third in the home video-game business, behind Sony and a resurgent Nintendo, and its earnings are plunging because of write-downs of inventory at Sega of America. So, both companies will try to become an entertainment giant together. **********Hayao Nakayama, president of Sega, said that the companies' businesses overlapped 30 percent and that the rest of the businesses would complement each other. ''We are really oriented toward technology,'' he said. ''But Bandai has logistics power and marketing power. They are very good at developing cute merchandise. The low-tech and high-tech combination is very good.'' **********The two companies, he said, would combine distribution to save money. Bandai, which is Japan's largest toy company and third in the world behind Mattel and Hasbro, can help make toys of Sega characters like Sonic the Hedgehog while Sega could make games of Bandai characters. **********But some said they did not see the logic behind the merger. ''I am surprised,'' said Nobuyuki Idei, president of the Sony Corporation, which has had its own bad experience with mergers as it tried to become an entertainment company. ''I still cannot find a reason'' they decided to merge, he said. **********Reinier Dobbelmann, an analyst with SBC Warburg Securities in Tokyo, said merging would not solve Bandai's and Sega's problems. ''The overall strategic picture stays doubtful,'' he said. ''There are theoretical synergies, but execution counts. And both companies have big ideas, but they don't carry them out.'' **********Under the agreement, announced today after the market closed here, Sega stockholders will receive 0.76 share of Sega Bandai for each share they own. Bandai stockholders will receive one share of the new company for each Bandai share they own. **********Bandai closed today at 2,560 yen, up 200 yen; Sega closed at 3,660, down 60. At those prices, the merger is worth roughly 129 billion yen -- a little more than $1 billion. **********Makoto Yamashina, president of Bandai, will become president of the new company. Mr. Nakayama of Sega will be vice chairman and chief executive. The chairman will be Isao Ohkawa, current chairman of Sega and head of the CSK Corporation, a Japanese software company that owns 20 percent of Sega. **********Sega's 32-bit video-game machine, the Saturn, is being outsold by the Sony Playstation and by the new Nintendo 64. Sega has been losing money on its home video-game business and making up for it with profit from video arcades. **********Late last month, Sega forecast that its net profit for the fiscal year ending in March would be 5.3 billion yen, or about $45 million, instead of the 10 billion yen it had been projecting. **********Bandai has specialized in licensing the rights to make toys, candy and other goods based on television cartoon characters. Its revenue is above $2 billion. Last week, it said it would have a net loss of 9 billion yen, or about $75 million, in the fiscal year that ends in March, instead of the profit of 10 billion yen it had been forecasting. Sales are expected to be 200 billion yen, or $1.7 billion, instead of the previously forecast 270 billion yen.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/18/world.snippet: Islamic Group, believed responsible for killing scores of tourists at temple in Luxor, remains Egypt's most active Islamic fundamentalist organization, despite years of harsh Government repression and imprisonment of 15,000 sympathizers and top le...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/18/world.main_headline: Despite Crackdown, Islamic Group Keeps Killing
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/18/world.print_headline: Despite Crackdown, Islamic Group Keeps Killing
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/18/world.body_text: **********Even after years of harsh Government repression, even with 15,000 sympathizers imprisoned and its top leaders in jail, exile or both, the militant movement thought to have killed scores of foreign tourists in Luxor remains  Egypt's most active Islamic fundamentalist organization. **********In recent months, the Egyptian Government has been claiming success at bringing the Islamic Group --  Al Gamaa al Islamiya in Arabic --  under tighter control. **********But that is not the same thing as eradicating it. Instead, the struggle seems to have merely transformed the Islamic Group from a highly disciplined organization that assassinated Anwar el-Sadat in 1981 into a far more loosely knit group of cells. **********While these cells have become less and less effective in Egypt's cities, today's attack shows that they are still able to wreak havoc in sporadic attacks on tourists or in the countryside. **********The damage this can do to a country where poverty is deep and tourism is enormously important was evident in the shock expressed here today by Mamdouh el-Beltagui, Egypt's Tourism Minister. Here for the first day of the London Travel Fair, a major event for tourist operators, he found himself unable to boast that Egypt had conquered terrorism and its threat to travelers. **********''I can't predict at this stage what is going to happen about tourism to the country,'' Mr. Beltagui said. **********In Egypt, Nabil Osman, the Government's spokesman, said, ''We have never said we stopped these groups but that we had contained them.'' He added that terrorism was ''an international phenomenon.'' **********What he did not say was that Egypt had largely succeeded in recapturing an enormous flow of tourism, which had sharply fallen in 1993 and 1994 during a previous wave of  attacks on tourists, and now will probably have to start again. **********The Islamic Group was founded in the late 1970's by a band of radical Muslim theologians, led by Sheik Omar Abdel Rahman, and former army intelligence officers and lawyers. The sheik was later exiled and is now serving a life prison sentence in New York for his role in inspiring the 1993 attack on the World Trade Center; the former army officers and lawyers are all now serving life sentences in Egypt. **********The group's most spectacular attack was the assassination of President Sadat while he was reviewing a military parade in 1981, and in subsequent years it staged attacks on prime ministers, cabinet ministers, ranking police officers, secularists and intellectuals, including the Nobel literature laureate Naguib Mahfouz, who was stabbed in an assassination attempt in 1994, when he was 82. **********In the last five years, however, its status and tactics have changed.  President Hosni Mubarak and a succession of interior ministers have claimed, with some justification, to have broken the framework in which  fundamentalist terror had operated in Egypt. This was accomplished  with a ruthless and highly effective security campaign, and with a diplomatic offensive that cut off funds for the militants from rich supporters in Saudi Arabia and Kuwait. **********Egyptian officials estimate that the movement now has at most a few hundred operatives, who are hounded by security forces. Having been chased out of big cities, they typically hide out now in a few villages and towns in southern Egypt. Their targets tend to be foreign tourists or the largely defenseless 10 percent of Egyptians who are Christians. **********The attacks on tourists are a  threat to Egypt because of its economic vulnerability; the tourist industry brings in a desperately needed $3 billion a year. Beyond that, the Islamic Group's very survival  erodes Egypt's efforts to portray itself as a dominant Arab nation with a future based on democracy and economic ties to the wider world. **********Today's attack came after the top six jailed leaders of the Islamic Group made repeated appeals, starting in July, for a cessation of violence  ''for the sake of Islam and Muslims.'' **********They seem to have concluded that the battle to convert society by force has been lost, even though the basic political environment in which they recruit converts remains the same:  the Government resists democratization while endemic corruption and vast disparities of wealth continue.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/26/busin.print_headline: New York Notebook : VEBA Looks to U.S.
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/26/busin.body_text: **********The forces that are shaking up the once-staid utility industry have companies scrambling to develop 21st-century strategies. A utility that is moving on several fronts is VEBA AG, one of the five largest listed companies in Germany. **********VEBA began as an electric utility and has branched out into several related fields, such as chemicals, commodities trading and telecommunications. The company was one of the first in Germany to adopt U.S.-style accounting standards, and it is planning to list American depositary receipts for its shares on the New York Stock Exchange in October. **********Ulrich Hartmann, the VEBA chairman, wants an American partner in telecommunications to take the place of Cable & Wireless PLC, which dropped out of an alliance to challenge Deutsche Telekom in Germany. Currently, VEBA has a venture, called o.tel.o, with RWE AG, another big German utility, and 20 percent is being reserved for a foreign telecommunications company. **********Mr. Hartmann said VEBA was negotiating with several U.S. concerns, including GTE Corp., SBC Communications Inc. and BellSouth Corp. He said he preferred a U.S. partner to tap into American technical and marketing expertise. **********Unlike many conglomerates, which prefer not to raise their Wall Street profiles for fear of attracting a corporate raider, VEBA is courting U.S. institutional investors. It is only "poorly managed conglomerates" that have to fear break-ups, he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/23/world.snippet: United Nations Security Council says Iraq's failure to open disputed sites to weapons inspectors is unacceptable; stops short of condemning Iraq (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/23/world.main_headline: Security Council Insists Iraqis Allow Arms Search
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/23/world.print_headline: Security Council Insists Iraqis Allow Arms Search
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/23/world.body_text: **********The Security Council said today that Iraq's failure to open disputed sites to weapons inspectors was ''unacceptable'' and demanded once again that President Saddam Hussein allow the inspectors to see ''any and all'' buildings, equipment, documents and vehicles they want. **********But the Council, blocked by Russia with at least the tacit support of several other members, stopped short of condemning Iraq. And the statement issued today, which followed inconclusive meetings in Baghdad last week between the Iraqis and the chief arms inspector, contained no specific threats. **********It was nonetheless welcomed by Bill Richardson, the United States representative, who called the statement ''another strong signal'' that Iraq ''must comply with all Security Council resolutions.'' **********Sergei Lavrov, the Russian representative, who was largely responsible for removing the condemnatory language from the statement, said afterward that he thought it important that the measure included an acknowledgment that efforts are being made to find a way for Iraq to meet all its obligations. Other diplomats said this appeared to be a nod to Russian diplomacy. **********Responding to calls from Russia, France, China and Egypt that Iraq should see some future hope of having sanctions eased if it is to be expected to cooperate fully, Mr. Richardson said earlier today that it was Baghdad's refusal to accommodate requests by Richard Butler, the chief inspector, for access to ''sensitive'' sites that was keeping the sanctions in place. **********Mr. Butler returned from Baghdad with a list of several categories of areas that Iraq wanted to put off limits, wholly or in part: ''sites of national security significance,'' ''presidential and sovereign sites,'' civilian properties for which permission to visit would have to be sought from the owners, and foreign-owned properties.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/21/busin.snippet: Corning Inc, whose name has for decades been synonymous with Pyrex, Corning Ware and other household brands, says it will sell controlling interest in its consumer products business to AEA Investors, a New York investment firm; AEA will pay Cornin...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/21/busin.main_headline: Key Division To Be Sold By Corning
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/21/busin.print_headline: Key Division To Be Sold By Corning
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/21/busin.body_text: **********Corning Inc., whose name has for decades been synonymous with Pyrex, Corning Ware and other household brands, said yesterday that it would sell a controlling interest in its consumer products business to AEA Investors, a New York investment firm. **********AEA will pay Corning $975 million in cash for 89 percent of the Corning Consumer Products Company. AEA has agreed to keep the division's main plant in Corning, N.Y.; to honor its contract with Local 1000 of the American Flint Glass Workers Union, and to retain the division's management. **********Corning's decision to sell the housewares business was no surprise. The company has for the last few years been focusing more and more on high-technology businesses like photonics -- the lasers, amplifiers and other equipment that blast signals down the fiber optic pipelines of modern telecommunications. It announced in May that it wanted to sell the housewares operation, so that it could raise more cash to pump into photonics research and acquisitions. **********Still, most analysts had expected that the Newell Company, Rubbermaid or another housewares company would be the likely buyers. And, most expected Corning Consumer Products, with annual sales around $630 million, to fetch no more than $650 million. **********''When I heard $975 million I couldn't believe it, it was so much more than anyone expected,'' said Andrew Sutphin, an analyst at NatWest. **********Vincent Mai, AEA's chief executive, did not return several calls yesterday. **********Van C. Campbell, Corning's vice chairman, said that Corning would use the cash it is getting to pay down debt and expand its high-purity fused silica business -- which makes materials used in the manufacture of space shuttle windows, telescopes and semiconductors -- as well as to expand its photonics businesses. He added that the decision to sell to AEA, not a housewares company, was purely financial. ''They came up with the best bid,'' he said. **********Investors seem pleased with Corning's strategy. The company's stock, which was mired in the low $30's last fall, has been trading in the $60's for several months now. Before the deal was announced yesterday, the stock had been trading down about $3 from Tuesday's close, a drop analysts attributed to factors like profit taking rather than disillusionment with the company. After the AEA deal was announced, the stock bounced back somewhat, closing at $59.375, down $1.625. **********''The company is now going to trade at the high multiples of a telecommunications company, not the low ones of a pie plate company,'' Mr. Sutphin said. **********For those managers and workers who will stay with the consumer products company, being sold to a financial investor might be seen as a mixed blessing. The business must now build its own financial support staff, and provide other services it had always received from Corning -- and would presumably have received from a buyer like Newell, which makes Anchor Hocking glassware and Miro cookware. Corning has agreed to continue handling accounts payable and other functions for a few years. **********But on the positive side, a financial buyer rarely meddles much in the operational side of a working business. And, after a couple of years of painful cost-cutting, Corning's consumer products division has been quite profitable. ''Another housewares company would have its own ideas about how to run the business, and their own people to carry them out,'' said Peter F. Campanella, who is now, and will remain, the consumer products company's chief executive. **********Unionized workers, too, are sorting out the pros and cons. ''Right now I'm not worried,'' said Stephen A. Mandell Sr., president of Local 1000, which has more than 400 members in the housewares plant. Still, he says that he will feel more comfortable after he has learned more about the new buyers. ''Sure I'm worried that this is a financial investor,'' he said. ''I've heard too many horror stories about financial outfits that buy a business, milk it, and bingo, they're gone.'' **********Actually, AEA consists of investors whose personal backgrounds suggest that they are not purely financial players. The firm was formed in 1969 by retired chief executives of such Fortune 500 companies as General Electric, Ford and Chrysler, all of whom spent their careers deeply involved in the operations of those companies. **********''These are not the types of people to milk businesses,'' Mr. Campanella said. ''They're the type that I can bounce ideas off.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/09/busin.snippet: Diary of business events of week ended Mar 9; graph; photos; drawing (M)ÿ
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/09/busin.body_text: **********BERLITZ ECONOMICS **********Translating Greenspan **********Biblical scholars have it easy: all they have to do is debate nuances in the ancient Greek. Trying to make sense of today's economy is a far tougher task: you have to figure out what Alan Greenspan is saying. The week before last, according to some highly reliable translations, he said stock prices were too high, and prices dutifully slipped for a few days. Last week, though, he said, ''There is a valid argument as to sustaining the level of prices,'' which some dusty Greenspan scholars translated as ''never mind.'' Stocks dutifully rose nearly 100 points. It's still never entirely clear what he means, though, so maybe the answer would be to translate everything he says to ancient Greek, then back again. **********EMPLOYMENT **********Little Snow, Lots of Jobs **********When the Northeast and other parts of the country practically skip winter, as they did this year, it does wonders for the construction industry, which added 109,000 jobs in February. That was the driving force in an overall gain of 339,000 jobs in the month, the biggest increase in nine months, which helped push the nation's unemployment rate down to 5.3 percent from 5.4 percent. Uh-oh, you say -- the economy's overheating, inflation's headed back, stocks will crumble. But the market didn't plunge, because of another point in Friday's job report: companies are not exactly spreading the wealth, with hourly earnings up a measly 3 cents. Can't buy much inflation with that. **********PATRIOT GAMES **********The Pajamas Are Coming! **********Say you're 11, and your mother sends you to buy chewing gum, vowing punishment if you balk. Your father, though, vowed to punish you if he ever caught you buying gum. What to do? That's roughly the position Wal-Mart found itself in recently in Canada, but it wasn't gum -- it was pajamas. The pajamas, you see, were made in Cuba. Can't sell 'em, dictates the Helms-Burton Act. So Wal-Mart, when it discovered the offending garments, started pulling them off the shelves. Wait a second, said Canada's Government -- you can't do that either. It's against Canadian law to obey that American law. Various nations, Canada included, are challenging Helms-Burton, saying it is America's attempt to strong-arm the world. Washington, with a straight face, responds that it may have to label this a ''national security'' issue. Invasion of the killer pajamas. **********HOLLYWOOD **********$60 Million Monsters **********Imagine it. Imelda Marcos, opening her closet, is shocked, shocked to find all those shoes. Absurd? Well, consider this: Movie executives were variously ''horrified,'' ''disturbed,'' ''appalled'' and merely ''upset'' last week when the Motion Picture Association of America announced that the average cost of making and marketing a movie had reached nearly $60 million last year, two and a half times the price a decade ago. Come on, now. Those are the very executives who order all those snazzy car chases, all those buildings being blown up, all those sky-high salaries for the stars of the moment. Is it all necessary? Instead of charging $7 or $8 for a ticket, couldn't they charge $4.50 and, after the hero jumps in a car to pursue the villain, just put a silent-movie title on the screen that says: ''Imagine a chase scene here. (You know: just like all the others you've seen.)'' **********FEDERAL LARGESS **********Remember the Richest **********Washington, you may have heard, has a terrible time balancing its books. Congress has an annual brawl about some odd amendment to force it to mend its ways, with the latest effort dying a hero's death last week in the Senate. The problem, you see, is that there are all these worthwhile things the Government feels it must do -- like, say, offering a half-million dollars to Greenwich, Conn., so it can spruce up its main street. Now this street, mind you, is not exactly a grim boulevard of plywood-clad windows and broken bottles. Far from it. The Government, though, in its infinite wisdom, does not discriminate against the Rolex and Lauren set, so it deemed Greenwich worthy of this largess. But last week Greenwich, in its infinite wealth, proudly said, No thanks. **********LEGAL FOLLIES **********Caution: Falling Warnings! **********Which are more plentiful -- products that could harm us, or lawyers dying to sue someone? That's a tough one. It's tempting to say lawyers, of course. But think of all the things either slowly poisoning us or threatening to puncture, scald or otherwise attack us. Product makers, naturally, want to avoid injuries -- but, it often seems, they especially want to avoid lawsuits. So as lawsuits get sillier -- ''No one warned me not to swallow that telephone,'' the plaintiff complains -- product warnings have matched silliness for silliness. ''Cape does not enable user to fly,'' warns the Batman costume. ''This product does not have brakes,'' warns a plastic sled. And, of course, the post-lawsuit warning on McDonald's coffee: ''Caution: Hot!'' Well, yes. **********TOUGH JUSTICE **********Hoffenberg's Day in Court **********If you get a letter from Steven Hoffenberg promising untold wealth if you'll only give him your life savings to invest, it might be best to file it with the rest of your junk mail. If you hear that Mr. Hoffenberg is offering to buy, say, some local tabloid, it's a safe bet the deal won't fly. Mr. Hoffenberg, you see -- brash, unlikely bidder for The New York Post, and the man who bilked investors out of hundreds of millions -- was sentenced last week to 20 years in prison. Harsh, you say? Not to the judge, who dispensed this stern justice after hearing numerous tales of lives smashed by Mr. Hoffenberg's ''greed.'' This man, he said, must be ''barred from causing further damage to society.'' Mr. Hoffenberg did get one break: the judge now says he owes his victims just $462 million, not $475 million. The stone, in other words, must shed a drop less blood. **********CABLEVISION **********The Only Game in Town **********If you want to watch New York's sports teams on television, your choices now practically come down to this: Cablevision, Cablevision or Cablevision. The big Long Island cable company, which already owns half of Madison Square Garden, is buying the other half from ITT for $650 million. By combining the MSG Network with Sportschannel, Cablevision will have a virtual lock on everything from the Knicks to the Yankees to the Rangers. Given how sports-addicted New Yorkers are, that's a lot of power in one place -- like having the only bar in a town full of heavy drinkers -- and concerns quickly arose about what this would do to prices. So if you need your regular dose of sweating, swatting superstars, think good thoughts about Cablevision. **********WALL STREET **********A Paycheck Apart **********Wall Street, in an economic sense, has seceded from New York City. It used to be that when the securities industry was fat and happy, the rest of the city was fat and happy, too -- that when jobs and salaries rose downtown, they rose everywhere. No more. While the pin-striped few have been getting those Ferrari-size bonus checks, wages elsewhere have stagnated. From 1989 to 1995, securities workers' pay -- adjusted for inflation -- soared 42 percent, while wages outside those bustling walls have not even crept ahead by 4 percent. Do those millions buy happiness, though? The statistics are inconclusive.

"We've seen a real bloodbath in many of these markets,&...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/06/your-.main_headline: Briefcase : 'Be Brave, Buy Asia,' Mobius Decrees
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/06/your-.print_headline: Briefcase : 'Be Brave, Buy Asia,' Mobius Decrees
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/06/your-.body_text: **********The time has come to be courageous and invest in Southeast Asia and other battered emerging markets, in the opinion of Mark Mobius, fund manager and oracle of Templeton Investment Management. "We've seen a real bloodbath in many of these markets," Mr. Mobius said this week in London. **********Exhorting investors to take the plunge after the markets had taken theirs, he said: "To buy when people are despondently selling takes the greatest fortitude and provides the greatest rewards." **********Templeton takes a value-driven approach to investing, looking for cheap stocks rather than those that have already built up momentum in earnings growth. The latter often carry high price tags in anticipation of even further strong earnings growth, leaving them vulnerable should growth falter. **********There are plenty of cheap stocks in Asia, where some markets have lost more than half their value in the last year. They have been beaten down to the point, Mr. Mobius said, that all bad news, announced or expected, has been factored into prices "From a macroeconomic viewpoint, the picture is very dark," he said. "From a stock-market viewpoint, we will start to see a recovery. **********"Next year will be a period of stability," he said. "Most markets will move sideways. Then, near the end of the year, we will start to see strength. In some of these countries we could see quite a quick turnaround." **********His favorite market is the hardest hit, Thailand, but "all these Southeast Asian nations are interesting," he said. **********As for Hong Kong, he said that greater inflation there than in the United States had left the currency about 40 percent overvalued relative to the U.S. dollar but that the peg to it should hold. **********To compensate for the discrepancy, he said, authorities will try to engineer a gradual decline in real estate prices, especially of high-priced properties, by stepping up sales of government housing. **********Mr. Mobius acknowledged that Templeton's funds had been knocked by the emerging-markets sell-off. Amending an adage, he said, "You should invest when there's blood running in the streets, even when some of it is your own."

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/11/busin.snippet: Letter by Gerald Shirley on April 13 article by Peter Schuck and Ian Ayres on car buying made simpler (S)é
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/11/busin.main_headline: Simpler, Maybe, But Is It Useful?
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/11/busin.print_headline: Simpler, Maybe, But Is It Useful?
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/11/busin.body_text: **********To the Editor: **********In ''Car Buying Made Simpler'' (Viewpoint, April 13), Peter Schuck and Ian Ayres say state motor vehicle departments already have financial data bases based on sales tax reporting by dealers on their new-car sales. They suggest that from this data, we can determine which dealers operate with the lowest profit margins and that the states should offer the information to car buyers. **********It would be astonishing, however, if the information supplied by dealers to a motor vehicle department or a sales tax agency included a detailed showing of what options or trade-in allowance was given on individual sales. Without such input, how would it be possible to extract the actual net profit or margin on the basic car itself? **********Besides, there are already a number of very capable, cost-effective search firms -- reachable by phone, fax and the Internet -- that will find you the best buy. **********Finally, since when are government agencies supposed to furnish consumers with a comparison-shopping service? It would save money for those who took advantage of it, but the state's sales tax revenues would decrease. And the need to make up the shortfall surely would have an impact on consumers' wallets in some other way. **********GERALD SHIRLEY **********Tuckahoe, N.Y., April 22

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/26/busin.snippet: Investment Company Institute reports mutual fund investors are turning their backs on overseas stock funds, with net inflow in Oct down to $1.3 million from average of $4 billion a month earlier in year; reports $187 million in net new funds flowe...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/26/busin.main_headline: THE ASIAN CRISIS: THE U.S. INVESTORS ; Government Bond Funds Receiving Influx of Cash
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/26/busin.print_headline: THE ASIAN CRISIS: THE U.S. INVESTORS ; Government Bond Funds Receiving Influx of Cash
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/26/busin.body_text: **********Mutual fund investors turned their backs on overseas stock funds in October and instead sought the shelter of United States Government bond funds, which received new cash for the first time in four years. **********Fund shareholders continue, of course, to favor funds that invest in American stocks. So far this month, money has poured into those funds at Fidelity Investments and the Vanguard Group, the two largest fund companies, as well as at Charles Schwab & Company, which sells mutual funds from hundreds of smaller companies. **********The money entering funds has slowed somewhat from last month, but ''that's not surprising,'' said Brian Mattes, a Vanguard vice president, given the recent volatility in the domestic and foreign stock markets. In addition, he said, ''investors usually hesitate to buy until after most funds have paid out distributions'' of capital gains and dividends, which for most fund companies occurs in early to mid-December. **********Until last month, investors had remained similarly steadfast in their love for international and global stock funds, despite their having been battered for months by Asian currency devaluations and unstable equity markets that stretched from the Pacific Rim through Latin America to Eastern Europe. **********Tutored by fund companies and investment advisers to diversify by sending money to the far corners of the globe, Americans this year added an average of $4 billion a month to international stock funds, which invest only outside the United States, and global funds, which can also buy American stocks. **********In October, however, only $1.3 million trickled into international and global funds, according to figures released yesterday by the Investment Company Institute, a mutual fund trade group. Not since December 1990, when $55.9 million flowed out of the group, have overseas stock funds suffered a worse month. **********Meanwhile, Government bond funds, once the largest category of fixed-income mutual funds, received $187 million in net new cash in October, the trade group reported. That ended a string of months in which money flowed out of the Government funds that stretched back to October 1993, shortly before the Federal Reserve moved to raise interest rates. **********As money dribbled out of Government bond funds over the last four years, and as the returns from fixed-income investments have lagged behind those of equities, other categories of bond funds have become more popular with investors, particularly those specializing in high-yield or junk bonds and municipal bonds. **********Funds investing in fixed-income securities with high current yields accounted for the biggest portion of the cash flows to fixed-income funds all year, including in October, when all bond funds received $3.7 billion, about even with the previous month. **********Those latest developments overseas and at home apparently did little to dampen investors' enthusiasm for American stock funds, which received a revised $18.2 billion in new investments last month, the fourth-highest total so far in 1997. **********Previously, the trade group had estimated that stock funds of all types had added $21 billion last month, which would have been the third-highest inflow of the year. While the revised figure is down from September's intake of $25.7 billion, it remained above the October 1996 figure of $13.5 billion. **********As expected, the October cash flows left the total collected by stock funds so far in 1997 ahead of last year's record pace. In the first 10 months of 1997, investors added $195.6 billion to their stock fund investments, bringing the total assets of the funds to $2.3 trillion. In the period last year, stock funds took in $192.5 billion, on their way to a record 12-month total of $221.4 billion. **********The two largest fund companies reported that the cash has continued to flow this month, although at slower rates than before the stock market's late-October slump. **********Fidelity and Vanguard each expect their stock funds to receive $1.5 billion in new investments in November, officials at those companies said yesterday. At Vanguard, that is about half the level recorded in October, said Mr. Mattes. **********But T. Rowe Price reported that domestic stock funds are attracting more new money this month than last, while international funds continue to lose money. **********At Schwab, whose Mutual Fund Marketplace serves as a primary distributor for the funds of hundreds of companies, net flows into all stock funds measured about $330 million so far in November, about half the level of last month, with the largest flows  into the most conservative stock funds like growth and income funds, which invest in blue-chip stocks that typically pay dividends. **********Bond funds, however, have added to their take, gaining $291 million in net new cash so far in November, up from $170 million for all of October.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/02/busin.main_headline: Using the boss to pitch the product comes to cyberspace as the Street.com bids for subscribers.
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/02/busin.print_headline: Using the boss to pitch the product comes to cyberspace as the Street.com bids for subscribers.
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/02/busin.body_text: **********ENLISTING the top executives of consumer product companies for double duty as pitchmen -- from Lee A. Iacocca and R. David Thomas to Victor Kiam and Frank Perdue -- has long been popular. Now that ploy is being deployed for cyberspace. **********The Street.com L.L.C., which operates a fledgling on-line financial news service, is centering a television and print campaign on its co-founder and chairman, James J. Cramer, the free-tongued money manager who doubles as a financial journalist for newspapers, magazines and cable networks as well as the Street.com Web site (http:// www.thestreet.com). **********The campaign, produced by Ryan Drossman & Partners in New York, carries the assertive theme ''Get it right.'' The goal is to sell subscriptions to the site, at $12.95 a month, by capitalizing on the irreverent, street-smart image of Mr. Cramer, who is also president of Cramer Berkowitz & Company, a private money management firm. **********''In extensive focus-group research before we created the advertising, we found our target audience was the heavy trader who has the mindset almost of a gambler,'' said Avi Dan, senior vice president for strategic planning at Ryan Drossman. ''He wants information that will give him an edge, wants it fast and from a credible source. **********''And this audience is very skeptical about financial information,'' he added, 'thinking a lot of it is hogwash. They need someone they can relate to and believe in like Cramer, who's one of them.'' **********Neil Drossman, chairman and creative director at Ryan Drossman, agreed that Mr. Cramer's take-no-prisoners personality was an asset. **********''When we met him, he was passionate and outspoken almost to the point where we didn't quite believe it,'' Mr. Drossman said. ''What better face to put on it?'' **********So in one commercial, Mr. Cramer spoofs the classic campaign for Smith Barney with a haughty John Houseman. ''If we made money the old-fashioned way,'' Mr. Cramer declares, ''we'd still be driving Model T's, dialing rotary phones and getting our fingers dirty from ink.'' **********In the other commercials, Mr. Cramer's pugnacious intensity and bombastic delivery evoke Peter Finch as Howard Beale, the news anchor who becomes the ''mad prophet of the airwaves'' in the 1976 film ''Network.'' **********One spot presents Mr. Cramer ranting about ''those boring blue-chip stocks, stocks that you buy and love and buy some more. **********''I hate them with a passion,'' he continues, ''because you can never have an edge on them. They are for lazy managers.'' As he speaks, these words appear on screen: ''Tell us what you really feel, Jim. Don't hold back, it's unhealthy.'' **********Mr. Cramer, in a phone interview punctuated with brief asides to associates at Cramer Berkowitz to ''Bring in all the Seagate common'' and ''Let Western Digital run,'' described the campaign strategy as driven by sound business reasons rather than by ego. **********''It makes sense to use me,'' Mr. Cramer said, ''because the voice of the publication is derivative of my voice. It's suffused with a jocular, 'sportsy' attitude and spirit.'' **********Mr. Cramer praised the sports sections of newspapers for offering a ''higher accounting'' of who they cover than do business sections. **********''The sports section says Messier's tired,'' he said, referring to Mark Messier, the captain and center of the New York Rangers. ''If he were the president of a company, the story would never say he was tired. It would say he's 'subdued.' **********''And if Jimmy Key were the C.E.O. of General Electric and left for Allied Signal,'' he continued, referring to the pitcher the New York Yankees let go to the Baltimore Orioles, ''they'd never ask, 'Who let him go?' I say, find the bad guy.'' **********Mr. Cramer, who shares ownership of the Street.com with its editorial staff and Martin Peretz, editor in chief and chairman of The New Republic magazine, acknowledged that sometimes the bad guy is nearby. **********''My voice is, 'Trust no one, including us,' '' he said. ''When we screw up, at least we'll tell you.'' **********For instance, when asked how much has been spent on Street.com, Mr. Cramer replied, ''About $3 million, of which I'd say $2 million was good spending and $1 million was errant spending on ill-fated direct marketing and initially poorly executed technology.'' **********Mr. Cramer also admitted to being ''incredibly nervous'' about how the campaign fares because, he said, ''not since my junior year of high school when I played Lieutenant Rooney -- the cop who comes in at the end -- in 'Arsenic and Old Lace' have I done any acting.'' **********So far, the Web site has registered 5,700 members, Mr. Cramer said. To get to 25,000, the break-even figure, he added, ''we'll commit to a couple million dollars'' in ad spending. **********''If we catch on fire, we'll have 50,000 paid subscribers by the end of the year,'' Mr. Cramer said, which ''would justify three or four million in advertising. And with 100,000, it would be five million.'' **********Plans call for the commercials to begin this week or next week in Dallas and San Francisco; if successful, they will run nationally in August or September, Mr. Cramer said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/03/your-.body_text: **********How far is up? A Money Report reader in Britain has written to inquire whether it is too late to buy Telecomunicacoes Brasileira SA, given its spectacular price run-up in the past year. Shares of the telephone company, known as Telebras, were at $60 in June, when the Money Report ran a story on investing in Brazil's utility privatizations. They have since soared to $110 **********Nevertheless, there ismileage left in Telebras, said some analysts, who are projecting anywhere from $140 to $150 a share over the next 12 months. **********"It's woefully undervalued, and still the least-expensive telephone company in Latin America," said Raymond Liguori, who follows Telebras for Merrill Lynch & Co. He said a "huge" rate increase in November 1995 drove the company's performance during 1996. Only a few weeks ago, a rate restructuring was announced that will reduce long-distance rates but boost by 60 percent the rates of local calls, which have a far heavier volume. The restructuring also will raise monthly fees. **********Mr. Liguori suggested that individual investors buy and hold Telebras through its full privatization, scheduled for 1998. Once that has happened, he said, the company's value will be further enhanced as foreign telecommunications groups become investors, vastly improving efficiency and purchasing pieces of the company, such as its cellular phone operation. **********Is there any downside in this rosy picture? **********"Telebras is a proxy for the Brazilian economy," Mr. Liguori said, "and if anything happens there, it will bear the brunt of bad economic news." Investors will also need patience, since he thinks the privatization is likely to be delayed to 1999. Still, he added, "It's moved from the point of whether privatization occurs, to when." **********Depositary receipts for Telebras are listed on the New York Stock Exchange and the London Stock Exchange. **********(IHT)

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/04/busin.snippet: Acer America Corp has parted ways with Hal Riney & Partners after only 15 months; creative portion of advertising account, with billings estimated at $10 million, has been awarded to Kahn/Weber/Harris (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/04/busin.body_text: **********The Acer America Corporation in San Jose, Calif., a unit of the Taiwan company Acer Inc. that markets personal computers, said yesterday that it had parted ways with Hal Riney & Partners in San Francisco after only 15 months. As a result, the creative portion of the account, with billings estimated at $10 million, has been awarded without a review to Kahn/ Weber/Harris in Half Moon Bay, Calif. **********Tom Henry, director of marketing communications at Acer, confirmed a report of the change in the Daily Fax edition of Advertising Age. He attributed the decision to a shift to product from brand advertising. Mr. Henry said that Riney will continue to handle the media portion of the account until that portion of the account is placed in review in the spring of 1998.
