https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/16/busin.print_headline: COMPANY NEWS; SYNOPSYS TO BUY VIEWLOGIC FOR $512 MILLION
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/16/busin.body_text: **********Synopsys Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Viewlogic Systems Inc., a rival maker of software for designing computer chips, for more than $512 million. News of the deal drove up shares of Viewlogic $2.6875, or 12 percent, to $25.1875, on the Nasdaq market. Under the agreement, Synopsys, which is based in Mountain View, Calif., would pay 0.6521 share, or $28, for each of Viewlogic's 18.3 million shares outstanding. Synopsys earned $23.7 million, or 57 cents a share, on revenue of $353.5 million last year. Viewlogic, of Marlboro, Mass., had earnings of $11.3 million, or 66 cents a share, on sales of $132.9 million. Synopsys shares sank $3.125, to $39.8125.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/06/world.snippet: At least four British employees of visa section of British High Commission in Lagos, Nigeria, have been sent home in recent weeks because of what diplomats suspect is major visa-selling ring (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/06/world.main_headline: 4 Britons Recalled From Nigeria in Visa-Selling Investigation
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/06/world.print_headline: 4 Britons Recalled From Nigeria in Visa-Selling Investigation
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/06/world.body_text: **********At least four British employees of the visa section of the British High Commission here have been sent home in recent weeks because of what diplomats suspect is a major visa-selling ring. **********Some were sent home for their own protection and some because of suspected involvement in irregularities, said John Whattam, spokesman for the High Commission. He did not elaborate. **********Four British police officers have arrived to investigate possible irregularities in the visa section of the High Commission, or embassy. **********British visas are said by European diplomats to be available on the black market for around $3,000. Diplomats say they believe much of the business is run by well organized criminal rings. **********The United States and European countries are reluctant to grant visas to Nigerians out of the concern that they will remain in the country they visit. **********Nigerian newspapers have reported with delight the allegations that British citizens are involved in the illegal sales. A number of newspapers have been quick to take editorial shots at Britain after being the object of disparaging British statements about official corruption in Nigeria. **********''Stinking British Embassy,'' read the banner headline Saturday in the newspaper Concord. Under the headline was the official picture of Queen Elizabeth II. **********Word of the British visa scandal has spread a sense of distress through other Western embassies in Lagos. ''We are being extra vigilant,'' said Joseph Melrose, the American charge d'affaires. **********The United States Embassy said it has received reports of people from the outside claiming to be able to influence the visa process, and promising to provide visas for a fee. The Embassy said those reported to be involved have no official standing with the embassy. **********There have also been reports made by people seeking visas from both the German and United States Embassies that Nigerian gate guards demand bribes just to let applicants pass. **********The major concern of American diplomats is the falsification of documents. The Embassy has received reports from international airports of Nigerians traveling on doctored American passports. Embassy officials suspect that attempts are also being made to forge American visas in Nigeria. **********Not only is Nigeria one of the world's major drug-trafficking points, but most public corporations have reputations of being corrupt, and fake documents of virtually any kind are easily available on street corners. **********American diplomats say more than 40 percent of the documents accompanying visa application forms they receive are false, with the German Embassy saying the figure is 90 percent for its visa section. **********''We can't catch them all,'' said one European diplomat, speaking on condition of anonymity. ''We're lucky if we can identify a fifth of the false papers.'' **********An article published in a Nigerian travel journal last year gave detailed instructions how to make arrangements to get a foreign visa. **********''If you want to make everything go faster, turn up for the interview panel with, say, $5,000 to $10,000,'' it advised, reminding applicants to bring personal documents like marriage certificates, which are available for the equivalent of $6, and to dress well for the interview.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/22/busin.snippet: AT&T Corp says that net income from continuing operations dropped 24 percent in first quarter and that next quarter will also fall short of earlier estimates; reports income of $1.12 billion, compared with $1.46 billion in first quarter of 1996; r...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/22/busin.main_headline: AT&T Profit Down; Weak 2d Quarter Seen, Too
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/22/busin.print_headline: AT&T Profit Down; Weak 2d Quarter Seen, Too
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/22/busin.body_text: **********A month after warning that it faced a gloomy financial future, AT&T delivered the first bitter spoonful yesterday. The company said that net income from continuing operations dropped 24 percent in the first quarter and that the next quarter would also fall short of earlier estimates. **********AT&T reported income from continuing operations of $1.12 billion, compared with $1.46 billion in the first quarter of last year. Its revenue inched up 1.5 percent, to $13.05 percent from $12.85 billion. **********Although analysts had been preparing for lower earnings, AT&T still managed to disappoint them. And several said yesterday that they planned to lower their projections for the rest of the year. **********''This is a little like the Titanic,'' said Linda B. Meltzer, an analyst at UBS Securities. ''AT&T's earnings are at the high end this quarter and are only going to go down for the rest of the year.'' **********The company's shares dropped 62.5 cents yesterday, to $33, in active trading on the New York Stock Exchange. **********Including income from discontinued operations of $4 million, its net income was $1.13 billion, or 69 cents a share, down from $1.36 billion, or 85 cents a share, a year earlier. The 1996 quarter took into account a loss from discontinued operations of $107 million, or 7 cents a share. **********Several analysts focused on the widening gap between AT&T's sluggish revenue growth, and the growth in the volume of calls, which was relatively robust, at 6.7 percent. They said the disparity underscored AT&T's buffeting by rivals like GTE and discount carriers like World Xchange. The new competitors are eroding its profit margins even as the overall long-distance market grows. **********Even AT&T's booming wireless division is starting to show scars from competition, as wireless upstarts invade major markets like New York City. Revenue in the division grew nearly 14 percent, to $1.02 billion, but AT&T signed up 9.7 percent fewer new subscribers in the first quarter than it did in the comparable period last year. **********Steven W. Hooper, chief executive of AT&T Wireless Services, said in a conference call with analysts that price competition had erupted in several AT&T markets. But he predicted that the new competitors would not be able to sustain their offers of free telephone minutes for long. **********As for the wired business, revenue in AT&T's consumer division declined $62 million, to $6.05 billion, while revenue in the healthier business division increased $129 million, to $5.45 billion. **********Despite the poor results, AT&T appears to be taking the first steps to turn around its core business. Gail J. McGovern, head of the consumer long-distance division, said the company had sharply cut the number of checks it sends people to woo them to switch to AT&T. Last year, those checks cost the company $1 billion. **********''While we have much to do and implement, our marketing transformation has begun,'' Ms. McGovern said. **********At AT&T's presentation to analysts last month, she pledged to reduce the percentage of customers drawn by checks to 20 percent from 60 percent by the end of the year. Yesterday, she said the company had already pushed the share below 40 percent. **********''The consumer business is going through a difficult period,'' Stephanie Comfort, an analyst at Morgan Stanley, said. ''But you can see a glimmer of hope at the end of the tunnel.'' **********AT&T's business division is also exhibiting some strength. Jeffrey Weitzen, the head of the unit, said it had signed major new contracts in the quarter with Kmart, SmithKline Beecham and the United States Treasury Department. **********Some analysts, however, were troubled that AT&T recorded only $1 billion in capital expenditures in the first quarter. The company said last month that it would spend $7 billion to $8 billion this year to upgrade its wired and wireless phone networks -- a huge outlay that contributed to its pessimistic earnings forecast. If AT&T still plans to spend $6 billion to $7 billion in the remaining three quarters of the year, analysts said, it could further drag down earnings. **********Beyond capital spending, AT&T is also finding day-to-day competition more expensive. The company said its costs jumped to $424 million in the first quarter because of the larger cash reserve it was setting aside to compensate for unpaid bills. New Federal regulations are also forcing AT&T to pay local phone companies more to connect the calls of customers who dial toll-free numbers from its pay phones. **********''The cost pressures are intense, and 1998 is going to be even worse,'' said Frank Governali, an analyst at Credit Suisse First Boston. **********A final area of weakness is AT&T's financial services division, primarily its Universal Card. Revenue in the division declined 18.7 percent, to $390 million, as the company continued to feel the effects of a change in its accounting methods last year, and the declining use of the card. **********AT&T's travails in the long-distance market contrast starkly with the situation of regional Bell telephone companies, which are riding a tide of growth in the local market. The BellSouth Corporation announced yesterday that its income rose 11 percent, to $693 million, in the first quarter. **********Those figures excluded a one-time gain of $344 million that BellSouth recorded in the first quarter of 1996 from the sale of its paging operations. Factoring in that gain, net income dropped nearly 29 percent. BellSouth's revenue increased 6.7 percent, to $4.8 billion. **********The company said its growth was driven by a seemingly insatiable appetite for additional phone lines. BellSouth, which offers local phone service in nine Southern states, added a record 254,000 residential phone lines -- 106,000 of which were second lines. The company said it was the first quarter that it had ever sold more than 100,000 second lines.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/18/busin.snippet: Economists at National Association for Business Economics annual meeting say sustained prosperity, corporate downsizing that has made research expendable and backlash against economic fraternity's inlfated forecasting claims have all combined to m...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/18/busin.main_headline: Brother (or Sister), Can You Spare a Dime for a Boom-Era Economist?
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/18/busin.print_headline: Brother (or Sister), Can You Spare a Dime for a Boom-Era Economist?
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/18/busin.body_text: **********The better the economy, the worse things seem to get for economists. **********Fifteen years of expansion interrupted by just one brief downturn in the early 1990's have helped to erode the market for the people in American corporations who study the economy for a living. ''If your job is forecasting recessions, you've got a pretty sleepy job,'' said Paul Boltz, an economist at T. Rowe Price Associates in Baltimore. **********That was just one reason that the annual meeting of the National Association for Business Economics, which concluded here today in this city known for celebrating good times, was such a sedate affair. **********Sustained prosperity, corporate downsizing that has made research expendable and a backlash against the economic fraternity's inflated forecasting claims have all combined to make the life of a business economist tougher than ever. Indeed, for a lot of economists these days, job insecurity is not an abstract principle but a day-to-day reality. **********Much of the program at the meeting was given over to self-improvement panels on topics like ''successful job switching,'' ''hot career opportunities'' and ''how economists can play a role in their firm's decision making,'' and corridor talk often began with old friends telling of new jobs or the search for them. **********Among the missing was Alison Lynn Reaser. A former economist at  First Interstate Bancorp in Los Angeles, she lost that job in the takeover by Wells Fargo & Company. She landed at Barnett Banks in Florida but is now uncertain of what will happen after its acquisition by Nationsbank of Charlotte, N.C. Ms. Reaser had signed up to attend the meeting here but could not make it because of a freeze on travel by Barnett, a friend said. **********''Hundreds of economists are in the same boat,'' said Ken Ackbarali, a Los Angeles consultant who lost his job in the Wells Fargo takeover of First Interstate. **********John H. Ortego was left behind in Albany when his one-time employer, the Key Corporation, moved to Cleveland. ''I have joined the army of the self-employed,'' said Mr. Ortego, who just resigned his latest post as an economist in Buffalo with the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. **********While banks and industrial companies have been trimming economics departments for years, the employment distress in this field has never been so acute. And the contrast with the 1980's -- which started with a deep recession and saw record Federal budget deficits amid a booming stock market and the end of high inflation -- could not be starker. **********''We were in nirvana as economists in the early 80's,'' said Bernard M. Markstein, who set up a consulting business in Phoenixville, Pa., after losing a job at Meridian Bank just before it was taken over by Corestates Bank. **********Now, cost-conscious senior management finds little use for predictions from in-house experts when a wide array of forecasts, none of them particularly more trustworthy than another, are readily available. **********''Forecasting,'' Mr. Markstein acknowledged, ''is not what we do best.'' **********Not that they don't keep trying. The National Association for Business Economics consensus predicts that the economy will grow 2.3 percent next year. And slightly more than half of the respondents are forecasting a recession in 1999. But even the experts do not put much stock in those predictions. ''There was a lot of money to be made'' in forecasting, especially of interest rates, said William Dunkelberg, an economics professor at Temple University and chief consultant to the National Federation of Independent Business. ''Now we know we can't do that.'' **********That explains why the association, which has seen membership decline 10 percent over the last decade, is searching for a new identity. **********''We are less and less an association of traditional members doing macroeconomics forecasting in a corporate center economic unit,'' said C. Mark Dadd of AT&T, the current president of the association.  To reflect the new reality, the group just changed its name from the National Association ''of Business Economists'' to the National Association ''for Business Economics.'' **********Its new mission is to help members apply their economic skills to specific corporate problems rather than make grand but dubious pronouncements about the entire economy. **********This somewhat humbler ambition seemed especially striking when set against the opening address on Monday by Jack Guynn, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta, who declared the stellar performance of the economy to be a triumph of national economic policy making rather than favorable circumstances and improved corporate competitiveness. **********''The conventional explanations,'' he said, ''do not recognize the central role of the monetary policy the Fed has made over the past 17 years and the more recent contribution of improved fiscal policy.'' **********At other sessions, one speaker after another concentrated on practical ways for economists to ''add value,'' enhancing their careers by filling such specialty niches as litigation analysis and transfer pricing or adopting strategies for turning themselves into executives. **********In the end, several economists noted, they are victims of the very market forces that the profession so often exults. And with the market changing, economists must change, too.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/18/busin.snippet: Small investors seem unfazed by recent 247-point drop in Dow Jones industrial average; feel similar market adjustments have repeatedly occurred in long bull market that many analysts say began in 1982; few of the dozens of investors interviewed be...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/18/busin.main_headline: Little Shaken, Small Investors Say Stock Plunges Are to Be Expected
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/18/busin.print_headline: Little Shaken, Small Investors Say Stock Plunges Are to Be Expected
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/18/busin.body_text: **********Bud Sadoff was sitting in front of his computer terminal last Friday when the big stock market plunge began. And his television set, not too far away, was tuned to CNBC financial news. **********As he watched, the Dow Jones industrial average fell sharply, culminating in a 247-point loss, the biggest one-day selloff in almost six years. **********But the 64-year-old retired engineer, who has made a hobby of tracking the market's every move, was unshaken by the news. **********''I don't think it's all that surprising,'' Mr. Sadoff said in a telephone interview from his home in Chevy Chase, Md. ''It'll go down another 100 or 150 points, but I'm not that nervous.'' **********Mr. Sadoff is unfazed because market adjustments like this have repeatedly occurred in a long bull market that many analysts say began in 1982. He remembers October 1987, when the Dow plummeted 508 points in a single session, to 1,738.41. Yet just 12 days ago, the blue-chip index reached 8,259.31, a fourfold gain. **********It is that kind of return that has drawn millions of first-time investors into the stock market in the last decade. And it is that kind of investor attitude that has kept the market upbeat, even in sharp downturns like the current one. **********Of course, no one is willing to say that the Dow will not fall further this week, but few of the dozens of investors interviewed this weekend believe that the market is seriously ailing, or about to collapse. Indeed, many displayed a degree of self-assuredness that seemed to border on arrogance. **********''Yes, a 247-point drop is a big number,'' said Lou Methner, 70, of Denver. ''But out of how many Dow points?'' **********7,942. **********''And what was the Dow at six months ago?'' **********6,988. **********''Well, there you go. It's been a good run this year.'' **********This is much the same sentiment that was expressed in March and April, when the Dow tumbled 9.8 percent over several weeks after the Federal Reserve raised interest rates to slow what appeared to be an overheating economy. **********But then, as now, confident investors said they considered the downturn in market prices to be a good buying opportunity. **********Still, with the Dow off 6.8 percent in the last seven sessions, some people on Wall Street wonder whether the market will now see its first 10 percent decline since 1990. This is the longest stretch that the Dow has ever gone without such a drop. And some Wall Street analysts wonder whether reaching that level might depress investor sentiment. **********On the whole, though, analysts are unshaken by the market's recent slide, partly because they had been calling for such a pullback. After all, the Dow was up nearly 29 percent in little more than three months, and that kind of pace cannot be sustained, they said. Broader market gauges, like the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, have also risen sharply. **********To those analysts, the selloff might have been sparked by any of a number of reasons: the United Parcel Service strike, for example, which created fears of rising labor costs. Or a spurt of selling linked to the recent reduction in the capital gains tax rate. Or warnings of profit slowdowns from Coca-Cola and Gillette, which had been two of the steadiest performers. **********But many individual investors pointed out that the market had been spooked before by similar concerns, only to rebound. In other words, the decline is only a mild correction, they said over and over, using the Wall Street lingo for a sharp, but temporary, price decline that interrupts a longer, upward trend. Some called it a buying opportunity, and others suggested that a short-term slump was healthy for the market. **********This is the individual investor as stock market guru. And why not? While some of Wall Street's best-known strategists have been bearish for years, Americans have been piling into the stock market in droves. The explosion of money invested in mutual funds, notably in 401(k) retirement plans, is what has given the bull market its momentum. **********Besides, they say, the economy is humming along, inflation seems to be absent, interest rates are stable, the dollar is king and corporate profits remain strong. There is even talk that the economy has entered a qualitatively new era, one in which all these market-friendly trends converge and can be sustained. **********Of course, last week -- as the market was sliding -- mutual fund companies began reporting that the big inflows of July had slowed, and even turned around, according to Mutual Fund Trim Tabs, a tracking service. About $3.2 billion was redeemed from stock funds last week, the biggest pullback since the late-winter selloff. But many investors interviewed this weekend said that they had sold some shares simply to take profits after the recent gains and to wait out the current downturn -- not to flee. **********Indeed, it is that kind of investor -- investors like Robert Boisselle -- who are powering the bull run. Mr. Boisselle, a retired real estate broker in Redding, Calif., tunes in to financial news every day, and calls up his stock portfolio on the Internet each evening. His advice to friends: stay the course. **********''We had a pretty fat correction on Friday,'' he said. ''But I've been through corrections before. In fact, I look forward to them as a cleansing of the market.'' **********Vince Capurso, a tax lawyer in New York, also sees therapeutic effects in a quick, sharp downturn. In fact, for more than a year, he has been slightly bearish on the market, worrying that his fellow investors were too euphoric. **********''I've got a friend who, at 50 years old, retired and got a severance package,'' he said. ''He took that money and invested it, and he's been making 30 or 40 percent a year. Now he has a couple million in the stock market, and he wants to be a money manager. He thinks it's so easy to make money, but the fact is, these are the golden years.'' **********In fact, Mr. Capurso said, four of his six closest friends all want to quit their jobs to become money managers. A nice correction, he said, might temper such exuberance. **********While Mr. Capurso frowns on overly optimistic market sentiment, he believes that the heightened interest in the market will help buoy its long-term prospects and prevent a small downturn from becoming a collapse. Ordinary investors, he reasons, are more sophisticated than ever, aided by technological advances that bring Main Street and Wall Street closer. **********Throughout the country, investors are trading shares over the Internet, tuning in to financial news networks and even wearing beepers to track companies that plan to split their stock; these investors believe that splits augur well for a company's future, and they quickly buy those shares on such news. **********Indeed, market news just will not go away. CNBC superimposes minute-by-minute Dow industrial figures, allowing viewers access to every uptick or downtick. CNBC can also be seen by passersby in Times Square, on a gigantic outdoor television screen. **********But that is not all. Customers at Brooks Brothers, while hunting for a nice new blazer, can check stock quotes at a Bloomberg financial news terminal. The Regency Hotel in New York also has a Bloomberg terminal, in its restaurant. **********There are also scores of Internet sites devoted to the markets, like Wall Street City, or the Silicon Investor for technology-stock buffs. And on the World Wide Web, stock talkers were debating over the weekend whether the market was primed for a full-fledged crash. **********On a Web site devoted to the market, one disturbed investor posted a message that read: ''In the past two weeks, the Dow is down 7 percent. I am sick and tired of people calling this a technical correction. The fact is the market is crashing.'' **********But another replied: ''I think it is a normal (probably overdue) correction. Why do you think we will have a crash? What economic/political/financial event has given you this belief?'' **********As for Mr. Sadoff, the unperturbed engineer, he said he would wait out the downturn and then sink more cash into the market. ''I've been lightening up on stocks a little in the past few weeks,'' he said. ''But when the charts start to show it's safe, I'll start sticking my toe in the water again.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/03/world.snippet: Driver of Israeli Army truck and 12 soldiers are hurt in firebomb attack near West Bank Palestian refugee camp, Jalazoun; attack is most serious in series of recent assaults on Israeli vehicles traveling West Bank roads; Israeli border police impo...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/03/world.main_headline: Army Truck Firebombed; 13 Israelis Are Wounded
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/03/world.print_headline: Army Truck Firebombed; 13 Israelis Are Wounded
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/03/world.body_text: **********A passenger truck carrying Israeli soldiers plunged off an embankment, overturned and burned today near this Palestinian refugee camp after a firebomb was thrown through its windshield. **********The driver and 12 soldiers were  hurt in the attack, the most serious in a series of assaults in recent weeks on Israeli vehicles traveling West Bank roads. **********There has been daily stone-throwing at Israeli cars in the West Bank and some firebombs have also been  thrown during a wave of violent Palestinian protests that began after groundbreaking work started two weeks ago on a new Jewish neighborhood in East Jerusalem. **********The Israeli Channel 2 television station reported tonight that Defense Minister Yitzhak Mordechai had approved plans to build thousands  more apartments in Jewish settlements in the West Bank -- a move likely to further aggravate tensions. **********The incident today occurred at a bend in the Ramallah-Nablus road that bypasses Jalazoun, a hillside refugee camp from which stones have been thrown at Israeli vehicles in recent days. **********The Israeli commander at the scene, identified only as Lieutenant Colonel Shlomo, said a firebomb was  thrown through the windshield of the driver's compartment of the passenger truck, causing the driver to lose control of the vehicle. **********The truck went off the road, overturned and caught fire, but the soldiers and driver were freed without serious injury. A fire truck from Ramallah was the first to arrive at the scene after it was called by Palestinians, and its crew extinguished the flames. Israeli medical teams evacuated the wounded. **********Colonel Shlomo said that tracks left by the attackers led to the middle of Jalazoun, where residents were ordered into their homes as soldiers searched for the assailants. Israeli border police officers circled the camp in a jeep, announcing a curfew over a loudspeaker and warning that ''violators will be punished.'' **********Outside Nablus, the Israeli Army moved up tanks to deter an attack on the Joseph's Tomb shrine in the city during a march by students to the home of a Palestinian police officer who was killed on Tuesday during stone-throwing clashes with Israeli troops. The shrine, guarded by Israeli soldiers, was attacked by rioters last September and six soldiers and two Palestinians died in gun battles. **********At the neighboring Jewish settlement of Itamar, two residents were arrested after they were accused of  beating a disabled Palestinian after their car was stoned. The stone-throwers fled, leaving behind the disabled man, who complained that he was beaten and who later identified the two residents as assailants to the Israeli police. **********In Gaza, Abdullah Shami, a leader of the militant Islamic Holy War movement, asserted that Israeli intelligence agencies, and not his group, were behind two apparently botched suicide attacks in the Gaza Strip on Tuesday that killed the bombers and wounded several Palestinians. **********But acquaintances of the dead Palestinians said they were known to be supporters of Islamic Holy War, which initially took responsibility for the explosions. About 30 Islamic Holy War members were reportedly arrested by the Palestinian police on Tuesday night.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/11/world.snippet: Egypt launches crackdown on rock music, following official accusations that fans have engaged in wild and perverse conduct that violates Islamic law against contempt of heavenly religions; fans are accused of activities ranging from satanic ritual...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/11/world.main_headline: It's Heavy Going for Sex, Satan and Heavy Metal
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/11/world.print_headline: It's Heavy Going for Sex, Satan and Heavy Metal
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/11/world.body_text: **********The official accusations have shocked Egypt's conservative society, with tales of clandestine parties in which young people took drugs, engaged in group sex and then unearthed corpses from Cairo cemeteries. **********The Egyptian press has been even more lurid, saying the young fans of heavy-metal music were performing satanic rituals, even urinating on the Koran and the Bible and slaughtering cats, rats and other small animals to drink their blood. **********Dozens of suspects have been arrested by Egypt's powerful state security police, and there have been reports that some may soon be charged under a statute that prohibits ''contempt of heavenly religions.'' **********''The first thing they wanted to know was whether I was chasing cats and drinking their blood,'' said a 21-year-old woman whose dark makeup and clothing are the uniform of a youthful rebellion in Egypt now under attack by the Government. **********The young woman, the lead singer  in an Egyptian rock band, said that the police in commando uniforms who burst into her bedroom at 3 A.M. on Jan. 22 had also questioned her about her religious beliefs and that she had answered ''by quoting the Koran.'' **********She and others who have since been released but still insisted on anonymity suggested that the accusations against them and others were the products of nothing more than popular imagination and official spite. **********The arrests were the first official crackdown on rock music in Egypt, whose main preoccupation in recent years has been the activities of Islamic militants, not what the Government calls a secular extreme. **********And because most of the suspects come from well-to-do families, the new vigil outside a Cairo prosecutor's office where they have been interrogated represents a jarring contrast from the usual crowd: women dressed from head to toe in black as they wait for husbands and sons accused of links to the religious militants. **********Of the more than 80 young rock fans who were arrested last month,  some 20 remain behind bars. And after weeks in which rumors of wild conduct by the young and rich leaped into the popular press, the official crackdown has been widely applauded by Egyptians who in taxis and coffee shops now refer disparagingly to the ''deviant youths.'' **********But the crackdown has been criticized by some intellectuals and human rights advocates as reflecting an unfortunate Egyptian predisposition to use security forces to address social problems. **********''The police can only arrest those who break the law,'' the prominent writer Fahmy Howeidi wrote in the Government-run newspaper Al Ahram. ''But they would be assuming a bigger role than they can fill if they think they can reform misdeeds.'' **********Like most things Western, heavy-metal music came late to Cairo, and it enjoys only a limited following. But over the last year its screeching guitars and often violent lyrics had emerged, for some, as a vehicle for the kind of unrestrained expression on which Islamic culture frowns heavily. **********Those who have attended them say  recent heavy-metal gatherings have at the least been notable for the consumption of alcohol and for public displays of affection, both generally taboo. In mimicry of Western bands and their followers, some fans have also gone so far as to adorn their clothing with symbols meant to have Satanic significance. **********Whether what occurred beyond the public gaze went further to include the kind of blood-and-sex rituals that the popular Egyptian magazine Rosa al-Yousef has described may never be known. But the reports that began late last year set off such an outcry that Interior Minister Hassan al-Alfi, the architect of Egypt's six-year crackdown on Islamic militants, swiftly pledged in reference to the heavy-metal fans ''to identify these groups and uproot them all.'' **********Among those who complained most loudly about the reported evil deeds was the Grand Mufti of Egypt, Nasr Farid Wassail, who as the highest authority in Sunni Islam wields considerable power even in what remains a secular state. The Mufti, who has portrayed the offenders as apostates before God, was reported to have met personally with Mr. Alfi last December to demand that they be made to repent. **********The ''contempt of heavenly religions'' statute under which the authorities say that those arrested may be charged was incorporated into Egyptian law to try to limit sectarian strife between Muslims and the country's Coptic Christian minority, legal experts here say. **********The law carries a maximum sentence of five years in prison, and was invoked in the early 1980's as the grounds for the arrest of militant Muslim preachers who had preached against Copts, who make up about 10 percent of the population. **********Among the offenses punishable under the statute are the unearthing of corpses, the desecration of holy books and the ridiculing of religious rituals or figures, including the Christian, Islamic and Jewish prophets. In practice, the legal experts say, the law has been more often waved as a club than wielded as a legal weapon, and some think that the authorities' main purpose now is to deliver a powerful scare. **********Among youthful sectors of Egyptian society most tempted by the extremes of Western tastes, the episode already appears to have prompted some behavior modification. **********''Almost everyone I know has cut his hair short'' to avoid being mistaken for a heavy-metal fan, said Akram Mustafa, a student at the American University in Cairo, an expensive private institution. ''And girls  won't wear their black lipstick or even their black leather jackets.'' **********But after nearly three weeks in which those still in custody have neither been charged nor released and face the specter of being charged with what amounts to an offense before God, people sympathetic to them have voiced mostly bitterness. **********''We all danced and sang when we were young, and we never got arrested for it,'' said a mother who recently waited in vain with her sister, her lawyer and the family driver for news of her son, who is still in custody. ''What's wrong with that?''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/19/busin.snippet: Lois/USA acquires Fogarty Klein & Partners for undisclosed amount of cash and stock; William Fogarty and Richard Klein will continue as co-chief executives of Fogarty Klein, and Tom Monroe will continue as president and chief creative officer (S)
