https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/19/busin.print_headline: Lois/USA to Acquire Another Ad Agency
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/19/busin.body_text: **********Lois/USA in New York said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Fogarty Klein & Partners in Houston, which would become a second agency network to complement shops operated under names like Lois/EJL and Lois/USA. The purchase will be made for an undisclosed amount of cash and stock. **********Fogarty Klein, founded in 1980, has estimated billings of $170 million from clients like the Garden Ridge Corporation, a chain of home-decoration stores, and Texaco Natural Gas. William Fogarty, 64, and Richard Klein, 62, will continue as co-chief executives of Fogarty Klein, and Tom Monroe, 51, will continue as president and chief creative officer. **********Fogarty Klein, which offers advertising, direct marketing, interactive, Yellow Pages, sales promotion and public relations services, has offices in Texas, in Austin, Dallas and San Antonio, and in Milan, Ill., as well as Houston. Lois/USA has offices in Chicago, Detroit and Los Angeles as well as New York. **********The deal is the most recent in a spate of efforts by agencies to add second networks, including the proposed acquisition of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt by True North Communications and the investment in Bartle Bogle Hegarty by the Leo Burnett Company.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/14/busin.snippet: Guinness PLC and Grand Metropolitan PLC say they will forge ahead with their $20 billion merger, this time with approval of LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton SA, which had said it would try to block the deal; LVMH's chief executive Bernard Arnault ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/14/busin.main_headline: LVMH Now Backs Merger Of Grand Met And Guinness
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/14/busin.print_headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; LVMH Now Backs Merger Of Grand Met And Guinness
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/14/busin.body_text: **********Ending a messy war over the future of the European spirits business, Guinness P.L.C. and Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. said yesterday that they would forge ahead with their $20 billion merger, this time with the blessing of LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton S.A., which had said it would try to block the deal. **********For his concessions, LVMH's chief executive, Bernard Arnault, is to gain control of most of the drinks distribution network of the new company, which will be known as GMG Brands, as well as a seat on its board. LVMH is also to receive $:500 million, or about $810 million, split evenly between cash and a special dividend that would be distributed to all GMG shareholders. **********Investors applauded the news, seeing savings, economies of scale and the end of what had been expected to be a protracted battle. In London, the shares of Guinness rose 28.5 pence, to 605.5 pence, and those of Grand Met were up 21 pence, to 604 pence; in Paris, LVMH stock rose 25 francs a share, to 1,248. **********The news came as a surprise to many analysts, because Mr. Arnault has previously shown a taste for lengthy fights. **********Guinness and Grand Met said in May that they intended to merge their drinks and foods businesses, which together make up the lion's share of the European spirits business, as well as Guinness beer and Grand Met's Burger King restaurants and Pillsbury food units. **********Mr. Arnault, who owns stakes in both Guinness and Grand Met and whose luxury-goods company owns several high-end spirits, including Moet et Chandon and Hennessy Cognac, opposed the merger, lest he end up a lesser player in liquor. **********Mr. Arnault instead proposed that Guinness, Grand Met and LVMH merge their drink businesses, that Grand Met spin off its food entities and that Guinness get rid of its breweries. He also sought a 35 percent stake in that merged company. **********Guinness and Grand Met took a dim view of Mr. Arnault's proposal. He then began to increase his stake in Grand Met, raising it to 11.1 percent. Though he cut his position in Guinness, he kept an 11.47 percent stake. That gave him more than the 10 percent needed to call a special shareholder meeting at each company. **********Eventually, the parties came to the bargaining table. Under yesterday's 10-year agreement, the current drinks distribution ventures of LVMH and Guinness in the United States, Asia and France are now to include Grand Met brands. LVMH is to retain the 66 percent it owns in its own drinks business, Moet Hennessy, and the 34 percent that Guinness owns will go into GMG Brands. **********It was not immediately clear yesterday whether there were three moderate winners or three partial losers emerging from the deal. ''It was a good settlement for both sides,'' said Russell Duckworth, an analyst at Deutsche Morgan Grenfell in London. ''Guinness and Grand Met have come to an agreement with LVMH and reduced the risk of them disrupting the deal. But they paid for it by giving up their side of the benefits of distribution.'' **********The merged parties estimate that the reconfigured distribution network will save them about $:20 million each annually in costs. But there is some question as to how much that savings may be worth, since Mr. Arnault's support came at so high a price. And while Mr. Arnault expressed pleasure in the deal, it is not as sweet as the one he had proposed. **********''It is disappointing to see that LVMH is not coming in 100 percent,'' said Martin Hawkins, an analyst at Greig Middleton in London. ''It would have been unusual if Grand Met didn't go through with Guinness anyway, so this added nothing to the merger but cured what would have been a lingering aggravation.'' **********Mr. Arnault may have conceded earlier than he would have liked because he had trouble convincing investors that his alternative proposition was worth the end result. **********LVMH shares have suffered recently as sales of its luxury fashion, leather and spirits businesses have been sluggish, in part because of a weaker yen which has limited spending overseas by Japanese travelers. **********Some of Mr. Arnault's biggest shareholders may well have been clamoring for results. ''I thought he would fight it out,'' said Cedric Magnelia, an analyst at Credit Suisse First Boston in London. ''But a lot of large institutional investors would not support his proposition.'' **********On the other hand, Mr. Arnault may use his new board seat, his hand in distribution and his generally aggressive nature to push for the break of assets he has sought. **********''Both managements have looked in the past and wondered if the groups together make sense,'' said an investment banker who worked on the deal and spoke on the condition of anonymity. ''If it makes sense from shareholder viewpoint, I am sure they will consider it.'' **********Regulatory agencies in the United States and Europe have yet to sign off on the merger. The European Union has already expressed some concern about GMG's possible dominant market position in Greece, Spain, Belgium and Ireland. European regulators may force the new company to shed some holdings; in that case, it would most likely get rid of secondary brands. **********Some analysts said they thought that regulators would cause little trouble, but others worried that selling pieces of the company would erode the point of the merger, which was to dominate all aspects of the spirits business. **********''The story of the late 80's was spirits companies wrestling back control of third-party distribution,'' Mr. Hawkins noted. ''Now, the regulatory authorities are trying to push back the clock by removing vertical integration.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/17/busin.snippet: Funds Watch column notes survey finding that many Americans are far more confident about their ability to select television set than to choose mutual fund (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/17/busin.body_text: **********Many Americans are far more confident that they can buy the right television than the right mutual funds, according to a survey conducted by Neal E. Cutler, professor of financial gerontology at Widener University in Chester, Pa. **********The findings suggest, among other things, that recent proposals to replace the Social Security system with private investment plans would prove to be very unpopular, Dr. Cutler said. **********''The public isn't ready to make the long-term investment decisions that privatization would require.'' he added. **********As part of a national study of financial literacy started in February 1996, Dr. Cutler asked 1,000 people about their financial knowledge of savings, investment and health-related topics. He also asked them how confident they were that they had enough information to make good decisions. **********A surprising result of the survey, he said, was the low level of confidence that baby boomers -- who are often financially savvy and experienced consumers -- have in their ability to buy shares of a mutual fund. **********The survey focused on funds, life insurance and home mortgages. But for comparison's sake, it included questions about three consumer products: automobiles, televisions and home computers. **********The boomers were quite confident about the quality of their TV purchases, with 82 percent responding that they knew enough to make a good decision. Meanwhile, 66 percent said they were confident to buy an automobile; 52 percent, life insurance; 50 percent, home mortgages, and 45 percent, home computers. **********Trailing were mutual funds, for which only 32 percent said they were confident that they could make the right decision. The low confidence level was particularly surprising, Dr. Cutler said, because of the high knowledge levels of the participants; a large majority gave correct answers to a series of true-or-false questions about funds. **********Moreover, baby boomers with higher incomes had little more confidence about fund decisions. Thirty-one percent of those who earned more than $50,000 a year were confident about their purchases, versus 27 percent of those earning less. **********The low levels of confidence may reflect the fact that over the last decade, mutual funds ''have become just as varied and chaotic as the larger equity markets that they were supposed to simplify,'' Dr. Cutler said. **********In Brief **********Thomas F. Marsico, who led Janus 20 and Janus Growth and Income to the top of the performance charts, left Janus last week.  Scott Schoelzel takes over Janus 20, while David Corkins will manage Growth and Income. **********John C. Bogle, the founder of the Vanguard Group, will step down as chairman early next year, and will be succeeded by John J. Brennan, the chief executive. Mr. Bogle will continue to advise the company as a director. **********Fleet Financial Group agreed last week to buy Columbia Management, which runs about a dozen funds with about $6 billion of assets. **********Shareholders of Pilgrim America Bank and Thrift, a closed-end fund, will vote Oct. 16 on whether to convert it to an open-end fund, which would allow investors to redeem their shares. It has been trading at a double-digit discount to the value of its portfolio.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/26/news/.body_text: **********Hospitals that once routinely performed autopsies have been cutting back to save money. But if anything, family members are quicker now than in the past to insist on answers about how their relatives died. They may suspect malpractice, or want to learn whether a genetic defect was involved. **********Pathologists who operate laboratories had quietly done private autopsies for years, without advertising their services. Now they are going public with services like the toll-free number of a Florida doctor, Brian McCarthy: 1-888-DR-AUTOPSY. "We can answer questions or relieve somebody's anxiety or guilt," he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/24/busin.snippet: A major Thai bank being considered for purchase by the American giant Citibank fired its president and chairman Tuesday in a management shake-up that analysts said would be played out across Asia's crisis-hit banking systems as foreigners move in....
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/24/busin.main_headline: Thai Bank Shake-Up:Foreigners at the Gate
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/24/busin.print_headline: Thai Bank Shake-Up:Foreigners at the Gate
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/24/busin.body_text: **********A major Thai bank being considered for purchase by the American giant Citibank fired its president and chairman Tuesday in a management shake-up that analysts said would be played out across Asia's crisis-hit banking systems as foreigners move in. **********"First Bangkok City Bank was considered to be a more family-run bank," Tanya Sirivedhin, assistant governor of the Bank of Thailand, said. "Credit procedures at some family-run banks are not as professionally run as would be desired." About 40 percent of First Bangkok's shares are controlled by Thailand's so-called whiskey king, Charoen Siriwattanpakdi, who holds most of the country's licenses to produce and distribute liquor. He took control of the bank about a decade ago. **********Owned by families or influenced by national industrial policies, banks across Asia ignored international lending practices and spent years building up portfolios of risky debt. Although eager for capital from outside investors, the region's banks have been reluctant to give control to foreigners. **********"These perverse lending practices combined with lax regulation and protectionist policies for local banks created the powerful concoction that led to today's economic crisis," a senior foreign banker in Thailand said. "Every bank in this country needs more professional management." **********The last six months of economic crisis have revealed the level of risky loans and prompted Moody's Investors Service Inc. on Monday to lower the national credit ratings of Thailand, Indonesia and South Korea to "junk" status, a rating normally assigned to risky corporate ventures. **********Although Thailand is desperate for billions of dollars to meet tough new standards imposed as part of the International Monetary Fund's bailout, a line of credit to replenish depleted government reserves, Thai banks and authorities have resisted allowing foreign partners to take control. **********"This reluctance to give away control is ultimately going to work against them," Sriyan Pietersz, a strategist at SocGen Crosby Securities, said. "Changes in the boardroom are a step to facilitating a takeover or merger that would in the end bring an infusion of new capital." **********Miss Tanya said the central bank, which holds a 15 percent stake in First Bangkok City Bank, approved of the commercial bank's move and hoped the installation of a more professional management team would raise confidence and stop a recent flood of withdrawals from the bank. **********Citibank's country manager, Henry Ho, said he had had no role in the changes and only heard about them after the official announcement. **********"We are in the midst of conducting due diligence, with 30 people reviewing all components of the bank," Mr. Ho said. "We will decide the value of the bank when we have finished due diligence by the end of February." **********"Thai officials are desperate to make the Citibank deal happen," said Masatsugu Nagato, general manager of the Industrial Bank of Japan. "There have been many rumors about foreign takeovers, but not many have taken place. Now the authorities have shown they are willing to take action to make changes happen." **********Thailand recently relaxed ownership rules that had limited foreigners to a 25 percent stake in the country's financial institutions. Now, with prior approval, foreigners may own 100 percent of Thai banks and finance companies. **********Changes may be taking place at the official level, but the lead editorial of The Nation newspaper Tuesday suggested popular sentiment remained unchanged. The newspaper accused foreign banks of acting with "undue self-interest" in a time of economic upheaval. **********"The Foreign Bankers Association is creating grudges among Thai corporate borrowers, bankers and policy makers," the newspaper's editorial said. "It would be better for members of the Foreign Bankers Association to keep their mouths shut and not use this fragile opportunity to bargain in public." **********But the symbolic importance of the Citibank deal has been raised by recent failed attempts to bring in foreign investors.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/04/busin.snippet: Federal Reserve survey shows even as more employers are driven to extraordinary lengths to find qualified people to fill jobs, bulk of American work force is still not winning sizable wage increases; as result, inflation pressures remain largely i...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/04/busin.main_headline: Fed Survey Finds Wages Still Contained
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/04/busin.print_headline: Fed Survey Finds Wages Still Contained
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/04/busin.body_text: **********Even as more employers are driven to extraordinary lengths to find qualified people to fill jobs, the bulk of the American work force is still not winning sizable wage increases, a Federal Reserve survey showed today. **********As a result, inflationary pressures remain largely in check, a situation buttressed by financial disruption in Asia that is curbing demand for this country's products while spurring imports of cheaper foreign goods. **********This double-barreled force for containing prices, and its implications for slower growth, was seen by analysts as further reducing the possibility that the inflation-wary Fed would need to raise interest rates. **********''Tight labor markets but still no sign of a breakout in inflation,'' said Paul L. Kasriel, an economist at the  Northern Trust Company of Chicago, of today's report covering developments through Nov. 24. ''And, already, there were some reports of slower orders from Asia.'' **********In a survey of conditions prepared by its 12 district banks for a Dec. 16 policy meeting, the Fed found ''a continued moderate pace of economic growth'' but with activity restrained by labor shortages, rail bottlenecks and weaker export markets. **********Other concessions to employees in the tight labor market include bonuses, discounts, flexibility on hours and workplace rules and the conversion of part-time jobs to full time. **********The survey also found that business travel and tourism continued to boom along the East Coast, with Boston and New York reporting a shortage of hotel rooms and rising rates, especially in Manhattan. The survey found that commercial landlords had greater leverage to raise rents. **********Central Ohio had an especially severe shortage of seasonal workers but the Cleveland Fed also cited a falloff in Asian orders for equipment to manufacture semiconductors. **********Banks in various districts reported a surge of mortgage refinancing, with rates of consumer delinquency ''little changed, on balance.'' **********In another report, the Commerce Department said sales of new homes fell unexpectedly by 1.7 percent in October to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 797,000, down from September's revised rate of 811,000. The department originally estimated the September sales rate at 800,000. Though the declines were widespread, it still left home sales at relatively high levels.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/09/busin.snippet: Sony Corp says that it plans $60 million expansion of its Sony Technology Center in San Diego, adding more than 450 jobs to current work force of 4,000 (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/09/busin.main_headline: Sony Plans to Expand San Diego Plant
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/09/busin.print_headline: Sony Plans to Expand San Diego Plant
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/09/busin.body_text: **********The Sony Corporation said today that it planned a $60 million expansion of its Sony Technology Center in San Diego, adding more than 450 jobs to a current work force of 4,000. **********The consumer electronics company, based in Tokyo, said the expansion would focus on a new manufacturing line for its large-screen computer tube production at its Rancho Bernardo site. **********The company expects the new line to produce an additional six million units a year beginning next summer. **********Sony also opened a $25 million, 277,000-square-foot engineering center in San Diego, called Genesis, which will create and test new products, technologies and manufacturing methods. **********Sony had sales of 2.170 trillion yen, or $18.31 billion, for the year ended March 31.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/09/busin.snippet: Copper prices rise after larger-than-expected drop in stockpiles renews expectations that demand will keep supplies lean (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/09/busin.main_headline: Copper Prices Move Higher As Drop in Supply Accelerates
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/09/busin.print_headline: Copper Prices Move Higher As Drop in Supply Accelerates
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/09/busin.body_text: **********Copper prices rose yesterday after a larger-than-expected drop in stockpiles renewed expectations that demand would keep supplies lean. **********On other markets, wheat prices rose and soybeans fell. **********The London Metal Exchange said yesterday that its copper inventories had fallen 6,475 metric tons, to 167,125 tons as of Monday. Analysts had generally expected a decline of 2,000 to 4,000 metric tons. (A metric ton is 1.1 ton.) The exchange's copper stockpile is now 48 percent lower than it was a year earlier. **********The decline provided the latest evidence that demand for copper is strong. Builders are the largest consumers of copper, and last week, the Commerce Department reported that American construction spending rose 2.3 percent in February, the second consecutive increase. **********''Stockpiles are falling because demand in the U.S. is still fairly good and the recent economic data are very constructive,'' said William O'Neill, director of futures research at Merrill Lynch in New York. **********Copper for May delivery rose 2.15 cents, to $1.069 a pound, on the Comex division of the New York Mercantile Exchange. On Monday, copper prices fell to their lowest point since Feb. 4 amid concern that rising  interest rates in the United States would curb demand. **********Wheat prices rose as a Chinese purchase from Canada raised hopes that other buyers were set to place orders. **********China recently bought 500,000 to 1.5 million metric tons of Canadian wheat, traders said, and could buy as much as 100,000 additional tons. Algeria, Egypt and Iran are also expected to order a total of about 650,000 tons soon, traders said. **********The sales put added pressure on worldwide supplies. The International Grains Council expects global inventories to total 100 million metric tons by June 30, among the lowest levels of the last 20 years. **********Wheat for May delivery, which would come from last year's crop, rose 1.5 cents, to $3.82 a bushel, on the Chicago Board of Trade. **********Soybeans fell on concern that demand for the United States supply would fall as record harvests are expected in South America. **********July soybeans fell 14 cents, to $8.535 a bushel.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/22/busin.snippet: Family control of Dart Group, retail empire founded a half-century ago by Herbert H Haft, effectively ends in Maryland courtroom; appearing before Federal bankruptcy judge, Haft agrees to accept $42 million in cash payment in exchange for relinqui...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/22/busin.main_headline: Founder of Dart To Cede Control
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/22/busin.print_headline: Founder of Dart To Cede Control
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/22/busin.body_text: **********Family control of the retail empire founded a half-century ago by Herbert H. Haft effectively ended today in a Maryland courtroom. **********Appearing before a Federal bankruptcy judge in Greenbelt, Md., Mr. Haft agreed to accept a $42 million cash payment in exchange for relinquishing control of the Dart Group, the empire based in Landover, Md., that began with a discount drugstore and grew to include Crown Books, Shoppers Food Warehouse and other entities that employ thousands of people. **********The settlement between the Dart Group and the Hafts ends a feud that had torn apart a family -- as well as a business empire -- over the last several years, a feud in which Mr. Haft dismissed his wife, a son and a daughter from their posts in the family-owned enterprise. **********Amid a thicket of suits and countersuits among siblings, parents and offspring, the family's real estate management company, Combined Properties, was forced to file for bankruptcy protection in 1995. **********Faced with the prospect that their feud could bring down their family fortune, the Hafts agreed to bury the hatchet, said David Roseman, a lawyer for the Dart Group.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/01/busin.snippet: Gwen Bennett's fight for control of Vernon Downs race track in upstate New York outrages victims of pyramid scheme allegedly run by her husband, Patrick Bennett, through his Bennett Funding Group; it owed $1 billion to banks and to 12,000 investor...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/01/busin.main_headline: They're Off and Running, but With Whose Money?
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/01/busin.print_headline: They're Off and Running, but With Whose Money?
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/01/busin.body_text: **********GWEN BENNETT grew up around harness racing. Her father was a horseman, so were her customers at a local restaurant, and so was the man she married; they had their first date at the Vernon Downs race track, and watched his horse win. **********So when she found out the track had serious financial problems, she says, she just had to get involved in trying to oust the old management and bring in new blood with new ideas. ''I'm doing this because I care about my community,'' she said last week. **********But what strikes her supporters as spunk looks like monumental chutzpah to thousands of people from faraway Miami to nearby Syracuse who are watching the battle over the track with outrage. **********That's because Gwen Bennett is the wife of Patrick Bennett, whom regulators accused a year ago of running the biggest pyramid scheme in American history through the companies known as the Bennett Group of Syracuse. When the companies collapsed, they owed about $1 billion to banks and to 12,000 individuals who invested in leases on office equipment, according to the bankruptcy trustee handling the case; roughly $600 million is missing. **********Among the missing money is about $4 million that Pat Bennett used to buy a stake in the small public company that owns the race track, the stake that Gwen is now using to try to take control, according to the trustee, Richard C. Breeden, the former chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission. He was appointed by the bankruptcy court with the backing of his former agency. **********Mr. Breeden is trying to stop the Bennetts from gaining control of the track. ''That would create a lot of new victims of this whole saga, and there are victims enough,'' he said. As long as the Bennetts are involved, he argues, the track cannot raise money and is in danger of closing, perhaps costing hundreds of jobs in an area where work is scarce. **********But Mr. Breeden is not getting much help from state or Federal regulators, the bankruptcy court, or even the Justice Department, which has taken no further action against Mr. Bennett after filing a criminal complaint a year ago charging him with perjury and securities fraud. **********Mr. Bennett has denied the charges, but has refused to comment further. His lawyers say that if mistakes were made, Mr. Bennett never meant to do anything wrong. He remains here in Vernon, a village of some 1,200 people, living in his family's elegant gray-and-white house, chatting with neighbors at the post office -- and talking with Gwen about her campaign to take over Vernon Downs. **********The track fight is rubbing salt in the wounds of the investors, many of them elderly, who have lost big sums in what they were told was a conservative investment. At a meeting of investors last month in Newark, a crowd of about 400 reserved its strongest applause for one of their fellows, Morton B. Kushner of Huntingdon Valley, Pa. ''It's been almost a year and Patrick Bennett is still walking around free, still doing business,'' Mr. Kushner said angrily. ''If a criminal stole $100 from a store, he'd be locked up in jail!'' **********The Bennett situation shows how widespread and unexpected the consequences of a huge financial collapse can be, and how they can seem to overwhelm the system that is supposed to deal with them. The S.E.C. says the equipment leasing was a fraud and filed a civil case against the Bennett companies last year. But the S.E.C. has no criminal powers and little control over people who, like the Bennetts, are not technically in the securities business. **********The United States Attorney's office in Manhattan says it has been conducting an active investigation, but the lawyer handling the case was, until March, busy prosecuting another matter. Securities lawyers say the case is finally heating up again, and there may be legal developments soon. **********The Bankruptcy Court in Utica, the site of most of the Bennett litigation, has been swamped with hundreds of lawsuits as people fight over what is left of the Bennett empire. The bankruptcy is unusually complicated because of ''the allegations of fraud, questions of how to divide the pie and questions of who owes the estate money and assets,'' said Harry M. Gutfleish, a lawyer representing creditors. Adding to the confusion is the fact that Bennett litigation is taking place all over the state. **********Investors say that dealing with the aftermath of the Bennett collapse has left them feeling angry, embarrassed, betrayed and neglected. **********One investor from New York, a freelance writer in his 60's who spoke on the condition that his name not appear in print, said he had neglected his work for the last year to cope with the Bennett mess. ''To lose the money is bad enough, terrible,'' he said, ''but then to chase after all the paperwork, try to network with others to try to find out what was going on -- it took up an enormous amount of time that could have gone to business, or just to enjoying life.'' **********LARGE-SCALE pyramid schemes, in which early investors are paid off by later victims' money, appear to be on the rise. Investors lost almost $500 million  investing in bonds and notes sold by Towers Financial, a failed bill-collection agency run by Steven Hoffenberg, who was briefly publisher of The New York Post. Mr. Hoffenberg was recently sentenced to 20 years in prison. **********In other recent cases, the S.E.C. has accused the Better Life Club of Washington of preying on low- and middle-income investors who lost about $50 million, and regulators have called the First Interregional companies in New Jersey the ''Baby Bennett'' case because it, too, involved equipment leases. **********Ponzi schemes do not generally hurt big insurance companies, banks, government agencies or even the overall securities markets. The victims are usually individuals, and they often suffer huge losses. ''When pyramid schemes collapse, the people at the bottom tend to lose everything,'' Mr. Breeden said. ''That is much closer to a street robbery'' than securities fraud, he added. **********And there are usually many secondary victims: children for whom there will be no college; spouses for whom there will be no retirement; communities, charities and legitimate businesses whose dreams were fed with money that may have been stolen. **********There were several such businesses in and around Syracuse, an economically depressed area for which the Bennetts once served as economic engine and beacon of hope. Among them was Vernon Downs. **********The race track, built deep in the countryside between Syracuse and Utica in 1953 when harness racing was a booming sport, is a pale gray oval three-quarters of a mile around, flanked on one side by gentle green hills and on the other by a sprawl of low white buildings that include an enclosed grandstand, a clubhouse and offices. Below these buildings is a series of stables that can hold almost 1,000 horses. **********During the 1960's and early 1970's, Vernon Downs boomed; on special nights, more than 10,000 people would show up and bet half a million dollars or more, and even an average night would find a crowd of well over 4,000. **********''I grew up here when it was lot of fun to come in and go to work,'' said Frank O. White Jr., 42, a soft-spoken and articulate man with light-brown hair and wire-rim glasses. Like his father before him, Mr. White is chief executive of Vernon Downs and the small public company that owns it, Mid-State Raceway Inc., whose stock is traded in the ''pink sheets'' listing of over-the-counter stocks; he has never worked anywhere else. **********But by 1980, Vernon Downs was in decline, as were all the harness racing tracks in the state. Gamblers were increasingly turning to the state-run lottery and to off-track betting parlors, which return relatively little money to the tracks. Attendance at the tracks plunged, and so did the amount of money bet. **********Fortunately, the situation was not dire, Mr. White said last week in his cozy office overlooking the track. Vernon Downs had no debt and had invested money during its glory days, so that investment earnings helped cover operating shortfalls. **********In 1992, when Mr. Bennett bought a controlling interest in the track from three of the founders, including his father, ''Pat was like the salvation, the answer to getting the industry going again,'' Mr. White said. ''He was very aggressive, a good marketer, and he knew a lot of people in the industry.'' **********He was also a high roller by Vernon Downs standards; Mr. White said that anyone who bet $3,000 a night was a big bettor at his track. **********At first, the new marketing plans all seemed to be working. Mr. Bennett also came up with the idea of building a nice hotel on the track's grounds, a plan that became even more attractive when the Oneida Indian Nation announced it was opening a casino less than five miles away. **********The track leased land to a partnership controlled by Pat and Gwen Bennett. The Bennett companies paid to build the Comfort Suites hotel, which opened in 1994 and was the first hotel to feature betting not just in the lobby but in the rooms as well, Mr. White said. **********Mr. Bennett also promoted the idea of corporate sponsors for special races. Such sponsorships eventually brought hundreds of thousands of dollars into the track's coffers. What Mr. White did not realize at the time, he said, was that the sponsors were affiliates of Mr. Bennett's. **********Looking back, Mr. White said, perhaps he should have realized something was wrong. ''There were always rumors about where all this money was coming from -- comments were made, but you didn't really take credence in them,'' he recalled. ''After all, they were the business of the year in Syracuse in 1994, one of the fastest-growing companies in America.'' **********But according to a lawsuit filed in the Utica Bankruptcy Court by Mr. Breeden, the money Mr. Bennett used to buy the race track stock was not really his; it was taken from various Bennett company accounts, the suit said. And almost everything owned by various members of the Bennett clan -- including Pat's brother Michael and his parents, Edmund and Kathleen -- was paid for with company money but ended up in the family's name, the trustee says. Among the family's onetime possessions were yachts, a gambling riverboat called the Speculator and a series of hotels and motels. **********BY late 1995, the Bennett empire was starting to crack. The S.E.C. had intensified its investigation of the company, which had been selling hundreds of millions of dollars of unregistered securities that the company said were backed by leases. Some of these leases were fakes, Mr. Breeden said; others were real, but were sold to as many as seven different investors. **********Even worse, the pyramid had gotten so big that it was imploding, Mr. Breeden said. Although the company was getting $13 million a month in lease payments, it owed investors $30 million a month. The only way to cover the shortfall, he said, was to sell a lot more phony securities or to raise cash by selling assets. Patrick Bennett dumped  stock investments and other holdings at cut-rate prices, the trustee contends. **********His Vernon Downs holdings may have presented a particular problem because, if he were to be convicted of a crime, state gaming regulators would probably force him out of the business. **********In December, Mr. Bennett transferred his Vernon Downs stock to a company controlled by his wife; she signed a $1.9 million promissory note. Mr. Bennett then sold that note to a longtime business associate from Long Island named Neil Wager. **********Three months later, the S.E.C. filed a civil suit against the Bennett companies, the United States Attorney in Manhattan charged Mr. Bennett with securities fraud and perjury and the Bennett companies sought bankruptcy protection in Utica. **********It was not until the end of April that Mr. Bennett met with Mr. White to tell him that the stock had been transferred to his wife. Though Mr. White knew Mrs. Bennett -- ''we talked, passed pleasantries,'' as he put it -- she had not been directly involved in the track. **********Mr. Bennett suggested that Mid-State's board invite his wife to their meetings, since she apparently owned 54 percent of the stock. But the board decided against it. **********Why? ''The integrity issue,'' Mr. White said. ''If the sport doesn't have integrity, it will vanish. If even the perception is that there isn't integrity, it will hurt -- that's the bottom line.'' That perception could come, he said, from any indication that the Bennetts might be actively involved in the track. **********The Bennetts took it personally ''that the track had to distance itself from their situation,'' said James Moran, the track announcer and publicity director, who has worked at Vernon Downs since 1962. **********''That's how the feud began,'' he said **********IT would take a hard heart to blame Gwen Bennett for taking it personally. She says that the allegations about the Bennett companies are too complicated for her to understand, but that they have destroyed her family. ''They make my husband out to be a crook, but I believe in him,'' she said, adding that she does not think any investor will end up losing money. **********A friendly and outspoken woman, Mrs. Bennett looks far younger than her 38 years. She still wears a large diamond ring and pendant but her clothes are not fancy; she describes her style as ''Casual Corner, $99.'' After eight years of staying home with her two young sons, she has gone back to work to support her family, running the Winner's  Circle restaurant at the Comfort Suites hotel. Like almost all of the family's assets, the hotel will probably end up in the hands of the bankruptcy trustee or other creditors. **********Mrs. Bennett said she had always been interested in the track, had concerns about how it was being run and wanted her husband to sell his interest to her. How was she going to pay off the note? Dividends on the stock, she says vaguely. (The company's last dividend payment, in 1994, was 10 cents a share; Mrs. Bennett owns 135,600 shares.) **********Why does a woman with so many problems want to get control of a money-losing race track? Her opponents have speculated that she wants to insure that she has work if her husband loses everything. ''I think she's holding on in the hopes that some white knight will come and rescue her, but we don't think she's very realistic, or has very much business acumen,'' said Ronald M. Terenzi, a lawyer with Berkman Henoch Peterson & Peddy in Garden City, N.Y., which represents Mr. Wager, the note holder. **********Mrs. Bennett says, however, that she is in the fight not for herself, but for the horsemen and the community. And she denies that her husband put her up to it. ''Anybody that knows me,'' she said, ''knows this is really me.'' **********During the summer of 1996, the track's troubles mounted. Although attendance rose, the amount bet continued to drop, and Patrick Bennett's corporate sponsorships had evaporated. Almost $50,000 was unaccounted for because of problems at the hotel betting operation, Mr. White said. **********The company's auditors, Coopers & Lybrand, had quit abruptly. (Mr. Breeden, the bankruptcy trustee, was until recently a partner there.) Because of the Bennett involvement, Mr. White said, it took him a month and many rejections before he could find new accountants. **********Meanwhile, Mrs. Bennett said, she had lost all confidence in Mr. White and the rest of the board after she heard they planned to borrow money without, in her view, a plan to pay it back. She decided to nominate her own slate of directors, including Robert McSweeney, the manager of the Comfort Suites, and Jeremiah Law, owner of the Squat and Gobble restaurant, where she was working as a waitress when she met Mr. Bennett. **********Now it was Mr. White's turn to be offended. The only qualifications of the nominees ''appear to be their past affiliations with and loyalty to you and your husband,'' he wrote in a letter to her. **********''The board's fiduciary duty to all shareholders precludes endorsement of unqualified candidates,'' the letter continued. **********The matter came to a head at a special shareholders meeting in January, which was attended by Pat and Gwen Bennett, a fact that made the Syracuse newspapers. Mr. Bennett may have tipped things over the edge when he questioned Mr. White about the company's pension plan; the Federal Department of Labor has accused Mr. Bennett of mishandling the Bennett companies' plans, a charge he has denied. **********''Our directors wanted to kill him,'' Mr. White said. ''He had the gall to get up and question our integrity.'' **********Mr. Wager, the Long Island businessman, also turned up with his own slate of candidates. One of them, a businessman from Muscle Shoals, Ala., was elected, along with Mrs. Bennett's candidates. But the board promptly moved to foil the Bennetts by expanding the number of directors to 12 and reappointing the three members defeated in the election. **********AFTERWARD, the lawsuits started flying. Mrs. Bennett, who has four more candidates she wants on the board, has sued in State Supreme Court in Albany to force the Vernon Downs directors to schedule another election. Mr. Breeden, the bankruptcy trustee, has sued in Bankruptcy Court in Utica to get control of the shares he says were really paid for by the Bennett investors. And last month, Mr. Wager sued Mrs. Bennett in Supreme Court in Mineola, N.Y., on Long Island, saying that because she has defaulted on her note, the Vernon Downs shares really belong to him. **********The race track remains in a financial bind. The Oneida County government has offered to lend the track money to preserve jobs, but not until the ownership issues are resolved. Mr. White says no one will lend the track money as long as the Bennetts are involved, and Mrs. Bennett says she can  bring in local investors, but not until the current management is out. **********Although the people in this drama remain angry and determined to prevail, there is also a note of regret and nostalgia in their voices. **********Mr. Breeden, sitting in the Bennetts' old offices in Syracuse and listening to the anguish of thousands of investors desperate for money, thinks about how much better things would be if the brokers flogging Bennett securities had been required to notify his old agency, the S.E.C., about their activities. ''I could have put a rule in place had I understood the problem, so it's a little frustrating,'' he said. **********Mr. White wonders if he should have gone into another business, one that was growing, not declining. ''I look at what Tiger Woods has done for golf and I think about things that are on the rise,'' he said. ''When I was younger, I thought I could turn it around.'' **********And Mrs. Bennett says she is determined to wear a happy face in public, but sounds sad. ''I wish for the days when we were entertaining our friends,'' she said, ''going to Vernon Downs and and watching the beautiful horses race.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/18/busin.body_text: **********Too often, mutual fund portfolios grow out of control as investors add interesting or new funds but neglect to prune their holdings. **********Now is a good time for a spring cleaning, says Maria Crawford Scott, editor of the American Association of Individual Investors Journal, in the May issue. If you haven't done it lately, review your mutual fund portfolio and discard inappropriate, redundant or poor-performing funds. **********How many funds is too many? That varies, but for a stock portfolio, Ms. Scott describes a five-fund model: a large-capitalization domestic stock fund, a small-cap domestic stock fund, an international large-stock fund, an emerging markets fund and perhaps a midcap stock fund. **********To create a complete portfolio, add an intermediate-term Government bond fund or a single-state municipal bond fund, maybe a high-yielding junk bond fund and probably a money market fund. Doing all that would bring the total to eight funds. Choose many more and you will be buried in reports and tax statements, spend too much time tracking the funds and pay for unnecessary duplication of holdings, Ms. Scott warns. **********If you have too many funds, extricate yourself from the thicket carefully, she continues. Decide which funds to keep based in part on your overall asset allocation target. Then look at which funds have the best long-term performance prospects and the best coverage of an investment category. As you prune, add the money harvested to these funds to remain fully invested. **********When you own funds with duplicate coverage and similar performance, first sell the ones in tax-deferred accounts, since that won't create any tax burden. Funds in which you have sizable gains in taxable accounts are more problematic, but don't hold onto subpar performers just to avoid incurring taxes. Eventually, a better performer should more than compensate for any initial tax payment. **********Consider taking losses to offset such gains. For example, if you have losses in a fund that you want to continue holding, sell shares and then repurchase them after 30 days. (If you repurchase shares immediately, the tax loss will be deferred until the second block of shares is sold.) **********Ms. Scott advises holding onto funds that are marginal performers if they have sizable gains, but says you should be prepared to sell them if the opportunity arises. That might occur if you have an offsetting loss in your portfolio, or if you are in a particularly low tax bracket one year. Otherwise, use the fund for withdrawals -- and don't reinvest dividends. **********Investors who want to own shares in only a few funds should consider a low-cost index fund, Ms. Scott says. Finally, fight the urge to invest in a new fund unless it covers new ground and can play a meaningful part in your portfolio, she advises. **********Advice on Rollovers **********T. Rowe Price Associates has started a service to help investors roll over their company retirement assets into individual retirement accounts. Investors complete a questionnaire, and Price then recommends an asset allocation and appropriate funds in its family. Representatives also oversee the rollover. The service carries a one-time charge of $100, which is refunded if the money is invested with Price. The rollover advice kit is available by calling (800) 472-5000. **********New Funds **********The latest entrant in the index market is Strong Funds. Its new Strong Index 500 fund aims to approximate the returns of the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index by investing in a limited partnership managed by Barclays Global Fund Advisors, which in turn buys the securities in the index. The minimum investment is $2,500. Strong Capital Management will cap expenses until at least 1999 at 0.45 percent -- more than double the cost of the Vanguard and the new Fidelity index funds. **********The Security Value fund seeks long-term capital growth by buying stock in companies that are undervalued relative to assets, cash flow and potential earnings growth. The lead manager, Terry A. Milberger, also runs the Security Equity fund. **********In Brief **********Scudder Capital Growth was renamed Scudder Large Company Value. Scudder Quality Growth was renamed Scudder Large Company Growth. **********Tweedy, Browne is offering a free 42-page investment booklet, called ''What Has Worked in Investing,'' to investors who call (800) 432-4789.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/24/busin.body_text: **********The Dow Chemical Company said today that its third-quarter profit fell 10 percent, as increased shipments of some chemicals failed to offset falling chemical prices and the strong dollar's erosion of gains in foreign sales. **********Dow Chemical, the No. 2 chemical maker in the United States, reported net income of $422 million, or $1.85 a share, down from $469 million, or $1.92, a year earlier. Revenue fell 2.6 percent, to $4.86 billion from $4.99 billion. **********More than half of Dow's sales are outside the United States, and the dollar's high value against other currencies makes sales in those currencies less valuable when translated into dollars. **********Dow's earnings still exceeded analysts' expectations of $1.81 a share. The earnings were reduced by $155 million because of the high dollar and falling chemical prices, the company said.

The closely held Network Multi-Family, based in Dallas, has more than 200,000 subscribers in apartment complexes in 38 states. Western Resources, a gas utility based in Topeka, Kan., also disclosed yesterday that it had sold 5.4 million Tyco International Ltd. shares to Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc. for $446 million. The sale reduced the company's stake in Tyco to about 4.6 percent from about 6.5 percent. On Aug. 15, Tyco agreed to discontinue all litigation with Western Resources arising from Tyco's $5.6 billion acquisition of ADT Ltd. in July. Western was a rival suitor for ADT.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/08/your-.print_headline: Briefcase : Clients Lacking, Fidelity Cuts Funds
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/08/your-.body_text: **********Little more than a year ago, Fidelity Investments boasted 23 currency funds and claimed it had the largest selection of any fund manager. But investors were mostly looking for dollars and Deutsche marks, and now 10 funds have been closed because of lack of interest. **********The most recent closures affected five funds, which invested in Austrian schillings, Norwegian kronor, Singapore dollars, Spanish pesetas and Swedish kronor. **********A Fidelity spokeswoman, Jo Roddan, said that although the relatively low interest rates of some countries had focused investment on major currencies offering higher yields, it was difficult to say why investors had stayed away. **********Fidelity aimed the funds at investors looking for offshore tax breaks rather than speculators. These investors were likely to be more attracted to high deposit returns than to the relative shifts in each currency's value, Ms. Roddan said. The funds aim to provide returns to retail investors at money-market rates, something usually available only to large, institutional investors. **********To achieve the economy of scale needed to affect such deals, Fidelity needed to attract more cash than it had in each of the defunct funds. As with previous closures, investors were able to cash in their holdings or switch free of charge into any of Fidelity's remaining currency funds. **********(IHT)

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/17/busin.body_text: **********The stock of the Eastman Kodak Company continued to fall yesterday, a day after the company warned Wall Street about weak earnings for the third quarter and the year. **********The shares fell $3, or 5 percent, to $57. **********In a conference call with securities analysts yesterday, Kodak executives said consolidation in the photo finishing industry has led to reduced prices for color paper. Competition with the Fuji Photo Film Company has caused Kodak to lose market share in the United States film business, and Kodak said the rate of loss has accelerated at mass merchandisers, drug stores and food stores. **********Kodak also said disposable-camera pricing was down about 7 percent from a year ago as it competes against lower-priced branded and private-label cameras, said Alex Henderson, an analyst with Prudential Securities. **********Kodak's chairman, George M. C. Fisher, said during the conference call that he saw no reason that the company could not achieve its 10 percent earnings growth target over time. **********The photography and imaging giant said it expected its promotional efforts and discount coupon offers to close some of the gap in film pricing and reverse the accelerated market share loss seen in the summer.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/04/world.snippet: New Israeli-Palestinian peace talks begin in Washington, with little chance of quick accomplishments since key Palestinian officials failed to show up; American officials are annoyed that Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat sent high-level officials b...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/04/world.main_headline: Israeli-Palestinian Talks Get Off to a Shaky Start in Washington
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/04/world.print_headline: Israeli-Palestinian Talks Get Off to a Shaky Start in Washington
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/04/world.body_text: **********New Israeli-Palestinian talks opened here today, but with little chance of quick accomplishments since key Palestinian officials failed to show up. **********American officials were annoyed, they said, that Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, had sent high-level negotiators but had not included officials with the expertise needed to help resolve specific issues that have blocked progress for nearly a year. **********Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright ''had a very blunt meeting with the Palestinian delegation'' and told them that ''it's going to be very hard to move'' without them, an American official said. Later this evening, she was told that two more Palestinian officials would arrive on Wednesday to join three others already in Washington, American officials said. **********The talks had already been delayed one week by the Israeli Foreign Minister, David Levy, who said he needed specific instructions from his country's full Cabinet in order to go ahead with these negotiations. **********American officials said they were irritated by what they saw as diplomatic gamesmanship on the part of both the Israelis and Palestinians. They complained that this only added to difficulties Ms. Albright faced as she tries to restore trust in the deteriorating efforts to achieve a permanent Middle East peace. **********American officials said they had given both sides a specific agenda and requested a delegation capable of doing the job at hand. **********Before the Palestinians acceded to Ms. Albright's demand to send the additional officials, the State Department spokesman, James P. Rubin, said of the absence of suitable Palestinian negotiators, ''It's a matter of concern, and we're trying to fix it.'' **********He refused to otherwise characterize Ms. Albright's reaction, but said, ''They're not here, and we'd like them to be here.'' He added that ''a significant part of the morning'' had been spent in discussing ''our concern that without them we won't be able to make any progress.'' **********Mr. Rubin also declined to say whether he thought the Palestinians were sending a signal, but Mr. Arafat, speaking last week, said the talks were ''a waste of time'' because of sharp differences in the Israeli-Palestinian agenda. **********On Sunday, Mr. Arafat said he was sending his second-in-command, Mahmoud Abbas, known as Abu Mazen, but only because Ms. Albright had invited him. He also sent two other senior officials; the problem today was the absence of lesser-ranking officials with expertise on specific issues. **********The Palestinians want to discuss a second withdrawal of Israeli troops from areas of the West Bank, a step that has been delayed since September, rather than concentrating on other interim issues that have held up progress in the talks. The issues  include a Palestinian airport in Gaza; a seaport; a planned industrial park in Karni, near the Israeli border, that could eventually provide 20,000 jobs for Palestinians living in Gaza, and safe passage for Palestinians between the West Bank and Gaza Strip. **********Mr. Levy, leading a delegation of 14 officials, said he was prepared to discuss all issues with the Palestinians, including the troop redeployment and Ms. Albright's request for a ''time out'' on unilateral Israeli actions that anger the Palestinians. **********Israeli officials expressed relief that it was the Palestinians who were now bearing the brunt of American irritation. But American and Israeli officials acknowledged that the new dispute was a reflection of the continuing Palestinian mistrust of Israeli motives.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/21/world.snippet: Adriaan Vlok, South Africa's former Minister of Law and Order and highest-ranking official to apply for amnesty, testifies that former Pres P W Botha personally ordered bombing that destroyed South African Council of Churches headquarters in 1988,...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/21/world.main_headline: Testimony in South Africa Ties Ex-Leader to Bombing
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/21/world.print_headline: Testimony in South Africa Ties Ex-Leader to Bombing
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/21/world.body_text: **********Edging closer to illuminating the role of top government officials in the political violence that pervaded South Africa under apartheid, the  Truth and Reconciliation Commission has received testimony that former President P. W. Botha personally ordered the bombing that destroyed the South African Council of Churches headquarters in 1988. **********The testimony comes from the highest-ranking official to apply for amnesty, Adriaan Vlok, former Minister of Law and Order. In the 84-page document he submitted to the commission, Mr. Vlok said the former President had told him to destroy the headquarters, called Khotso House, because it had become a ''house of evil.'' **********The Johannesburg headquarters was virtually demolished in June 1988 by an explosion that slightly injured 23 people. Mr. Vlok said Mr. Botha congratulated him later on a job well done. **********The testimony is the first to be made public that directly links the former President to acts of terror.  The revelations represent a major step for the Truth Commission, which was set up to uncover as much as possible about this country's brutal past. In exchange for full disclosure, the commission can offer amnesty from both civil and criminal prosecutions. **********In recent years, many parliamentary hearings, judicial inquiries, criminal prosecutions and private lawsuits have explored the violent crimes of the apartheid era. But no verdict has laid culpability directly at the feet of high-level government officials. **********Mr. Vlok's submission was handed  to the commission before the May 10 deadline for amnesty applications, but it was not made public until today when a Cape Town newspaper, The Cape Times, published excerpts from a copy it had obtained. **********In his application, Mr. Vlok said  Mr. Botha had asked him to destroy  the headquarters of the Council of Churches because the group was sheltering anti-apartheid activists. **********Mr. Vlok quoted Mr. Botha as saying: ''I have done everything possible to persuade them to come to their senses but nothing helps. We cannot act against the people. You must render that building of theirs unusable . . . Whatever you do, you must make sure that nobody is killed.'' **********The six-story Khotso House -- the name means House of Peace in the Sotho language -- had become a symbol of nonviolent resistance to apartheid. The explosion was one of a series of attacks on buildings housing anti-apartheid and civil rights groups, unions and church organizations. **********In his application, Mr. Vlok also asked for amnesty for his role in planning the bombing of a trade union headquarters in 1987, for defaming an anti-apartheid activist by falsely accusing her of a taking part in the Khotso House bombing and for engaging in efforts to place ''small explosive devices'' in movie houses that wanted to show the film ''Cry Freedom,'' which told the story of Steve Biko, the black nationalist leader. **********The application would normally not have been made public until Mr. Vlok was called to testify at an amnesty hearing. The Truth Commission issued a statement saying it was investigating whether any of its members had leaked information about Mr. Vlok's application. The statement also said that the deputy chairman of the commission, Alex Boraine, had already called Mr. Vlok to apologize in the event that it was responsible. **********Mr. Vlok said he was angry that his application had been made public prematurely but accepted the commission's apology. **********''I did not leak it and my attorney did not leak it.'' Mr. Vlok told the South African Press Association. **********Mr. Botha, 81, who was South Africa's head of state from 1978 to 1989, when he suffered a stroke, has been in retirement since then, living on a remote farm north of Cape Town. Mr. Botha, known for his irascible temper and imperious ways, warned as the Truth Commission was being created in 1995 that he would not seek amnesty or have anything to do with the panel. **********But after the chairman of the commission, Archbishop Desmond Tutu, visited him last year, he agreed to answer a list of written questions. He has not done so yet. Efforts to reach him today were unsuccessful. **********The Truth Commission was intended as a sort of compromise, a two-year inquiry intended to help put the past to rest without expensive and politically divisive trials. It is expected to issue a report on its findings next March. **********But it has had trouble reaching into the upper echelons of the former government. Most of those who have come forward to apply for amnesty are lower-  and mid-level security officers, many of whom believe they were following high-level orders but who offered no proof. Mr. Vlok, however, was a member of the National Party Government's inner circle. **********In recent weeks, the commission has come under harsh criticism from Mr. Botha's successor, F. W. de Klerk, who was President until the country's first election open to all races in 1994. Mr. de Klerk, who still heads the largely white-supported National Party, has accused the commission of being biased against him and has demanded an apology from Archbishop Tutu for remarks he made last month after Mr. de Klerk testified before the commission. **********Mr. de Klerk has maintained that torture, murder and terrorist acts were never government policy and that he had no reason to seek amnesty. At a recent commission hearing, he said he ''was as surprised as anyone else'' at the scope of the killings and torture that had been uncovered so far. **********This prompted Mr. Tutu to say he found Mr. de Klerk's statements hard to believe. **********On Thursday Mr. de Klerk turned to the courts, asking them to stop the Archbishop from making further statements that would harm Mr. de Klerk's ''credibility, impartiality or integrity.'' The suit also asks the courts to find Mr. Boraine, who similarly criticized Mr. de Klerk, unfit for his job with the commission. A hearing is scheduled for Aug. 26. **********In recalling the events surrounding the bombing of Khotso House,  Mr. Vlok said Mr. Botha had congratulated him on the success of the operation at a meeting of the State Security Council, a group that convened regularly to discuss security issues and was considered even more important than the Cabinet. **********Whether Mr. de Klerk was a member of that group at the time is not a matter of public record.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/16/busin.snippet: Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corp president Jack Bovender says company has received expressions of interest from number of potential buyers of portions of business, but it currently is interested only in selling its home care operations; adds company i...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/16/busin.main_headline: Columbia/HCA Cites Talks With Potential Buyers
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/16/busin.print_headline: Columbia/HCA Cites Talks With Potential Buyers
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/16/busin.body_text: **********The Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation has received expressions of interest from a number of potential buyers of portions of its business, but it currently is interested only in selling its home care operations, the president of the company said yesterday. **********In an interview, Jack Bovender, the president and chief operating officer of Columbia, said that the company was not currently negotiating with any of the potential bidders, who have emerged in the weeks since Thomas F. Frist Jr. was named as chairman and chief executive of Columbia, succeeding Richard L. Scott, the company's co-founder. **********''It's premature,'' Mr. Bovender said of the expressions of interest by potential bidders. ''People are starting to assume that we have this elaborate game plan about what we are going to do, and that is not true.'' **********Columbia, which has been struggling under the weight of an unfolding criminal investigation, announced last week that it planned to sell its home health care division, apparently helping to spark the interest in other portions of the company. **********Mr. Bovender said that while Columbia might later determine that there were portions of the company top executives wanted to sell or that the company had received an offer too good to refuse, the executives simply had not developed enough information to make such decisions. **********''There's nothing wrong with people sending a letter saying they are interested in something,'' Mr. Bovender said, ''but if they think it is going to create immediate interest, it's not.'' **********He added that Columbia itself was not for sale. **********Among the companies that have approached Columbia about acquiring some portions of it is HealthSouth, which operates rehabilitation hospitals and outpatient surgery centers. **********HealthSouth's interest, which was first reported in The Wall Street Journal yesterday, is focused on not only the rehabilitation and outpatient business, but also its diagnostic unit and occupational clinics. **********In an interview, Richard Scrushy, the chairman and chief executive of HealthSouth, said that he had let Dr. Frist know of his interest, but that no negotiations had yet ensued. **********''All I did was let him know I was interested,'' he said. ''They said they didn't know what they were going to do, and if they did they would let me know. There is nothing else to it, period.'' **********Mr. Scrushy said that his company was not interested in purchasing Columbia's acute care hospitals or home health care business. The company had approached Columbia last month with a tentative offer of $45 a share, but received no response and has since withdrawn its indication of interest. **********Columbia shares were trading in the low $40's last February, before the first indications of the Government's interest in the company emerged. But as disclosures of the investigations and other issues emerged, the stock lost about 25 percent of its value, closing yesterday at $32.375 a share, up $1.0625, on the New York Stock Exchange. **********HealthSouth investors also reacted positively to the news of that company's efforts to buy portions of Columbia. The shares rose as much as $1.25 a share yesterday, before closing at $23.9375, up 31.25 cents. **********In the interview, Mr. Bovender said that Columbia's home health care division had attracted expressions of interest from a number of other health care companies in the field. But he said that there were as yet no formal offers and no negotiations. **********The decision to sell the home health care division was part of a corporatewide reorganization of Columbia, which the new management adopted as part of a strategy to deal with Government concerns. **********Portions of the Federal investigation involve the home health care business, in particular whether the company's hospitals improperly shifted costs to the home health care operations in order to increase total reimbursement under complex Medicare policies. **********Problems with the company's cost reports have led to the indictments of three Columbia executives in Florida on charges of fraud. A Federal prosecutor said earlier this week that more indictments were likely.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/09/busin.body_text: **********Planet Hollywood names drinks after Demi Moore and Arnold Schwarzenegger movies. Hard Rock Cafe displays glitzy memorabilia like Billy Joel's old piano. At the Applebee's Neighborhood Bar and Grill in this suburb of Kansas City, the closest things to celebrity memorabilia are the autographed sneakers of Bill Elliott, a former basketball star at nearby Olathe South High School. **********And while there are no celebrity pianos, a used fire hose from the local fire department hangs on the wall. **********At Applebee's restaurants nationwide, the menu, too, has a hometown feel, featuring ''neighborhood specialties'' with local touches like chicken-fried steak in Texas and seafood gumbo in Boston. And if all that neighborhood feeling is not enough, there is the price: The average bill is $8.50 a person, at least a dollar lower than at many competing chains in the ''casual dining'' market -- including Chili's Grill and Bar, TGI Friday's and Olive Garden. **********The idea is to make the restaurants seem local, cozy and affordable. And so far it has worked. Planet Hollywood and Hard Rock Cafe may get a lot more attention, but Applebee's -- taking a far different, less citified approach -- has become the nation's largest and fastest-growing casual-dining chain in terms of number of stores and is among the largest and fastest growing in revenue and earnings. Today, Applebee's International Inc. has sales of $1.5 billion and operates more than 840 restaurants in 45 states, primarily in towns and sprawling suburbs in the Midwest and South. **********Undaunted by all the competitors in this corner of the restaurant market, Applebee's plans to double in size within five years, opening at least 135 restaurants this year alone. That means moving into new, sometimes more urban terrain, including the New York metropolitan area. **********Applebee's is also rolling out a new chain of Tex-Mex restaurants, called Rio Bravo Cantina. In addition to the 38 restaurants it now operates, the company plans to add 27 this year. Rio Bravo, which operates in the Southeast and Midwest, competes with chains like Chi Chi's and El Torito, both units of Family Restaurants Inc. **********But continued growth will not come as easily. Even as Applebee's expands, sales at its restaurants open more than a year have declined or been flat in recent years. **********Then there is the question of the company's relationship with its largest franchise owner, Apple South Inc. of Madison, Ga., whose chief executive tried to take over Applebee's in 1994 and who is opening a chain of Mexican restaurants that competes with Rio Bravo in some markets. **********Indeed, while a consensus of 16 analysts polled by the First Call research firm rates the company's stock a buy, Applebee's shares have been up and down since reaching a high of $31 in January. They were unchanged yesterday at $25.75. **********Applebee's -- the name was chosen because it sounded apple pie American -- was created in Atlanta in 1980 by Bill and T. J. Palmer, a husband and wife who sold it to W. R. Grace three years later. Abe J. Gustin Jr., now chairman and co-chief executive, and a partner who has since retired became franchise owners in 1986 and bought what had become a 41-restaurant chain in 1988. **********In the late 1970's, Mr. Gustin had been dismissed as national sales director of the Joseph Schlitz Brewing Company after he and several other executives were investigated by the Government on accusations of kickbacks and price-fixing. Although he was never charged with a crime, ''I felt if I was going to get back to work, it would have to be as an entrepreneur,'' Mr. Gustin said. **********Now, at 62, he is handing off Applebee's leadership to Lloyd L. Hill, a former president of Kimberly Quality Care, a health care company in Boston. Mr. Hill has no previous restaurant experience but was brought in to transform Applebee's entrepreneurial culture into a more corporate one. **********Applebee's is known for both its bite-size ''riblets'' and ever-changing menu. A popular new dish called ''N'Awlins Skillet'' -- a mix of grilled chicken, smoked sausage and sauteed shrimp, onions and bell peppers on a bed of rice -- is one of several new entrees served on skillets and priced as low as $6.99. **********The mozzarella sticks and tequila-lime chicken notwithstanding, customers say they also like the mix of the raised bar in the middle of the restaurants and the family-style booths, where children are given crayons and balloons. **********''It's a kind of Friday's-type atmosphere,'' said Kristina Quick, holding her 4-month-old daughter, Katelyn, at an Applebee's in Kansas City, Kan. ''I mean it's casual enough that the baby can scream.'' **********Her husband, Matthew, added, ''They have a pretty affordable brunch, and I'm a chicken wings fan, and I would rather not take my wife and daughter to a bar for chicken wings.'' **********Applebee's, based in Overland Park, Kan., a suburb of Kansas City, has capitalized on health-conscious consumers seeking alternatives to fast food at a time when some older chains' concepts have gone stale for many diners. Darden Restaurants Inc., for example, is closing about 50 unprofitable Red Lobster and Olive Garden restaurants. **********By contrast, Applebee's has reported several years of revenue and income growth, including a 23 percent increase in sales and a 30 percent jump in earnings last year. In the most recent quarter, ended March 30, sales increased 22 percent, and earnings grew 30 percent, the company announced this week. **********Its expansion reached New York City last week with the opening of a restaurant in Bayside, Queens, to be followed in the next few years by more restaurants in Queens and in Brooklyn. The company also has restaurants on Long Island, including one that opened in October in New Hyde Park, and on Staten Island, including one at the Staten Island Mall. **********In Westchester County, Applebee's has a restaurant in Mamaroneck and opened one last month in Mount Kisco. And in New Jersey, it has several restaurants, including in Paramus, Piscataway and Woodbridge. **********In the growth strategy of the company, its franchise system is seen as one of its greatest strengths. In a market dominated by corporate-run chains, like Red Lobster, Ruby Tuesday and Chili's, 80 percent of Applebee's restaurants are operated by franchise owners whose fees -- an initial investment of about $35,000 and 4 percent of monthly gross sales -- pay for research and development, staff training and advertising. That is in addition to the $1.2 million investment to build the restaurant, which does not include the price of land. **********The company says the franchise system provides it with entrepreneurs who have a keen understanding of their markets, everything from which local athletes' baseball bats to hang on restaurant walls to which dishes sell well at nearby mom-and-pop restaurants. **********''In our restaurants we had crab soup for a while, which was a very popular item in Maryland,'' said Harry T. Rose, who owns six restaurants in Pennsylvania, New Jersey and Maryland and plans to open five this year. **********Mr. Gustin, the chairman, said he never expected the chain to grow to its current size, ''but it just kind of continued to explode and grow.'' **********Yet Applebee's is not without its problems. Analysts note that the casual-dining market is becoming saturated. And Even as Applebee's expands, sales at its restaurants open at least a year declined in 1995 and were flat last year. The company, though, says it is shortsighted to focus on sales at those restaurants. This is happening, the company says, at a time when it is deliberately cutting into revenue of existing restaurants by opening others nearby in an attempt to dominate the market. **********There is also the question of the company's relationship with its largest franchise owner, Apple South, a public company that operates 354 restaurants, including 238 Applebee's. Tom E. DuPree Jr., Apple South's chief executive, once tried to take over Applebee's. And rather than buy into the Rio Bravo concept, he has invested in a rival chain called Don Pablo's Mexican Kitchen. Both Mr. Gustin and Mr. DuPree maintain, however, that relations between the companies are fine, and they note that Applebee's other franchise owners operate other types of restaurants as well. **********What the company cannot so easily dismiss, however, is the tougher competition it will face in larger cities. By operating in small markets, Applebee's benefits from lower real estate, construction and labor costs, which helps it, in turn, offer entrees at competitive prices. **********But ''when they get into head-to-head competition with people like Friday's,'' said John Gilbert, vice president of marketing for Friday's, ''they will struggle.''
