https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/07/world.snippet: Pres Clinton and family, in Spain for NATO summit meeting, spend afternoon on royal yacht with King Juan Carlos and Queen Sofia; photo (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/07/world.main_headline: Traveling Clintons Frolic On European Playground
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/07/world.print_headline: Traveling Clintons Frolic On European Playground
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/07/world.body_text: **********It used to be that President Clinton was an unrelenting traveler. Unless there was a golf course in the vicinity, he would rush from nation to nation, from summit meeting to state visit, in long grueling days without a moment's leisure. **********But weeks after his re-election in November, Mr. Clinton showed signs of easing his pace when he snorkled in the waters of the Great Barrier Reef during a visit to Australia. Then, just after New Year's, he lazed in the Virgin Islands. And he had been planning to play golf with a pro, Greg Norman, in Florida in March when he took the late-night stumble in Mr. Norman's walled compound that led to his knee surgery. **********Now having made the progression from wheelchair to crutches to cane to walking stiffly, but unencumbered, Mr. Clinton is risking playfulness once more. **********He stopped in this European playground of sparkling bay, soaring sandstone cathedral and late night cafes this weekend on his way to the NATO summit meeting in Madrid, where the alliance will admit new members from the former Warsaw Pact. Mr. Clinton is the guest here of King Juan Carlos and Queen Sofia of Spain, who keep a summer palace nearby. **********This afternoon, the President, his wife, Hillary, and daughter, Chelsea, set out with the King and his wife on the royal couple's sleek white yacht, Fortuna, barreling off into the Mediterranean with Juan Carlos at the wheel. Jose Maria Aznar, the Spanish Prime Minister, and his wife also joined the group. **********The scene quickly became slightly surreal. Queen Sofia playfully snapped camera shots of the photographers on land taking pictures of the Clintons and of her. Three small speedboats packed with American Secret Service agents traveled with the yacht -- one in front, two trailing. And a boat named Sinatra filled with American reporters trailed along farther behind. **********When the small flotilla passed alongside the Hue City, an Aegis-class cruiser docked in the harbor, American sailors lining the railing to see the Commander in Chief were called to attention and saluted. Mr. Clinton smartly returned the salute  and waved to the crew. **********Though a local English-language newspaper could not resist one article about the Senate hearings on campaign finance practices, which are about to open, the Clintons seemed as relaxed as the reams of tourists who cram Majorca's yachting ports and multicolored high-rise hotels. The yachters stayed on the seas for six hours, anchoring for a long time outside the small port town of Punto Andraitx, away from paparazzi and curious crowds. **********Mr. Clinton also proved an enthusiastic sightseer on this visit. On Saturday, just off an overnight flight from Washington on Air Force One and squired by the King, he toured Bellver Castle, a 14th-century fortress surrounded by a moat that features a panoramic view over the harbor and the surrounding city. The motorcade to the castle stretched 30 cars long. **********The President displayed his interest in architecture by pointing out to reporters some of the nuances of the castle. ''I've never seen anything like this before,'' he said. ''Two different architectual styles on two different floors. And round. Very rare, Gothic. Some of it is Romanesque, though. I've never seen anything like it.'' **********Reminded that the fortress was once a prison, he said, ''Almost makes you want to go to jail out here doesn't it?'' Mrs. Clinton laughed. **********The couple were soon joined by  Chelsea, who is touring Europe this summer after her high school graduation. After several hours in their quarters in the Almudaina Palace, a 10th-century Moorish castle with watchtowers and ramparts, the Clintons and a young woman traveling with Chelsea walked across a cobbled road to tour the Gothic cathedral that towers over the city. **********Late Saturday night, the Clintons startled vacationers by stopping for coffee and dessert under the outdoor awnings of a cafe named Cappuccino, and the Secret Service placed a phalanx of agents along the sidewalk outside the President's table. **********As the other diners applauded, the restaurateur presented Mr. Clinton with a saxophone to inspect. But the President did not try to play it. His aides said it lacked a reed.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/04/busin.snippet: Time Warner Inc and Tele-Communications Inc agree to create new joint venture that will own cable systems and to expand existing partnership; moves will also allow both companies to reduce debt on their balance sheets; two giant cable operators wi...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/04/busin.main_headline: Cable Venture Formed by 2 Industry Giants
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/04/busin.print_headline: Cable Venture Formed by 2 Industry Giants
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/04/busin.body_text: **********Time Warner Inc. and Tele-Communications Inc. have agreed to create a new joint venture that will own cable systems and to expand an existing partnership. The moves will also allow both companies to reduce the debt on their balance sheets. **********The two giant cable operators will create a cable company in Texas by pooling roughly half a million subscribers each. **********The two companies already have a partnership in Kansas City, Mo., that they will expand. Tele-Communications will contribute 95,000 subscribers to the venture, and Time Warner will put a small amount of equity into it. When completed, it will have about 300,000 customers. **********Time Warner, which is based in New York, will put $650 million in debt onto the balance sheet of the joint ventures, thereby reducing its overall debt burden to $16.6 billion from $17.2 billion. **********Tele-Communications, which is based in Englewood, Colo., is putting roughly $800 million in debt onto the balance sheet of the joint venture, reducing its debt-to-cash-flow multiple to 5.7 from 6.2. After the deal the company's total debt will be $13.2 billion. **********In a separate move, the two companies said that they were swapping cable systems in a variety of markets, including Florida, Chicago, New Jersey and Bucks County, Pa.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/29/busin.snippet: Moody's Investors Service on Friday cut the rating on Thailand's government debt to one notch above junk-bond status, as the central bank released a statistical snapshot of the country's increasingly beleaguered economy.. Finance Minister Tarrin N...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/29/busin.main_headline: Moody's Cuts Thailand's Debt Rating As Data Highlight Economic Gloom
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/29/busin.print_headline: Moody's Cuts Thailand's Debt Rating As Data Highlight Economic Gloom
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/29/busin.body_text: **********Moody's Investors Service on Friday cut the rating on Thailand's government debt to one notch above junk-bond status, as the central bank released a statistical snapshot of the country's increasingly beleaguered economy. **********Finance Minister Tarrin Nimmanahaeminda said he regretted the downgrade of sovereign debt because it would raise the cost for international borrowing by the government and the Thai private sector, prolonging the country's economic hardship. **********The downgrade was the third this year by Moody's, as Thailand faces its worst economic crisis in more than a decade. **********Moody's, which downgraded sovereign debt to Baa3 from Baa1, said further downgrades were possible, adding that the change reflected deteriorating credit and financial fundamentals in the economy. Ratings were also lowered for almost all the country's commercial banks, including Bangkok Bank PCL, Thai Farmer's Bank PCL and Siam Commercial Bank PCL. **********Analysts said the downgrade was no surprise, just a confirmation of the terrible state of the economy. **********The Stock Exchange of Thailand's index closed down 3.96 points, at 395.47, — about one percent — with banking and finance sector stocks posting losses. **********Until recent months, Thailand had been praised by the press as a commercial miracle and exalted by the World Bank as a model economy. But the monthly book of central bank statistics released Friday read like a cautionary tale of excess consumption. **********Department-store sales, which grew nearly 32 percent in 1995, have dropped 4.3 percent in the first nine months of the year. Beer sales, which expanded 17.2 percent last year, evaporated to 0.9 percent over the same period. **********Electricity consumption by medium-sized businesses, which grew 13 percent in 1995, fell nearly 20 percent this year to September. **********The news was not entirely glum: Thailand reported its first monthly trade surplus in a decade, partly aided by a fall in the value of the baht. But the current account — the overall measure of trade in goods and services — remained in deficit due to low tourism revenue. The Bank of Thailand's chief economist, Kleothong Hetrakul, said September exports surged 52 percent year-on-year in baht terms, compared with 25.1 percent in August. **********However, dollar-denominated exports rose only 8.7 percent in September due to an estimated 12 percent fall in the value of the baht during the month, she said. **********"The statistics are only now catching up," said Chris Baker, author of several books on the Thai economy. "But the economy has come apart over the last four years because no one properly managed liberalization." **********Liberalization brought a tidal wave of money at low interest, much of which was loaned to stock and real estate speculators through the country's 91 finance companies. **********The stock and real estate bubbles burst early this year, and in the past four months the authorities have suspended 58 of the now debt-laden finance companies. **********Hit by a slowdown in exports and overwhelmed by bad debt, Thailand was forced to float the baht after a costly and unsuccessful defense by the central bank. **********The statistics released Friday highlighted the bursting of the real estate and stock bubbles, with the value of land transactions dropping 27.1 percent in September from a year earlier, and a 48.8 percent plunge in the value of the total capitalization of the Thai stock market in the same period. **********Failing confidence in the finance institutions can be seen by the 57.5 percent drop in deposits at finance companies in September from a year earlier. And despite increased export demand thanks to the lower value of the baht, the Thai manufacturing-production index declined by 6.7 percent in September from a year earlier.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/30/busin.snippet: Renewed speculation about possible breakup of Port Authority of New York and New Jersey raises concerns about authority's bonds; experts hold dissolving agency would require far more political cooperation and willpower than currently exists, that ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/30/busin.main_headline: Jitters for the Port Authority's Bondholders?
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/30/busin.print_headline: Jitters for the Port Authority's Bondholders?
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/30/busin.body_text: **********WITH the recent appointment of his good friend and trusted lieutenant, Robert E. Boyle, as executive director of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, Gov. George E. Pataki has revived talk about breaking up the sprawling agency that operates the road, rail and air gateways to the region. **********For the many people who own a piece of the Port Authority's $5.5 billion in outstanding debt, that raises the inevitable question: How could such a major restructuring affect the value of their bonds? **********History can provide little guidance, Port Authority officials and bond analysts said, because no multistate agency has disbanded in the many decades that Congress has allowed their creation. **********But history aside, bondholders should relax, the experts said. Dissolving the agency would require far more political cooperation and willpower than currently exists, they said. And a major downsizing of the Port Authority through, say, the divestiture of its airports, would face huge financial and political obstacles. **********Even if there were a huge restructuring of the agency, the political pressure from Wall Street, major institutional investors and elected officials to protect bondholders' interests would be overwhelming. **********''My feeling is that there is no way they could split it up without bondholders being covered, because it would be so politically unpopular,'' said Andrea Bozzo, managing director of Fitch Investor Services. Fitch, a credit rating agency, has not changed the bonds' rating or put a watch on them since the recent developments, she added. **********Nevertheless, some bondholders may view Mr. Pataki's recent statements with concern. He has echoed Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's complaints that the agency favors New Jersey, does a poor job of running John F. Kennedy International and La Guardia airports and ought to reduce its real estate holdings. Indeed, Mr. Pataki told Crain's New York Business recently, ''In my mind, it is still an open question whether the Port Authority is salvageable.'' **********Mr. Pataki has made the issue more real by asking Mr. Boyle to study how to make the Port Authority work more efficiently, and, if that is deemed impossible, to propose ways to restructure it. **********Aides to both Mr. Pataki and Mr. Boyle said the new executive director's primary goal was to make the agency succeed, not kill it. ''The Governor sent him in here with the mission to see what it would take and how to go about making this place work,'' said Mark Hatfield, director of communications for the Port Authority. **********Making any changes would be highly complicated because the agency is the child of two states. Dissolving it would require the consent of both states' Governors and Legislatures. And though Mr. Pataki is raising the idea, there is little interest in Trenton. **********The agency has sold assets, as it did last year with the Vista Hotel and is considering doing now with the World Trade Center. Because all Port Authority revenues go into a general fund, the sale of a few properties does not affect the agency's ability to repay bondholders, analysts said. **********But what if the Port Authority were to reduce significantly its revenue stream by divesting itself of some big assets, like the airports? Many experts question whether there are even any takers for such properties, and if there were, whether the public would stand for privatizing something as important as a leading airport. **********Nothing in the bonds' covenants prevents such sales, however. And bondholders may not be fully reassured by the statements of Port Authority officials that any sale proceeds must be used to redeem agency bonds or to invest in new projects whose revenues could be pledged to bondholders. **********FOR instance, bondholders often get irked if their bonds are recalled early, said Jim Lynch, publisher of the Lynch Municipal Bond Advisory report. In such cases, investors lose a stream of income they had assumed would be there, and though they can buy another bond with the redemption proceeds, they may not find one as much to their liking as the one recalled. And even if bonds are not redeemed, bondholders who liked the idea of having their Port Authority investments backed up with revenues from, say, airports, might feel less secure if the revenues came from something else, like a real estate development. **********All the talk about restructuring the Port Authority has not affected the sale of its bonds, judging by a recent $300 million offering in January. Mr. Lynch said those bonds had fluctuated with the market, but not because of Mr. Pataki's remarks. **********That may change if Mr. Boyle urges Mr. Pataki to seek an agency overhaul, but for the moment many analysts are unperturbed. Mr. Lynch said major institutional investors still consider Port Authority bonds a good buy and do not pay much attention to the griping of politicians. **********''They know if the state were to try an end run, selling certain assets that are key to providing revenues, the state would be in court in a flash,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/03/busin.snippet: In a week marked by global flight to financial havens — notably U.S. government bonds — the dollar stood out only because it attracted so little interest. .Over the week, the dollar slipped 2.5 percent against the Deutsche mark, finishing a
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/03/busin.main_headline: Despite Global Financial Uncertainty, the Dollar Finds Few Takers
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/03/busin.print_headline: Despite Global Financial Uncertainty, the Dollar Finds Few Takers
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/03/busin.body_text: **********In a week marked by global flight to financial havens — notably U.S. government bonds — the dollar stood out only because it attracted so little interest. **********Over the week, the dollar slipped 2.5 percent against the Deutsche mark, finishing at 1.7250 DM. Against the yen, the dollar slipped 1.3 percent, to 120.40 yen. **********Running an annual trade deficit of some $200 billion and another outflow of some $20 billion servicing the U.S. debt held by nonresidents, the United States ranks as the largest importer of foreign capital needed to balance its international accounts. As such, said Paul Meggyesi of Deutsche Morgan Grenfell in London, it is "clearly more exposed to the contraction in capital flows which typically accompany financial market crisis." **********Moreover, the foreign-exchange crisis in Asia, which has spread to Latin America, has central banks selling dollars to try to thwart their currencies' weakness, forcing them to liquidate dollar holdings. **********Federal Reserve custody holdings of Treasury securities for foreign central banks have dropped $22.4 billion over the past two months, declining in just the past two weeks by a whopping $14.7 billion. **********"This is clearly of significance for both U.S. financial markets and the dollar," Mr. Meggyesi said. In addition, the dollar market's enormous liquidity — usually its strong point — can be a problem. Avinash Persaud at J.P. Morgan & Co. in London said the dollar had been sold most heavily when trading on the New York Stock Exchange was temporarily halted twice Monday. **********"The inability to sell stocks led to an increase in dollar sales, almost as a hedge against further declines in stock prices," he said. **********Similarly, he said, a sell-off in the Brazilian stock market led to a surge of dollar sales on the expectation that the spread of the crisis to Latin America would be damaging to the United States, the largest trading partner of the region. **********Further weighing on the dollar is the widespread expectation that the Federal Reserve Board will not dare to raise U.S. interest rates during the present turmoil, whereas Germany — being less exposed than the United States is to developments in Asia or Latin America — might continue to snuggle its rates higher. **********At the same time, however, according to Neil MacKinnon of Citibank in London, there is "no big appetite" to sell the dollar short. "The U.S. economy is in good shape," he said, "and the fundamentals are good." **********Trading last week showed strong support for the dollar when it dipped briefly below 1.7100 DM. **********Analysts such as Paul Chertkow at UBS Ltd. in London, who predict an early Fed tightening but no quick move by the Bundesbank, say the dollar is capable of a final bounce toward 1.80 DM. **********Others, such as Mr. Persaud, who expect U.S. interest rates to hold steady predict a drop. **********"The dollar's highs are behind us," Mr. Persaud said. **********"A downtrend is under way that will carry the dollar to 1.60 DM in a year's time." **********The yen, virtually all agree, should be weaker, but it is being supported by the global market turmoil, which is inhibiting Japanese investment abroad and probably encouraging some short-term repatriation of capital.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/24/busin.snippet: Delta Air Lines Inc says earnings rose 6.8 percent in fiscal first quarter; net income rose to $252 million from $236 million a year earlier; revenue rose 3.5 percent, to $3.55 billion from $3.43 billion; Southwest Airlines says net income rose 52...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/24/busin.body_text: **********Delta Air Lines Inc. said today that its earnings rose 6.8 percent in the fiscal first quarter, beating estimates, on higher air fares and increased traffic. **********Net income for the quarter, which ended on Sept. 30, rose to $252 million, or $3.26 a share, from $236 million, or $2.98, a year earlier. Per-share figures reflect the payment of preferred dividends. Revenue rose 3.5 percent, to $3.55 billion from $3.43 billion. **********The earnings easily beat the average estimate of $2.97 a share from 11 analysts surveyed by I.B.E.S. International Inc. The results extend a strong showing for major airlines, including American Airlines and the U S Airways Group. **********Another big carrier, Southwest Airlines, also reported strong earnings today, saying net income had risen 52 percent in the third quarter because of higher air fares and lower fuel prices. Net income rose to $92.5 million, or 60 cents a share, from $60.9 million, or 40 cents, a year ago. Revenue for the quarter climbed 12 percent, to $997.2 million from $891.5 million. The results beat an average earnings estimate of 58 cents from 17 analysts surveyed by the First Call Corporation. **********The shares of Delta, which is based in Atlanta, rose 12.5 cents, to $106.875. Those of Southwest, which is based in Dallas, fell 50 cents, to $35.3125. **********''Industry fundamentals are jelling right now both with higher-than-expected traffic and benefits from higher fares,'' said Candace Brown, an analyst at Merrill Lynch. **********Delta said revenue passenger miles -- a primary measure of airline traffic -- rose almost 5 percent, to 26.59 billion miles. A revenue passenger mile represents one paying passenger flown one mile. **********Operating expenses rose 4.2 percent, to $3.12 billion in the quarter. **********Earlier this month, Delta said its fiscal first-quarter earnings would exceed profit from a year earlier, contrary to a warning issued last month.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/15/busin.snippet: Indonesia's currency falls more than 6 percent against American dollar after Indonesian central bank allows it to float, joining other Southeast Asian nations in bowing to market forces (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/15/busin.main_headline: Indonesia Floats the Rupiah, And It Drops More Than 6%
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/15/busin.print_headline: Indonesia Floats the Rupiah, And It Drops More Than 6%
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/15/busin.body_text: **********Indonesia's currency fell more than 6 percent against the American dollar today after the Indonesian central bank allowed it to float, joining other Southeast Asian nations in bowing to market forces. **********The bank abandoned the trading range it had maintained for the currency, the rupiah, after a failed attempt on Wednesday to keep the currency within that range by raising interest rates and intervening in the foreign-exchange market. **********The rupiah was quoted at 2,830 against the dollar this afternoon in the Indonesian capital, Jakarta, more than 6 percent weaker than the level of 2,644 to the dollar immediately before the decision was announced. **********In allowing the rupiah to float to free-market value, Indonesia joined Thailand, Malaysia and the Philippines, all of which have allowed their currencies to fall after assaults on them in the foreign-exchange markets by speculators. **********The rupiah had tumbled after the devaluation of the Thai baht on July 2, amid concern that Thailand's financial troubles would spread in the region. Thailand, which has secured a $16 billion package of international assistance, suffers from a current-account deficit, mounting bad bank debts and an overbuilt -- thus weak -- property market. **********Speaking of the rupiah's decline, ''basically, there's no point trying to fight speculators,'' said Chong Yoon Chou, a fund manager at Aberdeen Fund Managers Asia Ltd. here. ''It will get worse before it gets better.'' **********Trying to block attacks on the currency, Indonesia had widened the rupiah's trading band to a 12 percent range on July 11. It sought to maintain the band by buying and selling the currency; in doing so, it spent $1.5 billion over the last six weeks. **********Until today, Indonesia had used the trading band to allow the rupiah to fall roughly 4 to 5 percent a year against the dollar in order to keep the nation's exports competitive. **********Finance Minister Marie Muhammad said today that Indonesia would maintain a tight interest-rate policy to help the rupiah. Overnight rates surged 16.5 percentage points today, to 36 percent. **********Higher rates generally support a currency by increasing the returns from investments in that currency that pay interest. **********The Indonesian decision to float the rupiah worried foreign investors because earnings denominated in rupiah convert into less foreign currency as the currency weakens. Hurt by that concern, and by the interest-rate increase, Indonesia's benchmark stock index fell 2.4 percent today. **********''Foreigners are concerned about Asia in general and the depreciation of the rupiah,'' said David O'Neil, head of research at Lippo Securities in Jakarta. ''Is it going to go down further?''                     -------------------- **********Dollar Rebounds Some **********By The Associated Press **********The dollar rose nearly 2 percent against the Japanese yen and advanced in most other foreign-exchange dealings yesterday on positive market reaction to data showing that inflation remained benign in the United States. The dollar was also lifted by further currency turmoil in Southeast Asia. **********The demand for dollars partly reversed a sharp drop the day before, though the rebound against the German mark was muted. **********In intraday dealings, the dollar traded as high as 118.10 yen, the highest level in a week, before settling in New York late yesterday at 117.94 yen, up from 115.69 late Wednesday. **********The dollar reached an intraday high of 1.8472 marks before settling in New York at 1.8407, up from 1.8352. The dollar declined against the British pound, which settled in New York at $1.5906, up from $1.5840.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/21/busin.snippet: Treasury securities end mostly higher, as renewed anxiety over growing inflationary pressure eases slightly; 30-year bond rises 7/32, to price of 99 13/32, with its yield declining to 6.42 percet from 6.44 percent; graph (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/21/busin.main_headline: Bonds Climb As Inflation Concerns Ease
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/21/busin.print_headline: CREDIT MARKETS; Bonds Climb As Inflation Concerns Ease
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/21/busin.body_text: **********Treasury securities ended mostly higher yesterday, partly rebounding from a sharp selloff Friday, as renewed anxiety over growing inflationary pressure eased a bit. **********Traders said that the market's ability to recover some ground provided a lift to investors uncertain about whether the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates at its policymaking meeting next month to thwart inflation's rise. **********The 30-year bond rose 7/32, to a price of 99 13/32. Its yield, which falls when the price rises, declined to 6.42 percent, from 6.44 percent on Friday. **********The uncertainty confronting the bond market last week was caused partly by the Commerce Department's report that industrial production gained seven-tenths of 1 percent in September, a reading much stronger than expected. The department also revised upward industrial production gains for the previous two months, raising the possibility that the nation's third-quarter economic growth -- to be reported next week -- is closer to 4 percent than the 3 percent estimated earlier. **********A lack of economic news this week means little guidance for a market trying to determine whether the Fed's policy-making board, the Federal Open Market Committee, will raise interest rates at its Nov. 12 meeting. But traders assessing the industrial production data said that the market might have overreacted. **********Maury N. Harris, chief economist at Paine Webber, said he believed a Fed rate increase remained unlikely, because the higher industrial production ''was accompanied by continued strong productivity gains, which helps contain inflation and also raises the Fed's speed limit.'' **********Mr. Harris said that a key determinant about inflationary pressures for the Fed would be the employment cost index for the third quarter, which is scheduled for release next Tuesday. Mr. Harris said he believed the index would register a gain of seven-tenths of 1 percent to eight-tenths, considered a modest advance. **********The only Government economic data this week are the August trade balance figures, scheduled for release today, and initial unemployment claims on Thursday. Next week, a crop of statistics are due, including Government reports on September durable goods orders and the third-quarter gross domestic product. **********Rates at yesterday's weekly Treasury bill auction were mixed, with the range mostly in keeping with expectations or even a little higher. The average rate for a three-month bill was 4.96 percent, down two basis points from a week ago, while the average rate for the six-month bill was up 3 basis points, to 5.15 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. **********Kim Rupert, an economist with Standard & Poor's MMS, a San Francisco market research and analysis firm, said that bills were looking a little expensive yesterday, especially after recent volatility in the financial markets drove some investors from both the equity market and the long end of the yield curve to the relative safety of the bill sector. **********A scarcity of new bills also helped lift prices. But supply may work against the market in coming weeks and months. Ms. Rupert noted that there is considerable corporate supply in the pipeline, while the Treasury will be selling about $27 billion in two-  and five-year notes next week, followed in early November by about $38 billion in 3-year, 10-year and 30-year issues. **********The following are the results of yesterday's Treasury auction of new three-month and six-month bills: **********(000 omitted in dollar figures)                     3-Mo. Martin Davies will serve as president of the company, which is based in Austin, Tex. **********Digital Anvil will initially make games that run on personal computers, and it is expected to produce games for video consoles in the next few years. https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/26/busin.main_headline: New Mutual Fund Prospectus Being Prepared by the S.E.C.
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/26/busin.print_headline: New Mutual Fund Prospectus Being Prepared by the S.E.C.
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/26/busin.body_text: **********The Securities and Exchange Commission is preparing to extensively revise the mutual fund prospectus, the basic sales document used to detail the risks and investment style of funds, the commission's chairman said yesterday. **********The official, Arthur Levitt Jr., said in a speech in Boston that regulators would consider removing disclosure requirements that have turned prospectuses into documents that ''tend to obscure the essential information that would help people make investment decisions.'' **********Under the proposals, which further flesh out Levitt campaigns of the last four years, fund companies could cut down on ''generic disclosure of technical, legal and operational matters common to all funds,'' including only ''essential information people should know about that particular fund before investing.'' **********To accomplish its goal of getting more people to read the disclosure documents, Mr. Levitt said the S.E.C. would propose the inclusion of a new risk-return summary at the beginning of all prospectuses, a narrative description of risks, a bar chart illustrating a fund's returns over the last 10 years and a table comparing the fund's performance with that of a broad market index. **********He expressed belief that the new measures would allow investors to discern the risks of a fund portfolio as a whole, rather than focus on detailed risks of ''individual securities or other tiny components of the funds' holdings.'' **********As expected, Mr. Levitt also said that the commission would consider adopting rules allowing fund companies to sell shares in mutual funds based only on fund profiles rather than on the full prospectus. Companies are now allowed to sell shares to individuals only after the potential buyer has viewed a prospectus. **********For two years, the fund industry has been testing profiles -- shortened versions of the prospectus that give basic information about performance and risks. The new rule would require that fund companies supply the complete prospectus to buyers only upon confirmation of their purchases.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/11/busin.snippet: European Union is expected to authorize governments to impose heavy sales taxes on callback services, which cut cost of international phone calls for European customers by dialing them through United States, where rates are much lower; France and ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/11/busin.main_headline: Europe's Cheap Phone Calls (Via U.S.) to Cost More
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/11/busin.print_headline: Europe's Cheap Phone Calls (Via U.S.) to Cost More
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/11/busin.body_text: **********European governments are preparing to steal some thunder from one of America's flourishing and most subversive exports: a backdoor way of making cheap international phone calls. **********Later this month, the European Union is expected to adopt a rule that will allow governments to impose heavy sales taxes on callback services, which can cut the cost of international phone calls in half for European customers by having them dial through the United States. **********France and Germany, which impose value-added taxes of 21 percent and 15 percent, respectively, on all goods and services, including telephone calls, have already announced plans to start imposing the taxes immediately. Every other European country has asked the European Commission for permission as well, and are all expected to follow suit. **********But at least some of the callback entrepreneurs, who are all based in the United States, say the Europeans will never be able to collect. The customers may well be in France or Germany, but the service and the billing is carried out in places like Florida, New Jersey or Seattle. **********''I don't see how they will be able to track us,'' said Eric Doescher, director of marketing for International Kallback, a Seattle-based company that boasts 90,000 customers and $100 million in sales. **********Callback services, most of which are garage-sized start-ups, have soared in popularity and sophistication in the last several years. European government officials recently estimated that the industry sales were $500 million last year and would probably hit $1 billion in 1997. Even the AT&T Corporation, which fretted for years about the legality of callback services, recently jumped into the market. **********The key to callback services is a mischievously clever way of exploiting the huge spread between telephone rates in the United States, where heavy competition has brought prices down over the last decade, and the rates charged by state-controlled monopolies in most other countries. **********Callback services essentially allow callers in Europe to reverse the charges. A customer in Paris who wants to call Dallas, for example, begins by dialing an automated callback service in the United States.  The person hangs up as soon as the American phone rings, and the callback service dials the customer back moments later. The person then dials the number in Dallas, and the call is put through. **********The result: the call is billed at American rates rather than, say, those of France Telecom or Deutsche Telekom. The savings are so great, in fact, that a large percentage of customers dial through the American callback services to make calls within Europe. **********But now European governments want to subject customers of callback services to their value-added taxes, which vary by country but are sometimes above 20 percent. Until now, the companies have been exempt from these taxes because their operations and billing have been from the United States. **********European officials contend that they are just trying to create a level playing field, because customers who use traditional companies like France Telecom or Deutsche Telekom pay the value-added tax. **********''The European Union is only trying to make it so that everyone starts on the same footing,'' said a representative of France Telecom. **********With savings ranging from 50 to 80 percent, the callback services would still retain a competitive edge even with the taxes, although some customers might find the slight inconvenience less worthwhile. **********The European Union's new rules could also affect on-line services and Internet providers, because they apply to all telecommunication services that are used by customers within a European country. In theory, according to industry experts, a company in the United States that offers on-line shopping over the Internet or that sells information would be obligated to pay value-added taxes to the government of each customer's country. **********That raises difficult practical and legal issues, because the Internet dissolves national boundaries and allows people to surf at random between sites around the world. To collect sales taxes, governments would have to know which customers were buying goods or services from which overseas companies and then somehow collect the tax. **********That prospect already rankles some European experts. ''How can the European community take a U.S. company and tell them that you are now a German citizen and you have to pay us taxes?'' asked Thomas Ulrich, general manager of Bendig & Partners in Regensburg, Germany, which provides Internet services and markets callback services based in the United States. **********Collecting taxes from callback services may be more straightforward. Georg Hofer, general manager of Telepassport, which markets callback services in Frankfurt, said his company would make sure the taxes were paid if it had to. **********''We are still investigating it right now to see if it applies to us,'' Mr. Hofer said. ''But we are prepared to do it.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/16/your-.snippet: LIONS are more commonly associated with Zimbabwe than tigers. But in terms of economic performance there is no doubt that the country is the tiger of Southern Africa. . In just one year, Zimbabwe's stock market capitalization has doubled. The tota...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/16/your-.body_text: **********LIONS are more commonly associated with Zimbabwe than tigers. But in terms of economic performance there is no doubt that the country is the tiger of Southern Africa. **********In just one year, Zimbabwe's stock market capitalization has doubled. The total, $6 billion, is still very small by the standards of developed markets — the Johannesburg Stock Exchange is capitalized at $283 billion, for example — but it makes Zimbabwe by far the most attractive market a region that is enjoying unprecedented growth. **********The 12 members of the Southern African Development Community all registered growth last year, eight of them at a rate of 5 percent or more. Such progress would be extraordinary anywhere, but it is astonishing in a region that until recently was torn apart by war. **********"Africa used to be tarred with the same brush. If there were problems in one country investors would ignore the rest," said David Masters, senior analyst at the Boston office of Micropal, the London-based fund data company. **********"But Southern Africa has changed, and now that people are waking up to the opportunities, there are going to be considerable inflows into the region over the next few years," he said. **********Zimbabwe is the region's most populous and prosperous country apart from South Africa and the obvious target for investors. It accounts for 0.5 percent of the assets of the 106 global emerging-market funds tracked from Micropal, up from 0.3 percent last year. That gives it the lion's, or tiger's, share of allocations to Southern Africa excluding South Africa, which rose to 0.7 percent of the funds' portfolios, up from 0.4 percent a year ago. **********Indeed, a number of funds dedicated to the region has sprung up in recent years. Morgan Stanley invests 21 percent of its $327 Africa Investment Fund Inc. in Zimbabwe. The fund, which trades on the New York Stock Exchange, has gained 27.15 percent so far this year. A further 43.1 percent of its assets are invested in South Africa. **********Other funds that now invest heavily in Zimbabwe include: Alliance's Southern Africa fund, Barings' Simba Fund, the GT Africa Funds, the Merrill Lynch Middle East and Africa funds and Calvert New Africa. **********Raymond Goldblatt, Capetown-based manager of Fleming's $86 million New South Africa Fund, devotes virtually all the fund to South Africa and Zimbabwe. **********"The Zimbabweans are managing their companies in environments of very high inflation [21.4 percent in the year to June 30] so their company earnings look very good," Mr. Goldblatt said. He favors the beverage hotels and leisure company Delta, the bank NMB and the building company Portholds. The New South Africa Fund has gained 21 percent so far this year. **********Investors in Africa and further afield bemoan what they perceive as a shortage of stocks in Zimbabwe, a common complaint in emerging markets. Not surprisingly, local institutions have an extremely low proportion, just 5 percent, of their investments in the stock market. **********"There is not nearly enough to buy, and buying can be a self-fulfilling prophecy," Mr. Goldblatt said. "By the time you put through an order at 10 Zimbabwe dollars a share, you find that it has shot up to 11 dollars a share." **********The country's ambitious privatization program should help. "The recent privatization of Dairy Boards of Zimbabwe Ltd. was a huge success and we expect the same from the Commercial Bank of Zimbabwe and the Cotton Company of Zimbabwe later this year," said Simon Ried, a broker at Edwards & Co. in Harare. "It is still very early days but all of this is very good news for us in this country." **********Shares in these three companies should be available to foreign investors by October, when exchange controls will be relaxed, at least for some offerings. By then, investing in Zimbabwe should be simply a matter of picking sectors and stocks. **********Agriculture, notably tobacco, is still the big earner, accounting for about 15 percent of gross domestic product last year after jumping almost 50 percent in local currency terms. Indeed, a prolonged dry season and resulting poor harvest in 1995 caused Zimbabwe's GDP growth to shrink to 3 percent, or about the current U.S. rate. One year and one good rainy season later, it shot up to 6 percent. **********The manufacturing sector is gaining fast, however. Analysts expect it to rise by 7 percent this year, thanks to improved consumer demand for beverages, tobacco and clothing. By next year manufacturing should be the largest contributor to growth. Manufacturing stocks should rise 48 percent next year in local currency and 32 percent in 1999, they predicted. **********The outlook for Zimbabwe's mining industry is equally rosy. Although the market remains depressed this year by low international metal prices, the Edwards & Co. analysts expect gains of 8 percent in 1998 after the Hartley Platinum mine comes on stream at the end of this year. "The high level of exploration activity currently being undertaken provides a measure of excitement for this sector," they said. **********Aline Sullivan **********- **********- **********For more information, call: **********- **********FLEMING'S New South Africa Fund, 2721 794 7007. **********MORGAN STANLEY Africa Investment Fund Inc., 1 212 762 7600. **********MERRILL LYNCH Middle East Africa Funds, 1 212 449 1000.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/18/world.snippet: South Koreans vote amid economic crisis to choose President to preside over far-reaching industrial overhaul; candidates, including front-runners, Kim Dae Jung and Lee Hoi Chang, seek to portray selves as reassuring figures able to lead nation to ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/18/world.main_headline: South Koreans Vote, Seeking Rescue From Economic Crisis
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/18/world.print_headline: South Koreans Vote, Seeking Rescue From Economic Crisis
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/18/world.body_text: **********Voters began casting their ballots this morning for a new President to rescue this nation from its financial crisis and preside over a far-reaching industrial overhaul during the next five years. **********As the candidates finished their campaigning on Wednesday night, bellowing in hoarse voices to shoppers in the markets, the election came to be widely seen as a milestone in Korean history. **********It is a bit like the American Presidential election of 1932, during the Great Depression, and each candidate is trying to portray himself as a reassuring Roosevelt-like figure able to lead the country to economic recovery. **********The two leading candidates, Kim Dae Jung (pronounced kim-day-joong) and Lee Hoi Chang (pronounced ee-hweh-chahng), were neck and neck in opinion polls, but they come from very different backgrounds. Mr. Lee is a former judge and the epitome of the establishment, while Mr. Kim is a legendary democracy campaigner in Asia whom past South Korean Presidents repeatedly tried to kill. **********If Mr. Kim wins, it will be the first peaceful transfer of the presidency to the opposition party in modern Korean history. Just 10 years ago, when Mr. Kim was also running, the country was rife with rumors that his victory would provoke a military coup. Now there are no such rumblings. **********In any case, this will probably be the closest and most democratic election Korea has ever had, and the dominant issue is simply who will be able to resolve the national crisis and restore South Korea to greatness. **********''I ran three times before in presidential elections, and this is surely my last chance,'' Mr. Kim declared as campaigning ended on Wednesday. ''I thank the public for reserving me until today, when the nation truly needs a strong and capable leader.'' **********Mr. Kim also warned that if Mr. Lee was elected, ''the nation will plunge into deeper crisis.'' **********Mr. Lee responded by suggesting that the financial markets would effectively punish Korea if it chose Mr. Kim. ''If a figure lacking credibility with the international community takes office, there would be a further exodus of our meager foreign capital,'' Mr. Lee declared, referring to Mr. Kim. **********Both Mr. Lee and Mr. Kim have lived in the United States and speak fairly good English, and each portrays himself as the international candidate with the ties to Washington that can help resolve the crisis. **********Both candidates now say they favor far-reaching economic changes in accordance with the International Monetary Fund's bailout of South Korea. **********Financial analysts said that the stock market would probably react better to a win by Mr. Lee, as he is regarded as more of a pro-business candidate, while Mr. Kim is seen as a populist who might be reluctant to close bankrupt companies and put people out of work. **********On the other hand, Mr. Kim has far more credibility with labor unions, and with the poor and disenfranchised. If Mr. Kim backs a far-reaching restructuring program, he may be able to do it more easily than anyone else. **********Mr. Lee is gambling that voters will be angry at the governing party but fearful of turning to the untested opposition at a moment of crisis, and he has spoken under the banner of ''stability against turmoil.'' **********''Since the economy is experiencing difficulties and the country is unstable, the entire nation must be led by a responsible and stable political force,'' Mr. Lee declared on Wednesday. **********Mr. Kim is hoping that the public will be so disgusted by the Government's mishandling of the crisis that it will punish Mr. Lee and the governing party, and he tells voters, ''the country needs a shift of power.'' **********Traditionally, South Korea has been fiercely divided by regional rivalries that go back many centuries but have been exacerbated in recent decades. Mr. Kim is the hero of the Cholla provinces in the southwest, and he normally gets almost all of the votes there but few in the rest of the country, particularly the southeast. **********Those rivalries are still evident in this election, but they may have subsided a bit. There is no candidate from the southeast this time, for Mr. Lee was born in what is now North Korea. **********In addition, Mr. Lee made a campaign swing to Kwangju, in the heart of Cholla, as a show of broad-mindedness. During his two-hour visit, he was heavily protected by riot-equipped policemen and by guards sent by Mr. Kim's supporters, who feared that any clashes could be used against their candidate. In the end, the visit went smoothly. **********''A national leader should not neglect any city or province,'' Mr. Lee thundered in his speech in Kwangju, which chafes at the neglect it has suffered from the Government for several decades. **********The campaign has also been remarkable for its historical ironies. In a tribute to pragmatism or opportunism, depending on one's analysis, Mr. Kim has allied himself with an erstwhile rival who symbolizes the military dictatorship that tried to kill Mr. Kim in the 1970's. **********He has struck a deal with Kim Jong Pil, who has strong support in the southeast but was the founder of the Korean Central Intelligence Agency and was a top adviser to President Park Chung Hee in the 1960's and 1970's. **********President Park's Government tried to murder Kim Dae Jung several times, and the K.C.I.A. once kidnapped him while he was visiting Tokyo, apparently with the idea of drowning him in the ocean. Western governments intervened, and Kim Dae Jung's life was spared. **********Under the agreement between the two men, Kim Dae Jung would become President initially, but South Korea could then move to a parliamentary system headed by Kim Jong Pil.
