https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/30/world.snippet: Pres Clinton's summit meeting with Pres Jiang Zemin seen showing how abnormal ties with China remain; talks before and during summit have been marked by extremely tough bargaining (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/30/world.main_headline: A Yield of Little More Than 'Normalization' of Abnormal Relations
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/30/world.print_headline: SUMMIT IN WASHINGTON: THE IMPLICATIONS; A Yield of Little More Than 'Normalization' of Abnormal Relations
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/30/world.body_text: **********The Chinese hailed today's summit meeting as a ''normalization of relations'' between Washington and Beijing, but in fact it indicated how abnormal the relationship remains.  Hot lines and reciprocal summitry, however useful, inevitably evoke memories of the cold war and United States-Soviet relations, which were anything but normal. **********But managing United States relations with China -- arguably the most important relationship of the post-cold-war world -- will require a more subtle, less Manichean cast of mind than the cold war did. Then, most elements of American society were on the same page. Now they are not, with business pushing for freer trade, trade unionists complaining about unfair competition from cheap goods, and members of Congress and churchmen stressing human rights. **********And all the while, more Americans, perhaps needing one, are coming to regard China as an adversary, if not in political at least in economic terms. In a new Gallup poll taken for CNN and USA Today, 36 percent said they regarded China as unfriendly or an outright enemy. In 1983, before Tiananmen Square, the figure was 21 percent. **********In a news conference with President Jiang Zemin of China this afternoon, an event that lasted more than an hour, President Clinton never once described anything that had happened during the Chinese leader's visit to the United States this week as ''historic.'' **********For the usually ebullient Mr. Clinton, who often points with pride to landmarks and milestones and political breakthroughs, it was a telling omission that epitomized the difficulty of relations between Beijing and Washington. If he seemed muted, an American official said, it was because the negotiations before and during this summit conference, the first of its type in a decade, have been marked by ''ask-no-quarter, give-no-quarter bargaining.'' **********The official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said that ''after days and days and days, we have found it difficult to have even the most basic kinds of discussions with China,'' except for an important agreement on the first export to China of advanced American nuclear technology. **********On the crucial question of human rights, the two leaders might as well have been on different planets. Top American negotiators had tried to convince Mr. Jiang at least to express remorse for the deaths of demonstrators in Tiananmen Square in 1989, even if he was unwilling to say the decision to open fire was wrong. **********When Mr. Jiang did not do so, and instead said at the news conference that the Chinese Government had ''drawn the correct conclusion'' and moved swiftly to insure stability, and when he said blandly that ''it is just natural for our two countries to hold different views on some issues,'' Mr. Clinton had no choice, his aides said, but to respond bluntly. He did so, asserting that the shootings and ''the continuing reluctance to tolerate political dissent'' had kept China from developing a significant level of support in the world. **********It was a stark admission of failure, unusual in summit annals. **********The plain fact is that in Chinese-American relations many of the most important questions are not susceptible of solution by top political leaders, or they are susceptible of solution only by running greater risks than the politicians are willing to accept. Most of the progress that has been made, and it is limited, has been made by businessmen and only ratified later by governments, like the big deal under which Boeing will sell 50 jetliners to China. **********''In many senses,'' Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin told American executives in Beijing last month, ''you have invested in this relationship more fully than we have in Washington.'' And today Mr. Clinton gave a certain primacy to economics when he was asked why the United States did not try to broker an agreement between China and Taiwan, as it had sought to do in Bosnia and the Middle East. **********''Since so much investment and contact has gone on in the last few years between Taiwan and China, I think the Chinese people know how to resolve this when the time is right,'' he said, taking the ball from the hands of the diplomats and putting it squarely in the hands of business. **********Except in Washington, where such events always matter more than they do in the country at large, the spotlight has been stolen from the summit conference by the gyrations of Wall Street, gyrations that had their origin in Southeast Asia and in China's new special administrative zone, Hong Kong. **********Only 15 years ago, Americans and their Government felt powerless to stop the march of the Asian economies, and they feared the loss of jobs and control of American financial markets. Now they feel powerless to halt the rot in the Asian economies, and they still fear the loss of jobs and control of American financial markets. **********When cracks began to appear in the ''tiger economies'' of Southeast Asia some months ago, the Administration decided not to attempt any bailout of the type used successfully during the Mexican crisis of 1994-95.  Mr. Rubin has said repeatedly that the United States must not allow itself to be seen as the world's banker of last resort, ready to step into every financial crisis everywhere.  To do so, he has contended, would spawn more crises. **********Even after Monday's plunge in stock prices on Wall Street, there was more talk than action in Washington. That brought criticism from some experts on the region, including a former ambassador, a Democrat, who described the failure to intervene as ''a craven and ultimately damaging approach.'' **********Ultimately, government has to try in some areas, no matter what the problems, because there are a number of things that business cannot or will not do. Human rights are one subject to which business executives are averse. Nor can they negotiate trade agreements, so the Clinton Administration has put a huge effort into finding some way to to integrate China into the world economy and into making it possible for Beijing to join the World Trade Organization. **********But no headway at all was reported after this summit meeting on that difficult subject, either. **********The best the two leaders and their associates could do was concentrate on process, agreeing to meet regularly and to set up a communications link. Mr. Clinton agreed to visit China next spring. Mr. Rubin and Zhu Rongji, China's economic czar, agreed to talk about instability in financial markets. **********There was also talk of ''a constructive strategic partnership,'' but precious little flesh was put onto those bare rhetorical bones, beyond some generalized talk about dealing with continued instability on the Korean peninsula and some significant progress in coping with the touchy problem of nuclear proliferation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/13/world.snippet: Over 100,000 desperate Hutu refugees have fled to makeshift camp near Ubundu, Zaire, pursued by Tutsi-led rebels; rebels, led by Laurent Kabila, maintain that their goal is to overthrow Zaire's longtime dictator, Mobutu Sese Seko; they also want t...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/13/world.main_headline: Hutu Refugees Trapped in Zaire Between Tutsi and the Crocodiles
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/13/world.print_headline: Hutu Refugees Trapped in Zaire Between Tutsi and the Crocodiles
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/13/world.body_text: **********For worn and famished refugees, the makeshift camp strung out like a splintered cross alongside this town's grassy landing field has the frightening feel of the end of the line. **********After a walk of over 300 miles, pursued by this country's Tutsi-led rebels through some of Africa's thickest jungles, terrorized and uprooted each time they set up camp, more than 100,000 desperate Hutu have come to gather here. **********Ahead lie the crocodile-infested rapids of the Congo, which they have no means to cross. From behind, perhaps as little as 20 miles away, their pursuers are approaching, threatening a vengeful rout. **********From the start of Zaire's civil war, the conflict's goals have been neatly twinned. All along, the rebels, led by Laurent Kabila, have maintained that their goal is to overthrow Zaire's longtime dictator, Mobutu Sese Seko. **********But throughout, their campaign has just as surely revealed another consistent priority: breaking up the huge concentrations of Hutu who have sought refuge in Zaire since Rwanda's own civil war in 1994 and hunting down all those hiding among them who may have taken part in the massacres committed against the Tutsi. Many among the fleeing Hutu have been armed by Zaire's Government as counterinsurgents. **********Never have the rebellion's two goals been closer to realization. Mr. Kabila's fighters are already believed to be surrounding the regional capital, Kisangani. And a successful rebel push through this area would decimate the haggard Hutu population -- the largest remaining Hutu refugee group in Zaire -- just as surely as the capture of Kisangani would deliver a crippling blow to Mr. Mobutu's Government. **********''We are hungry and we are sick, but above all we have lost all morale,'' said Imaculee Mukarugwiza, a widowed Hutu schoolteacher huddled here with her own two children and five orphans she has taken in since Zaire's rebellion set off the long westward march of refugees in October. ''After what we have been through, it is hard for many of us to recognize each other. Our elders are shriveled and dying and our children already look old.'' **********Questions of strategy debated on both sides of this country's war are mere abstractions for the refugees gathered in the open fields here. Their worst nightmare is a repetition of the routs they have suffered every step of the way, from the rebel bombardment of the huge Goma camp at the war's start to the overrunning of their last settlement at Tingi Tingi. **********''Are all of us guilty of genocide, even these little children?'' asked Mrs. Mukarugwiza. ''We have been chased through the bush like animals. And in three days, Kabila's men will be upon us again, leaving 100,000 of us a choice of death under their bombs or in the jaws of crocodiles.'' **********As she spoke, a sea of people in tattered clothing, many of them visibly weakened by their trek, gathered around one of the first foreigners they have laid eyes on since fleeing Tingi Tingi 11 days ago under a hail of bullets. **********Far from a scene of mass confusion, one quickly makes out the steely young men who, with a whisper and hand sign, or a few words in Kinyarwanda, seem to easily command obedience and keep order. **********Though most of the Hutu refugees in Zaire played little or no role in the 1994 massacres, international relief officials say that many of these authoritative young men are veterans of Rwanda's former Hutu-dominated army or members of Interahamwe, the militia that carried out a campaign of killing against Rwanda's Tutsi minority. **********The campaign against the Hutu refugees has been especially unforgiving, foreign diplomats and Zairian human rights experts say, because many of Mr. Kabila's fighters pushing westward toward Kisangani are Tutsi volunteers from Rwanda bent on avenging the death of relatives at the hands of Hutu. **********For weeks before Mr. Kabila's men made their push on Tingi Tingi, then home to more than 150,000 Hutu, Zaire's constantly retreating army plied the refugee camp with weapons, hoping that properly armed, the former Hutu soldiers would blunt the rebellion's advance. Under international pressure for a cease-fire, Mr. Kabila pledged he would not attack the Tingi Tingi camp, only to have his men overrun it a few days later. **********Refugees here who traveled for more than a week through dense forest tell of being chased for days with the sound of gunfire and mortars seemingly never more that a bend in the footpath away. **********''We walked all day and all night because there was no way to rest,'' said Dr. Camille Kabakira, who has still not seen several of his family members since the attack. ''So many people got lost and left behind in the terror. There was a panic and people scattered as best they could.'' **********In this respect, Zaire's civil war has meant the pursuit of Rwanda's ethnic conflict clear across a neighboring country. Since there appears to be no end to the blood animosity between Hutu and Tutsi, the only answer many Hutu here see for themselves is to beg for international protection or keep pushing westward. **********The refugees' current position makes that second option extremely perilous. The Zaire Government has forbidden the use of a ferry to carry the Hutu across the Congo River. And even if it were to approve, officials of the United Nations High Commission for Refugees estimated that it would take 100 days to get all of the people across. **********''Let's say they got across the river,'' said Corrine Perthuis, a commission official. ''It wouldn't change anything. We must find a way to provide security for these people from attack.'' **********There has been much talk in recent weeks as well of a ''humanitarian corridor'' that would allow the able-bodied to walk or return in trucks to Rwanda. Despite what they have experienced in their flight across Zaire, however, only a minority of the refugees seemed eager to return home. **********Asked who among them would board a plane for Kigali, the Rwandan capital, if one were to arrive, a handful of men in a thick crowd began to raise their hands before a debate rose up and they were intimidated into changing their answers. **********''If we go to Kigali, it is just making their job of getting rid of us easier,'' said Christophe Sibomana, an angry, rail-thin 30-year-old, referring to Rwanda's Tutsi-dominated Army. ''We would prefer dying right here and leaving the burden on the conscience of the world.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/04/world.snippet: US orders sailors on its vessels docking in Manama, Bahrain, to be denied liberty after US Embassy receives information that terrorist attack might be planned against US forces in Bahrain; map (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/04/world.main_headline: In a Bahrain Port, No More Sailors on the Town
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/04/world.print_headline: In a Bahrain Port, No More Sailors on the Town
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/04/world.body_text: **********As a liberty port, Manama cannot compete with the raunchiness of Manila or Bangkok, but the men and women of the United States Navy still regard it as an oasis in the heart of the Persian Gulf. **********Filipino barmaids, to the blare of heavy-metal music, serve up Coors in cans -- nectar in a sheikdom sandwiched by Saudi Arabia and Iran. **********''It would take a brave man to open a girlie bar,'' as one foreigner hastened to point out, but Bahrain has managed to carve out a spirit so cosmopolitan that a framed commendation in one nightspot begins ''Thanks for the nights we can't remember.'' **********So some dismay and apprehension have settled in here in the weeks since the United States abruptly ordered sailors on its vessels docking here to be denied the liberty that had become a custom. At the same time, a 7 P.M. curfew was imposed for all of the 1,000 land-based Navy personnel at the headquarters here of its Fifth Fleet, and the United States Embassy has recommended that even American civilians steer clear of bars and restaurants, saying it has received information that a terrorist attack might be planned against American forces in Bahrain. **********Now the bar stools and dance floors that offered an antidote for thousands of sailors every month are almost empty. Bahrain, a safe and welcoming harbor to the Navy for nearly 50 years, is no longer seen as immune from the kind of anti-American militancy that has preoccupied United States military planners since it exploded back onto the scene in the Persian Gulf region with a bomb attack on an American target in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, some 18 months ago. That attack was followed by another last June that killed 19 Americans. **********The latest warning issued by the embassy here, dated April 23, reported that the embassy ''continues to receive information about possible terrorist threats to the U.S. military in the region, including Bahrain.'' It urged all Americans to ''exercise the strongest possible caution.'' **********Other foreigners, including more than 5,000 Britons, have shrugged off the expressions of alarm, and many American civilians say they have seen little reason to be concerned. The island also remains a haven for Saudis, Kuwaitis and others who are by far the largest share of tourists, flocking here in droves every weekend to seek out the turquoise waters and relaxed atmosphere that makes Bahrain something akin to a Virginia Beach, even if the standard dress is white robes and black chadors. **********Led by the Emir, Sheik Isa bin Sulman al-Khalifa, who has been in power for 38 years, the ruling family of Bahrain has made little secret of its displeasure at the American action. After sparring for more than two years against a campaign of scattered arson and small-scale bombings that has been waged by members of the Shiite Muslim majority, the Emir and his family, who like most prominent landowners and businessmen here are Sunni, worry that a further sullying of Bahrain's image could complicate their efforts to attract tourism and foreign businesses as substitutes for a small and declining oil sector. **********Bahrain is is the smallest oil producer in the Middle East, with production of about 40,000 barrels a day -- less than 1 percent of what is produced by Saudi Arabia. But for now, it remains dependent on the petroleum industry, earning additional revenue from an offshore oilfield shared with Saudi Arabia and by refining Saudi oil, arrangements that bring total oil and gas earnings to about $2.5 billion a year, about half the Government's total revenue. **********Until the beginning of April, as many as three Navy ships tied up in Manama every week, and there were few restrictions on where sailors could head in their off hours. **********But since it made the warning public on April 7, the Navy has diverted vessels in need of liberty to the United Arab Emirates, where there are American worries stemming from a fatal accident in which a United States sailor was found at fault. For the last 18 months, liberty beyond the Jebel Ali port there has consisted of organized outings in large escorted groups. In the meantime, those aboard the handful of ships already at anchor in Bahrain or those that have visited the port since have mostly had to gaze from the bridge or the deck at Manama, where the raucousness of bars like the Hunter's Lodge and Tabasco Charlie's had become the stuff of Navy lore. **********''The intent is to avoid large gatherings of Americans that would create an inviting target, given the current environment,'' a United States official here said. **********American vessels have been based in Bahrain since 1948, and its designation in 1995 as the permanent headquarters of a re-created Fifth Fleet has added to its uniqueness in the Persian Gulf, where conservative sensibilities mean that other countries in which large numbers of American military personnel are stationed, including Saudi Arabia and Kuwait, prefer to describe the arrangements as temporary. **********Some 19 United States vessels are now in the narrow, shallow waters of the Persian Gulf, carrying about 12,000 sailors and airmen. That is  slightly lower than the recent average but still reflects the substantial buildup of American forces in the region that has been under way since the Persian Gulf war in 1991. **********While some reports published after the warning was issued drew a link between the United States concerns and the domestic unrest here, American officials have gone out of their way to suggest that the assumption was wrong. **********Since it began in December 1994, the campaign of violence has claimed nearly 30 lives in the name of an effort to persuade the Emir to restore an elected Parliament, which was disbanded in 1975. Hundreds of people remain in jail, including Shiite clerics who have become heroes to their followers, and the crackdown by the authorities drew criticism in the most recent State Department human rights report. **********But despite the high visibility of Americans here, none of the attacks have been aimed at American or even clearly Western targets, and neither the graffiti emblazoned in Shiite villages nor the statements issued by leaders of the movement have even hinted at anti-American sentiment. **********Among those who have been convicted of plotting against the Government, one group of Shiites was accused of taking part in a campaign orchestrated by Iran, and American officials have said they are convinced that those accusations are true. They say that at least some among the group, more than a dozen of whom were sentenced to jail terms after a secret trial last month, were provided with military training by Iran at camps outside Teheran and in the Bekaa region of Lebanon. **********Bahraini and American officials now describe the group as a Bahraini Hezbollah, with ties to its Iran-backed Lebanese namesake, which has a long record of attacks against American targets. But Western diplomats here emphasized that there was no clear evidence of a link between the Bahraini Shiites and the Saudi Shiite who is now being held in a Canadian court in connection with the June bombing of the American barracks in Saudi Arabia. **********The American Ambassador, David Ransom, was said by people who attended a meeting on April 6 at the American Embassy to have called the audience's attention to newspaper reports describing threats against United States forces in the Persian Gulf region made by Osama bin Laden, the multimillionaire Saudi dissident whom the State Department has labeled ''one of the most significant financial sponsors of Islamic extremist activities in the world today.'' **********Mr. bin Laden, who was stripped of his Saudi citizenship in 1994 and has now taken refuge in Afghanistan, has in several interviews over the last six months threatened to declare a holy war against the United States and its allies if Washington does not remove its forces from the region.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/03/busin.snippet: American Advertising Federation inducts six executives into Advertising Hall of Achievement (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/03/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; Ad Group Chooses 6 For 1997 Honors
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/03/busin.body_text: **********The American Advertising Federation in Washington has selected six executives 40 and younger to be inducted into the Advertising Hall of Achievement for 1997. The honors complement the organization's Hall of Fame, which pays tribute to older executives. **********The six are: Mary L. Baglivo, 39, president of Euro RSCG Tatham in Chicago, a unit of Havas Advertising; J. Scott Crystal, 40, vice president and advertising director at the National Geographic Society in New York; Dawn Hudson, 39, executive vice president for marketing and strategic business development at the Frito-Lay Company division of Pepsico Inc. in Purchase, N.Y.; G. M. O'Connell, 35, president and chief operating officer at TN Technologies in Westport, Conn., a unit of True North Communications; Jack Rooney, 39, vice president for marketing at the Miller Brewing Company in Milwaukee, part of the Philip Morris Companies, and Gary Topolewski, 40, executive vice president and chief creative officer at Bozell Detroit in Southfield, Mich., a unit of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt. **********The inductees will be honored at a luncheon in New York on Nov. 10. An award is being planned that would honor Jack Avrett, co-chairman of Avrett, Free & Ginsberg in New York. Mr. Avrett, who died in August, helped found the Hall of Achievement.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/26/busin.snippet: Nitto Life Co, a Japanese golf course operator, seeks court protection from creditors along with its parent, Nitto Kogyo Co (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/26/busin.main_headline: Golf Course Operator in Japan Seeks Protection
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/26/busin.print_headline: Golf Course Operator in Japan Seeks Protection
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/26/busin.body_text: **********The Nitto Life Company, a Japanese golf course operator, sought court protection from creditors today along with its parent, the Nitto Kogyo Company, saying it was no longer able to pay the costs of past business expansions. **********Nitto Life applied for protection with the Tokyo District Court this afternoon with liabilities of 69.279 billion yen, about $532 million. Of that, 37.4 billion yen came from loans by financial institutions and 26.382 billion yen from membership guarantees repayable to members. **********''Expansions into related businesses such as running hotels and restaurants, and creating golf courses abroad were the cause of the failure,'' said the Nitto Life's chairman, Hitoshi Matsuura, who is also chairman and chief executive of Nitto Kogyo. ''The responsibility lies solely with me.'' **********Mr. Matsuura said he decided to ask for court permission to stop repaying creditors and members instead of filing for bankruptcy because he wanted to allow members to continue playing on Nitto's golf courses while the company tries to restructure its operations by shedding unprofitable businesses. **********Nitto Life is 48.5 percent-owned by the Seven Ocean Club Company, a subsidiary of Nitto Kogyo. **********Nitto Kogyo also filed for court protection with 276.235 billion yen in liabilities. The company has so far reimbursed 2.6 billion yen worth of membership rights, out of total repayment demands for 6.7 billion yen, a company lawyer, Hiroyuki Kawai, said. **********It also spent 8.5 billion yen in loan guarantees to consumer finance companies that loaned money to prospective golf course members and later defaulted on those loans, Mr. Kawai added. **********The Nitto Kogyo group owns 30 golf courses in Japan and six abroad -- five in the United States and one in Britain, with total membership of more than 73,000. **********Nitto Life reported a net loss of 2.6 billion yen and a current, or pretax, profit of 68 million yen for the full year ended Sept. 30.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/14/world.snippet: Rebel forces break through Zaire's last major defensive position short of capital, Bankana, and say they will arrive in Kinshasa within hours; Government forces, in frantic retreat, blow up bridge at Bombo River to try last stand; Pres Mobutu Sese...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/14/world.main_headline: Zairian Rebels Push Past Army In Final March Toward Capital
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/14/world.print_headline: Zairian Rebels Push Past Army In Final March Toward Capital
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/14/world.body_text: **********Zairian rebel forces broke through the Government's last major defensive position short of the capital today and announced that they would arrive in the city within hours, in their final push in a seven-month fight to topple President Mobutu Sese Seko. **********Advancing 20 miles in a day of determined fighting, the rebels forced the Government to abandon its fortified position at Bankana, less than 90 miles east of Kinshasa. In a frantic retreat, Government forces blew up a bridge at the Bombo River, where they could attempt a last stand, but Western military analysts tonight gave it little chance for success. **********Despite the increasingly desperate situation, aides close to Mr. Mobutu described a leader profoundly out of touch, a physically weakened man who has retreated to his bunker and believes that his army, with the help of fighters from the Angolan opposition movement Unita, is actually recapturing lost ground. **********If rebel troops enter the city, one official said, there is no doubt that Mr. Mobutu would order his army to fight them. **********Reacting to the rebels' announcement that they would enter Kinshasa in a matter of hours, the Government  imposed a curfew of 8 P.M. to dawn on the city, and called on residents to take up arms to defend the capital. **********''The Zairian Army forces are determined to defend their just cause and will defend Kinshasa and its environs,'' said the Government's Information Minister, Kin-Keiy Mulumba. ''The Government signals that the population has the legitimate right to defend itself.'' **********But foreign diplomats said the rebel advance could quickly turn into a rout, and clouded the prospects for a second meeting between Mr. Mobutu and the rebel leader, Laurent Kabila, which was scheduled to be held aboard a South African warship off the Congolese coast on Wednesday. **********''They are on their way now,'' a  Western diplomat said of the rebels, predicting that they would take Kinshasa as early as Thursday. ''This is serious now.'' **********The South African Government, which is host of the talks, said the meeting between Mr. Mobutu and Mr. Kabila would go ahead as scheduled, and said there had been progress toward arranging a peaceful transfer of power to the rebels, but it cautioned that there were no guarantees of an agreement. **********Until now, Mr. Mobutu has refused demands that he hand over power directly to the rebels with minimal conditions other than guarantees for his own safety. Mr. Kabila has continued to say that he will accept nothing else, and has warned that the meeting on Wednesday would be Mr. Mobutu's last chance for peaceful surrender. **********Reflecting the quickly shifting reality on the ground, Zairian officials said the United States Ambassador here, Daniel H. Simpson, today urged the Prime Minister, Gen. Likulia Bolongo, to order his remaining troops to allow the rebels to enter Kinshasa peacefully. **********Mr. Kabila claims to have an army of 70,000 soldiers. Western military analysts cannot confirm that number but say he has recruited heavily in recent weeks after the fall of several major cities. Mr. Kabila's army has also been augmented by the arrival of thousands of second-generation Zairian exiles from Angola, who fought on the Government side in Angola's long civil war. **********The rebels' early recruits came from North and South Kivu Provinces and were predominantly Banyamulenge, Zairian ethnic Tutsi. The recruits who were in exile in Angola are Katangese, from southern Zaire. **********As combat has drawn closer to the capital, international mediators and foreign diplomats have grown increasingly concerned about the prospect of fighting in this crowded city of five million, and about a repetition of pillaging by Government soldiers, such as occurred in 1991 and 1993. **********With that danger in mind, Western embassies have stepped up their calls for their citizens to leave Kinshasa immediately. Some 3,500 Western troops, including about 1,200 Americans in Brazzaville, the Congolese capital, were in a state of heightened alert for an evacuation of Kinshasa. **********In Kinshasa, the news of the rebel advance set off a late-afternoon wave of panic. Travel agencies were packed with wealthy Zairians and foreigners who were scrambling to cross the Congo River to Brazzaville, where many of them hoped to find seats on heavily booked flights to Europe and South Africa. **********The air of panic was increased further by an explosion aboard one of the Congo River ferries returning here early this evening from Brazzaville, and wild stories about the opening of hostilities circulated in the city. **********In fact, Zairian and Western military sources said the blast, which killed five people, appeared to be the  accidental explosion of a grenade, possibly after it had been left on the ferry by a deserting Government soldier. **********By late afternoon, even before the curfew announcement, the usually hectic streets of central Kinshasa had nearly emptied, and the money changers who are a fixture on downtown street corners had deserted the area. **********Hoping to speed the Government's fall, opposition parties have called for a three-day strike to paralyze Kinshasa beginning on Wednesday, and many politicians have begun organizing welcoming committees to greet the arriving rebels. **********Reports reaching Kinshasa from the southern rebel-held city of Lubumbashi tonight said that wild celebrations, with troops firing their guns off in the air, had broken out in celebration of the rebels' advance on  the capital. **********Tracts supposedly printed by the rebels have turned up all over Kinshasa urging Government soldiers to lay down their arms and raise white flags in a sign of peace. **********Given Mr. Mobutu's deep unpopularity, the strike on Wednesday is seen as virtually guaranteed to succeed, and almost no one here expects the Government's call to arms to be heard. **********In nearly 32 years of rule, Mr. Mobutu became one of the world's richest leaders, while driving his country, perhaps Africa's most richly endowed, into deep poverty. Mr. Kabila, who has waged unsuccessful revolts against Mr. Mobutu for three decades, launched his Alliance of Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Congo with heavy backing from Rwanda and Uganda last October and has marched from victory to victory in a seven-month war. **********Even as the fall of Kinshasa appeared increasingly imminent, however, members of Mr. Mobutu's entourage said the 66-year-old leader remained convinced that his forces had begun to rally after seven months of uninterrupted losses, and were about to turn the war around. **********In the last two days, close associates of Mr. Mobutu say, the President has insisted to his family and advisers that the Government had recaptured the city of Kikwit, which is deep behind rebel lines and securely held by Mr. Kabila's forces. **********''They are all dreaming up there,''  a presidential aide said of Mr. Mobutu's immediate entourage, which is cloistered in a hillside military camp at the city's edge. **********''They pick up the telephone and shout orders, promising this and that, saying that fresh funds are on their way, but there is nothing they can do,'' the aide said. ''No one can live this out the way they are living it, but I feel sorry for them now. They still believe they can hang on.'' **********Told of Mr. Mobutu's optimism, a Western diplomat said, ''It is depressing, but I guess we have finally reached the bunker.'' **********If Mr. Mobutu is forced to flee, Zairians and diplomats say, his escape would most likely be by helicopter. Members of his entourage say he has moved his personal effects from his palace in his northern hometown, Gbadolite, to Morocco, and it is assumed that if he goes into exile it would be to that country or to his home in southern France. **********Mr. Mobutu, who is believed to be in the terminal phase of prostate cancer, has been under heavy medication for weeks, and in recent public appearances has shown signs that he is growing steadily weaker. **********And, as the political and military situations have grown increasingly desperate, Mr. Mobutu has shut himself off from meaningful contact with all but an inner circle composed of his immediate family and a handful of close associates, most of whom are drawn from his own northern ethnic group, the Ngbandi. **********Associates of the President said that a meeting of his inner circle turned into a disaster last week, when family members urged that he abandon power and fly to France for urgently needed treatment. Since then, it is not known whether any member of Mr. Mobutu's entourage has brought up the subject of exile  again. **********Given the situation on the ground, however, few people here doubted that Mr. Mobutu would soon give up power, by flying into exile or by defeat. **********''Mobutu is dead already,'' said Ilondo Elongu, manager of the state insurance corporation here. ''He cannot give instructions to anyone concerning the country's future. The only thing he has left is his family.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/02/world.main_headline: Israeli Wounds 6 Arabs in Hebron Rampage
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/02/world.print_headline: Israeli Wounds 6 Arabs in Hebron Rampage
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/02/world.body_text: **********An Israeli soldier with a history of mental problems opened fire today on a crowded Palestinian market here, wounding six Arabs and delaying the completion of the agreement on a transfer of power to Palestinians in Hebron. **********Although the soldier said his intention had been to sabotage the Hebron agreement, the Israeli and Palestinian leaders, who were to have met today to conclude the agreement, both insisted that they would press on despite the violence. **********The Israeli Defense Minister, Yitzhak Mordechai, said Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, would meet soon, possibly on Thursday, to resolve final points of contention and to initial the long-delayed agreement. **********If they do initial it, the agreement still needs to be approved by the Israeli Cabinet and Parliament, meaning that the redeployment of Israeli troops stationed in Hebron would not be likely until next week. **********The quick and effective cooperation to defuse a potentially explosive incident seemed to reflect the new recognition of mutual dependence that has come to the leaders through the crises of the last seven months and the protracted haggling over Hebron. **********Today, Mr. Netanyahu telephoned Mr. Arafat within half an hour of the shooting to declare his regret for what he described as a ''criminal act,'' and Mr. Arafat spread the word  that there was to be no retaliatory violence. **********By contrast, the conflict over the opening of a tourist tunnel in Jerusalem three months ago quickly escalated into a shooting war, in large part because of the sharp mutual distrust between the two leaders. **********Today tensions subsided, and by evening Mr. Mordechai was meeting at the American Ambassador's residence with Mr. Arafat's top aides, Mahmoud Abbas and Yasir Abed Rabbo, and with Dennis Ross, the  special envoy from the United States. Negotiations continued deep into the night. **********The latest crisis broke at 9:55 A.M., when a soldier identified as Pvt. Noam Friedman, 22, walked out in the main square of the ancient center of Hebron and opened fire  with an M-16 assault rifle on a crowded Palestinian vegetable market. **********Witnesses said he fired one burst, sat down and fired another. Within  seconds, Israeli soldiers pounced on  him and disarmed him as he yelled, ''Don't shoot me!'' **********Chaos ensued, with most Palestinians trying to escape and others trying to charge at the gunman. Several more Palestinians were injured in the panic. Order was soon restored, and Israeli medics rushed to administer first aid to the wounded until ambulances arrived. A brief riot broke out outside the hospital where the wounded were taken. **********Israeli authorities ordered all Palestinians in Hebron to stay indoors, the entrance to the city was closed, and senior officials including Mr. Mordechai and the Army chief of staff, Lieut. Gen. Amnon Shahak, arrived to calm soldiers, settlers and Palestinians. The head of the Israeli security service, Ami Ayalon, met publicly in the main square with the Palestinian chief for the West Bank, Jibril Rajoub. **********As information began to accumulate about Private Friedman, it became increasingly evident that he was not an active religious nationalist extremist in the mold of Yigal Amir, the assassin of the former Prime Minister, Yitzhak Rabin. Instead, the soldier was characterized as a lonely and troubled person who was expelled from a religious institute because of psychiatric problems  and whose Army enlistment was postponed because of them. All indications were that he had acted alone. **********Private Friedman, a bespectacled  man with a scraggly red beard and the fringe of a tzitzit, the undershirt  of an Orthodox Jew, exposed beneath his fatigues, was performing his mandatory military service. He was assigned to an administrative unit nowhere near here when he decided to create an incident to block the agreement on Hebron, he told investigators. **********On being led to the police van for transfer to Jerusalem, reporters shouted questions to him. ''Are you a normal person?'' a reporter called out. **********''Completely normal,'' he replied. **********''One who kills innocent people is normal?'' **********''They aren't innocents,'' he said. ''They are haters of Israel.'' **********It was not immediately clear how many shots Mr. Friedman managed to squeeze off at close range in the  dense crowd in the market. **********In February 1994 another Jewish settler, Dr. Baruch Goldstein, walked into the tomb of the biblical patriarch Abraham, which is sacred to both Muslims and Jews, and opened fire on praying Palestinians, killing 29 before his rifle jammed and he was overwhelmed and killed by survivors. **********That massacre hangs heavy over all the deliberations about Hebron, and undoubtedly was one reason for the alacrity with which leaders  leaped to head off a confrontation. **********The question certain to be studied in coming days was how a man with Private Friedman's history, which was said to include a recommendation from a psychiatrist that he not be inducted into the army, could have been drafted and issued a weapon. **********In the immediate aftermath of the incident, Israeli politicians and settlers from across the political spectrum denounced the shooting, while Palestinian officials pointed to it as evidence that the problem in Hebron was not the risk of Palestinian terrorism, but terrorism by Jewish zealots. **********Mr. Netanyahu, who had spent the entire night before successfully ushering a lean 1997 budget through the Parliament -- it passed shortly before 6 A.M. today by a vote of 60 to 42 -- issued prompt statements denouncing the shooting. **********''I want to make unequivocally clear: the agreement that we have spoken about in recent months is an essential need in order to prevent violent acts from both sides of the sort we saw today,'' he said. ''And I want to say again in a sharp way that no crime and no violent act will stand in the way of our completing the work.'' **********Mr. Ross, who has been instrumental in bringing the agreement close to conclusion in the last two weeks, issued a statement on behalf of President Clinton expressing ''horror and outrage'' at the shooting. **********Mr. Ross added, ''Those who use violence cannot be permitted to be the arbiters of the future.'' **********Mr. Clinton, on vacation in the Virgin Islands, took time out to call Mr. Arafat for about five minutes to express his sympathy, according to the Reuters news agency. **********Asked why he did not telephone Mr. Netanyahu, the President replied: ''Because he didn't lose the people. I called Mr. Arafat because I had to call, because they were Palestinians that were shot. If it had been Israelis that had been shot I would have called Mr. Netanyahu.'' **********Mr. Arafat said the incident was a ''regrettable act.'' His lieutenants, however, were more explicit in using the incident to hammer away at the constant Israeli emphasis on safeguarding the 450 settlers living in the heart of Hebron. **********''There is no peace with settlers living amidst Palestinians,'' said Saeb Erekat, the chief Palestinian negotiator. ''Palestinians demand protection for the Palestinian people in Hebron, instead of having Israel demand more security for killers in Hebron.'' **********While Private Friedman may have believed he was acting in support of the Hebron settlers, their reaction was to denounce him, in part because they seemed to believe that the shooting would strengthen the Palestinian cause and so undermine whatever hope they still had of successfully influencing a Cabinet vote on the pullout from Hebron. **********Seven of Mr. Netanyahu's 18 ministers have already declared themselves against the agreement, and if two more join them -- a distinct possibility -- the withdrawal could be in new trouble. **********At the same time, spokesmen for Israeli settlers said the shooting was an argument against an Israeli withdrawal because Israel's presence allowed it to put Hebron under curfew today, presumably preventing any Palestinian attacks on Israeli enclaves. **********''We reject any act of bloodshed such as this,'' said David Wilder, one of the spokesmen for the Hebron settlers. ''I can't believe that a person would come down and start shooting and think he's doing us a favor. However, we feel that a situation like this proves the instability of the situation which would arise should the Israeli Army withdraw. What happens after the Arabs are armed? What happens then?'' **********In fact, the redeployment plan would leave a strong Israeli force in place around the enclaves, just as there was today, and by all accounts it was Palestinian officials, not Israeli troops, who kept the Palestinian neighborhoods calm today. **********Simmering tensions between the settlers and the Army surfaced when General Shahak, the Army Chief of Staff, stalked out of a meeting with settler leaders after Rabbi Moshe Levinger, one of the original Hebron settlers, refused to shake his hand and said: ''I'm revolted by the Army. I can't even look at you.'' **********Under the 1995 Israeli-Palestinian agreements, Hebron was to be the seventh West Bank city to come under Palestinian control. But the transfer has been complicated and repeatedly delayed by Israeli fears for the security of the Jewish militants, who live in the center of Hebron to maintain their claim that the city is a biblical birthright of the Jews. **********When Mr. Netanyahu took office in June, he declared that he would toughen the security provisions that had been negotiated by the previous Government. But after seven months of crises, recriminations and talks, Mr. Netanyahu succeeded in wresting only minor changes from the Palestinians. **********It is this fact that has led seven of Mr. Netanyahu's Cabinet members to declare their opposition to the agreement. **********The other cause for the protracted delay was Mr. Arafat's distrust of Mr. Netanyahu's long-term intentions. The Palestinian leader insisted that any deal on Hebron be accompanied by guarantees that Israel would stick to other commitments, including further withdrawals, the release of prisoners and a road connecting the Gaza Strip and the West Bank. **********Most of those demands are expected to be resolved through an American-brokered document appended to the agreement. But among the last details that Mr. Arafat and Mr. Netanyahu must nail down is setting a deadline for the next Israeli withdrawal.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/09/busin.snippet: State Street Global Advisors introduces fund designed to invest in emerging nations whose economies are not included in any well-known, investible indexes; fund, set up as common trust fund, is not available to individuals (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/09/busin.print_headline: INVESTING IT GLOBALLY; Trailblazers, A Fund for You
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/09/busin.body_text: **********AS if emerging markets did not prove exciting enough for investors recently, now comes an even more speculative alternative: The Pre-Emerging Markets fund, introduced last week by State Street Global Advisors, the money management arm of the State Street Corporation in Boston. **********The Pre-Emerging Markets fund is not, as its name implies, designed to invest in parts of the world where the economies have yet to grow. Rather, explains Peter Leahy, a State Street managing director, the fund invests in countries whose economies ''are emerging but which are not included in any of the well-known, investible indexes,'' like those tracked by Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter, Discover & Company. **********So if buying shares of promising young companies based in Botswana, Ghana, Ecuador, Trinidad and Tobago, Mauritius, Kenya, the Ivory Coast or Bangladesh seems like the thing to do, this might be the fund that can make it happen. **********But it is not open to individuals. Its formation as a common trust fund means it is available only to investors not subject to United States income taxes -- that is, pension funds, foreign entities and the like. **********And rather than trying to pick the best-performing stocks in those markets, the fund will be passively managed -- that is, it will invest in companies that dominate the indexes of those individual countries. Initially, it will limit investments to about $3 million, for all markets combined. **********Of course, the fact that State Street is introducing the Pre-Emerging Markets fund now raises the question of whether investor confidence was at all affected by the recent selloff in post-emerging and still-somewhat-emerging markets. **********On that, Mr. Leahy demurs. ''We're not saying that now is the time to buy pre-emerging markets,'' he said. ''The timing is purely coincidental. But we think that a critical mass of our clients might be interested in expanding their investment horizons, and this is a tool to help them to diversify.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/07/world.snippet: Mali's political crisis began with flawed elections for new National Assembly in April; Pres Alpha Oumar Konare governs with assembly composed almost solely of members of his own party; Prime Min Ibrahim Boubacar dismisses opposition's charges tha...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/07/world.main_headline: Mali's Slips Reflect Stumbling African Democracy
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/07/world.print_headline: Mali's Slips Reflect Stumbling African Democracy
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/07/world.body_text: **********When this country emerged from 31 years of dictatorship and held its first free elections in 1992, comparable examples of democratic change on this continent could be counted on one hand -- with fingers to spare. **********But as a wave of political renovation swept Africa in the early 1990's, Mali's example was quickly followed by many others. **********Since then, with several countries undergoing military coups, or with incumbents wielding their authority practically to eliminate meaningful competition, the tide of African democracy appears to have subsided. **********And with Mali now in its worst crisis since its transition from dictatorship, eyes are again on this country. Mali's success or failure will quickly be used in the debate about whether the world's least-developed continent is socially or economically ready for Western-style democracy. **********Mali's current political crisis, like those of many of its neighbors, began with deeply flawed elections -- for a new National Assembly last April. **********Diplomats, international observers and senior Malian officials say the vote was poorly organized. As a result, on the day of the election there was widespread confusion at polling places about who was eligible to vote and many of the polls opened late in the day or never received all of their voting materials. **********With returns showing a near landslide for the governing party, Mali's opposition cried foul, accusing supporters of President Alpha Oumar Konare of trying to rig the vote. **********Anxious not to lose the credibility that has made his country a favorite of international donors, Mr. Konare quickly agreed to cancel the results and to organize a second election. But on the eve of that vote, the opposition called for a boycott and began waging a campaign of protests and attacks on offices of the governing party that led to at least one death. **********The re-run of the election was eventually held in July, with a second round in August. Before that, in May,  Mr. Konare, an archeologist by training who insists that this is his last term in office, won re-election virtually unopposed. **********Today, the President governs with a National Assembly composed almost solely of members of his own party, the Alliance for Democracy in Mali. Meanwhile 10 opposition leaders remain in jail over the death of a police officer who was lynched at an opposition meeting last month. **********For members of Mali's so-called radical opposition -- those who boycotted the elections -- the current situation reflects their expectations for a regime that they contend has, all along, only played at democracy for external consumption. Like governments in many of this country's undemocratic neighbors, the opposition contends, the Government has angled for near-absolute power at home. **********''The President can give all of the beautiful speeches he wants to about democracy, along with the elaborate justifications of his policies,'' said Mohamedoun Dicko, secretary general of the Miria party, an opposition group that supported the electoral boycott. ''The fact remains that his party wants to restore one-party rule, and that the National Assembly has again become monochromatic because of this Government's actions.'' **********Prime Minister Ibrahim Boubacar Keita has dismissed the opposition's charges and called those who boycotted the elections ''simply political hooligans.'' **********In fact, many Malians, as well as many foreigners, say that for all the surface similarity to crises elsewhere, several political features set Mali apart from its neighbors, and it is these features that they say, in the end, may save its democracy. **********For all of the signs of a political machine that critics say is growing up around Mr. Konare's presidency, there is no evidence, foreign diplomats say, of any major Government-organized attempt at fraud in any of the country's recent elections. **********Since the vote, Mr. Konare has promised broad electoral reforms that include campaign funding and spending limits for all parties. **********The Malian media have a remarkable degree of liberty to criticize the Government or to support opposition positions. Significantly, in a country where illiteracy remains high, this freedom extends to private radio stations as well as newspapers. **********Mr. Konare, who is 51, has repeatedly gone out of his way to state his intention to retire from politics at the end of his second term, refusing the urgings of some of those around him that he change Mali's Constitution to permit a third term. **********But if facts like these set Mali apart, it is equally true that many of its difficulties stem from realities that have stymied new democracies elsewhere in Africa -- from Sierra Leone and Niger, where soldiers have seized power, to Zambia and Chad, where incumbents have rigged elections to insure comfortable victories. **********During four decades of independence from colonial rule, many Africans say, one-party rule bred a culture of intolerance and left political skills of coalition-building, negotiation and compromise atrophied. **********These traits can be seen as readily among those in opposition as in hard-liners in the governing party here. **********Moreover, in many of Africa's extremely poor countries, like this one, the state and its resources are the only economic game in town and politics in the recent democratic era has often quickly devolved into a deadly winner-take-all struggle for the spoils. **********''In your country, you have Democrats and Republicans, and when one side loses, they pack their bags and go home, making a living at law or medicine or whatever, while they bide their time for the next election,'' said Gen. Amadou Toumani Toure, who remains a national hero here for taking power briefly in 1991 at the end of the dictatorship and organizing the country's first democratic elections, in which he was not a candidate. **********''In a country as poor as Mali, that kind of thing goes over very badly,'' General Toure said. ''That is why I think we must find a more consensual way of governing democratically.'' **********For others, the most serious liability of this new struggle over access to the resources of the state is the fact that in countries whose development needs remain staggering, political debate is almost always about power and rarely about policy. **********''Elections and alternance are obviously important,'' said Aminata Traore, a sociologist who has sought to mediate in the crisis between the Government and opposition here. ''But we have spent five years without asking essential questions about our development. Elections are being reduced to a fratricidal struggle between self-interested politicians.'' **********Some African leaders have said that the continent is simply not yet ready for Western-style electoral systems. **********Uganda's President, Yoweri K. Museveni, has instituted a ''no-party'' voting system in his country, which he rules with a strong authoritarian hand. **********In recent years, Mr. Museveni's Uganda -- which has enjoyed relative stability and fast economic growth and has received the strong backing of Washington and international financial institutions -- has emerged as something of a model for many of its neighbors. **********For his part, Mr. Konare, whose country is surrounded by outright authoritarians and far less democratic states, rejects the no-party model and remains confident in Mali's democratic experiment. **********''I do not underestimate the difficulties, but I do not accept excuses that say Africa should not make an effort to be pluralist,'' Mr. Konare said. ''I have a lot of respect for the President of Uganda, but I don't know how much of the Museveni experiment will survive Museveni. Here, I am certain that pluralism will survive Konare.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/22/world.snippet: Russia thwarts proposal to have international organization supervise elections that Bosnia Serb Pres Biljana Plavsic has called in her power struggle with her predecessor, Radovan Karadzic; this is setback for Clinton Administration and major Euro...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/22/world.main_headline: Russians Are Said to Block Plans for Bosnian Serb Elections
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/22/world.print_headline: Russians Are Said to Block Plans for Bosnian Serb Elections
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/22/world.body_text: **********In a closed-door meeting here today, Russia put the brakes on a proposal to have an international organization supervise elections that the Bosnia Serb President, Biljana Plavsic, has called in her power struggle with her predecessor, Radovan Karadzic. **********The Russian action is a setback for the Clinton Administration and major European Governments, which have openly sided with Ms. Plavsic in her political war, including her call for elections in the Serbian-controlled territory of Bosnia. She has formally requested the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe to supervise the elections, which she would like to be held in October. **********At a meeting of the 54-member organization here today, support for Ms. Plavsic's request was virtually unanimous -- with the exception of Russia -- said diplomats who attended the meeting. **********While continuing to apply pressure on Moscow behind the scenes, diplomats here made an effort to gloss over the Russian opposition in public. The tactic is to not embarrass the Russians, which could be counterproductive, said an official with the security organization. **********At a news conference here late this afternoon, following a meeting of the security organization, no mention was made of the Russian position in the opening statements by senior diplomats, including Robert Frowick, a former American Ambassador who is the head of the security organization's mission in Bosnia. **********When asked specifically about the Russian position, Ambassador Carlos Westendorp, a Spanish diplomat who is the High Representative in Bosnia and is responsible for the enforcement of the Dayton peace accords on the ground, said, ''Russia fully shares the need for holding elections'' and for the security organization to supervise them. **********But when speaking on condition of anonymity, diplomats told a different story. **********Reading from his notes of the meeting, one senior Western diplomat said that while the Russian delegation professed support for Ms. Plavsic, it had said there were unspecified ''unresolved questions'' about the elections and the role of the security organization. **********An effort to get a comment from the Russian delegation following today's late-afternoon briefing was unsuccessful; the person answering the phone at the Russian mission to the security organization said no one would be available until Friday. **********Russia has long been the Serbs' major outside ally, and Moscow is reluctant to get caught in an internal Serbian power struggle. **********Though Ms. Plavsic was a strident nationalist throughout the war, she has reluctantly accepted the Dayton agreement, something that Dr. Karadzic, who has been indicted on war crimes charges, has adamantly refused to do. **********But she has been unable to carry out her policies because of the opposition of Dr. Karadzic's hard-line allies in the parliament. **********President Plavsic dissolved the parliament last month, saying she had the authority under the Bosnian Serb Constitution. While many neutral observers questioned her reading of her Constitutional powers, the Clinton Administration and most Western Governments accepted it. **********Diplomats today expressed hope that Russia might be persuaded to change its position on the elections. **********Without the security organization, it is doubtful whether the elections would be fair or even if they could  proceed at all. In addition to logistical support, the security organization would provide much of the money needed to carry out the elections.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/21/busin.snippet: Medical costs, which have risen less than inflation for last three years, are inching upward and may be poised for sharper rise, especially for small businesses; employers project 4 percent rise this year as managed care companies strive to make u...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/21/busin.main_headline: Health Care Costs Edging Up And a Bigger Surge Is Feared
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/21/busin.print_headline: Health Care Costs Edging Up And a Bigger Surge Is Feared
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/21/busin.body_text: **********Medical costs, which have risen less than inflation for the last three years, are beginning to inch ahead and may be poised for a sharp rise, especially for small businesses, according to employers, actuaries and industry consultants. **********Employers across the country said their health care costs were headed for a 4 percent increase this year, according to a survey released yesterday. And some health care experts project 5 to 10 percent growth in medical costs in 1998. **********Prices are under growing pressure as managed care companies strive to make up for the thin profits they tolerated while holding down prices and pushing for new members. **********And the underlying forces that drove up health care costs in the 1980's are still powerful: the aging population, compounded now by middle-aged baby boomers who require more medical services; more expensive medical technology like bone marrow transplants to help cancer patients, and new drug combinations, like those for AIDS that can cost $12,000 a year. **********Costs might also rise fractionally from new Federal and state laws that prohibit some cost-cutting efforts, such as insurers' limiting of hospital stays after childbirth. **********Hospitals and doctors in some cities, meanwhile, have increased their ability to demand higher fees by forming alliances and merging into bigger entities. **********Higher prices are expected to fall especially heavily on private employers as the Government squeezes Medicare payments to hospitals, doctors and health maintenance organizations. Many H.M.O.'s have been getting relatively generous Medicare fees, which make it easier to offer low prices to employers and workers in the private sector. **********Employers predicted that their medical costs would grow by 4 percent in 1997, a jump from the 2.5 percent average rise last year, according to a survey of 3,200 employers with 10 or more workers published yesterday by the Foster Higgins benefits consulting firm. **********The combined annual premiums paid by employers and employees averaged $3,915 an employee in 1996, compared with $3,821 in 1995 and $3,741 in 1994, which was the only recent year when premiums fell (by 1.1 percent), the Higgins survey said. **********The Labor Department said consumers' medical costs rose 3 percent last year while the overall Consumer Price Index was up 3.3 percent. **********Aetna Inc., for example, one of the biggest health insurance companies, said its premiums were 3 percent to 6 percent higher than last year in managed care plans and up to 10 percent higher for traditional fee-for-service insurance. Premiums had been flat during 1996 at both Aetna and its U.S. Healthcare unit. **********Some who track medical costs say the increases, which are already reflected in managed care premiums in some regions, may surge in 1998 as a number of inflationary trends come together. ''With the changes in Medicare, we might see a return to double-digit health care inflation in 1998,'' said John Erb, a principal at Foster Higgins and the chief analyst for the survey. **********Peter Reilly, an actuary with Milliman & Robertson, another benefits consulting firm, said his calculations  projected increases of 3 to 5 percent this year and 5 to 8 percent in 1998. **********''Everything we hear is that prices are beginning to tick up again to high single digits and even double digits,'' said Rob Fowler, executive director of the Council of Smaller Enterprises, a coalition of 12,500 employers in northeastern Ohio. **********Beverly Sloan, executive director of health benefits at U S West, the Denver-based telecommunications company, said the company's health costs rose 5 percent in 1996, after three years of increases of 2 percent or less. **********''Medicare is the 800-pound gorilla,'' she said. If the Government clamps down on Medicare to reduce Federal spending, that will increase the pressure on insurers and health care providers to raise charges to private employers, she said. **********Trying to fend off that possibility, U S West, like many big companies, is requiring its health plans to offer three-year contracts. **********Bob Dankmyer, a vice president of Marriott International, said his company was demanding ''multiyear rate guarantees'' that would limit increases to the growth in the Consumer Price Index. **********''If you are big and strong and a good negotiator, you pay less,'' said Kenneth S. Abramowitz, a health care analyst at the Sanford C. Bernstein & Company securities firm. **********But small employers may not be able to stop the H.M.O.'s and providers of health care from ''slam-dunking the private sector,'' as Ms. Sloan put it. BB Graphics, a printing company with seven employees in Merrillville, Ind., had a 25 percent rise in its costs last year and expects a further 7 percent increase in May, said William Stack, the owner. **********Stuart Altman, a health policy professor at Brandeis University, said, ''We haven't broken the cycle of people wanting more health care.'' As evidence, he pointed to the popularity of health plans that still allow members to select physicians and influence their own care. **********''Most managed care companies have done a decent job of getting discounts from providers,'' he said, ''but they have not fundamentally changed the practice of medicine. With managed care, health care costs are going up more slowly, but they are still going up.'' **********Mr. Fowler of the Ohio coalition said, ''We may have squeezed out all that we can through managed care.'' **********And Mr. Abramowitz said: ''The pendulum is swinging. The news media tell you to consume more health care. You have your rights to the drugs and doctors you need. Drug companies are advertising direct to the consumer and hospitals are marketing themselves.'' All the pressure to consume adds to costs, he said. **********In New York State, higher hospital charges following rate deregulation may add 2 percent to costs in 1997, for a total increase of 6 percent, said David Snow, an executive vice president with Oxford Health Plans. Paul Philpott, a senior vice president of Physicians Health Services, said deregulation might raise premiums beyond 6 percent in New York. **********Professor Altman of Brandeis said the return of medical inflation would reflect ''the old insurance cycle: they overestimate their ability to control costs and lose money for a couple of years, then they make it up by raising their premiums.'' **********Mr. Reilly of Milliman & Robertson said insurance companies and H.M.O.'s ''don't forecast the future growth of costs very well.'' **********''They look at their past experience,'' he said. ''It's like they were driving a car with their eyes on the rearview mirror.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/02/busin.snippet: Article by James H Smalhout on state of Social Security system; says Social Security is in deep trouble and so far, America has been keeping its head in the sand, tinkering around the edges and condemning us and our children to sky-high payroll ta...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/02/busin.body_text: **********JUST how far is Social Security under water? People like to quote numbers as if they're gospel. The Government says Social Security can stay afloat until 2072 if it raises payroll taxes by 2.2 percent. But that's hardly the end of it. **********Social Security would start hemorrhaging red ink again in a flash if the Government closed the gap today. That's because the 2.2 percent would be just enough to cover the bill for the next 75 years. But there are big deficits waiting in year 76 and beyond. And they're going to pop up on Social Security's radar screen and into the system's costs next year and every year thereafter. **********That 2.2 percent increase in the payroll tax would be on top of the 12.4 percent that already goes to Social Security -- in other words, almost a 20 percent increase in the rate. But experts quietly acknowledge that taxes would need to be twice as high 75 years from now to pay for the program we have today. That's about 25 percent of pay! **********Not surprisingly, this has yet to make its way into official Government reports. But the blind spot has already helped create Social Security's current mess. Back in 1983, a commission headed by Alan Greenspan ''fixed'' the program for the next 75 years. Since then, we've added 14 years of high Social Security shortfalls to the forecast and now -- surprise, surprise -- we are told that the program is under water again. **********The economist Edward M. Gramlich thinks the Government should avoid this continuing embarrassment by calculating what's needed to pay for Social Security on a permanent basis. Mr. Gramlich, whose appointment to the Federal Reserve Board was confirmed by the Senate on Thursday, was chairman of the Advisory Council on Social Security last year. **********It is bad enough for the Government to tell us half-truths about the tax increase needed to keep the system afloat. But the Government also maintains that the 2.2 percent solution is based on ''intermediate'' assumptions about evolving trends in our population and the economy. Not so. **********Consider the projection for future life spans. According to Samuel Preston, a demographer at the University of Pennsylvania, the life expectancy in Japan was 79.7 years in 1994. But Social Security assumes that America won't catch up to that figure until 2050 -- a lag of 56 years. Many demographers think that is way off. They believe that Americans will live about five years longer than the Government assumes. **********Or, consider Social Security's assumption about the future growth of wages. It calculates this rate at nine-tenths of 1 percent a year, after inflation. That is much higher than the average of six-tenths of 1 percent since 1975. And the difference becomes huge over 75 years. **********Keeping the books this way makes the program look healthier than it is and protects it from short-term change. But it also sets up the system for a huge fall. **********Shripad Tuljapurkar, a forecaster with Mountain View Research in Los Altos, Calif., makes the important point that there would be only a 50-50 chance that the books will balance even if the Government's intermediate assumptions seem about right today. But are 50-50 odds good enough? **********The time has come to face real and growing risks, not just to cut the numbers to suit the current fashion. We live in a world where almost anything can happen. If the country wants to be, say, 95 percent certain that Social Security will be safe for the next 75 years, taxes would need to go up much more than 2.2 percent. **********People therefore need a much better benchmark to tell them how much their  benefits are at risk. Fortunately, that yardstick is available. It is based on standard statistical techniques that forecasters working for private business use routinely. **********REGARDLESS of whether Social Security's horizon should be forever or much shorter than it is today -- or whether its method for assessing risks is outdated -- it is clear that the solution's cost rises each year. But we can't stop thinking about tomorrow just because it isn't pleasant or because we want to protect sacred cows. Social Security is in deep trouble. So far, America has been keeping its head in the sand, tinkering around the edges and condemning us and our children to sky-high payroll taxes in the future. **********Britain and Chile have acted decisively. They have been financing most of their social security systems privately and in advance, either through mandatory individual retirement accounts or company plans -- both of which replace pension payments from the government. More and more countries will be following their examples because they can be the best way to prevent Social Security's black box from turning into an enormous black hole.
