https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/04/busin.body_text: **********Venezuela joined other big Latin American borrowers today, introducing a plan to sell $1 billion worth of 30-year bonds, the longest-term bonds sold in the country's modern history. **********Under the plan, investors would pay for the new bonds with cash or with outstanding Brady bonds, the higher-yield securities partly backed by United States Treasury debt that were created in a 1990 restructuring of Venezuela's bank debt. **********''What it shows is a growing investor preference for noncollateralized emerging-markets exposure,'' said Lawrence Goodman, head of Latin American economic research at Salomon Brothers, adding that this had already been found with Mexico, Brazil and Argentina.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/06/world.snippet: Oneksim Bank, overcoming opposition of Prime Min Viktor S Chernomyrdin, both manages and wins auction of 38 percent stake in Norilsk Nickel owned by Russian Government; auction, throwback to kind of insider privilege and backdoor manuevering that ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/06/world.main_headline: Russian Bank With Sway Wins Auction
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/06/world.print_headline: Russian Bank With Sway Wins Auction
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/06/world.body_text: **********Overcoming efforts by Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin to delay the sale, one of Russia's most powerful banks plunged ahead today with an auction for one of the state's most valuable assets. **********Not surprisingly, since a subsidiary of Oneksim Bank was managing the bids, Oneksim Bank won 38 percent of Norilsk Nickel, one of the world's largest producers of nickel, copper and platinum. **********The bank's $250 million bid won easily -- Oneksim Bank had barred foreign investors and had only one competitor, a little-known Russian industrial consortium. **********The auction itself was a throwback to the kind of insider privilege and backdoor maneuvering that has tainted past Government efforts to sell off state property. **********But paradoxically, it seems far less contentious than last month's open and highly competitive auction of the state telecommunications giant. Oneksim Bank won that battle, only to unleash a bitter war with other powerful banks that lost out. **********Worried about those political repercussions, Mr. Chernomyrdin said on Monday that the Norilsk auction should be postponed. Oneksim Bank lobbied heavily today and was finally given the green light from the Prime Minister to go through with the auction. **********The way Oneksim won the auction today is unlikely to dismay rival bankers, who were not interested in the problem-ridden mining and smelting giant -- or in fair play. But Oneksim's latest acquisition could discredit the Government's pledge to even the playing field in the notoriously murky field of privatization. **********Last month, Oneksim Bank unleashed a political bloodbath when it joined a Russian and Western consortium to win 25 percent of Svyazinvest, the state-owned telecommunications giant. **********First Deputy Prime Minister Anatoly B. Chubais insisted that the Svyazinvest auction, at least, had been fair and that the highest bid ($1.9 billion) had won. **********But the losing consortium, which included a banking and media tycoon with close ties to the Kremlin, Vladimir Gusinsky, viewed its defeat as a betrayal and began a campaign to discredit Oneksim Bank and the Government officials who supported the winners. **********Most economists agreed that the Svyazinvest sale met Western standards of fairness and disclosure, but few view today's auction in the same light. And the Russian state property committee, the agency that oversees privatization and finally allowed the sale to go through, immediately hedged its bets when the results were announced. **********''The fact that the auction has taken place will not prevent the prosecutor's office, on the Government's behalf, from disputing the results in court,'' said Sergei Molozhavny, deputy head of the committee. **********Oneksim Bank won the right to manage the Government's 38 percent share of Norilsk Nickel in 1995, part of a so-called loans-for-shares program that has become a symbol of the favoritism and inequities that have troubled privatization. **********Led by Oneksim Bank's chairman, Viktor Potanin, who a year later briefly served as a Deputy Prime Minister, a group of Kremlin-favored banks struck a deal offering loans to the cash-starved Russian Government in exchange for trusteeship of some of the country's most valuable metal and oil companies. **********When those assets came up for auction, the banks that managed them usually won the bid -- often at a fraction of the market value. **********After obtaining the shares, Oneksim Bank has struggled to improve management of the huge, debt-ridden plant in Norilsk, which despite its huge reserves of nickel, palladium and other metals and $6 billion in sales last year, is plagued with problems. **********But the bank, which wrote the rules for loans-for-shares program, was one of its biggest winners, taking among other things Norilsk and Sidanko, a major oil company, in the free-for-all. The auction today was merely the bank's effort to consolidate a victory won two years ago. **********And today, the bank's clout is considerable. Russian television networks reported that Mr. Potanin, the Oneksim chairman, had met privately with Mr. Chernomyrdin today and dissuaded him from delaying the auction. **********The one other company permitted to compete in the auction, Peredovye Promyshlennye Tekhnologii, did not contest its defeat. ''I think that everything was admissible,'' Sergei Barbashov, a company spokesman said after the results were announced.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/24/busin.snippet: Dow Jones industrial average loses 20.87 points to close at 6,812.72; Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks loses 0.97 point, to 773.64; Nasdaq composite index gains 14.40 points, or 1.19 percent, to 1,227.14; table (L)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/24/busin.main_headline: Technology Stocks Surge, But Others Sag
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/24/busin.print_headline: Technology Stocks Surge, But Others Sag
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/24/busin.body_text: **********Stocks slipped yesterday, a day after the Dow Jones industrial average posted its second-largest point gain in history. **********The Dow, which had risen more than 442 points in the previous seven sessions, lost 20.87 points yesterday to close at 6,812.72. **********The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks also fell, though just slightly, losing 0.97 point, to 773.64. **********But technology stocks, mired in a slump since late January, surged yesterday, lifting the technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index 14.40 points, or 1.19 percent, to 1,227.14. **********Analysts, however, continue to be troubled by the huge volatility in the market, part of a yearlong pattern that has seen the Dow rise 637 points, then fall 693 points, then recover 442 points, before yesterday's close. **********''The most consistent thing about the market is its inconsistency,'' said Elizabeth J. Mackay, the chief investment strategist at Bear Stearns. ''We have these big upswings and then sharp downturns. It's more chaos than usual.'' **********Ms. Mackay and other analysts say that the market is grappling with conflicting signals about earnings and interest rates, and those concerns are fostering greater fluctuations in stock prices as investors scramble for ways to lock in what they hope will be a third consecutive year of sizable returns. **********Recently, blue-chip stocks have enjoyed a big lift, aided by strong quarterly earnings. But many analysts worry that the recent run-up in prices is too narrowly confined to large-capitalization stocks. **********''This is not a very healthy kind of rally,'' said Richard McCabe, chief market analyst at Merrill Lynch & Company. ''Its durability is questionable unless it can broaden out.'' **********One sign of a robust bull market, Mr. McCabe said, is heavy buying across the board. But in the last few sessions, blue-chip stocks have seen large gains on days when there was low trading volume and weakness in the broader market. **********Indeed, there is a growing consensus on Wall Street that 1997 will not be a spectacular year. More likely, analysts say, it could turn out to be a flat year marked by huge volatility swings. **********Even though the Dow and S.& P. 500 are up about 5 percent, some analysts said there are big obstacles up ahead. **********David Shulman, the chief equity strategist at Salomon Brothers, is pessimistic about the market's prospects this year. He said that with fresh economic data, such as first-quarter figures on the gross domestic product, scheduled for release next week, the market could lose some of its recent gains. **********''I still think the market's going down,'' said Mr. Shulman, who had earlier forecast the Dow to end the year at 5,750 -- a 10 percent decline from last year. ''We'll start worrying about interest rates again because all the stuff that made for strong earnings is going to tell the Fed to tighten again.'' **********Indeed, quarterly earnings continue to be strong, according to First Call Inc., which tracks earnings. But yesterday, the real gains were in the technology sector, where Microsoft  gained 4 1/2 a share to close at 115 1/8 -- a 52-week high. This year, shares of Microsoft are up 39 percent. Shares of Intel also rose yesterday, up 5 1/8 to 146 1/4. And Dell Computer -- up 49 percent this year -- gained 2 1/2, to 79 3/8. **********Of the Dow's 30 component stocks, Procter & Gamble and Du Pont were the biggest losers yesterday. Procter & Gamble lost 3 1/8 a share, to 125 1/2, and shares of Du Pont fell 2 1/4, to 106, despite posting first-quarter earnings that were stronger than expected. **********Shares of I.B.M. rose 2 3/8, to 142 3/8, in anticipation of the company's earnings report, which was released after the market closed. Earnings were essentially flat, but I.B.M. reported better-than-expected profits. **********ON THE WEB **********The latest stock and mutual fund quotations, along with news updates, are available on the Internet from The New York Times on the Web: www.nytimes.com

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/26/busin.snippet: Lawyers have found niche in debt collection business; while most collection agencies can only threaten to sue delinquents, lawyers actually do; applying mass-production techniques, law firms will often receive thousands of cases a month from credi...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/26/busin.body_text: **********WHAT could be more appealing to a lawyer than a big cash payoff? **********Answer: Lots and lots of little cash payoffs, if the lawyer specializes in debt collection. **********Perhaps it was inevitable in a fast-growing industry with revenues that now exceed $5 billion a year, but lawyers have found their niche. Whereas most collection agencies can only threaten to sue, the lawyers actually do. **********Applying mass-production techniques, law firms will often receive thousands of cases a month from credit card issuers and other national lenders and pass them on to lawyers licensed in each state. **********Linda Straub Lacey, a paralegal for Gary Becker, a collections lawyer in Minneapolis, taps a few buttons on a personal computer. Its modem squeaks and squawks for a minute or so, as the machine gathers the pertinent information on two dozen debtors of the day. A few more taps at the keyboard and the information is sent to a word processor that will print a form letter demanding payment. **********If the debtor does not respond -- and most don't -- the same word processor will print a lawsuit and send it out. If the debtor still does not respond -- and, again, most don't -- Ms. Lacey will go to court for an award judgment. That, in turn, will enable her computer to write the most important document, a letter to an employer, garnishing the debtor's wages. **********Even that is no guarantee that the creditor will be repaid in full, or even see a penny. Federal law says that no more than 25 percent of a person's take-home wages can be seized in this way. And some claims, like child support, take precedence over bad debt. Moreover, any given creditor often has to fight over the spoils with other lenders. **********''I have some payroll people call me and say there are six garnishments ahead of me,'' Ms. Lacy says. ''Do I want to wait in line?'' **********In Minnesota, a lender can garnish wages for 70 days, then has to go to the back of the lien. As a result of all the constraints, Mr. Becker said his firm collected money on only two of every five judgments it won. **********''If someone had been scraping by on $400 a week, and you garnish $100 a week, they may not be able to live on $300, so they consider bankruptcy,'' he said. **********For all the difficulty of wringing relatively small sums out of individual debtors, the scale of the effort can mean big money for the firms that do it. Typically, they charge a commission of 20 percent to 25 percent of the money they collect. **********They are working on ways to deal with bankruptcy, too. Warren Rosenfeld, a partner in McNeily & Rosenfeld, a Washington collections law firm that runs a nationwide referral network, specializes in helping lenders get money from people after they have sought bankruptcy protection. **********The firm uses two techniques. The ''good guy'' program offers fresh credit to bankrupt people in return for their paying off some old debt. The ''bad guy'' program, by contrast, seeks to collect debt that is not protected by bankruptcy law, such as that incurred no more than 60 days before a filing or under fraudulent circumstances. **********''We are chasing people who have abused credit before bankruptcy,'' Mr. Rosenfeld said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/20/busin.snippet: Think New Ideas, interactive shop in which Omnicom Group owns minority stake, completes acquisition of Fathom Advertising; Interpublic Group of Companies forms Coleman Group Worldwide, network of companies specializing in corporate identity and pa...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/20/busin.body_text: **********Two agency companies said yesterday that they had expanded in the interactive marketing and corporate identity fields. **********Think New Ideas in Los Angeles and New York, an interactive shop in which Omnicom Group owns a minority stake, completed the acquisition of Fathom Advertising in Los Angeles, formerly the Ketchum Advertising Los Angeles unit of Omnicom. Terms of the deal, which had been expected, call for Omnicom to exchange its 100 percent interest in Fathom for more shares of Think New Ideas, raising Omnicom's stake in that agency to about 19 percent from 17 percent. **********The 25 employees of Fathom and accounts like the Oracle Corporation, with billings estimated at $16 million, will join the Los Angeles office of Think New Ideas. Larry Kopald, 43, managing partner and chief creative officer at Fathom, becomes chief creative officer at Think New Ideas and president of its Think West unit. **********Think New Ideas has 180 employees who work for clients like the Netscape Communications Corporation and the Rockport unit of Reebok International Ltd. **********And the Interpublic Group of Companies formed Coleman Group Worldwide in New York, a network of companies specializing in corporate identity and package design work. The new unit, part of the Allied Communications Group of Interpublic, will serve as a holding company for Coleman Group, a part of Interpublic since 1995. Owen W. Coleman, 56, president and chief executive at Coleman Group, will also be chairman and chief executive at Coleman Group Worldwide. **********Also, Coleman Group Worldwide acquired a majority interest in Planet L.L.C. in London, a corporate identity and package design agency that will be renamed Coleman Planet & Partners. Terms were not disclosed.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/25/busin.snippet: PSA Peugeot Citroen thought it had a winning formula for India when it arrived in 1994: Jump early into a virtually untapped market, launch a tried-and-tested model, and tie up with one of the country's few established automakers..Three years late...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/25/busin.main_headline: Its Joint Venture, Now in Third Year, Is Stuck in Reverse : Peugeot Skids on India's Roads
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/25/busin.print_headline: Its Joint Venture, Now in Third Year, Is Stuck in Reverse : Peugeot Skids on India's Roads
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/25/busin.body_text: **********PSA Peugeot Citroen thought it had a winning formula for India when it arrived in 1994: Jump early into a virtually untapped market, launch a tried-and-tested model, and tie up with one of the country's few established automakers. **********Three years later, Peugeot's troubles in India are mounting. **********Its joint venture with Premier Automobiles Ltd. has lost roughly dollars 35 million and desperately needs a cash infusion; production has almost come to a standstill, according to people close to the project, and the French automaker's commitment to staying in India is unclear. **********"I'm not in a position to say whether we will stay in India or not," said Vincent Adenis-Lamarre, the Paris-based area manager for South Asia. Peugeot executives in Bombay declined to comment. **********The French carmaker's woes in India are the second blow to its Asia strategy. Peugeot also is winding up operations in the southern Chinese city of Guangzhou after an unsuccessful 10-year run. **********Car sales in India have failed to grow as quickly as manufacturers expected since 1993, when New Delhi opened the national market. **********None of the foreign players, including Ford Motor Co., General Motors Corp. and Daewoo Corp., is making money yet. **********But industry analysts say Peugeot has made some critical mistakes. **********Despite a one-year start over Ford and GM, it underestimated the competition; Peugeot's model, the 309, is unpopular, and its partner is a financially weak, family-run business struggling to survive in a liberalized economy. **********What's more, early this month Peugeot took Premier to court to try to block a separate joint venture with an Italian rival, Fiat SpA. **********"To gain market share in a place like India, you have to pump in a lot of money and be patient," said N. Sreenivasan, an auto analyst at Jardine Fleming Brokerage. "Peugeot does not seem to be sure of its strategy for India." **********For now, the company is sticking with the 309, a model that Indian consumers are well aware has been phased out in Europe. **********Mr. Adenis-Lamarre said research had indicated that the model repre- **********sented the correct "tradeoff" between affordability and style for price-sensitive Indians. But poor sales suggest otherwise. **********"Peugeot took a colonial approach," said Hormazd Sorabjee, editor of Auto India magazine in Bombay. "They figured that after driving old cars for so long, Indians wouldn't mind driving a discontinued model. But today in India, a car is an icon of who you are and how well you are doing." **********Not all of its troubles are Peugeot's fault. Intermittent strikes at the Premier plant near Bombay where the 309 is assembled disrupted output for several months last year. The strikes, which also affected another Premier plant, further debilitated the Indian partner. **********"We don't have deep enough pockets to solve our own problems and also contribute to the joint venture with Peugeot," said Maitreya Doshi, managing director of Premier. **********The situation is so dire that in recent months the cash-strapped venture has not been able to afford components from the parent company in France to keep up production. Only 3,000 309s have rolled off the assembly line since late 1995. **********Peugeot and Premier each took a 32 percent stake in the project, with the rest held by financial institutions and the public. The initial Peugeot investment amounted to about dollars 75 million, and the project has received no fresh funds since. Instead of cash, Premier contributed one of its two factories. **********Sources close to the venture say that Peugeot pledged this year to invest more — if Premier put up money too. Short of cash, Premier offered instead to sell out entirely to Peugeot. **********But after extensive negotiations over price, Peugeot decided it was willing to acquire only a majority stake. **********Premier refused. That would mean, Mr. Doshi said, "holding a huge financial investment without having any management control over the business." **********On top of the financial discord, Peugeot and Premier now are facing off in court over Premier's plans to build the Fiat Uno passenger car. **********Peugeot gave its tacit consent to a 1995 deal between Premier and Fiat under which Premier would be licensed to assemble the Uno. Under that agreement, the Italian car giant was not to own any equity in the venture. **********A few months ago, however, Fiat agreed to invest in the Uno project and acquire majority control. **********"Fiat will treat the project like its own baby," said Mr. Doshi, whose company is to retain a 49 percent stake in the venture and a role in management. **********Premier and Peugeot disagreed over whether the Fiat venture violated a no-compete clause in their agreement. **********The court issued an injunction Sept. 5 that forced Premier to cancel a meeting at which it was to seek shareholder approval for the Fiat alliance. Premier has appealed the ruling. **********Meanwhile, Premier and Peugeot have reopened negotiations over the sale of Premier's stake. **********Unlike Peugeot, Fiat is clearly bullish on India. The Uno project is part of Fiat's plan to invest dollars 1 billion in several businesses here over the next five years, and a fully owned Fiat subsidiary is expected to begin manufacturing its Palio model here by late 1999. **********"The Fiat group has decided to make India a key element in its worldwide industrial strategy," the company's chief executive, Paolo Cantarella, said during the most recent of his three visits to India. **********Peugeot's chairman, Jacques Calvet, has yet to visit the country.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/19/busin.snippet: After decades of eking out a third-rate existence in the shadow of the Hollywood studios, Europe's film and television producers are breaking into the big time. . Jan Koerbelin, president of the entertainment division at Pro Sieben Television AG i...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/19/busin.main_headline: MEDIA MARKETS : Europe's Studios Take On Hollywood
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/19/busin.print_headline: MEDIA MARKETS : Europe's Studios Take On Hollywood
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/19/busin.body_text: **********After decades of eking out a third-rate existence in the shadow of the Hollywood studios, Europe's film and television producers are breaking into the big time. **********Jan Koerbelin, president of the entertainment division at Pro Sieben Television AG in Germany, cited International Business Machines Corp. recently as an analogy for Europe's new competitive spirit. **********"For years everyone said that it was impossible to compete with IBM," he said, "and then all of a sudden IBM's day was over, and people noticed that, lo and behold, there were a lot of other good computer makers around." **********Mr. Koerbelin and other Europeans now insist that Hollywood's hold on the world's television screens and, to a lesser extent, over global movie screens is beginning to wane. Even in Southern California, studio bosses have felt the first stirrings of the new tide. **********"In my opinion, Hollywood is coming awfully close to missing the international boat," Jeff Sagansky, the president of Sony Pictures Entertainment Inc., said in a speech last month. What is more, he said that a handful of French, German and British media concerns, such as Kirch Group in Germany, TF1 SA in France and Carlton Communications PLC, "are now firmly in charge of Europe's entertainment future." That process has advanced furthest in television production. "The old phenomenon of American television series appearing in British prime time is almost a thing of the past now," said Nigel Walmsley, chairman of Carlton Television. **********"A successful domestic program will consistently outdraw American series and get 40 to 50 percent of the viewers." **********Familiar faces, places and story lines account for some of the new European edge. A steady increase in the quality of those programs has also helped. Inspired by Hollywood, Europeans have edged away from their dialogue-heavy stage-inspired productions and have moved in the direction of faster-paced and more visual fare. **********"We are also using better-looking actors now," said Mr. Koerbelin. **********The sheer proliferation of new outlets for programs has also helped. Fifteen years ago, shows like "Starsky & Hutch" and "Dallas" dominated TV ratings across Europe. Back then, most Europeans only had access to one or two state-owned stations. National markets have since been thrown open to a profusion of independent commercial stations, all hungry for new programs. **********"In the last decade, French television production has grown to three or four times what it was," said Stephane Sperry, executive vice president for programming at Canal Plus SA. That growth is still accelerating. Two years ago, for instance, both Kirch and Carlton produced 400 hours of original programming. This year, they will each produce 500 hours. **********This year, Carlton will spend pounds 170 million (dollars 269.8 million) making programs ranging from "Inspector Morse" to "Bramwell," a Victorian-era medical drama. Many of those will find their way to prime time slots on Britain's largest television channel, ITV, which will spend pounds 800 million on programs this year, pounds 750 million of it for British-produced programs. **********"People prefer local productions," said Ludvig Zusalm, head of international production at Columbia Tristar, a subsidiary of Sony Corp., in Munich. "They want to see their own stories and their own actors." **********Alone among the Hollywood studios, Columbia Tristar has made it a top priority to give Europeans what they want. It began in 1992 by rewriting scripts of the American comedy series "Who's the Boss?" and remaking it in Britain under the title of "The Upper Hand." **********Next, the studio took its concept of what the industry calls "format adaptations" to Germany, producing German versions of everything from "Maude" to "Married With Children." When audiences and critics alike panned those efforts, Columbia began producing original German fare. The first offspring of that effort, a half-hour comedy series called "The Campers," made its debut to good reviews last month. **********Having made the leap into local production, however, Columbia must now confront the same problem long faced by the Europeans — the unlikelihood of finding big audiences for programs outside their home markets. Shows like the German detective series "Derrik," which has found a mass audience in France and in Italy, are rare. **********Working in English gives British producers a huge advantage, especially in the rich American market where dubbed programs are poorly received. For that reason, bigger-budget Continental productions, such as Kirch's dollars 120 million series on the Bible, are almost always shot in English and frequently feature big-name American or English stars. **********Britain's language edge helps explain why the country boasts the largest and most successful television-production industry outside America. Still, with international sales last year of less than dollars 400 million compared with Hollywood's dollars 4 billion, Britain's television producers have a long way to go. **********Producing almost exclusively for their home markets, Europeans can still make good money in television production but not the vast profits posted by Hollywood. Andrea Kirkby, a media analyst at Daiwa Europe in London, lauded the Europeans for the improved quality of their programs but said the industry was not yet equipped to compete on American terms. "They have produced some hits," she said, "but they are still not set up to keep grinding 'em out like Hollywood does." **********But that is changing. The proliferation of television channels, which soon will switch into high gear with the introduction of digital-television systems in major European markets, appears to guarantee a sellers' market in television programs for some time to come. **********To meet that demand the Europeans are planning major expansions. Pro Sieben, for instance, only started making its own productions three years ago. This summer, it plans to use a hefty slice of the proceeds from its expected 1 billion Deutsche marks (dollars 593 million) stock-market flotation to delve deeper into television and possibly even movie production.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/27/busin.snippet: Investor uncertainty about extent of problems in Asia and fallout on corporate earnings of American multinationals leaves Wall Street stocks mixed; Dow Jones industrial average is down 14.17 points, to 7,794.78; table (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/27/busin.main_headline: Stocks Close Mixed, With Dow Off 14.17
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/27/busin.print_headline: Stocks Close Mixed, With Dow Off 14.17
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/27/busin.body_text: **********Investors gained some solace from calmer markets in Asia yesterday, but uncertainty about the extent of the problems in the region and the fallout on corporate earnings of American multinationals left Wall Street stocks mixed. **********While Japan's benchmark stock index rose 1.1 percent yesterday, changing gears after a 5.1 percent stumble Tuesday, multinational companies like Procter & Gamble and Coca-Cola pulled the Dow Jones industrial average down 14.17 points, to 7,794.78, as broader market indexes eked out small gains. The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks rose 0.82 point, to 951.64. **********''I think it makes sense for investors to be wary of what's happening,'' said Barbara Marcin, senior portfolio manager at Citibank Global Asset Management. **********Although American multinational corporations receive only a small percentage of their earnings from Asia, Ms. Marcin believes that the downturn in that region could have a broader impact worldwide by damping demand for other countries' products as well. **********Asian markets continued to steady early today. At the midday recess in trading, the benchmark Nikkei index of 225 Japanese stocks was ahead by 290.41 points, or 1.81 percent, at 16,335.96. **********South Korean stocks ended their morning session down 2.32 points, or a half of 1 percent, at 436.38, while Hong Kong stocks were little changed in early trading. **********Despite the calm in Asian stock markets, Japan's financial problems are worrying some strategists in the United States. **********''This development can't be overlooked; it's not a transitory event,'' Marshall Acuff, equity strategist at Smith Barney said of the recent bank and brokerage firm failures in Japan. But, investors and analysts are having a difficult time gauging the impact because ''we don't know how much Asia is going to slow down and we don't know what industries and companies are going to be affected.'' **********As a result, being wary of multinationals is an ''appropriate first response,'' Mr. Acuff added. **********And comments from Asian and American leaders at the Asia Pacific economic conference in Vancouver, British Columbia, did not totally reassure investors that the crisis was under control, said Hank Herrmann, chief investment officer at Waddell & Reed in Kansas City, Kan. **********''The Canada conversations were mostly to say that the central banks are prepared to insure liquidity in the event of more problems,'' Mr. Herrmann said. **********''It's good for depositors, but I don't know that that's all that reassuring'' for investors, he added. **********While the Asian crisis unfolds, Mr. Herrmann believes investors should avoid cyclical stocks, which would perform poorly if the Asian economic slowdown is a significant drag on American growth, and companies in the capital goods sector, such as heavy-equipment manufacturers. **********Instead, they should focus on companies with more predictable earnings from domestic sources and little exposure to emerging markets. **********''I think there are opportunities on a long-term basis, but I wouldn't want to be calling the bottom,'' he said. Clearer signs of the impact on United States companies may not come until first-quarter earnings reports in 1998, he said. **********Some investors seem to be in Mr. Herrmann's camp. Alan Bond, chief investment officer for Bond Procope Capital Managagment which oversees $500 million, is reducing his exposure to technology shares like Applied Materials, the leading maker of semiconductor maufacturing equipment, and will not increase his holdings of money center banks with exposure to Asia. **********Instead, he's buying retailers like Costco and regional banks like Fifth Third Bancorp in Cincinnati, Sovereign Bancorp in Wyomissing, Pa. and Northern Trust Corporation in Chicago. **********''We're not running for the hills, but it's certainly a run for cover,'' Mr. Bond said of his more domestic stance. **********Elizabeth Mackay, chief investment strategist at Bear, Stearns, said investors could consider multinational companies with limited exposure to Asia such as American Express and Hewlett-Packard. For Hewlett, ''Europe is probably more important to them than Asia,'' she added. **********Ms. Marcin of Citibank said she believed that some declines among multinationals may have been overdone and investors should consider picking up capital goods stocks like Deere, Boeing and Raytheon. Having exposure to overseas markets is still ''an attractive long-term quality for a company to have,'' she said. And some investors believe that even as events unfold, it is safe to stick a toe or even wade into Asian waters. **********ON THE WEB **********The latest stock and mutual fund quotations, along with news updates, are available on the Internet from The New York Times on the Web: www.nytimes.com

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/31/world.snippet: China's Government-controlled television and newspapers have not mentioned impromptu debate on human rights between Pres Jiang Zemin and Pres Clinton at their news conference on Oct 29 (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/31/world.main_headline: At Home, Rosy News for Jiang's Trip
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/31/world.print_headline: SUMMIT IN WASHINGTON: IN CHINA; At Home, Rosy News for Jiang's Trip
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/31/world.body_text: **********Among the mandatory smiles and pageantry of Jiang Zemin's state visit to Washington this week, the impromptu debate on human rights between Mr. Jiang and President Clinton at their news conference Wednesday stood out as unusually frank. For American viewers at least, it was a reminder of the differences that remain despite a multitude of agreements and shared hopes. **********But few Chinese are apt to learn about this telling moment because the pointed exchange was not mentioned at all in the news coverage here. All week the Government-controlled television and newspapers have extolled the happy moments of the trip and glossed over less pleasant tidings. **********Viewers this evening of China's only national television newscast watched the Clintons and Gores meet Mr. Jiang and his wife, sat through nearly the entire American national anthem and watched the 21-gun salute. They heard a long summary of the leaders' joint statement, covering everything from environmental agreements to the desire for world peace. **********The news conference itself was shown only briefly, and the crowd of protesters across the street from the White House was not mentioned at all. From the long and lively press conference, the Government-run China Central Television showed only a moment of each leader's statement about constructive cooperation, and a Chinese reporter lobbing Mr. Jiang a softball of a question. **********The television networks and newspapers here -- all Government controlled -- have been remarkably consistent. The images given the Chinese people have been resolutely upbeat, with special emphasis on the pomp and symbols. The newspapers have sometimes mentioned, amid the long lists of achievements, that the two countries have differences on human rights, but then report only Mr. Jiang's justifications. **********Mr. Jiang clearly wanted this trip to give him new stature as a leader, and China new stature as a world player. Each day's ceremonies have been featured atop page one of every major newspaper, crowding down news about the stock market chaos in Hong Kong, and they have filled the opening minutes of every news broadcast. **********''The goverment sees this visit as a very big event, and they give the media very detailed directions about what to print,'' said Wu Guoguang, a former editorial writer of the People's Daily who left China in 1989 and now teaches at the Chinese University of Hong Kong. **********Longtime China-watchers in the diplomatic community here are not surprised by the timid and uniform press coverage, a habit of Communism that has not waned in the new era of economic opening. The Chinese leaders need time to mull over the results of this American visit, said a Western diplomat, and in the meantime would find it risky to allow attention for anything so heated as Wednesday's Presidential retorts. **********The trip has produced one mystery. Mr. Jiang's hourlong swim in Hawaii, a feat of stamina by any measure, would seem designed to impress the Chinese people and harked back to famous swims by Chairman Mao and Deng Xiaoping. Yet while the Western and the Hong Kong press gave wide coverage to the event, someone high in the Chinese government apparently decided that this would not strike the right tone at home: Chinese television and newspapers ignored it. **********A possible answer was suggested by Mr. Wu, the former People's Daily editor. He recalled that several years ago Li Peng, the Prime Minister, took a swim in the Dead Sea during a visit to the Middle East. The publication of a picture of him lolling in the water coincided, unfortunately, with a period of disastrous flooding in southern China, and Mr. Li's public image took a dive. **********''Maybe the papers learned a lesson from that,'' Mr. Wu said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/10/busin.body_text: **********Shares of National Semiconductor tumbled nearly 12 percent today after the company reported mixed results for its fiscal second quarter. **********Revenue and earnings from its core chip business were well above most analysts' estimates, but there were steeper-than-anticipated losses from the Cyrix Corporation, which National acquired in July. **********National Semiconductor shares fell $3.625 each, to $27. Analysts said the shares were caught in the technology downdraft created by the Oracle Corporation's surprisingly weak numbers, but that investors were also concerned about the dilutive effects of the Cyrix business. Cyrix makes microprocessors, which put National in direct competition with the Intel Corporation. **********For the quarter ended Nov. 23, National earned $28.9 million, or 17 cents a share, up 10.7 percent from $26.1 million, or 17 cents a share, in the corresponding period a year earlier. Sales rose 5 percent, to $719.9 million. **********Excluding one-time charges, and the effects of the Cyrix merger, National said it earned $72.5 million, or 46 cents a share, on sales of $640.3 million from its core businesses. Cyrix lost $17.8 million on sales of $79.6 million.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/22/world.snippet: Article profiles David J Scheffer, US Ambassador at Large for War Crimes; entirely new position, brainchild of Sec of State Madeleine K Albright, is aimed at giving war crimes, genocide and crimes against humanity higher priority in American forei...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/22/world.main_headline: Making Sure War Crimes Aren't Forgotten
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/22/world.print_headline: Making Sure War Crimes Aren't Forgotten
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/22/world.body_text: **********On a gentle hillside a few miles from here one afternoon this month, David J. Scheffer, the Clinton Administration's Ambassador at Large for War Crimes Issues, stepped slowly through a field of wooden crosses marking the spot where Hutu extremists slaughtered thousands of Tutsi in 1994. **********In a light drizzle, he bent over and struggled to right one of several crosses, worn by weather and time, that had fallen into the weeds. It stood for a moment, teetered, and fell again. Riding back to Kigali, he asked an embassy official if there might not be a way for the United States to pay for stone grave markers. **********''Because they aren't going to last like that,'' he said. **********It was a modest gesture but for Mr. Scheffer a fitting one. As Ambassador at Large, he has been handed the task of insuring that the sorts of atrocities carried out in Rwanda -- and all too often in other conflicts around the world -- do not fade into history like the crosses on the hillside. **********His is an entirely new position, the first devoted exclusively to the most egregious violations of humanity. **********It was the brainchild of Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright, long an advocate of international justice, to give the issue of war crimes, genocide and crimes against humanity a higher priority in American foreign policy, separating it from the State Department's bureau overseeing human rights generally. **********She even put Mr. Scheffer's office on the seventh floor of the State Department, which in the hierarchy of the place puts it very near the Secretary's -- a sign seen all the way to embassies here in East Africa that his job has influence. **********The question now is whether Mr. Scheffer -- an earnest, talkative lawyer from Norman, Okla., who was confirmed by the Senate on July 31 and sworn in a week later -- can make the job one of the signatures of Ms. Albright's tenure as Secretary of State, as she would like, and not just another well-meaning idea that gets lost in the pragmatic trade-offs of diplomacy. **********Diane F. Orentlicher, director of the War Crimes Research Office at American University Washington College of Law, said that by creating the position, Ms. Albright had committed herself to real results, not just symbolic ones. Otherwise, she said, she will face charges that the appointment was nothing more than a response to pressure in Congress to do more, especially in Bosnia. **********''In the best sense, the Administration has stuck its proverbial neck out,'' she said. **********On his inaugural trip as Ambassador, which was to take him from East Africa and Congo to the Balkans and then the Hague, Mr. Scheffer learned firsthand that mere gestures, however heartfelt,  would go only so far in a country where more than 500,000 people  died in one of history's worst episodes of genocide. **********A day after his visit to the cemetery in Nyanza, he found himself sharply questioned at the American cultural center here in Kigali by an invited group of Rwandan dignitaries more interested in justice than symbolism. **********''I don't think the problem is money,'' declared Tomas Ndahiro, a journalist with Rwanda's quasi-official radio, echoing the doubts many Tutsi have about the world's zeal to punish those responsible for the massacres. ''I think it is a lack of moral commitment.'' **********Mr. Scheffer, for his part, acknowledges that he is starting his job fighting against the notion of irrelevance. ''It is my responsibility to demonstrate this is more than symbolic,'' he said in an interview during his visit here. **********His initial focus will be on the nascent war crimes tribunals now trying to prosecute those who carried out the worst crimes in Rwanda and the former Yugoslavia, but his portfolio extends far beyond the Balkans and Central Africa, to Iraq and Cambodia, and any other place where war crimes may yet arise. **********And it includes Ms. Albright's ultimate goal of creating a permanent international criminal court, a controversial idea in Congress and elsewhere because of its potential to reach over sovereign borders. **********Mr. Scheffer, who is 44, is a lawyer who specialized in international law in private practice for seven years with Coudert Brothers of New York City, and later researched and taught the subject at Columbia, Harvard and the Georgetown University Law Center. **********More important, as Ms. Albright's top aide in Washington while she was the chief American delegate to the United Nations, he represented her at the regular ''deputies committee'' meetings of the top aides to President Clinton's foreign policy team. **********As Ms. Albright's counsel, Mr. Scheffer was also a central player in the Administration's policy on war crimes, having a large hand in Security Council deliberations that led to the tribunals for the former Yugoslavia and Rwanda, the first international courts to try cases of war crimes since the Nuremberg and Tokyo tribunals after World War II. **********After the massacres of thousands of Bosnian Muslims in Srebrenica in 1995, Mr. Scheffer  helped pry loose aerial reconnaissance photos from the intelligence agencies that Ms. Albright used to warn Bosnian Serbs publicly not to tamper with evidence of war crimes. ''We will be watching,'' Ms. Albright said at the time. **********In June, after he was nominated but not yet confirmed for his new job, Mr. Scheffer led the Administration's scramble to find a way to bring Pol Pot of Cambodia to some international trial. It was Mr. Scheffer who identified Canada's law on genocide as a possible avenue for trying the Cambodian.  Nothing came of the idea, however, as Pol Pot is believed to remain under Khmer Rouge control after a brief show trial in July. **********In debates in the Administration, as he struggles to bring attention to an issue that had been an afterthought, Mr. Scheffer must often juggle competing interests in the State Department and with other agencies, notably the Pentagon, which has clashed with the department over how aggressively NATO troops should pursue indicted war-crime suspects in Bosnia. **********''The Administration consists of many people with many different viewpoints,'' said Ms. Orentlicher of American University. ''He has the job of making the case for doing what must be done.'' **********With the rank of ambassador, Mr. Scheffer now also has the authority to deal directly with foreign governments. In mid-September, he met with officials from Rwanda's Tutsi-led Government to make the case for better cooperation with the International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda. And he went to Burundi to warn President Pierre Buyoya's Government to stop summary executions and other abuses if it ever hoped to persuade the United Nations to create another international tribunal to prosecute those who killed 50,000 Tutsi in 1993. **********''You have to deal with the issue of accountability,'' he said in Burundi, ''or you will never end the violence here.'' **********In his appearance at the cultural center here and over lunch with members of Rwanda's nascent bar association, Mr. Scheffer said he had started his inaugural trip as Ambassador in Africa deliberately because Rwanda's tribunal has received far less attention and support than the tribunal for the former Yugoslavia, which is based in The Hague. **********''The most challenging test for the rule of law in our generation is the genocide of 1994 that consumed Rwanda,'' he said at the cultural center, promising to do more to give the victims a sense of justice. **********The gap between promise and reality, however, was clear when he visited a church in Ntarama, south of Kigali, where the decomposing bodies of more than 5,000 victims of the genocide remain to this day as a macabre memorial to the killing. Mr. Scheffer called it ''a memorial to the living dead.'' **********A Tutsi woman, Christine Mukaruyenzi, guided him through the church, strewn with bones and clothing stained with dried blood. It was in the church on April 15, 1994, that she and her eight children had gone to hide when the killings started. Only she survived. ''We hope the world will never forget this,'' she told him. **********But it was clear there was little chance that all those responsible for the killings would face justice. ''It's not really a mass murder,'' Mr. Scheffer said as he stepped over shattered, decaying bones and skulls, many showing the machete blows that killed the victims. ''It is individual murder, person by person, that becomes mass murder.'' **********Mr. Scheffer said it was vital to create a greater sense of justice and thus, hopefully, reconciliation in Rwanda, by shoring up the tribunal for Rwanda. The tribunal's failure to complete a case, nearly three years after it was established, has created animosity with Rwanda's Government that Mr. Scheffer sought to ease during his meetings with Government officials. **********To that end, he stopped at the tribunal's headquarters in a grimy cement conference center in Arusha, Tanzania, before coming to Rwanda. **********In a series of meetings, Mr. Scheffer chided the tribunal's judges for moving cases too slowly -- it has only three trials under way, and they are in various states of suspension -- and he deplored the dismal working conditions of the building itself, which lacks even reliable phone service. **********At the same time, he sounded more sympathetic than critical, comparing its efforts to the effort made by the United States to try Timothy McVeigh. ''What we're talking about in Rwanda,'' he said, ''is more than 500,000 murder cases.'' **********Beyond the two tribunals, Mr. Scheffer has long lists of priorities for an office that is just getting off the ground. **********He said he wanted to focus attention on Burundi and Congo, to hold Pol Pot accountable for the killing fields of Cambodia and to establish at least ''a record'' if not a prosecution of war crimes that the United States believes Iraq committed against the Kurds and the Kuwaitis. **********Mr. Scheffer's work has already clashed with Realpolitik. After leaving Kigali, Mr. Scheffer went to Congo, where he deliberately avoided a public confrontation with the Government of President Laurent Kabila, who is fighting with the United Nations over an investigation into atrocities committed during his alliance's overthrow of Mobutu Sese Seko. **********Eager to maintain ties with Mr. Kabila and avoid alienating his African allies, American officials have limited their public criticism of his opposition to the United Nations investigation. **********''There are times,'' Mr. Scheffer said, ''when I need to be low-profile to accomplish what we want.'' **********Mr. Scheffer said he did not expect to be the last Ambassador at Large for War Crimes. ''If human nature continues to be of the same character as it was in the 20th century,'' he said, ''there will be more than enough work to do.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/22/busin.snippet: Publishers remain enthusiastic about business of almanacs, especially general-interest books like World Almanac and Book of Facts and Information Please Almanac; economics of almanacs is appealing to publishers, because they can bring out new book...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/22/busin.main_headline: The Old-Fashioned Almanac Thrives in the Age of the Internet
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/22/busin.print_headline: The Old-Fashioned Almanac Thrives in the Age of the Internet
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/22/busin.body_text: **********In the library of Oak Hill Elementary School in the Kansas City suburb of Overland Park, Kan., one set of books gets used more than most: the almanacs. **********''For class work and even for fun, the kids love to sit and read them for hours,'' said Sharon Coatney, the school's librarian. ''Children are fascinated with trivia and new things. They love to ask each other, 'did you know such and such,' and almanacs give them a lot of such and suches.'' **********Almanac publishers have counted on schools to introduce new generations of buyers to their books. Even in the era of CD-ROM's and the Internet, with their promise of vast storehouses of information, publishers remain enthusiastic about the business of almanacs, especially general-interest books like the World Almanac and Book of Facts and the Information Please Almanac. **********Two big publishers entered the almanac market this year, bringing out The Wall Street Journal Almanac and The New York Times Almanac. **********The economics of almanacs is appealing to publishers, because they can bring out new books every year at a relatively low cost. Although each year's edition will include new articles and other updated information, much of the data can be recycled from year to year. Moreover, although almanac sales are quite large by publishing standards, and there are no big-name authors demanding huge advances and royalties. **********There is, of course, a wide variety of almanacs available, with some focusing mainly on sports or entertainment -- or on the weather as the Old Farmer's Almanac does. But the most popular are the general-interest almanacs, which compile hundreds of thousands of facts about a broad range of topics, from abortion to the zodiac. An estimated two million of these almanacs are sold each year, for less than $11 apiece. **********And a large portion of those sales occur during the holiday season. The new almanacs dated 1998 appeared in bookstores in November and early December, and they are favored by some gift shoppers. **********''These books are phenomenal sellers, especially during this season,'' said Robert Wietrak, a vice president of merchandise at Barnes & Noble. His stores sell 75 percent of their almanacs from November through January. **********''Everyone likes almanacs and they make great stocking stuffers,'' he said. ''We will sell about 300,000 almanacs altogether. That would make almanacs one of our top 10 nonfiction books for the year.'' **********The giant in this category is the 130-year-old World Almanac, published by Primedia Reference Inc. It sells about 1.2 million copies each year, more than double the sales of its nearest competitor, the Information Please Almanac, published by Information Please L.L.C. **********Now, Ballantine Books, a unit of Advance Publications that publishes The Wall Street Journal Almanac, and Penguin Reference Books, a subsidiary of Pearson P.L.C. that publishes The New York Times Almanac, are each betting that the name of a big national newspaper will provide a competitive edge. **********''The almanac publishing business is a tough game,'' said John W. Wright, general editor of The New York Times Almanac. ''To market against the World Almanac, you need another brand name, and that's where The Times comes in.'' **********Ronald J. Alsop, editor of The Wall Street Journal Almanac, has a similar view. ''Taking on the existing almanacs is not easy because you have to be truly distinctive to stand out,'' he said. **********To that end, The Wall Street Journal Almanac has adopted some of the look and feel of the newspaper, with the articles and charts being provided by The Journal's staff. **********Mr. Alsop, who is also a news editor at The Journal, which is owned by Dow Jones & Company, contended that his almanac was more forward-looking than its competitors. ''Other almanacs have the history of the Liberty Bell,'' he said, ''but is that really what people want to know? We have information that is relevant to people as we approach the year 2000. For example, we tell you what the fastest-growing occupations will be between now and 2005.'' **********The New York Times Almanac, meanwhile, portrays itself as the ''almanac of record,'' and Mr. Wright said the book reflected the newspaper's ''thorough coverage of the U.S. and the world.'' **********Unlike The Wall Street Journal Almanac, which was created from scratch, The New York Times Almanac has some of its roots in a prior book, the Universal Almanac. **********Mr. Wright was previously the editor of the Universal Almanac. Its publisher, Andrews & McMeel, decided to discontinue the book with the 1997 issue. The Universal Almanac was well respected and comprehensive, but its sales were lower than those of its competitors. **********But Mr. Wright owned the rights to the content of the Universal Almanac, so he approached The New York Times Company with the idea of creating a new almanac with the newspaper's name on it. Penguin was then brought in as the publisher. **********The New York Times Almanac includes a good deal of information from the Universal Almanac, although Mr. Wright rejects contentions by rivals that the old almanac is merely repackaged. He noted that some members of The Times news staff contributed articles about the major news events of the year, as well as the maps in the book. **********It is too early to tell whether the new books are making a serious dent in the market share of the older books. Ballantine said its first print run of The Wall Street Journal Almanac was 165,000 copies, while Penguin said it also printed 165,000 copies of The New York Times Almanac. **********The World Almanac also traces its roots to the newspaper business. The first edition of the almanac was published by The New York World in 1868. That almanac ceased in 1876, but Joseph Pulitzer, who acquired The World in 1883, revived the book in 1886, and it has been published since then by various companies. **********By most counts, almanacs tend to be impulse purchases that are not regularly repeated. According to Richard W. Eiger, publisher of the World Almanac, about 20 percent of his customers buy new almanacs every year, and about 50 percent buy new copies every two to three years. **********Mr. Eiger said he was not overly worried by his new competitors. ''We respect the competition and are alert to it,'' he said. **********And Elizabeth Buckley Kubik, general manager of Information Please L.L.C., also showed little concern about the new almanacs. ''We don't consider them players, because we are not sure if they are in it for the long run,'' she said. The Information Please Almanac, which has been published since 1947, is seeking a competitive advantage by providing a midyear update to book buyers who want it. **********Regardless of the competition, Mr. Eiger said the World Almanac would maintain its $500,000 marketing budget. The others are estimated to spend at least $100,000 each. **********He did point out, however, that the World Almanac did not raise its retail price from $9.95 a copy. The others are all $10.95 each. **********Mr. Eiger said he was not surprised that almanacs sell well, even with competition from the Internet and CD-ROM's. ''Our almanac allows you to get to specific information without trawling through dozens of Web sites to find it,'' he said. **********Others have a similar view. ''Finding information on the Internet can be a nightmare,'' said Barbara Berliner, coordinator of NYPL-Express, a fee-based research service of the New York Public Library. ''With an almanac it's quicker, easier and more accurate.'' **********Still, the almanac publishers are developing on-line projects. For example, Ms. Kubik of Information Please said her company had invested ''a seven-figure sum'' to open a World Wide Web site next month. **********Meanwhile, at the Oak Hill Elementary School, the library is acquiring about 30 copies of the 1998 World Almanac. ''As soon as the new books arrive, they are snapped up by the kids,'' Ms. Coatney said. ''They will use them and use them until they fall clear apart.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/15/world.snippet: Waiting for China, Reporter's Notebook on preparations for Hong Kong's handover to China; says Secretary of State Madeleine K Albright and British Prime Min Tony Blair will witness handover, but will boycott subsequent swearing in of Hong Kong's n...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/15/world.main_headline: Pounding and Protests for Hong Kong's Big Day
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/15/world.print_headline: Pounding and Protests for Hong Kong's Big Day
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/15/world.body_text: **********Jutting into Victoria Harbor, its swooping layered roof a manta-ray-like addition to the skyline, is the nearly completed convention center where the Union Jack will be lowered for the last time and China's five-star red flag raised over the territory. A slew  of carpenters' hammers echoed through the two main halls this  week: the hall where at midnight on June 30 Beijing's resumption of sovereignty will be made formal, and a second hall where soon after midnight its appointed government will be sworn in. **********Britain's new Prime Minister, Tony Blair, will be here to see the sun set on empire, as will Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright, dozens of other foreign ministers and much of China's senior leadership, including President Jiang Zemin and Prime Minister Li Peng, the man reviled here for ordering the violent repression of the Tiananmen Square protests in June 1989. **********But unlike the majority of guests, Ms. Albright will join Mr. Blair in boycotting the subsequent swearing in of Hong Kong's new government, a gesture of protest against China's abolition of the territory's elected legislature and its installation of an appointed assembly, what it is calling the provisional legislature. **********''It wouldn't be appropriate,'' the  State Department spokesman, Nicholas Burns, said earlier this week.  Mr. Blair then announced his decision to join Ms. Albright in her protest. **********Britain's last Governor here, Christopher Patten, the first non-diplomat to hold the post and a former chairman of Britain's Conservative Party, introduced a sweeping range of democratic elections here in recent years, moves that were denounced by Beijing. The mainland Chinese press lathered invective on Mr. Patten for giving Hong Kong's citizens a voice in their own governance, labeling him, among other things, a ''prostitute for a thousand years.'' **********Despite the actions by Washington and London, other Western and Asian democracies have declined to join in the protest, including Australia, New Zealand and Japan. ''We're an independent country,'' said Alexander Downer, Australia's Foreign Minister. ''We'll make up our own minds what we want to do as the Australian Government.'' **********Newspapers here sympathetic to Beijing's plans for Hong Kong were quick to attack Ms. Albright and Mr. Blair. ''The provisional legislature is a concern only of China,'' wrote Sing Tao Daily, ''and it is ridiculous for foreign agencies to voice any opinion on the issue or intervene in the internal policies of China.'' **********One question that remains unanswered, and on which officials showing reporters around the halls where the hand-over ceremonies will take place expressed ignorance, is what door Ms. Albright and Mr. Blair will use when they walk out of the formalities. **********Celluloid Opium War **********Lest the passage of 156 years cloud memories of how Hong Kong fell into British hands, a $15 million Chinese-made movie extravaganza ''The Opium War'' was released here this week. The premiere was attended by the cream of the future post-colonial elite, including Tung Chee-hwa, the man Beijing has chosen to run the territory, and assorted Communist Party luminaries. **********Xie Jin, the director of the film, equated it with Stephen Spielberg's ''Schindler's List'' -- a comparison he said was valid, because, after all, Queen Victoria, monarch when Hong Kong was ceded to Britain in 1841, was little better than Hitler. **********Notable by their absence were the current leaders of Hong Kong, particularly Governor Patten. Nor were there any representatives of Jardine, Matheson. Jardine's was the company whose shipments of opium to China were guaranteed by British guns in the colonial adventure by which Hong Kong became a prize of empire. **********China's representative at the gala made it clear what the film was all about. ''Hong Kong is about to return to the motherland,'' said Zhang Junsheng, the second-ranking Communist Party official here. ''This is a great event that washes away more than 150 years of shame left by the Opium War. The showing of 'The Opium War' will attract the rapt attention of all the people of Hong Kong.'' **********Well, not all. **********Dennis Eng, film critic of The Hong Kong Standard, struggled to stay awake through the 140 minutes of historic didacticism, after which he wrote, ''The result seems more like a loud cannon blast that disappears into a cloud of smoke.'' **********The film opened on Friday to the general public but is facing stiff competition from the likes of Bruce Willis, Gene Hackman and Winona Rider, all appearing in movies more attuned to Hong Kong tastes. **********Eagerness for Troops **********Beijing has decided, apparently, that Britain will not go gently into its post-colonial night. This week, China decided that it wanted to move the main force of its People's Liberation Army garrison into Hong Kong early, before it resumes control on July 1. **********Already, Beijing has a 200-man unarmed advance unit here to prepare for the expected 10,000 Chinese troops who will be stationed here.  Now, though, Beijing insists that it bring in more troops and weapons early ''so that after the completion of the hand-over ceremony they can take up defense responsibilities,'' according to Beijing-controlled newspapers here. **********Britain immediately dismissed the suggestion, declaring that it retains responsibility for Hong Kong's defense until midnight on June 30. **********In any case, Governor Patten observed, it was unclear what foreign threat Hong Kong was faced with that would require armed Chinese troops. British troops here are known less for being armed with weapons than a pint of beer. **********China's military, though, appears convinced that the United States and Britain are conspiring to undermine Hong Kong. China Defense, an official newspaper of the mainland's military establishment, wrote this week that ''out of a need to maintain its global strategic position, the United States is strengthening its intelligence work in Hong Kong, supporting Hong Kong's Democratic Party and fostering political forces.'' **********The Democratic Party is the largest of the territory's political parties and the party that won the greatest number of seats in the legislative elections of 1995. **********''Before and after Hong Kong's return,'' China Defense wrote, ''some U.S. politicians and intermediaries will certainly stir up trouble over the Hong Kong issue. So-called 'democrats' within Hong Kong society will cooperate from afar with international forces hostile to China. We must take precautions and then wait and see.''
