https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/06/busin.body_text: **********Clearing the decks for a new management approach, the president of Philips Electronics N.V., Cor Boonstra, accepted the resignation of a third 30-year-veteran senior manager. Since becoming president in October, Mr. Boonstra, 59, has repeatedly pledged to turn around, sell or close unprofitable divisions and return Philips, the world's third-biggest electronics manufacturer, to double-digit growth. **********Jan Tollenaar, 59, quit Philips's management board yesterday for what were called ''personal reasons.'' Frank P. Carrubba, 59, left the six-member board on Feb. 13, when his contract ran out. The previous president, Jan D. Timmer, left the supervisory board last month.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/25/busin.snippet: Conference Board reports its index of consumer confidence rose in June for fourth straight month, reaching 28-year high of 129.6, up from revised 127.9 in May (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/25/busin.body_text: **********Americans' confidence in the economy continued to climb this month, suggesting that consumer spending may rebound. **********The Conference Board said yesterday that its index of consumer confidence rose in June for the fourth consecutive month, reaching a 28-year high of 129.6. That was up from May's revised index of 127.9, previously reported as 127.1. **********Economists had expected the June report to show a decline in the index. **********''Consumers continue to be bullish about the economy,'' said Lynn Franco, associate director of the Conference Board's consumer research center. **********Rising incomes, low unemployment and low inflation are contributing to Americans' exuberance about the economy, analysts said. ''Consumers are reloading for the third quarter,'' said Anthony Chan, chief economist at Banc One Investment Advisers in Columbus, Ohio. **********Strong consumer confidence has not translated into increased spending during the current quarter. But economists, investors and even policy makers at the Federal Reserve expect consumer purchasing to strengthen in coming months. Such spending accounts for about two-thirds of economic output. **********Alice M. Rivlin, the vice chairwoman of the Fed, said in a recent interview that the sluggish retail sales that have hindered economic growth in the second quarter were ''not likely to persist because all the signs that make consumers feel good are there.'' She predicted ''good, healthy growth'' ahead. **********With consumers alternating between spending sprees and periods of unexpected austerity, the economy grew at the rapid annual pace of 5.8 percent in the first quarter and then slowed to an estimated 2 percent rate in the current quarter. **********Those ups and downs in consumer spending are not unusual and, more important, help stretch the nation's seven-year expansion, said David Jones, chief economist at Aubrey G. Lanston in New York. Americans ''are positive, but they still wait for a bargain before they buy; they're not speculating like we saw in the 1970's and 1980's,'' he said. **********That, in turn, means that consumers are less likely to send the economy into a growth spiral that would cause the Fed policy makers to tighten credit severely. **********In yesterday's report, the Conference Board said the index gauging consumers' expectations for the next six months fell to 110.7 in June from 111.4 in May, while the index tracking their assessment of present conditions advanced to 157.8 from 152.6.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/30/busin.snippet: Handful of companies that went public on Oct 29, so soon after market crash, are generally warmly received by investors, with shares of most closing higher for day; analysts say activity in initial public offerings, or IPO's, signal sharp reversal...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/30/busin.main_headline: Surprisingly Warm Greetings For Several Initial Offerings
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/30/busin.print_headline: THE MARKET TURMOIL: THE NEW ISSUES; Surprisingly Warm Greetings For Several Initial Offerings
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/30/busin.body_text: **********The shares of start-up companies are usually regarded as those most at risk when markets plummet, as they did on Monday. So gyrating markets often scare fledgling companies from trying to offer shares to the public for the first time. **********But yesterday proved to be a solid, confidence-building session in the closely watched market for initial public offerings, or I.P.O.'s. The handful of companies that bravely went public yesterday were generally warmly received by investors, with the shares of most closing higher for the day. **********The activity in I.P.O.'s signaled a sharp reversal in sentiment from the start of the week, when analysts feared new issues might come to a halt for a week or more. **********''Monday now looks like a hiccup, and sentiment is pretty positive,'' said Ryan Jacob, an analyst at IPO Value Monitor, a research service. **********The shares of MMC Networks Inc., a Silicon Valley maker of microchips used in computer networks, nearly doubled their offering price of $11 on the first day of trading, closing at $21.375 a share. Another new issue, Beringer Wine Estate Holdings, a winery in St. Helena, Calif., had an offering price of $26 a share, and closed at $32.50 a share. And shares of Casella Waste Systems Inc., a garbage collector and recycler, which had an offering price of $18, closed at $22.25. **********Not all new issues were greeted enthusiastically. Shares of the Tropical Sportswear International Corporation, a men's clothing maker, closed at $12.3125, slightly more than the $12 offering price. American Residential Investment Trust, which invests in adjustable-rate mortgages, closed at $15 a share, unchanged. **********Still, institutional investors seemed ready to buy the new shares. If some deals met more enthusiasm than others, it was a sign that things were back to normal -- as long as some measure of stability returned to the stock markets as a whole. **********A portfolio manager who had just been hammered on a very bad day might shun the market for initial offerings that day, said Cristina Morgan, a managing director for Hambrecht & Quist in San Francisco. **********''But in general, when portfolio managers are making a decision to invest in a particular company,'' she said, ''that is exactly what they are doing. Those decisions are not a referendum on the market as a whole.'' **********At an I.P.O. seminar yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel in Manhattan, the 150 participants seemed not too unnerved by the market's gyrations. Preparation for going public typically takes three to six months, as a start-up's executives work with lawyers and investment bankers and meet with prospective institutional investors. So executives at the seminar said they were not focusing much on market swings. **********''Real volatility in the markets can, of course, delay an I.P.O. for days or even a couple of weeks,'' said Richard Kalenka, a partner at Price Waterhouse, which sponsored the seminar. ''But stock market gyrations should not have any real impact on the growth or financing plans of solid start-ups.'' **********Besides, he said, ''any company that is really desperate for cash from an I.P.O. and can't wait a week or two doesn't have much of a business, and it has problems an I.P.O. isn't going to really solve.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/28/world.snippet: Rescuers on Sumatra work through thick haze from forest fires to dig through wreckage of Indonesian airliner; all 234 people on board were killed when Airbus A-300 crashed in remote terrain near Medan; photo of grieving relatives; map (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/28/world.main_headline: Rescuers Search Indonesian Air Crash Site
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/28/world.print_headline: Rescuers Search Indonesian Air Crash Site
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/28/world.body_text: **********Working in a thick haze from nearby forest fires, rescuers on the island of Sumatra today dug through the debris of an airliner that crashed on Friday in Indonesia's worst air disaster. **********Officials said all 234 people on board, including 12 crew members, were killed when the Airbus A-300 crashed in remote, hilly terrain 30 miles short of the airport at the city of Medan, 900 miles northwest of here. **********The rescuers were shown on television carrying away bodies in black plastic bags or wrapped in sarongs or large banana leaves. Officials said that so far, only 11 bodies had been identified. **********Airline officials said they had not yet recovered the flight data recorder and cockpit voice recorder and did not yet know the cause of the crash or whether choking smoke had contributed to it. **********Sumatra is one of the areas in Indonesia where vast forest fires have been spewing tremendous clouds of smoke into the sky, blanketing much of southern Southeast Asia in what has become a major international disaster. **********Many airports in several countries have been closed because of the haze, which is also darkening the sky and causing respiratory problems among millions of people in Malaysia, Brunei, the Philippines and Thailand. **********On the same day as the Airbus crash, two cargo ships collided in the Strait of Malacca, between Indonesia and Malaysia, where the smoke has severely reduced visibility. Twenty-eight crew members were reported missing. **********The airline, Garuda Indonesia, said it would begin an inquiry into the plane crash. Airbus Industrie, the manufacturer of the aircraft said it would also send investigators. **********The official Antara news agency said the pilot had radioed ahead for landing instructions minutes before the crash and had said the haze was causing poor visibility. **********But officials at Polonia International Airport in Medan said that it was equipped with modern guidance systems and that the aircraft was approaching for what should have been a normal instrument landing. **********Airline officials said visibility at the airport at the time of the crash was 600 yards, which is sufficient for an instrument landing. **********The head of the Garuda Indonesia Communications Forum for Pilots,  Shadrach Nababan, said: ''Haze is an ordinary thing for pilots. There are instruments in the plane and on the ground that can be used.'' **********Witnesses said the aircraft appeared out of the haze, hit the tops of trees and then exploded, though it was not clear whether the explosion came before or after the impact. **********A plane still 20 miles from an airport would normally still be thousands of feet in the air. **********The smoke caused the closure of the airport today, as hundreds of grieving relatives waited here in anguish for a special flight that was scheduled to take them to the crash site. **********Some wept as they examined green paper boarding passes for the names of friends and relatives. **********Antara said that two Americans, six Japanese, four Germans and a Belgian were aboard. There were unconfirmed reports that British and Taiwanese citizens were also aboard. **********Rescuers said the bodies were strewn over a wide area, some of them in trees, some buried in the mud. In many cases, only parts of bodies were recovered. A mass burial was planned for those that could not be identified. **********Garuda, Indonesia's flagship carrier, has been criticized in the past for poor pilot training and poor performance. The airline has had six major crashes since 1982. The total death toll in those crashes is 56. **********Indonesia's worst previous air disaster was in 1992 and did not involve Garuda. In it, 136 people died when an air force Hercules C-130 crashed in a Jakarta suburb.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/03/busin.snippet: First Union Corp says its investment banking unit has received approval from Federal Reserve to begin equity underwriting; regulatory approval is first step in bank's plan to begin providing stock underwriting (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/03/busin.main_headline: A New Market For First Union
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/03/busin.print_headline: A New Market For First Union
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/03/busin.body_text: **********The First Union Corporation said today that its investment banking unit had received approval from the Federal Reserve to begin equity underwriting. **********That unit, the First Union Capital Markets Corporation, started underwriting debt in May 1995. The new authority allows First Union, based here, to expand its high-yield bond business into equity warrants and preferred stock. **********The regulatory approval is the first step in the bank's plan to begin providing stock underwriting. **********Banks have been entering the equity underwriting business to provide a service that banking laws prevented them from offering before and to protect themselves from losing customers to Wall Street investment banks. **********First Union is the ninth commercial bank to receive equity underwriting powers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/23/busin.snippet: Edwin W Rawlings, four-star general who became top executive at General Mills after retiring from Air Force, dies at age of 93 (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/23/busin.main_headline: Edwin W. Rawlings, 93, General And Chairman of Food Company
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/23/busin.print_headline: Edwin W. Rawlings, 93, General And Chairman of Food Company
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/23/busin.body_text: **********Edwin W. Rawlings, a four-star general who became a top executive at General Mills after retiring from the Air Force, died on Dec. 8 in a nursing home in Auburn, Wash. He was 93. **********General Rawlings joined General Mills, which makes cereals, snack foods, yogurt and baking products, as a vice president for finance in 1959. He was named president in 1961, and chairman and chief executive in 1967. While he was president and chief executive, the company sold half its flour mills and an unprofitable electronics unit, while emphasizing name-brand lines like Cheerios, Gold Medal and Betty Crocker. **********General Mills also began buying other companies, acquiring Kenner Products, a toy company, in 1967, and Parker Brothers toys, Gorton's seafood and Monet costume jewelry the following year. General Rawlings retired as chairman and chief executive in 1969, but remained on the board through 1976. General Mills continued its expansion, buying Red Lobster restaurants in 1970, Eddie Bauer clothing in 1971 and Yoplait yogurt in 1977. In the late 1980's and early 1990's, the company moved into European markets, and sold its nonfood businesses. **********General Rawlings graduated from Hamline University in St. Paul in 1927 with a degree in economics and received a master's degree in industrial management in 1939 from the Harvard Business School. He joined the Flying Cadets, a reserve unit in 1929, and received his commission the following year. He stayed in the Army Air Corps, and then the Air Force for 31 years, rising to the rank of Air Force brigadier general in 1945 and four-star general in 1954. **********During World War II, General Rawlings was responsible for supplies and materials to meet aircraft production schedules. General Rawlings brought the armed services into the computer age at the end of World War II, and mirrored this accomplishment in academia when he helped establish the first undergraduate computer literacy program, at Hamline in the late 1960's. **********Starting in 1951, General Rawlings was in charge of buying and maintaining the entire aircraft fleet and its equipment for the Air Force, a position involving thousands of aircraft and billions of dollars annually. **********General Rawlings is survived by four sons, Peter E., of Williamsburg, Va.; Charles F., of Bellevue, Wash.; Richard W., of Minneapolis, and John F., of Seattle; his sister, Marcella Engerbretson of Tracy, Minn., and eight grandchildren. His first wife, Muriel Peterson, died in 1983, and his second wife, Kathryn Fradkin, died in 1990.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/06/busin.body_text: **********Huntington Bancshares, expanding its presence in Michigan, said today that it had agreed to buy the First Michigan Bank Corporation for $908 million. **********First Michigan operates 90 branches exclusively in Michigan. It has $3.6 billion in assets. Huntington, with more than $21 billion in assets, operates in Ohio, Florida, Indiana, Kentucky, Michigan and West Virginia. **********First Michigan's shareholders are to receive 1.05 shares of Huntington's stock for each share they own. https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/23/world.main_headline: A New Day In Congo, But Fingers Stay Sticky
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/23/world.print_headline: A New Day In Congo, But Fingers Stay Sticky
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/23/world.body_text: **********This hilly suburb of Congo's capital, where the breeze blows cool, and the meticulously kept tropical gardens of the wealthy fairly resemble visions of earthly paradise, had not seen such a change since the end of Belgian rule in 1960. **********In the very first days after President Laurent Kabila took power in May, weeks before he could himself move into the luxurious official residence of the deposed dictator, Mobutu Sese Seko, virtually an entire country's elite was in flight, displaced by a swarm of newcomers. **********For weeks, Binza's heights crawled with two kinds of traffic: the armed security forces taking possession of sumptuous villas for the new generals and ministers in charge of this vast country, and the moving trucks carting new property in, and often old valuables out -- most often for quick sale. The only people busier were the locksmiths who were removing old locks and delivering fresh sets of keys to the inheritors of hillside estates. **********But once the grab for property and goods began to extend its fingers down Binza's hillsides into the hot and dusty city of Kinshasa below, where owners of even modest properties were awakened in the night by soldiers with guns who made claims on their belongings, it was not long before the ordinary people of the city were complaining bitterly over the arbitrary powers of the people who claimed to have liberated them. **********This week, Mr. Kabila held a stormy Cabinet meeting in which, Congolese officials say, he repeatedly banged his fist on the table and berated his ministers for their greed. For the record, the next day's newspapers published a laconic communique saying that the President had ''forbidden those in Government to abuse their positions to rob the belongings of others.'' **********But for now, in a land where the equation ''power equals property'' dates at least to King Leopold of Belgium, for whom all of the Congo was a private domain in the 19th century, skepticism over whether Mr. Kabila will be able to instill a new ethic seems far more prevalent than confidence. **********If change is going to come, many here say that there is no better place to start than the Government's Office of Ill-Gotten Goods. The office, set up in the early days of Mr. Kabila's Administration, is a kind of economic police with broad powers to seize, manage or liquidate the assets of the corrupt officials who flourished around Mr. Mobutu during three decades of ruinous rule. **********For the time being, there is no means for anyone to appeal the office's decisions. One senior official said simply: ''We serve as the judicial police and as the judge. Here, there is a presumption of guilt.'' **********But many here have begun to grumble about the office itself, whose fingers reportedly began to grow sticky as soon as it began seizing the properties and businesses of the late dictator and his large circle of collaborators. **********For weeks, Kinshasa's lively newspapers have been filled with reports of shady dealings by the Office of Ill-Gotten Goods, and some senior officials in the agency have been dismissed. **********Working out of a leafy villa in central Kinshasa that was acquired by Mr. Mobutu early in his rule, Jean-Baptiste Mulembe, the 54-year-old director of the agency, spends long days receiving reports from his inspectors and a legion of informers, as well as anguished visits from the freshly dispossessed. **********Still, even with the Government showing its displeasure, Mr. Mulembe, a Mobutu opponent who spent most of his adult life in exile in Europe, revealed little self-doubt about his mission and blamed the press for the appearance of trouble. **********''There are people here who just wish to see the negative in everything this Government does,'' said Mr. Mulembe, his voice hoarse after a day of meetings. ''We are trying to rebuild a ruined state, and are not out for vengeance. After the war, de Gaulle created a special bank from the proceeds of goods seized from Nazi collaborators. **********''What we are doing is much the same, and if people don't appreciate it now, one day they will recognize the service we have rendered to the nation.'' **********Told of the historical parallel Mr. Mulembe drew with postwar France, Isungu ky-Maka, a prosperous private banker, chuckled. He insists that everything he owns he came by honestly but he had several of his properties seized after the Kabila Government took power. **********''These people came in here with the attitude that they are Saint Just and everything they find is corrupt, which gives them the right to do whatever they want with you and your belongings,'' Mr. Isungu said. ''But if they care to talk about history, the Soviets who took over everything in 1917 ended up in total failure. In fact, three years after his expropriations began, even de Gaulle was disavowed.''

Puig, which is based in Barcelona and is one of the fe...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/17/busin.main_headline: Turbulence in the Haute Couture World:Sanofi Sells Nina Ricci to Puig
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/17/busin.print_headline: Turbulence in the Haute Couture World:Sanofi Sells Nina Ricci to Puig
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/17/busin.body_text: **********In yet another shake-up in the world of haute couture, the house of Nina Ricci has been sold by the French pharmaceutical giant Sanofi SA and bought by the Spanish perfume company Puig Group. **********Puig, which is based in Barcelona and is one of the few remaining independent, family-owned fragrance houses on an international level, announced Tuesday that it had taken control of Ricci from its owners, Sanofi and the Fuchs and de Kousmine families. **********Gilles Fuchs is president of Ricci. **********Layoffs among couture workers and decreasing revenue at Ricci — sales fell 5 percent last year, to 1.1 billion French francs ($185.1 million) — had led to persistent rumors that Sanofi, which is controlled by the oil company Elf Aquitaine SA, was putting the unprofitable 65-year-old couture house on the block, although sources in Paris say this year's figures are encouraging. **********Puig, which had revenue of $500 million in 1996, declined to say how much it had paid for Ricci, but Mariano Puig Jr., grandson of the founder and chief executive of Paco Rabanne Paris, described it as a "fair price." **********Ricci will now be directly associated with Paco Rabanne, one of Puig's success stories. **********The Spanish parent has steered sales of the French couturier's fragrances to projected 1997 revenue of 520 million francs. **********Rabanne has taken a one-third stake in Ricci, with other Puig companies making up the rest. **********The sale underlines the reality of the modern couture business: that it is essentially about perfume, not clothing, and that only clearly focused, specialist companies with big bucks to spend can compete in the luxury business. **********Ricci's cash cow is L'Air du Temps, one of the world's perennial top 10 fragrances, which is celebrating its 50th anniversary this year. **********Once the sale of Ricci is concluded Jan. 8, Sanofi will have left in its beauty stable only one big star: Yves Saint Laurent Parfums, which had sales of 2.49 billion French francs in 1996. **********Sanofi's minor brands are the perfumes of Fendi, Krizia, Oscar de la Renta, Roger & Gallet and Van Cleef & Arpels. **********In spite of the fact that Sanofi has reported good third-quarter results for 1997, with beauty sales up 6 percent in the first nine months over the previous year, industry sources say that in the long term, Sanofi is likely to concentrate on its health-care sector. **********Industry sources say the company might get out of fragrances altogether after its contract with Yves Saint Laurent and his partner, Pierre Berge, expires in 2002. **********Puig, by contrast, which has the delicate touch needed for dealing with designer divas and changing fashions, is looking to expand its upscale sector, which includes the fragrances of the American designer Carolina Herrera. **********Although it has a mass business in soap, toiletries, personal hygiene and beauty products, it holds the No.1 fragrance position in Spain with 20 percent of the market, and it called Ricci a growth opportunity. **********"We see growth," Mr. Puig said. "but at our own pace. We don't belong to a big organization, and we have the time and the will to go for the medium and long-term and to find the potential of the brand." **********Mr. Puig is one of the third generation of a company that has been managed by the four sons of Antonio Puig, who died in 1979.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/28/busin.snippet: Advertising column describes three new advertising campaigns from cruise line industry, sponsored by Norwegian Cruise Lines, Royal Caribbean International and Cruise Lines Industry Assn (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/28/busin.main_headline: Down to the sea in marketing: three big new campaigns for the cruise line industry.
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/28/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; Down to the sea in marketing: three big new campaigns for the cruise line industry.
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/28/busin.body_text: **********CRUISE line advertising is still a long way from reaching saturation levels, but it has been growing steadily for several years and shows every sign of continuing to set records. **********Early this month, for example, the Cruise Lines Industry Association, a trade group, began an $8 million yearlong campaign called ''You haven't lived until you cruise.'' Norwegian Cruise Lines recently rolled out an ad campaign primarily aimed at travel agents that will cost nearly $1 million this quarter. (It will follow up with a national consumer ad campaign in January.) And Royal Caribbean International is spending $5 million for sole sponsorship of the halftime show during the Super Bowl, to be held in San Diego on Jan. 25. **********The Royal Caribbean ads will be aimed in large part at extolling the pleasures of cruising on any of Royal Caribbean's 12 ships or on any of the 5 ships of Celebrity Cruises, which Royal Caribbean acquired last summer. **********''The challenge is to be seen as a global provider of vacation options, not just these two little cruise lines in Miami,'' said Mark Kammerer, director of marketing for Royal Caribbean. ''Next year, our joint revenues will exceed $1.5 billion.'' **********The ads for Royal Caribbean are being created by McKinney & Silver, a unit of the CKS Group in Raleigh, N.C. Celebrity is handled by Harris Drury Cohen, an agency in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., that is also working on the Cruise Lines Industry Association campaign. **********Discounting concerns that the price it paid for the Super Bowl sponsorship is akin to putting all of Royal Caribbean's advertising eggs in one basket, Art Sbarsky, Celebrity's senior vice president of marketing, said that at least 85 percent of the millions who watch the halftime show on television have never gone on a cruise. **********Expanding on Mr. Kammerer's theme, Mr. Sbarsky said: ''If we were just a cruise line, our sponsorship wouldn't make economic sense. But we're a huge vacation company.'' Seeing a backdrop of Super Bowl spectators basking in the San Diego sun in midwinter, he said, is likely to make those millions of television viewers think about vacations.  If the ads do their job, that will translate into cruise vacations with Royal Caribbean or Celebrity. **********Sponsorship of the San Diego Super Bowl provides another benefit to Royal Caribbean. ''The following year the Super Bowl will be played in Miami, our backyard, '' Mr. Kammerer said, ''and we have the option for that halftime show.' **********The previous campaign for Norwegian Cruise Lines -- ''It's different out here'' -- created by the Omnicom Group's Goodby, Silverstein & Partners in San Francisco, won awards from the advertising industry. But the ads raised eyebrows in the cruise industry for their sensual imagery, and drew criticism from Bob Dickinson, the president of Carnival  Cruises, the industry giant. Ads that emphasize glamour rather than value, he said, ''send messages that 'I need a $50,000 wardrobe' or that 'I need my breasts augmented or my teeth capped' to go on this cruise line or that.'' **********Norwegian's new ads take a much different tack. **********Created by Young & Rubicam Chicago, which won the account three months ago, the ads in the trade press are intended both to build the Norwegian Cruise Line brand and to differentiate it from other cruise lines and land-based vacations. Its general theme, the ''Norwegian Way,'' highlights the tradition of Norwegian seafaring excellence. **********Thus one ad, with an Old World globe adorned by wooden Viking ships, asks: ''O.K., so Norwegians discovered all the world's sea routes.  But what have they done for you lately?'' The facing page says: ''New routes. New ports. New itineraries.'' **********Another ad shows a partly opened can of sardines on one page, dancing and dining passengers on the other page. ''Ask any Norwegian,'' the headline says. ''It's not the size of the vessel. It's the space per passenger.'' **********A plaque depicted in another ad, obviously aimed at the spate of megaships that cruise lines have added recently, describes the Norwegian Way thus: ''We believe a ship should be a ship, not a floating mall. Authentic, romantic, civilized. Long on choices, not on lines.'' **********It should be noted, however, that the cruise line's Norway, at 1,035 feet, remains the longest cruise ship afloat. But Nina Cohen, vice president of marketing for Norwegian Cruise Lines, said what other Norway loyalists maintain -- that the classic lines and generous amounts of wood used in construction of the ship (which was built in 1960 as the S.S. France) give it an unexpected intimacy. **********Beyond that, she noted that while the company has been Norwegian since it began, ''The Norwegianness has never been used as a raison d'etre.'' **********''In fact,'' she continued, ''we called ourselves N.C.L. Now we're breaking out.'' The company is doing so not just in its ads, but by changing the name of three ships: the Seaward, to Norwegian Sea; Dreamward, to Norwegian Dream, and Windward, to Norwegian Wind. **********''The ads are whimsical, tongue in cheek and relevant,'' Ms. Cohen added. ''How can you not love them?''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/03/busin.snippet: Competition between television broadcasters and wireless communications services gives rise to new sub-industry of radio tower companies; they are vying to tie together far-flung clusters of local transmission antennas into national webs that will...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/03/busin.body_text: **********The competition between television broadcasters and wireless communication services is giving rise to a new sub-industry of tower companies. They are vying to tie together far-flung clusters of local transmission antennas into national webs that will bring next-generation technology to customers. **********Stunning growth projections for wireless services are drawing big-name investors to this infant industry. With outside investment capital nurturing their national ambitions, these little-known tower companies have been transforming themselves over the last two years into integrated operators that can offer wireless carriers an array of services from finding new sites to building towers to leasing antenna space on underused radio towers. **********''It came from nowhere,'' said Brian G. Coleman, a wireless communication analyst for BT Alex. Brown in San Francisco. **********Among the dominant players in the antenna business are American Tower Systems of Boston; Omni America Wireless L.P. of West Palm Beach, Fla.; Telecom Towers Inc. of Alexandria, Va., and the Castle Tower Corporation and the American Tower Corporation, both based in Houston. **********Demand for transmission towers and antennas is soaring. Driving the demand is the expected shift by the nation's 1,500 television stations to high-definition television and new Federal regulations that allow a handful of wireless services to compete in a single market. So far, just 3 percent of telecommunications traffic is over the current wireless network, most of that cellular phone conversations. But that is expected to change. Already, some of the new wireless services, called personal communications services or P.C.S., are operating, carrying not only phone chatter but Internet data and paging signals. **********The tower companies expect a near-term flurry of activity from broadcasters retrofitting or replacing their existing towers, so-called ''candelabras'' that can support a small cluster of television or radio antennas. A tall tower can be 2,000 feet and cost, on average, $3 million. Even more capital is needed to meet demand from wireless services, whose tiny 2.2 million subscriber base is supposed to increase to 54.3 million in a decade, according to Paul Kagan Associates Inc., a media research firm in Carmel, Calif. **********That sort of consumer acceptance would require adding 80,000 P.C.S. antennas to the 20,000 already built over the last 15 years for cellular customers. P.C.S. antennas, at about $200,00 each, have a range of one to six miles and need to be only 200 feet in the air. By contrast, cellular antennas now are 6 to 12 miles apart. **********But the growing demand for antennas coincides with growing opposition to them for esthetic and health reasons. An increasing number of municipalities have been imposing moratoriums on tower construction, even though part of the Telecommunications Act of 1996 prohibits banning towers but does not address moratoriums. Tower companies are resorting to such costly ''stealth'' solutions as embedding antennas in clock towers, cemetery crosses and palm trees. Others are striking roof-top management deals, luring owners with the promise that every multistory building will become a revenue-producing cell site. **********Given the zoning hurdles, companies with existing towers are likely to prosper first. ''Most wireless carriers would like to go out and lease 40 towers in a region rather than contacting 40 different landowners,'' Mr. Coleman said. **********Anthony S. Ocepek, chief operating officer of Omni America, said, ''Our goal is to be in all phases of the business.'' The company is being backed by $100 million from Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst Inc., a Dallas investment firm with interests in radio and television stations. **********After four years of trying, construction is about to start on Omni America's first 1,220-foot tower. It will provide digital television signals for Milwaukee's two public broadcasting stations. When completed in 1999, the $7 million tower will be able to support 12 television stations, 14 FM radio stations and 35 wireless services. But it will not fill up for about eight years, Mr. Ocepek said. **********''We think of it as vertical real estate, a vertical shopping mall,'' said Carl E. Hirsch, chief executive of Omni America, which also owns towers in Florida and Ohio. Last month, Omni America acquired a one-third interest in the Kline Iron and Steel Company in Columbia, S.C., one of the few companies that build tall towers. Mr. Hirsch learned firsthand the value of a well-sited tower as chief executive of a company that owned KJOY-FM in Los Angeles in 1985. **********''The hidden jewel was the tower site,'' Mr. Hirsch said. The region's coastal foothills create dead zones for cellular customers. As a result, KJOY's 150-foot tower in the Santa Monica Mountains near Beverly Hills became a prized relay point for cable and cellular providers. ''That turned out to be a bonanza,'' Mr. Hirsch said. Tower revenue rose from $400,000 annually to $2 million before the station was sold in 1989. ''We want to take advantage of inherited sites that are underutilized,'' he said. **********This is a tall order, considering that Omni America's sister companies own 8 television stations and more than 400 radio stations. **********In just the last two years, American Tower Systems, a unit of the American Radio Systems Corporation of Boston, has cobbled together 920 antennas in more than a dozen deals that together cost $316 million. The tower company is to be spun off next year to shareholders of American Radio, which was sold to the Westinghouse Broadcasting Corporation in September. The tower company's pro forma cash flow is expected to be $20 million this year and $35 million next year. **********''If as a company, we can construct 30 big towers a year and generate a 25 to 30 percent return on our investment, that's a secure income stream,'' said Steve Dodge, the chairman and chief executive of American Radio, who will hold the same positions with the spun-off company. **********''You don't have to deal with personalities, unions,'' he said. ''Broadcasting is emotional; its management intensive. By comparison, towers are deaf, dumb and mute. **********There are risks, though, like cash-short customers and the unexpected. For example, General Wireless Inc. filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection last week, unable to pay for the P.C.S. licenses it won in Government auctions. And earlier in the month, a new 2,000-foot tower under construction in Mississippi toppled, sending three employees of Le Blanc Communications Inc. of Canada to their deaths. **********But finding potential investors to help bankroll acquisitions is no problem for tower companies. Telecom Towers, which owns or manages 3,000 sites, has teamed up with Cox Communications Inc. Castle Tower, which bought the British Broadcasting Corporation's transmission sites and has another 3,000 in the United State, is backed by two private investment companies. The American Tower Corporation, which owns and operates 600 towers, was considering a public offering until it found an equity partner in Clear Channel Communications Inc., a broadcaster. **********Mr. Dodge, who will receive $103 million in stock and options when American Tower Systems is spun off, wants to rein in expectations for what is quickly becoming the darling of investors. ''The financial community is impatient to play this industry,'' he said. ''People view it as a way to play the explosive growth in wireless.'' **********He cautioned, ''This is a young business.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/01/busin.main_headline: Japanese Phone Giant Buys a U.S. Stake
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/01/busin.print_headline: Japanese Phone Giant Buys a U.S. Stake
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/01/busin.body_text: **********Making its first significant push into the American telecommunications market, the Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to pay $100 million for a minority stake in Teligent Inc., a small wireless communications company. **********N.T.T., based in Tokyo, is one of the world's largest telecommunications companies with annual revenue of roughly $71 billion. But unlike other foreign phone giants, including British Telecommunications P.L.C., Deutsche Telekom and France Telecom, N.T.T. has maintained low visibility in the United States. **********By acquiring 12.5 percent of Teligent, N.T.T. is making a small but potentially lucrative bet that some American companies seeking integrated voice, data and video communications will choose a relatively untested wireless technology over fiber optic cable, the prevailing delivery system. **********Teligent is aiming to take customers from the regional Bell companies by offering advanced communications services directly to buildings without wires. Within three years, it hopes to offer service in 74 metropolitan markets in 34 states. **********As it has tried to establish its credibility, Teligent's greatest asset has perhaps been the strong reputation of its chairman, Alex J. Mandl, a former No. 2 executive at the AT&T Corporation. The company can now also count on technical assistance from one of Japan's leading research and development laboratories. **********''N.T.T.'s decision to invest $100 million in Teligent strengthens our effort to increase competition in local telephone markets,'' Mr. Mandl said in a statement yesterday. ''By offering high-quality, high-capacity, facilities-based communications services to small and medium-sized businesses in the United States, Teligent will help fulfill the promise of the Telecommunications Act of 1996.'' The law was meant to foster competition in local phone markets. **********Akihiko Okada, a spokesman for the United States subsidiary, NTT America Inc., commented: ''Wireless local loop providers like Teligent are very interesting and attractive for N.T.T. The headquarters is very interested in the local access opportunities.'' **********Teligent was not the only local telephone company attracting attention yesterday. The Wall Street Journal reported that Worldcom, the fourth-largest long-distance carrier, was planning to acquire Brooks Fiber Properties, a small, independent local phone company. **********Both companies refused to comment, and the shares of both ended lower in trading yesterday. Worldcom declined $1.1875, closing on the Nasdaq market at $35.375; Brooks Fiber closed at $46.6875, down 18.75 cents, also on Nasdaq. **********Teligent is a private company owned mostly by the Associated Group Inc. and a unit of Telcom Ventures, an investment fund. Those investors announced that they would put an additional $60 million into the company. **********Teligent plans to offer about 10 percent of its stock, worth about $100 million, to the public by the end of the year. That offering, along with stock options for Mr. Mandl and other executives, is expected to dilute N.T.T.'s stake in the company to roughly 10 percent. **********Teligent also plans to issue about $250 million of high-yield debt and secure bank loans of about the same amount by the end of the year. **********In 1994 N.T.T. invested $75 million in Nextel Communications, a mobile wireless company. That stake is now worth less than 1 percent of Nextel. **********Since then, British Telecom has agreed to acquire MCI Communications, and France Telecom and Deutsche Telekom have debated enlarging their 10 percent stakes in the Sprint Corporation. **********''Traditionally, N.T.T. really hasn't made that many investments in developing countries or developed countries,'' said Ayesha Ahmad, an analyst at Pyramid Research, a telecommunications consulting firm in Cambridge, Mass. ''Now, maybe they are becoming more aggressive.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/22/world.snippet: Cambodia's rival Prime Ministers, Prince Norodom Ranariddh and Hun Sen, appearing together to mark what they say is important moment, announce that Khmer Rouge leader, Pol Pot, had been captured and that they will ask United Nations to help put hi...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/22/world.main_headline: Cambodian Rivals Say They Will Bring Pol Pot to Justice
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/22/world.print_headline: Cambodian Rivals Say They Will Bring Pol Pot to Justice
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/22/world.body_text: **********Appearing together to mark what they said was an important moment, Cambodia's rival Prime Ministers announced today that the Khmer Rouge leader, Pol Pot, had been captured and that they would ask the United Nations to help put him on trial. **********''The two Prime Ministers will be writing a letter to the Secretary General of the United Nations asking to set up an international tribunal,'' said First Prime Minister Norodom Ranariddh, as Second Prime Minister Hun Sen stood nearby. **********After a week of confusing reports about violent conflict among the Khmer Rouge leadership, the leaders' announcement was given added weight by the presence here on an official visit of Prime Minister Chawalit Yongchaiyut of Thailand, a country that has maintained close underground contacts with the Khmer Rouge for years. **********''I find it all very plausible,'' said Steven Heder, a lecturer at the University of London who has studied the Khmer Rouge. ''There may be elements of this that are a political game, but in its broad outlines I don't think it's a game.'' **********Mr. Hun Sen's presence also added credibility. It helped defuse suspicions that the report, like earlier ones, might be part of an attempt by the Prince to gain leverage in a rivalry with his co-Prime Minister. **********If Pol Pot has indeed been captured, the event marks a step toward closure in one of the most tragic episodes of the century. From 1975 to 1979, he led a fanatic Maoist movement that turned on its own population in a bloodletting that took at least a million lives. **********And if Pol Pot, 69 and reportedly ill, was indeed put on trial, the proceedings would emphasize the long reach of justice, across the 18 years in which he has lurked in the jungles pursuing his war. **********The announcement today followed a week of self-contradictory reports from Prince Ranariddh and his aides that had been met with growing skepticism here in the absence of independent evidence. **********The Prince had reported that the Khmer Rouge leadership had split in a violent confrontation and that Pol Pot was fleeing, pursued by guerrillas who had turned against him. **********The only support for his account came from clandestine broadcasts on Khmer Rouge radio, which reported Pol Pot's capture Friday for the second time in a week. **********Although much skepticism remained, particularly among Cambodians who deeply mistrust the Khmer Rouge, most experts said today that they were leaning toward believing the announcement. **********Still, it did not appear that Pol Pot was in the custody of the Cambodian Government. He was apparently being held by Khmer Rouge soldiers who have turned against him and have been in negotiations with Prince Ranariddh. Many Khmer Rouge troops and their commanders have defected to the Government over the last year. **********The Prince said Pol Pot was in Anlong Veng, the Khmer Rouge stronghold north of Phnom Penh. **********''Eventually,'' he said, ''with the agreement of Hun Sen, maybe we will, maybe, I think, one day to bring you to see him.'' **********If Pol Pot is in the hands of other Khmer Rouge fighters in Anlong Veng, it is not clear what might happen next. Where would he be taken, how would his security be assured and what would be done with him in the many months it might take to organize an international tribunal? **********And despite their statements today, do the two Cambodian leaders really wish to see a tribunal proceed? Mr. Hun Sen is a former Khmer Rouge member, Prince Ranariddh is a former battlefield ally of the Khmer Rouge and his father, King Norodom Sihanouk, was once its figurehead leader. **********But the capture of Pol Pot would be a crucial event in Cambodian history, and events are already showing a momentum of their own. **********Mr. Hun Sen, who as recently as Friday disparaged Prince Ranariddh's reports, stood beside his rival this morning and for the first time endorsed his words. **********''I have expressed my views in the past,'' he said, ''but this morning I have been briefed by the Prince that Pol Pot and Khieu Samphan have already been arrested.'' Mr. Khieu Samphan is the nominal leader of the Khmer Rouge. **********''The next step, I think,'' Mr. Hun Sen added, ''would be for Prince Ranariddh and myself to send a letter to His Excellency the Secretary General of the United Nations to bring those people to an international court of justice.'' **********Mr. Khieu Samphan's status now is unclear. For days, the Prince has been describing him as a ''hostage'' of Pol Pot in his flight through the jungle. But today the Prince said both men should face trial. **********The odd report that Pol Pot had taken hostage several of his top lieutenants after killing his former Defense Minister, Son Sen, had added to suspicions here that an elaborate charade was being played out. **********But Mr. Heder said such a scenario would be ''totally at variance'' with a pattern of behavior the Khmer Rouge have followed for decades. **********''They don't call people traitors who are not traitors,'' he said. ''They don't announce they have arrested people who are not arrested. This is not to suggest that they are angels; just to suggest that they operate along a certain fairly standard, well-known script and that they know no other way of operating.'' **********Since its formation in the 1960's, the Khmer Rouge has cast a long shadow. Even after it was driven back by a Vietnamese invasion in 1979, the continuing presence of Pol Pot has hindered Cambodia's recovery from its trauma. **********Prince Ranariddh told reporters: ''I believe that this capture and arrest of Pol Pot, we can consider that it is the end of the Khmer Rouge movement as a political movement and a military movement. **********''Pol Pot is a criminal, a criminal against humanity. But I have to say that we have to provide a fair trial.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/08/world.main_headline: France Charges 6 Libyans With '89 Sahara Jet Bombing
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/08/world.print_headline: France Charges 6 Libyans With '89 Sahara Jet Bombing
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/08/world.body_text: **********French anti-terrorism investigators said today that they had asked a court to try the brother-in-law of Libya's leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, and five other Libyan operatives in absentia next year on charges of blowing up a French airliner and killing 171 people over the Sahara in 1989. **********The principal investigating magistrate in the case, Jean-Louis Bruguiere, previously accused Abdallah Senoussi -- Colonel Qaddafi's brother-in-law and the former No. 2 Libyan secret service official -- and three other Libyan agents of blowing up a DC-10 airliner of the now-defunct airline UTA. **********French investigators said they believed that Mr. Senoussi had ordered the strike to retaliate against France for using its troops to resist a Libyan invasion of Chad. **********Judge Bruguiere's final report asked prosecutors to try Mr. Senoussi, two of the three other men who were charged earlier and two additional Libyan intelligence officials on the evidence he has gathered against them, officials said. **********That evidence includes confidential documents dating from a year before the bombing instructing Libyan agents to plan a strike against France, investigators said, and testimony from a Congolese witness who told them that Libyan operatives had paid a friend of the Congolese to check onto flight UT-772 from Brazzaville to Paris with a Samsonite suitcase containing a bomb. **********The bomb carrier was supposed to get off at an intermediate stop but was not allowed to do so and died with the rest of the passengers when the plane exploded high over Niger en route to France. **********In debris scattered over hundreds of square miles of desert, French investigators found a fragment of Samsonite bearing traces of pentrite explosive, they said, and determined that it had been placed aboard the plane in Brazzaville, Congo. **********By 1992 Judge Bruguiere had pinpointed Libya's secret services as his main suspects, but his efforts to go to Libya to investigate were rebuffed by the Libyan authorities. **********Last July, Colonel Qaddafi finally allowed the judge to spend more than two weeks in Libya interrogating members of Libyan intelligence services. He returned with a Samsonite suitcase, containing more than three pounds of pentrite explosive and a detonator. French officials say the device was identical to the one that blew up the DC-10. **********Perhaps as quid pro quo, French investigators have said they have no evidence that Colonel Qaddafi personally ordered the airplane bombing, and have not accused him. Nor have they charged Moussa Koussa, the Libyan Deputy Foreign Minister who was named in an earlier preliminary indictment in 1991. **********British and American investigators have also accused Libya of planting the bomb that blew up Pan American Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland in 1988, killing 270 people.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/11/world.snippet: Protestant Orange Order, in concession intended to prevent renewed sectarian violence in Northern Ireland, says that it will not hold parades through areas where Roman Catholic residents have threatened to block them (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/11/world.main_headline: Protestants in Ulster Call Off Parades in Catholic Areas
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/11/world.print_headline: Protestants in Ulster Call Off Parades in Catholic Areas
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/11/world.body_text: **********In a concession intended to prevent renewed sectarian violence in Northern Ireland this weekend, the Protestant Orange Order said today that it would not hold parades through areas where Roman Catholic residents have threatened to block them. **********The Orange Order, an all-male Protestant organization considered anti-Catholic by many of the Catholic minority in the Protestant-dominated Ulster, said its units would not march through potentially volatile areas on Saturday. **********The Saturday parades were planned to celebrate the victory of the Protestant forces of William of Orange over his Catholic father-in-law, King James II, at the Battle of the Boyne on July 12, 1690. The victory established the Protestant domination of Britain and Northern Ireland. **********Many Catholics find the parades triumphalist and insulting; Protestants say they have the right of public assembly in a democratic country. **********Catholics in Belfast, the provincial capital, and in Londonderry, Newry and Armagh, all of which have Catholic majorities, had threatened to use force to block the parades, in which the Orangemen march in black suits with orange sashes and bowler hats, usually to the beat of huge drums and blaring martial music. **********The parades, once enjoyed by both Protestants and Catholics, have become politicized by Protestant leaders and those of Sinn Fein, the political wing of the Irish Republican Army, as the two sides maneuver for position in the formal peace effort in the province. **********In its statement, the Orange Order said it would not march through volatile areas this year, but reserved the right to do so in the future. **********''This action,'' the statement said, ''has been taken to avoid the enemies of our Protestant heritage being given the opportunity to create a situation resulting in major civil disorder with a possible loss of life.'' **********Tonight Gerry Adams, the Sinn Fein president, said of the Orange statement, ''I welcome this decision; I wish it had been made sooner.'' **********In Dublin, the Irish Prime Minister, Bertie Ahern, said that the decision was a ''very positive gesture'' and that he hoped Catholic leaders would respond in kind. **********Sir John Alderdice, head of the Alliance Party, a 60-40 mix of Protesants and Catholics, said the decision required courage. ''A profound sigh of relief will go across every responsible voice in Northern Ireland,''he said. **********There was no immediate reaction from the Catholic community groups opposed to the parades. Generally, the groups are led by men who have close ties to Sinn Fein and, in two cases, by former I.R.A. men who have served time in British prisons for terrorist crimes. Normally, they alter their tactics to reflect Mr. Adams's attitude. **********Last Sunday a Protestant parade through a Catholic area of Portatown, southwest of Belfast, provoked three days of violent Catholic protest throughout the province. Dozens of police officers and civilians were injured; trains, buses and private cars were hijacked and burned; Catholic demonstrators threw hundreds of flaming bottles of gasoline at the police, who responded by firing heavy plastic bullets. Property damage was estimated at $30 million. **********Catholics attributed the rioting to the British Government's decision to permit the Portadown parade; they rejected the reasoning of the head of the Royal Ulster Constabulary, Ronnie Flanagan, who said the permit was intended to save lives. Mr. Flanagan implied that many Catholics would have been endangered by Protestant attacks if he had canceled the parade. **********Britain's Secretary for Northern Ireland, Mo Mowlam, declined to cancel the parade and supported Mr. Flanagan, and was villified by local Catholic community leaders. **********Catholics who live along Lower Ormeau Road, in the south of Belfast, had been particularly adamant that ''no orange feet'' would march past their houses this Saturday. The residents recalled that at the parade five years ago, passing Orangemen taunted them by holding up five fingers as a reminder that Protestant paramilitaries had once murdered five Catholics, not during a parade, but at the Sean Graham bookmaking office, which is a few yards from the route. **********Last year, security forces imposed a virtual curfew on the area until the parade passed, without serious incident.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/19/world.snippet: Senate Foreign Relations Committee chairman Sen Jesse Helms, in letter to Sec of State Madeleine K Albright, tentatively supports expansion of NATO; says he will help lead fight for ratification of plan if Clinton Administration addresses serious ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/19/world.main_headline: Helms Offers Deal to Back Bigger NATO
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/19/world.print_headline: Helms Offers Deal to Back Bigger NATO
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/19/world.body_text: **********Senator Jesse Helms, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, gave his tentative support today for the expansion of NATO, saying he would help lead the fight for ratification of the plan if the Clinton Administration addresses a series of ''serious concerns.'' **********It was the most definitive statement on NATO, to date, from Mr. Helms, whose support is crucial to President Clinton's effort to bring three former adversaries -- Poland, the Czech Republic and Hungary -- into the military alliance in time for its 50th anniversary in 1999. **********Mr. Helms made his offer in a letter to Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright on Wednesday. **********''I have arrived at my decision to support NATO enlargement based on my belief that this is a worthwhile endeavor,'' Mr. Helms wrote. ''However, my support must remain conditioned upon our ability to work together to include proper safeguards that ensure enactment of an amended treaty is in our nation's best interests.'' The amendment he was referring to would change the original North Atlantic treaty, signed in 1949, to admit the new members. **********Mr. Helms said he intended to hold hearings in the coming weeks on the proposed enlargement of NATO, and he invited Ms. Albright to the first of those hearings, scheduled for Oct. 7. **********''It is my hope and expectation that, if we work together, the hearing process will build sufficient support in the Senate for approval,'' he said. **********Pushed by President Clinton and other Western leaders, NATO extended invitations in July for Poland, the Czech Republic and Hungary to join the 16-member alliance by 1999. **********In the United States, the Senate must ratify changes to the treaty governing NATO. Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the majority leader, has endorsed the idea. Mr. Helms was the last major political hurdle. **********On July 9, a day after the invitations were extended, Mr. Helms listed 10 steps he said he wanted the Administration to take, points he reiterated in his letter to Ms. Albright. **********''The Administration must outline a clear, strategic, military rationale for NATO enlargement that identifies the threats the alliance may face in the coming century and why an enlarged NATO is necessary to counter those threats,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/31/world.snippet: Ignoring order by Sierra Leone's new military authorities closing all borders, US Marines land in capital of Freetown and evacuate hundreds of foreigners fleeing looting and violence that followed armed coup; map (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/31/world.body_text: **********Ignoring an order by Sierra Leone's new military authorities closing all borders, United States Marines landed today in Freetown, the country's capital, and evacuated hundreds of foreigners fleeing looting and violence that followed an armed coup on Sunday. **********The marines began the operation before dawn, flying helicopters from the Kearsarge, an American warship anchored 12 miles offshore. They assembled at a seaside hotel in Freetown at which hundreds of Americans and other foreigners had been told to gather to await evacuation from the country. **********By early evening, when the operation was halted for the day, about 900 people, including 330 Americans, had been flown to the safety of the Kearsarge, and the United States Embassy was closed. The State Department had estimated that 350 Americans were in the country. **********Britain, Sierra Leone's former colonial power, flew 400 Britons and others out of the country on Thursday. Radio reports from Freetown said that the Sierra Leone Army, which mounted the coup on Sunday, made no attempt to interfere with the evacuations. **********Tension has remained high in Freetown since the coup, which was mounted by junior army officers. According to local press reports, at least 100 people were killed in the coup and its aftermath, and for several days Freetown was overrun with roving bands of soldiers who looted much of the city. **********A foreign ministers' gathering of the Organization of African Unity in Harare, Zimbabwe, today unanimously condemned the overthrow of Mr. Kabbah, Sierra Leone's first democratically elected leader, and called on the country's neighbors to ''take all necessary measures to make life impossible for the new regime.'' **********On Wednesday, Nigeria, the region's military powerhouse, dispatched about 900 heavily armed soldiers to Sierra Leone to join the 700 already posted there as part of a defense treaty between the two countries. There were unconfirmed reports today that Ghana and Guinea have also committed troops to a regional intervention to restore Mr. Kabbah. **********Nigeria's Foreign Minister, Tom Ikimi, told the BBC that his country's responsibility was to ''insure peace, security and the return of legitimate government to Sierra Leone.'' **********Since their arrival, the Nigerian troops have taken up positions at Freetown's international airport, and at other strategic sites in the city. So far, they have made no hostile move toward the new military rulers, who are led by Johnny Paul Koromah, a 33-year-old major. **********Western diplomats said today that Nigeria had urged Major Koromah to surrender power, but added that they had not been informed of the measures Nigeria intended to take if he should fail to do so. One diplomat said, however, that there was a growing feeling that Nigeria had decided to intervene once the Western evacuations had been completed. **********Major Koromah has sought to counter his isolation by joining forces with the Revolutionary United Front, a rebel movement that launched a disastrous civil war in Sierra Leone in 1991. **********The head of the rebel group, Foday Sankoh, an eccentric leader whose rhetoric marries Maoism and West African mysticism, has told his fighters to come to the army's aid. In recent days, hundreds of rebel fighters have been seen streaming into the capital to join the Government forces, their erstwhile enemies. **********Mr. Kabbah's deposed Government is being defended by hundreds of traditional hunters known as Kamajors, who have threatened to march on the capital in support of the elected President, now in exile in neighboring Guinea. **********''There are all the makings of a very explosive situation there,'' said one Western diplomat. ''They have already taken a big hit with the looting, but the quicker this gets sorted out, the less damage this country will have to endure.''
