https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/14/busin.main_headline: ITT Plans More Reductions In Corporate Work Force
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/14/busin.print_headline: ITT Plans More Reductions In Corporate Work Force
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/14/busin.body_text: **********Facing a crucial shareholder vote next month, the ITT Corporation announced another round of cost cuts yesterday, a move analysts said could help in its fight to avoid a takeover by the Hilton Hotels Corporation. **********The moves that ITT described -- combining headquarters for its corporate, gaming and Sheraton hotel operations and eliminating 86 positions from its headquarters staff -- will result in pretax savings of about $55 million a year, ITT said, and will generate a charge against fourth-quarter earnings. ITT did not give an amount for the planned charge. **********ITT, which faces an $11.5 billion offer from Hilton, said that the cuts were part of its plan to split itself into three companies and buy back $2.1 billion in stock and $2 billion in debt. The anticipated savings come in addition to $25 million in savings ITT said it would realize in April, when it cut 125 positions from its headquarters staff in Manhattan. **********The new headquarters staff will consist of about 80 people, ITT said, down from 323 in April. ITT said it would move from its current headquarters at 1133 Avenue of the Americas, at West 54th Street, to either the Sheraton Hotel Complex in Manhattan; offices in the New York suburbs of Westchester County, N.Y., or Fairfield County, Conn., or to Sheraton's offices in Boston. **********In a statement, Rand V. Araskog, ITT's chairman and chief executive, said that the latest round of cost cuts would go into effect once the breakup of ITT had been achieved. **********Earlier this month, a Federal judge in Nevada ruled that ITT, which has not held a shareholders meeting since May 1996, could not unilaterally enact a breakup without shareholder approval. **********''We now see no reason to wait,'' in announcing the cost savings, Mr. Araskog said. ''We are committed to serving the best interests of our sharheolders and we are evaluating the best way to return this incremental value to them.'' **********Analysts said that the move could help ITT raise its share buyback offer from $70 as a way of winning shareholder approval. ''The expense reduction gives them more cash flow, which means they can increase their offer,'' said Jason Ader, an analyst at Bear, Stearns & Company. **********The announcement is also part of a campaign to win the support of shareholders, who will vote on Nov. 12 on the merits of the competing plans. ''From now until the meeting, Hilton and ITT will both be putting their best foot forward with the hope of winning over shareholders,'' Mr. Ader said. ''This is just like a political campaign.'' **********Marc A. Grossman, a spokesman for Hilton, said ''whatever amount ITT tacks on to their cash tender offer only decreases the value from something else'' in the company. **********''The point of the transaction we are proposing is about growth, about creating the kind of value for shareholders you can get by combining these two companies and coming up with the world's greatest gaming and hotel company,'' he added.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/26/busin.snippet: Profile of Dr Thomas F Frist Jr, new chmn of Columbia/HCA Healthcare (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/26/busin.main_headline: A Gentler Hand at Columbia's Helm
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/26/busin.print_headline: A Gentler Hand at Columbia's Helm
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/26/busin.body_text: **********In Thomas F. Frist Jr., Columbia/HCA Healthcare has the friendlier face it needs to reassure investors and perhaps strike a deal with Federal investigators. **********Dr. Frist agreed to sell his Hospital Corporation of America to Richard L. Scott's company in 1993, seeing in Mr. Scott an aggressive manager better able to run the world's largest hospital chain. But as Federal investigators swarmed and allegations of wrongdoing multiplied, Dr. Frist questioned whether Mr. Scott had gone several steps too far. **********''At any institution, there is a time for a different style to take it to the next level,'' Dr. Frist said yesterday, later adding, ''There is a trust level that is not there.'' **********Although Dr. Frist had offered some incentives for doctors to send their patients his way, he stopped short of Columbia/HCA's practice of making them investors in his hospitals. He is now scrapping this policy at Columbia/HCA. **********And if the Hospital Corporation of America faced its share of challenges and lawsuits from aggrieved competitors and doctors, it was never confronted by Federal investigations of the nature facing Columbia/HCA. **********Mr. Scott wears his intensity on his sleeve. Dr. Frist, whose brother, Bill, is a Republican Senator from Tennessee, comes across as a folksy Southerner -- Big Tommy, is his nickname. **********''With Tommy, you really got the impression of a person who was comfortable in his position of authority,'' said Jeff Goldsmith, a hospital strategist. **********Dr. Frist had urged Mr. Scott to lighten up. When the company headquarters were in Louisville, Ky., Dr. Frist successfully urged Mr. Scott to delay his 6 A.M. Monday teleconferences by an hour, complaining that the time difference forced him to stand ready at 5 A.M. in Nashville. **********Unlike Mr. Scott, who is a lawyer, Dr. Frist is a doctor who made his career in the hospital business. Trained as a surgeon, Dr. Frist served as a flight surgeon in the Vietnam War but never practiced. Instead, he founded the Hospital Corporation of America with his father and another partner in 1968. **********He was inspired by a fraternity brother whose father started the Holiday Inn chain, transforming an industry and bringing computerization, standardization and economies of scale. Obsessed with overcoming the stereotype of doctors as poor managers, he built and bought his way into making his company the nation's largest hospital chain by the late 1980's. **********As Medicare cut payments, however, the Hospital Corporation of America and other chains fell from favor with investors. Dr. Frist and backers, including Richard Rainwater, responded by taking the company private in 1988 then public again in 1992. Mr. Rainwater, who was building his own hospital chain with Mr. Scott, was central in arranging the companies' merger in 1993. **********Dr. Frist, 58, received a bachelor's degree from Vanderbilt and his M.D. from Washington University School of Medicine in St. Louis. As Columbia's vice chairman until he became chairman and chief executive yesterday, Dr. Frist is also the company's largest individual shareholder. His 14.6 million shares, or 2.2 percent of the company, were worth $524.7 million at yesterday's close.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/18/world.snippet: Estimated 5,000 koalas live on Kangaroo Island in Australia; their numbers have increased so sharply that they are killing eucalyptuse trees on whose leaves they depend for food; wildlife officer Drew Laslett is in charge of controversial program ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/18/world.main_headline: Australia's Population Crisis: Cuddly Little Critters
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/18/world.print_headline: Australia's Population Crisis: Cuddly Little Critters
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/18/world.body_text: **********Eucalyptus trees with peeling gray and beige bark drape tangles of bushes along the dry flats of the Cygnet River north of this township. **********Drew Laslett, a wildlife officer, points at a type of eucalyptus known as a manna gum where a male and female koala, brown-furred and gray in the underparts, are in separate high forks, warily looking down through a fringe of frayed branches. **********''That's their ice-cream tree,'' said Mr. Laslett, head of a project causing contention here on Kangaroo Island, southwest of Adelaide, and throughout Australia. **********He is in charge of the sterilization of koalas, whose numbers have increased so sharply that they are killing the trees on whose mildly toxic leaves they depend for food. **********Destruction of the eucalyptuses not only threatens the koalas with mass starvation but also makes the cracked soil less resistant to erosion and flooding and hurts insects, birds and other creatures nurtured by the same boughs and leaves. **********The cost of the sterilization program is at least $500,000 over the next 18 months. Though a relatively modest amount, many local residents say the money is wasted. **********''Taking a gun is the cheapest way,'' said David Bell, a retired airport supervisor with a small farm near here. ''A few farmers could have handled the problem quietly. Now we've got all this fuss. It's just a big public relations exercise.'' **********John Ayliffe, another part-time farmer who also helps run a gallery in neighboring Kingscote with his wife, Jenny Clapson, an artist, called  it ''sheer lunacy.'' He said that since it is impossible to find, let alone sterilize, all koalas, the problem would  never be resolved. ''Sterilized koalas still eat, and that's where the problem is,'' he said. **********Animal rights supporters say it is outrageous to subject koalas to the ordeal of capture and surgery. **********''We're terrorizing the koalas,''  said Leighton Booth, who works in the kitchen of an island hotel. ''This situation is not their fault, but ours. We've cultivated too much of the land and introduced too many sheep. People should be out planting trees, not roping koalas.'' **********Koalas were introduced to Kangaroo Island only 70 years ago, along with platypuses, brush turkeys and wombats. Kangaroos were already  plentiful. Australians feared that economic development on the mainland would endanger many of their distinct creatures and looked to this island as a natural refuge. **********Koalas flourished in the new habitat free from any natural predator. Foxes, like rabbits, introduced for the hunt on the mainland, never made it to the island, and the economy remained rural. **********But koalas are a little like rabbits when it comes to reproduction. Nobody knows exactly how many are living here, but official estimates place the number at 5,000, compared with 18 in 1923 and a human population on the island today of 3,500. **********The program envisages relocation to suitable habitats on the mainland and to world zoos that often clamor for koalas. **********But Barbara St. John, a scientific officer who works with Mr. Laslett in South Australia's Department of Environment and Natural Resources, says the numbers are too great for relocation alone as a solution. ''Only a large-scale fertility control program will reduce the future birth rate of koalas,'' she said. **********The killing option is rejected by the South Australian state government. ''The image of our national icon projected around the world dropping dead from trees would hardly do our tourism any good, and might easily trigger international boycotts,'' Mr. Laslett said, **********Ms. St. John cites a letter received by the state government from Brigitte Bardot, well known for her campaigns against the slaughter of animals for their furs, warning against harming koalas. **********The two wildlife management officers were in the Cygnet River Valley with a group of volunteers, led by Scott McDonald, a local schoolteacher, who had organized three teams of five young men and women each to get the koalas down from the manna, blue-gum and other stricken eucalyptuses. **********Climbers use a kind of lasso and then with tugging, poling and the waving of a red flag above the animal's head encourage it to descend. **********In the manna gum the male and female, gripping branches with their two-thumbed hands, are not at all happy about the sudden attention. It takes nearly half an hour to get each of them to the ground and into waiting burlap sacks unhurt. Though unusually gentle, koalas, when agitated, may bite and claw fiercely. **********Tim Lashmar, 19, and Scott Redden, 18, both from the island and considering forestry careers, have succeeded in nudging the male down. **********Mr. Lashmar is bitten in the thigh as he grabs the animal to tag the ear. He grins. ''Only a pinch.'' Later the animal will get a permanent ID from a microchip with a bar code embedded in the shoulder. **********Next step is the nearby trailer that a local veterinarian, Dr. Greg Johnsson, has converted for surgery. **********His nurse, Nadia Jackson, holds an anesthesia mask over the furry faces as he performs a vasectomy on the male, then a tubal ligation on the female. Each operation takes 10 to 15 minutes. When the koalas wake they are returned to their original trees. **********''I'd hate to think of how many times I've done this sort of thing on dogs and cats and rams,'' Dr. Johnsson said. ''But koalas? That's something else again. It's a learning experience.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/14/busin.snippet: Japan's gross domestic product increased 1.6 percent in first quarter as consumers rushed to buy goods before tax increase on April 1 (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/14/busin.body_text: **********Japan's economic output surged in the first quarter as consumers rushed to buy goods before a tax increase on April 1 -- but the higher taxes are likely to slow the economy's growth for the rest of the year. **********The Economic Planning Agency said today that gross domestic product increased 1.6 percent in the first quarter from the prior three months, or at an annual rate of 6.6 percent. The quarter's expansion, which exceeded expectations, pushed growth for the fiscal year that ended March 31 to 3 percent, the strongest since 1991. **********Consumer spending, which accounts for three-fifths of total economic output, rose 4.6 percent in the first quarter from the preceding three months. The economy received a further lift from exports, which were aided by the yen's weakness. **********For the rest of the year, however, economists expect a slowdown because of the April 1 increase in the consumption tax to 5 percent. The increase, coupled with the ending of special income tax rebates and a rise in medical insurance fees, will cool consumer demand and hurt manufacturers and retailers, the economists said. **********The tax increase is already cutting into sales of automobiles, homes, electronic goods and office equipment.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/06/busin.snippet: US Robotics Corp, in bid to attract casual Internet user, has begun advertising on television and featuring unconventional spokesmen; in separate television spots, British physicist Stephen Hawking and co-founder of Apple Computer Inc Stephen Wozn...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/06/busin.main_headline: Unconventional spokesmen talk up U.S. Robotics' fast modems in a new TV campaign.
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/06/busin.print_headline: Unconventional spokesmen talk up U.S. Robotics' fast modems in a new TV campaign.
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/06/busin.body_text: **********IN a bid to attract the casual Internet user, the U.S. Robotics Corporation, the largest maker of computer modems, has begun advertising on television and featuring unconventional spokesmen. **********In separate television spots, the British physicist Stephen Hawking and the co-founder of Apple Computer Inc. Stephen Wozniak discuss the importance of modems and the Internet. The spots, begun on Jan. 8, have been so popular that a third will come out next month featuring a person the company says is equally renowned in the computer world. **********The ads -- U.S. Robotics' first entry into television -- focus on a fast new modem that is scheduled to ship to retailers next week. More generally, the spots stress the role modems play in surfing the Internet. **********''People think a modem is just a $200 add-on, but it's not just an add-on,'' said Jerry Johnston, vice president for corporate communications at U.S. Robotics, the industry leader, which is based in Skokie, Ill. ''It turns your computer into an access device. You can travel the world with that modem.'' **********Professor Hawking and Mr. Wozniak were chosen for their famous technological achievements. **********''We wanted to generate trust,'' said Ted E. Xistris, who oversaw the project at the Leap Partnership, the Chicago agency that created the ads. ''So we found visionaries who use U.S. Robotics technology, and we let them tell the consumer how it makes their life more productive.'' **********In one spot, Professor Hawking, author of the best-selling book, ''A Brief History of Time,'' is shown at Cambridge University, where he teaches. He has amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, better known as Lou Gehrig's disease, and so is confined to a wheelchair and speaks via a keyboard-controlled voice synthesizer. **********''My body may be stuck in this chair,'' Professor Hawking says in the spot, ''but with the Internet my mind can go to the end of the universe.'' **********The spot with Mr. Wozniak shows him with students, talking about how modems connect personal computers, which he helped pioneer 20 years ago. **********Mr. Wozniak, who teaches children about computers near his home in Northern California, said he did the ad because he values the Internet and uses U.S. Robotics modems almost exclusively. ''When they approached me, I said, 'Hey, I happen to use their modems, I like their modems, and I want to do something nice for them,' '' he said in a recent interview. Coincidentally, Apple Computer announced on Tuesday that Mr. Wozniak would rejoin it as an adviser to the chairman. **********Both men have appeared in other advertising. Mr. Wozniak was in an ad for the Datsun 280z during the mid-1980's and on a billboard for Apple laptop computers in 1992. Mr. Hawking appeared in ads for British Telecommunications, which ran in England in 1994 and 1995, said James R. Barron, a spokesman for British Telecommunications. **********The response to the two U.S. Robotics ads has been so strong that the company will soon add a third, set to begin showing by the end of March. Hundreds of consumers have told the company that they are impressed with the ads, especially because the company was able to enlist people with the scientific authenticity of Professor Hawking and Mr. Wozniak, said Neil S. Clemmons, vice president for marketing in the personal communications division of U.S. Robotics. **********The ads highlight a new line of U.S. Robotics modems, called x2 Technology, which will enable users to connect to the Internet over standard telephone lines at speeds as high as 56 kilobits a second, nearly twice the rate of today's fastest conventional modems. Other companies are developing this type of modem, but U.S. Robotics appears poised to beat them to market. **********The entry into television advertising -- unusual for modem makers --  is an attempt to capture the growing segment of computer buyers who purchase their machines specifically to connect to the Internet. **********''Traditionally, modem manufacturers have advertised in PC magazines,'' said Eric C. Buck, a telecommunications analyst at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette in New York. ''Now, the sophistication of the buyer is decreasing. So now the PC buyer is the guy who watches more TV than reads magazines.'' **********The company did not disclose the budget for this campaign. Mr. Buck, however, noted that the company had recently added substantially to its spending on sales and marketing. For fiscal 1996, U.S. Robotics spent $100.8 million on the category, more than double the amount spent the year before. **********In contrast, revenue in that period grew by about 80 percent. ''Sales and marketing expenditure is growing even faster than sales, and I think that's due to promotional increases,'' Mr. Buck said. **********The ads are running nationally, on network and cable television. They are accompanied by five print ads -- only one of which features Professor Hawking -- that are running in computer publications and popular magazines, including Time and Rolling Stone. They are also being considered for use in Britain, said Mr. Xistris of the Leap Partnership, which is part of the Leap Group, whose other clients include Ameritech and Pizza Hut.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/06/world.snippet: Canadian judge upholds deportation order against Hani Abdel Rahim al-Sayegh, Saudi terror suspect, opening way for US to question him about bombing of American military complex near Dhahran in 1996 in which 19 airmen died; backs findings by intell...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/06/world.main_headline: Judge Says Canada Can Deport Suspect in Lethal Saudi Bombing
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/06/world.print_headline: Judge Says Canada Can Deport Suspect in Lethal Saudi Bombing
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/06/world.body_text: **********A Canadian judge upheld a deportation order against a Saudi terror suspect today, opening the way for the United States to question the man about the bombing of a military residence in Saudi Arabia last year that killed 19 Americans. **********Judge Donna McGillis took less than an hour to reach a decision upholding the Canadian intelligence service's allegation that the Saudi, Hani Abdel Rahim al-Sayegh, had been involved in the terrorist attack and should be deported. **********It is now up to Canada's Immigration and Refugee Board to decide where Mr. Sayegh will be sent. Since he passed through Boston on his way to Ottawa from the Middle East last August, he could be sent to the United States or back to Saudi Arabia. **********The proceedings could take as long as several weeks, officials said. **********The F.B.I. wants to question Mr. Sayegh about his alleged role in the bombing last June at Al Khobar Towers, an apartment complex in Dhahran, Saudi Arabia. **********''We would at some point wish to talk to that individual, but we don't know until we have those conversations what the information might be,'' the F.B.I. Director, Louis Freeh, said on Sunday on the NBC News program ''Meet the Press.'' **********Mr. Sayegh's arrest in Ottawa in March was considered a major breakthrough in the investigation of the bombing. But doubts soon arose about the quality of the evidence against him, and whether it was strong enough to be used if he was put on trial in the United States. **********Officials in the Justice Department in Washington said today that no decision had been made on whether to ask Canada to consider deporting Mr. Sayegh to the United States. **********A criminal trial in the bombing could have serious repercussions. The Canadian intelligence service has indicated that Mr. Sayegh is a member of Saudi Hezbollah, or Party of God, which has links to Iran. Such a finding in a criminal case could create pressure for a retaliatory attack against Iran. **********But when he applied for asylum in Canada as a political refugee last August, Mr. Sayegh said he belonged to a dissident group of Saudis opposed to the current Government. The Saudi Government contends that the Dhahran bombing was not the work of domestic dissidents. **********Canadian intelligence agents assert that Mr. Sayegh, 28, signaled the driver of a truck loaded with 5,000 pounds of explosives to enter the compound in Dhahran last June 25. He is alleged to have sped off, with several others, just before the bomb was detonated, demolishing the front of the apartment building. Nineteen American airmen were killed, and more than 500 Americans and Saudis were wounded. **********Canadian officials assert that a Hezbollah cell in Canada helped bring Mr. Sayegh to Ottawa a few weeks after the bombing. A similar deportation proceeding in 1994 disclosed the existence of a terrorist network in Canada, officials say. **********Mr. Sayegh, wearing a white dress shirt, dark slacks and metal-rimmed glasses, smiled and even laughed throughout the hour he spent in court today. As he was led from the courtroom, he was asked if he wanted to say anything about his involvement in the bombing. He smiled and shook his head. **********After he was arrested in March, Mr. Sayegh told reporters that he had been in Syria on the day of the bombing. Later he said he had been in Qum, Iran, on that day, and that he had studied in Iran for several years. **********His lawyer, Douglas M. Baum of Ottawa, said Mr. Sayegh had decided not to testify today. Mr. Baum said the decision did not imply criminal culpability in the bombing.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/11/busin.snippet: TBWA Chiat/Day says it will close its St. Louis office, opened in 1983, by end of year (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/11/busin.main_headline: TBWA to Close St. Louis Office
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/11/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; TBWA to Close St. Louis Office
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/11/busin.body_text: **********TBWA Chiat/Day said yesterday that it would close its St. Louis office, opened in 1983, by the end of the year. **********''This has been a difficult decision to make,'' said Bob Kuperman, North American president and chief executive of TBWA Chiat/Day, part of the TBWA International unit of Omnicom Group. But ''our strategy demands that we dedicate resources to building and strengthening our core offices,'' he added. Core offices are in New York, Toronto and Venice, Calif. **********The St. Louis office has 40 employees and billings estimated at $25 million from clients like Union Electric and its parent, Ameren; The St. Louis Post-Dispatch, owned by the Pulitzer Publishing Company, and the St. Louis Convention and Visitors Commission. **********Mary Tetlow, 40, managing director of the office, and Duncan Milner, 40, creative director there, will be transferred to other offices of TBWA Chiat/Day.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/25/busin.snippet: Outlook for investing in Dalton Specialties Ltd, four-year old firm that runs 10 coffee bars, discussed; firm offers stock and warrants through direct public stock offering to raise money for expansion; is announcing deal on posters and offering n...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/25/busin.main_headline: Pouring Itself Into the Stock Market
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/25/busin.print_headline: Pouring Itself Into the Stock Market
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/25/busin.body_text: **********THE coffee bars that have sprung up across the country like froth on a well-made cappuccino make the point: Americans love gourmet coffee. For some investors, however, the industry may serve up a bitter brew. **********But the executives at tiny Dalton Specialties Ltd. are not daunted by that possibility. The four-year-old company operates 10 coffee bars, most of them in New York City,  and it has increased its revenue nicely, to $2.8 million for the nine months ended Sept. 30. Indeed, Dalton wants to add as many as 43 outlets in the next two years. So late last month it began to go public to raise $3 million for expansion. **********Rather than going public in the usual way, Dalton is using a direct public offering, a process that has become increasingly popular with small companies. Forgoing an underwriter, the company is announcing the deal on posters and is offering the needed documents at its shops, on its Web site (www.daltoncoffee.com) and through a toll-free number (888 325-8669). **********Dalton hopes to sell 42 percent of the company, offering as many as 600,000 units at $5 apiece. A unit consists of 10 shares and five warrants. Each warrant is good for the purchase of one additional share for 65 cents. **********At first blush, the deal -- which carries a $500 minimum purchase -- looks tempting; after all, the coffee business is good. True, the amount of coffee being consumed per person is not growing, said Harry Balzer, a consumer researcher at the NPD Group, a company in Rosemont, Ill., that specializes in food trends. But the percentage of coffee sold at coffee bars is rising fast. In a recent survey of about 33,000 consumers, NPD found that, on average, people made 42 percent more visits to coffeehouses or coffee bars during the year that ended in February than during the year before. **********Still, can small retailers like Dalton compete against the might of, say, Starbucks, with its 1,200 coffee bars? **********''Absolutely,'' said Bruce Milletto, the president of the Bellissimo Coffee Education Group, which provides consulting services to the coffee industry and others. Smaller companies can succeed, he said, if they offer better products or service. Oddly, they can also enhance their chances by situating themselves near big enterprises' outlets -- a strategy Dalton follows. **********''What these larger companies are doing is raising industry awareness, so it's actually an advantage to be near them,'' he said. **********But these theories about small coffee enterprises are one thing. The reality of their stock performance is another. **********True, Starbucks has done well; its stock has risen sharply in the last two years, from about $12 to $33.75 at Friday's close. But many small coffee companies that have gone public recently have seen investor interest evaporate as fast as the steam from an espresso machine. Diedrich Coffee of Irvine, Calif., with about 40 coffeehouses in the West, put its stock on the market at about $10 in September; it closed on Friday at $2.875. Coffee People, with about 20 stores in its home state of Oregon, opened at $9 in September and now sells for $5.75. **********''These offerings have almost all been disasters,'' said Michael T. Moe, an analyst at Montgomery Securities in San Francisco. ''I suspect that most of these companies just weren't ready for prime time.'' **********Investors may be worried that Dalton is  similarly small and young. Equally troubling, the neighborhood charm that often helps small coffeehouses succeed -- Mr. Moe calls them ''nonalcoholic 'Cheers' '' -- may be lost as these newly public companies seek the growth they need. ''As you go past 10, 20 or 30 stores, replicating that atmosphere becomes more difficult,'' Mr. Moe said. **********Dalton's share price of 50 cents does not appear too costly. And Dalton's price-to-sales ratio, which compares a stock's price with a company's annual sales per share, is 2.0, versus 3.7 for Starbucks. But Dalton seems pricier when compared with other small companies like Diedrich, which has a 0.6 ratio, or Coffee People, at 0.8. **********Moreover, Dalton has yet to turn a profit, partly because it has plowed money into new stores. For the nine months ended Sept. 30, it lost $164,000. The offering is small, too. Its 6 million shares, which pale next to Starbucks's 78 million shares outstanding, may be illiquid, or difficult to trade. **********WHAT about the warrants? These devices, essentially options, help small companies to keep up interest in a stock down the road, said David Menlow, president of IPO Financial Network in Springfield, N.J. But for investors, they amplify risk. **********If Dalton stock does not rise past 65 cents, for example, the warrants that investors bought will be worthless. And if the stock does rise past that sum and investors consequently exercise many warrants, the stock's value will be diluted by the increase in shares. The bottom line? With warrants, a stock may need to appreciate substantially to make it profitable for investors. **********A decline in Dalton stock is not far-fetched. Since 1993, Dalton has had a stock issue on the Vancouver Stock Exchange. And while those shares came close to $2 (Canadian), or $1.54 (United States), in mid-1994, they soon fell. For the last two and a half years they have generally traded between 20 cents and 50 cents (Canadian), closing on Friday at 43 cents. **********Kevin Dalton, a company co-founder, said he was aware of the downside of warrants for investors, as well as the problems that coffee company stocks have had. But such difficulties are ''a risk that all new companies take'' when they go public, he said. He also believes that the best that Dalton can do for itself and for investors is to compete well. **********''Obviously, we're hoping to run the company as best we can,'' he said. ''We plan on being careful in picking our sites, and in maintaining high-quality product and service.'' **********Regardless of whether Dalton succeeds, it faces another problem: the way it went public. Mr. Dalton said he did not want to make  a direct public offering; in fact, he said, he spent a year trying to get Wall Street firms to do the job. But he had no luck. **********''We were too small,'' he said. **********So Dalton took the do-it-yourself route. **********Sales have been ''modest'' since the stock went on sale April 23, Mr. Dalton said. But so far the company has registered its stock only in New York, although it is now seeking additional approvals in California, Connecticut, New Jersey and Pennsylvania so that investors there can purchase the securities. **********According to Tom Stewart-Gordon, publisher of SCOR Report, a Dallas newsletter on small corporate offering registrations, direct offerings have grown substantially in recent years. In 1996, 190 companies used the method, versus 145 in 1995. By issuing stock directly, companies avoid underwriter fees, and can advertise the deal on, say,  their six-packs (Spring Street Brewing) or macaroni boxes (Annie's Homegrown). **********But while, according to Mr. Stewart-Gordon, the quality of direct offerings is improving, they also raise investor risk. **********Because the issues lack underwriters, for example, no investment bankers are checking the company's references and no analysts or brokers are researching or recommending the stocks. Thus, investors can obtain little independent information. And the typically few shares that are issued can become even more illiquid because many directly offered stocks, including Dalton's, trade on no exchange. They trade on ad hoc markets. **********Dalton, for example, plans to seek a broker to match buyers and sellers or, failing that, to set up an in-house service. Investors can call Dalton's toll-free number for developments. (Don't expect the stock to have a ticker symbol, however it may eventually trade. Because there is no exchange, there is no ticker.) **********But before deciding whether to buy in, separate your taste for gourmet coffee from the needs of your purse. ''With these investments,'' Mr. Menlow said, ''investors are asked to take on an inordinate level of risk.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/01/busin.snippet: Securities Data Co says stock and bond underwriting rose 12 percent in first three months of 1997, even as rising interest rates indicated potential slowdown in sales over coming year; first-quarter surge was fueled by sale of bonds and other debt...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/01/busin.main_headline: Debt Issues Fuel Gain in Underwriting
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/01/busin.print_headline: Debt Issues Fuel Gain in Underwriting
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/01/busin.body_text: **********Stock and bond underwriting rose 12 percent in the first three months of 1997, even as rising interest rates indicate a potential slowdown in sales over the coming year. **********The first-quarter surge was fueled by the sale of bonds and other debt, which rose to $239.3 billion in the first quarter, compared with $214.6 billion in the similar period of 1996. **********But higher interest rates, a weakness in technology stocks and investor trepidation about corporate earnings growth dampened underwriting volume in other areas. Sales of common stock in the United States declined 7 percent, to $21.3 billion, according to the Securities Data Company. The most drastic drop in equity issues came in the underwriting volume for initial public offerings, which fell nearly 30 percent, to $5.9 billion, from $8.6 billion in the first three months of 1996. **********''The recent volatility in the marketplace and the rise in interest rates has begun to affect the new issue market,'' Brian Hehir, co-chief of global equity markets at Merrill Lynch & Company, said. ''It had its most impact on the I.P.O. volume, which is down. And the new-issue backlog is only about $13 billion at a time when we should be approaching our seasonal peak.'' **********In the first quarter, the securities industry underwrote $273.3 billion worth of domestic debt and equity issues, up from $245 billion in the comparable period last year, according to Securities Data. **********Merrill Lynch remained the top debt and equity underwriter over all, a position it has held since 1988. Merrill underwrote 312 deals worth more than $44 billion. Goldman, Sachs & Company came in second, followed by Salomon Brothers, J. P. Morgan & Company and Lehman Brothers. The five firms collectively accounted for nearly 60 percent of all underwriting fees. **********The total disclosed fees collected by all underwriting firms fell by 9.8 percent in the first quarter to $1.8 billion, according to Securities Data. At Morgan Stanley Group Inc., underwriting fees fell almost 42 percent in the first quarter to $132.6 million. But Merrill; Goldman; Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc., a unit  of the Equitable Companies; Lehman Brothers and J. P. Morgan reported higher income for the three-month period, indicating that the largest firms, with the most access to global markets, are tightening their grip on underwriting and are able to offset declines in the United States with activity in Europe, Asia or Latin America. **********Interest rates rose in the last month as investors anticipated the Federal Reserve's decision last week to increase the overnight lending rate in an effort to stem inflation. The yield on 30-year Treasury bonds, a benchmark for setting prices on other debt, climbed above 7 percent for the first time since September. The 4 percent drop in the Nasdaq composite index in the last month only increased the uneasiness among investors. **********''We've seen a weakness in the secondary markets in telecommunications and technology areas, traditionally a big part of the markets,'' said Marc L. Paley, the managing director at Lehman Brothers who is in charge of equity syndications. ''To the degree that the secondary market is volatile, it'll hurt the new issue market in a major way.'' **********But interest rates are not yet so high as to discourage companies like Raytheon and Norfolk Southern and other companies engaged in strategic acquisitions from entering the bond markets, said John Massad, a partner at J. P. Morgan in charge of debt syndication. Certainly the cash is there. Attracted by the higher interest rates, insurance companies, pension funds and mutual funds continue to funnel money into bonds. **********''The rise in interest rates has been relatively modest, and relative to historic levels, interest rates are still at attractive levels,'' Mr. Massad said. ''So companies are still issuing debt. The volume may be off as much as 20 percent in the coming quarter, but we don't expect a dramatic decline. These rates are still attractive to issuers.'' **********But rising interest rates may affect the junk bond market, which saw a 20.6 percent jump in offerings in the first quarter. Donaldson, Lufkin, the leading firm in the field, underwrote the largest high-yield bond so far of the 1990's, the $2 billion sale of debt by Tenet Healthcare. **********''This was a very attractive time to issue long-term capital,'' said Bennett Goodman, who heads the high-yield bond department at Donaldson. ''Interest rates were very low, and the typical high-yield bond had a 9.5 precent coupon, while Treasuries were yielding 6.5 percent.'' **********But with interest rates rising on high-yield bonds, corporations may opt to go elsewhere for money. ''High yield bonds may not be as attractive as bank debt or selling equity related security,'' Mr. Goodman said. ''Right now there's a very hot bank-debt market, and that'll begin to cannibalize the high-yield market.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/17/world.snippet: Thousands of Zairians in Kisangani wear white headbands in show of solidarity with rebel soldiers who captured city, possibly dealing fatal blow to tottering Government of Pres Mobutu Sese Seko; are walking streets freely for first time in weeks, ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/17/world.main_headline: A Fallen City, Seeking Peace, Greets Rebels
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/17/world.print_headline: A Fallen City, Seeking Peace, Greets Rebels
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/17/world.body_text: **********Thousands of people wore white headbands today to show solidarity with the rebel soldiers who marched victoriously into this sweltering river town on Saturday, dealing what many consider a fatal blow to the tottering Government of President Mobutu Sese Seko. **********The white headband ''stands for peace,'' said one man. ''The people are very happy because finally it is calm here.'' **********A day after rebels captured the city, Kisangani's beleaguered residents were walking the streets freely for the first time in weeks, celebrating the departure of Government troops and Serbian mercenaries who during months of occupation had robbed and mistreated them, summarily executing some for minor infractions. **********''We are liberated,'' said Albert Nyembo, a university student, who is 22. ''They are not rebels,'' he added. ''They are liberators.'' **********Residents said that despite weeks of preparation, Government troops put up almost no resistance, and that some had begun to flee even before the rebels arrived at the outskirts of town at about 2 P.M. Saturday after taking Bangoka International Airport, about 12 miles to the east. **********The final push started on Friday night, when the rebel column neared the airport and started battling the mercenaries defending its perimeter. **********In Kisangani, residents said, the Government troops rioted and looted all night long, throwing grenades into shops, stealing cars and firing into the air. **********Witnesses told of chaotic scenes on Saturday morning as Government soldiers scrambled to get their families and belongings onto boats and across the river to the west bank. The soldiers left hauling mattresses, television sets, radios, pots and pans, anything they could carry. **********''They were shooting in the air the whole time,'' said Pele Lesondja, a 32-year-old hotel manager. ''They were stealing taxis and minibuses. They also took all the ferry boats and canoes and fled to the other bank.'' **********Rebel officials said that most of the retreating soldiers headed southwest toward the town of Opala, but that thousands of others scattered into the jungle. About 260 Government soldiers straggled back to the city today and surrendered to rebel commanders. **********The dismal performance by the Government troops was a humiliating defeat for Mr. Mobutu. Kisangani was the headquarters for the Government's heralded counteroffensive, and it was supposed to be heavily defended by several elite battalions as well as a company of about 300 Serbian mercenaries. **********The mercenaries had fortified and mined the perimeter of the airport, which they used as their headquarters. The airport had been the last major runway still in Government hands in the eastern half of the country. **********Now that it is under rebel control, the Government cannot mount a counteroffensive or resupply its soldiers in the region, where the roads are often impassible. **********Joseph Kabila, the rebel commander in charge of the assault on the city, said today that the only real resistance his troops had faced came 34 miles northeast of Kisangani. **********Commander Kabila, the 25-year-old son of the rebel leader, Laurent Kabila, said the rebels fought for four days along that road, beginning Tuesday morning. He said the Government troops had used heavy guns, tanks and mortars to stop the rebel advance. For three days, both sides exchanged artillery fire without either making progress. **********Then on Friday morning, Commander Kabila said, the rebels were able to outflank and break through the Government line. Government troops scattered in the bush, he said, and the Serbian mercenaries, many of whom were handling the big guns, retreated about 22 miles to Bangoka Airport and dug in. **********When the rebel column arrived at the airport Friday afternoon, the mercenaries began shelling them and the rebels returned the fire. By 7 P.M., the mercenaries started pulling out, evacuating several hundred Government troops on cargo planes, Mr. Kabila said. As they retreated, they blew up their artillery pieces and an ammunition dump. **********The rebel commander denied reports that some Government units, including the 31st Paratroop Brigade, had switched sides and helped defeat the mercenaries holding the airport. He also denied reports that Angolan troops had joined the rebels. **********He said most of the resistance came from the Serbs and from former Rwandan Hutu soldiers, who came to Zaire as refugees in 1994. The Zairian Government soldiers, he said, did not appear to have the stomach for a battle. **********''They don't have the brains to fight the war and they are not dedicated,'' Commander Kabila said. ''They don't have a reason to fight. We have a reason to fight. That's what kept us going all this time.'' **********The fall of the city was the biggest blow to the Government since the rebels took up arms in October. In sixth months, they have seized more than a sixth of Zaire. **********The rebels accuse Mr. Mobutu of driving what should be a rich nation into poverty by enriching himself and his political allies and neglecting public works. **********But their cause cannot be separated from the ethnic conflict between Tutsi and Hutu in neighboring Rwanda. The core of the rebel fighters are Zairian Tutsi, many of whom fought in the Rwandan civil war in 1994. **********They started the revolt after the Government in South Kivu Province tried to strip them of citizenship and deport them to Rwanda in September. **********Some of these Zairian Tutsi rebels are also seeking revenge against Hutu refugees who fled Rwanda in 1994, after a Rwandan Tutsi rebel army came to power. That army halted the mass killings of Tutsi by Rwanda's previous Government, led by Hutu. **********Among the 100,000 refugees still lost in Zaire are thousands of former Hutu soldiers, Government officials and militia members who took part in the massacres. In recent months, they have been rearmed and fighting for the Zairian Government. **********About 70,000 of these people have arrived at Ubundu, a town 80 miles south of Kisangani on the Congo River. The refugees -- hungry and exhausted -- are camped on the east bank. Some have drowned trying to cross the swift, crocodile-infested waters to the west. **********It remains unclear what the rebel commanders will do about the refugees now that they control Kisangani. Laurent Kabila, the rebel leader,  has said repeatedly that the refugees are free to march home. But there have been persistent reports of Tutsi rebels killing Hutu refugees, in revenge for the mass killings in Rwanda. **********For most of the people in Kisangani, the rebel victory was a godsend. Thousands went out to meet the first rebel soldiers who trooped into the town on Saturday. Many mobbed the soldiers, embracing and cheering them on their way into the city center, witnesses said. **********''They were jubilant,'' the younger Mr. Kabila said. ''To say they were excited is an understatement.'' **********Both the Zairian soldiers and the mercenaries have earned a reputation for brutality. Several residents said one of the Serbian commanders, who went by the name Colonel Yugo,  established a petty reign of terror in the last two weeks. **********Claiming to have authority from President Mobutu, the Serbian colonel summarily executed several people who were arrested for not carrying their identity cards, witnesses said. **********Damien Fikirini, a 32-year-old unemployed man who walked the streets after dark for the first time in months, said he supported Mr. Kabila for one reason: the rebels had brought peace and security to Kisangani. **********''The movement will grow,'' he said. ''We hope that Kabila will continue all the way to the capital.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/14/busin.snippet: Laura Pedersen-Pietersen (Minding Your Business) column answers reader's question about municipal bonds, namely what to do with New York State bonds when moving out of the state; chart; graph (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/14/busin.main_headline: Muni Bonds: You Can Take Them With You
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/14/busin.print_headline: MINDING YOUR BUSINESS; Muni Bonds: You Can Take Them With You
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/14/busin.body_text: **********Q. I'm retiring and moving to Florida. Do I have to sell my New York State municipal bonds and replace them with Florida bonds? **********B. INGHAM **********Syosset, N.Y. **********A. Setting up shop in a new location usually causes some confusion.  Years back, for instance, General Motors realized that Nova, its popular Chevy model, meant ''It won't go'' when translated into Spanish. **********But one thing is certain: When it comes to a municipal bond, you can take it with you. No law prohibits you from owning the bonds of one state after you have moved to another. **********However, most municipal bonds do have a home-state advantage. Such bonds are typically free from Federal income tax. But when you live in the issuing state, the interest is usually free from state and local income taxes, too. Generally, this is not so with out-of-state bonds: If you live in, say, California and own New York municipal bonds, you will pay California tax on the bond income. **********But that does not mean you should necessarily sell or swap your New York bonds for Florida ones. To decide, do the math. **********Specifically, you must determine if the yield on the New York munis, minus the taxes you must pay Florida on those out-of-state bonds, will be greater than the yield you would get on Florida municipal bonds. The calculation demands a close look at yields, tax rates and commissions. **********For the most part, the current interest-rate climate dictates bond yields. Variations tend to reflect the differences in bond quality -- their credit ratings, maturities, call provisions and so on. But you may still want to comparison-shop because, just like the highway speed limit, bond yields can vary slightly from state to state. This is a result of the supply of and demand for the bonds. **********Florida may be as renowned for its freedom from an individual income tax as it is for Key lime pie. But the Florida life is not all sweet when it comes to investment income. The state levies a tax on intangible personal property, like cash, stocks and most bonds (but not Florida munis). **********The intangibles tax sets a rate of  $2 for every $1,000 worth of investments, as measured by their fair market value. However, the first $20,000 ($40,000 for joint filers) of  your bonds is exempt from all tax.  The next $80,000 ($160,000 for joint filers) is subject to an assessment of only $1 per $1,000. Only for investments in excess of $100,000 ($200,000  for joint filers) would you pay the full $2 per $1,000. **********In other words, unless you are a mogul or a movie star, ''you may discover that in the case of Florida, the tax is quite minimal'' on out-of-state munis, said Marybeth Whyte, a director at Salomon Brothers Asset Management. For instance, for a single person, the tax on the market value of $80,000 of bonds would be only $60 and the tax on $100,000 worth would be $80 -- about the price of a day at Disney World. **********But commissions must also be considered. At a typical 1 percent commission, it would cost $2,000 to sell $100,000 in muni bonds and then to buy new ones. And if your New York bonds have appreciated, you may also have to pay tax on the gains. **********The commission seems hefty compared with the $80 tax. But before deciding to stay with your New York bonds, remember that you will pay the commission only once. The intangibles tax will be due every year. If  your New York bonds have 30 years to maturity, for example, your intangibles payments will total $2,400. **********After you have crunched the numbers, you can decide whether to hold your old bonds or to buy new ones. But there are other considerations. **********If you opt to swap, for example, you may want to buy Florida bonds with a longer duration than the ones you are selling. By extending the maturity, you can normally receive a higher yield and make up some of the outlay for the commission and any taxes due on the gains. However, during that longer time there is a greater risk of rising interest rates, in which case the value of your bonds would fall. That doesn't matter, of course, if you hold them to maturity. **********You may also want to check with a Florida broker. ''A local broker may have better access to the Florida muni market,'' said Robert Zipf, author of ''How the Bond Market Works'' (Prentice-Hall, $17.95). **********Another factoid: The Florida intangibles tax is figured on your investments as of one day only, Dec. 31.  It doesn't matter what you own during the rest of the year. Think of it as the Sunshine State's own little way of saying ''Happy New Year.'' **********Despite all the fine points, there are general rules for munis and moving. For example, if you are going to a high-tax state, like Massachusetts or New Jersey, a bond swap is more likely to be in your interest than if you go to a lower-tax state. **********Also, watch your tax bracket. If you are retiring as well as moving,  you may no longer be in a bracket high enough to make munis worthwhile. The best course, then -- assuming you want to keep holding bonds -- is to sell your munis in favor of Treasuries, which are federally taxable although exempt from state and local taxes, or corporate bonds, which are taxed at all levels. **********Nevertheless, many people who own muni bonds are in too low a bracket for the bonds to make sense,  Mr. Zipf said. So why do they own them? Three reasons, he said. Some investors just prefer not having to set aside a portion of their interest checks for taxes. Others may have fallen into a lower tax bracket --  through a job change, retirement or a business loss -- since the original purchase was made. And some buyers simply do not realize that they could be getting a better return from a taxable bond. **********But if muni bonds are right for you,  pack a calculator with the sunscreen when you head to Florida. Don't expect to avoid the hard work even on  the ''miracle flight'' -- the name a flight attendant friend of mine has given her New York-Florida route. About 20 wheelchairs are requested for the flight's pre-boarding , but, oddly, not for disembarking. Moments after landing in Fort Lauderdale, most of the former invalids are seen striding briskly into the sunshine. Our very own Lourdes.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/16/busin.snippet: Sony Corp gains control of midsized Japanese advertising agency, Tokyu Agency International Inc, in bid to tap into rapidly growing market for ads on Internet and satellite television; Sony increases its stake to 94 percent from 12.5 percent; fina...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/16/busin.body_text: **********The Sony Corporation said yesterday that it had gained control of a midsized Japanese advertising agency in a bid to tap into the rapidly growing market for ads on the Internet and satellite television. **********The company's president, Nobuyuki Idei, said Sony had increased its stake in Tokyu Agency International Inc. to 94 percent from 12.5 percent. He declined to say how much it paid for the shares, which it bought on May 1. **********Tokyu Agency International had sales of 32.5 billion yen ($273.7 million) last year, making it Japan's 20th-largest advertising firm. About a third of its business came from work with Sony. **********Sony named new executives to run the company and changed its name to Intervision Inc. The electronics maker and media company will use the agency to develop advertising for cable and digital television, game software, the Internet and more traditional media outlets, Mr. Idei said. **********The Tokyu Corporation, a Japanese railway system operator, owns the remaining 6 percent of Intervision. **********Sony bought the shares from Tokyu and D'Arcy, Masius, Benton & Bowles International Inc., the United States ad agency that owned 24 percent of Tokyu Agency International.

''A couple of people walked out with minor burns and minor cuts,'' said a United States Navy petty officer who helped at the scene. ''I couldn't understand how anyone could survive.'' **********Terrorism is not considered a likely cause of the crash. The main suspicion seems to be an error in landing in rainy weather, when the system that guides incoming planes was shut down. **********Articles, pages A8 and A9.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/03/busin.snippet: Toyota Motor Co takes legal action to block Republic Industries, headed by H Wayne Huizenga, from buying up its dealerships, the first attempt by an auto maker to slow the rapid consolidation of automotive retailing by publicly traded companies; T...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/03/busin.main_headline: Toyota Seeks To Halt Buying Of Dealerships By Republic
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/03/busin.print_headline: Toyota Seeks To Halt Buying Of Dealerships By Republic
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/03/busin.body_text: **********Toyota took legal action today to block Republic Industries from buying up its dealerships, the first attempt by an auto maker to slow the rapid consolidation of automotive retailing by publicly traded companies. **********Toyota filed a petition today asking the Texas Motor Vehicle Board, a state agency that rules on disputes between auto makers and their franchises, to halt Republic's recently announced deal to acquire a Toyota dealership in Houston. But the petition was broadly worded, asking the board to affirm Toyota's position that it is not in the public interest to allow anyone to acquire a lot of dealerships quickly. **********In addition to the Houston dealership, Republic bought a Toyota dealership in Miami at the beginning of this year and announced another deal on Monday to buy a Toyota dealership in Tempe, Ariz. James E. Press, a senior vice president for sales at Toyota, said that Republic had notified Toyota of plans to acquire 59 of its dealerships over the next 18 months, accounting for 20 percent of Toyota's nationwide sales. **********Mr. Press said that Republic had not yet proved that it could run even a few dealerships, much less dozens, with the quality of customer service and repair work that Toyota requires. ''They're not operating a dealership that we know of for more than four or five months,'' Mr. Press said in a telephone interview. ''Isn't it reasonable that we would want to slow things down and see how things work before we turn over 20 percent of our volume?'' **********Republic, which has already become the nation's largest automotive retailer, was quick to criticize Toyota's move. ''We think the action is without merit,'' said J. Ronald Castell, Republic's senior vice president for marketing and communications. Republic has already completed without difficulty the acquisition of a dealership in Midland, Tex., that sells Chevrolet, Buick and Mazda cars, said Mr. Castell, who declined to comment on Toyota's specific concerns. **********Toyota has a policy of trying to prevent any person or company from acquiring more than one dealership every nine months. Toyota has also maintained a policy until now of barring any person or company from owning more than seven Toyota dealerships and three Lexus dealerships. **********Franchise agreements with car dealers give auto makers the authority to veto the transfer of franchises to anybody the auto makers deem unsuitable. But state laws put many limits on the auto makers' ability to exercise this veto, so most dealership transfers are routinely approved. State regulatory agencies like the Texas Motor Vehicle Board administer these laws. **********Auto industry officials expressed surprise that Toyota had chosen to make its stand in Texas, where the vehicle board has a reputation for siding with dealers against auto makers. Because Republic bought its second dealership in Texas less than three months after its first purchase, Mr. Press said, Toyota had to take action there. **********''We're playing the hand that has been dealt to us,'' he said. **********According to Automotive News, an industry publication, Republic reached agreements through March 20 to acquire 73 dealerships with $4.7 billion in combined 1996 sales. **********Republic has already concluded broad dealership acquisition agreements with the General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company and less formal arrangements with other auto makers, although not with Toyota. The agreements provide a legal framework for the auto makers to approve each acquisition quickly as they come along. **********In exchange, auto executives say, Republic has promised at least some of the auto makers that it will continue to participate in regional advertising purchases with smaller, independent dealers. That limits Republic's ability to use its greater sales volume to demand better rates for advertising than its competitors can negotiate. **********In a filing a month ago with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Republic also disclosed that it had agreed to sell its G.M. and Ford dealerships back to the manufacturers if a change of control occurred at Republic that either manufacturer viewed as unacceptable. **********Chrysler officials have already said they will not allow any individual or company to buy more than 10 of their dealerships nationwide, more than 6 in any of the company's 25 sales regions or more than 2 in any market. Other auto makers have not disclosed any limits on the acquisition of dealerships but are widely thought to have them. **********G.M. and Ford have been particularly receptive to Republic because they want to reduce the number of their dealerships. Ford has close to 90 dealerships in the Los Angeles area alone, and they tend to compete with one another instead of going after Japanese rivals. Toyota has no need or desire to reduce the number of its dealerships, Mr. Press said. **********H. Wayne Huizenga, Republic's chairman, said in an interview last month at the company's headquarters in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., that Republic would be able to find economies of scale from running many dealerships. **********But consumer advocates are beginning to worry about the consolidation of automotive retailing. ''Consumers may end up with higher prices and fewer model choices if a significant segment of the market is controlled by Republic or any other group,'' said Mary Ponder, a senior projects director at the Consumer Federation of America. **********Republic has been buying large dealerships with good reputations for customer service. While some big dealers have welcomed Republic's acquisitions as a chance to sell their operations for a handsome price, many smaller dealers have been worried that Republic will monopolize some markets and drive them out of business.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/27/busin.snippet: Little-known but promising technology called micro-electro-mechanical systems (MEMS) uses tiny sensors, motors, valves and other devices embedded on computer chips to sense heat, light, motion and sound and take appropriate action; applications ra...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/27/busin.main_headline: High-Tech Push To Make Small More Beautiful
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/27/busin.print_headline: High-Tech Push To Make Small More Beautiful
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/27/busin.body_text: **********At the Xerox Corporation's research center here is a remarkable model, a miniature structure covered with a wired web of sensors that look like small baby-bottle nipples. Working together, sensors like these may someday enable buildings or highway overpasses to adjust instantly so that they dance in harmony with an earthquake, rather than crumble under its tectonic force. **********This is cutting-edge research to be sure -- and highly pragmatic here, three miles from the San Andreas Fault. But nimble buildings are just one possibility that researchers envision for a little-known but promising technology called micro-electro-mechanical systems. **********These Lilliputian sensors, motors, nozzles, valves or other mechanical systems will be able to sense heat, light, motion and sound. Placed on the surface of computer chips, these tiny devices will also be smart enough to interpret what it all means and take action. **********Some of the more intriguing applications now in the lab include an airplane wing that can maneuver without the aid of either ailerons or rudders. Instead, the skin of the wing has a ''peach fuzz'' of two-tenth-millimeter sensors. Controlled by computers, these minuscule flaps can monitor the air sweeping across a wing in flight and respond in concert to stabilize or even turn an aircraft. **********Other futuristic applications include substitutes for paint that fill in cracks or release a fire retardant when exposed to heat; automobile bumpers that repair themselves, and sensors embedded in a cellular telephone that could pinpoint the user's location. **********Increasingly sophisticated micro-electro-mechanical systems, known as MEMS, may soon be making their way into so many elements of everyday life that many scientists and engineers believe they could eventually have an effect as profound as that of the microchip. **********''The 1980's were defined by the microprocessor, and cheap lasers have made possible the communications advances of the 1990's,'' said Paul Saffo, a computer industry consultant at the Institute for the Future in Menlo Park, Calif. ''The first decade of the next century is going to be shaped by MEMS.'' **********Micro-electro-mechanical systems are already much more than a futuristic vision. An estimated $2.2 billion worth of these devices are sold annually for use in products like automobile air bags and home blood-pressure kits. And a market is seen emerging for inexpensive chemical analysis instruments -- the equivalent of a laboratory on a chip. **********Especially in the aftermath of disclosures that troops during the Persian Gulf war were exposed to toxic residue from destroyed Iraqi munitions dumps, the Pentagon is eager to have inexpensive, portable means for detecting chemical and biological weapons. With MEMS, researchers hope to replace cumbersome $17,000 laboratory spectrometers -- instruments that measure light waves to determine the chemical composition of substances -- with $20 devices that could easily be carried by foot soldiers. **********Typically, the goal with MEMS is either to replace existing devices with cheaper, more efficient technology, or to develop entirely new capabilities that were once simply beyond the reach of earlier electro-mechanical technologies. **********In less than a year on the market, for example, a $7 MEMS sensor from a company called Analog Devices has become the leading motion detector used in automobile air bags. The sensor, which instructs the air bag to inflate, consists primarily of a microscopic whisker of silicon that  can detect a car's sudden deceleration when it hits an object. The Analog Devices sensor is not only less than half the price of earlier mechanical sensors, but industry engineers say it is much more reliable. **********And a new type of projection-television system, with much brighter, sharper pictures than previously available, has a MEMS-based video-display system developed by Texas Instruments. The projector is powered by an array of millions of microscopic controllable mirrors floating on a single silicon chip called a digital light processor. Projection systems that are based on the technology, used primarily for business conferences in auditoriums and other large-audience settings, are now being sold by manufacturers, including Electrohome, In Focus Systems, Nview and Proxima. **********Despite the recent rush toward MEMS in laboratories in the United States, Asia and Europe, the underlying ideas were conceived nearly four decades ago. **********One early proponent of micro-miniaturization was Richard Feynman, a professor at the California Institute of Technology who would later win a Nobel Prize for his work in quantum physics. In a now-famous 1959 lecture at the annual meeting of the American Physical Society, Dr. Feynman urged engineers to pursue ultra-small technology for manipulating and controlling things and processes, speculating that tiny computers would one day be able to store the contents of the Encyclopaedia Britannica on the head of a pin. (An angels' dance that is now within the realm of the feasible.) **********Today, dozens of small American start-up companies are on the brink of bringing new MEMS applications to market. In Silicon Valley, for example, a company called Cepheid is developing micro-instruments for biomedical testing, including a fluid-testing chip that will combine valves, sensors and channels all on a single sliver of silicon. Intended to test blood and urine for a variety of medical conditions with high accuracy at low cost, the device is expected to reach the market within a year. **********Another company, Redwood Microsystems, is building pressure-flow regulators and micro-valves that make laparoscopic surgery and other medical and industrial applications more precise and less expensive. Silicon Light Machines is working on an alternative approach to Texas Instruments' digital light processor, using tiny gratings that act as electronic prisms to diffract light, rather than reflect it, producing full-color images from a single beam. And a start-up called Telenekron is working on a new class of chemical sensors for various uses in gas meters and automobiles. **********One reason MEMS researchers are so confident about progress is that the technology draws on many of the powerful manufacturing techniques already well proved by the semiconductor industry -- techniques that can churn out millions of copies of even the most complex designs at remarkably low cost. **********In creating a microscopic MEMS pressure sensor, for example, engineers employ the same kinds of masks and etching compounds used in the production of silicon chips. By etching away most of the surface material they are able to create a diaphanous diaphragm as thin as a single micron. (A human hair is at least 75 microns thick.) Pressure from these sensitive diaphragms can be read by a thin layer of electrical resistors embedded into the surface, whose voltage fluctuates with the diaphragm's subtlest movement. **********To be sure, big challenges remain for MEMS researchers. Placing millions of individual components on a tiny microchip is only the beginning. Making these arrays work in concert is a matter taxing even the expertise of researchers adept at a field known as massively parallel computing. **********MEMS developers, led by Andrew Berlin, a scientist at Xerox's Palo Alto Research Center, face just such a task in trying to figure out how those future highway-support columns would coordinate the small electronic pulses from the millions of MEMS sensors coating the column's surface. The pulses would be used to damp the vibrations from an earthquake, but no known computer would be fast enough to control such a multitude of sensors. **********By programming the individual sensors to interact only with their neighbors, however, it may be possible to break down the computing problem to a manageable size. Already, the Xerox team has used this approach in the laboratory to increase more than fivefold the strength of a model column for brief periods. **********Whatever the technical obstacles,  the new frontier of MEMS could also bring with it thorny social problems. For example, a 1995 study group in the United States, sponsored by the Advanced Research Projects Agency of the Pentagon, proposed the idea of ''surveillance dust.'' Each dust particle would consist of tiny sensors with a miniature parachute, microphone and infrared detector. Sprinkled over a battlefield, this dust would float for five hours or more to give pinpoint information on enemy locations. Privacy experts, however, worry that such technology could soon be widely deployed for civilian as well as military applications. **********But such concerns seem unlikely to slow the MEMS forward thrust. Despite some still-formidable technology hurdles, industry pioneers are now confident that they will be able to replicate the prodigious feats of the microelectronic world -- in the new micro-mechanical realm. **********The optimists include Gordon Moore, chairman emeritus of the chip maker Intel, who helped turn the transistors of the 1950's and 1960's into the semiconductor chips of the 70's, 80's and 90's. **********''It took a long time for the transistor to have an impact,'' he noted. ''MEMS is a really intriguing technology, and I believe it will have a significant impact in the next century.''
