https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/11/your-.snippet: POLITICAL UNREST in Asia has a history of upsetting foreign investors, but those pragmatic souls who look beyond the newspaper headlines often find silver linings..Jardine Fleming Securities, the biggest money manager in Hong Kong, has a strategy ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/11/your-.main_headline: In Asia, Unrest Can Spell Opportunity
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/11/your-.print_headline: In Asia, Unrest Can Spell Opportunity
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/11/your-.body_text: **********POLITICAL UNREST in Asia has a history of upsetting foreign investors, but those pragmatic souls who look beyond the newspaper headlines often find silver linings. **********Jardine Fleming Securities, the biggest money manager in Hong Kong, has a strategy ofbuying securities when there is civil unrest, hoping for gains after calm is restored. **********Just days after political trouble in Indonesia last year, for example, a report by Jardine Fleming's closed-end Indonesia Fund dismissed the rioting in Jakarta as having no fundamental effect on company earnings over the long term, since the major question surrounding Indonesia is not the economic system, but rather who will succeed President Suharto. **********The report argues that "historically, almost every political disturbance in Asia has represented a buying opportunity for long-term investors." **********The document added that "The reasons are quite consistent: political disputes have often been over either personalities or the rate of change, not the system or change in itself." **********Investors who followed Jardine Fleming's advice at the time would have been pleased.Major stocks that compriseJakarta's composite index fell by as much as 8 percent before recovering days after the riots, and the index rose by more than 19 percent from that point to the end of the year.(The Jardine Fleming fund underperformed the index by 4 percent). **********THE LIST OFmajor buying opportunities goes on: In Hong Kong, after the Chinese crackdown on democracy demonstrators in Beijing in June 1989, the Hang Seng Index fell below 2,100, but by the end of 1989 had rebounded to 2,837, an increase of more than 35 percent. **********In March 1996, Taiwan's major indexwas depressed after China carried outmilitary exercises off the island. China was furious at Taiwan for conducting democratic presidential elections. **********As the tension mounted, many investors dumped shares, but after the elections the market rose more than 47 percent by year's end from its low point. **********The same thing happened to stocks following violent unrest this decade in Thailand and India. If stocks have since performed sluggishly in those markets, the culprits have not been bombs or riots, but rather poor electronics exports or a bad investment environment due to misguided fiscal policy. **********WHEN THE KEY INDEXon the Bombay exchange soared 5.7 percent in a single day at the end of 1996, it was not because violence had been quelled. Rather, itfollowed news that the Indian government would immediately remove a capital-gains tax on sales of stock in state-owned companies. **********Why do fund managers bail out in times of crisis, time and again? **********"What you always do in a crash is you go back to your home," said a manager in Hong Kong. **********"It's a lot easier to explain to your trustees that Wal-mart or Marks & Spencer let you down if you're a British manager. But if you get hurt on a Taiwan stock, your people will ask 'What were you doing in Taiwan?' " **********Buying when there is blood in the streets, as Lord Rothschild once recommended, can be "a pretty brutal reaction to some country's democratic struggles, but the stock market can be a brutal place," said Ted Pulling, who manages an Asia-wide fund for Jardine Fleming as well as the firm's India investments. **********YET REPEATEDLY, Asian markets bounce back from unrest. "Asia has this fantastic capacity to find compromise, and economic growth in most of these countries is quite handsome," Mr. Pulling said. **********The problem with Jardine Fleming's rule lies in the exceptions, in addition to the fact that most of Asia's stock markets are so young that there is not a lot of history to go on. **********Real political change does happen from time to time, whether or not by violence, and sometimes it means bad news for companies, as with India's previous government, whichimposed the now-removed capital-gains tax. **********More ominously for investors, a foreign company that derived most of its earnings in China before the 1949 revolution would have been out of business after the Communists marched in unless it took evasive action and decamped to Hong Kong, as many did. In retrospect, it seems amazing that so many businesses stuck it out through 1950 to see what life under Mao would be like. **********Besides, who says the rioting in Indonesia, for example, is not over what kind of system is in place? According to David Holloway, a Hong Kong director at the corporate-risk consultants Kroll Associates, that is precisely what the unrest in Indonesia is about. Rioting tends to affect stocks associated with the family and friends of President Suharto. **********Strikes in South Korea this month also are aimed at changing the system: the demonstrators are against a new labor law that would reduce the barriers to firing workers. **********The critical thing to decide in the face of unrest is whether the events will lead to systemic change, and, if so, what kind of change that will be, said Bob Broadfoot, of Hong Kong's Political and Economic Risk Consultancy. **********If the change in an entire regime means that companies favored by the government stand to lose market share, some other company — domestic or foreign — ought to be poised to try to fill the resulting gap. **********"Any political change you can make money from," said Mr. Broadfoot, "and any political change you can lose money from."

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/17/news/.main_headline: American Airlines Resuming Service After Clinton Stops Strike
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/17/news/.print_headline: American Airlines Resuming Service After Clinton Stops Strike
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/17/news/.body_text: **********WASHINGTON—                     American Airlines service was nearly back to normal Sunday, a day after President Bill Clinton ordered pilots back to work. But the prospect that his action might merely delay a strike appeared certain to jostle and confuse domestic and international travel until a solution is reached. **********Mr. Clinton intervened Saturday to halt a minutes-old strike at the nation's second-largest airline, appointing a board to study the dispute and postponing a walkout by American's 9,000 pilots for at least 60 days. **********American flight managers scrambled to reorganize service and, in the end, canceled fewer than 100 of 2,200 daily departures. Restoration of full service "could be a few days away," said a spokesman at the company's headquarters in Fort Worth, Texas. **********Many passengers planning to travel over the three-day U.S. holiday week- **********end had protectively booked on other airlines, and many American jets flew half-full on Saturday and Sunday. **********Some airlines, taking advantage of the ripple effect still rocking American's schedule, said they would continue to add extra flight and staffing over the next few days in key markets. **********Tour operators in the Caribbean and in ski resorts, meanwhile, were still fearful of cancellations. **********"The next few months will be a mess," said Jeffrey Long, an airline analyst with J.P. Morgan Securities Inc. "Because of the uncertainty hanging around them for the 60 days or so, people may still likely book away from them." **********In explaining Mr. Clinton's intervention, spokesmen cited the huge impact a strike would have had on the economy and on Americans' travel plans. The airline carries 20 percent of U.S. passengers and has 86,000 employees. **********The strike threatened losses to the U.S. economy estimated at $200 million a day and to the airline of $30 million a day. Even with a strike averted, for now, American is likely to lose many millions of dollars because of reduced bookings, analysts say. **********Travelers will be able to reap some short-term benefits, however, as American cut its fares to lure back concerned customers, and other major carriers responded in kind. An American spokesman said Sunday that response to the fare offer had been "overwhelming." **********Mr. Clinton's intervention was the first by a U.S. president in an airline dispute in nearly 30 years, though there have been 18 major airline strikes in that period. Some critics of his action said he was ill-advised to intervene now. **********"It sets a dangerous precedent," Kenneth Quinn, former chief counsel of the Federal Aviation Administration, said Sunday on CNN. "It's going to be very difficult for this president, or any president in the future, to face a strike by a major airline and say it does not constitute an emergency." **********The White House spokesman, Michael McCurry, touched on the sensitivity of presidential intervention in a labor-management dispute. **********"No Democratic president likes to prevent the ability of workers to strike," he said. "But at the same time, there were legal grounds and economic grounds for doing this, as well as the travelers who would be stranded on a holiday weekend." Monday is Presidents Day, a federal holiday. **********Other critics of the president's move said the 60-day cooling off period he ordered might only have postponed an inevitable confrontation between American, a unit of AMR Corp. and the Allied Pilots Association. **********But many travelers breathed sighs of relief when they heard that Mr. Clinton had ordered the cooling-off period **********The threatened strike caused short-term confusion for many airlines. **********An agent for Continental at the Dallas-Fort Worth airport said the airline had a 60-percent no-show rate Saturday, after all its flights had been overbooked. Apparently, large numbers of people double-booked with other airlines but then flew with American when the strike was stopped. **********At O'Hare International Airport in Chicago, officials had stockpiled cots and blankets for stranded travelers, added workers to help book alternative travel plans and prepared a command center to oversee the operation. **********Company officials tried to minimize the impact of the brief strike. "If it hurt us at all," said a spokesman, Al Comeaux, "it was less than a bad storm at one of our hubs." **********A few international departures, to Europe, Japan and South America, were canceled Saturday. They were announced before the midnight Friday strike deadline because the company did not want to have planes stranded at foreign airports.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/20/world.snippet: Russian police retaliate against American diplomatic motorists in Moscow for embarrassing series of traffic violations involving its diplomats in New York; Moscow traffic police begin highly unusual road checks of vehicles driven by American, Fren...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/20/world.main_headline: Russia and U.S. Are at War (But Only if You're Driving)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/20/world.print_headline: Russia and U.S. Are at War (But Only if You're Driving)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/20/world.body_text: **********With the American flag fluttering from his limousine, the top United States diplomat here rode out of his embassy on Thursday. **********But no sooner had the car belonging to the diplomat, John Tefft,  passed through the embassy gates than it was stopped by the Russian traffic police on Moscow's Garden Ring road. **********After a check of official documents, the diplomat's car was allowed to drive on. But there seemed little mistaking the message to American officials: **********Russia would retaliate for an embarrassing series of traffic violations its diplomats had been accused of in New York. And not even even Mr. Tefft, the charge d'affaires and senior American diplomat here pending the appointment of a new ambassador, would be exempt. **********''They were hitting really hard,'' an American official said today, referring to the recent, and highly unusual, road checks of American diplomats. **********For four decades, Moscow and Washington were bitter political adversaries. But now, with the cold war behind them, Russia and the United States appear to be embroiled in a tit-for-tat traffic war. **********Ever since a Russian envoy and his Belarussian colleague were accused late last month of abusing their diplomatic status and becoming involved in an altercation with New York police officers, Russia's Foreign Ministry has responded with howls of indignant protest. **********And articles have appeared in the Russian press accusing Western diplomats of drunkenness and irresponsible behavior on Russia's anything-goes highways. **********But the latest twist is something Moscow's traffic police call ''Operation Foreigner.'' On Thursday, the first day of the campaign, according to a police spokesman, traffic officers stopped 1,000 foreign-owned cars. More than 200 violations of traffic rules were discovered, he said, most committed by Americans. **********Russian traffic officials publicly insist that they are merely trying to maintain order in the disorderly scrum that typifies Moscow's road travel. But Western officials, as well as many Russians, trace the crackdown to politics. **********Certainly, Russia's feud with New York's police department contrasts markedly with the approach taken by Georgia. When a Georgian diplomat was accused earlier this month of causing a fatal accident in Washington, the Georgian Government apologized and stripped the envoy of his diplomatic immunity so that he could be prosecuted. **********But then, Georgia is seeking to strengthen its economic and diplomatic ties with the West while the Russians see their run-in with the New York police as the latest in a series of painful humilations. **********Russia's dust-up with the New York police began last month when Russian and Belarussian diplomats scuffled with the police after being accused of parking near a fire hydrant and seeking to drive while intoxicated. **********It intensified last Monday, when New York police officers ticketed the limousine of the Russian Ambassador to the United Nations three times for illegal parking. **********Three days later the Moscow police launched ''Operation Foreigner,'' with Americans, British and French diplomats apparently receiving the brunt of the attention. Over the weekend, however, the number of road checks appeared to decrease. **********Singling out Americans is a simple task since their cars display telltale license plates, with the numerals ''004'' identifying their nationality. The letter ''D'' identifies diplomats. The letter ''K'' is used to identify  foreign correspondents. **********In addition to Mr. Tefft, the embassy's chief of protocol was stopped three times on the way between the ambassador's residence and the embassy. **********The American Embassy is still in the process of compiling a statistical record of the road checks. But one official said today that when Mr. Tefft asked at a meeting of senior American officials about their recent experiences driving in Moscow, ''everyone had a story to tell.''

Ayer & Partners in New York, a unit of MacManus Group, which handles corporate advertising for G.M.; Campbell Mithun Esty in Minneapolis, owned by top managers and the Interpublic Group of Companies, and the TL Partnership in Dallas, a unit of Omnicom Group. https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/07/busin.snippet: Dow Jones industrial average closes down 1.15 points, to 6,944.70; Nasdaq composite index loses 13.66 points, to 1,315.43 (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/07/busin.main_headline: Stocks Slip a Bit as Wall Street Braces for Data on Employment
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/07/busin.print_headline: Stocks Slip a Bit as Wall Street Braces for Data on Employment
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/07/busin.body_text: **********Stock prices dipped yesterday as Wall Street braced itself for today's report on February employment, which could provide further clues to the state of the economy and the direction of interest rates. **********After racing up about 50 points yesterday morning, the Dow Jones industrial average slid throughout the afternoon to close down a minuscule 1.15 points, to 6,944.70. **********Yesterday's turnaround was driven by another broad selloff in the technology sector and a weak bond market that grew increasingly nervous about the employment report. **********''Until there's downward pressure on inflation, the market's likely to remain cautious,'' said Alan Ackerman, a market strategist with Fahnestock & Company. Following last week's suggestion by Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, that the Fed may take ''pre-emptive'' action against inflationary pressures by raising short-term interest rates, bond prices have been sliding, pushing yields higher and thereby making bonds more competitive with stocks. **********The yield on the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond rose to 6.88 percent yesterday from 6.82 percent on Wednesday. Analysts said that an uncooperative bond market had  made it difficult for stock prices to push higher. **********''Clearly, we're at a point where investors are waiting for the fundamentals to change,'' said Joseph Battipaglia, chief equity strategist at Gruntal & Company. ''Since, we're already at high valuation levels there isn't much room to move. And today, there was a lot of anticipation about the employment numbers.'' **********While a weak bond market seemed to sap the energy out of the Dow industrials, the volatile technology sector once again saw heavy casualties. The technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index lost 13.66 points, to 1,315.43. Of the 10 largest Nasdaq stocks in terms of market capitalization, nine lost ground yesterday, including many of the biggest technology issues. Shares of Intel, Microsoft, Cisco and Oracle all declined in value. Intel lost 4 1/8, to 145 3/8; Microsoft lost 215/16 , to 9715/16 ; Cisco was down 2 1/4, to 54 5/8, and Oracle was off 33/16 , to 369/16 . **********After its recent losses, the Nasdaq composite index is up only 1.89 percent for the year. In comparison, the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks -- which lost 3.43 points yesterday to close at 798.56 -- is up 7.8 percent on the year, and the Dow is up 7.7 percent. **********The technology sector, which helped propel stock prices higher in the second half of last year, now finds itself badly trailing the broader market. And some analysts wonder whether stock prices can make steady gains without the aid of what has become an increasingly important part of the nation's economy. **********Among Dow stocks, Sears has now overtaken Du Pont and Philip Morris as the year's biggest gainer. Although shares of Sears lost 1 yesterday, to 54 5/8, it is up 19 percent.  Shares of I.B.M., Texaco and Disney bucked the trend yesterday. I.B.M. was up 1 1/8 points, to 146 5/8; Texaco was up 2 1/8, to 103 7/8, and Disney gained 1 5/8, to 75 1/8. The biggest loser was Merck, down 1 3/4, to 92 1/4. **********ON THE WEB **********The latest stock and mutual fund quotations, along with news updates, are available on the Internet from The New York Times on the Web: www.nytimes.com

Compass, a British food services company, said it expected the acquisition, which should close next Monday, to increase earnings in the first full year of operation. Compass said it would soon acquire the remaining shares, which are held by SHRM management. **********Compass also said it had agreed to sell its 11 percent stake in the restaurant company Generale de Restauration to the French conglomerate Compagnie Generale des Eaux for an undisclosed amount. https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/18/busin.body_text: **********To the Editor: **********''Red Herring Over Independent Boards'' (Viewpoint, April 6) describes why there is no need for any economic ''proof'' of the worth of independent corporate directors. **********I would add that there is a simple reason such a proof does not -- and cannot -- yet exist: the truly independent director is a relatively recent development, and the independent board is even newer. HORTON **********DeLand, Fla., April 7

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/16/busin.snippet: Dow Jones industrial average rises 47.39 points, to 7,333.55; Nasdaq composite index rises 18.03 points, or 1.35 percent, to 1,353.58; table (L)

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/16/busin.body_text: **********Stocks surged yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average closing at more than 7,300 points for the first time. **********Stocks were bolstered by manufacturing data that pointed to a slowing economy, suggesting that Federal Reserve policy makers would not need to raise interest rates when they meet on Tuesday. **********The Dow rose 47.39 points, to 7,333.55, with virtually all the gain coming in the final hour of trading. **********The Nasdaq composite index, loaded with technology issues, rose 18.03 points, or 1.35 percent, to 1,353.58, its best gain in nine sessions. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 5.84 points, to 841.88. **********Reports on factory utilization across the country and a review of Philadelphia-area manufacturing suggested that growth is slowing from its decade-best rate in the first quarter, diminishing the potential for inflation. **********''The markets either don't expect a Fed rate increase, or they expect a benign one,'' said Laszlo Birinyi, who runs his own research firm in Greenwich, Conn. **********Advancing issues outpaced those that declined by 1,302 to 1,188 on the New York Stock Exchange. **********Shares of the Intel Corporation rose for a second day, extending its comeback after two rival makers of computer chips filed lawsuits contending that Intel's best-selling Pentium chip uses their patented technology. Intel climbed 5 1/4, to 158 1/8, after falling as much as 13 in the previous two sessions. **********Shares of the Hewlett-Packard Company rose 2 1/4, to 58 7/8, on expectations that its second-quarter profit would exceed estimates on strong sales of servers and other computers. After the market closed, the company posted earnings of 75 cents a share, 6 cents less than estimates. **********Shares of Amazon.com Inc., a money-losing Internet book retailer, soared on their first day of trading. Amazon jumped as much as 12, to 30, before closing at 23 1/2. Strong demand for shares bolstered the initial sale price to 18 each late on Wednesday, more than the original forecast of 12 to 14. **********Gateway 2000 Inc., a direct-marketing retailer of personal computers, saw its shares surge 7 1/2, to a record 68 7/8, after the company said it would split its stock 2 for 1, buy back as many as 10 million shares and move to the New York Stock Exchange from the Nasdaq market. **********Among retailers, Gap Inc. said its profit rose to 31 cents, from 28 cents in the quarter a year earlier, matching forecasts; its shares rose  5/8, to 32 3/4. The Kmart Corporation's stock  fell  3/8 a share, to 14 1/8, after it reported profit of 3 cents a share, better than some analysts' forecasts. Investors apparently anticipated slower growth later this year. **********The Capital One Financial Corporation's shares fell 3 1/2, to 36 3/8, after the company forecast lower-than-expected earnings for its second quarter. **********Oil shares declined as the slowing economy and ample supplies pointed to a decline in petroleum prices. The Exxon Corporation lost 1, to 58 7/8; Texaco Inc. fell  7/8, to 110 1/8. **********Banks gave up some of Wednesday's gains. Shares of the BankAmerica Corporation fell 1, to 119 7/8, after rising 4 on Wednesday. **********Shares of Intuit Inc. climbed 3 3/16 ,  to 27 1/8, on speculation that the financial software company might be acquired as soon as Monday. **********ON THE WEB **********The latest stock and mutual fund quotations, along with news updates, are available on the Internet from The New York Times on the Web: www.nytimes.com

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/19/busin.snippet: Philips Lighting Co, Philips Electronics NV unit, plans news conference at which it will offer to give competitors technology for making fluorescent bulb that does not leach mercury; seeks to head off possible Environmental Protection Agency move ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/19/busin.main_headline: Philips Concession on Bulbs May Have Political Motive
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/19/busin.print_headline: Philips Concession on Bulbs May Have Political Motive
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/19/busin.body_text: **********The Philips Lighting Company is casting it as environmental enlightenment. But it smacks a lot of enviro-politics. **********The issue involves burned-out fluorescent light bulbs, which since 1990 have been designated as hazardous waste because they contain mercury that can contaminate ground water. Now, though, the Environmental Protection Agency is considering whether to take fluorescent bulbs off its most-hazardous list so they can be sent to regular landfills. **********Two of the leading fluorescent bulb makers -- the General Electric Company and Osram Sylvania Inc., a unit of Germany's Osram G.m.b.H. -- support such a move by the E.P.A. But Philips, which is a subsidiary of Philips Electronics N.V. of the Netherlands, is the industry's lone voice of opposition. **********Why? Market motives. **********Two years ago Philips's Alto fluorescent lamp, for now the lowest-mercury bulb available, became the first fluorescent lamp to pass the T-Clip test -- the Toxicity Characteristic Leaching Procedure test that the E.P.A. uses to see whether mercury can leach out of a spent bulb. **********As a result, while users of other bulbs have to hire licensed hazardous waste haulers to dispose of them in registered hazardous waste dumps, at a cost of as much as $1 a bulb, users of Alto bulbs can simply throw them away. **********Given that American industry tosses out some 550 million fluorescent bulbs each year, Philips currently has a marketing edge that the company does not want to lose. So, sensing that the E.P.A. and Congress are veering toward its competitors' court, Philips is staging a media event. **********At noon today, the company will hold a news conference in Washington to announce that it will share its Alto technology with its competitors. Several environmentalists have promised to share the podium, as has Senator John D. Rockefeller 4th, Democrat of West Virginia -- the state where Philips makes most of its Alto bulbs. **********Giving technology away might seem a strange way to maintain a competitive edge -- even if, as Philips contends, it would take competitors at least three years and tens of millions of dollars to catch up. But, in fact, Philips and General Electric have a cross-licensing agreement that gives G.E. access to most of Philip's technology anyway. And Osram Sylvania has started to market its own low-mercury bulb, which the company believes could also pass the exhaustive T-Clip testing process. **********So what is Philips up to? **********Apparently, it hopes that the gimmick of seeming to give away its technology will pique enough public interest to put a spotlight on the whole disposal issue. That could make members of Congress reluctant to prod the E.P.A. to ease its restrictions, lest they appear to be anti-environmental. And, if it also happens to give free publicity to Alto bulbs, so much the better, from Philips's standpoint. **********''We're hoping a news conference will give broader awareness to the product itself,'' Steven M. Goldmacher, a Philips spokesman, said. **********In fact, the amount of mercury in fluorescent bulbs has been steadily dropping. In the last dozen years, the average amount of mercury in a four-foot fluorescent lamp has plunged to 22.8 milligrams from 48.2 milligrams. And some industry experts predict that the average will dip below 12 milligrams by 2000. **********''A lot of the newer lamps would pass the T-Clip, because everyone is reducing the amount of mercury that leaches out,'' one E.P.A. official, speaking on the condition of anonymity, said. **********Specifically, Philips wants fluorescent bulbs to be covered by the E.P.A.'s so-called universal waste rule, which would ease some record-keeping burdens for the bulbs' users but would still require special handling. G.E. and Sylvania want the E.P.A. to pass what regulators call a conditional exclusion rule, which would allow spent bulbs to be dumped in state-approved municipal landfills. **********Until recently, as the E.P.A. has pondered a rule change, the National Electrical Manufacturers Association had been lobbying for the conditional exclusion that two members, G.E. and Osram Sylvania, still seek. But once Philips, also a member of the association, broke ranks, the group went mute on the subject. **********''The position of the industry now is that we have no position,'' said Eric Erdheim, the association's senior manager for government affairs.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/24/world.snippet: United States and Japan agree to boster military ties despite warnings from China against stronger alliance; new ties replace guidelines set in 1978 as basis of military cooperation in event of war or another crisis in or near Japan; State Sec Mad...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/24/world.main_headline: Risking China's Wrath, U.S. and Japan Bolster Military Ties
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/24/world.print_headline: Risking China's Wrath, U.S. and Japan Bolster Military Ties
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/24/world.body_text: **********The United States and Japan agreed yesterday to strengthen their military relationship despite warnings from China that the stronger alliance was a provocation that would threaten peace and stability throughout Asia. **********The new ties replace guidelines  set in 1978 as the basis of military cooperation in the event of a war or another crisis in or near Japan. **********Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright and Secretary of Defense William S. Cohen announced the revisions after a meeting at the Waldorf-Astoria in Manhattan with their Japanese counterparts, Foreign Minister Keizo Obuchi and Defense Minister Fumio Kyuma. **********Under the agreement, Japan would provide support for American military operations in the event of a military confrontation or other crisis, including allowing the use of its bases in emergencies. **********The guidelines also called for Japan to take part in minesweeping efforts in international waters, to enforce economic blockades and to help evacuate civilians trapped in unstable countries. In addition, the two countries agreed to step up their efforts to coordinate their ''defense policies and military postures'' and to share covert intelligence. **********Ms. Albright and Mr. Cohen hailed the agreement -- which came after a year of negotiations and protests inside and outside Japan -- as an important step for promoting security in Asia and the Pacific. **********''These guidelines that are being updated are designed to help face the challenge not of the past but of the future,'' Mr. Cohen said. **********They then sought to reassure China and other countries in Asia that the new ties were not an effort to bolster American might and influence at the expense of others. **********A statement by the two countries went to great lengths to note their interest in cooperating with China, although it did not mention Taiwan, a major source of Chinese concerns. Beijing has publicly complained that the alliance could draw Japan into supporting the United States in any defense of Taiwan. **********''The new guidelines are not aimed at any individual nation, any third nation,'' Mr. Cohen added. ''But by strengthening the security relationship benefits with Japan, it benefits all of the nations in the region.'' **********The announcement came only hours before Ms. Albright met China's Foreign Minister, Qian Qichen, as part of a flurry of meetings over the next two weeks with ministers and other diplomats gathering in Manhattan for the opening of the United Nations General Assembly. **********Appearing at a news conference with Ms. Albright last night, Mr. Qian responded curtly when asked about the new guidelines. **********''The position of the Chinese side has been made clear again and again,'' he said. But the issue did not appear to dampen the mood of their meeting, the sixth between Mr. Qian and Ms. Albright. **********Ms. Albright called him ''my good friend'' and said the United States ''had made progress in almost all'' of the areas where it disagrees with China, which include proliferation, trade and human rights. **********The meeting was intended to smooth the way for the summit next month between President Clinton and President Jiang Zemin, and afterward a senior State Department official suggested that ''concrete steps'' were still needed to make that summit meeting a success. **********Throughout the cold war, the United States committed itself to the defense of Japan, but on terms that left many unanswered questions about the extent of Japan's military role.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/08/busin.snippet: Federal Communications Commission unanimously approves sweeping reshuffling of phone rates; moves will generally keep down local phone rates for consumers while lifting rates for businesses; long-distance rates for all customers will fall 5 percen...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/08/busin.main_headline: BIG RESTRUCTURING OF PHONE CHARGES APPROVED BY F.C.C.
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/08/busin.print_headline: BIG RESTRUCTURING OF PHONE CHARGES APPROVED BY F.C.C.
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/08/busin.body_text: **********In the most sweeping effort yet to set the ground rules for a coming battle in telecommunications, the Federal Communications Commission took steps yesterday to reshuffle billions of dollars of telephone rates -- raising prices for some services and lowering them for others. **********The new rules, which were approved unanimously, will generally keep a lid on local phone rates for consumers while lifting rates for businesses. Long-distance rates for all customers will decline by 5 percent to 15 percent, under a related agreement between the commission and the AT&T Corporation, the nation's dominant long-distance provider. **********The commission's chairman, Reed E. Hundt, said in an interview yesterday that the new rules would deregulate the industry even as they promoted a cherished goal of the Clinton Administration: connecting the nation's schools and libraries to the Internet. **********''What we did today is to realize the impossible dream of connecting every single American to the information highway, while figuring out how to pay for it,'' a jubilant Mr. Hundt said. **********But some lawmakers and industry experts said that the F.C.C., in trying to appease all potential opponents of the plan, had fallen short of its stated mission: to strip decades of subsidies from the nation's telephone industry and move it closer to a free-market model. **********''The commission is doing less, and postponing it longer, than people ever expected,'' said Scott Cleland, an analyst with Schwab Washington Research Group, an investment advisory firm. **********Mr. Cleland said the commission had tackled only a fraction of the $23 billion in subsidies that undergird the telephone industry. And the commission deferred until next year the thorny question of how to provide affordable phone service to rural areas, which are expensive to serve. **********Still, yesterday's rules were a historic step in unraveling six decades of Government regulation. And they elicited a generally approving response from consumer advocates and industry leaders. **********''Our great fear was that as you opened telephone markets, there would be a big rate increase,'' said Gene Kimmelman, the co-director of Consumers Union, a lobbying group in Washington. ''This sends the right message that we want to put downward pressure on rates.'' **********Robert E. Allen, the chief executive of AT&T, said in a statement, ''The F.C.C. has crafted a good compromise that will result in tangible benefits for American consumers.'' **********These are some of the main components of the F.C.C.'s plan: ***********It will sharply cut the charges that long-distance carriers pay to local phone companies for access to their customers by $1.7 billion in 1997 and $18.5 billion over five years. Access charges are set artificially high so that local phone companies can charge less for residential phone service than it costs them to provide it. ***********It will establish a relatively small Universal Service Fund of $4.65 billion. The proceeds will go to equip schools and libraries with high-speed connections to the Internet, to provide rural health care centers with phone service and to continue to serve rural customers while the F.C.C. devises a new system of rural subsidies. ***********It will impose an additional fixed charge of $1.50 a month on second residential phone lines, and an extra $3 fixed charge on business lines to help the local companies recoup the lost access revenue. ***********It will allow the local companies to charge long-distance carriers a flat monthly fee of $2.75 a line for every business customer. Analysts expect the long-distance carriers to pass along that charge in the form of higher long-distance bills. **********The MCI Communications Corporation and other long-distance carriers had argued that the F.C.C. ought to slash access charges by $10 billion in one fell swoop. The regional Bell companies warned that doing so would force them to raise rates for local service. **********In the end, Mr. Hundt sided more with the Bells -- reducing the charges by only $1.7 billion in the first year. He said that a more Draconian cut was unnecessary because access charges would fall naturally as new rivals invaded the markets of the local companies. **********Even the more modest cuts in access charges did not mollify some companies. GTE and BellSouth both harshly criticized the rules, saying that they would lead to higher local rates. **********For now though, the F.C.C. seems to have heeded the call of several senators from rural states who publicly warned Mr. Hundt in Congressional hearings not to raise local rates. **********Mr. Hundt even got a bonus over the weekend when AT&T signed an agreement with the F.C.C. to pass along all the savings it derived from lower access charges to customers in the form of lower long-distance rates. Based on AT&T's market share, that would amount to $900 million -- or a 5 percent decline in daytime and evening rates and a 15 percent decline in night and weekend rates. **********Yesterday, people familiar with MCI said it, too, would pass along savings of $340 million; Sprint is also expected to follow suit. **********Despite the F.C.C.'s delicate balancing act, there were clear winners and losers in the rules. Residential customers with one phone line will see no upward spike in their monthly local bill and may even pay less over all, since their long-distance rates will drop. **********But people who order a second line will pay an extra $1.50 a month charge, in addition to the $3.50 charge for each line that all customers now pay. Some Internet service providers complained that this could dampen use of the Internet, since many people use second lines for on-line connections. **********Stephen M. Case, the chairman of America Online Inc., said he was worried that a few consumers would drop his service. But he said he was relieved that the F.C.C. ignored the requests of the Bell companies to impose a whole new set of access charges on Internet service providers. **********Businesses with multiple lines will also have to pay more: $3 a month for each line over the $6 a line they already pay. In addition, they are likely to absorb the $2.75 in flat fees that long-distance carriers will be charged by local companies for every business line. **********The decision to load the new costs on businesses provoked a storm of protest from lobbyists for business customers. A day before the rules were issued, Mr. Hundt capitulated to their request to lower the flat fee to $2.75 a line from $4.50 a line. **********''Businesses are going to continue to underwrite too many costs, but I praise the F.C.C. for taking out the worst of anti-business regulations,'' said Brian Moir, a Washington lawyer who represents the International Communications Association, a trade group for business customers. **********Clearly, the sweetest moment for Mr. Hundt came yesterday afternoon at the National Geographic Society in Washington, where he and Vice President Al Gore celebrated the schools and libraries initiative with a coalition of educators and librarians. **********Yet some experts said it was precisely the extra money for schools and libraries that would make the F.C.C.'s rules difficult to sustain over the long haul. In effect, the Government is adding new costs at the same time that it is trying to squeeze out existing subsidies. **********''The Universal Service Fund is simply too big to encourage competition and deregulation,'' said Thomas Duesterberg, a senior fellow at the Hudson Institute who specializes in telecommunications issues. **********Sharon L. Nelson, the chairman of the Washington State Utilities and Transportation Commission, said she was worried that the F.C.C. could wind up shifting the onus for rate increases to the states. **********Mr. Hundt acknowledged that the F.C.C. faced a hard slog as it began the next phase of deregulation: determining the cost of providing affordable phone service to rural areas. **********But given the whirlpool of competing economic, political and commercial interests that the F.C.C. escaped this time around, Mr. Hundt was allowing himself to savor yesterday's achievement. **********''Unlike Houdini, we did not do this in a locked safe underwater,'' he said. ''We did this in full public view.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/20/busin.snippet: Wheat futures prices surged on March 19 on Chicago Board of Trade on concern that spring planting might be delayed by flooding in northern Plains; wheat for May delivery rose 7.25 cents, to $3.91 per bushel (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/20/busin.main_headline: Wheat Prices Surge on Fear That Floods May Delay Crops
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/20/busin.print_headline: Wheat Prices Surge on Fear That Floods May Delay Crops
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/20/busin.body_text: **********Wheat prices surged yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade on concern that spring planting might be delayed by flooding in the northern Plains. **********On other markets, gasoline prices rose. **********The Red River Valley dividing North Dakota and Minnesota, one of the most fertile wheat-growing regions in the country, could see record floods this spring because of a heavy snowfall, the National Weather Service said. **********Farmers normally would start planting the spring wheat crop in the next few weeks. But, said Jeff Wilson, an analyst at Brock Associates in Milwaukee, the heavy snow pack could delay planting. **********Wheat for May delivery rose 7.25 cents, to $3.91 a bushel. July wheat, the most actively traded contract, rose 7.75 cents, to $3.8325 a bushel, the highest for that contract since Sept. 27. **********Any delays in planting would come at a time when domestic inventories are low. Stockpiles are expected to be around half the normal levels in May, according to Department of Agriculture estimates. North Dakota and Minnesota together grow about 63 percent of the nation's spring wheat, according to the agency. **********Gasoline rose after a report of an unexpectedly big inventory drop drew concern about shortages during summer's peak demand. **********Gasoline inventories fell 4.32 million barrels last week, to 198.17 million barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Last April, prices surged to a 15-year high on concern that inventories would be too low to meet summer demand. Inventories now are 4.6 percent lower than they were a year ago. **********''This was supposed to be a flat week'' for gasoline inventories, said Bill O'Grady, an energy analyst at A. G. Edwards & Sons in St. Louis. ''In gasoline we shouldn't have seen a draw of this magnitude. This is big.'' **********April gasoline rose 0.48 cent, to 67.96 cents a gallon, on the New York Mercantile Exchange. **********The American Automobile Association said average domestic retail gasoline prices fell 1.6 cents a gallon in the month ended last Sunday. The average price for self-serve regular gasoline was $1.271 a gallon, 9.1 cents higher than last year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/18/busin.snippet: Financial Accounting Standards Board delays putting into effect criticized rules on derivatives to give banks more time to adjust their computer and accounting systems; chief point of contention is proposed rule that would force companies to tell ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/18/busin.body_text: **********The Financial Accounting Standards Board today delayed putting into effect sharply criticized rules on derivatives to give banks more time to adjust their computer and accounting systems, a board spokeswoman said today. **********The postponement of the Jan. 1, 1999, starting date was sought by lawmakers, banks and accounting firms. **********The chief point of contention was a proposed rule that would force companies to tell their shareholders more about the value of transactions they enter into involving derivatives. Critics argued that the rule would make companies' balance sheets appear more volatile than they really are. **********Companies can now in many cases enter into derivatives  deals with no impact on their financial statements. Derivatives are investments that are tied to -- or derived from -- the performance of an underlying asset or market. **********The rules will go into effect after June 15, 1999, the F.A.S.B. spokeswoman said. **********The rule will become effective on Jan. 1, 2000, for the  publicly held American companies whose fiscal year coincides with the calendar year, Securities and Exchange Commission data show.
