https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/15/busin.body_text: **********THE July issues of Worth and Money magazines offer strikingly different snapshots of the ''best'' places to live in America. But some second and third thoughts may be in order before you start packing. **********Worth's rating is focused on money, dependent solely on median home prices -- with the assumption that whatever else makes the living good will follow in the wake of wealth. Money's rankings are based on statistics and survey results in nine categories: the economy, health care, crime, affordable housing, education, weather, transportation, leisure activities and the arts. The results are sometimes quirky. **********John Koten, Worth's editor, defended his magazine's second annual survey, ''The Richest Towns,'' against reader criticism last year that such an article didn't belong in an investing magazine. **********''Where to reside is one of the most important financial decisions anyone can make,'' Mr. Koten writes. ''That means the towns we include are those that the market has, for one reason or another, deemed among the most desirable. They're valuable places to live because they provide connections to  society's movers and shakers; because they're (usually) near places where fortunes are being made, and because they offer privacy, prestige and comfort. These are all things that help successful people become even more successful -- certainly one definition of a worthy investment.'' **********Worth says the richest town is Matinecock, population 880, on the North Shore of Long Island. The town's median home price is $1.5 million and there are seven local  country clubs. But don't rush to call your real estate agent; Worth says homes there rarely come on the market. **********The others in the top 10, along with median home prices, are: Aspen, Colo., $1.4 million; Rolling Hills, Calif., $1.1 million; Centre Island, N..Y., $999,000; Snowmass Village, Colo., $975,000; Rancho Sante Fe, Calif., $970,000; Atherton, Calif., $967,500; Hillsborough, Calif., $931,500; Jupiter Island, Fla., $922,500, and Kapalua, on Maui in Hawaii, $900,000. These are all small places, ranging from a population of 12,300 in Rancho Santa Fe (yes, the site of the Heaven's Gate suicides) to 408 in Kapalua. **********The list includes 238 towns -- wealthy areas of larger cities are not counted -- and the cutoff point for home value is $300,000. **********Unlike the 1996 ratings, this year's do not take household income into account. States with the most rich towns are California, 78; New York, 55, and New Jersey, 24. Most of the high-priced real estate can be found near San Francisco (Silicon Valley money), Los Angeles (Hollywood megabucks) and New York (Wall Street wealth). **********The whole exercise is a paean to money. The writer, Jane Berentson, senior editor of Worth, waxes enthusiastically that Aspen's home values get ''a boost from wealthy celebrities, people like former Playboy cover girl Barbi Benton and her husband, George 'Mobile-Home King' Gradow.'' **********Money magazine takes a broader, more statistical approach in ''The Best Places to Live Today,'' by Carla Fried with Jeanhee Kim and Amanda Walmac. It ranks 300 towns, cities and areas, big and small. **********The winner is Nashua, N.H., where a four-bedroom house costs $125,000 (and the property tax is $3,700), the unemployment rate is 2.3 percent and there is no sales tax or state and local income tax. The rest of the top 10, in order, are: Rochester, Minn.; Monmouth and Ocean Counties, N.J.; Punta Gorda, Fla.; Portsmouth, N.H.; Manchester, N.H.; Madison, Wis.; San Jose, Calif.; Jacksonville, Fla., and Fort Walton Beach, Fla. **********Dead last on the list is Davenport, Iowa, and Money all but apologizes for it. ''Residents feel their place is a pretty darn fine spot to live,'' the article says. But despite 42 miles of picturesque bike trails, six museums and three riverboat gambling casinos, the city still comes up short. The region's overall violent crime rate, an important factor in Money's poll of readers, is 27 percent higher than the national average.  And it's a three-hour trek to Chicago for top restaurants and major league sports. **********BUSY BANDWAGON The crowded field of personal-finance magazines is beginning to breed look-alikes -- at least on their covers.  Forbes and Fortune, which have long had sections dealing with personal finance, appear to have joined the fray. **********Forbes's June 16 issue, containing an annual investment guide, has a cover article on second careers as the key to successful retirement. The cover could have been designed by Money; the photograph shows an aerobics instructor going through her paces.  No cigar-chomping cable-TV mogul here. **********Fortune's June 23 cover has a teaser  headline --''Nine Stocks to Bank On'' -- that reads like it came from Smart Money's playbook. Even the venerable Economist, on its May 31-June 6 cover, features a cartoonlike drawing of a tax collector chasing a man with a cellular phone around a spinning globe. It illustrates an article titled''The Disappearing Taxpayer,'' about the difficulty of assessing and collecting taxes in a global, high-technology economy. **********LISTEN UP, FED David Hackett Fischer, a professor of history at Brandeis University, argues in the July-August issue of Bloomberg Personal that the Federal Reserve is obsessed with inflation fears and runs the risk of prompting a world depression. **********CREDIT WHERE DUE Kiplinger's and Money see bright spots for women in terms of credit and pensions. Kiplinger's notes that for the first time men and women who are business owners have about the same access to business capital, according to the Census Bureau and the National Foundation for  Women Business Owners. Money says women could get bigger pensions under proposals in Congress, including one that would expand the so-called homemaker individual retirement account. **********ON THE WEB Money's World Wide Web site (www.money.com) offers links to what it considers top Internet spots for information on stocks, mutual funds, financial calculators and the like. Smart Money, in its June Issue, had a cover on its 10 favorite Web sites, but they are not linked to a central site like Money's. Money articles and advice are  also available on line through Compuserve. **********BITS AND PIECES Smart Money's July issue rates discount brokers . . . . Individual Investor thinks it's time to jump back into some Japanese stocks. . . . Several magazines predict a pickup for bond prices in the second half of the year, along with a correction in stocks.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/10/busin.snippet: Labor Department reports that producer prices in December rose half a percent, more than expected, but so-called core rate, which excludes energy and food, rose only one-tenth of 1 percent, less than was expected; in full year, producer prices ros...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/10/busin.main_headline: Producer Data Show Inflation Still Moderate
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/10/busin.print_headline: Producer Data Show Inflation Still Moderate
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/10/busin.body_text: **********Producer prices rose more than expected during December, the Government reported today, but when the cost of energy and food was excluded, the increase was below forecasts. **********The Labor Department said that producer prices over all grew half a percent in the month, exceeding analysts' expectations of a gain of three-tenths of 1 percent and above November's increase of four-tenths of 1 percent. However, the so-called core rate, which excludes the energy and food categories, rose only one-tenth of 1 percent, below the forecast of a gain of two-tenths of 1 percent. **********The small rise in the core rate, which is watched closely because prices for energy and food are especially volatile, cheered the financial markets by adding to speculation that the Federal Reserve would not raise interest rates soon. The good news on inflation helped to send the Dow jones industrial average up 76.19 points, to 6,625.67. **********The president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago, Michael H. Moskow -- a voting member of the Fed's policy-making committee -- said today that ''we should have another year of respectable growth with low inflation and low unemployment.'' **********In the full year, producer prices rose 2.8 percent, faster than 1995's 2.3 percent increase and the biggest annual gain since 1990, when the Persian Gulf crisis pushed up oil prices. The core rate rose only six-tenths of 1 percent in 1996, well below 1995's 2.6 percent increase and the second-smallest yearly gain on record. **********In another report today, the Labor Department said first-time claims for state unemployment insurance fell last week to 361,000 from 374,000 a week earlier, the largest decline since mid-October. **********Today's inflation report showed that producer energy prices, which account for 13.6 percent of the Producer Price Index for finished goods, rose 3.1 percent during December -- the biggest gain in a year. However, wholesale food prices, which make up 22.8 percent of the index, decreased one-tenth of 1 percent. Wholesale auto prices rose three-tenths of 1 percent, as did wholesale tobacco costs. **********The question is whether rising oil prices will lead to higher costs for other goods. Mr. Moskow of the Chicago Fed said he did not expect that to happen. **********In a speech Wednesday night in New York, the Fed's vice chairwoman, Alice M. Rivlin, said, ''It's hard to remember any time when the overall economic situation looked so good.'' The economy, she said, showed ''no clear signs of overheating or serious imbalance.'' **********The White House spokesman, Michael D. McCurry, said today that the Clinton Administration was focusing on the core rate component of the Producer Price Index ''because a large part of the increase reported is due to the home heating oil and gasoline price increases.'' Given that, he said, the President was not particularly concerned. **********To be sure, some prices have moved higher since December. The price of oil for February delivery has climbed back above $26 a barrel from the low $20 range a month ago. And the Goldman, Sachs & Company industrial metals commodity index has increased about 2 percent since the end of December.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/13/busin.snippet: In Las Vegas, Nev, where crassness has long trumpeted classiness, new trend is to build luxury hotels designed to attract upscale vacationers; hope is that they will spend more money on food, lodging and entertainment, even as they lose less money...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/13/busin.main_headline: Building a Classier Image; Las Vegas Hotels Woo Blue Chip Visitors
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/13/busin.print_headline: Building a Classier Image; Las Vegas Hotels Woo Blue Chip Visitors
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/13/busin.body_text: **********The newest way to make an impression on the garish Las Vegas Strip is through Impressionism itself. The Bellagio, a luxury hotel being built in a city known for its girlie shows, clanging slot machines and the Liberace Museum, will have its hallways graced by about $130 million worth of paintings by the likes of Renoir, Monet and Picasso. **********Down the road, Circus Circus Enterprises, known for a flagship hotel that features $29 rooms, $3 all-you-can-eat buffets and trapeze acts high above the blackjack tables, is building a resort that will include a hotel managed by the tony Four Seasons Hotels Inc. **********Las Vegas is adding a little elegance to its ebullience, a little class to its crass. The latest mantra here is go upscale: attract upper-middle-income vacationers -- not necessarily avid gamblers -- who might normally head for Palm Springs or La Jolla, Calif.; Scottsdale, Ariz., or Santa Fe, N.M. **********Behind the move is a change in the economics of Las Vegas. In the past, rooms, food and entertainment were mainly loss leaders, sold cheaply to lure customers into the casino. **********But as Las Vegas has broadened its appeal, the average visitor is dropping less at the roulette table. At the low-priced Circus Circus hotel, for instance, ''A lot of people are sleeping there but not playing the casinos,'' said Glenn Schaeffer, the president of the parent company. **********So he and other casino owners are trying something radical: to turn a profit on rooms, food, entertainment and shops. In 1996, these nongambling revenues accounted for 47 percent of the Strip's total, up from 42 percent in 1990, the Las Vegas Convention and Visitors Authority says. **********Still, the average hotel rate for all of Las Vegas has only crept up to $58, so hotel keepers think there is room to charge even more by making accommodations more luxurious. Higher room rates are also needed to recover the costs of the extravagant theme hotels now under construction, like the $1.5 billion Bellagio, which hopes to charge an average of about $165 a night, a new high for Las Vegas. **********Risks abound in this strategy, though. Visitors may balk at high room rates if cheap ones are still plentiful, and giant hotels run the danger of becoming impersonal. Most important, though: Can Las Vegas absorb all these new rooms? **********Las Vegas, of course, has been redefining itself for a decade. **********In recent years it has shed some of its Sin City reputation and turned itself into a playland for middle-American families by building hotels with theme-park-like attractions -- erupting volcanoes, battling pirates and Greenwich Village street scenes. This attracted mainly low-budget vacationers lured by the inexpensive hotels and meals. **********But the latest moves, if they succeed, will broaden the market further and help transform this desert hub into a more traditional resort, with golf, tennis, spas, ritzy shopping centers and gourmet restaurants. **********The Bellagio is far from alone. The Desert Inn is just completing a $200 million renovation aimed at making it the first five-star hotel in Las Vegas. While most hotel-casinos require guests to run a gantlet of slot machines to find the registration desk, the Desert Inn, owned by the ITT Corporation, features a lobby five stories high, and not a bing or a bong within earshot. **********The Ritz-Carlton Hotel Company is entering the Las Vegas market, agreeing to manage a 526-room hotel in the new 640-acre Mountain Spa Resort being built on the outskirts of the city by Jack Sommer, owner of the Aladdin Hotel. **********Ritz-Carlton and Marriott International, which owns 49 percent of Ritz, have also signed letters of intent to manage hotels to be built on the property of the MGM Grand. ITT's Caesars Palace, long considered one of the most upscale hotels, has just added a new, even more luxurious 1,200-room tower. **********The new establishments are not necessarily aimed at the high rollers who bet up to $200,000 on a single hand of baccarat. Las Vegas already treats them very well indeed. **********The Las Vegas Hilton offers high rollers free penthouse suites, each more than 12,000 square feet, with private pools and lawns, furnishings befitting Versailles, and tuxedo-clad butlers on duty 24 hours a day. **********Nor are the moves aimed at families with children. While the building of theme hotels has made Las Vegas more of a family place, gaming executives -- perhaps spooked by the murder of a 7-year-old girl in May in a casino in Primm, Nev. -- now say that was never the intention. **********''Every time I saw kids in Las Vegas they were crying,'' said Stephen F. Bollenbach, president and chief executive of the Hilton Hotels Corporation. Even Mr. Schaeffer of Circus Circus says: ''We're not McDonald's that advertises to kids. We're Wendy's, where parents want to go and the kids can find something to eat.'' No, the goal is more upscale visitors, yuppies and DINK's (dual income, no kids). **********The proportion of visitors bringing children, while doubling since 1990, is still only 11 percent, and that is why strategies are being re-evaluated. MGM Grand Inc. is cutting the size of its unprofitable theme park in half. It will use the space for the new Ritz and Marriott Marquis hotels, a conference center and a spa with six swimming pools, waterfalls, a river and private cabanas. **********And food, often neglected in a place famous for groaning breakfast buffets and unlimited prime rib, is also getting ritzier. One pacesetter has been Rio Hotel and Casino Inc., which has used fine food and an all-suite environment to become one of the faster-growing properties in the city. Still, insisted the chairman, Anthony A. Marnell 2d: ''Las Vegas is not trying to change its image. It's just addressing an apparent desire''  of more demanding consumers. **********Rio has hired well-known chefs like Jean-Louis Palladin, formerly of the Watergate Hotel. It spent about $400,000 to buy part of Andrew Lloyd Webber's wine collection when it was auctioned and added it to a large wine cellar run by a master sommelier from the Ritz hotel in London. Now, Rio is even thinking of opening a restaurant in New York. **********Other trendy restaurants that have opened in Las Vegas in the last few years are Wolfgang Puck's Spago, San Francisco's Fog City Diner and Mark Miller's Coyote Cafe. Bellagio will house the first branch of Le Cirque outside New York. **********As for high-end shopping, the Forum Shops, situated at Caesars Palace and developed by Simon DeBartolo Group, has been a big success since it opened in 1992 and has just doubled its size, adding retailers like Bernini, Emporio Armani and an F.A.O. Schwarz store with a three-story-high Trojan horse in front. Of course, this being Las Vegas, every locale must have a themed attraction, so statues come to life in the fountains, re-creating the destruction of Atlantis. **********Some business executives here worry about becoming too snobby. ''The danger is that Las Vegas loses the reputation as a bargain,'' said Ellis Landau, chief financial officer of the Boyd Gaming Corporation, which owns the Stardust hotel. ''We still need that.'' **********That, of course, assumes the upscale move succeeds, which is far from assured. ''It's awfully tough to change your product image and move upscale,'' Craig Sullivan, the chief financial officer at Primadonna Resorts, said at the recent World Gaming Congress and Expo here. In an attempt to change its image, for instance, Circus Circus, whose stock price has been battered this year from more than $37 to around $23, is thinking of changing its name. **********Even though business executives and higher-income vacationers might spend $200 or $300 a night on a hotel in New York or Los Angeles, that does not mean they will pay that much in Las Vegas, where perfectly decent rooms are available for less than $100. **********Some of the new high-end hotels will have thousands of rooms, making it hard to deliver personalized service. ''What happens is people are treated like cattle and the quality of the experience goes down,'' said John Koster, president of the Desert Inn, which has 715 rooms. **********Air service is another bottleneck. While overtaxed McCarran International Airport is adding new gates, it is served mainly by Southwest Airlines and America West Airlines, discount carriers without much first-class or business-class service. Direct flights from East Coast cities are rare. **********The biggest risk is whether Las Vegas can absorb all the high-class rooms and shopping malls. Las Vegas is in the midst of a building boom that over the next few years could add 20,000 to 60,000 rooms to the 104,000 already here. **********Named for a resort area in northern Italy, the 3,000-room Bellagio, being built by Mirage Resorts and scheduled to open in the fall of 1998, will have a nine-acre man-made lake with what is promised to be a spectacular fountain show. **********Hilton's 3,000-room Paris, to open in 1999, will cost about $760 million and feature a 50-story replica of the Eiffel Tower. In addition to its 400-room Four Seasons hotel, Circus Circus's $800 million Project Paradise will have its own 3,400-room aquatic-theme hotel-casino in which guests will be able to swim in a pool with sharks -- separated by an acrylic wall. **********The grandest of all, if it gets enough financing, might be the nearly $2 billion Venetian being built by Sheldon G. Adelson, who made his fortune selling the Comdex computer trade show to a Japanese entrepreneur. It will have 6,000 suites and will be a re-creation of Venice, complete with canals and gondoliers who croon in Italian. **********So far, the city has worked on the premise that supply breeds demand -- build it, and they will come. And sure enough, as the castle-shaped Excalibur, the pyramid-shaped Luxor and other theme hotels have sprouted one after another, the number of visitors has continued to rise. **********But this year, Las Vegas is feeling the effects of overbuilding. In the first eight months of the year, the supply of rooms rose 10 percent, but there were only 4 percent more visitors. So much for raising room rates. Rooms for two in midweek are being advertised for $35 at the Frontier and $55 even at the relatively high-end Rio. **********The Stratosphere, a new casino at the seedier north end of the Strip, built as a huge tower with a roller coaster on top, is operating under bankruptcy protection. Some other less spectacular properties are also ailing, and a shakeout is expected. **********''We are beyond building spaces, we are building conversation pieces,'' said Alex Yemenidjian, president and chief operating officer of MGM Grand, which is controlled by the financier Kirk Kerkorian. ''There will be eventually a half a dozen properties in Las Vegas that will command 90 percent of the public attention, and then every other property will be a dormitory.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/17/busin.snippet: Some big insurers, alarmed by research showing that sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks are inflicting unusually costly harm to cars and their occupants in collisions, are raising liability rates on oversize vehicles in what could amount to l...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/17/busin.main_headline: BIG INSURERS PLAN TO INCREASE RATES ON LARGE VEHICLES
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/17/busin.print_headline: BIG INSURERS PLAN TO INCREASE RATES ON LARGE VEHICLES
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/17/busin.body_text: **********Alarmed by research showing that sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks are inflicting unusually costly harm to cars and their occupants in collisions, some big insurers are raising liability rates on the oversize vehicles in what could amount to the largest overhaul of liability coverage since the rise of no-fault laws a quarter-century ago. **********To convince auto makers that such vehicles must be modified to make them less dangerous, the insurers are also bankrolling new studies and planning an ambitious series of crash tests. **********For motorists, the pocketbook effects of the overhaul of insurance rates could prove startling: a liability rate increase of up to 20 percent for drivers of sport utility vehicles and pickups over the next several years and a cut of up to 10 percent for car owners. That will likely mean an extra $50 to $700 a year in liability insurance payments for the first group, depending on current rates, and a saving of $25 to $350 for car owners. **********Two of the nation's largest insurers, Farmers Insurance Group and the Progressive Corporation, have already begun changing the way they calculate their rates. Executives at Allstate, Nationwide, Geico and USAA said they were reviewing the issue but were unlikely to make any decisions until they had more data, including broad studies by industry groups that will not be completed until next spring. **********Actuaries for Farmers and Progressive said that the reason for their rate moves was simple: Their customers who drive sport utility vehicles and pickups have been incurring unusually expensive claims to cover the damage and injuries they inflict during accidents. Rather than continuing to spread the extra cost among all drivers, including car owners, these insurers are starting to set rates accordingly. **********''It's pretty obvious the size and weight of these vehicles and the way they're built is contributing to the loss experience,'' said Jonathan Adkisson, an actuary at Farmers, a unit of B.A.T. Industries and the nation's third-largest insurer after State Farm and Allstate. ''When an accident occurs, the heavier vehicles are more likely to inflict damage and injuries, and these result in larger claims, so it seems appropriate to charge the drivers of those vehicles higher premiums.'' **********The biggest sport utility vehicles, like the Ford Expedition and the Chevrolet Suburban, weigh 5,200 to 6,000 pounds, while midsize sedans typically weigh 2,900 to 3,300 pounds. Sport utility vehicles also ride higher off the ground, so they tend to override the occupant protection features of cars and tend to have stiff frames that crumple the other vehicle in crashes. **********Liability coverage applies only to property damage and injuries caused to others by the policyholder. Rates for collision coverage, which applies to repairs of a policyholder's own vehicle, already take into account the fact that sport utility vehicles and pickups suffer less damage in crashes. **********Separate rates to cover the policyholder's injuries generally do not take into account the extra protection that these bigger vehicles provide to their occupants but are beginning to do so. But adjustments to this coverage offset only a small part of the extra liability cost. **********Indeed, if the full liability rate increase goes into effect, drivers of sport utility vehicles and pickups will be paying substantially larger total insurance bills. **********Two groups in Washington, financed by most of the nation's insurers, are working on studies that will include 6 to 10 crash tests pitting sport utility vehicles against cars. The tests are partly intended to put pressure on Federal regulators, who have repeatedly postponed such studies. Regulators have just begun planning six crash tests, which will begin this winter. **********Two crash tests already conducted in Europe by independent researchers found that sport utility vehicles, because of their height and weight, caused substantial damage to cars' passenger compartments. **********The insurers want auto makers to design vehicles that are more compatible in crashes, said Brian O'Neill, president of the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety and the Highway Loss Data Institute, the Washington groups conducting the studies. ''We need the manufacturers to say, 'Wait a minute, what happens when the Ford Expedition hits the Ford Escort,' '' he said. The controversy over the safety of air bags had distracted insurers until recently from the more important safety issue of sport utility vehicles, he added. **********Auto industry executives say they are constantly conducting research into ways to reduce the damage their products inflict -- indeed, Ford has long been Detroit's leader on many safety issues. But they also contend that some incompatibility is inevitable because Americans want a range of vehicle sizes. Helen Petrauskas, Ford's vice president for environmental and safety engineering, said that higher rates of seat belt use and reductions in drunken driving could yield greater safety gains than design changes in sport utility vehicles. **********While the number of very large sport utility vehicles is rising especially quickly, the likelihood that any single big sport utility vehicle will kill a car occupant is falling, according to new research by Ford. It attributes the improvement partly to greater use of seat belts and air bags, partly to better-designed cars and partly to a shift in who drives sport utility vehicles. Suburban families are increasingly replacing single men as owners. **********But what is particularly interesting about the Farmers and Progressive research is that unlike that of Ford, the insurers were able to take into account differences in driver age, sex, location and previous driving record. And what the insurers have found is further evidence of a safety problem: that the same driver will inflict considerably greater damage and injuries when driving a sport utility of almost any size than when driving a car. **********The industry research groups headed by Mr. O'Neill are conducting further studies. The safety institute intends to release a statistical study this fall of the death toll inflicted by sport utility vehicles and pickups. In a separate study next spring, the safety institute plans up to 10 crash tests. **********The data institute is drafting a third study, scheduled for release next April, that will look at insurers' costs to repair vehicles hit by sport utility vehicles and pickups. **********Kim Hazelbaker, the institute's senior vice president, who is overseeing the study, said that his initial computer data had already showed a significant problem that was likely to provoke industry action. The institute had earlier found that property damage liability costs for insurers from accidents involving large sport utility vehicles were 72 percent higher than for the average car. By contrast, property damage caused by large luxury cars was 19 percent below the average. **********The institute first studied the issue in 1994. But most insurers showed limited interest, Mr. Hazelbaker said, until sales of the biggest sport utility vehicles began surging a year ago and until a series of articles in The New York Times over the last seven months described the dangers that the bigger vehicles pose. **********Progressive actually began making slight adjustments to liability rates by vehicle model in the 1980's, and it has been moving to much larger adjustments over the last two years as the range of family vehicles on the road has widened. It now calculates liability rates based on a motorist's age, driving record and other variables and then increases the total by up to 20 percent for the bigger and most dangerous sport utility vehicles and pickups and by roughly 8 percent for smaller models. It subtracts 10 percent for the least dangerous car models. **********But Progressive has long been a maverick in the collegial insurance industry. Much more significant is the fact that before Farmers Insurance entered the Pennsylvania market last month, it quietly chose for the first time to file a rate schedule with regulators that adjusts liability  premiums by vehicle model. The move by Farmers puts pressure on existing insurers in Pennsylvania to follow suit; their alternative is to risk losing car owners who could find a better deal at Farmers while being stuck with less profitable drivers of sport utility vehicles. **********It is not clear how fast competition will force insurers nationwide to adjust liability rates by model. Insurers have been reluctant to move quickly -- even Farmers has not decided to act in its more established markets. Calculating such rates can be expensive, requiring the training of agents and the reprogramming of computers. An insurer that imposes big rate increases for sport utility vehicles could also drive many customers to rivals that do not raise rates. Insurers, performing similar calculations to those Progressive has made, are likely to make comparable rate adjustments, as Farmers has already done in Pennsylvania. **********Adjusting rates by vehicle would be the biggest change in automotive liability insurance since no-fault laws became popular in some states a quarter-century ago, said Howard L. Cohen, vice president for actuarial research at Geico. No-fault laws tend to make liability insurance less expensive but do not eliminate it. **********Only one big insurer is actively hostile to adjusting liability rates by model: State Farm, the industry leader with 18.8 percent of the market. Dale Nelson, a State Farm actuary, said the insurer tracked its combined bodily injury and property damage liability costs by model and had found higher costs only for large pickup trucks, which it has not bothered to reflect in its rates. **********But State Farm's experience often differs from other insurers because it has an unusual number of older, rural customers. And Mr. Nelson's views offer little reassurance for car drivers: sport utility vehicles may actually save insurers money in a few accidents, he said, by killing people who might otherwise have survived with serious injuries. Severe injuries tend to produce larger settlements than deaths, he explained. **********The Allstate Insurance Group is more interested in adjusting liability rates. ''What I would envision is a liability system that varies rates more finely by make and model,'' said Michael A. LaMonica, Allstate's vice president for automotive insurance pricing. **********The industry's trade groups are convinced that liability rates by model are almost inevitable. Sean Mooney, chief economist of the Insurance Information Institute in New York, said that the growing power of computers made it easier to calculate rates based on more variables and that competition forced insurers to use such calculations. **********Since the 1970's, insurers have been using vehicle model data to calculate rates for theft and collision insurance. Sport utility vehicles are so sturdily built and so heavy that they suffer relatively little damage in crashes, and this is reflected in generally lower collision rates for them. Because liability rates are not similarly adjusted, the overall cost of insuring a sport utility vehicle can actually be cheaper now than insuring a similarly priced car. **********Most insurers also do not adjust their rates by vehicle model for personal injury insurance, which covers some initial expenses for injuries suffered by a policyholder during an accident. Because occupants in sport utility vehicles and pickups suffer slightly fewer injuries in accidents, Farmers offers them a lower rate for this coverage in Pennsylvania and Progressive does so nationwide. But the reduction offsets only a small fraction of the higher liability rates imposed by those companies because personal injury coverage does not include pain and suffering payments or legal fees and thus is much cheaper than liability coverage. Only 40 percent of all insured motorists nationwide take personal injury insurance because it is required by just 13 states, including New York, and often overlaps with employer-provided health care policies. **********Rather than calculate liability rates by model, many insurers have been relying instead on rules of thumb that were developed decades ago. Allstate, for instance, gives a 10 percent discount on bodily injury and property damage liability rates for subcompact cars weighing less than 2,100 pounds because lighter vehicles do less damage in collisions. But Allstate does not charge extra for sport utility vehicles that weigh three times as much. **********The Insurance Services Office, which is owned mainly by 643 small insurers and helps them calculate rates, uses an equally outdated system. It has five broad categories based on the ratio of a vehicle's weight to horsepower, a system calculated in the 1970's to penalize sports cars that are lightweight but very powerful. But that formula now puts sport utility vehicles in the best category for liability insurance because of their weight. **********''The system just doesn't work anymore,'' said Chris Guidette, a spokesman for the Insurance Services Office, adding that the office plans to begin computer analyses soon to develop a better system. **********The question now is whether higher rates will affect the sale of sport utility vehicles. When insurers raised collision rates for so-called muscle cars in the 1970's, sales slumped. **********But buyers of sport utility vehicles are often so prosperous that they may not notice the extra cost. The typical Chevrolet Suburban buyer now earns more than the typical Cadillac buyer, while the average household buying a Range Rover or Lexus LX450 earns $360,000 a year. **********To leave the rates as is, however, could open the insurance industry to criticism, Mr. Mooney said. Flat liability rates tend to put an unfair burden on lower-income car drivers, who are in effect subsidizing the affluent owners of sport utility vehicles, he said. **********''That's an issue that we certainly have to look at,'' Allstate's Mr. LaMonica said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/27/world.snippet: Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel lashes out at Pres Clinton, declaring that entire Jewish state felt humiliated by his refusal to meet with him during recent visit to US; calls Clinton's action unbecoming; White House denies snub was intende...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/27/world.main_headline: Netanyahu Says Clinton's Refusal to Meet Him 'Humiliated' Israel
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/27/world.print_headline: Netanyahu Says Clinton's Refusal to Meet Him 'Humiliated' Israel
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/27/world.body_text: **********Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel lashed out at President Clinton today, declaring that ''the entire Jewish state feels humiliated'' by Mr. Clinton's refusal to meet him during Mr. Netanyahu's visit to the United States last week. **********''It's unbecoming,'' Mr. Netanyahu said of Mr. Clinton's action in a CNN interview in Jerusalem. ''It doesn't befit nations who are allies and even doesn't befit nations who are not allies, and I believe that the United States probably would agree with me if they thought about it.'' **********The Prime Minister's anger reflected the current tension between his Government and the United States over the lack of progress toward a lasting Middle East peace. **********The tension comes as the United States tries to hold together the coalition that defeated Iraq's forces in the gulf war in 1991. Some Arab nations in the coalition declined to attend a recent Middle East economic conference as a protest against the stall in the Arab-Israeli peace talks. **********In today's interview, the Prime Minister's anger flared when he was asked, ''Do you believe the President of the United States is trying to humiliate you?'' **********Laboring for a moment over his words, Mr. Netanyahu said: ''No Prime Minister of Israel is humiliated personally. All insults are directed to the office of the Prime Minister of the state of Israel, and the entire Jewish state feels humiliated if such action is directed against us.'' **********Hours before the interview, the White House spokesman, Michael D. McCurry, said at a routine briefing that, Middle East news accounts to the contrary, no snub had been intended. Tonight, the White House said it was not prepared to comment on Mr. Netanyahu's latest remarks. And The Jerusalem Post reported Wednesday that the Israeli Embassy in Washington had been instructed to stop trying to arrange a meeting between the two men. **********Just before Mr. Netanyahu's visit, where the Prime Minister appeared before Jewish groups in Los Angeles and Indianapolis, the White House said scheduling problems would prevent Mr. Clinton from meeting him, and that no snub was intended. **********But that explanation did not convince many diplomats. For one thing, the paths of Mr. Clinton and Mr. Netanyahu practically crossed in Los Angeles. And Mr. Clinton did find time the week before to visit King Hussein while the Jordanian leader was in the Mayo Clinic in Minnesota for tests.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/30/busin.snippet: Ukraine's new prime minister, Valeri Pustovoitenko, was appointed late in July by President Leonid Kuchma, the latest in a succession of five politicians to take on the job.Charged with kick-starting lagging reforms, boosting foreign investment fr...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/30/busin.main_headline: ECONOMIC SCENE : Ukraine Tries Again to Free Economy
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/30/busin.print_headline: ECONOMIC SCENE : Ukraine Tries Again to Free Economy
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/30/busin.body_text: **********Ukraine's new prime minister, Valeri Pustovoitenko, was appointed late in July by President Leonid Kuchma, the latest in a succession of five politicians to take on the job.Charged with kick-starting lagging reforms, boosting foreign investment from its current, derisory level of $1.2 billion and encouraging growth, he faces an uphill task. **********"Europe's biggest unexplored market," to quote the phrase used by the official literature, has disappointed investors on almost all scores. After six years of independence, growth is still negative while privatization has moved at a snail's pace. **********July saw some positive developments. Observers were encouraged by the resignation of the reform-averse prime minister, Pavlo Lazarenko. The state budget was finally passed, albeit seven months late. **********Yet, Ukraine has yet to attract significant amounts of large-scale foreign investment since the demise of the Soviet Union. The situation has slightly improved over the course of this year, reflecting low inflation and a committee established with foreign investors to monitor financial conditions in the country. **********The weak attraction for investors is harming the country's economic development. **********"In Ukraine, this is where reform progress has been weakest," said Michael Friedlander, head of economic research at Nomura International in London. "Foreign investment aids restructuring and the development of export-orientatedindustries." **********Nomura two weeks ago underwrote a $450 million one-year note for Ukraine in the country's debut on the international bond market, and the issue has done well. It was sold at a yield of about 9.44 percent and ended this week at 8.80 percent, illustrating some investor confidence. **********But more typical of Ukraine's recent history was Motorola Inc.'s March decision to withdraw from a potentially lucrative satellite-communications deal, blaming an unstable business environment. Foreign investors are accustomed to red tape, paying kickbacks and retroactive legislation, but the biggest problem, several said, is Ukraine's illogical and onerous tax system. **********The system allows authorities to demand levies well in excess of 100 percent, often retroactively and without warning. Businesses that the tax system has not discouraged or pushed into bankruptcy have instead been pushed underground. **********"When transition started in Ukraine, the shadow economy was around 12 percent of GDP. Today, it is at least 50 percent and maybe even more," said Daniel Kaufmann, former World Bank representative in Kiev, now with the Harvard Institute of International Development. **********Despite widespread recognition of the problem, the Parliament (the Rada) has rebuffed attempts to reform the tax system. **********At the beginning of the year, then Deputy Prime Minister Viktor Pyznenek presented a package to the Rada that he said would lower the burden, simplify collection and thus actually increase the overall tax take. **********Four months later, in April, he resigned in protest at the Rada's failure to pass the bill. In late June, the Rada finally passed the reform, in a watered-down version, with only two of the original 11 proposals going through. The remaining nine are to be discussed in the coming month. **********What astounds observers is that the Rada's resistance to the reform has persisted despite warnings that the economy faces negative growth this year and in 1998 following last year's 10 percent contraction in gross domestic product. **********In a study that incorporates findings taken from a representative survey of 50 firms in Kiev and Lvov, Mr. Kaufmann argues that Ukraine's tax and import duty regime have bred systematic misreporting. **********Firms typically "hide" 40 percent of their profits, over-report their costs by 135 percent and, thanks to onerous payroll taxes, which include both social security contributions and a special Chernobyl tax, under-report their payroll by 51 percent. **********Mr. Kaufmann suggests that high taxes explain Ukraine's poor record in attracting foreign investment, and the Finance Ministry's inability to meet revenue targets, thanks to a "Laffer-curve effect." **********Almost as bad news is the amount of time the bureaucracy requires companies to spend dealing with it over matters such as licenses and paperwork **********Mr. Kaufmann's sample found that over 1996, companies spent an astonishing 40 percent of the working day dealing with officials, 10 percent more than in 1995. This compares with 30 percent in Russia, but only 15 percent in Lithuania and a mere 8 percent in another developing market a continent away: El Salvador. **********Given such figures, it seems hardly surprising that private enterprise prefers to exist in the shadows, where at least it will know how much protection money must be paid to organized crime. **********Yet, the effect of a sustained gray economy is significant. **********Not only do these companies not contribute to tax revenue but, because they do not officially exist, they also cannot borrow from legitimate sources and cannot, therefore, grow. This, in turn, impacts on Ukraine's long-term development and undermines growth prospects.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/31/busin.snippet: Many America Online customers remain angry, saying refunds could hardly make up for their lost business and time; some customers are particularly irked by inadequate staffing of telephone lines America Online set up to handle refund requests; comp...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/31/busin.main_headline: On-Line Ire Is Not Pacified By Agreement
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/31/busin.print_headline: On-Line Ire Is Not Pacified By Agreement
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/31/busin.body_text: **********One day after the nation's largest provider of cyberspace services, America Online Inc., agreed to pay millions of dollars to compensate subscribers for two months of network congestion, many customers refused to be mollified yesterday, saying that the refunds could hardly make up for their lost business and time. **********Some customers said that America Online added insult to injury by inadequately staffing the telephone lines it set up to handle refund requests, leading to confusing journeys through touch-tone telephone systems and long waits on hold. And others said that America Online's policy of giving the largest refunds, about $40, to the smallest users was unfair to those who had suffered the most. **********''I think it's a great public relations move,'' said Conan S. Cocallas of Fairfield, Calif., who blames a recent inability to get through to the service for costing his small computer-parts supply company a $3,000 order. ''But there is really no way to compensate for time lost. For people whose businesses rely on it, there's no way to say, 'We're going to give you back all that time you wasted listening to busy signals in front of your computer.' I just want it fixed.'' **********But Stephen M. Case, the chairman of America Online, said: ''The feedback I got today from members was favorable. People wanted to know what steps we were going to take to satisfy our customers and we told them.'' **********Even some of the most critical customers said they would stick with the service until the network logjam had been cleared. The company has promised to spend $350 million to increase capacity and has said the problems will be resolved by June. America Online, which is based in Dulles, Va., and surpassed eight million subscribers last week, reached the pact with the attorneys general of 36 states on Wednesday after the prosecutors threatened to sue the company for deceptive business practices. Moving away from charging users for each hour spent on line, the company began offering -- and aggressively promoting -- a new price plan early last month that promised unlimited access to the service for $19.95 a month. **********But the company seemed to underestimate both existing users' appetite for on-line time and the number of new customers the offer would attract -- 1.4 million since last October. By the middle of last month, many America Online subscribers faced interminable busy signals whenever they tried to dial into the service with their computer modems. **********America Online still offers hourly rates, but the company said a vast majority of its customers now subscribed to the unlimited-use plan. **********Under the agreement the attorneys general will not file lawsuits against America Online. In exchange, the company will give subscribers who request it compensation ranging from a full, $19.95 refund for customers who used the service for less than two hours during either December or January to a 25 percent, $5 rebate for users who spent between 8 and 15 hours in either month on line. The company has said that the settlement will cost less than $50 million. **********Customers who spent more than 15 hours on America Online in either December or January are not eligible for a refund for that month, though all customers can choose to receive a free month of service if they write to an address in Utah. **********That satisfied the attorneys general but was an affront to some America Online subscribers. **********''Nonsense. Total nonsense,'' said Peter J. Magliarditi, describing the deal. Mr. Magliarditi, an independent researcher in Lewiston, N.Y., is seeking class-action status in Federal District Court in Buffalo along with 100 other America Online customers for a lawsuit against the company for breach of warranty. ''They are punishing the people who tried the hardest to get on line by giving them no refund,'' he said. **********But Mr. Case defended the refund plan as fair. ''The sense was that for someone who used 100 hours in a month, a refund was less appropriate than for someone who used 10 minutes in a month,'' he said. ''The principle that has been guiding our thinking all along was that we've spent a decade building this brand and we want to do everything necessary to protect it and enhance it.'' **********That thinking appeared to please investors -- shares of America Online closed up 62.5 cents, at $37.875, on the New York Stock Exchange, after a big increase on Wednesday -- but did not go over well with Roberta Rosenfield, a retired schoolteacher in Nanuet, N.Y., who has subscribed to America Online for two years. **********''I called the number they gave and held on for 40 minutes,'' she said. ''It's a mess. During those 40 minutes they repeated a list of 15 other numbers to call for this or that. I tried one or two but didn't get anywhere. **********''We just want to get our money back.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/27/busin.snippet: At heart of Justice Dept's suit against Microsoft is question of what features belong in computer operating system; outcome could have far-reaching impact on software industry, especially on Microsoft's fundamental strategies for enhancing Windows...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/27/busin.main_headline: Fight Tests Boundaries On Software Operations
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/27/busin.print_headline: Fight Tests Boundaries On Software Operations
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/27/busin.body_text: **********At the heart of the Justice Department's latest beef with the Microsoft Corporation is a question that constantly plagues the software industry: Just what features do belong in a computer operating system? **********What the Justice Department decides could have a far-reaching impact, not only on the software industry as it struggles to improve the Internet experience, but on Microsoft's fundamental strategies for enhancing Windows with an ever-expanding array of new functions and for securing its near monopoly in the operating system market. **********In its complaint filed last week, the Justice Department accused Microsoft of using its dominance of the operating systems market to force computer makers to include Microsoft's Internet Explorer Web browser on their machines. The terms of a 1995 Justice Department decree forbid Microsoft from tying the licensing of one product to another. **********Microsoft executives counter that Internet Explorer, a World Wide Web navigation program, is not a separate product from Windows 95, but an improvement to it, even though the two are often purchased separately. Web navigation, the company argues, is an extension of the Internet access already in the operating system. **********''Our success comes from being able to innovate in all these directions,'' Brad Chase, a Microsoft vice president, said. ''Telling us we can't improve Windows is telling us we can't compete.'' **********Next year, the company intends to dramatize this point further with the next major release of the operating system, Windows 98, which fully integrates Internet Explorer. Microsoft officials argue that it is not possible for the industry to establish solid boundaries between functions that belong in the computer's operating system and those that belong only in other applications, like a Web browser. At a conference last week, Microsoft's chairman, William H. Gates, indicated the company had no intention of changing, describing several further planned enhancements. **********Those include speech recognition, allowing the computer user to operate the computer with voice commands, and ''machine vision,'' -- the computer's ability to recognize a particular user and respond to his behavior and expressions. **********For Richard Gilbert, a professor of economics at the University of California at Berkeley, the issue comes down to how much usefulness a particular feature adds to the operating system, and how broadly it will be used. He compared it with the Justice Department's investigation long ago of the Chrysler Corporation for requiring customers to buy a radio with every new car. Now consumers expect a radio in every new car. **********''Microsoft is kind of like Chrysler then,'' said Professor Gilbert, who was chief economist in the Justice Department during the investigation of Microsoft that led to the signing of the consent decree in 1995. He added, ''Antitrust law is about protecting consumers, not protecting rivals.'' **********Professor Gilbert said he expected the Justice Department's complaint to be decided narrowly, on the straightforward issue of whether Microsoft violated the decree by coercing its licensees. The issue of whether the company has the right to incorporate previously separate functions into its operating system will meet the test at a later point, he said, adding, ''I don't think we should build a case against Microsoft simply because they're able to build a Web browser into their operating system and provide more functionality.'' **********Not everyone agrees. Edward J. Black, president and chief executive of the Computer and Communications Industry Association, said the industry was capable of defining the boundaries of an operating system. **********''The idea that the operating system can be this huge, constantly expanding bubble goes against what most people view as what an operating system needs to do,'' he said. **********Granted, Microsoft has a long history of taking features that were once the basis of distinct software programs and absorbing them into its operating system. Today from within Windows 95, for example, computer users can send a fax, compress files, send E-mail messages and write simple documents. Not  long ago, each of these functions required the user to buy a freestanding software program. **********In many cases, Microsoft's enhancements to the operating system led to the demise of software providers, third-party markets. **********But Microsoft officials have long argued that enhancing the operating system benefits customers. ''To remain competitive in software, you have to add new stuff, new functionality,'' said Stewart Alsop of New Enterprise Associates, a venture capital firm in Menlo Park, Calif. **********But, he added, ''The fact that this issue now exists in the open makes it tempting to think of Microsoft as either right or wrong,'' Mr. Alsop said. ''The truth is this is a gray area.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/16/busin.snippet: Floyd Norris comment on battle for control of Student Loan Marketing Assn; scores management's refusal to let shareholders elect new board while voting on privatization plan they must approve to keep quasi-public firm from being phased out; notes ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/16/busin.main_headline: Owners Get Short Shrift at Sallie Mae
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/16/busin.print_headline: Owners Get Short Shrift at Sallie Mae
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/16/busin.body_text: **********Proxy fights are a rarity in American business, in part because they cost so much to wage. But when they do take place, everyone agrees that it is, in the end, up to the shareholders to decide who should run the company they own. **********But that's not the case in one of the most fascinating battles for corporate control now being fought. That battle is taking place at the Student Loan Marketing Association, better known as Sallie Mae, which is in the process of converting from a Government-sponsored enterprise to a completely private company. **********As a result of that unusual status, Sallie Mae now has a board that includes members never elected by the shareholders. Also as a result of that status, the current battle is not subject to regulation by the Securities and Exchange Commission, which probably would not stand for the tactics being used to entrench management. **********Sallie Mae has led an exciting life since President Clinton was elected. He proposed having the Government make direct loans to students, thus effectively cutting out Sallie Mae, which buys such loans from banks. The stock plunged, and then fell further when 1994 profits were disappointing. **********In 1994, a management-suite dispute resulted in the departure of the chief operating officer, Albert A. Lord, leaving the company's chief executive, Lawrence A. Hough, solidly in control. Then, in 1995, Mr. Lord and a slate of his associates waged a bitter proxy fight. After the court battles were through, Mr. Lord and seven associates were elected. But Mr. Hough had the support of six directors chosen by shareholders and of seven additional members appointed by President Clinton. So he kept control without the support of most holders. **********Last year, everyone was content to keep the status quo, and there was no proxy battle. The company made progress, thanks to cost-cutting and other moves, for which both sides take credit. And then, in September, Congress approved a bill allowing the company to be privatized, assuming a plan is approved by shareholders and directors by March 1998. If not, the company will be phased out. That, it appears, would be a disaster for shareholders. **********Now we have the company's plan, which shareholders will vote on in May. The plan contains all kinds of anti-takeover provisions and would establish a new board. The dissidents are not to be on that board (they were offered 2 of 18 seats, but turned them down). There is to be no election for the board, just a vote on approving the reorganization plan. **********If the plan is approved, there will be no shareholder vote on directors in 1997, and in 1998 only a third of the board will be up. So dissidents -- who won the last contested shareholder vote -- could not conceivably take control until 1999. And maybe not then. The plan would let the board enlarge itself and appoint new members, who might still have a majority even after two elections. **********Mr. Lord's group is trying to get holders to schedule another meeting, but it is unclear when such a meeting would be held or what it could accomplish, just as it is unclear whether the board would amend its plan even if shareholders were in rebellion. **********This battle looks like a grab for power, on both sides. And the ones to decide the victor ought to be the shareholders. By arranging things so that shareholders can vote only on on a needed reorganization plan, and not on directors, the board has struck a blow against democracy. **********It may be legal. But it isn't right.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/24/busin.snippet: Copper prices rise for fifth day on Comex division of New York Mercantile Exchange as strike at Escondida copper mine in Chile, world's largest, slows copper output at a time of dwindling inventories (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/24/busin.main_headline: Copper Prices Rise a 5th Day As Chile Strike Slows Output
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/24/busin.print_headline: Copper Prices Rise a 5th Day As Chile Strike Slows Output
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/24/busin.body_text: **********Copper prices rose yesterday for a fifth day on the Comex division of the New York Mercantile Exchange as a strike at the Escondida copper mine in Chile, the world's largest, slowed copper output at a time of dwindling inventories. **********On other markets, wheat prices fell **********Escondida miners were scheduled to vote yesterday on the same pay proposal that the company offered when the strike began on Friday, according to union officials. **********Concern is mounting that a continuing impasse will further reduce Escondida's operations, which are already 40 to 85 percent of normal, union and company estimates say. **********The drop in output comes at a time when stockpiles of the London Metal Exchange copper have fallen for nine consecutive weeks, reaching 149,100 metric tons, less than half the levels of a year ago. A metric ton is 1.1 tons. **********''All the news at the moment hints at supply disruptions,'' said Malcolm Freeman, a trader at GNI Ltd. in New York. ''At the same time, London Metal Exchange copper stockpiles are very low and there's very good demand. Copper could just run and run at the moment.'' **********In New York, copper for May delivery rose 2.9 cents, to $1.128 a pound, the highest since March 31. **********Wheat dropped as rains on crops in Europe eased concern that recent dry weather would damage plants and reduce production in one of the world's largest growing regions. **********July soft red winter wheat fell 11.25 cents, to $4.3575 a bushel, on the Chicago Board of Trade. **********Light rain fell on southern England yesterday and rain is forecast for the major growing regions of Britain and France through the weekend, the Weather Services Corporation of Lexington, Mass., said. **********The rain is bringing much needed moisture to Britain and France, where rainfall in growing regions since March 1 was running at a third or less of normal, said Joel Burgio, a Weather Services meteorologist. The two countries grow more than half of the wheat produced by the European Union, the world's top exporter. **********Reduced crops in Europe would come at a time of record global wheat consumption and dwindling United States reserves.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/26/busin.print_headline: EARNING IT; That Unwritten Code Against Fraternization
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/26/busin.body_text: **********IN the 1980's it was rumors -- repeatedly denied -- of an office affair between the then Bendix Corporation chairman, William Agee, and his aide, Mary Cunningham, that resulted in headlines and led to the resignation of Ms. Cunningham. Last week, the scandal involved Martin E. Hanaka, the president of Staples Inc., who resigned after a subordinate accused him of assaulting her during an argument after what the company described as a ''personal relationship'' between the two. **********The company concluded that Mr. Hanaka had violated its ''fraternization policy,'' prohibiting managers from having a personal or romantic relationship with a subordinate, a Staples spokeswoman said. **********Mr. Hanaka declined to discuss the matter, but a spokeswoman has been quoted as saying there was no romantic relationship. **********Almost as surprising as the public resignation and accusation against Mr. Hanaka is the fact that Staples, founded in 1986, had a written policy on what is forbidden. **********The military, as Americans have learned, has rigorous rules against fraternization, but most civilian concerns lack any written policy, according to experts in the field. In an informal survey of a half-dozen of the nation's biggest companies, only two -- General Motors and Wal-Mart -- said they had a written policy on employee fraternization, although three reported less formal rules. **********A 1994 survey by the American Management Association, an organization with 10,000 corporate members, found that only 6 percent of those responding had a written policy on employee dating. **********''I think some companies are afraid to delve into this tricky area and are afraid of offending employees and afraid of lawsuits,'' said Michael D. Karpeles, lead employment lawyer at a Chicago law firm, Goldberg, Kohn, Bell, Black, Rosenbloom & Moritz. ''I think the employees rightly or wrongly will think that the company is trying to intrude into their private lives.'' **********AT&T used to have a written policy discouraging dating between any employees, said Burke Stinson, senior public relations manager there. But that was discarded in 1984. ''The idea shifted from this regimented approach to one of benign neglect,'' he said. Now, the company has an informal, unwritten policy that applies only to supervisors, who are made to understand that dating subordinates is a problem, which is resolved by a transfer, not a dismissal. **********Whether companies need such policies depends on whom you ask. Mr. Karpeles said companies should, in writing, ban relationships between a supervisor and a subordinate. Such relationships can call the manager's judgment into question and create morale problems because other employees suspect that the boss is showing favoritism. **********He said that if such a relationship soured, it could open up the company to accusations of sexual harassment. And, of course, sexual harassment can exist even if there is no romantic involvement. **********According to the American Management Association survey, one-third of the men and 15 percent of the women who reported having an office romance said they had had one with a subordinate. Over all, 37 percent the women said they had had an office romance, compared with only 20 percent of the men. **********Mr. Karpeles doesn't recommend forcing out either love-struck offender. Instead, he suggests transferring one of them or at least having an objective supervisor evaluate the subordinate's performance. **********That seems to be the tack followed at General Electric. The company has no written policy dealing with fraternization, said Bruce Bunch, a company spokesman. But, he added: ''Our practice is, where we are aware of a personal relationship between two employees, we take steps to insure that one does not supervise the other. We want to make sure it's very clear that at G.E. recommendations about salary and promotions are based solely on job performance.'' **********Other companies sometimes rely on quiet persuasion to end an affair involving an executive. Mr. Karpeles tells of the chairman at a Chicago-area company who had a little talk with the president to let him know his affair had become an issue in the office and to ask him to think about whether this was good for the company. The president, Mr. Karpeles said, ended the relationship. **********In-house romances that involve adultery are especially disconcerting to companies, said Kathleen Reardon, a management professor at the University of Southern California and author of a book about men and women in the workplace, ''They Don't Get It, Do They?'' (Little, Brown $12.95). She said companies were often reluctant to accuse someone of adultery without proof and were even more unwilling to get that proof. Instead, she said, the employee might be told, ''It's your life but that doesn't go down well with people upstairs around here.'' **********Companies have to be careful about singling out married workers for discipline, Mr. Karpeles added, because most states have laws prohibiting discrimination on the basis of marital status. Any nonfraternization rules must apply equally to single lovers and married ones, he said. **********Both Mr. Karpeles and Dr. Reardon said companies tended to simply leave amorous employees alone unless a supervisory relationship was involved. Less than 1 percent of the executives in the 1994 survey said their companies banned all employee dating. And 74 percent said they thought it was O.K. to date a co-worker, although only 21 percent approved of dating a subordinate. **********As more women work alongside men and employees pull longer hours, affairs are bound to occur, Mr. Karpeles said. A rule designed to stamp them out would be ''laughably unreal,'' he said. ''You can't stop love.'' **********Then, of course, there is the prospect of a counterattack from the outcast lovebirds. Wal-Mart was sued in 1993 by a couple found to be dating while one was still married, albeit separated. The New York Attorney General weighed in with a second suit, contending that Wal-Mart's action violated a state law prohibiting businesses from dismissing employees for lawful activities occurring outside the workplace. Both suits were later dismissed. **********In the Silicon Valley, Lawrence J. Ellison, head of the Oracle Corporation, dated an Oracle administrative assistant, Adelyn Lee, for about 18 months starting in 1991. She was dismissed, and filed a suit contending wrongful termination, saying she had been bullied into having sex. **********Mr. Ellison testified that he had a sexual relationship with Ms. Lee, but said he did not order her fired. **********Oracle agreed to pay Ms. Lee $100,000 in her wrongful-termination case, and she agreed to retract her accusations. But in a twist, she was later convicted of perjury and falsifying documents for sending a phony E-mail message to help in her suit. She was sentenced to a year in prison and ordered to return the $100,000. An appeal has been filed, and the case is pending. **********John Challenger, executive vice president of the outplacement firm Challenger, Gray & Christmas, said his company handles about a dozen cases annually in which a manager has been pushed out after an affair with a subordinate. **********He said companies sometimes rethink dismissing the subordinate, who is usually a woman. Worried about sexual harassment suits, ''They end up backtracking and trying to keep the person,'' he said.
