https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/17/busin.body_text: **********Avenor Inc. of Montreal said yesterday that it would sell its 53 percent stake in Pacific Forest Products Ltd. for $573 million (Canadian), or $418 million (United States). Under the agreement, TimberWest Forest Holdings, a logging company in Vancouver, British Columbia, and Avenor's partner in the venture, will offer $29 (Canadian), or $21.18 (United States), a share for Pacific's stock. TimberWest will own all of Pacific's timberlands, consisting of 308,750 acres, which are mainly on Vancouver Island. As part of the same transaction, Doman Industries, based in Duncan, British Columbia, agreed to buy three sawmills and other assets from the venture for $144 million (Canadian), or $105.2 million (United States).

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/24/world.snippet: Vice Pres Al Gore, visiting Russia, seeks to nudge issues toward resolution in approach aimed at avoiding open confrontation and minimizing risk of embarrassing failure; his aides insist approach is key to forging effective ties; incremental strat...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/24/world.main_headline: Diplomacy, Gore-Style, Is a Study In 'Process'
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/24/world.print_headline: Diplomacy, Gore-Style, Is a Study In 'Process'
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/24/world.body_text: **********After days of closed talks about the obstacles facing American oil companies in Russia, Vice President Al Gore and Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin announced a decision: They agreed to work on the problems over the next two months. **********From the moment Mr. Gore arrived in Russia, his strategy has been to nudge issues toward resolution. It is a deliberate approach that avoids open confrontation and minimizes the risk of embarrassing failure. **********Aides insist that Mr. Gore's workmanlike approach is vital to forging effective relations with the Russians. But it also makes Mr. Gore appear a less than dashing figure at a time when he is trying to demonstrate his skills as a statesman. **********If Mr. Gore had a favorite word this week it has been ''process.'' The two sides established a ''process'' for discussing American complaints that Russian scientists are selling missile technology to Iran, Mr. Gore noted proudly. They set up a ''process'' for airing their disagreements over a new bill that protects the Russian Orthodox Church from competition with other Christian faiths. And that was before tonight's ''process'' on oil investment disputes. **********To be sure, some of these processes have eventually yielded results. The two sides, for example, sealed an agreement today to halt the production of weapons-grade plutonium in Russia. **********Russia had agreed in 1994 to shut down three nuclear reactors used to heat the Siberian cities of Tomsk and Krasnoyarsk because of United States concerns that the plants also produce plutonium that can be used to make nuclear weapons. But Moscow later concluded that it could not carry out its pledge because it lacked the money to construct non-nuclear power plants. **********Under the new accord, the Russians will continue to operate the reactors but will convert them so that the plutonium they produce is not weapons-grade. The United States will pay the $70 million cost and the work is to be completed by 2000. American officials had hoped to sign the agreement months ago, but it was held up by bureaucratic snags within the Russian Government. **********But some emotionally charged disputes may not lend themselves to Mr. Gore's incremental approach. **********Mr. Gore criticized the religion bill passed by the lower house of Parliament on Friday, saying that it discriminated against minority religious groups. He stressed that American and Russian experts would get together to discuss the bill and how it might be changed. **********''We have set in motion a process that will convey to Russian officials the concern about certain aspects of this pending measure, which may abridge basic citizens' freedoms, as we read the language,'' Mr. Gore said. **********But Sergei Yastrzhembsky, spokesman for President Boris N. Yeltsin, told the Itar-Tass news agency today that Mr. Yeltsin was basically satisfied with the wording of the new bill and is likely to sign it. **********The dispute over billions of dollars in planning American oil projects will also be a difficult test. **********There are plenty of problems. Amoco has run into major difficulties with its Russian partners. Exxon was outraged when the Government revoked its right to develop oil in the far north. The Timan Perchora project, run by a consortium of Western and Russian oil companies, has been thwarted by local authorities. Major projects are also still awaiting parliamentary approval. **********To dramatize his case to Mr. Chernomyrdin, Mr. Gore waved newspaper articles suggesting that Russia was acquiring a bad reputation among foreign investors. **********A senior American official said Mr. Gore had succeeded in focusing Russian attention on the oil problem. American and Russian experts are to study the issue for two months and issue recommendations for solving it. **********What will come out of the talks is unclear. The Russians have indicated that they will try to come up with a creative solution for Exxon's difficulties. **********Moscow has also reversed -- at least temporarily -- its decision to end the privileged access Conoco and two other companies enjoy to oil pipelines under joint ventures with the Russians. **********''We will eventually get to firm and final closure on these issues,'' a senior American official vowed tonight. ''It may take time but we will succeed. The key to success is that the leading figures do not think the other side is out to snooker them.'' **********Some oil executives, who have been struggling with the byzantine politics of oil for years here, were more skeptical. **********But few doubt that, come what may, Mr. Gore will slog on. Next year, the United States will host the tenth session of the Gore-Chernomyrdin Commission on Economic, Security and Scientific Issues. It is part of the process.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/31/busin.main_headline: Cost Analysis Is Mightier Than The Ax
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/31/busin.print_headline: Cost Analysis Is Mightier Than The Ax
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/31/busin.body_text: **********When Dave Whiton drove to Des Moines last winter, he thought he was riding the wave of the Republican revolution. **********Mr. Whiton, co-owner of the Whiton Feed and Milling Company of Perry, Iowa, appeared before a Congressional panel to plead for shelter from what he saw as a deluge of red tape from a half-dozen distant and acronymic regulatory agencies. **********He was encouraged by David M. McIntosh, a young, aggressive Republican from Indiana who became chairman of a House subcommittee on regulatory affairs after the 1994 G.O.P. sweep of Congress. At their high water mark little more than a year ago, Mr. McIntosh and his zealous band of deregulators appeared close to making huge strides in paring down the Federal regulatory apparatus. **********But it looks as if Mr. Whiton, along with millions of other American business owners and managers, will have to learn to live with the regulators after all. **********Following a rocky two-year voyage through the last Congress, the Republican effort to roll back decades of accumulated Federal regulations has stalled on the shoals of partisan conflict, Presidential politics and public doubt. With the White House out of reach for another four years and smaller majorities in Congress, Republicans have abandoned their crusade to sweep away the panoply of Federal health, safety and environmental edicts. **********In this less superheated environment, the talk in Washington instead is of incremental, bipartisan efforts to more carefully weigh the consequences of new rules. One leading initiative involves two Senators -- Carl Levin, a Democrat of Michigan, and Fred D. Thompson, a Republican from Tennessee -- who are working quietly toward a compromise plan to streamline Federal rule-making and require detailed cost-benefit analyses for major new regulations. **********But large battles still loom over where to draw the line between the promised benefits of Federal regulations and their very real costs. Even as Congress seeks a legislative truce, the Clinton Administration is moving forward on several fronts to enact broad new rules governing air quality, workplace safety, ergonomics, food purity and chemical exposure that may impose costly new requirements on business. **********The Environmental Protection Agency last November issued proposed rules on small dust particles and ozone in the atmosphere. The Labor Department's Occupational Safety and Health Administration is moving toward standards to reduce repetitive stress injuries in scores of industries from meatpacking to carpet laying. OSHA is also preparing to impose new limits on workers' exposure to methylene chloride, a toxic chemical used to strip paint. The Food and Drug Administration is proposing a new seafood inspection program. **********On his trip to Des Moines, Mr. Whiton, whose family-owned mill in central Iowa employs seven workers, asked Mr. McIntosh's help in easing rules generally designed for much larger operations. He likes to tell the tale of his father's citation by an inspector from OSHA for failing to have a toilet-paper holder in the mill's bathroom. **********''Who actually thinks up these rules?'' Mr. Whiton asked in a telephone interview. ''Of course we comply, but a lot of it is redundant and overbearing. We're just a small family operation, but we have to go through all the baloney the majors do.'' **********He finds the Transportation Department's random testing for drug and alcohol abuse for his three drivers particularly irksome. **********''I've got to give them a half-day off work and pay $50 for the test and their mileage,'' Mr. Whiton said. ''I can understand the reason for testing the interstate truckers, but my guys drive at most 50 miles, and I've known them all their lives.'' **********Mark Snider, a Transportation Department spokesman, said that substance abuse testing was required for all commercial trucking operations, regardless of the size of the fleet or the territory traveled. Mr. Snider noted that the regulation had survived several court challenges. **********Still, Administration officials contend that they, too, have been listening to people like Mr. Whiton. **********They are taking steps, they say, to ease the regulatory burden without abandoning the protections the Government provides against the risk of workplace injury, environmental damage and the like. Not only do they not intend to unleash a torrent of new rules, officials insist, they are also continuing to bring greater openness to the process and to replace a penalty-based model of enforcement with one emphasizing greater collaboration between government and industry. **********''What has made this arena so contentious is the feeling by business people that a lot of regulatory actions are capricious and coercive,'' said Elaine Kamarck, a senior aide to Vice President Al Gore and director of his ''reinventing government'' initiative. The Administration's intent, she added, is to alter ''the mindset of regulators from that of cops to making sure that people are complying with the law. This is a big, big change.'' **********As examples of the Administration's commitment to regulatory revisions, officials cite the elimination of 16,000 pages of superfluous rules from the Code of Federal Regulations and the enrollment of 115 companies in OSHA's Voluntary Protection Program, which exempts employers from routine inspections if they meet minimum safety standards. **********This has been tried before. It was under President Ronald Reagan, for instance, that OSHA first turned from measuring its success by the amount of fines collected to voluntary programs aimed at reducing workplace accidents. C. Boyden Gray, who was chief counsel to Mr. Reagan's task force on regulatory relief, said that the Gore initiative was ''merely reinventing what we were doing.'' **********And Mr. Gray, now an industry lobbyist, questioned whether the effort extended to the E.P.A.'s enforcement of the Clean Air Act. ''They're still in the bean-counting mode over there,'' he asserted. **********Industry officials applaud the Administration's efforts to make regulators friendlier to business, even if they remain skeptical about its ultimate intentions. **********Indeed, much of the good will among business that the ''reinventing government'' moves generated was overwhelmed in late November when the E.P.A. proposed its sweeping new standards for airborne particulate matter and ozone -- soot and smog. The new rules, the first major revision of Clean Air Act standards since 1990, have touched off what amounts to a holy war between industry and Government. **********''This issue is our overriding concern,'' said Jerry J. Jasinowski, president of the National Association of Manufacturers and a leader of an industry coalition formed to fight the new air quality rules. ''It imposes such high costs. This is absurd. Everything pales beside that.'' **********Like most bitter debates in Washington, this one boils down to two fundamental questions: How much will it cost? And who pays? **********Mr. Jasinowski said the new E.P.A. rules would throw hundreds of communities out of compliance with current air quality rules and cost business and local governments tens of billions of dollars in exchange for unproven health and environmental benefits. **********Federal health and safety officials, and the environmental and public-interest lobbies that prod them, argue that the Government is often under no obligation to take costs into account. Indeed, the Clean Air Act specifically requires that the E.P.A. ignore them when setting air pollution standards. Nonetheless, they say, clean air -- like uncontaminated water, safer workplaces and untainted food -- carries real benefits, not all quantifiable, that easily overwhelm the costs. **********Environmental officials, citing dozens of scientific studies, argue that the new air standards will result in 20,000 fewer premature deaths, 250,000 fewer cases of childhood respiratory ailments and 9,000 fewer hospitalizations for lung complaints a year. The agency estimates the health benefits at $58.1 billion to $120.5 billion a year, with only $6.6 billion to $8.5 billion in annual compliance costs by the year 2007. **********Business interests dispute these figures and reply that there is a tipping point at which the cost of these uncontrovertible benefits become a job-killing burden. **********Mr. McIntosh, who spearheaded the drive for a broad regulatory overhaul in the last Congress, said that he would continue to hold the Administration's feet to the fire. The Gore initiatives were a positive first step, he said, ''but we need to codify that in law so that agencies have to follow it as a matter of Federal law.'' **********Mr. McIntosh, who served earlier as director of the deregulation-minded White House Competitiveness Council under then-Vice President Dan Quayle, acknowledged the changed political calculus in the current Congress required a more restrained approach. ''Rather than one big regulatory reform law,'' he said, ''you'll see a series of free-standing initiatives, restrictions through the appropriations process and stricter oversight.'' **********He has found an unlikely ally in Senator Levin, who was instrumental in derailing the grandiose Republican regulatory rollback effort in the last Congress. **********Mr. Levin, the second-ranking Democrat on the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee, has long advocated mandatory cost-benefit and risk assessment studies for all major proposed Federal environmental and workplace rules -- the holy grail of the anti-regulation forces. But he has sought to tread a narrow path between his two most important constituencies, the United Auto Workers and the automobile manufacturers, who are often on opposite sides of regulatory battles. **********Mr. Levin said he intended to introduce a bill, almost certainly with Republican co-sponsors, that would be designed to force agencies to conduct cost-benefit studies before issuing new rules, but not necessarily bind the Government to the results. **********''There are occasions when Congress has decided that they wanted a health or environmental benefit to be achieved even if the benefit cannot justify the cost,'' Mr. Levin said. **********Senator Thompson, the chairman of the Governmental Affairs Committee, indicated that he and Mr. Levin were not far apart on the issue. ''Regulations have improved the quality of life, and we certainly have to keep that in mind,'' Mr. Thompson said. ''But we can do a lot better in terms of the quality of regulatory analysis; we can do a lot better in terms of making it more understandable, so there's more accountability. And we have to go back and review the old regulations from time to time.'' **********Gary Bass, director of O.M.B. Watch, an advocacy group that generally supports Government regulation, said he was surprised that Mr. Thompson and Mr. Levin would be discussing a bipartisan bill so soon after Democrats gained the upper hand politically by portraying Republicans as being cavalier about threats like choking hazards for children and bacterial contamination of hamburger. **********There are already laws on the books to guarantee the weighing of the relative costs and benefits of proposed new rules, Mr. Bass said. What is needed instead, he said, is more disclosure of industry lobbyists' behind-the-scenes manipulations of the rule-writing process. **********''Congress can't even pass a budget,'' Mr. Bass said. ''How can it review thousands of agency regulations each year? I just consider it meddling.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/17/busin.main_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING ; Expanding their range, infomercials push charitable donations rather than sales.
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/17/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING ; Expanding their range, infomercials push charitable donations rather than sales.
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/17/busin.body_text: **********AN unusual infomercial that is scheduled to begin a test run today will seek charitable contributions from viewers rather than beseech them to buy cookware, cosmetics or car wax. **********The glossy 30-minute infomercial, to appear as paid programming on local television stations and cable networks, is titled ''Circle of Friends'' after a fund-raising program for the American Paralysis Association, a nonprofit organization founded in 1982. The actor Christopher Reeve, who broke his neck two years ago in a horseback-riding accident, is the focus of the infomercial, which asks for donations to help find a cure for spinal-cord injuries and other causes of paralysis. **********Nabisco Inc. and its Snackwell's line of baked goods have donated $125,000 of the initial $150,000 being spent to buy commercial time for ''Circle of Friends.'' Mr. Reeve appears along with his wife, Dana; seven stars, five of them Oscar winners, and scientists involved in spinal-cord research. **********The project is emblematic of a trend that has seen infomercials enter eleemosynary realms, pitching causes instead of products. Other long commercials aimed at raising funds include appeals for the St. Jude Children's Research Hospital and the Save the Children Federation. **********''In one way, it's unfortunate we have to do this'' to raise funds, said Fred Vanore, president of Vanore Productions, which produced the Reeve infomercial along with Global Vision Networks. ''In another way, we're lucky to have this ability to reach people.'' **********''I don't think it's bad that it's paid programming,'' he added, ''because when you get down to it, all programming is paid. This gives us time to tell our story.'' **********That story is told in an emotional manner intended to motivate viewers to donate to the association by calling toll-free telephone numbers or visiting its World Wide Web site.  There is an uplifting theme song, ''Shining Star,'' sung by Chaka Khan; gauzy biographical montages of Mr. Reeve; heart-tugging footage of paralyzed children, and glowing tributes to Mr. Reeve by Mel Gibson, Judith Light, Paul Newman, Rene Russo, Susan Sarandon, Meryl Streep and Joanne Woodward. **********The infomercial opens with footage from the film ''Superman,'' showing the Man of Steel (Mr. Reeve) rescuing Lois Lane (Margot Kidder). When she asks, ''Who are you?'' he replies, ''A friend.'' **********Then Ms. Sarandon, the host of the infomercial, comes on screen. ''In the movie 'Superman,' my friend Christopher Reeve was always there to catch someone just in the nick of time,'' she says. ''In real life, no one was there to catch him.'' **********Still, the tone and manner of ''Circle of Friends'' are much less hyperbolic than viewers are used to in product-selling infomercials or telethons. For instance, at one point, Mr. Reeve, in discussing his life before his accident, offers a wry joke, asserting that he considered himself ''pretty much bulletproof in fact -- no 'Superman' pun intended.'' **********And after some low-key banter between Mr. Reeve and Ms. Sarandon, she raises a question about his unflagging faith that a cure for paralysis is imminent. **********''You speak so optimistically,'' she says, ''but I've got to tell you, there's some people who tell you you're being just a little unreal.'' Mr. Reeve replies: ''I don't believe in false optimism. That really would be a waste of time. I believe in actually what can be done.'' **********Michael Manganiello, associate director of the Christopher Reeve Foundation, which last night presented $500,000 to the paralysis association for research, said: ''For so many years, spinal-cord injuries and diseases of the brain and central nervous system were considered so hopeless. But now the scientists know what they have to do; they just need the money to do it. **********''When you see Chris in the chair every day, it lowers your resistance to asking people favors,'' he continued, ''because you want to get him out of the chair.'' **********The donation from Nabisco marks its first such infomercial sponsorship, though the company has participated in other so-called cause-related marketing projects. **********''It's very different and innovative,'' said Ann Smith, a spokeswoman for Nabisco in Parsippany, N.J., a unit of the RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation. ''There's a good deal of promise that a cure is around the corner and if we could be a part of that, it would be wonderful.'' **********And of course a program-length television commercial is very different for the paralysis association. **********''You have to test the medium and see if it works,'' said Mitch Stoller, president and chief executive in Springfield, N.J. ''Based on research on other organizations that seem to have succeeded with the medium, it is worth the try.'' **********As for how much he hopes the infomercial can raise, Mr. Stoller said: ''I've been in the nonprofit sector for close to 16 years now. That's too long to think about predicting goals. You never know till you get out to the public, but my gut feeling tells me we'll do very well.'' **********If that happens, there could be a second installment of ''Circle of Friends,'' featuring additional stars like Tom Hanks. **********And if the infomercial ''is not raising money,'' Mr. Stoller said, ''we will not continue it, the same as with any other fund-raising vehicle.'' **********Whether or not ''Circle of Friends'' continues, more cause-related infomercials may be coming to a set near you. Frank Brady, president at Global Vision Networks in Montville, N.J., said he was ''working on three additional ones right now, in land mine removal, infectious diseases and cosmetic surgery for children.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/04/busin.body_text: **********Lucent Technologies Inc., AT&T's former equipment business, said today that it expected its second-quarter earnings to be more than double analysts' estimates because of rising sales and aggressive cost-cutting. **********The company, spun off by AT&T a year ago, said its profit would be $55 million to $65 million, or 9 cents to 10 cents a share, for the quarter that ended Monday. Lucent was expected to earn 4 cents a share, according to analysts' estimates. **********Lucent sold more of its lucrative software that controls the switches at the heart of telephone networks, lifting its profit margin. That optimistic assessment drove its stock 3.5 percent higher in the face of a 40-point drop in the Dow Jones industrial average. **********''In this market, I was real happy to have a positive surprise,'' said Scott Vergin, a portfolio manager at the Lutheran Brotherhood in Minneapolis, which owns 336,000 Lucent shares. **********Lucent's shares rose $1.75 today, to $52, in trading of 4.03 million shares. **********Investors who bought Lucent a year ago at its initial public offering price of $27 would have seen a 93 percent increase.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/23/busin.print_headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS; Russian Oil Producer Posts 8% Drop in Net
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/23/busin.body_text: **********Lukoil Holding, Russia's largest oil producer, said yesterday that its net income fell 8 percent in the first nine months of the year, to 2.408 trillion rubles ($419.2 million), or 3,597 rubles (62 cents) a share, compared with 2.609 trillion rubles, or 3,898 a share, in the period a year earlier. The results are unaudited and are calculated according to Russian accounting standards. **********The company did not provide quarterly earnings. It reported net income of 1.741 trillion rubles in the first half, down 2 percent, and 757 billion rubles in the first quarter, up 11 percent. That would suggest the company had net income of 667 billion rubles in the third quarter, down 32 percent from the second quarter and off 20 percent from the period a year earlier.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/14/world.snippet: Albert Wohlstetter, influential innovator in strategic nuclear doctrine who advised Democratic and Republican Administrations on military strategy, dies at age 83; photo (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/14/world.main_headline: Albert Wohlstetter, 83, Expert On U.S. Nuclear Strategy, Dies
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/14/world.print_headline: Albert Wohlstetter, 83, Expert On U.S. Nuclear Strategy, Dies
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/14/world.body_text: **********Albert Wohlstetter, an influential innovator in strategic nuclear doctrine who advised Democratic and Republican Administrations on military strategy, died on Friday in his home in the Laurel Canyon area of Los Angeles. He was 83. **********Mr. Wohlstetter's career as a strategic analyst was guided by certain key principles, including his conviction that the United States should be able to control its military forces in such a way as to permit varying the American response to foreign aggression according to the circumstances. The goal of such control, he felt, was to insure that the United States would not be obliged to mount an initial nuclear attack on the Soviet Union -- known to military analysts as a ''first strike'' -- but would have a variety of options instead. **********Writing in Commentary in the early 1980's -- when nuclear doctrine was seen as being about how to deter nuclear attack and what to do should deterrence fail -- Mr. Wohlstetter contended that the President must be perceived as having choices in order to deter an attack, and that the President could not be left without choices should deterrence fail. **********Mr. Wohlstetter and his wife, Roberta Wohlstetter, also an expert on national security, were awarded the Medal of Freedom in 1985 by President Ronald Reagan for their ''great contributions to the security of the United States.'' Mr. Reagan said Mr. Wohlstetter had been ''influential in helping to design and employ our strategic forces.'' **********Mr. Wohlstetter was a senior policy analyst on the staff of the Rand Corporation, the California-based think tank, from 1951 to 1963 and a consultant to Rand for decades afterward. He also taught at the University of California, Los Angeles, and the University of California, Berkeley, in the early 1960's and at the University of Chicago from 1964 to 1980. And he was a longtime executive of Pan Heuristics Services, Inc., a California-based consulting firm dealing in security policy whose clients included the departments of State and Defense as well as private corporations. **********A native New Yorker, Mr. Wohlstetter grew up in Manhattan and attended public schools. He earned a bachelor's degree and, in 1938, a master's degree, in mathematical logic from Columbia University. In the 1940's he worked for the War Production Board, and later went on to work in the aviation industry and  as a Government housing executive. **********He later became a member of Rand's research council and chairman of Rand's research program on conflict in allied, neutral and satellite countries. The studies that he carried out at Rand in the 1950's were all done for one client, the United States Defense Department, and were for the most part highly secret. **********Soon after he joined Rand, a colleague there, Charles Hitch -- who later became an Assistant Secretary of Defense under Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara in the 1960's -- suggested that Mr. Wohlstetter carry out a research project about the selection and use of strategic air bases -- that is, air bases for nuclear bombers. There were no nuclear missiles until the mid-1950's. **********James Digby, a friend of Mr. Wohlstetter who worked with him at Rand, recalled yesterday that Mr. Wohlstetter's paper ''resulted in a change of Strategic Air Command's basing policy so that bombers were based far from the Soviet Union, and their bases, highly protected. This in turn led to the ability to strike back even after receiving a first attack by the Soviets.'' **********In the 1970's, after Mr. Wohlstetter had left Rand, he and his wife performed studies on the Persian Gulf  on behalf of Rand and with the Department of Defense as the client. These studies affirmed that the United States' European allies were highly susceptible to having important oil supplies blocked. **********Also in the 1970's, Mr. and Mrs. Wohlstetter increased their analyses of the ramifications of the spread of  nuclear weapons, and by some accounts that work led to changes in American law concerning the export of nuclear material, notably plutonium, and of nuclear technology. **********In addition to his wife, the former Roberta Morgan, whom he married in 1939, Mr. Wohlstetter is survived by a daughter, Joan Wohlstetter Hall of Manhattan.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/09/busin.main_headline: Big H.M.O. a Victim Of Its Own Ambition
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/09/busin.print_headline: Big H.M.O. a Victim Of Its Own Ambition
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/09/busin.body_text: **********Oxford Health Plans grew as it promised the convenience and savings of a health maintenance organization with the freedom to see any doctor by agreeing to share the cost. **********But Oxford has now become the victim of its own grand ambition. The H.M.O. has fallen behind in paying doctors and hospitals, owing hundreds of millions of dollars. **********Its problems may echo elsewhere. If Oxford cannot do what it has promised at a profit, other managed care companies may feel less pressure to be as friendly to consumers. **********Business Day, page D1.

He said TBWA Chiat/Day, a unit of Omnicom Group, would participate in the review along with three other New York agencies: Bozell Worldwide, a unit of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt; Lowe & Partners/SMS, which is owned by the Lowe Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies, and Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising, part of Cordiant P.L.C. https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/22/busin.main_headline: Uncovered Short Positions Decline 1.4% on Big Board
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/22/busin.print_headline: Uncovered Short Positions Decline 1.4% on Big Board
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/22/busin.body_text: **********The New York Stock Exchange said yesterday that open positions on short sales declined 1.4 percent, to 3.39 billion shares, for trades in the month ended July 10 and settled on July 15. The drop was down from last month's record high of 3.44 billion. **********Short interest was equal to 1.7 percent of the total shares listed on the Big Board. Open positions on short sales are shares that have been borrowed and sold, but not yet covered by repurchase. **********On the smaller American Stock Exchange, short interest rose seven-tenths of 1 percent, to 172.4 million shares -- a new record -- for the same period, the exchange said. **********In a short sale, an investor borrows shares from a brokerage firm and sells them, hoping to buy them back at lower prices and make a profit. If the shares rise in price, the short-seller faces a loss. **********High short-interest positions have been considered an indicator of bearish sentiment. But some analysts say large short-interest positions are a positive sign because short-sellers eventually have to buy the shares back. Short interest can also rise as a result of complex trading strategies involving options, futures and other stock-related derivatives. Investors also sell short for merger arbitrage. **********SHORT SALES TABLES EXPLAINED **********Cover ratio represents the number of days, at average volume level, that it would take to purchase the number of shares sold short. **********A -- American Stock Exchange. **********N -- New York Stock Exchange. **********N.L. -- Not listed. **********+ -- Stock split. *********** -- (American Stock Exchange only.) May have been affected by arbitrage transactions resulting from any one or more of the following: proposed or pending acquisitions; convertible securities of the same company; rights offerings; stock splits or distributions; tenders; other special situations. **********Short interest may also be affected by options positions.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/21/world.snippet: Brazilians are riveted by real life romantic adventure of Carla Coehlo, 29-year-old artist and former local beauty queen, who has absconded with 35-year-old impoverished suitor who courted her via computer, pretending he was rich; both have become...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/21/world.main_headline: Like TV Come to Life, Outlaw Lovers' Escapade Rivets Brazil
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/21/world.print_headline: Like TV Come to Life, Outlaw Lovers' Escapade Rivets Brazil
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/21/world.body_text: **********With 17 people in the hands of kidnappers here just this month, the parents of Carla Coelho feared the worst, soon after their daughter took off to meet the rich stranger who had been courting her through her computer screen. **********Five days after she left home, Ms. Coelho stopped calling her parents. The police feared Ms. Coelho might have been kidnapped or murdered, after learning that her supposedly wealthy suitor turned out to be behind on his child support payments. **********But over the weekend, the word spread that Ms. Coelho was safe, and her story turned from a routine police-blotter item into a front-page tale of virtual love transformed into real-life romantic adventure, with a big supply of funny money. A 29-year-old artist and former local beauty queen, Ms. Coelho appears to have joined her suitor, 35-year-old Flavio Oliveira da Silva, on a high-living tour of resorts in northeastern Brazil, bouncing checks everywhere they went. **********Hotel keepers and restaurant owners said they did not appear in distress. In fact, they seemed very much in love. **********''They're together and happy, leading an irresponsible life,'' police officer Luiz Carlos Dantas of Interstate Police in Ceara reportedly said. ''They've cut loose from the real world, and have connected in a virtual world.'' **********Like ''Natural Born Killers'' but with checkbooks instead of guns, the couple has taken in a honeymooner's itinerary of the finest spots in the northeast. **********First, they went to Fortaleza, which has great beaches and a weekly music festival. There they skipped out on a $1,500 hotel bill. **********Then they stayed at Jeriocoacoara, a remote resort also known for its fabulous beaches. Then it was on to Camoci. **********Last Thursday, they turned up at a hotel in Panaiba, a coastal resort, and they are now believed to have reached Maranhao state. **********Maria Rodrigues Coelho, Ms. Coelho's mother, said in her hometown of Campo Grande that her daughter had been intensely lonely when she began her Internet romance, having broken up with her last boyfriend five years earlier. Mr. da Silva told her he was a wealthy ranch owner and sent her pictures of himself standing next to an airplane and on a ranch. He sent her flowers and poetry. **********Even her mother rooted for the stranger when Ms. Coelho quit her job to go off and meet him in Goiania early this month. ''He was the son-in-law I always dreamed about,'' she told reporters. **********In one of her postcards before she broke contact with her family, Ms. Coelho wrote that she had married her cyberbeau. But the police found that Mr. Silva's profile was altogether more virtual than anyone counted on. **********He was unemployed and lived with his parents in a poor neighborhood. Far from having an airplane, he did not even have cab fare, which he borrowed from his parents to collect Ms. Coelho from the airport. **********Though Ms. Coelho is no longer a missing person, she is now considered a fugitive. Police in four states are searching for the couple. **********She is charged with writing bad checks, and he with using a false identity.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/01/world.snippet: New US Amb to France Felix G Rohatyn finds himself in middle of crisis over $2 billion natural gas investment in Iran by French company Total; French officials have made little secret of their contempt, shared by most governments in Europe, for US...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/01/world.main_headline: New U.S. Envoy to Paris Ponders His Stormy Start
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/01/world.print_headline: New U.S. Envoy to Paris Ponders His Stormy Start
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/01/world.body_text: **********Barely three weeks after presenting his credentials as the new American Ambassador to France, Felix G. Rohatyn found himself today in the middle of a full-fledged crisis over a $2 billion investment in Iran by the French oil company Total. **********French officials from President Jacques Chirac and Prime Minister Lionel Jospin on down have made little secret of their contempt, shared by most governments in Europe, for American legislation that threatens sanctions against foreign countries that invest more than $20 million in Iran. And on Monday, Mr. Jospin went so far as to express enthusiasm for the oil deal, which had been a long time in the making for Total and its Russian and Malaysian partners. **********''Why now?'' Mr. Rohatyn asked himself, in shirt sleeves during an interview today in his New Deal-era embassy office off the Champs-Elysees. He was apparently taken aback by the timing of Total's announcement and Mr. Jospin's support for it. **********''You know, at age 69, you are not surprised by much,'' he said. ''Does it poison the relationship between France and the U.S.? I hope not. I don't believe it will. It shouldn't.'' **********An open relationship, he said, would always have differences, but it should be able to overcome ''singular events'' like this one. **********Mr. Rohatyn, a former partner of the Lazard Freres investment firm in New York City, implied that conversations he and other American officials have had with Europeans in high places about their dealings with Iran had not led them to believe a major confrontation would be in the works so soon. **********Mr. Rohatyn presented his credentials to Mr. Chirac on Sept. 11, succeeding Pamela Harriman, who died on Feb. 5 after suffering a stroke. His perfect French and his expertise in the world of international finance both earned a warm welcome in the diplomatic and corporate salons of Paris, a capital preoccupied with preserving French influence in an increasingly competitive global economy that the French think is dominated by Anglo-Saxon interests. **********''Globalization doesn't carry a threat, but it carries discipline, and then you always have a notion that we are imposing an American-style Anglo-Saxon capitalism,'' he said.  ''People forget that 10 years ago, we were being written off, and Japan and Germany were going to take over the world. Now that, like a lot of economic predictions, turned out to be wrong.'' **********Mr. Rohatyn spoke coolly about the deal involving Total, which was once state-owned but is now almost entirely privately held. One way to view the issue, he said, was to see it as ''three private companies deciding to make an investment, recognizing that there are risks in this investment because it flies in the face of the law in the U.S.A.'' **********''They decided to make the investment, presumably because they thought the profit was greater than the risk, and they clearly knew the risk,'' he said. ''They evaluated it, and now they have to deal with it, whatever that risk turns out to be.'' **********Gazprom, a huge and politically influential Russian petroleum company, and Petronas, a Malaysian state oil firm, are partners with Total in the Iranian deal. **********Mr. Rohatyn would not say today what steps he thought the Clinton Administration would take under the Iran-Libya Sanctions Act, often called the D'Amato law after Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York, a Senate sponsor. **********But he had an answer for French and other European critics of the D'Amato law and the Helms-Burton law relating to business dealings with Cuba; these critics complain that the laws are examples of attempts by Congress to legislate beyond American boundaries. **********''The issue of extraterritoriality, you know, that's a little bit like modern art,'' he joked. ''What is extraterritorial?'' **********After the European Union's executive commission threatened to disapprove the Boeing Company's merger with McDonnell Douglas last summer, he said, Boeing had to agree to remove exclusivity provisions from 20-year supply contracts with three domestic United States airlines -- American, Continental, and Delta. **********''A lot of people back home thought that was extraterritorial,'' Mr. Rohatyn said. ''It's not an open and shut issue.'' Beyond the problem of Total's decision to put $2 billion into exploitation of an Iranian gas field, he said, was a more important quandary facing Washington and its European allies. ''That is, how does the West, how the European Union, France, and the U.S. deal with the behavior of a state that can pose a danger to Western society,'' he said. **********Washington suspects that Iran has tried to develop nuclear weapons and missiles to deliver them, with help from unemployed Russian scientists. The European Union has its own problems with Iran; its member states withdrew their ambassadors from Teheran last summer after a German court found Iranian leaders directly responsible for the killing of three Iranian Kurdish opposition figures in the bombing of a cafe in Berlin in 1992. **********''One of the unfortunate things about the timing of this,'' he said of Total's decision, ''is that it may get in the way of what I think is clearly a more important discussion.'' That, he said, would include an evaluation of a change in direction by the authorities in Iran after last summer's presidential election there. **********Keeping up good American relations with France despite continual French suspicions that America would secretly like to relegate its oldest European ally to the rank of a second-rate economic and military power bedevils every American ambassador to Paris. **********One of Mr. Rohatyn's jobs has been reassuring banking friends and the numerous French officials he has been calling on that the United States does not oppose the European Union plan to create a common European currency, the euro, in 1999. **********''We have an interest in a strong Europe, and Europe has an interest in a strong U.S.,'' he said. ''The euro is a European construction. The criteria of who should join, when, what the parities should be, are all very important, somewhat technical issues in which we have no say, and no preference. **********''There is this notion that we are threatened by the euro, that the dollar is threatened by the euro,'' he laughed. ''It is absolutely not true.  Our interest is in the outcome. If their decision is to go ahead, we hope that will be successful.''                     --------------------        Albright Criticizes France **********Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright strongly criticized France last night for supporting the Total project, expressing frustration that ''our friends and allies'' did not agree with the United States' efforts to isolate Iran because of its support for terrorism. **********Ms. Albright also said that while the election of Iran's new President, Mohammed Khatami, was ''intriguing,'' his Government had done nothing to change what she described as Iran's sponsorship of terrorism, its pursuit of weapons of mass destruction and its efforts to undermine the Middle East peace process. **********''It is also a grave concern to us that our friends and allies don't get it,'' Ms. Albright said, speaking to the Council on Foreign Relations in New York City. ''They seem to think that there is some way that we can deal with them without in some way supporting'' Iran's behavior.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/01/busin.snippet: Appeals court in California has upheld $96 million jury award to inventor Carlile R Stevens and about 200 investors who contended that energy-saving fluorescent lighting technology he had developed was suppressed by Universal Manufacturing Corp, c...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/01/busin.main_headline: Award to Lighting Inventor Upheld on Appeal
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/01/busin.print_headline: Award to Lighting Inventor Upheld on Appeal
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/01/busin.body_text: **********An appeals court in California has upheld a $96 million jury award to an inventor and about 200 investors who contended that energy-saving fluorescent lighting technology he had developed was suppressed by the company that acquired the rights to it. **********The inventor, Carlile R. Stevens, and his main business partner, Bill Alling, argued that they had been defrauded by the company, the Universal Manufacturing Corporation, now a division of Magnetek Inc.. **********They licensed the patents to Universal in 1981 in exchange for a percentage of future royalties. Experts testifying at the trial contended that the suppression of this technology  cost the American public $100 billion in lost energy savings. **********Such technology, which replaced magnetic ballast with electronic versions, has become widely used in fluorescent lighting in the last five years. Ballast is used to steady flourescent lighting; without it, the lights would flicker and would be difficult to turn on. **********Mr. Stevens's original invention did not share in the growth of the new technology. By 1994, when a jury in Oakland, Calif., found in favor of Mr. Stevens and his investors after a 10-year legal process, other companies had come up with their own technologies and were no longer as interested in his version, which he called Luminoptics. **********Universal, which made the old kind of magnetic ballast, contended that the new technology was too complicated to manufacture. In 1984 Universal was acquired by Magnetek, which is based in Nashville and makes electrical equipment. When Magnetek acquired Universal, it obtained indemnity against the litigtaion from Universal's former parent company, Northwest Industries, now Fruit of the Loom Inc. **********Mark Steinkrauss, vice president for corporate relations at Fruit of the Loom, said on Friday that its lawyers had not yet read the decision and that the company was not in position to say whether it would further appeal the decision. **********The lead lawyer for the plaintiffs, Eugene Crew of the law firm of Townsend & Townsend & Crew, said that consumers had to pay billions of dollars more in electricity costs during the 1980's because Universal did not make a good-faith effort to bring Luminoptics to market. **********Luminoptics uses electricity more efficiently than conventional systems to create light and dims the lights if a room gets more intense daylight, providing additional power savings. **********Mr. Stevens, who is in his mid-60's, said in an interview that because his invention was not brought to market, he had run up debts stemming from his considerable investment in developing the system. **********''It's been tough since I put so much money into it,'' he said. He recalled that he had begun to work on the technology in the early 1970's when the energy crisis prompted searches for greater efficiency. **********Despite the difficulties with getting his system out on the market, he said he had kept busy and gotten patents on other inventions like the Clapper, a device sold on television that turns lights on and off when someone claps his or her hands. He also has a patent on technology that allows people to turn lights on and off by touching the base of a lamp. **********''I still have lots of ideas,'' he said. ''I have an idea often in the middle of the night, and I go down to the lab.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/08/busin.snippet: Dow Jones industrial average rises 29.84 points, to close at 6,555.91; Nasdaq composite index surges 14.62 points, or 1.18 percent, to close at 1,251.35 (L)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/08/busin.main_headline: Technology Stocks Up Again While Dow Also Gains
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/08/busin.print_headline: Technology Stocks Up Again While Dow Also Gains
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/08/busin.body_text: **********For the second consecutive session, a rally in technology stocks yesterday helped lift the stock market, which had been suffering through its worst slump in two years. **********While the Dow Jones industrial average rose 29.84 points to close at 6,555.91, the Nasdaq composite index -- heavily weighted with technology stocks -- saw its third consecutive gain of more than 1 percent, surging 14.62 points, or 1.18 percent, to close at 1,251.35. **********''What you're seeing in technology stocks is a reversal of the extreme pain they have endured recently,'' said Charles G. Crane, chief market strategist at Key Asset Management. ''This is a market that will continue to be known for its volatility and its rotation, and today technology took center stage.'' **********For investors, this has been a tumultuous year. And no index has been as volatile as the Nasdaq, which first raced ahead of last year's close by 7.5 percent, then plunged 13.5 percent off its January high, and now -- in the last three sessions -- has gained about 4.1 percent. **********In fact, at the close of trading yesterday, the Nasdaq completed its best three-day stretch in more than five years. Not since December 1991, when the Nasdaq rose about 4.8 percent over the course of three sessions, has the index had such a run. **********Through much of the day, the rally was led by the Nasdaq's big four in technology: Intel, Microsoft, Cisco Systems and Oracle. But Intel, which rose by as many as 4 1/8 points, was sold off late in the day to close up  1/4 at 145 1/4. Microsoft rose 1 11/16, to 95 7/8; Cisco Systems gained 3 9/16, to 54 7/16, and Oracle was up  7/8, to 39 3/4. **********Among the strongest technology stocks yesterday were shares of semiconductor companies. The Philadelphia Semiconductor Index rose 5.88 points, or 2.1 percent, to 291.81, a 52-week high, led by shares of Novellus Systems, up 3 3/4, to 80 3/4, and Texas Instruments, up 2 3/8, to 85 3/8. **********Analysts said that semiconductor stocks had gained partly on anticipation of first-quarter results from Advanced Micro Devices, up 3 3/8 yesterday, to 43, and Motorola, up 1 3/8, to 61 1/8. After the market closed, both companies reported better-than-expected earnings. **********Broader indexes also gained yesterday. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 4.23, to 762.13, and the Russell 2000 index of small-capitalization stocks rose 4.07, or 1.19 percent, to 344.91. **********While technology and small-cap stocks continue to trail the larger market this year, in recent days they have been gaining on blue-chip issues, partly because they were battered so severely in February and March, analysts said. **********Christine A. Callies, the chief investment strategist at Credit Suisse First Boston, said investors might also be turning their focus away from concerns about higher interest rates to focus on earnings. **********''The stock market is shifting gears between an interest rate-driven environment and an earnings-driven environment,'' she said. ''The stock market's been concentrating only on the dark cloud -- interest rates. Now it's trying to shrug off the higher rate environment, using profits as a rationale.'' **********Even so, stock prices gained only tentatively yesterday in relatively light trading. Volume on the Big Board was 453.8 million, down from an average of 514 million this year. **********Within the Dow, I.B.M. was the best performer, buoyed perhaps by strong technology demand. I.B.M. rose 3 1/4, to 132 1/4. Other gainers were Exxon, up 3 1/8, to 105, and Goodyear Tire, up 2 1/4, to 53 1/4. Procter & Gamble was the worst-performing Dow stock, down 1 3/4, to 117 1/4. **********After gaining early in the day, the Dow steadied, rising about 50 points. But a late selloff, particularly in shares of I.B.M., pulled the index down in the last 30 minutes. **********It has been that kind of year for the Dow. After beginning the year at 6,448.27, it took 31 sessions to get to the 7,000-point level and then 17 more to peak at 7,085.16, on March 11. But just 16 sessions later, the Dow had plunged back to 6,477.35 -- the steepest decline since 1994. **********Most analysts believe that a bull market correction has taken place, an adjustment of 5 to 10 percent after a spectacular run that saw the Dow rise 26 percent from September to March. Although the market has steadied in the last few sessions, many analysts believe prices could slump much more. **********ON THE WEB **********The latest stock and mutual fund quotations, along with news updates, are available on the Internet from The New York Times on the Web: www.nytimes.com

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/09/busin.snippet: Jack Scarangella letter on Louis Uchitelle's Feb 16 article on contrasting views of economists Paul Krugman and Lester Thurow, particularly their explanations for growth of income inequality in United States (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/09/busin.main_headline: A Tale of 2 Economists: Sizing Up the Income Gap
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/09/busin.print_headline: A Tale of 2 Economists: Sizing Up the Income Gap
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/09/busin.body_text: **********''Like Oil and Water: A Tale of Two Economists,'' by Louis Uchitelle (Feb. 16), examined the contrasting views of Paul Krugman and Lester Thurow of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, particularly their explanations for the growth of income inequality in the United States. Here are some readers' responses. **********To the Editor: **********Paul Krugman attributes American income inequality to technology. Lester Thurow says the reason is a global economy in which low-wage, foreign workers adversely affect the wages of American low-skilled workers. The problem is more basic. Much of what we produce does not contribute to our standard of living or quality of life. A prime example of waste in our economy is in military spending, the biggest item in the Federal budget. We rationalize that it provides jobs, so we see it as a national project, a sort of a Works Progress Administration for a new era. **********The W.P.A. of the 1930's produced many useful things. But the excess tanks and other vehicles that are used for maneuvers or war games do not improve our national security. **********By moving jobs to education, the environment and other areas, low-income workers will benefit most. **********JACK SCARANGELLA **********New Rochelle, N.Y., Feb. 16

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/09/world.snippet: Changes both profound and trivial, visible and not, are reshaping Hong Kong in wake of Chinese takeover, even as much of Hong Kong life remains same; Tung Chee-hwa, presenting first state-of-the-territory address on 100th day of Chinese rule, deta...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/09/world.main_headline: Change in Hong Kong Is Slow but Sure
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/09/world.print_headline: Change in Hong Kong Is Slow but Sure
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/09/world.body_text: **********One hundred days after China raised its red flag here, ending 156 years of British colonial rule, Hong Kong is feeling a new and uncertain mood. **********''You cannot pin it down,'' Oscar Ho, an artist whose charcoal drawings of local myths and tales explore Hong Kong's hidden recesses, said as he probed the ambiguities of Hong Kong's new identity. **********''It's gradually happening,'' he said. ''People are getting more and more conservative. The first couple of months were O.K., but it's beginning to worry me now.'' **********Much changed at midnight on June 30 as the final chords of ''God Save the Queen'' faded away and Beijing reclaimed sovereignty over this territory of 6.4 million people. Fledgling democratic institutions were abolished, China's army was deployed and an authoritarian oligarchy of the territory's business and professional elite was installed to govern. **********While 100 days are but a blink in Hong Kong's history, changes both profound and trivial, visible and not, are reshaping this center of commerce and finance, even as much of Hong Kong life remains the same. **********Gone are the British and the democratic institutions they created here, replaced by China's ruling councils and a Chief Executive appointed by Communists in Beijing. **********Gone are the kilted soldiers of the Black Watch, the bagpipes and the Union Jack, supplanted by the People's Liberation Army and the Chinese flag. Gone are stamps with the Queen's portrait, English cooking at government functions and the sense that everything and anything was possible and permitted. **********The Chinese Army is here, but in virtual seclusion, living in the beige concrete pile still called the Prince of Wales Barracks. Queen's Road Central, still named that, continues to course with the well-dressed professionals in the banks, finance houses, development concerns and the many companies that have made this one of Asia's pre-eminent centers of business and investment. **********Political demonstrations, illegal in the rest of China, occur several times a week here. **********Tangible traces of British colonialism are steadily seeping away. The bright red cast-iron mailboxes emblazoned with the royal seal, some from the reign of Edward VII, have been replaced by austere green boxes. Tens of millions of coins with Queen Elizabeth's face, still legal tender, have vanished into the coffers of coin collectors. And Government House, where London's representative lived, is dark and abandoned. **********But the nature of Hong Kong's transformation, or indeed whether it has changed at all, is a matter of perspective. For many people, nothing has really changed, while for others this place has begun a transition to becoming just another Chinese city. **********For Tung Chee-hwa, 60, the shipping magnate selected by Beijing to run Hong Kong, ''it's business as usual in Hong Kong,'' a mantra he invokes repeatedly, here and during an official visit to Washington last month. **********Today, continuing the custom of British colonial governors, he presented his first state-of-the-territory address to Hong Kong. **********''Hong Kong's reunification with China,'' Mr. Tung told 60 Beijing-appointed legislators on this 100th day of Chinese rule, ''requires us to appreciate and accept one practical and profound truth: Hong Kong's prosperity and stability are closely linked with those of the mainland.'' **********And then, over the course of 125 minutes, Mr. Tung elaborated his agenda for governing Hong Kong, detailing a series of policies from building more housing to creating high-tech industrial parks, from new railroads to increasing welfare payments to the needy elderly by $1.65 a day. **********Reflecting the pre-eminence of big business in his administration, much of his address was devoted to how he intends to enhance the business climate and Hong Kong's waning regional competitiveness. **********Only in a line at the end of his speech did Mr. Tung set May 24 as the date for elections to the legislature. The election rules insure the dominance of business leaders, professionals and pro-China candidates. **********Mr. Tung has been fond of telling foreign audiences that the territory has remained unaltered by the resumption of Chinese rule. **********''There has been no change in the life style to which we are accustomed,'' Mr. Tung told the United States Chamber of Commerce during his Washington visit. ''And our economy continues to expand. It is deeply in China's interest that Hong Kong should continue to work well under the 'one country, two systems' concept,'' a reference to Beijing's formula for Hong Kong's semi-autonomy as a Chinese ''special administrative region.'' **********But Hong Kong's way of life is changing. Those changes are often neither drastic nor Draconian, but they are altering this territory in ways that are now and will increasingly be less international and more Chinese. **********Unlike his garrulous and outgoing predecessor, Chris Patten, Mr. Tung avoids local reporters, releases virtually no information about his weekly activities and in public rarely departs from stodgily written speeches. **********No change has been more immediate than the abolition of democratic institutions. **********On a frantically busy corner in the central business district the other day, Emily Lau, overwhelmingly elected to Hong Kong's legislature in 1995 but ousted by China on July 1, pleaded with the lunch-time rush of passers-by through a loudspeaker. **********''When the Chinese Government took over Hong Kong on July 1, all of us in the pro-democracy movement were thrown out of the legislative council,'' she said. ''I want to assure you we will continue to fight for democracy, human rights and the rule of law.'' **********Although she and 28 other proponents of universal suffrage lost their seats on July 1, these former lawmakers continue to speak out, to appear at public demonstrations against Mr. Tung's government and to raise money for severely limited legislative elections next year. **********''I don't think the Hong Kong people have much confidence in these elections,'' said Ms. Lau, who will be required to give up her British citizenship if she wants to run for the legislature. ''They know the rules are rigged. They know the government is not accountable. But we have to stop feeling helpless.'' **********Only those members of the territory's business elite who will be voted into the legislature by their companies are permitted to retain foreign passports. **********One of those who now sit in Hong Kong's appointed provisional legislative council, as it is known, is David Chu, a wealthy developer who gave up his United States passport in a public embrace China's rule of Hong Kong. **********''What has changed,'' he said. ''One word. Nothing. There is absolutely nothing going on.'' **********Yet even Mr. Chu, after some prodding, admitted that at least politically, the territory had regressed under Beijing's hand. **********''The political changes are a step back,'' he said. ''But nobody is saying it is a permanent step back. It's a temporary setback for democracy.'' **********When for the first time Hong Kong officially celebrated China's national day on Oct. 1, marking the day 48 years ago when Mao mounted the Gate of Heavenly Peace in Beijing and declared, ''The Chinese people have stood up,'' there was less a sense here of patriotic acclaim than of deep paradox. **********Nearly half of Hong Kong's people fled China for political or economic reasons since the Communist takeover on the mainland in 1949, and like all Hong Kongers they are now struggling to find a place in their new Chinese nation. **********In Fanling, a town in Hong Kong's New Territory, Polly Lee and Terence Cheng strolled down the street, glancing in closed store windows. **********''We don't feel any different,'' said Mr. Cheng, who said the couple were textile workers in their 20's, ''but that might change.'' **********This undercurrent of uncertainty over how Hong Kongers see themselves was reflected in an opinion poll released last week by the University of Hong Kong. **********Slightly more than 60 percent of those surveyed by the university said they were not proud of having become citizens of China, and only 17.5 percent actually regarded themselves as Chinese citizens. Nearly 40 percent defined themselves as ''Hong Kong citizens.'' **********''We are a city of Chinese people, but we've never been a Chinese city,'' said Margaret Ng, a lawyer and former legislator here. **********But moves, deliberate and not, are afoot to make this a Chinese city.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/03/busin.snippet: Pres Fidel Ramos of Philippines says country's gross domestic product grew by 6.5 percent in 1996, fueled by economic reforms and political unity; economists are skeptical about Ramos's estimate (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/03/busin.main_headline: Philippine Economy Is Said to Rise 6.5%
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/03/busin.print_headline: Philippine Economy Is Said to Rise 6.5%
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/03/busin.body_text: **********The President of the Philippines, Fidel Ramos, said yesterday that the country's gross domestic product grew by about 6.5 percent last year, fueled by economic reforms and political unity. ''I believe 1996 will stand in our national annals as a time when we mastered the test of nationhood and met the challenge of development,'' Mr. Ramos said in a nationally televised year-end report. **********Economists said it was unlikely 1996 G.D.P. growth will reach Mr. Ramos's estimate. The domestic economy had to expand by more than 8 percent in the fourth quarter, which would be the swiftest growth in eight years, to achieve 6.5 percent for the full year. G.D.P. increased 5.4 percent in the first three quarters of last year, while gross national product rose 7.1 percent in that period.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/24/busin.body_text: **********The Buick division of the General Motors Corporation has named the Euro RSCG Tatham unit of Havas Advertising in Chicago to handle an undisclosed project. **********Mark A. Rollinson, a Buick spokesman in Flint, Mich., confirmed a report of the assignment last week in Adweek, describing it as a one-time project. Though he declined to discuss details, Adweek reported that it involved production of a film primarily for screening at auto shows as well as internally. **********Mr. Rollinson said the project would not affect the status of Buick's national agency, McCann-Erickson Detroit in Troy, Mich., which is part of the McCann-Erickson World Group of the Interpublic Group of Companies. A predecessor of Euro RSCG Tatham, the Kudner agency, handled the Buick advertising account until losing it to McCann-Erickson in 1958.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/29/busin.snippet: Stratton Oakmont Inc, which has filed for bankruptcy protection and was earlier expelled from securities industry, wants to reorganize as merchant banker (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/29/busin.body_text: **********Stratton Oakmont Inc., which filed for bankruptcy protection last week and was expelled from the securities industry almost two months ago, wants to reorganize as a merchant banker. **********Stratton Oakmont, based in Lake Success, L.I., filed for protection from its creditors on Friday under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code in Manhattan. The move came after a decision by the National Association of Securities Dealers on Dec. 5 to expel Stratton; its president, Daniel M. Porush, and its head trader, Steven P. Sanders, from the securities industry. **********The expulsion involved excessive markups in a small company's securities, but the N.A.S.D. also cited the firm's long disciplinary history involving other so-called boiler-room tactics. Stratton, Mr. Porush and Mr. Sanders have appealed the expulsions to the Securities and Exchange Commission. **********In its bankruptcy filing, the company listed $5.5 million in assets and $19.2 million in liabilities. Of the liabilities, more than $11.8 million was for settlements of customers' arbitration cases; an additional $2.7 million was for legal fees.
