https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/08/busin.body_text: **********The Philip Services Corporation is considering making an offer for the Safety-Kleen Corporation, a waste recycler that is the target of a $1.8 billion hostile takeover bid by Laidlaw Environmental Services Inc. Philip has begun a review of Safety-Kleen and signed a confidentiality agreement, a company spokeswoman said yesterday. Laidlaw's bid, announced Tuesday, is worth about $26 a share, consisting of $14 in cash and 2.4 of its shares for each Safety-Kleen share. Philip, based in Hamilton, Ontario, acquired three steel scrap processing companies last month for $496 million.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/14/world.snippet: Interview with Massimo Cacciari, Mayor of Venice, Italy, who voices concern that Rome is taking too long in facing up to secessionist fevers in Veneto region (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/14/world.main_headline: In Not-So-Serene Venice, Leaders Fear Rising Desire for Secession
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/14/world.print_headline: In Not-So-Serene Venice, Leaders Fear Rising Desire for Secession
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/14/world.body_text: **********Last September, Venice was made to play the unwilling host at the theatrical birth of Padania, the name of northern Italy's threatened breakaway state. Then, in May, in a dramatic late-night stunt, a group of radical secessionists scaled the bell tower in St. Mark's Square and unfurled the banner of La Serenissima Repubblica -- the Most Serene Republic -- as this watery city and its far-flung empire were known until two centuries ago. **********Venice is not a city that needs to attract attention, but flamboyant publicity like this would be a nightmare for any mayor, which is why it is probably a good thing that Venice's Mayor, Massimo Cacciari, is, by profession, a philosopher. **********Now 53, he will return to the study of theological philosophy when he steps down after the November mayoral elections. But as he gets ready to leave, Mr. Cacciari, who came to City Hall three years ago advocating greater local powers for Italy's cities and regions, is increasingly worried that Rome is taking too long to face up to the secessionist fevers in the Veneto region around Venice. **********''We need some real tangible proposals, otherwise the delirium of secession will only grow,'' said Mr. Cacciari, sitting in an office with high windows on the Grand Canal. ''A process has been set off in the Northeast and especially in the Veneto with the set of social dynamics which, if not met by a strong political response, will only continue to grow. If a snowball doesn't stop, it will become an avalanche.'' **********Federalism is on the agenda of an Italian parliamentary commission charged with producing a package of sweeping constitutional reforms this summer. But Mr. Cacciari and others feel that the commission has so far dealt with the issue of decentralization in a superficial manner, oblivious of the urgency that the Northern League -- the major secessionist party -- and various splinter groups have injected into the debate. **********The League, headed by Umberto Bossi, perhaps Italy's most volatile political figure, has shown no signs of gaining strength since 1996, when it won 10 percent of the national vote -- and as much as 40 percent in some regions of the Veneto. But Mr. Cacciari says that the League is now after more than mere votes. **********''The electoral question is not the one that is troubling, but rather the fact that the league has taken on an increasingly hostile and overbearing attitude,'' Mr. Cacciari said. ''They are becoming more intolerant, more bellicose.'' **********Even if the constitutional commission comes up with a federalist solution, these proposals must first be approved by Parliament and then by a national referendum before they go into effect. In the meantime, Italy is heading for another key test, as it struggles to meet the criteria for the European monetary union -- a verdict with wide implications for Mr. Bossi's movement. **********If Italy is left out of the first launch of the common European currency in 1999, the exclusion will give the Northern League more ammunition to argue that Italy's fortunes are being dragged down by an economically backward south, and a politically irresponsible Rome. For the small and medium-sized businesses whose exports have been behind the recent boom in the Veneto, which has one of the highest per capita incomes in Italy, exclusion from their customers' currency could be economically and psychologically crippling. **********''If Italy doesn't make it into the common currency, that is something Bossi will play off,'' said Francesco Jori, a political reporter for Il Gazzettino, a Venice newspaper. ''If that were to happen, the North would feel penalized as a result of the south, and there would be a real risk of a split.'' **********Venice, which has long regarded itself as the queen of Italian cities, has mainly stayed aloof from Mr. Bossi, whose style many here regard as vulgar and crude. In the 1996 national elections, the league won 22 percent of the votes here -- one of its lowest showings in the region. With its industrial base in its Mestre area, Venice has long been a bastion of the left; its historical center on the lagoon, which has seen its population drop from 150,000 to 70,000 in the last few decades, is more preoccupied with saving its soul from the invasion of mass tourism than with the theoretical question of independence. **********But for Mr. Cacciari, being Mayor of Venice for almost four years has only given him more proof of the stifling hand of what he calls the world's most centralized Government. ''From the organization of work to financial planning to public works, local administration is suffocated by the central bureaucracies,'' he said. **********But in reaching back to the past, to the days of the Serenissima, when Venice was a state unto itself, local historians argue that the secessionists are simply confusing their myths. **********''Within the myth is a total ignorance of history,'' said Prof. Gino Benzoni, of the Institute of the History of the Venetian State and Society. ''They invoke the myth of the Serenissima totally ignoring the contents of a history in which Venice, and its ruling nobility, dominated the Veneto region. But the myth has an anti-Rome function, and Bossi uses that myth to stir up and keep the anti-Rome sentiments boiling, and these sentiments are real.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/01/busin.snippet: Interview with Dennis R Beresford, retiring chairman of Financial Accounting Standards Board; photo; board's role in compelling companies to recognize cost of retiree benefits noted, as well as Congressional pressure that thwarted proposal to make...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/01/busin.main_headline: From the Chief Accountant, a Farewell Ledger
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/01/busin.print_headline: From the Chief Accountant, a Farewell Ledger
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/01/busin.body_text: **********DENNIS R. BERESFORD, who has been chairman of the Financial Accounting Standards Board for a turbulent decade, will step down at the end of this month. During his tenure, the board forced companies to begin recognizing the cost of post-retirement benefits while employees are still working. That angered many companies, but is now generally viewed as wise. **********But the board also underwent the embarrassment of issuing a standard for accounting for income taxes and then, in the face of widespread criticism, backing down and changing the standard. **********And perhaps most humiliating, the threat of Congressional action forced the board to retreat from a proposal to make companies treat the value of stock options handed out to employees as an expense. It settled for requiring companies to put in their footnotes to financial statements what the cost would have been had they treated it as an expense. **********As the 58-year-old Mr. Beresford leaves, the board is close to issuing a standard on derivatives that will make it easier for investors to see what companies are doing with these complex financial instruments, but that has also angered some companies that will be affected by it. **********It is not clear who will succeed him. A candidate needs the approval of the Financial Accounting Foundation, a group that includes many business representatives who are concerned about too-strict standards, and of the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, Arthur Levitt Jr., who is determined that the F.A.S.B. remain independent of the businesses whose accounting it regulates. Finding an accountant whom all can accept is proving difficult. **********Mr. Beresford was national director of accounting standards for Ernst & Young before he joined the board, and will become a professor of accounting at the University of Georgia. In an interview in the board's offices, in Norwalk, Conn., he said he had failed in one of his main goals -- speeding up board action -- but he voiced pride in the board's accomplishments.   FLOYD NORRIS **********Q. After 10 years, are you sorry to leave? **********A. No. **********Q. Why not? **********A. I've enjoyed the time here very much, but I think it's healthy for the organization and healthy for me, as well, to have some amount of turnover. I'm happy to have served and am very happy to be leaving. **********Q. Do you think there's more business hostility to the F.A.S.B. than there used to be? **********A. I don't think so. When we were working on retiree health care, people said, ''Is this the most contentious issue you've ever dealt with?'' And certainly when we were dealing with stock options, that was the question. **********A few years ago we dealt with a very tiny issue. It said that if a mutual life insurance company wanted to say its reports were in conformity with generally accepted accounting principles, they actually had to follow generally accepted accounting principles. And when we put that out for comment, you would have thought it was going to be the end of the world for mutual life insurance companies. They were up in arms and they were trying to lobby their friends in Congress and so forth. **********'Strategic Retreat' on Options **********Q. What about the stock options? You basically were blocked from changing the accounting for that by politics. **********A. That's one way of looking at it. The way I would phrase it is that we made a strategic retreat. It became obvious that if we had pursued the expense-recognition requirement there was a virtual certainty that we would have been overruled by either Congress or the S.E.C. **********Q. Was the S.E.C. not willing to support you? **********A. The S.E.C. never really made an absolute statement one way or the other, but it became clear that they were not going to be able to support us. And it might not have even been in their hands because the legislation was introduced and had enough support to overrule even an S.E.C. position. And the bad part was not just the particular issue in question -- the stock compensation issue -- but that the legislation would have provided a system whereby the S.E.C. would have had to explicitly review and concur with everything the board would do in the future. It basically would have emasculated the private sector standard-setting process. **********Frankly, the footnotes now provide the same information that would have been in the income statement. We didn't get all of what we had hoped for but we got most of it. It's going to be very interesting, now that companies have started reporting the new information, to see exactly how that's going to affect decisions by investors and creditors and others. **********There have been two issues in the history of the F.A.S.B. where it really came down to absolute interference with our best thinking through lobbying efforts and through governmental intervention. One was stock options. The other was the oil-and-gas issue back in the mid-1970's. Given the fact that we are not a governmental organization, that we need reasonable support from all of our constituents -- the business community, the accounting firms, the analysts, the regulators -- it seems to me that having to strategically retreat only twice in 24 years is a pretty darn good track record. **********Foundation Support **********Q. Mr. Levitt, the S.E.C. chairman, criticized the Financial Accounting Foundation, the organization that chooses board members and arranges financing for your activities, for not backing the F.A.S.B. **********A. He was concerned that as a result of the efforts on the stock compensation project and what he perceived as perhaps some developing storm clouds on the derivatives project, there was a chance that the F.A.S.B. was going to lose support. And I think he viewed himself as part of the problem as well, that because he had not more strongly supported the F.A.S.B. on the stock compensation project, that could encourage others to make lobbying end runs and ultimately lead to more serious damage of the standard-setting process. **********Q. In the end, the S.E.C. forced the foundation to add more public trustees. Was that gain worth the pain of the fight? **********A. It got acrimonious during the time that it was going on and I think both the S.E.C. and the F.A.F. could have handled it better, including keeping it out of the newspaper. But I think it has created a situation that's a lot better for both the trustees themselves and for the F.A.S.B. I didn't think that we were not being supported by the trustees, but I think it has improved the situation a lot. That's probably the best thing that's happened to the F.A.S.B., at least institutionally, in the whole time I have been here. **********Q. You came from one of the major accounting firms, and before you joined the F.A.S.B., you were involved with advising the board. Critics say the Big Six are not speaking on behalf of what they think is best accounting but on behalf of what they think their customers want. **********A. Remember that it used to be that the accounting firms made generally accepted accounting principles through the Accounting Principles Board. It was judged in the early 1970's that that wasn't the best process and therefore it was turned over to a very independent private-sector group, namely the F.A.S.B. **********As a result, most of the participants in our process now feel that they should provide advice on their particular point of view and what is in their own particular interest. And then it should be up to us to make the difficult judgments. **********I provided some advice to the accounting firms on more than one occasion in speeches and articles, saying, ''I don't want you to think that you have to express a view on behalf of clients. I want you to say what you think is in your best interest.'' **********I'm concerned that too much of the time the accounting firms haven't told us when they think there's going to be a very significant audit issue associated with a new proposal. If they think something is just too fundamentally judgmental, for example, and wouldn't really result in sufficient reliability in financial reporting, I think they have a responsibility to say that. **********With respect to whether they are speaking for clients, there's probably more of that than in the past. But the reality is that there isn't a single view among their clients on most of these issues. Maybe the stock compensation project was one. But there's a vast array of comments on derivatives. Large, industrial-type corporations might have one view and large money-center banks might have a different view and smaller financial institutions might have still another view. **********There is more sensitivity among the accounting firms about what the clients think about their views. I am aware that, quite frequently, an audit client will ask the firm what its positions have been on F.A.S.B. proposals. **********Those Pesky Derivatives **********Q. Let's go back to derivatives for a moment. Are you sorry that you're not going to complete that project before you leave? **********A. Yes and no. I'd hoped that we would be able to finish the project because it is a very important one and I think that we're going to make great progress in the accounting in that area. But no in the sense that it shows that the system is not beholden to one individual, that it's absolutely imperative that we work through the issues and that we not try to meet some arbitrary deadline. We're going to finish it, in my opinion, early in the next fiscal year of the organization -- in September, something like that. **********Q. Some people say that one reason you've had so much trouble on the derivatives proposal is that you're working with an amalgam of two diametrically opposed accounting theories: one being that you should carry assets at historical cost, the other that you should carry them at fair market value. And such an amalgam cannot endure. **********A. The board shares that view. In the derivatives project we made it very clear that the board's vision, a longer-term objective, is that all financial instruments should be carried at fair value. That would eliminate a fair number of the problems associated with the derivatives issue. It wouldn't eliminate all of them by any means, though, because one of the primary questions about derivative financial instruments arises where you're hedging forecasted transactions that aren't even in your financial statements yet -- next year's sales or next year's costs or a purchase of a machine two years hence or the forecasted issuance of debt. **********Having a fair-market measure for all financial instruments would simplify things, but it also raises other complications, such as how do you determine the fair value of certain instruments? So I asked a team of board members and staff about a year ago to start working on a road map for the details of a project that will get us there. I believe in the next two to three years the board will be in a position to propose comprehensive fair-value accounting for financial instruments, and that will resolve a number of the issues. **********Q. One argument made is that the sheer level of opposition to some board proposals proves that your ideas are not generally accepted and therefore cannot be generally accepted accounting principles. **********A. If nothing else, it's a public relations problem for us. Basically, what generally accepted accounting principles means is whatever is required by the F.A.S.B. or other standard-setters. It might be, perhaps, more acceptable to some people if it were called something like generally required accounting principles. **********But some people say that unless at least half of the comment letters are in favor of something, then you shouldn't adopt it. Well, that simply isn't the way we see our responsibility. We see our responsibility as being leaders, and we recognize that we are likely to get more negative letters than positive letters on a lot of our projects because people who are in the opposition are more motivated to write to us. **********A pretty large percentage of our constituency simply wants to know what they're supposed to do and they'll follow the guidance that they're given as long as there's some reasonable consideration of the costs that they have to incur, and so forth. It's a relatively small number of people who fight us, but they're very vocal and well-organized and have a lot of resources. **********Q. Do you think there's a danger of having accounting standards be too specific and accountants become not professionals but merely functionaries? **********A. Yes, I think there is. In my opinion, it's a balancing act. It's very hard to get it right. There's virtually no standard that the F.A.S.B. has ever written that is free from judgment in its application. Lease accounting, for example, has a very specific test: If your minimum lease payments are equal to at least 90 percent of the fair value of the asset, then you have to capitalize; if it's 89 percent, you don't capitalize. But even there, there's judgment involved in estimating the fair value. And in many other cases -- my favorite example is loan losses -- there's no way a standard can be anything other than a broad amount of guidance that requires substantial professional judgment. **********Q. I've spoken to corporate financial officials who don't like many of the things you've done in recent years, who speak bitterly of what they view as a conspiracy between you folks and the Big Six to deprive accountants of judgment so that accountants will be protected if someone sues. **********A. There's certainly no conspiracy between the Big Six and us. The Big Six people really get very upset when people say that because they feel they're being punished for our sins. **********But the reality is that we do get requests for specificity from accounting firms -- the Big Six firms in particular, because they're more actively involved in our process than are some of the smaller firms. But we also get requests for specificity from corporations. Now, not every corporation, obviously, wants as much guidance as others. But at one recent meeting of our Emerging Issues Task Force, one of the corporate people in the public meeting said something like: ''I want to know exactly how I'm supposed to account for this particular transaction. I don't want any ambiguity whatsoever.'' **********High Points, Low Points **********Q. As you look back over your 10 years here, what are you most proud of? **********A. I think I'm most proud of the fact that we have endured and have such strong support from the Securities and Exchange Commission. Another thing is that the F.A.S.B. has adopted a strategic plan. It's a long way to go to get it all in place and fully functioning, but I'm proud of that. **********And I'm proud that we've done a lot in the international area. That's something that I take more personal pride in than almost anything else because I was the one who got us started. But the main sense of pride is that we have survived and that we are a very viable organization. **********Q. Michael Cook, the head of Deloitte & Touche and the chairman of the Financial Accounting Foundation, told me recently that he wasn't sure that there would be an F.A.S.B. in 10 years, because international standards might have taken over and rendered the F.A.S.B. obsolete. Do you agree? **********A. No. I believe the F.A.S.B. will continue as the standard-setter for U.S. corporations and as the leader for standard-setters throughout the world. In my opinion, there's no possibility that the F.A.S.B. will not be here in 10 years' time. **********Q. What have been the biggest disappointments of your tenure? **********A. Probably that things still move very slowly. When I came to the board, I said that that's something I'd like to improve. It hasn't happened. We have adopted some new ideas as part of our strategic plan and we are at least going to be a lot more careful in trying to plan out our work. **********For example, we have made a commitment that we will not take on a project unless we firmly believe that we can finish it within no more than three years. But that's more of a philosophy as opposed to an actual accomplishment at this point. **********I guess I'm more of a realist now that I recognize that it's complicated -- that there are outside forces that don't want us to move as quickly as we should, for example. All of the due process that we follow is important and if we didn't have the challenge to our proposals, we wouldn't be issuing the highest quality standards. **********The biggest amount of time, though, is spent on getting agreement on the board. We have seven very strong intellects. **********Q. Are there any accounting standards that you think you didn't handle very well? **********A. Well, we certainly didn't handle the accounting for income taxes project very well. We issued a final standard and then had to go back and revise it substantially just a couple of years later. The first one was almost hopelessly complicated, and it didn't come up with reasonable answers in some cases. That was a bit of an embarrassment.  But I think it also showed that the board was not afraid to admit a mistake. **********We try very hard on our projects to learn both the good and the bad things that have occurred and then apply them on other projects. But it doesn't always work. We thought we had learned a lot on the retiree health care issue, that having early communications and going out and trying to sell our ideas and understand different points of view helped a lot in making our final standard much more acceptable. When we tried to apply some of those same techniques in the stock-options project, it didn't work. **********Seeking a Successor **********Q. They seem to be having some trouble finding your successor. What characteristics are most important for the job? **********A. You really have to believe in the importance of this activity. It sounds a little corny,  but it's really more of a calling than an assignment. Once you get here, there's an awful lot of negativity associated with the position. And unless you are firmly a believer, it could get you down fairly quickly. **********A lot of people answer in a cliche, saying we have to have a real thick skin. I don't think that's really quite right. I like to say you have to have a medium skin because if you have a thin skin, the criticism will get to you and you won't be able to handle the position; if you have too thick a skin, it will appear, at least, that you're oblivious to reasonable criticism. **********Q. Thank you.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/21/world.snippet: Opposition to Pres Alberto K Fujimori of Peru grows as Government undertakes repressive campaign to remove all obstacles to insure that he wins unparalleled third term; Government has engineered dismissal of three Supreme Court justices who ruled ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/21/world.main_headline: As Peru's Leader Cracks Down, Opposition Grows
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/21/world.print_headline: As Peru's Leader Cracks Down, Opposition Grows
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/21/world.body_text: **********Only three months ago, President Alberto K. Fujimori was riding high on a wave of popularity driven by the daring rescue of hostages held by leftist guerrillas at the Japanese diplomatic residence here. **********Peruvians and foreign governments had nothing but praise for Mr. Fujimori for carrying out the raid with so few casualties among the hostages and rescuers -- a feat he called a ''victory for democracy.'' **********But now, after a string of blatant attacks against the judiciary, the press and critics, Mr. Fujimori has few supporters. His approval rating is at a low point, five members of his Cabinet have resigned and thousands of people are protesting in the streets. **********Reveling in the success of the hostage raid, Mr. Fujimori's Government has undertaken a repressive campaign in recent weeks to remove any obstacle to his winning an unparalleled third term. **********His administration engineered the dismissal of three Supreme Court justices who ruled that it was unconstitutional for Mr. Fujimori to run for President again. It also tapped the telephones of prominent citizens and journalists, and tried to shut down the television station that exposed the illegal wiretaps. **********While Mr. Fujimori's critics predicted that he would use the hostage rescue to advance his political agenda, almost no one expected him to go to such extremes, which have led many people here to conclude that the President has lost control of the Government to Peru's notorious intelligence service and armed forces that have long been the foundation of his rule. **********Analysts have long described Mr. Fujimori's Government as a tripod in which the President shares power with the heads of the military and the intelligence service. But the moves undertaken by the administration in recent weeks have convinced many analysts that Mr. Fujimori has lost the upper hand. **********''This is the beginning of the end for Fujimori and the dictatorial way he has ruled Peru,'' said Javier Diez Canseco, an opposition Congressman. ''Fujimori either has to break ranks with the generals and advisers that are behind his repressive regime, or they will break him. There is too much public outrage for things to continue as they have.'' **********In recent days, thousands of union workers, professionals and students, waving banners and chanting anti-Fujimori slogans, have filled the plazas and streets of Lima in the largest demonstrations against the Government's policies since Mr. Fujimori took office in 1990. **********''A few weeks ago I would have been afraid to march against the Government, because people who protest are often killed and tortured,'' said Jorge Marina, a teacher who demonstrated last week in front of the Presidential Palace. ''But Fujimori has gone too far this time. There is no democracy left. There is no hope for our children.'' **********Even many of Mr. Fujimori's close friends and allies, including Cabinet members, foreign diplomats and members of Congress, have expressed concern about the latest direction of his Government. **********Foreign Minister Francisco Tudela said he had resigned along with four other ministers as ''a matter of conscience.'' **********A public opinion survey released here today by Imasen, a leading polling firm, found that 19 percent of 400 people questioned in Lima last week approved of Mr. Fujimori's Government, compared with 39.5 percent in May and 77 percent after the hostage rescue in April. It was the lowest popularity level for Mr. Fujimori in his seven years of power. No margin of sampling error was given for the poll. **********Giovana Penaflor, Imasen's director, attributed Mr. Fujimori's plummeting popularity to ''the fact that he has not provided the country with a clear and direct explanation of these scandals and he has not convinced people that as head of state, he is the one who is running Peru.'' **********What has apparently angered Peruvians the most was the Government's decision last week to revoke the citizenship of the owner of the television station that uncovered a scheme by the national intelligence agency to secretly record the telephone conversations of dozens of politicians, business executives and journalists. The telephones monitored included a cellular phone of The New York Times in Peru. **********Because Peruvian law requires investors in national television stations to be citizens, the majority shareholder and administrator of the station that broadcast the wiretapping report, Baruch Ivcher, could be required to sell his stake. He has filed a lawsuit seeking to block the Government's action. **********''The absolutely stupid mistake of stripping Ivcher of his citizenship has created an environment of political and economic instability,'' said Alejandro Toledo, a well-known economist and former presidential candidate. ''This Government had been walking on three big legs, but now one leg is shorter than the other two, and that's why President Fujimori can't make the changes that necessary to return democracy to Peru.'' **********Political analysts here said that Peruvians are especially troubled by Mr. Fujimori's refusal to remove two officials who are believed to be the architects of the wire-tapping scandal and the driving force behind the administration's dictatorial style. **********They are Vladimiro Montesinos, the de facto head of the intelligence service, who rarely appears in public but is one of the President's closest advisers, and Gen. Nicolas Hermoza, the chairman of the joint chiefs of staff, who backed Mr. Fujimori when he assumed near-dictatorial powers in 1992. **********As in other crises, Mr. Fujimori has remained largely secluded in the Presidential Palace, where he held a brief news conference last week in which he denied that his Government had conducted illegal wiretaps and sought to assure Peruvians that he was still in command. **********At the news conference, General Hermoza said, ''We want to emphatically express our subordination, loyalty and disciplined support.'' But many Peruvians recalled numerous incidents in recent years when the military openly defied Mr. Fujimori's orders. **********For example, despite an executive order from Mr. Fujimori, army officials refused to release a retired general whom they had jailed after he publicly disclosed cases of torture and murder within the military and intelligence service. **********So far the crisis has had little impact on Peruvian financial markets or on the flow of foreign investments. But local business leaders and foreign investors have expressed concern over the Government's recent actions, particularly the move against Mr. Ivcher. **********''Obviously a crisis of this nature makes investors nervous, but so far we believe Peru's economic fundamentals will remain intact as it goes through this transition from an authoritarian government,'' said Juan Carlos Garcia, head of Latin American equity research for Santander Investment Research, an investment bank. **********''In many ways this crisis is healthy,'' Mr. Garcia said, ''because it sets the stage for thinking about who comes next after Fujimori. He cannot stay in power forever.'' **********Mr. Fujimori, who was elected to a second four-year term in 1995, has said he wants to run again in 1999. Last year, he persuaded Congress, which is controlled by his political party, to pass a legal interpretation declaring that his second term counted as his first.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/03/busin.snippet: Gasoline prices surge on New York Mercantile Exchange after Exxon Corp says a unit at Texas refinery is still closed, meaning another week of reduced supplies (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/03/busin.main_headline: Gasoline Prices Rise Sharply As Refinery Unit Stays Shut
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/03/busin.print_headline: Gasoline Prices Rise Sharply As Refinery Unit Stays Shut
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/03/busin.body_text: **********Gasoline prices surged on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday after the Exxon Corporation said a unit at a Texas refinery was still closed, meaning another week of reduced supplies. **********Natural gas prices also rose sharply. On other markets, gold fell after a report that Russia sold 31 metric tons. **********While there were signs last week that refinery problems nationwide were easing, the announcement by Exxon about its refinery in Baytown, Tex., the nation's second largest, revived concerns about supply. **********The end of the summer driving season ''doesn't mean demand drops off two million barrels'' a day, said Tom Bentz, director of energy trading at High Yield Analytics Inc., a New York-based brokerage firm. ''There still are refinery problems out there.'' **********The 110,000-barrel-a-day Exxon unit, which closed Aug. 12, was expected to restart during the weekend. It now may not reach full capacity until next Monday, traders said. **********Gasoline for October delivery rose 1.57 cents, or 2.6 percent, to 62.79 cents a gallon on the New York Mercantile Exchange. October crude oil rose 4 cents, to $19.65 a barrel. **********Natural gas rose to a seven-month high as the onset of the peak hurricane season caused concern that production in the Gulf of Mexico could be disrupted at a time of low supply. **********Storms brewing from the Yucatan Peninsula into the eastern part of the gulf are slowly moving westward, the National Weather Service in Miami said, adding thatanother system in the Atlantic, 500 miles east of the Lesser Antilles, is also moving west. **********Natural gas for October delivery rose 7.9 cents, or 2.9 percent, to $2.793 for 1,000 cubic feet, the highest for a contract closest to expiration since Jan. 27. **********Gold fell in response to reports that the Russian Finance Ministry sold 31 metric tons in August. The sale was aimed at paying off state debts to gold mining companies, according to the Russian news agency Interfax, which reported the sale. The balance of the proceeds after paying the mining companies will be transferred to the state. **********Gold for December delivery fell $1.60, to $325.80 an ounce, on the Comex division of the New York Mercantile Exchange.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/15/busin.main_headline: Treasury Prices Move Higher Again on Good Economic News
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/15/busin.print_headline: Treasury Prices Move Higher Again on Good Economic News
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/15/busin.body_text: **********Prices of Treasury securities continued to forge ahead yesterday on good economic news, but further gains were stymied by profit taking in a shortened trading session ahead of the long Washington's Birthday weekend. **********With the Government's quarterly refunding now complete, traders were willing to bid up prices and their mood was strengthened by weaker than expected economic data concerning price pressures at the manufacturing level that were released yesterday. The data, which showed an unexpected drop in producer prices, lowered fears about a move by the Fed to raise interest rates over the near term. **********The newly issued 30-year bond rose 17/32 , to a price of 10110/32  to yield 6.53 percent, down from 6.62 percent on Thursday and down 17 basis points from the week before. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. **********Rumors of a large leveraged seller of a block of five-year Treasury securities, worth between $600 million and $1 billion, circulated among traders yesterday morning. The rumor, which contributed to profit taking by traders, helped cut short the rally that began on the news of falling producer prices. **********Anthony Chan, vice president and chief economist at the Banc One Investment Advisors Corporation in Columbus, Ohio, said bond traders had been expecting the producer price report to show higher food and energy prices, even if the core rate, which excludes food and energy, was low. But energy prices actually fell and food prices rose less than expected, providing a welcome surprise for credit market investors. **********Even so, Mr. Chan was skeptical,  saying that he expects pressure to build for sharply higher prices in the future. But he said it was likely that the Fed would wait for real price increases to reach the consumer level before acting on interest rates. **********''It is clear that today's P.P.I. report should permit the Fed to remain on hold even in March, when they next meet,'' he said. ''Consequently, what the report really suggested to most market investors is that the central bank is unlikely to rock the boat until at least the end of the first half of the year at the earliest.'' **********The next most important piece of market-friendly data after the P.P.I., he said, is industrial production in January. ''Everyone knew that overall manufacturing employment only rose modestly while manufacturing employment and overtime hours sharply declined, thereby pointing in the direction of moderate industrial production growth,'' Mr. Chan said. Total industrial production was flat in January. **********Yesterday's economic reports  strongly suggest that the economy is definitely slowing down from its strong growth pace in the fourth quarter of 1996. It gave bond investors a big enough comfort zone to buy securities without fear that the Fed would suddenly raise interest rates. ''However, what today's numbers don't tell you is whether this slowdown will be swift enough to help the economy avoid any significant increases in inflation throughout the entire year,'' Mr. Chan said.

There are increasing signs that it may be.. A recent rash of high-profile mergers, t...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/15/busin.main_headline: THINKING AHEAD : European Business Tries to Do Better
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/15/busin.print_headline: THINKING AHEAD : European Business Tries to Do Better
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/15/busin.body_text: **********Could it be that Europe is finally beginning to restructure its business and industry to cope with global competition — a decade or more behind the United States? There are increasing signs that it may be. **********A recent rash of high-profile mergers, takeover bids and plant closures could be only a foretaste of what lies ahead — especially if the planned single currency is introduced in much of the European Union's commercial heartland less than two years from now. **********American-style restructuring has gone furthest in Britain. But on the Continent, too, companies have started to merge into larger units, trim management and concentrate on the activities they do best. **********The popular image of a soaring America eclipsing a waning Europe was always exaggerated. Europe has world-class companies, for instance, in autos, food, oil, chemicals, pharmaceuticals, banking and insurance. **********But restructuring in Europe has been more cautious and less visible than in the United States. Much of the reorganization undertaken by large European companies has been internal, escaping general notice. **********The more ostentatious attempts — like Renault's recent controversial plan to close a plant in Belgium and Krupp Hoesch AG's failed takeover bid for Thyssen AG in Germany — illustrate the difficulties Europe faces in consolidating its industry. **********Europe certainly still has far to go in many ways to match the drive of the United States and emerging countries in Asia. Labor unions, governments and the European Commission did their best to thwart Renault in Belgium, and Krupp failed to overcome Germany's traditional dislike of hostile takeovers. **********But the other, less obvious message of Renault's Belgian debacle is that the European auto industry is finally trying to grapple with overcapacity. And although Krupp's bid for Thyssen failed, the two companies did agree to merge their steel interests in a much-needed rationalization. **********Across the Continent, government telecommunications monopolies are beginning to shake themselves free of the past, and many companies are making better use of technology and increasing productivity — one factor contributing to high unemployment. **********That is Europe's real problem: Its efforts to restructure are not creating jobs. Europe, for instance, lags badly in information and communications technology, which generates many of the best new jobs in America. **********The move of European workers from manufacturing to services is still too slow, especially in Germany, and some service sectors, such as airlines, telecommunications and finance, are "crying out for rationalization," according to Mark Howdle of UBS Ltd. **********Some restructuring reaches across borders, like the merger planned by France's Lyonnaise des Eaux SA and Compagnie de Suez SA, which includes Belgian interests. But most mergers are still inside national boundaries. **********France is fostering economic nationalism and inefficiency by rejecting a bid from Britain's General Electric Co. for the French defense company Thomson-CSF. Nationalism helped fuel the outcry against Renault in Belgium. **********Although competition, especially from Japan, sparked America's restructuring, European companies are still too often shielded by protectionist regulations and practices. **********Business confidence is sapped by uncertainty over the future of European unity, and although the European Union's single market has helped tear down barriers to the movement of people and goods, many still remain. **********A single currency should intensify intra-European competition, training European companies to become global performers. The currency's launch, says John Llewellyn of Lehman Brothers in London, can be expected to herald a new wave of European investment and rationalization. **********Europe is unlikely ever to react with the speed of America — its culture and its people's expectations are different. But if they want to play in the global league, Europeans should curb their nationalistic instincts and step up the current, halting pace of change.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/19/busin.snippet: Stock market extends early-year rally on February 18; Dow Jones industrial average rose 78.50 points, to close at record 7,067.46 (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/19/busin.main_headline: Stocks Climb; Dow at High Of 7,067.46
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/19/busin.print_headline: Stocks Climb; Dow at High Of 7,067.46
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/19/busin.body_text: **********Continuing to defy the predictions of even the most optimistic bulls, the stock market extended its early-year rally yesterday, rising sharply. **********The Dow Jones industrial average -- which had slumbered through much of the session -- awoke in late trading and rose to close up 78.50 points, or 1.12 percent, at a record high of 7,067.46. For the year, the Dow is up 9.6 percent. **********While much of yesterday's trading activity revolved around a number of high-profile mergers and acquisitions, the late-afternoon rally among blue-chip stocks lifted most indexes, and left many analysts perplexed. **********''Today's a tough call,'' Warren Epstein, director of trading at Richard A. Rosenblatt & Company, said. ''The market's up and there's really nothing to speak of. It must be momentum,'' he said of a market that rose about 80 points in the last hour. ''To see the market do something that doesn't make a lot of sense really doesn't surprise me.'' **********Among several analysts, however, there is a growing consensus that heavy cash inflows into mutual funds are driving stock prices higher. While healthy corporate earnings, low inflation and a benign bond market continue to bolster equities, some believe that the influence of hoards of cash is beginning to outstrip other fundamentals. **********''There are times in the market where you're not trading statistics, but you're trading momentum,'' said Raymond Worseck, chief economist at A. G. Edwards in St. Louis. ''The dynamics of current money flows are overwhelming the economic statistics.'' **********The Dow was led yesterday by Philip Morris, up 5 3/4, to 131 1/4, after Bloomberg News reported that American cigarette makers were negotiating to settle health-related lawsuits. **********More than two-thirds of the Dow's gains were attributed to Philip Morris and four other companies: Procter & Gamble, J. P. Morgan, Boeing and Merck -- most of which have been among the best-performing Dow stocks this year. **********Procter & Gamble was up 4 5/8 yesterday, to 129 1/2; J. P. Morgan was up 2 3/4, to 109 1/2; Boeing was up 2 1/4, to 110, and Merck was up 1 7/8, to 99 1/4. **********''The story is we have been narrow, we continue to be narrow and it really doesn't matter because we've had concerted basket buying of these stocks,'' said Scott Bleier, chief investment strategist at Prime Charter Ltd. ''This is the continuing deployment of funds into the favorite stocks.'' **********The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks also set a record yesterday, closing up 7.81 points, to 816.29. Notable among the S.& P. stocks this year have been financial services issues. **********In fact, financial stocks have seen the most impressive gains this year. The S.& P. Financials Index, for example, is up 17.87 percent, far outpacing the S.& P. 500, which is up 10.2 percent. **********Even better is the S.& P. Banks Composite, up 18.1 percent, partly because not one of the 27 banks listed in the index has lost ground this year. Even its worst performer, Corestates Financial, is up 6.02 percent. **********Financial issues got an extra lift yesterday after H. F. Ahmanson, the nation's largest savings and loan, made an unsolicited offer to acquire Great Western Financial, a deal that would create one of the largest financial institutions in California. Shares of Great Western soared 10 5/8, to 44 7/8, and shares of Ahmanson were up 4 3/8, to 44 7/8. **********Several other merger deals made news yesterday. The Evergreen Media Corporation, which owns radio stations nationwide, agreed to buy Chancellor Broadcasting. Shares of Evergreen lost 1 1/4, to 31 1/2, and shares of Chancellor rose 6.25 cents, to 28. **********In health care, the HealthSouth Corporation said it would acquire Horizon/CMS Healthcare for nearly $1 billion. Shares of HealthSouth fell 2 1/8, to 41, and Horizon rose 2 1/4, to 16 1/2. **********ON THE WEB **********The latest stock and mutual fund quotations, along with news updates, are available on the Internet from The New York Times on the Web: www.nytimes.com

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/19/busin.snippet: Survey conducted by Elrick & Lavidge shows majority of respondents, 66 percent, say they would do nothing if Dow Jones industrial average fell 1,800 points or more in one day, equivalent of 23 percent drop on Oct 19, 1987; 14 percent say they woul...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/19/busin.print_headline: FUNDS WATCH; Vowing Not to Blink
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/19/busin.body_text: **********The best way to weather market breaks is to build a long-term diversified portfolio and sit tight. **********That has been the conventional advice to investors and it seems that more than a few have heeded it, from the findings of a study sponsored by American Century Investments, the mutual fund company in Kansas City, Mo., on the eve of the the 10th anniversary of the 1987 stock market crash today. **********The survey, conducted by Elrick & Lavidge, a national market research firm, explored whether another crash would alter investment behavior. Five hundred telephone interviews were conducted between Aug. 24 and Sept. 4 among people who owned stock mutual funds or individual stocks and did not work in the financial services industry. **********A majority of respondents, 66 percent, said they would do nothing if the Dow Jones industrial average fell 1,800 points or more in one day, the equivalent of the 23 percent drop on Oct. 19, 1987; that share of respondents is virtually the same that sat tight 10 years ago. However, 14 percent said they would add to their investments, presumably immediately after a big decline on the theory that they could find some bargains. **********A majority, 56 percent, said that a future market correction was not a major concern because they are long-term investors. And while only 25 percent could foresee the Dow  dropping as much as it did 10 years ago over the next 12 months, 39 percent did expect that to happen in the next five years. **********Notwithstanding their concern about a coming market break, very few respondents have adjusted their portfolios during the last year to prepare for a correction. Only 23 percent of the participants have moved money among investments in their taxable accounts to better withstand a stock-market correction, and only 20 percent of respondents with company-sponsored retirement plans have moved investments in those  plans. In both cases, the most common reason was to diversify their portfolios. **********While the respondents' outlook was not exactly bleak, it was also not as wildly enthusiastic as the expectations voiced in a national survey reported earlier this month that was conducted for Montgomery Asset Management, a fund company in San Francisco. In that study, in which 750 fund shareholders were questioned, the respondents said they anticipated average annual returns of 34 percent on their fund investments over the next 10 years -- or roughly three times the average annual return from stocks over the last 60 years. **********A 3.8% Increase In Industry Pay **********Many Americans are reaping big returns from their fund investments this year, and people in the fund industry continue to be generally well-compensated for helping achieve those returns. **********The annual percentage increases in total compensation (salary plus  bonus) were, to be sure, small this year: 3.8 percent over all and just 1 percent for chief executives. But chief executives still had an average total compensation of $1,026,900, according to an annual study conducted  by Buck Consultants, a human resources firm in New York, which surveyed the compensation levels in effect on April 1 this year. **********''With mutual fund companies coming off back-to-back strong years, bonuses paid to C.E.O.'s this year mirrored what they received last year,'' said Paul Gavejian, a principal and compensation consultant in Buck's office in Stamford, Conn. **********Some people in the industry, however, received much larger increases. Heads of fixed-income investing, for example, received a 25.4 percent increase in total compensation, to an average of $652,900, and the average compensation for chief administrative officers jumped 23 percent, to $225,700. **********And some fund executives saw their compensation decline sharply.  Total compensation for taxable-bond chiefs fell 37 percent, to an average of $540,200. Heads of tax-exempt securities investments earned $375,900, on average, a decline of 15.5 percent. **********The survey, based on responses from 51 fund companies, looked at total compensation levels for more than 100 positions, as well as at compensation practices and policies. **********New Funds **********Compass Capital International Small Cap Equity will use a value approach to picking stocks with market capitalizations of $100 million to $1 billion in developed and emerging markets. The maximum initial sales charge is 5 percent. **********Kemper High Yield Opportunity aims for high total return through current income and capital appreciation by owning junk bonds. It will be run by Michael McNamara and Harry Resis, co-managers of Kemper High Yield, and Dan Doyle, a Kemper analyst. Unlike Kemper High Yield, the new fund can invest in instruments not commonly found in high-yield funds; specifically, it can invest up to 20 percent of its assets in equities and 25 percent in emerging-market debt securities. The maximum initial sales charge is 4.5 percent. **********Twentieth Century Emerging Markets aims for capital growth by investing mainly in stocks of small and large companies in Africa, Latin America, Eastern Europe and Southeast Asia. The minimum investment  is $10,000; subsequent minimum investments are generally $50. **********In Brief **********Shareholders approved a proposal by Vontobel U.S. Value to become a nondiversified fund, which will allow it to concentrate its portfolio in fewer positions.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/27/world.body_text: **********Palestinians and Israelis traded rocks and rubber bullets for the seventh day in the West Bank today as Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu awaited the arrival of Washington's Middle East mediator and pondered whether to bring the opposition Labor Party into his Government. **********The rioting, which has pitted Palestinian youths against Israeli soldiers daily in Bethlehem and Hebron for a week, spread today to the West Bank city of Ramallah, where several hundred Palestinian students spent several hours raining stones on Israeli troops and being pelted with tear gas and rubber bullets in exchange. About two dozen Palestinians were treated for various injuries. **********In Bethlehem, protesters burned American and Israeli flags but were restrained from rock-throwing by Palestinian police. **********Ramallah was the place where similar disorders last September, touched off by Israel's opening of a tunnel in the Old City of Jerusalem, suddenly turned murderous as the two sides began swapping gunfire. The fighting spread through the West Bank and Gaza Strip and left more than 70 dead. **********After that violence, the special American envoy to the Middle East, Dennis Ross, spent long weeks brokering an Israeli withdrawal from Hebron, which was finally completed in January and was supposed to have ushered in a more stable relationship between Mr. Netanyahu and Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader. **********But the partnership soon disintegrated after Israel began building a new Jewish neighborhood in East Jerusalem and announced a redeployment in the West Bank that the Palestinians found insultingly small. Mr. Arafat severed the negotiations, and once the bulldozers began work on the neighborhood, Har Homa, Palestinian youths took to the streets. **********Beginning his latest Middle East trip today, Mr. Ross flew first to Morocco to meet with Mr. Arafat and was expected in Israel late Thursday. **********American officials said he would be seeking a clear declaration from Mr. Arafat that he is against the use of terror and violence, in the wake of Israeli charges that he gave a ''green light'' to Islamic militants to mount terror attacks against Israel. A suicide bombing in Tel Aviv last Friday killed three Israeli women. **********From Mr. Netanyahu, Mr. Ross is expected to seek some actions to allay the anger roused by the recent Israeli decisions. **********Officials said that Mr. Ross was not bringing any specific proposal and that his main mission was to consult with the squabbling sides on how to break the deadlock in negotiations. He is to return by the weekend to report to President Clinton and Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright. **********One idea that the Americans are reported to be interested in is Mr. Netanyahu's proposal to set aside the existing ''interim'' agreement, which envisions more partial withdrawals while a final settlement is being negotiated, and jump directly to accelerated ''final status'' talks, with a six-month deadline for reaching agreement. **********Mr. Netanyahu raised the plan with King Hussein of Jordan last week, but the Palestinians dismissed it as an attempt to elude obligations under existing agreements. **********In the American view, the attempt to maintain the existing schedule has only led to confrontations in the last eight months and no further action is required by Israel for another six months in any event, so nothing would be lost in starting intensive talks. In any event, negotiations on a final settlement were originally supposed to have begun last week. **********Mr. Ross's return coincided with growing indications in Israel that Mr. Netanyahu was considering taking his Likud Party into a ''national unity'' government with the rival Labor Party and its leader, Shimon Peres. **********After eight months of incessant crises with the Palestinians and with his contentious coalition of rightist and religious parties, Mr. Netanyahu is thought to be seriously tempted by the notion of a coalition. It would give him more flexibility and credibility in negotiations with the Palestinians, and would protect him against the constant threat of being brought down by a no-confidence vote in Parliament. **********Both of the actions that led to the current crisis, the proposed Jewish housing project and the small West Bank withdrawal, were effectively dictated by threats from right-wing Cabinet members to bring down the Government. **********Israel has had national unity governments before, most recently a Labor-Likud coalition from 1984 to 1988 in which Mr. Peres and Yitzhak Shamir of the Likud took turns serving as Prime Minister. **********But if such a coalition is formed now, Mr. Netanyahu would remain Prime Minister, since he was directly elected by the country's voters rather than by Parliament. The change would be in the makeup of the Cabinet, where Labor would probably demand an equal number of portfolios to Likud. **********Mr. Peres has made no secret of his interest in joining a coalition, since it is effectively his last chance to serve in the Israeli Government. He has announced that he will not run for re-election as party leader in the Labor election scheduled for June 3, when the leadership is expected to pass to Ehud Barak, a former army Chief of Staff and Defense Minister. **********For Mr. Peres, a seat on the Cabinet could also give him an opportunity to revive the peace agreements of which he was the premier architect. By all accounts, his joining the Government would be predicated on a firm understanding about the direction of Israeli-Palestinian progress. **********Though talk of a national unity government has been in the air for months, it gained intensity after Mr. Peres met recently with Mr. Netanyahu. Israeli officials said President Ezer Weizman was also actively involved in promoting such a coalition and the Americans looked favorably on it. **********Mr. Netanyahu has formally denied any such plans. After the daily Yediot Ahronot published what it said was a lineup of a new national unity cabinet, Mr. Netanyahu's office issued a statement saying: ''The Prime Minister has not decided to form a national unity government, and any talk about its makeup, size and other details is journalistic speculation.'' **********And any move by the Labor Party depends on the outcome of a police investigation into influence-peddling in Mr. Netanyahu's Government. The findings are expected any day. **********But it is no secret that Mr. Netanyahu has welcomed the speculation as a means of keeping his present unruly coalition in line. Mr. Netanyahu would also presumably prefer a unity government with Mr. Peres, who poses no future political threat, than with Mr. Barak, who is likely to be his challenger in the next national election. **********But Mr. Barak would have to receive a senior ministry, probably Defense, to agree to a merger. That speculation has raised the hackles of Defense Minister Yitzhak Mordechai, who has threatened to quit if Mr. Netanyahu tries to shift him to another post.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/23/busin.main_headline: VIEWPOINT; Some Privacy, Please, For E-Mail
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/23/busin.print_headline: VIEWPOINT; Some Privacy, Please, For E-Mail
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/23/busin.body_text: **********AN employee's right to E-mail privacy has little or no legal foundation. Various courts have ruled that neither the Federal nor state constitutions provide privacy protection regarding E-mail in the workplace, and only a few states have passed laws that specifically protect employees' E-mail messages. In general, office E-mail is no more protected than employees' telephones, which are fair game, given proper warning by the employer. **********In fact, many corporate policies warn employees that E-mail is about as private as making a personal call over a speaker phone in a crowded office. At employee orientations at Kmart, new workers are told that personal use of E-mail could result in dismissal. **********And many employers haven't shied away from exercising their right to examine workers' E-mail. While statistics differ, various surveys agree that more than a third of corporations regularly monitor their employees electronically, which generally includes E-mail spot-checks. (The actual number may be higher because not all executives are likely to be candid when questioned about surveillance practices.) **********Recently, large companies have also used new software, like Assentor or Spyglass Surfwatch, that allows them to screen large numbers of messages without actually reading them. The software detects certain key words that hint at behavior the company is seeking to control, then retrieves those messages for perusal. **********Aside from exercising what they consider their legal right, corporations rationalize eavesdropping on other grounds. Surveillance, they argue, is needed to insure that productivity is maintained, that trade secrets are kept, that crimes are not committed on their premises and that employees do not use E-mail to harass one another. **********(In a case that was dismissed last summer in Federal court, Morgan Stanley was sued by black employees who contended  that a hostile environment existed at the firm because a racist message was sent on the E-mail system. Chevron agreed to a settlement with four female employees who contended that sexist jokes, circulated via the company's computer system, were part of a pattern of sexual harassment.) **********EMPLOYEES do have some recourse if their corporations have granted certain privacy rights. But few companies have done so, and even then their workers must be willing to take their cases to court. Corporations, however, would be well advised to grant employees a measure of privacy. After all, companies are not merely places of employment; they are something of a community, too. ''On the job'' is where many employees form much of their social network, where they make friends and develop loyalties. **********In the 1980's, corporations were so worried about competing that they paid little attention to things like communal feelings or their employees' commitment to the workplace. But many companies have recently recognized that their streamlining has gone too far -- that impersonal efficiency is often penny-wise but pound-foolish, that corporate interests may be better served by a happier labor force. Indicators of this progression include so-called dress-down days,  corporate retreats and enhanced parental leave. **********Popular fears about privacy violations, real or imagined, offer a particularly inviting opportunity for corporations to show support for workplace community. A granting of privacy rights at work can demonstrate this concern, especially if it comes as a gesture of genuine trust rather than a step required by law. **********The details matter less than the sentiment behind them, but some options come readily to mind. Employers, for example, could provide employees with a bloc of expressly private E-mail terminals -- perhaps equipped with encryption software. Or companies could stipulate that messages preceded by a code word -- or all messages sent to an employee's home -- will not be screened unless there is evidence from some other source that a crime has been committed or that a corporate policy has  been violated. The employer might even declare a maximum number of private messages. **********Other avenues may well be found, but  companies first need to accept a basic point: that even if they aren't required to provide their employees with E-mail privacy, it would be more communitarian, and possibly profitable, to do so.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/21/world.snippet: South Afridan prison at Robben Island is now visited by tourists who line up to see small cell where Nelson Mandela was imprisoned for 18 years; photo; map; local charter boat captains, who have been taking tourists on luxury cruises around island...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/21/world.main_headline: Historic Prison Site Is a Bit Punishing to Tourists
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/21/world.print_headline: Historic Prison Site Is a Bit Punishing to Tourists
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/21/world.body_text: **********On the boat over, Nonga Ndabankulu teased his children about their expectations. They thought the island would be larger. He said that was only because such big things had happened here. **********But now, in the grim passageway outside the cell where Nelson Mandela was imprisoned for more than 18 years, they could only stare. **********''It is so small,'' Mr. Ndabankulu said finally. ''As tall as he is, it means he never was able to stretch. I think the old man was very strong to survive this. It was very cruel.'' **********Since the island opened to tourists on Jan. 1, thousands have lined up to see the place that Mr. Mandela, who is now the President, once called ''the harshest, most iron-fisted outpost in the South African penal system.'' **********Some have stood outside the cell and cried. Almost always there is total silence as gaily dressed tourists, hauling children and video cameras, contemplate what life must have been like here. **********But if the final destination, a one-story stone barracks surrounded by rusting razor wire, has become a shrine, the pilgrim's path to it is across troubled waters. **********A fight has broken out between local charter boat captains and the Government over who has the right to carry tourists from the jaunty Victoria and Alfred wharf -- a slick collection of malls and museums that is one of Cape Town's premier tourist destinations -- to the cell where Mr. Mandela became a legend. **********The charter owners, who have been taking tourists on luxury cruises around the island for years and expected to be allowed to land passengers here when it opened, say the Government's decision to run its own ferries and keep exclusive landing rights is eviscerating their business. Overnight, they said, they lost half of their business, and they are consulting lawyers. **********On Jan. 4, defying the Government, they took more than 200 tourists to the island and allowed them to go ashore. The Government responded by blockading the prison entrance. **********''We can't compete,'' said Bruce See, the head of Boat Owners and Charter Association. ''Looking at it from a boat isn't enough if there is the possibility of going on the island.'' **********Mr. See says the competition is unfair, especially from a Government whose policy is to privatize state assets. **********But the new temporary administrator of the island, Andre Odendaal, says the battle is about the charter boat captains' ''old South African arrogance.'' **********He wants to make sure that nonwhites can profit from a state asset. ''There is no way we can allow people like that to barge in,'' he said, referring to the charter boat captains. ''They have no black ownership, no black crews. They are a monopoly in their own right.'' **********Right now, the Government's $16 boat and bus tour is not exactly fun. **********There are not enough seats on the ferry's hard benches, so many passengers stand or lean. Full boats inexplicably idle at the dock in the blistering sun while the passengers watch comfortable charter boats whiz off, half empty. **********And just when passengers begin muttering about being overcome by the boat's diesel fumes, the captain points out that they are having an authentic experience. The ferry, named the Diaz after the Portuguese explorer Bartholemew Diaz, used to carry prisoners to the island. **********The rickety buses on the other side do not offer much comfort either. They have no air-conditioning, and most of their windows are stuck shut. To maintain what Mr. Odendaal calls the ''sensitive ecological balance of the island,'' which is home to gazelles, ostriches and thousands of penguins, passengers are not allowed off during the hourlong ride except at the prison. They are instructed not to  pick up even a pebble as a souvenir. **********''You just can't have hundreds of people runing around wherever they want,'' Mr. Odendaal said. ''You could do real damage.'' **********Mr. Odendaal says everything about the tours will be reconsidered in April, when the tourist season is over. For now, they are all the Ministry of Arts and Culture could come up with in the four months since Parliament decided to make the island a monument. **********The decision ended years of speculation about its fate since the last political prisoners were removed from the island in 1991. More than 200 proposals were made, including ones for a casino and a vast resort. **********Given Robben Island's history, almost nothing seems absurd. It was, at various times, home to a leper colony, an insane asylum and an army base. It was used as a prison as far back as the 1600's. But in the 1960's a special compound was built for nonwhite political prisoners. It was a place intended to punish, without even a pretense of rehabilitation. **********In weather that ranged from scorching hot to piercing cold, they were forced to break rocks in lime quarries. Food and clothing were rationed according to race: ''Coloreds,'' or people of mixed race, could wear long pants and eat bread with supper; ''Africans'' wore shorts and got less meat and no bread. Assaults were frequent. Beaten prisoners were forced to clean their own blood-spattered cells. **********The tour is led by former prisoners. Some, like Bongani Jonas, are working here temporarily. A former guerrilla in Umkhonto we Sizwe, the military wing of Mr. Mandela's African National Congress, he is now a colonel in the South African Army. **********But others like Patrick Matanjane, who spent 20 years on the island, hope for a permanent job. Some forner Robben Island prisoners are now in the Cabinet. But at a reunion last year, it was clear that hundreds of others are barely scraping by. **********Mr. Matanjane said that when he first returned to the island he cried. But nowadays he finds it very beautiful. **********The guides do their best to explain the harshness of life here. How it took years for the prisoners to win the right to more than one letter every six months and even then, the censors often cut the letters to shreds. How important prisoners like Mr. Mandela often spent 14 hours a day in isolation cells with only buckets for toilets, and often sick from the miserable food. How cold sea water showers gave many men rashes. How everyone slept on grass mats with a single blanket. **********Except for a cot and a wooden table in Mr. Mandela's cell, the prison has been stripped clean, without so much as a poster on its pale gray walls. No sodas or souvenirs are hawked anywhere. **********Some of the tourists grumbled. Others thought it appropriate. **********''It sure isn't a comfortable or fancy tour,'' said Cecil Triegaardt, a communication consultant. ''And there isn't a lot to see, either. But that's not really what it's about, is it? It's something you do because you need to.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/24/busin.snippet: Outlook for stock prices discussed in light of parallels between current market exuberance and bull market that preceded Oct 1987 stock market crash; review of developments that led to crash makes it obvious that United States economy is in much s...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/24/busin.main_headline: 10 Years After, Lessons of an Earlier Market Peak
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/24/busin.print_headline: 10 Years After, Lessons of an Earlier Market Peak
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/24/busin.body_text: **********IT was a glorious summer on Wall Street. Stock prices rocketed to a series of new highs as investors poured record amounts of money into mutual funds. The last recession was a distant memory, and, although interest rates were perking up a bit, inflation appeared under control. With Labor Day approaching, few saw any reason for the market run-up to end anytime soon. **********Sound familiar? The description fits today, but the same events transpired in the summer of 1987, at the end of one of the greatest bull runs in Wall Street history. On Aug. 25, 1987 -- 10 years ago tomorrow -- the Dow Jones industrial average peaked at 2,722.42, culminating a spectacular advance of more than 40 percent in just eight months. **********Who on Wall Street that day could have known that less than two months later, those gains would evaporate in a frenzy of selling, the memory of which still produces knots in the stomachs of many market longtimers? **********To some who lived through it, the crash of Oct. 19, 1987 -- when the market plummeted 22.6 percent in a single session, a percentage decline nearly twice as large as the 1929 debacle that ushered in the Great Depression and more than seven times the 3.1 percent plunge that rattled Wall Street nine days ago -- seemed like a bolt from the blue. **********But even as the first crocus poked its head out of the still-thawing ground that spring, signs of trouble were sprouting on the economic landscape. By late August, they were everywhere, and a few nervous investors were beginning to sniff a disaster. Before the market opened on that Black Monday in October, stock prices had already fallen more than 17 percent from their peak. **********With the parallels between the market exuberance of 1987 and 1997 so stark, the question naturally arises: Are there also parallels between economic conditions then and now that forebode another market meltdown? **********A review of the developments that led to Black Monday makes it obvious that the United States economy is in much sounder shape now than it was then. **********In addition, policy makers have clearly learned the lessons of that era and are not likely to make the same mistakes. **********But the same historical retrospective shows that even as events that bring down a market unfold, their capacity for damage often goes unrecognized. And that raises a troubling question for investors in 1997: Now that the economic generals know how to fight the last war, will they recognize the warning signs of the next one? **********So many economic and political episodes -- from the recent currency crisis in Southeast Asia to last month's balanced-budget accord in the United States -- hold the potential for disruptive consequences that even the savviest policy maker cannot know exactly how to respond to them. And market downturns have a habit of catching people by surprise. Indeed, the big guessing game on Wall Street these days is whether a correction or worse is under way at this very moment. **********That said, many analysts are much more comfortable with the resilience of the American economy today than they were a decade ago. ''From my perspective, 1997 and 1987 are very dissimilar,'' said Wayne D. Angell, a Bear, Stearns economist who 10 years ago was a member of the Federal Reserve Board. ''At that time, you had a deterioration of the economic policy environment, which meant stocks were not going to work as the market had priced them. **********''The economic condition was worsening from October 1986 through October 1987,'' he added. Today, by contrast, it is not. ''My major responsibility is to blow the whistle of alarm if economic policy starts to deteriorate,'' Mr. Angell said. ''I do not see any signs of that occurring. I continue to expect that the bull market goes on and on and on, interrupted only by some corrections.'' **********Letting the Good Times Roll **********Probably the most striking similarity between 1987 and today is the investor euphoria that in both periods helped fuel the market to ever loftier peaks -- peaks that, then as now, economic killjoys were warning were unrealistic by traditional measures. The good times, it seemed, would never end. **********''I would say that things today are maybe 70 percent similar to 1987'' in that regard, said Robert Farrell, a senior investment adviser at Merrill Lynch who in 1987 was the firm's chief market strategist. ''On an economic basis, the two periods are different.
