https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/06/world.snippet: Inconclusive end to peace talks between Zairian Pres Mobutu Sese Seko and rebel leader Laurent Kabila leaves capital of Kinsahsha rife with rumors and panic; city's elite is deeply disappointed that Mobutu failed to conclude deal for his departure...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/06/world.main_headline: In Zaire's Encircled Capital, A War of Words and Nerves
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/06/world.print_headline: In Zaire's Encircled Capital, A War of Words and Nerves
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/06/world.body_text: **********To walk the streets of this nervous capital is to discover quickly that the battle for Kinshasa is well under way. Bullets and bombs are not yet flying, but rumors of the imminent arrival of the rebel leader, Laurent Kabila, are -- and they leave no one here indifferent. **********By the time peace talks ended inconclusively late Sunday between Mr. Kabila and the cancer-stricken longtime President of Zaire, Mobutu Sese Seko, in neighboring Congo, the rumor mill here was already spinning out of control. **********International flights out of Zaire would be suspended as of Wednesday, said one rich, panic-stricken Zairian, afraid of being trapped here by the rebels. Western troops encamped across the river in Congo would be here before Mr. Kabila's fighters could get here, another more hopeful story had it. **********Worst of all, for those who felt they were guilty by association with Africa's longest-standing President, was the apparently unfounded rumor that guerrilla units were already in place in Kinshasa. **********But if the wealthy were anticipating the future with alarm, poorer residents were looking back with disgust. ''Didn't you notice that you had to drive through a lot of mud to get here,'' asked Justin Mukema, a 24-year-old student in the Macina district, near Kinshasa's international airport. ''Is it normal that the streets should be like this in the capital of a country that is rich? Mobutu has tricked all of his adversaries until now, but the time has finally come for him to go.'' **********In a seven month campaign for power, Mr. Kabila's forces have swept clear across this huge country and are indeed preparing to grab the capital, with its five million residents. But as with every other battle in what may be remembered as Africa's most lopsided war, the rebel leader seems to have selected provocative rhetoric as his weapon of choice for capturing Kinshasa. **********As Mr. Kabila spoke from his southern stronghold of Lubumbashi this morning, his opening shots in the siege of the capital came as a direct personal threat to the embattled President: ''If Mobutu surrenders power now I will guarantee his safety and that of his biological family. If not, we will have to chase him away in humiliation.'' **********Mr. Kabila claimed that his fighters were only 40 miles away from Kinshasa's international airport, at the capital's eastern edge, and would begin carrying out their threat against the President ''within two or three days.'' **********The warning came as Bill Richardson, who is the United States' chief delegate to the United Nations and President Clinton's special envoy here, flew to Lubumbashi to urge Mr. Kabila to cooperate in efforts to arrange what the diplomat called ''a peaceful entry into Kinshasa.'' **********Word of a supposed rebel threat to the Kinshasa airport was already hanging thickly in the air Sunday evening, however, explaining, many here believe, Mr. Mobutu's abrupt decision not to take a 45-minute flight home from the meetings in Congo's port city of Pointe-Noire last night as expected, but to wait instead until after daybreak today. **********Mr. Kabila has used much the same tactic in capturing every other major city of Zaire: announcing days, sometimes weeks, beforehand that his men are coming and sweating the enemy out by raising the tension level to the point where Government troops flee rather than fight. With each new conquest, the threats grow more and more difficult to ignore, even as they become more fantastic. **********Kinshasa, of course, is different: There is no other city to which to flee anymore. So among Kinshasa's elite, where there is deep disappointment that Mr. Mobutu did not conclude a deal for his departure Sunday that would spare this city a rebel assault, people seem just a hairsbreadth from full-blown panic. **********''Mobutu said his health would not allow him to climb into a helicopter to take him to the meetings with Kabila,'' said one resident of Binza, a hilly neighborhood of huge, high-walled villas. ''Why has he come back here then? When we start hearing gunfire he will surely find a way to jump into a helicopter, and we will be left behind to pay.'' **********Down the hill, in Kinshasa's teeming low-lying districts people cite other reasons for regretting that Mr. Mobutu did not simply quit power, as many poor Kinshasans had hoped he would on Sunday. **********A crowd there heaped invective on Mr. Mobutu, making it clear Mr. Kabila and his rebels will be greeted as eagerly in Kinshasa as in any of the other places they have already conquered. **********''Let Mobutu understand that Zaire does not belong to him anymore,'' said Sylvie Ndjoli, a 30-year-old hospital worker. ''Why didn't he just leave yesterday?'' Then, answering her own question, she added almost wistfully: ''He is too used to the power, the honors, the red carpets. If he loves his people it is not too late to look around, and the balance sheet he will find is disastrous.'' **********But if Mr. Kabila has used morale-sapping propaganda to devastating effect throughout this war, many here fear that even a dying Mr. Mobutu, the man who has run this country for 32 years through ruse and cunning, may have yet more tricks up his sleeve. **********''You cannot count this man out until he is dead,'' said Sylvain Matumbo, a furniture maker. ''And since he considers Zaire his creation, when he dies, he may try to take us all with him.'' **********Indeed, in the Matonge district of Kinshasa today, residents told foreign journalists that they had gotten wind of a plot by Mr. Mobutu to explode a tiny research nuclear reactor to spread radiation over the area and stop Mr. Kabila's advance. **********Others spoke of marabouts, or sorcerer-soothsayers, from Zaire and other parts of Africa being flown into the country to work at the President's side in concocting a spell that will dissipate months of disastrous luck and turn the rebels back. **********A more sober appraisal came from a columnist in Le Potentiel, one of the city's most prominent newspapers. **********Noting that Mr. Mobutu has always had a strong superstitious belief in dates with the number 4 in them, including the two coups in which he took power, the columnist concluded that yesterday's failed meeting, on May 4, signified an end to the chief's magic. **********''The mythification is over,'' wrote Tshidibi Ngondavi. ''The marshal needs another number. From now on, four equals bad luck.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/14/busin.print_headline: Nokia Reports 76% Profit Surge in Quarter
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/14/busin.body_text: **********Nokia, one of the world's largest manufacturers of mobile telephones, said today that pretax profit jumped 76 percent in the fourth quarter of 1996 and that it expected strong growth this year. **********The Finnish company recovered from cost and inventory problems, enabling its pretax profit to rise to 1.67 billion markkaa, or $341 million. Operating profit increased to 1.74 billion markkaa from 1.02 billion, and sales grew 16 percent, to 12.67 billion markkaa from 10.96 billion. **********Pretax profit for all of 1996 fell 21 percent, to nearly 3.9 billion markkaa from 4.93 billion, slightly below analysts' expectations. Earnings were hurt at the beginning of the year by high production costs, a problem Nokia said was now fully resolved. Full-year sales increased about 7 percent, to 39.32 billion markkaa from 36.81 billion. **********''The mobile-phone operations are recovering very fast,'' Jyrki Hilli, an analyst at Arctos Securities here, said. ''The problem they had in mobile phones is over now, and it's back to business as usual.'' Mr. Hilli maintained his assessment that Nokia stock would outperform the market. **********The company had said that poor organization and ''logistical problems'' increased component and production costs, which in turn reduced profitability in its mobile-phone operations. Today, though, its chief executive, Jorma Ollila, said Nokia was on track to make more money this year. ''On an overall basis we believe that we are well positioned to exploit new opportunities during 1997 and that Nokia will continue to demonstrate strong growth and good profitability,'' Mr. Ollila said in a statement. **********The company's shares were unchanged in Helsinki trading today, at 320 markkaa. On the New York Stock Exchange, Nokia's American depository receipts -- each representing one share -- fell $3, to $64. **********Nokia's profit rose almost twice as fast in the fourth quarter as that of its bigger Swedish rival, Ericsson, because Nokia had taken charges at the end of 1995 as it discontinued unprofitable television operations. Motorola, the big American manufacturer of cellular phones and semiconductors, reported a decline in profit for the latest quarter, citing sluggishness in its chip sales. **********Fourth-quarter sales for Nokia's mobile-phone division, accounting for more than half its revenue, rose 37 percent, to 7.14 billion markkaa.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/18/busin.snippet: ONCE again Congress is being asked to approve legislation that would allow nonfinancial corporations to own and control commercial banks. If approved, this would eventually be harmful to all Americans because it would undermine the very essence of...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/18/busin.main_headline: Keep Banks Out of Corporate Claws
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/18/busin.print_headline: Keep Banks Out of Corporate Claws
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/18/busin.body_text: **********ONCE again Congress is being asked to approve legislation that would allow nonfinancial corporations to own and control commercial banks. If approved, this would eventually be harmful to all Americans because it would undermine the very essence of a democratic and competitive economy. **********The proposal comes up about twice a decade. It last appeared in earnest during the Bush Administration, when it was part of a package to attempt a comprehensive reform of the financial system. Basically, the argument then was that banks were in difficulty and short of capital. Commercial enterprises would take over the banks, infuse new capital and thereby lift a potential burden from the backs of weary taxpayers, who were already reeling from the cost of the savings and loan bailout. **********This time around, the argument for commercial ownership of banks must take different lines because these days banks are profitable, have healthy balance sheets and may even have excess capital. Indeed, this Administration's case is based less on pragmatism than on fatalism. **********Essentially, Treasury officials assert that the marketplace is already mixing finance and commerce. Insurance companies own securities firms. Nonfinancial corporations own insurance companies. Commercial enterprises are allowed to buy savings institutions and convert them into banks. Therefore, they already have entree into the world of banking. What's the harm in letting them have direct entree? Problems would be minor, the argument goes, since few nonfinancial companies want to take over banks, anyway. **********I strongly disagree. First of all, there will be problems and they will not be minor. But it is particularly misguided to start an analysis of the long-term consequences of such a major policy shift with the assumption that it won't happen much and therefore there is nothing to worry about. Well, if it won't happen much, why authorize it in the first place? **********We should start instead with the assumption that if commercial ownership and control of banks is permitted, it will set the tone for all future consolidation in the industry. It would become commonplace, not exceptional. What, then, will the long-term consequences be? **********The joining of industry and banking would eventually alter the economic and financial system for the worse because it would hurt free enterprise and lead to a corporatist state. And over time, it would produce mammoth entities with a strong influence on the flow of credit and thus on business competition. **********A large corporation could use its bank to extend credit to those who can benefit the whole organization. The bank would attract low-cost funds through insured deposits and could use them to finance retailers, jobbers, manufacturers and individuals who further the distribution of the parent's products and services. The bank might withhold credit from those who are, or could be, competitors to the parent. Thus, the cornerstone of effective banking -- independent credit decisions based on objective evaluation of creditworthiness -- would be undermined. **********For monetary policy, the merging of banking and commerce would be detrimental for at least two reasons. The first is that no matter how many times the authorities may say the opposite, the safety net that now covers large banking institutions deemed to be ''too big to fail'' would have to be extended to shield their parent corporations as well when they are in difficulty during a period of monetary restraint or a business recession. Otherwise, the bank would inevitably be vulnerable to huge withdrawals of deposits. Fire walls between a bank and its parent simply would not work. **********Second, support for a steady anti-inflationary monetary policy would wane if corporations controlled banks. There is a basic difference between banking and industry: banks are the channel through which the central bank tries to achieve its objectives; corporations are the central bank's targets. It is corporate profits that are restrained or enlarged through monetary policy. Consequently, it is in the nature of corporations to have more of an inflationary bias, wanting to avoid any monetary restraint because it slows sales and cuts profits. **********AS for our long-term economic growth, the creation of giant banking-industrial combinations would have numerous detrimental consequences. It would create a powerful, self-perpetuating elite, and it is folly to believe that government would stay aloof from this elite group. Through the back door would come insidious forms of influence-peddling and unaccountable decision-making. **********This industrial-banking-governmental leadership group would become highly protective of existing organizations. For many corporations and wealthy families, the emergence of a corporatist state with an elitist control over the economy may be quite desirable. Economic inefficiencies could be covered up. Downside economic risk could be limited through the safety net. **********Moreover, allowing a commercial enterprise to take over a bank provides no significant compensating benefits. It is not necessary for attracting new capital, nor does it provide experienced, skilled management to help banks deal with periods of stress. A commercial or industrial enterprise is generally unable to provide such executives for a bank (nor would a financial institution be the natural place to look for the scientists, engineers and marketers central to the success of a commercial or industrial enterprise). **********Yes, banking faces formidable challenges. But banks must respond by using their own technical and intellectual resources. I can't see how having a commercial company as owner would help.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/26/busin.snippet: South Korean Government more than doubles its bank bailout fund to almost $4 billion, offering special loans to Korea First Bank and investments banks at prime interest rates in effort to prevent bankruptcies from crippling financial industry (S)

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/26/busin.body_text: **********The South Korean Government more than doubled its bank bailout fund yesterday to almost $4 billion, offering special loans to Korea First Bank and investment banks at prime interest rates in an effort to prevent bankruptcies from crippling the financial industry. **********In a speech, the Finance and Economy Minister, Kang Kyung Shik Kang, said the Government would increase a special fund to save troubled banks to 3.5 trillion won ($3.9 billion) from 1.5 trillion won. https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/04/busin.snippet: Specialty advertising units are being formed by WPP Group and Omnicom Group; WPP unit specializes in advertising aimed at children and teen-agers; Omnicom's is devoted to public relations; Bates USA unit of Bates North America will resign, effecti...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/04/busin.main_headline: WPP and Omnicom form specialty units; Bates resigns an account, and Publicis buys a stake.
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/04/busin.print_headline: WPP and Omnicom form specialty units; Bates resigns an account, and Publicis buys a stake.
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/04/busin.body_text: **********THE lull that settled over Madison Avenue during the Labor Day weekend ended abruptly yesterday with a spate of news that included the formation of specialty units by the world's two biggest agency companies, a resignation of a large account and an acquisition. **********The units are being formed by WPP Group, the world's No. 1 agency company, and Omnicom Group, which ranks second. The WPP unit specializes in advertising aimed at children and teen-agers; Omnicom's is devoted to public relations. **********The WPP unit, named Gepetto & Company after the creator of Pinocchio, will operate as a stand-alone part of WPP's Specialist Communications operations. It will be separate from the unit's advertising agencies like Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide and J. Walter Thompson. **********Gepetto, based in New York, will be led by three executives who last week suddenly left Saatchi & Saatchi's Kid Connection, a unit of the Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising arm of Cordiant P.L.C. in New York that also specializes in pitches aimed at younger consumers. **********Julie Halpin, 34, formerly senior vice president and general manager of the Saatchi unit, becomes chief executive at Gepetto. Chris McKee, 33, formerly executive vice president and executive creative director of the Saatchi unit, becomes chief creative officer at Gepetto. And Rachel Geller, 46, formerly worldwide director for strategic planning at the Saatchi unit, becomes chief strategic director at Gepetto. **********At Omnicom, the public relations unit, named Communications Consulting Worldwide, will become part of its Diversified Agency Services operations. It will be based in St. Louis and serve as an umbrella management organization for five agencies, all of which will continue operating autonomously. **********John D. Wren, president and chief executive of Omnicom, said that by the end of the year, fees for Communications Consulting Worldwide would reach more than $300 million, which would make it the world's largest public relations group. **********The formation of the unit comes as Omnicom completes an acquisition that was announced in April of Fleishman-Hillard in St. Louis, the nation's No. 6 public relations agency, with billings estimated at $100 million. Fleishman-Hillard becomes part of Communications Consulting Worldwide along with Porter Novelli International in New York, the fourth-largest public relations agency, with billings estimated at $122 million, and three smaller public relations shops owned by Omnicom. **********Two of those shops -- Brodeur Porter Novelli in Boston and Copithorne & Bellows in San Francisco -- specialize in technology accounts. The third, GPC International in Ottawa, offers consulting services in government relations and public policy in Canada and Europe. **********John D. Graham, 60, chairman and chief executive of Fleishman-Hillard, will continue in those roles and add the new position of chairman and chief executive of Communications Consulting Worldwide, reporting to Mr. Wren. **********Peter Hehir, chief executive of the Countrywide Porter Novelli unit of Porter Novelli International in London, will add two new positions: vice chairman of Communications Consulting Worldwide and chairman of Porter Novelli International. **********Robert T. Druckenmiller, 55, who had been president of Porter Novelli International, will take two new positions: president of Communications Consulting Worldwide and chief executive of Porter Novelli International. Mr. Druckenmiller and Mr. Hehir will report to Mr. Graham. **********And John Brodeur, 47, will remain chief executive at Brodeur Porter Novelli and succeed Mr. Druckenmiller as president at Porter Novelli International, with responsibilities for American operations. **********Omnicom executives said in April that they had planned to merge Fleishman-Hillard and Porter Novelli International. But ''rather than risk damage to two strong, vital, growing brands,'' Mr. Druckenmiller said, ''what made more sense was to maintain the integrity of separate operations while looking for ways to work together.'' **********In another post-Labor Day development, the Bates USA unit of Bates North America in New York said that it would resign, effective in 90 days, the account of the athletic footwear and apparel division of the Woolworth Corporation, with billings estimated at $40 million. **********Bates USA has worked for the Foot Locker, Lady Foot Locker, Kids Foot Locker and Champs Sports retail chains, handling the account since 1994 after absorbing AC& R Advertising, the Foot Locker agency of 20 years. **********Bill Whitehead, chief executive of Bates North America, part of the Bates Worldwide unit of Cordiant,  attributed the resignation to ''philosophical, management and compensation differences with the client that could not be resolved.'' **********''We've been getting calls from Nike and Reebok on how good the work was,'' Mr. Whitehead said in a telephone interview from London, referring to the two main footwear makers whose products are sold by Woolworth Athletic Group. **********''And we had a concept for Foot Locker as the working man's Niketown that we believed we could get to work,'' he added. ''But you can't be in business when a client wants you to do a whole bunch of work and doesn't want to pay for it.'' **********Mr. Whitehead said the resignation had ''absolutely nothing to do with'' a disclosure by Woolworth Athletic Group in early June of talks with agencies as part of what was described as a ''resource assessment'' of the account. **********Jack Aneser, senior vice president for marketing at Woolworth Athletic Group in New York, said: ''We've spoken to over 15 different resources in reassessing what our needs are. That might have annoyed Bates, but that's life.'' **********''We have completed a pretty comprehensive resource review,'' he added. ''We're satisfied with who we've spoken to and in the next few weeks, we'll resolve how to handle this and who will be part of it.'' **********Mr. Whitehead said that the resignation would not affect Kinney Shoes, another retail account that Bates USA handles for Woolworth, because that chain is owned by a different division, Woolworth's Specialty Retail Group. **********As for the acquisition, Publicis Group in Paris said it had acquired a 60 percent stake in Mojopartners, an agency with offices in Australia and New Zealand that has been renamed Publicis-Mojopartners. Terms were not disclosed. **********The deal is part of ambitious plans by Publicis to expand internationally after the end of an alliance with True North Communications in Chicago, which owns agencies like Foote, Cone & Belding. **********Mojopartners has 250 employees and offices in Auckland, Brisbane, Melbourne, Sydney and Wellington, handling accounts with billings estimated at $145 million. Clients include the Coca-Cola Company and Nestle S.A. -- both also clients of Publicis. Graeme Wills, chairman of Mojopartners, continues in that role at Publicis-Mojopartners.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/11/busin.body_text: **********Cassandra Ides Jones, a former  executive of the Chase Manhattan Bank and the owner of an interior design company, died on Thursday at her home in Manhattan. Mrs. Jones, who was 48, died of breast cancer, her husband, Robert Childress Jones Jr., said. **********Mrs. Jones was among the first group of women junior executives whose careers moved into a higher gear in 1978 when Chase settled a sex discrimination lawsuit brought two years earlier by 18 other women. **********She worked in the bank's international institutional and corporate departments, as country officer for Bermuda, in credit positions in Milan, Italy, and New York and in private banking before leaving the bank in 1988 and opening De La Verne Design, an interior design firm. One of her private banking clients, the interior designer John Saladino, named his Cassandra chair after her. **********In addition to her husband, she is survived by two daughters, Caroline and Claire, and a brother, William Ides of Huntington, L.I.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/26/busin.snippet: Investors with failed Yamaichi Securities Co take collapse in stride, reassured by Japanese Government pledges that they will not suffer losses; those waiting to withdraw funds appear embarrassed, reflecting Japanese view of stock market as sort o...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/26/busin.main_headline: THE ASIAN CRISIS: THE JAPANESE INVESTORS ; In Tokyo, Taking a Collapse in Stride
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/26/busin.print_headline: THE ASIAN CRISIS: THE JAPANESE INVESTORS ; In Tokyo, Taking a Collapse in Stride
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/26/busin.body_text: **********Tamio Shiraishi arrived at the Yamaichi Securities Company's branch in Otemachi, Tokyo's banking center, at 7 A.M. today with his newspaper and plans to withdraw his assets. **********No, Mr. Shiraishi, a 76-year-old former liquor wholesaler, was not overly concerned that the failure of Yamaichi, one of Japan's ''Big Four'' brokerage firms, would hurt clients like him. **********''I'm not too worried because the ministry said I shouldn't worry,'' Mr. Shiraishi said, referring to the Ministry of Finance, which has promised that Yamaichi's clients would walk away unscathed from the country's biggest financial debacle since World War II. ''I just came early because I thought it would be better to get ahead of the crowds.'' **********Indeed, since the announcement, Tokyo has gone even further to reassure the public. A senior Bank of Japan official said this evening that Japan's ruling party would move quickly to devise a plan, which could be announced on Dec. 10 in conjunction with a package of tax reforms, to use public funds to steady the country's deteriorating financial system. [Page 6.] **********[On Wednesday, Tokuyo City Bank, a small regional bank burdened by bad loans and rising losses, became the fourth Japanese financial institution to fail this month.] **********For the 50 people lined up quietly outside the Yamaichi branch, panic seemed far from their minds. Like Mr. Shiraishi, most appeared reassured by the Government's statements. **********Rather, several waiting to enter the Yamaichi branch seemed embarrassed. Some wore sunglasses, a fashion accessory far less common in Japan than in the United States. One woman took the extra measure of draping a large scarf over her head. Many buried their faces in books and newspapers, and others turned toward the wall when they saw reporters and photographers. **********Their sheepishness may have partly reflected how the stock market is widely viewed in Japan: a sort of disreputable casino. Making money through shrewd investment, rather than hard work and industry, runs counter to Japanese ethics, a perception that shows up in statistics. **********Of the universe of Japanese personal financial assets, only 6.1 percent are invested in securities, according to J. P. Morgan Securities Asia Ltd., compared with 22.4 percent in the United States. The vast majority, 56.9 percent, are held as currency or deposits. **********Indeed, the biggest beneficiary of Yamaichi's collapse will likely be the postal savings system, the $2 trillion pool of savings administered by the Post Office. **********Hosoya Shinobu, a 49-year-old housewife waiting on the Yamaichi line, said that when her husband had dispatched her this morning to claim their assets he said ''gambate,'' or persevere -- a Japanese way of saying ''good luck.'' **********''I'm very worried about the other assets,'' she said. ''I feel I should withdraw all our assets from other institutions as well and put them in postal savings because it's a national institution and that makes me feel safe.'' **********Mrs. Shinobu was not the only one worrying about the overall safety of the Japanese financial system after the collapse of Yamaichi. **********Stocks plunged in the wake of the announcement. The Nikkei index of 225 issues dropped 5.11 percent on Tuesday -- the first day of trading this week -- pulled down by heavy selling of bank shares. **********Japanese newspapers and television spent the weekend assessing the comparative strengths of various banks and brokerage firms. Most reports concluded that the biggest banks would not be allowed to fail, but that a range of weaker second-tier financial institutions would eventually go bust. **********On Friday, Moody's Investors Service rated the financial strength of one Japanese insurer, the Toho Mutual Life Insurance Company, as ''very poor'' and four others as ''poor.'' **********Two banks, the Yasuda Trust and Banking Company and the Chuo Trust and Banking Company, have the ratings agency's lowest rating, and a third, the Long-Term Credit Bank, has its second-lowest rating. **********The public's growing awareness of the depth of the problems that have festered in the financial system since the bubble economy burst here in the early 1990's also seems to have raised acceptance for the idea of using public funds to protect depositors. Many, though, seem wary of using the same money to prop up banks. **********The Government is trying to find a way to use public funds without raising the angry outcry that accompanied a similar bailout of some housing lenders last year. **********''I want them to protect my assets, that's all I want,'' said Masahiko Tada, a 26-year-old salaryman, or midlevel manager, who was waiting to retrieve stocks worth between 700,000 yen and 800,000 yen -- or between roughly $5,555 and $6,350 -- his entire savings. ''I'm not worried about the system itself.'' **********While Mr. Tada and others were not too concerned about the fate of their own assets, they worried that a financial meltdown would threaten Japan's stature internationally. **********Shigeru Morii's 84-year-old mother not only had an account at Yamaichi, but also one at Hokkaido Takushoku, Japan's 20th-largest bank, which failed last week. Mr. Morii, a cab driver, said he was relieved the Government had in both cases protected her assets. **********''But, you know,'' he said, ''we are suddenly in a terrible world. I could not imagine this kind of thing happening even a year ago.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/07/busin.snippet: Investors buy Treasury securities amid optimism that economic growth is slow enough to keep inflation at bay; 30-year bond gains 10/32, to price of 101 19/32, with yield at 6.26 percent; graph (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/07/busin.main_headline: Treasuries Up In Optimism On Economy
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/07/busin.print_headline: CREDIT MARKETS; Treasuries Up In Optimism On Economy
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/07/busin.body_text: **********Faced with reduced prospects of an interest rate increase by the Federal Reserve after a benign employment report on Friday, and with few economic reports due early this week, investors bought Treasury securities yesterday amid optimism that economic growth was slow enough to keep inflation at bay. **********The 30-year bond gained 10/32, to a price of 101 19/32, with the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, at 6.26 percent, down from 6.28 percent on Friday and a 19-month low. **********Last week, at the central bank's monetary policy meeting, Federal Reserve officials kept the Federal funds target rate, which banks charge each other for overnight loans, unchanged at 5.50 percent. The employment report, like other recent economic data, hinted that growth had moderated, which has cheered bond market participants, whose investments are eroded by inflation. **********The market's rise yesterday was also attributed to buying from overseas and by investors covering short positions -- that is, buying back borrowed securities to cover failed bets that the market would fall. For foreign buyers, the United States bond market remains the most attractive in the world. **********Ken Logan, managing analyst at Technical Data of Boston, said the market was aided by the apparent calming of tensions in the Middle East, which let oil prices settle to levels that the bond market was more comfortable with. **********Gerald A. Guild, senior vice president of the taxable fixed-income department at Advest Inc., said he, like other analysts, believed that bond yields were dropping because market participants were not concerned about inflation and because they also felt that the economy could not sustain its rapid rate of growth. **********''Until now people have not accepted the notion that inflation is really under control and demanded an excessive premium'' of more than four  percentage points in the difference between inflation and bond yields, he said. Historically, he added, the premium has been three percentage points or less. That means there is considerable room for the yield on the 30-year bond to drop, even below its low of 5.79 percent in 1993. **********Standard & Poor's MMS International, a market research and analysis firm in San Francisco, said that while professional Fed watchers remained split on when the next rate increase would come -- with six out of 21 surveyed on Friday now expecting a tightening in November and 11 of 21 expecting one in December -- ''the market has voted even more clearly, pushing the chances of a tightening out to nine months.'' **********Yesterday, in an address to the Rockland County Business Association in New York, the New York Federal Reserve Bank president, William J. McDonough, said the Fed's policy continued on the tight side, with a bias toward increasing rates. **********Rates at yesterday's Treasury bill auction were in line with expectations, but with limited investor interest now that the three-month rate is below 5 percent. At auction yesterday, the three-month bill remained  at 4.93 percent, unchanged from last week, while a six-month bill was sold at a rate of 5.01 percent, or about 7 basis points less than a week ago. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. **********The following are the results of yesterday's Treasury auction of new three-month and six-month bills: **********(000 omitted in dollar figures)                     3-Mo. https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/27/busin.snippet: Digital still camera that Toshiba Corp will start selling this summer is first by major Japanese electronics company to use new type of image-capturing device that might one day make possible exquisitely tiny camera-on-a-chip; such cheap micro-cam...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/27/busin.main_headline: Imaging Device Makes Chip-Sized Cameras a Real-World Possibility
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/27/busin.print_headline: Imaging Device Makes Chip-Sized Cameras a Real-World Possibility
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/27/busin.body_text: **********The digital still camera that Toshiba will start selling this summer does not look much different from dozens of cameras that have flooded the market lately. But on the inside, the camera holds  what could be the seed of a revolution. **********The camera is the first by a major Japanese electronics company to use a new type of image-capturing device that might one day make possible the exquisitely tiny camera-on-a-chip. **********Such cheap micro-cameras could be plastered everywhere as security monitors or placed in the rear bumpers of cars to help drivers back up. They might even make possible the camera in the glasses frame used by Tom Cruise in ''Mission: Impossible.'' And instead of highlighting a passage in a book with a colored marker, a student of the future might take a snapshot of the passage with a camera built into a pen. **********Until now, camcorders and digital still cameras, which store images electronically rather than on film, have captured images using a chip called a charge-coupled device, or C.C.D. **********But these devices have some drawbacks. They use a lot of power, requiring bulky batteries, and are made with a process different from that used to make other microelectronic circuits. That makes it difficult to combine a C.C.D. with other circuits on the same piece of silicon. **********The LSI Logic Corporation, for instance, will introduce a chip that has almost all the circuitry needed for a digital still camera -- but not the C.C.D., which must still remain separate. **********The Toshiba Corporation's imaging chip, however, is made using a process known as CMOS (pronounced SEA-moss), the same process used for making many other integrated circuits. **********That process could result in economies of scale by allowing the imaging chips to be made on big production lines used for other chips. It should make it possible to combine on a single piece of silicon the image sensor, timing controls, image compression and memory needed for a camera -- producing the camera-on-a-chip. CMOS imaging chips also use far less power than C.C.D.'s. **********One big application could be video cameras small and cheap enough to be built into every personal computer, allowing PC users to hold video conferences. Creative Laboratories Inc., the Singapore company known for its Sound Blaster audio boards, is introducing a PC video conferencing system using a CMOS imaging chip from VLSI Vision Inc. in Edinburgh. **********Sensors using CMOS, which stands for complementary metal-oxide-semiconductor, could also tilt the balance of power in the industry, allowing Americans and Europeans a chance to catch up with the Japanese, who now dominate the market both for C.C.D.'s and the camcorders and digital cameras that use them. **********''CMOS imaging allows other companies to get into the imaging business,'' said Bryan Ackland, a researcher for Lucent Technologies, the equipment manufacturer spun off from the AT&T Corporation. Lucent has been researching CMOS imaging chips but has not yet decided to make a product, he said. **********The Sony Corporation and the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company are the leading suppliers of the charge-coupled devices, about 20 million of which were produced for use in cameras and camcorders last year. Including simpler devices used in fax machines and other office equipment, the total market was estimated at about $650 million. **********But the CMOS sensors have been pioneered by two start-ups, VLSI in Scotland and Photobit L.L.C. in La Crescenta, Calif., a spinoff from the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's Jet Propulsion Laboratory. Other start-ups include Omnivision Technologies in San Jose, Calif., and Suni Imaging Microsystems in Mountain View, Calif. **********Numerous big American companies, including Eastman Kodak, Polaroid, Hewlett-Packard, I.B.M., Intel and National Semiconductor, are working on CMOS imaging chips, said Eric R. Fossum, chief scientist at Photobit, who introduced the technology to many of those companies when he was at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory. By contrast, he said, when he approached Japanese companies a few years ago, ''the reaction was fairly uniformly uninterested.'' **********That might no longer be the case. Toshiba has become a leader in the new imaging technology. ''We've suddenly got a shot of credibility from Toshiba,'' Peter B. Denyer, chief executive of VLSI, said. **********Matsushita is also working on CMOS imagers that would be combined on a chip with image-compression circuitry, Akira Matsuzawa, a researcher on the project, said. **********Both types of imaging chips have an array of cells representing the individual picture elements, or pixels. When light falls on the surface of the silicon cells, it is converted into an electric charge in proportion to the brightness of the light. **********The problem delivering the signals to a device that reads them. Connecting a wire to each pixel would cover the chip, blocking out the light. And the charges are so weak that they would be obliterated if put on a common wire, called a bus. **********The C.C.D., invented in the late 1960's at Bell Laboratories, solved this problem by transferring the charges from pixel to pixel in an elaborate bucket brigade. But this requires three different voltages and a lot of time and power. **********But with semiconductor features constantly shrinking, it has become possible to put an amplifier inside each picture cell to increase the charge, allowing it to be transferred off the chip on a common wire and making the CMOS approach practical. **********Still, some attempts to develop such sensors have floundered because the images have been poorer in quality and resolution than those captured by C.C.D.'s. A particularly big problem has been noise, which produces unwanted lines or dots on the image. **********So far, CMOS imagers have been used in only a few applications where low cost has been more important than image quality. VLSI Vision's sensor is used in the Kidcam, a black-and-white camcorder for children that is sold by Tyco Toys. **********But now the quality is improving and the chips are starting to advance into mainstream products. **********The Toshiba camera uses a CMOS imaging chip with 330,000 pixels, standard for consumer-level cameras. The camera, which is expected to sell for about $500 in the United States, can be plugged directly into a card slot in a personal computer to transfer the images for display on a monitor. **********The Vivitar Corporation, a camera equipment maker based in Newbury Park, Calif., is introducing a digital still camera using a CMOS imaging chip from VLSI Vision. It will capture 800,000 pixels, the first such camera with that resolution to have a price of less than $500, said Alexis Gerard, publisher of Future Image Report, a Burlingame, Calif., newsletter on digital cameras. **********At a technical conference in February, Toshiba announced that it had developed a CMOS imaging chip containing 1.3 million pixels, the highest resolution now supported by monitors. **********Not everyone is so gung-ho on CMOS imagers. With C.C.D.'s, ''the picture quality is much better than with CMOS image sensors,'' said Nobukazu Teranishi, a senior manager in the sensor research laboratory of the NEC Corporation. **********Sony, which has produced 50 million C.C.D.'s to date and now churns out nearly a million a month, is increasing its manufacturing capacity to meet increased demand. **********A problem for producers of CMOS imagers is the head start that C.C.D. makers have. ''The C.C.D. is very mature technology and they have a very strong marketing capability,'' said Junichi Nakamura, a researcher at the Olympus Optical Company, which has a small research project on CMOS imagers. **********But Vern Klein, who is in charge of selling LSI Logic's new camera chip to digital camera makers, disagreed. ''All our customers believe that CMOS sensors will be the way forward,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/15/busin.snippet: Eastman Kodak Co says net earnings declined 43.4 percent in third quarter, to $232 million from $410 million a year earlier; sales fell 8 percent, to $3.79 billion from $4.12 billion (L)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/15/busin.main_headline: Kodak Sales and Earnings Continue to Show Declines
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/15/busin.print_headline: Kodak Sales and Earnings Continue to Show Declines
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/15/busin.body_text: **********The Eastman Kodak Company, whose digital photography business continues to bleed profusely, said yesterday that its sales and earnings had declined for a second consecutive quarter. **********Kodak said net earnings declined 43.4 percent in the third quarter, to $232 million, or 71 cents a share, from $410 million, or $1.22 a share, a year earlier. Sales fell 8 percent, to $3.79 billion from $4.12 billion. Excluding a onetime charge in the latest quarter, the earnings were equal to 80 cents a share. **********Perhaps most sobering for investors, Kodak's digital division, the area to which Kodak has hitched its future, lost $150 million in the third quarter, as much as it lost in the whole first half of the year. **********The announcement immediately set analysts clamoring for an overhaul of the digital business. ''They have to decide what products they do and don't need,'' said Robert P. Curran of Merrill Lynch. **********Still, the overall results did not faze investors. A month ago, when Kodak warned that its earnings for all of 1997 could be 25 percent below those of 1996, its stock plunged. After that warning, analysts had expected even lower operating earnings for the third quarter -- 74 cents a share, according to a survey by I.B.E.S. International Inc. As a result, Kodak's shares rose $1.125 yesterday, to $64.6875. **********Some of the decline in earnings was attributable to unusual factors. The 9-cent-a-share charge was for an unfavorable appeals court ruling on a monopolistic practices suit. Currency translations accounted for a hit of 20 cents a share. And Kodak's business in writeable compact disks, which turned a tidy profit in the first quarter, racked up losses in the third quarter, when competition drove CD prices from $4 to below $2. **********Also, analysts expect Kodak's losses in the digital division to start dwindling next quarter and to taper off next year. ''They're not losing money because they have bad products, but because their investments in digital haven't paid off yet,'' said Peter J. Enderlin, an analyst with Smith Barney. **********Kodak's film sales, meanwhile, may be looking up. Its main competitor, Fuji Photo Film, imports the film it sells in the United States from the Netherlands, so the strong dollar has helped it keep prices down. Next month, Fuji will start making film in the United States, so this advantage may be lost. **********Kodak's Advantix cameras, hybrid products that use digital and conventional film technology, are starting to sell well after they were reintroduced following sluggish sales. **********All told, while operating profits in Kodak's consumer lines were down about 21 percent from a year earlier, sales stayed flat at $2.075 billion. **********Kodak has also been trying to reduce its costs. The company already has cut 200 management jobs and has promised to cut 10 percent of its lower-level work force before the year is out. And in a conference call with analysts, Harry Kavetas, Kodak's chief financial officer, promised that Kodak would slash costs and prune product lines even more. **********But many analysts worry that the company will not go far enough. ''They'll write down some inventory, maybe cut some hidden $100 million business, but at the end of the day their cost savings will be piddling,'' warned B. Alexander Henderson, a Prudential Securities analyst who is advising clients to shun the stock. **********Ulysses Yannas, an analyst with Mercer, Bokert, Buckman & Reid, also said he wanted more Draconian cuts than Kodak might have in mind. He wants Kodak to cut its $1 billion annual research budget by at least $200 million, and consolidate or sell many manufacturing operations. ''They've got the lowest sales per employee in the industry, so they've got to get costs down,'' he said. **********Whether Kodak will cut enough to soothe Wall Street fears will become clear on Nov. 11, when Kodak has said it will divulge a restructuring plan. ''The question is not, will they take corrective action, just to what degree,'' said Jack L. Kelly, an analyst with Goldman, Sachs. ''There is no way management can let these losses continue to mount up.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/16/world.snippet: Foreign economists, sociologists and union and political figures have visited Netherlands in weeks preceding meeting of European leaders that begins in Amsterdam on June 16; they seek to understand what has kept Netherlands so stable, prosperous a...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/16/world.body_text: **********The Dutch are used to living with a potent mix of neighbors often seen here as more pushy or flamboyant than themselves. They watch the mighty Germans, the elitist French and the insular British and sometimes get a little sour about being ignored while others drive European affairs. **********So it is with some amusement that the Dutch suddenly find themselves upheld as a model for the rest of Europe. **********In the weeks preceding the meeting of European leaders that begins here on June 16, foreign economists, sociologists and union and political figures have visited seeking to understand what has kept the Netherlands so stable, prosperous and curiously without strikes. **********As Europeans wring their hands over what is usually presented as a choice between heartless American-style modernizing of their economies and preserving the old European social safety nets, many people say the Dutch have found a ''third way'' combining an open, vigorous market with generous social benefits and a measure of social justice. **********Critics point to the high percentage of temporary jobs and social benefits that they say are still too expensive. But for the last five years the Dutch economy has grown faster than those of Britain, France and Germany, and unemployment -- at 6.5 percent -- is well below that of the large European countries. **********The Dutch example has begun to gain wide attention with the approach of next year's deadline for the strict criteria countries must meet if they want to join the common European currency. Countries aspiring to use the currency, called the euro, are in the midst of austerity programs that have led to social unrest and antagonized voters. Leaders at the meeting here are expected to sign an accord aimed at insuring the euro's stability. **********The Dutch say they have invented nothing new by keeping down wages, inflation and interest rates, and by easing the rules for hiring and firing and for opening new businesses. **********But what is different here, often astonishing foreign analysts and investors, is the painstaking consensus building that has avoided social unrest and made wide changes possible. In contrast to the convulsions of bigger neighbors like Britain, France and Spain, the Dutch have worked on avoiding ideological confrontations and for more than a decade have sustained a pact between left and right. As long as unions accepted financial discipline, management has not demanded the dismantling of the welfare state as the price of investing and creating jobs. **********In May, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, the Paris-based research organization of the industrialized nations, noted the Dutch success. It said the country had found a way to tackle unemployment and introduce reforms ''through a consensual process, involving the social partners and clearly not threatening social cohesion.'' **********A recent scene in Amsterdam would have been hard to imagine in London or Paris: the leader of the biggest labor confederation, addressing a workers' congress, declared with passion that it was vital to maintain the strength of the Dutch currency and of the planned European currency. In the front row was the president of the Netherlands central bank, Wim Duisenberg, who applauded, beaming. **********''I might have phrased it a little differently,'' he said afterward, ''but I could sign my name to this.'' **********Such a fraternal scene is not unusual for this country, whose Prime Minister, Wim Kok, was himself a labor leader. **********Now in the spotlight as the host for the European meeting, Mr. Kok has a reputation as a skillful negotiator. He is widely credited as the chief architect of the ''social pact'' between Government, employers and unions that has insured stability. **********As the country's top labor leader, in 1982 he helped launch the pact under which labor federations kept to wage demands of 2 percent per year in exchange for shorter work weeks and more jobs. He stuck to austerity as the Finance Minister from 1989 to 1994, the year he became Prime Minister as leader of a left-right coalition. On a Continent where people are widely disgruntled with politicians, his approval ratings have remained high. **********The Dutch say their achievements have come from tough negotiations.  Cuts in unemployment benefits have pushed people back to work, and the large number of workers calling in sick dropped when new laws shifted the burden of sick pay to employers. As Cees Oudshoorn, an official at the Ministry of Economy put it, ''The Dutch miracle, if it exists at all, is that our labor unions could be convinced to rally around a free-market economy.'' **********Signs of a flourishing market abound. On the outskirts of Amsterdam and around Rotterdam, the world's busiest port, new office parks have drawn foreign companies. Consumers are driving up sales in stores, which only last year got permission to stay open after 6 and on Sundays. **********One telling indicator is the growth of job agencies, which have expanded by 50 percent in the past four years. They advertise a plethora of vacancies in technical jobs, services, sales and health care. **********To draw more people, especially women, into the work force, the Government has deregulated work hours, allowing previously unthinkable part-time and temporary contracts. This has made job agencies into a growth industry, now employing more than 12,000 people. Randstad, the largest temporary help chain, had a staff of 1,600 in 1993 and has 2,800 today. **********''We know where the shortages are, and we help companies plan their work force,'' said Maarten den Ottolander, a Randstad director. ''In the past, temporary jobs could last only six months, but now that they are unlimited, the agencies' role in the market is becoming very big.'' **********One result of the new flexibility is that the Dutch now have Europe's most developed temporary job market. Critics complain that it is a serious weakness that one-third of Dutch jobs are now temporary or part-time. But part-timers still get benefits like vacation and health insurance, and after six months they begin accumulating pension rights. **********Hersta de Goede, in her early 20's, is herself doing temporary work at Randstad and represents the view of many people just out of school. ''I'd prefer to work full-time,'' she said. ''But this is better than no work.'' **********Nicolette Koopman, 23, works three days a week at an Amsterdam bookshop. She said she preferred this to full-time work. ''It gives me time to do other things,'' she said. ''If I need more money, I can get extra odd jobs.'' **********The lively temporary job market seems indeed a boon for young people here, compared with France, where 27 percent of young people are unemployed. But things look worse for workers over 35. Specialists say that the easy-come, easy-go market makes it harder for older employees, because they are more expensive and seen as working less hard. **********Skeptics say the Dutch still have a way to go before all the unaffordable fat from the welfare state is trimmed. Some 800,000 people in a population of 15 million draw disability pay for mild or vague ailments, including ''stress.'' That is 100,000 fewer than three years ago, when the Government tightened the rules. **********Other problems loom. Religious leaders have warned that inequality has risen with the more competitive market. An aging population means that today's benefits may not go on, as workers paying for them become proportionately fewer. **********Yet other Europeans have said that they wish their statistics were as rosy as the Dutch, and that they were as skilled at avoiding political conflict. Whether the Dutch social contract is exportable is unclear. The country has long been governed by coalitions and may be more used to deal-making and compromise than other European countries. **********The endless meetings and debates that come with the Dutch consensus model can seem exasperating to foreign businessmen. But some foreigners note that the lengthy sessions in which the Dutch thrash out ways to live together -- ''a kind of never-ending group therapy,'' in the words of one diplomat -- have recognizable results. The approach has produced a level of trust in the system. **********''It's enough to make politicians in France envious,'' one French resident said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/03/busin.snippet: Futures Trading report; crude oil prices surge (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/03/busin.main_headline: Oil Surges on Fear of Break In Iraq and Colombia Supplies
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/03/busin.print_headline: FUTURES MARKETS; Oil Surges on Fear of Break In Iraq and Colombia Supplies
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/03/busin.body_text: **********Crude oil prices rose to their highest level in four months yesterday because of tensions between Iraq and United Nations weapons inspectors and concern over an impending strike by oil workers in Colombia. **********On other markets, soybeans rose on news of the largest United States weekly export sales in a decade, and copper skidded to a nine-month low on a continued increase in supplies. **********The United Nations said its inspectors were denied access this week to three suspected arms sites in Iraq. Officials see the incidents as a violation of the Persian Gulf war cease-fire, which gives inspectors wide latitude in making sure that the Iraqis honor their promise to relinquish their most deadly weapons. **********The dispute increases the chance that a United Nations report due Oct. 11 on the status of Iraq's disarmament will be negative and will move the Security Council to impose stiffer sanctions on Iraq. Traders also worried that the tensions might affect a plan under which the Baghdad authorities are allowed to sell $2 billion of oil every six months to raise money for humanitarian needs. That comes up for renewal in December. **********Oil prices also rose on reports that a planned 24-hour strike next Thursday by state oil workers in Colombia might turn into an open-ended action, although the workers have made no official changes in their plans. The oil workers are striking in sympathy with unions protesting Government plans to privatize companies in other industries. **********In trading yesterday, crude oil for November delivery rose 72 cents, to $21.77 a barrel, on the New York Mercantile Exchange -- the highest price since June 2 for a contract nearest to delivery. **********Soybeans rose after the Agriculture Department showed weekly United States soybean sales of 1.4 million tons, the highest since 1987. Shipments from South America are almost exhausted, and buyers from Europe and Asia are now seeking to buy from the United States. At the Chicago Board of Trade, soybeans for November delivery rose 7 cents yesterday, to $6.275 a bushel. **********Copper prices fell after warehouse data showed increases in mine output continuing to outpace demand. Copper for December delivery fell 2.85 cents on Comex, to 93.75 cents a pound.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/19/busin.snippet: New respectability reigns in corporate takeover game, compared with 1980's, when acquisitions were likened to Wild West shootouts; corporate raiders no longer launch hostile takeovers with high-risk junk bonds and sell acquisitions piecemeal for q...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/19/busin.main_headline: It's the Era of the Civilized Hostile Takeover
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/19/busin.print_headline: It's the Era of the Civilized Hostile Takeover
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/19/busin.body_text: **********Ronald C. Cambre, chairman of the Newmont Mining Corporation, was prepared for the looming takeover battle. Newmont had survived an assault once before, at the height of the 1980's hostile takeover frenzy, fending off one of the most aggressive corporate raiders, none other than the Texas oilman T. Boone Pickens. **********And now Mr. Cambre had at his side Steven McArthur Heller of Goldman, Sachs & Company, the investment bank that has long portrayed itself as the defense adviser of choice for targets of hostile bids. **********But this was the 1990's, the era of globalization and finding the right business ''fit.'' Corporate America's view of hostile takeovers had evolved from outraged to indulgent, and so had Mr. Cambre's -- so much so that this time around, he was the predator instead of the prey. At first, his secret merger talks last year with the company he coveted, the Santa Fe Pacific Gold Corporation, were friendly. But when he realized shortly after Thanksgiving that his would-be partner was planning to break off the engagement and tie the knot with Newmont's rival, the Homestake Mining Company, he turned on Santa Fe with a fury. **********Three months later, he emerged victorious, acquiring Santa Fe for $2.43 billion and creating the biggest gold-mining company in North America. **********''The hostile deals of the 1980's were made by people viewed as bust-up artists and speculators looking for short-term profit,'' said Robert Kindler, a partner at the law firm of Cravath, Swaine & Moore who specializes in takeovers. ''The deals today are strategically driven. Companies believe that if they can only achieve their goals through a hostile bid, they're willing to do it.'' **********What a difference a decade makes. In the 1980's, takeover battles were like Wild West shootouts, and descriptions of the strife relied on the imagery of violence: greenmailers and raiders with their bear hugs and Saturday night specials were pitted against white knights and corporate managers who fended off their attackers with poison pills and shark repellent. There was even a famous ''Predators Ball'' to celebrate the mayhem. **********Today, a new respectability reigns in the takeover game. No longer do the likes of Mr. Pickens, Ronald O. Perelman and Carl C. Icahn begin raids with high-risk junk bonds only to carve up their acquisitions and sell off the pieces for a quick profit. Instead, corporations seek to forge ''strategic alliances'' that will enable them to grow and prosper in an increasingly competitive marketplace. And the lexicon of even the most hostile endeavors is filled with sober phrases like synergy, the global marketplace and accretion to earnings. **********And almost everybody, it seems, is doing it. Mainstays of the Fortune 500 like Johnson & Johnson and  I.B.M. began their first hostile takeovers in 1995. In January, the Hilton Hotels Corporation made a $10.5 billion hostile bid for the ITT Corporation, and a month later H. F. Ahmanson & Company, a large savings and loan company on the West Coast, made a $5.9 billion hostile offer for the Great Western Financial Corporation in an attempt to shift toward retail banking. This week, Ahmanson sweetened the bid to $6.6 billion.So far this year, there have been 12 hostile or unsolicited bids, totaling $25 billion. **********Once content to tend their regulated monopoly franchises, utilities and railroads are suddenly conducting their own raucous hostile battles in the wake of deregulation and consolidation. Western Resources Inc. not only won the first hostile takeover in the utility industry last month, but the company hired David C. Wittig, a takeover specialist from Salomon Brothers, to be its president. Felix G. Rohatyn, the investment banker at Lazard Freres & Company who once likened Mr. Perelman to ''the Huns and the Visigoths'' for his hostile raid on Revlon in 1986, now works with the financier. **********American corporations today have been so thoroughly downsized and restructured that there is little fat for a 1980's-style raider to squeeze out. And junk bonds have mostly dried up as a source of corporate financing. In the 90's, the driving force behind takeovers is the scramble to stay big and strong enough to withstand the twin currents of globalization and deregulation. **********As a result of the more businesslike environment, even the losers in the current crop of takeover battles display a gentility that would have been unthinkable in the 1980's. Jack E. Thompson, chairman of Homestake, for example, took his failure to gain control of Santa Fe with equanimity. **********''In order to compete, there is a critical mass you have to have today,'' Mr. Thompson said matter-of-factly. ''It was a reasonable reaction for Newmont to try and grab Santa Fe by any means. I was a little set back by some of the subsequent comments. All in all, I thought it was pretty professional, but not a pleasant thing to go through.'' In fact, he added, ''I can see circumstances where we might end up in a hostile bid.'' **********Wayne W. Murdy, executive vice president of Newmont, had no hard feelings, either. ''We felt that the synergies between our companies were so strong that we wanted the opportunity to take our story to the Santa Fe shareholders,'' he said. **********With a rising stock market, corporations are well financed for such deals. At the same time, investors are playing one of the raiders' old roles -- prodding chief executives to increase earnings. When revenues are flat, many corporate chiefs now look to combine with similar businesses in order to dominate markets and cut costs by eliminating overlapping operations. **********No industry is immune from the new merger fervor. Last year, the Dayton Hudson Corporation withdrew from an attempted $6.9 billion takeover of the J. C. Penney Company after Penney rejected the offer, but both companies, as well as the the Kmart Corporation, remain prime targets of other expansion-minded retailers, in the view of some investment bankers. With convergence in vogue in the rapidly deregulating utility industry, nearly any natural-gas company is a potential target for an electric utility hoping to grow and survive into the next century. **********In finance, banks and insurance companies that want to invade Wall Street have increasingly been looking at companies from Paine Webber Group Inc. to the American Express Company as potential takeover targets, friendly or otherwise. In a possible prelude to a takeover attempt, the Bank of New York Company announced earlier this year that it would try to increase its stake in the State Street Boston Corporation after merger talks between the two companies had failed. **********And Newmont Mining's conquest of Santa Fe has only fueled speculation that more takeover activity may be at hand in the gold-mining industry, with both the Battle Mountain Gold Company in Houston and Getchell Gold Corporation in Englewood, Colo., considered as prime candidates. **********Yet all this activity draws little of the outrage vented at the swashbuckling raiders of a decade ago. John E. Hayes Jr., chairman of Western Resources, drew little criticism for breaking a vow he made five years ago not to be ''involved in hostile takeover activity'' when he started not one but two takeover bids last year -- one for the Kansas City Power and Light Company and the other for ADT Inc., the giant home-security company. Has corporate America been worn down -- or co-opted? ''The new respectability is really a product of the shift from financial transactions to strategic transactions and a shift in the nature of the bidders,'' said Martin Lipton, a partner with the law firm of Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz, which that specializes in corporate takeovers and invented the poison pill defense. ''When you have I.B.M. and Johnson & Johnson doing it, you're hard pressed to say it's not respectable.'' **********Certainly, executives at the International Business Machines Corporation thought they had no other choice in 1995 but to begin their first hostile raid on the Lotus Development Corporation, an event that also marked the first hostile takeover in the software industry. With consolidation afoot in the industry, it had become increasingly important for computer manufacturers to forge direct links with software companies or risk being held captive to a competitor. **********Lawrence Ricciardi, general counsel to I.B.M., acknowledged that the company had some trepidation about a takeover attempt, particularly when Lotus's greatest asset -- its employees -- might flee from an ugly dogfight. So, the company issued a $10.3 billion bid, high enough to be taken seriously on Wall Street and at Lotus, and honed a story of how well matched the two companies were to assuage the fears of Lotus employees. **********''We had had conversations with Lotus and weren't able to persuade them to make a deal with us,'' said Mr. Ricciardi, a veteran, like Louis V. Gerstner Jr., I.B.M.'s chief executive, of RJR Nabisco in its shell-shocked, post-takeover days. ''We were concerned that if we kept pushing them on a friendly basis, we might drive them into the arms of a third party. The only surprise in the end was that it was the shortest hostile deal to turn into a negotiated transaction, only seven days.'' **********The recent bidding war for Conrail Inc., the Philadelphia-based railroad that had a virtual monopoly over rail freight in the Northeast, by the CSX Corporation of Richmond and the Norfolk Southern Corporation of Norfolk, Va., was also driven by a fear of being left behind in an expanding market. Conrail agreed this month to a $10.3 billion deal that would split the railroad between the two suitors. **********To be sure, hostile takeover attempts still represent a minority of the record-breaking number of mergers today. According to the Securities Data Company, there were 73 hostile or unsolicited bids announced in 1996 and 97 in 1995, with a combined value of $155 billion. In 1988, however, there were 168 hostile bids valued at a total of $222 billion. **********''It's still very hard to accomplish a hostile deal, even though it's clear there is no longer a stigma attached to doing one,'' Mr. Kindler of Cravath Swaine said. ''The courts have become more favorable to target companies, and you have to be certain when you start a hostile bid that there is no other company in the world that is willing to pay more.'' **********John Gutfreund, the former chairman of Salomon Brothers, offers a rare voice of caution, suggesting that mergers that appear to make sense today because of rising stock prices could backfire if the economy turns sour. ''Shareholders, particularly institutional shareholders, want to get the fastest possible large return and that, in effect, endorses behavior that was previously considered unclub-like,'' Mr. Gutfreund said. ''The deal makers cut the cloth to fit the fashion.'' **********And Mr. Rohatyn notes that for all the difference in style between the current spate of mergers and those of the 1980's, both tend to result in mass layoffs. ''It is a social issue,'' he said, that is still festering.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/16/busin.main_headline: Officials Say Dutch Chief Is Still the Favorite : Paris Again Seeks to Win Top European Bank Post
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/16/busin.print_headline: Officials Say Dutch Chief Is Still the Favorite : Paris Again Seeks to Win Top European Bank Post
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/16/busin.body_text: **********European finance officials said Tuesday that France was mounting a new behind-the-scenes political campaign to try to ensure that the first president of the future European central bank will be a French national. **********But two well-placed monetary officials, commenting on a German press report that Paris would like the job to go to Michel Camdessus, managing director of the International Monetary Fund, predicted that the post would not go anyone from either France or Germany. **********"The decision will be made in the spring of 1998, and it will have to be made on the basis of unanimous agreement," a high-level European monetary official who spoke on condition of anonymity said. **********"Whatever France wants, the smaller countries will not support a Frenchman, nor will they support a German." **********The official added that France's jockeying for position could be a harbinger of the political difficulties that would accompany the launching of a single European currency and related efforts to coordinate policies. **********The favored candidate to run the European central bank once a single currency is launched is still Wim Duisenberg, currently governor of the Dutch central bank. **********Mr. Duisenberg, 61, has been the favorite since he was named last year to take over this July as head of the European Monetary Institute, the forerunner of the central bank. **********French opposition to Mr. Duisenberg was first expressed at a European Union summit meeting in Dublin in December, when President Jacques Chirac said the Dutch candidate would not automatically be entitled to the post. On Tuesday, Catherine Colonna, a spokeswoman for Mr. Chirac, declined to comment except to say, "We made a statement in Dublin, and that statement is still valid." **********In January, European officials told the International Herald Tribune that 14 of the 15 EU government heads had assured Mr. Duisenberg that he was the leading candidate for the job. **********But on Tuesday, the Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung said France would oppose Mr. Duisenberg's appointment and instead propose Mr. Camdessus. As part of a supposed deal with Germany, France would then back a German to head the IMF, the newspaper reported. **********A senior non-German official said Tuesday that France was arguing that because the headquarters of the European central bank will be in Germany, France should be granted the presidency of the bank. **********"The French are making a new push, they are campaigning, but it will not work," said the official, who is in daily contact with top monetary officials throughout the European Union. Both this official and another European financial official familiar with single-currency politics said France was in no position to either offer or guarantee the IMF job to a German or anyone else. **********In recent months, European officials have said that Jean-Claude Trichet, governor of the Bank of France, harbors strong ambitions for the job.
