https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/08/busin.body_text: **********The Schering-Plough Corporation said yesterday that it would buy back $1 billion in stock and that it expects to beat analysts' third-quarter earnings estimates as sales of its allergy drug Claritin lift profits. Claritin is the No. 1 antihistamine in the United States market, with $1.2 billion in 1996 sales. Shares of Schering-Plough rose $2.375, to a new closing high of $56.875. The company, which is based in Madison, N.J., expects to earn 48 cents a share in the third quarter, two cents higher than the average estimate of 25 analysts surveyed. The company earned 39 cents a year ago. Schering-Plough said it would begin the buyback as soon as it completed an earlier $500 million stock repurchase program. That program is about 85 percent complete.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/01/news/.main_headline: Her Death Is Less a Morality Play Than a Modernized Greek Tragedy : The Royal Superstar
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/01/news/.print_headline: Her Death Is Less a Morality Play Than a Modernized Greek Tragedy : The Royal Superstar
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/01/news/.body_text: **********LONDON—                     From the single flower laid beside palace walls to the grand tributes from world leaders, the heartfelt reaction to the death of Diana, Princess of Wales, comes from society's emotional gut. **********The outpouring of grief is a mixture of shock at the sudden tragedy, anger at the waste of a young life, compassion for private family anguish and sadness for public loss. And, mixed in with that, the numbing guilt that we, with our voracious appetite for ownership of the "People's Princess," are somehow implicated in her end. All these emotions will be translated into concrete action in the following weeks and months: the funeral and public mourning; a desire to protect the motherless princes; an urge to give continuing support to the princess's issues and causes, and a debate about unacceptable intrusion into the private lives of public figures. **********But the death of the Princess Superstar, apparently on the cusp of an emotional tranquillity that had thus far eluded her, has a deeper resonance. It offers neither a fairy tale with an unhappy ending nor a morality play with obvious heroes and villains, but rather a Greek tragedy rescripted for modern times. **********The princess had long since passed from being part of the royal pageant — its scintillating and its darker side — to reach iconic status. She was up there with the figures that the world knows on first-name terms: Elvis, Jackie or Marilyn, who, like Diana, was 36 years old when the reality of her life was enshrined in myth. **********In her transformation from the traditionally passive and pretty princess to active world figure, Diana had also become symbolic of the power of modern woman to steer her destiny. **********While men often (openly or privately) sympathized with Prince Charles when the princess went public about her rotten marriage, women cheered her on. She deliberately took the dangerous decision to move her life into the fast lane — not just with her penchant for jet-set life over the stuffiness of the royal court, but in her willingness to bare her soul about her emotions, her bulimia and the infidelities of her husband and herself. **********Her critics will see in this a streak of self-destructiveness that foreshadowed the tragic ending. **********If Diana's story reads like a soap opera, she contributed to the screenplay. By so obviously enjoying her cover-girl status, and inviting the world to share the roller-coaster ride of her personal life, she became the ultimate celebrity symbol of a media-saturated age. **********Diana was, in fact, the first media-savvy royal, a television princess who honed her image to the small screen rather than the big crowd. **********Queen Elizabeth had, it is true, invented the idea of the royal "walkabout," but her dignity and restraint put a glass wall between herself and her subjects. **********Diana became master of the one-on-one encounter — not just with the sick and distressed, but also with a face drawn from the crowd. And while this made great television and newspaper pictures, it also had an enormous popular impact. **********From the reaching out, literal and figurative, grew Diana's role as a quasi-saintly figure, whose way of communicating with the old, the young, the victims of AIDS or land-mine injuries, crossed barriers of age and language. Instead of the post-Victorian royal image of a family steeped in bourgeois values overlaid with pomp and circumstance, Diana appeared to be reinventing earlier mystical concepts of kingship, when the "laying on of hands" was part of any royal progress. **********In an age when conventional religion is often abandoned or deemed inadequate, this "Diana-worship" fulfilled a need. **********And whereas it might have seemed mawkish or weird, people believed in Diana because she was so obviously searching for answers for herself. Her unhappy marriage and its aftermath were filled with visits to psychics, psychoanalysts, faith healers and clairvoyants (most recently with Dodi al Fayed, who was killed in the same accident). **********Diana therefore became not one of "them" — a distant royal with a gracious interest in ordinary folk — but one of "us." **********In every facet of her life, she appeared to mirror the norm in the late 20th century — especially for her gender. **********She was a tireless mother who turned out to have come from a dysfunctional family. People saw her hugging her kids and remembered the story of how her own childhood was haunted by the memory of her mother's departing footsteps crunching down the drive. **********From "Shy Di," whose sweet side-long glance made her look like a startled fawn, she morphed into a business person and working mom, whose causes were big issues in which she proved that one person could make a difference. **********Her time off was also like that of ordinary folk. Ignoring royal etiquette, the princess threw herself into races at the children's school sports days. Her vacations were not behind castle walls, but a glamorized sun-and-sand version of other people's holidays. **********She was venerated for her extraordinary, charismatic beauty, elegance and style — but then revealed that her exterior was as much a facade as her fairy-tale romance with the Prince of Wales. Then she rebuilt her body and her confidence at the gym, as though to prove that glamour is something that any woman can aspire to. **********Even her revelations about her love affair with James Hewitt and her recent flaunting of an intimate relationship can be seen as a mirror image of the "girl power" that dominates the 1990s. **********Diana's presentation of herself as a sexual being was an affirmation of the reality of modern women's lives — the diametric opposite of the image of the innocent and virginal princess sacrificed on the altar of royal conformity in her 1981 marriage. **********How much of all Diana's life was about manipulation through the media to feed the fantasies of an adoring public? In recent weeks, comparisons drawn between Diana's relationship with the playboy Mr. al Fayed and Jackie Kennedy's relationship with Aristotle Onassis suggest that people were not entirely happy with this picture-perfect romance. **********By turning so much of her life into a photo op, she reaped the bad harvest of complicity with the media. **********Yet the princess, even stripped of her official royal status, had still seemed the best hope of the monarchy for giving itself a purpose, a position and above all a coherent image in the modern world. The reaction of the royal family to her death — its ability to express the emotional grief of the public — may determine its status and even its survival. **********When the young Queen Elizabeth II came to the throne in 1953, symbolizing the hope of renewal in a postwar world, her prime minister, Winston Churchill, called her "a flash of color on the hard road we have to travel." He said, "We don't know how lucky we are to have her." **********In Britain and the wider world, most ordinary people would echo those sentiments about Diana and feel that a light is extinguished with her death.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/15/busin.print_headline: New Netscape Web Browser To Offer Push Technology
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/15/busin.body_text: **********The Netscape Communications Corporation plans to incorporate so-called push technology, which automates the delivery of content, into the latest version of its Internet browser. **********Netscape Communicator, the successor to the Netscape Navigator browser, would offer push technology through a feature called Netscape Netcaster, the company said yesterday. **********Netscape Communicator will be available commercially by the end of June for $59.95, the price for Netscape Navigator. Netscape said a preview release would be available from its World Wide Web site within 30 days. **********Blurring the distinction between the Internet and broadcast media like television, products like Netcaster are intended to create channels by which content creators would deliver their material to users. With Netcaster, users could select from a number of channels included with Netscape Communicator, or subscribe to other channels using the technology on the Web. **********Netscape said that it would also distribute software programming tools to allow corporate customers to create their own content for delivery to Netcaster using internal intranets. **********Netscape also plans to announce today that more than 20 partners, including Time Warner, ABC News, CNN, Hotwired, Infoseek, Sportsline, Hearst New Media and others would use this technology to deliver Internet-based content to users. **********''It's easy for content providers to create these channels,'' Mike Homer, Netscape's senior vice president for marketing, said yesterday. **********''It gives them a new way to deliver content to users in the millions. It's designed for ubiquity, and it's several months ahead of I.E.,'' he said, referring to Microsoft's browser, Internet Explorer. The Microsoft Corporation said three weeks ago that it would incorporate push technology in the next version of its browser, Internet Explorer 4.0, which will not be released until later this summer. **********But Yusuf Mehdi, Microsoft's group product manager for Internet clients, said Explorer had an advantage in that it would use existing push technology developed by companies like Pointcast, Backweb and Intermedia, rather than a new system. ''I.E. 4.0, when we ship it, will turn any Web site on the Internet into a channel publisher,'' he said. He said that a preview version would be available within two months. **********Kathey Hale, an analyst with Dataquest, said that both companies still needed to demonstrate the utility of push technology, and to improve the reliability of their products before they were ready for release. ''Nobody has clearly articulated how push technology will be universally useful in our lives as opposed to intrusive,'' she said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/13/busin.print_headline: Bonds Break Out of Slump After Tame Data
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/13/busin.body_text: **********Bond prices rallied strongly yesterday, the first gain in four days, after tame reports on producer prices and retail sales for August suggested that the Federal Reserve might not need to raise interest rates this month to slow the economy. **********The 30-year Treasury bond gained 1 10/32, to a price of 97 10/32, pushing the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, to 6.58 percent, from 6.69 percent on Thursday. For bondholders, the day's gain amounted to about $13.13 for $1,000 invested. **********The Labor Department reported that producer prices rose three-tenths of a percent and one-tenth of a percent when volatile food and energy prices are excluded. Both figures were within expectations, and were ''not exactly a harbinger of an imminent upturn in inflation,'' said Sherry Cooper, chief economist at Nesbitt Burns Securities, a Canadian firm. **********Retail sales for August were another pleasant surprise for the bond market, rising four-tenths of 1 percent instead of the expected increase of seven-tenths of a percent. **********Anthony Chan, vice president and chief economist at the Banc One Investment Advisors Corporation in Columbus, Ohio, said, ''Unequivocal euphoria is the best way I can describe what the mood of the market was like after investors read the results of both the P.P.I. and the retail sales reports.'' **********He said that while the reports did not eliminate the possibility of an increase in interest rates by the Fed, they made it likely that any such move would come later rather than sooner. **********Hugh Whelan, vice president and portfolio manager at Aeltus Investment Management, was not surprised by yesterday's gains. ''We have gotten past big numbers,'' he said, adding that economic reports next week could cause some problems, but were not being awaited with the same fears as yesterday's data. **********Also yesterday, Argentina, in its largest debt sale ever, sold $2.25 billion of 30-year bonds in an effort to repurchase Brady bonds outstanding. The new issue will now be the country's longest-maturity bond, according to Government officials. **********On Thursday, Venezuela took advantage of robust demand for high- yielding securities to sell $4 billion of its 30-year bonds. Investors paid for most of the issue by swapping Brady bonds. **********The new Argentine global bonds, whose sale is being managed by J. P. Morgan & Company, were given a 9.75 percent coupon and priced to yield 305 basis points more than a United States Treasury security with a similar maturity. Investors paid for about 75 percent of the new bonds by swapping Brady bonds.                     -------------------- **********Dollar Weaker vs. Mark **********By The Associated Press **********The dollar tumbled for a second day yesterday, to its lowest level against the mark since early July, weakening on speculation that the German central bank would raise interest rates soon. **********But the dollar continued to rise against the yen, reflecting both the weakness of the Japanese economy and traders' desire to sell yen for the German currency. **********In late New York trading, the dollar settled at 1.7720 marks, down from 1.7805 marks late Thursday, and its lowest level since July 10. The dollar was quoted at 120.96 yen, up from 119.55 yen.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/20/busin.snippet: E W Scripps Co agrees to acquire newspaper and broadcasting properties of Harte-Hanks Communications Inc for between $605 million and $775 million; deal involves six Texas newspapers--The Corpus Christi Caller-Times, The Abilene Reporter-News, The...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/20/busin.main_headline: Scripps to Buy Harte-Hanks Media Assets
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/20/busin.print_headline: Scripps to Buy Harte-Hanks Media Assets
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/20/busin.body_text: **********The E. W. Scripps Company said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the newspaper and broadcasting properties of Harte-Hanks Communications Inc. for between $605 million and $775 million. **********Harte-Hanks, which is based in San Antonio, said in March that it would sell its newspaper and broadcasting properties in order to focus on faster-growing direct marketing and free publication businesses. **********''Newspapers have been the heritage of the company,'' Larry D. Franklin, the president and chief executive of Harte-Hanks, said in a telephone interview. ''But strategically this will allow us to focus all our resources on these other businesses, which together account for about 75 percent of our revenues.'' **********The deal involves six daily newspapers -- five of them in Texas -- along with the television station KENS-TV and the radio station KENS-AM, both in San Antonio. **********''This is the kind of deal we've been looking for,'' William R. Burleigh, the chief executive of Scripps, said. ''For an attractive price, we are going to greatly increase the geographic diversity of our newspaper division through the addition of five mid-sized markets in the vibrant Texas economy, plus one growth market in South Carolina.'' **********The price Scripps will pay for the properties depends on the outcome of Federal legislation, introduced last month, to restrict the tax-free sale of assets under a so-called Morris Trust structure. A vote on that bill is expected later this year. **********If a tax-free exchange of shares is allowed, Scripps will pay about $425 million in its stock and assume $200 million of Harte-Hanks debt. If Scripps assumes no debt, the amount of stock it will issue will increase to a maximum of $605 million. **********If the Morris Trust structure is disallowed, Scripps will pay $775 million in cash for the properties. **********Scripps said that regardless of how the assets are paid for, the deal is expected to dilute its 1998 earnings by about 5 percent. **********The deal is subject to approval by the Federal Communications Commission. Scripps said it did not expect the deal to close until 1998. **********Wall Street analysts said the deal made sense from both sides, even without the Morris Trust provision. **********''Strategically, Harte-Hanks had a reason to sell and strategically, Scripps had a reason to buy,'' Lauren Fine, an analyst at Merrill Lynch & Company, said. ''If Scripps were to get these assets at, say, $625 million, I would say it is a home run. At $775 million, it is not a bad deal, but not overwhelmingly positive.'' **********On the New York Stock Exchange, Scripps's shares fell 12.5 cents, to $38.125. Harte-Hanks's stock price rose $1.125, to $30.125. News of the deal appeared in The Wall Street Journal yesterday. **********The properties Scripps is acquiring ''fit in their core competencies of television and newspapers,'' Michael Kupinski, an analyst at A. G. Edwards in St. Louis, said. **********''The San Antonio television station is in a great market, and the newspapers are in small but good growth markets with attractive operating margins,'' he said. **********The five Texas papers Scripps is acquiring are The Corpus Christi Caller-Times, The Abilene Reporter-News, The Wichita Falls Times Record News, The San Angelo Standard-Times and The Plano Star Courier. Also included in the deal is The Anderson Independent-Mail in South Carolina. The San Antonio television station, KENS-TV, is a CBS affiliate. **********Excluding its newspaper and broadcasting properties, last year Harte-Hanks had revenue of about $600 million, Mr. Franklin said. **********The Cincinnati-based Scripps has television stations in nine markets and newspapers in 16 markets. The company also has an entertainment division that includes two television production companies, a licensing and syndication branch and a cable television network. Last year, it had revenue of $1.1 billion.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/15/news/.main_headline: OBITUARY : Giovanni Agnelli, Fiat Heir, 33, Dies
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/15/news/.print_headline: OBITUARY : Giovanni Agnelli, Fiat Heir, 33, Dies
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/15/news/.body_text: **********PARIS—                     Italy went into mourning Sunday after the death over the weekend of Giovanni Alberto Agnelli, the 33-year-old heir apparent and designated future chairman of the Fiat group. **********Mr. Agnelli, an immensely popular national figure who was the nephew of Fiat's honorary president, Gianni Agnelli, died Saturday after a nine-month battle against a rare form of stomach cancer. **********Mr. Agnelli was buried early Sunday morning at a private ceremony in Turin attended by close family members, including Avery Howe Agnelli, his American wife of 13 months. He also left behind a baby daughter, Virginia Asia, who was born in September. **********Giovanni Alberto Agnelli was born in Milan on April 19, 1964. His father was Umberto Agnelli, grandson of the founder of Fiat, Giovanni Agnelli, and the younger brother of Gianni. His mother was Antonella Piaggio, of the eponymous motor scooter company that is based in Tuscany. **********Mr. Agnelli, who was educated at McCallie Academy in Chattanooga, Tennessee, and at Brown University in Providence, Rhode Island, was chairman of Piaggio. In recent years he had turned the company around and built it into the European market leader and the fourth-biggest scooter maker in the world, after Honda, Suzuki and Yamaha of Japan. **********The Italian public, and the media, loved the young Agnelli and considered him an Italian version of John F. Kennedy Jr. He was rich, strikingly handsome, always smiling and the leading voice of his generation. **********The death of Mr. Agnelli will re-ignite speculation about who will take over the chairmanship of Fiat when Cesare Romiti, 74, steps down this year or next. In 1995, the young Mr. Agnelli became known as the "crown prince of Fiat" when he was publicly anointed as the successor by his uncle Gianni, who called him "the most qualified" member of the family to take over. **********In national terms, the loss of Mr. Agnelli is a setback for millions of Italians who saw him as a symbol of generational change, as a spokesman for the need to reform Italy's clubby and oligarchic system of capitalism and as an ardent supporter of political reforms. **********Mr. Agnelli was a supporter of progressive center-left politicians and also an outspoken critic of old-style practices in Italian and European capitalism. In an interview in 1996 with the International Herald Tribune, he warned that the Italian economy would suffer unless there was soon a "generational change" among its top managers and "more of a free-market approach" in finance and industry. **********Unusually, Mr. Agnelli extended the criticism to his own family, saying, "The establishment should follow the rules of the market more because more competition is good for consumers, industry and investors." Many Italians were struck when Mr. Agnelli, a member of the Fiat board, said: "That establishment includes, of course, my own family. I cannot exempt Fiat from what I am saying." **********Mr. Agnelli, who lived in a 16th century villa not far from the Piaggio headquarters near Pisa in Tuscany, announced last April that he had been diagnosed with cancer. He underwent several months of chemotherapy at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Hospital in New York, before returning home to Turin in August. **********Italy's business and political elite offered condolences as soon as the news of Mr. Agnelli's death broke Saturday. **********"He was the symbol of youth," said Prime Minister Romano Prodi, while attending a summit meeting of European Union leaders in Luxembourg. "He died just as he was beginning to collect the fruits of life."

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/19/world.snippet: Investors in South Korea react with some anxiety to election of longtime dissident Kim Dae Jung to lead nation through time of financial hardship; Korean stock market opens down nearly three percent and currency also falls; concern is that Kim, li...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/19/world.main_headline: South Korean Election Leaves Many Investors Wary of Future
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/19/world.print_headline: South Korean Election Leaves Many Investors Wary of Future
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/19/world.body_text: **********Investors reacted with some anxiety today to the election of the longtime dissident Kim Dae Jung to lead the nation through a time of financial hardship. **********The Korean stock market opened for trading down nearly 3 percent. By early afternoon, the Korea Composite index was down 5 percent, to 397.44. The Korean currency, the won, dropped to 1,623 to the dollar, compared with its previous close of 1,481 won. **********The reaction stems partly from fears that Mr. Kim, a liberal populist with strong support from organized labor, might resist fulfilling the agreement South Korea made with the International Monetary Fund for the $57 billion rescue of the South Korean economy. **********The I.M.F. agreement will result in the opening of Korea's markets to foreign products and investors, something Mr. Kim has been wary of in the past. The agreement is also likely to cause widespread unemployment as money-losing banks and other failing businesses are closed. **********In a speech and news conference this morning, the President-elect tried to reassure foreign investors and lenders, whose decisions will largely determine if South Korea defaults on foreign debt held by its banks and corporations. **********''I will thoroughly implement a free market economy,'' Mr. Kim said. ''I will boldly open the market. I will make it so that foreign investors can invest with confidence.'' **********But while Mr. Kim said he would ''diligently carry out the I.M.F. terms,'' he added that he would ''continuously negotiate with the I.M.F. regarding minor and specific problems,'' in order to minimize job losses and bankruptcies. **********Mr. Kim, who heads the largest opposition party, had said during the campaign that he would renegotiate the I.M.F. agreement. When such comments scared foreign investors, leading to sharp drops in stock prices and the won, he reversed himself and embraced the accord. **********But some business executives fear that Mr. Kim is not consistent in his policies, aggravating uncertainty that already clouds the economic outlook. By contrast, Lee Hoi Chang, the candidate of the ruling Grand National Party, is considered much more predictable. **********Another concern is that Mr. Kim and his party, the National Congress for New Politics, do not control the National Assembly, which will convene next week to pass reform laws required by the I.M.F. Although the assembly's majority is held by the Grand National Party, political deadlocks could impede the reform. **********Moreover, Mr. Kim will not formally take power until Feb. 25. Until then, he will have to cooperate with the incumbent, President Kim Young Sam, his long-time rival. This could make it more difficult for South Korea to navigate the crucial next few weeks, when billions of dollars in foreign debt must be repaid.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/25/busin.snippet: Federal Communications Commission rejects BellSouth Corp's application to enter long-distance telephone business in South Carolina (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/25/busin.main_headline: BellSouth Long-Distance Bid In South Carolina Is Rejected
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/25/busin.print_headline: BellSouth Long-Distance Bid In South Carolina Is Rejected
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/25/busin.body_text: **********The Federal Communications Commission today rejected the BellSouth Corporation's application to enter the long-distance telephone business in South Carolina. The decision had been expected. **********The five-member commission unanimously concluded that the Atlanta-based Baby Bell had not sufficiently opened its local telephone markets in South Carolina to competition. Under last year's telecommunications law, the big regional phone companies can enter the $90 billion long-distance market only after their local markets are open to competition. **********The commission had earlier rejected a bid by the Ameritech Corporation of Chicago to offer long-distance service in Michigan and an application by the SBC Communications Corporation of San Antonio to enter the business in Oklahoma. **********The commission's chairman, William E. Kennard, said today that BellSouth had ''made significant progress'' but failed to meet all of the law's standards. For example, he said, the company had not provided rivals with the same easy access to its network as it does to itself. As a result, he said competitors ''are much more likely to experience errors and delays'' when trying to connect new customers. **********Nevertheless, Mr. Kennard said the BellSouth application ''moved us much closer to the day'' when a regional Bell company would meet the law's requirements. **********BellSouth, which lobbied aggressively for approval of its petition, said it was disappointed. **********The Justice Department had recommended that BellSouth's South Carolina application be blocked. A separate BellSouth application to enter the long-distance business in Louisiana is also likely to be rejected by the commission, as the Justice Department has recommended. **********State regulators in South Carolina had approved BellSouth's long-distance application.The company had taken out full-page advertisements in local newspapers saying, ''This Christmas, the F.C.C. has a chance to deliver a real gift to millions of residential consumers.'' It promised to create 7,500 jobs.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/25/busin.snippet: Richard L Scott, deal maker who built Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corp, country's biggest for-profit hospital chain, appears close to resigning as chairman and chief executive; Columbia/HCA board meets to decide strategy of dealing with array of Gover...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/25/busin.main_headline: Chief Seems About to Quit At Columbia
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/25/busin.print_headline: Chief Seems About to Quit At Columbia
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/25/busin.body_text: **********Richard L. Scott, a deal maker who built the Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation, the country's biggest for-profit hospital chain, appears close to resigning as chairman and chief executive. **********The Columbia/HCA board was meeting last night in Nashville, where the company is based, to decide strategy on dealing with an array of Government fraud investigations, which have depressed Columbia share prices, and a takeover discussion with the Tenet Healthcare Corporation, the second-largest investor-owned hospital chain. **********Mr. Scott's take-no-prisoners business style, and success in stitching together 340 hospitals and 570 home health care centers -- which is the country's largest home health network -- has provoked a backlash of opposition among doctors, hospital executives and state attorneys general across the country. **********People who are eager for the Tenet deal, which would create a juggernaut of about 475 hospitals and $30 billion in revenue, hope that banishing Mr. Scott could open the door to settling the various fraud investigations. Government officials have declined to discuss their plans or possible outcomes. **********A person involved in the negotiations between the two companies said he had learned that Mr. Scott would be out by the end of the week. Asked about this, the company declined to comment on the report but did not deny it. Mr. Scott could not be reached for comment. **********Agents from half a dozen Federal agencies are working on the Columbia/HCA investigation. A spokeswoman for the Justice Department said last week that 35 search warrants had been served in seven states -- Florida, Texas, Tennessee, North Carolina, Utah, Oklahoma and Georgia -- on hospitals now or formerly owned by Columbia and two companies doing business with the chain. **********The investigators have sifted records from at least 50 Columbia hospitals and raised questions about Medicare billings for services by doctors, recruitment of physicians, referrals to home health agencies and blood laboratory work. **********Mr. Scott, a health care lawyer originally from Kansas, was picked out of obscurity by Richard Rainwater, the Fort Worth financier, to head the company. Mr. Scott owns about 1.4 percent of Columbia shares, according to company filings in March; those would be valued at $340 million at yesterday's closing price of $36.25, down 6.25 cents on the New York Stock Exchange. **********Merger negotiations with Tenet, which have been intermittent for more than a year and were disclosed in The Wall Street Journal on Wednesday, are snagged on the difficulty of valuing Columbia. It is virtually impossible to know whether or how much Columbia/HCA might have to pay to settle with the Government. **********''They've got to find a way to get the value up to the $40 range for Tenet shareholders,'' Dan Cain, a health care investment banker, said of the stock price, ''and invent a creative way so the Tenet shareholders are not buying into a bottomless pit.'' **********Mr. Cain, who advised nonprofit hospitals in a number of deals with Columbia, suggested that Tenet stockholders could be given ''a warrant or contingent note'' with a value that would vary depending on the size of the settlement, ''if it's a $500 million penalty, if it's a $750 million penalty, and so on.'' **********Tenet had its origins in National Medical Enterprises, a much smaller hospital chain that paid $379 million in 1994 to settle Federal and state charges involving fraud and abuses of psychiatric patients, and several hundred million dollars more to insurance companies and individuals. Jeffrey C. Barbakow, the chairman and chief executive of Tenet, had been a National Medical Enterprises board member who was brought in to clean up the mess and settle with the Government. **********While the combined hospitals of Columbia and Tenet would be less than 15 percent of the country's hospitals, their dominance in Texas and southern Florida might well raise antitrust issues. **********Columbia has 25 hospitals in southern and southwestern Florida, and Tenet has 11. In Houston, which has roughly 40 hospitals, Columbia operates eight acute-care hospitals and Tenet runs five. And of the nine hospitals in El Paso, Columbia has four and Tenet has two. **********Jeffrey C. Villwock, an analyst with Robinson-Humphrey, said there would be ''serious antitrust problems in Florida,'' among other places. **********The Columbia chain, which started out small in Texas and South Florida, vaulted to the top when Mr. Scott and Mr. Rainwater negotiated mergers with groups of hospitals formerly operated by Humana Inc., HCA and Healthtrust. **********Thomas N. Frist, whose family started the Hospital Corporation of America, the parent of HCA and Healthtrust, owns 14.6 million shares, or 2.2 percent of Columbia, now valued at $529 million. Mr. Frist, a career hospital executive, is said to be displeased by Mr. Scott's aggressive operating style. **********Kenneth S. Abramowitz, a health care analyst with Sanford C. Bernstein & Company, said Mr. Frist, who is a Columbia board member, might be given the role of negotiating with the Government. Other analysts said that Mr. Frist could become interim chief executive following a removal of Mr. Scott. **********Mr. Barbakow, chairman of Tenet, would be expected to head the combined company, if the deal goes through. **********''There are three parties at the table,'' said Margo Vignola, an analyst with Merrill Lynch & Company, ''Columbia, Tenet and the Federal Government.'' **********Mr. Cain, the investment banker, said that Mr. Scott had brought new life to for-profit hospital stocks, which were ''languishing on Wall Street'' when he bought his first hospitals in El Paso. ''But he expanded in such an antagonistic style that the Government, the payers, the physicians and the not-for-profit hospitals are completely focused on him as the Darth Vader of the industry,'' Mr. Cain said. **********''What Wall Street wants,'' Mr. Cain added, ''is a softer, gentler investor ownership model, which can get on with the consolidation of the health care industries but without all this controversial byproduct.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/07/world.snippet: Mexico tentatively identifies body of man who died in Mexico City hospital after facial surgery and liposuction as billionaire drug trafficker Amado Carrillo Fuentes; Mexican anti-drug agents, who once seemed sluggish in prosecuting Carrillo Fuent...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/07/world.main_headline: Mexico Finds Body But Then Wonders: Is It Top Drug Boss?
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/07/world.print_headline: Mexico Finds Body But Then Wonders: Is It Top Drug Boss?
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/07/world.body_text: **********In what appears to be a macabre final chapter for one of the hemisphere's premier pulp fiction figures, the Government said today that ''there are indications'' that a man who died here after facial surgery and midriff liposuction was Amado Carrillo Fuentes, the billionaire drug trafficker. **********The announcement came during a transcontinental pursuit of the body, in which Mexican anti-drug agents, who once seemed sluggish in prosecuting the drug trafficker, aggressively chased his presumed cadaver. **********They trailed the body from a hospital here to a funeral parlor in the state of Sinaloa, where they seized it by judicial order and shipped it back to Mexico City for a battery of autopsies and D.N.A. tests. **********The Government said it could not confirm the death of Mr. Carrillo Fuentes ''with total certainty.'' But Thomas A. Constantine, the director of the United States Drug Enforcement Administration, said in a telephone interview from Washington that the Mexican authorities had matched the body's fingerprints with those of Mr. Carrillo Fuentes and that American agents had been allowed to view the body. **********''I would say that this has believability,'' Mr. Constantine said. ''I'd rather have him alive to find out all he knew, but this is the second-best option.'' **********Mr. Carrillo Fuentes was an entrepreneur in the $10-billion-a-year business of smuggling South American cocaine and other drugs through Mexico into cities across the United States. **********In recent years he consolidated under his influence Mexico's entire drug underworld, except for one murderous rival gang, the Arellano Felix family of Tijuana, and had even begun to dominate in his relations with Colombian suppliers. **********Mexican and United States officials said his apparent death would destabilize narcotics relationships across the continent. Several officials suggested that his younger brother Vicente would try to take his place. But a fierce battle for succession could break out among his lieutenants and competitors trying to muscle into his organization. **********Mr. Carrillo Fuentes, whose age has been given as 41 or 42 -- authorities have found two birth certificates -- rose to vast wealth in the 1980's but remained an obscure figure until 1994, when he earned the nickname ''Lord of the Skies'' by having multi-ton cocaine loads flown to Mexico from Colombia in converted commercial jetliners. Except for a brief detention in 1989 and despite his indictment in Miami and Dallas on charges of smuggling heroin, marijuana and cocaine, Mr. Carrillo Fuentes avoided arrest here, moving freely between his mother's home in Sinaloa, the northern cities that were his major operational centers and his sprawling haciendas and penthouse apartments elsewhere. **********Mr. Carrillo Fuentes spent his billions freely, buying protection from senior Mexican law enforcement officials and politicians, including two state Governors, United States officials say. In February, Mexico's top anti-drug official, Gen. Jesus Gutierrez Rebollo, was arrested on charges of putting his entire central Mexican command of 38,000 troops at the trafficker's service. **********Mr. Carrillo Fuentes operated a sophisticated intelligence operation, using computerized scanners to eavesdrop on hundreds of phone lines. He appeared to have enlisted General Gutierrez's cooperation largely by offering reconnaissance information on rivals. **********But there seems to have been a drastic change in his life in the weeks before General Gutierrez's arrest. **********Mr. Carrillo Fuentes barely escaped capture by a 300-troop force of soldiers that raided his mother's ranch at Guamuchilito, a village outside Culiacan in Sinaloa, and soon he became a full-time fugitive. **********The Drug Enforcement Administration has received unconfirmed reports in recent months that he has been in Russia, Cuba and South America, Mr. Constantine said. **********Although a consensus seemed to  form that Mr. Carrillo Fuentes is dead, some remained skeptical. ''I wouldn't believe it until there's absolutely foolproof positive identification,'' said one senior United States official. ''It sounds like a cheap novel. A man dies after having plastic surgery. He walks away with a new name, a new face, a new stomach. It just seems too cute.'' **********The reports of Mr. Carrillo Fuentes's death began to circulate on Friday. Government agents began investigating them on Saturday, a statement issued today by Mexico's Attorney General's office said. **********The agents found that a man identifying himself as Antonio Flores Montes, 42, checked into the Santa Monica Hospital in the upper-class Polanco district here on Thursday, listing a false address, ''to submit himself to procedures of liposuction and extensive facial surgery.'' **********The surgery lasted eight hours, the statement said, after which the patient was moved to a recovery area and later to a private room. At 6 A.M. Friday, a duty physician found him dead in his bed, and the hospital filled out a death certificate listing heart failure as the cause. **********Early Saturday, the body, identified as that of Mr. Flores, was put aboard an Aeromexico flight by a Mexico City mortuary and shipped to Culiacan, where it was transferred to a funeral home, the statement said. **********By that time, word of the reported death had made its way into Sinaloa newspapers, and hundreds of weeping relatives and gunmen were converging at his mother's Guamuchilito ranch. Later on Saturday, Mexican drug agents seized and examined the body and checked its fingerprints, the statement said. **********The Government statement did not report the result of the fingerprint exam, but Mr. Constantine said it had provided a positive identification of Mr. Carrillo Fuentes. **********On Saturday evening, the trafficker's mother, Aurora Fuentes Lopez, visited the Culiacan mortuary. She emerged minutes later and told reporters, ''Yes, it's my son.'' **********Early today, the body was flown again to Mexico City for further tests. The Government promised to allow Michael Garland, the D.E.A.'s attache in Mexico, to view the body, Mr. Constantine said. **********Nonetheless, there was continuing skepticism, reflecting a recent stream of somewhat baroque official statements here, including the breathless announcement by Mexico's Attorney General that a skeleton unearthed at the bidding of a fortune teller was the body of a Congressman wanted for questioning in a murder trial. The story was a complete charade. **********But in Guamuchilito, scores of grieving relatives continued to trudge into the family ranch today. **********It is uncertain whether Mr. Carrillo Fuentes's brother will be able to take his place. ''Vicente doesn't have the juice,'' said a former American drug official with experience in Mexico. ''He doesn't have the respect that his brother commanded. He may try to step in, but others will say, 'You're not your brother. We're not going to follow.' So there'll probably be some little wars.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/16/busin.print_headline: Newest Bre-X Suit Will Seek $101 Million
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/16/busin.body_text: **********A court here today permitted a shareholder lawsuit to proceed against officials of Bre-X Minerals Ltd. to reclaim profits they made by selling shares before the company collapsed in a gold-discovery fraud earlier this year. **********Lawyers for the shareholders said the planned suit, which will name the company's chief executive, David G. Walsh, and other Bre-X directors and officers, will seek $140 million (Canadian) -- about $101 million (United States). **********Bre-X consultants, such as SNC-Lavalin, will also have to explain how Bre-X's much-touted discovery in Indonesia turned out to be a fraud, the lawyers said. **********''Here we come, ready or not,'' said Harvey Strosberg, a Windsor, Ontario, lawyer representing a group of Ontario shareholders, including several institutions holding millions of Bre-X shares. ''We are coming after these people with everything we have.'' **********The ruling, by the Court of Queen's Bench here, gave the groups permission to start what is known as a derivative action, allowing them to sue in Bre-X's name to recover profit made by company insiders on the sale of shares. **********Mr. Strosberg said he would go to court to begin the derivative action after Justice Robert Cairns lifts Bre-X's protection from such suits under Canadian law. **********He said the issue would be the responsibility insiders have to the company, not just shareholders. **********The suit will follow several others pending against Bre-X, its management and consultants. **********The company gained bankruptcy protection in May after its stock collapsed, caused by the disclosure that its gold find in Busang, on the island of Borneo, once touted as one of the richest in history, was a fraud, showing only negligible traces of gold.

The unit being acquired is the Air Restraint and Technical Products division of JPS Automotive L.P. Safety Components will also pay off the division's $650,000 debt, and it will buy a 350,000-square-foot building adjacent to the property of the division, which is based in Greenville, S.C., for $1.25 million. Safety Components, a manufacturer of air bag components, expects to add $80 million in revenue through the acquisition to give it total revenue of about $200 million.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/30/busin.body_text: **********Prices of Treasury securities slumped in thin trading yesterday, despite a housing report that showed a decline in the sales of existing homes. A rally in stocks and news of more expected help for South Korea weighed on bond prices as investors moved money from the Treasury market into equities. **********The price of the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond declined 9/32  to 102 28/32 . The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 5.92 percent from 5.90 percent Friday. **********This week is among the market's slowest, noted Ken Logan, a managing analyst with Technical Data in Boston, and yesterday's trading was about half the normal daily volume. ''It was a type of session that many in the market anticipated and hoped for as they prepared to put another trading year in the books,'' he said. ''When the new year hits, look for all market eyes to be on the fluid situation in Asia and all ears to be on Fed Chairman Greenspan's Jan. 3 speech to the American Economic Association in Chicago for the market's next directional move.'' **********The National Association of Realtors said yesterday that sales of existing homes fell two-tenths of 1 percent in November, after three months of gains. Although the decline was expected, it suggested that the economy is slowing to a pace that could keep inflation in check and the Federal Reserve from increasing interest rates. **********But the bond market was under other pressures yesterday, including the seasonal reality that market participants are not likely to take big positions going into the close of the quarter and the year-end period. **********The shaky Asian markets, which have supplied the energy for gains in Treasury securities as investors sought safety, failed to provide much impetus for buying yesterday. **********Robert Pugliese, senior vice president and director of the fixed income department at J. W. Charles Securities in Boca Raton, Fla., showed little concern about the decline. ''If you had a wish list,'' he said, ''a bond bull couldn't ask for a better scenario than this. When investors come back and reassess the big picture, they will find many compelling reasons to be optimistic about bonds.'' **********Among some of the reasons, Mr. Pugliese cited talk in Washington of a prospective Federal budget surplus, increases in productivity, declining import prices, a strong dollar and stable-to-declining wholesale and consumer prices. ''Simply put, an inflation outlook that couldn't look any more favorable,'' he remarked. **********Analysts said the Treasury's weekly bill auction was about average, with the three-month and the six-month maturities selling at identical rates: 5.285 percent. The three-month bill was down from 5.295 percent last week, and the six-month bill down from 5.315 percent. https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/26/world.main_headline: In the Land of the Small It Isn't Easy Being Tall
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/26/world.print_headline: In the Land of the Small It Isn't Easy Being Tall
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/26/world.body_text: **********A quick glance around is enough to tell the arriving visitor here that Ghana is a country designed for the abbreviated of stature. **********Visit most homes and the doorways are low. Lie down on any bed outside of the major international hotels and discover how short a mattress can be. And if you are over 6 feet tall, don't even think about buying clothes off store racks here; they won't fit. **********The esthetic value placed on compactness has long been enshrined in the famous wooden sculpture of the prevailing ethnic group in this part of West Africa, the Akan, who sculpt muscular carved couples of men and women in a squatting posture, almost as if to emphasize their shortness. **********And while Ghanaians are almost unfailingly friendly, in a society where an average adult male stands  about 5 feet 8 inches, it is not a place where a 6-foot-4-inch foreign journalist can expect to work without drawing stares. **********''When we were in school we were always forced to sit in the back,'' said Godwin Kuadey, a broad-shouldered, booming-voiced 6-foot-7-inch man who is now chief superintendent of the Ghanaian police. ''If you ever sat anywhere else, people would complain you are blocking their view. On the playground, when we played volleyball, people would tease me, calling me the pole.'' **********In a country where some regions lack clean water or electricity, where hunger and illiteracy afflict many, Mr. Kuadey's complaint may seem trivial, but it is serious enough to the members who have sought comforting solidarity in the Tall Men's Club of Ghana. **********The association aims, say members like the police superintendent, to defend the rights of this country's least-known oppressed minority: the few who tower over the many. **********For the 65 or so members over 6 feet tall who banded together to form the club a year ago, the handicaps of being statuesque in the land of the squat range from the mundane difficulties of finding shoes that fit to discrimination against tall people in the workplace. **********Most of all, though, the group aims to give its members, who have gone from being awkward wallflowers at teen-age parties to uncomfortable standouts in crowded office elevators, the self-confidence to get over what many say has been a crippling shyness and get on with their lives. **********''To be a tall person can be quite embarrassing, especially for a lot of younger guys,'' said Sammy Dodoo,  33, a manager at a telecommunications company here who is 6 feet 4 inches tall. **********''This society does everything it can to remind you that you are too tall. The result is that lots of tall people feel shy about asserting themselves, or even coming out.'' **********Although Ghana's Tall Men's Club organizes regular fund-raisers for charity work, operates an agricultural cooperative that hopes to become a big exporter of tropical produce, and provides volunteers for good works like cleaning up the grounds of the state hospital, the primary focus of the monthly meetings it holds in Accra's Y.M.C.A. seems to be making its members feel more secure about themselves. **********''Our biggest preoccupation is to improve the social and financial well-being of our members,'' said Joseph Mensah, 50, a founder of the club, who at 6-feet-2 is one of its shortest members. **********''We can't do this until we have begun to make people feel proud of themselves. So we have adopted a motto that tells our members it is not enough to be tall, you must also be outstanding.'' **********The idea for the club came to him, Mr. Mensah said, when his teen-age daughter remarked that her father always seemed to surround himself with tall people, starting with his own family. **********Like most every member, Mr. Mensah, who is a civil engineer, said  he remembers the teasing of classmates over long legs that wouldn't fit under his school desk or between the tightly spaced seats of the city's ramshackle buses. **********''When kids are playing soccer no one wants you on their team because you are so tall,'' he said. ''When you are standing in a crowd, the short people start to jeer you, telling you that you are too tall, that you should get back. When boys start dating, everyone makes fun of you because of your height.'' **********As their first political effort, Ghana's tall men are seeking to change official standards in building codes and procurement of office furniture more suitable for tall people. **********The drive takes its inspiration from tall men's crusades in places like Belgium and the Netherlands, where, Mr. Mensah said, similar organizations have had some successes in winning concessions. **********Not everyone shares the sense of tall Ghanaians as put upon. In a quick poll of Ghanaian women met in the streets of this city on a recent afternoon, few could understand why tall men would feel shy or unwanted. **********''Where are all these tall men, and what is their problem?'' asked Abla Amoakwa, 26, a single woman who works as a secretary. ''Every woman I know would prefer to go out with a tall man. The problem is that there just aren't any here.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/03/world.snippet: Diplomatic efforts to bring together Zaire Pres Mobutuo Sese Seko and rebel leader Laurent Kabila for talks fall through after day of relentless confusion, after Kabila refuses to fly to offshore vessel for security reasons; Mobutu, who has advanc...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/03/world.main_headline: Zaire Negotiations Collapse as Rebel Balks on Security
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/03/world.print_headline: Zaire Negotiations Collapse as Rebel Balks on Security
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/03/world.body_text: **********After a day of relentless confusion, diplomatic efforts to bring President Mobutu Sese Seko and the rebel leader, Laurent Kabila, together for shipboard talks fell through this evening when Mr. Kabila stood up his rival, refusing to fly to the vessel for security reasons. **********Mr. Kabila's decision came after the meeting, which was expected to transfer power between the two men, had been delayed for several hours by Mr. Mobutu and an elaborate improvisation over how to get the ailing Zairian President on board. **********Mr. Mobutu, who is suffering from advanced cancer and is unable to stand up unassisted, arrived this morning at Pointe-Noire, a Congolese port, but refused to walk up a steep 31-step gangplank to the ship, sending diplomats and his hosts scurrying to devise other solutions. He also refused to board the ship by helicopter, invoking advice from his doctors that the vibrations could harm him. **********After considering even using a crane to hoist Mr. Mobutu aboard, the ship was maneuvered so he could be driven up a cargo plank in an armored black Cadillac as he waved through dark windows to journalists. **********It was not clear if Mr. Kabila planned to travel to the ship on Saturday, when diplomats hoped to reconvene. Reports from Luanda, the Angolan capital, where the rebel leader spent much of the day, said that Mr. Kabila was complaining he had not been officially invited to the meetings and that he was concerned about his safety. **********But diplomats here said Mr. Kabila appeared to get cold feet out of fear that the discussions would require him to form a government not entirely of his choosing. **********The United States has expressed its desire to see a ''broadly inclusive transitional government'' that could contain members of both Mr. Mobutu's political movement and Zaire's traditional opposition, which the rebel leader has resisted. **********Tensions were high today in Kinshasa, the Zairian capital, a crowded city of five million, where many feared that word the talks had failed could lead to a panic by Government soldiers, who would then expect an imminent rebel assault. **********Already the capital's leading hotels have been filling up with wealthy Zairians worried about a possible repeat of violent bouts of pillaging by Government soldiers in 1991 and 1993, which took numerous lives and left much of the city in ruins. **********''This is what these talks are all about, avoiding the burning of Kinshasa,'' said one Western diplomat. ''Kabila is coming one way or another. But hopefully it won't have to be with guns blazing.'' **********The breakdown of talks even before they had begun left Mr. Mobutu, President Nelson Mandela of South Africa and President Clinton's special envoy, Bill Richardson, steaming off the Congolese port aboard the Outeniqua, the South African icebreaker chosen as a neutral meeting place. **********In Washington, Administration officials expressed disappointment and annoyance with Mr. Kabila.  ''The U.S. Government is very disappointed, and Kabila's refusal to show is directly contradictory to all the assurances he gave Richardson,'' one official said. ''It just doesn't go over very well.'' **********Many had wondered whether Mr. Mobutu's health would allow him to negotiate at all with Mr. Kabila, the rebel leader whose armies control over two-thirds of Zaire and are now advancing on the capital. **********From their conception, the talks between Mr. Mobutu and Mr. Kabila, an idea worked upon for weeks by Mr. Mandela, and pushed strongly during Mr. Richardson's shuttle diplomacy of the last few days, have been plagued by strong disagreements over an agenda. **********Even as Mr. Kabila was waiting for Mr. Mobutu to board the ship, before setting out to join him, his troops, heavily assisted by Angola, have been massing around Kinshasa poised to strike quickly if Mr. Mobutu refuses to resign. **********Advanced elements of Mr. Kabila's army are now believed to be little more than 100 miles east of Kinshasa, and Western intelligence reports indicated that rebel units were massing to the southwest of the capital, near the Angolan border with Bas-Zaire province. **********In addition, rebel units were said to be fast moving into position to attack the capital from Tshikapa to the southeast, also near the border with Angola. **********As if to drive home the point that Mr. Mobutu's political end is at hand, the rebels announced today that they had taken the President's birthplace, the northern city of Lisala, without a fight from Government troops, who looted the town before fleeing. **********Though widely believed to be nearing death, Mr. Mobutu has been fighting for a departure that would allow him to hand over power with dignity to an interim authority, rather than to Mr. Kabila directly. **********Deepening the air of uncertainty, close associates of the Mobutu family have said that whether or not the President agrees on anything with Mr. Kabila, his health will not allow him to come back after the talks. The fortunes and leverage of the two sides were reflected today by their supporting casts. Mr. Kabila spent hours meeting in Luanda, Angola, with his two biggest backers, President Jose Eduardo dos Santos of Angola and Vice President Paul Kagame of Rwanda. **********Rwanda committed officers, equipment and troops at the earliest stages of Mr. Kabila's uprising, and Western diplomats say Angola has contributed large amounts of cash in recent weeks, as well as tanks and other heavy weapons, and airlift capacity for moving troops around the vast Zairian countryside. **********Asked what the involvement of the outside countries was about, a member of Mr. Richardson's delegation said, ''Payback, payback, and in Angola's case, diamonds.'' **********Mr. Mobutu has had a large hand in the civil wars of both Rwanda and Angola, and Zaire's support for Angola's rebel movement enabled its leader, Jonas Savimbi, to control most of the border between the two countries, and Angola's lucrative diamond trade. **********Mr. Mobutu had hoped to bring at least two fellow African heads of state, Gnassingbe Eyadema of Togo and President Omar Bongo of Gabon, aboard the Outeniqua for moral and political support. But when Mr. Kabila got wind of this, he reportedly threatened to pull out of the discussions, and the plan to bring in other leaders was canceled.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/09/busin.snippet: Dow Jones industrial average surges 103.82 points, or 1.32 percent, to close at record 7,962.31; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rises 6.55 points, to record 918.75, and Nasdaq composite index increases 14.36 points, to record 1,485.10; Russell ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/09/busin.body_text: **********The stock market soared to record levels again yesterday on growing optimism about corporate profits and a stable economy. **********Despite persistent concerns about lofty valuations, investors continue to bid up share prices to the surprise of many on Wall Street. **********The Dow Jones industrial average, up more than 23 percent in just over six months, surged 103.82 points, or 1.32 percent, to 7,962.31. It was the Dow's 32d record close this year and its first close ever above 7,900. **********Broader market indexes also set records. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 6.55 points, or 0.72 percent, to 918.75, and the Nasdaq composite index increased 14.36 points, to 1,485.10. The Russell 2000 index also set a record, gaining 2.02 points, to 398.28. **********''The market's just feeding on itself,'' said Larry Wachtel, a market analyst at Prudential Securities. ''You have all the facets in place for the bull market, but what you also had today was individual stocks moving forward.'' **********With investors increasingly confident that the economy is strong but not inflationary, many have begun to turn their attention to individual issues as the second-quarter earnings season begins. **********Yesterday, for instance, the Dow was bolstered by heavy demand for cyclical issues. Shares of International Paper jumped 4 15/16, to 56 1/8, after the company said that it would cut 9,000 jobs, or 10 percent of its work force, and sell $1 billion of assets next year to improve profit margins. **********Caterpillar, the equipment manufacturer, and Du Pont, the oil and chemical producer, were also big gainers in the Dow. Caterpillar rose 2 3/4, to 111, a 52-week high; Du Pont advanced 2 3/8, to 65 1/16, also a 52-week high. **********''Investors are confident that the earnings outlook for cyclicals extends beyond 1997 and into 1998,'' said Thomas McManus, an investment strategist at NatWest Securities. ''In other words, what you're seeing is a realization that the period of profitability may last longer than previously expected.'' **********Other chemical and paper product companies also gained, including Champion International, which rose 3 3/8, to 60, a 52-week high. **********Procter & Gamble, however, was the Dow's leading gainer, up 5 1/4, to 149 3/8. Shares of the Travelers Group were the worst-performing Dow issue, down 11/16, to 66 7/8. **********Much of the gains, however, were made in the last hour and a half, when the Dow shot up about 80 points, largely because of gains in International Paper and Procter & Gamble, which at about 3:40 P.M. announced a 2-for-1 split and said it would raise its quarterly dividend. **********Technology stocks were strong yesterday. The Pacific Stock Exchange high-technology index rose 1.8 percent, outperforming the Dow, and the Nasdaq 100 -- the largest 100 stocks on the Nasdaq and a gauge heavily weighted with large technology issues -- rose 1.5 percent. Last year, at this date, the Nasdaq was down 8 percent from a month earlier. But this year, in the last month, the Nasdaq has risen 5.7 percent. **********Among the catalysts for the technology sector were shares of Compaq Computer -- which last week announced a 5-for-2 split. Shares of Compaq surged 4 7/8, to 119 3/8, ahead of the company's release tomorrow  of second-quarter earnings. **********''You had Compaq running ahead of its earnings report,'' said Paul Rich, a trader at BT Brokerage. ''All around we had a strong, broad-based rally.'' **********Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was strong at 531.5 million shares; advancers beat beat decliners, 1,699 to 1146. **********And with all the major indexes at record highs, analysts say that even bearish investors are buying into the market, driving up prices at a time when things are usually weakening. **********''This is supposed to be the summer doldrums, but everyone is playing the game,'' said Mr. Wachtel at Prudential. ''Anything that's playing to history isn't working.'' **********ON THE WEB **********The latest stock and mutual fund quotations, along with news updates, are available on the Internet from The New York Times on the Web: www.nytimes.com

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/25/world.print_headline: PRESIDENT PRESSES ASIANS AT SUMMIT ON FISCAL TURMOIL
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/25/world.body_text: **********A day after describing the spreading economic turmoil in Asia as a mere glitch, President Clinton met today with leaders of the region's largest countries to deliver a tougher message, telling them that while the United States and international organizations could help, they would have to take painful steps on their own to recover. **********Mr. Clinton held back-to-back meetings with the leaders of Indonesia, China, Japan and South Korea, four nations that represent the full range of economic, geopolitical and human rights issues driving American policy in Asia. **********Against a backdrop of escalating trouble in Japan's financial system, continuing jitters in stock and currency markets worldwide and the likelihood that Asia's woes will slow global economic growth, Mr. Clinton emphasized to his counterparts that the solution to the region's economic problems had to start with more prudent policies at home, White House officials said. **********In particular, Mr. Clinton told Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto that Japan needed to deregulate its economy, strengthen its ailing banking system and pursue an economic recovery built on domestic demand and not cheaper exports. Mr. Clinton emphasized that strengthening Japan economically was crucial to restoring stability across Asia. **********''We just want to be in a position to be supportive when we can,'' Mr. Clinton said. ''But I think Japan can lead Asia out of this difficulty with the strength of its economy.'' **********He said all the leaders should work with the United States in pressing developing countries to take part in plans to curb emissions of pollutants and reduce the dangers to the environment from global warming. **********To President Jiang Zemin of China and to President Suharto of Indonesia, Mr. Clinton again raised longstanding American concerns about human rights. He welcomed the release last week by Beijing of Wei Jingsheng, China's most prominent dissident, and pressed for further releases. And he raised with Mr. Suharto American unhappiness about the treatment of ethnic minorities in East Timor and about the repressive nature of the Indonesian Government. **********Mr. Clinton spoke about ''the need for countries like Indonesia to deal with how to accommodate order and liberty and to create the correct balance as they develop,'' said Samuel R. Berger, his national security adviser. ''In the new information world, provisions need to be made for people who move to the beat of a different drummer.'' **********Asked how Mr. Suharto responded, Mr. Berger said he ''did not respond to that directly.'' **********The sessions dominated the first of two days of meetings among the leaders of the 18 members of the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation forum. While Mr. Clinton and his counterparts from other nations continued to stress the region's resiliency and underlying strengths, their conversations here were tinged by deep concern that the financial turmoil had not yet been brought under control and could still permanently tarnish its standing as a driving force in the global economy. **********Administration officials dismissed concerns that Japan could follow South Korea as the next country to need an international financial bailout. But they said the situation warranted acute international attention to prevent a further spread of instability. They said finance ministers from many of the affected nations would meet in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, next week and again in Japan in January. **********''My view is that we should approach this with determination, but with confidence,'' Mr. Clinton said. **********Administration officials said the Asian leaders Mr. Clinton met with all endorsed the American-backed strategy for dealing with the crisis. **********The strategy calls for the International Monetary Fund to take the lead role in dealing with any countries that need international financial assistance. It also allows countries in a region to put together backup pools of financial help if I.M.F. assistance proves insufficient. And it calls on nations to enact more prudent economic policies in return for receiving international assistance. **********Hanging heavy over today's proceedings was the failure of Japan's fourth-largest securities firm, Yamaichi Securities Company. It was the second failure of a major financial institution in Japan in recent weeks, and it heightened concerns that Asia's spreading woes could lead to further failures among Japan's beleaguered banks and set back Japan's already faltering efforts to spur its economy. **********American officials said Mr. Hashimoto did not provide Mr. Clinton with any details of his plans to deal with the banking crisis beyond emphasizing protection of depositors rather than financial institutions. But Deputy Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers said the United States was satisfied with the Japanese Government's statement that it would take the ''necessary steps to contain the effects'' of the Yamaichi collapse. **********American officials also reported progress on another of the economic issues facing them in the region, negotiating the terms under which China would join the World Trade Organization, the body that sets the rules for international commerce. **********Administration officials said China had made a ''significant'' new offer to the United States Trade Representative, Charlene Barshefsky, in the last several days, and that Presidents Clinton and Jiang had directed their trade ministries to follow up with further talks. The officials did not provide any details of the new offer.

The company, which is based in Rancho Cordova, Calif., said late Tuesday that its earnings for the second quarter ending March 31 would match analysts' forecasts of 22 cents a share, with revenue slightly ahead of the first quarter. https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/08/busin.print_headline: Moderate Weather Forecasts Send Oil and Gas Lower
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/08/busin.body_text: **********Heating oil prices fell on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday, dragged down by revised forecasts for warmer-than-usual temperatures in the coming week. **********Other energy prices also fell. On other markets, copper rose. **********Temperatures close to normal are forecast for New York and most of New England, according to the Weather Services Corporation of Lexington, Mass. Temperatures could rise as much as 6 degrees above normal through the weekend in some areas. **********The rise in temperatures in the Northeast would reduced demand for heating oil in the nation's largest consuming region and ease concern that inventories are too low. **********''Three days of bitter cold weather is market-grabbing news, but we haven't had that much of a winter so far,'' said John Saucer, an energy analyst at Smith Barney in Houston. ''Prices need not be that high.'' **********February heating oil tumbled from Monday's three-week high to 72.49 cents a gallon, down 1.15 cents. **********The falling heating oil prices pulled other futures lower. Crude oil for February delivery dropped 14 cents, to $26.23 a barrel, and February gasoline fell 0.42 cent, to 72.10 cents a gallon. **********Natural gas prices plunged amid expectations that the current cold spell in the Midwest would end in the next few days. Gas for February delivery fell 30.2 cents, to $3.334 for a thousand cubic feet. **********Copper rallied to its highest price in more than a month as expectations for strong demand in the first quarter outweighed larger inventories. **********Copper stored in London Metal Exchange-approved warehouses worldwide increased by 11,475 metric tons between Friday and Monday, to 134,700 metric tons. A metric ton is 1.1 tons. **********March copper on the Comex division of the New York Mercantile Exchange rose 3.6 cents, to $1.0515 a pound. March is the month of strongest demand for copper wire and rods, said John Gross, vice president for strategic metals at the BICC Cables Corporation in West Nyack, N.Y.
