https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/16/busin.main_headline: Kodak Profits Fall 45.6%, But Investors Bid up Stock
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/16/busin.print_headline: Kodak Profits Fall 45.6%, But Investors Bid up Stock
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/16/busin.body_text: **********The Eastman Kodak Company, which upset investors last month by reporting that revenue thus far in the year was lower than expected, said today that earnings fell in the first quarter, in line with expectations. **********The company, which makes photographic products and imaging equipment, said the dollar's strength made its products more expensive abroad, sales growth slowed in emerging markets and price competition intensified. **********Kodak's chairman and chief executive, George M. C. Fisher, called the first quarter's performance unacceptable. But he added in a statement that ''we firmly believe our strategies, which have been in place for some time, are the right ones.'' **********Net income fell 45.6 percent, to $149 million, or 45 cents a share, from $274 million, or 80 cents a share, in the 1996 first quarter. The results for the latest quarter included a pretax charge of $186 million, or 37 cents a share, related to the purchase of Wang Laboratories Inc.'s software business last year. **********Operating profit in the latest quarter was $272 million, or 82 cents a share. That was down seven-tenths of 1 percent from the year earlier. **********The profit decline was Kodak's first in two and a half years. The per-share operating profit met the expectations of analysts, several of whom had lowered their earnings estimates by about 10 cents a share after the company said on March 21 that its January and February sales, excluding its recently sold copier assets, were essentially unchanged from a year ago. **********Kodak shares rose because the results eased investor fears that the company had more unpleasant surprises in store after last month's disclosure. On the New York Stock Exchange today, Kodak gained $2.25, to $75.375. **********Sales in the quarter fell 7 percent, to $3.20 billion from $3.45 billion, reflecting in part the sale of some of Kodak's copier business to Danka Business Systems P.L.C., announced last September. Sales in the United States decreased 6 percent while international sales fell 8.7 percent. **********Kodak said stronger sales in March enabled it to post a 2 percent gain in sales from continuing operations for the quarter. ''This was something of a relief just in the sense that clearly March is back on trend,'' said Michael Ellmann, an analyst at Schroder Wertheim & Company. **********Profit from consumer imaging products, including film for amateur photographers, photo paper and photo lab services, fell 10 percent, to $145 million from $161 million. Sales rose 3 percent, to $1.50 billion from $1.46 billion. **********At the commercial imaging division, which makes copiers, X-ray film, microfilm and professional photography products, profit fell 77 percent, to $55 million from $239 million, reflecting in part the charge for the Wang software acquisition. Sales fell 16 percent, to $1.64 billion from $1.94 billion. **********Mr. Fisher said total sales would have increased 5 percent if not for the effect of the strong dollar, which reduced the amount of American currency produced by sales denominated in other currencies.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/06/busin.snippet: Harvey J Lieberman essay on looking through his papers as he prepares to retire from job as deputy director of state psychiatric institution (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/06/busin.main_headline: My Shining Moment At the Top of the Heap
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/06/busin.print_headline: My Shining Moment At the Top of the Heap
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/06/busin.body_text: **********AFTER 24 years with one employer, who would have guessed it would come to this? **********One year ago this month, on a Friday, I stood in my office in the executive suite of a modern state psychiatric center -- a deputy director and psychologist, 52 years old, dressed in a sport jacket and slacks, looking out my window at the water view I enjoyed. I had just won early retirement. New York State had offered the opportunity as part of its downsizing and privatizing plans for government services, and I had applied. But because of an odd set of circumstances, I learned only three hours before the end of the eligibility period that my application had been accepted. This meant that the notification of my retirement coincided with my last official day of work. **********As my thoughts raced between the regretful ''I love it here'' to the determined ''No, it's time to move on -- there's nothing to be gained by being present at the end,'' my secretary walked in. She had a sad look on her face and boxes in her hands -- ''for whatever you want to take home,'' she said, adding as she left, ''I'll start going through the files.'' **********Files. My life's work. I shuddered, then dug into the drawers in my office. I was startled to find so much paper. ''Look how much I don't need,'' I said. ''Into the trash with you.'' Why had I kept all of this? **********I have always loved my work, but over the years as a government employee, I had grown tired of defending government's right to provide high-quality services. Excellence is hardly relevant when the state is holding the ax of privatization over everyone's head. **********I was leaving, but I would not be out of work. I had a fine job offer in hand. Thoughts of the journey ahead energized me through the sad handshakes and hugs that interrupted my packing. **********After one break, though, I returned to my office to discover that one of my boxes -- with 20 pounds of papers, tapes and souvenirs, was missing. My secretary shrugged: ''I warned you not to put anything you wanted to save on the floor,'' she said. To the housekeeper, it seemed, that spelled junk. **********Frantically, I called housekeeping  and learned that the cleaning person in question had already left for the day. Then came the really bad news: the contents of the box had probably landed outside, in one of the center's three huge trash bins. **********I rushed out to see if I could find my papers before they were hauled away. It was a hot and sticky day, and I was perspiring from anxiety and exertion in my race against an unknown garbage truck. **********The metal bins had walls about 5 feet high, 10 feet long and 6 feet wide. The first bin was stinky with overripe fruit and other food remains. No papers there, thank goodness. The second contained only long metal bars and scraps of sheet metal. **********With great trepidation, I peered into the last, which was half full. Yes! There, on top of other office discards, were my papers. Behind the bin was the box. **********But how could I rescue my belongings? I could seek help from the maintenance department -- after all, I was still the deputy director, if only for another hour. But what if the garbage truck arrived during the few minutes I was away? **********I soon decided that it wasn't right to ask anyone for help. Had I been so ruined by bureaucracy and position that I could no longer perform basic life chores for myself? **********Resolutely, I threw in the box and grabbed the side of the warm green bin with both hands. After looking both ways to be sure no one was coming, I tossed one leg over the side of the bin and then pulled myself in. And there I was, standing on top of a mound of waste that made me 9 feet tall. **********After a few moments of playing out several fantasies, including jumping up and down and waving to people at a distance, I got to work. I refilled the box, carried it to the edge of the bin and let it plop to the ground. With a quick au revoir, I climbed out. My heart raced; sweat ran down my face. Another wave of embarrassment swept over me. Then, surprise! Out of me pushed a deep, extended laugh, laden with tension: Here I was, not quite retired and already treated like a human version of a superannuated wreck --  discarded, most ingloriously, on the trash heap. No longer of value to the administrative machine, I joined the rest of its useless material. **********BUT I soon replaced that metaphor with a more satisfactory, and accurate, explanation. After all, such longtime employment shouldn't end on a sour note.  And my need for a meaningful, positive existence kept me from translating this accident into something  without redemptive qualities. **********As I walked away from the bin to share this tale with friends, I understood that what had happened to me was part of the prolonged blessing that had been my whole work experience. That day, I intentionally dove into the garbage to rescue work I cherished. How many individuals from life's various pathways feel their work deserves such preservation? And that is the essence of my profit from years of hard work. Lucky me.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/07/world.snippet: Public disclosure of document prepared for Peter Costello, who led Australia's delegation to recent South Pacific Forum meeting, is causing new strains in Australia's difficult relations with Pacific neighbors and embarrassing Government; document...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/07/world.main_headline: Australians Make a Candid Error, Angering Their Neighbors
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/07/world.print_headline: Australians Make a Candid Error, Angering Their Neighbors
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/07/world.body_text: **********The public disclosure of an Australian document is causing new strains in Australia's difficult relations with its Pacific neighbors and has embarrassed the Government. **********The document, which was written for an Australian Cabinet member and includes blunt assessments of other countries' leaders, was left at a registration desk in the Hilton Hotel in Cairns on July 11 during a meeting of the South Pacific Forum, a partnership of Australia and New Zealand and 14 smaller South Pacific nations. It was found by a Reuters correspondent, Terry Friel. **********The document, prepared for Australia's Federal Treasurer, Peter Costello, who led his country's delegation, criticized economic management of several countries in the region, suggesting that corruption is not only rampant but retarding economic growth. It also makes candid assessments of leaders and their foibles. **********Winston Peters, New Zealand's Deputy Prime Minister and Treasurer, is depicted as ''a loose cannon'' and an ''opportunist.'' He ''can be a prickly nationalist with an eye to popular causes and would not be above exploiting New Zealand sensitivities toward Australia if it served his purpose.'' He ''enjoys late hours in nightclubs.'' **********A passage about Sir Geoffrey Henry, Prime Minister of the Cook Islands, says, ''He has been drinking heavily as the pressure of the economic crisis has mounted.'' **********The Australian Financial Review has put the entire text on the Internet at www.afr.com.au. **********Mr. Peters dismissed the Australian assessment as the work of ''an  ignorant bureaucrat.'' Mr. Henry said he was ''surprised and bewildered'' by reports he was drinking heavily. **********Reaction from other leaders has been angrier. Acting President Ruben Zackhiras of the Marshall Islands, which heads the economic forum, noted ''shock and dismay among forum countries'' and ''damage to Australia's standing in the forum community.'' **********Fiji's Prime Minister, Sitiveni Rabuka, called the briefing document a ''show of disrespect.'' **********Most governments make confidential evaluations of their main interlocutors, but these usually stay confidential. **********In Australia the task has been assigned to a small group of intelligence analysts in the Office of National Assessments, which reports directly to the Prime Minister and the Cabinet. **********Their documents, including the one left on the Hilton desk, are marked ''For Australian Eyes Only,'' the Government's highest security classification. **********Mr. Costello, in a television interview. acknowledged holes in the security arrangements at the Cairns conference. His department has opened an investigation, he said, and ''if they can ascertain the people responsible for the breach of security they will be bringing the relevant proceedings against them.'' **********Government officials insisted that the document has no status or weight and does not reflect Government policy and that therefore no apology is required. **********Tensions in the region have surfaced as Australia continues trying to come to grips with its strong Western heritage and its geographical and increasingly important trading position in Asia. **********Australia has been seeking closer ties not only with the economic forum countries, but also with the larger members of the nine-member Association of Southeast Asian Nations.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/02/busin.snippet: Federal Judge Carleton D Powell says Federal law that prevents millions of Americans from taking tax deduction for contributions to individual retirement accounts in years when they change jobs is 'harsh' but adds that he has no power to overturn ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/02/busin.main_headline: Judge Upholds 'Harsh' Law On Retirement Accounts
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/02/busin.print_headline: Judge Upholds 'Harsh' Law On Retirement Accounts
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/02/busin.body_text: **********A Federal law that prevents millions of Americans from taking a tax deduction for contributions to individual retirement accounts in years when they change jobs is ''harsh,'' a Tax Court judge has held, but he added that he had no power to overturn it. **********The law denies I.R.A. tax deductions to individuals who make more than $35,000 in any year if they were also eligible for as little as one day to participate in a 401(k) plan. That creates a costly obstacle to retirement savings at a time when when there is widespread uncertainty about whether today's younger workers will collect full Social Security benefits and when fewer jobs come with traditional defined benefit pensions. **********The decision, by Judge Carleton D. Powell, also comes as Congressional Republicans have been denouncing the I.R.S. for its administration of the tax laws. The service's defenders say that many of the actions that most anger taxpayers are the fault not of the I.R.S., but of Congress, which makes the rules. **********The law the judge upheld is costly to thrifty workers, potentially costing people who change jobs annually between high school graduation and age 25 more than $519,000 in reduced savings when they retire, while bringing the Government only $4,480 in additional revenue. **********Most 401(k) plans require new employees to wait a year before they can begin making contributions, severely restricting their ability to make tax-deductible contributions to retirement savings in years when they change jobs. Last year one in four workers, or more than 28 million Americans, had been in their current jobs for less than a year, the Bureau of Labor Statistics estimated. **********The Internal Revenue Service attorney who represented the Government, J. Paul Knap, said yesterday that he agreed with Judge Powell that the law was unfair, but that the I.R.S. had no choice but to enforce it. **********The case was brought by Colleen Henry, 37, a reporter for WISN Channel 12 in Milwaukee, who put $2,000 into an I.R.A. in 1993 and took a deduction that reduced her Federal income tax by $560. The I.R.S. disallowed the deduction because for the first three weeks of 1993 Ms. Henry worked at a Chattanooga, Tenn., television station that had a 401(k) plan. **********Ms. Henry said that she did not contribute to the 401(k) plan in Tennessee because she knew she was switching jobs and because under its rules the most she could have saved in three weeks was $190. **********Ms. Henry, who acted as her own attorney, told Judge Powell in June: ''I know I am going to lose because the law is the law. But sometimes the law is wrong, and I hope you are an enlightened judge, and even if you decide I have to pay the tax I hope you will make a statement that this law is dumb and send a message to Congress.'' **********In an opinion issued Tuesday, Judge Powell said he had no power to rule that her participation in the Chattanooga 401(k) plan was de minimis, or insignificant, or to consider the fact that she was not eligible to participate in her new employer's 401(k) plan during 1993. **********''While the result may seem harsh,'' Judge Powell wrote, ''we cannot ignore the plain language of the statute and, in effect, rewrite the statute to achieve what may be a more equitable result.'' **********Mr. Knap, the I.R.S. attorney, said he had no choice but to argue that Ms. Henry's tax deduction should be denied. **********''She has a great argument with Congress that this isn't terribly fair,'' Mr. Knap said. **********A worker who changes jobs once a year between ages 18 and 25 would lose a tax deduction worth $560 annually at the 28 percent income tax rate on income above $35,000. Not being able to save that $560 in each of those years reduces retirement savings by $519,000, assuming the 10.9 percent long-term return for stocks, when the worker turns 67 and becomes eligible for Social Security.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/18/busin.snippet: Motorola Inc confirms it plans to build $12.9 billion global satellite network, Celestri, to provide voice, data and video communications to phone companies, businesses and telecommuters; analysts question extent of demand and financing for ventur...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/18/busin.main_headline: Motorola Sets $12.9 Billion Plan To Build Global Satellite System
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/18/busin.print_headline: Motorola Sets $12.9 Billion Plan To Build Global Satellite System
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/18/busin.body_text: **********Motorola Inc. confirmed yesterday that it planned to build a $12.9 billion global satellite network to provide voice, data and video communications to telephone companies, businesses and telecommuters. **********The venture, called Celestri, is Motorola's third and biggest satellite plan. It would dwarf satellite systems planned by the Teledesic Corporation and by a joint venture between Alcatel-Alsthom S.A. of France and Loral Space and Communications Ltd. of the United States. **********Motorola's venture was reported by The Wall Street Journal yesterday. The company filed plans for Celestri with the Federal Communications Commission on Friday. **********Global satellite systems are intended to provide such services as  video conferencing and high-speed Internet access, and are aimed at the corporate world. Celestri may be the first such system to use both satellites orbiting at low altitudes and satellites that operate at high altitudes and retain a fixed location in relation to the Earth. **********Some analysts, however, wondered whether there would be sufficient demand and, more important, financing to make the proposed satellite ventures viable. **********''We're really close to the point where we've got too many people chasing the same dollars'' in the satellite market, Scott Wright, an analyst with Argus Research, said. ''Nobody knows how big this market is or how fast it's going to develop.'' **********Still, shares of Motorola rose $1.25 yesterday, to $71, on the New York Stock Exchange. **********Motorola's Celestri announcement came less than two months after the Boeing Company was picked as the lead contractor for a $9 billion project to build Teledesic's satellite network. Teledesic, backed by the wireless pioneer Craig O. McCaw and William H. Gates 3d of the Microsoft Corporation, plans a $9 billion satellite system to offer services similar to those planned by Celestri. **********And Alcatel-Alsthom and Loral recently proposed a $3.9 billion satellite system called Skybridge. The system will be based on 64 low-orbiting satellites and is expected to begin operating in 2001. **********In addition to Celestri, Motorola also has plans for two other satellite networks. Through its 21 percent stake in Iridium L.L.C., Motorola has already started a $5 billion satellite system for wireless phone calls. Motorola has also proposed a project called M-Star, a $6.1 billion venture that will use 72 satellites.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/03/world.snippet: Kim Hyonh U, North Korea's Ambassador to UN hospitalized in New York since August 12 without medical insurance or financial help from impoverished Government, has reportedly received pledges of aid from Korean-Americans (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/03/world.main_headline: Korean-Americans Assist an Ailing Envoy From the North
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/03/world.print_headline: Korean-Americans Assist an Ailing Envoy From the North
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/03/world.body_text: **********North Korea's representative at the United Nations, who has been hospitalized in New York since Aug. 12 without medical insurance or financial help from his impoverished Government, has received pledges of aid from Korean-Americans, according to Korean-language newspapers. The prospective donors, who are believed to be of varying political views, apparently fear that the envoy, Kim Hyong U, could be recalled by Pyongyang and sent home without treatment. **********Mr. Kim, 62, is a patient at New York University Medical Center in Manhattan, where he is undergoing tests, hospital officials said today. They said they could not give more details about his health without his consent. **********Korean-American newspapers first reported on Friday that the envoy, whom they described as a diabetic, had developed lung problems and had been admitted to the hospital with the help of a Korean-American clergyman and Korean-speaking American doctors. **********North Korea has no hard currency to support its missions abroad, and North Korean diplomats do not have health insurance, diplomats from other countries said. Most other missions subsidize or sometimes pay fully the medical insurance of diplomats and their families, who usually face far higher health costs in New York than in their home countries. **********The Korea Times, a Korean-language paper published in New York, reported on Aug. 29 that there were also concerns but no evidence that Mr. Kim was considering defection and thus was under suspicion after two other North Korean envoys --  Chang Sung Gil, Ambassador in Cairo, and his brother, Chang Sung Ho, a trade mission official in Paris -- were given asylum in the United States a week ago. **********The Korea Central Daily News, another local Korean-language paper, reported on the same day that Ambassador Kim faced medical bills that could range as high as $40,000 to $50,000. The paper said that although Mr. Kim had no hope of government help, hospital officials had been told that there would be local sources of support, apparently from a number of anonymous donors who rallied to the envoy's cause. **********American diplomats dealing with problems arising between foreign missions and institutions of all kinds in the United States said today that they were not aware of Mr. Kim's plight. The United States does not have diplomatic relations with North Korea, whose radical Communist Covernment is considered by Washington to have committed acts of international terrorism like assassinating South Korean Cabinet members and blowing up a passenger aircraft. **********The Clinton Administration says that Pyongyang is also selling weapons to enemies of Washington, most recently missiles to Iran. Talks between the United States and North Korea on missile exports were broken off last week after the Cairo and Paris defections. **********Washington, however, has been contributing to an international fund to send food to the North Koreans, who are facing severe famine after two years of floods and now a summer-long drought. The country's economy has been steadily deteriorating for decades under a nationalistic ''self-reliance'' system that turned its back on the outside world and left the country's farmland depleted and its treasury bare. **********A diplomat at the North Korean mission who was not identified denied today that Mr. Kim was still in the hospital. ''He is at home and he is fine,'' he said, demanding to know why a newspaper was asking questions about the envoy. **********North Korea is one of the world's most secretive countries. Various people involved with Mr. Kim's case, in and out of the hospital, say that it has been very difficult to communicate with the mission to discuss the diplomat's treatment. **********A Korean-speaking doctor treating Mr. Kim said that he could not disclose details of the envoy's condition because of hospital rules protecting the privacy of patients unless the envoy agreed to make the nature of his illness public. Hospital staff members say the ambassador is visited frequently by his wife and now and then by another member of the North Korean mission staff but is otherwise alone.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/26/world.snippet: United States concludes that senior Bosnian Serb leaders are orchestrating attacks on NATO troops and senior Administration officials say that NATO will retaliate if incidents continue (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/26/world.main_headline: U.S. Links Top Bosnia Serbs to Attacks
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/26/world.print_headline: U.S. Links Top Bosnia Serbs to Attacks
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/26/world.body_text: **********The United States has concluded that senior Bosnian Serb leaders are orchestrating attacks on NATO troops and  senior Administration officials said today that NATO would retaliate if the incidents continued. **********The attacks have presumably come in response to the arrest of one war-crimes suspect and the killing of another. The persistence and severity of the attacks -- which American and NATO officials initially discounted as isolated incidents, often involving drunken Serbs -- have raised concerns about the security of the 30,000 NATO-led troops in Bosnia. **********A senior Administration official in Washington said there would be ''serious consequences'' in the event of  ''even one more such action.'' **********''We've had enough of this,'' the official said. **********Administration officials declined to specify how NATO forces would retaliate, though one said commanders in Bosnia had virtually unlimited authority to act when faced with a threat to the NATO troops. **********The first steps are likely to be diplomatic, but the officials said the next ones could include cracking down on television broadcasts the Serbs have used to incite attacks and seizing caches of weapons the Serbs were required to warehouse as part of the Dayton peace accords. **********In recent days, a parade of American and European envoys has denounced the attacks and warned Bosnian Serb leaders in their stronghold,  Pale, against inciting attacks. **********Today's sharper warnings came after yet another attack on NATO forces. Before dawn this morning, an American soldier's car was damaged by a firebomb in Vlasenica, a village in the Serb-controlled part of Bosnia, according to a statement issued by the American military headquarters in Tuzla. No one was injured and the fire was extinguished. **********While no one has been killed in the series of attacks, several troops have been injured, including a Dutch soldier who was wounded by shrapnel from a grenade attack in Kotor Varos and an American who was attacked by an unknown prowler outside his home, also in Vlasenica. **********The attacks, which initially were written off as isolated incidents, began after the surprise operation by NATO forces on July 10 in which British special forces killed a Serbian official indicted for war crimes by the international tribunal in The Hague and arrested another in a  separate raid. **********The actions against the suspects, who had been charged in sealed indictments, reflected a new resolve by NATO to enforce the terms of the Dayton accords, including the capture of suspected war criminals. **********The arrests also struck fear in the Bosnian Serbs, particularly those in Pale, the nationalist stronghold still dominated by Radovan Karadzic, the former president of the Bosnian Serbs, who himself is under indictment on war-crimes charges. **********In public statements, Bosnian Serb leaders have denounced the arrests,  but at the same time urged people not to retaliate. However, television and radio broadcasts have been increasingly inflammatory, and in recent days posters have appeared defending Dr. Karadzic. **********At first, NATO's commanders discounted the idea that the attacks might be coordinated, and officials here in Washington, while denouncing them, played down their seriousness. **********''In the last day or two, some of the people subscribing to that view have begun to change,'' another official said today. ''This turnaround is particularly pronounced at the Pentagon.'' **********The officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said there is evidence of the involvement of the Interior Minister, Dragan Kajic, who is known to follow the orders of Dr. Karadzic. Mr. Kajic was at the center of the recent power struggle among Serbian leaders, when the  Bosnian Serb president, Biljana Plavsic, tried to fire him. Dr. Karadzic's supporters retaliated by expelling Mrs. Plavsic from the ruling party and demanding her resignation. **********The officials said they would also hold the Bosnian political leadership responsible, including Momcilo Krajisnik, who holds the Serbian seat on the three-member presidency ruling all of Bosnia. **********The officials said the attacks would not force NATO to back away from its more aggressive approach to the mission in Bosnia, including more arrests of war-crimes suspects. However, in recent days, NATO officials have indicated that more arrests are not planned for now. **********Over the last few days, the American representative to the United Nations, Bill Richardson, and the American special envoy for Bosnia, Robert S. Gelbard, have traveled through the region and called for an end to the attacks. **********One Administration official in Washington said NATO was stepping up its warnings to demonstrate its resolve to the Serbs. **********The United States has also succeeded in forcing the International Monetary Fund to postpone for at least two months the release of $38 million in loans for Croatia. **********The Administration has pressed the fund and other international financial institutions, like the World Bank, to deny Croatia assistance until President Franjo Tudjman does more to live up to the terms of the Dayton accords, including the arrests of war criminals. **********The money was the second installment of a $486 million, three-year loan approved by the I.M.F. earlier this year, but the fund's directors, meeting in Washington, agreed to delay an economic review that would have freed up the money, fund and Administration officials said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/15/busin.body_text: **********American Pilots Walk Out; Clinton Orders Them Back **********President Clinton intervened moments after midnight to halt a strike by American Airlines pilots that had threatened to disrupt air travel nationwide. The action -- the first such move by a President in an airline strike in 31 years -- will keep American's planes flying for at most 60 days while negotiations continue. Mr. Clinton took the steps after refusing to tip his hand yesterday on whether he would intervene, hoping that the pressure would force the parties to agree. $(Page 1.$) **********In an era of weakened labor unions, the pilots are one segment of the American work force that may be stronger than ever. The pilots' dispute represents a rare instance in which a union in the United States holds not only extraordinary power over its employer, but also over much of the country. Pilots at American and other airlines have tried to flex their muscles before, but they have much more in their favor now. **********News Analysis. $(1.$) **********In the hours before the strike deadline thousands of prospective passengers at Kennedy, La Guardia and Newark airports -- as well as at airports around the country -- struggled to make last-minute changes in plans ahead of a holiday weekend. $(37.$) **********Canada Seeks Banking Competition **********Canada plans to bolster competition in its tightly controlled banking industry by loosening restrictions on foreign banks from the United States and other countries, officials in Ottawa announced. Legislation to be introduced later this year would enable foreign banks to compete more aggressively against Canada's six large national banks in making loans, doing corporate business and offering consumer services like credit cards. $(38.$) **********Shift in Detroit Newspaper Strike **********Striking unions at Detroit's two newspapers -- The Detroit Free Press and The Detroit News -- planned to make an unconditional offer to send 2,000 striking employees back to work after 20 months on strike. The union said it made the move in the hope of getting back pay for the workers. The newspapers said the offer constituted an end to the strike. $(9.$) **********Huge Paper Company Merger **********Abitibi-Price and the Stone-Consolidated Corporation said that they would merge in a transaction valued at about $1.7 billion, creating the world's largest maker of newsprint. Paper companies have been consolidating as they struggle to overcome lower prices, overcapacity and a limited number of newsprint buyers. Combined, the two Canadian companies would have annual sales of $3.6 billion, and about 8 percent of the global newsprint market. $(49.$) **********Stocks End Week With a Whimper **********The euphoria that swept Wall Street into a new millennium this week ended not in a bang, but with a whimper. After gaining 574 points, or 8.9 percent, in just seven weeks, and reaching the 7,000 milestone on Thursday, the Dow Jones industrial average slumped, closing down 33.48 points, to 6,988.96. For the week, the Dow rose 133.16. $(36.$) **********Prices of Treasury securities forged ahead on good economic news, but further gains were stymied by profit taking in a shortened trading session ahead of the long Washington's Birthday weekend. The yield on the newly issued 30-year bond fell to 6.53 percent, down from 6.62 percent on Thursday and down 17 basis points from the week before. $(36.$) **********Dollar Closes Mixed **********The dollar was mixed, touching a four-year high against the yen and 34-month high vs. the mark on benign inflation news, the ebullient stock market in the United States and more economic weakness in Germany. $(48.$) **********Coffee Prices Retreat **********Coffee futures prices retreated for the first time in a week on concern that production in Brazil, the world's biggest producer, would be higher than has been expected. $(48.$)

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/06/world.snippet: Miladin Zivotic, leading dissident during Communist era in Yugoslavia and one of most prominent domestic critics of Serbian involvement in Balkan wars, died on Feb 26 at age 66; photo (L)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/06/world.main_headline: Miladin Zivotic, 66, Serb Foe of Nationalism
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/06/world.print_headline: Miladin Zivotic, 66, Serb Foe of Nationalism
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/06/world.body_text: **********Miladin Zivotic, a leading dissident during the Communist era in Yugoslavia and one of the most prominent domestic critics of Serbian involvement in the Balkan wars, died at his home in Belgrade on Feb. 26. He was 66. **********The cause of death was a heart attack, his family said. **********Mr. Zivotic was the leader of the Belgrade Circle, a small group of intellectuals and artists who condemned the Serbian role in the wars in Bosnia and Croatia. The group, which he helped found in 1992 and which included Yugoslavia's best-known dissident, Milovan Djilas, tried to reach out to Muslims and Croats to create a common front against nationalist movements in the Balkans. It was often denounced by the authorities as being a tool of Serbia's enemies. **********To register his disapproval of the siege of Sarajevo by the Bosnian Serbs, Mr. Zivotic visited the city in 1993, slipping through Bosnian Serb lines. **********He was also an outspoken critic of Serbia's treatment of non-Serbs within its borders, especially the some two million Albanians in the Kosovo region. And when nationalists began to threaten Muslims in the Sanjak region of Serbia early in the Bosnia war he went to live with Muslim families. **********''This is not just the death of an individual, but the death of an intellectual tradition,'' said Obrad Savic, the editor of the Belgrade Circle journal. ''He was rejected all his life. He lived on the margins. But he never gave up his engagement in the world. He believed passionately in the common humanity of all people and endured great hardship and loneliness in his battle for human decency.'' **********Despite his stature he was ignored by the Serbian press, even the opposition press, and was never invited to speak at the anti-Government protests that gripped Belgrade for the last three months. **********The decision by student and opposition leaders to keep him away came because of his firm belief that Serbian society could only renew itself by accepting the blame for the Balkan wars and ridding itself of Serbian nationalist invective that he denounced as racist. **********''The first act any new president of this country must do is travel to Sarajevo and beg for forgiveness, just as Willy Brandt did when he traveled to Warsaw,'' he said in an interview shortly before his death, referring to the West German Chancellor who pursued a policy of reconciliation with the enemies of German Nazism. ''This is the only way we can begin to heal ourselves.'' **********Such language still angers many Serbs who insist that they are the victims in the war and attack the Serbian President, Slobodan Milosevic, not for starting the war but for withdrawing Belgrade's support for the Serbs in Bosnia and Croatia. **********Mr. Zivotic first came to prominence in 1968, when Yugoslav university students staged anti-Communist protests at the time of the Soviet-led invasion of Czechoslovakia. For their support of the students he and seven other philosophy professors were dismissed. He started the Free Belgrade University, which met secretly in houses and whose classes were often broken up by the police. **********Mr. Zivotic did not return to his University of Belgrade post until 1987, seven years after the death of Tito. **********Soon after he regained his old position, he found himself ostracized again because of his condemnation of growing Serbian nationalism. As the wave of nationalism swept through the educational system he was denounced by students and professors as a traitor to the Serbian cause, and he retired in 1994. **********Although a searing critic of his own society, Mr. Zivotic was reluctant to criticize Serbia's opponents. After a lengthy critique of the Serbian Orthodox Church, which he condemned as ''the cradle of Serb nationalism and an enemy of modernity,'' he was asked to assess the role of the Roman Catholic Church, the dominant religion in Croatia, in the conflict between Serbia and Croatia. **********''My role is to examine and criticize myself and my society,'' he said.  ''It is up to the Croatians to examine themselves. I am not competent to be their critic. Ask them.'' **********He is survived by a son, Aleksandar, and a daughter, Dragana Jovicevic, as well as his former wife, Milica, and two grandchildren.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/29/busin.snippet: Apple Computer Inc introduces its highly anticipated advertising campaign, carrying theme 'Think different'; it is start of ambitious, multimillion-dollar effort to polish Apple's image, which has been bruised by serious setbacks in personal compu...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/29/busin.main_headline: New Apple Ad Lifts Off From Disney's Land
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/29/busin.print_headline: New Apple Ad Lifts Off From Disney's Land
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/29/busin.body_text: **********Apple Computer Inc. has not officially adopted the Walt Disney ditty ''It's a Small World'' as a corporate song. But it might as well after the cozy events surrounding the introduction last night of a highly anticipated advertising campaign. **********The Apple campaign, carrying the theme ''Think different,'' began with a slick, star-stuffed television commercial during the broadcast of the animated film ''Toy Story'' on ''The Wonderful World of Disney,'' a new weekly ABC series. The 60-second commercial, which ran twice during the movie, is the start of an ambitious, multimillion-dollar effort to polish Apple's image, which has been bruised by serious setbacks in the personal computer market. **********But it also gave new meaning to the term synergies, of which media executives are so fond. ABC is owned by the Walt Disney Company, which produces ''The Wonderful World of Disney'' and also released ''Toy Story'' in theaters in 1995 and on videotape last year. The animation techniques for ''Toy Story,'' moreover, were developed by Pixar Inc., whose chairman and chief executive is Steven P. Jobs. **********Mr. Jobs also co-founded Apple years ago and recently returned there, now serving as interim chief executive. After Apple began a review of its advertising account, he was instrumental in the choice of the TBWA Chiat/Day unit of Omnicom Group in Venice, Calif., as Apple's new agency. **********TBWA Chiat/Day is also the agency for ABC, creating the humorous ''TV is good'' image campaign for the network and ads for shows for the 1997-98 season -- like ''The Wonderful World of Disney.'' **********Apple's ''Think different'' campaign has been eagerly awaited in part because of how Mr. Jobs orchestrated publicity for the commercial's appearance last night. Some details about the spot were shared with reporters last week before Mr. Jobs decided that the anticipation would be heightened if Apple and TBWA Chiat/Day declined to disclose further information. **********The commercial is a paean to achievement, audaciously comparing Apple to world-changing individuals as disparate as Albert Einstein, Bob Dylan, the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr., Ted Turner, Amelia Earhart, Alfred Hitchcock and Pablo Picasso. **********''Here's to the crazy ones,'' declares the announcer, the actor Richard Dreyfuss, ''the misfits, the rebels, troublemakers.'' But apart from their accomplishments, what the 20 or so famous figures have in common -- and their relationship if any to computers -- is unclear. At the end, as if trying to explain, Mr. Dreyfuss asserts that what they all share is ''genius,'' because ''the people who are crazy enough to think they can change the world are the ones who do.'' **********The campaign will continue with additional commercials as well as billboards and print and transit advertising. To help rekindle Apple's reputation for unconventional marketing, there will also be ads in unconventional media like posters pasted on walls and wrapped around buses.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/03/world.snippet: Sinn Fein, political wing of IRA, wins two seats in British Parliament in its strongest showing ever in a British election; Gerry Adams and Martin McGuinness are elected as Sinn Fein takes seats away from both mainstream Catholic-dominated Social ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/03/world.main_headline: In Best Tally Ever, Sinn Fein Wins 2 Seats in Westminster
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/03/world.print_headline: In Best Tally Ever, Sinn Fein Wins 2 Seats in Westminster
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/03/world.body_text: **********In its strongest showing ever in a British national election, Sinn Fein, the political wing of the Irish Republican Army, won two seats in the British Parliament, according to results announced today from the voting on Thursday. **********Both Gerry Adams, the Sinn Fein president, and the party's No. 2 official, Martin McGuinness, were elected from Northern Ireland. Their overwhelmingly Roman Catholic party took seats away from both the mainstream Catholic-dominated Social Democratic Labor party and the hard-line Protestant Democratic Unionist Party. **********Before the election, Sinn Fein held no seats in the Westminster Parliament and had never won two seats in the House of Commons. **********Mr. Adams and Mr. McGuinness, who has been Sinn Fein's chief negotiator with British officials in the peace effort, will not occupy the seats, however, because Sinn Fein policy precludes them from taking the required loyalty oath to the British Crown, which the party considers an illegal occupier. But they said the party would open offices in London near the House of Commons and argue their positions from outside. **********The effects the results might have on efforts to end the sectarian conflict in Northern Ireland were unclear. But experts said Sinn Fein was now in a stronger political position and better able to insist that it has a moral and political mandate. **********The largest Protestant party, the Ulster Unionist Party, was also strengthened, while the hard-line Protestant party of the Rev. Ian Paisley, the Democratic Unionist Party, was weakened. **********Of the 18 seats from Northern Ireland, the mainstream Ulster Unionist Party, the largest political organization in the province, gained 1 seat and now holds 10; Mr. Paisley's party lost a seat and has 2; a smaller unionist party has 1, and the Social Democratic Labor Party, after losing a seat to Mr. Adams, has 3. **********The Social Democrats received 60 percent of the Catholic vote and Sinn Fein received 40 percent. Sinn Fein's total vote in this Protestant-dominated British province was 16.1 percent, the highest province-wide total ever. **********The question now is whether the new configuration will move the stengthened mainstream unionists toward accepting Sinn Fein at the negotiating table, and whether Sinn Fein's show of strength will produce an I.R.A. cease-fire. **********Mr. Adams made it immediately clear that he would use his party's showing to argue that Sinn Fein should be invited to join the formal peace talks when they resume in Belfast on June 3 under the chairmanship of George J. Mitchell, a former United States Senate majority leader. **********The Irish and British Goverments have said that Sinn Fein should be excluded from the talks until the I.R.A. restores the 17-month cease-fire it broke in February 1996. Sinn Fein advocates a peaceful settlement of the conflict, but steadfastly refuses to condemn the I.R.A.'s campaign of violence. **********Today, Mr. Adams said, ''I want to see an end to all armed actions,'' but he said nothing about trying to persuade the I.R.A. to restore the cease-fire. His message for the Dublin and London Governments, he said, was that his party's victory meant it deserved ''equality'' and ''inclusive negotiations.'' **********The new British Prime Minister, Tony Blair, said little during his campaing about what his Northern Ireland policy would be. But in an article in The Irish Times in Dublin on Monday, he wrote: ''Perhaps Sinn Fein's ambivalence about violence reflects its small electoral base. But democracy requires that even the smallest party pursue its aims through methods that are exclusively peaceful. It is a lesson that Sinn Fein must learn before it will earn the right to sit and talk with other democratic parties in Northern Ireland.'' **********John Hume, the leader of the Social Democrats, who was re-elected from the western part of the province, said he hoped that the Labor Government would invite Sinn Fein when the peace talks resume. This implied, as Mr. Hume has repeatedly stated, that there would first be an I.R.A. cease-fire. ''Let's keep spilling our sweat and not our blood,'' he added. **********While Mr. Hume and Mr. Adams are enemies in elections, they were together in initiating the current peace effort in 1993 and have said that, with the elections over, they will again cooperate to move the stalled peace effort forward. **********Most experts say that, in effect, Mr. Hume's cooperation with Mr. Adams in the peace effort helped elect Mr. Adams over Mr. Hume's Social Democratic colleague, Dr. Joe Hendron. Mr. Adams had won the seat twice, in 1983 and 1987, before Dr. Hendron defeated him in 1992 by 589 votes. This time, Mr. Adams won by 7,000 votes. **********Mr. McGuinness won in the Mid-Ulster district, defeating the incumbent of the hard-line Democratic Unionists, the Rev. Willie McCrea.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/20/world.snippet: Clinton Administration moves quickly to extend ties and recognition to rebel alliance now ruling Zaire, pledging its help in building democratic government and adopting name rebels have given country, Democratic Republic of Congo (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/20/world.main_headline: U.S. Accepts Kabila, but Cautions on Democracy
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/20/world.print_headline: U.S. Accepts Kabila, but Cautions on Democracy
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/20/world.body_text: **********The Clinton Administration moved quickly today to extend ties and recognition to the rebel alliance now ruling Zaire, pledging its help in building a democratic government and adopting the name the rebels have given the country, the Democratic Republic of Congo. **********But the Administration also called on the country's new leader, Laurent Kabila, to begin taking steps toward a democratic government by holding elections soon and by including opposition figures in the provisional government he is expected to announce when he arrives in Kinshasa on Tuesday. **********Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright said that international support -- and, implicitly, aid -- for the government depended on Mr. Kabila's willingness to establish democracy after more than three decades of autocratic rule under Mobutu Sese Seko. **********''We are making it very clear that it is important for the new government to be inclusive, to be concerned and do a lot about democratic practices and human rights,'' Ms. Albright said at a news conference in Wilmington, Del. **********The Administration's reactions today reflected both the hope and ambivalence that have greeted the fall of Mr. Mobutu and the rise of Mr. Kabila. **********While officials here in Washington have expressed relief that the rebels captured Kinshasa, the capital, with relatively little bloodshed, they remain wary of Mr. Kabila's intentions, noting that the rebel leader has suggested that a transition to elections could last from one to five years. And despite repeated contacts as his rebellion swept over the country, Mr. Kabila has shown little interest in acceding to the United States' demands, even though he has told American officials he shares their views on democracy and a market economy. The officials said Mr. Kabila's announcement of a new government would be an early test of those promises. **********Moving to shore up diplomatic contacts with the new leadership, the American Ambassador in Zaire, Daniel H. Simpson, met in Kinshasa today with two of Mr. Kabila's senior aides, Deo Bugera and Paul Kabungo. Mr. Simpson reiterated the United States' eagerness to see the rebels embrace political figures who long opposed Mr. Mobutu, including his longtime rival, Etienne Tshisekedi. **********In what officials in Washington interpreted as a hopeful sign, Mr. Bugera, the secretary general of the rebel alliance, asked the Ambassador how to contact Mr. Tshisekedi. Mr. Simpson dialed his cellular phone and handed it to him, an Administration official said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/16/busin.body_text: **********Griffin Bacal in New York has named Robert Moehl to oversee its creative output in the new post of executive vice president and executive creative director. Mr. Moehl, 50, will supervise day-to-day creative operations, reporting to Joe Bacal, 63, co-chairman and creative services director. Mr. Moehl joins Griffin Bacal, a unit of Omnicom Group in New York, after four years at D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles in New York, part of MacManus Group, where he was senior vice president and executive creative director on accounts like Procter & Gamble.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/21/busin.print_headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS; French Insurer's Shares Rise on Bid Speculation
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/21/busin.body_text: **********Shares of Assurances Generales de France S.A., France's second-largest insurer, surged as much as 36.2 percent yesterday amid expectations that another company would make a bid higher than the one from Assicurazioni Generali S.p.A. Assurances Generales de France's shares rose as high as 320 francs ($53.78), from 235 francs ($39.50) on Oct. 10, the last time they traded, and higher than Generali's unsolicited offer of 300 francs ($50.42) a share. They were suspended on Oct. 13, when Italy's biggest insurer made its bid of 55 billion francs ($9.24 billion).  They closed at 318.4 francs ($53.51). **********Assurances Generales de France has rejected the Generali bid, saying it was too low. It now needs to find a company rich enough to outbid Generali while keeping its own management and structure in place.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/12/world.snippet: Africans in Muzarambani, Zimbabwe, may be induced by money to consider elephants more than big cranky pests that devour crops and knock over huts; money from tourism and few hunting licenses has built local clinic and beer hall; photo; map; Zimbab...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/12/world.main_headline: Where the Elephants Pay Their Way
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/12/world.print_headline: Where the Elephants Pay Their Way
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/12/world.body_text: **********The footprints, as big as birdbaths, can still be seen in Edward Mandizwidza's muddy fields here weeks later. **********For three days, two elephants came out of the nearby wilderness and, in the moonlight, fed on Mr. Mandizwidza's crops. In the morning, his neat rows of cornstalks were interrupted by huge empty areas. **********Mr. Mandizwidza is far too scared of elephants, which kill at least one person a year in this district 100 miles north of Harare, to stay up all night banging a pot to drive them away. On the other hand, he wasn't all that upset either. Lately, the district has been making money from the elephants here in the flat Zambezi Valley where baobab trees with thick trunks offer the little shade to be found. **********Most of the money, which flows from tourism and a handful of very expensive hunting licenses, has been used to build Muzarabani a clinic, a cattle feedlot and a treasured beer hall. **********Mr. Mandizwidza wants a fence, but to keep the elephants in, not out. **********''I would want this fence there tomorrow, even today,'' he said, pointing to a line beyond his fields where another district begins. ''The elephants give some benefits to us.'' **********Now there is the possibility of even more elephant money to tempt villagers to regard the animals as something more than really big, cranky pests. **********Zimbabwe, Botswana and Namibia have huge stockpiles of tusks from elephants that died naturally, were culled to limit populations or were killed for threatening people. The three nations are joining forces this year to fight the international ban on the sale of ivory. If they prevail when the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species, or Cites, meets in Zimbabwe in June, it will be the first time since 1989 that a legal sale of African ivory will be allowed. **********A bruising battle is expected. Southern African countries proposed renewing ivory sales at the 1992 and 1994 meetings, but backed down after animal rights groups and other African countries said that would lead to a new round of poaching. **********This time, though, a new proposal may have a chance. The three countries want to sell one large batch of ivory a year to Japan, which has promised not to export any of it. Despite an international campaign by animal groups to discourage an affinity for tusks -- one that was very effective in Europe and the United States -- Japan has never lost its appetite for ivory purse ties and other carved knicknacks. **********In the basement of the National Parks headquarters in Harare, lined up on rough wooden shelves under 24-hour guard, Zimbabwe has 40 tons of tusks, each stamped with an identification number. Botswana has 30 tons. Namibia has about 8 tons. **********With offers as high as $250 a pound coming in, such stockpiles could mean millions to countries where subsistence farming is the norm and running water and electricity are rare. **********Botswana officials say their commitment to conserving wildlife has been proved: 37 percent of the nation's land is in parks or conservancies. But they argue that such an investment must be rewarded. **********''We need to have something to give back to the communities who bear the brunt of this,'' said Joseph Matlhare, deputy director of the Department of Wildlife and National Parks. ''If there are benefits that can accrue other than tourism, we want to look at that. There are plenty of communities where people are getting killed when they go to fetch water.'' **********Elephants may be threatened elsewhere on this continent, but not in most of southern Africa. Poaching is negligible in Zimbabwe, Botswana and Namibia, which all have growing populations of elephants -- more than 150,000 among them, experts estimate. That's too many, some think. Some forests have been stripped down to stumps. **********What the countries do not have is cash -- cash that could be used to build fences, monitor elephants and compensate farmers like Mr. Mandizwidza. Government officials and local conservationists argue that the income would help make local people like the Muzarabani residents more tolerant of the huge herbivores, which can eat for up to 18 hours a day and will happily knock down a farmer's granary hut to get at the food inside. **********The three are tired of paying the price for other countries, like Angola, where war decimated the herds, and Kenya, where incompetence and corruption let poachers flourish. Moving adult elephants is dangerous and expensive, so herds cannot simply be shipped north. **********''There is every indication that there is a much greater understanding of the problems in southern Africa this year,'' said Jonathan Barzdo, who monitors the issue for Cites. ''And they have a much better proposal with strict controls in place.'' **********But some conservation groups, especially American and European ones, say the proposal will open the floodgates, encouraging the kind of poaching that saw the continent's elephant population fall from 1.3 million in 1979 to an estimated 500,000 today. **********''It's the first deadly step toward full-fledged resumption of the ivory trade,'' said Wayne Pacelle, vice president of the Humane Society of the United States, which intends to lobby against the proposal. **********The Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species, which has 136 member countries, has no sanctions to impose on members that ignore its rules. But experts say poor countries are often bound in indirect ways. Tourism and foreign aid could dry up if they do not toe the line. **********Experts with the Convention on International Trade and Endangered Species like some aspects of the proposal. One-time sales would be easy to inspect and control, they said. But they find flaws too. Zimbabwe has not stemmed ivory smuggling at its borders and Botswana has not promised to use the ivory revenues for conservation or for villages in elephant areas. **********Certainly the income has gone a long way to changing attitudes in Muzarabani, where the elephant was previously best appreciated as barbecue meat. Nowadays farmers like Mr. Mandizwidza are even pressured to keep quiet about crop damage so Government sharpshooters won't kill the elephants as nuisances before fee-paying foreign hunters can be flown in. **********''People are beginning to understand that there is a need to preserve the elephant, not just for the income but because it is our inheritance,'' said the district's chief executive, Luckson Chisanduro. ''But the income doesn't hurt.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/28/world.body_text: **********Following are excerpts from remarks by President Clinton and President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia as they signed an agreement between Russia and NATO. Mr. Yeltsin's remarks were translated by a Russian Government translator. **********President Clinton **********Ladies and gentlemen, on this beautiful spring day in Paris, in the twilight of the 20th century, we look toward a new century with a new Russia and a new NATO, working together in a new Europe of unlimited possibility. The NATO-Russia Founding Act we have just signed joins a great nation and history's most successful alliance in common cause for a long-sought but never before realized goal -- a peaceful, democratic, undivided Europe. **********The United States feels a great deal of gratitude today. The world my predecessors dreamed of and worked for for 50 years is finally within reach. . . . **********From now on, NATO and Russia will consult and coordinate and work together. Where we all agree, we will act jointly, as we are in Bosnia where a Russian brigade serves side by side with NATO troops, giving the Bosnian people a chance to build a lasting peace. Deepening our partnership today will make all of stronger and more secure. **********The historic change in the relationship between NATO and Russia grows out of a fundamental change in how we think about each other and our future. NATO's member states recognize that the Russian people are building a new Russia, defining their greatness in terms of the future as much as the past. Russia's transition to democracy and open markets is as difficult as it is dramatic. And its steadfast commitment to freedom and reform has earned the world's admiration. **********In turn, we are building a new NATO. It will remain the strongest alliance in history, with smaller, more flexible forces, prepared to provide for our defense, but also trained for peacekeeping. It will work closely with other nations that share our hopes and values and interests through the Partnership For Peace. **********It will be an alliance directed no longer against a hostile bloc of nations, but instead designed to advance the security of every democracy in Europe -- NATO's old members, new members, and non-members alike. **********I know that some still see NATO through the prism of the cold war, and that especially in NATO's decision to open its doors to Central Europe's new democracy, they see a Europe still divided, only differently divided. But I ask them to look again. For this new NATO will work with Russia, not against it. And by reducing rivalry and fear, by strengthening peace and cooperation, by facing common threats to the security of all democracies, NATO will promote greater stability in all of Europe, including Russia. And in turn, that will increase the security of Europe's North American partners, the United States and Canada, as well. **********We establish this partnership because we are determined to create a future in which European security is not a zero-sum game -- where NATO's gain is Russia's loss, and Russia's strength is our alliance's weakness. That is old thinking; these are new times. Together, we must build a new Europe in which every nation is free and every free nation joins in strengthening the peace and stability for all. **********President Yeltsin **********I'll be absolutely frank and candid with you and tell you that for the Russian leadership the decision to prepare a document with NATO was far from easy. **********We had to make sure we protected the security of our country; but at the same time we also had to, of course, create the basis, the foundation for a constructive cooperation between Russia and NATO. **********Russia still views negatively the expansion plans of NATO. At the same time, however, we recognize, we pay tribute to the readiness exhibited by NATO countries, despite those difficulties, to reach an agreement with Russia and take into account our interests. **********And that is precisely the rationale of the situation we're experiencing now, the difficulty of negotiations between Russia and NATO and also the essence, the thrust, of the Founding Act itself. **********Through joint efforts in that document we try to answer very difficult questions. **********And those very difficult issues deal, first of all, with nondeployment of nuclear weapons. **********There is an obligation to nondeploy on a permanent basis NATO's combat forces near Russia. All of this means that we have agreed not to harm the security interests of each other. And I think it is the most important accomplishment for us all. **********What is also very important is that we are creating the mechanisms for consultation and cooperation between Russia and the alliance. And this will enable us to -- on a fair, egalitarian basis -- to discuss, and when need be, pass joint decisions on major issues relating to security and stability, those issues and those areas which touch upon our interests. **********The fate of this continent, Europe, has not been  easy. It is very easy to list the wars and skirmishes it has undergone. Each century has brought with it new tests and new challenges, new wars to the soil of this continent. **********Several times attempts to stem this tragic chain of events have been made, but now our efforts can and should bear fruit. It has been almost 10 years, and for the first time in history, the people of Europe are joined together by common democratic values.
