https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/25/your-.body_text: **********WHETHER you are a stock-market novice or a seasoned investor, forming an investment club a sort ofdo-it-yourself mutual fund —can be a useful way to learn more about stock selection while having fun andseeing your investments grow.Or so goes the theory. **********Club members contribute agreed-upon sums, often monthly, and meet to decide what investments to buy and sell. Most of the organizations have elements of social clubs, which can make them fun to belong to although at the risk of limiting profitability. **********TheMoney Report has profiled several of these clubs, and this week we check in with three of them. What we found was that when a club identifies and maintains a sensible strategy, it prospers — but those that are more relaxed stand to lose money. **********The Victoria Investment Club of Cornwall,in England,iscelebrating a rare coup. Its 17 members recently took part in an investment challenge sponsored by ProShare (UK), an independent body that represents British investment clubs. The Victoria club beat investors at NatWest Stockbrokers, winning a prize of £5,000 ($8,100) **********What makes this achievement all the more remarkable is thatuntil recently the club's investments have not been very successful. When the club was mentioned in a Money Report article in October 1995, it was running at a loss. Derek Richards, the chairman, acknowledgedthat there was too much chitchatand not enough serious work being done. **********Mr. Richards saidinvestment performance started to pick up when the members decided to treat the venture like a business instead of just a social club. "The members agreed on a definitive investment strategy and stuck with it irrespective of market movements. Rather than invest piecemeal in a mixture of blue-chip, medium-sized and small companies, we decided to concentrate solely on small companies and limit our investment in each stock to £1,500," he said. **********"The club also decided to get rid of stocks that were showing a loss. In the past we held onto loss-making companies in the hope that their performance would eventually improve." **********The club currently holds eight stocks. In 1996, the club made an overall gain of around 30 percent. Members arelooking at several new investment possibilities for 1997, including Flying Flowers Ltd., a British mail-order company listed on the London exchange, andT.V. Corp., a television production services company. **********The Sirens, an all-women investment club from Oxford, in England, was featured in The Money Report early last year because it had been awarded the ProShare prize for the most promising new investment club of 1995. **********The club maintains an ethical investing philosophy. It will not, for example, invest in any company linked to tobacco production, defense and the exploitation of animals or Third World resources. **********In recent months, the club has not been doing very well.Profits are down and club morale has suffered as a result.Beverly Chisnall, the chairman, said the club was a victim of its own success. "We got carried away with our initial good fortuneand started cutting corners. Reseach was not as thorough as it could have been and several poor investment decisions were made," she said. **********The club decided to get rid of most of its recent holdings and more or less start from scratch. Rather than invest hundreds of pounds in individual stocks, members agreed to save up and invest larger amounts, up to £3,000 in some cases. **********The Sirens' top holding is in National Express Group PLC, a British bus company. It is also looking to invest a significant sum in Oxford Instruments PLC, a medical-equipment manufacturer. "We try to invest in local companies as much as possible. Some of our members know this Oxford Instruments very well and are confident in the management team. The balance sheets are also encouraging," Ms. Chisnall said. **********Few investment clubs that have been going for more than five years can claim to have had a trouble-free run. The Taffy Investment Club of Kansas is a rare exception. The club, which comprises four generations of the Taylor and Andrews families, boasts an average annual return of 25 percent.Even more remarkable, the club has never had an unprofitable year in its decade-long history. **********Robert Taylor, who, at 76, is one of the oldest club members, describes the club's investment strategy as "conservative" and "long-term." He said: "We buy established companies with good growth prospects and hang onto them through thick and thin." The club's first purchase, Home Depot Inc., is still in theportfolio. **********Mr. Taylor admitted to being "pretty nervous" about the current state of the U.S. stock market.The club has decided to look at defensive stocks in the next few months to guard against a likely downturn. Topping the list is Exxon Corp., the oil and gas giant: "We think that the consumption of these commodities is going to continue to grow." **********For further information on investment clubs, contact the World Federation of Investors Corp., S-11389 Stockholm, tel 46 468 457 1500, or ProShare Investment Clubs, Library Chambers, 13& 14 Basinghall Street, London EC2V 5BQ, tel 44 171 600 0984.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/14/busin.snippet: Institute of Canadian Advertising, a trade organization based in Toronto, is undertaking unusual initiative to convince American marketers to consider advertising agencies in Canada (L)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/14/busin.main_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING ; A Canadian agency group hopes to persuade potential clients to take a look north of the border.
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/14/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING ; A Canadian agency group hopes to persuade potential clients to take a look north of the border.
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/14/busin.body_text: **********WHEN advertisers introduce campaigns with provocative or contentious creative elements, they often say they are trying to ''push the boundaries.'' Now an agency association is asking them to consider doing that literally. **********The Institute of Canadian Advertising, a trade organization based in Toronto, is undertaking an unusual initiative to convince American marketers to consider shops north of the 49th parallel when they award accounts. The effort being sponsored by the institute, which is the Canadian equivalent of the American Association of Advertising Agencies, carries the theme -- what else? -- ''Push the boundaries.'' **********''Canadians are not well known for standing up and saying, 'Look at me,' '' said John A. Harding, executive vice president of the institute. ''But we have a story to tell.'' **********''An advertiser in New York doesn't think twice about using an agency from Minneapolis or Portland,'' he added. ''It's just as conceivable to look at an agency north of the border.'' (Or in the case of Detroit area advertisers, south of the border.) **********The ambitious initiative includes print advertisements, direct and interactive marketing and a public relations campaign, all meant to generate requests for a videotape and booklet about the abilities of Canadian agencies. The effort is indicative of the growing globalization of advertising as multinational marketers increasingly look at results rather than passports. **********''Where ideas come from is not as important as whether or not they work,'' said Andy Krupski, chairman of the institute's business development committee, who is president and chief executive at the Grey Canada unit of Grey Advertising in Toronto. ''This is the first step in a continuing program to make sure the world is aware of the talent that's in Canada.'' **********The initiative offers a lengthy list of what the institute describes as the advantages of hiring Canadian agencies, from favorable exchange rates to efficient production facilities to experience in ethnic marketing. **********''Our industry has to work in two official languages by law,'' Mr. Krupski said, referring to English and French, ''and in three or four by a market perspective. Because we have a lot of constituencies, we have to make ideas strong enough to work across cultural lines.'' **********''And typically we do that with fewer dollars than may be afforded in the U.S.,'' he added, ''which may make us more agile and frugal.'' **********But persuading Americans that other countries can be capable of effective work is a challenge not unlike withstanding a Canadian winter without a warm coat. **********''U.S. chauvinism'' is daunting, said Stan Sutter, editor of Marketing Magazine, a weekly trade publication in Toronto, who described the initiative as ''calling the bluff of all the companies that say they believe in globalization.'' **********''If globalization is real,'' he asked, ''why not use an agency in Toronto, Vancouver or Montreal?'' **********Another reason the institute is prospecting for American clients, he said, is that ''since the recession of the early 1990's, it's been tough on the agency industry here.'' ''Accounts keep going south,'' he added. **********O. Burtch Drake, president and chief executive of the association of American agencies, echoed that. **********''A lot of companies are handling Canada out of the United States,'' he said, ''which eventually leads to a consolidation of Canadian assignments -- handled by Canadian agencies or Canadian offices of U.S. agencies -- at U.S. agencies.'' **********''I know the people up there quite well,'' he added, referring to the managers of Canadian agencies, ''and they're good, smart ad people. But there are some pretty good agencies here. The ultimate test is whether the work will be as good as they can get here.'' **********At least one advertiser has decided that a Canadian agency ought to handle an American assignment. TDL Group Ltd., a unit of Wendy's International that operates the Tim Hortons chain of Canadian doughnut and coffee shops, is using its Canadian agency, Enterprise Creative Selling, to create campaigns to introduce Hortons in American markets like Detroit and Columbus, Ohio. **********''We believe our agency up here understands our business and the message we need to get across in a new market,'' said Patti Jameson, corporate communications director at TDL Group in Oakville, Ontario. ''There is some merit in saying that opening a store in Buffalo is very similar to opening a store in Mississauga,'' a Toronto suburb. **********But last month, Northern Telecom in Brampton, Ontario, shifted its corporate advertising account from one American agency (J. Walter Thompson San Francisco, part of WPP Group) to another (the Bozell Worldwide unit of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt in New York). **********Indeed, Mr. Krupski said, one goal of the initiative is to remind Canadian advertisers ''not to forget there's some good talent up here, too.'' **********Several agencies in Toronto are contributing to the effort: the Harrod & Mirlin unit of True North Communications and the Saatchi & Saatchi Canada unit of Cordiant P.L.C., which worked on the print ads; Grey Interactive, which designed a World Wide Web site (http://www.ica-ad.com), and Spectrum Public Relations, part of the BBDO Canada unit of Omnicom Group.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/08/world.snippet: Recent criticisms of Albania by Italian diplomats heightens tensions in already sensitive relationship betwen both countries; statements have fueled controversy three weeks before Albanian elections, in which outcome could be test of Italy's credi...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/08/world.main_headline: Controversy Diminishes Italy's Clout In Albania
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/08/world.print_headline: Controversy Diminishes Italy's Clout In Albania
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/08/world.body_text: **********Two embarrassing episodes have given Italian diplomacy in Albania a black eye, self-inflicted at a critical moment in the sensitive relationship between the countries that face each other across a narrow stretch of the Adriatic Sea. **********First, Italy had to recall its longtime Ambassador to Albania because of damaging things he reportedly said in a taped conversation, a transcript of which was printed in an Albanian newspaper. Then last weekend, his successor's appointment was withdrawn within 48 hours of its announcement because of comments he reportedly made to an Italian newspaper. **********Only three weeks remain before Albanian elections, considered crucial for restoring stability to a country that was teetering on the edge of anarchy in March, after people revolted over the collapse of several get-rich-quick investment schemes. And with each day come reports of fresh violence, casting a long shadow over an already shaky democratic process. **********The latest report, on Albania's state-controlled television on Wednesday, was of a hand grenade thrown at a rally for President Sali Berisha outside the capital, Tirana. That report came two days after 20 people were wounded by a bomb blast at a Tirana cafe owned and frequented by ranking members of the opposition Socialist Party. **********The violence is a major concern for the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe, which under the leadership of a former Austrian Chancellor, Franz Vranitsky, has undertaken to monitor the June 29 elections and try to keep them free of the fraud that clouded Mr. Berisha's victory in voting in May 1996. **********But Italy also has a lot at stake in the Albanian voting, including its credibility as an international crisis manager. **********In the early days of the crisis, Italy -- faced with an influx of 16,000 Albanian refugees -- took a lead role in trying to drum up a common European policy. It failed to get full support from its northern partners but was given the command of a 6,500-troop multinational force deployed in Albania two months ago under a limited United Nations mandate. **********For that reason, and because of the legacy of the occupation of Albania by Italy's Fascist Government before World War II, the Albanian mission has been viewed here and abroad as a test of Italy's military and diplomatic leadership. And while the Italian military performance in Albania generally gets good marks, the embarrassments over the ambassadors is seen as evidence of Italy's difficulties in coping with its new responsibilities. **********''The real problem is that this is the first time we are taking the lead in an international crisis and because of our long tradition of following in the wake of others, we have discovered that we lack a proper decision-making structure,'' said Franco Venturini, a noted commentator on foreign affairs for the newspaper Corriere della Sera. ''The result is that we have not had a solid agreement on policy right from the beginning.'' **********What made the fiasco of the ambassadors so embarrassing was that their reported comments -- denied in both cases -- reflected the real splits that have beset Italy's Albanian policy, principally relations with Mr. Berisha. **********The outgoing Ambassador, Paolo Foresti, was quoted by the Albanian opposition newspaper Independent as urging a top Berisha ally to undercut a pre-election accord negotiated by Mr. Vranitsky. **********His successor, Manfredo Incisa di Camerana, was quoted by the Italian newspaper La Repubblica as saying Mr. Foresti himself had a history of political involvement. **********Ever since Albania emerged in 1990 from the isolation imposed by its longtime Communist rulers, Italy has taken a close interest in its neighbor. Italian businesses moved into Albania, and Italian political leaders soon took up positions on Albanian politics, with right-wing leaders favoring Mr. Berisha's Democratic Party and leftists showing more sympathy for the Socialist opposition. **********The recent appointment of Gen. Franco Angioni, a respected former commander of Italian troops in Lebanon, to head an intergovernment task force on Albania based in Rome is widely seen as a way of straightening out the mixed signals coming from Rome in recent weeks. **********But according to foreign and Italian analysts, it is also a recognition that Italian involvement with Albania is not likely to end soon after the June election. **********''The problem of Albania is potentially everyone's, but most immediately, it is Italy's problem,'' a foreign diplomat said. ''And the appointment of General Angioni is a sign that the Italians are coming to grips with the fact that the burden is going to be theirs for a long time.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/18/world.main_headline: The Great Gold Rush in Zaire
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/18/world.print_headline: The Great Gold Rush in Zaire
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/18/world.body_text: **********Even before the leader of Zaire's rebellion can finish off the dictatorship of Mobutu Sese Seko and seize this country's capital, a series of major business deals may enable him to resist Western pressures for economic change and democracy. **********The most spectacular of these deals, an $885 million contract between the rebellion and an American mining company, American Mineral Fields, announced Wednesday in the rebel-held city of Lubumbashi, would rehabilitate zinc, copper and cobalt mines in the country's southern Shaba Province. **********Now, Zairian economic experts, former Government officials and diplomats here say that business like this has dramatically increased the leeway for the leader of the rebellion, Laurent Kabila, to decide whose aid and advice to accept, even when he has not won power outright. **********In recent weeks, as Mr. Kabila has drawn closer to his goal of unseating Mr. Mobutu, many Western Governments have taken the view that the impending change here is bound to bring improvement to Africa's worst-governed country. **********Far from a statement of faith in Mr. Kabila, a lifelong revolutionary with a checkered past, this optimism is based in large part on the notion of leverage. Although Zaire is richly endowed with natural resources, its economy is near collapse, and many assume that rebuilding the country will require huge amounts of foreign assistance. **********Mr. Mobutu has been cut off from foreign aid and lending during this decade, and there has been an assumption throughout this war that Mr. Kabila, or whoever succeeds the longtime President, would be eager to ingratiate himself with Western governments in order to have access to development loans and other assistance. **********''You are not going to see any kind of American aid program here before we have elections,'' said a senior Western diplomat. ''We will not support dictator Kabila.'' **********But starting late last year, almost imperceptibly at first, and quickly gathering steam, there has been a rush of mining companies and other economic operators out of Kinshasa, where corruption has always made business difficult, into rebel-held areas rich in minerlas, where Mr. Kabila's associates have been quick to offer advantageous terms to adventurous investors. **********The first of Mr. Kabila's major deals involved the huge Kilo-Moto gold field in northeastern Zaire, which is commonly referred to here as Mr. Mobutu's personal gold mine.  At Kilo-Moto, a senior Zairian mining official here said, a Belgian-South African company that was turned down last year for a $162 million in World Bank financing to rehabilitate the mine is now raising money for the project by buying gold from free-lance miners, which is exported at a handsome profit. **********Officials here said that another company, the Canadian-controlled firm Sominki, which formerly mined tin in Zaire, is now investing in gold production in the region of the rebel-held east-central city of Kindu. **********Where Zaire's official gold mining registry used to show receipts for several major foreign mining firms, today, in a reflection of the loss of most of the country's mineral rich zones to the rebellion, there is only one Western company that still declares its gold production -- about 200 pounds each month -- to Mr. Mobutu's Government. **********Most of the other operators are believed to be already active in rebel-held zones. **********Mining experts say that in recent years Zaire has had fraudulent exports of about 900 pounds of gold each month, and by sanctioning the official corruption that has been a way of life here, the rebels stand to gain an even bigger windfall from this. **********''The east of our country is so rich that is does not need to have huge investments to restart the economy,'' said Willy Katupa, editor of the Zairian economic review Perspectives. ''Just by controlling the borders and diminishing fraud, the rebellion can expect to start receiving large sums of money. The foreign investment will certainly follow.'' **********The story here is much the same for diamonds. Until recently, Kinshasa was averaging about $20 million a month in revenues from small-scale diamond producers, and an additional $8 million a month from the state-owned industrial mining company, Miba. But with the fall of East Kasai Province two weeks ago, all of that wealth, and the cash flow it generates, is controlled by the rebels. **********Many here fear that Mr. Kabila's treatment of Miba's wealth may be indicative of his broader approach to power. Although the charges are unproved, it is widely believed in diplomatic and business circles that when Mr. Kabila swept triumphantly into the diamond-mining capital of Mbuji-Mayi recently, he forced Miba's managers to hand over all the production on hand. **********The director of the company, Jonas Mukamba, a longtime partner of Mr. Mobutu, was reportedly flown off to Goma where he is said to be under house arrest. **********''The March diamond production was already packed up and awaiting transport to Kinshasa,'' said one senior mining official here, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. ''Kabila just carted it off.'' **********In the 1970's, long after Zaire's other early insurrections had collapsed, Mr. Kabila reportedly thrived with a small band of rebels in the Fizi-Baraka mountains of eastern Zaire by mining gold and paying off soldiers sent to wipe them out. **********''This is a guy who knows a little bit about gold and corruption,'' said one regional military analyst. **********Little, meanwhile, is known about Mr. Kabila's philosophy of government. Based on his movement's statements so far, it can be said that there is no inclination toward Western-style elections presided over by international observers. **********Today, in fact, the strongest outside influences on Mr. Kabila come from Uganda's President, Yoweri Museveni, whom he calls a ''good friend,'' and the Rwandan Vice President and strongman, Paul Kagame. Both leaders took power by force. **********Neither Uganda nor Rwanda bear much resemblance to Western democracies, and Mr. Kabila seems to have followed Mr. Museveni's early political blueprint by saying that he will not tolerate opposition political parties during a transitional phase in power. **********During Mr. Kabila's early years in revolt against Mr. Mobutu, he was known as a committed Marxist. The beliefs that he seems to have carried through the years come from Patrice Lumumba, a hero of African nationalism who was Zaire's first prime minister. Mr. Lumumba, who was assassinated in 1961 with the direct encouragement, if not participation, of the Central Intelligence Agency, strongly believed that African countries had to find their own paths and could not have their futures dictated by outside powers. **********Many of those who watch Mr. Kabila expect that he will bear this same trait, making him highly resistant to demands to implement Western-prescribed economic liberalization programs or install a political system with generous guarantees of political freedoms and effective checks and balances of state institutions. **********More importantly, with vast mineral wealth that is relatively easy to pluck, and foreign investors already beating at his door, he may feel no compulsion to do so. **********''We are standing here watching Kabila sweep up our country, promising changes that he hasn't bothered even to describe to us,'' said a Zairian banker who has opposed Mr. Mobutu in the past and now fears the unknown under Mr. Kabila. ''The international community has just stood by watching this, and by the time we figure out where this man is taking us, it may be too late to change the course of history.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/14/world.snippet: Germany rebuffs suggestions by France's new Socialist Govt to revive earlier plans to ambitious European public works projects to reduce unemployment before common currency is introduced in 1999 (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/14/world.main_headline: Germany Rebuffs French Call for Big Public Works Projects
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/14/world.print_headline: Germany Rebuffs French Call for Big Public Works Projects
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/14/world.body_text: **********Germany today rebuffed suggestions by France's new Socialist Government to revive earlier plans for ambitious European public works programs to reduce unemployment before a common currency is introduced in 1999, according to officials at a meeting of leaders of both countries here. **********''I don't think much of spending money twice that we never had in the first place,'' Chancellor Helmut Kohl  said after meeting in central France with Prime Minister Lionel Jospin and President Jacques Chirac, who called the elections that brought Mr. Jospin to power in an upset victory in France two weeks ago. **********The summit meeting, held at a technology and amusement park called the Futuroscope, was unusual in that it did not produce an agreed French-German position in advance of the meeting of European Union leaders in Amsterdam next week. **********Mr. Kohl and his embattled Government, in the throes of a struggle to bring the German budget deficit down to the levels Germany itself insisted on to make the common currency as strong as the mark, expressed confidence that France would sign a pact next week pledging continued deficit discipline after the new currency comes into being. **********Mr. Jospin and other officials did not rule that out. ''Our economies cannot develop, or be responsive to the needs of our peoples, solely on a monetary or anti-inflationary basis,'' Mr. Jospin said today. **********The French Finance Minister, Dominique Strauss-Kahn, said: ''We want to fight public deficits, and we also want to fight unemployment. I have good hope of a solution.'' **********Mr. Jospin's Government wants the leaders to agree next week on a revision of the 1992 Treaty on European Union that would include language making jobs a priority of European economic policy. The revision was planned to smooth preparations for the common currency and to prepare the way for admission of new members from Central Europe to the European Union after the currency goes into effect. **********Neither French nor German leaders made public any details of exactly what the new French Government was asking for, but they said that discussions would continue over the weekend and in Amsterdam. **********But according to aides to Mr. Chirac, whose ousted conservative Government cut spending in the last two years, Mr. Kohl made clear that the strapped Germans could not agree to any measures that would cost more money or add to the European bureaucracy in Brussels. **********German officials said they could agree to work together to improve coordination of the economies of the 15 European Union countries, whose welfare states are now supporting 18 million unemployed people. **********Both Mr. Kohl and Mr. Chirac say part of the reason for the high unemployment is that the high payroll charges and income taxes required to support the welfare state discourage companies from hiring people and make welfare more attractive than earning a living. **********Large Government deficits also perpetuate heavy taxation. Mr. Jospin and his people here appeared to be heading toward an acceptance of the need to hew to the monetary agreement's strict limits on budget deficits, but want a promise of political flexibility in their application. **********Neither France nor Germany is likely to meet the treaty requirement of a deficit of 3 percent of gross domestic product or less by the end of this year, according to a forecast this week by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development in Paris. The projection was for  deficits of about 3.2 percent. **********The treaty would allow governments to go forward anyway with the new currency, the euro, as long as prospective participants seemed to be moving in the right direction. **********But Germans fear that too much political interference or laxity could doom the euro to being the kind of weak currency that Mr. Kohl promised skeptical Germans they would never be asked to swap for their strong German marks. The mark and other participating national currencies are to disappear in 2002 under the plan. **********Late last year, when Mr. Chirac's conservatives controlled the French Government, Mr. Kohl got France and the other European countries to agree to a ''stability pact'' pledging them to keep their budgets balanced after the new money came into circulation in 1999. **********But instead of leaving it to independent central bank bureaucrats to decide whether countries actually met the criteria, as the Germans wanted, European leaders did what France wanted and reserved that judgment for themselves. **********During the election campaign, Mr. Jospin said that the conservatives had gone too far and that he would not be bound by the pact if he became Prime Minister. **********Now that he has, he agreed with Mr. Chirac today that France could not go back on its word. Mr. Kohl, for his part, said the subject was closed anyway; the only items under discussion were amendments to the European Union Treaty, he said. **********Mr. Jospin's Government is banking on understanding from the political leaders who will decide who gets into the currency club and who stays in. ''The criteria will be considered in their political and historical context,'' Mr. Strauss-Kahn said today. **********During the election campaign, the Socialists and their Communist allies, who hold three Government ministerial posts, promised to create 700,000 jobs to bring down France's 12.8 percent unemployment rate,  without additional Government spending or higher taxes. **********Mr. Jospin is to reveal the details of the Government's program in Parliament on Thursday.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/24/busin.snippet: Edwin P Neilan, former head of US Chamber of Commerce, dies at age 92; photo (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/24/busin.body_text: **********Edwin P. Neilan, a tough-talking former head of the United States Chamber of Commerce who campaigned against what he considered excessive Government spending, died on Saturday in his hometown of Corpus Christi, Tex. He was 92. **********As president and then as chairman of the chamber in the early 1960's, Mr. Neilan carved a broad swath in Washington as he railed against the expansion of the Federal Goverment and the political culture it fostered. **********As the Government broadened social spending programs it encouraged a system of ''seduction by subsidy,'' Mr. Neilan said, in which politicians conspired to buy votes with promises of pork-barrel spending. **********''The old-fashioned ward heeler who rounded up and delivered derelicts to the polls at $1 a vote was an honest man compared to the widespread public immorality that has infected otherwise reputable and respectable American men and women who are willing, even eager, to turn their elected representatives into bagmen,'' he said in a speech at the National Press Club on Aug. 7, 1963. **********The speech gained national attention and drew the ire of some Congressmen, including Representative Wright Patman, Democrat of Texas, who said the Federal Government had made aid payments of more than $2,000 on a farm owned by Mr. Neilan. **********In 1964 Mr. Neilan attacked President Lyndon B. Johnson's War on Poverty as a ''billion-dollar boondoggle'' designed to win votes rather than help the poor. He supported Senator Barry Goldwater, Republican of Arizona, during that year's Presidential campaign. **********He said then that his campaign to shrink the Federal budget had generated 10,000 letters in his favor and only one against him. **********During his two years at the top of the Chamber of Commerce Mr. Neilan was also chairman of the Bank of Delaware Corporation, which was acquired by the PNC Financial Corporation in 1989. PNC Financial changed its name to the PNC Bank Corporation in 1993. **********Mr. Neilan joined the Bank of Delaware in 1940, became its chairman in 1959 and retired in 1970. Shortly after graduating from Rice University in 1928 he joined the Federal Reserve Bank, where he worked as an examiner in Dallas, New York and Philadelphia. **********Mr. Neilan is survived by two sisters, Bernice Neilan Luhnow of San Antonio and Bonnie Neilan Milton of Seattle. **********After Mr. Neilan made headlines with his anti-Government spending campaign some conservatives urged him to run for political office. He declined. **********''I'm not noted for finesse,'' he said in September 1963. ''When I want to drive at something, I want to drive pretty hard and pretty direct.'' **********''Very few politicians succeed by being blunt,'' he said. ''I'd be a dead duck before I started.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/15/busin.snippet: Christie's PLC, renowned international auction house, receives $825 million takeover bid from SBC Warburg Dillon Read--company that owns controlling interest in outfit (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/15/busin.main_headline: Christie's Is Bid $825 Million, But for Itself
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/15/busin.print_headline: Christie's Is Bid $825 Million, But for Itself
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/15/busin.body_text: **********Christie's International P.L.C., the renowned art auction house, has received the biggest single bid in its 231-year history: $825 million, for itself. **********The takeover bid for Christie's comes from the Swiss-owned investment firm SBC Warburg Dillon Read, officials close to the firm said yesterday. Directors of Christie's met in London last night to consider the offer, but executives of the company would not disclose what action, if any, the board had taken. **********Christie's said last week that it was in talks with a potential buyer, which it did not identify. Since Dec. 4, the company's stock, which is traded in London, has risen nearly 31 percent on speculation about a takeover. **********''We think they will view the bid favorably,'' one official of SBC Warburg said, speaking on condition of  anonymity. **********If the deal goes through, it will give expansion-minded Christie's executives access to the Swiss investment establishment's deep pockets. SBC Warburg is owned by the Swiss Bank Corporation, which last week agreed to merge with Union Bank of Switzerland to form the world's second-largest banking company. **********Moreover, the proposed deal for Christie's would enable SBC Warburg to offer the auction house's expertise to important clients who want to buy or sell fine art. **********It was unclear last night whether SBC Warburg planned to buy the auction house outright or in partnership with other investors -- in particular, the British billionaire Joseph  Lewis, the company's biggest shareholder. Any deal would need the approval of Mr. Lewis, who controls more than 29 percent of Christie's  stock. The Sunday Telegraph of London reported yesterday that SBC Warburg offered Mr. Lewis a 29 percent stake in a new company it would set up to acquire Christie's. Mr. Lewis, who lives in the Bahamas, could not be reached for comment. **********Last year, Christie's barely surpassed its chief rival, Sotheby's Holdings Inc., in total art auction sales for the first time in decades, with each selling about $1.6 billion. But there are indications that Christie's has since widened its lead. **********Sotheby's is drawing its own share of interest from outside investors. Last week, the Bass family of Fort Worth disclosed that it would seek Government approval to raise its stake in Sotheby's to 25 percent from 13.5 percent. **********Both SBC Warburg and the Bass family are investing in a risky and expensive business, since prices for fine art can fluctuate sharply, depending on the economy. **********Still, the art market has been strong this year. Last month, Christie's sold a collection of modern art owned by Victor and Sally Ganz, which included paintings by Picasso, for a record $206.5 million. **********Christie's, which is based in London, has 40 offices around the world and its core business has been expanding greatly in the United States and Asia. **********In 1996, Christie's posted a pretax profit of $53.6 million, and its net income for the first six months of this year rose 22 percent, compared with the 1996 period.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/22/busin.snippet: Mexico's Grupo Televisa SA says it expects to pay one-time charge of $80 million in connection with its cost-cutting program (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/22/busin.body_text: **********Grupo Televisa S.A. said today that it expected to pay a one-time charge of $80 million in connection with its cost-cutting program. **********The Mexican multimedia company said that most of the expenses were related to severance and termination payments for senior executives and their staffs. **********Grupo Televisa is trying to save about $90 million each year for the next three years. As part of the program, the company will freeze certain executive salaries and reduce overtime. It will also institute a new performance-based compensation policy for senior executives that will replace salary increases with stock options. **********The company also plans to reduce real estate rental expenses, including renegotiating existing leases and maximizing occupancy in company-owned buildings. **********Additionally, Grupo Televisa said it planned to reduce circulation of its magazines and reduce excess promotional expenses for records and publishing. Employee travel, amenities and charitable donations will all be reduced. **********American depository receipts for Grupo Televisa shares closed at $27.875, up $2.375, on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/24/busin.snippet: Stock markets in a number of countries hit record highs last week. Bond markets were also rallying. And the dollar was setting a three-year high against the Deutsche mark and a four-year high against the yen. Then, poof! The dollar fell. Stock pri...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/24/busin.main_headline: A Warning of Turmoil in World Markets
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/24/busin.print_headline: A Warning of Turmoil in World Markets
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/24/busin.body_text: **********Stock markets in a number of countries hit record highs last week. Bond markets were also rallying. And the dollar was setting a three-year high against the Deutsche mark and a four-year high against the yen. Then, poof! The dollar fell. Stock prices fell. Bond prices fell. **********But the turmoil last week may just be a taste of what is to come. With worries mounting about an increase in U.S. interest rates and doubts increasing about the likelihood of European monetary union occurring on schedule, analysts such as Avinash Persaud at J.P. Morgan in London are warning that markets may be heading into a period of increased volatility. **********Last week's big hits in Japan are a case in point. The drops occurred Thursday, the day newspapers around the world headlined the death of Deng Xiaoping. Then on Friday, the Nikkei index of Tokyo stock prices scored its largest daily gain in almost a month. **********That looks curious until you consider that the news of Mr. Deng's death was overshadowed by a report in the Nihon Keizai Shimbun, Japan's leading financial newspaper, that the government was preparing a dramatic policy to stabilize real estate prices. **********Any move to deal with Japan's long-festering property crisis would be bullish for the economy and good news for stock prices — and it would give the green light to the Bank of Japan to lift interest rates from their current historic low of 0.5 percent. **********But by late Friday, analysts had concluded there was little immediate substance to the story, and that the government — worried about how the markets would react to the news of Mr. Deng's death — had planted the story as insurance to keep stock prices from falling. Apparently overlooked by Tokyo was how the "news" would affect the positions of banks and hedge funds that have borrowed billions of dollars worth of virtually no-cost yen to finance the purchase of high-yielding government paper in the United States and Europe. The prospect of a rise in interest rates led to massive selling of foreign bonds and the dollar to repay the yen loans. **********With the late realization that there was no immediate policy action planned, the panic unwinding of positions abated. After hitting a low of 122.51 yen on Thursday, the dollar ended the week at 123.265 — down just one yen from the previous week.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/01/busin.snippet: Prices of Treasury securities are mixed, as end-of-month buying partly offsets investors' concern that Federal Reserve will raise short-term interest rates to keep economy from overheating (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/01/busin.main_headline: Long Bond Unchanged in Mixed Trading
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/01/busin.print_headline: Long Bond Unchanged in Mixed Trading
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/01/busin.body_text: **********Prices of Treasury securities were mixed yesterday, as end-of-month buying partly offset investors' concern that the Federal Reserve would raise short-term interest rates to keep the economy from overheating. **********Traders said the morning release of economic reports showing a rise in home resales and manufacturing heightened the anxiety investors evidenced since Wednesday. The Fed chairman, Alan Greenspan, said in Senate testimony then that the central bank could move pre-emptively to counter inflation without waiting for signs to appear. **********The price of a 30-year Government bond was unchanged from Thursday at 9725/32 , to yield 6.80 percent, while the price of a two-year note fell 1/32 , to 9920/32 , to yield 6.08 percent. **********''It's simple,'' said David Ader, managing analyst with Technical Data, Boston. ''The market believes that Greenspan has told us he wants to tighten, and he doesn't need inflation to do it. He is willing to make a pre-emptive move, and we are still reeling from that pronouncement. I don't see a chance for this market to have much more than a short-lived bounce until, and unless, we get some very friendly data.'' **********The National Association of Realtors reported that resales of homes rose 2.1 percent in January, a stark contrast to analysts' forecast of no change. And the Chicago Purchasing Management Association said its February index of manufacturing rose to 56.2 from 55.9 in January, a sign of improving manufacturing in the region, as the prices-paid component, which is viewed by some market participants as a measure of inflation, fell to 56 from 57.4. **********''However,'' said Maury N. Harris, chief economist at Paine Webber, ''the vendor performance index of delivery lead times,'' which, he said, is one of Mr. Greenspan's favorite indicators, ''jumped from 47.6 to 56 in the Chicago purchasing agents' survey.'' **********He added, ''The odds for Fed tightening will rise further if a similar vendor performance rise is reported in the overall N.A.P.M. survey to be released on Monday.'' **********The Commerce Department said fourth-quarter gross domestic product grew at an annual rate of 3.9 percent last year, down from its original estimate of 4.7 percent. But the drop did little to comfort investors, since the revised number was still fairly strong. Analysts surveyed by Bloomberg News had forecast that G.D.P. would be revised down to 4.2 percent. **********Despite the downward revision, analysts noted that some market participants saw within the report a drop in inventories, which could be a sign of strong first-quarter growth. **********Elliott Platt, director of research at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, said economic growth during the first two quarters of 1997 would be contingent upon trade. He said the trade deficit was unsustainably low in the fourth quarter of 1996. **********The February employment report on Friday will help investors develop a view as to the outlook for a rate increase at the March 25 Federal Open Market Committee meeting. **********The Fed has held the line on a rate adjustment since January 1996, even as the economy expanded because inflation has been benign. February nonfarm employment is expected to rise by 204,000, slowing from a 271,000 rise in January.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/01/busin.snippet: Summit Bancorp says agrees to buy Collective Bancorp for $867 million in stock, cementing its position as largest bank based in New Jersey (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/01/busin.body_text: **********Summit Bancorp said today that it had agreed to buy Collective Bancorp for $867 million in stock, cementing its position as the largest bank based in New Jersey. **********Summit would add 50 branches and double its market share in southern New Jersey. The combined bank would have 16 percent of New Jersey's deposits -- up from Summit's current share of 13 percent -- 350 branches in New Jersey and Pennsylvania and $23 billion in assets. **********Under terms of the agreement, Collective stockholders would exchange each of their shares for 0.895 of a Summit share. That gives the transaction a value of about $42.51 a share, based on Thursday's closing price, or about 2.3 times the book value of Collective and 13 times its 1997 earnings. **********In Nasdaq trading, Collective's shares fell 87.5 cents today, to $41.125. On Thursday, the stock had surged $3.875, or 10 percent, to a 52-week high of $42. **********On the New York Stock Exchange, Summit rose 31.25 cents, to $47.8125.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/03/busin.snippet: Currency traders head for safe harbors, buying American dollars and British pounds in light of Socialist victory in France and an unusual domestic spat between German Government and the central bank involving nation's gold reserves and budget; ana...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/03/busin.main_headline: Dollar Gains as Traders Bet Euro Will Be Weakened
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/03/busin.print_headline: Dollar Gains as Traders Bet Euro Will Be Weakened
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/03/busin.body_text: **********Faced with a Socialist victory in France and an unusual domestic spat between the German Government and the central bank, currency traders headed for safe harbors today. They quickly bought up American dollars and British pounds while pushing down the value of both the French franc and the German mark. **********Analysts said today's activity reflected a sentiment that Europe's two biggest economies were moving away from strict fiscal and monetary austerity and that the proposed single European currency, the euro, would be weaker than the rock-hard currency akin to the German mark that European leaders have promised. **********Until the political landscape settles down, currency traders are avoiding holding the franc and the mark and are betting that the dollar and the pound will strengthen as safe currencies of choice for now. **********In currency trading in New York today, the dollar settled at 1.7300 marks, up sharply from 1.7063 marks on Friday, and at 5.8320 French francs, up from 5.7595 francs. The British pound fell to $1.6359 from $1.6410. The dollar was also higher against the Japanese yen, rising to 116.58 yen from 116.22 yen **********Late today, there was the first sign of hope that one battle might soon end. Germany's Finance Minister, Theo Waigel, signaled that the Government might be willing to back down on its hotly contested plan to reduce its budget deficit this year with a bookkeeping maneuver to revalue the central bank's gold reserves. The plan would inject some of the gain into the Government treasury and bring Germany's deficit closer to the strict criteria called for in the plan for a single currency. **********Last week, when the central bank objected to the timing of the plan, the German Government said it would go ahead anyway. The Bundesbank wants to revalue its gold hoard but not before May 1998 when the European Union will have decided which countries will initially participate in the single currency. Doing it sooner, the bank declared, threatens its independence and weakens the new currency. **********But late today Mr. Waigel said, ''We will discuss this with the Bundesbank,'' adding, ''We will try to do this in mutual agreement.'' He did not make clear what he had in mind but if he delayed the plan by a year, as the central bank prefers, Germany's budget deficit would exceed the criteria set out for the creation of the euro and would probably undermine its strength. **********Regardless, most analysts say the credibility of the euro has taken a serious blow. **********''What we have to conclude is that European Monetary Union will get off the ground, but as a much weaker currency,'' said J. Paul Horne, an economist for Smith Barney in Paris. ''The two principal actors seem to be saying, 'Let's get to the altar in the easiest way.' '' **********In theory, a weaker euro would hurt the United States by making American-made goods more expensive. Conversely, a strong dollar and a weak euro would make European-made goods less costly. **********European stock markets reacted calmly to the Socialist victory over the conservative coalition of President Jacques Chirac of France. On the Paris Bourse, blue-chip stocks in the CAC-40 index initially plunged by nearly 3 percent but then regained their value and ended the day slightly above Friday's close. The German market closed up 1.63 percent; the London stock exchange ended down 1.27 percent. **********The results puzzled some market analysts, particularly because the Socialist victory in France should in theory spell bad news for French business. But analysts said the stock market's sanguine reaction was partly because investors had furiously sold off French stocks through much of last week, after the first round of elections on May 25 signaled that Mr. Chirac's Government was in deep trouble. **********Beyond that, they said, the movements in both markets reflected a general notion of less strict economies. More relaxed economic policies could easily add some zip to the depressing level of economic activity in both countries, but they could also lead to a much weaker and less credible euro, which is scheduled to make its debut in 1999. **********The French Socialist leader who was named Prime Minister today, Lionel Jospin, has adamantly insisted that countries should not be forced to meet the strict numerical targets for deficits, debt levels and inflation that now determine who will and will not be a part of the new euro.  In a deep break with German views, moreover, he has called for opening the euro to countries like Italy that fall well short of the monetary union's strict criteria. **********The French shift and Germany's new attempts to fudge its own deficit problems through bookkeeping maneuvers have both increased the chances that the new monetary union will have a wider but weaker membership. **********''We have been predicting for some time that the European Monetary Union would be relatively wide, and both these events push things in the same direction,'' said Kermit L. Schoenholtz, global economist for Salomon Brothers in London. ''It should not be surprising if the euro begins somewhat weaker'' than politicians have hoped, he added. **********Sylvain Hefes, managing director for Goldman, Sachs & Company in Paris, said France's leftist Government would bring less change than expected because the Government had very little money to work with. **********''The Socialists asked for a complete audit of public finances today, and what they are going to find is that they have almost no maneuvering room,'' Mr. Hefes said. ''They will not be in a position to do a lot of things.'' **********That now leaves Europe's political leaders, particularly in Germany, with a painful decision. Should they plunge ahead with the euro, even if it would be significantly weaker than the vaunted German mark or even the French franc? Or should they delay the start of the euro until countries have their economies in better order? **********Most financial and political experts believe that European leaders have staked so much of their political careers on the euro that they have long since passed the point of no return. The rise in the dollar, they said, signals a belief that the euro will be started but will be weaker. If investors believe the euro will be delayed or scrapped entirely, that generally sends the German mark up in value because investors would be no longer be expecting the mark's replacement by a weaker currency. **********Nevertheless, tensions between France and Germany over the euro are likely to increase. Even under the conservative coalition, France repeatedly battled against Germany's seemingly ironclad determination to impose firm and unchangeable numerical fiscal requirements on countries that would participate in the euro. They have also carried on a running battle over whether political leaders should retain some oversight over the new European central bank -- a French idea that is anathema to the Germans.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/09/busin.snippet: Securities and Exchange Commission chairman Arthur Levitt Jr, on eve of Congressional hearing on proposed accounting rule, defends Financial Accounting Standards Board, panel of accountants established by commission to come up with standard way fo...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/09/busin.body_text: **********On the eve of a Congressional hearing on a proposed accounting rule that has drawn fierce criticism, Arthur Levitt Jr., the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, sharply attacked Congress and the banking industry for intervening in the independent process by which such rules are written. **********He defended the Financial Accounting Standards Board, a panel of accountants established by the commission to come up with a standard way for companies to report to their investors how much they earn, own and owe. **********''Without such rules, the investor would stand unprotected, uninformed and unaware of misleading or deceptive disclosures by those who may seek to distort financial reality,'' Mr. Levitt said in remarks prepared for a speech last night to the Conference Board, a business group. **********''The S.E.C. has traditionally resisted its power to second-guess a F.A.S.B. rule,'' Mr. Levitt said. ''Now Congress, under pressure from some in the business and banking community, is thinking of intervening in this nonpartisan process and second-guessing us both.'' **********The flash point for the fight is a proposed rule that would force companies to tell their shareholders more about the value of transactions they enter into involving derivatives, investments whose value is derived from some underlying asset or index. Currently, companies can often enter into derivatives deals with no impact on their financial statements. **********Banks, which both use and sell derivatives, have criticized the accounting board's proposal for being even more misleading than the current rules. Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, has echoed these criticisms, as have many lawmakers in Washington. **********Last week, a House subcommittee held a hearing into the issue, and yesterday 23 members of the panel wrote a letter to the F.A.S.B. asking it to delay and reconsider its derivatives rules. **********''Members of the subcommittee expressed real concerns about the particular difficulties raised for the banking industry, bank regulators, and other effects on investors, consumers and users of financial statements,'' the letter said. **********Today, a Senate subcommittee is also scheduled to hold a hearing on the same issue. **********In his prepared remarks, Mr. Levitt specifically took issue with the proposal by John S. Reed, the chairman of Citicorp, to eliminate the F.A.S.B. altogether and have the S.E.C. write accounting rules. **********In a letter to The Wall Street Journal this week, Mr. Reed wrote that ''the basic idea of having a well-funded and competent organization dedicated full time and solely to changing something produces more change than makes any sense.'' **********Mr. Levitt called Mr. Reed's argument ''rich with irony.'' **********''Here, after all, is a bank C.E.O.  urging the Government to immerse itself in the details of technical accounting rules that are important to the bank's business,'' Mr. Levitt said.  ''I wonder if the theory is Government officials would develop better rules because they are much more reasonable, practical, thoughtful and flexible than their rigid, insulated and unresponsive brethren in the private sector.'' **********A spokesman for Mr. Reed said last night that his criticism of the accounting board was that it was ''disdainful of the users.'' **********''It should be independent, but not in an ivory tower manner that doesn't take into account the practical effects of its decisions,'' the spokesman said. **********Mr. Levitt defended the board, noting it has forced companies to disclose otherwise hidden liabilities. For example, in 1992 the F.A.S.B. forced General Motors to admit it was obligated to pay the health care costs of its retired workers, knocking the value of its shareholders' equity from $27 billion to $6 billion, Mr. Levitt said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/05/busin.snippet: Stanford and Columbia universities have just released results of two-year study that looked at hiring practices of 80 Western branches of a large bank--the name of which was not disclosed--and found that job applicants who were referred by employe...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/05/busin.main_headline: In a Job Hunt, It Often Is Whom You Know
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/05/busin.print_headline: In a Job Hunt, It Often Is Whom You Know
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/05/busin.body_text: **********CHICKEN soup may or may not cure the common cold. But just in case there are any doubts about another common assumption, ''It's not what you know, but whom you know,'' a new study could dispel them. **********Stanford and Columbia universities have just released the results of a two-year study that looked at the hiring practices of 80 Western branches of a large bank -- the name of which was not disclosed -- and found that job applicants who were referred by employees had a big edge in getting interviews and in being offered jobs. **********During the period of the survey -- January 1993 to March 1995 -- the bank received 5,568 applications to fill 326 entry-level jobs like personal banker, mortgage consultant and teller. Even though only 441, or less than 8 percent, of the applicants were referrals, 351 of them, or 80 percent, were interviewed and they received 115, or 35 percent, of the jobs. **********The study found that the key difference between applicants with referrals and those without was simple: the former had important information about the bank and the skills it wanted; the latter did not. **********Roberto Fernandez, an organizational behavior professor at Stanford's Graduate School of Business who conducted the study with Kathryn Neckerman, a sociology professor at Columbia, said employees who referred applicants had also advised them about what to emphasize in resumes and when to submit those resumes. **********''This shows that having inside information from personal contacts can help guide you through the hiring process,'' Dr. Fernandez said. ''It's like getting married; it's always better to know more information about the person ahead of time.'' **********Eva Wisnik, president of Wisnik Career Strategies, a career consulting firm in New York, said such information could be vital. ''The person with the best information will have the best job opportunities,'' she said. ''Having this information makes someone sound like an insider even if they're not.'' **********Preliminary results from the study also showed that employees who had received referrals ultimately proved to be better suited for their positions. For companies, that can mean less turnover and reduced recruiting costs. For employees, referring friends can sometimes lead to cash bonuses. **********The bank in the study, for example, encourages its employees to make referrals by paying them up to $1,000 if a person they recommend is hired and stays with the bank for at least three months. The Hyatt Hotels Corporation of Chicago pays employees from $100 to $1,000 for successful referrals. **********Noreen Heron, the director of public relations at the Hyatt Regency Chicago, recommended her friend, Mary Rownd, for a marketing job with Hyatt Hotels last year. When Ms. Rownd was hired as manager of hotel marketing in September, Hyatt paid Ms. Heron $250. **********''It's wonderful that Hyatt thinks we're all marketers for the company,'' Ms. Heron said. ''Having the program is a good-will gesture and it shows you feel positive about the company.'' **********Anie Chinarian, assistant vice president for human resources at Hyatt, said that when its employees made referrals, ''they're saying that they want their friends and relatives to share in this.'' **********Whittman-Hart Inc., a consulting firm in Chicago with 1,000 employees, has paid a total of $400,000 to its workers since 1993 for making referrals. Jim Slattery, the principal in charge of recruiting, said the company had cut its recruiting costs by 38 percent, to $6,200 for each hire, since it began the referral program. Outside recruiters previously provided 20 percent of all new hires, he said, but provide only 3 percent now. **********''We save money, bring in people more suited to our firm, and employees have the chance to select whom their colleagues will be,'' Mr. Slattery said. **********Barry Lawrence, a spokesman with the Society for Human Resource Management in Alexandria, Va., estimates that half of all companies with more than 500 employees have a referral program, although some  reward employees only with merchandise, like television sets, or by buying them lunch. **********ALTHOUGH Dr. Fernandez said it was difficult to generalize about the results of the study, he said ''they are suggestive to what other companies with programs are doing.'' He said the bank's referral program likely led to the strong showing of the applicants recommended by employees. **********Dr. Fernandez has begun a second study, to measure the job performance and turnover rates of referrals and nonreferrals. He said this study, involving 350 customer-service representatives in the bank's credit card division, should be completed by June.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/29/busin.snippet: Securities and Exchange Commission acuses Jerome L Dodson, portfolio manager of Parnassus Fund, one of largest mutual funds that practice 'socially responsible' investing, of illegal ue of brokerage commissions generated by the fund and of overval...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/29/busin.main_headline: S.E.C. Accuses a Fund of Illegal Fee Use
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/29/busin.print_headline: S.E.C. Accuses a Fund of Illegal Fee Use
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/29/busin.body_text: **********The Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday accused the portfolio manager of the Parnassus Fund, one of the largest mutual funds that practice ''socially responsible'' investing, of the illegal use of brokerage commissions generated by the fund and of overvaluing a security in the fund's portfolio. **********The charges are the first to be brought against a mutual fund manager as part of the S.E.C.'s continuing investigation of so-called soft-dollar arrangements, in which brokerage firms provide indirect compensation to money managers, usually in the form of research, in exchange for transactions and the accompanying commissions. **********The S.E.C.'s charges were also noteworthy in that they named one current and one former independent trustee to the fund as well as the manager, Jerome L. Dodson. In recent months, the S.E.C. chairman, Arthur Levitt Jr., has focused attention not only on the soft-dollar issue but also on the duties of independent directors in protecting mutual fund investors. **********In an interview, Mr. Dodson, who is also president of the San Francisco-based money management firm that oversees the fund, said the fund, which has $274 million in assets, and its three trustees would mount a vigorous defense against the charges, which he said had no merit. **********''It seems like the S.E.C. is trying to seize on something highly technical to prove something that is not there,'' Mr. Dodson said. Given the S.E.C.'s increased scrutiny of the fund industry recently, he added, ''I think we got caught in a buzz saw.'' **********The S.E.C. said it would ask an administrative law judge to assess civil monetary damages as well as a cease-and-desist order against the fund management company, Parnassus Investments; Mr. Dodson; David L. Gibson, a San Francisco lawyer in private practice who has been a trustee since 1986, and Marilyn M. Chou, an executive vice president with the Xintec Corporation, a biomedical company in Oakland, Calif., who served as a fund trustee from 1985 to March 1996. **********The S.E.C. also contended that the fund had gone outside its fundamental investment policy in making a $100,000 loan to Margaux Inc., a company whose stock the fund owned. Mr. Dodson said the transaction was not a loan but rather an equity investment, in the form of a convertible debenture, which was made after Margaux filed for bankruptcy protection in March 1989. (It was liquidated in mid-1995.) **********The fund already owned 565,000 shares of Margaux stock, and from December 1990 through March 1993 the fund valued the stock and the debenture at $562,500, or roughly 37.5 cents a share. **********But the S.E.C. contends that during that period, the shares, which were not traded on any major American stock exchanges, were worth as little as 1 cent each. **********Investors who bought or sold shares in the mutual fund during that period did so at an incorrect share price, the S.E.C. said, a violation that was ''aided and abetted'' by the two independent trustees. **********The S.E.C. also contended that Parnassus Investments had improperly used $67,025 of soft-dollar credits generated by fund brokerage transactions between 1989 and 1995. The commission said the company used the money to buy computer hardware and software for use in providing accounting and transfer agent services to the fund. **********Mr. Dodson said that those purchases were made with the best interest of shareholders in mind and that the use of soft dollars had allowed the fund to lower the fees it charged investors for those services. In addition, he said, the management company paid back the $67,025 to the fund after the S.E.C. raised questions about the transactions in 1995.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/03/busin.snippet: Article by M Susan Hamilton on her entrepreneurial son who, after having spent six summers at camp, has mastered skills in selling or bartering food he brought from home (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/03/busin.body_text: **********TWO cases bottled water. Check. Two cases instant soup packs.  Check. Two cases granola bars. Check. Two cases Pringles potato crisps. Check. Clothes, sneakers and sports gear. Check. **********So read the priority list as my 14-year-old son packed for camp earlier this summer. For four weeks, he played team tennis and casual lacrosse; he painted and sculpted and tie-dyed and designed macrame jewelry. But, as a budding entrepreneur, he also bartered bottled water for lacrosse balls, made a few dollars selling Pringles to the deprived, and then spent those dollars keeping the local Subway shop in business. **********My son knows the camp manual by heart; this was his sixth time at this summer playground in the Berkshires. So he is well aware that there is ''absolutely no food allowed in the bunks.'' Except, that is, in the unit head's cabin, the counselors' stashes and the campers' locked trunks. The authorities, it seems, generally look the other way. So the most important  skill is knowing how to keep track of trunk keys while wearing loopless, pocketless soccer shorts. Keeping track of the black-market food index, he said, is easy. **********The first week of camp, Pringles sell at close to market value, or $1.39 a cylinder. The second week, the price is $5, and the third week, just before Visitors Day, it's close to $10. **********''Where,'' I asked my son, ''do the kids get that kind of money?'' **********''Oh, easily,'' he replied, a little too blithely. **********Explaining the camp's business opportunities, he said: ''Everything is timing. You sell as little as possible in the first and second week, and wait until the kids are hungry enough. The peak selling time is the end of the third week, before the kids have spent money on camp trips and before their parents' trunkload of junk food arrives.'' **********Seasoned campers track food trends. My son's first letter home explained the importance: ''Mom, I missed the big wave. I brought plain Pringles. This year, the barbecue flavor is da-bomb,'' meaning the best. He had a solution, though: ''I traded a few cylinders for the upmarket barbecue, but I know I can sell off the plain ones, too.'' **********I was sure he could. At a local craft fair earlier this year, my son set up a booth among the adults, intending to sell custom-made macrame necklaces and bracelets. But he quickly switched to offering ''hair wraps'' to young girls -- braiding their hair with ribbons, macrame rope or embroidery thread -- when he sensed there might be a demand. He charged the girls $7 apiece, and the demand was so great that he had to enlist two friends to help when the line grew too long. He netted $150. **********When the campers, meanwhile, pocket some money from selling food, what do they do with it? Simple.  They buy more food -- namely, underground Subway sandwiches.  Footlong subs -- meatball, vegetarian or chicken -- can command $12  because there is only one direct delivery route: through a counselor whose favor a camper has curried. **********The second-most-prized item is pizza. But delivery is a bit dicier because the campers order it on their own. One boy, who had smuggled in a cell phone so he could call home whenever he wanted, once subcontracted the phone to another camper to order six pizzas. The order specified: ''Meet you at the electronic gate. If you see a 'big guy,' (a.k.a.a counselor), run to the other gate by the lake and I'll meet you there.'' **********My son said those pizzas arrived successfully. But on the next order, the delivery man had to avoid the main gate, then tripped on the run to the lake. He made the campers pay for the dropped pizzas. **********WHILE buying has its risks, selling bottled water is good business. The first and second weeks, all campers have enough bottled water under their bunks. The true marketeers stretch their stock into the third week, when supplies are thinning. The trick is to identify the big spenders. The tennis players, it seems, will pay almost any price to take their own water to the courts.  The soccer players are less fussy and the lacrosse players settle for the fungus-y water from the hose. **********So, did my son make any money this summer? **********''Mom, this year camp was my all-time best -- my food and water supply ran out just at the end,'' he said  when I picked him up last weekend. ''You'd be proud of me. I broke even.''
