https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/19/world.snippet: Historians say that no one knows when ancient town of Khiva, Uzbekistan, was founded, but that has not prevented Pres Islam Karimov from declaring Oct as its 2,500th anniversary; laborers have been working frantically to clean Khiva's streets and ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/19/world.main_headline: Along the Old Silk Road, a New Effort to Shine
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/19/world.print_headline: Along the Old Silk Road, a New Effort to Shine
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/19/world.body_text: **********Historians say that no one knows when this ancient Silk Road town was founded, but that has not prevented President Islam Karimov from declaring October as its 2,500th anniversary. **********For weeks laborers have been working frantically to clean Khiva's streets, repair its imposing monuments and build towering scaffolds to hold powerful lights and loudspeakers brought from Germany for the occasion. Mr. Karimov has planned lavish celebrations to which he has invited officials from around the world, and to spice the invitation he has announced that this month is also the 2,500th birthday of the town of Bukhara, where he is staging another extended party. **********Khiva, Bukhara and nearby Samarkand are built around spectacular mosques and palaces that testify to this region's astonishingly rich history. Each was once the center of an empire, attracting titanic figures like Alexander, Genghis Khan and Tamerlane. **********Because it stood at the heart of the Silk Road, the land that is now Uzbekistan attracted traders from across Europe and Asia. It acquired a sense of self-importance and destiny that President Karimov now seeks to embody. **********Mr. Karimov -- whose term of office expired in 1995 but was extended for five years after a referendum in which a reported 99.6 percent of the people voted to keep him in power -- also embodies the tradition of authoritarian rule that has dominated life here for centuries. **********With 23 million people, Uzbekistan is the most populous of the five Central Asian countries that emerged in 1991 as the Soviet Union collapsed, and senior officials make no secret of their ambition for regional leadership. The celebrations they are holding in Khiva and Bukhara, like their failed attempt to bring the Olympic Games to Tashkent, the capital, reflect their desire to lift Uzbekistan out of anonymity and make it a player in world affairs. **********The Central Asian republics are being courted by outside powers in part because of their strategic location between Russia, China, Iran and the Indian subcontinent. Their markets and resources, which include large oil and gas deposits, have only begun to be exploited. A country that can emerge as dominant in this region, Uzbek leaders reason, will have a voice in international politics. **********But those ambitions are stumbling over political and economic obstacles. Although Mr. Karimov insists that he is committed to reform, the habits he and other Uzbek leaders learned while rising through the Communist system have proved hard to break. Their plans for opening the country to democracy and foreign investment are clashing with their instinctive fear of losing control. **********Human rights conditions here have improved since the early 1990's and especially since President Karimov's visit to Washington last year. Still, there is no independent press, protest meetings are forbidden and opposition political parties are banned. **********But despite the slow pace of change, there is no ground swell of protest against the Government.  Two neighboring countries, Afghanistan and Tajikistan, have been consumed by ethnic and religious wars, and many Uzbeks seem willing to accept Mr. Karimov's heavy-handed rule as long as he keeps the country stable and at peace. **********''Ninety-nine percent of the people in this country don't even think about democracy and human rights,'' said Tohir Bokayev, a metalworker in Bukhara. ''Their main concern is everyday life. People here have no experience with Western-style democracy.'' **********Mr. Bokayev is trying to chip away at the monolith. He applied several months ago for permission to start an independent newspaper, and as he expected, it was denied. Now he plans to publish a newsletter that will carry only advertising and information like bus and train schedules. **********''You don't need permission to start a newsletter as long as it doesn't carry news,'' he said. ''I want to start this way, and then as time passes maybe we can expand it into a newspaper.'' **********As in most parts of the former Soviet Union, life is hard for most of Uzbekistan's people. Even in Tashkent it is unusual to find an ordinary person who earns more than $1,000 a  year. Prices are high, and many people find that rising costs have put health care and other social services out of their reach. **********Efforts to diversify the cotton-based economy depend largely on foreign investment, but corruption and broken promises have driven some investors away and deeply frustrated those who remain. **********Currency controls are so strict that foreign businesses often cannot withdraw their own money from banks. Local employees may not be paid in dollars, and companies that want to send Uzbeks abroad for training often find it impossible to obtain exit visas for them. **********To put it another way, conditions for foreign business here are so difficult that not even McDonald's has arrived yet. **********''They sign contracts without even reading them,'' a German hotel manager said. ''When you have a disagreement with a local partner, you tell him to look at what's written in the contract and he says: 'Contract? What's that?' '' **********The impulse that makes the Government reluctant to open the economy also leads it to equate political opposition with subversion. **********''Because of Karimov's authoritarian style, Uzbek society is stagnating,'' said Mikhail Ardzinov, leader of a human rights group the Government does not recognize. ''In Russia you see dynamic economic thinking and open debate about problems and possible solutions, but Karimov will not tolerate that here.'' **********Although the Government denies holding political prisoners, Mr. Ardzinov estimates that there are 32, nearly half accused of fomenting Islamic radicalism. The powerful security police keep close watch on mullahs and other religious figures, determined to prevent the growing interest in Islam from spilling over into politics. **********''I am very happy that our President is banning Islamic fundamentalism,'' said Dildora Alimbekova, a Tashkent seamstress who has formed an association of female entrepreneurs. ''I'm a bit surprised to see what is happening in my own family. I have 48 nieces and nephews. These young people are very interested in Islam, and half of my nieces are covering themselves in the old Islamic way. I discuss it with them, but they don't accept my point of view and argue strongly against me.'' **********Uzbekistan remains a decidedly secular country where there is no taboo against drinking alcohol or wearing short skirts and where one of the capital's most popular restaurants is called Pork Chop. But especially in the northeast Fergana region, the country's most densely populated, there are signs of an Islamic revival. **********At the bazaar in Kokand, one of the largest towns in Fergana, it is no longer unusual to see veiled women. Vendors sell cassettes on which prominent mullahs extol the virtues of religious education and belief. **********In Andijan, another Fergana town, a 60-year-old trader, Abdulrahim Abdulaim Oghli, said he had dreamed all his life of making the hajj, the Muslim pilgrimage to Mecca but never believed it would be possible because such pilgrimages were banned by the Soviet authorities. **********''Now, praise Allah, I have made the hajj twice,'' he said. ''Since independence, people have followed their desire to become more religious. My grandson is reading the Koran and is about to finish it.'' **********President Karimov, though determined to prevent fundamentalism from taking hold, has sought to conciliate and co-opt the Muslim leadership rather than repress it. Always seeking to balance competing forces, he speaks warmly about Islam despite the fact that for years he served an officially atheistic system. **********Confronted with a choice about whether to make the hajj himself, which might set too strong a religious example, or to stay at home, which might offend practicing Muslims, Mr. Karimov came up with a typically adroit compromise. He traveled to Mecca, but although he visited holy sites he did it out of the hajj season so he would not seem to be encouraging excessive devotion. **********''You may not like Karimov, but most people think he's what we need at this moment in our history,'' said Odil Ruzaliev, a reporter for one of Tashkent's Government-controlled television stations. ''Let's give him a chance. In such a young country, why criticize?''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/02/busin.snippet: Market Watch column on recent huge declines in Dow Jones industrial average; says investors will move from less attractice stocks to more attractive ones, but they will not get out of them market; graph (L)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/02/busin.main_headline: MARKET WATCH ; These Good Times Will End With a Whimper
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/02/busin.print_headline: MARKET WATCH ; These Good Times Will End With a Whimper
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/02/busin.body_text: **********The bull market lives on, thanks to millions of Americans who did exactly what they had told pollsters they would do: They stayed calm when Wall Street panicked. Some even bought stocks. **********''All the new investors since 1987 learned that you should buy the dips,'' said Donald B. Marron, the chairman of Paine Webber. ''And that may be close to a majority of all investors.'' **********The panic on Monday set off the New York Stock Exchange's circuit breakers and forced all American markets to close early. It terrified people around the world, but not in Peoria, Ill. or Boise, Idaho. And that illustrated just how much Americans now believe in stocks as the one and only superior long-term investment. **********This panic was largely a matter of professional investors getting worried about the risks of collapsing prices, profits and banks in Asia. It will be interesting to see if it has a long-term effect on attitudes toward investing in emerging markets. But it is not likely to damage confidence in American stocks. **********Bears on the American stock market need to remember that stocks do not go up or down because of earnings, or interest rates, or because they are trading at ridiculous multiples of profits or sales. They go down when there are not enough buyers at a certain price. If something does not influence investors, it won't affect prices. **********That is why the stock market's high valuation is not very important right now. Investors will move from less attractive stocks to more attractive ones, but they will not get out of the market. **********Alan Greenspan, in his Congressional testimony last week, tried to gently criticize that attitude, saying that stock price gains since 1995 appear to be based on the assumption that profits would keep rising indefinitely from already high levels. He knows that is unlikely to happen and seems to regret his own public flirtation with the so-called new paradigm, which holds that this time is different. But his ability to influence the market is limited, assuming he is unwilling to raise interest rates enough to bring on a recession. **********Someday, of course, there will be a bear market. But it is unlikely to begin with a crash. As last week showed, even a very bad day will not shake a public that deeply believes in the long-term case for stocks. **********The more likely picture is a choppy market, followed by a slow decline, like the one in the late 1960's and early 1970's. Faith in stocks as sure things was strong then, as it is now. The Dow Jones industrial average peaked at 1,051.69 on Jan. 11, 1973, not far above where it had been a few years before. **********The 1973-74 bear market began slowly. Not until November, after the Dow was down 11.3 percent from the peak, did the market have a day in which prices fell by 2 percent. By then, there was obvious economic news to explain a weak stock market: an Arab oil embargo that was leading to the first oil price shock and a deep recession. The worst day of that bear market saw a 3.5 percent fall, less than half the decline that was seen last Monday. But by the time prices bottomed in late 1974, the Dow was off 45 percent from the peak. The worst days came near the end, not at the beginning, of the decline. **********It took months, and even years, of performance that fell below expectations before most investors got out. **********It will probably take a real recession to kill this bull, and then it will die slowly. But once it is dead, it may be a long time before a new bull is born. The 1973 high stood as a record until 1982.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/29/world.snippet: IRA acknowledges detonating two bombs in Cheshire town of Wilmslow; link seen to British parliamentary campaign; bombs disrupted rail traffic, but injured no one (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/29/world.main_headline: I.R.A. Admits It Planted 2 Bombs in England
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/29/world.print_headline: I.R.A. Admits It Planted 2 Bombs in England
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/29/world.body_text: **********The Irish Republican Army acknowledged today that it had detonated two bombs on Wednesday in northwestern England. **********The incidents were widely seen as an I.R.A. effort to remind the public and political leaders that it was still capable of violent attacks during the British parliamentary campaign leading up to the election on May 1. **********The bombs, which disrupted rail traffic but injured no one, exploded in the Cheshire town of Wilmslow. **********The acknowledgment came in a telephone call to RTE, the Irish national radio and television network in Dublin. The caller, using a recognized code word to identify the call as coming from the I.R.A., did not refer to another bomb attack on Wednesday night, on a Royal Ulster Constabulary base in the British province of Northern Ireland. The police shot a suspected attacker and arrested him in a local hospital in Coalisland, County Tyrone. **********The attacks came as unconfirmed reports circulated here and in Northern Ireland that the I.R.A. was preparing to call a new cease-fire to replace the one it broke, after 17 months, on Feb. 9 last year. Since then I.R.A. attacks in England and Northern Ireland have killed five people, including three British soldiers, and injured several hundred. **********The Irish Times said in a front-page report on Thursday that ''senior security figures'' in Ireland ''are still hopeful that the I.R.A. is moving towards a second cease-fire.'' **********But the I.R.A., in a message Thursday, made no such suggestion, saying, ''We remain committed to bringing the British Government's undemocratic rule of the occupied part of our country to an end,'' using phrases that normally refer to violence. The message added that the organization was ''ready to face our responsibilities in facilitating a process aimed at securing a lasting resolution to the conflict,'' a reference to the efforts of its political wing, Sinn Fein. **********The message also praised I.R.A. prisoners who had attempted to escape from the Maze Prison, near Belfast, by digging a tunnel; the tunnel was discovered last Sunday. **********There is always speculation at Easter weekend that the I.R.A. may do something spectacular to mark the most important event in its history, the Easter Rising of 1916. On that Easter Monday, republicans began a weeklong insurrection against British colonial authorities. Southern Ireland gained independence in 1922, but the treaty with Britain, which left the six northern counties in British hands, was rejected by some republicans, who provoked a civil war with the new Irish Free State. **********The I.R.A. campaign, which accelerated in 1969, is to push the British authorities out of the North. Sinn Fein presses that goal politically; the party, which holds about one-third of the Catholic vote in the North, has candidates running in the British election, including Gerry Adams, its president. **********But because the I.R.A. broke its cease-fire last year, Sinn Fein has been excluded by the Irish and British Governments from the broad-based peace talks that began last June. The talks accomplished little, and they have been suspended until June 3, after the British election.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/26/busin.snippet: Junk E-mail, called spam, is jamming electronic mailboxes of companies that provide gateways to cyberspace; some Internet providers are trying to sue junk E-mailers for electronic trespassing; legal system is scrambling to catch up to problem; two...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/26/busin.main_headline: On the Information Highway, E-Mail Litter Problem Grows
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/26/busin.print_headline: On the Information Highway, E-Mail Litter Problem Grows
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/26/busin.body_text: **********Early one morning two weeks ago, Jason Lavoie, a network engineer for a company that provides Internet access in Maine, was rudely awakened by his beeper. There was trouble on the system that demanded immediate human intervention. **********Logging onto his computer to see what was wrong, Mr. Lavoie found hundreds of messages jamming his electronic mailbox -- complaints about a flood of commercial E-mail that appeared, to the untrained eye, to be coming from his employer, Maine Internetworks Inc. **********Before Mr. Lavoie could figuratively pull the plug, thousands of unsolicited advertisements for a company called Master Graphics in Fallbrook, Calif., had come coursing through Maine Internetworks' computer system and were relayed to Internet users across the country -- who were now letting him know how they felt about it. **********It did not matter that Master Graphics was not a client of Maine Internetworks -- Mint.net, for short -- which has strict rules against sending unsolicited commercial E-mail. The sender managed to hide his E-mail address from potentially angry Internet users by routing the mailing through Mint.net without permission or payment. Mr. Lavoie had to spend the rest of the day cleaning up the mess and plugging the security hole that allowed the computer to be infiltrated. **********''It costs us bandwidth and system resources, and it costs my time to respond to the complaints,'' Mr. Lavoie said. ''What the sender really is doing is shifting the cost of junk E-mail to the end user rather than to the person sending it.'' **********What happened to Mint.net occurs every day on the Internet. Junk E-mail, called spam, has been a problem ever since the public began to join scientists and academics on the Internet several years ago. But what was a trickle has become a torrent. **********Several times a week, and often several times a day, Internet users log on to America Online, Compuserve, Netcom or one of the many smaller companies that provide gateways to cyberspace and find an increasing number of shrill promotions clogging their electronic mailboxes: ''Make Big $$$ On Line -- Secret Revealed,'' ''Stuff for FREE!'' or ''You Can Now Dramatically Increase Your Sexual Attractiveness!'' **********While some Internet providers are trying to sue junk E-mailers for electronic trespassing, the legal system is scrambling to catch up to a problem rapidly becoming as obnoxious to many people as dinner-time telemarketing. Last week, two anti-spam bills were introduced in Congress, and the Federal Trade Commission will conduct a hearing on the problem next month. **********Wildcat entrepreneurs selling everything from software to sex have learned that it is so cheap to automatically crank out millions of messages that just a few sales can easily cover the cost. The irritation the mass mailings cause to everybody else is considered well worth the price -- especially with loads of new software making it easy for junk E-mailers to cover their tracks. **********Commercial mailers even spam the spammers. Last month, a mass E-mailing for a program called Stealth Mailer was sent by Fred@nowhere.com. ''Send Your E-Mail Out, At Up to 250,000 + Messages/Hour,'' the ad promised. To help the mailers escape detection, the program allows them to fake the return address and route the junk E-mail through different servers. Internet service providers ''will spin their wheels'' trying to track down the culprit, Fred@nowhere.com boasted. **********''Last year at this time, I'd get maybe a few junk E-mails a week,'' said Scott Hazen Mueller, vice president of engineering for Whole Earth Networks, an Internet service provider in San Francisco. ''Now I get 5 to 10 a day.'' Before Mr. Mueller tightened security, hit-and-run junk E-mailers were infiltrating the mail server at Whole Earth Networks several times a week. **********The problem is figuring out where the spam comes from and to whom one can complain. Federal law makes it illegal for companies to send unsolicited business faxes, but  there is no law preventing a junk E-mailer from writing the same unwanted message to millions of hard disks. **********Federal law also requires telephone marketers to stop calling people who complain about the intrusions, but complaints to junk E-mailers -- if they can be found -- are almost always ignored. **********In addition to disguising the source of their mailings by routing them through unsuspecting third parties, junk E-mailers commonly forge their electronic return addresses. The Master Graphics spam that jammed Mint.net's computer supposedly originated from an address in an Internet domain called Dcez.com, run by the DC Easy-Link Corporation in Alexandria, Va. But E-mail to the address was automatically returned marked ''User unknown.'' **********Anyone who wanted to complain directly to Master Graphics was confronted with another obstacle: The company has no listed phone number; only a street address was given for those who wanted to order the company's product, a digitized personal signature to use on computer-generated documents. An attempt to arrange an interview with Master Graphics' representatives by mail was unsuccessful. **********''You'd think that any business model that depends on alienating 99 percent of your target market would be guaranteed bankruptcy,'' said Stanton McCandlish of the Electronic Frontier Foundation, a public policy group in San Francisco. ''If you get this type of advertisement, the sender is either a scam artist or totally clueless. It's time for the free ride to end. Why should the whole network have to pay for you to send eight million E-mails for free?'' **********Some service providers try to fight back by using filters to block mail from notorious spammers. But junk E-mailers just keep changing their Internet addresses, like mutating viruses eluding an immune system. And even blocking junk E-mail is costly, eating up a large amount of a service provider's computer time. **********Sensing that stopping junk E-mail has become a popular cause, Representative Chris Smith, Republican of New Jersey, introduced legislation last week that would broaden the law against junk faxes to include E-mail. Another bill introduced by Senator Frank H. Murkowski, Republican of Alaska, would require junk E-mail to be clearly labeled as an advertisement and include a real street address, E-mail address, telephone number and valid routing information. **********Some Internet denizens fear Senator Murkowski's approach would legitimize junk E-mail, and the idea of any kind of legislation runs contrary  to some people's libertarian view of the Internet. ''There is no way to legislate this problem away unless every single jurisdiction in the world adopts the same law,'' said Mr. McCandlish of the Electronic Frontier Foundation. **********But Mr. Mueller, who recently helped start a group called the Coalition Against Unsolicited Commercial E-mail, said a country that became a haven for junk E-mailers could be threatened with the ''Internet death penalty,'' having its connections to the United States cut off. **********Marc Rotenberg, head of the Electronic Privacy and Information Center, a nonprofit group in Washington, said a ban on junk E-mail might be unconstitutional. He thinks the flow could be stemmed by prohibiting the resale of E-mail addresses. **********''You don't have many people sending junk E-mail who are collecting the addresses themselves,'' he said. ''They are buying them from a broker. That's an area that we think could be regulated.'' **********Some large Internet service providers, fearing Government regulation and realizing that fighting spam can be a selling point in a competitive market, are going after junk E-mailers in the courts. Earlier this month, Earthlink in Palo Alto, Calif., won an injunction against Cyber Promotions of Philadelphia, one of the biggest junk E-mailers. A Los Angeles Superior Court judge found that Cyber Promotions had trespassed upon Earthlink's electronic territory and prohibited the mass E-mailer from sending advertisements through Earthlink's computers without permission. **********Sanford Wallace, the president of Cyber Promotions, which has also been the target of legal action by the on-line services Compuserve and America Online, insists that he has done nothing illegal and that his company is providing small businesses with a valuable service. ''E-mail is a fraction of the cost of any other medium, and it goes at the speed of light,'' he said in an interview. **********Cyber Promotions and its Internet service provider, Apex Global Information Services, called Agis.net, in Dearborn, Mich. -- one of the few service providers that allow junk E-mailing -- have tried to fend off possible regulation and counter bad publicity by promising to develop a universal list of consumers who have asked not to receive junk E-mail. **********And Cyber Promotions is collecting names -- 38,000 so far -- of people who have told the company they want to receive E-mail advertisements. ''That's Plan B,'' Mr. Wallace said. ''When and if a law says we can't do Plan A -- sending unsolicited E-mail -- then we will be prepared.'' **********But many Internet users, who feel violated when they find any kind of advertisement injected into their computers, are leery of such promises. Not all of them are willing to wait for a legal remedy or industry self-regulation. Earlier this month, a group of Internet users tried to crash Cyber Promotions' computers by sending a barrage of electronic messages. That assault was fended off, but the next day a more sophisticated hacker attack knocked the company off the Internet. **********Cyber Promotions was barely fazed. The next day it was back on line churning out millions of messages a day for its customers and selling software to help freelancers send junk E-mail. One of the products, Webcollector, crawls through the World Wide Web and harvests E-mail addresses. In the interest of diversification, the company also sells E-filter, which consumers can use to block Cyber Promotions' junk E-mail from their computers. **********The offering for the software was sent by junk E-mail.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/18/busin.snippet: New York State Department of Economic Development says it has named Toolbox Communications in New York as lead creative agency to handle its spring and summer travel and tourism assignment, known as 'I Love New York' campaign; account had been han...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/18/busin.main_headline: Toolbox to Handle New York Account
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/18/busin.print_headline: Toolbox to Handle New York Account
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/18/busin.body_text: **********The New York State Department of Economic Development said yesterday that it had named Toolbox Communications in New York as the lead creative agency to handle its spring and summer travel and tourism assignment, known as the ''I   New York'' campaign. **********The account had been handled by Ogilvy & Mather New York since January 1995. Billings were estimated at $11 million. **********John Melia, a spokesman for the department in New York, said that Toolbox was awarded a one-year contract with a renewal option after a six-month mandated review that began with more than 1,000 requests for proposals, including inviting Ogilvy, which is a unit of the WPP Group. **********The review had been narrowed to more than 100 contenders and further narrowed to Toolbox and four other agencies: Citigate Albert Frank in New York, a unit of Citigate Communications Group; Media Logic in Albany; Nabors and Friends in White Plains, and Oberlander Design in Albany. Mr. Melia said that Media Logic and Oberlander had also been signed for some creative and concept projects. **********Media First International in New York was named to handle the media portion of the account, Mr. Melia added. The Toolbox campaign, which will begin running next month, will carry the theme ''What did you expect. This is New York.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/16/busin.snippet: Delta Air Lines and US Airways are about to get some new competition in New York-Washington air shuttle market; Atlantic Coast Airlines, a United Express regional carrier operating out of Dulles International Airport in Washington, will begin regu...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/16/busin.main_headline: Delta and US Airways will soon face competition in the New York-Washington air shuttle market.
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/16/busin.print_headline: Delta and US Airways will soon face competition in the New York-Washington air shuttle market.
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/16/busin.body_text: **********DELTA AIR LINES and US Airways are about to get some new competition in the New York-Washington air shuttle market. **********Atlantic Coast Airlines, a United Express regional carrier operating out of Dulles International Airport in Washington, will begin regular service between Dulles and La Guardia Airport on Aug. 1. Delta and US Airways fly out of Washington National Airport. **********A.C.A. will offer nine round-trip flights on the route on weekdays; these will leave every two hours from both Dulles and La Guardia beginning at 6:30 A.M. and ending at 10:30 P.M., which is later than either Delta's or US Airways' final departures. Less frequent service will also be available on weekends. **********The A.C.A. flights -- which will take 70 minutes -- will be on 29-seat Jetstream J41 turboprop planes; the peak one-way fare will be $186, compared with $178 for both Delta and US Airways. Passengers will be able to accrue mileage on the frequent-flier program of UAL's United Airlines. **********Dulles is a 40-minute, $45 cab ride from downtown Washington, while the same trip from National takes 15 minutes and costs $12. **********Delta and US Airways both said they expected to make no changes in their shuttle service as a result of A.C.A.'s move. **********According to the Metropolitan Washington Airports Authority, which operates both National and Dulles, Delta currently controls 57 percent of the New York-Washington shuttle market -- which the Department of Transportation says is the 10th busiest in the United States -- and US Airways 43 percent. **********Tales of Two Cities **********More than 2,000 restaurants in two of the best United States cities for dining, New York and San Francisco, are the focus of new guides, Access New York Restaurants 1997-1998 and Access San Francisco Restaurants 1997-1998 (HarperCollins, $13 each). **********The books are divided into chapters on individual neighborhoods, with descriptions of restaurants and food shops; a map displaying them; recommendations from chefs and local residents, and short articles on specialties like coffee breaks in New York and dim sum in San Francisco. **********Each book also begins with a ''top 10'' restaurant list, chosen by its author. Andrew Ackers wrote the New York guide and GraceAnn Walden the San Francisco guide. **********Hotel Update **********The five-star Moscow Marriott Grand Hotel is scheduled to open in late summer. The second Marriott in Moscow, the hotel will have three restaurants; a health club with indoor pool, saunas and Jacuzzi; 24- hour room service; limousine service; a business center, and a conference hall big enough for 350 people. **********The Hilton Hotels Corporation is rolling out shuttle vans, equipped with wireless technology from Geotek Communications Inc. of Montvale, N.J., that guests can use to check in at Hilton airport hotels.  When guests board the van, they show the driver either a credit card or membership card in Hilton's frequent-guest program, which the driver then uses to register them. Upon arrival at the hotel, guests are met by a Hilton employee bearing a registration packet and room key; they can then go directly to their room.  Vans are currently in use at Hiltons in Newark and Miami. A spokeswoman said the company was considering using them in New York, Philadelphia, Washington and Orlando, Fla., later this year. **********Next month Regent International -- a unit of Four Seasons Regent Hotels and Resorts -- will expand its Regent Club service to its hotel in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia. Similar to clubs at Regent hotels in Jakarta, Indonesia, and Bangkok, Thailand, the Kuala Lumpur club will offer special check-in; liquor, snacks and a buffet breakfast; free local calls; personalized stationery and business cards; unlimited pressing of clothes, and trip planning and reconfirmation. The fee to use the club, which is on the 18th and 19th floors of the Regent Kuala Lumpur, will be $50 a day. **********Susse Chalet, which operates 36 hotels on the East Coast, has started a loyalty program. Guests who stay eight nights will receive points that can be redeemed for 60 minutes' telephone time from MCI Communications or 500 miles in the frequent-flier programs of AMR's American Airlines, Delta or US Airways. **********Cashing in on the current cigar craze, Canadian Pacific Ltd.'s Doubletree Hotel Anaheim/Orange County has introduced its own line of premium cigars hand-rolled in Honduras. They are priced from $7.50 to $9 each. Drinks to complement the cigars are also served in the hotel's lobby bar after 4 P.M. daily.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/07/world.snippet: Sec Madeleine Albright will meet in Europe with Israeli and Palestinian leaders, in hopes of making some progress on peace effortsbefore Mideast economic conference in Qatar; Arab countries have threatened to boycott conference because of long dea...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/07/world.main_headline: Albright to See Arafat and Netanyahu to Try to Break Impasse
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/07/world.print_headline: Albright to See Arafat and Netanyahu to Try to Break Impasse
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/07/world.body_text: **********With only modest progress after four days of Israeli-Palestinian talks here, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright is making plans to meet in Europe next week with leaders from both sides, American and Israeli officials said today. **********Ms. Albright wants to show accomplishments and ''real momentum'' in Middle East peace efforts before she arrives at a Middle East economic conference in Doha, Qatar, on Nov. 16, the officials said. **********Arab countries, including America's allies like Saudi Arabia and Egypt, have threatened to boycott the economic conference, or to send low-level delegations, because of the long Palestinian-Israeli deadlock that Ms. Albright is trying to crack. **********But James P. Rubin, the State Department spokesman, said, ''We don't feel a greater sense of urgency about the Middle East peace process because of the Doha conference.'' **********Officials of all three sides said there was good will and seriousness at the talks this week, but no breakthroughs, especially on the larger issues. Those include Israeli-Palestinian security cooperation, a freeze on Israeli settlement activity and other provocative unilateral actions, the further withdrawal of Israeli  troops from the West Bank and how to move quickly to talks on a final settlement between the two sides, including the status of Jerusalem. **********On the pressing issues that matter most to the Palestinians: the troop withdrawal and final-status talks, there was no progress at all, officials said. The Israeli Foreign Minister, David Levy, could not negotiate serious alterations in the Israeli package, officials said, and the Palestinians rejected the idea of dealing with the issues as a package. **********That is why Ms. Albright wants to see the Israeli Prime Minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, and the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, next week, in separate meetings, probably in London and Geneva. **********The two sides also discussed smaller questions, known as ''interim issues,'' which were supposed to have been settled 10 months ago. Those include a new airport for Palestinians in Gaza, a seaport, an industrial park and safe passage for Palestinians between the West Bank and Gaza Strip. **********Officials said no agreements were concluded because the details remain complicated and all the required experts were not here. For instance, officials said, while the airport is largely resolved, there are still details to be settled over how to schedule takeoffs and landings and air rights. On the seaport, the difficult issue of how to inspect shipments to insure Israeli security has not been worked out, they said. **********But Israeli and Palestinian officials were eager today not to criticize the other, and Mr. Levy and the Palestinian negotiator, Mahmoud Abbas, known as Abu Mazen, were complimentary. ''It's true that we did not reach any agreement in the different areas, but I can say that we did reach a great deal of understanding and common ground on each other's needs,'' Mr. Abbas said. **********Mr. Levy said, ''I believe that our work in this week has restored trust and has provided a good basis for our continued work, and I am returning home very satisfied.'' **********The Israeli Ambassador to the United Nations, Dore Gold, however, said today that the Palestinians were not heeding Ms. Albright's admonitions for a ''time out'' on provocative actions. ''It's outrageous that just as Israel is taking risks to conclude negotiations on a Palestinian airport in Gaza, the Palestinians are launching a four-pronged attack on Israel at the United Nations,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/29/busin.snippet: Hilton Hotels Corp bid for ITT Corp, half owner of Madison Square Garden, could give Garden yet another new parent; Hilton might seek to sell stake; possible buyers include Fox Sports unit of News Corp (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/29/busin.main_headline: If Deal Occurs, the Garden Faces Still Another Round
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/29/busin.print_headline: If Deal Occurs, the Garden Faces Still Another Round
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/29/busin.body_text: **********Once again, Madison Square Garden may have a new owner. **********In 1994, the Garden bounced from the ownership of Paramount Communcations to Viacom Inc. to a partnership of the ITT Corporation and the Cablevision Systems Corporation  for more than $1 billion. **********The sports and entertainment complex will gain a new parent if the Hilton Hotels Corporation succeeds in its $6.5 billion unsolicited bid for ITT. If Hilton wins, it may seek to sell its half-interest in the Garden to focus on the hotel and casino businesses. Analysts say the Garden may be worth between $650 million and $1 billion. **********Although there are several possible suitors, Fox Sports, a unit of the News Corporation, is being mentioned as one company that would have much to gain by acquiring the arena because of its battle to get the Fox News Channel carried on cable television in New York. **********''Fox could be in the hunt for it because it would give them tremendous leverage to get the Fox News Channel on in New York City,'' said Bob Gutkowski, the former president of the Garden and now the president of the Marquee Group, a sports and entertainment marketing company. Time Warner has refused to place the Fox News Channel on its New York City cable television system, arguing that there are already enough such channels. **********Mr. Gutkowski added that Fox Sports would also get ''the best regional sports network in the business -- the MSG Network -- the Knicks, the Rangers and the building.'' **********Fox Sports is a partner with Liberty Media, a unit of Tele-Communications Inc., in a regional cable sports service, Fox Sportsnet, which owns or is affiliated with sports channels around the country. The venture would covet the addition of the MSG Network, a highly profitable division of the Garden, which has 5.4 million subscribers. Liberty showed its interest in the Garden in 1994, when it made an unsuccessful bid of $1 billion to acquire it. **********Fox Sports, though, was noncommittal yesterday. ''It's premature,'' Vince Wladika, a spokesman for Fox Sports, said. ''But we find ourself again on the list of usual suspects.'' **********Rupert Murdoch, the News Corporation's chairman, also has been said to be a potential buyer of the Los Angeles Dodgers baseball team and any new National Football League team in Los Angeles. **********But the Garden is expected to be alluring to other companies. Marc Ganis, president of Sportscorp Ltd., a sports consulting firm, said that the Garden would appeal to a large investment firm like Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company because of its cash flow. A spokesman for Kohlberg Kravis declined to comment. **********Michael Ozanian, deputy editor and sports valuation expert at Financial World, said that a possible route for Hilton, if it acquires ITT, would be to sell its stake in the Garden to the public. Recently, H. Wayne Huizenga spun off 49 percent of his Florida Panthers hockey team at $10 a share. The stock price has since tripled. **********If Hilton buys ITT and wants to auction its 50 percent stake in the Garden, it would have to go through Cablevision, which has the option to buy ITT's share. In a statement yesterday, the cable system operator, which is based in Woodbury, L.I., said the Garden properties were ''important assets for Cablevision and we will maintain our ownership.'' **********But Cablevision could be unwilling or unable to buy out ITT's stake, whatever its worth. Cablevision is loaded with debt, and it lost $232.9 million in the nine months ended Sept. 30. It also has yet to repay the loan it received from ITT to acquire its stake in the Garden. **********Harold Vogel, an analyst with Cowen & Company, said that the Garden was worth more than the $1 billion Cablevision and ITT paid in 1994 because of increased cash flow since the acquisition, greater efficiencies in its operations and greater use of the arena. **********''It's in pretty good shape for a higher price,'' Mr. Vogel said. **********Other experts said that despite quadrupling cash flow since 1993 to between $80 million and $90 million last year, Garden management has squeezed as much as it can from operations and has reached the limit on ticket-price increases. ''I'd say it's worth $650 million to $725 million,'' said David Wolfe, an analyst with Oppenheimer & Company. He said the high cost of player salaries would be a problem for any buyer. **********Another ITT asset Hilton might shed is WBIS-TV, a new business and sports station ITT acquired jointly with Dow Jones & Company for $207 million. ''People in the TV business could be interested in a station with access to the New York-New Jersey market,'' Mr. Vogel said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/28/busin.snippet: Harold Osrow, chairman of Osrow Products, company he founded to produce an array of novel household items he helped invent, died on March 20 at age 80 (L)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/28/busin.main_headline: Harold Osrow, 80; Built a Much Better Broom
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/28/busin.print_headline: Harold Osrow, 80; Built a Much Better Broom
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/28/busin.body_text: **********Harold Osrow, an entrepreneur who couldn't leave well enough alone until he was satisfied he had made it better, cheaper or more convenient, died on March 20 at Columbia-Presbyterian Hospital. A resident of Dix Hills, L.I., he was 80 and had been chairman of Osrow Products, the company he founded to produce an array of novel household items he had helped tinker into being. **********His family said the cause was lung cancer. **********In an age in which the development of increasingly complex computers and other electronic products  transformed American society, Mr. Osrow was an inventor who concentrated on the simple things of life: the broom, for example. **********There had been brooms before Mr. Osrow came along, and they swept well enough, but until he and his younger brother Leonard introduced the Osrow Twin-Sweep in 1947, households needed a variety of brooms. The sleek aluminum Osrow, which became something of a sensation at Macy's, not only adjusted from a push broom to an upright, it also came with separate broomhead attachments, for indoor or patio use, that made it four brooms in one. **********To Mr. Osrow, a native of Jamaica, Queens, who briefly attended City College before serving with the Army in World War II, such inventiveness was something of a family tradition. His father, who owned a garment business, had been a tinkerer who obtained half a dozen patents over the years. **********Indeed, it was one of his father's leftover inventions, a hand-held dishwasher, that gave Mr. Osrow his start. The Osrow dishwasher was simply a brush attached to a hose that slipped over the kitchen faucet, but while it sold well enough to lead Mr. Osrow to brooms and beyond, it was its increasingly complex car-washing derivative with soap dispensers and swirling brushes that made Osrow a mainstay in the automotive products field. **********Like other inventors who often have accidental brainstorms, Mr. Osrow, who eventually held more than 30 patents, made a small fortune on a false start. In an effort to develop a portable windshield defroster that would attach to a car's cigarette lighter, he tested a prototype plug-in model in the freezer unit of his home refrigerator one night. When all the excess ice melted away in a manner of minutes he repackaged his idea as a defroster that proved popular until the advent of self-defrosting refrigerators. **********As for all that ice buildup on car windshields, Mr. Osrow abandoned his idea for a battery-powered defroster in favor of one that ran on elbow grease -- a plastic windshield scraper cum snow brush that proved so popular that Mr. Osrow sold them by the millions every year. **********As other products were added, the company, started in accordance with ancient entrepreneurial tradition in a garage in Ridgewood, Queens, expanded rapidly until it occupied a 120,000-square-foot factory with 350 employees in Old Bethpage, L.I. At its peak in the early 1980's it had sales of about $10 million a year. **********For all of Mr. Osrow's fascination with gadgetry, one of the company's more popular products, a cordless iron, reflected his marketing savvy. **********In addition to paying more for convenience, he once explained, consumers will spring for a cordless item ''because of the mystery of it.'' **********Still, the mainstays for Mr. Osrow's company, which introduced the talking ice cream machine (it played ''Happy Days are Here Again,'' when the ice cream was done) were products designed to make life easier. **********Unfortunately, one of its most popular products, a home pasta-making machine, proved the company's undoing when it was established that another company had invented it first. The resulting patent-infringement suit led Osrow Products into bankruptcy in the mid 1980's, although several of the company's products are still sold under the Osrow name by other companies. **********Mr. Osrow may have lost his company, but he still had his old eye for invention. Forming a new company, P.T.H.Y. (for ''products that help you''), he helped develop a commercial fudge-making machine, and when that enterprise failed he shouldered on. **********Just two weeks before his death he was working on his latest brainstorm, a coffee table that rises and converts to a full-size dining table. **********Mr. Osrow, whose first marriage ended in divorce, is survived by his wife, Laura; three children from his first marriage, Richard of West Bayshore, L.I.; Laurel of Manhattan, and Terry of Huntington, L.I.; his wife's two children by a previous marriage, Perry Sann of Summit, N.J. and Steven Sann of Port Washington, L.I., and four grandchildren.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/15/busin.body_text: **********China said today that it would extend $1 billion in special credit to Thailand, demonstrating a new link to other Asian nations. **********Beijing in recent years has rarely given financial aid beyond a few Communist countries. But ''unstable finances in one region are harmful for everybody,'' the governor of the Chinese central bank, Dai Xianglong, said today. https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/14/busin.snippet: Pharmacia & Upjohn, big multinational drug maker, says it will move its headquarters to mid-Atlantic state in US from Britain; Pharmacia declines to provide specific location (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/14/busin.main_headline: Pharmacia's Headquarters To Go to U.S. From Britain
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/14/busin.print_headline: Pharmacia's Headquarters To Go to U.S. From Britain
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/14/busin.body_text: **********In a trans-Atlantic variation on a familiar story in which a company moves its headquarters to a suburb near the home of the chief executive, Pharmacia & Upjohn, the big multinational drug maker, announced yesterday that it would move its headquarters to a mid-Atlantic state from Britain. **********While Pharmacia declined to provide a specific location, analysts said the company, which has been going through a rocky period, would probably join the large pharmaceutical companies based in central New Jersey. Fred Hassan, the recently appointed chief executive, lived in Florham Park, N.J., in Morris County until he moved to Britain last May. **********The new headquarters will consolidate its management, which is spread over four countries: Windsor outside London; Kalamazoo, Mich., the original home of Upjohn; Stockholm, the base of Pharmacia, and Milan, Italy. The new American headquarters will have 500 employees, including a North American sales group now in Kalamazoo. **********The top people had to ''spend half their lives in airplanes,'' said Viren Mehta, a pharmaceutical analyst with Mehta & Isaly in New York. He said the company had chosen New Jersey for the new home office. **********''It was logical to go to the center of gravity of the global pharmaceutical industry,'' said Mr. Hassan, who added that he had left New Jersey ''with the intention of being in London for several years.'' **********He declined to specify a state for the new headquarters, which could inflame local real estate markets, but he said New Jersey, which already has more than 50,000 pharmaceutical workers, was ''clearly one of the leading candidates.'' **********Mr. Hassan said the move would help Pharmacia & Upjohn ''to reverse the company's disappointing sales and earnings by aggressively growing in the U.S. -- the largest and most profitable market.'' He said his management team, including Carrie Smith Cox, from American Home Products; Ian McGinnes, a former Glaxo executive, and Goran Ando, a Swedish research chief, was ''starting to come together.'' **********After the merger two years ago of Pharmacia A.G. of Sweden and Upjohn, based in Kalamazoo, the company added a small overall headquarters in Windsor in hopes of keeping the executives in Stockholm and Michigan happy and effective. John Zabriskie, a former senior executive of Merck & Company, was chief executive of Pharmacia & Upjohn, until he resigned last January. In April, Jan Ekberg, the chairman, acknowledged that forecasts of growth and savings after the merger had been overly optimistic, even though 3,000 jobs were eliminated. **********Mariola Haggar, an analyst at Deutsche Morgan Grenfell, said the growth potential for drug makers in the United States seemed much stronger than in Europe and Japan, where governments are ''grappling with budget deficits'' and are trying to reduce spending on drugs. **********Mr. Hassan, who was born in Pakistan, said Pharmacia's ''most important new product'' was Detrusitol, for urinary incontinence, which he said was a largely ''undertreated'' problem for 10 million Americans, mainly older women. **********Pharmacia & Upjohn also has high  hopes for Edronax, a new type of antidepressant that may reach the American market in 1999. **********But ''Detrusitol and Edronax may not be enough,'' said Ms. Haggar at Deutsche Morgan Grenfell, to fill a hole left by patent expirations on several important Upjohn drugs. Earlier, Upjohn had disappointing results with Rogaine, a treatment for hair loss, and a drug for stroke and brain trauma that is still not ready for marketing, Mr. Mehta noted. **********Ms. Haggar said Pharmacia & Upjohn, like other big drug makers, would have to make licensing deals for promising drugs developed by smaller and foreign companies, while it waited for its own pipeline to produce. She said Mr. Hassan had had good results with such deals at American Home Products. **********''There is a big Fred factor in Pharmacia & Upjohn's stock price,'' she added. **********Yesterday, shares of Pharmacia, closed at $35.125, up 6.25 cents.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/09/busin.snippet: Specialty stores are attempting to build brand image for their own labels through new advertising campaigns; at Talbots Inc an extra $13 million has been earmarked this fall for ad campaign, created by Arnold Communications, to tell shoppers that ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/09/busin.main_headline: Specialty clothing retailers this fall want to let shoppers know that they, too, are a brand.
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/09/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; Specialty clothing retailers this fall want to let shoppers know that they, too, are a brand.
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/09/busin.body_text: **********FOR the last few years, department stores have stolen the limelight from specialty clothing retailers, luring shoppers with designer names and constant sales. **********This fall, specialty stores are fighting back, attempting to build a brand image for their own labels through new advertising campaigns. Several retailers greatly increased their advertising budgets this fall, flooding women's magazines with image campaigns to let shoppers know that they, too, are a brand, just like Calvin Klein and Ralph Lauren. **********At Talbots Inc., for example, an extra $13 million was earmarked this fall for a campaign, created by Arnold Communications, to tell shoppers that the store was returning to its roots in classic styles. In 1995, the company, spent only ''a few million dollars'' on advertising, said Margery Myers, a Talbots spokeswoman. Part of that money was also spent to spiff up the company's other marketing devices, like its shopping bags. **********The campaign depicts women wearing very uncomplicated looks -- a simple red suit, a white blouse or a heavy fisherman's sweater -- while going about daily tasks such as walking the children to school, preparing dinner or getting a parking ticket. **********''This campaign underscores that we are the headquarters for classics and will be doing them for years on,'' Ms. Myers said. ''We wanted to show what classics meant in today's life styles. Our market is 35 to 55, and most women in that segment are juggling multiple roles. They want to convey they care a lot about looking good and stylish, but they don't want to spend any time on it.'' **********Talbots is badly in need of a shot in the arm; sales have been weak all year, and the retailer has alienated its regular customers, with overly trendy offerings. **********Meanwhile, executives from the Ann Taylor Stores Corporation said that their fall campaign was the biggest one ever for the specialty retailer, whose sales have lagged in the last couple of years. Although the company would not disclose its budget, it said that it spent an extra $2 million this fall to put advertisements in nine women's magazines. In 1995, Ann Taylor had no fall campaign at all. **********''This campaign was designed to build top-of-mind awareness,'' said Catherine Sadler, the executive vice president of marketing at Ann Taylor. ''And to position us as accessible and relevant to our customers' lives.'' **********Translation: an advertisement that features a shirt, jacket, hat and pants shows that the store sells many interchangeable separates, and the fact that a woman is studying while wearing one Ann Taylor outfit and skipping about in a carefree manner in another shows that one can wear these clothes in all types of situations. **********''This is the first time I have seen all these retailers at once trying to get across the message of the attributes of their brand,'' said Maura Hunter Byrne, a retail analyst at J. P. Morgan. **********''Last year, the women's businesses in the department stores got a lot of attention because they were introducing the Lauren line, and Tommy and Nautica things,'' Ms. Byrne said. ''The Gap was losing market share, Talbots had problems and Ann Taylor brought in consultants. Now, it is all about their name being a brand name and needing to think just like branded products.'' **********Nine West Group, the shoe store chain, has also climbed on board in a big way. In a nine-page advertisement shot by the fashion photographer Herb Ritts and produced in-house, the company goes to great lengths to portray itself as a sexy  fashion brand and not just a store doling out everyday navy pumps. **********The advertisements were shot with a hazy orange glow. Each page shows a different product, like a wine-colored leather purse, or a trendy pair of ankle boots, or a pair of fishnet tights -- again stressing the depth of the retailer's product line. **********Although the company would not disclose its budget for this campaign, it spent ''50 percent more than last year,'' said Stacy Lastrina, vice president of corporate marketing for Nine West. ''Today brands are built emotionally,'' Ms. Lastrina said. ''You have to get a message across and show what the brand ideology means to her life.'' **********Translation: You too may have three gorgeous men gaze lovingly at your sandal-clad ankles while you hang loose in a really hip North African-themed bar, if only you shop at Nine West.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/26/world.snippet: Rations received by the people of Baghdad this month, more than five months after Iraqi oil began to flow again under United Nations supervision, were more bountiful than at any time since the end of the Persian Gulf war in 1991; however, the oil-...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/26/world.main_headline: Iraqis Laugh Again and Lather Up
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/26/world.print_headline: Iraqis Laugh Again and Lather Up
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/26/world.body_text: **********Sometimes it is the small things that make a difference, and that may be the case in the new nexus between the Government of Iraq, the United Nations and soap. **********Until this month, the soap provided to Iraqis as part of a paltry basket of Government rations was universally reviled: colorless, latherless and smelling faintly of the lard from which it was usually made. **********But, finally, Iraqis have a reason to smile. More than five months after Iraqi oil began to flow again under United Nations supervision, the rations that people received this month were more bountiful than at any time since the end of the Persian Gulf war in 1991. Along with flour, rice and beans, the latest baskets included fresh-smelling bars of soap, one reason that some Iraqis are talking about feeling human again. **********''Of course it makes a difference,'' said Haifa Abul Amir, 24, a mother of two who shares a cramped house in the ragged Baghdad suburb of Huriya with her husband and her parents. ''That other stuff wasn't fit for any person.'' **********Adopted as a ''temporary measure'' to ease the hardships caused by United Nations efforts to squeeze the Iraqi Government, the oil-for-food plan that has begun to sweeten life here will expire on June 9, and it is not clear whether it will be renewed. **********The United States has said it is not entirely satisfied that all revenues from the $2 billion worth of oil that Iraq was authorized to sell are being used properly. Iraq has complained that the United States has been overzealous, holding up delivery of food and other goods that should have arrived months ago. A report from the United Nations Secretary General, Kofi Annan, that is expected to address these issues is expected within days. **********But with tons of food, detergents and even medical supplies beginning to enter Iraq, Iraqis who have complained for years of being pawns to bigger rivalries say they have begun to regain a measure of dignity. **********''Now when we bake bread we run out to show it off to the neighbors,'' said Najad Salman, 44, the mother of Ms. Abul Amir. ''The flour they gave us before couldn't make a decent loaf, but now we all are better off.'' **********For Iraqis who have suffered through the years of sanctions, weathering illness and malnutrition, the change has been a long time coming. **********Although various oil-for-food plans have been proposed by the United Nations for years, the Iraqi Government long rejected them as an infringement of its sovereignty. Even after it shifted course and gave a tentative go-ahead in January 1996, the final details took nearly a year to be resolved. **********Iraqi oil did begin to flow again last Dec. 9, an event accompanied by lavish ceremonies and celebratory gunshots in the streets, but it took nearly three months before the first shipment of food -- chick peas, white beans and cooking oil from Turkey -- arrived. **********A special United Nations committee in New York has blocked or put on hold nearly half of the contracts for food and other goods that have been submitted under a cumbersome approval process for which the Iraqis blame American interference. **********As late as April, so few supplies of food and other goods had arrived in Iraq that the monthly ration provided by the Government to its 22 million citizens remained essentially unchanged. Rations were increased by a few pounds of flour per person only after the Government agreed to draw 40,000 tons of wheat from its own strategic reserves. **********But in the last two months a burgeoning flow by land and sea has brought a total of 550,000 tons of food and other goods into Iraq, where they are being distributed by Iraqi officials under United Nations supervision. In the Kurdish areas of northern Iraq, which lie outside the control of the Baghdad Government, the distribution is handled by United Nations agencies. **********Sugar and tea remain in short supply and the quantities distributed to Iraqis this month remained unchanged. But the supplies of all other goods have been considerably bolstered, increasing the average daily calorie allotment by about 90 percent, to about 2,300 per day. **********The package still does not include meat or eggs, and it provides milk only for youngsters less than one year old. As many as one in four Iraqi children still suffer from some form of malnutrition, United Nations officials say, and most Iraqis still find it necessary to buy some goods on the open market, where a dozen eggs can consume about half a government worker's monthly salary. **********''It's a drop in the bucket,'' Iraq's Information Minister, Hamid Yousef Hammadi, said of the help provided by the oil-for-food agreement, although he quickly added, ''It's better than nothing.'' **********The United Nations Humanitarian Coordinator for Iraq, Steffan de Mistura, declined in an interview to say  whether he thought the oil-for-food deal should be extended, but his comments left his sentiments clear. **********''The needs of the population are clearly identified, and they are large,'' he said. **********Under the accord, Iraqi is permitted to sell only about one-fifth of the oil that it did before the Persian Gulf war. Of the $2 billion that it was permitted to earn from the sale of oil in the six months that will end on June 9, nearly 30 percent has been set aside to settle the claims of those displaced by the war and to pay for the costs of United Nations operations here. **********But still, from those limited oil sales alone, the plan sets aside $805 million for food, $65 million for soap and detergent, $210 million for medicine, and tens of millions more for projects to improve electricity, water, agriculture and education. **********Some Western diplomats say they worry that the scheme may simply allow the Government of President Saddam Hussein to divert resources that it once had to spend on food toward darker purposes. They say these could include efforts to rebuild weapons systems that Iraq has been compelled to destroy under the United Nations resolutions that were imposed after the Persian Gulf war. **********But people in Baghdad who have  begun to taste life's simplest pleasures again would rather talk about how their lot is improving. **********''It smells nice, it cleans better, and at least it has a pretty color,'' said one of several woman who volunteered their praise, unprompted, for the pinkish bars of Jordanian soap passed out at a monthly ration of one and a half per person. ''We all still have big problems, but I'm beginning to feel a little better about the little ones.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/27/world.snippet: Russian space officials say that it will take two weeks to transport vital repair equipment to stricken Mir space station, which was seriously damaged when unmanned Progress cargo vessel slammed into it on June 25 (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/27/world.main_headline: Tools to Fix Space Station to Arrive in 2 Weeks
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/27/world.print_headline: Tools to Fix Space Station to Arrive in 2 Weeks
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/27/world.body_text: **********Russian space officials said today that it would take two weeks to transport vital repair equipment to the stricken Mir space station . **********The station was seriously damaged on Wednesday when an unmanned Progress cargo vessel slammed into it, curtailing Mir's power supply and forcing the two Russians and an American on board to seal off one of its seven compartments, the Spektr module. **********Yuri Koptev, chief of the Russian Space Agency, said that another unmanned Progress cargo craft would be launched in 11 days with special equipment for repairs. It takes about two days for the Progress to reach the space station. **********''The astronauts will have to make a space walk to complete the repairs to the Spektr module,'' Mr. Koptev said. ''For that, special equipment should be delivered.'' **********In a conversation with NASA officials in Houston today, Michael Foale, the American astronaut aboard Mir, said he and his two  crewmates were feeling fine and adapting to the cramped, dark conditions on the station. **********Mr. Foale's personal belongings and most of his scientific equipment and experiments are in the sealed-off Spektr module. Asked what gear he would like to have included in the supply ship scheduled to visit Mir, Mr. Foale requested a medical kit to replace one left in the damaged module, a shaver, a toothbrush, three tubes of toothpaste and a pair of shoes. **********Frank Culbertson, NASA's director of the Mir space shuttle cooperative program, said at a news conference in Houston that United States experts were helping assess the damage to Mir and would help with repairs if the Russians requested it.  It is unlikely that NASA would move up the next scheduled visit of an American space shuttle to the Russian station, now planned for late September, he said. **********Mr. Culbertson said that before sending an astronaut, Wendy Lawrence, up to Mir on that flight to replace Mr. Foale, NASA had to determine that the stay would be safe and that there would be worthwhile research for her to do in light of the loss of perhaps half of the United States equipment aboard Mir. **********As Russian and NASA officials met here to discuss possible repairs,  Russian officials repeated that they had no plans to evacuate the Mir, a procedure that might result in the loss of the space station. The Mir  generally needs to be manned to stay in the proper orbital pattern over an extended period, said an American official. He said the Russians had a multibillion dollar investment in the Mir and would try to preserve it as long as there was no danger to the crew. **********But the Russians were not minimizing the seriousness of the accident and said they were prepared to order an evacuation if air pressure fell precipitously. So far, the air pressure in the undamaged part of the craft is satisfactory, Russian officials said. **********A major problem is the loss of much of the vessel's power. The power problem developed after the Progress cargo vehicle destroyed a solar array and damaged cables to other solar arrays while the crew of the Mir was practicing a docking maneuver. **********NASA officials said on Wednesday that half of the power had been lost but Russian officials said today that electrical power had been cut 25 percent to 30 percent. Because of the reduced power, the crew has canceled scientific experiments and because of the power problems, television pictures were not transmitted from the craft.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/20/busin.snippet: President Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe on Wednesday defended his government's decision to pay large amounts of compensation to veterans of the country's fight for black rule, saying the recent move would not derail its economic reform efforts and sho...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/20/busin.body_text: **********President Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe on Wednesday defended his government's decision to pay large amounts of compensation to veterans of the country's fight for black rule, saying the recent move would not derail its economic reform efforts and should not deter foreign investors. **********The comments by Mr. Mugabe came as Zimbabwe encountered its worst economic difficulties in years. Fears about a mushrooming budget deficit and the suspension in July of balance-of-payments loans from the International Monetary Fund caused the Zimbabwe dollar to tumble last week, prompting the government to impose stiff foreign-exchange controls Tuesday. **********The situation has raised concerns that Southern Africa could be caught up in the recent financial maelstrom emanating from Southeast Asia just as the region was beginning to see its best economic growth in decades. The countries of the Southern African Development Community had growth averaging 4 percent in 1996, and political leaders are hoping to translate the region's new peace and political stability into sustainable development. **********Mr. Mugabe said the veterans' payments were an essential act of social justice that would help alleviate poverty among some 60,000 former soldiers who fought to topple Zimbabwe's white-minority government in the 1970s. He said the country would finance the one-time payment of about 4.5 billion Zimbabwe dollars ($352.9 million) out of its own resources and told foreign investors they should not be concerned. **********The funds "won't come from investment capital," he said at a conference on Southern African trade and investment here, organized by the International Herald Tribune. **********In Harare on Tuesday, Finance Minister Herbert Murerwa of Zimbabwe unveiled an emergency austerity package of spending cuts, tax increases and foreign-exchange controls. The package was intended to finance the veterans' payments, stabilize the Zimbabwe dollar and persuade the IMF to resume the balance-of-payments loans. **********It was unclear whether the measures would reassure investors, however. Many economists say the government can ill afford the payments with the budget deficit already soaring. Moreover, a decision announced Tuesday requiring companies to close about $160 million of foreign-currency accounts worried many executives, who said the accounts were vital to financing trade and encouraging investment. The move requires companies to sell their dollars, rand and other foreign currencies. **********"It will make investors who are seeking export earnings think twice," said Bernard Tafa, executive director of Chibuku Regional Investments, a Mozambique brewing company. **********Justifying the move, Mr. Murerwa said companies had been abusing the accounts to speculate against the local currency rather than to finance genuine business transactions. "This is a time for nation-building, not speculation on the currency," he said. **********Mr. Murerwa's austerity package, designed to reduce the deficit by 3.8 billion dollars this year, also included a freeze on 1.1 billion dollars of spending, stepped-up tax-collection efforts and a strong hint of new tax increases. **********On Wednesday, the dollar traded at 12.75 to the U.S. dollar, compared with a range of 11 to 12 before Friday.
