https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/14/busin.snippet: Laura Pedersen-Pietersen responds to Elliott Prag's letter on becoming a cook at South Pole; photo (L)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/14/busin.main_headline: MINDING YOUR BUSINESS ; Where to Go to Make Some Really Cold Cash
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/14/busin.print_headline: MINDING YOUR BUSINESS ; Where to Go to Make Some Really Cold Cash
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/14/busin.body_text: **********Q. I'm told one can make a lot of money as a cook at the South Pole. How do I go about getting a job there? **********ELLIOTT PRAG **********Detroit **********A. East Hampton it's not. Even the masochistically inclined will tell you there are better places below the Equator to get a kitchen job this fall than in Antarctica, the world's coldest, driest, windiest and most remote continent, where summer temperatures range from a balmy 40 degrees Fahrenheit to 40 below. **********Picture a land one-fifth larger than the United States and Mexico, 98.4 percent of it covered by ice and the rest by wind-scoured rocks. Since the establishment of the Little America encampment by Adm. Richard E. Byrd in 1929, the United States has had a major presence there, exploring the polar region, its ecosystems and climate, using the vast ice shield as a scientific platform for studying not only the earth's upper atmosphere but also near-outer space. It was in Antarctica, site of the cleanest air in today's world, that we first learned the character and causes of the ozone hole, of global warming and, from a meteorite pried out of  the ice, of the possibility of extraterrestrial life on Mars. **********More revelations may be forthcoming. By 2005, the 25-year-old dome-shaped South Pole station will undergo a multimillion-dollar renovation that will require much manpower and should greatly increase the ability to do modern scientific research. **********Still, considering that for now, fewer than 200 people a year make the three-hour ski-plane flight from the main American base at McMurdo Sound to work at the geographic South Pole, I don't think there will be much demand for a sous-chef. But whoever works in the kitchen at the Amundsen-Scott polar station will still need an aptitude for creative cooking. Much of the fare is canned, frozen or freeze-dried, though bread is baked fresh daily and soups are made from scratch. One specialite de la maison is ''buzz bars'' -- brownies with chocolate-covered espresso beans baked into them. **********Food supplies, flown in periodically from New Zealand, often arrive in odd proportions; for instance, a huge bundle of green onions, but no lettuce or any other salad makings. This might lead one to ponder the fortunes awaiting the person who sets up Antarctica's first sled-through fast-food joint. **********Seriously, your source was probably referring to joining the support staff at one of the three American scientific research facilities and two ships operated under the aegis of the National Science Foundation. Each year, the United States (one of 26 nations studying Antarctica) deploys about 650 people to perform scientific research and an additional 2,500 to fill an array of support jobs in areas like global communications, data entry, hospital services, safety training, housing construction, vehicle maintenance, firefighting, housekeeping, waste management, recreation, airfield crash rescue, janitorial services and, yes, food handling. Those numbers will grow with the renovation project. **********(The National Science Foundation will also provide field support for a few artists, writers, historians and scholars who wish to  experience the bottom of the world, though it will not pay them.) **********Most jobs require an uninterrupted four- to six-month stint during the austral summer months, October through February. The ranks thin during the winter months, when the weather can be diabolical: temperatures as low as 117 degrees below zero, hurricane-strength winds and blinding snowstorms that can last three or more days. Despite all this, many workers go back for more. **********While there are no hardship bonuses, the pay for nonscientific work isn't bad. Salaries are based on Denver-area wages and range from $300 a week for unskilled labor to $1,200 for managers and those with technical skills. A cook makes $400 to $600 for a 54-hour workweek plus a 16 percent bonus for completing the stint. A repeat visit would earn a 5 percent base pay increase and an 18 percent completion bonus. **********However, you would probably save more money than if you worked stateside because your expenses are paid and, well, there aren't many places to spend your money (though there is an A.T.M. at McMurdo Station). Rob Holmes, a meteorologist who has worked several stints at an Antarctica  weather station, says he has his paychecks deposited directly into his bank account, collecting interest until his return to Oregon, Wis. **********The research stations are small communities, with a variety of jobs and activities.  Off-hour pursuits include hiking, cross-country skiing, crafts, sports, movies, and -- surprise -- science lectures. **********''There's a small PX-like store for souvenirs, alcohol and toiletries, a few bars and you can always order from Lands' End or L. L. Bean,'' Mr. Holmes said. ''Just don't ask for overnight delivery.'' **********That's some Antarctish humor, because the sun never sets during part of the summer, so there is no night. E-mail, satellite TV and Internet access have also lessened the isolation, so you don't have to worry about arriving at McMurdo, the only United States installation south of Guantanamo Bay with a bowling alley, and being greeted by a bunch of hirsute green-stamp collectors grabbing at your lapels and demanding, ''Who shot J.R.?'' **********If you are interested in nonscientific work in Antarctica, you can get in touch with the  Antarctic Support Associates in Englewood, Colo., (800 688-8606, extension 3198), the main contractor supplying the National Science Foundation with support staff. The contractor usually starts accepting summer job applications in April. **********The process is essentially the same as seeking employment stateside unless you specifically ask for a ''winter-over'' job.  Those who do will have to pass a psychological test and an extensive physical exam because medical care is limited and emergency evacuation impossible during the winter. **********Some winter workers are advised to travel extremely light -- in particular, by getting rid of their impacted wisdom teeth before embarking. Pregnant women need not apply. **********Incidentally, more women than ever are signing up for Antarctic duty, noted Rebecca L. Johnson, author of ''Braving the Frozen Frontier: Women Working in Antarctica'' (Lerner, 1997, $17.96). **********''You'll see women working in all the traditionally male-dominated fields, including construction and engineering,'' she said, finding remarkably little sexism on the job. ''Ironically, there's a larger percentage of men working in food service.'' **********After their selection, the workers go to Christchurch, on New Zealand's South Island, where they receive their cold-weather gear, take a safety training course and then take a five-hour flight to McMurdo Station. **********To pursue study in Antarctica as a scientist or research assistant, one may call the National Science Foundation (703 306-1234) or visit its Web site at http://www.nsf.gov/. **********''Antarctica is the place for scientists in many disciplines to really make their mark,'' said Dr. Bernard Stonehouse, an authority on Antarctica at the Scott Polar Research Institute in Cambridge, England, and author of the forthcoming ''Antarctica, the Traveller's Guide'' (Harold Martin & Redman, 1997, $21.95). **********Coincidentally, say a number of travel-trend spotters, Antarctica beckons as a destination for plucky tourists. This year, more than 12,000 visitors are expected to touch down on ''the ice.'' By the millennium, as many as 20,000 will head for the Penguin Trail annually. In anticipation, Lonely Planet Publications last year published ''Antarctica,'' a 362-page guidebook aimed specifically at such intrepid travelers, and sold a bundle of them at $17.95 each. **********But what is the appeal, if not the free ice? ''It's an expensive adventure holiday for people that have been everywhere and want to view magnificent, unspoiled alpine scenery, sculpted ice, penguins, wildlife, and enjoy some history,'' Dr. Stonehouse said. And, of course, some travelers collect continents and need that elusive seventh. **********Dr. Stonehouse says more than a few seasoned American tourists trace their decision to encounters with Admiral Byrd in the 1930's. He is said to have ended many a lecture by patting the heads of schoolchildren and insisting, ''You must go there someday.'' Apparently, now in their 60's and 70's and with 401(k) money to spare, those kids are taking him at his word. **********Dr. Stonehouse also says Antarctica has been climatically maligned. **********''Individuals have experienced much worse weather during winters in the northern Midwest and Canada than they'll find in Antarctica during the summer,'' he said.  ''I've met some elderly ladies from the Bronx who hadn't walked more than 50 yards in the last 10 years and were having a fine time.'' **********That may be all well and good, but frankly, having spent 17 years growing up outside frigid Buffalo, I'll pass on any more cold-weather duty, thank you. **********Questions about investing, careers and personal finance can be sent to Minding Your Business, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York 10036. Or send them by E-mail to yourmind@nytimes.com. Questions can be answered only in the column, not by mail, E-mail or telephone.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/13/world.main_headline: U.S. to Increase Funds for Anti-Milosevic Media and Unions
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/13/world.print_headline: U.S. to Increase Funds for Anti-Milosevic Media and Unions
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/13/world.body_text: **********The United States is significantly expanding its support of newspapers, radio stations and trade unions opposed to President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia, senior American officials said today. **********While the money to be distributed in 1997 is small -- about $2 million -- it is five times the $400,000 provided last year. The officials said the increase was a direct result of the pro-democracy demonstrations in Belgrade and other cities against the authoritarian rule of Mr. Milosevic. **********The aid is another indication of a shift in policy away from Mr. Milosevic, who was a crucial supporter of the Dayton peace accords of December 1995, which halted the war in Bosnia. American officials now say Mr. Milosevic is no longer critical to stability in Bosnia. **********''His days are numbered,'' one official said. ''Now it's a matter of when his era ends, not if, and how it does. Even if he survives, he won't be able to exercise the same unbridled rule. The rules have changed.'' **********Some of the money can be delivered immediately through the American Embassy in Belgrade in small grants valued at $5,000 to $10,000, the officials said. The support is to be given not in cash but in goods, like computers or newspaper ink, and  technical assistance. **********Most of the aid, which has already been appropriated, is to be funneled through American groups like the National Endowment for Democracy, the National Democratic Institute and the International Foundation for Electoral Systems. These foundations can usually provide support faster than the Agency for International Development. **********The groups, officials said, will organize programs to train journalists, union leaders and political parties in the ways of democracy. In other countries this has included teaching political parties how to use polling data and advertising, and to draw up party platforms. **********While praising the program, some representatives of the groups criticized the Administration for being so late. In 1996, they point out, the Government aid of $400,000 was dwarfed by funds provided by the private Open Society Institute, led by the financier George Soros, and by European countries. **********Senator Richard G. Lugar, Republican of Indiana, has been prominent in urging more support for independent news media in Serbia. **********The effort was hampered last year by American sanctions against Serbia and by the general atmosphere of suppression, American officials say. Efforts by the Embassy to find worthy recipients independent of the Government were made difficult by the ''reticence'' of Serbian organizations to seek or accept aid from Americans, a senior official said. **********But after the demonstrators, who demanded the reinstatement of opposition victories in local elections in November, began to chip away at Mr. Milosevic's rule, Serbian organizations were more willing to come forward. **********And American credibility with the opposition was helped by the decision in December to incorporate reports from the independent radio station B92 into transmissions of Radio Free Europe when Mr. Milosevic tried to shut it down. **********''People have shed their fears about operating in public,'' one senior official said. ''People are more approachable, and more willing to take risks in approaching American officials.'' **********A successful program will still require the tolerance of the Serbian Government, which could withhold visas for American aid workers and experts working for the American groups, or prevent Serbs from traveling to the United States for training and study. **********''If they do that, we have big problems,'' the official said. ''But we're plunging ahead in expectation of approval of the Serbian Government to work in Belgrade.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/24/busin.main_headline: For World Bonds, an Uncertain Time
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/24/busin.print_headline: For World Bonds, an Uncertain Time
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/24/busin.body_text: **********World bond markets are headed into a twilight zone, hampered by an inability to see clearly and a loss of liquidity. **********The drying up of liquidity — mainly because of the confluence of the Easter holidays, the end of the Japanese fiscal year on March 31 and the end of the first quarter elsewhere — is the most transient of the problems. **********But combined with the uncertainty about fundamental issues that is likely to linger, investors can be expected to remain defensive and averse to risk for an extended period. **********The most immediate worry is the level of U.S. interest rates. A quarter-point rise in the cost of overnight money, to 5.50 percent from 5.25 percent, after the meeting Tuesday of Federal Reserve Board policymakers is now widely considered a foregone conclusion. **********Beyond that, the consensus breaks down. Will it be a one-off increase? "Unlikely," said John Lipsky at Chase Manhattan Bank. "It would seem trivial to try to fine-tune monetary policy to such a degree," he said, adding that he expected the federal funds rate to be at least 5.75 percent by the end of the year. **********Stephen Roach at Morgan Stanley & Co. said that "this is not a central bank that is about to squander years of hard-won credibility over a measly 25 basis points — the increase should be viewed as the first of many" en route to 6.50 percent by the end of the year. **********His is an admittedly extreme view, but if correct, it exposes a rocky road for European bonds, which are not only influenced by developments in New York but also have their own problems, notably whether the planned monetary union proceeds and, if so, with which countries. **********In Europe, uncertainties about monetary union are driving investors out of the higher-yielding peripheral bond markets — Italy, Spain, Sweden — which continued to sell off last week. Fears of a delay and signs of strong German growth buoyed the Deutsche mark, but yields on 10-year government bonds ended the week almost a quarter point higher at 5.92 percent. **********The problem for investors is that they have no way of knowing what is likely to happen. U.S. economic data indicate a faster-than-expected rate of growth but with inflation still contained. Only subsequent data over the coming months will offer a clue as to how much further, if at all, the Fed needs to tighten. **********One irony of the current situation is that investor confidence in the Fed's ability to contain inflation is so high that long-term interest rates have barely moved. The benchmark 30-year government bond currently yields 6.96 percent, compared with 6.72 percent at the start of the year. **********Had the rise been sharper, the increase in the cost of money would have been causing a natural restraint on the upswing. But without that added drag, the Fed may be forced to push up more sharply the short-term rates it controls. **********As rates in the bond futures market already incorporate an increase in the cost of borrowing dollars, no big reaction is expected after Tuesday's announcement. The market reaction will be "muted," said Avinash Persaud at J.P. Morgan & Co., "with attention focused on if and when the Fed moves next."

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/01/world.snippet: Celebration marking transfer of rule in Hong Kong to China may be moment of patriotic pride, but is also business opportunity for merchants who can profit by selling mementos commemmorating event (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/01/world.main_headline: Cashing In On Hoopla: A Colony Of Kitsch
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/01/world.print_headline: Cashing In On Hoopla: A Colony Of Kitsch
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/01/world.body_text: **********Samuel Ng slid his latest creation across a table, a sly smile on his face. ''Just for Hong Kong,'' he announced. **********Before him, he rotated a 5-inch high, bottle-fat wooden doll, one side painted as a British soldier, the reverse as a Chinese soldier. Then he removed the outer shell to reveal a Chinese soldier. And inside that was a British one. And inside that, a Chinese. And inside that? A condom. **********''It's a bit unusual,'' beamed Mr. Ng. ''But we wanted to be different. It's different, isn't it?'' **********This may be a moment of patriotic pride, a time to reflect on the perfidy of British colonialism, a time to cherish China's millenniums of culture. But, in time-honored Hong Kong fashion, it has also been a time to make money. **********British flags coming down, Chinese flags going up, new civic symbols -- the bauhinia plant (rather unfortunately a sterile hybrid) and the white dolphin (on the verge of extinction as a result of Hong Kong's breakneck development) -- all a marketer's dream. **********There are T-shirts of course (''The Great Chinese Takeaway'' is  a current favorite), ashtrays sporting Chinese flags and ceramic mugs with stylized bauhinias. There are new first-day stamp issues, special pizzas and Red Dawn Lager -- ''Hong Kong's only handover beer.'' For the nostalgic, there's aerosol Canned Colonial Air: The Last Gasp of Empire, for $7. **********Baccarat crystal weighed in with a $42,250 sculpture of a child being suckled by its mother -- ''Back to the Motherland,'' they call it -- in a limited edition of 30. Susanna Lui, who sells them at the Peninsula Hotel, said only two were left. **********''Most of the regular buyers of this sculpture,'' she said, ''are regular customers of Baccarat. This is a limited edition, so our customers wanted it.'' **********Christofle, the silver maker, churned out 1,997 sculptures of two clasped hands, dubbed ''Hand in Hand,'' for $6,250 each. ''It's not gaudy,'' insisted Jennifer Shun, who sells the hands for Christofle. ''It's quite different from our traditional merchandise and has many symbolic meanings.'' A bit more expensive than hot cakes, the hands were still going fast, she said. ''We've got two left.'' **********And because Hong Kong is Hong Kong, speculators have been frantically trying to figure out what will increase in value and what won't. It seems that neither the last commemorative coin set issued under British rule nor the coins still in circulation bearing the visage of the Queen will have much lasting value. Despite the onset of Chinese rule, nearly 2.2 billion coins sporting the Queen are still in circulation. **********Then there are car license plates, an assemblage of letters and numbers that often attract frantic bidding if a particularly auspicious series of numbers comes up for auction. The combination 8888 is about as precious as it gets, since 8 in Cantonese also sounds like the word for good fortune. **********So one would have thought that a plate reading HK1997 would be particularly sought after. Alas, it was not to be when the plate's owner, who bought it cheaply years ago, failed to get the price he was seeking: $600,000. But for most people, especially the thousands of tourists who happen to be in Hong Kong for this moment in history, a cornucopia of cheap kitsch awaits. **********''I want something that looks good and means something,'' declared Janine Thomas, a San Franciscan who was shopping at the China Products Shop under a huge sign that read, ''HK Handover Commemoration Sale.'' She settled on a T-shirt that read ''One Country, Two Systems,'' a slogan coined by the late Chinese leader Deng Xiaoping to describe Hong Kong's somewhat autonomous relationship with the mainland. **********China's effort to cash in on the hoopla, however, seems to have gone awry. ''The Opium War,'' the most expensive movie made in China, a didactic extravaganza depicting Britain's armed forces ramming opium down China's throat, has flopped at the box office. Steven Spielberg's new movie, ''The Lost World,'' about dinosaurs, is in town and lines stretch around the block. **********Patriotism may be the theme of the day, but James Wong Jim, a well-known local actor, songwriter and flamboyant master of ceremonies, backed out of serving as host at one of the televised celebrations because he was asked to donate his talents to the festivities. **********''I am a professional master of ceremonies,'' Mr. Wong told a local paper. ''I only work for money. If I get paid, I will do the job. If I don't get paid, I will not do it. This is the virtue of capitalism.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/06/busin.snippet: America Online Inc returns to profitability in its third quarter after six months of heavy losses; company earned $2.6 million on revenue of $456.2 million for quarter, which ended on March 31 (L)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/06/busin.body_text: **********America Online Inc. said yesterday that it had returned to profitability in its third quarter after six months of heavy losses. The results surprised Wall Street analysts, who had predicted another loss for the nation's largest on-line service provider. **********America Online's advertising revenue surged while marketing costs were forced lower as part of a legal settlement with state attorneys general that forced the company to cut back its advertising. **********As a result, the company earned  $2.6 million, or 2 cents a share, on revenue of $456.2 million, for the quarter, which ended on March 31. Analysts polled by First Call had expected a loss of 7 cents a share. **********The modest earnings were a retreat from the $15.1 million profit the company posted in its third quarter a year ago, but marked a significant improvement from more recent results. Over the previous two quarters, the company had posted a combined loss of $508.5 million. **********''I think we have turned the corner as relates to returning to profitability and we anticipate seeing progress in the future quarters,'' Stephen M. Case, America Online's chairman, said. ''The progress we saw this quarter provides greater confidence in the soundness of our strategy.'' **********A cornerstone of that strategy was repositioning America Online as a media company along the lines of a magazine or newspaper, one that sells its product for about what it costs to make and hopes to make most of its profits from advertising. **********In February the company signed up its largest marketing client, Tel-Save Holdings Inc., a long-distance telephone operator. Tel-Save, which buys long-distance time in bulk and resells it at a profit, paid America Online what amounted to a $100 million advance. **********America Online booked about $12 million of that fee this past quarter, helping overall advertising and transaction revenue jump more than threefold to $60.7 million. **********Following the media-company model and forced to compete against companies that offer low-cost connections directly to the Internet, America Online abolished most per-hour charges in December. In their place, it established an ''all you can eat'' plan, offering unlimited access to the service for $19.95 a month. **********Users flocked to the service, but America Online's infrastructure could not handle the demand. **********Prodded by users, attorneys general from 36 states negotiated an agreement with America Online that required the company to offer refunds to many subscribers and to drastically curtail its advertising. **********So the company's marketing costs fell by almost 40 percent, from $146.8 million in the quarter that ended in December to $89.5 million in the most recent quarter. Mr. Case said the company intended to reduce marketing costs all along. **********Some analysts questioned whether America Online could sustain its profitability, noting declining gross profit margins and the artificially low marketing expenses. But others were ebullient. **********''They can turn on the engines now,'' said Alan M. Braverman, an analyst with Credit Suisse First Boston. ''They've just scratched the surface with advertising and electronic commerce. I think the earnings are very sustainable.'' **********America Online did not announce the earnings until after financial markets closed. But shares of America Online began to rise almost immediately after the New York Stock Exchange opened yesterday, finishing the day at $51.50, up $4.25. **********Before the markets opened, Hambrecht & Quist, a West Coast brokerage firm, announced that it had initiated coverage of America Online with a ''buy'' rating. Hambrecht & Quist's chief executive, Daniel H. Case 3d, is a brother of Mr. Case, the America Online chairman. The analyst who wrote the positive report said that the family connection had no bearing on his analysis.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/14/world.main_headline: Pomp Bars Poor at Mother Teresa's Rites
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/14/world.print_headline: Pomp Bars Poor at Mother Teresa's Rites
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/14/world.body_text: **********Mother Teresa was buried yesterday in Calcutta, India, after a funeral largely closed to the poor she had devoted her life to helping. **********In six hours of ceremonies that began with a military escort from a quiet convent church and ended with a Gurkha rifle salute over her tomb, the nun was honored with both pomp and sorrow by her city, her adopted country and the world. **********The crowds that assembled to see her cortege pass were far smaller than expected and far more decorous than usual in India. https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/08/busin.snippet: Market Place column on Nine West Group's accounting problems that has resulted in Securities and Exchange Commission inquiry and its investor relations problem with several institutional investors and securities lawyers (L)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/08/busin.main_headline: Nine West Faces Problems on Two Fronts
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/08/busin.print_headline: Nine West Faces Problems on Two Fronts
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/08/busin.body_text: **********The question is whether Nine West Group, the shoe manufacturer and retailer, has a bigger problem with accounting or investor relations. It's a close call. **********Nine West's accounting problem became public on Tuesday, when the company disclosed in a paragraph buried deep in a routine annual filing that the Securities and Exchange Commission was investigating its accounting procedures. Specifically, the company said it had learned on May 1 that the commission voted on April 10 to upgrade an informal staff inquiry into a formal investigation, a step that allows the commission staff to issue subpoenas for information. The dispute was vaguely described as relating to ''the company's revenue recognition policies and practices.'' **********Nine West's investor relations problem erupted about the same time -- and is continuing, in the eyes of several institutional investors and securities lawyers. **********An appropriate response for a widely held company traded on the New York Stock Exchange would have been to issue a news release detailing the nature of the dispute and giving the company's spin on the issue, said John C. Coffee Jr., a securities law professor at Columbia University. Tucking the news into a buried paragraph of a lengthy routine filing ''looks like an attempt to bury a needle in a haystack,'' he said. ''If this is a modest dispute over some gray accounting principle, they have certainly blown it up into a far more serious issue by the way they have reacted,'' he added. **********An institutional investor who owns Nine West shares said he thought the company had simply misjudged the importance of the news. ''The company was not overly sensitive to what makes investors jump around,'' he said. ''They were probably shocked at the reaction.'' **********Robert C. Galvin, the company's chief financial officer, would say only that the timing and nature of the disclosure were  made ''on the advice of counsel'' and that he felt it had been completely appropriate, despite the result. **********And the result was a doozy -- especially for the many investors who lack split-second access to corporate documents filed with Federal regulators. **********The company, whose brands of shoes include Nine West, Amalfi, Bandolino, Enzo Angiolini and Easy Spirit, filed an amended annual report citing the investigation with the S.E.C. about 2:30 P.M. on Tuesday. The news was first reported on Federal Filings, a wire service for professional investors, at 2:49 P.M., but other major news services were slower off the mark. **********''As soon as we saw the headline on the Dow wire at 3:18 P.M., we tried to reach the company,'' a New York Stock Exchange spokesman said. After asking if further news would be issued, the Big Board halted trading at 3:51 P.M. Until then, it was likely that many of those who bought the hundreds of thousands of shares that were traded did not know what the sellers knew. The stock last traded at $32.50, down $6.125 from the last trade before the news got out. **********The Big Board was in ''continuing discussions'' with Nine West on Tuesday night and into yesterday morning about ''whether there would be further disclosure,'' the spokesman said. The ''culmination of those discussions'' was a news release at midmorning, after which trading resumed at 1:08 P.M.. yesterday. The company's shares closed at $34.125 each, up $1.625. **********The news release by Nine West gave a bit more information about the S.E.C.'s concerns, which it said focused on accounting methods used by divisions it acquired when it bought the footwear operations of the U.S. Shoe Corporation in May 1995. In addition, Mr. Galvin held a conference call with Wall Street professionals, and offered another tidbit: The dispute concerned the recognition of revenue from wholesale distribution and covered only sales after the acquisition and before the end of Nine West's 1996 fiscal year on Feb. 1, 1996. **********But ''on advice of counsel,'' he did not say very much more about the dispute, other than to insist that it would not be financially important to the company. **********Thus, much remains vague as trading opens today. **********What does the S.E.C. think might be wrong with the way the company measured its revenue? Mr. Galvin would not say, either in the conference call or a later interview, and S.E.C. officials declined to comment as a matter of policy. **********There is one aspect of wholesale distribution that might give rise to serious accounting disputes. The company puts revenue on its books when it ships shoes to wholesale customers, those who resell the shoes through noncompany outlets like department stores. It makes allowances for estimated returns and discounts that it may have to give the stores for slow-moving styles. A lawyer familiar with S.E.C. operations noted that some companies had increased reported revenues by making confidential side deals with customers that reduced or removed the customers' risks. **********The company said it did not know why the informal inquiry by the S.E.C. staff, which began last fall, escalated to a formal investigation.  A formal investigation gives the S.E.C. subpoena power, and companies will often do everything they can to cooperate to avoid having subpoenas issued, particularly to customers. Mr. Galvin said the company was cooperating with the commission, but would not say whether the S.E.C. staff agreed. He said he did not know of any subpoenas that had been issued. **********Why did the company wait until Tuesday to disclose something it learned last Thursday? The company said it took time to consult with its lawyers. **********If the accounting was faulty, how much did it affect earnings? That answer will remain unavailable until more information is released.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/29/busin.snippet: Financial services advertisers are reassessing their sales pitches after stock market's wild swings; some are changing how they talk to customers and potential customers, while others are sticking with their campaigns (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/29/busin.main_headline: New Ad Themes Come With Tumult in Market
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/29/busin.print_headline: New Ad Themes Come With Tumult in Market
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/29/busin.body_text: **********There has been frenzied activity in the last two days at the intersection of Wall Street and Madison Avenue as financial services advertisers reassess their sales pitches after the stock market's wild swings. Some are changing how they talk to customers and potential customers, while others are sticking with their campaigns. **********''We are making adjustments to our advertising as we speak,'' said Michael J. Hines, vice president for marketing and communications at the Prudential Insurance Company of America in Newark. **********''We're in the process of shipping out for tomorrow to various newspapers an ad that says, 'A Prudential reminder: The market is volatile but your investment strategy shouldn't be,' '' Mr. Hines said, adding that a television version was also being produced to run in local markets today and nationally tomorrow. **********The Prudential Securities unit ran a newspaper ad Sunday about bonds after markets fell sharply last week and reran that ad yesterday -- a day after the Dow Jones industrial average plunged 554.26 points. **********''People are expecting the company to have something to say'' when markets move so frantically, Mr. Hines said. ''If you just go under a rock when the going gets tough, people don't think you're relevant.'' **********Robyn Tice, a spokeswoman for Fidelity Investments, a unit of the FMR Corporation in Boston, said that her company had been ''refocusing our advertising in the last 24 hours in light of the market.'' **********''The themes we're emphasizing right now,'' she added, ''are that Fidelity provides a variety of tools and access to information for investors and that we're long-term investors and our customers should have long-term horizons.'' **********One company, E*Trade Group in Palo Alto, Calif., is considering some short-term changes for print ads and banner ads on World Wide Web sites. **********''There may be a tactical opportunity to demonstrate the benefits of electronic trading in an up-and-down market,'' said Sheri Baron, president and strategic planning director for the E*Trade advertising agency, the Gotham Inc. unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies in New York. **********''But the advertising we're running that is long-term brand-building advertising will not be significantly impacted by this,'' she added. **********Several companies and their agencies said they would not change their advertising or marketing plans. **********''You always have a contingency plan because declines are something you always worry about on a short-term basis,'' said Ron Berger, a partner at Messner Berger Vetere McNamee Schmetterer Euro RSCG in New York, a unit of Havas Advertising that handles campaigns for Oppenheimer Funds Inc. and the Nasdaq stock market. **********''But by the time we got a chance to talk about the market,'' he added, ''it went up 150 points.'' **********Besides, Mr. Berger said, ''for Oppenheimer, we talk about 'The right way to invest,' which is that if you're in the marketplace, you ought to be in for the long haul.'' **********Judy Torello, a spokeswoman for the Bates Worldwide unit of Cordiant P.L.C. in New York, which creates ads for the T. Rowe Price Associates mutual funds, said that her agency planned no changes in those ads ''consistent with a long-term view.'' **********Others who said there would probably be no changes in their campaigns included Donny Deutsch, chief executive of Deutsch Inc. in New York, which works for AIM Management Group, a mutual funds company; Emily Porter, a spokeswoman for the American Express Company in New York, and Nancy Mitchell, a spokeswoman for Charles Schwab & Company in San Francisco.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/21/world.snippet: Gunman believed to be Palestinian militant kills Yeshiva student Gabriel Hirschberg and critically wounds his friend in Jerusalem (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/21/world.main_headline: A Jew's Slaying Fuels Tensions in Jerusalem's Muslim Quarter
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/21/world.print_headline: A Jew's Slaying Fuels Tensions in Jerusalem's Muslim Quarter
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/21/world.body_text: **********In the alley where Gabriel Hirschberg was cut down by a burst of automatic weapons fire early today in Jerusalem's walled Old City, four of his fellow yeshiva students held a study session opposite a makeshift memorial of Israeli flags and a candle. **********Bent over religious books, the students from the Ateret Cohanim Yeshiva -- run by a right-wing group that has been buying homes in the Muslim quarter and elsewhere in East Jerusalem -- recited their lessons as Palestinian schoolgirls walked by warily, averting their eyes. **********''This is to wake people up,'' said one of the yeshiva student, sitting near a bullet-scarred wall. ''Something happened here.'' **********At about a quarter past midnight, Mr. Hirschberg, 26, was walking with a friend in the dark alley when a gunman believed to be a Palestinian militant sprayed them with automatic weapons fire. Both of the students were unarmed and unaccompanied by the yeshiva's security guards or border police who guard the area. **********Mr. Hirschberg, an immigrant from Hungary, was killed; his friend was badly wounded. (Initial reports said the second man also died.) The police said the weapon used was an AK-47 assault rifle. No arrests were reported, and there was no immediate claim of responsibility. **********The shooting seemed designed to challenge Israel's control over East Jerusalem and the recent moves to expand Jewish settlement in the area, which Palestinians see as the capital of their future state. It also raised particular alarm since it was the first anti-Israeli attack with an automatic weapon in recent memory in East Jerusalem, where most assaults have been with knives. **********''This attack with firearms here, inside the Old City, is something we're not familiar with, and we will have to treat it seriously,'' said Public Security Minister Avigdor Kahalani. **********Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu met with several cabinet ministers and security officials and announced later that a police post with several Cabinet ministers and security officials would be set up near the site of the shooting and that more security forces would be sent to the Old City. He said he had instructed the security forces to give ''top priority'' to capturing the assailants and preventing further attacks. **********''We cannot accept as self evident an attack inside the Old City, in the heart of the capital of the State of Israel,'' Mr. Netanyahu said at a news conference called to announce an inquiry into allegations by some cabinet ministers and Likud Party leaders of improprieties at a party convention last week. **********Mr. Netanyahu said that Israel would maintain ''all of Jerusalem under Israeli sovereignty and under law and order.'' **********''We will not compromise, neither in the war against terrorism nor on our hold in Jerusalem,'' he said. **********The Ateret Cohanim settlement group has operated with funding from American supporters, including Irving I. Moskowitz, the Miami physician who caused a storm two months ago when settlers moved into a house he had bought in the Arab neighborhood of Ras al-Amud outside the Old City. **********Mati Dan, the director of Ateret Cohanim, said that the shooting was meant to disrupt what he called coexistence between Arabs and Jews in the quarter. ''This attack did not come from here,'' he said. ''The terrorist organizations want to disrupt normal life, and they are uncomfortable with the fact that we live as good neighbors.'' But many Arabs see the Jewish presence as an intrusion.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/11/busin.snippet: American Assn of Advertising Agencies steps up efforts to recruit members of minority groups for agency industry by establishing independent charitable foundation that will provide college scholarships (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/11/busin.body_text: **********The American Association of Advertising Agencies in New York is stepping up efforts to recruit members of minority groups for the agency industry by establishing an independent charitable foundation that will provide college scholarships. **********To help raise funds for the foundation, the association, also known as the Four A's, will add additional prizes and categories to its annual awards competition, which will become a separate event rather than part of the Four A's annual meeting. Proceeds from entries will go to the foundation, which will also accept donations. **********The awards will be renamed the O'Toole Awards, after the late John O'Toole, a president and chief executive of the association. The competition will incorporate two previous award competitions, the A+ Creative Awards for agencies and the John O'Toole Advertiser Awards for clients.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/02/world.snippet: Russian federal security service reports arrest of Ronald L Bliss, 29-year-old American engineer working on telephone project in Rostov-on-Don, for spying; colleague was also questioned and released; Bliss is charged with importing and illegally u...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/02/world.main_headline: Russia Arrests an American And Accuses Him of Spying
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/02/world.print_headline: Russia Arrests an American And Accuses Him of Spying
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/02/world.body_text: **********An American businessman working on a telephone project in Rostov-on-Don has been arrested as a spy, the Russian federal security service said today. **********The businessman, Ronald L. Bliss, 29, is an engineer for Qualcomm, a telecommunications company based in San Diego that recently signed a contract with a Russian concern, Elektrosviaz, to install a wireless communications network in Rostov. He was arrested on Nov. 25 and has been in custody since. A colleague was also questioned, then released. **********The Russian federal security service said Mr. Bliss was charged with importing and illegally using a satellite receiver to conduct topographic measurements and others intended to determine the shortest distance between points. **********''The information gathered by Bliss from restricted sites in the cities of Rostov and Bataysk is secret,'' a statement from Russia's security service said. **********The United States Embassy in Moscow vehemently denied the charges. ''Mr. Bliss is a private-sector businessman,'' Richard Hoagland, the American Embassy spokesman here said. ''He has no connection with the U.S. Government, and he is not a spy.'' **********There have been a number of cases of Westerners being detained while using surveillance equipment in sensitive areas or near military posts. The Rostov case was reminscent of at least one other incident where an American with advanced telecommunications equipment was arrested as a spy by local representatives of the Russian Security Service, which in Soviet times was known as the K.G.B. **********Aleksandr Zdanovich, director of public relations for the security service, said Mr. Bliss probably ''did it on his own initiative, having nothing to do with the interests of the firm.'' **********He said an investigation would determine whether the company was also culpable. ''The work of intelligence and counterintelligence never stops under any circumstances,'' he added. **********The exact details of the Rostov case remain unclear. Qualcomm company spokesmen in San Diego said they were baffled. **********''To our knowledge Mr. Bliss's activities were all in accordance with local and federal laws,'' said Daniel O. Pegg, senior vice president of public affairs. ''All the equipment was declared on import documents, and was well-known and spelled out in the request from our Russian client, Elektrosviaz. Richard was merely doing his job as a field technician in what we hope will be the finest telecomunnications system in Russia.'' **********Qualcomm, which has plans to operate in a number of Russian cities and throughout some other former Soviet republics, opened an office in Moscow last May.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/29/busin.snippet: NPC International Inc says that it acquired 126 restaurants from Pizza Hut Inc for $56 million (S)

NPC International, based in Pittsburg, Kan., is a restaurant franchisee. Pizza Hut is a unit of Pepsico Inc., based in Purchase, N.Y. https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/25/busin.snippet: Germany and European Commission reach preliminary agreement to divert 90.7 million marks, or $51 million, in state aid to plant in state of Hesse; Karel van Miert, European Union competition commissioner, agrees to accord and will seek approval fr...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/25/busin.main_headline: Volkswagen to Divert State Aid to Plant
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/25/busin.print_headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS; Volkswagen to Divert State Aid to Plant
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/25/busin.body_text: **********Germany and the European Commission reached a preliminary accord yesterday for Volkswagen A.G. to divert 90.7 million marks, or $51 million, in state aid to a plant in the state of Hesse. Karel van Miert, the European Union competition commissioner, has agreed to the accord and will seek approval from his European Commission colleagues, according to the German Economics Ministry. The subsidies will be diverted for the expansion of VW's car parts factory in Kassel.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/06/news/.main_headline: No Desire to Become Beijing Satellite : Singapore Is Resisting The Influence of China
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/06/news/.print_headline: No Desire to Become Beijing Satellite : Singapore Is Resisting The Influence of China
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/06/news/.body_text: **********SINGAPORE—                     Since the end of the Cold War, Singapore — the only country with an ethnic Chinese majority in Southeast Asia — has developed increasingly close ties with China. **********It has major investment and trade with the mainland, while Beijing's Communist rulers frequently send delegations to Singapore to learn how the island-state maintains one-party dominance of government and a booming free-market economy. **********In some ways, China's great experiment with "a socialist market econ- **********omy" that combines capitalism with political control is Singapore writ large. **********Yet on their frequent visits to China, Singapore's leaders — many of whom speak Chinese — insist that official talks are conducted through an English-language interpreter. And when Beijing staged missile tests and large-scale military exercises near Taiwan ahead of the Taiwan's presidential elections in 1996, Singapore was one of the few countries in Southeast Asia to warn publicly against the use of force. **********The point is not lost on China or on Singapore's neighbors. **********Singapore's "foreign-policy equilibrium is seriously threatened by China's increased assertiveness on East Asia's strategic stage," said Tim Huxley, director of the department of Southeast Asian studies at the University of Hull in England. "Singapore's ethnic composition and strong economic links with China could leave the city-state dangerously exposed in an increasingly hostile, anti-Chinese regional environment." **********As China emerges as a major power, Singapore's government is stepping up its efforts to prove that it will never allow the emotional tug of Chinese language and culture to turn Singapore into an offshoot of the Chinese mainland. **********The issue emerged as a major point of contention in the general elections in Singapore last week, when the government accused an ethnic Chinese opposition candidate, Tang Liang Hong of the Workers' Party, of espousing policies to turn the island into a Chinese state. **********Since Singapore's independence in 1965 — which was preceded by violent race riots — the governing People's Action Party has insisted that English be the country's common language. The policy is designed to ensure that all races — Chinese, Malays, Indians and Eurasians — have equal opportunities in education and jobs. **********Ethnic Chinese account for just over 77 percent of Singapore's population, while Malays make up 14 percent and Indians 7 percent. **********"China will grow stronger over the next 20 years, and Chinese will become an important language internationally," said Goh Chok Tong, an ethnic Chinese who is Singapore's prime minister. "Unless we take a clear stand now, there will be a powerful temptation for a Chinese electorate to push for a more prominent role for Chinese language and culture. This will be a very serious problem for Singapore. We are not a Chinese country, and we must never allow Chinese chauvinists to turn us into one." **********Mr. Tang of the Workers' Party has denied being a Chinese chauvinist, and each side has threatened to sue the other for defamation. **********The debate has struck a chord elsewhere in Southeast Asia, where Singapore — with a population of just 3 million — is dwarfed by its neighbors, Indonesia, Malaysia and the Philippines. **********Those countries have a combined population of nearly 300 million, most of whom are of Malay stock, although ethnic Chinese minorities have a disproportionately large influence in trade and commerce. **********Indonesia and the Philippines are suspicious of China's long-term intentions toward the region, and both Malaysia and the Philippines have conflicting claims with China to ownership of some of the Spratly Islands in the South China Sea. **********Singapore occupies a key strategic position on the Malacca Strait, the main maritime channel for ships sailing between the Pacific and Indian oceans. **********Lee Kuan Yew, another ethnic Chinese who is Singapore's senior minister, warned during the election campaign that if Singapore — which currently allows U.S. military forces access to its bases — became a Chinese state, it would invite interference not just from neighbors but from outside powers wary of China's influence. **********"A lot of countries will want to interfere, and these will not be just our neighbors in the region," Mr. Lee said. "Big countries in the international community will not allow a China base in Southeast Asia."

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/12/busin.snippet: Shares of Kulicke & Soffa Industries plunge 27 percent after company says that earnings for current quarter will not meet expectations because South Korean chip makers are delaying orders (S)

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/12/busin.body_text: **********Shares of Kulicke & Soffa Industries plunged 27 percent today after the company said that earnings for the current quarter would not meet expectations because South Korean chip makers were delaying orders. **********Kulicke & Soffa, a semiconductorproduction-equipment maker based in Willow Grove, Pa., west of here, said uncertainty among Korean customers was causing some orders for this quarter to be rescheduled later. **********The stock fell $6.75 today, to $18.125, in Nasdaq volume of 3.5 million shares. **********South Korea produces about one-third of the world's memory chips, casting it as an important market for semiconductor-equipment makers like Kulicke & Soffa. **********The company said that earnings for its first fiscal quarter, ending on Dec. 31, would fall below a First Call analysts' consensus of 38 cents a share. A year earlier, Kulicke had earnings of $419,000, or 2 cents a share, on revenue of $81.8 million. **********The company said it was still assessing the likely effects of the Korean crisis on the rest of the fiscal year. It also said that underlying demand for semiconductors was strong and that its customers would continue to add capacity through the year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/19/your-.main_headline: Why to Seek Safety in Foreign Stocks
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/19/your-.print_headline: Why to Seek Safety in Foreign Stocks
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/19/your-.body_text: **********IS THE correction over? That's the question everyone seems to be asking. My answer is, "I don't know, and you shouldn't care." **********The prices of stocks, in concert or individually, bounce up and down in the short run, but in the long run they produce annual returns of 8 percent in real terms, or about 11 percent with today's inflation. **********In fact, stocks are such a great deal that, for years, economists have been trying to explain something they call the "equity premium puzzle." In plain English, they wonder why it is that stocks return so much, compared with investments like Treasury bills. **********The best explanation seems to be that investors are extremely — indeed, irrationally — risk-averse. A century of history shows that if you can hold onto your stocks for at least 10 years, even in the face of some big price drops, you'll end up making very good money. But many investors can't stand that kind of volatility, so, in economic terms, they demand higher returns to compensate. **********Risk aversion is simply a fact, and when it comes to stocks, nearly everyone is scared. And that fear causes investors to do some stupid things, such as selling a perfectly good stock because it has dropped. For that reason, it's vital to invest in a way that protects you from yourself. **********In simple terms, this means a less risky portfolio — one that's not so susceptible to the extremes of the market's ups and (especially) downs. You can buy bonds or money-market funds, of course, but then you'll sacrifice profits. What's surprising is that there's a way to lower risk while raising your returns. **********The answer is a carefully balanced combination of foreign and U.S. stocks. "Diversifying Overseas," an excellent new publication from T. Rowe Price, the Baltimore-based mutual-fund house (1-800-638-5660), explains the phenomenon by examining returns and risk of international equities over the past 20 years. **********A portfolio consisting of only U.S. stocks "had an average annualized return of about 14.5% . . . and a standard deviation of 14, meaning that two-thirds of the time, the annual return was within a range of 0% to 28%." **********But as more foreign stocks were added to the mix, "the portfolio's returns increased, but the degree or volatility, or risk, actually declined." **********Return up, risk down! You can't beat that combination. But it doesn't last forever. If you keep adding foreign stocks to your portfolio, return will rise, but so will risk. Price researchers found that the optimal risk/reward allocation "was about 30% foreign and 70% U.S. stocks." **********That ideal ratio produced a 14.75 percent return at a standard deviation of 12.95. A portfolio that's 60 percent foreign and 40 percent American had the same deviation as an all-American portfolio but returned nearly 15 percent. A portfolio that's 100 percent foreign had a return of 15.25 percent but with a very high standard deviation of 18. **********As you can see, foreign stocks by themselves are riskier than U.S. stocks. So why does overall risk decline when you add riskier foreign stocks to your U.S. holdings? Because the two kinds of stocks don't move in tandem. When American stocks fall sharply in a year, foreign stocks may rise, or at least not fall so much, so they provide ballast for your portfolio. **********Let's look at the last four years, during which foreign stocks have been underperforming domestic. A 70-30 mix of U.S.-foreign stocks produced an average annual return of 17.0 percent vs. 17.8 percent for an all-U.S. portfolio. But the 70-30 mix was less risky. Its annual returns went from a low of 3 percent to a high of 30 percent, compared to range of 1 percent to 37 percent for the all-U.S. portfolio. **********Will foreign stocks continue to lag, especially with the U.S. economy so far ahead of those in Europe and Japan? Don't count on it. In fact, with unemployment high (11.3 percent for Germany) and growth low (0.8 percent for France), many countries may be hitting bottom, their stocks ripe for purchase. **********Get diversified into foreign stocks. In a rocky market like this, it can save you from your own worst instincts.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/19/busin.snippet: Internship experts estimate that 50 to 60 percent of all student internships are unpaid; they say figure is closer to 100 percent in glamorous fields like entertainment and politics; there are plenty of paid internships, some of them with bigger p...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/19/busin.main_headline: Glamorous Internships With a Catch: There's No Pay
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/19/busin.print_headline: EARNING IT; Glamorous Internships With a Catch: There's No Pay
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/19/busin.body_text: **********HOPE WAGNER, a sports administration major, scored a dream summer job. **********Ms. Wagner, a senior at the University of Nebraska at Kearney, worked in the media relations department of a professional sports team. She drafted news releases, clipped newspaper articles and helped with community relations programs. **********Her big project, the one that will be front and center on her resume, was a 75-page media guide for the coming season, which  she helped finish over Labor Day weekend. **********Ms. Wagner, one of five interns, took home plenty of souvenirs from the team -- T-shirts, bumper stickers, key chains and watches -- but not a penny, not even gas money for all the errands she ran. **********She was an unpaid intern, one of thousands of students working for nothing but experience and, sometimes, for college credit. **********''They treated me well while I was there, but I just think the whole idea of unpaid internships isn't fair,'' Ms. Wagner said. ''At times I just got so frustrated thinking how many hours I put in for free.'' **********Internship experts estimate that 50 to 60 percent of all student internships are unpaid. The figure is closer to 100 percent in glamorous fields like entertainment and politics, they say. **********To be sure, there are plenty of paid internships, some of them with bigger paychecks than the students' parents earn. **********Intel, the chip maker, pays undergraduates $450 to $750 a week and provides moving expenses, discounted housing and a free rental car, according to ''America's Top Internships'' and ''The Internship Bible,'' sister guides that are part of the Princeton Review series by Random House. **********Interns at General Motors earn $450 to $600 a week and receive health insurance, paid vacation days and round-trip travel, according to ''The Internship Bible.'' **********BUT internship listings often show no compensation. And the programs  aren't all offered by struggling nonprofit organizations or small businesses. The Princeton books and ''The Yale Daily News Guide to Internships'' list unpaid internships for well-known businesses like Barney's New York, Merrill Lynch and NBC. **********Although internships seem largely unregulated, there is a law governing the programs. The Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938, which established minimum wage and overtime protections for workers, lists six criteria employers must meet for interns to be considered trainees and thus not guaranteed the minimum wage. Even internships that offer academic credit must comply. **********Labor lawyers zero in on two stipulations:  the intern cannot displace a regular employee and the company must derive no immediate advantage from the student's work. **********''The bottom line here is whether the activities primarily benefit the individual or the employer,'' said a spokesman for the  Labor Department. **********Ms. Wagner's internship experience was not uncommon, and neither was that of Kerrie Brown, a St. Bonaventure University student, two years ago. Ms. Brown, now a senior, worked for a small cable television station in Maryland. She wanted to get a taste of broadcast journalism and was told she would learn about news writing, production and more. All she did was answer phones and watch television for commercials the station produced. **********''They had me doing secretarial work that they should have been paying someone else to do,'' she said, adding that she quit when a paid internship opened up at a local newspaper. **********So how do so many businesses and organizations continue diving into a gigantic pool of free labor year after year? **********College career counselors and others say various factors are at play. First, the law is not aggressively enforced and is somewhat ambiguous. Second, there is no shortage of applicants for unpaid positions, especially in glamorous fields. **********And both the interns and the businesses seem to enjoy, or at least tolerate, the benefits of the system enough to not rock the boat. Interns can gain invaluable training and good credentials, and there is not much of an incentive for blowing the whistle; the businesses gain free labor and a first peek at workers who are about to graduate. **********''In the 12 years I've been in the field I've never heard of a case where an employer has been even chastised for abusing that law,'' said Dawn Pettit, executive director of the Cooperative Education Association, an organization in Columbia, Md., that promotes work-classroom programs. **********A Pittsburgh labor lawyer, Donald O'Connor, said there had been some cases, including one nearly three years ago in which a public relations agency reached a settlement over billing of clients for the unpaid work of interns. The firm agreed to pay more than $30,000 in back pay to a group of former interns and to pay future interns. **********The Labor Department says there have not been many violations, but concedes that it typically does not investigate a company unless there are complaints. **********''It's not like we have an enforcement program focused on interns,'' the Labor Department spokesman said. **********Ms. Pettit said she would be concerned if a student's unpaid work contributed to big profits. **********''When the student is going there and they're part of a team working on a project ultimately resulting in millions of dollars of income -- some software program, for example -- then, no, it's not fair if she's the only one not being paid,'' she said. **********Unpaid internships, however, may be seen as a rite of corporate passage. As Samer Hamadeh, 28, co-author of ''The Internship Bible'' and ''America's Top Internships'' says, ''This is the way you break into the work world in America.'' **********The numbers bear that out. Some internships attract a flood of applicants. ''America's Top Internships,'' for example, says the ''Late Show with David Letterman'' gets about 750 applicants for 30 unpaid positions,  even though they rate high on the guide's busy-work meter -- running lots of errands, making copies and answering phones. Penguin Books gets about 200 applications for eight unpaid positions in editorial, marketing, sales and other departments, while 250 applicants vie for one summer internship at Elite Model Management in Beverly Hills, Calif., the Yale guide said. **********Mr. Hamadeh, whose internships included a paid stint pumping airplane grease through pipes for Chevron, now hires interns and pays them. But he said there were additional costs for a company. **********''You have to spend a lot more time training them,'' he said. ''They're often much younger and have no office skills.'' **********The companies would ''never hire any of these people otherwise,'' he added. **********INCREASINGLY, said Jack Tinker, director of career services for Connecticut College in New London, Conn., potential employers want -- and schools require -- work experience. And that encourages the current system, with would-be interns unwilling to demand pay. **********Mr. Hamadeh, quoting figures from the National Society of Experiential Education, said that as recently as 1981, just one in 36 college graduates had done an internship.  Ten years later, the figure jumped to one in three. Mr. Hamadeh said that more recent surveys put the figure at about two out of three. **********Supporters of unpaid internships say the benefits outweigh the short-term sacrifices. **********''Our students are coming out with contacts, they're coming out with confidence, they're coming out with stronger resumes,'' said Laura McKaie, assistant dean of career education at the Long Island University Brooklyn campus, where the median age is 26 and many students support families. **********Internships are especially crucial in industries where contacts are the only way in the door. Steve Cook, a 1997 graduate of Northwestern University's film school, said the Hollywood jobs in which he was interested were not advertised, so it was essential to have a network of people to call regularly. **********Mr. Cook, who just directed his first film, ''The Choir Invisible,'' started internships as soon as he graduated from the Lawrenceville School near Princeton, N.J. He spent his college summers in California, working without pay for companies including Hollywood Pictures, NBC, the Gersh Agency and Prufrock Pictures, the actress Meg Ryan's production company. **********Despite her frustrations and empty bank account, Ms. Wagner said she would do her  internship with the sports team all over again. She sought the job and volunteered to do the media guide, for which the team was prepared to hire a graphics artist. **********''I thought it would be a good opportunity for me to try something big like that,'' she said. Ms. Wagner lived with her parents, who took care of her bills.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/08/world.snippet: United States says Federal Bureau of Investigation probes intercepted conversation between Israeli intelligence officer in Washington and superior in Israel that suggests Israel has intelligence source that can obtain confidential American diploma...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/08/world.main_headline: F.B.I. Inquiry: Is Israel Using Mole in U.S.?
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/08/world.print_headline: F.B.I. Inquiry: Is Israel Using Mole in U.S.?
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/08/world.body_text: **********The F.B.I. is investigating an intercepted conversation that suggested the Israeli Government has an intelligence source that can obtain confidential American diplomatic material, United States officials said today. **********But they said the investigation, which arose after American intelligence eavesdropped on a conversation between the Israeli Embassy here and Tel Aviv, has so far been inconclusive. **********Officials said the inquiry has not yet determined whether the possible intelligence source, referred to in the conversation by what appeared to be a code name, is from another country or the United States. One official suggested that the F.B.I. has identified no suspect in the case. **********Israeli officials today flatly denied allegations that they are engaged in espionage in the United States or that Israel has a mole in the American Government handing over documents. **********''Israel does not indulge in any kind of illegal action in information gathering in the United States,'' said David Bar-Illan, the chief spokesman for Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu. **********The existence of the intercept was first disclosed by a report today in The Washington Post, which described the intercept of a conversation between an Israeli intelligence officer in Washington and his superior in Tel Aviv. **********Quoting ''sources with direct knowledge of the inquiry,'' The Post said the Washington-based Israeli wanted guidance on whether he should go to ''Mega'' for a copy of a letter written by Warren M. Christopher, then Secretary of State, to the Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat. **********According to The Post, the Washington-based Israeli said in Hebrew that ''the Ambassador wants me to go to Mega to get a copy of this letter.'' The supervisor in Tel Aviv reportedly said: ''This is not something we use Mega for.'' **********An American Government official today confirmed that the F.B.I. is investigating the intercept ''and what it means.'' Among the many possibilities under investigation, officials said, are whether Mega refers to an American citizen or someone from a third country. **********One Israeli official acknowledged  that in mid-January ''a lot of people wanted this letter,'' which was published two weeks later in the Israeli newspaper Ha'aretz. But this official said that ''to jump to the conclusion that there is an American official manipulated by Israel or paid by them is a jump too far.'' **********The official confirmed that Israeli officials often used code names in trans-Atlantic conversations and said: ''Maybe that's not the exact code name. Maybe it's not a person, but a code name for an organization or a method.'' **********American officials said they would have no official comment on the report. After the usual consultation among agencies, a State Department spokesman, John Dinger, said: ''We don't comment as a matter of policy on alleged intelligence matters.'' **********The Israeli Ambassador here, Eliahu Ben Elissar, also denied the allegations of spying in vehement terms. ''The story is absolutely baseless,'' he said. ''Israel is not involved in any kind of espionage or trying to obtain intelligence from the United States. We work only in diplomatic channels in the framework of friendly relations with the United States.'' **********And in Jerusalem, a senior official in Mr. Netanyahu's office said: ''Israel does not use intelligence agents in the U.S. Period.'' **********Still, senior Western diplomats expressed skepticism about the blanket Israeli denial of espionage here, and one American official who did not want to be identified pointed to the case of Jonathan Pollard. Mr. Pollard, an American who was working as a civilian intelligence analyst for the Navy, was arrested in 1985 and pleaded guilty in 1986 to spying for Israel and remains in prison serving a life sentence. **********Israeli officials insisted then that Mr. Pollard had been recruited in an operation run outside normal, authorized channels by Rafael Eitan, who worked for the Defense Ministry and the Prime Minister's Office. **********But the Pollard case did great damage to relations between the United States and Israel, one Israeli official said, He noted that there has been no formal accusation since of Israel spying against the United States. **********The letter in question was a set of assurances given to Mr. Arafat by Mr. Christopher on Jan. 16 and represented part of the accords reached with American mediation about the withdrawal of Israeli troops from most of the West Bank city of Hebron. A parallel letter to the Israelis was made public by Mr. Netanyahu, but Mr. Arafat did not do the same. The letter assured the Palestinians that Israeli commitments to them were viewed by the Americans as commitments to them, as well.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/02/busin.snippet: Luther G Simjian, inventor, dies at age 92; photo (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/02/busin.main_headline: Luther Simjian Is Dead at 92; Held More Than 200 Patents
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/02/busin.print_headline: Luther Simjian Is Dead at 92; Held More Than 200 Patents
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/02/busin.body_text: **********Luther G. Simjian, a prolific inventor who held patents on devices as diverse as the flight simulator, the self-focusing camera, the automated teller machine and the Teleprompter, died at his home in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., on Oct. 23. He was 92. **********During an inventing career that spanned seven decades, Mr. Simjian, a Turk who immigrated to the United States at the age of 16, held more than 200 domestic and international patents, most in electronics and optics. **********''Many called him the second Thomas A. Edison,'' said Richard G. Snyder, president of Reflectone Inc., a company in Tampa, Fla., that Mr. Simjian founded in 1939. **********Initially educated in the Middle East and France, Mr. Simjian finished his secondary education in New Haven, where he lived with an uncle. **********Taken with the idea of studying medicine, Mr. Simjian, after finishing high school, began to work in the photographic laboratory at the Yale University Medical School. **********But he proved so deft with a camera that thoughts of studying medicine were set aside, and in 1928 Mr. Simjian was named the first director of a newly created photography department at the Yale Medical School. **********While at Yale, Mr. Simjian patented several new devices, including the self-focusing camera in 1932 and a color X-ray machine in 1934. **********In 1939, he founded Reflectone, which was initially based in Stamford, Conn., to develop and manufacture his inventions. **********Disturbed by the deaths of many contemporaries and friends during World War II, Mr. Simjian invented the Optical Range Estimation Trainer, the first flight simulator of its kind, to train pilots and tail gunners. **********In the early 1960's, Reflectone was merged with the Universal Match Company. Later, it was spun off as an independent, public company and earlier this year was sold for about $90 million to the British Aerospace Company. It remains in the business of making full-flight simulators for commercial and military aircraft. **********Mr. Simjian subsequently formed two other companies, General Research Inc. and Command Automation Inc. as umbrella organizations for his increasingly eclectic list of inventions. **********Over the years, those included a supersonic exploring device for the ultrasound procedures used in hospitals, a method for tenderizing meat and a remote controlled postage meter. **********''One thing I discovered about myself in the early days of my life is that I can't stick with just one idea for too long,'' Mr. Simjian wrote in a autobiography that was privately published earlier this year. **********In the 1960's, he received more than 20 patents on ideas that form the basis of automated banking, from the notion of creating a machine that could accept deposits and dispense cash at any hour. **********In his autobiography, Mr. Simjian said he had doubts about whether  bank customers would place their faith in a machine to take their money ''with no proof of what they had put in other than a printed receipt.'' **********Indeed, a precursor of what is now Citicorp took a few of Mr. Simjian's machines on a trial basis, but after about six months the bank, which later became the first big user of such machines, told him they had only limited appeal, according to Mr. Simjian's autobiography. **********''It seems the only people who were using the machines were a small number of prostitutes and gamblers who didn't want to deal with tellers face to face,'' Mr. Simjian wrote. ''And the bank said there were not enough of them to make the deal lucrative.'' **********A golfer, Mr. Simjian developed and patented a computerized indoor golf practice range during the 1960's. When a ball is struck, an analog computer calculates and projects its flight on a screen. In 1973, he created an exercise bike that massages the torso while the rider pedals. **********''He once sent me a swivel chair he invented that allowed you to sit at a dressing table and look at your hair from four different angles,'' said Bobbie Kay Stafford, an associate at the New York brokerage firm of Melhado, Flynn & Associates. She was Mr. Simjian's stockbroker for the last 16 years of his life. **********Indeed, despite failing eyesight, Mr. Simjian kept on inventing until his death. In March, he received his last patent, for a process designed to improve the resonance of wood used in making musical instruments. **********In 1978, in recognition of his work,  Mr. Simjian received the Eli Whitney Award by the Connecticut Patent Law Association. **********He is survived by his wife, the former Gladys Cannon, of Fort Lauderdale; a daughter, Maryjo S. Garre of Barrington, Ill., and three grandchildren.
