https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/17/busin.snippet: Growing multibillion-dollar struggle to acquire MCI Communications Corp highlights feeding frenzy in telecommunications industry for investment bankers and lawyers, those profit-hungry advisers who counsel both sides of merger; as British Telecomm...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/17/busin.main_headline: As MCI Fight Grows, the Wall St. Entourage Builds
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/17/busin.print_headline: As MCI Fight Grows, the Wall St. Entourage Builds
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/17/busin.body_text: **********The growing multibillion-dollar struggle to acquire the MCI Communications Corporation highlights the feeding frenzy in the telecommunications industry for investment bankers and lawyers, those profit-hungry pilot fish who  counsel both predator and quarry in big acquisitions and mergers. **********As British Telecommunications, Worldcom and now the GTE Corporation all vie to spend tens of billions of dollars in cash or stock to buy MCI, a growing list of Wall Street's finest financiers and lawyers have turned up in the deals. **********To begin with, Lazard Freres & Company advised MCI while N. M. Rothschild of London and Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter, Discover & Company counseled British Telecom when the first proposal was made earlier this year. **********Then Salomon Brothers appeared as adviser to Worldcom, when that upstart telecommunications company stunned the business world with its $30 billion all-stock bid on Oct. 1. MCI added Lehman Brothers as an adviser alongside Lazard. And now Goldman, Sachs & Company and the Bear Stearns Companies have appeared as advisers for GTE, MCI's latest suitor. **********Merrill Lynch & Company, Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, and Credit Suisse First Boston, which have all spent millions of dollars building big telecommunications banking practices in recent years, are perhaps the few well-known Wall Street names in the telecommunications investment banking business not yet to be involved in this deal. Indeed, so many firms are involved that many of the industry's best analysts can no longer speak publicly about the deal because their firms are working on it. **********Don't spare too much thought for these or the other banks and financial advisers building telecommunications practices, though. There is quite enough business to go around as this industry, already with estimated worldwide revenues of $700 billion and $1 trillion of market capitalization, sets about exploiting new technologies and servicing new customers. **********Merrill, for example, is just completing a $7 billion offering of shares for France Telecom, and is also involved in privatizing telecommunications businesses in Portugal, Hungary, India and Italy. It now has 70 telecommunications bankers, up from just 15 four years ago, according to Thomas S. Middleton, a managing director and co-head of the firm's global telecommunications investment banking. **********The battle for MCI is affecting just about all the Wall Street bankers who specialize in telecommunications as well -- whether they're directly involved in the transaction or not. **********''All of us are scrambling to stay up with the events unfolding here, and the way big companies are thinking about their businesses,'' said Colin R. Knudsen, a managing director at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. ''If you'd asked me six months ago whether there was a chance of a bidding war for MCI, I would have said not a chance. This will change everything in the telecommunications industry.'' **********Big law firms are making out handsomely in the maneuvering for MCI, too. Simpson Thacher & Bartlett is advising MCI, while Cravath, Swaine & Moore counsels Worldcom, and Shearman & Sterling represents British Telecom. O'Melveny & Myers and Fried, Frank, Harris, Shriver & Jacobson are said to be working with GTE, according to people involved in the bids. **********Yet more law firms and investment banks may soon join in the jostling around MCI. The current guessing game on Wall Street is what other players may enter the game next. **********''In the light of what is going on, what is AT&T doing? The Baby Bells, how long can they sit on the sidelines?'' said one senior telecommunications investment banker yesterday, who spoke on condition of anonymity. **********The prize for the investment bankers who actually do a deal as large as this one is considerable: a likely fee of more than $30 million for the acquirer's advising bank or banks, and a sum of several millions for MCI's financial advisers. But even those firms involved with the also-rans will pick up valuable scraps -- a few million dollars in fees. **********If and when an agreement to sell MCI is struck, there will be a huge amount of follow-up business for Wall Street, as well as for the big commercial banks, such as Chase Manhattan, Nationsbank, Citicorp, J. P. Morgan and BankAmerica that specialize in financing telecommunications, bankers said yesterday. There would, for instance, be asset sales and restructuring as the new merged company sorted out its combined operations. **********The activity in the telecommunications banking business has been good for Wall Street's headhunters, who said yesterday that only the growth of health care investment banking has come close to matching it in recent years. **********''It's obvious that telecommunications people who know about the industry are going for premiums on Wall Street,'' said Dirk A. Himes, a vice president at A. T. Kearney, an international executive search firm based in Chicago. **********''There has been more recruiting in telecommunications,'' said his colleague, Joseph C. Haberman, in the firm's New York office. The surge is ''between them and health care and gaming, the emerging growth sectors of the economy where there is a lot of capital-raising.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/07/world.snippet: Pres Mobutu Sese Seko of Zaire will make state visit to Gabon, a trip is widely seen as way for him to escape before rebels capture his capital, Kinshasa; diplomats from United States, South Africa and other nations have been working in last few d...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/07/world.main_headline: In Zaire, a Signal That Mobutu May Depart Today
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/07/world.print_headline: In Zaire, a Signal That Mobutu May Depart Today
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/07/world.body_text: **********With rebel forces pressing ahead in a campaign to capture this city, state television announced this evening that President Mobutu Sese Seko would leave the country on Wednesday for a three-day visit to nearby Gabon -- a trip that is widely seen here as a way for him to escape before his capital falls. **********The announcement came a day after the rebel leader, Laurent Kabila, threatened to hunt down Mr. Mobutu and his closest supporters in the streets if the President did not resign. **********The official explanation for the trip is a meeting of French-speaking regional leaders to discuss the crisis that is gripping Rwanda, Burundi and Zaire. Officials were quick to insist that the President would return afterward. ''It is almost certain that Mr. Mobutu will leave tomorrow,'' said a senior Presidential aide. ''He will return by all means from Gabon on Friday.'' **********But another member of the Presidential entourage, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said, ''We all expect that after Gabon he will go to the hospital somewhere for treatment.'' Mr. Mobutu, 66, is suffering from prostate cancer, and spent several months in France for treatment over the last year. **********Diplomats from the United States, South Africa and other countries have been working steadily in the last few days to ease Mr. Mobutu out of power and avoid a violent takeover of this crowded city of five million by the rebel forces. **********If Mr. Mobutu departs on Wednesday as planned, he will be able to leave his country on official business, as head of state, rather than surrendering to Mr. Kabila or simply resigning, something he has vowed never to do. **********With Mr. Mobutu gone, diplomats here say there would be far less chance that the Special Presidential Division, a loyalist guard drawn from Mr. Mobutu's own northern Ngbandi tribe and related ethnic groups, would mount a last-ditch battle to defend the city from capture. **********Tension has risen steadily in this city in recent days along with expectations of an imminent rebel arrival. Kinshasa has already been heavily looted twice this decade by Government soldiers, and many fear a repetition of the destruction if soldiers here were to panic. **********Unconfirmed reports from rebel sources said that Government soldiers pillaged Gbadolite, Mr. Mobutu's hometown and site of his principal palace, today. Mr. Kabila's forces recently took Mr. Mobutu's birthplace, Lisala, and were believed to be advancing on Gbadolite, both in Zaire's far north. **********According to diplomats and travelers arriving in Kinshasa from the south of the city, Mr. Kabila's rebels are already present in limited numbers on Kinshasa's southern outskirts, and the rebels are reported to be preparing a much larger buildup in the city of Kikwit, some 240 miles to the east. **********A Western diplomat here said he expected that once Mr. Mobutu left, the rebels would make a quick thrust to capture Kinshasa's international airport, 16 miles east of the city. Mr. Kabila has already identified the airport as a target. **********If the airport is captured, the rebel forces can begin flying troops to Kinshasa in large numbers from bases in the country's south, and from neighboring Angola, which has become Mr. Kabila's biggest backer in recent weeks. **********In a move that was interpreted by many as an effort to calm rumors of the rebels' arrival here, Mr. Mobutu's military Government announced today that it had recaptured Kikwit, and killed 500 of Mr. Kabila's men in fierce fighting. Diplomats and regional military analysts dismissed those reports. **********Government officials also reported fighting at Kenge, a rebel forward base 140 miles to the east of Kinshasa. The diplomats and analysts said, however, that the skirmishes at Kenge were likely to have involved Angolan forces from that country's Unita rebel movement hired by Mr. Mobutu to slow the rebels' advance on Kinshasa. **********The military analysts said that far from falling back into Government hands, Kikwit has become a major staging area for the rebels, who are said to be flying troops to the city of 250,000 in large numbers from Lubumbashi, in the south, and from Angola. **********''What you've had in the last couple of days is basically every kind of aircraft imaginable flying rebel troops into Kikwit,'' said a regional military analyst. ''Once Kenge is secured, they'll start flying smaller planes in there, and from there, Kinshasa is just a short hop away.'' **********At Mr. Mobutu's palace here, located in a normally tranquil military garrison known as Camp Tshatshi, the busy movement of soldiers suggested that, for the President's guard, the front lines in Zaire's war had receded all the way to the camp's entrance gates. **********Within the gates, trucks ferried soldiers and rocket launchers back and forth in front of a huge billboard painted with a portrait of Mr. Mobutu that read, ''Welcome Back Papa Marshal.'' Jittery soldiers chased away a journalist who tried for a few moments to inquire about Mr. Mobutu's family. **********For most residents of the capital today, however, life went on as normal, despite reports of the rebels' continued advance. Most of the population here seems to be eagerly awaiting Mr. Kabila's arrival, still seeing him as a liberator after more than three decades of ruinous rule by Mr. Mobutu. **********''After 32 years under one man we are saturated,'' said Jocelyn Kimbombo, a 27-year-old seamstress. ''We don't know exactly what Kabila will do for us, but we all hope that he will think about his country more than Mobutu did.'' **********Mr. Kabila's international reputation has continued to deteriorate, even as people prepare to welcome him here. **********Mr. Kabila's movement, the Alliance of Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Congo, was created with the help of Rwanda six months ago during an uprising in eastern Zaire by ethnic Tutsi there. **********Relief officials say that throughout the alliance's campaign for power in Zaire it has simultaneously waged a merciless war against the large population of Hutu refugees in Zaire, many of whom took part in the 1994 massacres of the Tutsi minority in Rwanda. **********In recent weeks the rebellion's treatment of Rwandan Hutu refugees has come under attack by foreign diplomats, United Nations relief agencies and other aid groups in Zaire. There have been reports and some direct evidence that rebel forces had a hand in killing refugees as well as in blocking relief efforts and attempts to return refugees to Rwanda. **********Emma Bonino, the European Union's commissioner for humanitarian affairs, said Mr. Kabila had turned eastern Zaire into ''a slaughterhouse,'' and publicly questioned whether the rebel leader would be an improvement over Mr. Mobutu's dictatorship. **********In recent days, international human rights investigators have said that Mr. Kabila's forces have denied them access to areas in eastern Zaire where there have been persistent reports of massacres by the rebels. **********At the same time, relief workers in the northeastern city of Kisangani have complained that rebel forces have impeded work intended to save tens of thousands of Hutu from disease and starvation after their camps were attacked by rebels and local villagers recently. **********''I don't even think that when you are dealing with cattle you treat cattle like that,'' Juan Carlos Brandt, a United Nations spokesman, said today.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/22/busin.snippet: Kimberly-Clark Corp, whose paper products such as Kleenex tissue and Scott paper goods face pricing pressure and stiffer competition, particularly in Europe, announces it will dismiss about 5,000 workers and sell or close as many as 18 plants; com...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/22/busin.main_headline: Kimberly-Clark to Dismiss 5,000 Workers and Eliminate 18 Plants
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/22/busin.print_headline: Kimberly-Clark to Dismiss 5,000 Workers and Eliminate 18 Plants
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/22/busin.body_text: **********The Kimberly-Clark Corporation said yesterday that it would dismiss 7 percent of its employees, or about 5,000 workers, and sell or close as many as 18 plants. The cuts, which will start immediately, come as  company products like Kleenex tissue and Scott paper goods are facing pricing pressure and stiffer competition. **********As a result of the cuts, the company, which also makes Huggies diapers and Kotex feminine products, will take a fourth-quarter charge of $590 million, or $1.06 a share. The company said the plan would save $200 million a year by 2000. It  described the cuts as worldwide but as for specific location would say only that 60 percent would occur in North America. **********''By consolidating facilities, we will eliminate excess, high-cost production capacity and narrow our focus to advanced technologies,'' said Wayne R. Sanders, the chairman of the company. ''We also are setting the stage for the next generation of supply chain savings, which will enable us to further streamline the way we distribute our products and provide additional funds to invest in the growth of our global brands.'' **********Kimberly-Clark, a $13 billion company based in Dallas, announced the cuts after the stock market closed. Earlier, its shares rose $1.875, to $53.75. **********Many of Kimberly-Clark's problems stem from too much capacity in its tissue business, aggressive competition, particularly in Europe, and pressure to keep prices low. The pricing issue alone will reduce operating profit by about $250 million this year. **********''The company kind of hit a pothole this year,'' said Kathryn McAuley, an analyst who follows the company for Brown Brothers Harriman. ''Their markets have been very difficult. This is an environment where you have very low inflation and it is very difficult to raise product prices, so one has to focus more on the bottom line, on the cost structure. That is what happens when prices are somewhat stagnant.'' **********Yet, since the problems are largely attributed to difficulties in the tissue business, one question is how much of the company's troubles can be attributed to its acquisition in 1995 of the Scott Paper Company, which had just undergone major surgery led by Albert J. Dunlap, a turnaround expert who has been called Chainsaw Al for the way he downsizes companies. **********Revamping of Kimberly-Clark tissue operations will account for 70 percent of the charge. And at least two of the plants scheduled for sale or closing are former Scott tissue mills, one in Winslow, Me., and the other in Marinette, Wis. **********Kimberly-Clark, which would not identify the other plants that are on the block, insisted that the announcement yesterday was not a reflection that in buying Scott it had purchased a company that was still ailing. **********''The Scott merger has been beneficial; we are achieving the expected synergies,'' said Tina Barry, a company spokeswoman. ''Our gross margins and our operating profit margins are 3 to 4 percentage points higher than pre-merger levels.'' **********The company said the cutbacks would eliminate excess production capacity, including more than 200,000 metric tons of high-cost tissue manufacturing capacity. The excess tissue capacity results from improvements in productivity and technology since the merger that the company says caused it to produce more products that it could sell. **********Even so, consolidating the companies seems to have been a tougher job than Kimberly-Clark had expected. **********''Kimberly knew the Scott facilities were older and that Dunlap had been there for a short period of time and some of the changes he made were somewhat cosmetic,'' Ms. McAuley said. ''What Kimberly had hoped was that the market would grow. The market didn't grow and that highlighted the problem with Scott.'' Nonetheless, Ms. McAuley said, the Scott acquisition was a good investment. **********Mr. Dunlap, now chairman of the Sunbeam Corporation, said yesterday that Scott, which had been losing money for years before he took it over, was a healthy company by the time Kimberly-Clark bought it. He also said the cuts announced yesterday were not surprising. **********''It says zero about the health of Scott at the time they acquired it,'' Mr. Dunlap said. ''Even if you put together two of the most efficient companies in the world, you're still going to have consolidation, just like you do in the aerospace industry or the banking industry.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/16/busin.snippet: Antitrust talks between Boeing Co. and the European Commission stalled Tuesday, with no sign of a breakthrough that could avert a serious trade dispute between the United States and the European Union..The commission said late Tuesday that Boeing ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/16/busin.main_headline: Brussels Demands More Concessions : EU-Boeing Talks Stall As Trade Fight Looms
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/16/busin.print_headline: Brussels Demands More Concessions : EU-Boeing Talks Stall As Trade Fight Looms
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/16/busin.body_text: **********Antitrust talks between Boeing Co. and the European Commission stalled Tuesday, with no sign of a breakthrough that could avert a serious trade dispute between the United States and the European Union. **********The commission said late Tuesday that Boeing had failed to address its concerns regarding the proposed acquisition of McDonnell Douglas Corp. and that it fully backed the tough stance taken by its antitrust chief, Karel Van Miert. **********"Boeing has so far not agreed to measures which would meet these concerns," the EU's executive agency, said. It said it would not approve the acquisition, currently valued at $15.5 billion, "unless the legitimate competition concerns of the commission can be met and genuine choice maintained for purchasers of aircraft worldwide." **********The commission will decide on the issue July 23, but officials insisted that Boeing had to come up with a more acceptable range of propositions immediately to allow time for consultation with the 15 member governments. **********The commission objects to key aspects of the Boeing-McDonnell Douglas deal, which it claims will give Boeing a dominant advantage over Airbus Industrie, the European aircraft consortium. **********By taking over McDonnell's defense activities, the commission argues, Boeing will be in line for U.S. government research contracts and will benefit from military patents and licenses. **********The EU argues that this would violate the 1992 agreement on new aircraft subsidies between Europe and America. The United States has rejected any such parallel. **********The commission alleges that Boeing already has taken advantage of its dominant market position by signing 20-year exclusive deals to supply planes to three of America's top airlines. Airbus' chairman, Jean Pierson, says this effectively locks his company out of an important segment of the market for the next half century — 20 years for the deals to run their course plus the 30 years it will take the planes to wear out. **********The commission's concern extends equally to three areas: dominant market share, exclusive deals and defense spin-offs. A commission official said there had been movement on only one of those issues, but he did not say which one. **********The commission cannot prevent the acquisition, but officials said it could fine Boeing and its partners, just as penalties can be levied on European companies operating in the United States that breach American antitrust regulations. However, U.S. officials threatened that any such fines would be viewed as an illegal tariff, which could lead to Washington imposing trade sanctions on products from EU countries and protesting to the World Trade Organization. **********Joel Klein, the Justice Department's antitrust chief, told EU officials Sunday that the U.S. government would stand squarely behind Boeing. "U.S. interests are implicated by the merger on both the defense and civilian side," he said. **********Boeing has hundreds of European suppliers and its senior executives warned at the recent Paris Air Show that antitrust action by the commission could have heavy consequences. **********Boeing also argues that a takeover of McDonnell Douglas, which would give it some 70 percent of the market for civilian airliners above 100-seat capacity, does not fundamentally change the situation since McDonnell has virtually run out of orders for such aircraft. **********Boeing's stock rose 25 cents to $57.375 in late New York trading, while McDonnell Douglas's rose 37.50 cents to $73.1875

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/30/world.snippet: Publisher, Little Brown & Co, postpones publication of The City of Light, book purporting to show that Jacob d'Ancona, 13th-century Italian-Jewish merchant, visited China four years before Marco Polo; move follows rumors among scholars that book m...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/30/world.main_headline: China, Pre-Marco Polo? Publisher Puts Off Book
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/30/world.print_headline: China, Pre-Marco Polo? Publisher Puts Off Book
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/30/world.body_text: **********Citing doubts raised about its  authenticity, the publisher Little, Brown and Company announced yesterday that it was postponing publication of a book purporting  to show that a 13th-century Italian-Jewish merchant visited China four years before Marco Polo. **********The book, ''The City of Light,'' which had been scheduled for publication on Nov. 3, is based on a manuscript said to be written by a 13th-century figure, Jacob d'Ancona. A contemporary British writer who taught at Oxford University for many years, David Selbourne, said he had discovered the work in Italy and then had translated and edited it. **********A front-page article about the book appeared in The New York Times on Sept. 21. But recently there has been talk among scholars that it might be a hoax. Jonathan Spence, a specialist in Chinese history at Yale University, said yesterday that descriptions of sexual practices, street life and other elements led him to doubt the book's genuineness. A review by Mr. Spence was scheduled to appear in The New York Times Book Review on Oct. 12 but has been suspended. **********''We had sent copies of galleys out to a broad spectrum of academics looking for concerns and enthusiasms,'' said Sarah Crichton, the Little, Brown publisher in New York. ''We also sent it to Jonathan Spence. We heard through reporters last week that he felt it was a fake and would be saying so in The Times.'' **********But she said: ''We are not doing this to sidestep a bad review. Other academics we respect very much are raising concerns.'' **********She said Little, Brown's sister company in England would publish the book in October. **********Mr. Selbourne, reached at his home in Urbino, Italy, vouched for the book, a vivid account of a journey undertaken by d'Ancona in 1270 through China, Syria, the Persian Gulf region and India. **********''Uncreative academics are always distressed when a fellow academic writes something which attracts attention and becomes popular or sells,'' he said. He called the objections ''the product of destructive spite.'' **********Mr. Selbourne, 60, has taught the history of ideas at Ruskin College, Oxford, and is the author of ''The Principle of Duty,'' a 1994  book of political philosophy. **********The manuscript describes in detail the Chinese coastal city of Zaitun. There are dramatic accounts of the city's rulers, criminals and prostitutes. At one point, d'Ancona writes, he took part in a civic debate on whether Zaitun should assemble an army against Mongol invaders. **********Mr. Selbourne said an Italian who lived near Urbino brought him the manuscript in 1991. He said he was allowed to translate and edit it only after pledging not to disclose the owner's identity or to show anyone the original. **********In an interview, Mr. Spence cited aspects of ''The City of Light'' that he said raised questions. **********D'Ancona, for instance, describes the sexual behavior of Chinese women. ''The intimate description of male and female private parts would not be common in a journal of that time, especially from a religious man,'' Mr. Spence said. **********Mr. Spence also doubted that a foreigner could take part in a debate on assembling an army. **********Also. he said, the merchant describes ''the incredible noise of a constant number of carriages.'' But he said: ''This was not an area of carriages. They mostly had sedan chairs and coolies.'' **********Mr. Selbourne said the descriptions of sex were ''somewhat unusual,'' but added, ''Jews don't have a puritanical view of sex.'' **********As for d'Ancona's participation in civic debate, Mr. Selbourne said, ''Jacob may have invested himself with more persona than he may have had.'' In reference to the carriages, he said, ''I may have mistranslated.'' **********Mr. Selbourne said: ''It's either a hoax being passed off on me, or it's a work written by me.  Then it's a great picaresque, philosophical novel, which I would be proud to have written.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/03/busin.snippet: Robert T Coonrod is named president and chief executive of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting (S)

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/03/busin.body_text: **********Robert T. Coonrod has been named president and chief executive of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting, its board announced on Wednesday, adding that he was ''unanimously and enthusiastically'' chosen. The corporation, a private, nonprofit group, oversees the development and financing of public television and radio in this country. **********Mr. Coonrod, 52, has been the organization's executive vice president and chief operating officer for the last five years and has been acting president since April, when Richard W. Carlson resigned. **********Before joining the Corporation for Public Broadcasting in 1992, he was deputy director of the Voice of America and an executive with the United States Information Agency. **********''He has the trust of most people in this very complex and independent-minded business, and he has lots of experience,'' said William Baker, president of WNET/13, New York's public television station. ''We are delighted with this choice.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/14/world.snippet: Story circulating in Bosnia is that in closing months of Bosnian war two years ago, Radovan Karadzic, leader of Bosnian Serbs, was swindled out of $6 million by arms dealer who promised to deliver nuclear weapon which could end war; Karadzic denie...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/14/world.main_headline: An Old Tale Of Swindle Resurfaces In Bosnia
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/14/world.print_headline: An Old Tale Of Swindle Resurfaces In Bosnia
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/14/world.body_text: **********The secret weapon that cost the Bosnian Serbs $6 million in cash was handed over by somber men in a clandestine meeting on a windswept bridge in the closing months of the Bosnian war two years ago. In return, they were passed a brass container the size of a suitcase that they were told contained a football-sized nuclear weapon, or so the story goes. **********The container was spirited to the mountain town of Pale, headquarters of Radovan Karadzic and his wartime government. Dr. Karadzic, unable to contain his excitement, pried open the lid and stared inside to see his prize, which the seller, a Liberian arms dealer, said was made with a substance called Red Mercury. **********''It was filled with this jelly-like material,'' said Predrag Ceranic, the head of the secret police at the time, who said he was involved in the operation. ''Mr. Karadzic immediately suspected that he had been cheated. He told everyone in the room that maybe this was just jelly.'' **********Mr. Ceranic has a sheaf of documents to support his story. But his timing in announcing it -- just before the recent Bosnian Serb parliamentary elections -- and his current allegiance to Dr. Karadzic's rival, Biljana Plavsic, suggest that whether the story is true or not the tricks and posturing of modern democratic political campaigning have not eluded the Bosnians. **********Aides to Ms. Plavsic, the Bosnian Serb President, naturally confirmed the tale told by Mr. Ceranic, who broke with Dr. Karadzic this summer and is now the chief of state security for Ms. Plavsic. And officials loyal to Dr. Karadzic, predictably, dismissed it. **********''This is part of the campaign against Dr. Karadzic,'' said Slavko Paleksic, the Minister of Police in Pale, who was reached by telephone. ''Dr. Karadzic is the very personification of our struggle and this is why Plavsic and her supporters keep up these attacks. It seems a shame to accuse a man who is not able to defend himself, who cannot even leave his own home. If this happened in 1995, why do these people decide to tell us about it now?'' **********Perhaps unknown to Dr. Karadzic, the mysterious substance has been the center of several swindles in recent Eastern European history. **********''It was a crazy idea, but Dr. Karadzic is a gambler and he was willing to part with a lot of money, taken from the Serbian people, to realize his dream of getting his hands on a nuclear weapon,'' Mr. Ceranic said. ''He began to speak openly in early 1995 about the arrival of a secret weapon that would end the war, although at the time few people knew he intended to buy a nuclear bomb.'' **********Mr. Ceranic said that in January 1995, Dr. Karadzic made contact with the arms dealer, Nikolas Oman, who said he had contacts with Russians peddling a miniature neutron bomb that weighed less than 5 pounds. The arms dealer promised Mr. Karadzic that 12 hours after detonation there would be no harmful radiation, Mr. Ceranic said. **********''Nikolas told the Defense Minister that Red Mercury looked just like Ping-Pong balls,'' Mr. Ceranic said. **********After the first $6 million in cash, the remaining $60 million would be raised by mortgaging a state-owned oil refinery in Srpski Brod to a Liberian-owned company, Orbal Marketing Service Ltd. **********On March 1, 1995, according to legal documents in Mr. Ceranic's possession, the company gave the Bosnian Serb Government a $60 million mortgage for the refinery. **********Milan Ninkovic, the Bosnian Serb Defense Minister at the time, withdrew $6 million from the central bank in Banja Luka a few weeks later, according to the documents. **********''Once the formalities of the mortgage were complete, arrangements were made for the delivery of Red Mercury,'' Mr. Ceranic said. ''At the end of March, a passenger car arrived at the Gradiska border crossing from the direction of Zagreb. It was met by Ninkovic and an armed escort.'' **********Russian gangsters have been selling ''pure fusion'' Red Mercury weapons in Eastern Europe for more than a decade to clients from rogue states and terrorist groups. Red Mercury samples that have turned up in Europe have proved to be innocuous. Most scientists say that the small nuclear weapons, as well as the substance allegedly used to make them, do not exist. **********That apparently was the case with the Bosnian Serb purchase. **********According to Mr. Ceranic, Dr. Karadzic, in a panic, sent top aides to Moscow to find out more about Red Mercury and what exactly his $6 million had bought. ''When the delegation got back to Pale they reported to Karadzic that he had been swindled,'' Mr. Ceranic said. **********''Mr. Karadzic was disappointed,'' Mr. Ceranic. ''He was hoping to use a nuclear weapon in the war, or at least be able to threaten to use it.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/10/busin.snippet: Netscape Communications Corp shows more staying power than industry skeptics though possible in face of competition from formidable Microsoft Corp; Netscape is surviving, even thriving, under leadership of James L Barksdale, who has proved to be s...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/10/busin.main_headline: Defying a Juggernaut; Netscape Maneuvers for Position in a Microsoft-Ruled World
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/10/busin.print_headline: Defying a Juggernaut; Netscape Maneuvers for Position in a Microsoft-Ruled World
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/10/busin.body_text: **********Around Netscape's corporate campus here in Silicon Valley, the company's big rival to the north is sometimes referred to as the ''Chinese army'' -- an adversary with seemingly limitless troops. In terms of money and manpower, head-to-head comparisons of the Netscape Communications Corporation and the Microsoft Corporation are a misnomer. ''Our nose is firmly pressed against Microsoft's shin,'' one Netscape executive said. **********Until recently, the company that fueled the Internet revolution appeared to be in decline, withering under Microsoft's assault. Netscape's share of the market for Internet browser software was falling and experts predicted further sharp losses to Microsoft. Business magazines from Fortune to Red Herring questioned Netscape's ability to compete, if not survive. In August, the Aberdeen Group, a research firm, published a report with a title that captured the consensus of industry opinion: ''Netscape's Diminishing Role as an Internet Superstar.'' **********But Netscape's star has regained some of its luster lately, prompting a reassessment of the outlook for the company even before Washington's decision last month to enter the browser war. The Justice Department is seeking a court order to stop Microsoft from forcing computer makers that use its Windows operating system to also use its Internet Explorer browsing program. A Federal court will probably not rule on the matter for months, yet the impact of the Justice move, if any, may be to slow Microsoft's advance in the browser market. **********Yet even without Washington's help, Netscape has recently shown more staying power than the industry skeptics thought possible. Last month, for example, Netscape reported strong third-quarter financial results, with both revenues and profits rising 50 percent, silencing worries that the company's growth was stalling. **********''Netscape has held up remarkably well, better than a lot of people expected, myself included,'' said David M. Smith, an Internet software specialist at the Gartner Group, a research firm. **********Still, life is always risky for an upstart leader in a young market that the Microsoft mothership in Redmond, Wash., has determined to rule. Many other companies, to be sure, are up against Microsoft in segments of the Internet software market, including Sun Microsystems, Oracle, I.B.M. and Novell. They are all partners with Netscape in various ways in an informal ''anybody but Microsoft'' camp. But Microsoft's other major competitors are older, bigger and diversified, benefiting from the ballast of other businesses. **********As a pure Internet company, Netscape does not enjoy those advantages. That is why the fast-growing, profitable three-year-old has seen its stock price fall by nearly 40 percent in the last year. ''Microsoft depresses our stock price because we're perceived as being in its cross hairs,'' explained Peter Currie, an executive vice president for Netscape. **********The Grown-Up **********Barksdale Brought Netscape Credibility **********The person principally responsible for charting a course that enables Netscape to survive, even thrive, in the shadow of Microsoft is its president and chief executive, James L. Barksdale. And Mr. Barksdale, by all accounts, deserves much of the credit for Netscape's resilience to date. He has brought strategic direction and management discipline to the young company, according to industry executives and analysts, and he has proved to be a skillful salesman who can persuade button-down corporate America to buy from an Internet pioneer. **********''Barksdale is the guy who adds adult credibility to what would otherwise be a band of techies,'' said Richard Shaffer of Technologic Partners, a research firm. **********In some ways, Mr. Barksdale is an unlikely software executive. At 54, he is twice the age of many of his employees. A Southerner, born and raised in Jackson, Miss., he is laconic of speech, fond of homespun one-liners populated by snakes, dogs, chickens and country porches -- known as Barksdaleisms at Netscape. His is not a personal style familiar to the software business, a hyperkinetic industry where people typically try to win arguments by simply talking faster than anyone else. **********Mr. Barksdale, however, has spent most of his career on the sober side of the software business -- buying it instead of selling it, using it instead of creating it. He is probably best known for his 13 years at the Federal Express Corporation where he rose to become chief operating officer, serving as the principal architect of the computerized tracking and delivery system so critical to the company's success. **********''Jim Barksdale's great strength is in understanding the uses of technology,'' said Frederick W. Smith, the chairman of Federal Express. ''He's not a technologist, but a manager who is technologically literate.'' **********Friends and colleagues describe Mr. Barksdale as a brilliant and charismatic leader. While traveling with Mr. Barksdale recently, L. John Doerr, a leading venture capitalist in Silicon Valley and a director of Netscape, said: ''Fedex drivers would see him on the street, come over and give him a high five. He's inspired great loyalty wherever he has been. He is one of the great business leaders of America.'' **********In a leadership gesture not lost on his team, Mr. Barksdale cut his own salary to $1 this year, explaining that the company could do better things with the money. **********Mr. Barksdale, of course, is also an intense, relentless competitor. To his rivals at Microsoft, the clearest evidence of Mr. Barksdale's no-holds-barred approach is Netscape's legal strategy. He constantly tells his workers that the company must rely only on its success in the marketplace, but Mr. Barksdale has prodded Washington to take antitrust action against Microsoft. **********The Netscape campaign, according to Nathan Myhrvold, chief technology officer of Microsoft, resembles a ''Nixon-era dirty tricks team.'' **********''Don't believe this notion that Barksdale is some gracious Southern gentleman,'' Mr. Myhrvold added. ''That's nonsense.'' **********Mr. Barksdale understandably takes a different view of his company's antitrust appeals. ''Microsoft is a great company,'' he said, ''and it would be even better if it did it legally.'' **********An antitrust ruling against Microsoft could slow it down, but will not stop its march in the Internet market. The Chinese army is indeed coming. Since April 1996, Microsoft's share of the browser market has increased to 36 percent from 4 percent, estimates Zona Research, a market research firm. Over the same span, Netscape's browser share has slipped to 62 percent from 87 percent. **********The Competitor **********Financial Muscle And a Good Browser **********Microsoft brings not only muscle and marketing dollars to the contest, but, increasingly, technical excellence as well. In several product reviews in computer magazines and newspapers, the new version of Microsoft's Internet Explorer browser has beat out Netscape's Navigator in terms of ease of use and features. **********Mr. Barksdale and the Netscape team say that the browser has been a vehicle to become noticed. But Netscape's business, they say, more and more depends on selling the back-end network software and services to help companies use the Internet as a rich, low-cost communications tool to streamline the way they produce, sell and service products. And for corporate America, the potential Internet productivity payoff lies in creating tighter links with workers, suppliers and consumers. ''An enterprise software company,'' Mr. Barksdale said, ''that's what we want to be.'' **********So if Microsoft's browser share crosses the 50 percent mark in a year or 18 months, as most analysts expect, that is not a problem, Mr. Barksdale insists, as long as Netscape continues to extend its reach in the broader Internet software market. **********The Internet business, Mr. Barksdale says, will not evolve as did the operating- system business -- a winner-take-all market that Microsoft dominates. As long as the software of different companies contains a core of industry standards -- or is ''open,'' in geekspeak -- Netscape, Mr. Barksdale says, should be able to hold its own. **********''Our bet is that the Internet will not be a winner-take-all market and that Netscape will be a big winner in this world,'' he said. **********Mr. Barksdale's confidence rests on his past experience with networks, physical or electronic, at Federal Express and McCaw Cellular Communications Inc., where he was president and chief operating officer. The magic of networks, he says, is that they create growth, new markets and new business opportunities. **********''Networks create traffic,'' he said. ''You can't size a bridge by counting the swimmers. We're pursuing the same model here that Fedex built a great business on.'' **********Mr. Barksdale's long-range strategy is sound, most analysts say, but getting there will not be easy. The corporate business will build gradually, and big companies are conservative buyers. The first real sign of trouble at Netscape will divert a flood of business to Microsoft. **********So for the next few years, at least, Netscape must report strong growth in revenues and profits, quarter after quarter without faltering. The industry's perception that Netscape has momentum is vital to the company's survival. It needs every cent it can scrape together from selling its browser program and the server software that acts as the hub of computer networks, as well as hawking advertising and electronic commerce deals on its Web site. **********It is up to Mr. Barksdale to keep on course. That means not only moving quickly, but also recovering quickly from mistakes. Earlier this year, Netscape tried to sidestep Microsoft in the browser war by bundling its browser into a product called Communicator, which includes E-mail,  group discussion and conferencing features. **********Yet in August, with customers and corporate partners slow to embrace the bundled program, Netscape reversed course and once again began offering a stand-alone version of its browser. **********The company's ability to recover quickly from such tactical missteps speaks well of Mr. Barksdale and his team, said David Yoffie, a professor at the Harvard Business School. ''Barksdale has done an impressive job so far, but he still faces a huge challenge,'' Mr. Yoffie said. ''The Netscape-Microsoft competition may not be a winner take all. But if Netscape stumbles, a snowballing effect will work to the advantage of Microsoft. Barksdale has very little margin for error.'' **********The Choice **********Join Microsoft, Or Go It Alone? **********Still, the predicament Mr. Barksdale faces today is one he chose freely: he had his chance to side with Goliath instead of David. In 1994, the AT&T Corporation was engaged in the lengthy process of acquiring McCaw Cellular, where Mr. Barksdale was president and chief operating officer. Mr. Barksdale had told AT&T he would stay on through completion of the acquisition and a brief transition period, but no longer. **********With Mr. Barksdale known to be leaving, Netscape was not the only company interested in him. In the summer of 1994, Mr. Barksdale says he was approached twice about becoming the president and chief operating officer of Microsoft. **********But being a high-level underling at Microsoft, he recalled, did not appeal to him. ''Why walk into that snake pit,'' he said. ''I'd be surrounded by three wizards who had done everything and who couldn't be told anything. And I wouldn't be captain of my own ship.''He was referring to William H. Gates, chairman of Microsoft; Steven A. Ballmer, executive vice president, and Nathan Myhrvold, chief technology officer. **********Lured by the opportunity at Netscape, Mr. Barksdale became the company's president and chief operating officer in January 1995, eight months before Netscape sold shares to the public. **********Today, Netscape and Microsoft are bitter rivals, but they considered becoming partners. Microsoft first talked to Netscape about licensing its browser technology in late 1994, when Mr. Barksdale was a director and planning to become chief executive. The licensing discussions did not get very far, Mr. Barksdale says: The Netscape side felt Microsoft offered too little money and wanted access to virtually all its technology. **********The more serious proposal came in the summer of 1995, Mr. Barksdale says, when during a meeting with Microsoft executives at Netscape's offices, one Microsoft executive pulled Mr. Barksdale aside in a hallway and said Mr. Gates wanted to buy a stake of more than 15 percent in Netscape. In return for its cash, Microsoft wanted a board seat and rights to license Netscape technology. As a start-up company about to go public, Mr. Barksdale was told, Netscape could benefit enormously from ''the Bill effect,'' the endorsement of Mr. Gates. **********After weighing the offer, Netscape rejected Microsoft's embrace. ''It could have been a quick start,'' Mr. Barksdale said. ''But I felt that allowing Microsoft on the board was letting the fox in the henhouse.'' **********Netscape's co-founders, James H. Clark, the chairman, who also founded Silicon Graphics Inc., and Marc L. Andreessen, a 26-year-old executive vice president, who helped write the original Mosaic browser at the University of Illinois, are more blunt. Doing a deal with Microsoft, they say, is often an act of corporate suicide. **********''I can't think of one company that collaborated with Microsoft and became a significant company,'' Mr. Clark said. **********In Mr. Andreessen's view, such invitations from Microsoft are ''the Silicon Valley I.Q. test.'' He explained: ''You can say no to Microsoft, and you have to. Microsoft designs partners out of the action, out of the business, in most cases.'' **********All this is revisionist vitrol, according to Microsoft executives, who say Netscape was at least as interested in cooperation as was Microsoft. And if the Netscape side was suspicious of Microsoft's motives, there were also qualms about the rapprochement talks within Microsoft's headquarters. **********''Fool that I was, I was quite optimistic that we could do something together,'' said Mr. Myhrvold, the chief technology officer. ''But there were people inside Microsoft who thought Barksdale was taking advantage of me, just trying to gain knowledge of our Internet plans.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/18/world.print_headline: A Key Ulster Protestant Agrees to Join Talks With Sinn Fein
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/18/world.body_text: **********The leader of the largest Protestant political party in Northern Ireland agreed today to take part in formal, broad-based peace talks that include Sinn Fein, the political wing of the overwhelmingly Roman Catholic Irish Republican Army. **********By agreeing to enter the talks,  David Trimble, head of the Ulster Unionist Party, became the first Protestant unionist leader to agree to attend negotiations with Sinn Fein since Ireland was divided in 1922 into the independent Irish Free State and the British province of Ulster. **********Mr. Trimble said his first act would be to try to have Sinn Fein expelled from the talks. But officials said such a move would not succeed because the Irish and British Governments, sponsors of the talks, want Sinn Fein at the negotiating table. The talks on the future of this Protestant-dominated British province resumed in Belfast on Monday with the admission of Sinn Fein. **********''We have no illusions about the character of Sinn Fein,'' Mr. Trimble said at Castle Buildings in the Stormont area of Belfast, where the talks are under way. ''We did not invite them to the table, but we are not afraid of them and we're not going to run away. We are not here to negotiate, but to confront and expose the fascist character of Sinn Fein.'' **********But most officials at the talks expected that eventually he would face Sinn Fein across the negotiating table, possibly in the coming weeks. **********Gerry Adams, president of Sinn Fein, said Mr. Trimble was ''play acting,'' but welcomed him to the talks. **********''We will have negotiations,'' said Ray Burke, the Irish Republic's Foreign Minister and chief delegate at the talks. ''Mr. Trimble has shown great courage by coming here.'' His remarks echoed those of Mo Mowlam, Britain's Northern Ireland Secretary. **********Mr. Trimble's decision to take part in the talks represented a sharp change in his policy. A year ago, when he controlled enough unionist votes in the British Parliament in London potentially to oust the Government of former Prime Minister John Major, he vowed not to enter talks until Sinn Fein and the I.R.A. guaranteed that disarmament of the guerrillas would begin during the talks. Mr. Major supported his position. After Tony Blair became Britain's Prime Minister last May with a large majority, Mr. Trimble's power waned and he was persuaded to enter the talks, but he did not move quickly. **********On July 20, the I.R.A. resumed its cease-fire, but said it would not disarm during the talks, and stated last week that, in effect, it would feel justified in resuming its bombing and shooting campaign if it did approve any pact the talks produce. **********Mr. Trimble also said he did not trust Sinn Fein's pledge on Monday to adhere to nonviolence, a promise that gained the party admission to the talks. Then Mr. Trimble accused the I.R.A. of involvement in the non-lethal bombing on Tuesday of a police station in a town west of here. **********The I.R.A. denied involvement, but Mr. Trimble called again for the ouster of Sinn Fein from the talks. The Irish and British Governments declined to expel Sinn Fein, because they believe that without Sinn Fein at the table no significant agreement can be reached. **********Officials and experts say Mr. Trimble changed his mind finally after the province's business leaders urged him to join the talks and recent polls showed that more than 90 percent of his party's supporters felt he should face Sinn Fein across the table, not attack it from outside.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/27/busin.body_text: **********Consumer Optimism Bolsters Growth Outlook **********Reports hinted that consumer spending could remain strong for the rest of the year, driving further strong economic growth. **********The Conference Board reported that its consumer confidence index rose to 129.1 points this month from 126.3 in July, bouncing back near the 28-year high seen in June. Orders for durable goods eased by six-tenths of 1 percent in July, the Government said, but analysts saw underlying strength in the report. Yet another report showed that sales of existing single-family homes rose in July. $(Page D2.$) **********Military Contractor to Be Sold **********United Defense, a maker of armored military vehicles, is changing hands; its joint-venture owners, FMC and Harsco, accepted an $850 million bid from the Carlyle Group, a leveraged-buyout firm. $(D2.$) **********Much at Stake With New Chip **********In a top-secret project code-named Merced, Intel and Hewlett-Packard are designing a computer chip that would mark the most significant shift in the history of the immensely popular Intel microprocessor family. Market Place. $(D8.$) **********Another Decline for the Dow **********Stock prices drifted lower again as blue-chip issues continued to flounder in what has become a stalled bull market. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 77.35 points, or nearly 1 percent, to 7,782.22. $(D8.$) **********Treasury prices, however, ended a string of four straight declines, recovering from early weakness as an auction of new two-year notes was well received. The 30-year bond yield fell to 6.64 percent from 6.66. $(D6.$) **********The dollar plummeted to a five-week low against the mark because of continued concerns that the German central bank will raise interest rates soon despite opting not to do so yesterday. $(D7.$) **********Toyota Pact Lifts Republic Stock **********Shares of Republic Industries surged 7.5 percent following the announcement that the company, the nation's largest car dealership owner, had reached an agreement with Toyota. Republic's shares had been in a slump since the spring, when Toyota and Honda began to battle Republic's plan to buy car dealerships nationwide. $(D2.$) **********Canadian Insurers Lock Up Deal **********Great-West Lifeco, Canada's largest group life and health insurer, said that it had raised its offer to buy London Insurance and that the companies had signed an agreement to prevent other bids, superseding an earlier agreement between London Insurance and the Royal Bank of Canada. $(D8.$) **********Battle Over a Memoir **********The publishing house of William Morrow is battling with Whitewater prosecutors over an unfinished manuscript for a memoir by the fallen Justice Department official and Clinton confidant, Webster L. Hubbell. $(A1.$) **********Union Alliance Expected **********The Union of American Physicians and Dentists, one of the few independent doctors' unions, plans to announce that it will join forces with the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees. $(A18.$) **********Managing Different Risks **********Richard L. Huber, the new chief executive of Aetna, is known as a wizard of the corporate comeback. But his turnaround efforts extend beyond his business life: Mr. Huber and his wife, Roberta, live in a troubled Hartford neighborhood that is miles from the lush suburbs where most of the city's business elite have settled. And he has bought almost one-fourth of the buildings on his street, in a crusade to clean things up. $(A1.$) **********A Hot Tourist Tip **********The stock market has been booming, and tourists are coming to New York in record numbers. Until recently, one trend apparently had nothing to do with the other. But now visitors from Main Street and elsewhere are increasingly flocking to Wall Street. $(D23.$) **********Corn and Soybeans Lower **********Prices for corn and soybeans fell sharply amid indications that the crops seem headed for bumper harvests. $(D7.$)

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/22/world.snippet: Vice Pres Al Gore begins three-day visit to Russia that aides hope will direct attention away from his political troubles and toward role as world statesman; he is greeted by Prime Min Viktor Chernomyrdin at Vnukovo airport in Moscow; series of ca...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/22/world.main_headline: Gore in Russia, Hoping to Be Cast in a Different Light
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/22/world.print_headline: Gore in Russia, Hoping to Be Cast in a Different Light
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/22/world.body_text: **********If Vice President Al Gore thought he would get away from questions about campaign finance once he had landed in Russia, he soon found out otherwise. **********No sooner had Mr. Gore arrived at  the Vnukovo airport in Moscow tonight than a Russian reporter asked him if the fund-raising allegations that had dogged him at home would hamper his effectiveness here. **********Mr. Gore said with a smile that he was glad to see that Russia had a strong and free press. His official Russian hosts were less amused. They abruptly shut down the impromptu news conference. **********Wrapping himself in the mantle of a diplomat, Mr. Gore began three days of meetings with Russia's top leaders on a lengthy list of issues ranging from plutonium production to oil agreements to religious freedom. **********If Mr. Gore's aides are successful, it will also be a week of high-profile meetings and carefully scripted photo-ops, all intended to direct the spotlight away from the Vice President's political troubles and toward his role as a world statesman. **********To be sure, Mr. Gore and the Russian Prime Minister, Viktor S. Chernomyrdin, have been holding these biannual sessions for years -- so many years that the talks are denoted with Roman numerals, like Hollywood sequels or Superbowl games. (This week's meeting is officially known as Gore-Chernomyrdin Commission IX, though the cognoscenti simply call it G.C.C.) **********But this time the public relations team is pulling out all the stops. **********There is, for example, ''the walk in the woods.'' On Monday, Mr. Gore and Mr. Chernomyrdin will be driven to a lunch spot near a leafy sanitorium for the former Communist and present-day post-Communist elite. They will then stroll through the woods together before a ''prepositioned pool'' of photographers and television cameramen. **********Mr. Gore will be the host of an unusual ''media roundtable'' with American reporters to discuss the intricacies of American-Russian relations. No Russian reporters are invited to this made-for-America event, which his aides hope will give the Vice President a chance to display his policy expertise. **********Mr. Gore's team is also exploring a visit to a Moscow jazz club. That could help overcome the Vice President's wooden image, though it is not yet clear when it would be sandwiched into his crowded schedule. **********American reporters complained earlier this year that they were locked out of a speech Mr. Gore gave to the American Chamber of Commerce in Tokyo. But under the new policy of maximum exposure, the news organizations have been invited to Mr. Gore's opening remarks to the American Chamber of Commerce here. **********Mr. Gore's wife, Tipper, also has a busy public schedule. She will be meeting with characters from the Russian version of Sesame Street and visiting a Russian school that stresses teaching about the environment. **********It would be wrong to think, however, that G.C.C. is all public relations. Each commission session is, in fact, a series of meetings involving American Cabinet-level officials, Russian ministers and seemingly hundreds of aides from both sides. The many issues that Mr. Gore and the Russians will discuss are complicated and often nettlesome. **********The two sides, for example, plan to seal an accord requiring the Russians to alter nuclear reactors in Tomsk and Krasnoyarsk so that they no longer produce weapons-grade plutonium. The Russians had earlier promised to shut down the reactors, only to backtrack after concluding that they needed them to heat the Siberian cities. **********The Americans also want the Russians to return to the Atomic Energy Ministry several American supercomputers acquired for Russia's nuclear program in circumvention of American export restrictions. **********Mr. Gore plans to press the Russians to stop their scientists from helping Iran to develop new surface-to-surface missiles and to curtail nuclear cooperation. **********The Russian Atomic Energy Minister, Viktor Mikhailov, proposed tonight that the United States and Russia jointly monitor the nuclear reactor that Russia is selling to the Iranians. But such a step would not address American concerns that the project would help Iran to develop its nuclear expertise and to acquire nuclear technology. **********On the economic front, Mr. Gore is expected to try to help American companies that have become increasingly frustrated over breakdowns in their multi-billion dollar oil-production agreements with the Russians. **********The Vice President will also press the Russian leadership to reject a bill that the Russian Parliament passed on Friday to protect the Russian Orthodox Church from competition with other Christian faiths. Persuading President Boris N. Yeltsin to block the law will be a herculean chore, since it closely resembles his own draft. **********And that is not to mention discussions on space cooperation, a new tax code, the sale of Russian uranium, environmental issues, and the prospects for Russian ratification of the START II treaty reducing strategic nuclear arms and the international accord banning chemical weapons. **********After the three days of talks, a meeting with Mr. Yeltsin and a news conference, Mr. Gore and Mr. Chernomyrdin are to leave on Wednesday for Samara, a Volga River city that is under the sway of economic reformers and that welcomes foreign investment. **********For all of the time invested, previous Gore-Cheronomyrdin meetings have rarely produced dramatic results. Mr. Chernomyrdin is more of a status-quo figure than the dynamic free-market advocates in the Russian Government like Anatoly B. Chubais and Boris Nemtsov. **********Nor have the meetings always enabled Mr. Gore to put his best foot forward. Mr. Gore had a awkward moment in 1994 when his meetings coincided with the Russian onslaught on Chechnya. Trying to avoid offending the Russian Government, Mr. Gore described the fighting as an internal Russian problem -- a stance that was soon superseded by Washington's anxiety over the brutal nature of the Russian attacks and the fate of civilians. **********Still, United States officials say the meetings help keep communication channels open and provide a venue for hammering out agreements. Mr. Gore is also practiced in dealing with the Russians, which should enable him to avoid the tentative approach he was criticized for during his trip to China in March. **********And while the Russians may not make many concessions, they seem willing to help Mr. Gore achieve a public relations success. ''Our friendship on the personal level is very important,'' Mr. Chernomyrdin said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/21/busin.main_headline: Diller's HSN In $4.1 Billion TV Asset Deal
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/21/busin.print_headline: Diller's HSN In $4.1 Billion TV Asset Deal
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/21/busin.body_text: **********In a deal that thrusts Barry Diller once again into the thick of entertainment programming, his company, HSN Inc., agreed yesterday to acquire the Seagram Corporation's USA and Sci-Fi cable channels as well as almost all of Seagram's Universal Studios television production company for $4.1 billion in cash and stock. **********HSN, which owns or has interests in 18 television stations, the Home Shopping Network and Savoy Pictures Entertainment as well as a stake in Ticketmaster Group Inc., will pay Seagram $1.2 billion in cash and $2.9 billion in HSN stock, representing 45 percent of HSN's equity. **********The deal gives Mr. Diller the opportunity to establish a broadcast network that might hope to compete with ABC, CBS, NBC and Fox -- or at least to fare better than two other network upstarts, the Warner Brothers Network and the United Paramount Network. **********News of the deal sent shares of both HSN and Seagram higher. HSN climbed $3.25, or 8.4 percent, to $41.875, on the Nasdaq market, while Seagram rose $2.8125, or 8.7 percent, to $35.25, on the New York Stock Exchange. **********''The deal raises the value of Mr. Diller's TV stations, because he would have more programming assets with which to try and improve their ratings performance over the long term,'' Harold Vogel, an analyst with Cowen & Company, said. **********Mr. Diller, HSN's chairman, who is widely credited with creating the Fox Network for the News Corporation earlier in his career, has subsequently sought and failed twice to re-enter entertainment television programming, by attempting to take over CBS and then trying to outbid Viacom Inc. for control of Paramount Communications. **********Yesterday's deal could enable Mr. Diller to attempt innovative scheduling in both cable and broadcast televison. For example, Mr. Diller said, one plan might be to run new programs on his television stations, which reach 39 percent of American households, as well as on USA Network, a channel available on most cable systems. That might enable HSN to sell national advertising, as does a national broadcast network. **********To avoid scheduling conflicts in a single market, the programs could run on cable and on over-the-air television in different time slots or even on different days. **********To satisfy cable operators who might argue that new cable programming should be available only on their systems -- and not over the air -- HSN might offer cable operators cut-rate or free advertising on its stations, Mr. Diller said. **********''Unless you have the ability to cross-promote your programs, how will anybody know what you have to sell?'' Mr. Diller said. **********He added that he was not abandoning previously announced plans to put local programming on his stations. He said he always expected to offer 10 to 12 hours of local programming a day, and 4 to 6 hours of national programming. **********Under the deal, Liberty Media, the programming arm of Tele-Communications Inc., the nation's largest cable operator, which already owns 15 percent of HSN, has the right to increase that stake to 25 percent. **********Liberty could invest as much as $700 million, using both cash and assets, Mr. Diller said. Since Liberty owns interests in a number of cable programming services, it may transfer some of those to HSN as part of its equity investment, further bolstering HSN's cable programming. **********And Liberty's tie to Tele-Communications is expected to help smooth cable distribution for HSN's cable services. Mr. Diller will retain voting rights over both the Seagram and the Liberty shares. **********Also, Seagram has agreed not to buy more HSN stock for four years, after which it can increase it stake to 57 percent. If Mr. Diller dies or decides to sell HSN, Seagram has the right to buy his 8 percent stake and the Liberty stake and to propose a merger for the whole company. **********Since Seagram acquired 80 percent of MCA Inc., the parent of Universal, for $5.8 billion in 1995, investors have been concerned that Seagram did not own sufficient distribution outlets for its film and television programming operations. Now it will  have access to HSN's 18 television stations as a programming outlet as well as retaining distribution rights at USA Network. **********While Seagram is giving up direct management control of some key assets, analysts said that in the long term the new deal would give Seagram a good chance to enhance the  value of those assets. **********''We have answered the TV strategy issue,'' Edgar M. Bronfman Jr., Seagram's chief executive, said yesterday. **********''It doesn't matter if the path takes a decade,'' he said, referring to the agreement to buy back HSN. ''We have the chance to build assets and we want a large diversified media business.'' **********Although Seagram is putting the television production business into the venture, it will retain sole ownership of Brillstein-Grey, a television production company that it bought last year. Universal Television will also continue to produce half-hour comedies, the staple of the network television business. It could also produce programs for both USA Network and HSN's television stations.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/31/world.body_text: **********Senior Albanian officials today accused the Italian Navy of causing the deaths of dozens of Albanian refugees on Friday when one of its vessels rammed and sank a boat in which the Albanians were fleeing their homeland. **********The charges appeared to diminish the chances that an Italian-led security contingent could help stabilize the chaotic political situation in Albania. Italy was preparing today to step up its efforts to lead the military and police contingent for the delivery of food, medicine and other aid, to help prevent the flight of growing numbers of refugees. **********The Albanian Ambassador in Rome, Pandeli Pasko, presented a list today with 117 names of Albanians he said had been aboard the boat when it went down, including 34 survivors who were taken from the sea on Saturday. The bodies of three women and one man were also recovered. **********After he spoke with the survivors, Mr. Pasko said they had supplied the names, mostly of women and children. The refugees were said to have been jammed into the boat's hold when it went down in 2,400 feet of water, and he said as many as 79 more people might have perished. **********''The frigate hit the boat two times,'' Mr. Pasko said in a statement, ''first in the back and then on the side, after which the boat capsized. And according to the Albanians, this was done on purpose.'' **********The Albanian craft was a naval boat apparently hijacked by gangsters in the southern Albanian port of Vlore and used to ferry the refugees to Italy for a price. It sank after it was rammed by an Italian warship, the Sibilla, as it enforced a blockade of the Italian coast. **********Roughly 13,000 Albanians have reached Italy in recent weeks to escape their country's turmoil, which began with citizen protests over failed financial pyramid schemes that wiped out the savings of many Albanians. **********The Italian Foreign Minister, Lamberto Dini, in an interview today in the Turin daily La Stampa, sought to deflect blame for the naval disaster from the Italians, accusing the Albanian vessel of trying to evade the Italian ships that pursued it. After several risky maneuvers, he said, the Albanian boat ''set itself on a collision course with our vessel, which could not avoid it.'' **********The captain of the Sibilla, Maurizio Laudadio, was relieved of his duties today, and Italian officials promised a swift investigation. Officials said high winds and generally stormy conditions had made further efforts at finding survivors or the bodies of victims very difficult. **********The episode is expected to complicate the Italian effort to assemble the multinational security contingent, which was approved on Friday by the United Nations Security Council. The force is to consist of roughly 2,500 soldiers and police officers, with the immediate task of cooperating with Albanian security forces to secure the airport in the capital, Tirana, and the ports of Durres and Vlore, in the south. **********In Tirana today, Parliament, which is dominated by the Democratic Party of President Sali Berisha, voted 97 to 1 to approve the deployment of the contingent. After the vote, Mr. Berisha sought to assure the Italians that the soldiers faced no danger in Albania, where they would find a ''friendly people that appreciates their mission.'' **********But even as Parliament voted, the Foreign Minister, Arjan Starova, denounced the sinking of the refugee boat as a ''national tragedy.'' **********Italian officials said advance units of the contingent could begin arriving in Albania this week. Several European countries, including France, Spain, Portugal and Greece, have said they would consider sending personnel, but only Romania has thus far agreed to supply a force, of about 400 soldiers. **********The naval episode only underscored the complexity of the situation Italy faces. The Government of Prime Minister Romano Prodi feels constrained to take measures to help restore order in Albania, not least to stem the flow of refugees to Italy. It is responding to a wave of anti-immigrant feeling among Italians, who view the refugees as competitors for dwindling jobs, given record levels of unemployment, or who associate them with lawlessness and prostitution. **********The Government in Rome is also under pressure from Italian businesses, which are among the principal contributors to the meager foreign investment in Albania since the collapse of Communism there in the early 1990's. **********This week, Red Cross aid workers in Albania expressed concern that the Italian-led contingent could step into a trap in Albania, given the complexity of the feuding between Mr. Berisha and the coalition Government of the Socialist Prime Minister, Bashkim Fino, which Mr. Berisha accepted only under intense international pressure. **********Indeed, most of the refugees on the Albanian vessel came from Vlore, one of the cities where the Italian-led contingent will be deployed. Last week in Vlore, Mr. Fino's Government reached an agreement with representatives of armed insurgents in the south that was denounced by Mr. Berisha. **********About 7,000 people rallied in Vlore today to denounce Italy over the boat collision, Reuters reported. **********Italian officials say they will not let the naval episode hinder deployment of the security contingent. **********Mr. Dini predicted that deployment would take ''several days,'' yet he acknowledged that it could be ''complicated, involving taking control of ports in cooperation with regular Albanian forces.''
