https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/26/busin.snippet: Trans World Airlines says auditors included qualification in annual report raising questions about carrier's ability to continue as going concern; publicizes statement in tandem with an announcement of plans to raise $50 million in private offerin...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/26/busin.main_headline: Auditors Raise Question of T.W.A.'s Continued Operation
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/26/busin.print_headline: Auditors Raise Question of T.W.A.'s Continued Operation
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/26/busin.body_text: **********Trans World Airlines said yesterday that its auditors had included a qualification in the annual report of the carrier regarding its ''ability to continue as a going concern.'' **********T.W.A. publicized the statement in tandem with an announcement yesterday that it wanted to raise $50 million in a private offering. The timing suggested that the airline was trying to fully disclose risks to potential investors. **********Still, the airline has struggled for years, and many analysts saw the disclosure as another sign of its questionable future. At the end of 1996, the airline had a cash cushion of $181.6 million; analysts estimated that had shrunk to about $120 million now. **********The airline, which is based in St. Louis, has reported deteriorating financial results since the crash of  Flight 800 off Long Island last July. Though most major airlines are seeing strong profits these days, T.W.A. posted a fourth-quarter loss of $258.6 million, worse than expected. **********Last week, the Standard & Poor's Corporation, the credit rating agency, said that T.W.A.'s cash balance at the end of year was small for an airline of its size. ''However, it appears to be sufficient to carry the company through the remainder of the seasonally weak winter period,'' the agency said. **********New management at the airline is trying to improve its service and focus its route network more on its hub airport in St. Louis. But, Standard & Poor's added, ''T.W.A.'s liquidity and financial condition leave little room for error or adverse industry developments.'' **********The airline has for years defied predictions of its early demise, but the industry is changing in ways that are making other airlines increasingly tough rivals. **********Marketing alliances between larger United States and foreign carriers with better service reputations are giving travelers more choices for flying abroad. **********''You've got to have an edge in the marketplace,'' said Kevin C. Murphy, an analyst with Morgan Stanley & Company. ''T.W.A. is ill suited for that environment.'' **********Earlier this month, shares of T.W.A. were bolstered by publicity about persistent theories that Flight 800 was brought down by a missile, which, while not considered accurate by crash investigators, would relieve the airline of financial responsibility for the disaster if they were true. **********The airline said last week that a Saudi Arabian, Prince Walid bin Talal, had bought 5 percent of its shares. Yesterday, T.W.A.'s shares closed at $7.625, down 12.5 cents.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/30/busin.snippet: Olivetti SpA and Wang Laboratories Inc say they are talking about merging Olivetti's Olsy computer systems and services unit with Wang's operations; Wang says Olivetti would retain interest in combined business (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/30/busin.main_headline: Olivetti and Wang in Talks on Unit Merger
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/30/busin.print_headline: Olivetti and Wang in Talks on Unit Merger
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/30/busin.body_text: **********Olivetti S.p.A., the Italian office products and telecommunications company, and Wang Laboratories Inc., the American computer services company, said today that they were talking about merging Olivetti's Olsy computer systems and services unit with Wang's operations. **********''Olivetti would retain an interest in the combined business,'' Wang said in a statement, which followed Italian newspaper reports of such talks. ''There can be no assurances that the discussions will lead to a transaction.'' **********Olivetti confirmed that the two companies were in talks. The companies did not say when they expected the talks to conclude or what the transaction would be worth. **********The talks come as Olivetti, which sold off its money-losing personal computer division this year, is transforming itself into a telecommunications company. Olivetti controls Omnitel Italia-Pronto S.p.A., one of Italy's two mobile-phone networks. **********Italy's Il Sole/24 Ore newspaper first reported on Wang's talks with Olivetti last month, but the two companies would not confirm the report until now. **********Olsy had 1996 sales of 4.5 trillion lire ($2.6 billion), with one-third from Italy and most of the rest from elsewhere in Europe, Olivetti said. **********Another Italian newspaper, MF, said earlier this month that Olivetti might sell most of Olsy to Wang in exchange for 600 billion lire, or about $350 million, in cash. Wang would assume some of Olsy's debt and a stake of up to 20 percent in a venture to be created by the merger of the two companies' information technology businesses, MF said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/24/busin.main_headline: McDonald's Posts a Gain of 12% in Profits
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/24/busin.print_headline: McDonald's Posts a Gain of 12% in Profits
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/24/busin.body_text: **********The McDonald's Corporation said yesterday that its earnings rose 12 percent in the fourth quarter as its expansion offset declining sales at existing restaurants. **********McDonald's, the world's largest fast-food chain, said net income rose 12 percent, to $410 million, or 58 cents a share, from $366.8 million, or 51 cents, a year earlier. **********McDonald's was expected to earn 57 cents a share, based on the average estimate of 21 analysts surveyed by I.B.E.S. International. Shares of McDonald's, which is based in Oak Brook, Ill., rose $1.25, to $46.50. **********Revenue rose 8.9 percent, to $2.82 billion from $2.59 billion. **********The latest quarter's results included a $48.7 million charge for steps to strengthen the company's business in the United States, including the costs of closing some small restaurants, the chief financial officer, Michael Conley, said. The company also had a $50 million tax benefit from international transactions. **********Sales in the United States rose 3 percent, the company said, but only because of the addition of new restaurants. ''In the U.S. we really weren't very happy with our performance,'' Mr. Conley said. ''We can do a lot better than that.'' **********International sales, which contributed 59 percent of McDonald's operating income, rose 11 percent. **********The company said more than 70 percent of the restaurants it planned to open in the next year would be outside the United States. McDonald's both operates and franchises restaurants in its chain.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/29/busin.body_text: **********Gain in Japan Stocks Helps Bolster Wall Street **********Stocks rose yesterday in the United States, helped by the third straight advance in the battered Japanese stock market, where fear of more financial failures abated somewhat. **********The Dow Jones industrial average ended 28.35 points higher to close at 7,794.78, narrowing its weekly loss to 57.94 points. Broader market indicators also gained in holiday-shortened trading hours. But other Asian markets slumped. South Korea's market fell 1 percent early today after falling 4.9 percent yesterday.   [Page D2.] **********The dollar rose against the yen on resilient concern about Japan's weak economy and financial system, despite the eased atmosphere of crisis.   [D4.] **********Earnings and Spending Show Gains **********The Government reported stronger-than-expected increases in October personal income and personal spending, reflecting the economy's vibrancy and the increased affluence of American consumers. The data also provided statistical cheer for American merchants, coinciding with the traditional first day of the holiday selling season.   [D3.] **********Bonds were little changed on the strong economic numbers. Although the gains in income and spending suggested the possibility of higher inflation, forecasters asserted that the longer-term trend was for an economic slowdown.   [D2.] **********Vote for Accounting Merger **********Partners at Price Waterhouse and Coopers & Lybrand, two of the world's largest accounting firms, have voted overwhelmingly to merge. The deal still requires the approval of the Justice Department.   [D2.] **********Total Takeover for Vendome **********Cie. Financiere Richemont, which owns 70 percent of Vendome Luxury Group, will buy the rest for $1.73 billion, strengthening its hold on the group's global luxury brands like Cartier jewelry and Montblanc pens.   [D14.] **********Canadian Real Estate Deal **********Oxford Properties Group of Toronto will acquire the Canadian real estate company Burcon Properties Ltd. for $428 million (United States). Burcon owns a majority stake in Oxford, which owns and manages commercial real estate.   [D3.] **********Fox Buys Children's Show **********''The Magic School Bus,'' an animated children's program on science, is leaving public television for the Fox network. Fox needs educational programs to comply with new Federal regulations.   [B17.] **********India in Ford's Headlights **********Ford said it would make India a base for exports worldwide and would introduce new models there despite a slowdown in India's  economy. Ford also said it was optimistic about Asia's condition over all.   [D2.] **********Finding Religion, Again **********Fearing they have neglected their faith, thousands of time-starved professionals are organizing religion classes in hundreds of companies. From Bible study lunches at Northrop Grumman to Torah classes at Microsoft to Koran study groups at Intel, such classes are proliferating.   [A1.] **********Bingo Battles Back **********Bingo, the anchor of charity fund-raisers hurt by an onslaught of legalized gambling, is making a comeback with the aid of modern electronics. Thousands of grandmothers across the country have been dragged into the high-tech age via the use of small computers that enable them to increase their chances of winning at bingo.   [A1.] **********Some Markets Closed **********Commodity exchanges in New York were closed yesterday. Commodity exchanges in Chicago, the stock market and Treasury market had abbreviated hours. All United States markets were closed Thursday.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/03/busin.print_headline: Diana Coverage Said to Hurt Retail Sales
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/03/busin.body_text: **********Growth in retailers' sales during September was slower than expected because consumers stayed home at the beginning of the month to watch television coverage of the death of Diana, Princess of Wales, Telecheck Services Inc. said today. **********The effect on spending was similar to that of the 1996 Summer Olympic Games and the Persian Gulf war, Telecheck, a unit of the First Data Corporation, said. **********The princess died in a car crash in Paris on Aug. 30. Her funeral was in London on Sept. 6, a Saturday, and was broadcast live during the early hours of the day in the United States. **********According to the Telecheck Retail Index, which tracks the number of checks written by consumers, sales at stores open at least a year rose during September in the Southwest, Southeast and Northeast and fell in the West, Midwest and mid-Atlantic states. **********Sales were worse than expected even though there was one more Sunday in the month than there was a year earlier. **********The survey included more than 27,000 individual stores. Retail chains will report their September sales next week.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/20/world.snippet: Colombian officials are considering peace proposal from rebel leader, Manuel Marulanda Velez, that would end undeclared war that has been bleeding nation for 40 years; Pres Ernesto Samper photo (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/20/world.main_headline: Colombia Rebels, Feeling Strong, Offer Peace
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/20/world.print_headline: Colombia Rebels, Feeling Strong, Offer Peace
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/20/world.body_text: **********While guerrilla movements in much of Latin America have been withering or making peace in recent years,  the handover on Sunday of 70 soldiers and marines who had been held hostage, on terms that leftist guerrillas first dictated nine months ago,  illustrated that the opposite has been happening in Colombia. Here, the rebels' muscle is still growing, to the point that they have become a competing authority operating parallel to the elected Government in much of the countryside. **********That is one reason a peace proposal put forward by the rebels who freed the hostages is generating discussion among Government officials about starting peace talks to end an undeclared war that has been bleeding this Andean nation for 40 years. **********In a speech read on his behalf during the liberation of the soldiers, the guerrilla leader, Manuel Marulanda Velez, laid out his conditions for a peace accord. He called for the Colombian military to be deployed as a border patrol rather than as a force to maintain internal security; the permanent evacuation by the Government from some municipalities; an end to special emergency zones where civil liberties have been suspended, and the dismantling of groups of citizen-informers that the guerrillas consider legalized right-wing paramilitary groups. **********The talks that led to the liberation of the hostages were the first direct ones between the Government and the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia since 1991. The organization is one of three guerrilla groups operating in Colombia. **********''The atmosphere has changed; there's a change of attitude on their part,'' said Gilberto Echeverri Mejia, the Minister of National Defense, referring to Mr. Velez's guerrilla organization. **********The Attorney General, Jaime Bernal Cuellar, said the rebels' proposal was ''welcome'' and worth studying, though the details might be thorny. **********Some officials pointed to Guatemala and El Salvador as countries that had negotiated an end to long periods of violence, and asked why Colombia should be different. **********But the enthusiasm was confined largely to the political leadership, and the very suggestion of peace talks irritated key military leaders, who have made no secret of their distaste for a central event in the hostage release -- the evacuation of government soldiers in a vast area in which the release took place. **********Gen. Harold Bedoya, chief of the armed forces, called the delivery of the soldiers a circus. ''When one sees drug dealers saying they're politicians, that's part of the circus,'' he said. The general added that when the army returns to the area it evacuated, it will do so in full force. **********Others, like Alfonso Valdivieso, the former chief prosecutor who recently declared his candidacy for president, said that it was the wrong moment for the Government to negotiate because the guerrillas would be in a strong position. **********That strength was readily visible in Cartagena de Chaira, a pueblo built by internal refugees of a war between liberals and conservatives in the 1950's that claimed some 200,000 lives. The population of the village was swollen by peasants pushed off their land by large landholders, and sustained by those escaping poverty elsewhere in the country. In Cartagena de Chaira, people follow the guerrillas out of fear, certainly, but also because they share a common experience and perspective. **********Several residents said that in the absence of governmental institutions or attention, they turn to the guerrillas to solve daily problems. A woman who is repeatedly abused by her husband may seek redress from the guerrillas, who might require the husband to give the wife money and allow her to leave him. A coca grower said it was also the guerrillas who made coca farmers grow food on two-thirds of their farmland, so the families would not go hungry. **********By default in such areas, the rule of the guerrillas stand as unofficial law. Until the Government reduced the coca trade in the region last year by limiting supplies of gasoline and cement, which are used in producing coca paste, the guerrillas also taxed growers 10 percent of the value of the paste they sold. **********A 10-point plan the guerrillas have issued as their platform includes turning over strategic industries to state ownership, erecting trade barriers to protect domestic crops and industries, and earmarking 50 percent of the budget for social welfare. Such measures might seem out of fashion in many countries today, but  the message does not seem outdated to the huge numbers of of Colombians who live in poverty, or to the millions of small farmers whose crops cannot compete with foreign imports. Beneath a veneer of modernity, these Colombians live in a pre-industrial age. **********The guerrillas have at times been as intolerant of dissent and disobedience as the right-wing paramilitaries. . Both sides have outlawed electioneering during municipal elections in October in the zones they control, and declared some candidates military targets.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/03/busin.snippet: Letter by Nancy J Governali on July 13 article on raising a family on one income (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/03/busin.body_text: **********To the Editor: **********Re ''One Income. One Purpose. Yes, a Family Can Stay Afloat'' (From the Desk Of, July 13): **********The writer, Cynthia Tavlin, must have been watching my husband and me raise our two sons. As my Social Security statement shows, there were eight years during which I had no income. The birth of my first son followed a decision to dedicate a portion of my career to parenting. **********After those eight years, I returned to education, and will start my 21st year as a teacher in September. In teaching junior high math, I find that the personal trait often missing in unsuccessful students is the same one Ms. Tavlin sees in those must-work, two-income families: the ability to delay gratification. **********Thus, as I strive for the best ways to teach my eighth graders a rigorous pre-algebra course, I work even harder to release the stranglehold that pleasure has on many of them.  Some things in life may not be immediately enjoyable -- like studying difficult topics in math, or sacrificing financially for quality parenting. **********So how are my own children doing? One is an engineer; the other is a securities analyst. Over all we have been blessed with health and the wealth of a life focused on our family and meaningful work. No one could convince us that we couldn't have made it on one salary. **********NANCY J. GOVERNALI **********Cortland, N.Y., July 20

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/12/world.snippet: Rwandan Hutu refugees and few hundred hastily recruited European and African mercenaries form backbone of Zairian Government force fighting Zairian rebels backed by Rwanda and Uganda; Zaire's own soldiers, who left trail of looting, rape and death...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/12/world.main_headline: In Zaire's Unconventional War, Serbs Train Refugees for Combat
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/12/world.print_headline: In Zaire's Unconventional War, Serbs Train Refugees for Combat
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/12/world.body_text: **********Every morning, from an airport at the edge of this crumbling city, Yugoslav jets with Ukrainian pilots take off with a scream, headed east toward a huge, shifting war zone, bombing anything that moves in the impenetrable forest below. **********On the ground at the airport, Serbian trainers with tattoos and shaved heads drill members of an elite Zairian unit, showing them how to break down and clean the new mounted machine guns and shoulder-fired rockets that the Serbs have supplied to Zaire in defiance of an international arms embargo. **********Zairian rebels supported by neighboring Rwanda and Uganda have declared this city, Zaire's third-largest, as their next strategic target. In an effort to blunt the rebel advance, Zairian Government forces with little appetite for battle have distributed assault rifles and mortar charges by the planeful to Hutu refugees from neighboring Rwanda. **********Some of the Hutu are militia members who organized mass killings of members of their home country's Tutsi minority in 1994, while others are former members of the Rwandan Army, which was defeated by the Tutsi-led forces now in power in Rwanda. **********The Rwandan Hutu and a few hundred mercenaries recruited in haste from a handful of European and African countries form the backbone of the Zairian Government fighting force in what by any standard has to be one of Africa's least conventional wars. **********Zaire's own soldiers, after blazing a trail of looting, rape and death from the Rwandan border zone, which they fled in November when the rebellion against President Mobutu Sese Seko began, remain twitchy and virtually useless in combat and are mostly left to guard this city. **********Because Kisangani has been sacked by unpaid Zairian Army troops twice already in this decade, the population is wary. Given this mistrust, few soldiers dare circulate in town alone, despite the assault rifles they wear slung over their shoulders. **********''You've got a bit of everything here,'' said one international aid worker with long experience in Zaire. ''Hutu who have participated in genocide, Serbs who are most probably war criminals and, on the other side, Tutsi-controlled forces that are trying to pull off a genocide of their own.'' **********Credible witnesses, from church workers to captured rebels, say Tutsi -- the predominant ethnic group among the Zairian rebels in this region -- have been hunting down young Hutu men as the rebels have advanced inexorably across the country. **********These witnesses said rebels swept into the small town of Shabunda the other day, encircled as many of the 40,000 or so Rwandan refugees as they could, separated out the young Hutu men and machine-gunned an unknown number. The others were simply allowed to go. **********Senior Zairian Army officers gave separate accounts of the ''confession'' of a captured rebel sentinel whom they identified as Matthieu Bafanga. They said he told them two days ago that he had been paid $450 to gather information on the movements of Hutu refugees through east-central Zaire. **********There are as many as 300,000 Rwandans stranded in Zaire. Most are ordinary men, women and children, but it is widely believed that there are also thousands of former Hutu militiamen and soldiers. Many of these people already risk death from starvation, dehydration and disease, but for their pursuers, that is not enough. **********''The goal of the Rwandan Government, and the reason they have supported this rebellion, is that they are determined to exterminate the Hutu fighters for fear that one day they will come back for revenge,'' said one longtime European resident who once fought as a mercenary here and maintains contacts in the war zone. **********The rebellion began with a group of Tutsi who have lived in Zaire for centuries. Since then, Laurent Kabila, a lifelong rebel from faraway Shaba Province, has assumed leadership and successfully expanded the force to include other traditional enemies of President Mobutu, Zaire's longtime dictator. **********If Zaire's insurrection, which has made impressive gains in recent days, has become a bid for outright power by Mr. Kabila, it also remains a continuation of Rwanda's civil war in a new theater, the forested heart of Zaire. **********And for Zaire's embattled Government, led for 31 years by Mr. Mobutu, who is simultaneously fighting advanced cancer, this war is most of all a desperate struggle to hang on to power. **********At the airport here -- where the grim Serbian trainers were sweating profusely through their attempts to train Zairian commandos, who often had no clue as to how to use the new weapons -- an officer made no attempt to minimize the army's problems. **********''The enemy is hitting us in so many places that it is very difficult for me to say where the front is,'' said Lieut. Col. Nufuta B. Kasonga, who traced a spider web of rebel movements with his finger on a map. ''The entire east of the country is affected, and they seem to be able to push wherever they want to. What I can tell you is that there is no way that an African rebellion could achieve all of this by itself.'' **********Colonel Kasonga, like the political authorities in the capital, Kinshasa, insists that Mr. Kabila's rebels have been heavily assisted by the armies of Rwanda, Uganda and, to a lesser extent, Burundi. In recent days, Washington has officially come around to this view, publicly warning those countries to stop destabilizing Zaire. **********Many of the recent battlegrounds, in towns like Bafwasende, northeast of Kisangani, have been strongholds of opposition to the Government for three decades. **********Earlier insurrectionists, known as the Simbas, were chased by Belgian mercenaries through the same forests and bombed from the same skies by CIA-contracted Cuban pilots, veterans of the Bay of Pigs invasion. **********While some Zairian officers spoke with determination about eventually winning a war that they knew they were losing, others, who insisted on anonymity, were far more grim. They bemoaned the undisciplined troops, a corrupt and discredited Government and a population that in many areas has been cooperating with the rebels. **********''There is a grand complicity between the people in most of these areas and the rebels,'' said one senior officer, who shrugged as he spoke of the long odds of his cause. ''We don't get any intelligence from them, and many of them are hunters who have no problem picking up weapons against us. **********''After what the Government and the army have done to the people in this country, who can blame them?'' **********A second officer, speaking in resignation, said winning the war was already beyond this army: ''It is true when they say our soldiers are not motivated. They haven't been paid and haven't been led. The only way out of this now is for the Government to make some gesture.'' **********Suggestions that the Government negotiate its way out of this crisis have been angrily rejected until now. At the same time, the political system has never been more feeble. **********When the opposition called a national strike for Monday to demand the resignation of Mr. Mobutu's Prime Minister, Kengo wa Dondo, every major city in Zaire, including Kisangani, was closed for business. **********Foreign diplomats and Zairian military and political analysts here say that if Kisangani falls to the rebels -- a prospect that some consider likely -- the Government will fall and Zaire will dissolve into chaos. **********People close to the Zairian military say precautions are already being taken for a last stand to defend this city. They say that if the threat to Kisangani materializes, mercenaries in the northeast of the country led by Christian Tavernier, a former Belgian officer who has taken part in numerous mercenary adventures here in the last three decades, will be recalled to mount the city's final defense. **********For some, though, the real danger to Kisangani, where few support the Government and many already hate the army, comes from within. **********Since early in his rule, Mr. Mobutu has deliberately kept his army weak and divided, so that it could never threaten his personalized system of power. Whenever the dictator encountered a threat to his rule, he was able to rely on foreign allies, from the United States, Belgium and France to Morocco and Senegal, to help put down the trouble. **********With the loss of the strategic importance that Zaire enjoyed throughout the cold war, the country also lost the military training and assistance that outside powers once openly competed to provide. **********As a result, in the recent fighting the army has spent nearly as much energy chasing deserting units that were pillaging Zairian towns as it has confronting its battlefield adversaries. **********''It is too late to start training people in a country where the army has no tradition of fighting,'' said one foreign military expert. ''At the first sign of trouble, those soldiers that resist looting fire off all of their rounds in the air, strip off their uniforms and run away.'' **********In recent days, the few commercial aircraft that stop in Kisangani and Kindu, the only major airports controlled by the Government in the east, have been crowded by the families of soldiers who, sensing the rapid approach of trouble, have been fleeing to the capital, Kinshasa. Even as they carry their families' belongings on board, many cling nervously to their rifles. **********The army is feared more for the internal threat it poses. That was nearly realized last week when a soldier who was involved in a deal for diamonds shot and killed a pregnant woman. That night, hundreds of angry people marched on the Governor's home, and witnesses said many of them were shouting, ''We want Kabila!'' **********''All it would take is for a few bad soldiers to start acting up here and this place will go up in smoke,'' said one longtime resident. ''The rebels probably can't bite off something as big as Kisangani yet. But if things go wrong here, the population themselves would become rebels overnight.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/22/busin.snippet: Article on popular new brand of soft drinks called energy drinks or extreme beverages; says beverages are generally high in caffeine and sometimes laced with so-called exotic additives, like Brazilian guarana berries or ginseng; holds products, wh...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/22/busin.main_headline: Caffeinated Drinks Catering to Excitable Boys and Girls
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/22/busin.print_headline: Caffeinated Drinks Catering to Excitable Boys and Girls
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/22/busin.body_text: **********They can get you ''high'' or give you a quick ''lift.'' Some people just want them for the ''buzz'' or the sheer pleasure of getting a ''rush,'' while others are lured by the possibility of heightening their sexual drive. **********If these descriptions elicit the illicit, that is because they are probably meant to. These are the terms behind the marketing for a popular new brand of soft drinks called energy drinks or extreme beverages. The beverages are generally high in caffeine and sometimes laced with so-called exotic additives, like Brazilian guarana berries or ginseng. And they all appeal to young people. **********The products, which are under fire from some health experts and banned in at least one school, are primarily marketed to teen-agers and Generation X'ers, many of whom have grown up relishing Nike's mantra to ''Just Do It'' and Gatorade's dictum: ''Life is a Sport. Drink it up!'' **********Indeed, the market for such drinks is so enticing that Coca-Cola and Pepsico -- the twin titans of the beverage industry -- have entered the fray by creating their own supercharged brands, which are now hitting the national market. **********The granddaddy of them all is Pepsi's Mountain Dew, the 50-year-old beverage that has been reincarnated in recent years through a marketing campaign that appeals to young people's eagerness to live on the edge. But that is just the beginning. Surge, which is Coke's answer to Mountain Dew, calls itself a ''fully loaded citrus soda'' and advises drinkers to ''Feed the Rush.'' Meanwhile, the label on Josta -- Pepsi's new caffeine-charged drink -- says that ancient Indians believed that guarana berries had a ''raw, primal power.'' **********The aim of all this heavy breathing is clear: to capture a share of the market for fruit juices and caffeinated beverages, one of the fastest-growing segments of the soft-drink business. **********''In today's society, people are trying to get as much boost as they can, and a drink is one way to do it,'' said Gerald Celente, publisher of Trends Journal. ''And caffeine is the new-millennium drug of choice.'' **********What these beverages have in common is the goal of capturing the fickle taste buds of the ''pumped up'' generation, marketers say, those youths who straddle the world between the hip-hop styles of many inner-city youths and the ''extreme sports'' forays of privileged suburban teen-agers. **********''There's sort of this need for sensory overload,'' said Michael Bainbridge, a senior vice president at the Sterling Group, a brand identity consultant in New York. ''People are looking for total stimulation in all walks of life, and beverages are one way to get that.'' **********And if there is any doubt about what these new energy drinks offer, their names leave little to the imagination. Among the labels are Jolt, Hype, Boost, Guts and Zapped. Others with equally aggressive names include X-Treem Caffeine and Game Face, replete with logos of lightning bolts and spike-headed athletes. **********''What the cola companies have found is that cola is dead,'' said Steven Grasse, head of Gyro Worldwide in Philadelphia, an advertising firm that specializes in marketing to teen-agers and 20-somethings. ''Kids are saying, 'Those are the drinks of my grandparents.' '' **********While the beverage giants bring big budgets and sheer marketing power, most of the new energy drinks are being dreamed up by small outfits operating with much narrower margins. Many of them do not even register yet on the charts of soft-drink sales, according to Beverage Digest, an industry newsletter. But they are turning up at sporting events, dance clubs and a growing number of convenience stores. **********What worries some critics and educators, though, is that the promotions for these new drinks hint at illegal stimulants. For example, two new drinks -- XTC and Krank20 -- are eerily similar in name to illegal drugs like ecstasy, a hallucinogenic stimulant, and crank, a nickname for methamphetamines. **********XTC, a European import that bills itself as a ''carbonated slap in the face,'' says it offers an ''energetic blend of mystical herbs.'' And a bottle of Krank20 is simply caffeinated water with almost twice the caffeine level of Classic Coke. ''Krank20 is water with caffeine,'' the company boasts at its Web site. ''Lots of caffeine. All that we could get away with. If this stuff doesn't roll your oats, better check your pulse.'' **********Many of the drinks rely on similar innuendo. Several beverage makers, for instance, say that guarana is an aphrodisiac. Jolt Cola, which has been around since 1986, promotes itself as ''soda that pops.'' The label on Guts, which is made in New York, reads, ''Warning: contains high energy.'' And Go Go, a drink that is being consumed by ''ravers'' --  young partygoers -- bills itself as an energy drink that will ''blow your mind.'' **********Beverage makers acknowledge that their marketing of these drinks is designed to be stimulating but insist that the tag lines are not meant to be taken literally. ''I won't deny that there's a certain amount of promiscuity with energy drinks,'' said C.J. Rapp, president of the Global Beverage Company in Pacific Palisades, Calif., which sells Jolt and XTC. ''And I won't deny that that's part of the appeal. But to people of the youth generation, the name XTC is cool. The baby-boomer generation would see it in its literal sense; to Generation X, it's merely a figure of speech.'' **********As for Guts, due out in September, the test-marketing shows that this is just ''what our target audience wants,'' said Michael Lyons, a vice president at Guts Beverages, based in Quebec. Mr. Lyons said the target audience for Guts was originally ages 12 to 24. But after testing, the group was broadened to include children as young as 9. As enticements, the company plans to use cartoon characters: a rhinoceros, dinosaur and a turtle. **********Asked whether 9-year-olds need a ''high energy drink,'' Mr. Lyons said, emphatically, ''They're already drinking Mountain Dew and Dr Pepper!'' Indeed, market research shows that Mountain Dew is more than twice as popular than other soft drinks among children younger than 6. **********Some public health advocates are concerned about the wisdom of pushing young children and teen-agers to consume caffeine, which they say is mood-altering and at least mildly addictive. **********Michael Jacobson, executive director at the Center for Science in the Public Interest in Washington, said that he petitioned the Food and Drug Administration earlier this month to require foods and beverages to label their caffeine content. **********''Why there's been a surge in caffeinated soft drinks and waters, I don't know,'' he said. ''I guess we're in a somewhat wilder society than we used to be, and people figure they can get a kick out of soft drinks.'' **********Others, such as Margaret Mohrmann, the head mistress at the Academy, a school for gifted students in Little Rock, Ark., are concerned that children, already full of jitters, will become even more hyperactive after drinking heavily caffeinated beverages. **********Last April, the Academy banned Surge from its snack bar after the students drank themselves into a frenzy. ''I just couldn't believe it,'' Ms. Mohrmann said. ''The kids were holding two in their hands and drinking one after another. When they weren't jumping up in the bathroom, they were climbing the walls.'' **********Ms. Mohrmann said the school was going to ''try it again'' but would limit students to one can of Surge a day. **********While the stimulant plays a crucial role in the appeal of such drinks, the rise in their popularity is not so much about caffeine as it is a tale of how beverage makers -- taking their cue from the sports apparel industry -- are trying to sell a life style. Beverage makers are hoping to score in the same way, say, that Tommy Hilfiger fashions did. **********The model for such promotions is Mountain Dew, which markets to youths with irreverent television spots that show young people engaged in sky-surfing, skateboarding, bungee-jumping and other so-called extreme activities. Despite imitators like Kick, which bills itself as the ''hard core, psycho, nitro drink in a can'' and is made by Royal Crown Cola, a unit of Triarc, Mountain Dew has maintained its dominance of the category and is the fastest-growing soft drink in the country. **********The selling of energy drinks in Asia and Europe is even more explicit than in the United States. And it works. In Europe, energy drinks -- with names like Red Bull, Power Kid and Start Me Up -- sold 500 million liters, or 132 million gallons, according to Canadean, a beverage research firm based in London. **********Hans Vriens, the managing director of Red Bull North America, has recently brought the drink -- its slogan: ''Red Bull gives you wings'' -- to the United States. ''Some energy drinks have the good stuff, and some don't,'' Mr. Vriens boasts. ''We have one brand, one size. There are hundreds of copycats. You take a drink called Hype. That's just what it is.'' **********Companies are mixing, blending, spiking and adding ''exotic'' ingredients to try to bolster their drinks in addition to their sales. Last year, Pepsi even came out with a coffee cola, Pepsi Kona -- which urged customers to ''spank your senses'' -- but the drink was pulled after faring poorly in test-marketing. **********But the youth market seems to be the litmus test on new fashions and new drinks. ''The consumption rate among young people is huge,'' said John Sicher, publisher of Beverage Digest in Bedford Hills, N.Y. ''And brand preferences are not yet formed. They're just going into convenience stores and experimenting.'' **********Just when every beverage maker in America appears to have jumped on the energy drink bandwagon, though, youth fashions are moving in new directions. ''People in the underground are now talking about going back to the natural,'' said Joanne DeLuca, a partner at Sputnik Inc., a marketing group that tracks youth trends for companies like Pepsi and Reebok. ''Now they want natural drinks.'' **********But do not count out the high-energy approach just yet. Pepsi, for instance, is said to be at work on a new, caffeinated lemon-lime drink, tentatively named Storm. **********''Teens are looking for a turn-on that doesn't put them in jail,'' said Tom Pirko, president of Bevmark L.L.C., a beverage consultant. ''They want more stimulation.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/08/world.snippet: Sheik Ahmed Yassin, newly freed leader of militant Islamic movement Hamas, lays out series of positions that seem to hold out prospect of compromise without abandoning traditional aims and methods of Hamas; says suicide attacks on Israel can be su...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/08/world.main_headline: Freed Hamas Leader Suggests Terms for Truce
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/08/world.print_headline: Freed Hamas Leader Suggests Terms for Truce
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/08/world.body_text: **********The newly freed leader of the militant Islamic movement Hamas, guiding it again as a free man, laid out a series of positions today that seemed to hold out a prospect of compromise without abandoning the traditional aims and methods of Hamas. **********Sheik Ahmed Yassin said that suicide attacks on Israel could be suspended under certain conditions, but that an overall truce would require a full Israeli withdrawal from the West Bank and Gaza Strip and the removal of Jewish settlements there. He ruled out permanent reconciliation with Israel. **********The sheik, the founder and spiritual leader of Hamas, spoke to reporters here as he received hundreds of well-wishers, including Yasir Arafat, on his first full day at home after serving eight years of a life sentence in Israeli jails. He was freed last week in exchange for the release of two Israeli agents arrested in Jordan after a failed assassination attempt there against a Hamas leader. He arrived in Gaza Monday. **********Easing back into his leadership role, the sheik seemed to be charting a cautious political course, but the  conditions he spelled out for a suspension of violence seemed highly unlikely to be met by Israel. Nevertheless, David Bar-Illan, communications director for Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, said that the sheik's remarks were ''worth watching'' and ''a positive development if it means something, not just part of the usual rhetoric.'' **********Mr. Yassin's statements came as  Israeli news organizations reported that King Hussein of Jordan had passed on reports of a Hamas cease-fire proposal to Israeli officials two days before the botched assassination attempt, but that the King's message only reached Mr. Netanyahu a day after the incident. **********Abdel Aziz al-Rantisi, the most senior Hamas figure in Gaza after Mr. Yassin, denied today that there had been any cease-fire proposal. ''We have checked with our brothers in Jordan, and there was no such initiative,'' he said. **********Mr. Yassin said it was up to Israel to determine whether there could be a suspension of suicide bombings. **********''The Jews are those who will determine that,'' he said. ''If they stop their attacks on civilians, land confiscation, house demolitions, and release the prisoners and the detainees, then we will definitely ease up, God willing,'' the sheik said. **********A truce with Israel is permitted by  Islam, but not a permanent reconciliation, the sheik added. ''If Israel withdraws completely from the West Bank and the Gaza Strip and it removes all of its settlements, I will make a truce with it,'' he said. **********Similar conditions for a truce have been set in the past in leaflets issued by the armed wing of Hamas after bombings in Israel, but Israeli Governments have not taken them to be serious offers. **********Asked if he would press for more suicide attacks if his terms for a truce were rejected by the Israelis, the sheik replied: ''It is inconceivable that a person should stand idly by while his soil is occupied, and his people and homeland are degraded.'' **********He added: ''In our religion it is forbidden to kill a child, a woman or an elderly man, but when you kill my wife, my daughter, my son, I have the right to defend myself.'' **********While insisting that Hamas would not negotiate with Israel, the sheik left a door open to indirect contacts through the Palestinian Authority. ''If we want something, we ask for it from the Palestinian Authority, and it will negotiate about it with Israel,'' he said. ''We don't have two authorities.'' **********While some Israeli security officials have warned that the sheik's return might embolden Hamas to make fresh attacks, Palestinian officials and commentators heard a politically shrewd ambiguity in his remarks today. The sheik's careful language, they said, indicated that he could become a force for moderation within Hamas now that he is no longer behind bars. **********''He's willing to deal,'' said Ziad Abu Amr, an academic expert on Islamic movements and a Palestinian legislator from Gaza. ''He's a little ambiguous, this is his political style, he doesn't want to commit if nothing is offered.'' **********But Sheik Yassin ''will be a moderating influence on his colleagues'' Mr. Abu Amr added. ''He doesn't want to complicate the situation. He is a reformist, still fighting to change his society, not a revolutionary like the new breed of Hamas leadership that was the product of a revolutionary situation -- the intifada.'' **********Although Sheik Yassin's wide popularity in Gaza poses a challenge to the leadership of Mr. Arafat, his return might also provide the moral authority necessary for Hamas and the Palestinian Authority to halt anti-Israeli violence. **********The two men projected a sense of harmony when they met tonight near the sheik's home in the shabby Sabra neighborhood of Gaza. **********Mr. Arafat took the sheik's limp hand and told him: ''God willing, we will pray together in Al Aksa Mosque,'' referring to the mosque in Jerusalem that is Islam's third holiest shrine.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/23/busin.snippet: Peter Lund, president of CBS television network, resigns after being informed that he will no longer oversee CBS's television stations division; executives say Michael H Jordan, chief executive of CBS and its parent company, Westinghouse Electric,...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/23/busin.body_text: **********Peter Lund, the president of the CBS television network, has resigned after being informed that he would no longer oversee CBS's television stations division, high-level executives within the company said yesterday. **********The executives said that Michael H. Jordan, the chief executive of CBS and its parent company, Westinghouse Electric, had told Mr. Lund that he was reorganizing the company to put the 14 CBS stations under the direction of Mel Karmazin, the chief executive of the corporation's radio division. Mr. Karmazin was the president and chief executive of Infinity Broadcasting, which Westinghouse acquired last year for $3.7 billion. **********Mr. Lund then told Mr. Jordan that he was quitting, according to one executive who had spoken with Mr. Lund. **********Mr. Lund, 56, had been president of CBS since 1994. **********''I just didn't agree with the proposed new structure,'' Mr. Lund said last night. ''This is not about Mel -- I think Mel will do a terrific job. But this is a serious difference of opinion on how the responsibilities should be divided.'' **********Whispered word of the resignation quickly spread through a packed cocktail party last evening at Tavern on the Green in Manhattan, where hundreds of advertising representatives had gathered with CBS Entertainment division executives to celebrate after an afternoon presentation to advertisers of CBS's fall prime-time lineup for the coming season. **********Mr. Jordan attended the party, but when questioned by reporters he declined to comment on the Lund matter. **********CBS executives questioned at the advertisers' party expressed shock and dismay at the news. They also said that whatever the merits of the reorganization, to have this upheaval happen on the day the company was trying to make a positive impression on potential advertisers was poor timing. **********''The timing couldn't be worse,'' one senior executive said, citing not only the prime-time presentation yesterday, but the annual meeting of affiliated stations, scheduled for next week in Los Angeles, at which CBS had planned to promote its stability. **********Mr. Lund was popular with CBS station executives, who felt he was on his way to turning the company's fortunes around, and some of them reacted with shock to news of his resignation. **********The resignation greatly increases the power of Mr. Karmazin, whose experience is in radio. **********Indeed, many CBS television executives had already expressed concern, even before yesterday, at a possible increase in power by Mr. Karmazin. **********In June 1996, Westinghouse purchased Infinity Broadcasting for $3.7 billion, giving the corporation 83 stations in 16 markets with total advertising revenue of more than $1 billion. The deal was said to be the largest in the history of radio. **********But the year before, when Westinghouse took over CBS, Mr. Jordan took special care to point out the value of CBS's radio division, and even to express his admiration for its then-rival, Infinity, whose radio personalities included Howard Stern and Don Imus. **********One CBS executive at yesterday's party spoke of a ''palace revolt brewing,'' saying division heads would unite to try to persuade Mr. Jordan to reverse his decision. **********But another, equally high-placed executive said that ''palace revolt is too strong a term,'' despite the widespread respect for Mr. Lund and dismay at the news. **********In November 1995, the Federal Communications Commission approved Westinghouse's $5.4 billion purchase of CBS, which at that time had been running a distant third to NBC and ABC in the prime-time ratings.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/16/busin.snippet: Pres Clinton says Mexico has repaid the $12.5 billion it borrowed from Washington to stave off financial collapse two years ago, and done it three years ahead of schedule; this ends one of Clinton's riskiest overseas ventures and releases Mexico f...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/16/busin.main_headline: Mexico Repays Bailout by U.S. Ahead of Time
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/16/busin.print_headline: Mexico Repays Bailout by U.S. Ahead of Time
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/16/busin.body_text: **********President Clinton said today that Mexico had repaid all of the $12.5 billion it borrowed from Washington to stave off a financial collapse two years ago, ending one of Mr. Clinton's riskiest overseas ventures and releasing Mexico from tight economic controls imposed by Washington. **********The repayment of the loan -- three years ahead of schedule -- was marked by a celebration at the White House today presided over by Mr. Clinton and Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin, who had warned that a default by Mexico could bring down economies around the world. **********''Two years ago helping our friend and neighbor in a time of need was quite controversial,'' Mr. Clinton said today, a reference to his decision to do an end run around Congress, which refused to act on an emergency package for Mexico, and to lend the cash from funds under the President's control. **********''Some said that we should not get involved, that the money would never be repaid, that Mexico should fend for itself,'' Mr. Clinton said. ''They were wrong.'' He stopped short of naming those opponents, who included Ross Perot, Patrick J. Buchanan and Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, the New York Republican. **********Mr. D'Amato made several attempts to stop the transfer of funds to Mexico, declaring in March 1995 that ''the Mexican bailout is a failure'' and that the Administration had made the economic climate in Mexico ''far worse than it needed to become.'' **********Today, Mr. D'Amato issued a terse statement saying that he was ''pleased'' and attributed the quick repayment to ''vigilant Congressional oversight.'' **********In the end, Mr. Clinton said, the United States ran a profit of more than half a billion dollars on the loans. **********That money, which American officials said would go toward deficit reduction in the United States, is above the interest the cash would have earned had it remained in the Federal Reserve's emergency stabilization fund, which was originally designed to steady the dollar rather than the currencies of allies. **********In Mexico City, the news prompted a rally in the stock and bond markets -- in part because paying off the loans meant that the country no longer needed to put up its oil production revenues as collateral. The Mexican stock market rose 2.66 percent today and is up more than 12 percent this year. **********President Ernesto Zedillo declared that the Government had made a ''bold step toward the economic recovery of Mexico.'' **********In fact, what Mr. Zedillo did today was what most prudent homeowners do when interest rates dip: he refinanced. In the seven months that followed the collapse of the peso in December 1994, and the ensuing dance with national bankruptcy, private lenders refused to go near Mexico, only worsening its troubles. **********For that reason, Mexico secured a credit line from the United States of $20 billion, but only needed to borrowed 60 percent of that. But now, with renewed confidence in the Government's reforms -- confidence that some economists warn is premature -- investors around the world are once again rushing to lend Mexico all that it needs. **********So Mr. Zedillo's Government is exchanging high interest loans from Washington with new bonds issued by Mexico. While those bonds carry relatively high interest rates, Mexican officials said today that they would save Mexico about $100 million a year in payments. **********''Some predicted that our country would collapse, that the foreign aid would be unpayable and infringe our sovereignty, and that in the short term we'd be in a worse crisis,'' Mr. Zedillo said in a morning speech in Mexico City. But the early retirement of the debt to the United States Treasury demonstrates, Mr. Zedillo said, ''the coherence and responsibility the Mexican people and Government have shown in these tough times.'' **********The Mexican debt crisis produced some of Mr. Rubin's tensest days at the Treasury, and in private he hinted that he worried throughout the spring of 1995 that it could fail. ''This was Bob Rubin's Bosnia,'' one of his top aides said today. ''And today he got the troops out.'' **********The usually understated former investment banker was clearly reveling in the success of the bailout today. **********In the Roosevelt Room at the White House, Mr. Clinton sidestepped a question about a recent decline in the value of the peso and deferred to Mr. Rubin, explaining ''you've made so much more money than I have.'' **********''There is a point to that!'' said Mr. Rubin, who usually makes no references -- even in jest -- to his huge fortune. **********Back at the Treasury later in the day Mr. Rubin raised an eyebrow when his deputy, Lawrence H. Summers -- who was the first to recognize the possible ripple effects of the crisis in emerging markets and who organized much of the loan effort -- joked that he would settle for just 1 percent of the Treasury's $580 million profit on the deal. **********''Larry, anything you can negotiate, I'm happy to split with you,'' Mr. Rubin shot back. **********While the Administration was eager to describe Mexico today as a patient in recovery, the cost was high for Mexican workers who lost their jobs during the austerity program imposed as a condition of the loans, for homeowners who were unable to pay their mortgages and for businesses that suddenly found themselves caught in a severe recession. **********Crime has soared in Mexico City, the pay of Mexican workers is still badly depressed, and the peso has stabilized but failed to return to its earlier values. While Mr. Clinton made much of the fact that American exports to Mexico were higher today than they were in 1994, before the crisis struck, he failed to mention that the trade deficit with Mexico had surged by nearly $18 billion. **********Mexico's Finance Minister, Guillermo Ortiz, said in an interview today that Mexico had assembled the funds for its final payment to the United States -- previously it had paid off about 70 percent of its debt -- by selling bonds denominated mostly in foreign currencies in European, Asian and American markets. **********The most recent bonds, which had terms of five to 10 years, generally longer than Mexico had on the United States debt, had yields of 3.35 percent more than United States Treasury securities. **********''That's a lot lower than we were paying a year ago,'' Mr. Ortiz said. The rates, which are also generally lower than those Mexico was paying to the United States, reflect the recovery of international confidence in Mexico's solvency made possible by Mexico's tough economic program and the American bailout, he said. **********''Obviously the crisis took a toll in terms of economic welfare, and incomes are still down from their 1994 level,'' Mr. Ortiz added. ''Consumption has not completely recovered yet. But had we not had the support of the international financial community and of the United States, the consequences would have been much worse.'' **********Nonetheless, average Mexicans will still have difficulty understanding today's debt-retirement celebrations, said Rafael Fernandez, a professor at the Autonomous Technical Institute in Mexico. ''The left will argue that in order to pay off these debts so quickly, Zedillo has had to impose tough austerity, and those that are suffering are the poor,'' he said. **********One of the byproducts of the Mexican crisis was a move by the United States to press for far more extensive disclosure of critical financial information by countries around the world -- data that had they been published by the Mexican Government in 1994 would have made it clear that the country's foreign exchange reserves had dwindled to dangerously low levels. That meant Mexico was unable to pay $29 billion in short-term debt that was denominated in dollars. **********Mr. Rubin and Mr. Summers worried during the bailout that they were creating a ''moral hazard'' -- that other countries around the world might see the United States as a lender of last resort in financial crises. **********''I'm not as concerned about that today,'' Mr. Rubin said this afternoon. ''This experience has been enormously painful for the Mexican people. Countries are unlikely to decide that if worse comes to worse, we'll do what Mexico did.'' **********Mr. Rubin and Mr. Summers have also worked to set up international emergency funds, to which all nations would contribute, to handle further Mexican-style crises. **********Today Representative James A. Leach of Iowa, the Republican chairman of the House Banking and Financial Services Committee, praised the success of the bailout but warned that ''great caution is going to have to be exercised in assuming that this is the only or best way to proceed.'' American taxpayers, he said, cannot be ''placed disproportionately in jeopardy.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/27/world.snippet: United States to grant political asylum to Chang Sung Gil, North Korea's Ambassador to Egypt, highest-ranking North Korean to seek asylum in US, his brother, Chang Sung Ho, diplomat, and their families; has brought them to US; Clinton Administrati...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/27/world.main_headline: DEFECTING ENVOY FROM NORTH KOREA TO GET U.S. ASYLUM
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/27/world.print_headline: DEFECTING ENVOY FROM NORTH KOREA TO GET U.S. ASYLUM
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/27/world.body_text: **********The United States announced today that it would grant political asylum to North Korea's Ambassador to Egypt, his brother and their families. Officials said American intelligence agents had spirited them out of Egypt and brought them to this country over the weekend. **********The Ambassador, Chang Sung Gil, is the highest-ranking North Korean to seek political asylum in the United States. While the Clinton Administration said little publicly for fear of upsetting delicate negotiations with North Korea, senior officials described the defections as an intelligence bonanza for the United States. **********As head of the embassy in Cairo, one of the North's most important  postings, Mr. Chang was familiar with his Government's dealings in the Middle East, especially its sale of missiles and other arms to Egypt, Syria and Iran, the officials said. The sales to Iran, in particular, have been of concern to the United States and allies in the region, including Israel. **********The fact that Mr. Chang defected to the United States -- and not to South Korea, as others have -- means that the Central Intelligence Agency will be the first to interview him, without having to work through the filter of South Korea's intelligence services. **********Mr. Chang's brother, Chang Sung Ho, also a diplomat, served most recently as the trade attache at North Korea's mission in France.  The Ambassador's wife is an actress who, one official said, had close ties with the leadership in Pyongyang, including North Korea's top leader, Kim Jong Il. Officials declined to disclose her name, citing security concerns. The South Korean press identified her as Choe Hae Ok. **********The State Department announced the defections one day before delegates from the United States and North Korea are to meet in New York for a third round of talks about missile proliferation. **********In those talks Washington has pressed the North to accept international restraints on exporting missiles and missile technology. American officials say they expect to discover at the talks on Wednesday whether the defections will produce any diplomatic fallout. **********$(North Korea demanded on Wednesday that Washington hand over the Ambassador and his brother, who it said had defected to avoid punishment for embezzling public funds and leaking state secrets, Reuters reported. A Foreign Ministry spokesman said the brothers had been dismissed in late July and ordered home for investigation. **********$(''Any individual or authority that conceals or protects the criminals will be considered to have been involved in their crimes and will be made to bear due responsibility,'' the official Korean Central News Agency quoted the spokesman as saying in a report monitored in Tokyo.$) **********Just last week the State Department announced that it had imposed new economic sanctions on North Korea for the ''missile technology proliferation activities'' of two companies. The two companies were accused of exporting components that could be used in missiles. The penalties are only symbolic, though, because the United States has no trade with North Korea. **********The State Department's spokesman, James P. Rubin, declined to provide more than the sketchiest details of the defections and the Administration's decision to grant asylum. He would not discuss how the diplomats had left Egypt. **********He did say the episode should have little effect on the missile talks in New York or on the ''four party'' talks that the United States, China and the two Koreas are to resume next month. Those talks are a forum for negotiating a formal peace treaty to end the Korean War. **********In recent years, as North Korea's increasingly isolated Government has faced economic collapse and political uncertainty, it has suffered scores of defections to South Korea, most of them through China or other third countries. **********Mr. Chang, 48, served as Ambassador in Cairo for three years. He was apparently only a month away from returning home when he appeared at the United States Embassy in Cairo on Friday seeking asylum, American officials said. He previously served in the Foreign Ministry, reaching the rank of Deputy Minister. **********The officials said Mr. Chang and his brother, who left Paris with his  wife and two children earlier, apparently had coordinated their defections. **********The United States has not yet officially granted asylum, but rather a temporary status, known as parole, that is the first step toward asylum. The officials said the Koreans would receive full asylum as soon as necessary legal steps were taken. **********The senior official said Mr. Chang might have feared punishment when he returned to Pyongyang, perhaps because he had failed to persuade Egypt to provide more emergency food aid. The Government in Pyongyang has desperately sought aid to cope with starvation brought on by the economic decay and by recent floods, followed now by a drought. In addition, South Korean reports said his son had earlier defected to the West, and presumably he would have faced punishment for that. **********Mr. Chang is North Korea's first Ambassador to defect, although lower-ranking diplomats in Africa defected in 1991 and 1996. **********The most senior North Korean to defect was Hwang Jang Yop, a former member of Pyongyang's ruling council and an early mentor to Kim Jong Il. He sought asylum in Beijing in February and, after a brief stop in the Philippines, arrived in South Korea in April. He defected after attending a conference in Japan, where he failed to obtain food aid. **********Mr. Hwang has since warned that his country is preparing to wage war against the South, but officials in Washington have played down his comments, saying he had not been in a position of power in recent years.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/17/busin.body_text: **********French Concerns Rebuffed As Currency Plan Proceeds **********European leaders reaffirmed their commitment to the planned common currency, agreeing to a ''stability pact'' that requires them to tighten government spending and dismissing French arguments that their No. 1 target should be the reduction of unemployment, not budget deficits. **********France's new Socialist Government had demanded public works investments to create jobs, but it retreated after Britain's Prime Minister, Tony Blair, above, and other leaders made clear at a summit meeting that they would not support such spending. Instead, the French won only vague language promising to address unemployment. $(Page A1.$) **********The dollar slipped, in part because traders bought German marks on diminishing fears that the single currency would be weak. $(D17.$) **********Maybe That's Why They're the Big 3 **********American car makers, inspired by the recent popularity of big cars and trucks, are planning ever larger models with equally gigantic sticker prices. Ford is planning a vehicle that at 19 feet would dethrone the Chevrolet and GMC Suburban by a foot as the longest mass-produced family vehicle ever built. $(A1.$) **********Ban on Liquor Ads on TV Delayed **********President Clinton's efforts to keep liquor ads off television were dealt a setback when a Republican member of the F.C.C., Rachelle B. Chong, won a delay of at least a month in a proposed investigation into the ads. $(A18.$) **********Nasdaq Rises, but Dow Is Off a Bit **********Stocks were mixed, after last week's buying spree.
