https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/15/world.snippet: Commander Vasily Tsibliyev and flight engineer Aleksandr Lazutkin of troubled Russian space station Mir return to earth, after longest, most serious and most highly publicized string of disasters in 11-year history of space station; comments by Pr...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/15/world.main_headline: Hapless Crew Of Mir Station Back on Earth
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/15/world.print_headline: Hapless Crew Of Mir Station Back on Earth
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/15/world.body_text: **********After six of the least glorious months in the history of manned space flight, the hapless crew of the Mir space station retreated from the cosmos this afternoon, floating to earth three hours later in a cloud of dust on the steppes of Kazakstan. **********''I hope that everything that went wrong here is leaving with us,'' the forlorn commander, Vasily Tsibliyev, told the three crew members who remained, as he prepared to leave the space station. ''We are leaving now. See you on earth.'' **********Upon being told that his Soyuz space capsule had successfully cast away from the Mir, Mr. Tsibliyev muttered, ''Thank god.'' **********And as soon as he and the flight engineer, Aleksandr Lazutkin, landed, after a final glitch or two, he flashed a big smile and said, in response to the usual question: ''What other feelings could we have? We are just happy to be back.'' **********The euphoria may fade fast, though, because Mr. Tsibliyev has some explaining to do. He presided over the longest, most serious and most highly publicized string of disasters in the 11-year history of the space station. **********President Boris N. Yeltsin has already set the mood for the return, complaining in an aside on Friday that the Mir was a technical marvel, and that its legion of recent problems was due solely to ''human error.'' That is shorthand for Mr. Tsibliyev, the 43-year-old veteran astronaut who spent seven months on the station in 1993 and six months there this year. **********In June he crashed a supply ship into the part of Mir that supplies much of its electricity, causing the station to lose nearly half its power. While he and his crew circled the globe there was a major fire, serious oxygen failures and several problems with the power supply system. The cooling system failed, and so did the process that turns urine into bath water. **********For a while a delayed supply ship forced the crew to wonder if it would ever be able to discard its own mounting heaps of trash. **********Then, after the crash in June, Mr. Tsibliyev developed stress-induced heart problems that convinced ground controllers he was in no shape to attempt the tricky repairs the station now needs to survive. **********Today Mr. Yeltsin released a statement praising the ''persistence, courage and heroism'' the astronauts showed during their mission. Nobody was fooled. At Mission Control, in the suburbs near Moscow, the deputy fight director, Viktor Blagov, suggested that Mr. Tsibliyev's troubles had just begun. **********''We have found not a single fault in the systems of either Mir or Progress during the collision,'' Mr. Blagov said at a news conference. Progress was the supply ship that rammed into the side of the Spektr science module while Mr. Tsibliyev was guiding it. ''A logical conclusion follows -- technology was not at fault there,'' Mr. Blagov concluded abruptly, implying rather baldly that the fault was Mr. Tsibliyev's. **********The final judgments on the crewmen will probably have to wait until next week, when other astronauts begin to repair the damage. They are  Anatoly Solovyov and Pavel Vinogradov, who arrived on the station Aug. 7, and the American astronaut Michael Foale, who is staying on from the earlier crew. **********First they will try to reconnect the power supply system that has been cut since the accident on June 25. If that succeeds, the team will try to find and repair the hole in the side of the craft. **********If they can fix the problem, then Mir will almost certainly continue  training astronauts to work on a new international space station. But if they fail, then the accident in June will almost certainly have meant the end of the space station, and possibly of Russia's long, vigorous role in manned space flight. **********Even today's getaway appears to have been marred somewhat by the type of minor problems that have come to define Mir. **********The crew landed a little early today and, according to Russian television, that was because Mission Control called a last-minute switch. **********Mr. Tsibliyev and Mr. Lazutkin were supposed to circle the station and photograph the damage before beginning their descent into the atmosphere. **********At the last moment, according to the network, they were told to skip the photo shoot. Why? In 1994, the last time Mr. Tsibliyev left the station, he ran his Soyuz capsule into one of its sides, a minor fender-bender that required no real repair. But at Mission Control today, the nervous leadership decided that their weary commander had had all the flying he needed and it was time to get him home simply and quickly. **********Even the final landing proved faulty. The engines that are supposed to fire and slow the capsule, and soften the impact, failed to work properly. The parachute system performed flawlessly, though, and neither the crew nor the capsule seemed harmed. **********As soon as they landed this afternoon the astronauts were flown by helicopter to a nearby base to undergo preliminary medical examinations. They then traveled by plane to Chkalovsky military air base near Moscow. Late this evening they arrived at the main space training ground, Star City, where they were to be reunited with their families. **********On Saturday the two will face the Russian press, which has devoured  their cosmic mishaps with great eagerness, for the first time. Soon after, if they choose, they will be free to try to forget the whole journey. **********''Sure they will have some effects of the trip and the re-entry,'' said Igor Goncharov, the mission's chief doctor, speaking about the psychological scars of the last six months. ''Who wouldn't after what they've been through?''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/05/busin.main_headline: I.M.F. Seeks Thai Decision on Lenders
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/05/busin.print_headline: I.M.F. Seeks Thai Decision on Lenders
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/05/busin.body_text: **********The International Monetary Fund wants the Thai Government to move faster on deciding the future of 58 finance companies that have been shut since June because of insolvency, the central bank governor said today. **********''The I.M.F. is satisfied'' with measures imposed since a $17.2 billion emergency credit line was extended in August, said the Bank of Thailand governor, Chaiyawat Wibulswasdi, after a meeting today with fund officials. The main concern is ''quick resolution'' about the insolvent lenders. **********''We should have a final decision in early December,'' the governor said. That would be just before a scheduled meeting in Washington by I.M.F. directors. The meeting will discuss the three-month review of Thailand's progress that is expected to be complete in about a week, he said. **********Thailand shut 16 lenders on June 27. Another 42 of the country's 91 nonbank lenders were shut in August, after Thailand sought the I.M.F.'s aid. The Thai central bank lent those 58 institutions 430 billion baht in its failed effort to keep them solvent. **********Though closed for regular business, some finance companies have been allowed to provide some services. **********Indonesia received a $23 billion credit line last week through the I.M.F. It immediately closed 16 banks permanently.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/23/busin.body_text: **********KERNAN-Leslie Hadden on October 21, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Walter Avery Kernan; mother of Anita Halton, Mary Rutherfurd, Emily Rafferty, Nancy Chamberlain, Beatrice and Charles; grandmother of Anita Halton; Leslie Coleman, Lily and Emily Rutherfurd, Nicholas and Sara Rafferty, and Katherine Chamberlain; and sister of Anita Hadden Page and the late Hamilton Hadden Jr. Funeral Mass, 10:30 A.M., Friday, October 24th, at Church of St. Ignatius Loyola, Park Avenue at 84th Street. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Interfaith Neighbors, Inc., 247 East 82nd Street, New York, New York 10028. **********KERNAN-Leslie Hadden. The Board of Directors and Staff of the Visiting Nurse Service of New York deeply mourns the loss of Leslie H. Kernan, a former Director and devoted friend. She served the agency with distinction in many capacities and will be sorely missed. Our sympathy is extended to her children and other members of her family. Carl H. Pforzheimer III Chairman of the Board Carol Raphael President and CEO **********KERNAN-Leslie. The families, staff and Board of Directors of Interfaith Neighbors extend their deepest sympathy to the Kernan family. A gentle, wise soul, a fellow board and council member, and a dear friend, Leslie (Coupie) will be sorely missed. Her dedication to Interfaith Neighbors will continue to make a huge difference in the lives of New York City children and families. **********KERNAN-Leslie. The Board of Directors of 1105 Park Avenue expresses their profound sorrow over the death of Leslie Kernan, a past member of the Board and long-standing resident of 1105 Park Avenue. On behalf of the residents of the building, we offer our deepest condolences to her family.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/02/busin.main_headline: Accounting Board Proposal On Derivatives Is Getting Heat
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/02/busin.print_headline: Accounting Board Proposal On Derivatives Is Getting Heat
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/02/busin.body_text: **********Ten years after it first began looking into the matter, the group responsible for establishing the nation's accounting standards has finally issued the draft proposal of a new rule that would require companies to report their use of derivatives -- those complex financial instruments like futures, swaps and options intended to protect against unforeseen risks. **********But some of the banks and corporations that object to the proposal by the Financial Accounting Standards Board are expected to continue fighting it in hopes of persuading the board to back down before adopting a final rule. **********Under the proposed rule, which the accounting standards board posted on its World Wide Web site (www.fasb.org) late Friday, companies would be forced to show the fair-market value of derivatives on their balance sheets. Under certain circumstances, they would also have to adjust their reported profit to reflect changes in the derivatives' value. **********The proposal, which runs some 200 pages and offers dozens of illustrations detailing the ins and outs of the rule, incorporates a number of changes from a preliminary outline offered by the accounting board more than a year ago. **********''The revised proposal reflects most of what we heard from respondents to the exposure draft,'' said Edmund L. Jenkins, the new chairman of the board -- an independent, private-sector group -- who said that it had sought to simplify the accounting and to allow companies greater flexibility. **********The draft will be subject to a 45-day comment period. After that, if the rule is finally approved by the board, it would go into effect at the beginning of 1999. **********The proposal for the complex new accounting treatment puts the F.A.S.B. on the hot seat. The group has been viewed as increasingly vulnerable to pressure from the companies that are affected by its rules. In one embarrassing failure, it was forced to retreat after it proposed requiring companies to treat the stock options they awarded employees as an expense. Protests from business, particularly high-technology companies, culminated in a threat of Congressional intervention. Another event of that sort would be a significant blow to the accounting board's credibility. **********Opposition to the proposed rule is already mounting. In recent weeks, dozens of executives from major financial companies like Bankers Trust, Citicorp, Chase Manhattan, Fannie Mae, Keycorp, J. P. Morgan and Goldman, Sachs have expressed concern about the rule's impact and argued that the board should have delayed issuing its proposal. And Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, has joined the argument, saying the board should reconsider its position because of companies' serious concerns that the rule ''would not improve the financial reporting of derivatives activities and would constrain prudent risk-management practices.'' **********But the accounting board seems to be marshaling strong support from outside its ranks as well as from the Financial Accounting Foundation, which supports and oversees the group. The foundation's new chairman, who took over Aug. 1, is Manuel H. Johnson, a former Fed vice chairman and co-chairman of Johnson Smick International, an economic consulting firm in Washington. Mr. Johnson was among the new trustees brought in last year when the Securities and Exchange Commission pushed for more public representatives on the foundation's board. **********''F.A.S.B. has not had a good enough network and system of support,'' Mr. Johnson said in a telephone interview before the draft proposal was released. ''It has been left out there isolated.'' **********Although the foundation has no say in the drafting of accounting rules, Mr. Johnson said he believed that the trustees could play a major role in educating their fellow executives and building more support from companies that use financial statements and benefit from the board's rule-making. **********Mr. Johnson's willingness to stand behind the board may be particularly valuable as a counterweight to Mr. Greenspan. ''I think the Fed is an important element,'' said Mr. Johnson, who worked with Mr. Greenspan at the central bank. He said he would try to make sure that the issues raised by the Federal Reserve, which oversees banking regulation, were considered carefully by the accounting board. **********But Mr. Johnson dismissed a notion raised in recent weeks that the board's process had not been sufficiently deliberate and open to comment. **********''No one can accuse F.A.S.B. of dropping a time bomb,'' he said, pointing out that the board had been contemplating the matter of financial instruments for a decade or more. ''This issue has been beaten to death.'' **********The board also has the backing of the Securities and Exchange Commission. ''We must not lose sight of the fact that this project grew out of widespread concerns about major derivatives losses that caught investors by surprise in 1994,'' said Michael H. Sutton, chief accountant for the S.E.C., in a prepared statement. ''The F.A.S.B.'s proposal responds to the need for more transparent derivatives accounting.'' Companies like Procter & Gamble and Gibson Greetings reported substantial losses from their use of derivatives. **********Among the board's other supporters are the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants, whose president and chief executive, Barry Melancon, described the issue as ''too complex to be determined according to purely political pressures.'' The Association for Investment Management and Research is also backing the accounting standards board. **********But banks, whose industry is most affected by the new rule, may still take their case to Congress. A letter from a group of 22 executives at major banks and corporations argued that the accounting treatment of derivatives involved crucial issues that ''must be considered, if not by the F.A.S.B., then by the Securities and Exchange Commission, other regulatory agencies or Congress.'' **********Mr. Jenkins expressed dismay at the notion that the development of accounting rules would become a subject of Congressional debate. **********''I would be quite disappointed if this matter comes before Congress,'' he said. ''I believe standard-setting belongs in the private sector.'' **********He is ready for battle, however. ''We are well prepared,'' he said, ''to defend what we have done.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/23/busin.main_headline: New Bells and Whistles, But the Same Old Wires
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/23/busin.print_headline: New Bells and Whistles, But the Same Old Wires
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/23/busin.body_text: **********ALMOST the entire world agreed recently to deregulate telephone markets, based on the American model. The move has been portrayed as leading to lower prices for phone calls -- a realistic possibility. But if you remember when the United States deregulated telecommunications a year ago, we were promised a lot more than just lower prices. Supposedly, the invisible hand of the marketplace would also build an information superhighway into our homes. Despite the talk from the deregulated utilities, this hasn't happened yet, and it doesn't look as if it will happen anytime soon. **********The twisted paths woven by the three cables coming into our homes -- electricity, telephone and cable television -- are matched only by the pretzel logic advanced by those who celebrate telecommunications  deregulation. When Congress and President Clinton deregulated the communications industry, the program was sold on the premise that competition allowing phone companies to carry television signals, for example,  would spur technical advancement and lower prices. Private investment, the theory  went, would provide all the capital needed for the information superhighway. **********But in a short time, deregulation has degenerated into a game in which the wires never change. Instead of a new fiber-optic cable in every home (carrying voice, data and video), the same old wires are simply being sold under different brand names and  with different pricing. **********The jury is still out on whether deregulation will lower prices, but it is becoming  clearer that no major communications companies plan a true information superhighway. Over the next few years, billions of dollars will be poured into selling new brands of services, but there are no signs that even a dime will be spent to bring a technologically superior cable to your home. **********For example, both AT&T and MCI have plans to offer local phone service on a widespread basis. But are they planning to build a new cable into your home? No. They want to use existing lines from the local telephone companies. **********A few years ago, several Baby Bells teamed up to find a way to deliver digital television over telephone wires, in anticipation of deregulation. Deregulation is here, and now their joint venture, Tele-TV, is  disbanding, saying the technical hurdles are too great. Instead, one of the phone companies, Pacific Telesis, will start offering wireless cable. But this 20-year-old technology, previously known as multichannel multipoint distribution service, or M.M.D.S., offers no advantages over cable or multichannel satellite television services except that it is cheaper to build than running wires into homes or launching a satellite. In New York City, Liberty Cable, a similar wireless cable service offering fewer channels than regular cable television, has operated for years. **********When allowing phone companies into the cable television business was first proposed, didn't everyone expect them to upgrade their phone wires? When competition was proposed for local phone service, wasn't it assumed that there would be new and improved wires to provide this service? By the same logic, cable television companies, now allowed to offer phone service, could enter the local phone market by leasing the existing phone wires from the Baby Bells, thus eliminating any need to upgrade their cable TV wires to handle phone calls. **********Now, electric companies are about to become deregulated. But don't expect any new and improved wires here, either. The plan is to allow similar leasing of existing wires. **********PACIFICORP, a West Coast power company serving 1.4 million customers, announced last month that it would start offering Internet access, long-distance telephone service and cable television. It sounds like a high-technology approach, especially if you have read reports  about how electric companies were developing ways to carry phone calls and other information over their wires. But take another look: Pacificorp has only made deals to resell a potpourri of services -- satellite TV, wireless modem service and long-distance telephone -- from existing providers using the existing wires. The breakthrough is that a single company will bill customers  for all the services. Similar plans for one-stop shopping were recently announced by two other power companies. **********Imagine the possibilities: If you're short of cash one month, instead of choosing between having your telephone or cable TV or electricity cut off, maybe you can lose them all at once. **********The comedian Jerry Seinfeld has defined regifting as giving a gift you've received to someone else. Now, rebranding -- providing an existing service under a new brand name -- has made a joke of telecommunications deregulation. Instead of freeing companies to develop exciting new technologies, it has freed them to develop new marketing plans to sell you services you can already get elsewhere. **********Perhaps the most pathetic example of re-branding is the way AT&T entered the multichannel television business last year to compete with cable television. Is this a new video-over-phone technology? No. AT&T just slaps its logo onto a standard satellite dish. This from the company that tantalized a generation of kids, myself included, with  the Picturephone at the 1964-65 New York World's Fair, and that, in 1984, was forced to divest itself of those very local phone wires they're now trying to lease back in the name of competition in local phone service. **********As a nation, we need to commit ourselves to building a true information superhighway. We need to invest in the communications infrastructure in the way we invested in the transportation infrastructure in the 1950's and 60's, with interstate highways. **********Just as these highways have promoted the free flow of goods, a national information superhighway would promote the free flow of ideas. Rechristening the same old wires and technology under new brand names adds about as much to the advancement of communications as Hershey adds to the future of chocolate by wrapping its Kisses in different wrappers for different holidays. **********Instead of building a bridge to the future,  we're turning our public utilities into ad agencies. So far, deregulation has contributed nothing toward building that bridge, but it's sure helping to build brand awareness.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/23/busin.snippet: Novelist Patricia Cornwell describes her personal and financial travails and her efforts to handle her fortune, which now amounts to about $10 million; photos; charts (L)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/23/busin.main_headline: New Chapter for a Serial Spender
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/23/busin.print_headline: New Chapter for a Serial Spender
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/23/busin.body_text: **********BY all rights, Patricia Cornwell should have been out celebrating at the dawn of 1993. Her crime thriller ''All That Remains'' was on the best-seller list and another, ''Cruel and Unusual,'' was on the way. The money was pouring in -- she had made more than $1 million the previous year -- and the actress Demi Moore was talking about starring as Dr. Kay Scarpetta, the medical examiner who is the heroine of Ms. Cornwell's novels, in a movie. **********Not bad for a 37-year-old divorced former reporter who three years earlier had been working in a windowless office in the basement of the Richmond morgue, borrowing money from friends to pay the bills. **********But instead of making merry, Ms. Cornwell sat alone in the living room of a rented beach cottage in Malibu, Calif., on a January afternoon, working on a screenplay for ''Cruel and Unusual'' and polishing off a pitcher of Bloody Marys. She then got into her rented Mercedes-Benz 190 and headed to the trendy Ivy at the Shore restaurant for dinner with her agent, Diane Cairns, and knocked back two glasses of wine. **********Driving home along the Pacific Coast Highway, she rammed the Mercedes into a stalled, empty van, flipped her car over three times. She ended up trapped, bruised and bleeding in the wreckage. A Jaws of Life rescue tool had to be used to pry her free. **********Three years later, the 41-year-old author of six crime best sellers, who made more than $17 million last year, travels New York City in a stretch limousine and appears at book signings with armed bodyguards, says she is glad she had the accident. She now says her personal life was spiraling out of control back then, threatening to ruin her finances as well, and her brush with death came as a wake-up call. **********''It was a necessary experience,'' Ms. Cornwell said in the living room of her rented apartment overlooking Central Park. ''Things were out of control. I was going to live or die. I was going to be bankrupt or I was going to make it.'' **********Running her hands through her streaked blond hair, she added, recalling the accident: ''I remember thinking I wasn't going to go yet. I had to straighten this out.'' **********There was a lot to straighten out -- both in her life and in her finances. Indeed, it is never easy to disentangle the two; when one is a mess, so frequently is the other. And Ms. Cornwell's life reads like a psychologist's checklist of emotional stress and excess: Abandoned by her father as a child and later placed in foster care by her emotionally distraught mother; hospitalized for anorexia as a teen-ager; infatuated with an English professor, whom she pursued in college and married upon graduation; tortured by mood swings throughout her adult life; involved in a messy lesbian love affair with a married F.B.I. agent several years ago, and periodically hooked on the alcohol she drank to calm her nerves. **********On top of that, she had no experience in handling large sums of money. She grew up poor; her professor-husband joined the ministry, and she chose low-paying careers -- first in journalism, then in clerical work. Worst of all, her emotional roller coasters were diagnosed as manic depression, a disorder often marked by episodes of irresponsible behavior and frantic spending. **********Then, almost overnight, Ms. Cornwell hit the big time. ''Postmortem,'' the tale of Kay Scarpetta's hunt for a serial killer, brought both critical praise and five major crime-fiction awards for its gritty realism. In quick order, she pumped out three more novels, ''Body of Evidence,'' ''All That Remains'' and ''Cruel and Unusual,'' similarly grisly tales about Ms. Scarpetta's exploits. Her books might have been made into movies by now, and she would be more of a household name, but for the fact that she insisted on retaining so much control over the projects. **********But Ms. Cornwell was ill-prepared to handle a fortune that now amounts to about $10 million. ''Unless you come from an extraordinary family, what do you have that ever equips you?'' she asked. 'Being a waitress at college certainly doesn't. Being a reporter certainly doesn't. Look at all the successful people and how they destroy themselves and others.'' **********Indeed, though Ms. Cornwell says otherwise, some former associates say financial success brought out the worst in her. Like so many other newly minted celebrities, she had no idea what to do with so much money and, instead of seeking out investment advice, she went on impulsive spending sprees. ''During my manic phases, I would buy a $100,000 Mercedes and drive it away in it, or I would buy $10,000 worth of jewelry,'' she said. One shopping trip resulted in $27,000 worth of furniture. She even hired her Richmond lawyer, Susan Armstrong, to handle her personal affairs at $75 an hour and had her phone lines switched to the law firm so a paralegal could answer her calls. **********And she recalled a nurse, ''sweet as she could be,'' when she had the stitches from the accident taken out. ''She looked at me in my Escada jeans,'' Ms. Cornwell added, referring to the luxury designer label. ''And she said, 'Oh, my God, sweet Jesus, is that Escada you have on?' So I went to the Escada boutique and bought her a $2,000 jacket. That's certainly not a good way to build a financial portfolio.'' **********Her accountant, Brian LaLonde, tried to restrain her, but to no avail. ''I would say, 'You're not getting any royalty checks or advance checks for a while,' '' Mr. LaLonde recalled. '' 'You need to stop spending.' '' **********IF her finances were getting hammered, her personal relationships were getting pulverized. She hired and dismissed members of her research staff with abandon. She had numerous money disputes with underlings, once accusing a former employee, Cynthia Stevens, of failing to return some property to her. (Ms. Stevens countersued Ms. Cornwell, complaining of sexual harassment. Ms. Stevens agreed to return the property and drop her complaint.) And she had a falling-out with an old friend, Dot Jackson, a colleague from her days as a crime reporter at The Charlotte Observer, over the credits to a screenplay on which they had collaborated, as well as over what Ms. Jackson saw as her bullying of employees. ''It was peculiar how many people Patsy thought were greedy, and they weren't greedy in anybody else's view,'' Ms. Jackson said. ''And she bad-mouthed them to everyone. She was a real bully.'' **********Though Ms. Cornwell last week offered to give Ms. Jackson the screenplay rights, Ms. Jackson said the matter was in the hands of her agent. (In the last year, Ms. Jackson has worked as an occasional freelance writer for The New York Times.) **********Ms. Cornwell's celebrity status left her so fearful that others might physically assault her that she began appearing at book signings with bodyguards, moved into a private community in Richmond behind a security gate, slept with a gun at her side, and started to carry firearms, she said, ''wherever it's legal.'' **********In one lengthy 19-point memorandum to her staff, she raised an alarm about a woman who she believed had become ''obsessive'' about trying to meet her. For her protection, she instructed her employees to get permits for concealed weapons, to get firearms training ''if they feel comfortable'' doing so, and to post a security guard at her door when she went to the hospital. She also asked them to use an alias when reserving plane tickets, hotel rooms and restaurant seatings -- ''except for places like Spago, where without my real name I might not get a table,'' according to the memo. **********Though she ordered that the memo be shredded after it was read, a copy was provided to The Times by a former associate. Ms. Cornwell said she did not remember the memo, but conceded that she takes ''any measure I need to for my security.'' **********AS for investing the cash that escaped her shopping binges, Ms. Cornwell didn't have a clue. ''There was more money coming in than I had ever had before,'' she recalled. ''I didn't know anything. My husband had signed all the checks.'' She tried to learn, telling herself, ''Patsy, you're a smart girl; you didn't just fall off a turnip truck,'' but the complexities of portfolio management eluded her. ''I certainly didn't know what a tax shelter was,'' she conceded. **********She invokes her tight working schedule to explain her financial ineptitude. Not only was she churning out books, she was absorbed in the task of building a staff and distracted by personal decisions like whether to buy a house or car. But she acknowledges that she was slow to seek professional assistance. ''I had no business manager,'' she said. ''Nobody was talking to me or telling me how much money I had.'' **********In 1991, she finally decided to seek financial advice from a friend at a Richmond money-management firm. For the first meeting with him, she got a lift to his office  in the morgue station wagon -- with a body rolling around in the back. As a favor, the adviser recommended that Ms. Cornwell put about $45,000 in a mutual fund that ended up earning only about 2 percent a year. **********Why it should take a near-fatal car crash to jar Ms. Cornwell back to reality and start her on the road to financial recovery might seem puzzling to ordinary investors -- the millions of Americans who force themselves to squeeze a few thousand dollars a year from their salaries into their 401(k) plans or other retirement accounts. **********But a look at her troubled life helps explain the riddle. A childhood scarred by separations from both parents led to adult years tormented by an increasing mood instability. By the time sudden wealth showered on her, Ms. Cornwell was simply incapable of responding with the discipline and maturity that any sound investment strategy would require. **********Her father, Sam Daniels, a Miami lawyer, and her mother were divorced when she was 5. She said he left home on Christmas Day to join his secretary, whom he had gotten pregnant. ''I was at that age when little girls worship their daddies,'' she recalled. ''It killed me. It absolutely killed me. I remember him coming out into the hallway. I knew immediately what he was doing. He was never coming back. I ran over crying and screaming and wrapped around one of his legs like a little tree frog and I was screaming 'Don't go! Don't go!' He kind of put me off. He didn't say anything. He just went out the door.'' **********After that, Patsy Daniels rarely saw her father. ''I used to walk to the post office on holidays and my birthday, several times a day, hoping for mail, or gifts,'' she recalled. ''But nothing came.'' **********In 1963, her mother moved the family from Miami to a two-bedroom house in tiny Montreat, N.C. Two years later, nearly broke and close to a breakdown, she left Patsy and her two brothers with neighbors -- the evangelist Billy Graham and his wife Ruth. The Grahams placed the children with Manfred and Lenore Saunders, Christian missionaries who had returned from Africa. **********Ms. Cornwell, who acknowledges having a Gothic imagination, remembers her foster mother with horror. ''That lady would glare at me with reptilian eyes,'' she said. ''She would make me do dishes again and again, six or seven times of washing the same jar. At school she would tell the teachers to watch me cause I was a cheater. **********''I write about fear because I know it better than anything partly because of the incredible fear I had living in that house,'' Ms. Cornwell added. **********AS she does often in recounting unpleasant episodes from her past, Ms. Cornwell paints herself as the victim of a cruel or uncaring adversary. But others do not share that view. Mrs. Saunders, told of Ms. Cornwell's painful memories, chuckled and said, ''I loved that girl, but I was a strict disciplinarian.'' The author's brother John, now a Navy officer, recalls the couple as strict but well intentioned. But Ms. Cornwell is ready with a retort. ''I was a girl,'' she said. ''I got treated differently.'' **********At the age of 18, Patsy Daniels was treated for anorexia for one month at the same hospital, Appalachia Hall, where her mother had been a patient. ''It was like 'One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest,' '' Ms. Cornwell recalled, referring to the novel and movie featuring a demented nurse who keeps her patients drugged like zombies. ''There were no young people, and everyone was walking around being zapped with shock treatments.'' Ruth Graham, who had befriended young Patsy and remains in close touch with her, confirms that the hospital ''was a really grim place.'' **********She muddled through and went on to Davidson College in Davidson, N.C., graduating not only with honors in English but with a husband, having doggedly pursued Charles Cornwell, an English professor in his late 30's. Her friends say now that the marriage was a disaster from the start and that she constantly derided her spouse. (Ms. Cornwell denies such behavior.) In any case, she soon turned her attention to a career, landing a reporting job at The Charlotte Observer in 1979 and eventually ending up on the police beat. **********When Mr. Cornwell moved to Richmond in 1981 to become a minister, his wife turned to writing books, starting with an authorized biography of Mrs. Graham that caused a temporary rupture in their relationship. By now, Ms. Cornwell had become immersed in the police culture that she covered at her newspaper, and decided to try her hand at crime novels. To learn more about the nitty gritty of police work, she took a job as a computer analyst in the Richmond morgue, spending much of her time with Marcella Fiero, a medical examiner, when she wasn't hanging out with the local police officers. **********Her first three books, based on a male detective, were rejected. Despairing, she asked her agent for advice, and was told she ought to write about her day-to-day experiences in the morgue. So she wrote ''Postmortem,'' her first Scarpetta novel. Though she got an advance of only $6,000, the novel's critical success launched her career. **********Slowly, her books caught on. Income from her writing jumped from almost nothing in 1989 to $560,000 in 1991 and $1.7 million in 1992 as her books reached the best-seller lists. As her fame grew, some former friends say, her obsession with money kept pace. A former associate recalls her as being obsessed with money. ''I can remember during a walk we took,'' this person said. ''She said, 'What do you consider a millionaire: $1 million in the bank or $1 million in assets?' '' **********And Ms. Jackson, her former colleague at the Charlotte newspaper, concurs. ''If you had money, it was good,'' she said. ''If you didn't have money, it was beneath her. In the beginning, she was hyper-intense about her work. But she was not arrogant or selfish or obsessive about money. She got that way when she began to get some.'' **********SIMULTANEOUSLY, Ms. Jackson asserts, Ms. Cornwell assumed an increasingly imperious stance toward employees, often requiring them to sign confidentiality agreements that bound them never to discuss her with former employees or with outsiders. Though Ms. Cornwell asserts that other celebrities do likewise, Ms. Jackson countered: ''I loved her, but I think she began believing her own press releases. I think she thought that if you want to get ahead, this is the way you treat people.'' **********Today, Ms. Cornwell acknowledges that her behavior turned erratic at times under the influence of her undiagnosed manic depression. ''That was not the best time of my life, I would be the first to admit,'' she said. **********But she rejects accusations that she worships money. ''I don't think about money,'' she asserts. **********One disappointment was her failed overtures to Hollywood celebrities. First, she wooed Jodie Foster to play Kay Scarpetta in a film, but Ms. Foster showed no interest. Then she held sporadic and ultimately unpleasant and unsuccessful discussions with Demi Moore to take the same role. **********''Demi made me angry,'' Ms. Cornwell said. ''She demanded to see the script before it was done. She sounded rather threatening on the phone.'' Ms. Moore did not return telephone calls seeking comment. **********For all Ms. Cornwell's fame, the only close and long-lasting relationships she formed were with her fictional protagonists: Kay Scarpetta and Ms. Scarpetta's niece, a lesbian F.B.I. agent. Ms. Cornwell found solace in writing, and came to view her characters almost as flesh-and-blood acquaintances with minds of their own. **********Each time she revisits them, she said, ''I put them on the page and they sit at the table and talk to each other, but I don't really hear them. I can't tell what they're feeling. It's like they're leaving me out and I don't appreciate it. Then I have to say: 'Look, either make me the center of your attention here or I'm going to delete you.'' **********''Sometimes, they just burst to life and next thing you know, I'm into page 200,'' she added. ''It's wonderful. It's like having a relationship.'' **********Even so, her depressions sometimes brought on writer's block. ''My mood would go up and down,'' she recalled. ''I couldn't get it to change. I would go for weeks and I couldn't write because I would get so depressed.'' **********In the fall of 1992, under a psychiatrist's care, she began taking the anti-depressant drug Prozac while at the same time seeking solace in alcohol. **********''I was drinking way too much,'' she said. ''I was going to bars -- gay bars or straight bars. I mean, I didn't care. That was manic behavior.'' **********The drinking and manic behavior continued -- and then came the car crash. **********While the accident didn't transform Ms. Cornwell overnight into a paragon of sweet reason and financial savvy, it started a process of soul-searching that has certainly changed her financial and professional life. **********Late in 1993, she checked into Edgehill Newport, a clinic for recovering alcoholics in Newport, R.I., that has induced her at least to reduce her drinking, she said. And her physician, Erica Blanton, diagnosed her as a manic-depressive and prescribed lithium to suppress the mood swings. **********At first, Ms. Cornwell resisted, but Dr. Blanton calmed her fears. **********''She told me I was bipolar,'' the author said. ''At first I didn't know what she meant -- I thought she was referring to my sex life.'' **********She began taking lithium in the spring of 1994, and she says she believes it has brought some balance to her life, making her a better listener and helping her deal with problems more calmly. ''I am more stable,'' she said. ''My chemistry is more stable. I don't make snap impulsive decisions because my brain is not working right. If I spend $20,000 on art now, I know that I can afford it. It doesn't put me close to the edge.'' **********To make her point, she pulled out a gold pillbox during a recent dinner at Elio's restaurant in New York City, removed a lithium pill and popped it into her mouth. ''I take it everywhere,'' she said. **********One thing she cannot control, however, is the publicity surrounding her romantic entanglements, notably an affair several years ago with the wife of an F.B.I. agent. That liaison came to a messy conclusion when the husband tried to ambush and kill his wife, who was also an agent, in a church basement in Manassas, Va. At his trial, he argued that the affair between his wife and Ms. Cornwell contributed to his mental instability and pushed him toward the crime. He was convicted of attempted murder. **********At first, Ms. Cornwall says, she feared that all the gossip about the incident would provoke a backlash against her and pigeon-hole her as a gay writer. **********''I had no idea what to expect,'' she said. ''Would people burn an effigy in my yard?'' **********She held a book signing with great trepidation, ordering her aides to sweep the bookstore for bombs and to hire ''every security cop we can get our hands on.'' She was relieved to find that news about her personal life had no effect on her book sales. **********She believes that her medication, as well as her experience, have made a difference in her work, too. She hired an office manager, Chris Bailor, a former Richmond policewoman, and the once-brisk turnover among her staff of seven women has slowed. **********Certainly Ms. Cornwell is more prolific than ever. The lithium ''has made my writing better,'' she said. **********Critics disagree. ''Hornet's Nest,'' her first novel without Dr. Scarpetta, is currently No. 4 on the New York Times best-seller list, where it has appeared for eight weeks. The Times's critic called the book ''exceedingly dull.'' A critic for Entertainment Weekly described the book as ''a mess.'' A review in The Daily News called it a book in ''the throes of an identity crisis.'' **********STILL, Ms. Cornwell says she can now concentrate better on her writing. Before, ''I would work. Then I'd get up,'' she said. ''Then I'd work, and I'd leave the house to do an errand. I'd do anything not to sit still.'' **********Lithium changed that, she said. ''I wrote 220 pages of 'Cause of Death' in 10 days'' back in 1995, she boasted. And, ''I didn't drink a pitcher of Bloody Marys afterward.'' **********But in fact, she has not sworn off alcohol, she acknowledged. ''I had to go out and drink tequila after that to try and knock myself out so I could sleep,'' she said, speaking at a rapid clip that suggests her moods can still be intense. 'But I didn't drink a pitcher of Bloody Marys and I didn't drive.'' **********Besides moderating her drinking, she is raking in the money. With four more novels reached the best-seller lists both in the United States and abroad, she earned $4.5 million in 1994, $7.4 million in 1995 and $17 million last year. **********Though Ms. Cornwell is not as widely known as Danielle Steele, Michael Crichton, Tom Clancy, John Grisham or Mary Higgins Clark, whose blockbuster books have become films or television movies, she too belongs to the club of a dozen or so authors who command multimillion-dollar advances. For United States rights to her next three books, Putnam has paid her $24 million, which she will collect as she delivers the manuscripts. **********Moreover, she now considers herself much more firmly in control of her money than ever. At the suggestion of her lawyer, Michael Rudell, a partner at Franklin, Weinrib, Rudell & Vassallo, a New York firm that specializes in the entertainment industry, she recently hired Stanley Gillman, a partner at the accounting firm of Yohalem Gillman & Company, as her financial consultant. **********Mr. Gillman's job is to advise her how to deploy a $5 million portfolio that is currently concentrated in blue-chip stocks. ''We are trying to help her find a good investment house,'' Mr. Gillman said, ticking off well-known Wall Street firms like Neuberger Berman, First Manhattan and Sanford C. Bernstein. Ms. Cornwell said her goals were quite conservative and acknowledged that she had none of the fascination with investing that characterizes her obsession with crime. ''If I were to sit down and spend all my time talking to lawyers and accountants, I would never write books,'' she said. ''I don't pretend to be a business person. I am just a person who has business who is an artist.'' **********In addition to her $5 million in liquid assets, Ms. Cornwell has an almost equal amount in property. She owns an office building, a home and land in Richmond valued altogether at roughly $3 million. She has condominiums in the Cayman Islands and in Hilton Head, S.C., worth about $2 million together. On top of that, she has put about $1 million into a charitable foundation. **********If she is more cautious about wasting money on cars and clothes and other consumer goods, Ms. Cornwell does not stint on paying big money to do research for her books, especially if that means flying off to far-away locales to capture the color of places she writes about or maintaining a permanent staff to help with her with research and travel arrangements. When she decided that the serial killer in ''From Potter's Field'' had to come from a pecan plantation, for example, her staff found a pecan plantation in South Carolina. She flew there immediately. **********As she was finishing her next book, ''Unnatural Exposure,'' last year, she said, ''I realized that Scarpetta had to go to London, and she had to go to Victoria Station.'' She flew there, too -- on the Concorde, at her own expense. **********''I want to go to strange places and I want to get there fast,'' she said. ''Read my books. There is an energy and an authenticity.'' **********Still, Ms. Cornwell allows her enthusiasms to be tempered by her financial overseers. When she suddenly decided she wanted to buy her own jet, for example, Mr. Gillman persuaded her to hold off. ''Let's get some information on the flying that you do first,'' he told her. ''Then you can decide if you should buy a jet, lease one or time-share it.'' **********Mr. Gillman also talked her out of paying cash for a $1 million office building that she bought in Richmond and into taking a 15-year, $700,000 mortgage instead. ''We felt she could make better use of the money than putting it into the building,'' he said. **********Aware of her history of impulsive buying, he has also tried to scold her out of repeating her past mistakes. ''I don't want you buying any more property. I know that's hard because I know how much you like to buy motorcycles or planes or whatever,'' Ms. Cornwell recalled. **********One area about which she is unlikely to listen to outside advice is her security. Ms. Cornwell never shows up at book signings without bodyguards. The security at her home is extensive and her driver is a former police officer. On a recent trip to Ireland, Finland and England to promote ''Hornet's Nest,'' she took several staff members and posted guards at book signings there, too. **********Ms. Cornwell, who estimates that she has attended some 600 autopsies, said the experience would make anyone ''intelligently cautious.'' ''You can't see all that and have the same view of how safe the world is,'' she said. ''When women come in and they have had their throats dismembered or been raped or men have been stabbed 120 times, you're never the same. You go home and you worry about things that other people don't. For me, it is compounded by being well-known and people are aware of you.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/23/busin.snippet: Pepsico Inc says third-quarter profit from continuing operations rose 42.7 percent from year earlier, to $551 million; net income for quarter was $658 million, including profit from discontinued operations of $107 million; this compares with net i...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/23/busin.main_headline: Pepsico's Profits Climbed By 42.7% in Third Quarter
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/23/busin.print_headline: COMPANY REPORTS; Pepsico's Profits Climbed By 42.7% in Third Quarter
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/23/busin.body_text: **********Pepsico Inc. said yesterday that third-quarter profit from continuing operations rose 42.7 percent as sales of salty snacks and soft drinks soared in its first quarter since spinning off its restaurant business. **********Profits of $551 million, or 35 cents a share, up from $386 million, or 24 cents, a year ago beat expectations of 32 cents a share, based on six analysts surveyed by First Call. **********Net income for the most recent quarter was $658 million, or 42 cents, including profit from discontinued operations of $107 million, or 7 cents. That compares with net income of $144 million, or 9 cents, in the period a year earlier, after a charge of $376 million, or 23 cents a share, related to the company's restructuring its international beverage business, and profit from discontinued operations of $134 million, or 8 cents. **********The spinoff of KFC, Pizza Hut and Taco Bell is part of the plan of the company's chairman, Roger Enrico, to shed cash-hungry businesses and better compete against Coca-Cola. **********Despite the strong earnings, Pepsico's shares fell $1.5625, to $38.4375, after hitting a 52-week high of $40.6875 early in the day. **********Analysts said the stock fell amid concern over a 2 percent drop in Pepsi's domestic beverage profits and because several analysts cut fourth-quarter earnings forecasts. **********''The U.S. beverage results were disappointing,'' said Caroline Levy,  of Schroder & Company, who upgraded Pepsi to ''outperform significantly'' on Monday. ''The stock had traded up in the last couple of days.'' **********Michael Branca at Lehman Brothers Inc. cut his fourth-quarter forecast to 28 cents a share from 31 cents. **********''The company is talking down numbers for the fourth quarter,'' said Jennifer Solomon of Salomon Brothers Inc. **********Revenue rose 3.9 percent, to $5.36 billion from $5.16 billion. **********The company's global snack food sales rose 7 percent. Volume growth increased 4 percent in North America and 11 percent internationally. The company said it saw strong sales of Lays, Doritos and other snacks in Mexico and Brazil. **********In the beverage business, case sales rose 4 percent in North America and 4 percent internationally, above analyst expectations. It was the first growth for Pepsi's international beverage business in a year. The international beverage division reported an operating profit of $75 million. Pepsi is restructuring its international bottling business and recently signed an agreement for Suntory to be its primary bottler in Japan. **********''The one question mark in the whole Pepsi story has been international beverages,'' said a Prudential Securities analyst, George Thompson. ''They appear to have the international soft drink business under control.'' **********Margaret Moore, Pepsi's vice president for investor relations, told analysts in an afternoon conference call that a turnaround in its international beverage business was slightly ahead of schedule, adding, ''But we're not going to let that go to our head.'' Pepsico's international profits offset a 2 percent decline, to $425 million, in operating profits in North America in the quarter. Pepsi said soft-drink prices remained competitive for most of the quarter, improving sales but lowering profits. **********In the United States, Pepsi said that almost all its bottlers had signed new contracts, freeing it to pursue fountain accounts from restaurants.  Still, Pepsi's sales did not stack up well against Coke in the quarter. Coke's global case sales rose 11 percent. In the United States, sales rose 6 percent.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/09/busin.snippet: Bank of Montreal to open bank in Dublin to service North American companies that have set up offices in Ireland and across Europe (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/09/busin.body_text: **********The Bank of Montreal said today that it would open a bank in Dublin to service North American companies that have set up offices in Ireland and across Europe. The bank, one of the 10 largest in North America, will also focus on companies in the International Financial Services Center in Dublin's docklands and European companies operating in the United States and Canada. The bank's decision strengthens Ireland's reputation as a premier site for North American companies locating in Europe.
