Alcatel said it would sell part of its ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/04/busin.main_headline: Firm's Plan to Sell Its Havas Stake Sets Off Series of Other Proposals : Alcatel Revives Bid For Thomson-CSF
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/04/busin.print_headline: Firm's Plan to Sell Its Havas Stake Sets Off Series of Other Proposals : Alcatel Revives Bid For Thomson-CSF
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/04/busin.body_text: **********Alcatel Alsthom said Monday it was resuming its bid for a major stake in the state-owned defense contractor Thomson-CSF in cooperation with the aerospace manufacturers Aerospatiale and Dassault Aviation SA. **********Alcatel said it would sell part of its stake in the media conglomerate Havas SA to raise the cash. Havas, meanwhile, was reported to be shopping for a bigger stake in Canal Plus SA, Europe's biggest pay-TV service. **********It appeared to be the start of another round of musical chairs involving many of the top players in French industry, finance and media. These were the moves planned Monday: **********Alcatel, a large electronics-equipment maker, would sell part of its 21 percent share in Havas and then team up with the two aerospace manufacturers to buy a 58 percent stake in Thomson-CSF that the government has been trying to sell for months. **********Compagnie Generale des Eaux would increase its stake in Havas by buying Alcatel's shares, but at the same time the conglomerate would hand over to Havas its 20 percent interest in Canal Plus, making Havas the owner of 40 percent of the television network. **********Canal Plus, already entrenched in France, Germany, Italy, Poland and Spain, would then seek to increase its subscriber base to 8.5 million households by expanding operations in the Benelux countries through its recent acquisition of the Dutch rival NetHold NV. **********Alcatel bid for Thomson last year but lost out to the missile-maker Lagardere Group, which is allied with two British companies, British Aerospace PLC and GEC Marconi. **********As part of the transaction, Lagardere was to have sold Thomson's multimedia division to Daewoo Electronics Co. of South Korea as part of a general sale of Thomson holdings. **********But the government canceled the deal Dec. 4 after the National Assembly's privatization commission objected to the sale of Thomson Multimedia amid massive public protest over an Asian takeover of such a well-known French company, and the decision brought down the entire delicately balanced Thomson privatization. **********Now, with cash from its sale of Havas shares and the support of Dassault and Aerospatiale, Alcatel would stand a better chance of pulling off the Thomson deal, analysts said. **********But such a Gallic solution may not be to the liking of European defense planners, given their emphasis on cross-border cooperation in the military and electronic fields. **********A Finance Ministry spokesman said an announcement on Thomson would be made before the end of this month. Alcatel confirmed that it was in discussions with privately owned Dassault and state-owned Aerospatiale about the Thomson takeover. **********But neither Dassault nor Aerospatiale, which are set to merge in 1997, would comment. **********At current market prices, the 58 percent of Thomson-CSF that the government wants to sell would cost about 11 billion francs ($2 billion). Thomson-CSF shares rose 4.60 francs to close at 169. **********Generale des Eaux, which has broad interests in public services, transport, media and other fields, would become one of the biggest players in the European media with a majority stake in Havas. The two companies said discussions were "in progress concerning their respective interests in audiovisual activities." **********In expanding its stake in Canal Plus, Havas would become more directly involved with media competitors such as Rupert Murdoch of News Corp. instead of being a holding company for a multiplicity of publishing and broadcasting interests. The prospect of stronger ties with Canal Plus sent Havas shares surging Monday. They closed 23.50 francs higher at 424, a 12-month high. Canal Plus fell 5 to 1,177. **********Alcatel fell 6 to 542. The company sold its media business to Havas in 1995, receiving in return its stake in the company.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/27/news/.main_headline: Curb Violates Free Speech, Supreme Court Rules, 7-2 : Justices Void Internet Indecency Law
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/27/news/.print_headline: Curb Violates Free Speech, Supreme Court Rules, 7-2 : Justices Void Internet Indecency Law
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/27/news/.body_text: **********WASHINGTON—                     The Supreme Court, taking up the question of free speech in cyberspace for the first time, ruled Thursday that a federal law that sought to curb indecency on the Internet was unconstitutional. **********The justices, by a vote of 7 to 2, agreed with a lower-court finding that the federal law, which sought to protect children under 18 from sexually explicit material, was drawn far too broadly and would deprive adults of access to materials they have a right to view. **********The decision was hailed by free-speech advocates, library groups, newspaper publishers and computer industry spokesmen. They said it could shape the court's approach to dealings with computerized communications for years to come. The Internet links perhaps 40 million computer users around the world, giving them access to vast information resources. **********The Clinton administration supported the overturned law, formally known as the Communications Decency Act. **********The administration is now expected to craft a more limited approach, relying on voluntary actions by the computer industry to produce improved software that can block indecent materials and calling on parents to monitor their children's computer use. **********Justice John Paul Stevens, writing for the court majority, recognized the "legitimacy and importance of the congressional goal of protecting children from harmful materials" but said that the law abridged constitutionally guaranteed freedom of speech. **********In an earlier case, he noted, the court likened a restriction on speech "to burning the house to roast the pig. The CDA, casting a far darker shadow over free speech, threatens to torch a large segment of the Internet community." **********He said that the government may not limit adults to "only what is fit for children." Obscenity and child pornography remain illegal. **********The two dissenters were Chief Justice William Rehnquist and Justice Sandra Day O'Connor. **********In a hearing on the matter in March, justices cast about for appropriate parallels in earlier forms of communication. **********Was the Internet to be compared to phone calls between friends, to radio, to public speech on a street corner or in a park? **********Justice Stevens, in describing the Internet's capacities, said that "any person with a phone line can become a town crier with a voice that resonates farther than it could from any soapbox." **********The law, he said, would have made criminals of parents who electronically sent birth-control information to their teenage children, and could even have been applied to the Carnegie Library's card catalog. **********Opponents of the federal law called the ruling a clear victory for free speech. **********"The court really did understand this new medium and finds that the medium is entitled to the same kind of broad protections that books and newspapers are entitled to," said Chris Hansen, senior staff counsel for the American Civil Liberties Union in New York. **********Coming on the heels of decisions in New York and Georgia against Internet limits enacted by state legislatures, Mr. Hansen said, "We now have a trio of decisions that provide extremely broad First Amendment protection for speech on the Internet." The American Library Association said it was "delighted with the court's ruling," which it called "a historic recognition of the principles of free speech." **********Among others challenging the federal law were America Online, an Internet provider; the American Society of Newspaper Editors and Apple Computer. **********Those groups said the law would restrict access not only to indecent words and pictures but to discussion of issues including safe sex, homosexuality or prison rape. **********Members of an anti-pornography group demonstrated outside the Supreme Court building Thursday against the decision. **********A chief sponsor of the federal law, Senator Dan Coats, Republican of Indiana, said he feared that the court had "entered dangerous, unexplored territory." **********The court, he continued, having long sought to protect of children from indecency in other media, "has withdrawn those protections from a child on a computer in his or her own home." **********New attempts to draft more narrowly worded legislation were expected. But the line drawn by the court — protecting adults' access to information — would appear to make a new approach to Internet policing technically difficult. **********The Communications Decency Act was passed in 1996 but never enforced because of court challenges. **********A federal court in Philadelphia declared the law unconstitutional and the Clinton administration appealed that ruling to the Supreme Court. **********The act imposed no restrictions on the considerable volume of indecent material sent from computers outside the United States, which some opponents said rendered it pointless.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/26/busin.snippet: Marisa Baridis, Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter, Discover & Co legal compliance officer is indicted on charges involving sale of insider information on merger and reorganization plans of 13 of firm's clients to brokers including Robert Breed, Howard B...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/26/busin.main_headline: Market Place; Lessons of Boesky and Milken Go Unheeded in Fraud Case
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/26/busin.print_headline: Market Place; Lessons of Boesky and Milken Go Unheeded in Fraud Case
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/26/busin.body_text: **********Late last month, a young couple met over drinks at C. S. Barrington's, a lobster and pasta restaurant on the corner of East 54th Street and Second Avenue in Manhattan. **********Marisa Baridis, 29, and Jeffrey L. Streich, 31, who both worked in the securities industry, had become acquainted on summer weekends in the Hamptons. **********But they were from opposite ends of Wall Street: Ms. Baridis was a legal compliance officer at Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter, Discover & Company, perhaps the most blue-blooded giant in the securities industry, while Mr. Streich was a struggling broker who had worked at a succession of smaller firms -- D. H. Blair, A. S. Goldmen and Gruntal Financial -- that specialize in speculative stocks. And during the summer, market regulators barred Mr. Streich from the industry, citing several violations of securities laws. **********Seated in front of the full-length window last month, the two seemed like just another attractive young couple out on a date. But this was not just any date. Mr. Streich was paying Ms. Baridis for sensitive inside stock information that she knew he would profit from, a lawyer involved in the case said. She was nervous, telling him she could go to jail. He swore ''on his mother's ashes'' that he would be careful with how he used the information. **********At Morgan Stanley, Ms. Baridis was in charge of maintaining a ''Chinese wall'' to avoid conflicts about privileged information within the firm. She had acquired a wealth of information about planned mergers and reorganizations of her firm's clients. But that weekend, instead of safeguarding that information, as she was legally bound to do, Ms. Baridis was selling it to Mr. Streich for $2,500 in hundred-dollar bills, something she had reputedly done several times before. **********What Ms. Baridis did not know was that Mr. Streich wore a hidden recording device that caught every word of their conversation. And they were sitting by the window so they could be caught on camera by an undercover crew working for the Manhattan District Attorney's office. **********The two even talked about their fears of being caught, comparing themselves to Michael Milken and Ivan Boesky, who pleaded guilty to securities felonies in the 1980's. **********The next week, on Monday, Nov. 3, detectives from the District Attorney's office appeared at Morgan Stanley's new offices off Times Square and took Ms. Baridis in for questioning. Later that week, she was charged with insider trading. **********Ms. Baridis was arraigned the next day in New York City Criminal Court and charged with grand larceny, possession of stolen property, scheming to defraud, accepting a bribe and securities fraud. Ms. Baridis's father, Anestis, who owns a bridge-painting company in Pennsylvania, met her $250,000 bail, securing it partly with his house. **********Yesterday, Ms. Baridis was arraigned again and indicted on new charges of grand larceny, conspiracy and bribery. The indictment also charged Robert Breed, 29, a broker at First United Equities; Howard Boyar, 34, a broker at GKN Securities, who resigned Nov. 12, and Vincent M. Napolitano, 29, who the authorities say ran a securities business out of an East Side apartment. They face charges including conspiracy, possession of stolen property, securities fraud and bribery. From the summer of 1996 through this month, the indictment said, they all traded on information provided by Ms. Baridis ''to make hundreds of thousands of dollars'' and conspired ''to steal more than $1 million through insider trading.'' Ms. Baridis made about $70,000, according to prosecutors. **********During this time, the District Attorney's office said yesterday, the defendants used confidential information from Morgan Stanley relating to 13 companies: Healthcare Imaging Services, Owen Healthcare, Starsight Telecast, Ontrak Systems, Square Industries, American Medical Response, Ocean Energy I, Georgia Pacific, Reading & Bates, Coram Healthcare, Doubletree, Rohr and Einstein Bagels. **********Mr. Breed and Mr. Boyar, who live on the Upper East Side, had both worked at D. H. Blair, where Mr. Streich started out. They had later gone on to work at A. R. Baron, a brokerage firm that was itself indicted earlier this year, along with 11 of its brokers and former executives, and has since closed. **********''When all the facts are in, I am confident that Ms. Baridis will not be the villain of the piece,'' said Paul Shechtman, a lawyer for Ms. Baridis at Stillman & Friedman, a New York law firm. ''Jeff Streich is a person who has difficulty telling the truth. What I have come to find is that when he prefaced a statement to Marisa with 'I swear on my mother's ashes,' it was a giveaway that he was about to lie.'' **********Matthew Brief, Mr. Streich's lawyer, did not return repeated telephone calls yesterday. Ron Rubinstein, Mr. Napolitano's lawyer, said his client had pleaded not guilty and had posted bail. John F. Triggs, Mr. Boyar's lawyer, also said his client had pleaded not guilty and posted bail, as did Michael Kalmus, a lawyer for Mr. Breed. **********Mr. Streich has gone underground; messages left with his father, a family friend and a former colleague elicited no response. ''No, he does not live here,'' said a woman who answered the telephone at a Manhattan number where his father said he might be reached. **********Mr. Streich's four-year securities career was apparently over after he was barred permanently in July and fined $50,000 for unauthorized trading in customers' accounts. Mr. Streich then somehow found himself ensnared in a growing investigation of A. R. Baron, a brokerage firm where several of his former Blair colleagues worked. That is what may have made him so eager to assist the District Attorney's office in its snaring of Ms. Baridis and the others. In yesterday's indictment, Mr. Streich was referred to as ''John Doe, a conspirator,'' and a prosecutor declined to confirm his role in the case. **********The fall for Ms. Baridis has been swift and sudden. Just a month ago, with her job at Morgan Stanley, four years' experience at Smith Barney and a law degree from Touro College, Ms. Baridis had bright prospects. When she was not working, Ms. Baridis liked to go to bars and party with her friends before retiring to her apartment at the Wellesley, an upscale building on East 72nd Street. **********In her career on Wall Street, Ms. Baridis would also have garnered an annual bonus that would lift her salary, which was more than $70,000 a year at Morgan Stanley. A little extra financial help from home meant that even with a $2,400 rent, Ms. Baridis could live relatively well. **********Prosecutors are now trying to freeze Ms. Baridis's assets and are seeking a forfeiture of $100,000 from her. Smith Barney has said that it is cooperating with the authorities. **********Jeanmarie McFadden, a spokeswoman for Morgan Stanley, said yesterday: ''After reviewing the grand jury indictment, we have terminated Marisa Baridis's employment with the firm, effective immediately. We will continue to cooperate fully with the District Attorney in this matter.''  Ms. Baridis had been on unpaid leave since her original indictment. **********Mr. Streich's descent was more gradual. A graduate of community college and the State University of New York at Brockport, he began his brokerage career in June 1991 at D. H. Blair, which just this year paid more than $4 million to settle a case with regulators related to overcharging and other infractions. He seemed to have found his niche, telling his father and friends that he had passed his broker's exams on his first try ''with flying colors.'' **********After a short spell at another New York brokerage, A. S. Goldmen & Company, in the late summer and fall of 1993, Mr. Streich moved to Gruntal for a few months before starting at Beacon Securities in March 1994. That firm never got off the ground, however, and Mr. Streich left in August 1995. **********Mr. Streich even persuaded Faith Merlob, a friend of his late mother, to invest $10,000 of her money in Beacon Securities, money that she lost, she said earlier this week. She does not blame Mr. Streich, she said, adding that he had called her recently to say that she might soon see a newspaper article ''about him being an informant.'' **********''Somebody has got to do something with all these brokerages,'' said Ms. Merlob, who said she did not blame Mr. Streich for her loss. ''He's really a nice person, he really is.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/27/world.snippet: Beijing's major newspapers carry front pages with identical layouts of Deng Xiaoping's funeral; newspapers have given extensive coverage to Deng's death, but there have been few articles about China's political transition; photo (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/27/world.main_headline: China Press Now Lacks Tea Leaves
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/27/world.print_headline: China Press Now Lacks Tea Leaves
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/27/world.body_text: **********On Red Star Lane, a narrow alleyway in downtown Beijing where tiny stalls compete for space to sell fruit, comic books, socks and newspapers, it was the newspapers that sold swiftly this afternoon. **********It did not really matter which newspaper a customer picked, because they all looked exactly the same. Beijing's major newspapers -- People's Daily, Beijing Daily, Guangming Daily, People's Liberation Daily -- all carried front pages with an identical layout, photographs and headline: ''Comrade Deng Xiaoping's Funeral Solemnly Held in Beijing.'' **********In a period of political transition, after Mr. Deng's death last week at 92, China's news outlets are the first place to look for a hint that a real change is under way, or that someone is challenging the new leadership headed by President Jiang Zemin. **********But today, the pages of China's major newspapers looked deadly dull, with the same full text of President Jiang's eulogy, itself a dry account of Mr. Deng's life and contributions that lacked any sign of initiative or rhetorical flourish. For a reader, not much to go on. **********In fact, with China changing so rapidly in business and society, it is striking how torpid and old-fashioned the news outlets remain, and it is even more striking on a big news day. The more modern China becomes each year, the more its official coverage of political events stands out for seeming to be stuck in another time. **********Given such a listless rendering of the day's news, what may be most surprising is that many newspapers sold at all. But Chinese newspaper readers, from years of practice, expect to look for subtle indications of political shifting, not for an accurate rendering of the day's events. **********So today's news of Mr. Deng's funeral, full of symbolism if not content, was something to feed on. The day's newspapers sold far faster than usual on Red Star Lane. **********''I want to read the speech,'' said Sun Yaping, a Government employee, referring to the way he will scour it for subtle references. ''This is an important time to read carefully.'' **********Wang Yanli, a retired man who wandered down the lane from his home to buy the afternoon paper, said: ''I'm getting old and don't care so much about politics. But I want to see how it looks today.'' **********Oddly, it is precisely at times of national crisis in China when journalists are least busy, rather than the reverse. With a large and sensitive news story at hand, a Chinese editor explained, the writing and layout are dictated entirely by the authorities at the Propaganda Department, with little room for much else. **********''They give us the material and put it in,'' said the editor, who insisted on anonymity. ''This week has been the most relaxed we've been in years.'' **********Wu Guoguang, a former editor at People's Daily who now teaches at the Chinese University in Hong Kong, pointed out that Chinese newspapers had progressed in small ways in the last 10 years, covering crime and international news that was simply omitted in the past. **********''In the political realm, you really have no chance of seeing anything in the newspapers,'' Mr. Wu said. ''If we have a serious power struggle, it is more likely to be reported in a debate over economic policy.'' **********Mr. Wu added that with the wheels of change turning slowly in China's top leadership, he did not expect to see any sign of serious debate in the Chinese news media for about six months. **********Virtually all newspapers in China are Government-controlled, and editors at the large ones take guidance daily from the Propaganda Department, now run by Ding Guangen. He has coordinated a political campaign in the last year to make sure that China's press, films and television are tightly supervised. **********Ever since the Communist Party took power in 1949, China's media have been used to carry out political campaigns. That situation reached an extreme at the height of the Cultural Revolution in 1966, when People's Daily reflected the fanatical attitude of the day with the headline: ''There Is Chaos Under Heaven -- the Situation Is Excellent.'' **********A glaring exception to state control over the news media came in 1989, when student demonstrations paralyzed the party's leadership and won the sympathy of newspaper editors. For three weeks, newspapers reported freely on the demands for democracy, free speech and, incidentally, freedom of the press.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/25/world.snippet: Leaders of Taliban, rigorously Islamic movement that controls most of Afghanistan, agree to uproot new poppy crops in Kandahar Province and to destroy any heroin laboratories in nation, which accounts for half of world's opium poppy production and...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/25/world.main_headline: Taliban Pledge to Rid Afghan Province of Opium Poppies
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/25/world.print_headline: Taliban Pledge to Rid Afghan Province of Opium Poppies
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/25/world.body_text: **********Leaders of the Taliban, the rigorously Islamic movement that controls most of Afghanistan, have agreed to uproot new poppy crops in part of the country as soon as they appear and to destroy any heroin laboratories in the country. **********The pledges came as a surprise to the head of the United Nations drug control agency, Pino Arlacchi, who said today that he had expected the Taliban leaders to take a harder line in negotiating. They gave him a general commitment a month ago to eliminate poppy production. **********Afghanistan accounts for half the world's production of opium poppies, from which heroin is made, and is the first target of an ambitious United Nations plan to eliminate the production of the poppies worldwide in a decade. **********The Taliban also unexpectedly proposed to eradicate all poppy cultivation within one year, but this schedule was reluctantly rejected by Mr. Arlacchi. **********''It is too radical,'' said Mr. Arlacchi, an Italian professor and politician who made a reputation fighting the Mafia and became head of the United Nations Drug Control Program in September. **********He said he had encouraged the Taliban to proceed more slowly, until the United Nations was able to come up with money for development projects that would provide income for poppy-growing farmers. Otherwise, only coercion can achieve the Taliban goal, Mr. Arlacchi said, and that would backfire. **********Still, Mr. Arlacchi was beaming after his three hours of negotiations with the Taliban, which began almost immediately when he arrived from Europe on Sunday. **********He was particularly exultant about a promise from the Taliban to allow women to work in a textile factory on the edge of town, which the United Nations will help rehabilitate. The extent of this commitment is not clear. But if it is fulfilled, it will be something of a breakthrough in the Taliban's treatment of women. **********Reopening the factory is part of a pilot poppy eradication project, which should lead to Kandahar Province being poppy-free within a year, Mr. Arlacchi said. **********During the negotiations, the Taliban also agreed to destroy all new poppy fields in this southern province, to destroy any heroin laboratories in the country and to allow United Nations officials complete access to all areas to insure compliance. **********But the path to a poppy-free Afghanistan is fraught with potential perils, not the least of which is the nature of the Taliban Government. **********''It is not recognized, and it is not credible,'' said a senior United Nations official who advised Mr. Arlacchi before the negotiations. ''Whatever they agree to, how long it will last, it's a relative matter.'' **********The Taliban, who began their march to power three years ago, now control about three-quarters of Afghanistan, including just about all of the poppy-growing regions. **********Only three countries have recognized the Taliban as the Afghan Government: Pakistan, the United Arab Emirates and Saudi Arabia. On her recent visit to an Afghan refugee camp in Pakistan, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright described the Taliban's treatment of women and children as ''despicable.'' Women are not allowed to work and must be fully covered when outdoors, and girls are barred from going to school. **********Mr. Arlacchi said he thought that the Taliban had embarked on a poppy eradication program in an effort to overcome their negative image in the world. ''I told them: 'Your image is bad. Nobody likes you. You are isolated.' '' Mr. Arlacchi said. ''I told them bluntly, 'You have two problems -- drugs and women.' '' **********He said he believed that the Taliban would deliver on their commitment, noting that they had virtually eliminated the use of hashish, long common here. And with their dictatorial powers, the Taliban have also successfully put many other Draconian measures into effect. **********Taliban officials said their commitment to eradicate poppy came from the Koran, which forbids the use of drugs, the Governor of Kandahar Province, Mohammed Hassan, said after meeting Mr. Arlacchi. **********''Because we are Muslims, we are against any kind of business with drugs,'' Mr. Hassan said. **********In exchange for the commitment to eradicate poppy cultivation, the Taliban want help from the United Nations in rebuilding the country, which has been devasted by nearly 20 years of war. Irrigation canals and roads must be repaired, and farmers desperately need seed and fertilizer. **********As a start, the United Nations will help get the textile factory 10 miles outside town operating again. **********The factory will provide jobs for 1,400, the plant manager, Mohammed Nausadi, 61, said as led a tour of the darkened plant on Sunday evening. Built by the West Germans in the 1970's, the plant has the capacity to produce 500 tons of yarn a year for carpet weaving, and a million yards of cloth for shawls, he said, animated by the thought of the machines soon humming again. **********When the factory was fully operating, it employed 53 women, Mr. Nausadi said. The small number is a reflection of the fact that even before the Taliban, women did not fare well in rural Afghanistan, where donkey-drawn carts move along dusty roads and villagers live in sand-colored hovels made of thick mud. **********Mr. Arlacchi said he hoped that about 200 women would be employed when the factory was fully operational again. **********But Governor Hassan said only that there had been an agreement ''in principle'' that women could work there. ''Let's see the condition of the factory,'' he said. ''Then the decision will be taken on how many.'' **********In keeping with Islamic principles, men and women will not be allowed to work in the same area, he said. That will require walls to be built. There will also be a separate entrance for women. **********With few factory jobs, farmers will be weaned away from poppy cultivation only if they can earn more from other crops, United Nations and Taliban officials agree. **********That may not be so easy. **********On the outskirts of town, hard against a rock outcropping, Wali Mohammed sold about 65 pounds of poppy seed last season. Buyers came from all over, he said, with a smile, and he was paid the equivalent of some $700. **********''It was a lot of money for me,'' said the 66-year-old peasant, who has 11 children. Today, he was working with a small knife around the onions and radishes he has planted. From these he will earn $200, he said. **********''After the vegetable season, I will grow poppy again,'' he said. **********Another farmer, Haji Ehsanullah, said he, too, was prepared to grow poppies this season. But he might forgo doing so. **********''If I get assistance from the Government, I will stop,'' said Mr. Ehsanullah, 45, the father of 10.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/08/world.snippet: United Nations Sec Gen Kofi Anan gives in to demand by Pres Laurent Kabila of Congo that UN replace international team of experts selected to investigate allegations of massacres of Hutu refugees from Rwanda; Kabila has objected to presence of Chi...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/08/world.main_headline: U.N. Yields to Congo on Massacre Investigation
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/08/world.print_headline: U.N. Yields to Congo on Massacre Investigation
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/08/world.body_text: **********Saying he has to be realistic in dealing with President Laurent Kabila of Congo, Secretary General Kofi Annan has given in to Mr. Kabila's demand that the United Nations replace an international team of experts who were to investigate allegations of massacres of Hutu refugees from Rwanda. **********''We expect the Secretary General to go to the Security Council tomorrow to brief them on his plans for putting together a new team,'' Fred Eckhard, Mr. Annan's spokesman, said at a briefing here today. **********The investigation of sites where Hutu from Rwanda may have been killed by forces loyal to Mr. Kabila beginning late last year was to have begun today. It is now likely to be postponed for some time, raising concerns that evidence can be removed or destroyed in the interim. **********The Kabila Government, which as a rebel movement ousted President Mobutu Sese Seko in May, has said that any killings were carried out by renegade troops, not as a matter of policy. The Government has also asked for 10 days' notice of the names of the new investigators and is insisting on other concessions. **********The decision to send a team more to Mr. Kabila's liking has distressed officials within the United Nations, who believe that at least 200,000 Rwandan Hutu once in eastern Congo, the former Zaire, are still unaccounted for. It has also led to sharp criticism from human rights groups. **********''This is a disastrous precedent,'' said Kenneth Roth, executive director of Human Rights Watch, who said that government leaders have not been accommodated this way in the past. ''Look at Cuba, Sudan, Iran, Iraq -- there are plenty of countries who have refused access,'' Mr. Roth said. ''In each case the United Nations has said: 'Look, this is who we appointed. You either let him in or suffer the consequences of becoming an international pariah.' '' **********Mr. Kabila has objected to the presence on the team of Roberto Garreton, a Chilean human rights lawyer. In April, Mr. Garreton said he had enough evidence of massacres to warrant a full investigation.  The 53-member United Nations Human Rights Commission then asked him to lead a team to eastern Congo, where reports of massacres are still accumulating. An advance party of negotiators spent more than a week in Kinshasa trying to reach an agreement with Mr. Kabila's Government. When that failed, the United Nations Human Rights Center in Geneva turned the matter over to Mr. Annan. **********At the State Department today, the spokesman, Nicholas Burns, said the Administration supported Mr. Annan's decision to take over responsibility for the Congo investigation. Mr. Burns also backed the Congo Government's request that the investigation should cover not only the reported deaths of Hutu, but also of Tutsi in what was then eastern Zaire since March 1993. **********In Geneva, Mr. Annan said on Thursday that ''the most important thing is for us to get the facts.'' **********''The alleged mass killings ought to be investigated, and we will do whatever we can to investigate them,'' the Secretary General said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/11/busin.snippet: Prices of US Treasury securities are slightly lower to unchanged; 30-year bond slips 2/32, to price of 94 3/32 to yield 7.10 percent, unchanged from April 9 (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/11/busin.main_headline: Prices Steady To Lower on Treasuries
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/11/busin.print_headline: Prices Steady To Lower on Treasuries
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/11/busin.body_text: **********Prices of Treasury securities were slightly lower to unchanged yesterday, as investors sold on the fear that forthcoming data would point to stronger inflation and keep the Fed in a restrictive mode. **********The 30-year bond slipped 2/32, to a price of 94 3/32 to yield 7.10 percent, unchanged from Wednesday. **********Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management, said: ''There have been few statistical releases for the bond market to digest thus far this week, and as a result activity has been rather lackluster. In fact, reaction to a larger-than-expected increase in the initial jobless claims was almost nonexistent, very likely because the rise was still rather small and certainly not indicative of any loosening of labor market conditions.'' But tomorrow morning, March statistics for both the Producer Price Index and retail sales are to be released, ''and the markets will be anxiously awaiting these statistics,'' he added. **********Mr. Fine said that even if the price index was favorable, it might not prove too helpful to the bond market, as the Fed is looking beyond the current inflation environment toward future price increases in determining monetary policy. **********''As a result,'' Mr. Fine said, ''the retail sales number takes on even more importance, particularly in light of Chairman Greenspan's comment that future spending is the key to economic outlook. Needless to say, retail sales in both January and February forged ahead rather strongly, and while spending in March is expected to have slowed somewhat from this overly rapid pace despite a boost from the Easter holiday at the end of the month, it is highly unlikely to deter the Fed from further tightening. **********''Indeed, until there is a definitive slowdown in the pace of economic growth, the bond market will continue to anticipate the next Fed move toward a less accommodative monetary policy.'' His reference was to Alan Greenspan, Fed chairman. **********In the week ended April 5, weekly initial claims for state unemployment insurance rose by 6,000, to 318,000, while in the week ended March 29 the number of people receiving unemployment insurance rose by 40,000, to 2.3 million. **********Both new claims and the four-week average have remained below 320,000 for nine weeks, the longest stretch in about eight years. The unemployment rate is 5.2 percent. **********The Government is expected to report today that retail sales last month rose six-tenths of 1 percent, following an eight-tenths of 1 percent increase a month earlier, according to analysts surveyed by Bloomberg News. A Producer Price Index reading higher than a one-tenth of 1 percent increase could cause bonds to come under selling pressure. **********Elsewhere, corporate borrowers are trying to sell debt before rates head higher. The Hilton Hotels Corporation plans to sell $300 million of 10-year notes that are expected to yield from 105 to 110 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, more than the 10-year Treasury note, which was yielding 6.89 percent by the close of the New York market. **********Analysts say Wednesday's larger-than-expected $2.5 billion sale by J. C. Penney Company shows that some investors have an appetite for corporate bonds.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/10/world.main_headline: Foreign Affairs Still Unpopular on Main St.
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/10/world.print_headline: Foreign Affairs Still Unpopular on Main St.
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/10/world.body_text: **********The American public is no more eager to have the United States play a greater global role than it was four years ago, while so-called ''opinion leaders'' have become much more confident about America's place in the world, according to an opinion poll scheduled for release on Friday. **********The survey, by the Pew Research Center for the People and the Press, was intended to measure changes in attitudes about American foreign policy over the last four years. **********For this survey, the pollsters interviewed a representative sample of 2,000 American adults by telephone in early September and also interviewed some 600 prominent Americans. **********The most striking aspect of the poll is the growing gap between members of the public and the unnamed opinion leaders, who have become more optimistic about America's place in the world and the ability of the Clinton Administration to manage foreign policy. **********Members of the public are no more isolationist than they were four years ago, but no more optimistic, either, the survey indicates, and majorities believe that events in Europe, Asia and even Mexico and Canada have little impact on their lives. **********Four years ago, only 28 percent of respondents described themselves as satisfied with world conditions, and today, the percentage is essentially the same, 29 percent, given a sampling error of plus or minus 2 percentage points. But among opinion leaders, 58 percent now say they are satisfied, compared to only 25 percent four years ago.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/08/your-.body_text: **********Because of global shifts in the retirement industry, investors planning for the long term are finding annuities an increasingly attractive option, according to a report funded by the Committee of Annuity Insurers. **********An annuity is a contract, purchased from an insurance company, that pays its holder fixed sums for a specified period of time or until the investor's death. Capital in typically grows tax-free, increasing by a set amount or at a variable rate linked to a mutual-fund investment. **********James Poterba, an economics professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and author of the study, noted that there had been a trend away from guaranteed lifetime benefits for retirees. In recent years, many workers have been participating in the creation of a retirement portfolio, as with the 401(k) plan in the United States and the personal pension plan in Britain. These plans offer holders increased involvement in the accumulation of assets, but do not address maintaining income after retirement. **********"People retire with a big lump sum, and have to figure out what to do with it," Mr. Poterba said. He added: "You want to avoid the chance that you live until you're 95 and run out of money. Annuities offer insurance against that risk." **********Variable annuities are a smart choice for young investors looking to build assets for retirement, according to Todd Porter, an analyst at Morningstar Group Inc. Fixed annuities, on the other hand, look good "if you're in your 60s and you want the security of the fixed payout," Mr. Porter said, because they are an essentially risk-free way to get fixed income with a modest (usually 3 percent to 6 percent) interest payment. **********(IHT)

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/25/news/.main_headline: Aide Calls IMF Rules For Bailout Too Strict : Thai Leader Reshuffles His Cabinet
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/25/news/.print_headline: Aide Calls IMF Rules For Bailout Too Strict : Thai Leader Reshuffles His Cabinet
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/25/news/.body_text: **********BANGKOK—                     After a week of intense political negotiations, Prime Minister Chaovalit Yongchaiyut appointed a new cabinet Friday and made clear his intention to call elections in Thailand as early as possible. **********The main focus of the reshuffle were the economic portfolios. Following Mr. Chaovalit's audience with King Bhumibol Adulyadej on Friday evening, the government announced a cabinet lineup that includes the country's fourth finance minister in 12 months. **********The economic portfolios were dominated by senior bankers, with the executive director of Bangkok Bank Plc., Kosit Papiemrat, appointed finance minister and the president of Siam City Bank Plc., Som Jatusipitak, taking over as commerce minister. **********Mr. Kosit will face the same political pressure that caused his two predecessors to resign. Two other former bankers, Thanong Bhidaya and Amnuay Viravan, each left the cabinet post following disputes with other cabinet members over raising taxes to meet austerity measures. **********The markets will judge the new cabinet when they reopen Monday, but economic analysts said Friday that they were not confident the new cabinet could do much to revive the country's economy. Their unease was increased after a top finance official appointed Friday said that conditions laid out to comply with a $17.2 billion International Monetary Fund-led bailout were too strict. **********Deputy Finance Minister Surasak Nananukool, whose comments have set off controversy in the past, said the conditions for reviving finance companies shut by the authorities were too strict. **********Since June, the government has shut almost two-thirds of the country's 91 finance companies. **********"They want the companies consigned to the Bank of Thailand to be healthier than those still operating," said Mr. Surasak, a former adviser to Mr. Chaovalit. "You don't ask a patient to run faster than people outside the hospital." He said the World Bank's demands for due diligence were too tough and the capital-adequacy ratio of 15 percent was too high. **********Mr. Surasak added that the shortage of cash facing the country's companies was a keen concern that might require further assistance from the IMF. **********"We have a unique situation with foreign commercial banks calling back loans on a massive scale," he said. "I don't know if the money we have will be enough; perhaps the IMF can provide a solution." **********The IMF has already complained of political interference in the implementation of the package, and Australia, a $1 billion contributor to the rescue, has said it would withdraw its portion if the Thais failed to follow austerity measures. **********"There are so many important groups to worry about with an election on the horizon," said an analyst who asked not to be named. "The IMF will be the most expendable." He added, "It has not happened yet, but Chaovalit might try to turn the external situation to political advantage by blaming things on the IMF." **********While the passing of constitutional laws to allow elections was expected to take about six months, the government spokesman said the laws for new polls would be in place by the end of the year. **********"The parliamentary debate and approval of the drafts, with cooperation of both the House of Representatives and the Senate, should be completed within a few weeks" and the government would "return the mandate to the people," the spokesman said. **********As Thailand's currency and stock market plunged, political wrangling has halted the implementation of the financial reforms required by the IMF rescue plan and put in place in August. **********The baht has lost more than 35 percent of its value since it was knocked off its dollar-linked peg in July. **********Newspaper editorials throughout the region have chided Thailand's politicians as "shameful," and several thousand protesters took to the streets of Bangkok this past week to prod Mr. Chaovalit to leave. **********Even the army, still an important factor in Thai politics, has begun urging the prime minister to move quickly to save the economy. **********But analysts said Friday they doubted the reshuffle would change the country's economic prospects. **********"The only thing that could change the economy and market sentiment is if the new cabinet can implement the rescue package," said Therapong Vachirapong, assistant vice president of Phatra Thankit Securities, referring to the bailout. "And there, the new cabinet faces the same old problems."

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/13/busin.main_headline: Brussels Seeks to Settle Crisis Over 2 Sanctions Laws : A Stay in EU-U.S. Trade Spat
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/13/busin.print_headline: Brussels Seeks to Settle Crisis Over 2 Sanctions Laws : A Stay in EU-U.S. Trade Spat
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/13/busin.body_text: **********Seeking to prevent the trans-Atlantic dispute over Cuba from undermining the World Trade Organization, the European Union on Wednesday requested a one-week delay in forming a WTO dispute panel in order to pursue a negotiated settlement of U.S. trade sanctions with President Bill Clinton's administration. **********The European move, which was welcomed by senior U.S. officials, raised hopes on both sides of a solution to the worst U.S.-EU trade dispute since the early 1990s. **********The one-week delay will allow for high-level negotiations. Officials said they expected the issue would be high on the agenda when Secretary of State Madeleine Albright tours European capitals next week, including a stop in Brussels on Tuesday for talks with the European Commission president, Jacques Santer, and the EU trade commissioner, Sir Leon Brittan. **********But officials cautioned that the political obstacles to a deal were numerous, and the time to resolve them was short. **********In announcing the delay, Sir Leon said the Union was not seeking a showdown with Washington but was determined to defend European commercial interests. **********"This is why we are eager to achieve an overall settlement of our differences with the United States over the unacceptable extraterritorial effects of the Helms-Burton and D'Amato acts," he said. The Helms-Burton Act contains sanctions for foreign companies that use expropriated properties in Cuba. The D'Amato Act allows the government to withhold U.S. financing and contracts from foreign companies that trade with Iran and Libya. **********The request for a delay, coming just one day before the WTO director-general was due to appoint a three-person panel to rule on the legality of the U.S. sanctions, reflected growing European concern that the United States would justify its sanctions on national security grounds and refuse to cooperate with the Geneva-based trade organization. **********Such hardball tactics would leave the WTO, launched just two years ago with a mission of resolving global trade disputes, "immeasurably damaged," Sir Leon said. **********But Sir Leon rejected any hint of a European climb-down in the delay. He said that the Union would press its WTO case by Feb. 20 if a settlement was not reached, and that he was confident of victory. **********"It is not credible to suggest that protection of U.S. national security requires interference in the legitimate trade of European companies with Cuba," he said. **********Sir Leon said that he has been in frequent telephone contact with Stuart Eizenstat, the U.S. undersecretary of commerce who is Mr. Clinton's special envoy on Cuba, but that Washington's talk has fallen far short of Europe's demands. **********"We've been involved in discussions with the Europeans," Mr. Eizenstat said in a statement, "and we appreciate the additional time to see if we can come up with an amicable resolution of this matter." **********What Europe is seeking, Sir Leon and other EU officials said, were guarantees from the administration not to use Helms-Burton provisions to bar any more European executives from entering the United States. **********The State Department last year barred two British executives on the board of Sherritt International Corp., a Canadian mining company, because Sherritt is a major investor in Cuba. **********In addition, Sir Leon said the EU was seeking to protect European companies from the reach of the D'Amato Act. **********With the Republican Congress still strongly supportive of the two pieces of legislation and European governments adamant about resisting what they view as American attempts to impose its laws overseas, officials said it would be difficult for negotiators on both sides to cut a deal and sell it at home by Feb. 20. **********But EU officials said they hoped a delay would de-escalate the dispute and reduce the risk that the United States might walk out on a WTO panel.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/16/busin.snippet: Radio Data Systems, 'smart' radios that can tune stations by format, interrupt cassette or regular programming for important announcements and print out data transmitted by stations, has not won acceptance in United States; failure comes despite e...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/16/busin.main_headline: Radio Technology Fails To Win U.S. Acceptance
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/16/busin.print_headline: Radio Technology Fails To Win U.S. Acceptance
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/16/busin.body_text: **********It was hailed by proponents as ''a revolution in radio,'' the venerable ''sound medium'' with a new dimension: the printed word. But today the technology known as R.D.S. -- for Radio Data Systems -- seems destined to join the eight-track tape and the Betamax videocassette recorder as a flop in the United States. **********''Smart'' radios arrived on American shores five years ago with impressive potential. They could tune stations by format rather than frequency and interrupt a cassette or compact disk -- or regular programming -- when they had something important to transmit about the weather or the traffic. They could even be equipped to print out information transmitted by the station. **********Adding to the prospects for success in America was the technology's encouraging record of consumer acceptance in Europe and East Asia. R.D.S.'s liquid-crystal displays of text could be placed on car, portable and home radios. **********Yet, despite a strong push by the Consumer Electronics Manufacturers Association and some of its members -- both of which furnished the needed hardware free to big radio stations in an effort to jumpstart R.D.S. -- the technology arrived here stillborn. Today, there is a growing sense among radio broadcasters and manufacturers that the breakthrough may never happen. **********''I don't see or hear much about it,'' said Ed Schwartz, the head of engineering for New York's WCBS-AM and WCBS-FM. **********The manager of a Duluth, Minn.,  FM station had never seen his own station's R.D.S. display until Bruce Elving, the publisher of FM Atlas, showed it to him. ''I guess that tells you something about the success of the medium,'' Mr. Elving said. **********James Stevens, product manager for radios at Blaupunkt, a pioneer in European R.D.S. since its start in 1985, called the situation in the United States ''a classic chicken-and-egg situation.'' Only several hundred commercial FM stations, of a total of 5,468, use the technology. This, along with the limited number of R.D.S. radios, falls well short of the critical mass needed. **********Experts on the technology react to the somber prognosis with regrets.  Mr. Elving regards the episode as a missed opportunity for broadcasters. He sees R.D.S. as ''an excellent promotional tool'' since call letters and format are flashed continuously on a liquid-crystal display. **********A radio that can print can also provide such information as song titles and artists without waiting for the disk jockey to do so. In Houston, KTBZ-FM has shown the potential of R.D.S. by transmitting such data to roadside electronic billboards. **********As originally conceived, an R.D.S. radio could be fitted with small printers similar to those that issue taxi receipts. These could contain information like titles, artists and where a CD could be purchased. Or a listener could hear a commercial while the radio printed a discount coupon. **********As engaging as all this might sound, it does not hint at what may be the single greatest utility of R.D.S.: its role as an aid to improved traffic-flow management. That is the case in Europe, where R.D.S.-equipped receivers are common in expensive automobiles, and public transportation officials have seized upon this technology. **********For an American motoring along the Autobahn, it can be unnerving at first to hear the music suddenly give way to an announcement about an accident ahead. In that setting, ''you get pretty quickly sold'' on the benefits of R.D.S., according to Eric Braun, vice president for new technology at the consulting firm of Frank N. Magid Associates. **********This same technology could also be used with an accessory buzzer to alert listeners to breaking news they might otherwise miss. **********With such an array of applications, how could R.D.S. miss? **********Experts cite a variety of reasons. For one thing, they say, the American version puts too great an emphasis on the printed identification of call letters and format to the exclusion of other features. They also blame poor promotion for the low consumer awareness. **********Most pointedly, the experts cite the reluctance of broadcasters to try anything that might remotely threaten the loss of their audience, even if only for a short interval. **********''I want my listeners to stay with my station,'' said one broadcaster who insisted on not being identified.  ''I don't want to give them reasons or give them technology that will enable them to suddenly tune out, automatically or otherwise.'' **********Also holding back R.D.S. in America is the fact that some of its selling points address needs peculiar to the European market. For example, the ability of the car radio to switch automatically from one network affiliate to another with a stronger signal is useful only for a network-based system of broadcasting. In the United States, commercial FM radio is devoted primarily to locally originated fare. **********Moreover, since the R.D.S. signal rides on an FM subcarrier, AM stations are effectively shut out. That is not a problem for Europe where news and information programming is in generous supply on FM. But in this country, most news and talk stations are AM. **********Mr. Elving has not given up all hope. Perhaps, he said, the analogy of color TV -- which took more than a decade to win consumer acceptance -- applies. But unless R.D.S. can be ''resuscitated,'' he warned, it will follow the path of Dolby FM, which, he recalled, ''went the way of the dinosaur.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/17/busin.snippet: Data General Corp, troubled minicomputer giant, is making comeback, fueled by sales of two new machines and fanatical commitment to cost-cutting; chief executive Ronald L Skates's turnaround strategy gets credit; photo (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/17/busin.main_headline: Data General Comeback Built on Cost-Cutting and Innovation
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/17/busin.print_headline: Data General Comeback Built on Cost-Cutting and Innovation
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/17/busin.body_text: **********After a decade of losses totaling more than half a billion dollars, the layoffs of more than 13,000 of the company's 18,000 workers and a close brush with bankruptcy, Data General's executives feel like survivors of an ugly train wreck. No one is quite ready to declare victory and celebrate. **********But after being written off as dead in the unforgiving world of high technology, the former high-flying minicomputer giant, a company whose brash and aggressive style was chronicled in Tracy Kidder's Pulitzer Prize-winning book ''The Soul of a New Machine,'' has turned around. **********The comeback effort has been fueled by the sales, if not souls, of two new machines and a fanatical commitment to cost-cutting. **********Always respected for its technological prowess, the Data General Corporation has been able to rebound because of two crucial product lines -- a high-end server called Aviion that is intended to accommodate the data processing needs of an entire corporation and a disk storage system called Clariion. Revenue growth was 10 percent in 1995, and 15 percent in 1996, when revenues from products -- as opposed to services -- grew by 22 percent. **********Wall Street has noticed. Data General's stock has jumped 43 percent from $14 to $20 since Jan. 1, closing at $19.25, down 25 cents, on Friday. Several analysts have switched their recommendations from hold to buy. **********''You have to give credit where it is due,'' said Peter Labe, an analyst with Buckingham Research Group in New York. ''They have met or exceeded expectations for six quarters now. We're past the point of calling it a turnaround.'' **********Mr. Labe said that he had not recommended Data General's stock since 1981, the year Mr. Kidder's book was published. **********Much has changed since Data General served as a bellwether for the minicomputer revolution that swept the industry in the 1970's. By the mid-1980's, when Data General reached $1.3 billion in revenues, the computing world had embraced personal computers, and sales of Data General's larger minicomputers quickly began to dry up. **********Data General was hit harder and faster than rivals like the Digital Equipment Corporation and I.B.M. because it lacked the large and loyal installed base of customers to sustain it through a transition to new products. **********Over the next decade, as the company scrambled to revamp its product offerings under the open-systems banner, sales of its Eclipse minicomputers dried up, falling by 40 percent annually starting in 1987. The old core business was disappearing faster than the new product, Aviion servers, could be put on the market. Last year, as revenues from the Eclipse line dwindled to $25 million (from $900 million in 1989), the minicomputer era ended for Data General. **********From 1986 through 1995, Data General lost $547 million, and the company laid off two-thirds of its work force. ''It was like a baseball bat to the knees,'' said Ronald L. Skates, Data General's 55-year-old president and chief executive. ''We came this close to going out of business,'' he added, with his thumb and index finger an inch apart. **********Some analysts remain conservative about the company. Shao Wang, of Smith Barney, said he was impressed with what he had seen, but he continues to put a neutral rating on the stock. ''The balance sheet is very clean and they are starting to attract some hotshot developers, but I'm not recommending it,'' he said. ''They've had such a long history of poor financial performance that six quarters of profitability feels relatively short. And these are the same guys running the show.'' **********Mr. Skates, an accountant from Price Waterhouse, took over as chief executive from the legendary founder of Data General, Edson D. de Castro, in 1989. Unlike such ill-fated rivals as Wang Laboratories and Prime Computer, Data General had avoided excessive debt, insuring that even in the worst of times the company always had more cash than debt and thus could narrowly avoid a Chapter 11 filing. **********Mr. Skates's strategy was to develop computers with open, nonproprietary systems for mid-sized companies. He entrusted the vision for the new products to Tom West, the hero of Mr. Kidder's book and a man who had somehow endured at Data General for 25 years, a notable feat in an industry marked by short bursts of technology genius followed by burnout. ''It's amazing they've been able to hold a talent like West,'' said Steven Smith, a Paine Webber analyst. **********Under Mr. West, the company developed its Aviion offerings and began building a fault-tolerant line of computers, which were built with twin systems, a main one and a permanent backup to provide a safety net against system crashes. In the early 1990's, short of cash to support the fault-tolerant products and fearing that that market was shrinking, Mr. Skates killed the project. But the development team had already produced the fault-tolerant storage system, which put Data General at the forefront of a new market. **********At first, Mr. Skates said, he did not realize what he had. At an Aviion product announcement in New York City in 1991, a financial analyst spotted the storage system and leaned over to Mr. Skates. ''This is a phenomenal product,'' he said. **********Intrigued, Mr. Skates returned to Westboro and immediately set up a separate business unit to build and sell the storage product, named Clariion. Lacking the financial resources to build a sales force to sell the product, he decided to offer the system to rival computer makers to sell under their own brands. **********It was a move into new territory for a company used to selling directly to customers. But ''Data General had the right product at the right time to catch an opportunity,'' said Clive Surfleet, marketing manager for Hewlett-Packard's Enterprise Storage Solutions Business. **********Hewlett-Packard became the first and biggest partner for Data General, reselling the Clariion product under the Hewlett banner. In less than four years, Clariion has become a $500 million business for Data General. Of that, nearly $300 million has been sold through Hewlett-Packard. Data General recently signed up other companies, vendors including Silicon Graphics and Storage Technology, to sell the product. **********Rick Chapman, senior vice president for information systems at Columbia/HCA Healthcare Systems, the $20 billion health care giant in Nashville, is one of Data General's largest customers, with an investment of up to $50 million in the company's systems. Mr. Chapman praised Data General's technology and its prices, which are generally lower than competitors. **********This year, the company is scheduled to introduce two new product lines. One is a more powerful high-end version of the Aviion server. The other is a small server to distribute information to a network of computers aimed at Internet users and planned to sell for less than $1,000. **********The new server, called ThiinLine, will be at the forefront of a family of Internet ''appliances'' that Data General plans to build in yet another separate business unit, Mr. West said. He pointed out that the ThiinLine concept complements the growing market for network computers, the low-priced, scaled-down Internet terminals that will provide easy access to simple Internet functions like E-mail and browsing. **********''There are 7 million servers on the Internet now and predictions are that there will be 70 million in the next two or three years,'' Mr. West said. ''The question is: what will these servers be? They will not be refrigerator-sized minicomputers or even general purpose computers. More likely they'll be specialized, single-function appliances with a two-button interface and the ease of use of a toaster.'' **********Despite its recent run of success, a decade of ill fortunes has rendered the company all but invisible, or worse, irrelevant. Although Mr. West said that recruiting top talent had become easier, Mr. Skates said his two biggest challenges were increasing the size of the sales force, from 800 to 1,100 people, and getting Data General's name on the lists of potential vendors at large companies. **********''We have a high success rate when we get a chance to bid, but the problem is we don't get invited in enough,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/17/your-.body_text: **********Taking refuge in commodities has long been a defense against inflation, but not something readily available to small investors. Now, with signs of inflation looming in the United States, a new open-end fund launched by Oppenheimer Funds Inc. hopes to remedy that. Its Real Asset fund will have a third of its assets in securities linked to the 22 commodities of the Goldman Sachs Commodity Index, including livestock, grains, oil and metals. The remainder of the portfolio will be invested in short-term U.S. government securities. **********The fund differs from existing commodity funds in several ways, according to Oppenheimer. The minimum investment is $1,000, and fees will total 1.5 percent a year, in contrast to commodities futures pools, which typically require at least a five-figure investment, and assess average fees of 2 percent a year, plus 20 percent of the profits. "It's really the first commodities fund which is broadly available for the average investor," said Rob Densen, an Oppenheimer spokesman. **********FOR MORE information, call 303-768-2424 or, in the United States, 888-470-0861. Oppenheimer's web site, www.oppenheimerfunds.com, has information on the fund and its prospectus.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/24/busin.body_text: **********''A Senior Discount? I Don't Deserve It,'' by Ted M. Levine (From the Desk Of, July 27), discussed the growing wealth of the 65-and-over age group -- and what he saw as the needless price breaks available to it. His opinions drew many responses from readers. **********To the Editor: **********Mr. Levine fails to take into account that when many of us who are now seniors earned our money, a new car cost about $3,000 and a house around $38,000. Now that $3,000 car I saved for 25 years ago costs $12,500 and the $38,000 house goes for $150,000. All that net worth mentioned in the article doesn't mean much when I can't replace the money once I've spent it. **********EVELYN CHURCH **********Washington, July 27

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/24/busin.snippet: Even most buoyant of stock markets, like Russia and Brazil, succumb to tidal wave of selling on Oct 23; mutual funds specializing in Latin American stocks have been among best performers this year, and Russian funds have been even hotter; but majo...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/24/busin.main_headline: Russia and Brazil Caught in Selling Surge
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/24/busin.print_headline: THE ASIAN CRISIS: MUTUAL FUNDS; Russia and Brazil Caught in Selling Surge
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/24/busin.body_text: **********What had been an Asian problem looks more and more like an emerging markets problem, as even the most buoyant of these markets, like Russia and Brazil, succumbed to a tidal wave of selling yesterday. **********The biggest repercussions were in the countries perceived to have the weakest currencies, and investors were reminded that a diverse portfolio representing many regions of the world does not necessarily provide real protection against a global downdraft. **********Mutual funds specializing in Latin American stocks have been among the best performers this year, and Russian funds have been even hotter. But yesterday the major stock market indexes fell by about 8 percent in Brazil, 4.5 percent in Mexico and 5 percent in Russia -- two to four times worse than the 2 percent decline suffered by American stocks. **********''There really didn't seem to be a place to hide yesterday,'' said Rajeev Bhaman, co-manager of the Oppenheimer Developing Markets fund. ''When the sentiment goes against a class of assets like the emerging markets, everything goes together.'' **********The widespread fallout from the Asian currency crisis, which caused the Hong Kong market to fall 10.4 percent yesterday, started to take a toll on American mutual fund investors, who previously this year have shown some skittishness at volatility in the American stock market. **********At T. Rowe Price in Baltimore, investors generally appeared to be moving money out of international funds yesterday and into either United States stock funds or money market funds, said Steven Norwitz, a spokesman. Similarly, at Fidelity Investments in Boston, investors made slight redemptions in international funds yesterday while moving money into domestic growth stock funds or money market accounts, said Teri Kilduff, a spokeswoman. And at Charles Schwab & Company in San Francisco, investors made net withdrawals of $13 million from mutual funds of all types yesterday, a spokesman said. **********What happens now in emerging markets around the world could depend as much on the reactions of American mutual fund investors as on the plans of central bankers around the globe. **********''If people end up withdrawing capital from these emerging markets, they could all be in trouble,''  Mr. Bhaman said. ''People may end up saying that because things are bad in China, they don't want to lend money in Brazil.'' **********So far, however, the problems have been contained in Asia, and nearly all of the withdrawals from emerging market mutual funds in recent weeks have been from funds that specialize in the Asian and Pacific markets, said Robert Adler, president of AMG Data Services, which tracks mutual fund cash flows. **********In the week ended Wednesday, Asian funds suffered net outflows of $53 million, while emerging market funds overall took in $149 million, Mr. Adler said. **********Funds investing in the Pacific region had already fallen 10 percent to 20 percent this year, before the sharp declines this week. And while most fund managers say they are attracted by the greatly depressed prices in Asian markets, they have been reluctant to plunge in and buy in the middle of the downturn. **********''The question is do you want to get in the way of a falling safe, even though you know there's lots of money in it,'' said Robert Swift, a senior portfolio manager at Putnam Investments. ''Right now, people are stepping aside.'' **********And when they do participate, they are as likely to raise cash in order to brace themselves for possible redemptions by shareholders. ''Depending on how fast we see stability returning, I think we could see investors make a high level of redemptions in emerging market funds in the next few weeks,'' said Angeline Ee, co-manager of the Montgomery Emerging Markets fund. **********That could spread the weakness in Asia to other regions. The markets outside of Asia that most worry fund managers include Brazil, which suffers from several of the same negative economic factors that have led to currency declines in Asia. **********''We have concerns about the real,'' the Brazilian currency unit, Ms. Ee said. ''Brazil has a current account deficit, a fiscal deficit, and the real is currently overvalued. I think that is why it was hit so hard today.'' **********Brazil is also one of the largest, most liquid Latin American markets, which means that it is one of the first emerging markets that mutual fund managers turn to when they need to sell stocks quickly. **********Other, smaller South American markets, however, appear to be less vulnerable. **********Certainly, Latin American stock funds still have big gains for the year, as do Russian funds. In Eastern Europe yesterday, Russian blue-chip stocks were hit the hardest, but stocks of smaller companies fell much less sharply yesterday. **********Christian Strenger, chief executive of Deutsche Bank's mutual fund unit, said he believed that because much of Russia's economic growth is internally generated, rather than dependent on exports, it does not face many of the dangers that have recently afflicted Asian markets. **********Whether Asia experiences the V-shaped decline and recovery that investors saw in Mexico two years ago, or a longer, drawn-out recovery like that experienced in Japan in recent years, depends on who steps forward to help the Asian countries and how willing those countries are to make often-painful economic adjustments. **********Not all Asian markets fell apart yesterday, and some managers foresee that the long-lasting effect of the currency problems there will be to make products from Asian countries more competitive. **********Stock prices rose in Taiwan, for example, and one big industry there -- makers of semiconductor manufacturing equipment -- could find that Asian currency declines have made their products more attractively priced relative to those of American and Japanese rivals. **********For investors in emerging market mutual funds, the least effective way to grapple with crisis is likely to be withdrawing money from emerging markets now, only to pour it back in when the stock markets appear on the upswing again is likely to be a fruitless pursuit. **********''Emerging markets have gained 15 percent annually over the long term, but that can vary by 40 percent each year,'' said David Bugen, a financial adviser in Chatham, N.J. ''That means you could make 65 percent in two out of three years, but on the other hand it's not unusual to lose 25 percent in a single year.''
