https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/17/world.print_headline: Nigeria May Ask U.S. Ambassador About Bombings
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/17/world.body_text: **********Nigeria's top police official has said he wants to question the American Ambassador and members of the Embassy staff about a series of bombings in the country. **********The Government has not specified why it wants to question the Ambassador, Walter C. Carrington. But the Inspector General, Ibrahim Coomassie, said on Tuesday, ''We certainly require a diplomatic immunity waiver to allow us to interrogate the U.S. Ambassador and several staff of the U.S. Embassy.'' The Americans say they have not received a request for a waiver. **********The military Government has accused the main opposition group, the National Democratic Coalition, of directing the bombings, most of which have hit military targets, and has openly stated suspicions that American diplomats knew in advance about the bombings, which have killed 10 people. After the first attacks, in November, the State Department issued a warning about the possibility of more. **********The Embassy issued a statement today reiterating condemnation of the bombings and adding, ''We stand ready to assist the Government of Nigeria in any way we can, commensurate with both U.S. and international law.'' **********The bombings, in Lagos and in other cities, have killed at least 10 people. **********The request to question the Ambassador follows an open Government attack on him last week in which the head of Nigeria's Civil Service, Alhaji Gidado Idris, said Mr. Carrington was not sending the right signals to improve relations between the United States and Nigeria. **********Mr. Carrington responded by saying he was disappointed with Mr. Idris's words. **********Sanctions were imposed on Nigeria in November 1995 after the execution of Ken Saro Wiwa and eight others who were campaigning for minority rights in the southeastern region of Ogoniland.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/26/busin.snippet: US Supreme Court rules, 6-3, that insider trading laws apply to people with confidential information even if they have no connection with company whose shares are being bought; ruling reinstates conviction of James H O'Hagan, Minneapolis attorney ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/26/busin.main_headline: Supreme Court Upholds S.E.C.'s Theory of Insider Trading
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/26/busin.print_headline: Supreme Court Upholds S.E.C.'s Theory of Insider Trading
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/26/busin.body_text: **********The Supreme Court provided a major victory to Federal prosecutors and securities regulators yesterday by ruling that insider trading laws apply to people who have confidential information even if they do not have any connection to the company whose shares are being bought. **********The Court, in a 6-to-3 decision, reinstated the conviction of James H. O'Hagan, a Minneapolis lawyer who had made $4.3 million in trading in Pillsbury stock and stock options after he had learned that Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. a London-based client of his firm, planned a hostile takeover bid for Pillsbury. The Minneapolis food company's share price soared after the Grand Met offer was disclosed. **********His conviction had been overturned by an appellate court that concluded that his conduct was not illegal because he was not an insider of Pillsbury, the company whose stock was being traded. **********Under the standard approved yesterday by the Court, anyone who gains inside information under conditions in which that person knows it is supposed to remain confidential may not use it for trading. That could cover anyone from a financial printer to a law firm secretary. But it would not cover someone who learned of the information by chance, such as overhearing a conversation in a bar. **********The Supreme Court decision, by Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, reinstated the conviction and in so doing upheld the ''misappropriation theory'' that the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit in St. Louis had ruled invalid. That theory had been used in many insider trading cases in recent years, among them those against Ivan F. Boesky and Dennis B. Levine, two Wall Street figures who went to jail in the 1980's. Had the appeals court's opinion been the law then, they would probably have escaped prosecution. **********''This decision reaffirms the S.E.C.'s efforts to make the stock market fair to all people, whether you're a Wall Street veteran or a Main Street newcomer,'' said Arthur Levitt Jr., the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission. **********The court ruling had been anxiously awaited at the S.E.C., which feared that the scope of current insider trading laws could have been severely narrowed. The S.E.C. brings civil cases on insider trading, while the Justice Department brings criminal ones, like the case against Mr. O'Hagan. **********Under the so-called classic theory of insider trading, which was not at issue in yesterday's decision, it is illegal for a corporate insider, or a temporary insider like a lawyer for the company, to trade in that company's securities on the basis of material nonpublic information. It is also illegal for someone who was tipped by such an insider to do so. **********The misappropriation theory extended liability to those who used such information from one company to trade in securities of another company. **********''It makes scant sense to hold a lawyer like O'Hagen'' to have violated the law, Justice Ginsburg wrote, in a decision signed by five other Justices, ''if he works for a lawyer representing the target of a tender offer, but not if he works for a law firm representing the bidder.'' **********She said the misappropriation theory was ''well tuned to an animating principle'' of Federal securities law, ''to secure honest securities markets and thereby promote investor confidence.'' **********While the misappropriation theory will most often be used in the context of corporate takeovers, it could have other uses as well. For example, an employee of the Food and Drug Administration who bought stock in a pharmaceutical company with the knowledge that the Government was about to approve a new drug could be charged under the theory. **********Even with yesterday's decision, some people with inside information would still be free to trade on it. Someone who obtained it innocently, such as by finding a document accidentally left in a taxi, could trade on the information. And while those who get tips from insiders would still be liable in most cases, the Government must show that the person receiving the tip knew or had reason to know that the person giving it was violating a confidence. **********The misappropriation theory was developed by courts after earlier Supreme Court rulings that had rejected cases brought against a financial printer and a securities analyst for trading on material, nonpublic information. It had been endorsed by several circuit courts of appeal, but rejected by two, leading to the Supreme Court decision. **********In the Supreme Court's only previous consideration of the misappropriation doctrine, a 1987 decision regarding R. Foster Winans, a former Wall Street Journal columnist who had bought shares before publication of a column about those stocks, the Court split 4 to 4 on that issue and did not issue a ruling. That left standing a decision by the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit in New York affirming the theory, but did not create a precedent binding on other circuits. **********Mr. O'Hagan was convicted on 57 counts and sentenced to 41 months in prison. In addition to violating the insider trading law, he was convicted of mail fraud and of violating an S.E.C. rule that bars insider trading in connection with a tender offer. The High Court reinstated all the convictions. **********Three Justices -- Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and Justices Clarence Thomas and Antonin Scalia -- voted not to approve the misappropriation theory. Justice Thomas, in a dissent, argued that the fraud committed by Mr. O'Hagan was on Grand Met, by depriving it of exclusive use of its information. The misappropriation was complete before the trade, and therefore the fraud was not ''in connection with'' the sale of securities, as required by the statute, Justice Thomas argued. **********Justice Thomas, joined by the Chief Justice, also said the S.E.C. rule on tender offers was illegal, but it was endorsed by the other seven Justices. All nine said they would reinstate Mr. O'Hagan's conviction on mail fraud charges. The appeals court had said that that conviction could not stand because it was based on the securities fraud conviction, but Justice Thomas rejected that argument. The others did not need to reach it, because they had affirmed one or more securities convictions. **********The case, United States v. O'Hagen, No. 96-842, was sent back to the Eighth Circuit, which may consider other parts of the appeal by Mr. O'Hagan that it had not previously considered because it had already thrown out the convictions. **********Mr. O'Hagan, who maintains that he bought Pillsbury stock and options to buy stock for reasons other than having inside information, has since been disbarred for embezzling $1 million from an escrow account he controlled. According to the Government, the insider trading was an effort to raise cash to cover up the original embezzlement. He was sentenced to 30 months in prison by a state court for the embezzlement.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/12/busin.body_text: **********STAYING at home to raise the kids and manage the household is politically correct these days. As of Jan. 1, it became financially correct, too. **********You might have missed it in the everything-but-the-kitchen-sink Small Business Job Protection Act of 1996, but a provision in the law almost doubles the amount that a couple with a nonworking spouse can contribute to individual retirement accounts. **********Effective for the 1997 tax year, the change means stay-at-home spouses and their employed mates can invest up to a combined $4,000 in I.R.A.'s, up from $2,250, putting them on par with families in which both spouses work. **********Before, only families with two wage-earning partners could contribute the maximum of $4,000, or $2,000 apiece. **********''It recognizes the value of the work women do in the home and takes into account that most women who are not employed out of the home now, will be, and need to worry about saving for retirement,'' said Ellen Bravo, the executive director of 9 to 5, a national association of working women. **********The so-called ''spousal I.R.A.'' is seen as a way to encourage more women to save for retirement. Numerous studies show that women fail to save enough for retirement, and for several reasons. Women tend to move in and out of the work force, making their saving sporadic. They live longer, requiring their savings to be stretched further. And women still earn less than men, compounding the first two problems. **********While the money in I.R.A.'s grows tax deferred until withdrawn, families still must meet certain tests to get an immediate tax deduction for their contribution. First, the spousal I.R.A. is available only to couples filing jointly; these couples can generally take the full $4,000 deduction on their income taxes if neither person is covered by a pension plan. If at least one person is covered, the couple can still take the full deduction if their adjusted gross income is less than $40,000. A partial deduction is permitted for those with incomes of up to $50,000. **********Because many families will not be able to get an immediate deduction, they will probably skip the new spousal I.R.A. And families with income low enough to qualify for the deduction may have trouble coming up with the spare cash to contribute. **********''The new law could help those families who make less than $50,000,'' said Tom Cooney, a tax expert with Rippe & Kingston C.P.A., an accounting firm in Cincinnati. ''But unfortunately, a lot of those people can't afford to save that sum or they are already working.'' **********John L. Steffens, an executive vice president of Merrill Lynch & Company, said of the I.R.A. change: ''This is a very important first step. Is it absolutely the best thing that could happen for women? Probably not.'' **********But response was strong on the first business day that the expanded accounts were available. Merrill Lynch said that on Jan. 2, its customers opened 4,000 spousal I.R.A.'s, up from about 400 on the same day last year. Planners urged investors with more income to look beyond the deduction. The money in I.R.A.'s still grows tax deferred, as it always has, and that benefit is available to all taxpayers, regardless of income. **********''If you have the cash flow to do it, I think it's a good idea, even if you don't get a deduction,'' said Cindy D. Coddington, a financial planner with David L. Babson & Company in Cambridge, Mass. **********For people who have I.R.A.'s containing deductible and nondeductible contributions, there is one big downside: an accounting headache when it comes time to make withdrawals. **********Anyone interested in making an I.R.A. contribution should do so now instead of waiting until the last minute, which would be April 15, 1998, for the 1997 tax year. The sooner your money is invested in an I.R.A., the longer it has to grow tax deferred.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/17/busin.snippet: Chicago Board of Trade opens for business on Feb 18 with what is billed as 'the world's largest trading floor'; Board of Trade officials say advanced technology should help exchange maintain its longtime ranking as world's leading futures and opti...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/17/busin.main_headline: Face Lift at Board of Trade: High Tech, Say Hello to Primal Instinct
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/17/busin.print_headline: Face Lift at Board of Trade: High Tech, Say Hello to Primal Instinct
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/17/busin.body_text: **********It's hoopla time at the Chicago Board of Trade, where what is proudly billed as ''the world's largest trading floor'' opens for business Tuesday morning. The new trading hall will be home to as many as 8,000 traders, brokers and support staff members. **********Board of Trade officials say the advanced technology should help the exchange maintain its longtime ranking as the world's leading futures and options marketplace. **********In fact, though, the new trading floor is not really a showcase of the cutting edge in trading technology. While the floor is ready for traders and brokers to use the latest  technology, the truth is that most have no intention of doing so for now. Trading on Tuesday will not look much different from trading last week, because the new floor is less a showcase than a reminder that the deployment of new technology is often retarded by the conflicting agendas, experience and fears of the people who will use it. **********The Board of Trade's chairman sees the new arrangement as a starting point that could accelerate technological changes there. ''The new floor creates an environment to get people to think less defensively about technology,'' said Patrick Arbor, the chairman. **********Ambivalence about new technology shaped the project from the very beginning. Early on, Board of Trade officials, sensitive to member criticism that the entire project was too ambitious, declined to invest $150,000 for a virtual reality mock-up of the new room. Mock-ups are a new but increasingly common architectural tool that compared with an old-fashioned model, gives clients a much truer perspective of how a room will look inside. But it all sounded too futuristic for Board of Trade officials. Only after the pits were constructed did members find problems with sightlines and other features that sparked bitter complaints and some revisions. **********''There's a lot of what's been done here that can't be explained except by referring to their traditions,'' said Charles Kinsey, chief executive of Space Management Programs Inc., the Chicago-based interior architect for the $182 million Board of Trade project and numerous other exchange building projects around the world. **********Those traditions start with ''open outcry'' trading, in which futures and options contracts on everything from corn to Treasury bonds change hands via shouted and hand-signaled bids and offers. Impenetrable to outsiders even when trading is calm -- and downright frightening when markets are moving fast -- it is a muscular world rooted in the 19th century, when the Board was created to trade corn contracts. **********Open outcry bears little outward resemblance to newer computer-based methods of trading where office-bound brokers and traders armed with sophisticated mathematical models and surrounded by screens of news and price information make deals with unseen counterparts as likely to be in Tokyo or London as across town. **********If where you sit in computerized trading is irrelevant, where you stand in open outcry systems is crucial. Brokers on the top rung at the outside of a pit have clear sightlines to booths at the edge of the trading floor from which they receive orders via hand signals. They also enjoy easier access than those in the pits to runners bringing information from other sources. They can also see the whole pit more easily, giving them an advantage in filling orders. **********Top-rung real estate at the Board of Trade's pits goes by general consensus to brokers with seniority and a track record of generating business in the pit. Many such brokers are reluctant to encourage the development of wireless communications and trading systems that could level the playing field for those deeper in the pit. They find allies for their position among traders in the pit who count on them for business. **********Over time, every pit develops a delicate ecology of relationships that new technology is bound to upset. It is an ecology so expensive and difficult to create from scratch these days that most new exchanges developed in recent years reside entirely on computers. But where it exists, open outcry is prized for making prices equally visible to all players. **********''There are all sorts of competing business interests within an exchange but there always seems to be a very strong sentiment of it ain't clearly broke don't fix it,'' said Daniel Rappaport, chairman of the New York Mercantile Exchange, which plans to move to its new trading floor at the edge of New York harbor on Memorial Day. **********For a time starting in the late 1980's, the common wisdom in trading circles was that for all their benefits open outcry systems were destined to go the way of the dinosaur. Where pit traders traditionally had the best seat for taking the pulse of the market, the advantage was shifting to office traders with easy access to news services and other information that drives prices. Some trading floors, like the London Stock Exchange, gradually became deserted as trading shifted to computers. **********The Board of Trade pursued a wide range of actions aimed at sustaining pit trading, including investing in electronic systems that would handle some of its products during hours when the pits were closed. **********The most ambitious of those investments, a joint venture with the Chicago Mercantile Exchange and Reuters to start a worldwide computer-based trading system called Globex, floundered both before and after the Board of Trade dropped out in 1994. The other, the Board's more modest Project A network, is growing steadily. **********The new floor comes on line at a time when many open outcry markets are thriving and many Board of Trade members feel less compelled to gamble on drastic changes. It was built primarily in response to overcrowding in the oft-renovated pre-World War II room across the street where Treasury bond futures, options and other financial contracts sensitive to changes in interest rates have been traded since the 1970's. These trades have mushroomed in tandem with the national debt. **********But many Board of Trade officials felt the building project had to add not just elbow room but better access to market information (the new room has giant electronic billboards carrying news from several wire services along with trading data) and faster communications among the employees and customers of trading firms. It also had to move everyone closer to paperless trading. **********That last goal requires electronic orders and record-keeping from start to finish, including the use of hand-held electronics in the pits. In essence, the people in the pits would have to combat the computer-equipped office traders by tying themselves into computer networks,  too. Without such technology to cut costs, speed up trades and record-keeping and provide clearer audit trails, the exchange might survive for decades but would almost certainly continue to lose market share to unregulated, over-the-counter traders. **********''We've put in place all the right building blocks with the new floor,'' claims J. Donald Karmazin, senior vice president of technology at the Board of Trade. **********Indeed, the new floor is designed to support the simultaneous use of 20,000 electronic devices, including 12,000 computers, 6,000 wired or wireless phones, and 2,000 video devices. Some 27,000 miles of cable on a service floor underneath the trading floor give member firms the flexibility to organize their voice and data equipment into local networks -- and reorganize them on the fly -- without venturing on to the crowded trading floor. **********For now, though, the only activity close to the long-range technology goal is a pilot project for one firm, a subsidiary of Timber Hill Group of Valhalla, N.Y., to trade extremely small lots of Treasury bond futures with an entirely electronic system that numerous other exchanges and the Commodity Futures Trading Commission have already approved. **********And only 14 firms will be initially putting clerks in the pits with devices that receive orders electronically, eliminating the pit brokers' reliance on hand signals from booths or paper slips that are now brought in by runners. Just 50 have signed up for wireless headsets although the new room is set up to handle hundreds of calls simultaneously. **********Suspicion that technology will cause more harm than good remains rampant. Other exchanges use video cameras to allow traders to see what is going on in other pits and provide the equivalent of instant replay footage in football games to settle disputes about whether a trade was really completed and who the parties were. The danger of such misunderstandings could be much greater in the new room, where pits are as much as 41 feet across, bigger than any the traders are used to. **********But fears that such cameras will become an abused instrument of surveillance for government regulators has led the Board of Trade to severely restrict their use.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/16/busin.snippet: Reed E Hundt, departing chairman of Federal Communications Commission, has failed in last effort to schedule new auctions for wireless communications licenses that are held by companies in danger of defaulting on more than $10 billion in payments;...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/16/busin.main_headline: Latest Effort to Schedule New Auctions for Wireless Licenses Fails
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/16/busin.print_headline: Latest Effort to Schedule New Auctions for Wireless Licenses Fails
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/16/busin.body_text: **********The departing chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, Reed E. Hundt, has failed in a last effort to schedule new auctions for wireless communications licenses that are held by companies in danger of defaulting on more than $10 billion in payments. **********Mr. Hundt spent the last two weeks trying to persuade his fellow commissioners to allow these companies to give back their licenses and participate in a new round of auctions without paying a heavy financial penalty. But the other three commissioners -- Susan Ness, James H. Quello and Rachelle B. Chong -- support an alternative proposal that would force the companies to forfeit millions of dollars. **********With his tenure as F.C.C. chairman likely to end next month, Mr. Hundt said yesterday that the commission would not be able to devise a solution before Congress appoints a new chairman and three commissioners. ''All this commission can do now is to bless a proposal, and that's a shame,'' he said in a telephone interview. **********The mounting financial troubles of the auctions have vexed the F.C.C. for more than a year. And Mr. Hundt's inability to solve the problem adds a sour note to the end of his otherwise productive term. Now, it is up to Mr. Hundt's nominated successor, William E. Kennard, to deal with these companies, which are tottering on the brink of insolvency. **********''You've got a three-way tug-of-war, and every solution leaves one party unhappy,'' said John Bensche, an analyst at Lehman Brothers who has advised the F.C.C. on how to deal with the troubled companies. **********The seeds of this impasse were planted in early 1996, when the F.C.C. auctioned off a swath of licenses for a new type of cellular service, called Personal Communications Services, or P.C.S. Although the licenses were reserved for small  entrepreneurial companies, they fetched huge prices, raising $10.1 billion for the Treasury. **********But the large numbers proved too good to be true. The winners of the P.C.S. licenses ran into financial trouble almost immediately, as the stock market turned hostile to wireless companies of all kinds. Last March, one of the largest bidders, Pocket Communications, filed for bankruptcy protection. And with several others threatening to do the same, the F.C.C. temporarily stopped collecting payments on the licenses. **********Since then, Mr. Hundt has been enmeshed in a tug-of-war with his three fellow commissioners about how to treat the license holders. He says the Government should forgive the bidders some of their debt to free up the licenses, so they can be reauctioned. Mr. Hundt's fear is that if the companies all filed for Chapter 11 protection, it would tie up the licenses for years -- depriving the F.C.C. of any revenue and consumers of new competitors in cellular service. **********''Bankruptcy litigation is the communications equivalent of a land war in Asia,'' said Mr. Hundt, who noted that he was familiar with bankruptcy law from his days as a corporate lawyer. **********But the other commissioners, led by Ms. Ness, contend that if the companies are absolved, it would corrupt the auction process and discourage other bidders from entering future auctions. Ms. Ness, along with Mr. Quello and Ms. Chong, have developed a plan that would relieve the bidders of some obligations, but would be far stricter than Mr. Hundt's approach. **********''To the extent that the F.C.C. disrupts the market, we are doing a disservice to people who believe in auctions,'' said Ms. Ness, who added that she is a former banker. **********Ms. Ness has softened her position in recent weeks. She said she would now be willing to allow companies to return half their licenses; in return, their debt would be halved. But she is adamant that the companies would have to forfeit their entire upfront deposit. **********Mr. Hundt said companies that returned half their licenses should be forgiven half their deposits. He also circulated a proposal under which a company would give back all its licenses, and would then receive a credit equal to half its initial deposit. The company could use its credit to bid in a reauction of those same licenses. **********For her part, Ms. Ness said such an arrangement would give an unfair advantage to existing license holders in a later auction. **********Whatever plan the F.C.C. adopts, the question is whether the companies or their creditors would return the licenses to the F.C.C. without any inducements. The F.C.C.'s negotiation with one bankrupt carrier, Pocket, suggests that the companies may play hard ball. **********Executives close to the company said the commission had offered Pocket a deal in which it would return all its licenses and be excused from its $1.3 billion in debt payments. But the company would forfeit its $130 million deposit. Alternatively, Pocket could return half the licenses and its debt would be cut in half. Lawyers for Pocket recently rejected the F.C.C. offer as unacceptable, according to these executives. **********But officials at the F.C.C. who are sympathetic to Ms. Ness said Mr. Hundt only offered that proposal after submitting an earlier plan that was far more generous to Pocket -- effectively dooming the later proposal. A spokesman for Pocket said the company would not comment. **********These F.C.C. officials, who declined to be identified, said Mr. Hundt was being obdurate in his refusal to compromise with his colleagues. They said he would rather put off the entire auction issue for the next F.C.C. than accept a plan other than his own. **********Mr. Hundt, meanwhile, tried to sound a collegial note. He said that the commissioners were far closer to agreement than they had been earlier this year. Among other things, all four commissioners now agree that the F.C.C. should not resume collecting payments until next March, giving the companies time to raise fresh capital. **********But time is not on Mr. Hundt's side. President Clinton nominated Gloria Tristani, a utility regulator from New Mexico, yesterday as his final nominee to the F.C.C. That opens the door to Congressional hearings on all four F.C.C. nominees, including Mr. Kennard. **********Barring any further hitches, Mr. Hundt may have to relinquish his office as soon as Oct. 3 -- leaving the thorny matter of debt-laden wireless companies for Mr. Kennard and his new colleagues to settle.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/23/busin.snippet: China's newly elevated economic chief, Zhu Rongji, says he plans to move cautiously in opening nation's markets and exposing its state-owned enterprises to foreign competition; Zhu also declares that it is 'unreasonable to exlude China from WTO,' ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/23/busin.main_headline: New Economic Chief Sees Slow March to Open China Markets
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/23/busin.print_headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; New Economic Chief Sees Slow March to Open China Markets
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/23/busin.body_text: **********China's newly elevated economic chief, Zhu Rongji, said today that he planned to move cautiously in opening the nation's markets and exposing its sclerotic state-owned enterprises to foreign competition. **********But Mr. Zhu, in his first public comments since becoming one of the country's three top leaders last week, also declared that it was ''unreasonable to exclude China from the W.T.O.,'' a reference to the continued insistence by the United States that China agree to a rigorous timetable for liberalizing its economy before it can join the World Trade Organization. **********The Clinton Administration, officials in Washington say, is under growing pressure to relax some of those requirements before President Jiang Zemin makes a state visit to Washington late next month. Later this week, Secretary of the Treasury Robert E. Rubin will spend two days in Beijing to set the stage for that meeting. **********While Mr. Zhu doled out morsels to a hungry audience of bankers and investors here today -- about new tax policies, protecting China's currency and finding work for millions of laborers whose jobs are threatened by privatization plans -- what he said was nearly overshadowed by how he said it. He joked easily, answered questions right from the floor, and made no effort to minimize the problems of China's deeply troubled banking system. **********''It wasn't exactly Oprah,'' a senior American official said afterward, ''but it wasn't the China we are used to seeing.'' **********On a key question many in the audience wanted answered -- how, exactly, China plans to transfer ownership of industries from the Government to some form of shareholding without casting millions of workers into the streets -- Mr. Zhu bobbed and weaved. But that was expected, mainly because he is considered the likely successor to Prime Minister Li Peng next spring. He has nothing to gain by further angering local officials who already view him as the architect of the downsizing process sweeping through China's resolutely noncorporate factories. **********For the Clinton Administration, perhaps the stickiest issue Mr. Zhu raised today was Chinese membership in the trade organization, a group of nearly 130 nations pledged to lower tariffs on imported goods and a regimen of steady economic liberalization. Two years ago, the Administration sent China a road map of changes it would have to make before it qualified, including a rapid end to subsidies of state enterprises. While some progress has been made in negotiations, officials fear there has not been enough for Mr. Clinton to declare at the talks next month that China is well on its way to membership. **********''This problem will be solved eventually,'' Mr. Zhu said with a broad smile today. ''It is unreasonable to make such demands on China, which is still a developing economy.'' **********There are some hints that the United States may soon back away from its hard-line stance, showing flexibility over the amount of time China will be allowed before it must comply with the rules. Japan has said it is ready to let China into the organization, which also acts as a court of world trading rules. Mr. Rubin is expected to talk about the issue when he meets Mr. Zhu and President Jiang at the end of the week. **********There were also hints today that China has been alarmed by the speed with which its Southeast Asian nations fell into a contagious currency crisis in recent weeks. Mr. Zhu said he had been advised to take his time before allowing investors to freely move capital of all kinds across Chinese borders. **********The Government-controlled China Daily said today that Liu Jibin, vice minister of finance, was backing away from any quick move to make the Chinese currency fully convertible into dollars, and vice versa. Mr. Liu was quoted as saying that the Southeast Asia crisis had sent ''a warning signal'' to other developing nations about the dangers of surrendering control of the currency to speculators and investors. **********Unlike the smaller Southeast Asians, though, China is coming to the markets well armed. Mr. Zhu disclosed today that foreign exchange reserves now stand at $131.6 billion, one of the highest levels in the world. They are so high, in fact, that officials traveling with Mr. Rubin say they believe the decision to keep that war chest securely in the bank may be unwise when the money could go toward buying power plants and other equipment that could help modernize industries that have changed little since Mao Zedong's death in the mid-70's. **********But over the long haul, Mr. Zhu declared today, Washington will get what it seeks: a far more transparent financial system. **********''To step up the reform of the financial system,'' he said, ''China will strengthen the currency-regulation function of the central bank and the financial supervisory systems, and promote the commercialization of state-owned banks.'' It is unclear, however, how he will dispose of huge loans that the banks made for political reasons rather than on the basis of credit-worthiness to failing state industries. **********''China will also improve the capital structure and quality of the commercial banks,'' he concluded, ''vigorously but steadily develop and regulate the financial market, improve and enact financial laws and regulations, and learn modern financial-management expertise.'' **********Already, Chinese leaders have found something in common with President Clinton that they can talk about next month: They have all been surprised that revenue has flowed into Government coffers faster than anyone expected. **********As a result, Mr. Zhu said, China would restore a series of tax exemptions for foreign technology and other goods that was revoked last year. **********''We will resume our policy of tax exemptions as early as possible,'' he said, leading some in the audience to speculate that in recent months the country had grown worried that American and Japanese companies were slowing their direct investments. Nonetheless, Motorola and General Motors, among others, are planning investments that could run into the hundreds of millions of dollars, and tax incentives might help close the deals.                     --------------------        I.M.F. to Raise Assessments **********By Bloomberg News **********The International Monetary Fund plans to increase its members' contributions by 45 percent, to the equivalent of $285 billion, reflecting the increased size of the global economy. **********In a statement, the I.M.F. said on Saturday that its executive board had agreed to recommend that the amount of money members add to the fund be increased by the equivalent of $88.4 billion. **********The contributions, called quotas, determine the amount that a country can borrow from the fund as well as its voting power within the 181-member organization. **********The increase comes as the fund is warning private lenders that they may have to share more of the pain in future bailouts like those engineered for Thailand and Mexico. **********The United States is the biggest contributor, providing more than 18 percent of contributions, or $36.1 billion. This is to drop under the new formula to 17.73 percent, and the Administration is expected to ask Congress for a further $14.45 billion.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/05/busin.snippet: Thailand's economic ministers approve details of multibillion-dollar international rescue accord with International Monetary Fund; some members of six-party governing coalition continue to resist reforms demanded by IMF; Prime Min Chavalit Yongcha...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/05/busin.main_headline: Thais Back I.M.F. Plan; Won't Ask Immediate Loans
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/05/busin.print_headline: Thais Back I.M.F. Plan; Won't Ask Immediate Loans
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/05/busin.body_text: **********Thailand moved closer to the completion of a multibillion-dollar international rescue package today as economic ministers approved details of an agreement with the International Monetary Fund. **********The I.M.F. is expected to provide a multibillion-dollar credit line to Thailand, although an aide to Prime Minister Chavalit Yongchaiyudh said there were no plans to draw on the credit immediately. Instead, he said, the loan authority would ''provide a cushion to our foreign reserves.'' **********In return for the aid, the Government is likely to raise taxes and reduce spending. Some members of the fractious six-party governing coalition were resisting those steps; the entire 49-member Cabinet is to consider the package on Tuesday. The measures ''will cause some negative or painful impact for the public, but investors should be able to understand,'' Chaiyawat Wibulsawadi, the central bank governor, said. **********The Government sought help from the I.M.F. a week ago. Thailand, reeling from the effective devaluation of its currency, the baht, and from a debt-plagued financial system, is struggling to turn around a once-thriving economy that is growing at its slowest pace in 11 years. **********A Government spokesman said the agreement with the I.M.F. would focus on four areas: supervision of financial institutions, public spending, currency policy and fiscal controls. The specifics are to be announced on Tuesday. **********Kenneth S. Courtis, chief economist in Asia for Deutsche Bank, said that Thailand needed at least $20 billion to bail out its financial industry and bolster the economy. **********In addition to the I.M.F., Japanese commercial banks are expected to participate in the bailout. They account for about 60 percent of the $60 billion in Thai private debt owed to foreign institutions. **********The Japanese daily Nihon Keizai Shimbun reported on Sunday that the I.M.F. package would include a $4 billion emergency loan and that the Export-Import Bank of Japan was ready to lend the same amount. **********Japan's vice finance minister, Takeshi Komura, said in Tokyo today that Thailand had not officially sought Japanese help but that Japan was ready to provide financial assistance, if necessary. **********Mr. Chaiyawat, the Thai central banker, said the Government was negotiating with ''quite a few countries'' for aid.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/05/busin.main_headline: Internet Profiles To Acquire a Rival
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/05/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; Internet Profiles To Acquire a Rival
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/05/busin.body_text: **********There was a significant consolidation in the field of Internet audience measurement yesterday as the Internet Profiles Corporation in Redwood City, Calif., said that it had agreed to acquire the technology and other assets of a rival, Netcount L.L.C. in Los Angeles. Terms were not disclosed. **********Internet Profiles, known as I/PRO, will purchase the products and intellectual property of Netcount and offer its services to Netcount customers. I/PRO and Netcount are now used to track visitors to more than 400 World Wide Web sites that I/ PRO executives estimated account for more than 70 percent of advertising spending on the Web. **********The deal calls for Netcount employees to help I/PRO in converting Netcount customers to I/PRO products and services; Netcount is expected to end operations on Monday. **********Plans call for the agreement, subject to the approval of the boards of both companies, to be completed by mid-December. I/PRO customers include AT&T Worldnet and NBC. Netcount customers include Hollywood Online, NBC and Warner Brothers.

BellSouth, a telecommunications company based in Atlanta, said it expected to post an extraordinary gain in the third quarter, ending on Sept. 30, as a result of the Optus sale. It also said Cable and Wireless would transfer to BellSouth its 22.3 percent interest in the Colombian cellular company Occidente y Caribe Celular S.A. https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/10/busin.snippet: Article on new Federal tax bill focuses on new options for retirement plans, specifically Individual Retirement Accounts, 401(k) plans and new Roth Individual Retirement Account; graph (L)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/10/busin.main_headline: Expanded Options for Salting Away Money to Retire
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/10/busin.print_headline: Expanded Options for Salting Away Money to Retire
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/10/busin.body_text: **********For all Washington's celebratory mood over the nation's first major tax cut in 16 years, Congress and the Clinton Administration hardly issued an open invitation to the party. Rather than an across-the-board tax cut, the $96 billion package is a series of narrowly focused measures intended to achieve specific goals. How much you benefit depends on your personal circumstances. Here is a guide to achieving key financial objectives under the new rules. **********THE new and expanded retirement-savings accounts created by Congress and the Clinton Administration will no doubt provide an impetus for more people to salt away more money. But the new choices  of savings vehicles will also force many people to make complex decisions about how to allocate money among existing programs like 401(k)'s and the new options, as well as to factor in changes like the reduction in capital gains taxes. **********''The real benefit of the tax bill for people who qualify is that there are now a bunch of options that will point people in the direction of saving for retirement and starting early,'' said John H. Gardner, a senior manager in the Washington national tax office of KPMG Peat Marwick, the accounting firm. **********The tax bill expanded the traditional Individual Retirement Account in several ways, including raising the income limits restricting eligibility for making tax-deductible contributions and allowing penalty-free withdrawals for some college expenses and for up to $10,000 to buy a first home. **********But the most far-reaching change was the creation of a new retirement account, named the Roth I.R.A. after its principal sponsor, Senator William V. Roth Jr., Republican of Delaware. The new I.R.A. is likely to prove a big hit with people whose income has been too high to qualify for traditional I.R.A.'s, as well as with banks and brokerage firms, which are feverishly developing plans to sell a variety of Roth I.R.A. investment alternatives. **********Under the Roth I.R.A., contributions are not tax deductible. But income accumulates in the account tax free, and as long as the account has been open for five years and the proceeds are used after age 59 1/2 or for certain other purposes, distributions from the account are tax free. The tax-advantaged contributions to the Roth I.R.A. are limited to $2,000 a year, the same limit applying to tax-deductible I.R.A.'s. **********Many people will not have a choice between the Roth I.R.A. and the traditional tax-deductible I.R.A. Although the income limits for the traditional I.R.A. will double over the next decade, to $80,000 in modified adjusted gross income (generally total income minus income adjustments other than IRA deductions) for joint filers and to $50,000 for single filers, the limits will leave many of the people who have the most money available for retirement savings ineligible. The income limits for the Roth I.R.A. are much higher, at $150,000 in modified adjusted gross income for couples filing jointly and $95,000 for single filers. **********For those eligible for both types of I.R.A., the choice between the two s hinges largely on whether they think their income tax rate will be substantially lower when they use the money. **********Deloitte & Touche, the accounting firm, calculated that the Roth I.R.A. was slightly more profitable for the person whose tax rate would be the same at the time of both contribution and withdrawal. But, the firm said, for the person whose tax rate would fall between contribution and withdrawal, the traditional I.R.A. would be more profitable, although only if the person invested rather than spent the tax savings in the first year. **********People with existing I.R.A.'s will have another tough decision to make: whether to convert them into Roth I.R.A.'s. The law permits such rollovers for people with income of $100,000 or less. But such a conversion would require paying taxes at ordinary rates on the withdrawals from the existing I.R.A. Whether the long-term benefits of a rollover would outweigh the immediate tax bill would depend on several factors, but financial advisers said rollovers would be most attractive to people who expect to remain in high income-tax brackets after retirement, since proceeds from the Roth account could be withdrawn tax free. **********Financial advisers said people who are eligible for 401(k) programs in which the employer matches part of the contributions would probably find the 401(k) still the best retirement savings vehicle. But the calculation would become more complicated if there is no employer match, a calculation based on a person's expected income tax rate when withdrawals are made from the I.R.A., and on the investment's rate of return and other factors. **********For people who still have money for retirement savings after their maximum 401(k) contribution, the Roth I.R.A. would almost certainly be best. **********The reduction in the capital gains tax should also lead people who are saving for retirement through variable annuities to take another look at their strategy. **********Annuities are essentially mutual funds in which profits accumulate tax-deferred until withdrawal, when they are subject to ordinary income-tax rates. Because much of any long-term profit on mutual fund investments will be subject to lower capital gains rates, annuities will become less attractive to some investors. But others will continue to find annuities preferable, because they often entail less risk than mutual funds.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/27/world.snippet: Environmental battle rages over development of Cardwell, fishing village on Australia's Queensland coastal wilderness; campaign to protect the coast has attracted support because of its proximity to Hinchinbrook Island, world's largest island nati...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/27/world.main_headline: Cardwell Journal; Mammals on This Coast: The Rare Kind, for Now
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/27/world.print_headline: Cardwell Journal; Mammals on This Coast: The Rare Kind, for Now
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/27/world.body_text: **********Margaret Thorsborne cannot forget the two stone-curlews -- their necks outstretched, their wings beating above the pitiless crunch of steel treads -- trying to chase away the bulldozer on the development site along the southern edges of town. **********''Those poor birds,'' said the slight, white-haired Mrs. Thorsborne, the eminence of the movement to preserve the Cardwell shorefront.  ''Their nest had been right there, just below the crest of beach. What a nightmare, this whole dreadful affair.'' **********Just across a channel from a United Nations-designated World Heritage site called Hinchinbrook Island, the Cardwell birds feed among threatened mangroves. The trees form a tangled scrim of tide-washed branches and roots, serving as a nursery for marine flora and fauna. **********That day three years ago, the bulldozer was cutting down some of the mangroves, preparing ground for a $100 million development of waterfront residences, shops, restaurants, a 210-berth marina and a hotel. Yet almost as fast as old mangroves were torn up, Mrs. Thorsborne, a 70-year-old widow, and legions of other conservationists were planting new ones, 12,000 seedlings in all. **********It is a testament to the intrepid trowel brigade, as well as to court challenges and any number of protests and demonstrations, that this development project, which has galvanized environmentalists throughout Australia, has made little progress in three years. **********Scars of the clearing remain. Some roads have been built on the site, dredging has started for the marina and glossy brochures have been printed. But although the developer has poured an estimated $12 million into the project, not one structure has risen and none of the blocks of real estate have been sold. **********The campaign to protect this stretch of Queensland coast from a project that would double the population of Cardwell, a fishing town of 1,200, has attracted support because of its proximity to one of the most environmentally fragile regions anywhere. **********Three miles across the Hinchinbrook Channel from Cardwell is Hinchinbrook Island, the world's largest island national park and a gateway to the Great Barrier Reef, which stretches 1,500 miles along the coast. **********The island, channel and reef are all listed under the World Heritage Convention of the United Nations Education, Scientific and Cultural Organization as worthy of special recognition and protection for the extraordinary diversity of their animal and plant life. **********The curlews may find other beaches. But the marine mammals flourishing around Hinchinbrook Island, and easily visible during one slow boat ride to the island, could be in mortal danger from scores of high-speed craft berthed in a new marina. **********The mammals include bottlenose, humpback and irrawaddy dolphins, and the even rarer dugongs, gentle creatures that hold their suckling young in their flippers and apparently love the taste of the sea grass around the island. **********Prof. Helene Marsh, of the department of tropical environmental studies and geography at James Cook University in Townsville, fears that dugongs will meet the same fate as their cousins, the manatees of Florida. From 1979 to 1991, she counted 628 manatees killed in collisions with boats in Florida waters. **********Professor Marsh estimates that 100 dugongs use Hinchinbrook Channel every year and that the population has remained relatively steady in recent years, although dugong numbers elsewhere along the Great Barrier Reef have declined. ''Even one fatality per year is likely to be unsustainable, on top of other impacts,'' she said. **********Yet Cardwell is sharply divided over the so-called Port Hinchinbrook development project. It is a town with no movie house, no supermarket, no high school and 12 long-vacant shops. Several modest motels, a gas station at either end of the main road and a couple of fish-and-chips establishments are the main features. You can drive through Cardwell in under 90 seconds, and most people do. **********So if tourism, which has brought prosperity to other parts of the Queensland coast, seems to have passed Cardwell by, some powerful figures think it only fair if it now catches up. **********Keith Williams, a colorful Queensland developer who bought the 260-acre site in 1993, has most of the local business officials on his side as well as the town council. **********Mr. Williams's main claim to fame is a Miami Beach-type project on nearby Hamilton Island, with high-rises, a 400-berth marina and an international airport that can handle Boeing 767's. **********Mr. Williams declined to return a phone call, but in press statements he has accused his opponents of using ''scare tactics'' to try to mislead residents about the effects of the development. **********A local real estate agent, Lindsay Hallam, who is seeking to sell 90 Port Hinchinbrook residential lots as well as condominiums and marina berths, is chairman of the Chamber of Commerce's Port Hinchinbrook committee. He says the town has been in decline a long time and ''needs the new facilities to get the jobs'' -- at least 50, he estimates, during the construction phase and 700 permanent jobs once the project is complete. **********In his office recently, Mr. Hallam pulled out charts and brochures and cited scientific evidence to try to lay to rest what he called misrepresentations of the project. **********''Of course we don't want people to destroy the area,'' he said. ''Far from it. If there are environmental problems, we say give us hard evidence. No one has done that.'' **********The rift between supporters and opponents is immediately evident from banners along the residential streets, which create the atmosphere of a political campaign. **********''So Long Dugong'' and ''No to Hinchinbrook Resort No Way'' face off against ''Port Hinchinbrook for Kids and Jobs'' or just ''Yes Yes Yes.'' **********As emotions have risen, so have reports of violence. Several protesters, many from Cairns and Townsville and some from as far away as Sydney, said they had been dragged through the mud and beaten. The police have rarely intervened, they said. So far, however, no one has been seriously injured. **********Mrs. Thorsborne, who lives in an old wooden house in a nearby rain forest surrounded by her beloved creatures, says she has received a telephoned death threat and been spat on in town. **********Another member of Friends of Hinchinbrook, Ken Parker, 38, who has been on disability since an accident at a local prawn farm, says he has received ''four or five telephoned death threats, and been advised to leave the country.'' **********But Mr. Parker, a Scottish-born boat builder and sailor who has lived here for 12 years, laughs off the threats. As his aluminum skiff kept the developers' dredge in the distance, he pointed to a dugong surfacing briefly on the starboard side, a sea turtle to port. **********''This has to be one of the most beautiful places in the world,'' he said. ''I don't think I could ever leave.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/13/busin.snippet: Price-earnings ratio, which compares stock price with company's profits per share, may be most common measure for finding low-priced deals in market; some investors turn to lesser-known instrument: price-sales ratio; this measure compares stock pr...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/13/busin.main_headline: For Stock Values, a Yardstick With a Difference
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/13/busin.print_headline: For Stock Values, a Yardstick With a Difference
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/13/busin.body_text: **********MANY investors treat the stock market like a flea market, poking through overpriced merchandise to find a real bargain. But rather than studying furniture styles or the history of glass making in the search for that low-priced deal, investors use statistical tools. **********The price-earnings ratio, which compares a stock price with the company's profits per share, may be the most common measure. Other bargain hunters look at a stock's price relative to the company's book value per share. **********Some, however, turn to a lesser-known instrument: the price-sales ratio. This measure compares the stock price with the company's sales per share, revealing how many invested dollars are needed to buy one dollar of revenue. At Disney, for example, the price-sales ratio is 2.31, derived by dividing the current share price ($72.375) by the sales per share ($31.38). Sales per share are calculated by dividing total sales ($21.18 billion) by the number of shares outstanding (675 million). **********The average price-sales ratio for the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index is 1.60. Value seekers typically focus on companies with low-priced stocks -- those with a ratio of less than 1. **********Investors who look to the price-sales ratio say it has several advantages. Although sales figures can be manipulated, they are not subject to all the stratagems that companies can use to embellish earnings or distort book value. ''Revenue is one of the things that is least fiddled with,'' said Kenneth L. Fisher, who runs Fisher Investments in Woodside, Calif. **********The price-sales ratio can also be a window on a company's near-term potential. A low price-earnings ratio -- signifying a cheap stock -- can simply mean the company has little revenue, and therefore little profit. Its shareholders are taking a leap of faith that the company can ring the cash register a lot more in the future than it has in the past.  But a low price-sales ratio often applies to a  company that already has significant sales; its costs just eat up much of its profits. In that case, all the company may need is an economizing program that widens the gap between what it takes in and what it keeps. **********''The price-sales ratio captures your imagination,'' said Edward Bousa, portfolio manager of the Putnam Equity Income fund. ''It gives you an idea of what an underperforming company could be worth if it got its margins up.'' **********In ''What Works on Wall Street'' (McGraw-Hill, 1996), James P. O'Shaughnessy, a money manager in Greenwich, Conn., found that from 1952 to 1994 companies with low price-sales ratios often sharply outperformed the market. In one calculation, involving the more than 10,000 companies with at least $150 million in market capitalization, Mr. O'Shaughnessy found that the 50 stocks with the lowest price-sales ratios had an average annual return of 15.42 percent over those 43 years, compared with 12.45 percent for the entire group. **********To study the price-sales ratio, The New York Times asked Compustat, a unit of Standard & Poor's, to rank all the nonfinancial companies in the S.& P. 500 by the measure. **********Of the 432 companies in the survey, which was conducted on Wednesday, Microsoft had the highest price-sales ratio, at 12.5, while the Fleming Companies, one of the nation's largest food wholesalers and distributors, had the lowest ratio, at 0.04. A total of 179 companies might draw the immediate attention of bargain hunters: they all had ratios of less than 1. **********But one of the first lessons of the price-sales ratio, Mr. O'Shaughnessy and others said, is that a low ratio by itself does not necessarily signal a good investment. **********For example, many companies in the survey have low price-sales ratios because they are in inherently low-margin businesses -- discount retailers, say, like Woolworth and Walgreen, which had ratios of 0.37 and 0.84, respectively. (When profit margins are so narrow that only a few cents land on the bottom line, investors pay less for a dollar of sales.) Generally, improving the margins of companies in such industries is not as easy as in other sectors. **********Other enterprises with low price-sales ratios belong to out-of-favor industries like paper and forest products, which are under pressure from lower-cost foreign producers and hurt by the strong dollar, according to Mr. Bousa. This group includes Boise Cascade (0.28), the Mead Corporation (0.59), Union Camp (0.81) and Westvaco (0.89). **********Similarly, according to Standard & Poor's stock reports, Fleming Companies had a rock-bottom price-sales ratio in part because supermarkets are starting to be food distributors themselves. That shift has helped push down the price of Fleming shares from about $30 in September 1995 to $16.25 at Friday's close. **********In other words, a low price-sales ratio is just the beginning. Investors must also scrutinize the company to see if it has the potential to improve its margins. **********In this further inquiry, Mr. O'Shaughnessy looks for companies whose earnings and stock prices have risen in the last year. ''This helps you find cheap companies that are on the rebound,'' he said. **********Such an approach has lead Mr. O'Shaughnessy to Kmart and TJX, retailers with price-sales ratios of 0.19 and 0.51, respectively, in the survey. **********In the early 1990's, Kmart lost market share to competitors like Wal-Mart and Target. In the last year, however, it has been closing underperforming stores, cutting corporate overhead, improving inventory and distribution systems and selling off interests in other retail chains to raise cash and strengthen its balance sheet. **********''The financial issues are almost out of the way, and they may pay off some debt ahead of time,'' Mr. O'Shaughnessy said. **********TJX, the discount-clothing chain that owns T. J. Maxx, is feeling the benefits of its acquisition of Marshalls, another off-price retailer, in late 1995. This has improved  buying power and lowered costs; indeed, the stock price rose from $17 to $47 last year in part because of these prospects. **********Moreover, TJX is far bigger than its largest competitor, according to a report by Jeffrey Feiner, of Salomon Brothers. That makes TJX ''a true emerging category killer,'' Mr. Feiner wrote. He also believes that the stock, despite its 1996 run-up, is cheap, at least when the company's projected earnings are considered. **********MR. BOUSA also seeks companies that have low price-sales ratios and  are cutting costs. He likes Whirlpool, Ryder System and Delta Air Lines. **********Whirlpool, with a ratio of just 0.40 in the Compustat survey, ''looks cheap for a company that is a leader in its business,'' Mr. Bousa said. Profits have been weak in its European divisions, he said, adding that he believes that the company has been ''very busy restructuring there, and we will soon start to see results.'' The company will also soon begin to see a payoff from its Asian investments, he said. **********Ryder, a leader in truck leasing and business shipping, had a price-sales measure of 0.43, but it is economizing, too. Closing less profitable offices and cutting some layers of management will help it save $75 million this year -- 1.6 percent of annual operating expenses -- and the same amount in 1998, Mr. Bousa said. ''At the moment, margins are well below what they should be,'' he said. ''I expect them to increase significantly over the next few years.'' **********Cost-cutting at Delta, the third-largest domestic carrier, is also well under way. Delta has been eliminating unprofitable routes in Europe, where new marketing alliances with Swissair, Sabena and Austrian Airlines may also help earnings. **********Delta, with a 0.51 ratio in the survey, is also trying to contain costs and increase productivity. ''Delta has done a tremendous job of working with a largely nonunion labor force in an industry that tends to be union,'' Mr. Bousa said. Moreover, Delta Express, which offers low-cost flights between the South and the Northeast, has limited inroads from discount carriers like Southwest and Valujet. **********What about high price-sales measures? Like the low ratios, they are just a guide.  Drug companies, for instance, often have wide profit margins. Thus, the Pfizer and Schering-Plough ratios of 4.9 and 4.8 do not  necessarily mean the stocks are pricey. **********But a lofty ratio can be a red flag. Microsoft's ratio of 12.5 is a caution for Richard H. Fontaine, portfolio manager of the Fontaine Capital Appreciation fund. **********''Microsoft is a great company,'' Mr. Fontaine said. ''But it is so big, it can only grow as fast as the industry. The premium the market is asking you to pay grossly overestimates the growth of this company.''
