https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/01/world.snippet: Global warming is re-igniting passions commonplace between India and West during cold war, just as both sides were beginning to put past frictions behind them; Indian environmentalists and politicians have joined chorus of angry denunciations of p...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/01/world.main_headline: GLOBAL WARMING: Around the Globe, Big Worries and Small Signs of Progress; In India, Climate Evokes Old East-West Passions
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/01/world.print_headline: GLOBAL WARMING: Around the Globe, Big Worries and Small Signs of Progress; In India, Climate Evokes Old East-West Passions
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/01/world.body_text: **********JUST as India and the West had begun to put past frictions behind them, global warming has come along to reignite the sort of passions that were commonplace during the cold war, when India's perspectives were those of an ally of the Soviet Union and a founder of what was known as the non-aligned movement, with its fixation on the evils done to developing nations by the rapacious West. **********In the months leading up to the United Nations conference on climate change in Kyoto, Japan, Indian environmentalists and politicians have joined in a chorus of angry denunciations of proposals that Western nations, particularly the United States, have advanced for limiting emissions of so-called greenhouse gases. Phrases like ''environmental colonialism'' and the ''Western rape and pillage of the world's resources'' have  poured forth, along with predictions that Kyoto could forge a new and even deeper split between the richer and poorer nations of the earth. **********At one level, the Indian anger seems curiously misplaced, considering the acknowledged deterioration of India's own environment and the blame that many of these same environmentalists and politicians place on governmental failures at home. If India's environment is visibly among the most polluted anywhere, particularly in terms of air quality in the major cities, it is a problem closely linked to a burgeoning population, now nearly 980 million, that has almost tripled in the 50 years since independence and continues to grow by 20 million every year with scant sign of any government effort to promote birth control. **********As anybody struggling with the choking levels of air pollution in New Delhi, Bombay or Calcutta can attest, India is fighting a losing battle with urban traffic levels that double every five years, Dickensian factories that generally ignore environmental controls and the reliance in heavy industry on heavily sulfurous coal. The situation in New Delhi, the capital, has become so threatening that some Western embassies have begun discouraging the assignment to India of any diplomat or family member with respiratory problems, especially small children. Indian experts have even warned that rising sea levels could cost the country large portions of its 3,000-mile coastline within the next 50 years. **********But when it comes to international efforts to deal with global warming, many of those who will have a decisive voice in India's policies approach the issue as though environmental degradation is mainly the fault of, and a problem for, the industrialized nations of the West. If there were any doubt of the strength of feeling on the matter, it was dispelled when Prime Minister Inder Kumar Gujral attended the meeting in Edinburgh in October of the nations of the Commonwealth and agreed to a closing communique that said, seemingly innocuously, that all countries attending the Kyoto meeting ''will need to play their part in policies that would result in significant reduction of greenhouse gas emissions.'' **********Mr. Gujral was met with a barrage of criticism at home to the effect that he had sold out India and other developing nations with large greenhouse gas emissions, China and Brazil prominent among them. Those nations have said that it is up to the United States and other Western nations to cut back on emissions without imposing similar requirements on poorer countries that are struggling to catch up economically with the West. This position has been squarely rejected by President Clinton, who announced in September that the United States ''will not assume binding obligations unless key developing nations meaningfully participate in the effort.'' **********Indians marshal numerous arguments against their country's accepting any mandatory emissions controls. Many are rooted in political arguments that depict the ''one-worldism'' of Western environmentalists as a mask for efforts to shackle the economic development of poorer nations just as they show signs of beginning to claim a greater share of the world's wealth. **********Even among Indian environmentalists who accept the need for limits, there is a common political premise: that whatever environmental regime emerges from Kyoto should be based on ''per capita entitlements'' to pollute the atmosphere, an approach that would ultimately allow India and China, with nearly two-fifths of the world's population, to pump more carbon dioxide and methane into the atmosphere than the United States, Canada and all the nations of the European Union combined.   JOHN F. BURNS

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/02/busin.snippet: Big Car rental companies, including Hertz and Avis, have stopped letting people rent cars using just Visa Check card or similar Master Money card from Mastercard; card companies, and banks that issue these debit cards are furious; car rental compa...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/02/busin.main_headline: Not All Plastic Is Created Equal When It Comes to Renting a Car
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/02/busin.print_headline: Not All Plastic Is Created Equal When It Comes to Renting a Car
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/02/busin.body_text: **********Remember that heartwarming commercial that ran during the Super Bowl in which Bob Dole could not buy lunch with a check at a diner in his Kansas hometown but could with his Visa debit card? Well, if Mr. Dole had tried to rent a car with that card, he would have gone nowhere. **********The big car rental companies, including Hertz and Avis, have recently stopped letting people rent cars using just a Visa Check card or the similar Master Money card from Mastercard. The card companies, and the banks that issue these cards -- known as debit cards -- are furious. And so are some customers. **********For years, the car rental companies have used possession of a credit card as a crude way to weed out potentially risky renters, just as they have usually ruled out renters under the age of 25. **********But this test does not work with debit cards, because banks will now give them to nearly anyone with a bank account. Charges on debit cards, which go under many names, come directly out of a customer's checking account almost immediately rather than appearing on a monthly credit card statement. And in contrast to using a credit card, which the debit cards physically resemble, no loan is involved in the transaction. **********Debit cards ''provide no qualification of creditworthiness,'' Lisa LoManto, a Hertz spokeswoman, said. ''Hertz is entitled to a certain level of confidence because in car rental, unlike almost any other business, the customer is given total control of a vehicle with an approximate value of $20,000.'' **********There are now more than 60 million Visa and Mastercard debit cards in use. They differ from the debit cards that are linked to automated teller machine networks like NYCE or MAC because their use at a retailer requires a signature rather than keying in a personal identification number. **********As these debit cards become increasingly popular, strains are appearing among customers, merchants and banks. The problems range from difficulties when the cards are lost or stolen to complaints from merchants -- including the nation's biggest retailer, Wal-Mart -- that the fees to accept these cards are too high. The new car rental rules represent the first case in which debit cards cannot be used in the same way as credit cards. **********Jack T. Kelly, owner of Pied Piper Real Estate in Provincetown, Mass., gave up all of his credit cards because he liked using his Master Money card instead. But he found himself potentially stranded when Hertz told him it would not accept his card to reserve a car for a coming vacation in Palm Springs, Calif. **********''They say that this card is usable anywhere a Mastercard is, and it certainly is not,'' he said in a telephone interview, fuming that the $23,900 balance in his checking account did not get Hertz, a unit of the Ford Motor Company, to change its policy. ''There are a lot of people like me who have done away with their credit cards and now are stuck.'' **********The rental car companies are requiring a customer with only a debit card to follow the same procedures as someone who pays cash. That involves making an application several weeks in advance and leaving a substantial deposit. **********Consumer advocates, who have battled the rental companies with accusations that they practice racial and age discrimination in renting and charge unjustifiably high insurance rates, said the new debit card rule might well be reasonable. **********''If we argue the car rental companies are responsible for any damage over $100 and that they can't discriminate on race or age,'' said Blair Horner, legislative director for the New York Public Interest Research Group in Albany, ''they should be able to make renters meet other tests. People who don't have a credit card should be able to rent a car, but they may have to go through a 30-day credit check.'' **********The card companies are split over how hard to defend their longstanding policy that credit and debit cards should be treated interchangeably. **********Stacey A. Pinkerd, the product manager for Visa's check card, said Visa ''reluctantly'' went along with the change. ''The car rental industry is unique because they are letting a customer drive their assets off the lot,'' he said. **********Mr. Pinkerd said Visa did insist that a customer be allowed to switch the rental payment to a debit card when the car is returned, even though a credit card had to be used to obtain the car. And he said Visa is working to find another way for car rental companies to screen debit card users. **********Mastercard, unlike Visa, says it intends to fight for equal treatment of debit cards. **********As for the banks that issue debit cards, they are upset that their debit card customers are being treated differently. ''We have received customer complaints about their inability to use a debit card to rent a car,'' said Richard Comandich, senior vice president of U.S. Bank in Portland, Ore. ''We hope Visa looks at the issue closely.'' **********Other bankers, speaking on the condition of anonymity, are much harsher. ''Visa has compromised the brand,'' one bank executive said. **********In 1996, there were 1.6 billion transactions on Mastercard and Visa debit cards in the United States, an increase of 95 percent from the year before. By contrast, there were 1.1 billion debit transactions linked to A.T.M. networks, up 32 percent, according to Bank Network News, a Chicago newsletter. **********The new debit cards have become more popular because they are easier to use and more widely accepted than those that require personal identification numbers. Moreover, for the tens of millions of Americans who do not qualify for a credit card, the cards are their first opportunity to put something with a Mastercard or Visa label in their wallets. Until recently, the cards also provided the easiest way for such individuals, many of whom have had financial troubles, to rent a car or buy merchandise over the phone. **********Banks like the debit cards because transactions on them are less costly to process than paper checks. Also, some banks charge customers a fee for the cards. And for the Mastercard and Visa versions, banks receive a fee from merchants of about 1 percent of the purchase price. **********Retailers, though, have become increasingly unhappy about the growth of these debit cards, precisely because they do not want to pay the fee. **********In October, Wal-Mart and the Limited sued Visa over its rule that forces merchants to take the debit cards if they also accept Visa credit cards. In February, the National Retail Federation joined the suit and added Mastercard as a defendant. **********What especially galls the retailers is that for them the Visa and Mastercard debit cards are a lot more costly than the older A.T.M. network debit cards, which charge only a few pennies per transaction. **********Confusingly, a single card can have both a Visa or Mastercard logo and the mark of an automated teller machine network like NYCE or MAC. If a signature is required, rather than a personal identification number, the fee paid by the merchant is higher. The credit card companies say the higher fee reflects a greater risk. Even though both types of transactions involve electronic verification of the money in the consumer's checking account, the card companies say their experience has been that signature transactions, which are processed more slowly, result in more overdrafts. **********For consumers the debit cards also carry a little more risk. If the card is stolen, a thief can go on a spending spree with the money in a customer's checking account. Federal law limits liability to $50 if the cardholder notifies the bank within two days of discovering a missing card. But the bank has up to 20 days to put the money back into the checking account. **********For Jack Kelly, the real estate agent who was not able to rent from Hertz, debit cards are losing their appeal. ''I was able to rent a car from Budget, but I don't think that will last,'' he said. ''If this doesn't change, I'll go back to using American Express.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/14/busin.snippet: Mazda Motor Corp says Henry D G Wallace, first foreigner to head a Japanese company, is retiring as president; James E Miller, Mazda executive vice president, will replace Wallace, whose contract is scheduled to expire in June; Miller, an American...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/14/busin.main_headline: First Foreigner to Lead Japanese Company Retires
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/14/busin.print_headline: First Foreigner to Lead Japanese Company Retires
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/14/busin.body_text: **********The Mazda Motors Corporation said today that Henry D. G. Wallace, the first gaijin, or foreigner, to head a Japanese company, was retiring. **********The departure of Mr. Wallace, who was Mazda's president, comes just a little more than a year after he was appointed to lead the ailing car manufacturer through a corporate overhaul. **********James E. Miller, 50, a Mazda executive vice president, will replace Mr. Wallace, whose contract was scheduled to expire in June. Mr. Miller, an American who has been groomed for the top spot at Mazda, is a former marketing executive at the Ford Motor Company, which owns 33.4 percent of Mazda. **********The resignation of Mr. Wallace comes after recent speculation, which Mazda did not deny, that he would be leaving. At the Tokyo Motor Show last month, there was talk that Mr. Wallace might leave because his wife was unhappy living in Hiroshima, where Mazda is based. **********Kaoru Kurata, the automotive industry analyst at Goldman, Sachs Japan, said, ''I'm slightly surprised, but we analysts have been assuming he would leave the company at the end of the year or early next year.'' **********The company was scheduled to release its six-month interim financial report today. Analysts expect Mazda to report 10 billion yen, or $80 million, in net losses for the first six months of the current fiscal year.  But they are confident that Mr. Wallace has engineered a turnaround that will start showing up in next year's numbers. He has streamlined management practices, forbidding senior managers from bringing support staff members to meetings and  establishing a promotional track based on merit rather than seniority. **********He also cut costs without layoffs and strengthened the company's ties to Ford. The companies have aligned their production cycles and will be sharing vehicle platforms and power trains. **********In Japan, where auto sales were down 9.6 percent in the first half of this year, Mazda was the only car maker whose sales did not shrink, said Edward Brogan, an automotive analyst at Salomon Brothers. The company introduced a small mini-van, the Demio, which was aggressively priced but profitable because it sold well. **********''They were surprised by its success,'' Mr. Brogan said. ''It was originally designed to draw people into the showroom.'' **********Though sales have improved in Europe, Mazda's sales in the United States, however, continue to lag, and the company has had to cut back on research and development and capital expenditures while getting its house back in order. **********Mazda's ads in Japan, featuring Mr. Wallace, a 6-foot-2-inch Scotsman speaking halting Japanese, are popular. **********''Using him as the face of the company has probably strategically been an error, given that he never said he was going to stay here forever,'' Mr. Brogan said. ''But the company did need some kind of face, and his was a good one.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/10/busin.snippet: Overnight shipping firms are offering tracking, other functions to customers using their World Wide Web sites; drawing; list (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/10/busin.body_text: **********''Point, click, ship.'' That mantra from a Federal Express Corporation advertising campaign sums up the ambitions the overnight shipping industry has for computer technology. Express companies compete with each other and the United States Postal Service not only on speed, price and reliability, but also on convenience and ease of use, and that is where computers come in. **********The World Wide Web is one of three main avenues for computerized service, providing basic information and performing a few useful tasks, primarily for occasional customers. For high-volume shippers, many of the big express companies supply special software to speed the flow of overnight letters and rush parcels. And the freight specialists offer ''logistics solutions'' to businesses, combining automated record-keeping with other services like handling of customs formalities. **********The most widespread function is tracking. Enter a shipping order number, and in some cases one more piece of data like the country of origin, into a screen form, and the site reports whether the parcel has been delivered, along with when, where and to whom. All the companies listed except TNT Worldwide Express, a subsidiary of TNT Ltd. of Australia, offer tracking through Web sites; Federal Express also offers tracking by return E-mail. **********Most of the sites offer a directory function that will provide the address, phone number and business hours of the company office nearest a given ZIP code in the United States. United Parcel Service also includes its drop boxes in office buildings and industrial parks, and gives the latest pickup times for each; Federal Express includes drop boxes and retail stores that accept packages for it. **********Looking up any of the companies' offices overseas is usually a less friendly process. DHL Worldwide Express, like some others, lets youchoose the desired continent by clicking on a map. After that, it usually is a matter of manually scrolling through lists of countries, and then cities in the country, though some sites will search for a specified city. The Fedex site seems at first glance to offer extensive information about each country it serves, but on closer inspection almost all of it turns out to be generic, with little other than contact numbers changing by country. **********Another common feature of all the express company sites is a big helping of the sort of public relations boilerplate that most corporate sites offer: company histories and mission statements, news releases and annual reports -- of interest to a potential employee or stockholder but little use to a customer. **********Special features make a few of the express company sites stand out. **********If you already have a Federal Express account number, you can generate a completed shipping order on your laser printer. (You still need a Federal Express shipping envelope, but you can order a supply on line; several other sites will also take orders for shipping supplies.) **********United Parcel Service has a rate calculator for shipments originating in the contiguous 48 states, and an E-mail-like way to request a pickup, handy for users whose Web surfing ties up their only phone line. **********Emery Worldwide, a unit of Consolidated Freightways Inc. that specializes in air freight and business parcels exceeding five pounds, allows tracking searches not just by shipping order number but also by the shipping or receiving customer's own package reference number. **********Another freight specialist, Burlington Air Express, a subsidiary of the Pittston Company, offers on its site both rate and time calculators. Type in ZIP codes for an origin and destination and the site will respond with the earliest day and time the company can promise delivery. **********In its own fashion, the Postal Service is also on the Web. Overnight letters are a sideline business for the ''snail mail'' people, but they can be tracked on line just as their commercial competitors can be. There is a comprehensive postage calculator in the site, but it requires a cumbersome march through as many as five linked pages to arrive at an answer; tables of postal rates are also available. And post office addresses can be looked up for any ZIP code. **********The rest of the service's huge site is devoted to reams of material on postal policies and regulations, contract bidding and procurement, stamp collecting, address changes, missing money orders, shipping supplies and passport applications, as well as miscellaneous red tape.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/19/world.snippet: Prime Min Necmettin Erbakan, first head of Islamic party to lead Turkey, yields to pressure from military and resigns on June 18 after nearly a year in power; asks Pres Suleyman Demirel to keep his coalition in power by naming Foreign Min Tansu Ci...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/19/world.main_headline: Pro-Islamic Premier Steps Down In Turkey Under Army Pressure
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/19/world.print_headline: Pro-Islamic Premier Steps Down In Turkey Under Army Pressure
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/19/world.body_text: **********Prime Minister Necmettin Erbakan, the first head of an Islamic party to lead Turkey, yielded to pressure from the military and resigned today after nearly a year in power. **********''I resigned because I am a true patriot,'' Mr. Erbakan said after a 45-minute meeting with President Suleyman Demirel. He asked the President to keep his coalition in power by naming his junior partner, Tansu Ciller, the secular Foreign Minister, as his successor. **********President Demirel made no statement, however, and aides said he would begin consultations with party leaders on Thursday. **********Mr. Erbakan, who will remain in office until his successor is sworn in, had been subjected to a sustained political assault by senior generals who complained that he was undermining the secular basis of Turkey's modern republic and its pro-Western stance in foreign and military affairs. **********In the year that Mr. Erbakan held office, the generals objected to overtures he made toward Iran and Libya, repeatedly took military initiatives without consulting him, and recently expressed fury at his refusal to curb religious academies and private Koran schools. **********The generals' political intervention never went beyond strong public statements. But the statements had escalated to the point that they seemed to imply the threat of direct action against Mr. Erbakan's Government. On three occasions since 1960, Turkey's military has staged coups after losing patience with civilian governments. **********The generals' campaign against Mr. Erbakan provided Turks with the spectacle of a powerful institution claiming to be so committed to defending democracy that it uses means that in many countries would be considered undemocratic. **********In fact, some critical commentators called the tactics a ''soft coup.'' But one secular leader, Denis Baykal of the Republican People's Party, said the military had played the role of a ''democratic pressure group.'' **********''We cannot ignore the fact that the army has contributed to this development,'' Mr. Baykal said. ''The thorn that dug itself into the foot of the democratic regime has been plucked out.'' **********Whoever President Demirel, the country's elder statesman, chooses as Prime Minister must put together a government that can win support from a majority of the 550 members of Parliament. With major parties suffering defections and party leaders offering various inducements to wavering members, it is highly uncertain that either Mrs. Ciller or the main opposition leader, Mesut Yilmaz, could succeed. **********President Demirel's other alternative is to name a caretaker government that would lead the country to elections within 90 days. **********Despite his resignation today, Mr. Erbakan, a veteran of three decades in Turkish politics, remains popular and has shown no intention of leaving the political stage. On the contrary, he said earlier this week that he would step down only as a way to reinforce his mandate through new elections. He likened such a maneuver to ''an airplane being refueled while it is flying.'' **********It is not clear when elections might be called, but aides to Mr. Erbakan said he would like them to be held as early as possible, perhaps in October. A federal prosecutor has filed a suit asking that Mr. Erbakan's Welfare party be banned as subversive, and party leaders fear that if elections are not held soon, an unfavorable verdict might prevent them from running at all. **********In an election, Mr. Erbakan would probably be helped by the lack of unity among secular parties. His Welfare party might be able to win votes by positioning itself as the victim of intrigues by military officers, press barons and other anti-Islamist figures whom he has denounced as ''secular fascists.'' **********In the absence of a strong leftist party here, Welfare has also become the political home of many villagers, migrants and poor people who feel themselves left behind by the social injustices that have accompanied Turkey's economic boom. In that sense, it is similar to many Islamic parties in North Africa and the Middle East, where the mosque has become a focus for social discontent as well as religious fervor. **********Still, various opinion surveys indicate that the military is the most respected institution in Turkey. Its actions against Mr. Erbakan have sharpened its profile as the guarantor of secular rule, but have also led to criticism that it is overstepping its mandate and acting as a partisan political force. **********Mr. Erbakan's Government was the 54th since the founding of modern Turkey in 1923, and the fifth in two years. The Welfare party won 22 percent of the vote in the December 1995 election, and secular parties spent months trying to form a government without him. Because of personal and political disagreements, they failed. **********Six months after the election, Mr. Erbakan forged an unlikely coalition with the secular True Path party. The True Path leader, Mrs. Ciller, became deputy prime minister and foreign minister despite the fact that she and Mr. Erbakan had traded bitter charges during the campaign. **********Military commanders were suspicious of the Government from the moment it was sworn in 50 weeks ago. They were unhappy with Mr. Erbakan's decision to pay early visits to Libya and Iran, which they consider hostile. Later they reached accords with Israel without consulting him. Recently, they began an offensive against Kurdish guerrilla havens in Iraq without notifying him. **********The military's displeasure broke into view in February, when it demanded that Mr. Erbakan retreat from his pro-Islamic policies. They insisted that he curb religious schools and ban private Koran courses. After some hesitation he promised to comply, but did not do so. Military leaders were infuriated.  On Monday, Mr. Erbakan issued a veiled warning to political leaders who seemed to be urging military intervention. ''We are all in the same boat,'' he asserted. ''Do not drill holes in that boat.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/19/busin.snippet: Fabri-Centers of America Inc, which owns more than 900 stores nationwide, agrees to pay $3.3 million to settle Federal charges that it misled investors by overstating earnings right before it sold securities in 1992 and for next nine months (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/19/busin.main_headline: Fabri-Centers Agrees to Pay $3 Million to Settle Charges
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/19/busin.print_headline: Fabri-Centers Agrees to Pay $3 Million to Settle Charges
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/19/busin.body_text: **********Fabri-Centers of America Inc., which owns more than 900 stores across the country, agreed to pay $3.3 million yesterday to settle Federal charges that it had misled investors by overstating its earnings right before it sold securities in 1992 and for the next nine months. **********The Securities and Exchange Commission filed a civil suit in Federal court in Washington against the company and two former financial officers, who are contesting the charges. Fabri-Centers is paying for their defense, a company official said. **********Fabri-Centers' chief executive, Alan D. Rosskamm, settled a related administrative complaint that he did not do enough to check into the company's financial statements before signing off on them. As is common practice in such settlements, neither he nor the company admitted nor denied the S.E.C.'s contentions. **********The company's class A stock fell 12.5 cents, to $16.375, on the New York Stock Exchange. Fabri-Centers, which is based in Hudson, Ohio, had disclosed in late 1995 that the S.E.C. might bring charges over its earlier financial statements. The company operates stores primarily under the Jo-Ann Fabrics and Cloth World names. **********The case is significant because of its emphasis on the accuracy of quarterly earnings reports on which investors rely, said Paul Gerlach, associate director of enforcement for the S.E.C. These are prepared by company managements and are not usually audited, he noted. **********The S.E.C's complaint also highlighted the role that company estimates can play when earnings are figured, a role that many investors may not be aware of. **********According to the S.E.C. complaint, Fabri-Centers, which sells fabric for arts and crafts, knew the dollar amount of sales at each store. But it did not know exactly what items were sold, so it did not know exactly how much profit it made on the sales. The company's practice was to do a detailed inventory of each store once a year, figure out what its profit margins were, and then apply those margins to future sales. **********But in the last two months of 1991, during the company's busiest sales period, it did not check out any operating stores, the S.E.C. contended. When the company closed its books for the year in February, the profits of more than 70 percent of sales were estimated. **********When the company resumed doing inventories in January and February, officials discovered that their margin projections were far too optimistic, in part because of stiff price competition, the S.E.C. said. This information was not disclosed in the company's annual or quarterly reports, or in the registration of a convertible debt issue that the company sold in March 1992. The $3.3 million payment Fabri-Centers agreed to make is based on profits it made in the debt issue, Mr. Gerlach said. **********The S.E.C. contended that Fabri-Centers' financial officers continued to try to cover up the problems with their estimates, using various accounting gimmicks that inflated results for three quarters. **********Fabri-Centers soon stopped relying on profit-margin estimates because it installed cash registers that kept a running tally of what products were sold, said Ron Gaston, the current chief financial officer. The company does not have to restate its earlier earnings as a result of the dispute with the S.E.C., he added. **********Robert L. Norton, who until last spring was Fabri-Center's chief financial officer, and Joseph E. Williams, who left his post as controller and senior vice president in June 1992, were named in the S.E.C. complaint. Stanley S. Arkin, the lawyer representing Mr. Norton, called the S.E.C. complaint unjustified. In a statement, Mr. Arkin, of the law firm Arkin Schaffer & Kaplan, said that Fabri-Centers under Mr. Norton's direction had made ''prompt and accurate disclosures,'' and that no investors had said they were injured. **********And Mr. Williams is ''highly confident that he did not do anything wrong,'' said his lawyer, Jeffrey B. Maletta of the firm of Kirkpatrick & Lockhart.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/12/busin.snippet: Auto industry regulators and engineers at conference in Dearborn, Mich, say that sport utility vehicles, mini-vans and pickups--so-called light trucks--pose serious safety problems to their occupants while increasing risk for other drivers on the ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/12/busin.main_headline: FURTHER PROBLEMS OF SAFETY FOUND FOR LIGHT TRUCKS
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/12/busin.print_headline: FURTHER PROBLEMS OF SAFETY FOUND FOR LIGHT TRUCKS
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/12/busin.body_text: **********Sport utility vehicles, mini-vans and  pickups  so-called light trucks -- pose serious safety problems to their occupants while increasing the risk for other drivers on the road, auto industry regulators and engineers said at a two-day conference that ended here today. **********Sport utility vehicles, which many Americans buy partly because they seem safer than cars in collisions between the two, roll over so often that their occupants are just as likely to die in an accident as car occupants, a prominent researcher said. Most of these rollovers are caused by collisions with other vehicles, curbs and other objects, and not by swerving, two Federal officials said. **********Brakes on light trucks, which now account for one of every two family vehicles sold, are generally not as effective as car brakes, partly because Federal safety standards for trucks are slightly more lenient than those for cars, a leading brake engineer said. **********Large sport utility vehicles and pickups account for an unusually large share of pedestrian deaths, apparently because of their weaker brakes and lack of maneuverability, a senior regulator said. **********Meanwhile, sport utility vehicles are nearly three times as likely as cars to kill the drivers of other vehicles during collisions, said Thomas Hollowell, a top researcher at the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. **********Regulators and insurers are becoming much more interested in the dangers posed by light trucks, to the dismay of auto executives, who worry that their most profitable models could soon be subject to tighter regulations or higher insurance rates. **********The Society of Automotive Engineers, a nonprofit group that plays a large role in setting technical standards, organized the conference in response to rising light-truck sales and growing industry interest in the associated safety issues. It was the industry's first gathering ever to review and seek solutions for the overall safety problems presented by light trucks. Journalists were not invited to the conference, but a reporter from The New York Times who registered was allowed to attend. **********In a speech at the conference, which focused mostly on sport utility vehicles, the auto industry's leading safety official responded indignantly to suggestions that a broad safety problem existed. Insurance data show that sport utility vehicles have a slightly lower death rate per registered vehicle than that of cars, said Barry Felrice, the director of regulatory affairs for the American Automobile Manufacturers Association. **********But Kennerly Digges, director of safety research at the National Crash Analysis Center, an organization financed by the Government and the auto industry, presented a study showing that once people in sport utility vehicles are involved in an accident, they are as likely to die as people in cars. That is true because the high death rate when sport utility vehicles roll over offsets the low death rate in all other collisions, Mr. Digges said. Sport utility vehicles are four times as likely as cars to roll over in an accident, he found. **********The insurance data cited by the auto manufacturers are not adjusted for the fact that sport utility vehicles are often driven by middle-aged parents who have few accidents regardless of what they drive. By looking at what happens to people in vehicles that are involved in accidents, Mr. Digges was able to focus on whether sport utility vehicles do in fact provide more protection. **********''People feel safer in them because they're higher and they're bigger, and as long as they're staying with all four wheels on the ground, they're fine,'' Mr. Digges said. ''But when they have four wheels in the air, there's a problem.'' **********Mr. Felrice said he was suspicious of researchers like Mr. Digges who use statistical tools to analyze death rates. He contended that the sheer size of sport utility vehicles had to improve occupants' chances of survival once they got into crashes. **********Auto makers contend that most rollover accidents occur when a vehicle hits a curb or other object with considerable force, upsetting the balance of the vehicle and causing it to turn over. Consumer Reports magazine has suggested that certain sport utility vehicle models can roll over even during tight turns without hitting other objects. But two Federal officials said today that 92 percent of all rollovers were caused by collisions or contact with other objects. **********Mr. Digges said sport utility vehicles rolled over so easily that even the best drivers were in danger because they might swerve to avoid an accident and hit a curb or another vehicle instead. Mr. Felrice acknowledged that the rate of rollover accidents in which someone died was two and a half times as high for sport utility vehicles as the rate for cars. But he contended that many of these rollovers occurred when young or impaired drivers hit curbs and other objects. Mr. Digges and Mr. Felrice agreed that the latest sport utility vehicles were less prone to roll over than earlier models. **********Mr. Felrice said the sheer weight of the biggest sport utility vehicles probably reduced their risk of rollovers. But Charles Kahane, a senior researcher at the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, presented evidence in a speech today that the frequency of rollovers was the same for all but the very smallest light trucks, which have a higher rate. The centers of gravity for the largest light trucks are so high as to offset the stability provided by their extra weight, Mr. Kahane said. **********Among the more popular sport utility vehicles are the Jeep Cherokee and Wrangler, the Ford Explorer and Expedition, the Chevrolet Blazer and Suburban and the Nissan Pathfinder. **********Federal safety standards are more lenient for light-truck brakes than for car brakes for measures  like stopping distances, while light trucks in general are harder to control than cars when drivers try to brake and steer at the same time, said John H. Sapp, the senior brake systems manager at Lucas Varity, one of the world's largest brake manufacturers. Light trucks are required to be able to stop from 60 miles an hour within 216 feet, for example, while cars are required to stop within 204 feet, he said. **********While some light-truck models meet some of the car brake standards, Mr. Sapp said he could not think of any light-truck model that met all car brake standards. Federal brake regulations issued two years ago will require all but the biggest sport utility vehicles and pickups to meet car standards in 2002. **********Mr. Kahane said in his speech that weak brakes and lack of maneuverability might explain why the biggest light trucks accounted for an unusually large share of pedestrian deaths. Most light trucks were designed for use in rural areas, not densely populated cities and suburbs, he noted. **********Mr. Hollowell, the Government's top researcher into what happens to vehicles during crashes, presented a separate study today confirming growing suspicions in the auto industry that light trucks are unusually deadly to car occupants. **********Sport utility vehicles are nearly three times as likely as midsize cars to kill the drivers of other vehicles during crashes, while full-size pickups are more than three times as likely to kill other drivers, according to Mr. Hollowell's statistics. The statistics are part of a new Government study to be released in February, Mr. Hollowell said. He also said that the Government would conduct six crash tests in January and February pitting sport utility vehicles, mini-vans and pickups against midsize sedans. **********Light trucks pose a danger because they are heavier than cars, ride higher off the ground and have stiff frames, Mr. Hollowell said. The stiff frames do not absorb much energy during a crash, transferring more of the force of a crash to whatever they hit. When a Ford Ranger hits a concrete barrier during a Federal crash test, the peak force of the impact against the barrier is twice as great as when a slightly heavier Ford Taurus hits the same barrier at the same speed, Mr. Hollowell said. **********Two auto maker engineers said that they privately welcomed greater public scrutiny of light trucks because it would strengthen the hand of safety advocates inside the auto makers who have questioned the shift toward ever bigger vehicles. Until recently, industry engineers who spoke up about light-truck safety received little attention as marketing executives focused on the immense profits, said one engineer who insisted on anonymity. **********''Voices were heard,'' he said. ''They just weren't listened to.''. **********Mr. Felrice said that safety had always been a top priority for the auto makers.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/05/world.snippet: China and Taiwan intensify their battle for recognition in Central America; 14 of 30 countries that recognize Republic of China on Taiwan, rather than People's Republic of China in Beijing, as legitimate government of China are in Central American...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/05/world.main_headline: Taiwan and Beijing Duel for Recognition in Central America
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/05/world.print_headline: Taiwan and Beijing Duel for Recognition in Central America
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/05/world.body_text: **********No sooner had China regained Hong Kong last month than Taiwan's Foreign Minister embarked on a three-week, 11-nation tour to shore up ties with his country's closest allies. His first stop was Honduras, where he and his Central American counterparts issued a joint declaration condemning China's designs on Taiwan. **********Though half a world away from East Asia, Central America has in recent years emerged as one of the main battlegrounds in the decades-old diplomatic struggle between China and Taiwan. Now, with Hong Kong under Chinese control, the scope and intensity of the contest between Communist Party leaders in Beijing and the prosperous island they regard as a renegade province have rapidly risen to new levels in this region. **********Of the 30 countries that recognize the Republic of China on Taiwan, rather than the People's Republic of China in Beijing, as the legitimate government of China, 14 are in Central America and the Caribbean. Taiwan's influence and generosity throughout the region are traditional and widespread and have led to increasingly conspicuous efforts by Beijing to neutralize that advantage. **********For Taiwan, relations with Central America and the Caribbean provide both political legitimacy and a promising market for trade and investment. This region's trade with China and Hong Kong is also booming, but China has been less successful, until recently, in efforts to persuade countries to recognize Beijing. **********''There have been rumors that after the first of July, perhaps the relations between my country and the nations of Central American and the Caribbean would be affected,''  Chang Hsiao-yen, Taiwan's Foreign Minister, said during a two-day visit here, referring to the date on which Hong Kong reverted to Chinese sovereignty. ''But those relations are solid and quite cordial, and I have come precisely to seek a better and more effective way to deepen them and increase our mutual support in the international arena.'' **********The maneuvering is especially intense here, and focuses on the Panama Canal, which the United States is scheduled to hand over to Panama on Dec. 31, 1999. China is the fifth largest user of the waterway, while Taiwan has cultivated a particularly close relationship with the Panamanian Government and has made large investments here, including a container port at a former American submarine base. **********''The Chinese, both China and Taiwan, have spotted an opening and are trying to exploit it,'' an American military official said. ''The United States is leaving Panama, there's a void, and each wants to fill it.'' **********To increase its limited leverage in the region, China has not hesitated to brandish Hong Kong. Even before assuming control of the former British colony, Beijing had warned nations recognizing Taiwan that they would have to close their consulates and negotiate new arrangements if they wished to maintain a diplomatic presence in Hong Kong. **********That alarmed many governments in this region that have made millions of dollars selling visas or passports to Chinese from Hong Kong and the mainland. Typically, a relative or close friend of a president is appointed consul general in Hong Kong, and a healthy cut of the sales flows back into the pockets of top government officials. **********In Panama's case, there is also an implicit threat to the lucrative business of ship registrations. Panama is the flag of convenience flown by thousands of ships around the world, including many owned by Hong Kong or Chinese fleets. In the past, those fleets have often registered their vessels and crew members through the Panamanian consulate in Hong Kong; but now they may turn to the Bahamas, a competitor that broke relations with Taiwan in July. **********But Taiwan is not standing pat. In his meeting with Central American foreign ministers, Mr. Chang indicated that Taiwan might be willing to hire Central Americans to replace its estimated 240,000 ''guest workers'' who are currently imported from the Philippines, Thailand, Malaysia, Indonesia and other countries that recognize Beijing. **********During the meeting in Honduras, the countries of Central America described Taiwan as ''a sovereign country'' and said that only ''peaceful means should be used to reach national unification.'' They also agreed to a summit meeting with President Lee Teng-hui in September in El Salvador. **********At a time when the United States is reducing its own aid to the region, the indications of Taiwan's largess are becoming an ever more visible part of the landscape. Police cars and garbage trucks in Haiti, for instance, proclaim in French that they have been ''donated by the Republic of China on Taiwan,'' as do the trash cans in Castries, the capital of the Caribbean island of St. Lucia. **********Missions from Taiwan have helped increase rice yields and organized fishing and agricultural diversification projects. Taiwan also helps pay the operating costs of several foreign ministries and police forces in the region and regularly sponsors trips by government officials, military officers and journalists to Taiwan for training courses or ''familiarization visits.'' **********China's approach to the region, in contrast, seems to emphasize the stick much more than the carrot. The result of those hardball tactics, it would appear, has generally been resentment. **********''You gringos have pushed us around for 150 years, and we never liked it,'' said the Foreign Minister of one Central American country. ''So what makes the Chinese think that kind of Great Power arrogance would be any more palatable coming from them? For them to tell us not to recognize Taiwan is no different than Washington saying we shouldn't have relations with Cuba.'' **********$(After Central American countries said in late July that they favored a plan to readmit Taiwan to the United Nations, China issued a letter publicly warning that ''they would ultimately pay the price'' for that position. President Arnoldo Aleman of Nicaragua responded by denouncing the Beijing Government as one that has oppressed and slaughtered its own people, and on Aug. 3 he left Managua for a five-day official visit to Taiwan.$) **********Early this year, after a peace agreement brokered by the United Nations brought an end to 36 years of civil war in Guatemala, China delayed deployment of a United Nations military mission for nearly a month to punish Guatemala for its support of Taiwan's readmission to the international body. **********In Panama, Chinese pressures have been aimed primarily at the economy. More than a quarter of the $5.5 billion worth of goods sold in the Colon Free Zone each year are imported from Hong Kong, and Panamanian executives are accustomed to flying there on short notice to conduct business. Now, however, they are being told that the Panamanian Government's friendship with Taiwan means they need visas to enter Hong Kong, which is causing costly delays. **********''The dispute between China and Taiwan is a political one that ought to be resolved in East Asia and should not spill over into Latin America,'' Nessim S. Bassan, president of the Colon Free Zone Traders' Association, said. **********There are also some indications that China now feels it can play the game through Hong Kong intermediaries. In July the Bahamas switched recognition from Taiwan to Beijing after Hutchison Whampoa, a Hong Kong conglomerate, agreed to invest more than $175 million in construction of a container port in Freeport and the purchase and refurbishing of three hotel complexes. **********In Panama, Hutchison Whampoa recently outbid American companies and secured the contracts to modernize and administer ports at either end of the Panama Canal. American officials have complained publicly that the bidding was marred by irregularities. **********''It is very hard to distinguish Hutchison Whampoa capital from mainland China capital,'' Mr. Chang, the Taiwanese Foreign Minister, said. ''Some people say we are using money to buy the region. That is not the case. It is mainland China who is doing this kind of thing, not us. But I think if they persist in this campaign against us, it is going to backfire against them.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/15/busin.snippet: Phonetel Technologies Inc says it agreed to acquire Communications Central Inc for about $12.85 a share, or about $165 million in cash and debt (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/15/busin.body_text: **********Phonetel Technologies Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Communications Central Inc., an operator of public pay telephones, for about $12.85 a share, or about $165 million in cash and debt. The purchase has been approved by the boards of both companies. Communications Central operates 26,000 pay telephones and inmate phones in 41 states and the District of Columbia. Phonetel owns about 41,300 installed public pay telephones. In Nasdaq trading, Communications Central's shares were up $2.25, or 25 percent, to $11.125, while Phonetel remained unchanged at $3.50 on the Amex.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/05/world.snippet: Algeria is set to hold multi-party elections; has barred Islamic party whose surged led mitilary to annul 1992 vote; extent of real parliamentary democracy appears strictly limited; authorities set security measures in bid to keep Islamic terroris...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/05/world.main_headline: Algeria Vote Nears, With Democracy in Ruins
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/05/world.print_headline: Algeria Vote Nears, With Democracy in Ruins
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/05/world.body_text: **********The first multi-party elections in Algeria since 1992 are to be held on Thursday, but the Islamic party whose surge led the military to annul that vote has been banished and the extent of real parliamentary democracy appears strictly circumscribed. **********Schools have been closed, weekly markets stopped, trucks banned from city centers and bus drivers ordered to search all bags as Algeria's military-backed authorities seek to insure an election undisturbed by the violence that has killed 22 people in Algiers this week and more than 50,000 since 1992. **********The country's undeclared war began after the generals who have exercised effective rule over Algeria since independence from France in  1962 canceled the second round of a parliamentary election that the Islamic Salvation Front seemed set to win. **********In response, Islamic insurgents began a campaign of terror that has been met by increasingly brutal reprisals from the military-backed authority known simply as Le Pouvoir, or The Power. Just who is killing whom, and in what numbers, has become increasingly murky in Algeria. **********The Islamic Salvation Front, which has been banned since the last elections, urged Algerians today to boycott the elections for the 380-seat National Assembly. In a statement issued here, the party said a solution to Algeria's crisis could be found only through negotiation and ''national reconciliation.'' **********An earlier appeal from the party, issued last month and calling for a dialogue between the military rulers of Algeria and the now-jailed leaders of the Islamic Salvation Front has been met with silence by President Liamine Zeroual, a retired general who was elected in 1995. **********The extent of the Islamic Front's support in Algeria now seems much diminished, Western diplomats said, eroded by the savage violence of the guerrilla groups that split from it and took to killing artists, journalists, teachers, foreigners and whole village communities. But it remains uncertain whether a lasting peace in Algeria can be established without some negotiation with the party. **********Peace has been a central theme of the campaigns of the 39 parties and 7,000 candidates competing in the election. The parties include a newly formed movement, the National Democratic Rally, which is close to Mr. Zeroual and amounts to Algeria's new official political force, and a moderate Islamic party known as the Movement for a Peaceful Society, which has taken up some of the populist themes that won support for the Islamic Front. **********Those two parties, the only ones with a strong organization throughout the country, are widely expected to win the largest shares of the vote, with the National Democratic Rally enjoying a marked advantage. The Parliament is to be elected under a system of proportional representation for parties that win at least 5 percent of the vote. **********''I have visited the entire country in recent weeks and peace is the one thing people want,'' said Saddik Debaili, leader of the Front for Socialist Forces, an opposition party with its base in the Berber region east of Algiers. ''Unfortunately, the election amounts to the completion of the coup d'etat begun in 1992 and so is unlikely to provide the basis for peace.'' **********Mr. Debaili's argument is based on the fact that, unlike the vote of 1992, this election is being held under the terms of a Constitution that appears to create a veneer of democracy while insuring that real power remains with the military-backed President. The Constitution was approved last November, officially by 85.8 percent of the population, but Western officials say that vote was marked by pervasive fraud. **********No international observers were allowed to monitor the vote on the Constitution. But more than 100 observers, including 8 Americans, have been invited from the United Nations, the Arab League and the Organization of African Unity to monitor the parliamentary election. **********There are, though, more than 33,000 voting stations and Mr. Debaili, speaking in a telephone interview from Algiers, contended that fraud would again be widespread. **********Disillusionment with politics, fear of violence and general exhaustion among a population struggling with falling salaries have insured that the campaign up to now has been generally listless, said Mustapha Bouchachi, a prominent lawyer in Algiers. **********Under the Constitution, the Parliament will have severely curtailed powers. It is to be overseen by a Council of the Nation, one-third of whose members are to be picked by the President. Because any law proposed by Parliament will have to be approved by three-quarters of the Council of the Nation, the President will enjoy an effective veto over the legislature. **********Nonetheless, Mr. Zeroual's determination to win control of the Parliament is clear. The National Democratic Rally emerged abruptly in April and has enjoyed huge financing  and support from regional governments. More than 80 percent of its candidates have already held positions in the state apparatus, and several government ministers are candidates for the party. **********Despite rising oil prices, the country's economy remains mired in a slump that has left close to 30 pecent of the population unemployed. **********The Movement for a Peaceful Society, led by Mahfoud Nahnah, a former Arabic language teacher and imam, has tried to move into the void left by the banning of the Islamic Front. Formerly known as Hamas, but always a moderate movement, it has a strong grass-roots organization and is promising small business loans and shorter working hours for women. **********In recent weeks, the National Democratic Rally has strenuously attacked Mr. Nahnah. Referring to his imprisonment in the 1970's for the sabotage of telephone lines to protest widespread nationalization,  Prime Minister Ahmed Ouyatahia said, ''Those who cut down telephone poles laid the groundwork for those who now cut off heads.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/21/busin.snippet: Why is this business cycle different from most others? Are the remarkably stable conditions over the past five years sustainable? Is inflation dead? Or is this all just a transitory phase of an irrational exuberance?.An intriguing in-depth analysi...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/21/busin.body_text: **********Why is this business cycle different from most others? Are the remarkably stable conditions over the past five years sustainable? Is inflation dead? Or is this all just a transitory phase of an irrational exuberance? **********An intriguing in-depth analysis by the London-based research team at Union Bank of Switzerland concludes that the exuberance, most evident in the U.S. equity markets, is not only rational but also likely to persist and encompass Western Europe and Japan before financial markets succumb to their traditional roller-coaster pattern. **********This business cycle is different, argue Bill Martin, Chris Carter and George Magnus, the authors of "Cycles and Securities," thanks to policy blunders that resulted in a period of exceptionally desynchronized economic activity in the United States, Germany and Japan. **********"The tranquillity of the 1990s is not due to sudden major shifts in the behavior of bond markets or real economies. Instead, the world had a lucky break," the UBS analysts wrote, due to "a unique set of accidents." **********These are identified as the reunification of Germany at the wrong rate of exchange, which set off an inflationary boom that then had to be contained, and the virtual locking of exchange rates within the European Union, in preparation for monetary union, to an appreciating Deutsche mark. **********The ensuing deflation in Europe coincided with Japan's belated efforts to burst the bubble that had been permitted to develop in domestic asset prices, severely damaging its financial system. **********As a result, the volatility of the global business cycle has been minimized. **********"There are only a very few instances this century — 1929, 1969, 1987 — when this measure of instability has been so low," the authors wrote. **********Despite the ominous comparison, they added that they "do not forecast a crash." **********"Chances are that the present highly stable conditions will continue this year and next," the authors wrote, and then ebb as volatility in global activity picks up. **********The timing of that expected turnaround is difficult to call, the authors acknowledge. But "for the next year or so," they said, investors should remain fully invested in stocks. For them, that means keeping 60 percent of portfolios in equities, 30 percent in bonds and 10 percent in cash. **********They recommend overweighting stock holdings in Japan and Europe and underweighting exposure in the United States, where they see the greatest downside risk. **********"In the very long run, bonds are likely to be a better defensive play than stocks," the analysts wrote. For now, they advocate bonds denominated in dollars or pounds. **********While U.S. and British interest rates are expected to continue rising, the analysts predicted much less risk in those currencies than in bonds denominated in marks or yen, as German and Japanese interest rates have not yet begun to rise and the possibility of such an increase is not priced into bonds.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/27/busin.snippet: Frederick W Zuckerman, former treasurer of Chrysler Corp, RJR Nabisco and International Business Machines Corp, dies at age 63 (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/27/busin.main_headline: F. W. Zuckerman, Former Treasurer Of 3 Corporations
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/27/busin.print_headline: F. W. Zuckerman, Former Treasurer Of 3 Corporations
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/27/busin.body_text: **********Frederick W. Zuckerman, a former treasurer of the Chrysler Corporation, RJR Nabisco and the International Business Machines Corporation, died on Sept. 19 at Columbia-Presbyterian Hospital in Manhattan at age 63. **********The cause was colon cancer, his daughter, Lee Zuckerman, said. Mr. Zuckerman was a resident of Manhattan. **********In 1979, Mr. Zuckerman helped persuade Congress to guarantee a $1.5 billion Federal loan to rescue Chrysler as the company teetered on the verge of bankruptcy. He resigned from the auto maker in 1990. After 11 years of commuting weekly between New York and Detroit, he said he had grown tired of the travel and the separation from his family. **********He became treasurer of RJR Nabisco in 1991 and left in 1993, when he rejoined I.B.M., as treasurer, after a 14-year absence from the company. He left in 1994 and became a merchant banker in a private partnership in New York. He was on the boards of eight companies. **********Mr. Zuckerman, who was born in Manhattan on May 4, 1934, graduated from Ohio State University in 1955 and earned a master's degree in business administration from Columbia University in 1958. He spent the next eight years with the Ford Motor Company and then served 12 years with I.B.M. **********In its February 1995 issue, CFO: The Magazine for Senior Financial Executives named Mr. Zuckerman one of 12 executives ''who made a difference'' -- even though he had never been a chief financial officer. **********The difference Mr. Zuckerman made, the magazine said, was in arranging huge offerings of Chrysler stock, repayment of the company's debt and repurchase of Chrysler's 14.4 million warrants to the Federal Government. He also helped RJR Nabisco regain its investment-grade rating. During his second stint at I.B.M., he insured the company's liquidity by negotiating a $10 billion, five-year revolving credit line with 81 banks. **********Mr. Zuckerman told the magazine that he had been offered the title of chief financial officer four times -- including by three companies that subsequently declared bankruptcy. **********''But I don't care about titles,'' he said. ''I care about two things: equity upside and fun. If you can make a lot of money for shareholders and negotiate the proper deals, you can also make a lot of money for yourself.  And fun -- fun is being party to a turnaround.'' **********Mr. Zuckerman, who was divorced, is survived by two daughters, Lee Zuckerman of Manhattan and Susan Seely of Menlo Park, Calif., and a grandson.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/03/world.snippet: White House announces First Lady Hillary Rodham Clinton will attend funeral of Diana, Princess of Wales, in recognition of close personal association between both women (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/03/world.main_headline: Hillary Clinton Will Go to Diana's Funeral
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/03/world.print_headline: Hillary Clinton Will Go to Diana's Funeral
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/03/world.body_text: **********A half-hour telephone conversation between President Clinton and Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain on Monday, followed by consultations between the two Governments, led the White House to announce today that Hillary Rodham Clinton will attend the funeral of the Princess of Wales in recognition of the ''close personal association'' between the two women. **********White House officials emphasized that Mrs. Clinton would not officially represent the nation. Because the ceremony will not be a state funeral, neither the President nor an official United States delegation will attend. **********Speaking on condition of anonymity, a White House official said tonight that the royal family and the Spencers, the Princess's family, ''sent a fairly strong signal that they believed that the First Lady was the best person to represent the President, the United States, and the American people.'' **********The official called reporters tonight to tell how the decision was made. The eagerness to provide such details may indicate White House concern that Mr. Clinton would otherwise have been seen as snubbing the memory of the Princess by not attending the service. **********On Monday, the White House announced that the President would not attend the ceremony, but Joe Lockhart, a White House spokesman, said that Mrs. Clinton ''will certainly take the condolences of her husband, the President, and we fully expect the American people will believe that she will be passing along the American public's condolences for them.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/22/busin.snippet: Club Mediterranee SA is counting on new marketing alliances with Levi's, Calvin Klein Cosmetics and Davidoff of Geneva, the cigar company, to lift it out of financial doldrums in which it has floundered since 1990; company says sales in US have be...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/22/busin.main_headline: Now, the well-packed carry-on for a Club Med vacation contains jeans, cologne and cigars.
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/22/busin.print_headline: Now, the well-packed carry-on for a Club Med vacation contains jeans, cologne and cigars.
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/22/busin.body_text: **********CLUB MED is counting on new marketing alliances with Levi's, Calvin Klein Cosmetics and Davidoff of Geneva, the cigar company, to lift it out of the financial doldrums in which it has floundered since 1990. **********The Paris-based Club Mediterranee S.A. says its sales in the United States -- its No. 2 market after France, generating one-fourth of total business -- have been flat, at $200 million, over the last five years, while the company has posted losses in three of the last six years. Club Mediterranee's shareholders have been so dissatisfied with the company's recent performance that in February, after last year's $130 million loss was announced, the chief executive, Serge Trigano, who is a son of the company's founder, was replaced by Philippe Bourguignon, the former head of Euro Disney. **********Industry officials say that confusion about the Club Med brand -- particularly over who vacations at the company's resorts, which it refers to as ''villages'' -- is partly responsible for Club Med's woes. Older travelers apparently think Club Med is for young singles, singles think it is for families, and families think it is for couples. **********''When people hear Club Med, they still think sex on the beach, even though it's not just for singles,'' said Bill Vervaeke, a former Club Med marketing official who is now senior vice president of Ryder & Schild, a Miami advertising agency. **********To try to clarify public perception of Club Med, Andrew Jordan, president of Club Med Sales Inc., the company's United States marketing arm, has refocused the company's strategy on selling Americans three separate brands -- villages for couples, for singles and for families -- and has hired brand managers to oversee each. The alliances with Levi's, Calvin Klein and Davidoff, a first for Club Med, are an outgrowth of this effort. **********Mr. Jordan, who joined Club Med last December from Coca-Cola, where he was a brand manager, said the goal was ''to sharpen the Club Med brand through synergy with other relevant brands.'' **********The Levi's promotion, conducted with the retail subsidiary of Levi Strauss & Company, gave individuals who signed up for a Club Med vacation in April or May a $50 gift certificate redeemable at Original Levi's or Dockers stores. Club Med advertised the offer in newspapers in eight cities and in travel trade publications; the ads were by Messner Vetere Berger McNamee Schmetterer Euro RSCG in New York, a unit of Havas Advertising. **********The Levi's partnership, Mr. Jordan said, ''is about creating value,'' appealing to all three tarket markets. He said Club Med villages registered a ''marked increase'' last month in first-time vacationers, some of which could be attributed to the promotion. **********The tie-in with Calvin Klein Cosmetics, a unit of Unilever P.L.C., is aimed at single vacationers and entails a sweepstakes contest that promotes Escape perfumes for women and men and awards trips to villages monthly through next January. **********The sweepstakes is featured in two-page Escape ads with scent strips in the May and June issues of Details, Road and Track and People magazines; it is also being promoted at Escape counters in 1,300 stores around the nation. Samples of the Escape scents are also being distributed to guests at Club Med's Turkoise village, in the Turks and Caicos Islands, and at the Copper Mountain village in Colorado. The ads for this tie-in were created by CRK Advertising in New York, the in-house agency for the designer Calvin Klein. **********The alliance with Davidoff involves another sweepstakes, with the first prize a Club Med vacation for two plus a year's supply of Davidoff White Label cigars. The contest will be promoted this summer in 90 cigar stores in the United States and on the cigarshop.com World Wide Web site. The target here, Mr. Jordan said, is affluent ''consumers we don't usually talk to'' who might be interested in Club Med's more exotic villages. **********Mr. Jordan said the three programs together would cost $1 million to $2 million. Officials at Levi's, Calvin Klein Cosmetics and Davidoff said they were sharing these expenses with Club Med. **********In addition, Mr. Jordan said, Club Med is spending $1 million on new direct-mail campaigns created internally and aimed at previous guests. **********The company is also devoting $300,000 to ads, also done in-house, promoting Club Med's golf and scuba programs; these ads will appear in the June and July issues of Self, Vanity Fair, George and Details magazines. People who call a toll-free number in the ads will receive a new brochure that describes Club Med's most upscale villages. **********To further promote its brands, Mr. Jordan said Club Med would spend more on traditional advertising this year than in 1996, when Competitive Media Reporting estimates it spent $8.4 million. Its agencies are Messner Vetere and Berenson, Isham & Partners in Boston. **********Commending Club Med's creativity with the new promotions, Bjorn Hanson, the hospitality industry chairman for Coopers & Lybrand, the consulting and accounting firm, singled out the Davidoff alliance as one that could update the company's image. **********But Mr. Vervaeke, the former Club Med official, predicted that the new alliances would not by themselves persuade many people to take Club Med vacations. **********''They don't explain what the product is to the target markets,'' he said. ''The first place they need to start is travel agents, and then they need to look at rebranding each segment, defining which clubs belong to each.''
