https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/10/busin.snippet: Societe Generale de Belgique SA sells 24 percent stake in Union Miniere SA to group of banks for $560 million in cash (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/10/busin.main_headline: S.G.B. Sells Stake In Union Miniere
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/10/busin.print_headline: S.G.B. Sells Stake In Union Miniere
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/10/busin.body_text: **********Societe Generale de Belgique S.A. said yesterday that it had sold a 24 percent stake in Union Miniere S.A. to a group of banks for 20 billion Belgian francs ($560 million) in cash, as Belgium's biggest holding company starts to focus on utilities. **********Guy Dellicour, S.G.B.'s spokesman, said the company would earn ''about 12 billion francs'' on the sale. He said that the buyers, which he declined to name, would sell the shares in the copper and zinc refiner to investors. **********Investors said the sale was part of S.G.B.'s strategy to concentrate on its 51.8 percent holding in Tractebel S.A., a Belgian power, energy and communications utility. S.G.B., which is controlled by the French holding company Suez Lyonnaise des Eaux, will keep a direct stake of about 22.5 percent in Union Miniere.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/11/world.snippet: Prince Norodom Ranariddh, who was ousted as Cambodia's joint leader in recent coup, says his Co-Prime Min Hun Sen decided to seize power to avoid investigations into drug trafficking by his associates and grenade attack on opposition political ral...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/11/world.main_headline: Defeated Cambodian Says Foe Feared Vote . . .
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/11/world.print_headline: Defeated Cambodian Says Foe Feared Vote . . .
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/11/world.body_text: **********Prince Norodom Ranariddh, who was ousted as Cambodia's joint leader last weekend, said in an interview today that his Co-Prime Minister, Hun Sen, had decided a month ago to seize power in a coup to avoid investigations into drug trafficking by his associates and a grenade attack on an opposition political rally. **********In an emotional account of recent events and an impassioned defense of his role in them, the Prince said  Mr. Hun Sen did not want to face elections scheduled to be held before next May, and had been maneuvered into agreeing to them only under pressure from European diplomats. **********The Prince said he fled to France from Phnom Penh, the Cambodian capital, early Friday morning after aides warned him that a coup was about to take place and that he might be held hostage or killed. He also said  Mr. Hun Sen, a former Khmer Rouge regional commander, was afraid the Khmer Rouge leader Pol Pot would be brought to trial. **********''He did not want Pol Pot to be tried,'' Prince Ranariddh said, ''because if Pol Pot were tried, maybe Pol Pot would say that the hands of Mr. Hun Sen are as bloody as those of Pol Pot himself.'' **********By seizing power, the Prince said, Mr. Hun Sen will transform the Communist Khmer Rouge from a dying movement into a renewed fighting force. He said the guerrilla force that ruled Cambodia in a reign of terror that cost more than a million lives from 1975 until 1979 and then battled the Vietnamese-installed government that Mr. Hun Sen eventually led, would not let the coup stand. **********''Thanks to the coup, the Khmer Rouge will survive,'' Prince Ranariddh said. **********When Mr. Hun Sen took control  and declared Prince Ranariddh a traitor who would be brought to trial if he returned to Cambodia, Mr. Hun Sen leveled similar accusations of illegalities at his Co-Prime Minister.  The two were forced to share power in 1993 after an election that Prince Ranariddh's royalists won by a small majority, only to be threatened by violence by Mr. Hun Sen and his Communist Cambodian People's Party. **********The Prince, son of King Norodom Sihanouk, said working with Mr. Hun Sen over the last four years had been ''a nightmare.'' **********''I was trained in a liberal education,'' said Prince Ranariddh, 53, who graduated from the University of Aix-en-Provence and taught political science there from 1976 to 1983, when he took a leading role in his father's resistance movement against the Hun Sen Government. **********''I was the son of a King, part of a royal family. He was a student in Hanoi, a Stalinist. He was trained by Pol Pot. He was trained in a very tough manner, as a battalion commander, if I'm not mistaken.'' **********He described Mr. Hun Sen as ''irrational'' and unbalanced in their dealings. ''Sometimes he was violent, very violent,'' he said. ''He was very emotional, always changing his mind. But it was the formula that failed.'' **********''We, all together, for the sake of peace, accepted a very unworkable formula in 1993: one Government, two Prime Ministers,'' Prince Ranariddh said. ''And now we have seen that we have failed, completely failed.'' **********''We, all of us, betrayed the will of the Cambodian people,'' the Prince said, his voice at the breaking point. ''In a very courageous manner, the Cambodian people voted in 1993 to express their will to see Cambodia not only as a peaceful country but as a liberal and democratic country. That is why Cambodians voted for me and not the Communists.'' **********In a long statement distributed to Cambodian missions around the world this week, Mr. Hun Sen accused Prince Ranariddh of illegally negotiating with the Khmer Rouge and hiding some of their fighters in his Phnom Penh house and party headquarters. **********Mr. Hun Sen also said that the Prince had been illegally importing weapons, and had been involved in drug trafficking, the smuggling of ancient artifacts and fomenting ''social unrest and anarchy.'' **********Prince Ranariddh said Mr. Hun Sen's executions of royalist officials  in recent days had nothing to do with their efforts to negotiate with the Khmer Rouge, as diplomats have suggested, but rather with internal criminal investigations. This was particularly true in the case of Ho Sok, who was killed on Tuesday, he said. **********''Ho Sok had absolutely nothing to do with the Khmer Rouge,'' Prince Ranariddh said. Then, in a reference to the head of the faction believed to be holding Pol Pot, he added that Ho Sok ''was not part of the negotiations between me and Khieu Samphan.'' **********''But he was responsible -- he was appointed by me -- to investigate the trafficking of marijuana and other drugs,'' the Prince continued. ''That is the reason why he was assassinated.'' **********Prince Ranariddh accused Mong Rithi, Mr. Hun Sen's personal financial adviser, of being involved in drug trafficking as well as the trade in children for child prostitution. This year's United States Drug Enforcement Agency report on Cambodia does not mention politicians by name, but says Washington is setting up a national drug unit for Cambodia because the police had been ineffective in combating criminal activity and that political controversy was hampering anti-narcotics efforts. **********Prince Ranariddh said he had heard that Mr. Hun Sen had decided on June 11 as the date for the coup, but that it had been clear for months that he and his royalist party were  under threat. Some of the harrassment was public, including an attack on his residence. **********This followed a grenade attack on an Easter Sunday rally in Phnom Penh by Sam Rainsy, leader of the new Khmer Nation, in which 19 people died. Critics of Mr. Hun Sen have called this an assassination attempt  on Mr. Rainsy, who was gaining popularity. **********In Washington, the Federal Bureau of Investigation, asked to look into the attack because of the presence of an American in the crowd, is nearing the conclusion that Mr. Hun Sen's bodyguards were involved. Cambodian journalists reported seeing police officers blocking rescue efforts. The United Nations has similar findings. **********Prince Ranariddh said he would go back to Cambodia to lead his royalist party, Funcinpec, in another election. But he added that he could not work with Mr. Hun Sen again and that he could not go to Cambodia now because of fears for his own safety. **********The Prince had meetings today with United Nations officials, including Secretary General Kofi Annan, and on Friday he is scheduled to meet in Washington with State Department officials and members of Congress. **********As today's meetings were taking place, the United States announced that it was suspending this year's $35 million aid to Cambodia for 30 days, in what the State Department spokesman, Nicholas Burns, characterized as ''a very hard line'' with Mr. Hun Sen. Also today, in a major rebuff, the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, meeting in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, decided to delay Cambodia's admission to the group. **********Prince Ranariddh said he would have four requests in his meetings. **********He wants diplomatic pressure put on Mr. Hun Sen, who he says has violated the 1991 Paris peace agreement that led to the United Nations-supervised elections in 1993. He wants governments and international organizations to put an aid freeze on Cambodia to demonstrate that coups carry a cost. He is seeking a mediator's role for King Sihanouk, now in Beijing for medical treatment. And, finally, he wants new elections. **********There is no time to spare, he said. **********''My followers in Phnom Penh and in the countryside are now the subjects of one of the most terrible repression coming from Hun Sen,'' he said. ''People are much more than frightened. It is back to the very totalitarian, Pol Potist style. The repression will be terrible, and the implementation will be terrible. I feel very, very sad for my country.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/15/busin.body_text: **********Banco Popular S.A., Spain's fourth-largest commercial bank, said yesterday that profit in 1996 rose 6.1 percent, to 61 billion pesetas ($459 million), as falling interest rates put pressure on loan revenue. **********The rise in profit was in line with the 6.2 percent increase in earnings in the first nine months, though at the low end of analysts' estimates for the full year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/27/your-.main_headline: Briefcase : 2 German Giants Make U.S. Debut With ADRs
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/27/your-.print_headline: Briefcase : 2 German Giants Make U.S. Debut With ADRs
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/27/your-.body_text: **********Two giants of German industry are making their debut on the New York Stock Exchange. Hoechst AG, the chemicals and life-science company, began trading its American Depositary Receipts on Wednesday, and is to be followed on Oct. 7 by Veba AG, the electric utility that is also in the chemicals, oil and telecommunications businesses. **********German companies have been latecomers to full listings in the United States, mostly because of a reluctance to meet accounting regulations that require more detailed financial disclosure. In 1993, the automaker Daimler-Benz AG became the first company to do so. But the desire to access U.S. capital markets is encouraging more to take the plunge. **********Hoechst and Veba merit the attention of global investors, according to analysts who follow them. Peter Blair of Salomon Brothers Inc. in London is one of several who has Hoechst on his "buy" list. **********"It's a company in transformation," he said, noting that it was moving out of the low-return commodity chemicals business, and building its profitable pharmaceutical, agro-chemical and animal health divisions. "Hoechst's pharmaceutical business was number five in the world last year, but it is still viewed as a chemicals company, so there's hidden value there." **********The restructuring is holding back earnings right now, but the payoff is coming, Mr. Blair said. By the year 2000, he sees Hoechst's earnings per share at 6.20 Deutsche marks ($3.50), more than double last year's 2.80 DM. The ADRs had been trading over-the-counter, where they closed at $43.75 on Tuesday. After moving to the Big Board, they were quoted at $44.31 on Friday **********Analysts are more cautious about Veba. Lueder Schumacher of NatWest Securities said he was positive on Veba's healthy electric-utility business, which accounted for more than half its profits last year, but was concerned about the firm's plans for its chemicals, transport and commodities trading units. **********Ricardo Barcelona of ABN Amro Hoare Govett agreed, noting that despite what he perceived as Veba's strategy to exit the chemicals business, it recently took a 36 percent stake in Degussa, a chemical manufacturer. **********The company said "the chemical business represents an important part of the Veba portfolio." Earlier this year, Ulrich Hartmann, the Veba chairman, said he was not unhappy with the idea of running a conglomerate. Only "poorly managed conglomerates" need fear corporate raiders, he said. **********Veba's telecommunications unit also needs a partner to help it compete in Germany's opening market, Mr. Schumacher said. Cable & Wireless PLC, the British telecom company, pulled out its 22.5 percent stake last year. . **********Mr. Barcelona has a hold rating on Veba, but Mr. Schumacher has an add recommendation, saying its longer-term story is good, and he has a target price of 114 DM over the next six months, compared with 102.8 DM on Friday.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/31/busin.snippet: Fierce competition among supermarket chains in Atlanta and other cities across US discussed; profit margins are so slim that big stores have taken to installing other services, from dry cleaning to gyms, to lure customers; photos; graphs; push to ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/31/busin.main_headline: Supermarkets Get a Brand New Bag
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/31/busin.print_headline: Supermarkets Get a Brand New Bag
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/31/busin.body_text: **********DAVID McFARLAND makes daily jaunts to a grocery store two miles from his home, but not for bread or milk. **********He goes to the Kroger supermarket in Alpharetta, a suburb north of Atlanta, to use the treadmills and stair-climbing machines in the store's fitness center. There is even a trainer with a degree in exercise physiology to guide him through his workouts. **********Carmella Edelman has little use for the treadmills, but she has become a regular at the store for its cooking school, across from the aisle where Maybelline mascara and Stephen King paperbacks are sold. For about $30 -- food included -- students learn to whip up duck ravioli with brown butter sauce, chocolate-chip biscotti and other such delights. **********Is your driver's license about to expire? You can renew it at the store's customer service counter. Other chains are offering sushi bars and shoe repair, or providing baby-sitting while harried parents shop. **********All this, of course, is intended to lure people into supermarkets, and not just to tighten abs or teach customers to stir-fry. Once they're inside, the grocery store of the 90's is designed to get shoppers not only to buy toothpaste and cereal but also to fill their carts with high-margin convenience items like boneless, skinless, marinaded chicken breasts. Behind the scenes, meanwhile, store operators are working to shave pennies off the cost of stocking chicken-noodle soup and other staples that add little to their bottom lines. **********The goal is to push razor-thin profits closer to 2 percent than 1 percent, which is about all that even the best operators have been able to achieve in the supermarket industry. That challenge is attracting some of the smartest money in the United States and Europe to a business rarely regarded as innovative. It is forcing supermarket operators to spend billions of dollars remodeling outdated stores and investing in technology. And it is driving already big chains into the arms of larger, more powerful merger partners. **********THE food fight in Atlanta is a microcosm of what is happening across the country -- especially in growing cities where chains can plant huge superstores amid newly sprouted suburban subdivisions, in hopes of cashing in on robust economies, relatively cheap land and rapid population growth. **********With profits so slim, the chase is do or die, and Atlanta's market is especially competitive. Some grocers in this city, which in the 1990's has had among the highest rates of store openings and new market entrants in the country, have already been driven out. And there are likely to be more casualties  when the economy inevitably slows. **********''The square footage that is going in there is just mind-boggling,'' said Bonni Zwickel, an industry analyst for First Boston, surveying the Atlanta market. ''Second- or third-tier players just have to fall out at some point.'' **********The reason for the industry's attempts to remake itself? Investors are demanding better returns at a time supermarket companies are losing business to unlikely competitors that now stock grocery items. Toys ''R'' Us sells diapers and baby formula. Wal-Mart is counted as the fifth-biggest supermarket chain in America. And many baby boomers would rather buy Boston Market's take-out meals than supermarket frozen dinners or -- of all things -- the ingredients to actually cook a meal. **********''The line between grocery retailers and other kinds of retailers continues to blur,'' said Paul Bernish, a spokesman for the Kroger Company in Cincinnati, which at $25 billion in sales is the nation's largest grocery chain. ''Without us taking action and becoming smarter ourselves, we face the possibility of losing our place in consumers' minds.'' **********In Atlanta, the competition is visible in bickering over ads and promotions, battles for prime real estate and a proliferation of store concepts that may not pay off. What, after all, does Kroger really know about the fitness business? In the Alpharetta store, it did cruelly plant the gym just a few feet from the bakery. **********Despite the risk that some of their efforts will flop, the dozen or so competitors here are undaunted. Kroger relies on service -- offering, for instance, dry-cleaning at some stores. A struggling local chain, Harry's Farmers Market, pulls in customers from 20 miles away with the most extensive product assortment in town, everything from fresh fish heads to $100-an-ounce balsamic vinegar. Winn-Dixie has positioned itself as the bargain shopper's alternative, advertising cheap wine and beef. Publix has simply bullied its way into the $6 billion Atlanta market, spending more than $300 million to open about 60 stores in five years. **********The aisles are becoming crowded in other cities, too. In Houston and Dallas, Albertson's and Kroger have displaced Houston-based Randall's as the market leader by rapidly expanding with new or revamped stores. And Safeway, in which the New York takeover firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts has a one-third stake, bought a leading chunk of the Southern California market last year when it acquired the Vons Companies. **********Other deals include the purchase of Stop & Shop Companies by Ahold N.V., a Dutch company, and the acquisition of Kash n' Karry Food Stores by Food Lion. In addition, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts recently purchased the Bruno's chain, continuing its spree of buying undervalued grocery companies with strong turnaround prospects. **********THE push to create larger regional chains is reshaping competition from Phoenix to Charlotte to Seattle, although parts of the Northeast have lagged behind the trend. The New York City area is an especially tough market that many operators avoid altogether because of its shortage of vacant land, high real estate and labor costs and zoning barriers. **********Even in New York, though, there have been changes. Stop & Shop is adding amenities in stores in Westchester County, including banks, pharmacies and expanded bakeries in some stores. Pathmark Stores is also upgrading and expanding. The company is building a store in Harlem and has said it will add bank branches in dozens of its New York stores. **********In the growth markets, however, consumers have come to expect even more variety, increased service and lower prices. While shoppers may judge the industry by the number of stores near their homes that have sushi bars, the real gauges of success have more to do with factors far from shoppers' view -- in produce coolers, warehouses and corporate offices. **********For example, customers at Kroger stores in Atlanta may think it is a coincidence when cashiers hand them coupons offering 50 cents off their favorite brand -- and flavor -- of ice cream. But scanners that tally their food bills at the checkout counters are simultaneously analyzing what they buy. This technology, growing in popularity among the chains, is being rolled out at hundreds of Kroger stores. **********The checkout data allow stores to instantly print coupons for items being purchased (or for similar products) and to electronically reorder merchandise as it sells. Because the promotions are linked to the inventory, fewer cases of soda collect dust in warehouses. **********Kroger, citing competitive reasons, declined to say how much money it was saving through its technology investments and other cost-cutting measures. Industrywide, though, such improvements can make the difference between turning a profit or reporting a loss as supermarket sales remain flat. **********THE industry's revenues, excluding sales from warehouse clubs and convenience stores, increased 11 percent last year, to $323.2 billion. But sales actually declined slightly after adjusting for inflation, according to Progressive Grocer, a trade publication. **********At the same time, the industry's operating expenses declined last year to 96.95 percent of sales, from 97.90 percent in 1995, according to the Food Marketing Institute, a trade group. Minute as that may seem, it was substantial for an industry that counts its profits in fractions of a penny: it contributed $3 billion to pretax profits, helping net income rise to 1.2 percent of sales from 1.14 percent in 1995 and a low of 0.49 percent in 1993, according to the marketing institute. **********Surprisingly, the value of supermarket stocks, which have always trailed the broader market, is still in the cellar. Food retailers' shares, as measured by the Standard & Poor's food retail index, rose 8.6 percent so far this year, versus the 21.4 percent gain for the 500 stocks in the broader S.& P. index. Part of the reason for the disparity is that the payoff from the big chains' costly investments is just beginning to show up on balance sheets; in addition, while supermarkets are becoming more efficient, many still suffer from heavy debts accumulated in leveraged buyouts during the 80's and early 90's. **********The attraction is that even with skimpy margins, large, well-run chains can turn in respectable profits. Kroger's net profit margin, for instance, was just 1.39 percent last year, but that translates into a decent $350 million on sales of $25 billion. **********Analysts say profitability should continue to edge up for the overall industry, between further cost-cutting and consolidations that are trimming purchasing, administrative, distribution and advertising expenses and giving grocers more clout with their suppliers. **********The industry makeover and the increased competition is fine by Ms. Edelman, the Roswell, Ga., woman who attends the Kroger cooking school in Alpharetta. She frequents several stores, depending on her needs. For recipe ingredients after class, she shops at Kroger. ''But actually, for my produce, I go to Harry's Market,'' she said. **********Already, the struggle to win the loyalty of customers like Ms. Edelman is taking a toll on some grocers. Winn-Dixie, long the No. 2 chain in Atlanta, behind Kroger, fell last year to third place, the victim of an assault on the market by Publix, a Lakeland, Fla., chain closely held by its employees. **********SIX years ago, when Ed Crenshaw, then a Publix executive vice president, pulled out his corporate credit card at a car rental agency in Atlanta, the clerk asked, ''What is Publix?'' and wanted to know if the name was spelled incorrectly. **********''We knew we would have to do a lot of work to develop the brand up here,'' said Mr. Crenshaw, now president of the company. So when Publix, looking to expand after saturating its home state, blew into Atlanta in 1991, the company simply offered what it determined was missing: newer, cleaner stores, more service and fresher perishable goods. In just five years, Publix claimed 14.4 percent of the Atlanta market. **********''We know how to make money,'' said Frank Hernandez, regional director for Publix in Atlanta. ''Once you give people something of value, they will come back. We are not trying be something other than a food business, so we don't want to have a smorgasbord of things in a food store and then let customers forget about food and the essential things that we built this business on.'' **********Customers say the approach is working. ''I used to shop at A.& P., but I got disappointed with their produce,'' said Veronique Maitre, a translator who was shopping recently at the Publix store in Alpharetta. ''They were out, or it didn't look good.'' **********Another shopper, Marie Vitalo has become a regular at Publix even though there is a Winn-Dixie store about a block from her house in Smyrna. **********''I like a clean, big store,'' said Ms. Vitalo, who works in accounting. **********Winn-Dixie, meanwhile, is determined to use pricing to win back customers like Ms. Vitalo. The parking lot of its Alpharetta store, which competes with two nearby Krogers and one of Wal-Mart's Sam's Club warehouse stores, is festooned with a large blue-and-white banner promising ''Lowest prices in town.'' Inside the store, signs and tags create a virtual sea of markdowns. The signs announce 40 percent off greeting cards, 50 percent off sunglasses, 15 percent off national-brand snack chips and 20 percent off school supplies. Some signs ask simply: ''Why pay more?'' **********''We are in a transition and have been for many years,'' said Mickey Clerk, a spokesman for Winn-Dixie, based in Jacksonville, Fla. ''Customers are stretched for time as well as for money, and what they want to do is find everything they want at the lowest prices they can in one place that is convenient for them. We were convenient before, but we didn't have the complete variety that today's customers want.'' **********So the company is closing stores throughout its system that are less than 30,000 square feet and replacing them with larger ones -- some up to 70,000 square feet -- with room for floral departments, pharmacies and bigger delis. **********A strategy of low prices and big investments may not seem like a smart game plan in one of Winn-Dixie's most competitive markets. But the chain has the resources to wait for weaker operators to fold; meanwhile, it continues to improve its stores to be more competitive with Kroger and Publix. **********Some competitors, though, have simply left or are struggling to keep up. Four years ago, Big Star, one of the retail arms of Fleming Companies, the giant food wholesaler, sold its Atlanta stores to A.& P. and left the market. Yet A.& P., which has been slow to upgrade its network of older stores, is barely clinging to sixth place in the market. **********''We were really consolidating,'' said Michael Rourke, a senior vice president of A.& P. ''A lot of stores we acquired were not up to today's standard and had to be closed.'' **********Grand Union and Piggly Wiggly supermarkets have also sold their Atlanta stores to other competitors, while Harry's Farmers Market, with five stores, hangs on, but has lost more than $23 million in four years. **********Even the market leaders have some housecleaning to do. An older Kroger store in the fashionable Buckhead section of Atlanta has dated fixtures and lacks the amenities found in the Alpharetta outlet. **********Such shortcomings are becoming less tolerable to Atlanta-area shoppers. Mr. McFarland, who works out at the ''cardiotheater'' in the Alpharetta Kroger, said he had noticed an overall improvement in the area's supermarkets in recent years, as more companies moved in. **********Besides the gym, which is run by Australian Body Works and costs $5 a visit for walk-ins, Mr. McFarland uses the pharmacy and the Nationsbank branch at the store. The added services have turned him into a Kroger regular when it comes time to shop for groceries. **********''You don't want to have to make two stops if you don't have to,'' said Mr. McFarland, 43, a wine supplier. And he has the sense that packing more into his busy schedule will become even easier as Kroger and the other grocers continue to offer not just better cuts of meat and more brands of cereal, but additional services as well. They have to, he figures, ''to keep up with everybody else in the neighborhood.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/22/busin.snippet: Toy Biz Inc reaches deal with Marvel Entertainment Group bondholders, led by Carl C Icahn, for merger with Marvel on terms satisfactory to the bondholders; move comes a day after Toy Biz backs out of deal with Marvel's management and banks (L)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/22/busin.main_headline: Toy Biz Reaches Agreement With Marvel's Bondholders
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/22/busin.print_headline: Toy Biz Reaches Agreement With Marvel's Bondholders
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/22/busin.body_text: **********In the continuing battle for control of Marvel Entertainment Group, Toy Biz Inc. defected to the other side yesterday. The move provided a gain for bondholders led by Carl C. Icahn. But the struggle is far from over. **********Toy Biz, a company partly owned by Marvel, has an exclusive license to develop toys based on Marvel comic book characters. It had been a key part of efforts first by Ronald O. Perelman, the financier who previously controlled Marvel, and then by Marvel's management and bank lenders, to reorganize the bankrupt company on terms that would leave holders of Marvel bonds and stock with only a very small stake in the company. **********But yesterday, Toy Biz said it had reached a deal with Marvel bondholders, led by Mr. Icahn, for a merger with Marvel on terms satisfactory to the bondholders. The move came a day after Toy Biz backed out of a deal with Marvel's management and banks. **********''We hope this will finally resolve the Chapter 11 of Marvel Entertainment and revitalize this great company to get Spider-Man, the Incredible Hulk and all the other great characters moving in the right direction again,'' Mr. Icahn said. **********While Mr. Icahn spoke of a consensus, the battle continues. The agreement was announced just before a bankruptcy judge began a hearing on whether to block the bondholder group from throwing out Marvel's board. **********Without the court's intervention, the bondholder group can do so because its bonds are secured by 80 percent of Marvel's stock, owned by Mr. Perelman, and the bondholders have gotten legal permission to seize that collateral. The judge issued no immediate ruling yesterday, and a Federal district judge later in the day ordered that no such move be made until a new hearing is held on Tuesday. **********Bank lenders, led by Chase Manhattan, oppose the bondholders' plan, contending that what they would get -- $300 million in cash or notes plus the Marvel subsidiaries Fleer, Sky Box and Panini, which sell sporting cards and stickers -- is too little. **********The banks have the option to oppose the plan in bankruptcy court, and, if the court agrees that the banks are being disadvantaged, the plan could be rejected. **********Under the plan, owners of Toy Biz would get 40 percent of the stock in the combined entity. Owners of Marvel, including the bondholders, would get 60 percent, but only after paying $200 million for additional equity through a rights offering. In addition, the rights offering would raise $100 million to $300 million by selling bonds, with the exact amount dependent on whether the banks end up getting notes or cash. **********In New York Stock Exchange trading yesterday, shares of Marvel rose 12.5 cents, to $2.25, and those of Toy Biz rose 75 cents, to $9.375.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/16/busin.main_headline: A Ticket to the Fast Lanes Of Money Management
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/16/busin.print_headline: AT THE GATE; A Ticket to the Fast Lanes Of Money Management
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/16/busin.body_text: **********INVESTORS looking to ride the wave of mergers sweeping the money management business can look forward to getting a new vehicle this week. Affiliated Managers Group, a company whose main business is buying money managers like the mutual fund firm Tweedy, Browne, is scheduled to sell shares to the public on Thursday. **********The offering represents the first opportunity for investors to gain exposure to a company associated with the money management business since 1992 when the St. Paul Companies sold 20 percent of the John Nuveen Company to the public. Since then, Nuveen stock has appreciated 100 percent. **********As a group, the stocks of companies that manage money for individuals and institutions have risen 130 percent since October 1994, compared with 94 percent for the market, according to an index of 14 money management stocks compiled by Putnam Lovell & Thornton, an investment banking firm that specializes in financial services companies. **********Given this performance and the lack of new offerings in the field, some analysts expect the Affiliated Managers offering by underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company to be well received. **********''We think there will be very strong interest in this offering,'' said Kathleen Smith, portfolio manager at Renaissance Capital, a firm in Greenwich, Conn., that researches and invests in initial public offerings. ''The fact is there isn't too much else out there.'' **********But other analysts are more cautious. ''It's tough to gauge,'' said Ryan Jacob, director of research at IPO Value Monitor, a research firm. But, he added, ''This won't be a hot deal.'' **********The strategy of Affiliated Managers is to buy majority interests in midsize money management firms and to profit by increasing its assets under management through these acquisitions and through the affiliates' internal growth. **********So far, the company has done a good job of acquiring its fair share of affiliates, said John Cabell, portfolio co-manager at the USAA Aggressive Growth fund and a potential investor. Since its founding in December 1993, Affiliated Managers has acquired 10 money management firms that oversee $43 billion in assets. Among the 10 are Skyline Asset Management, manager of the Skyline Special Equities and Skyline Special Equities II mutual funds, and First Quadrant, a  large quantitative investment firm that  uses computers in asset allocation and style management strategies. **********During the summer, the company scored its biggest coup by lassoing the Tweedy, Browne Company, which manages two top-rated mutual funds -- Tweedy, Browne American Value and Global Value -- as well as private money. With its $300 million price and $5.1 billion in assets, the deal gave Affiliated Managers credibility as a buyer of good-sized firms. **********''A pillar like Tweedy, Browne will attract other managers,'' Mr. Cabell said. **********In fact, the company has been mentioned as a potential buyer of Insight Management, the company founded by the Fidelity watcher and money manager Eric M. Kobren. That deal could be valued at up to $200 million, according to The Wall Street Journal. **********The biggest risk to the company is in its dependence on a favorable investment environment and a continuing flow of cash into mutual funds and other money management vehicles. If the stock market has a down year, companies that earn fees based on assets under management could see revenues suffer. **********''The offering seems to be fair,'' Mr. Jacob said, ''but investors need to understand they're taking market risk.'' **********Affiliated Managers, which is headed by William J. Nutt, former president of the Boston Company, an institutional money manager, is offering seven million shares of common stock, expected to be priced at $20 to $23 each. The proceeds will go toward paying down $139 million in debt. **********That will leave $206 million in long-term debt, but shareholders' equity will rise to $214.8 million. That relationship between debt and equity is reasonable, considering the fairly stable flow of asset management fees, analysts said. **********Given the likely institutional interest, the stock is expected to begin trading at a 16 percent premium to its offer price, said David Menlow, president of IPO Financial Network, which projects opening premiums on initial offerings. ''That's a good pop at the opening, but investors should be in this for the long term,'' he added. **********Financial services stocks typically do not provide investors with quick profits, he and others said, and Affiliated Managers is just turning the corner on profitability. The company earned $833,000 in the first nine months of 1997 after posting losses in each of the previous three years. **********Analysts expect the company to remain profitable. Earnings should increase 17 percent to 20 percent a year over the next two to three years, Ms. Smith estimated. **********The company motivates its affiliates to grow by leaving 25 percent to 45 percent of ownership in management's hands. Affiliated Managers contends that this structure is superior to that used by its closest rival for deals, United Asset Management, which typically buys 100 percent of a company. U.A.M.'s practice ''eliminates the possibility of disputes in valuing the minority share when it changes hands,'' said Jonathan Hubbard, U.A.M.'s manager of media relations. Mr. Hubbard added that U.A.M. provides its managers with other incentives, like revenue sharing and stock options, that allow them to share in their firm's growth. **********BECAUSE more than 1,200 companies in the United States and abroad have assets under management in its target range of $500 million to $10 billion, Affiliated Managers maintains that there are plenty of deals to be done. **********Many such firms got their start after the Employment Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, which created a need for professional management of pension funds. Their founders now face succession and liquidity issues, and Affiliated Managers provides a way to turn their investment in their businesses into cash to help in estate planning. **********Money managers at large firms also continue to set up shop on their own. Last year, the number of start-ups and so-called lift-outs -- in which groups of employees leave to join other firms -- exceeded acquisitions by 60 to 49, according to Investment Counseling Inc. of West Conshohocken, Pa. **********But Affiliated Managers is not the only company that has noticed this trend. Since its founding in 1980, U.A.M. has acquired 50 money management firms. Today, its firms manage $207 billion in assets. While shares of U.A.M. have been under pressure recently, it has provided compound returns of 14.02 percent a year since going public in 1986. **********Bradford I. Hearsh, managing director in the financial institutions group at Paine Webber, counts a half-dozen other firms that aim to invest in midsize money management companies. Among these are Value Asset Management, which is backed by a unit of BankBoston, and Matrix Capital Management, backed by Castle Harlan, the New York merchant bank. **********''There is a lot of fragmentation and owners seeking liquidity, which brings money out of the woodwork,'' Mr. Hearsh said. The price multiples being paid for money management firms in the midsize range have risen 23 percent since 1993, from 7.7 times cash flow to 9.5 times, according to data compiled by Putnam Lovell & Thornton. **********As for the internal growth of its affiliates,  Affiliated Managers has experienced ''nice increases in inflows of assets and performance'' so far this year, Ms. Smith said. **********But it is still early in the game, Mr. Hearsh cautioned. ''You have to believe that these holding companies can add value -- that managers can grow more quickly with A.M.G.,'' he said. ''This is still an open issue.'' **********There are other risks, analysts said. Affiliated Managers is highly dependent on its newest acquisition, Tweedy, Browne. If it were included in financial statements for the first six months of the year, its cash flows would account for 52 percent of the cash flows that Affiliated Managers receives from affiliates. **********''The big question going forward is what is Tweedy, Browne going to do,'' Ms. Smith said. The company has established solid long-term performance records and is extremely profitable, earning $21.8 million on $33.6 million in revenues before the partners took their profits last year. As Ms. Smith sees it, the offering ''sinks or swims on Tweedy, Browne.'' **********The offering remains attractive, however, to an investor like Mr. Cabell of USAA. ''If the equity markets continue to prosper, and I see no reason why Asia should be a problem,'' he said, ''this is a good way to participate in the money management business.'' **********Those who take a less sanguine view of the markets, however, like George Shirk, managing editor at New Issues, a newsletter based in Deerfield Beach, Fla., are more cautious. ''We just don't see the fundamentals in place for an investment advisory firm to excel in an overextended market,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/29/world.snippet: French archeological team is working amid untreated sewage in eastern harbor of Alexandria, Egypt, uncovering sunken remnants of ancient royal quarter that housed rulers, including Cleopatra, 1,600 years ago; remnants are being discovered within 1...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/29/world.main_headline: Alexandria Journal; Down Among the Sewage, Cleopatra's Storied City
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/29/world.print_headline: Alexandria Journal; Down Among the Sewage, Cleopatra's Storied City
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/29/world.body_text: **********The poet called it a wine-dark sea, but here the Mediterranean is obscured by something less poetic. **********It is sewage that flows untreated into coastal water. Beneath the surface of the once-fabled eastern harbor, it is rarely possible to see more than an arm's length away, a dismal reflection of the faded city that modern Alexandria has become. **********That is what makes it understandable -- but still nothing short of remarkable -- that only now, some 1,600 years after it slipped into the sea, the remnants of an ancient quarter that housed rulers including Cleopatra are being discovered within 100 yards of what is now the shoreline, in water just 15 feet deep. **********Along with modern filth, the centuries had collaborated to give the artifacts a hiding place, burying columns, statues and giant granite blocks deep beneath the sand or encrusting them in thick layers of a shell-like coating. **********In the past, those who searched the harbor had been able to find nothing, but that has changed with the use of technology that has enabled explorers to see through the gloom. **********''Where other people saw only rocks, we have been able to assemble a true picture,'' said Franck Goddio, a Frenchman whose team has used advanced magnetometers, radar and other devices to produce what Egyptian officials call a revolution in underwater archeology. **********What has been found so far -- sphinxes, pedestals and other artifacts, some with Greek inscriptions -- has substituted hard evidence for years of speculation about the layout of the ancient quarter, the heart of what in the three centuries before Christ was one of the most important cities in the world. **********But to unearth, clean, photograph and catalogue the artifacts, divers must still spend hours at work each day on the harbor floor, where the outflow of sewage from what has become a city of five million people can be felt as a detectable current. **********For perhaps a few hours every 15 days, the flow is shut down, and ''then you can really feel a difference,'' said Susan Henrickson, an American who is among the divers whose work within shouting distance of Alexandria's traffic-clogged corniche is painting a new picture of the city's former splendor. **********Accounts from the time have described the royal quarter as a walled city of splendid, lavish buildings and magnificent parks that made up about a third of the total area of the city, which was founded in 331 B.C. by Alexander the Great. **********But its most majestic years ended in 30 B.C., when the defeat of Cleopatra's forces in the battle of Actium transformed Egypt into a Roman province. And during the great earthquake and tidal wave that struck the city in the fourth century A.D., the royal quarter vanished. **********That left even its layout to be debated among scholars unable to uncover what the accounts say were a Ptolemaic palace, Mark Antony's Timonium, and temples of Isis and Poseidon. **********Cleopatra was the last of the Ptolemies, the dynasty of Egyptian rulers of Macedonian descent that was established after Alexander's death. Because she was among those who ruled from the royal quarter, Mr. Goddio's team has sometimes been hailed as having discovered Cleopatra's Palace. That very name conjures up those famous cinematic images of a powerful, seductive queen, her lover Julius Caesar and her suicide along with another lover, Mark Antony, in the aftermath of the Roman triumph. **********In fact, scholars say it is almost certainly too soon to tell which of the red granite, basalt, marble and limestone blocks that Mr. Goddio and his team are painstakingly mapping, photographing and cataloguing on the gloomy harbor floor might have been part of any particular structure. **********''We are excavating a town in which Cleopatra lived, but to this day there are no remains that can be precisely identified with her,'' said Dr. Manfred Clauss, a German expert on Cleopatra and professor of ancient history at Goethe University who is providing advice on the project. **********For researchers, an additional problem beyond the fact that the relics are underwater is that they must almost certainly remain there. After being sodden for so long in brine, even the hardest of stone cannot withstand being exposed to the air unless it is first painstakingly desalted, a process that can take as long as two years. **********At least for the indefinite future, Mr. Goddio and his team have agreed with Egypt's Supreme Council on Antiquities that everything found will remain beneath the surface, where it is cleaned, examined, photographed and mapped, under the supervision of Egyptian archeologists. **********Even for an object as small as a four-foot-long sphinx, the process can be painstaking, taking a team of two divers as long as a week just to pick away the deposits that encase just about everything on the harbor floor. **********And although special lights and ultra-wide-angle lenses make it possible to photograph most of the finds even in the underwater gloom, the team has had to come up with other techniques to record evidence that is less easy to see. **********With its financial sponsor, the Hilti Foundation, a private philanthropy based in Liechtenstein, Mr. Goddio's team has even developed a latex coating that has been used to lift away exact copies of otherwise indecipherable Greek inscriptions, thereby helping to date certain underwater finds. **********In hopeful moments, afloat off Alexandria, Mr. Goddio and his divers say they can almost imagine the day when the harbor might somehow be made pristine. They say they would wish for the creation of a kind of archeological theme park, where tourists could float in glass-bottom boats and gaze down at all that has been uncovered. **********But then they gesture across the water toward the crowded, dirty city, and say they recognize that they will have to be satisfied with much, much less. **********''They promised us last year that the sewage would stop in March, but nothing has changed,'' a diver who insisted on anonymity said of the Egyptian authorities. ''Now they say it will stop by the end of 1998. It's great to uncover antiquity, but it would sure be better without all this modern muck.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/18/world.snippet: Italian port of Brindisi is experiencing flood of Albanian refugees, creating quandry for local officials as to how to care for them; number has swelled from about 300 to 6,000 in past three days; estimates of Albanian refugees in Italy as whole a...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/18/world.main_headline: Albanian Refugees in Italy Are in a Kind of Crowded Limbo
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/18/world.print_headline: Albanian Refugees in Italy Are in a Kind of Crowded Limbo
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/18/world.body_text: **********Three days into the latest exodus of Albanians to Italy's southeast coast, this ancient port city has run out of room. **********On Friday, the number of refugees here was about 300; today it reached 3,000, not counting the latest arrival, an aging military frigate carrying about 900 people that ran out of fuel about 23 miles outside the harbor. **********All but about 120 of the ship's occupants were taken aboard an Italian ship and ferried north to the larger city of Bari, under armed guard. **********''We are completely full,'' explained Pietro Antonacci, the deputy police chief here in Brindisi, ticking off a list of 18 settlement centers commandeered since the weekend, including hotels, church centers, sports camps and nursery schools. The latest estimates of newly arrived Albanian refugees in Italy as a whole are close to 6,000. **********It was 7 P.M. on Friday when local officials in Tuturano, a farming village of 3,200 that lies among vineyards and olive groves about 10 miles outside Brindisi, had word that a busload of about 40 Albanians was on its way. Working through the night, they cleaned up an old nursery school that had been vacant for three years. **********Now the school is the temporary home of 40 Albanians, among them Nuredin Lejla and his family. The Lejlas were among the first families in the Albanian port city of Durres to make a dash for the open sea after hearing the first bursts of gunfire on Thursday. **********''Until then, Durres was calm, and then, little by little, the war came there,'' said Mr. Lejla, who looks older than his 44 years. ''Everywhere people were running because they were afraid.'' **********In normal times, a ferry takes about five hours to travel from Durres to Brindisi. But the Lejla family, together with about 70 others, piled onto what they described as a tugboat for a journey that lasted three days. For one thing, no one on board was much of a sailor, let alone a captain; Mr. Lejla, as a mechanic, had the most experience with boats. **********At one point in the middle of the night, the engine broke down, and they were stalled until another ship could come along and start it up again. The nights were cold, and the sailing was not smooth. **********''Everyone was sick the whole way,'' said Ada Lejla, 15, who was a student at a language school in Tirana. ''When we saw the lights of Brindisi, we were so happy.'' **********The boat was pulled into Brindisi harbor at dawn on Friday, and by the next day, the family and many of their fellow passengers had settled into the village nursery school, where hot meals are brought to them three times a day. **********''We want to stay, but we don't know if the Italians want us to stay,'' Ada said. **********They are in limbo, with temporary papers, a place to sleep, food to eat but no money, and for the moment, no prospects. Those Albanian refugees with relatives already in Italy who will come here to collect them are free to go; others can slip away, but not many have anywhere to slip away to, or the means to do it. **********Already, 650 refugees have been bused to other parts of Italy, to relieve the pressure on southern regions that already have high unemployment. **********The Italian authorities are offering assistance to the new arrivals, but not so much as to encourage more of them to come. On a visit to Brindisi on Sunday, the Italian Prime Minister, Romano Prodi, sent a clear message across the Adriatic when he said Albanians would not solve their problems by fleeing. He emphasized that about two dozen Albanians had already asked to be sent home as the violence there begins to ebb.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/30/busin.snippet: Stock of First Republic Bancorp falls 10 percent after company says it is no longer exploring possible sale or merger (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/30/busin.main_headline: FIRST REPUBLIC SHARES FALL AS SEARCH FOR BUYER HALTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/30/busin.print_headline: FIRST REPUBLIC SHARES FALL AS SEARCH FOR BUYER HALTS
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/30/busin.body_text: **********The stock of First Republic Bancorp fell 10 percent yesterday after the company said it was no longer exploring a possible sale or merger. In February, First Republic, based in San Francisco, Calif., hired Montgomery Securities to help in identifying and evaluating alternatives. But on Wednesday the company, the parent of First Republic Bank, called off the search for a buyer. It said it would continue to review alliances and possible acquisitions. Separately, the company said it had increased its stock-buyback plan by 500,000 shares, or 5 percent of its 10.03 million shares outstanding. Shares of First Republic fell $2.25 yesterday, to $20, leaving the company with a market value of $154 million.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/29/busin.snippet: Dow Jones industrial average falls 26.18 points, to 7,357.23; Nasdaq composite index is up 0.97, to 1,410.18, a third straight high (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/29/busin.body_text: **********Stocks closed mixed yesterday, with both the Dow Jones industrial average and the Standard & Poor's 500 stock index off, even though gainers exceeded losers on the New York Stock Exchange. Moreover, bond yields above 7 percent lured some investors away from equities. **********''The relative value of stocks to bonds is so much in favor of bonds that you have to bite'' and buy Treasuries, said Robert Streed, a money manager at Northern Investment Counselors, which oversees $7 billion. The yield on the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond held at 7.02 percent for a second day. **********The Dow industrials fell 26.18 points, to 7,357.23. Du Pont paced the decline, dropping 2 3/8, to 109 3/8, after Merrill Lynch cut its investment rating and earnings estimates for the company. Merrill cited lackluster European demand and a possible domestic economic slowdown that would reduce demand for Du Pont materials. **********Computer companies, which boast some of the fastest-growth rates among all stocks, withstood the decline, sending the Nasdaq composite index up 0.97, to 1,410.18, a third straight high. **********''The market's up 15 percent'' this year, said Kevin Parke, who helps manage $38 billion in stocks as director of equity research at Massachusetts Financial Services. ''Earnings will probably be up 10 percent or 11 percent for the S.& P. 500. I wouldn't look for huge returns in the market the rest of this year.'' **********Another reason achieving new highs may be difficult is that the rally since April has been fueled partly by declining interest rates and expectations of slowing growth in the economy. Recent economic reports undermined that outlook. **********Steady-growing consumer-product and drug companies were hardest hit yesterday. Coca-Cola fell 1 1/4, to 67 1/4. Merck dropped 1 3/8, to 92. **********Trading was about average on the New York Stock Exchange, with 487.3 million shares changing hands. In the broad market, the Standard & Poor's 500 Index fell 2.50, to 847.21. **********Shares of HFS fell 4 1/4, to 54 3/4, and CUC International Inc. dropped 1 3/4, to 23 1/4, amid investor concern that the proposed $11 billion merger of the companies would slow their growth rates. HFS owns several hotel chains, the Avis rental car company and a travel planning service. CUC, a top discount marketer that runs membership shopping clubs, would issue 434 million shares. **********The Charles Schwab Corporation gained 2 7/8, to 38 3/4, after Standard & Poor's said it would add the stock of the securities firm to the S.& P. 500 Index. Mutual funds that mimic the index will have to add the shares to their holdings. **********Shares of Nike climbed 3 7/8, to 64, on unconfirmed speculation that Berkshire Hathaway, which is controlled by the investor Warren E. Buffett, is acquiring the shares. **********Gains in 3Com, up 4 3/8, to 51 1/8, and Cisco Systems, up 5/16, to 69 1/16, which both make equipment to link computers to each other, helped bolster the Nasdaq. **********''The fastest-growing sector in our economy is information technology,'' said Mary Sunderland, a money manager at Skandia Investment Management, who holds 2.03 million shares of Cisco. **********U.S. Robotics, which 3Com plans to acquire, rose 7 3/4, to 88 1/2. **********Navistar International gained for a ninth day, up  1/8, to 15 7/8 -- its highest level since July 1995. Shares of the Chicago manufacturer of trucks, diesel engines and service parts have gained 69 percent in the last five weeks amid optimism for faster-than-expected profit growth. **********ON THE WEB **********The latest stock and mutual fund quotations, along with news updates, are available on the Internet from The New York Times on the Web: www.nytimes.com

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/19/busin.snippet: Treasury securities prices rise; 30-year bond rises 13/32, to 99 8/32, to yield 6.68 percent; graph (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/19/busin.main_headline: Gains Posted By Treasuries As Fed Buys
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/19/busin.print_headline: Gains Posted By Treasuries As Fed Buys
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/19/busin.body_text: **********Treasury prices gained yesterday, as the Federal Reserve Bank entered the market as an active buyer while a survey of business conditions showed pockets of weakness. Investors saw the survey as further reducing the chances that Fed policy makers will raise interest rates when they meet in two weeks. **********The price of the 30-year bond ended up 13/32, to 99 8/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction of the price, fell to 6.68 percent,  from 6.71 percent on Tuesday. **********The Fed's appearance as a buyer, called a coupon pass, was surprisingly large and drew buyers into the market. The Fed bought $1.64 billion of mostly two-year and five-year maturities with coupons running from June 1999 to May 2002. The Fed regularly makes such purchases to add money to the banking system. **********But it was the Fed's survey of regional business conditions, known as the beige book, that chiefly bolstered bonds. The survey said that while all 12 Fed districts expanded in May and early June, ''there were pockets of weakness.'' The survey saw labor markets tight, but with little or no wage pressure. **********Bond investors saw the survey as providing more evidence that the economy was slowing. Most market participants expect the Fed will hold rates steady at the July 1-2 meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee, the Fed's policy-making panel. **********Still, ''You couldn't call it broad- based participation,'' Robert Pugliese, senior vice president and director of fixed income at J. W. Charles Securities Inc. of Boca Raton, Fla., said of the rally. ''The beige book failed to present anything new that would keep the Fed from remaining neutral,'' he said. ''It could have gone the other way, as the market chose to ignore some of the negatives and concentrate on the positives.'' **********Increases in interest rates are expected for later in the year and into 1998 for two reasons, said the WEFA Group, an economic forecasting company in Bala-Cynwyd, Pa. First, the second-quarter slowdown in growth is in all likelihood just a temporary pause, with growth likely to rebound strongly in the second half of the year. Second, and more significant, tight labor markets seem likely to result in larger wage increases and more rapidly rising labor costs, which are then likely to make their way into consumer prices and somewhat higher inflation. **********As a result, WEFA forecast that the Fed's target for the Federal funds rate, which banks charge each other for overnight loans, will be increased to 6 percent from 5.50 percent by year-end and to 6.50 percent by the middle of next year. **********Elsewhere, the Treasury announced the size of its two-year and five-year note auctions for next week. On Tuesday the Government will sell $15.5 billion of new two-year maturities and on Wednesday, $11.5 billion of notes with a five-year maturity. In when-issued trading ahead of the auctions, the two-year note was being offered at a price to yield 6.02 percent and the five-year note at a price to yield 6.28 percent. **********Today the Treasury will sell $13 billion of new one-year bills through auction. By late yesterday, the rate of a one-year bill was 5.32 percent. **********In the municipal bond market, prices were little changed as states and local governments sold a total of about $2.3 billion of new securities, led by Los Angeles County's $1.3 billion of one-year tax and revenue anticipation notes through Merrill Lynch. The notes were tentatively priced to yield 3.8 percent.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/27/busin.snippet: Deutsche Bank AG reports setting aside $710 million in 1996 to reimburse customers and pay potential fines arising from previously disclosed irregularities by fund manager at its Morgan Grenfell Asset Management unit (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/27/busin.main_headline: Deutsche Bank Sets Fund for Irregularities
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/27/busin.print_headline: Deutsche Bank Sets Fund for Irregularities
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/27/busin.body_text: **********Deutsche Bank A.G. said today that it set aside 1.2 billion marks, or $710 million, last year to reimburse customers and pay potential fines arising from the previously disclosed irregularities by a fund manager at its Morgan Grenfell Asset Management subsidiary. **********The bank, Europe's largest, said the costs associated with Morgan Grenfell, as well as restructuring costs, weighed down 1996 net income, which rose 4.6 percent, to 2.218 billion marks. Before those items were included, operating profit increased 38 percent, to 5.8 billion marks. **********''The 1.2 billion marks reflects the precautions we took in connection with the damages at Morgan Grenfell Asset Management,'' Deutsche Bank's chief executive, Hilmar Kopper, said in a statement. ''Those are offset by profits from investments of roughly the same amount.'' **********Deutsche Bank dismissed the Morgan Grenfell fund manager, Peter Young, in September for violating limits on the amount of unlisted securities he placed in funds he managed. The bank had to buy back the securities and compensate investors. It faces a fine from regulators in Britain, where Morgan Grenfell is based. **********The bank also said that based on results in the first quarter it expected earnings to rise in 1997. That pushed up the bank's shares by 2.42 marks to 93.67 marks in Frankfurt.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/23/busin.snippet: Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Co says earnings in third quarter rose 8.5 percent to $432 million, before gain from sale of billboard business; gain of $495 million resulted in net income of $927 million; revenue in quarter increased 5.6 perce...

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/23/busin.print_headline: 3M Profit Rises 8% As Sales Are Strong
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/23/busin.body_text: **********The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company said today that earnings grew in line with estimates during the third quarter, lifted by strong sales and cost controls. **********The company's profit, before a gain, rose 8.5 percent, to $432 million, or $1.05 a share, from $398 million, or 95 cents a share, a year earlier. **********A gain in the latest quarter of $495 million, or $1.20 a share, from the sale of 3M's billboard business in August resulted in net income of $927 million, or $2.25 a share. In the period a year earlier, operating earnings and net income were the same. **********Analysts had expected 3M to report operating earnings of $1.04 a share. The company's shares rose $5.75, to $100.375 Revenue for 3M, whose products include Post-It notes and Scotch brand tape, increased 5.6 percent, to $3.83 billion from $3.62 billion. **********The company said sales growth exceeded the economic growth rates of the countries in which it operates, aided by the introduction of products. Still, the stronger dollar, which reduces foreign profits when they are converted into the American currency for reporting purposes, lowered per-share earnings by 7 cents, in line with expectations. **********Analysts said 3M was able to improve its margins by keeping expenses under control.

Energetica de Minas Gerais as part of a plan to expand into the Latin American electricity market. Southern, based in Atlanta, and AES,  based in Arlington, Va., bought the 33 percent stake in the regional utility, which is known as Cemig, for 1.13 billion reals ($1.05 billion). Their Brazilian partner is Opportunity Capital Partners Ltda., a Rio de Janeiro fund manager. Cemig serves 4.3 million customers and accounts for 13 percent of Brazil's total electricity sales.
