https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/01/busin.main_headline: Prague Notebook : Floats and Floods:Czech Woes Persist
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/01/busin.print_headline: Prague Notebook : Floats and Floods:Czech Woes Persist
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/01/busin.body_text: **********Three months ago, the Czech Republic government nearly collapsed when the koruna lost over 12 percent in one day, forcing the National Bank to raise interest rates and float the currency. **********The koruna's troubles spotlighted the failure of the Czech government to tackle head-on key economic reforms and massive demand for consumer imports that had left the currency overvalued. **********The result was a government shake-up, budget cuts and a weakening of the economy. Prime Minister Vaclav Klaus introduced a package of reforms and replaced the finance, trade and industry ministers. His coalition government won a vote of confidence by one ballot and promised action on a litany of economic woes: massive current account and trade deficits, a growing budget deficit, high interest rates, falling productivity, a bloated and overpaid industrial workforce, inefficient and indebted industry, and inefficient pension and health-care systems. **********Nearly three months later, almost none of that has happened. Floods that ravaged a fourth of the country in July and caused $2 billion to $3 billion in damage are partly to blame for the delay. Particularly troubling are plans to clean up the capital markets. Economists warn that unless Czech and foreign investors can feel safe investing in Czech stocks, the country will not attract the money it needs for reform. **********"I've seen no progress on making the markets more transparent," said Jack Schrantz, strategist at Raiffeisen Zentralbanken in London. "I've given up hope that they are going to do anything." **********Debate on the 1998 budget begins in mid-September, and opposition Social Democrats say they may call a new vote of confidence. To win, Mr. Klaus will have to cut the deficit and satisfy the subsidy-hungry farmers who support his fractious coalition partners, the Christian Democratic Union, who have hinted they could cross the floor if they do not get what they want.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/18/busin.snippet: Worldcom Inc defends its $34 billion bid for MCI Communications Corp, as Worldcom stock price briefly dips below $34, level that affects offer's value (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/18/busin.main_headline: Plunge in Stocks Puts Worldcom's Offer for MCI at Risk
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/18/busin.print_headline: Plunge in Stocks Puts Worldcom's Offer for MCI at Risk
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/18/busin.body_text: **********In what is fast becoming one of the biggest battles in Wall Street's history, Worldcom Inc. yesterday defended its $34 billion bid for the MCI Communications Corporation, as Worldcom's stock price briefly dipped below $34, a level that affects the value of its offer. **********If the price for Worldcom stock remains below $34, MCI stockholders would get Worldcom shares at a fixed ratio instead of a guaranteed $41.50 of Worldcom stock. That could make Worldcom's bid somewhat less attractive to MCI shareholders. **********A plunge yesterday in the Nasdaq stock market, where Worldcom's stock trades, underscored how fragile a currency such high-technology stocks can be. **********Asked what would happen if the stock dropped below $34, Josh Howell, a senior vice president, said:  ''Our offer provides MCI shareholders with superior near-term and long-term value.'' **********Wall Street analysts speculated yesterday that if there was more pressure on its stock price, Worldcom might soon be forced to rejigger its offer, perhaps supporting its huge stock bid with a cash component. Some estimated that this portion of the bid could easily total several billion dollars, even as much as $8 billion or $10 billion. **********With its audacious bid, Worldcom is trying to continue its record of rapid growth through acquisition. MCI had previously agreed to be acquired by British Telecommunications P.L.C., which then insisted on renegotiating that accord at a lower price, souring relations between the two companies. That prompted Worldcom's bid, which would currently be financed entirely with Worldcom stock. The GTE Corporation emerged this week with a $28 billion competing cash bid. MCI and British Telecom agreed this week that each would allow the other to talk with GTE and Worldcom. **********Worldcom seems confident that the superior performance of its stock in recent years will win over MCI's shareholders. ''Basically, I'd say look at the historical track record of our stock,'' Mr. Howell said. ''By a wide margin, it's the best- performing stock in the telecom industry in the past 10 years. We continue to believe that a three-way agreement between MCI, B.T. and Worldcom is in the best interests of all.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/08/busin.snippet: E I du Pont de Nemours & Co will invest $1.7 billion in Pioneer Hi-Bred International Inc, paying $104 per share for 20 percent of stock and control of two seats on Pioneer's board; move will create powerful rival to Monsanto and others in fast-gr...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/08/busin.main_headline: DuPont to Invest $1.7 Billion in Pioneer Hi-Bred
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/08/busin.print_headline: DuPont to Invest $1.7 Billion in Pioneer Hi-Bred
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/08/busin.body_text: **********E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company said today that it would invest $1.7 billion in Pioneer Hi-Bred International Inc., creating a powerful rival to the Monsanto Company and others in the fast-growing business of genetically engineered agriculture. **********DuPont will pay $104 a share for 20 percent of Pioneer's stock and control two of 15 seats on Pioneer's board. **********The stock of Pioneer, a producer of agricultural seeds, rose sharply today. **********The two companies plan to create one of the world's largest agricultural research and development collaborations, investing more than $400 million next year. Pioneer will also help market DuPont's genetically engineered corn, soybeans and grains. **********''You get a tremendous bang for your buck in an alliance with Pioneer in terms of getting your products to the market,'' said Jonathon Braatz, an analyst at George K. Baum & Company in Kansas City. **********Chemical and pharmaceutical producers like Monsanto, the Dow Chemical Company and Novartis A.G. are making an aggressive push into the agricultural biotechnology industry, which is expected to increase to $20 billion a year by 2010 from almost nothing today. **********Seed companies have become attractive targets as chemical companies look forward to the day when genetically engineered crops reduce the need for pesticides and fertilizers. **********In January, for example, Monsanto agreed to pay $1.02 billion for Holden's Foundation Seeds Inc., a corn-seed company with just $45 million in annual revenue, as part of a larger plan to spin off its chemical business and focus on agricultural products. **********For the Des Moines-based Pioneer, the alliance brings the research capabilities of one of the world's largest chemical companies as well as a much-needed dose of capital. **********''This is a big deal,'' said Timothy Ramey, an analyst at Deutsche Morgan Grenfell. ''For Pioneer shareholders this is a major equity investment at a premium price.'' **********Mr. Ramey said the agreement could propel Pioneer Hi-Bred shares above $100 as the company used the money from DuPont to buy back stock. **********Shares of Pioneer rose $13.875, to $90. DuPont gained 25 cents, to $69. **********DuPont will finance its investment with cash from operations and from borrowings. It expects to take a maximum noncash charge of $1 billion for its investment in Pioneer. **********The Wilmington, Del., company said it expected the investment to dilute its earnings by less than 2 percent next year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/28/busin.main_headline: Aggressive Strategies Pay Off for HFS
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/28/busin.print_headline: Aggressive Strategies Pay Off for HFS
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/28/busin.body_text: **********Since he founded what then was called Hospitality Franchise Systems Inc. in 1990 with the purchase of the Howard Johnson and domestic Ramada Inn franchise systems, Henry R. Silverman, chairman and chief executive of what is now HFS Inc., has been unrelenting in the pursuit of two goals: expanding access to consumers by acquiring new franchises and driving the stock price higher. **********On both counts, he has so far been remarkably successful. By agreeing to merge with CUC International Inc., analysts said, HFS has made a bold move to insure that it will continue to do so for the foreseeable future. **********''This transaction will enable both companies to maintain an unusually high rate of growth for longer than each would have been able to achieve independently,'' said Michael Rietbrock, an analyst with Smith Barney. **********Through an aggressive acquisition strategy, Mr. Silverman has assembled an empire that consists of a loose confederation of brands in related services: rental cars and hotels, real estate and mortgages. **********The string of franchises, put together over the last seven years through the acquisition of such properties as Super 8 Motels and Villager Lodge, Coldwell Banker and Century 21 Real Estate and Avis Inc., has generated mushrooming growth for HFS and earned it dedicated fans on Wall Street. **********Last year, the company earned $169.6 million, a 113 percent increase from 1995 net income. Revenue increased 93 percent, to $799 million. **********''HFS has a phenomenal collection of consumer platforms,'' said Neil Barsky, an analyst with Morgan Stanley & Company. ''And over the last five years, Henry Silverman has been one of the greatest creators of shareholder value. No chief executive I know of has done a better job of that.'' **********Few could dispute that last assertion: since its initial public offering in December 1992, at $4 a share, the price of HFS stock, after adjusting for splits, has risen fortyfold. The stock, which is traded on the New York Stock Exchange, closed yesterday before the announcement of the merger at $59, up $2. **********So far this year, Mr. Silverman had shown no sign of changing his strategy: he has struck a deal with the Hilton Hotels Corporation to acquire the franchising rights to Sheraton Hotels should Hilton succeed in its $6.5 billion hostile takeover bid for the ITT Corporation. **********HFS is also said to be in talks to buy the Signature Group, a direct marketing business, from the Montgomery Ward Holding Corporation for more than $1 billion in cash. **********Even as HFS rapidly builds its consumer businesses, it is still trying to figure out how to sell one franchisee's wares to the customer of another franchisee, analysts said, to get a Ramada Inn customer, for example, to rent a car from Avis. **********Mr. Silverman agreed. **********''From our standpoint, we were having difficulty in fully exploiting our capabilities,'' he said yesterday. **********CUC, on the other hand, reaches around 68 million consumers through its discount clubs, and is a company ''that truly knows how to market to consumers,'' Mr. Barsky, the Morgan Stanley analyst, said. **********''It would have taken HFS years to develop the skills that CUC already has,'' Mr. Barsky said. ''This merger accelerates HFS's business plan by several years.'' **********Indeed, even though the merger was billed as a marriage of equals, and Mr. Silverman and Walter A. Forbes, CUC's chairman and chief executive, will take turns running the merged company as president and chief executive, analysts are assuming Mr. Silverman will be first among equals. **********What was hailed as a bold strategic move might look somewhat different if the creator of HFS turned his attentions elsewhere. **********''It is very important to the Street that Henry remain active in the business,'' Mr. Rietbrock from Smith Barney said. ''It is very clear-cut that the market wants him to stay involved.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/31/busin.snippet: Europe's preparations for a single currency had the added benefit of smoothing the backlash from the financial turmoil rocking Southeast Asia, according to the European commissioner in charge of economic and financial affairs. . Yves-Thibault de S...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/31/busin.main_headline: EU's Monetary Commissioner Sees Stable Road Ahead for Single Currency : Asia Crisis Gives Euro Policies a Test Run
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/31/busin.print_headline: EU's Monetary Commissioner Sees Stable Road Ahead for Single Currency : Asia Crisis Gives Euro Policies a Test Run
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/31/busin.body_text: **********Europe's preparations for a single currency had the added benefit of smoothing the backlash from the financial turmoil rocking Southeast Asia, according to the European commissioner in charge of economic and financial affairs. **********Yves-Thibault de Silguy said that in contrast with the December 1994 financial crisis in Mexico, which had a rapid effect on Europe, the stock-market crisis that began in Hong Kong and rippled around the world has had little effect on Europe's main economic indicators. **********Even before the scheduled adoption of Europe's single currency, the euro, 14 months from now, the European economy is "better protected against international exchange movements," which is proof that monetary union will provide "stability in the international monetary and financial system," Mr. de Silguy said in an interview. **********Central banks have held firm on interest rates, and analysts have said the current world stock market correction is unlikely to have a significant impact on European growth prospects. Mr. de Silguy said the European Commission's upward revision of its economic forecasts for this year and next "shows that efforts to achieve sound public finances are beginning to bear fruit in Europe." **********He said, "This is translated into more growth and more possibilities to reduce unemployment, and it shows that the markets have integrated the euro." **********European economies are growing despite efforts to reduce public deficits to meet the single-currency criteria, Mr. de Silguy said. "We are feeling the effects of the euro even before it is has been formally introduced," he said. **********He said this had enabled those who had worked to put the euro in place "to transform an act of faith into an act of confidence." Uncertainty about the ability of several countries to meet the single-currency criteria has given way to a virtual assurance that monetary union will begin on time Jan. 1, 1999, with a broad group of as much as 11 countries. **********Lending credibility to the monetary system, governments have said they will announce the rates at which their currencies will convert to the euro as soon as member countries are selected in May. Meanwhile, central banks recently moved smoothly to align exchange rates in the kind of action that will become routine once the euro is introduced. **********He added that markets would decide whether the euro would become a reserve currency like the dollar. **********"You cannot impose a currency," he said. "But I think this will be a good currency, a stable currency. It will be strong and in demand and will be included in national reserves. Since 1980, the proportion of the dollar in world reserves has fallen and the share of the European currencies has increased, so the euro will continue a movement that is already there." **********Along with Denmark and Sweden, Britain has said it will not join the first wave of countries joining the euro, and Greece is unlikely to meet the criteria for membership. But although they will be excluded from a proposed council of euro members, Mr. de Silguy said, "exactly the same rules will apply to the first and subsequent waves." **********In any event, he said, Britain played an active role in the planning and preparation for the euro and will hold the presidency of the EU in the first half of next year, a period of crucial decision-making for the currency, including the selection of new members. **********He added: "Once the euro has been launched, I think there will effectively be more advantages in than out. The euro zone will have a character of attraction, of encouragement, of development, and those outside will benefit less," although they too will reap the benefits of financial and economic stability in Europe. **********The euro "will lead to greater integration," he said. "It will give more growth and confidence to Europe, and it will give Europeans, once they have the same banknotes in their wallets, the sentiment that they have a common existence. The concept of Europe will therefore become more concrete. Europe will have a more coherent economic policy. It will not be a federation, since the member states will keep responsibility for economic policy, but their individual margin for action will be restricted considerably."

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/21/world.snippet: Proposal to enlarge United Nations Security Council from its present 15 members to 24 is presented by Razali Ismail, General Assembly President who is chairman of panel that has been studying ways to reform Council (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/21/world.main_headline: U.N. Panel Proposes Expanding Security Council to 24 Members
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/21/world.print_headline: U.N. Panel Proposes Expanding Security Council to 24 Members
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/21/world.body_text: **********A proposal to enlarge the United Nations Security Council from its present 15 members to 24 was presented today by the chairman of a panel that has been studying ways to reform the Council for three years. **********Of the nine new seats being proposed for the Council, five would be permanent members and four would rotate in two-year terms. The new permanent members would not, however, have the veto power currently given to the five original permanent members -- the United States, Britain, France, Russia and China. **********The proposal, by Razali Ismail of Malaysia, who is also President of the General Assembly, represents a compromise on the highly sensitive issue of the composition of the agency charged with maintaining international peace and security. **********The plan calls for the election of two new permanent Council members from the industrial world. These two new seats would probably go to Germany and Japan. The other three new permanent members would be drawn from Africa, Asia and Latin America respectively. **********To be elected, all five new permanent members would need the votes of two-thirds of the 185 nations in the General Assembly. **********Mexico, Brazil and Argentina all want the Latin American seat; India, Pakistan and Indonesia are seeking the Asian seat; Nigeria, Egypt and South Africa all want the African seat. **********The four new non-permanent seats would also be chosen by a two-thirds majority of the General Assembly, one each from Eastern Europe, Africa, Asia and Latin America. **********Mr. Razali said ''an overwhelming number'' of members consider the veto right of the five current permanent members ''achachronistic and undemocratic.'' He said he was seeking ''to discourage use of the veto by urging the original permanent members of the Security Council to limit the exercise of their veto power to actions taken under Chapter VII of the Charter.'' **********This chapter allows the Council to take military action against countries found guilty of aggression. It was the chapter by which the United Nations authorized the use of force against Iraq in the Persian Gulf war. **********Several countries welcomed Mr. Rizali's plan as a good basis for negotiation, but said the proposal went too far and risked producing an unwieldy Council incapable of taking decisions. **********The alternative United States delegate, Karl F. Inderfurth, called it ''a major effort to move the difficult issue of Security Council reform forward.'' But, he said, ''an expansion to 20 to 21 members is the largest appropriate to preserve the Council's ability to respond effectively to what are often urgent demands.'' **********Britain's representative, Sir John Weston, took a similar line, saying that ''the size of the Council envisaged in the proposal is too large.'' **********Italy strongly opposes the plan because it does not want to see Germany become a permanent member unless it becomes one, too. The Italian representative, Francesco Paolo Fulci, said the proposal would create a train with 175 nations ''crowded into third class.'' **********Mr. Rizali is asking the General Assembly to approve the plan in principle by September and to choose the new permanent Council members by next March. **********Since enlarging the Security Council means amending the United Nations Charter, adoption of the plan requires the support of two-thirds of the General Assembly and ratification by the national legislatures of two-thirds of all members. **********The last Security Council expansion was in 1965, when the number of non-permanent members was raised from 6 to 10.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/27/busin.snippet: Growing debate over global warming, as well as El Nino phenomenon and intense smog over Southeast Asia, pushes environmental issues to forefront of news and onto many World Wide Web sites (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/27/busin.main_headline: Taking In the Sites; Environmental Issues Are Clarified
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/27/busin.print_headline: Taking In the Sites; Environmental Issues Are Clarified
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/27/busin.body_text: **********The growing debate over global warming, as well as the El Nino phenomenon and the intense smog over Southeast Asia, has pushed environmental issues to the forefront of the news. Beyond the immediate headlines, though, there is plenty of information available about the environment on the World Wide Web. **********''Environmental information is one the most exhaustive content areas on the Web,'' said Pranay Gupte, the editor of The Earth Times, which covers environmental issues. ''But much of it is confusing and not well organized, so it's easy to get overwhelmed by it all.'' **********He said much of the information on the Web was contradictory and ideologically driven. To try to clarify the situation, The Earth Times offers its own Web site, with articles from the paper as well as original pieces, focusing on issues like sustainable development on a global scale. **********The Envirolink site is one of the largest on-line resources. The site, which got its start in 1991 as an E-mail mailing list about the environment out of Carnegie Mellon University, features news sources, data bases, bulletin boards, chat rooms and links to other nonprofit organizations. A featured item this week: ''Your Clothing Is Killing You'' (a plea for organic clothing). **********The Environmental Protection Agency is another logical place to visit. The agency has a fairly sophisticated site that is constantly updated and aimed at a variety of audiences. **********For businesses, of course, making sense of complicated environmental laws is not easy. An attempt to make them easier to understand can be found at the site of the Environmental Compliance Assistance Center, a partnership of the E.P.A., industry and Front Range Community College in Colorado. **********The Pace University School of Law's Global Warming Central site focuses on the debate on global warming and provides useful data and links for understanding the controversial issues. **********The Environmental News Network, which bills itself as ''the environmental science supersite,'' provides news culled from various media outlets. The site also offers audio reports using Real Audio software, and users can sign up for a free E-mail newsletter. **********Two other comprehensive sources of environmental information are the sites of the World Wildlife Fund (which offers a free screen saver and a nature quiz) and the World Resources Institute, a research group in Washington. **********One place to find environmental sites is the search engine Yahoo, which has special sections dedicated to El Nino and smog. **********Given the nature of those involved in environmental issues, it is not surprising that advocacy plays an important role in many sites. Take the Environmental Defense Fund site, for example. It covers subjects like ''Reversing Decline of New England Fisheries,'' ''Something to Hide: The Sorry State of Plastics Recycling'' and ''Global Warming: Our Nation's Capital at Risk.'' A timely page even deals with tips for a ''green Halloween'' (among them: trick-or-treating with pillow cases and canvas bags instead of plastic bags and composting leftover jack-o'-lanterns). **********The Natural Resources Defense Council site allows visitors to send E-mail queries to its experts on environmental subjects and provides links to other organizations that are environmentally friendly. **********The site of the Sierra Club, the nation's largest grass-roots environmental group, also has information about protecting the Earth and details of the organization's Chico Mendes award, which is named after the late Brazilian environmentalist. **********The National Wildlife Federation's site offers a section for colleges and tips on how students can get involved in conservation and other ecological issues. **********Greenpeace, the environmental advocacy group, uses its site to promote its activities in a not-so-subtle way, outlining various campaigns against pollution, nuclear weapons and hazardous chemicals. **********While most advocacy groups campaign against problems that they attribute to businesses, there are companies that favor environmental restraint. The Greenmoney On-line Guide, which promotes ''responsibility from the supermarket to the stock market,'' has articles about, and links to, companies that are ''green friendly.'' **********Environmentally conscious tourism, or eco-tourism, is also represented on the Web. Try The Ecotourism Society's site and its guidelines for ''socially responsible travel.'' **********The death of the singer John Denver in a plane accident earlier this month has also drawn considerable attention to the environmental issues he championed. The Windstar Foundation, which Mr. Denver co-founded, has a site that explains those issues and the group's goals, as well as providing details about Mr. Denver's life as an environmentalist. **********Of course, there is another side to environmental advocacy. One of the sites with a conservative point of view is global warming.org, which is part of the National Consumer Coalition. Visitors can learn about ''Global Warming Science and Policy Scam'' and how ''Al Gore Proposes Birth Control and Abortion to Stop Global Warming.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/11/busin.snippet: Article on major areas expected to be in tax bill, with some of issues that could arise as lawmakers strive to keep down total cost to Government; topics discussed include changes in capital gains tax, individual retirement accounts, estate taxes,...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/11/busin.main_headline: To Sell Stock or Not: A Guide to the Budget Vigil
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/11/busin.print_headline: To Sell Stock or Not: A Guide to the Budget Vigil
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/11/busin.body_text: **********IT'S safe to sell stocks now and take profits, the top Republican Congressional tax writers say. If you do, you'll get the best tax deal available this year. **********On the other hand, maybe you won't. Maybe the best deal will be available only if you sell later. **********And what will that deal be? Nobody is saying because nobody knows. **********The tax deal worked out between Congressional Republicans and President Clinton is unique in that it has an agreement on only one item: the cost to the Government. That is supposed to be $135 billion over five years. **********Unfortunately for taxpayers who are trying to make plans, the costs of the various proposals that Republicans and the President are pushing add up to a whole lot more than the budget limit. And that is creating a series of fights -- the kind you get when there is only so much to go around and everybody wants more. **********A likely result is that while capital gains taxes are likely to be reduced, the bill that passes will be much less generous to investors than the original proposals. **********For about 18 hours last week, it looked as though the effective date of a capital gains tax cut was set, even if nothing else was. After the market closed on Wednesday -- a day when the Dow Jones industrial average plunged 139 points -- the chairmen of the two tax-writing committees, Representative Bill Archer, Republican of Texas, and Senator William V. Roth Jr., Republican of Delaware, announced that any capital gains tax cut would be effective for sales made that day, May 7, or later. **********But the next morning, Senator Tom Daschle, Democrat of South Dakota and the  minority leader, said that might not be true. It was not part of the original deal, he said, and was therefore subject to negotiation. **********So if you sell now, you may or may not get a lower tax rate. Robert Willens, a tax expert at Lehman Brothers, recommends that if investors want to take gains now, they should play it safe by using a technique called shorting against the box. In this method, an investor borrows the same number of shares in a company that he or she already owns and sells them, while holding onto the original shares. Such maneuvers will probably be outlawed under the bill, but they are still legal now. **********The following are the major areas expected to be in a tax bill, with some of the issues that could arise as lawmakers strive to keep down the total cost to the Government. **********CAPITAL GAINS The Republican proposal on capital gains has been for a long-term tax rate of half of any taxpayer's ordinary income tax rate. Currently, most investors pay 28 percent on long-term gains, although those whose ordinary rate is less than 28 percent pay that lower rate. The top marginal tax rate is 39.6 percent, so taxpayers in that group would pay a capital gains rate of 19.8 percent under the Republican proposal; for those in the 28 percent bracket, the rate would be 14 percent. **********Under these rate reductions, middle-class investors would get a better deal than those with the highest incomes. Their capital gains rate would be cut in half, while that of the big folks would fall by only 30 percent (from 28 percent to 19.6 percent). Of course, most of the capital gains go to those in the highest brackets. **********In the budget talks, games could be played to make that cut less generous. The Government could lengthen the long-term holding period, which is now one year. (Short-term capital gains are taxed at ordinary income tax rates.) Or it could put in a variety of holding periods, so that the longer the period, the lower the rate. Or the top rate could be cut only to 22 percent or 24 percent, instead of to 19.6 percent. **********Another method being bandied about would be to make the capital gains break subject to the alternative minimum tax, which allows fewer deductions and exemptions than the regular income tax. That would mean that some taxpayers would get little if any benefit from lower capital gains rates. **********The current law is that if you have net capital losses -- that is, more capital losses than capital gains -- you can take $3,000 of those losses as an offset against ordinary income. That could be abolished or, more likely, reduced by saying that you would need $6,000 of losses to offset $3,000 of income. **********It also appears likely that at least some of President Clinton's proposals to reduce what he views as evasion of capital gains will be included in the bill. These would include barring shorting against the box, and a possible attack on other Wall Street devices for accomplishing the same aim. **********The big revenue raiser in the package -- which would free up more money for other cuts -- could be to adopt his proposal for using average-cost accounting in computing gains. Now, for example, if you have 200 shares of Microsoft -- 100 bought for $50 in 1995 and 100 bought for $20 in 1993 -- and sell 100 shares for $120 each, you could say the ones you sold were the ones bought in 1995, and report a profit of $70 a share. But averaging would make you compute an average cost of $35, and give you a profit of $85 a share. **********If capital gains rates are cut, some individuals might want to reconsider holding stocks in tax-advantaged accounts like individual retirement accounts and 401(k) plans. Those plans have no tax as profits are made, but they are taxed -- at ordinary rates -- when the money is paid out after retirement. For investors who own both bonds and stocks, it might make sense to have more bonds in tax-protected accounts, and more stocks in regular accounts. In those accounts, ordinary income taxes would be owed on dividends, but any capital gains would be taxed at the lower rate. **********Another provision that could survive would expand the maximum exclusion for profits from the sale of a home, from $125,000 for people aged 55 and over to $500,000 for a couple filing jointly regardless of age. **********I.R.A.'S Currently, many individuals cannot contribute pretax dollars to an I.R.A. Senator Roth, in particular, has pushed for an expanded I.R.A. open to all. That could be a huge revenue loser, and if it survives at all, it is likely to be scaled back, perhaps with a phase-in period. **********One way to provide a big break, without costing the Government much in the early years, would be through a back-end I.R.A. That would involve contributing post-tax dollars to the I.R.A., but then not paying tax on the money when it was withdrawn. In effect, such I.R.A.'s would be treated like investments in municipal bonds. The cost to the Government would be big, but only in later years when many people were retiring. **********ESTATE TAXES The Republicans have talked about doubling the estate tax exclusion from $600,000 to $1.2 million. That would mean that millions of estates would pay no estate tax. But it would also be costly. A way to ease its budget impact would be to phase it in over several years. **********KIDDIE CREDITS One of the Republicans' favorite proposals is to give parents a tax credit of $500 a child. Again, this package may be too costly to the Government without some modification. The current proposal removes such a credit for couples making more than $110,000 a year. That income figure could come down. And the credit could be phased in, to delay the cost. **********EDUCATION PROVISIONS President Clinton wants tax code provisions to make college more affordable. He says $35 billion of the $135 billion in tax cuts should be earmarked for such college programs. The Republicans say they never promised that amount, although they agreed to try. His proposals would provide a tax deduction of up to $10,000 for college tuition and a $1,500 tuition tax credit for some students for each of the first two years.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/26/busin.snippet: Coca-Cola Co returns to 'hunk' theme by airing television commercial for Diet Coke that tells role-reversal tale about women ogling hunky man (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/26/busin.main_headline: Diet Coke Returns To Its Hunk Theme
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/26/busin.print_headline: Diet Coke Returns To Its Hunk Theme
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/26/busin.body_text: **********The Coca-Cola Company is hoping to get lucky again with a television commercial for Diet Coke that tells a role-reversal tale about women ogling a hunky man. **********The spot, introduced Monday night during the ABC broadcast of the Academy Awards, shows the man delivering cases of Diet Coke to an office filled with female workers; he is unaware of the admiration he is eliciting from them. The plot is evocative of a popular Diet Coke commercial from 1994 that centered on women ogling a construction worker from their office windows. That spot, and a 1995 sequel, turned a model named Lucky Vanous into a celebrity who subsequently made promotional appearances for Diet Coke. **********The new commercial, featuring a Canadian actor and athlete named Paul Johansson, was created by the Milan, Italy, office of the Leo Burnett Company. Though Burnett handles the Diet Coke account only in Italy, ''we thought it was a fun premise that was worth'' broader exposure, Kari Bjorhus, a spokeswoman for Coca-Cola in Atlanta, said yesterday. The spot was introduced in markets like France and Spain before coming to America, she added; the company will run it in Britain next month. **********Lowe & Partners/SMS in New York, a unit of the Interpublic Group  of Companies, continues as Diet Coke's agency of record, Ms. Bjorhus said. Lowe has created several spots, featuring new Diet Coke packaging and redesigned graphics, which began running last month.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/21/busin.snippet: Ignoring pleas from industry, the German Parliament's finance committee on Friday stepped toward resolving the budget crisis by proposing to scrap tax breaks for German companies next year as part of the government's tax-reform plans.. Finance Min...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/21/busin.main_headline: Industry Objects to Waigel's Latest Budget Proposal : Bonn Takes Aim at Tax Breaks
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/21/busin.print_headline: Industry Objects to Waigel's Latest Budget Proposal : Bonn Takes Aim at Tax Breaks
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/21/busin.body_text: **********Ignoring pleas from industry, the German Parliament's finance committee on Friday stepped toward resolving the budget crisis by proposing to scrap tax breaks for German companies next year as part of the government's tax-reform plans. **********Finance Minister Theo Waigel is counting on more than 4 billion Deutsche marks ($2.31 billion) in supplementary tax income next year from the plan, funds that are desperately needed to rescue Bonn's bid to join Europe's single currency in 1999 and ease strains among parties within the government of Chancellor Helmut Kohl. **********After Mr. Waigel unleashed a firestorm of criticism with other unsuccessful attempts to patch Bonn's deficits, he is now seeking a heavier business tax load as part of a broad package of unconventional budget measures that include selling oil from emergency stockpiles, sales of the government's stake in the national phone company, and another round of budget cuts from ministries. **********Significantly, his plans do not include actual tax increases, at least for now. The Free Democratic Party, Mr. Kohl's junior coalition partner, has threatened to leave the government if Mr. Waigel raises taxes. **********But Mr. Waigel still faces an uphill battle in pushing through his reforms. **********Mr. Waigel, who canceled his trip to Denver this weekend for the summit meeting of the world's biggest industrial powers, stayed in Bonn to continue consultations to win support for his latest measures. The search for cash already has put Mr. Waigel on a collision course with the powerful German central bank, which blocked him from repricing the nation's gold reserves as a way to raise money. **********The budget crisis, which has brought the government closer to collapse than any other time in its 14-year history, comes as Mr. Kohl's popularity has slipped in the polls. Mr. Kohl now trails the leading challenger from the opposition Social Democratic Party, Gerhard Schroeder, by a 2-to-1 margin, according a monthly survey by the Electoral Research Group. Only 30 percent of voters supported Mr. Kohl, down from 42 percent in May, the poll found. **********The government has until July 11 to agree on a comprehensive package to fill an estimated 27 billion DM hole this year and a 32 billion DM gap forecast for next year. **********Criticism of Mr. Waigel's budget management continued on Friday. **********The Federation of German Industry, the nation's premier business lobby, lashed out at the latest plans to add to the already burdensome tax load carried by German business. The federation accused Mr. Waigel of threatening German jobs, particularly for small and medium-sized business that cannot afford a tax increase. In particular, the federation criticized Mr. Waigel's plans to diminish tax write-offs at loss-making companies. **********The Berlin-based German Institute for Economic Research objected to another of Mr. Waigel's "accounting tricks," a revaluation of German dollar reserves. Heiner Flassbeck, chief economist at the institute, charged Bonn with conducting "a currency and economic policy bordering on the limits of respectability." **********There is no guarantee that the European Union will recognize windfall profits from the revaluation as a way to reduce the deficit when it chooses which countries qualify for currency union, since this breached the principle of sustainability, Mr. Flassbeck said. **********Rolf Peffekoven, a government economic adviser, said there was little chance the plans for the dollar reserves would improve Bonn's financial crisis. "We need lasting and solid finances and this has not been achieved through this," he said in a television interview.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/22/busin.snippet: Funds Watch column warns that typical foreign funds fail to deliver the promised diversification benefits; some funds recommended (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/22/busin.body_text: **********Because of the strong run-up in the United States stock market, investors may be eager to add to their stakes in overseas markets, expecting more value abroad. But they won't achieve the diversification benefits promised by advisers if they buy shares in the typical foreign fund, warns Tricia O. Rothschild in a recent edition of Morningstar Mutual Funds. **********Here is why, according to Ms. Rothschild, the international editor of the newsletter: Asset-allocation formulas that show the advantages of diversification are usually based on the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index (the proxy for United States stock markets) and the Morgan Stanley Europe, Australia and Far East index (the proxy for overseas markets). While the S.& P. is a good marker of large-cap American equity funds, the average foreign stock fund looks nothing like the Morgan Stanley EAFE. The primary reason, Ms. Rothschild explains, is that the Japanese market accounts for nearly one-third of the EAFE, but less than 20 percent of the average foreign fund. Japanese markets, quirky though they may be, tend not to move in close relationship to United States markets. **********So it's no wonder that foreign funds fail to deliver the promised diversification benefits. Over the last five years, the S.& P. index showed declines in 15 months, while the average foreign fund lost money in 80 percent of those months, too. And returns can be disappointing: the average foreign fund has not performed as well as the EAFE over the last 20 years. **********Ms. Rothschild says a small group of foreign funds holds out the possibility of better diversification: international small-capitalization funds, a relatively new group that focuses on smaller companies that aren't tied to multinational trends. Such funds are also more likely to hold stocks in emerging markets. And when the United States stock market has struggled, the foreign small caps have held up slightly better than their larger-cap cousins. **********None of this means that diversified international funds can't make great investments, she says. Funds like GAM International, EuroPacific Growth and Templeton Foreign are in the top 15 percent of all funds for the last decade. But for diversification, she says, investors should look closely at their international choices. **********Wage Pressure At the Top **********American workers may be gaining only slightly on the wage front, but the top officers of mutual fund companies are doing quite well. **********The median income for chief executives of mutual fund companies rose 18.4 percent in 1996, compared with 30 percent the previous year, according to Fund Action, an industry newsletter in New York. The findings are based on information from 15 publicly held fund companies that are required to disclose such data to the Securities and Exchange Commission. **********The median income, including base salary and short-term bonuses, was $1.45 million, up from $1.23 million in 1995 at the surveyed companies. **********Other executives are also faring well. Chief financial officers of fund companies enjoyed the biggest spike in income, 34 percent, to a median of $745,000 last year. **********Inner Circle At Fidelity **********The Spartan Gold Circle program from Fidelity Investments provides deep discounts, fee waivers and a service guarantee for investors who trade at least 72 times a year and maintain a balance of at least $20,000. **********These traders pay a flat commission of $25 on stock trades of up to 1,000 shares, and receive a 25 percent discount off regular Spartan rates on options trades. Fees for bank wires and transfers and for certain other services are waived. Investors who are not satisfied with their customer service can write to Fidelity within 30 days, requesting a waiver of the commission. **********Fund Managers **********Warren Isabelle left Pioneer Capital Management to join the Evergreen Keystone funds in January and to take over Keystone Omega from Maureen Cullinane. But Mr. Isabelle has now departed Keystone to start his own money management firm, and Ms. Cullinane continues to run Omega. **********New Funds **********Guardian Park Avenue Small Cap, which aims to buy stocks of companies with average market capitalizations of less than $1 billion, will be managed by Charles E. Albers, who runs the Guardian Park Avenue fund, and Larry Luxenberg, a securities analyst who has worked with him for 14 years. Guardian Baillie Gifford Emerging Markets will be managed by Guardian Baillie Gifford, a partnership between Guardian and Baillie Gifford Overseas, a subsidiary of a British investment management firm. The sales charge is 4.5 percent. **********Commerce Growth and Income aims for capital appreciation and current income by investing in undervalued companies with market capitalizations of more than $500 million and with a dividend yield exceeding that of the S.& P. 500-stock index. The fund expects to have significant weightings in utility, financial and energy stocks. The sales charge is 3.5 percent. **********Boston Partners Mid Cap Value looks for long-term growth of capital, and secondarily for current income, by investing mainly in a diversified portfolio of companies that have market capitalizations of $200 million to $4 billion. The minimum investment for institutional shares is $100,000, and the minimum for individuals is $2,500. **********Variable Annuities **********Phoenix Home Life Mutual Insurance has added four Templeton funds for investors in its variable annuities: Developing Markets, run by Mark Mobius; Asset Allocation; Stock, and International. **********John Hancock Funds Declaration Variable Annuity has added the John Hancock Financial Industries fund, managed by James Schmidt. **********In Brief **********Joan Binstock, formerly national director of investment management regulatory consulting with Ernst & Young, has joined Morgan Grenfell Capital Management as executive vice president and chief operating officer, a new post. **********Mainstay Convertible has closed to new investors, but existing shareholders can continue to buy shares.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/09/world.snippet: Nenad Dusan Popovic, leading economic expert in Tito's Communist Yugoslavia who defected in 1961 to teach and write in exile at Syracuse University, died on Feb 25 at age 87 (M)è
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/09/world.main_headline: Nenad Dusan Popovic, 87, Aide To Tito Who Defected to West
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/09/world.print_headline: Nenad Dusan Popovic, 87, Aide To Tito Who Defected to West
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/09/world.body_text: **********Nenad Dusan Popovic, a leading economic expert in Tito's Communist Yugoslavia who defected in 1961 to teach and write in exile at Syracuse University, died on Feb. 25 of bone cancer at his home on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. He was 87. **********Professor Popovic was chief of economic affairs in the Yugoslav Foreign Ministry when he took refuge, making him one of the highest-ranking Yugoslav officials to defect to the West. Part of his mission was to negotiate loans and credits for the Yugoslav Government. **********By his own account he had become thoroughly disillusioned with the Communist system and had planned a getaway with his family for some years. Once securely in this country, he accepted a professorship at the Maxwell School of Citizenship and Public Affairs at Syracuse. **********He taught comparative socialist and Western economics and the economics of less-developed countries. He received emeritus status as professor of international political economy in 1975 but continued to teach until about 10 years ago. **********He wrote in Serbo-Croatian and English, translating the authors Louis Bromfield and Somerset Maugham into his native tongue. **********In 1968 he published ''Yugoslavia: The New Class in Crisis,'' an echo of Milovan Djilas's caustic analysis of a self-perpetuating upper crust in an ostensibly classless system. In Mr. Popovic's version, power began to shift from clique to Communist clique with the entire system bound to crumble. **********Nenad Popovic was born in Sremska Mitrovica, Serbia, then part of the Austro-Hungarian Empire. He received a law degree from Belgrade University in 1932 and started a career as a banker and banking writer during the period of political turmoil between the world wars. **********The experience, he said later, left him dazzled by the social revolution in the Soviet Union. He joined the Communist Party, sub rosa, before World War II and spent most of the war as a German prisoner, only to be shunned by the Communists because of his bourgeois upbringing. **********Among other sins, he was a godson of the Archduke Franz Ferdinand of Austria-Hungary, whose assassination in 1914 in Sarajevo touched off World War I. **********Though he was banished from the Communist Party, connections nonetheless allowed Mr. Popovic to write under a pseudonym for the party newspaper Borba until his column's popularity brought him official rehabilitation. **********He served as an economic planner and vice president of the State Economic Council of Serbia, then part of Yugoslavia, before being detached in 1950 to the International Monetary Fund in Washington. He was also among the experts at the United Nations and in Paris who set up the International Development Agency and the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development. **********He is survived by his wife of 48 years, Tatyana; two daughters, Gina Goldhammer and Sanya Popovic-Bogdanich, both of Manhattan, and a grandson.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/20/busin.snippet: American Airlines and its pilots' union agree in principle on new contract, easing strike threat; accord must still be approved by Allied Pilots Association board and by union's members, who rejected previous accord in Jan; includes concession by ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/20/busin.main_headline: AMERICAN AIRLINES AND PILOTS REACH TENTATIVE ACCORD
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/20/busin.print_headline: AMERICAN AIRLINES AND PILOTS REACH TENTATIVE ACCORD
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/20/busin.body_text: **********American Airlines and negotiators from its pilots' union reached an agreement in principle yesterday on terms of a new contract, making another strike by the pilots somewhat less likely. **********But two significant hurdles remain to reaching a final agreement, and those uncertainties may give pause to travelers making plans to fly on American in late April, when a strike may still take place. **********The board of the Allied Pilots Association must vote on the deal, which it is scheduled to consider tomorrow or Saturday. If the board accepts the agreement, it must still be approved by a vote of the union's 9,000 members, who rejected a previous agreement in January. **********Although the latest agreement would provide higher compensation for the pilots than the rejected one, it also includes a concession by the union negotiators on which pilots will fly the small commuter jets that the airline wants to buy. This has been the central issue in the labor dispute. **********The agreement comes more than a month after a brief strike by the pilots was halted by President Clinton, who appointed a three-member board of mediators to work with the two sides to loosen them from their entrenched positions. The mediators submitted their report to President Clinton yesterday. **********Donald J. Carty, president of American Airlines, said: ''We are pleased to have a deal. While it does not give us all we had hoped for, we very much wanted to resolve this matter.'' **********People familiar with details of the negotiations said the two sides had reached an agreement in principle that was different, and somewhat better for the pilots, than what was recommended by the mediators. **********Although some details are still being refined, the agreement calls for the pilots to receive raises totaling 9 percent over the life of the contract, which would be in effect through 2001. In addition, the pilots would receive a large number of stock options. The company would also eliminate by the end of the contract a second-tier wage scale that dates back to early 1980's and has been criticized by American's pilots. **********In return for higher compensation, negotiators for the pilots' union have given up ground on the controversial issue of which pilots will fly the so-called regional jets that American wants to buy. These jets would replace turboprop planes on shorter, commuter routes between smaller and midsized cities. **********American has insisted that it will be at a competitive disadvantage if its higher-paid pilots at the main airline fly the smaller regional jets, because the commuter operations at other airlines like Delta are already flying these planes. Instead, it wants them to be flown by the lesser-paid pilots at the American Eagle subsidiary of the AMR Corporation, American's parent company. **********But the Allied Pilots Associaton has maintained that its members should fly the jets. The impasse over this issue led to the pilots' strike at American last month. **********The agreement in principle now calls for American Eagle pilots to fly the regional jets, but American executives have apparently tried to make this concession more palatable by, among other things, building restrictions on the kind of routes where American Eagle can fly these jets and guaranteeing greater job security for less senior members of the Allied Pilots Association. **********Still, even with better pay and other conditions, many pilots see it as an all-or-nothing issue, and say that it will set a dangerous precedent for the industry. One dissident group of pilots has rallied around the slogan ''Defending the Profession,'' and has lobbied other pilots to vote against any deal that surrenders jet flying to Eagle pilots, who are represented by the Air Line Pilots Association. **********''That is the most critical issue,'' said Glenn Schafer, coordinator for the group, which has received financial support from about 700 pilots. If the pilots are asked to vote on an agreement that concedes this point to the airline, ''then we wouldn't recommend the deal,'' he said. **********American's pilots have shown they are a demanding group. Their board tentatively agreed to a contract last November, but in January -- to the surprise of the company, investors and the union leaders who had blessed the deal -- the membership voted down the agreement, starting the timetable that led to the brief strike last month and the report from the mediators appointed by President Clinton. **********In a statement, the White House said yesterday that the mediators were recommending pay increases totaling 6.5 percent over the next four years. The board also recommended that pilots of American's commuter subsidiary, American Eagle, fly the so-called regional jets, with a number of restrictions to appease the Allied Pilots Association. **********The White House statement noted that the report was not legally binding on the parties, but that President Clinton expressed his hope that the board's recommendations would help the parties reach a settlement. **********''The best resolution is a negotiated settlement acceptable to both sides of this dispute,'' President Clinton said. **********If no settlement is reached by 12:01 A.M. on April 28, the pilots would be free to strike, but could be blocked by an act of Congress. **********The overall proposal that the pilots' negotiators have agreed to in principle is most likely better than what they rejected just before their strike. Although people familiar with details of those talks offered different versions of the proposal at the time, in broad terms it called for a raise of about 6 percent over a four-year contract and approximately five million stock options, each valued at $10 below market value. It also included the provision that Eagle pilots fly the regional jets. **********The agreement in principle was disclosed yesterday after the stock market closed. Earlier, shares of AMR ended trading down $1.625, at $84.625, on the New York Stock Exchange.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/29/your-.snippet: WHATEVER the advantages of investing in smaller companies, choosing the right stocks from the several thousand on offer worldwide can be a nightmare. Worse still, thanks to the sector's volatility, making the wrong choice can be especially costly....
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/29/your-.main_headline: Cutting the Small-Cap Universe Down to Size
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/29/your-.print_headline: Cutting the Small-Cap Universe Down to Size
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/29/your-.body_text: **********WHATEVER the advantages of investing in smaller companies, choosing the right stocks from the several thousand on offer worldwide can be a nightmare. Worse still, thanks to the sector's volatility, making the wrong choice can be especially costly. **********For these reasons, more professional and private investors are using so-called quantitative systems to make the task easier. Instead of sifting through acres of data by hand, information on any number of stocks can be screened by computer and ranked according to various valuation and risk measures. **********Investors looking for value, for example, are frequently attracted to stocks with relatively low price/earnings ratios: The lower it is, the more potential the stock is thought to have. But those seeking growth stocks may prefer ranking data according to earnings-per-share figures. **********The efficiency of such programs has even led many hands-on investors to use them, at least to some degree. For those with a more arms-length attitude toward choosing stocks by the numbers, there are so-called quant funds. **********Guinness Flight Hambro Asset Management Ltd. in London will soon start an international smaller-companies fund that depends on a computer to sift through thousands of stocks. The data is supplied by HSBC James Capel, another British fund manager, and includes detailed information on 2,000 smaller-company stocks worldwide dating from 1989. **********"It helps bring the universe of possible choices down to a level that enables managers here to cut out much of the laborious leg-work," said Camilla Reeves, a European fund manager with Guinness Flight Hambro. **********Apart from ranking stocks by P/E ratios, the Guinness Flight quant program can screen company debt ratios, earnings, book values and many others. The favored valuation type may change according to the sector or market — or just because of changing valuation fashions, Ms. Reeves said. **********One emerging valuation type is economic-value-added ratio, or EVA. It weighs the cost of the company's debts against the earnings drawn from its assets. By working through a series of equations, it is possible, in theory, to project the impact on the stock value. **********Another increasingly used valuation screen is the price-to-book-value ratio. This compares the company's stock price to the worth of its assets. When the total assets are more valuable than its shares, the stock may be worth buying. **********Mainstream software developers such as Microsoft do not offer stock selection programs as part of their money-based software for personal computers. Even if they did, investors would still have to find a source for stock data. The Internet is rapidly proving to be a rich and cheap source for quantitative stock selection. **********Alex Greyserman, a quantitative fund manager with Mint Investment Management Co. in New Jersey, said some Web sites offered the service free. **********The systems that Mint uses, he added, mostly just take the sweat out of a process that any investor could do. **********"One of our funds is totally quant-selected," he said. "Every three months, we choose from thousands of U.S. stocks to create a balanced, value-driven portfolio. It's not rocket science, it's just systematic. Really we could do the same thing by hand but it would take a long time." **********But Rick Lacaille, a fund manager with Gartmore Investment Asset Management Ltd. in London, said quant programs used by managers do not translate easily into the retail investment market. **********"With our quant funds, we're looking for broad themes, such as value or growth," he said. "We don't want to find specific undervalued stocks. That's what retail investors want to do." **********Instead, he recommended that investors screen stocks by computer to find a handful with growth potential before making a final selection manually. **********For private investors who do not have access to the Internet, several business-services companies provide screening programs. In some cases, however, the cost can be high. Bloomberg Business News offers a subscription on-line service that includes stock screening as part of its range. But $1,600 per month for the full system is not likely to appeal to investors interested only in stock-ranking. **********U.S. businesses such as Value Line and S&P PC Plus also provide both stock data and programs to screen it.Packages exist for mutual fund investors, too. In the United States, where the number of mutual funds has grown to about 10,000, picking the best fund has become almost as difficult as selecting individual stocks. **********The U.S. fund monitor Morningstar Inc. offers a quant-driven selection of funds on its database. So does LaPorte Asset Allocation System, which is part of Burlington Hall Asset Management in New Jersey. **********LaPorte's spokesman, Richard Oberuc Jr., said the program used more than 80 valuation types to rank U.S. mutual funds. Its main advantage is that users do not have to be computing or finance experts. **********"It's helpful to have a statistical training, but where businesses use this software they tend to delegate the job of running it to someone with little or no experience," he said. It is also helpful to have made a tidy sum already: The software costs between $6,000 and $7,000, including technical support **********For further information: **********BLOOMBERG BUSINESS NEWS UK, tel: 44 171 330 7500. **********LAPORTE ASSET ALLOCATION SYSTEM, tel: 1 908 813 0077; e-mail: sales@laportesoft.com. **********MORNINGSTAR INC. tel: 1 312 696 6000
