https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/16/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; Agencies just aren't interested in the ad executive crying to get out of every consumer.
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/16/busin.body_text: **********THE next time you think you may have a better idea for an advertisement than a Madison Avenue hotshot, know that even if you do, no one will likely pay attention. **********Agencies and their clients, it turns out, are bombarded every day with unsolicited suggestions for commercials and print ads through telephone calls, faxes and letters. The increasing attention paid to advertising in the news media has inspired more consumers to believe that they, too, can come up with creative and lucrative campaigns. **********''I think people are more fascinated with advertising than ever,'' said Jerry Della Femina, chairman and creative director of Jerry & Ketchum in New York, a joint venture of Mr. Della Femina and Omnicom Group. ''Once people feel comfortable with something, they say, 'Let's try it.' '' **********But when consumers try it, they most likely will not like it, because the answer from agencies and advertisers is almost always ''no.'' Sometimes, the unsolicited idea is returned with an appreciative form letter. Sometimes it comes back marked ''return to sender.'' And sometimes it is ignored altogether. **********The main reason for that rejection is fear of legal action from consumers who contend that campaigns created by advertisers' agencies were inspired by or developed from their submissions. **********''It's a ripe area for lawsuits,'' said Jim Astrachan, a lawyer who is editor of the Legal Advice newsletter in Baltimore, which focuses on advertising-related legal issues. ''Claims being made today are much larger in magnitude, and the cost of a case is so far in excess of what it was five years ago.'' **********Mr. Astrachan said he advised his agency clients to establish internal procedures to handle unsolicited ideas so that they never reach executives who make creative decisions. The origin of an idea is thus never in question. **********Most do just that. Typically, ad ideas are fielded by a single office like the public relations or legal department. Sometimes, mail room employees are trained to identify and intercept idea submissions. **********''We try to teach our people how to spot an advertising idea letter when it comes in, and they send it directly to me,'' said Skip McGovern, a vice president and lawyer at BBDO New York, a unit of Omnicom Group. The agency's policy is to send back a letter explaining that the agency cannot accept unsolicited ideas. **********''We have thousands of ideas in the bank,'' Mr. McGovern said, ''and what we don't want to happen is if people submit an idea that we already have and we go ahead and produce the commercial, they think we stole their idea.'' **********He speaks from experience, recalling a legal battle over the popular Diet Pepsi campaign featuring Ray Charles singing, ''You got the right one baby, uh-huh!'' A consumer sued, contending that the campaign had been based on an idea that had been submitted. The agency won, Mr. McGovern said, but only after a long and expensive legal fight. **********Jerry & Ketchum will not acknowledge unsolicited ideas, Mr. Della Femina said, and avoids opening letters that are thought to contain them. **********''It's dangerous,'' he said. ''The next thing you know, you are involved in a lawsuit.'' **********Donny Deutsch, chief executive of Deutsch Inc. in New York, described most unsolicited ideas as motivated by self-interest. The policy at Deutsch is to reply to such inquiries ''with a nice letter,'' he said, explaining the legal qualms. **********Several other agencies expressed similar sentiments, as did many big advertisers. **********The Coca-Cola Company ''responds to everyone with a policy statement,'' said Bob Bertini, a spokesman, that ''we rely solely on company employees, our ad agencies or entities retained by the company'' for ad ideas. **********At Johnson & Johnson, letters are sent to avoid ''possible confusion and misunderstanding about the origin of ideas,'' said Jeffrey Leebaw, a spokesman in New Brunswick, N.J. **********By ignoring consumer creations, are agencies and marketers missing out? Most seem to think not. **********Mr. Astrachan of the legal newsletter asserted, ''99.9 percent of the unsolicited ideas have no value.'' **********Mr. Della Femina agreed, describing them as ''all sounding like 'Putney Swope' campaigns,'' referring to the comic 1969 film about advertising that featured wildly satirical commercials. **********Consumers ''don't know the clients' problems,'' he added, ''or the marketers' needs.'' **********Ellis Verdi, president of DeVito/ Verdi, a creatively focused New York agency, said: ''Advertising is a craft, and it has to be learned. It's not something that consumers can do successfully.'' **********Not everyone concurs. **********''Our belief is that great ideas come from all kinds of places,'' said Nick Cohen, chairman and executive creative director of Mad Dogs and Englishmen, a small creatively focused agency in New York. **********If someone submits an unsolicited idea that is good as well as ''relevant to the issues the client needs to address,'' he added, ''we might even pursue it and involve that person in some way.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/14/busin.snippet: Many small towns across country, such as Pigeon Forge, Tenn, home of Dollywood, Dolly Parton's flower-laden theme park, have used local attractions to turn themselves into major tourist destinations; Pigeon Forge has developed tourism department t...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/14/busin.main_headline: Pigeon Forge, Tenn., Attracts Tourists And Money, as Well as Traffic Jams
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/14/busin.print_headline: Pigeon Forge, Tenn., Attracts Tourists And Money, as Well as Traffic Jams
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/14/busin.body_text: **********Not too many years ago, this town of fewer than 4,000 people in the foothills of the Great Smoky Mountains was a sleepy farming community with two stop lights. **********Now, Pigeon Forge and the equally tiny town of Gatlinburg, just five miles away, are each overrun by as many as 100,000 people on a summer's day -- a total of 10 million visitors each throughout the year. That makes them, other than the country music mecca of Nashville, the most heavily visited tourist destinations in the state, outpulling even the nearby Great Smoky Mountains National Park, which attracts nine million tourists a year. **********What's drawing the crowds to this remote corner of eastern Tennessee, 35 miles from Knoxville? Dollywood, Dolly Parton's flower-laden theme park, for one, and more than 200 stores in six outlet malls here and about 400 specialty stores in Gatlinburg. Nature is just one allure of many -- and not always the most popular one. **********As with other small towns that have hit it big as tourist destinations -- from Ashland, Ore., on the West Coast to Myrtle Beach, S.C., on the East Coast -- Pigeon Forge can point to plenty of new jobs and a new identity. **********But as many other boom towns have also found, explosive growth has not been an unalloyed blessing here and in the surrounding Sevier County. **********Tree-lined country roads have given way to a seemingly endless array of souvenir shops, miniature golf courses, restaurants, bungee jumps and other amusements that stretch for miles along U.S. 441, the traffic-clogged corridor that runs through the heart of both Pigeon Forge and Gatlinburg. **********Away from the main road, there is now a transient quality to life. Many of the thousands of new jobs in Pigeon Forge are low paying and hard to fill. Newcomers arrive sometimes with little more than the shirts on their backs, while others drift away disillusioned, uprooting their school-aged children with them. **********Town officials acknowledge the attendant social problems, and say they are working to improve them, but add that they have had no real choice about the basic direction Pigeon Forge has taken. **********''We don't have a single other industry but tourism,'' said Kay Powell, assistant director of the town's Department of Tourism. And at least the problems created by tourism, local officials say, are an improvement over what existed before. **********So Pigeon Forge -- like dozens of other similarly placed communities around the country -- continues to pursue tourists and their dollars with single-minded devotion. This despite the fact that growth has been blunted at many tourist towns, including Branson, Mo., the tiny but hugely successful entertainment center of the Ozarks where local officials are now struggling to overcome the disenchantment of some visitors turned off by the congestion and traffic jams that success has produced. **********Indeed, to keep things humming, Pigeon Forge has developed a tourism department that has contributed mightily to the town's success in taking in $545 million last year, its best year ever. (Gatlinburg, which has its own tourist bureau, pulled in nearly $307 million, also a record.) **********The largely home-grown tourism operation combines a small-town work ethic with big-city moxie, careful cultivation of the trade press, meticulous attention to detail and an $8.4 million operating budget that includes a robust $6.4 million for advertising. **********So meticulous is Pigeon Forge's attention to details, and so dogged its pursuit of dollars, that its 29-employee Convention and Visitors Bureau maintains 28 toll-free numbers, at a cost of $400,000 a year, in order to track the response to its ads in newspapers and on radio and television. Each month its staff examines the registration cards of hotels and campgrounds to compile ZIP codes, the average number in each party and the average length of stay. It also hires the Perdue Research Group in Nashville to ask recent visitors what they liked or disliked about Pigeon Forge. **********Whatever problems the town is having with traffic, it clearly is a big hit with many visitors. Consider the experience of the 41 members of the Germino family, who held their reunion here recently. They came from six states and as far away as Texas. **********''We chose it because it's not too expensive, it's centrally located and it has something for all our family's ages, from 10 months to about 70,'' said Debra Feinstein of Hicksville, N.Y., a granddaughter of the family patriarch who emigrated from Italy to New York in 1923. ''This whole area's great for a family vacation.'' **********At that moment Mrs. Feinstein, her husband, Andrew, and their two young daughters, Arianna and Sara, were strolling through Dollywood, which drew 2.1 million paying visitors last year. **********Because most visitors are drawn to both Pigeon Forge and Gatlinburg, officials tend to play down the rivalry between the two hamlets. Except on occasion. ''We were a tourist destination,'' said Tony Funderburg, a spokesman for the Gatlinburg Convention and Visitors Bureau, ''when Pigeon Forge was two lanes and a gas station.'' **********With shopping, attractions and 9 live music theaters, soon to be 10, many visitors here do not visit the national park at all, or zip in and out for what locals call ''a windshield experience.'' Dotty Germino of De Soto, Tex., who planned the Germino clan's recent reunion, did not make it to the park. ''There was so much for everyone to do,'' she said afterward, ''that I just ran out of time.'' **********Pigeon Forge and Gatlinburg ''are quite commercialized,'' Mrs. Germino said. ''But I guess that's to be expected in tourist towns.'' **********Others, too, are drawn to the region less for the natural beauty than for the array of shopping, entertainment and other lures. ''We spent last night in a honeymoon suite in Gatlinburg, and tonight we're aiming to stay here,'' said Garland Morris of Fort Oglethorpe, Ga. He and his bride, Mary Ann, had just pulled into the Pigeon Forge welcome center in a car whose windows were soaped with messages proclaiming them to be newlyweds -- she for the second time, he for ''the fourth and last,'' he declared. **********To turn the area into a year-round attraction rather than simply a draw during summer vacation and the fall leaf-turning season, Pigeon Forge officials take special pride in having created Winterfest, which stretches from November to February. Performed against a background of several million twinkling lights and five miles of snowflake silhouettes strung along the road leading to the national park, Winterfest brought in $121.7 million last winter, more than double what the town took in during those same months in 1989, before the annual event was created. **********Dollywood has also extended its season from early April through December, and right now is going full blast. Reminders abound of Dolly Parton, the country music star, from Dollywood Boulevard to her radio station, WDLY, to an exact duplicate of the cabin in nearby Locust Ridge where she and her 11 brothers and sisters grew up. **********While it has the usual roller coaster, ferris wheel and other thrill rides, the park also reflects a broader Appalachian hillbilly theme. Such touches include the food (fried green tomatoes) and music (bluegrass and gospel), along with blacksmith demonstrations, soap making and a hand-built grist mill powered by a giant water wheel. **********Ms. Parton has a financial stake in the amusement park and she attends special events at least four times a year. She is a tireless promoter for the attraction and the region. Its principal owners, though, are Jack and Pete Herschend of Branson, Mo., who also own Silver Dollar City there, as well as water-sport parks in Branson and Atlanta. **********With about 2,000 employees during peak season, Dollywood is the largest private employer in the county, helping to turn the area from a place where jobs were once scarce to a place where employers now fight over practically every job seeker. **********''When I started with the State of Tennessee it was an employer's market,'' said Chuck Bradley, the manager of the Tennessee Department of Employment Security, and the former mayor of Gatlinburg. ''You had 25 applicants for every job. Now you have 100 jobs for each applicant.'' **********Tourist industry jobs, of course, are notoriously low paying, rarely offering more than $7 an hour here. They generally lack health insurance, pensions or other benefits. Pat Gregory, the area manager for the Tennessee Department of Human Services for Sevier County and nearby Cocke County, said worker turnover was also high because of a shortage of child care. **********Affordable accommodations are scarce in town. As a result, about half the workers in Pigeon Forge and Gatlinburg live in Cocke County, about 35 miles away, while many businesses are permanently understaffed. **********Regardless, the impact of tourism has been overwhelmingly beneficial, Mr. Bradley said. He added, ''Forty years ago, there were no jobs at all.'' **********Extending the tourist season has helped mitigate the transient nature of the area. Jack A. Parton, superintendent of schools for Sevier County, said that 23 percent of the county's 11,000 students changed from year to year. ''But our dropout rate has fallen from 33 percent in 1988 to 8.5 percent this year,'' he said. ''I'm sure the extension of the tourist season has a lot to do with that.'' **********For all their commercial success, Pigeon Forge and Gatlinburg are not for everyone. Take Ashwin Dave, a quality control manager for Coca- Cola in Baton Rouge, La. After driving some 700 miles with his wife,  Geeta, and their two children, he stopped in Gatlinburg to ask directions to the entrance to the Great Smoky Mountains National Park. **********''Our purpose isn't to see artificial things,'' Mr. Dave said softly. ''I can play miniature golf back home.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/16/busin.snippet: Swiss Bank Corp will acquire Dillon, Read & Co, New York investment company, for about $600 million, one day after ING Groep of the Netherlands breaks off talks with Dillon (L)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/16/busin.main_headline: Swiss Bank Steps Up to Buy Dillon, Read on Rebound
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/16/busin.print_headline: Swiss Bank Steps Up to Buy Dillon, Read on Rebound
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/16/busin.body_text: **********The Swiss Bank Corporation said yesterday that it would acquire Dillon, Read & Company, the New York investment company, for about $600 million, one day after the ING Groep of the Netherlands said that its talks with Dillon had broken off. **********The transaction, which was negotiated in just the last few weeks, is further evidence of the determination of big European banks to build investment banking franchises in the United States. **********Swiss Bank paid handsomely for Dillon, Read, which has a storied history dating back to 1832 and now specializes in advising companies on mergers and acquisitions and in raising capital through equity and debt issues. The $600 million price is equal to three times Dillon's book value. That means that the firm's 50 partners, who own 75 percent of the company, and ING Barings, a subsidiary of ING Groep that owns the other 25 percent, will get big profits in the sale. ING's long-running negotiations with Dillon's partners to acquire the rest of the firm collapsed after executives could not agree on how to integrate the businesses. **********''Dillon, Read has very good management, and they have been very astute at selling themselves at a great price,'' said Perrin H. Long Jr., an independent analyst. **********Simon Canning, president and chief executive of SBC Warburg, Swiss Bank's investment banking and capital markets division, said, ''We want to be able to offer the widest possible range of investment banking services to our clients worldwide, and that requires a first-rate U.S. investment banking presence.'' **********Franklin W. Hobbs, Dillon, Read's president and chief executive, agreed, saying, ''This combination is an excellent fit for both firms, as it will enhance significantly the capabilities and resources we are able to offer our clients and the career opportunities available to our staff.'' **********Swiss Bank said it would incorporate Dillon, Read's business and more than 700 employees with those of SBC Warburg, with few layoffs. **********While the price that Swiss Bank is paying for Dillon may seem high,  established American investment banks are currently hot properties. Analysts generally expect that this acquisition, which follows the Bankers Trust Corporation's recent agreement to buy Alex. Brown & Sons, an investment bank, and Dean Witter, Discover & Company's pending merger with the Morgan Stanley Group, will be followed by other mergers and takeovers. **********There have been frequent reports recently of possible talks involving a number of banks and securities firms, including J. P. Morgan, Chase Manhattan, Nationsbank, the Bank of America, Lehman Brothers, Salomon Brothers, Donaldson Lufkin & Jenrette and Oppenheimer. In recent weeks, all these companies have declined to comment on speculation concerning their involvement in potential combinations. **********Against this background, said Sallie L. Krawcheck, an analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein & Company, the sale of a small-  to medium-sized brokerage company like Dillon, Read to a larger player with global aspirations, like Swiss Bank, ''is the type of deal one would expect to see.'' **********The acquisition, she said, should help Swiss Bank in the United States, because ''Dillon, Read has an extremely strong reputation.'' **********John Keefe, an independent bank analyst, said that Swiss Bank, while already holding a leading position in European investment banking markets, certainly ''needs as much mass as they can get here'' in the United States. **********The bank, which formed SBC Warburg when it acquired S. G. Warburg of London in 1995 for $1.4 billion, has expanded its American investment banking operations through a series of acquisitions. It acquired Brinson Partners, a Chicago asset management firm, in 1994, and a year earlier bought O'Connor Associates, a derivatives trading firm. **********Dillon, Read, which has not generally disclosed financial results because it is a private company, has certainly been profitable, according to its top officers. ''Since 1981, we have had an average return on our equity of 21 percent,'' said John P. Birkelund, Dillon's chairman, in an interview yesterday. ''We have never had a loss year'' during that period, he said, and ''our lowest annual return on equity was 9 percent.'' **********Mr Hobbs of Dillon, Read is expected to move to London soon to become global head of SBC Warburg Dillon Read, as the combined entity will be known. Dillon, Read will maintain its offices in midtown Manhattan, and Swiss Bank, which is  building new offices in Stamford, Conn., will move some employees to Dillon, Read's headquarters, the firm's leaders said yesterday. Among Dillon's former leaders is Nicholas F. Brady, who was chairman of Dillon, Read before becoming Secretary of the Treasury during the Reagan and Bush Administrations. **********SBC Warburg earned profit before taxes of $759 million in 1996, representing about 44 percent of its parent company's pretax earnings. The international investment bank has about 9,000 employees, of whom 2,000 are in the United States.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/04/busin.snippet: Ford Motor Co, in major alternative fuel program, to begin building 250,000 cars, mini-vans and pickup trucks annually that can burn ethanol or gasoline; Chrysler plans similar program, which will enable auto makers to meet Federal fuel-economy st...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/04/busin.main_headline: Ford Pushes an Ethanol Line, But Gas-Guzzlers Profit, Too
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/04/busin.print_headline: Ford Pushes an Ethanol Line, But Gas-Guzzlers Profit, Too
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/04/busin.body_text: **********The Ford Motor Company announced today that it would begin building 250,000 cars, mini-vans and pickup trucks annually that can burn ethanol or gasoline, in the largest alternative fuel program in the United States since the oil crises of the 1970's produced alarm about American reliance on imported energy. **********Chrysler is expected to announce a similar program next week, ethanol and auto industry officials said. General Motors is considering whether to follow Ford and Chrysler's example. **********Ford officials characterized their announcement as part of a corporate commitment to clean air. The No. 2 American auto maker said it hoped the sharp increase in the availability of ethanol-burning vehicles -- it made just 5,000 such vehicles last year -- would prompt more service stations to sell the fuel. Only 40 stations currently sell ethanol, which is grain-based alcohol mixed with a little gasoline. **********But as much as Ford and No. 3 Chrysler trumpet a commitment to the environment, they have an even bigger commitment to something they hold dear: profits. Under a loophole in Federal law, building the dual-fuel vehicles will help them sell more big-profit, big-engine, gasoline-guzzling trucks and sport utility vehicles at a time when strong sales of these vehicles is putting both companies at risk of violating Federal fuel-economy standards. **********Environmentalists were skeptical about the plan, contending that it violated the spirit, if not the letter, of the standards. **********Ford plans to make dual-fuel versions of the Taurus sedan, the Windstar mini-van and the Ranger pick-up truck. As far as buyers are concerned, the choice of fuels will make no difference, Ford said. **********Sticker prices will be identical. Ford will outfit the vehicles with stainless steel fuel systems that can run on either gasoline or ethanol, and they will have a small emblem on the sides of the car representing a green leaf sprouting from a roadway. Drivers will have the option of switching fuels every time they fill up. **********Michael T. McCabe, Ford's worldwide marketing manager for alternative fuel vehicles, acknowledged that many people might just put gasoline in the new vehicles. ''The customer is totally flexible,'' he said. **********That may be, but environmental groups scoffed at the idea of building such a huge number of vehicles, about 6 percent of Ford's total production last year, when there are currently only 40 stations that pump ethanol, all in the Midwest and Idaho. **********Daniel Becker, an energy expert at the Sierra Club, said Ford was inappropriately using a loophole in Federal fuel laws. ''Ford's announcement about making cars for which there is no fuel is a cynical ploy to avoid violating a law,'' he said. **********By law, the total of pickup trucks, sport utility vehicles and mini-vans an auto maker sells in a year must have fuel efficiency that averages 20.7 miles a gallon. If Ford and Chrysler sell too many versions with high horsepower and low fuel efficiency their ''fleet averages'' sink, and they can incur costly penalties. Although auto makers have managed to manipulate production and sales to avoid such fines, they have resorted to a host of methods, including flooding the market with smaller, more full-efficient models, often carrying large rebates, to keep their averages within limits. **********Federal fuel-economy laws are administered by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, which is part of the Transportation Department. The agency, which has a nonpartisan tradition, declined to comment on Ford's move. **********It is difficult to predict exactly how much Ford or Chrysler's overall fuel economy may be helped by selling dual-fuel vehicles. The formula that measures the fuel efficiency of these vehicles is quite complex. Mr. McCabe said, however, that for each such vehicle, Ford could effectively sell two more of its hot-selling, mammoth Expedition sport utility vehicles. But because the formula counts a dual-fuel vehicle as roughly equivalent to a gasoline-powered vehicle the gets 60 miles a gallon, the benefit could be even greater to the auto maker's fuel average. **********Auto makers earn this bonus regardless of whether the customer ever buys any ethanol. **********Not only is the fuel hard to come by, it is also more expensive to use. **********A gallon of ethanol fuel, actually 85 percent ethanol and 15 percent gasoline, sells for about the same or slightly less than a gallon of midgrade gasoline. But because of differences in the energy in each fuel, a car gets fewer miles to the gallon on this blend, known as E85, so the cost per mile can actually be about 15 percent higher, Mr. McCabe said. **********Besides the stainless steel fuel system, Ford installs an electronic sensor that continuously measures the proportion of ethanol to gasoline entering the engine and adjusts the operation of several engine parts . **********The sensor and stainless steel fuel system currently cost Ford an extra $300 a vehicle, but that should drop with larger-scale production, Mr. McCabe said. Beginning a year from now, Ford plans to make 50,000 to 60,000 Ford Ranger compact pickup trucks a year with dual-fuel engines, he said. Within four years, the company plans to make 250,000 midsize Tauruses, Rangers and Windstar mini-vans annually with dual-fuel engines. All of the enthanol cars will be powered by Ford 3.0-liter V6 engines. **********With sales rising year after year for Chrysler's Jeeps and Ford's F-150 full-size pickup trucks, and strong sales in the first year of the Ford Expedition, both auto makers are in danger of violating Federal laws and paying penalties that would run into the tens of millions of dollars. **********G.M., the world's biggest car maker, also has some difficulties complying with the fuel-economy rules but is focusing its energy on the development of electric vehicles rather than ethanol-powered cars. Most foreign auto makers, particularly the Japanese, have relatively little difficulty meeting the United States standards because they mostly make smaller, lighter cars and engines that get more miles to the gallon of gasoline. **********The N.H.T.S.A. has the authority from Congress to raise Federal fuel-economy standards as technology improves. But the Republican Congress, at the request of auto makers, has blocked it from doing so for the last two years by attaching provisions to the Federal budget blocking any spending for this task and may do so again this year. **********Auto executives are convinced that the White House would like to skirt Congressional opposition, although the Administration has not yet introduced any formal initiative to do so. But by building a lot of dual-fuel vehicles, the auto makers could protect themselves from all but the most stringent changes in Federal standards. **********Ford's average fuel economy for mini-vans, sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks for the 1996 model year was just 20.6 miles a gallon, while Chrysler's was just 20.3. Ford did not face any penalties because the law allows an auto maker to average any year with the three years before it and the three years after it. But with sales of pickup trucks and sport utility vehicles continuing to rise and overall fuel economy still falling, both auto makers are struggling even to meet the seven-year averages. **********Philip M. Novell, the general sales manager for Ford-brand cars and trucks, said in an interview that the company was determined to meet the law. Expanded production of the dual-fuel vehicles ''enhances our ability to comply with the law, and we will be in compliance,'' he said. **********In calculating the average fuel economy of an auto maker's vehicles, the Federal Government takes a weighted average based on each vehicle's efficiency in the city and on highways. By an odd coincidence, Brazil, the only large country that switched to mostly ethanol-powered cars after the oil crises of the 1970's, has been switching back to gasoline-powered cars as the Government reduces ethanol subsidies as supplies have proved irregular.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/19/world.snippet: Profile of wealthy Hong Kong industrialist Victor Fung; photo (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/19/world.main_headline: With Pride in the Family's Past, The Business Is Business as Usual
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/19/world.print_headline: With Pride in the Family's Past, The Business Is Business as Usual
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/19/world.body_text: **********Victor Fung, with cherubic cheeks and tending toward the chubby, hurtled along the marble floor of Hong Kong's still unopened Convention and Exhibition Center. Jutting deep into the waters of Victoria Harbor, the convention center, a building of glass walls and sweeping roofs, is Mr. Fung's baby. **********''Thirty-nine months ago,'' he said, beaming, ''if you had stood here you would have been in the middle of the harbor, soaking wet. Even by Hong Kong standards, this is an extraordinarily fast-track project.'' **********Glorious in its prominence, the center was hurried to completion under Mr. Fung's firm hand in one of the three careers he juggles -- this one as the leader of Hong Kong's Trade Development Council. So efficient, or hard-driving, was Mr. Fung in getting his $623 million edifice completed, that both China and Britain chose it as the place where the Union Jack will be lowered for the last time and the Chinese flag hoisted to reassert Beijing's sovereignty over Hong Kong after 156 years. **********A measure of historical vindication lies in the choice of Mr. Fung's building, if only because his grandfather, Fung Pak-liu, and a colleague founded one of the first purely Chinese trading companies in Hong Kong, Li & Fung. It was to become one of the many large conglomerates run by Hong Kong Chinese families that would eventually displace Britain's great trading houses. **********''Our company has a pretty interesting history, and my life has been tied up in it,'' said Mr. Fung, who runs the family business with his brother William. ''In 1906 -- that was still the Qing dynasty -- we were the first to bypass the British hongs,'' or trading houses, ''and set up a real trading company in Hong Kong. **********''My grandfather knew English -- he had taught English at King's College -- and knowing English made the difference,'' Mr. Fung said. ''He was able to communicate with buyers and sellers overseas. Our company traded rattan, porcelain. Now we're a $2 billion trading house -- a lot of consumer products, garments, textiles, toys.'' **********A man both modern and traditional, Mr. Fung lives in a penthouse with a spectacular view of Hong Kong atop a 30-story building he owns that stands on the site of the first family home. His mother lives across the hall in the other penthouse. His brother lives downstairs. **********He did not intend it to be this way. After attending the colony's most prestigious boy's school, King George V, he went to M.I.T. in 1962 to study electrical engineering. **********''I didn't really like it,'' he said. ''It's too rules-bound. There's no way to create anything, like when you're expanding a business.'' So he switched to Harvard for a doctorate in applied mathematics, and then went to work at Citibank in New York. **********''It was a very dynamic place,'' he said. ''I was only 24, but my superiors were only 30 or so. Everyone was young and excited.'' **********Back then, he said, ''I didn't really miss Hong Kong. We were having so much fun. I liked living in the States.'' Indeed, his embrace of American life and business led to American citizenship. **********''I guess I always knew I would come back to Hong Kong at some point, but I had no idea when,'' he said. ''I was the eldest son, but at one point I thought I might not have to do it.'' But in 1976, Mr. Fung, his wife, Julia, and two children, Sabrina and Spencer, returned to Hong Kong. ''It was like I was never gone.'' **********Over the years, Mr. Fung and his brother took the family's sprawling web of disjointed enterprises and created a more focused company, selling off bits and pieces to buying out 35 family members, including their father. ''I had a hard time applying M.B.A.-type thinking to the company,'' he said. ''It was a different type of organization. It was more a family, patriarchal-type company.'' Even so, ''I would never say the old ways were wrong.'' **********Today, he oversees a company with 5,000 employees and offices in 20 countries and divides his time among the Trade Development Council, Li & Fung and Prudential Asia Investments, where he is chairman. This last is a branch of the Prudential Insurance Company of America. **********''It's not exactly 1/3, 1/3, 1/3,'' he laughed. ''It's more like 1/2, 1/2, 1/2.'' **********Despite his American passport, Mr. Fung said, he is unalterably wedded to Hong Kong, regardless of who is running it. ''I'm really a Hong Kong person through and through,'' he said. ''We are a totally bicultural family. I think this is the special characteristic of Hong Kong people. We can work and live in either culture.'' **********Yet, the transition to Chinese rule does stir something in him. **********''As an ethnic Chinese, that drives the emotion more than the passport you carry,'' he said. **********Four Destinies **********For Hong Kong's 6.3 million people, the transfer from British to Chinese rule is just one element in their lives. These articles, by Edward A. Gargan, tell the stories of four residents, from four walks of life.
