https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/22/busin.snippet: Sales of low-cost personal computers to consumers are soaring now that up-to-date models sell for under $1,000; computer makers weigh whether surge is leading to overall expansion of home PC market; graph (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/22/busin.main_headline: Low-End PC's Take Growing Share of Home Market
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/22/busin.print_headline: Low-End PC's Take Growing Share of Home Market
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/22/busin.body_text: **********When the price of a personal computer fell below $1,000 earlier this year, consumers began flocking to stores in search of the ultimate deal. For the first time, they are discovering that $999 can buy the latest technology -- or something close to it -- rather than a closed-out model the manufacturer had long ago replaced with something bigger, faster and better. **********As a result, sales of these low-priced workhorses have been skyrocketing lately. While surveys from two companies that track such sales showed slightly different results -- in part because they used different methodologies -- both indicated that new, low-priced machines were having a profound affect on the industry. **********One survey, from Computer Intelligence Corporation showed that personal computers costing less than $1,000 accounted for nearly 23 percent of all retail PC sales in July, up from only 7.2 percent in January. Figures from Dataquest Inc. were lower, showing that PC's priced below $1,000 accounted for 16 to 18 percent of consumer PC sales in the second quarter. In both cases, it is important to note that the under-$1,000 figure usually does not include a monitor, which typically adds a minimum of $200 to the price. **********The first under-$1,000 Pentium PC from a major manufacturer arrived in January, when Packard Bell NEC introduced its D141 model. Since then, the company, which is based in Sacramento, Calif., has rolled out two more lines, and leads the category with about 28 percent market share, followed closely by Compaq with roughly 25 percent of the market. And I.B.M., Acer America and AST have also brought out models priced below $1,000 since. **********But even before that, tiny start-up Monorail Inc. jump-started the low-end market last year with an odd-looking but functional system that includes a built-in notebook-style L.C.D. screen. **********Just who is buying these systems is still a matter of debate. Fred Kern, vice president of product marketing for Packard Bell NEC, said the company's research showed that 70 percent of those who purchased its under-$1,000 PC's were either first-time buyers or people who had owned a computer in the past but stopped using it once it had become outdated. That was compared with the 50 percent of all Packard Bell systems that are bought by first-time buyers. **********But the big question is whether the surge in sales of low-priced systems is leading to an overall expansion of the home PC market, whose reach into American households has inched up from 38 to 41 percent in the past year. At Packard Bell, the answer is a hesitant ''yes.'' **********''We think the market is expanding because of this phenomenon but we don't have any firm data yet,'' Mr. Kern said. But industry analysts, who generally concur that it is too early to tell, say a surprisingly high number of these systems are being bought as replacement systems by experienced PC users, and by small businesses and corporations looking to equip low-end users inexpensively. **********What market researchers have discovered about the fickle consumer market could be disturbing for the makers of these personal computers. **********Surveys of the more than 60 percent of homes that don't own a personal computer show that price is not what keeps many of these people out of the computer store. Rather, it is the perception that they have no use for a computer. **********''The majority of home users who don't have a PC don't think they need it,'' said James Staten, a PC analyst at Dataquest Inc., a market research firm in San Jose, Calif. **********But that, too, appears to be changing, driven to a large extent by the extensive hype about the Internet, Mr. Kern said. Add to that some major improvements that are expected shortly in graphics technology, along with the imminent arrival of D.V.D., a new video standard that delivers higher quality full-motion video than CD-ROM disks, and personal computer makers have reason to hope that the die-hards will come around soon. **********These new low-priced systems have a significant advantage over low-end PC's that went on the market before them. Their most noteworthy feature is that they are able to run the latest software programs. **********''The sub-$1,000 market used to be close-out computers, typically a few generations old,'' said Matt Sargent, an analyst at Computer Intelligence. ''Now we have Packard Bell, Compaq and others announcing systems that were actually new technology.'' **********But that's not to say the low-end  personal computer is for everyone. While sales of these PC's may be surging, the volume is still small in comparison with higher priced systems, and the $1,500 to $2,000 PC remains the best seller. According to Dataquest, more than a million PC's priced in that range were sold to homeowners during the second quarter, compared with roughly 200,000 PC's priced below $1,000. **********The reason? At the lower end, customers may be getting current technology, but they are most likely getting a bare-bones configuration. Most home PC's in that range, for example, typically have only 16 megabytes of memory, hardly enough to run more than one program at a time, a feature more experienced users would want. And such computers typically have the slowest of the current Pentium processors, easily fast enough for most users, but perceived as insufficient for heavy number crunching or for some demanding graphics applications. **********Likewise, a sub-$1,000 system isn't likely to have the fastest CD-ROM drive or the fastest modem, both features many customers would prefer to pay extra to have. **********But as analysts point out, home consumers typically do not need the fastest processor and largest drive, as long as they can do what they need to: write letters, track home finances and perhaps browse the World Wide Web. For those things, $1,000 could be money well spent.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/16/busin.snippet: Mark E Whitacre, former executive with Archer Daniels Midland Co who worked as Government informant in sweeping price-fixing investigation, is indicted on charges that he defrauded the company of more than $9 million; 45-count indictment charges t...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/16/busin.main_headline: Informant in Archer Daniels Price-Fixing Case Is Indicted
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/16/busin.print_headline: Informant in Archer Daniels Price-Fixing Case Is Indicted
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/16/busin.body_text: **********Mark E. Whitacre, the former executive with the Archer Daniels Midland Company who worked as a Government informant in a sweeping price-fixing investigation, was indicted yesterday on charges that he defrauded the company of more than $9 million. **********The 45-count indictment, handed up by a Federal grand jury in Springfield, Ill., charges that Mr. Whitacre conspired with other executives to steal the money in a complex scheme involving fraudulent invoices, front companies, forged records and Swiss bank accounts. **********Archer Daniels accused Mr. Whitacre of stealing the money in 1995, and the executive has previously acknowledged obtaining it. But he has maintained for more than a year that he received it through an illegal, corporate-wide compensation system for its top executives. **********But, according to the indictment, the Government concluded not only that Mr. Whitacre's explanation was false, but that he had obstructed justice by trying to persuade a co-conspirator to back up his story. **********The indictment is something of a final unraveling of Mr. Whitacre, who was once considered a candidate for president at Archer Daniels, the grain giant. Only two years ago he was working side by side with law enforcement, secretly tape-recording his colleagues at Archer Daniels to prove a price-fixing conspiracy that he had exposed to the Government. **********And his cooperation proved fruitful: Archer Daniels, faced with Mr. Whitacre's tapes and competitors cooperating with the Government, pleaded guilty to price-fixing in October and agreed to pay a record $100 million fine. Several other Asian companies have also pleaded guilty to price-fixing and paid millions of dollars in fines. **********But by then, Mr. Whitacre's star had already dimmed as a result of the embezzlement allegations. He has spent much of the last year and a half publicly defending himself and attacking his accusers, from Archer Daniels to the Government. **********Mr. Whitacre was already charged last month with participating in the price-fixing conspiracy he exposed to the Government. Because he obtained the money illegally, Mr. Whitacre waived immunity under his cooperation agreement. **********Mr. Whitacre also conceded in an article in The New York Times yesterday that he had fabricated certain documents he provided to reporters to bolster his recent allegations of corruption in the price-fixing case by an agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation. Immediately after that admission, he agreed with a psychiatrist's recommendation and sought hospitalization for his poorly controlled manic depression. **********Mr. Whitacre's lawyer, Bill T. Walker, did not return a telephone call seeking comment. **********Justice Department officials declined to comment beyond what was contained in the 50-page indictment and an accompanying statement. **********In addition to the obstruction charge, the indictment charges Mr. Whitacre with wire fraud, filing false tax returns, money laundering, conspiracy and interstate transportation of stolen property. **********The indictment lays out a flurry of transactions, internal communications and discussions the Government says went into multiple transfers of cash to bank accounts controlled by Mr. Whitacre and certain of his colleagues, none of whom were identified by name. **********According to the indictment, the scheme began in the spring of 1991, and continued through about November 1995 -- some three months after Archer Daniels first disclosed the embezzlement allegations. **********The charges say that Mr. Whitacre, as the head of the Archer Daniels bioproducts division, created and submitted bogus invoices and other fictitious documents to the company to indicate that it owed money to various dummy companies actually owned and controlled by Mr. Whitacre and his associates. **********The bogus companies came with a range of names, including Aminac Mexico S.A. de C.V., Komven S.A. de C.V., Eurotechnologies, Covert & Associates, Far East Specialists, General Systems Inc. and four others. **********Apparently the first such payment was for $200,000, transferred to a company named JT Technologies. Later, another payment for $300,000 was made in the name of the same company. **********But, according to the indictment, JT Technologies performed no services for Archer Daniels. The indictment says that Mr. Whitacre conspired with another person for the JT Technologies transfer, but it does not identify that individual. **********However, other court and corporate filings show that the individual was Sidney D. Hulse, at one time an executive with Archer Daniels. But the records also show that at least one payment was made to JT Technologies prior to Mr. Hulse's ever working for Archer Daniels. **********Over time, the amount of money being transferred grew significantly. According to the indictment, in February 1992, Mr. Whitacre arranged for $695,400 to be wired from Archer Daniels purportedly for services performed by Eurotechnologies. **********While the indictment offers few details of that transaction, banking records show that the money went to account number 89-20107 at the Swiss Bank Corporation in Bern. That account was opened in the name of Eurotechnologies by Mr. Hulse, court documents show. In a lawsuit, Archer Daniels has contended that the money was subsequently wired to other accounts controlled by Mr. Whitacre, Mr. Hulse and a third Archer Daniels executive, Reinhard  Richter, former head of the Archer Daniels operations in Mexico. **********A telephone call to Mr. Hulse was not answered. Mr. Richter's lawyer did not return a message. **********After that, the transfers grew huge. According to the indictment, the following month Mr. Whitacre arranged for a wire to be sent from Archer Daniels to National City Bank in Minneapolis, instructing it to wire $1.5 million to Swiss Bank in Hong Kong. The money was purportedly payment for services provided by Far East Specialists, which is referred to in numerous documents as F.E.S. **********But, according to the indictment, F.E.S. was another front company, controlled by Mr. Whitacre and an associate. **********The most outsized transfer came in February, 1995, more than two years after Mr. Whitacre began secretly recording conversations at the highest reaches of Archer Daniels. In that instance, according to the indictment, more than $3.75 million was  wired from the Archer Daniels bank in Minneapolis to Chase Manhattan in New York. In turn, that money was transferred to the Union Bank of Switzerland in Zurich. **********The payment was made in the name of Applied Biotechnology Products Company, a concern purportedly doing business in Europe. But the Swiss bank account where the money ended up was owned and controlled by Mr. Whitacre. **********But perhaps the most damaging information in the indictment involves actions taken by Mr. Whitacre after he obtained the money. According to the charges, Mr. Whitacre used a Houston bank account controlled by a co-conspirator to deposit, withdraw and transfer his taxable income from the stolen money. That way, the indictment says, Mr. Whitacre avoided paying taxes. **********According to the indictment, in August 1995 -- the same month that Mr. Whitacre admitted to the Government that he had obtained the money -- he telephoned a co-conspirator  who was involved with the Far East Specialist transaction. **********In that call, the indictment says, Mr. Whitacre admitted that he had stolen more money from Archer Daniels than that known by the co-conspirator, who was not named. But he told the co-conspirator that he intended to represent the stolen money as part of an illegal corporate compensation scheme. **********In October 1995, that same co-conspirator was interviewed by the F.B.I., and he informed Mr. Whitacre about the meeting. Later, Mr. Whitacre telephoned the co-conspirator, the document says, but the executive would not take the call. **********According to the indictment, Mr. Whitacre appeared at the co-conspirator's home that same night and told him to describe the $1.5 million transferred to Far East Specialists as part of an off-the-books compensation scheme. **********Because of that attempt, Mr. Whitacre was charged with obstruction of justice for tampering with a witness.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/23/world.snippet: Leaders of US, China, Japan and other nations of Pacific Rim, since first meeting as group in 1993, have swaggered into their annual gatherings almost arrogant in their confidence that region will be 21st century's economic engine and new locus of...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/23/world.main_headline: Asia Nations Limp Into Fiscal Talks As Turmoil Rages
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/23/world.print_headline: Asia Nations Limp Into Fiscal Talks As Turmoil Rages
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/23/world.body_text: **********Since first meeting as a group in 1993, the leaders of the United States, China, Japan and other nations of the Pacific Rim have swaggered into their annual gatherings, almost arrogant in their confidence that the region would be the 21st century's economic engine and the new locus of world power. **********But as they assemble here this weekend, President Clinton and his counterparts from 17 Asian and North and South American members will nearly all be limping, wounded by global economic forces beyond their control and, in Mr. Clinton's case, undercut by domestic political defeats. **********On Friday, the financial turmoil that has been coursing through Asia claimed its largest victim, South Korea, the nation with the world's 11th-biggest economy. The Government in Seoul was forced to call on the international community for a financial bailout, a humbling step that has already been taken by Thailand and Indonesia. **********The upheaval has also hit hard in Taiwan, Hong Kong and the Philippines, and could even dent Japan. As a result, the turmoil and how to stop it will no doubt dominate the discussions among the leaders, although they are unlikely to take any action beyond offering reassuring words about their determination to restore calm in financial markets and prosperity throughout Asia. **********But the problems in Asia will have some concrete effects on American policy and on Mr. Clinton's ability to use the two-day gathering, which formally convenes Monday, to advance his own economic agenda championing free trade. The United States, particularly since Mr. Clinton became President, has based its approach to the region largely on expanding trade, a strategy embodied in a 1994 agreement with the Asia-Pacific countries to create a free-trade zone as early as 2010. **********Asia's economic woes are already reducing the region's demand for American exports and are showing signs of sending the trade deficit in the United States to new highs. Consumed by their domestic economic problems, and by their associated political difficulties, few of the Asian leaders here will have much stomach for new market-opening initiatives that might bring objections at home. **********Moreover, having failed this month in his all-out effort to win new trade-negotiating authority from Congress, Mr. Clinton clearly has less standing to demand that other nations take politically painful steps to drop their tariffs and other trade barriers. **********And if Mr. Clinton cannot quickly convince liberal Democrats in Congress to change their position and grant him the negotiating power, his opportunity to pursue new trade deals in many product categories will be all but closed off, even if Asian trading partners are willing. **********Mr. Clinton is also still smarting from Congress's rejection last week of his request for $3.5 billion in additional financing for the International Monetary Fund, the vehicle through which the bailouts of South Korea and other nations are being coordinated. **********Mr. Clinton has been pressing for more I.M.F. financing all year to deal with exactly the kind of situation that has now erupted in Asia. Although Administration officials are confident that Congress will approve the financing next year, some foreign officials said the situation hurts the United States in its efforts to maintain its effective control over the terms of the international bailouts. **********The mix of difficulties make this year the first real test of the annual gathering, known as the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation forum, or Apec. Founded in 1989 as a way for lower-level officials of Pacific Rim countries to discuss common interests, it was elevated to the status of a regional summit meeting by Mr. Clinton starting in 1993 as part of his effort to shift the nation's sights toward the economic opportunities and security challenges presented by a rapidly growing and modernizing Asia. **********The leaders ''face the most critical and difficult series of issues in the history of this young institution,'' said C. Fred Bergsten, the director of the Institute for International Economics. ''Their ability to respond effectively and decisively will go far toward determining whether Apec will become a central player in resolving regional and global crises.'' **********White House officials, while acknowledging the difficulties the Administration faces here, said the gathering would still be an effective stage on which to exert global economic leadership and, in particular, to highlight the benefits of trade and the need for Mr. Clinton to be granted so-called ''fast-track'' trade authority by Congress. With such authority, he can negotiate trade deals that Congress can approve or reject, but cannot amend. **********They said the meeting was expected to give formal approval to the policies at the heart of American strategy in the region: that nations  need to take responsibility for dealing with their financial problems by adopting more prudent economic policies, that the I.M.F. should take the lead when a bailout plan is necessary, and that countries should still work toward freer trade even while coping with economic difficulties. **********That policy was embodied in an agreement worked out by American and Asian officials in Manila this week. The agreement effectively scuttled an idea first floated by Japan, and strongly opposed by the United States, to create a bailout fund for Asian nations that would operate outside the I.M.F., which typically requires stringent austerity programs in return for its financial assistance. **********''In the past four years, obviously, with the enormous success of economies in Asia, there's been a good deal of emphasis upon what more can be done and how to take advantage of the rapidly growing economies,'' said Daniel Tarullo, Mr. Clinton's adviser on international economic affairs. **********''Obviously, this year, with the recent turmoil in a number of East Asian financial markets, there is a different tone and different atmosphere,'' Mr. Tarullo said. **********But he added the annual summit meeting would prove to be ''a good instrument in trying times as well as good times.'' **********American officials said that while they did not expect any big new trade deals, they were confident of winning agreement to drop trade barriers among the Pacific nations in one or two product categories ahead of the general deadline they have set of 2010 for the more developed nations. **********There is also likely to be some discussion with Asian countries of their willingness to agree to a proposed World Trade Organization plan to allow banks, investment firms and other financial services providers more freedom to do business in other countries. **********Mr. Clinton will also use the gathering to meet individually with leaders of several other countries, including Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto of Japan. Analysts and government officials are increasingly concerned that Japan's weak economy and the huge number of bad loans weighing down its banking system leave the country vulnerable to the spillover effects of the troubles in South Korea and Southeast Asia. **********Mr. Clinton may also meet with President Jiang Zemin of China. American officials said they would like to build on the Chinese leader's release last weekend of the prominent political dissident Wei Jingsheng and to discuss Mr. Clinton's planned visit to China next year. **********The leaders will also exchange ideas about how to deal with global warming in advance of an international meeting on the topic next month. And they are likely to consider inviting several new members into Apec, including Peru, Vietnam and Russia. **********The current members are Australia, Brunei, Canada, Chile, China, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Japan, Malaysia, Mexico, New Zealand, Papua New Guinea, the Philippines, Singapore, South Korea, Taiwan, Thailand and the United States.                     -------------------- **********Stocks Plummet in South Korea **********SEOUL, South Korea, Nov. 22 (Reuters) -- Stocks plunged more than 4 percent here today in response to South Korea's decision to seek a loan from the I.M.F. **********''Investors turned skeptical as they realized the I.M.F. bailout package would not be like a free lunch,'' said Choo Hee Yup, a broker at Dongwon Securities. The composite stock index shed 4.08 percent, or 20.64 points, to close at 485.43. **********South Korea said late on Friday that it had asked the I.M.F. to provide about $20 billion in standby credits to overcome the country's financial crisis.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/30/world.snippet: Czech Prime Min Vaclav Klaus, once revered at home and abroad as brilliant economist before popularity faded, resigns amid political scandal involving disclosures by political colleagues of secret slush fund held by his ruling party in Swiss bank;...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/30/world.main_headline: Czech Premier Steps Down After Havel Seeks Ouster
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/30/world.print_headline: Czech Premier Steps Down After Havel Seeks Ouster
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/30/world.body_text: **********After a stormy 11-hour session of his political party, Prime Minister Vaclav Klaus announced his resignation and that of his Government shortly after midnight this morning, bringing to an end the longest running premiership in post-Communist Central Europe. **********Mr. Klaus, once celebrated at home and abroad as a brilliant economist before his popularity faded and then suddenly crumbled over a campaign finance scandal, said he would not be part of a new government. **********President Vaclav Havel has scheduled talks today for the formation of a new government composed of Mr. Klaus's center-right Civic Democratic Party and its two junior coalition partners. **********In office for five years, Mr. Klaus, 56, was a disciple of the free market economist Milton Friedman and the former British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. His downfall was a result of the corruption brought about by the lack of regulation in the privatization of the Czech economy as it moved from Communism to capitalism and the corrupt campaign finance practices in his own party. **********The political crisis came after Mr. Klaus's colleagues in the Civic Democratic Party made damaging disclosures about a secret slush fund held by the party in a Swiss bank. **********The two junior coalition partners in the Klaus Government, the Christian Democrats and the Civic Democratic Alliance, withdrew their support, leaving the Cabinet with only half its members. **********Mr. Klaus, who rushed home on Saturday morning from a trip to Sarajevo, Bosnia, put up a last fight at an emergency meeting of his party's executive committee. **********But Mr. Havel, who does not have the constitutional power to dismiss a Government but has great moral authority in Czech politics, gave Mr. Klaus the final push in a televised speech Saturday afternoon. **********''The only fully sensible resolution would be for the Government as a whole, with its chairman in the lead, to hand in its resignation as soon as possible,'' Mr. Havel said. **********Mr. Havel tried to reassure the Czech people, who are only eight  years into democracy after more than 40 years of Communism, that the fall of a government was not the ''end of the world.'' **********The political upheaval has been brewing for months, largely because of corruption scandals in the stock market and the weak performance of the economy. **********But Mr. Klaus's undoing, came because of the financial scandal in his own party. Finance Minister Ivan Pilip, who also called for Mr. Klaus's resignation, acknowledged on Friday that the Civic Democratic Party held a Swiss bank account with $217,000 from private donors. **********Mr. Klaus has insisted that he did not know about the account, but members of his party assert that he was one of two party members who knew of it from its inception. **********Mr. Pilip was quoted in Czech newspapers on Saturday morning as saying that nearly all of the party's leaders were told of the account two months ago and that they decided that the money should be contributed to charity. **********Most serious from Mr. Klaus's point of view, according to Czech politicians, were accusations that the money was donated to the party in exchange for insider deals during the privatization process. **********The disclosures about the contributions were first made by the former Foreign Minister, Josef Zieleniec, who resigned last month, partly in disgust over what he called secrecy surrounding the party's finances. **********Two of the Civic Democratic Party's most senior members, Mr. Pilip and the former Interior Minister, Jan Ruml, who resigned this month, gave a harshly worded statement to Czech television on Friday saying that the continuation of Mr. Klaus in his leadership role was ''unbearable.'' **********Once the invincible politician of Central Europe, whose popularity was sometimes as high as that of Mr. Havel, Mr. Klaus has been losing popular support since before parliamentary elections last year. His party fared poorly in those elections, and he was forced to form a minority coalition Government. **********In the spring, a currency crisis forced the Government to devalue the crown, after Mr. Klaus had insisted that it would not be necessary. **********Mr. Klaus only grudgingly agreed in the last few months to plans for a securities exchange commission to regulate the scandal-ridden stock market. A number of small and medium-sized banks have collapsed this year, adding to the sense of unease in the economy. **********Most Czechs are not feeling richer, as Mr. Klaus promised five years ago, and many now know they may face unemployment as companies are forced to restructure.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/20/busin.snippet: Advertising column describes latest example of increasingly complex nature of promotional ploys that link marketers, retailers and media: an elaborate multimillion-dollar promotional marketing campaign centered on Women of the Year Awards bestowed...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/20/busin.main_headline: Glamour magazine signs up Diet Coke, NBC and Target.
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/20/busin.print_headline: Glamour magazine signs up Diet Coke, NBC and Target.
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/20/busin.body_text: **********IN a multifaceted promotional marketing campaign, a leading women's magazine is joining forces with a giant advertiser, a big retailer and the No. 1 television network. **********The elaborate multimillion-dollar campaign is centered on the Women of the Year Awards that are bestowed by Glamour, one of the Conde Nast magazines owned by Advance Publications. The partners recruited by Glamour for the foursome are: the Coca-Cola USA division of the Coca-Cola Company, which will be pitching its Diet Coke soft-drink brand; Target, the discount retail chain operated by the Dayton Hudson Corporation, which peddles Diet Coke and Glamour at its 751 stores, and NBC, part of the General Electric Company. **********Diet Coke will become the first sponsor of the Glamour honors for national achievement, which have been awarded since 1990, and create a parallel program, the Diet Coke Women at Their Best Awards, to fete women at the local level. The July, August and December issues of Glamour will carry advertising sections from Diet Coke tied to the promotion. **********Target shoppers, starting on June 29, will see in store aisles displays where they can enter names of women to compete for the local Diet Coke awards. Katie Couric, a Glamour honoree in 1992, will be the host of a special edition of the NBC News program ''Dateline NBC'' pegged to the 1997 Glamour awards -- and don't be surprised if a Diet Coke commercial or two turns up during that show, scheduled for Dec. 8. **********This ambitious cross-pollination is emblematic of the increasingly complex nature of promotional ploys that link marketers, retailers and the media. It seeks to build upon previous collaborative campaigns between Glamour and Target; Target and Diet Coke, and Diet Coke and NBC. The idea is for 1 times 4 to equal far more than 4 in terms of consumer interest and participation. **********''I hope everyone will get what they need out of this,'' said Mary Berner, publisher of Glamour in New York, ''emerging with something that helps all of our brands.'' **********She listed those goals: ''Glamour gets national television exposure. Diet Coke ties in with a franchise Coca-Cola thinks matches that brand and creates its own awards. Target gets store traffic. And NBC gets a terrific news program.'' **********Executives responsible for selling Diet Coke are enthusiastic about their role in what Lauren Bryant, assistant vice president for marketing operations at Coca-Cola USA in Atlanta, described as ''surrounding consumers'' with the promotion, particularly as the brand tries to refresh its appeal to the women who make up a large part of the Glamour readership, whose average age is 33. **********''This is so much in concert with our strategic positioning for Diet Coke as the brand for confident, fun, energetic women who want to look and feel their best,'' Ms. Bryant said. **********''The tonality and spirit of Glamour, the women they write about, are a great fit for us,'' she added. ''And the consumers walking into Target every day are looking for things like cosmetics, soft drinks and home furnishings to help them look and feel their best.'' **********Nancy Hendricks, Diet Coke brand manager at Coca-Cola USA, said that the ''aspirational aspect'' of the Glamour awards ''is very much in keeping with'' new Diet Coke advertising by Lowe & Partners/SMS in New York, part of the Lowe Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies, which carries the assertive theme ''You are what you drink.'' **********Ms. Berner agreed. **********''If you look at our magazine, which Ruth Whitney has edited for 30 years, we don't tell you you need to lose those five pounds to have a life,'' she said. ''You don't walk away saying, 'I'm fat; I have no boyfriend;  my house is ugly.' We tell you you're pretty terrific. So we get a more confident reader.'' **********Diet Coke signed a one-year agreement with Glamour to sponsor the awards and has subsequent right of first refusal. Winners in past years include, in addition to Ms. Couric, Jane Alexander, chairwoman of the National Endowment for the Arts; Sarah Brady, the gun-control lobbyist; Hillary Rodham Clinton; Joycelyn Elders, the former Surgeon General; Ruth Bader Ginsburg, the Supreme Court Justice; Elizabeth Glaser, the AIDS activist; Martina Nav ratilova, the tennis star, and Susan Sarandon, the actress. **********''The fact that the women are chosen by whether they have done something in a given year, and not just because they are celebrities, raises our comfort level,'' said David Corvo, vice president for NBC News in New York. ''We're confident that we and Glamour are on the same wavelength.'' **********''And though the show will have to appeal to a wide audience of men and women, as 'Dateline' always does,'' he added, ''an added attraction is that Glamour has an appeal to young women, which is a highly sought-after part of our audience.'' **********That is also a desirable demographic group for Target. **********''The Glamour reader fits our guest profile,'' said Lauri Matenaer, associate advertising manager at Target in Minneapolis, using that chain's term for customer, ''and Diet Coke is looking to beef up with our core guest.'' **********''We don't do a lot of different promotions,'' she added, ''but this was just so appealing.'' **********One danger with cross-promotions is that they become so intricate that consumers, cross-eyed, turn away. **********''Sometimes we complicate things in the spirit of making them bigger and better,'' Ms. Bryant of Coca-Cola USA said, ''but this is not some gee-whiz, over-the-top contraption.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/24/world.snippet: More than month after Uday Hussein, eldest son of Iraqi Pres Saddam Hussein, was shot in attempted assassination in Baghdad, he still has not been pictured standing, and there are suggestions that he may have been wounded more seriously than first...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/24/world.main_headline: Iraqi Exiles Say Hussein's Son May Be Paralyzed by Shooting
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/24/world.print_headline: Iraqi Exiles Say Hussein's Son May Be Paralyzed by Shooting
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/24/world.body_text: **********More than a month after he was shot in an attempted assassination in Baghdad, the eldest son of President Saddam Hussein still has not been pictured standing, and there are suggestions that he may have been wounded more seriously than first reported. **********At the same time, a leading Iraqi opposition figure said today in Syria that a subsequent roundup of suspects in Iraq has resulted in the arrests of some 600 people, including 20 high-ranking military officials. **********The opposition leader, Wafiq al-Samerai, a former Iraqi general and intelligence chief, said the blow to the opposition had been as serious as Iraq's penetration last June of a network reporting to another opposition group, the Iraqi National Accord. **********It was the third setback in eight months for opposition groups in Iraq. Opposition operations in northern Iraq had a setback in September when Iraq sent its forces into the northern Kurdish region. **********if Mr. Samerai's account is correct, it would be significant that the focus of Iraq's response to the attack on the younger Mr. Hussein has been on the military leaders and others from the Sunni Muslim-dominated central part of Iraq that provides the base of support for Saddam Hussein, the Iraqi leader. **********In its public statements, Iraq has appeared to blame the Shiite Muslim opponents of Mr. Hussein for the attack. The Shiites, whose base of operations is in neighboring Iran,  have claimed responsibility for the Jan. 12 shooting. **********Uday Hussein, 33, is a powerful figure with many enemies. He has been regarded by many as a possible heir to his father. Gunmen armed with machine guns opened fire on him from close range as he sat in his Porsche. The attack stunned many Iraqis for its brazenness. **********Interviewed several times from his hospital bed by Iraqi television, the younger Mr. Hussein has said that he is recovering, although he disclosed that bullets remain lodged in his body. **********In each appearance, the wounded Mr. Hussein has remained sitting in bed, with his torso and legs covered. Opposition officials who have studied the pictures say that he may be suffering from partial paralysis. **********Mr. Samerai, who fled Iraq in 1994, said the arrests could hurt the opposition in Iraq.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/24/busin.snippet: Floyd Norris column contends Thailand's economic troubles started processes that are causing currency turmoil through much of Asia and producing selloffs of nearly every stock market in world; maintains that processes have been complicated, and ha...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/24/busin.main_headline: Thailand's Currency Flutters, And Wind Is Felt in the U.S.
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/24/busin.print_headline: THE ASIAN CRISIS: MARKET PLACE; Thailand's Currency Flutters, And Wind Is Felt in the U.S.
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/24/busin.body_text: **********Can the economic troubles of Thailand, a small country in Southeast Asia, really have begun the processes now causing currency turmoil through much of Asia and producing selloffs in nearly every stock market in the world? **********Yes. **********But the processes have been complicated, and have taken months to shake the confidence of international investors and the bull markets around the world. By yesterday, that confidence had plunged, and stock markets fell sharply. The selloff in the United States, which sent the Dow Jones industrial average down 2.3 percent, was the mildest among major markets. It was a selloff that began in Hong Kong, where the stock market has fallen 23 percent this week. **********The effect of all the turmoil in Asia will almost certainly mean slower economic growth in that area and lower profits for some American and other multinational companies. And those Americans who invested in some mutual funds devoted to Asian markets have lost billions of dollars. **********But until this week, most economists had thought the impacts -- both economic and financial -- would be minor. The selloffs, however, have raised the specter of a worldwide loss of investor confidence. Were that to happen, the economic impact could be much greater. **********Most countries in Southeast Asia had chosen to tie their currencies to the dollar, with an exchange rate that is fixed or allowed to narrowly fluctuate. That had advantages for businesses, which could plan with some certainty, but it defied the fact that the economies were performing differently from the United States economy and each other. **********Over time, Thailand -- the first of the countries to suffer -- found itself with a currency that was overvalued. Imports were flooding in as Thais bought foreign luxury goods, and exports stagnated. Some international speculators began to bet the currency would be devalued. They did that by borrowing the currency -- called the baht -- and selling baht for dollars or other currencies. They would profit if they could later repurchase the baht for less. **********Thailand's responded with fury. It denounced speculators and took steps to punish them. It raised interest rates -- making it more expensive to borrow baht -- and prohibited some foreigners from possessing baht. That briefly strengthened the baht, and some speculators suffered substantial losses. **********But in the meantime, many Thais, particularly business people, became worried. They had borrowed dollars to finance their businesses, rather than borrowing baht, because interest rates in dollars were lower. If the baht were to fall, they would be in trouble, since the dollars needed to repay loans would cost a lot more baht. So many Thais bought dollars to protect themselves. And that buying, coupled with that of international speculators, overwhelmed the Thai Government's defenses. **********''When you have currencies under pressure, almost everyone becomes a speculator,'' Peter Allen, the head of emerging markets research at BankBoston, said yesterday. **********That process has been repeated in several Asian countries, among them Malaysia, Indonesia and the Philippines. Now it has spread to Hong Kong, a darling of international investors even after China retook control on July 1. The Hong Kong dollar has been fixed to the American dollar since 1984, under a system known as a currency board. Hong Kong currency is issued not by the Government, but by three banks. For every Hong Kong dollar they issue, they must deposit an equivalent number of American dollars. **********Hong Kong's interest rates have also been closer to American ones, and few people thought the currency was likely to succumb to pressure. But speculation it might nonetheless led to some of the same selling seen in other markets. **********To keep the currency stable, the annual interest rate on money borrowed for one night rose to as high as 300 percent. That makes it very expensive to speculate against the currency, and yesterday, even as Hong Kong stocks plunged, the Hong Kong dollar rose a bit -- evidently as currency speculators retreated. **********John Greenwood, the chief economist for GT Global, a mutual fund management company and a man named to the Order of the British Empire for his role in conceiving the Hong Kong currency system in 1984, said yesterday that he expected the Hong Kong currency to hold its value. But he noted that selling pressure had been greater than at any time since the Tiananmen Square killings in Beijing in 1989. **********He also said that were high rates to continue for months -- even at 30 percent or so -- it would depress the Hong Kong economy. **********It has taken months to persuade many investors that there was more to this crisis than currency values. When the baht cracked in July, Thai stocks rallied. (They have since fallen.) Numerous analysts opined that Thailand and other Asian countries  had buoyant economies that would perhaps grow even stronger since they were now blessed with cheaper currencies, making their exports more competitive. Some investors who withdrew money from Asia moved it to Latin America, confident that emerging markets were the place to be. **********But gradually, fear has set in that Asia, the strongest economic region in recent years, might be in trouble. That has set off alarms about growth elsewhere. **********Against the backdrop of record-high stock markets around much of the world, the worries led to waves of selling yesterday, first in Asia, then in Europe, then in the Americas. Latin America was especially hit, but the United States got off relatively lightly. In fact, after strong rallies earlier this week on strong profits from companies like I.B.M. and Microsoft, major American stock indexes remain higher for the week even after yesterday's selloff. **********For the American economy, the direct implications of the Asian turmoil are clearly negative, but have seemed likely to be mild. They will depress the profits of companies that sell things to the affected Asian countries. Relatively few Southeast Asian exports compete directly with American products, but those that do will likely be cheaper and thus do better. That could, of course, be good news for American consumers. **********The stock market selloffs yesterday smacked of panic, and panic usually abates within a few days. In fact, a security traded on the American Stock Exchange, equivalent to a basket of Hong Kong stocks, ended yesterday 3 percent higher than the Hong Kong market had been, indicating some traders expected Hong Kong to at least partly recover today. The longer-term question will be whether the Asian turmoil means world growth is likely to slow significantly. Were that the case, the high level of stock prices that has prevailed here and abroad could be in serious danger.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/20/busin.snippet: Government antitrust officials say internal company document demonstrates that merger of office supply giants Staples Inc and Office Depot Inc would allow new company to raise prices with impunity in dozens of markets across the US; lawyers for Fe...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/20/busin.main_headline: Antitrust Officials Argue Against Office Supply Deal
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/20/busin.print_headline: Antitrust Officials Argue Against Office Supply Deal
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/20/busin.body_text: **********Government antitrust officials said today that internal company documents demonstrated that a merger of the office supply giants Staples Inc. and Office Depot Inc. would allow the new company to raise prices with impunity in dozens of markets across the United States. **********Lawyers for the Federal Trade Commission opened their case against the merger before Judge Thomas F. Hogan of the Federal District Court for the District of Columbia. In a hearing expected to last a week, the agency is asking for a temporary restraining order to block the proposed $4 billion transaction, which the five-member commission  has twice voted to reject as anti-competitive. **********George S. Cary, deputy director of the F.T.C.'s antitrust bureau, said that internal pricing studies by Staples showed that the office supply chain charged significantly more for identical goods in markets where it had no competition from either of the other two office supply superstore chains, Office Depot and Office Max Inc. **********Mr. Cary said that company documents proved the Government's central contention: ''Where Office Depot and Staples compete, their prices are 5 to 10 to 15 percent lower than where they don't compete.'' **********If the merger is approved, Mr. Cary argued, the new company would be able to exercise its market power to raise prices for office products from ballpoint pens to file cabinets. **********Responding to the Government's presentation, lawyers for the companies brought before the judge newspaper advertisements, television and radio spots and a huge red and white banner promising lower costs and lower prices from the merger. **********''These defendants will not disappoint,'' said Donald G. Kempf Jr., a lawyer whose animated courtroom performance contrasted with Mr. Cary's low-key argument. ''They will deliver those lower prices to the American consumer.'' **********Mr. Kempf, who is a partner with the law firm of Kirkland & Ellis, said that executives had built the two companies into marketing powerhouses by buying in volume and undercutting the prices of competitors. He said that the new company intended to continue to grow after the merger by offering convenience and low prices. **********''The notion that Staples and Office Depot as a combined company would do an about-face and raise prices is not only wrong, it's unthinkable,'' Mr. Kempf said. **********Much of the day's argument centered on the definition of the market in which the superstores compete. **********The Government contended that office supply superstores competed  only against each other; eliminating one of the three major companies would leave at most two competitors in many markets and only one in 42 others. **********But the companies responded that the superstores controlled only 6 percent of the overall office products business. They compete against mail-order operations, local stationers, Internet buying services and large general retailers like Kmart and Wal-Mart. **********Mr. Kempf said that Wal-Mart was  expanding its sales of office goods while other new and existing concerns were competing head-to-head against the three superstores. **********''None of these people has gotten the word that they can't compete against Staples and Office Depot,'' Mr. Kempf said. **********Judge Hogan is expected to rule on the Government's request for an injunction in June. If he grants it, the case will be tried by an F.T.C. administrative law judge.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/23/busin.snippet: Philip Morris Companies announces strong second-quarter earnings; net income rose 13.3 percent, to $1.83 billion from $1.62 billion in year-earlier quarter; sales grew 5.2 percent, to $18.4 billion from $17.5 billion; chart (L)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/23/busin.main_headline: Earnings at Philip Morris Were Strong in 2d Quarter
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/23/busin.print_headline: Earnings at Philip Morris Were Strong in 2d Quarter
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/23/busin.body_text: **********The Philip Morris Companies announced strong second-quarter earnings yesterday, reflecting significant gains in domestic tobacco profits and market share as well as in international sales. **********Net income rose 13.3 percent, to $1.83 billion, or 76 cents a share, from $1.62 billion, or 66 cents a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier. Sales grew 5.2 percent, to $18.4 billion from $17.5 billion. **********Earnings for the second quarter matched the First Call consensus of 76 cents a share estimated by 16 analysts. Shares of Philip Morris rose $2.125 each yesterday, closing at $42.625 on the New York Stock Exchange. **********The second-quarter results were ''a remarkable performance, given an overall shrinking cigarette market,'' said Martin Feldman, a tobacco analyst at Smith Barney. **********For the second consecutive quarter, retail-store data from the A. C. Nielsen Company showed that Philip Morris's share of cigarette sales in the United States exceeded 50 percent. In the second quarter the total was 51.1 percent. The share of retail sales for the company's Marlboro brand rose 1.8 percentage points, to 35.2 percent. **********''Marlboro was the driving force of the company's cigarette business, amounting to more than 60 percent'' of its volume in the United States, said Emanuel Goldman, a securities analyst for Paine Webber. **********Domestically, the company sold 5 percent more cigarettes in the second quarter than it had in the comparable quarter last year, amounting to 60.8 billion cigarettes. Operating income from tobacco in the United States was $1.2 billion, 11.6 percent higher a year earlier. **********Worldwide, the company sold 238 billion cigarettes in the second quarter, 6.8 percent more than a year earlier. Worldwide volume for the Marlboro brand was up 5.4 percent. **********In Central and Eastern Europe, volume was up 10.5 percent, to 47 billion cigarettes. And in France, sales were up two-tenths of 1 percent despite the successful introduction of a value-oriented new brand by Rothmans, a subsidiary of Financiere Richemont A.G. of Switzerland. **********Philip Morris's gains in international results came despite the strengthening of the American dollar against European currencies and the Japanese yen, which makes American goods relatively more expensive. **********During the quarter, which ended June 30, the company agreed to be part of the tentative June 21 tobacco settlement agreement that is now being debated in Congress. The settlement would require cigarette companies to pay $368.5 billion over the next 25 years to compensate states for the costs of treating smoking-related illness and to finance nationwide anti-smoking programs. **********Operating income at the company's Kraft Foods unit in North America grew 12.4 percent ''due to the consolidation of the food business, volume growth and some pricing,'' Mr. Feldman said. **********''The moves they've made over the last few years are paying off for Kraft,'' Mr. Goldman said, ''including the way in which they've taken traditional, ho-hum brands and made them exciting.'' **********But at the company's international food division, volume was down 1 percent, Mr. Feldman said, though operating profit margins improved to 10.9 percent in the second quarter from 10.3 percent a year earlier. **********At the company's Miller Beer unit, sales, in volume terms, were up 3.1 percent, to 12.4 million barrels, ''a very good performance,'' Mr. Feldman said. **********Among key brands, shipments of Miller Lite rose 3.6 percent in volume, and Miller High Life shipments were up 10 percent. ''The company's new advertising seems to be working,'' Mr. Feldman said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/14/world.snippet: Jordanian soldier opens fire on group of Israeli schoolgirls visiting shared patch of land in Jordan Valley known as the Island of Peace, killing seven girls and wounding six others before his rifle jams and he is seized; photos; map; 23-year-old ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/14/world.body_text: **********A Jordanian soldier opened fire this morning on a group of Israeli schoolgirls visiting a shared patch of land in the Jordan Valley known as the Island of Peace, killing seven of the girls and wounding six others before his rifle jammed and he was seized. **********Nothing was immediately known of the soldier's motive. He was identified as Ahmed Mustafa, 23, an army driver from Adasiya, a village near the site of the attack, which occurred at about 11 A.M. According to some reports, other Jordanian soldiers described him as unstable, but Jordanian officials gave no immediate details from his interrogation. **********The sudden bolt of horror crashed in the middle of a raging political storm among the Israelis, Palestinians and Jordanians, and there were immediate suggestions among some Israelis that the gunman had been inspired by a sharply critical letter that King Hussein of Jordan sent to Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu on Sunday. **********The King denied the possibility that the shooting was related to his letter and broke off a visit to Spain to return to Jordan and issue a strong statement of condolence and remorse. He said he felt ''a deep sense of shame and anger that this thing should have happened.'' **********Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, who had begun the day with a blistering attack on Mr. Netanyahu in a speech in Bethlehem, later telephoned the Prime Minister to express his condolences and to propose a meeting. After rejecting an Israeli plan, offered last Friday, to withdraw from another 9.1 percent of the West Bank, Mr. Arafat had refused to take calls from Mr. Netanyahu. **********The 80 seventh- and eighth-graders from Beit Shemesh, west of Jerusalem, were on a field trip to the Jordan Valley and Golan Heights. Part of the outing was a visit to a tract of Israeli-farmed land between the Jordan and Yarmuk Rivers. **********The territory, about 10 miles south of the Sea of Galilee, was formally returned to Jordan when it made peace with Israeli in 1994, but was then leased back to an Israeli kibbutz. Naharayim came to be known as the Island of Peace, and is a popular spot to visit in the scenic northern Jordan Valley. **********The girls who survived the attack had varied recollections of the details, but they agreed that the eighth-grade girls had left their bus and were being told about the island by a guide when a soldier charged at them from a hill, an M-16 automatic rifle blazing. **********''The bus driver yelled, 'Get down!' I saw my friend lying next to me, she had blood all over, it was all over my pants,'' recalled Oshrat Azulai, 13, surrounded by sobbing parents and friends after the surviving girls returned to Beit Shemesh. ''Others were lying around bleeding and not moving. Everyone was shouting and running. The teachers stood in front of us. Two Arabs grabbed him; he was very near us.'' **********After finishing one clip of ammunition, the gunman inserted another, but his rifle jammed, and Jordanian soldiers overpowered him, yelling ''Madman! ''Madman!'' The soldiers then stripped off their fatigue shirts and rushed to help the dying and wounded girls. **********Some of the teachers said the Jordanians refused to let the Israelis take the wounded girls to Israel, and pushed a teacher away by force. Seven girls were taken to a Jordanian hospital, where five were pronounced dead. Two others died on arrival at an Israeli hospital. **********Israel's Defense Minister, Yitzhak  Mordechai, went to the scene and was joined there by Crown Prince Hassan of Jordan, King Hussein's brother. Mr. Mordechai said the soldier was a driver who had taken the weapon from another soldier. **********The description of the Jordanian soldier carried an eerie resemblance to that of the Israeli Army clerk who emptied a clip of bullets at Palestinians in the Hebron vegetable market  on Jan. 1, wounding five people. The Israeli, Noam Friedman, 22, has since been found mentally unsound by court-appointed psychiatrists. **********The shock of the killings spread instantly through the highly charged Middle East. Tensions between Palestinians and Israelis rose in recent days over the Israeli decisions first to build a new housing project for Jews in eastern Jerusalem, and then to withdraw from what the Palestinians charged was far too little of the West Bank. **********Mr. Arafat had refused to accept the ceded land and broke contacts with Israel and, defying Israeli protests, called an international meeting in Gaza for Saturday. **********On Sunday King Hussein sent a stinging personal letter to Mr. Netanyahu, charging that he was destroying the peace through his actions. **********At late-night funeral services today for four of the girls in Beit Shemesh, Mr. Netanyahu put a defiant edge on his eulogy. ''If anybody thinks that the murder of little girls will break this people, he doesn't know a thing about what this people is,'' he declared. ''If someone thinks he will break our spirit so that we give up our sacred homeland and our eternal capital, he doesn't know the great strength embodied in each and every person standing around me here today.'' **********Earlier in the day, Foreign Minister David Levy more overtly linked the shooting to the statements of Mr. Arafat and King Hussein. ''Who knows how many of these gun-toting lunatics are waiting for the green light in the form of a remark in which Israel is being described today,'' he angrily declared. **********Another Cabinet member, Education Minister Zevulun Hammer, was even more explicit. ''Perhaps the conclusion is that the King must hold his tongue so that a soldier doesn't take his words to mean more than he intended,'' he said on Army Radio. **********Some Palestinians said it was the Israelis who had set the tone for violence with their recent decisions. ''The situation which was created by the Israelis the last two or three weeks has created a lot of tension in the area,'' said Nabil Abu Rudeiheh, an adviser to Mr. Arafat. **********But both King Hussein and Prince Hassan denied a link between the King's letter and the crime, and both  took pains to underscore their commitment to peace with Israel. At the same time, Israeli news reports noted that on learning of the incident in Spain, King Hussein first telephoned President Ezer Weizman, then Defense Minister Mordechai, and only later Mr. Netanyahu. **********''Our soldiers are not politicized,'' Prince Hassan said while inspecting the site. ''If there has been a harsh exchange of words over other issues, let's try for once to keep our humanity apart from the political atmosphere. And if there has been a harsh exchange of words, I think it is probably intended to serve the interest of peace and to get back to working for peace instead of, God forbid, stimulating or inspiring such black acts of murder.'' **********In Spain, King Hussein said, ''When I warned a few days ago of the danger of the possibility of violence, I never thought it would lead to this.'' **********According to reports from Amman, the Jordanian capital, most Jordanians expressed dismay at the shooting. There were also reports that hundreds of soldiers lined up to give blood at the hospital where the girls were taken. **********''Now the Israelis are going to think that every Jordanian is like that stupid soldier and is going to attack every Israeli who comes to Jordan,'' said Maher Kadri, an Amman businessman. ''All we need is one drop of acid and an entire bucket of water turns bad.'' **********--------------------        Clinton Urges Restraint **********WASHINGTON, March 13 (By The New York Times) -- With the killing today of Israeli schoolchildren by a Jordanian soldier and ground-breaking expected early next week on a bitterly disputed Israeli settlement in East Jerusalem, President Clinton today implored regional leaders to exercise restraint. **********Mr. Clinton called the shootings a ''senseless denial of a future for these children.'' **********American officials said they would use the meeting of Palestinian and Arab leaders on Saturday in Gaza to press for calm. **********The meeting was called by Yasir Arafat, and Washington's agreement to send its Consul General in Jerusalem has been criticized by the Israeli Government and American Jewish organizations. But American officials say the meeting will be a discussion, not a negotiation, and that it will be a good occasion to try to encourage the Arab parties not to overreact to the groundbreaking at the East Jerusalem settlement.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/14/busin.snippet: Prophets of doom are beginning to be heard warning that economic globalization is propelling the world to some indescribable catastrophe. The warnings are frequently couched in apocalyptic terms — and usually imply it is all America's fault.. Typi...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/14/busin.main_headline: Thinking Ahead / Commentary : The Voices of Global Doom Are Wrong
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/14/busin.print_headline: Thinking Ahead / Commentary : The Voices of Global Doom Are Wrong
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/14/busin.body_text: **********Prophets of doom are beginning to be heard warning that economic globalization is propelling the world to some indescribable catastrophe. The warnings are frequently couched in apocalyptic terms — and usually imply it is all America's fault. **********Typical of the genre is a new book by the American author William Greider, "One World, Ready or Not: The Manic Logic of Global Capitalism," which is currently attracting attention in Washington. **********Mr. Greider expounds the familiar theme that multinational corporations are ruthlessly exploiting the workers of the world by switching production to wherever wages are lowest. Low-paid workers not only are stealing jobs from their brethren in richer countries, the theory goes, but will drag world wages down to their level. **********That much we have heard before, despite the fact that numerous serious economists have researched the proposition and found little evidence to support it — most foreign investment, for instance, leads to increased exports from home. **********But Mr. Greider and his fellow doomsayers undauntedly go much further. The mass victimization of workers, they say, will ultimately provoke a huge social upheaval. The world, Mr. Greider writes, is heading toward some kind of abyss — "an economic or political cataclysm of unknowable dimensions." **********There is no doubt that globalization is already provoking a political backlash. It can be seen in labor protests on the streets of Europe and in the postures of politicians such as Pat Buchanan and Ross Perot in the United States. **********Those angry voices will grow louder when recession next bites. War and suffering have not come to an end, and neither have ideological conflicts. But the doomsayers' warnings are based on severely flawed premises — and they stem from moral rather than economic judgments. **********Perhaps that is not surprising. For those who don't like capitalism, globalization presents an awkward problem — by most standard measures, it has been far too successful. **********The breakdown of economic barriers and the spread of private investment around the world are finally bringing hope and prosperity to vast regions hitherto mired in poverty. Developing nations are scrambling to climb on the bandwagon. **********This is because, although globalization does reflect Anglo-Saxon free-market principles, it is not exactly being forced down the rest of the world's throat by the United States. As China alone should show, most of the world is turning to capitalism because it has seen that it works. **********Of course, anyone can travel to Indonesia, as Mr. Greider did, and find labor abuses. But the vast majority of investment by multinational corporations does not go to low-wage countries. It goes to developed regions such as Europe, Canada and the United States. **********When companies choose investment sites, the prime considerations are usually not low wages, which account for only a fraction of production costs, but other factors, such as proximity to markets, transport and communications. **********Nor do most multinational companies abandon their factories when wages rise to look for lower-cost production elsewhere, as is frequently alleged. As Gary Hufbauer of the Institute for International Economics in Washington points out, most multinationals are not in labor-intensive businesses. **********When such things do happen, it is normally only in the highly labor-dependent clothing sector, in which multinationals are predominantly Asian, and in footwear. Even in those industries, most multinationals pay high wages by local standards. **********Of course there is exploitation — but that hardly began with globalization. American fortunes were made from sweatshops in the late 19th century and from slave labor before that. **********It is also true that not everyone is yet benefiting from the global economy, particularly in the poorest countries. But so far, globalization has done far more good than harm — and most multinational corporations are actually better behaved than they used to be.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/05/world.print_headline: Rights Group Assails U.S. on Land Mines and Ties With China
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/05/world.body_text: **********The Clinton Administration was accused of arrogance and ''active obstruction'' today in its policies toward international human rights in the annual report of Human Rights Watch. **********In a survey of 65 nations, the United States Government received some particularly strong criticism from the private human rights group on issues ranging from the global attempt to destroy land mines to the interplay of economic and human rights values in relations with China. **********''Many Western countries seemed more concerned with striking business deals than protecting human rights,'' Kenneth Roth, executive director of the group, declared in making public the 465-page survey of government repression in the world. ''The fundamental principle that human rights apply to all nations without exception -- the universality of human rights -- came under sustained attack in 1997.'' **********He called for an end to ''hostage politique'' in China relations: ''bargaining for the release of single individuals without changing the underlying structure that allows the Chinese Government to detain thousands of others in jail and to make new arrests.'' **********Human Rights Watch said the year was also notable for the emergence of a fresh twist on repression in Central Africa with the slogan of ''African solutions to African problems'' used as a ''thin cover'' for abusing citizens. **********Eritrea, Ethiopia, Rwanda and Congo (the former Zaire) were singled out, with European and North American governments accused of being eager to build ties with a new generation of African leaders who allegedly fail to rein in their security forces' resort to repression. **********In addition, the group described the United Nations Commission on Human Rights as ''increasingly crippled by its own indifference to the human rights record of its membership.'' This is a ''charade,'' Mr. Roth said, that has left the United Nations ''enfeebled'' in defending human rights as an issue that this year cost the lives of 15 rights monitors, all but one of them perishing in either Colombia or Rwanda. **********The criticism of the Clinton Administration was focused on its refusal to sign the treaty banning land mines and its reservations toward plans for an International Criminal Court and the proposed world ban on ''child soldiers'' below the age of 18. **********James P. Rubin, the State Department spokesman, described as ''obviously ridiculous'' the charge that the Government ''actively obstructed'' any move to strengthen the International Criminal Court in its proposed role of deterring despots. He also said there was ''no question'' the United States was a world leader in fighting the land mine problem, despite some reservations about the new treaty. **********''I think that if you look around the world and you ask the people of the world which nation they look to as the beacon for human rights, democracy and freedom, there's no question the answer will be the United States,'' Mr. Rubin said. **********But Mr. Roth contended there was ''a troubling arrogance'' in Washington toward international human rights law, with the Government wary of treaty provisions that might touch on domestic rights abuses. **********On China, he said Beijing was the greatest beneficiary of ''selective commitment'' to human rights by world powers eying the huge China market.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/19/world.snippet: Worst floods since 1961 ravage Somalia's Juba River valley, as torrential rains continue; flooding has killed hundreds of people, destroyed crops and food stores and turned many villages into islands; roads, airstrips and bridges are underwater fo...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/19/world.main_headline: Rain Is a New Agony for Somalia, As Villages Are Suddenly Islands
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/19/world.print_headline: Rain Is a New Agony for Somalia, As Villages Are Suddenly Islands
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/19/world.body_text: **********From the air, the place where the Juba River used to run is just a serpentine current threading through vast tracts of swamped fields and newly formed lakes. Alongside the turgid current, the roofs of villages peak out in clusters above the gray waters. **********Hundreds of desperate people have camped along the thin remains of dikes, waving hopefully at passing airplanes that cannot land. Others have clustered on bridges and bits of high ground surrounded by water, erecting tents and lean-tos. Many villages have become islands, cut off by the floodwaters. At its widest points, the flood stretches for seven miles on either side of the river, running as far as the eye can see. **********For the last month, the worst floods since 1961 have ravaged the Juba River valley in Somalia, killing hundreds of people and destroying crops and food stores on thousands of acres of farmland. Roads, airstrips and bridges were underwater today for a 200-mile stretch of the river, from the towns of Bardera in the north to Jumaame in the south. **********''It's completely flooded,'' Patrick Berner, a worker for the International Committee for the Red Cross, said. ''People are trapped. Some are sitting on dikes waiting for help. They are just trying to survive. They don't have any more food.'' **********Unlike past floods, the floods this year are hitting a nation without a central Government or a national army, a fractured country whose infrastructure has been ruined by six years of clan warfare. A famine caused by the fighting killed about 300,000 people in 1992. **********''We have no government, and we have no ability to solve this problem, no finances, nothing,'' Hassan Mohammed Mohammed, the commissioner of Bardera District, said. ''We are trying to organize people and to say you must do something yourself.'' **********What is more, United Nations officials said, few nations are willing to help Somalia in the aftermath of the disastrous 1993 United States-led mission to help the famine victims. **********The relief efforts ended in a debacle, with 18 American soldiers dead because of fighting among faction leaders and with widespread looting siphoning off food and supplies intended for the hungry. **********''There are concerns about coming to Somalia,'' Catherine Bertini, the executive director of the World Food Program, said in an interview here. ''Nobody wants to have a repeat of what happened a few years ago.'' **********For two weeks, United Nations agencies and relief groups have been clamoring for donations from developed countries. So far, they have raised $5.4 million of the $9.6 million they say is needed. **********Yet the relief operation has barely gotten under way. No country has been willing to donate helicopters to reach the flood victims, and though three small boats have been flown in to begin distributing food and medicine to villages in the flood plain, they are too few to help the majority of those stranded. **********This week, the United Nations rented four helicopters from a South African company, but they are not expected to begin flying into Somalia until Saturday. At least six more are needed, officials said. Ten small boats donated by Norway are also to be shipped in later this week. **********Though the Juba River often floods in October and November, the rains this year came early and have been torrential and unrelenting. **********It has rained nearly every day in Somalia for the last six weeks. In the Juba River valley alone, most towns have received 10 times the normal rainfall over the last six weeks, according to satellite imagery. **********Heavy rains in the Ethiopian highlands have contributed to the flood crests surging south along the Juba and Shabelle river in Somalia. In Kenya, the Tana River has also broken its banks and the coastal region around Mombassa has been hit with flash floods. **********Along the Juba River, tens of thousands of farmers have seen their crops, food stores and homes destroyed. Local politicians and employees of relief groups have told United Nations officials that at least 1,265 people have drowned. United Nations officials estimate that 223,000 of the 800,000 people living in the fertile lands between the Shabelle and the Juba rivers have been displaced. **********In the village of Sarinley, about two miles north of Bardera, residents said the river spilled over its banks on Oct. 19. For several days, the village was a small island, with most of its 370 families crowded onto a hillock surrounded by water, until the last few days. **********''The people here have never heard or seen such flooding,'' the village chief, Bara Irad Ali, said. ''It has never happened in history.'' **********As the town received a small shipment of biscuits and maize flour from aid workers today, farmers told of having lost everything when the river rose. Underground stores of sorghum were ruined. The irrigated onion and tobacco fields along the water are washed away. The fruit trees in riverside groves are dying. **********People have been reduced to eating bitter greens and slaughtering their livestock, most of which is suffering from foot diseases. **********''Please help me,'' an 85-year-old woman who gave her name only as Norio pleaded with a visitor. ''My house was flooded and destroyed. I have nowhere to stay in the night.'' **********Ahmed Gure, a 40-year-old farmer with 15 children, is typical of the farmers in Sarinley. When the waters rose four weeks ago, he and his family had to flee to higher land. Now, the 74 acres he had planted with onions, corn and tobacco are inundated and all his reserves have been flooded. **********''All of them are gone,'' he said, pointing out to the expanse of fetid water where his farm was. ''I have no idea what to do. This is a disaster.'' **********The rising floodwaters have brought other kinds of death, village leaders said. Many people are coming down with malaria, respiratory infections, and dysentery. **********At the hospital in Bardera, the director, Dr. Kasim Aden Egal, said he feared the worst was yet to come. He said the hospital lacks medicine and supplies since Doctors Without Borders, a relief organization, pulled out of the area six months ago when one of its doctors was killed by militiamen in another town, Baidoa. **********''The water is highly contaminated,'' he said. ''If there was a cholera outbreak, we are not in a position to do a lot.''
