https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/20/world.snippet: International delegation breaks ground near Kumho, North Korea, for project in which Western nations will give North Korea two modern nuclear reactors in exchange for North Korea's accord to give up older reactors that could be used to make nuclea...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/20/world.main_headline: A Ceremony in North Korea Breaks More Than Ground
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/20/world.print_headline: A Ceremony in North Korea Breaks More Than Ground
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/20/world.body_text: **********In a remote North Korean field surrounded by terraced hillsides, international delegates broke ground today on a remarkable construction project under which Western countries will give North Korea two modern nuclear reactors. **********The ceremony, which many critics had doubted would ever take place, marks a milestone in opening up North Korea to the outside world. It will lead to thousands of South Korean laborers, presumably well salted with spies, working within North Korea and sending mail and equipment and messages between two nations that technically remain at war. **********North Korea is perhaps the most isolated nation in the world, as well as one of the most armed, and today's spectacle of South Korean and American officials helping to open a nuclear construction program there would have been almost inconceivable just a few years ago. Some experts still doubt that the program will ever be completed, but for many the surprise is that it has gotten as far as it has. **********The nuclear reactors are being built for North Korea in exchange for Pyongyang agreeing to give up older reactors that international experts believed were a front for making nuclear weapons. After a tense showdown three years ago that by some accounts came close to war, North Korea agreed to abandon its nuclear program in exchange for getting shipments of oil and the construction of the two new light-water reactors, which are much more difficult to divert into the construction of nuclear weapons. **********''The work we celebrate today is on the cutting edge of future progress in the search for peace on this peninsula,'' Paul Cleveland, the American representative at the Korean Peninsula Energy Development Organization, declared as leaden skies drizzled on the dignitaries. The organization is a government-backed international coalition overseeing the reactor program. **********But the main ground that was broken was diplomatic. The Korean War, which lasted from 1950 to 1953, ended with only an armistice, and a final peace treaty, while under discussion, still seems some distance away. Thus the ceremony marked an unusual situation in which two archrivals agreed that one should build the other two nuclear reactors, before they even agreed to end their war. **********The situation was novel enough that 40 North Korean bureaucrats brought in for the ceremony seemed flummoxed about how they should react to South Koreans. According to a pool report by a small group of journalists whom North Korea allowed to attend the groundbreaking, some North Koreans applauded the chief South Korean delegate, while others looked around for guidance. **********The Korean Energy Development Organization has its headquarters in New York, but is charged with getting around minefields, literal and figurative, to set up reactors on the other side of the globe. Construction is expected to take up to a decade and cost $5 billion, most of which will come from South Korea and Japan. **********Despite its nominal focus, the organization is about developing far more than energy. It is a broad effort to entice North Korea into a dialogue and to take steps to build trust and eventually nurture a peace on the Korean Peninsula. **********''I think the presence of a South Korean work force in North Korea will help bring about changes and openness in North Korea,'' a senior South Korean official in Seoul said in a telephone interview. ''I understand 5,000 South Korean workers will go to North Korea to implement this, and I think that's an important first step in building inter-Korea exchanges.'' **********The North Korean customs officer who cleared diplomats and journalists coming from South Korea by ship to attend the ceremony also seemed to anticipate broader exchanges. According to the pool report, he joked, ''If it keeps on like this, there will be more every trip, and the whole of the South Korean population will soon be in the North.'' **********Still, the South Korean workers will be closely monitored and carefully segregated from North Korean society, barred from any contact with North Koreans except those chosen to work on the project. Even travel on North Korean roads does not offer a chance for contact with ordinary people. **********Many visitors have said North Korea is on the verge of a major famine, but the pool reporters said that in the area of the ceremony -- Kumho, on the east coast -- they saw no obvious sign of malnutrition and the fields seemed lush. Americans who have been based in Kumho to prepare for the reactor construction told reporters they also have not seen any signs of hunger, the pool dispatch said. **********Some critics have complained about the notion of the West helping  pay for nuclear reactors in North Korea. But Stephen W. Bosworth, the American who is executive director of the energy development organization, noted that the construction was obligatory under the agreement whereby North Korea gave up its old reactors. **********''We are not doing this to help the North Koreans,'' Mr. Bosworth said. ''We are doing this as our part of the bargain.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/18/busin.print_headline: ASHLAND MAY SELL UNIT INSTEAD OF SPINNING IT OFF
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/18/busin.body_text: **********After originally planning to spin off its oil and natural gas unit, Ashland Inc. is now considering a sale to another company in the face of sliding energy stock prices. In early March, the company filed for an initial offering of roughly 18 percent of the exploration and production business, which it has named Blazer Energy. The idea was to let the market set the unit's value, then spin off the remaining stock to Ashland shareholders. But Ashland officials said yesterday that they would allow third parties to examine the financial and operating information of Blazer Energy. The filing for Blazer estimated an offering price of $24 a share for 17.5 million shares. With debt, that valued the company at roughly $530 million.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/11/busin.snippet: US creates 262,000 jobs in December, and hourly pay rises by 6 cents, providing powerful new evidence that the economy is gathering fresh momentum and raising specter of higher inflation and of a decision by Federal Reserve to raise interest rates...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/11/busin.main_headline: JOB REPORT SHOWS UNEXPECTED VIGOR FOR U.S. ECONOMY
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/11/busin.print_headline: JOB REPORT SHOWS UNEXPECTED VIGOR FOR U.S. ECONOMY
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/11/busin.body_text: **********Jobs and paychecks grew with unexpected vigor in December, powerful evidence that the economy was gathering fresh momentum as 1996 ended, Labor Department figures showed today. **********Although the unemployment rate was unchanged at 5.3 percent, the 262,000 jobs created last month were  far more than economists had predicted, and there was a second consecutive large gain in average hourly earnings. Analysts said the robust report raised the specter of higher inflation and of a decision by the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates to counter it. **********Both fears combined to cause the bond and stock markets to plunge, although the stock market later recovered strongly. **********President Clinton dismissed any worries about inflation, pointing instead to the jobs created in his term. ''This is the first time in the history of our economy that over 11 million jobs have been created during one four-year Administration,'' he told reporters at the White House. **********The economy is ''on a roll,'' said Robert B. Reich, the Secretary of Labor, also playing down jitters about inflation. ''There's much to celebrate.'' **********While investors in the stock market ultimately agreed, traders in the bond market, which is sensitive to inflation, felt differently. The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond, an important benchmark for corporate and consumer interest rates, rose to 6.84 percent, as prices, which move in the opposite direction, fell. **********Interest rates are now nearly a half-point higher than in early December and a quarter-point higher than just before Christmas, when indications of economic resurgence first emerged. **********More economists joined the scramble today to raise estimates of economic growth in the final 1996 quarter, which already appeared to be higher than is consistent with steady inflation. They also raised their projections for the first half of this year. **********''You're starting off from a much higher platform,'' said William C. Dudley, a senior economist at Goldman, Sachs, who now figures the economy grew at a 3.6 percent pace, rather than 3 percent, in the quarter that just ended. **********But while the chances increased that the Federal Reserve will decide to tighten monetary policy, most analysts also agreed that the central bank would probably not act before its March 25 policy meeting. **********At that point, they said, it would be better able to tell whether growth will ebb on its own, helped by higher interest rates generated by the market. **********Some analysts predicted just this. ''The current strength in the economy will be temporary,'' said Mickey D. Levy, an economist at Nationsbank in New York. ''In the spring we'll see signs that the current rate of growth won't be sustained.'' **********The jump in payrolls of 262,000 was the biggest gain since August and about 50 percent more than the consensus prediction. The Labor Department also raised its previous tally of total job growth for October and November by 46,000. **********For the full year, the number of Americans with jobs climbed 2.8 million, split almost evenly between men and women. The labor force grew by 2.6 million, with women accounting for three-fifths of the increase. This has caused the jobless rate for adult men, which a year ago was higher than that for adult women, to fall to 4.4 percent, a half-point lower than that of the women. The unemployment rate for teen-agers last month was 16.5 percent. **********A startling development, however, was the large increase in average hourly earnings. Most specialists had expected little change after a huge 9-cent November increase but pay rose instead by an additional 6 cents. **********This suggested a hefty rise in the quarterly Employment Cost Index, to be published Jan. 28, an indicator that gets close scrutiny at the Federal Reserve. **********For the full year, average hourly pay rose 44 cents, or 3.8 percent, compared with gains of 3.2 percent in 1995, 2.7 percent in 1994 and 2.4 percent in 1993. **********One factor in the recent acceleration is the increase of 50 cents an hour in the Federal minimum wage that took effect Oct. 1. **********But workers in retail trade, where there is a concentration of the lower-paid employees, had average increases of only 2 cents an hour in December and 4 cents in November after an 8-cent October increase.  Secretary Reich said the law had had ''possibly a small effect'' on wages in general. **********Other signs of strength included 18-minute extensions of the factory and private-sector workweeks and 12 minutes more of factory overtime. The measures of factory hours have now rebounded to near-record levels and suggest that employers may need to step up hiring. **********Nearly all sectors of the economy added sizable numbers of jobs last month, with business services contributing 45,000 jobs after a small decline in November and retail trade added 48,000 jobs, many of them in restaurants and bars. **********Construction employment, aided by milder-than-usual weather in most of the country, rose by 23,000 and manufacturing rose by 19,000 despite a continued decline at factories that make electronic equipment. **********Government showed 31,000 more jobs, but most of this reflected the fact that fewer election workers than usual were hired in November and thus there were fewer to be dismissed in December. **********The combination of more people at work and longer workweeks drove the index of aggregate weekly hours up nine-tenths of 1 percent, to 139.2, assuring a big increase when the Federal Reserve reports on industrial production for the month next Friday, the payroll data also showed. **********The Labor Department's survey of households registered 211,000 more people with jobs last month than in November, enough to keep up with a 191,000 rise in the labor force and thereby hold the unemployment rate at 5.3 percent. **********The November rate had initially been 5.4 percent but this was recalculated downward as part of the usual year-end revision that incorporates updated seasonal adjustment factors. The rates for January, March and May were also revised one-tenth of a point lower while August was raised one-tenth of a point, to 5.2 percent. **********Regionally, the December jobless rate edged up two-tenths of a point, to 6.5 percent in the West and one-tenth of a point, to 5.6 percent, in the Northeast. The rate eased two-tenths of a point, to 5.2 percent, in the South and one-tenth of a point, to 4.5 percent, in the Midwest.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/23/busin.body_text: **********Ecolab Inc. bought a 14.9 percent stake in Gibson Chemical Industries Ltd. of Australia for about $18.7 million and said it was considering buying more. Ecolab, based in St. Paul, makes cleaning and sanitizing chemicals. It said it had bought 3.34 million shares of Melbourne-based Gibson Chemical, which makes similar products, on the open market. Gibson said it suspected that Ecolab, which already has Australian operations, planned to initiate talks with the company. A December 1996 report by the ratings agency Moody's Investor Service said Ecolab had a strategy of buying niche businesses to extend its own product range.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/06/busin.print_headline: Save the Last Laugh for Me
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/06/busin.body_text: **********Parting, as Shakespeare once observed, is such sweet sorrow. As those who have been involuntarily parted from a job well know, the last goodbye is all the sweeter if the final word comes from the one who is leaving and carries a nice, sharp barb. **********Ed McManus of Marlborough, Mass., has unpleasant memories of a former employer. ''A dangerous boss he was,'' he writes. ''He was unsure of himself and tried to cover that with a meanness which touched everyone around him. It wasn't enough to win. The other person had to lose.'' **********One day, this boss gave a termination notice to a man Mr. McManus calls Harry. ''It was a performance issue,'' Mr. McManus writes. ''There were two sides to it, but Harry was out, and we all knew it.'' **********Harry immediately began a job search and quickly found a superb position for which he was not quite qualified. Disappointed, he mentioned it to one of the boss's key aides, who immediately applied for the position and was hired on the spot. In his exit interview, the aide told the boss that the lead had come from Harry. **********The boss was furious, Mr. McManus writes: ''He stormed into Harry's office and read him out in a voice loud enough to be heard by all. As usual, he ended the tirade with a threat: 'I intend to do something about this.' **********''Harry thought for a moment, then said: 'You've already fired me. Does this new action involve my family?' '' **********Meredith Lewin of Plainview, N.Y., once worked for a family-run business where the boss's son was employed as soon as he finished college. The young man reported to a friend of hers. ''The less said about working with a boss's son, the better,'' she writes. ''Suffice to say this was an insufferable situation.'' **********Ms. Lewin says that one day her friend, ''who had the patience of Job, reached the end of his rope, cued up Johnny Paycheck's 'Take This Job and Shove It,' set it to play over the office P.A. system and marched himself out the door.'' **********If you're going to quit, it's absolutely wonderful to quit a job you could do without in the first place. M. Ali Stephens of Boca Raton, Fla., will never forget overhearing this parting shot: ''Frankly, I don't even know why I took this job. I'm vice president of my own company. And you don't even pay mileage!'' **********If you're going to quit, it also helps to be financially secure. Don Hague of Silver Spring, Md., once worked in Alexandria, Va., at a new hotel where the director of housekeeping was short on experience but was dedicated and popular with the staff. She was an acquaintance of a part-owner who acted as the chief operating officer, and she was the daughter of a rather wealthy man who was willing to assist her financially. **********So the chief operating officer, taking advantage of the woman's lack of experience, their supposed friendship and her father's generosity, hired her at a salary well below the industry norm, Mr. Hague says. **********When the woman discovered how underpaid she was, she protested and demanded a raise several times. But nothing worked. So she quit, and her department fell apart. **********Now desperate, the part-owner called her and promised that she would receive more money. How much he didn't say, but he told her she would ''be happy'' with her next paycheck. The woman returned to work. **********Friday came, and the paychecks were distributed. The woman looked at hers and went directly to the part-owner's office. **********Standing in front of his desk, she ripped her paycheck into little pieces, declared, ''It's not enough; I quit!'' and walked out. **********Some shots are heard 'round the world. And some reverberate through the office. Virginia Miles of Englewood, N.J., a marketing consultant, recalls a situation when a female worker endured sexual harassment from her male boss for a long time. Ms. Miles writes that the woman asked him repeatedly to stop, but that he kept bothering her. **********''Finally, she went into his office, resigned and then gave him a resounding slap across the face,'' Ms. Miles says. ''It could be heard all over the floor, and everybody at their desks burst into applause.'' **********If you're really good at this parting-shot business, sometimes you don't have to part at all, at least not for a while. **********Consider Richard Carlton of White Plains, who once had a colleague known to be ripe for dismissal. Sure enough, one day the man was called into the boss's office. Minutes later he emerged cool and collected, a faint smile on his face. **********He was asked what had happened. **********''He told me that I was fired,'' the man said. ''and I told him he couldn't do that -- it was Fire Prevention Week.'' **********Mr. Carlton's colleague was let go the following week. **********Despite the soul-satisfying joy of a zinging, stinging farewell, it pays to remember that life plays its little tricks. Goodbye, forever, sometimes turns out to be nothing more than so long for a while. **********More than 20 years ago, when Joseph C. Kaplan, now of Teaneck, N.J., was a young associate at a now-defunct Manhattan law firm, one of his older colleagues decided to trade his long hours and daily pressures for what he believed was the more genteel atmosphere of academic life. **********In a speech at his farewell party before going off to teach in law school, he began by saying, ''I have mixed emotions tonight: joy and'' -- then came a long pause -- ''glee.'' **********About three years later, he realized that he was paying for his shorter hours and diminished pressures with a reduced salary that made it difficult to support his growing family. He asked his old law firm if he could come back. He was eventually rehired, but not before a partners' meeting that included an extensive  discussion of his farewell remarks, which they remembered only too well. **********Mr. Kaplan provides a moral: ''Flourishes and revenge might be a catharsis, but be very careful because, as the New York Lottery tells us, 'You never know.' ''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/28/busin.snippet: Dow Jones industrial average drops 35.79 points, to 6,660.69, on New York Stock Exchange trading volume of 445.8 million shares; table (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/28/busin.main_headline: Stock Slide Continues, With Dow Off 35.79
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/28/busin.print_headline: Stock Slide Continues, With Dow Off 35.79
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/28/busin.body_text: **********Stock prices continued to slide yesterday on concerns that rising bond yields may start to lure investors away from the stock market. **********The Dow Jones industrial average lost 35.79 points to close at 6,660.69. It was the fourth consecutive day the blue-chip indicator has fallen, and the largest downturn since last July, when the Dow lost 245 points, or 4.4 percent in three days. Since Jan. 21, the Dow has lost 223 points, or 3.2 percent. **********The downturn in stocks -- which stalled an impressive early January bull run -- has occurred as the yield of the 30-year Treasury bond has continued a monthlong rise. The yield rose six basis points yesterday, to 6.94 percent, a gain of 16 basis points since Jan. 21. A basis point is one one-hundredth of a percentage point. The bond's yield is at its highest point since Sept. 24. **********''I think the bond market is giving a lot of people cause for concern,'' said Anthony F. Dwyer, chief market strategist at Rickel & Associates. ''More upticks in the bond market could scare people out of the stock market for higher yields.'' **********Several analysts said the bond market continued to be preoccupied with inflation in anticipation of the Labor Department's release today of the Employment Cost Index, which measures growth in labor costs and has been singled out by the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, as a key barometer of inflation. **********Analysts forecast the index to rise eight-tenths of a point for the fourth quarter, but if the figures come in above expectations, many in the bond market believe that the Federal Reserve bank would be under pressure to raise short-term interest rates in the near future, but not at next week's open market committee meeting. Raising rates could cause a further decline in the price of Treasury securites over the near-term and thereby lift yields even higher. That move could lure investors away from the stock market. **********Although the Dow has lost 223 points in the last four trading sessions, analysts said the recent losses are an example of how the market can suddenly change its focus from one set of factors to another: from excitement over strong earnings reports to concerns about higher interest rates. **********''There's this constant scrimmage going on between the good news and the bad,'' said Christine Callies, chief investment strategist at CS First Boston. ''The recent scrimmages have been won by the bond market, which has been slipping. With equity valuations now in the high range, investors are much more sensitive to disappointing news.'' **********Among the hardest-hit stocks in the last four sessions, has been I.B.M., whose shares have lost 13.3 percent since last Tuesday, following an earnings report that failed to live up to analysts' expectations. Yesterday, shares of I.B.M. lost 4 3/4, to 145 3/4, accounting for nearly half of the Dow's decline. **********General Motors also lost ground, falling  5/8 points, to 61 7/8, after the auto maker announced that it would buy back $2.5 billion in stock and increase its quarterly dividend 25 percent. Investors, who were expecting a larger buyback announcement, were disappointed. **********American Express also lost ground despite a strong earnings report. Shares fell 1 5/8, to 59 1/2. And shares of General Electric fell 1 1/2, to 100 3/8. Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was 445.8 million shares, much lighter than this year's average and far below last week's record-breaking performance. **********While the Dow has now retreated to 6,660 -- cutting its early January gains in half -- broader market indexes have also lost ground. The Standard & Poors index of 500 stocks lost 5.50 points to close at 765.02, and the Nasdaq composite index lost 11.02 points to close at 1,352.81. **********Still, most analysts said the downturn in the stock market had been a healthy development, one that has scared away some speculators and caused other investors to rethink some of their holdings. **********Analysts also said that investors were beginning to realize that some larger-capitalization stocks have in recent months become overvalued, and that was causing many investors to snap up small-cap stocks, which have failed to keep pace recently with the large-cap companies. **********''Maybe what we're seeing is some correction in the larger cap indices, while underneath that the average small-cap stocks have been doing better,'' said William L. Paternotte a research analyst at Alex Brown & Sons. ''Some believe corporate profits will be lackluster in '97. So there's a flight of money into companies that people think will produce superior results.'' **********ON THE WEB **********The latest stock and mutual fund quotations, along with news updates, are available on the Internet from The New York Times on the Web: www.nytimes.com

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/14/busin.body_text: **********Financial Giants Report More Strong Earnings **********J. P. Morgan, Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette and Smith Barney -- as well as its parent, the Travelers Group -- all reported strong profits, extending Wall Street's dizzying ride on the back of buoyant stock and bond markets. **********Those market gains have been fueled by strong corporate profits, record merger activity and a fair amount of optimism, though a few possible clouds have now appeared on the horizon. [Page D2.] **********Driven by the strong earnings, stocks rose modestly, with the Dow industrials advancing 27.01 points, to 8,072.22. Trading was light, with just 354 million shares changing hands on the New York Stock Exchange. [D16.] **********Reed-Elsevier and Rival to Merge **********The British-Dutch publisher Reed Elsevier and its Dutch competitor, Wolters Kluwer, said that they would join to create a publisher with revenue of $6.6 billion. [D6.] **********New Plan for Thomson-CSF **********The Government of Prime Minister Lionel Jospin, moving to consolidate France's military industry to meet increased global competition, chose a group of French companies led by Alcatel Alsthom in the latest plan to relieve the state of its controlling interest in Thomson-CSF, the military electronics company. [D4.] **********Bid for Building Materials Company **********Lafarge, a French building materials company, made a surprise $2.8 billion offer for a British rival, Redland. [D16.] **********$1.3 Billion Software Merger Set **********McAfee Associates, continuing its drive to become a powerhouse in computer networking software, agreed to buy Network General for $1.3 billion in stock. [D6.] **********Pharmacia to Move Base to U.S. **********Pharmacia & Upjohn, the drug maker, said that it would move its headquarters to a mid-Atlantic state from England. Analysts said central New Jersey was the likely location for the new base. [D4.] **********ITT Sets Cost-Cutting Moves **********ITT, slimming down in its fight to avoid a takeover by Hilton Hotels, said it would combine headquarters for its corporate, hotel and gaming operations and eliminate 86 positions from its headquarters staff. [D6.] **********Internet Messaging Venture **********America Online and Netscape Communications plan to announce an instant-messaging service -- a faster, group-oriented version of E-mail -- in a deal representative of the continuing integration of the Internet with traditional on-line technology. [D2.] **********'Moneypenny, Call the Lawyers' **********James Bond, at home in fast cars and casinos, may find himself in a less comfortable setting: court. Sony's Columbia Pictures studio said it had agreed with the producer and director Kevin McClory to produce a series of new 007 films. But MGM/UA, contending that it already owned rights to James Bond, vowed a legal fight. [D4.] **********Criticism for Hawaiian Estate **********The Bishop Estate of Hawaii, a wealthy landowner, investor and charity, has drawn fire from politicians and ordinary Hawaiians over allegations of financial mismanagement, among other criticisms. [A1.] **********Energy Futures Sharply Lower **********Energy futures prices tumbled, as the arrival of the American aircraft carrier Nimitz in the Persian Gulf proved uneventful, prompting heavy selling. Traders had feared that the ship's presence would increase tension. [D12.] **********The dollar climbed against most leading currencies after Japan said its trade surplus grew less than expected in August, reducing worries about trade strife. [D12.] **********Bond Market Closed **********The Treasury market was closed yesterday in observance of Columbus Day, though the stock market and other financial markets were open. On Friday, the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond ended at 6.42 percent. The Treasury market reopens today.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/30/busin.body_text: **********Pepsico Inc. said yesterday that it had received about $830 million from the sale of its Pepsico Food Systems restaurant-supply unit, which is based in Dallas, to Ameriserve Food Distribution Inc. The purchase price, which was previously undisclosed, was included in Pepsi's quarterly securities filing. The sale of the unit to Ameriserve, a subsidiary of Holberg Industries in Greenwich, Conn., was completed on July 11. Pepsico Food, with $3.4 billion in sales, distributes food to Pepsi's Taco Bell, Pizza Hut and KFC restaurant chains. Its sale resulted in a gain of $307 million, or 17 cents a share. Ameriserve, based in Brookfield, Wis., distributes food to more than 10,000 restaurants, including Wendy's, Burger King, Arby's, Dairy Queen and Subway.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/27/world.snippet: Canadian Federal inquiry concludes that thousands who contracted AIDS virus and Hepatitis C from contaminated blood in one of worst public disasters in Canada's history should be compensated without having to file lawsuits; report, written by Onta...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/27/world.main_headline: Canadian Study Says Tainted-Blood Victims Deserve Payment
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/27/world.print_headline: Canadian Study Says Tainted-Blood Victims Deserve Payment
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/27/world.body_text: **********Thousands of Canadians who contracted the AIDS virus and Hepatitis C from contaminated blood in one of the worst public health disasters in Canadian history should be compensated without having to file lawsuits, according to a federal inquiry released today. **********After several years of study, the report by Justice Horace Krever blames the system for the tainted blood and blood products administered in the early 1980's. While it singles out no one, the report sharply criticizes federal health officials for delays in using methods to screen donated blood sooner. **********More than 1,000 people in Canada were infected with H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, through the blood supply and unknowingly infected others. By the early 1990's, several hundred of the people who developed AIDS had died. Tens of thousands were infected with Hepatitis C, which can develop into a form that sometimes proves fatal. Ultimately, more than 3,000 Canadians are expected to die as a result of the tainted blood. **********The Canadian Red Cross Society, which played a central role in the nation's blood supply for half a century, was also criticized. The Red Cross has been forced out of the field as a result of the tainted blood scandal. Responsibility has now shifted to the provinces. **********Mr. Krever, an Ontario Court of Appeals judge, made 50 recommendations to overhaul Canada's blood system, including establishing independent auditors and paying compensation. Any action, however, would require government approval. **********Under an arrangement reached in  1993, some hemophiliacs who contracted AIDS during this period have already been awarded compensation of $23,000 a year, on the condition they waived their right to sue all agencies and corporations involved. Victims who developed Hepatitis C  were not compensated at that time. **********In the report, Mr. Krever recommends that people who find out they were infected before the blood supply was properly regulated should also receive compensation without having to prove fault. He does not exclude people with Hepatitis C. **********Durhane Wong-Rieger, who is with the Canadian Hemophilia Society, said the call for compensation is ''long overdue.'' **********''What the report shows is that many of the people who died, didn't need to die,'' she said. **********In his report, Mr. Krever says that  many of the ''problems stemmed from the way public health authorities dragged their feet in implementing new safeguards. For example, a safer blood concentrate used by hemophiliacs to control bleeding was not made available in Canada until 1985, a year after it had been developed. There were delays in screening blood donors and in setting up procedures for notifying blood recipients,'' he wrote. **********''The Red Cross should not have required conclusive evidence before taking strong action to reduce the risk of AIDS,'' Mr. Krever wrote. **********Canada's Minister of Health, Allan Rock, said today that the federal Government accepts its share of responsibility for the faults in the blood system. He said he would have to meet with provincial leaders before acting on recommendations in the report, and he issued an apology. **********''We can't undo the damage,'' he said. ''But we can express our profound sadness and deep regret for the harm done to so many Canadians and their families.'' **********While the release of the report was welcomed, many victims, including  Mark Bulbrook of Hamilton, director of the Ontario AIDS Network, said  they would push for a criminal investigation.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/25/busin.snippet: Japanese Finance Ministry, concerned that decline in bank lending will lead to more business failures, postpones imposition of penalties on banks that do not meet its standard of financial soundness; ministry postpones for one year sanctions that ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/25/busin.main_headline: Japan Postpones Deadline for Sanctions on Banks
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/25/busin.print_headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; Japan Postpones Deadline for Sanctions on Banks
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/25/busin.body_text: **********The Japanese Finance Ministry, concerned that a decline in bank lending will lead to more business failures, today postponed the imposition of penalties on banks that do not meet its standard of financial soundness. **********The lack of bank credits ''is more serious than expected,'' said Finance Minister Hiroshi Mitsuzuka. **********The ministry postponed for one year sanctions that were to have taken effect on April 1 against banks whose capital as a proportion of assets do not reach the minimum domestic standard of 4 percent. In doing so, the ministry retreated from a policy of allowing market forces to weed out weaker banks. **********Alicia Ogawa, an analyst at Salomon Brothers Asia Ltd., said, ''It's backpedaling at the speed of light. It's just going to serve to deepen the distrust that the rest of the world has towards Japanese regulation.'' The ministry's decision will delay the necessary consolidation of the banking industry, she said. **********Shares of Japanese banks fell today because of concern they may be exposed to loan defaults in South Korea. The bank-shares index fell two-tenths of 1 percent. The broader Nikkei index of 225 stocks rose 125.58 points, or nine-tenths of 1 percent. **********[On Thursday, the Nikkei continued to gain. At midday, the index was up 334.06 points, or 2.24 percent, to 15,259.04.] **********The ministry postponed punishment of banks with domestic operations until April 1, 1999, should it determine that the financial institutions can meet the 4 percent capital standard within that period. Banks operating internationally must still meet international standards by next April, the ministry said. **********The Bank for International Settlements requires a capital-adequacy ratio of 8 percent for banks operating internationally. **********The ministry will also relax rules requiring banks to step up disposal of bad loans next year. To comply with those rules, many banks have written off bad loans, forcing them to expend capital. **********To raise their capital-adequacy ratios, banks must also reduce assets. That means cutting lending. **********The credit squeeze threatens to choke the economy and reduce profits by forcing companies to slash capital spending. Scarcer loans are increasing the strain on companies already reeling from an eight-month downturn in sales.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/12/world.snippet: Sinn Fein leader Gerry Adams, following meeting with British Prime Min Tony Blair at 10 Downing Street, says visit, while highly symbolic, has afforded two sides a discussion in which they really 'engaged'; photo (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/12/world.main_headline: I.R.A. Figure Meets Blair at No. 10 in 'Moment in History'
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/12/world.print_headline: I.R.A. Figure Meets Blair at No. 10 in 'Moment in History'
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/12/world.body_text: **********Gerry Adams, the Irish nationalist leader, came to 10 Downing Street today and emerged from an hourlong meeting with Prime Minister Tony Blair saying, ''Usually moments in Anglo-Irish relationships in history are bad, but today was a significantly good moment.'' **********Customarily a dour figure, Mr. Adams was beaming when he stepped forth from the residence with the famous black door with the gold No. 10 on it and said he felt today was ''a moment in history,'' a claim that even his critics and opponents would not quarrel with. **********It had been 76 years since Michael Collins, the last Irish republican to cross the threshold of the official residence of British Prime Ministers, had come to see David Lloyd George. **********More recently, the Irish Republican Army had tried to bomb the site of today's meeting, lobbing mortars at 10 Downing Street in 1991 while Mr. Blair's predecessor, John Major, was meeting with his Cabinet in the very room where the Sinn Fein delegation gathered today. The shells fell harmlessly in the rose garden. **********Standing with his aides outside the same residence today, Mr. Adams, the leader of Sinn Fein, the political wing of the I.R.A., said that the visit, while obviously highly symbolic, had afforded the two sides a discussion in which they really ''engaged.'' **********''We certainly had the opportunity to put forward our view that all the hurt and grief and pain and division that has come from British involvement in Irish affairs has to end,'' he said. The meeting was not, he said, ''one where we put up our stock positions and Mr. Blair puts up his stock positions.'' **********A spokesman for Mr. Blair later agreed, saying that the session, which he called ''constructive and positive,'' had gone beyond ''people chanting mantras and slogans.'' He said the Prime Minister had sought and received from Mr. Adams a statement of his commitment to non-violence. ''It is important that I can look you in the eye and hear you say that you remain committed to peaceful means,'' the spokesman quoted Mr. Blair as saying. **********The Prime Minister told his visitors that if there was a return to violence, ''we waste the best possibility for peace that we have had for a generation.'' The I.R.A. renewed a lapsed cease-fire on July 20 and in September gained entry to the all-party peace talks now under way in Belfast. **********The party has obtained increasing recognition from Britain, a country that once so reviled Mr. Adams that his voice was not allowed to be broadcast here. In a step leading to today's meeting, Mr. Blair visited Belfast in October and greeted Mr. Adams for the first time. **********Besides the echo of history, there were also personal reminders to Mr. Adams today of the emotional freight attached to a meeting between a British Prime Minister and the leaders of a party that has until recently backed a violent struggle to oust the British from Northern Ireland. **********The father of a 12-year-old boy who died in an I.R.A. bombing of a busy shopping street in Warrington, Cheshire, in March 1993 called into a radio talk show to speak to Mr. Adams, and the mother of the last British soldier killed in Northern Ireland spoke to him from the curb of Downing Street before he went inside. **********Mr. Adams told the caller, Colin Parry, ''I know that you yourself and your family have suffered very much from conflict in my country.'' **********Rita Restorick, whose son Stephen was shot by an I.R.A. sniper on Feb. 12, said she told Mr. Adams that she hoped he would ''put an end to these horrible killings because I want no other mother to go through the pain I suffered.'' **********Mr. Adams said he had ''praised her for her courage'' and had told her that he knew ''many, many, many Mrs. Restoricks from our community, and nobody has a monopoly on grief or on suffering.'' **********Among the subjects that came up in the talks, Mr. Adams said, were transfers of Irish prisoners from British to Irish jails, demilitarization of the conflict and demands for a reopening of a widely questioned British inquiry into the killings of 14 civil rights marchers by British paratroopers in Londonderry in 1972. **********Mr. Adams caused a furor today by wishing ''good luck'' to a convicted I.R.A. killer, Liam Avarill, 32, who escaped from the Maze prison outside Belfast on Wednesday night by disguising himself as a woman at the end of a Christmas party for the children of jailed republicans. At this afternoon's meeting, Mo Mowlam, the British Secretary for Northern Ireland, pointedly told Mr. Adams his words ''had not been helpful.'' **********Among those expressing anger over the encounter today was Andrew Hunter, a Conservative member of a parliamentary committee on Northern Ireland. He said the invitation had been ''premature'' and that the I.R.A. cease-fire was not to be trusted because, he said, the organization was still recruiting, training and conducting private punishments. **********Ulster Protestants have condemned the meeting since it was first announced last month. Today Ian Paisley, leader of the Democratic Unionist Party, said: ''The whole thing was an exercise of outrageous hypocrisy and deliberate lying. Here we saw the Godfathers of those who planned the bombing of Downing Street, standing outside there and piously pretending they were engaged in a search for peace.'' **********In an interview with BBC Northern Ireland tonight, Mr. Blair defended his decision, saying that seeking to end the struggle that has cost more than 3,200 lives since 1969 was worth the Government ''taking every risk it can.'' **********There are splits in the ranks on both sides of the conflict. Two Protestant parties show no disposition to enter the peace talks, and dissidents and defectors from the I.R.A. have expressed impatience with the pace of the negotiations and Mr. Adams's decision to agree to principles of democracy and non-violence.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/12/busin.snippet: Pacifica Radio, left-oriented network based in Berkeley, Calif, is in midst of rancorous argument over what goes on air and who should decide; argument about programming and control is part of wider debate about purity or popularity of public broa...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/12/busin.main_headline: Clamorously, Pacifica Radio Dances Toward Mainstream
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/12/busin.print_headline: Clamorously, Pacifica Radio Dances Toward Mainstream
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/12/busin.body_text: **********Its name means ''peaceful'' in Spanish and its stated mission is to promote understanding among different groups of people. But financial pressure to reach a wider audience has supporters of Pacifica Radio, the left-oriented network based in Berkeley, Calif., in a rancorous argument over what goes on the air and who should decide. **********In a way, the argument about programming and control -- at the network's founding station, KPFA in Berkeley, and others -- is part of the wider debate about the purity or popularity of public broadcasting. But Pacifica's long tradition of advocacy and of anything-goes programming has made the adjustment all the harder to make. **********As Federal funds have stagnated and much of Pacifica's old radical audience has moved to mainstream fare, friction between professional managers and staff volunteers has grown. The network has moved to take power away from local advisory boards and give it to station managers, and to redraw program schedules to discard some of the more arcane, narrowly focused material. **********''People were not listening,'' said Pat Scott, executive director of the Pacifica Foundation, which governs the network, with its five affiliated stations. In addition to KPFA, they are WBAI in New York, KPFK in Los Angeles, KPFT in Houston and WPFW in Washington. Some Pacifica programming can also be heard on other stations. **********''The mission and vision of Pacifica is to promote peace and understanding,'' Ms. Scott said, ''and my position as executive director, and the position of the board of directors, is that we cannot fulfill our mission if people are not listening.'' **********Last month, however, the Corporation for Public Broadcasting, which gives Pacifica about $1 million a year, issued the results of an audit sought by opponents of the changes. The report accuses the Pacifica Foundation of, among other things, failing to comply with Federal open meeting laws and of undermining the autonomy of each station's local advisory boards. The audit was requested by a group called Take Back KPFA, which opposes the programming and management changes at the Berkeley station, a place where studio clocks were once banned as a way of freeing radio from time itself. **********Inspector General Armando J. Arvizu recommended on April 9 that Pacifica be given six months to comply with the audit's findings for open meetings and public notification or risk losing its funds. **********Ms. Scott called the audit ''completely false.'' She and Take Back KPFT will appear before the corporation in Washington next Monday. **********Ms. Scott said that local Pacifica stations had wide production freedom, and that the only network program they were required to broadcast was a daily newscast from Washington. At the same time, she insisted that KPFA's small audience made a more regular program schedule a necessity. ''We had a lot of balkanizing in our programming,'' Ms. Scott said. ''We had one program on Palestinians and one on Israelis and one on black Americans and so on, and we are moving away from that, and because this had been the tenor of the station for a long time, people are upset about it.'' **********Jeffrey Blankfort, a leader in Take Back KPFA, argued that some program changes might have been necessary, but that the Pacifica Foundation had been high-handed in cutting the authority of local advisers, volunteer programmers and technicians. **********''The positive thing about Pacifica Radio has always been that it was community-based and community-oriented and basically staffed by volunteers,'' Mr. Blankfort, a teacher, said. ''Pat Scott has tried to eliminate volunteers and to impose mainstream block programming, and this stands in contradiction to the long history of Pacifica.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/14/busin.print_headline: U.S. and Europe in Pact on Product Safety
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/14/busin.body_text: **********The European Union said today that it had concluded an accord with the United States to accept product safety tests performed on either side of the Atlantic, removing impediments to more than $40 billion of trade. **********The ''mutual recognition agreements'' involve products ranging from electrical appliances to medical equipment that account for $40 billion to $50 billion worth of European-United States trade annually. **********The European Union Trade Commissioner, Sir Leon Brittan, said in a statement that the agreement would ''cut red tape, reduce costs and bring products for health care patients, information technology users and other consumers onto the market faster without compromising quality.'' **********The agreement had been delayed by American concern about reducing the Food and Drug Administration's supervision of European Union-approved pharmaceutical products and medical equipment imported into the United States **********Along with pharmaceutical and medical devices, the agreement covers telecommunications equipment, pleasure boats and electrical goods. **********The European Union said it had also concluded a similar accord with Canada that would cover about one-eighth the amount of trade that the United States agreement would cover.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/16/busin.print_headline: Copper and Coffee Futures Take a Beating
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/16/busin.body_text: **********Copper prices tumbled yesterday on continuing signs that rising world production and slowing demand were increasing inventories. **********On other markets, coffee prices slid. **********Stockpiles in London Metal Exchange warehouses, where most of the world's copper reserves are stored, rose 4,575 metric tons, to 260,875 metric tons, the exchange said yesterday in its daily report. Supplies have more than doubled since late June and stand at their highest level in 11 months. **********Copper inventories are rising as many factories close or reduce operations for annual maintenance. At the same time, production is rising in Chile, the world's biggest producer, and in the United States. **********Copper for September delivery fell 3.8 cents, to $1 a pound, on the Comex division of the New York Mercantile Exchange, the lowest for an active contract since Dec. 17. An estimated 15,000 contracts changed hands, the exchange said, more than 60 percent above the daily average this year. **********Coffee fell to a three-week low on expectations that an industry report would show that United States stockpiles were growing at a time of slow roaster and consumer demand. **********As expected, the Green Coffee Association, a private trade group, reported after the market closed that stockpiles rose in July. **********Coffee for September delivery fell 6.6 cents, to $1.7795 a pound, on the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/23/busin.main_headline: Arianespace: Getting a Lift From Asia
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/23/busin.print_headline: Arianespace: Getting a Lift From Asia
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/23/busin.body_text: **********Arianespace, the European space transportation company, has established a dominant position in launching communication satellites. In Singapore, Ralph-Werner Jaeger, senior vice president of Arianespace for marketing, customer service and international affairs, discussed future business prospects with Michael Richardson of the International Herald Tribune. **********Q. What impact has the boom in satellite communications in Asia in recent years had on Arianespace's business? **********A. Asia is increasingly important as a satellite market. It now represents between 20 percent and 25 percent of our worldwide business. Of the 38 satellite-launch orders on our books worth nearly $3 billion, eight are for the Asia-Pacific market. **********Q. Why are communication satellites for television broadcasting, telephone services and data exchange in such strong demand in Asia? **********A. The region's rapid economic growth and development has called for major improvements in infrastructure of all kinds, including telecommunications. **********Many developing Asian countries have very limited fixed-line telephone services. They may be large continental nations like China and India or widely scattered island states like Indonesia and the Philippines. It would take years and huge expense to extend the cable networks in these countries, especially to remote areas. **********Satellites can provide much quicker and cheaper nationwide coverage for telephony and broadcasting. The diversity of cultures in Asia means that demand for a wide array of satellite television channels catering to different languages and tastes is even stronger than in Europe or the United States. **********Q. How does the Arianespace success rate for launching communications satellites compare with those of rival launchers in the U.S., Russia and China? **********A. Ariane rockets are the leading systems in terms of reliability, followed by Delta and Atlas in the U.S., and Proton in Russia. We have a success rate of about 97 percent. Theirs is around 96 percent. China's success rate is in the vicinity of 80 percent. The Chinese are working hard to improve it. **********Q. What advantages over the current Ariane-4 rocket will the Ariane-5 have for customers when it comes into service in early 1998? **********A. A 3 or 4 percent failure rate for launches is relatively high compared to failure rates of satellites once they are in orbit. Launch failures are costly when you consider that, on average, each rocket carries two satellites insured for as much as $500 million. **********Ariane-5 is designed to give even higher reliability than Ariane-4 and carry heavier and larger payloads. With Ariane-5, we will give customers a launch guarantee that no other rocket operator so far provides. In the very unlikely event of failure, our guarantee provides a relaunch free of charge at a time to suit the customer when the replacement satellite is available. **********Q. There are seven space launch organizations operating in Western Europe, Russia, China, the U.S. and Japan. Isn't that too many for the amount of business likely to be available over the next decade or two? **********A. It depends on how the space launch business develops. Arianespace has so far concentrated on large communication satellites for geostationary orbit high above the equator. We have about 60 percent of the global market for launching such satellites. Our market forecasts show that between 30 and 35 of these satellites will be launched each year over the next decade. **********There is also an emerging market for launching constellations of smaller communication satellites. **********Q. Will there be additional contracts from governments in Europe and elsewhere to launch military satellites for intelligence-gathering, surveillance and arms control? **********A. This is already big business in the U.S., where about 50 percent of Atlas and Delta launches are for the government, mainly for military satellites. For Arianespace, government contracts amount to less than 10 percent of our total business. **********Future space-station building and resupply could open up a major new business avenue for rocket operators.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/23/busin.snippet: Latin American stock and bond funds have both gained handsomely in recent years, exceeding 40 percent in some cases; recently, bonds have been replaced by stocks as winning investment in region; continued political changes and resurgent local econ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/23/busin.main_headline: Latin Markets Again Run With the Bulls
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/23/busin.print_headline: Latin Markets Again Run With the Bulls
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/23/busin.body_text: **********ANYONE who bought Latin American stock and bond funds a year ago can claim bragging rights at cocktail parties. The gains in both categories have been handsome, exceeding 40 percent in some cases. **********But a not-so-subtle shift has taken place early this year. After a two-year rally, bonds have been replaced by stocks as the winning investment in the region. **********After all, stocks are supposed to be the riskier, more rewarding investment in good times. And though the bonds have behaved much like stocks in recent years, money managers and financial analysts expect Latin American equities to now have their day in the sun. **********Continued political changes and resurgent local economies created the two-year bull market for bonds and set the stage for this stock rally. Enthusiasm for the stock markets has returned, though not to the frothy levels of 1993 before the Mexican peso crisis, says Juan Carlos Garcia, the head of equity research at Santander Investments in New York. **********To be sure, political risk remains apparent in Ecuador, Peru, Colombia and even Mexico. A political meltdown could occur elsewhere as well. Still, the stability of the governments and their economic policies after the devaluation of the peso in late 1994 has reassured investors. **********Money managers and equity analysts see relatively little risk in the region, barring volatility in the United States -- namely, a sharp increase in interest rates or a plunge by the stock market. **********''The current recovery in equity prices is driven by the improvement in risk perception,'' said Walter Molano, an SBC Warburg economist. **********The performance of the regional stock markets was solid last year, and mutual funds, stocked with blue-chip shares like Telebras, Telefonos de Mexico and Electrobras, performed well. Morgan Stanley's Latin American retail and institutional portfolios were the pace-setters, with gains of more than 46 percent for the 12 months ended on Feb. 14. **********The pace has picked up this year. Every Latin American stock fund tracked by Morningstar had a gain of more than 10 percent for the first six weeks of the year. The leader, Merrill Lynch Latin America, exceeded 17 percent. **********Still, the markets have room to run. While the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index in this country is trading at about 22 times earnings, Brazilian stocks have a p/e ratio of 12.4, Mexican stocks 19.5 and Argentine stocks 24.5, according to State Street Global Advisors, money managers. **********Mr. Garcia of Santander cites overall regional strength as a main reason for optimism. ''For the first time in Latin America, growth is at the same levels in all of the big countries,'' he said. The gross domestic products of Argentina, Brazil, Chile, and Mexico are growing at 3.5 percent to 5 percent, he said. **********More capital in the area and low valuations in most stock sectors will fuel equity growth, he said. Consumer products and construction sectors, dependent on domestic spending, look more attractive to him than defensive stocks like utilities. **********Other fund managers agree. ''In all of the Latin economies, we've seen strength in the core emerging-markets plays, such as telecom and infrastructure, and the next stage in that progression is for consumers to start spending,'' said Robert Furdak, manager of the State Street Global Advisors Emerging Markets fund. **********THE last couple of years, though, belonged to the region's bond markets. Fidelity New Markets Income returned 42 percent for the 12 months ended Feb. 14, and Bear Stearns Emerging Markets Debt gained 37 percent. **********The bargains found in Latin American debt in early 1995 no longer exist, but investors seeking a high yield will still find better value in the region than in the United States junk-bond market, said David Reiss, an emerging-markets fixed-income portfolio manager at Bankers Trust Global Investment Management. **********Latin debt captured the imagination of investors in 1995, when, despite a hangover from the peso crisis, it rose along with the United States Treasury market. **********Last year, Argentina's commitment to its currency, Brazil's move to keep President Fernando Cardoso in office and the successful international bailout of Mexico made the bonds perform like ''equities in drag,'' said Ali Naqvi, the head of emerging-markets fixed-income research at Citibank Global Asset Management. **********The ride shows no sign of ending. Ed Vaimberg, manager of the Bear Stearns Emerging Markets Debt Portfolio, predicts 20 percent gains this year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/25/busin.snippet: Manhattan-based knitwear company 525 Made in America is repeating memorable ad campaign, with dogs as models, that it began one year ago; company is quadrupling the budget, to $2 million, and introducing ads to new markets; campaign is created by ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/25/busin.main_headline: 525 Made in America continues to seek name recognition by using dogs to model its clothes.
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/25/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; 525 Made in America continues to seek name recognition by using dogs to model its clothes.
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/25/busin.body_text: **********A MANHATTAN-BASED knitwear company, 525 Made in America, is going to the dogs and is proud of it. **********This fall, the privately held manufacturer of men's and women's clothing and home accessories is repeating the memorable ad campaign, with dogs as models, that it began one year ago. This time around, it is quadrupling the budget, to $2 million, and introducing the ads to new markets. **********The campaign, the company's only one since it opened for business in 1986, was created by Leibler-Bronfman Lubalin, New York. **********Robert Bock, president of 525 Made in America, originally commissioned the advertising for the fall 1996 season because, he said, ''A lot of people were wearing our things but didn't know our name.'' (The 525 refers to the company's address on Seventh Avenue.) The goal, then and now, was to have ''people remember us,'' Mr. Bock explained. **********Developing brand recognition for the company was paramount, noted Peter Lubalin, creative partner of Leibler-Bronfman Lubalin, because ''these days you are what you wear; people buy by name and not style.'' **********Ads both last fall and this season feature dogs draped in 525 Made in America styles while engaged in human activities. Models in the new campaign are a poodle named Rosie; Jason, a Great Dane, and a bloodhound called Bernard. **********One ad says Rosie, wearing white sunglasses and the manufacturer's apparel while driving a white vintage Corvette, enjoys ''cruising in her latest 525 chenille sweater and scarf.'' A second ad shows Jason, attired in a sweater while reading a newspaper and drinking coffee, spending ''a relaxing Sunday morning dressed in his favorite 525 chenille sweater.'' A third ad, with Bernard wrapped in a throw, sipping brandy, smoking a cigar and reading a newspaper, says the dog is having ''a quiet evening at home enjoying the warmth of a brandy and his favorite 525 chenille throw.'' The tagline for all the ads is ''525 Made in America. For men, for women, for the home. (Dogs optional.)'' **********Mr. Bock said he opted for this strategy because he ''felt it would get our name noticed.'' He added: ''Calvin Klein just wants to shock you with his advertising, flip you out. We want the opposite. We don't want sex, because everybody does that.'' **********The ads are running as full-page spreads in the September issue of Vogue and Elle, the October issue of Elle Decor and House Beautiful and trade publications like DNR, HFN and Home Textiles Today. The manufacturer is buying space this month and next in New York on bus stop shelters, subway platforms and telephone kiosks. It will also advertise outdoors next spring in new markets, most likely Chicago, Dallas, Los Angeles and San Francisco. **********The $2 million budget, through next August, will be split between print and outdoor advertising. **********Last year, the campaign definitely caught the attention of retailers. In a review of fashion magazine advertising last September, Women's Wear Daily gave it an honorable mention, along with ads by famous designers with far grander budgets, like Tommy Hilfiger, Isaac Mizrahi and Giorgio Armani. **********The campaign also appears to have given a boost to Mr. Bock's business. He said sales were up 30 percent last year, to $29 million, because ''the product was right and the name was growing.'' He expects sales to exceed $40 million this year. **********To capitalize on the campaign, Mr. Bock opened the first 525 Made in America store in Riverhead, N.Y., in May, and is planning to open others. He is also adding two divisions: holiday knitwear this winter and children's clothing next fall. **********What impact the campaign will have in the future remains to be seen, of course. **********One naysayer is Vicki Ross, a New York retail consultant. She said she did not consider the ads ''1990's advertising,'' adding: ''I don't know if these are effective for the kind of person 525 is going after. This is a very sophisticated audience, and I don't think a dog reaches them. The product is very, very good. I don't think the advertising is that great.'' **********But others are upbeat. **********Alan Millstein, another New York-based retailing consultant, compared the ads to Kenneth Cole's highly regarded advertising for his footwear, a campaign that plays off social and political issues. ''They've got a clever agency and a modest budget, like Kenneth Cole with his advocacy ads,'' he said. ''Cole's ads accomplished the job, and got him recognition.'' **********Mr. Millstein also applauded the humor employed by Leibler-Bronfman Lubalin. ''Humor is rarely used by fashion marketers,'' he said. ''They're uptight, and they have a formula that's boring. Most use a beautiful woman and a world-class photographer in their ads, and then put their name on them.'' **********Dina Turner, the fashion editor for contemporary women's sportswear for the Tobe Report, an industry newsletter, is another booster. **********The fact that the 525 Made in America campaign is ''emblazoned in my mind's eye,'' she said, ''means that it's doing what it's meant to do.''

The company released its results after United States markets closed. **********In the most-recent quarter, a charge of $25.9 million, or 3 cents a share, for asset write-downs resulted in net income of $230.2 million, or 47 cents. https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/03/busin.snippet: Promus Hotel Corp and Doubletree Corp agree to merger that will create one of biggest hotel companies in the world, with combined revenue of $5 billion; merged company will control 1,136 hotels and 172,000 rooms and 40,000 employees in US; deal va...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/03/busin.main_headline: Promus and Doubletree Hotel Companies Will Merge
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/03/busin.print_headline: Promus and Doubletree Hotel Companies Will Merge
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/03/busin.body_text: **********The Promus Hotel Corporation and the Doubletree Corporation said yesterday that they had agreed to a merger that would create one of the biggest hotel companies in the world, with combined revenue of $5 billion. **********The merged company will control 1,136 hotels with 172,000 rooms and 40,000 employees in the United States. The combination of the two companies, whose brands include Red Lion and Embassy Suites, would create the sixth-largest company in terms of the number of hotels. Revenues from hotels the merged company would own, manage or franchise would be exceeded only by Marriott International and Bass P.L.C.'s Holiday Inn unit. Revenue figures include franchising and management fees, which go to the merged company, as well as revenue retained by the franchisees. **********The match of Promus and Doubletree was praised by analysts. **********''The merger combines Promus's historical strength in building and franchising brands, with Doubletree's ability to manage hotels and be an aggressive acquirer of properties,'' said Michael J. Rietbrock, an analyst with Smith Barney. **********The deal values Promus at about $2.1 billion and Doubletree at $1.8 billion. Under the terms of the merger, Promus shareholders will receive 0.925 share in the new company for each of their existing shares. Doubletree shareholders will receive the combined company's stock on a 1-for-1 basis. Based on shares outstanding, Promus shareholders will own about 55 percent of the new company. The transaction, set to be completed late this year, is expected to be tax-free to shareholders. **********The new company will be called the Promus Hotel Corporation. **********Shares of Doubletree tumbled $5.125, or 10 percent, to $44.875. On Thursday and Friday, the stock rose sharply on speculation that the company would be sold. Shares of Promus rose $1.9375 each, to $40.75. **********The deal is the latest of a wave of recent merger efforts in the hotel industry. The more notable include Hilton Hotels' so-far unsuccessful attempt to take over ITT, the owner of the Sheraton hotel chain, in a hostile $8.3 billion offer; Marriott's recent $1 billion purchase of Renaissance hotels; Doubletree's $1.2 billion purchase of the Red Lion chain, and Starwood Lodging's pursuit of Westin Hotels and Resorts, for which it has offered $1.4 billion. **********Doubletree's brands include Doubletree Hotels, Doubletree Guest Suites and Red Lion hotels, while the Promus brands include Embassy Suites and Hampton Inns and Suites. Together the companies' brands, which will retain their individual identities, range from midpriced, limited-service properties to upscale, full-service establishments. **********Joyce Minor, the lodging analyst for Lehman Brothers, said that Promus had been especially astute at stressing and enforcing quality. ''They're very finnicky about it, and that will benefit both companies,'' she said. **********Franchising accounts for almost 40 percent of Promus's revenue and almost 60 percent of hotel operating profits. A recent analysis by Bear,  Stearns said that three of its four brands ''dramatically outperform their respective brand segments.'' **********Doubletree, Ms. Minor said, is very good at pushing preferred vendor fees, which guarantee member hotels the lowest prices on a range of food, beverages and supplies. ''In exchange for getting those low prices,'' she added, ''the parent company gets a small percentage of the revenue to the supplier, which can be substantial.'' **********In a conference call with investors and analysts yesterday, executives of Doubletree and Promus expressed interest in also acquiring a luxury brand, or possibly developing one. **********''What they are creating,'' said Mr. Rietbrock of Smith Barney, ''is a portfolio of independently identified brands but bound by Promus's guarantee of 100 percent satisfaction or your money back.'' **********The guarantee, which has proved to be popular with the public, he said, is the first such chainwide guarantee, other than for special promotions. **********The companies estimate cost savings of $15 million to $20 million annually by combining operations. **********Raymond E. Schultz, president and chief executive of Promus, which is based in Memphis, will serve as chairman and chief executive of the new company, and as a member of the executive committee of the 14-member board, which will be drawn evenly from both companies. **********Richard Kelleher, president and chief executive of Doubletree, will serve as president and chief operating officer of the combined company, and will be an ex-officio member of the board's executive committee.  Upon Mr. Schultz's retirement, which he said yesterday would be at least a couple of years away, Mr. Kelleher will succeed him as chief executive. **********Doubletree, which is based in Phoenix, said that investors representing about 40 percent of its shares, including General Electric's pension trust and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company, had indicated they would support the merger.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/07/busin.body_text: **********A Federal judge in Houston let stand a $22.7 million libel judgment against Dow Jones & Company that stemmed from a 1993 article about a Houston brokerage firm that appeared in The Wall Street Journal, the company's flagship newspaper. **********In March, a Federal jury awarded the brokerage firm, MMAR Group Inc., which is now defunct, $222.7 million in the case, including $200 million in punitive damages. **********But in May, Judge Ewing Werlein Jr. of the Federal District Court in Houston cut the award to $22.7 million. **********Dow Jones had asked the judge to either grant a new trial or ''greatly reduce'' the remaining award, which represented compensatory damages to MMAR. But in a 38-page decision handed down yesterday, Judge Werlein let the compensatory damage award stand. **********''We expect shortly to appeal,'' Dow Jones said in a statement. ''We remain optimistic that this judgment ultimately will not withstand the scrutiny of the courts.''
