https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/21/busin.main_headline: Netscape Takes On Rivals in KPMG Deal
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/21/busin.print_headline: Netscape Takes On Rivals in KPMG Deal
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/21/busin.body_text: **********In its effort to prove itself a viable competitor in the corporate computer-networking market, the Netscape Communications Corporation is expected to announce today that the accounting firm KPMG Peat Marwick L.L.P. has selected the newest version of Netscape's business communications software as the standard for 17,000 workers in its 120 offices in the United States. **********The deal is an important endorsement for Netscape, which made its name with software for browsing the World Wide Web but is trying to challenge both the Microsoft Corporation and the Lotus Development unit of I.B.M. as the leading supplier of messaging software to businesses and institutions. **********No terms of the deal were disclosed. **********It remains unclear how many other big corporate customers may follow KPMG's endorsement of Netscape's software package, which combines a Web browser with work-group collaboration and electronic mail. The package, called Communicator, is still in a test version and will not be generally available for several months. **********Still, KPMG's adoption of the software will broaden Netscape's sales effort because the deal also calls for the accounting firm to become a prime reseller of the software to the clients of KPMG's information technology consulting business. **********Microsoft has put considerable pressure on Netscape over the last year by giving away its competing Web browsing software, and Netscape has countered by broadening the reach of its products to challenge both Microsoft and Lotus in the corporate computing market. **********Both Microsoft, with a product called Exchange, and Lotus, with its Notes product, have many customers who have bought E-mail software based on proprietary technical standards developed before the Internet became the computer industry's de facto standard. While Microsoft and Lotus are rushing to overhaul their existing software for use with the Internet, Netscape is hoping to leap ahead of them with Communicator, which is based on the Internet's so-called open standards. **********KPMG is a large user of an older Lotus E-mail software product called cc:mail, which it will phase out over the next year as it installs  an internal network built around the World Wide Web and Netscape products. **********Allan Frank, KPMG's chief technology officer, said that he was attracted to Netscape because KPMG believes in embracing Internet standards. But he stressed in an interview that he had chosen Communicator primarily for its capability as a Web browser, not its E-mail and work-group features. KPMG is building an internal Internet network, or Intranet, called KWEB, which the firm hopes will allow its employees to share information about customers, products and strategies. **********''We are using the Netscape browser as a window into that,'' Mr. Frank said. ''E-mail is just one part of the whole thing for us.'' **********Others in the industry believe that Netscape may have difficulty turning its market lead in Web browsers into a business that can compete in the broader field of corporate computer communications. **********''It will be interesting to see when it actually ships,'' said Sheldon Laube, chief technology officer and executive vice president of the USWeb Corporation, a large developer of corporate Web sites, referring to Communicator. ''I've used it, and its off-line abilities are not as rich as Notes and Exchange,'' he said. **********But David Smith, an analyst with the Gartner Group, a technology consulting firm based in Stamford, Conn., disagreed. ''E-mail is going to be the battleground for the Internet over the next 12 months,'' he said, ''And I think those products that are close to Internet standards are going to be the leaders.'' **********KPMG will also become a systems integration partner of Netscape, though Mr. Frank said that did not mean that KPMG would not install software from Lotus, Microsoft or other companies if it served the best needs of its clients. **********''We don't own stock in any company,'' Mr. Frank said. ''We have relationships with Netscape and we have relationships with other companies.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/12/busin.snippet: Time Inc executives say it is just coincidence that its Time magazine named Dr Andrew Weil as one of 25 most influential people in country just month before its New Media unit acquired the 'Ask Dr Weil' Web site; visitors to Dr Weil's site look at...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/12/busin.main_headline: For Cover Subject Of Time Magazine, A Time Warner Deal
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/12/busin.print_headline: For Cover Subject Of Time Magazine, A Time Warner Deal
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/12/busin.body_text: **********Time Inc. knows synergy. **********Just ask Andrew Weil. He's the New Age doctor who's selling books like ''Spontaneous Healing'' and ''8 Weeks to Optimum Health'' by the organic bushel. Dr. Weil, who studied medicine at Harvard University before studying medicinal plants in South America, has become a media star as he promotes the benefits of ginseng and steam baths. **********Time Inc., a unit of Time Warner Inc., has certainly helped. Time magazine named Dr. Weil one of the 25 most influential people in the country last month, calling him ''a family doctor to America.'' **********Then last week the family doctor arrived for an up-close house call, peering from the cover of Time. **********And Friday came the synergy, in a release that read, ''Time Inc. New Media announced today that it has acquired the 'Ask Dr. Weil' Web site (http://www.drweil.com) for the Pathfinder Network (http:// www.pathfinder.com).'' **********Pathfinder is Time Warner's site on the World Wide Web. According to analysts, it could use a doctor: it is estimated to be losing from $5 million to $10 million a year. Visitors to Dr. Weil's site look at about two million pages a month, making it a lucrative source of ad revenue. **********Dr. Weil's agent, Richard S. Pine, would not disclose terms -- ''He didn't get into it to get rich,'' said Mr. Pine -- but said on Friday that negotiations with Time Warner over the Web site had begun in January. **********Time Inc. executives say the events and their timing are just a coincidence. ''I didn't know they were buying it,'' said Time's managing editor, Walter Isaacson. ''It's just a very interesting topic to me. There's this incredible boom in interest in serious alternative medicine.'' **********The magazine story included a parenthetical note that Time New Media was negotiating with Dr. Weil. **********Dan Okrent, editor of Time New Media, which runs Pathfinder, said that he did not tell Mr. Isaacson about the negotiations with the doctor until a week or so before the cover story appeared. ''I would think it odd, if he didn't have three No. 1 books,'' said Mr. Okrent of the coincidence. ''He is the authoritative person on this subject.''   SETH SCHIESEL

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/11/busin.snippet: Dow Jones industrial average gains 44.33 points, to close at 7,886.76; Russell 2000 index gains 1.75, to close at record 399.15; Nasdaq composite index gains 4.30 points, to record 1,490.93; table (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/11/busin.main_headline: Stocks Close On High Side In Seesaw Day
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/11/busin.print_headline: Stocks Close On High Side In Seesaw Day
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/11/busin.body_text: **********Investors applied the adage of buying on the dips in price yesterday, helping stock prices rebound. **********It was another seesaw trading session, with several major stock indexes bouncing in and out of negative territory, but the bulls prevailed at the end of trading. **********After plunging 119.88 points in the previous session, the Dow Jones industrial average recovered 44.33 points yesterday, closing at 7,886.76. **********Analysts said that with the season of second-quarter earnings reports under way, investors were making selections based on the growth prospects of individual companies rather than overall sentiment. And as a result, the market posted mixed results. **********''People aren't quite sure what to do,'' said Robert Kahan, head of trading at Montgomery Securities in San Francisco. ''It's a very listless market. We just can't get a direction, but individual stocks are reacting.'' **********Among those reporting strong earnings yesterday were two Dow component companies: General Electric and J. P. Morgan, both of which matched expectations. Shares of G.E. rose 1 1/16 , to 69 1/2, and J. P. Morgan climbed 1 5/8, to 108. The Dow, however, was led by International Paper, which rose 3 1/16 , to 58, two days after the company said it would cut its work force and sell $1 billion in assets to improve its profitability. **********For the Dow, yesterday's session proved to be slippery. The blue-chip average gained early, then fell behind by about 35 points before soaring 70 points higher. In the final hour, though, the Dow lost some of those gains. **********''Just your garden variety volatility,'' said Arthur Hogan, a trader at Morgan Stanley & Company. ''But the broader market was a breath of fresh air after being knocked down'' on Wednesday. **********The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 6.24 points, to 913.78. And the Russell 2000 index, a gauge of small stocks, gained 1.75, closing at a record 399.15. **********The New York Stock Exchange index also rose, up 3.24, to 476.27. Volume was relatively strong, at 552.5 million shares, and advancing issues beat decliners by 1,788 to 1,056. **********Technology stocks, however, slumped yesterday after several computer companies posted weaker-than-expected earnings. **********Seagate Technology, which makes disk drives, and Pairgain Technologies Inc., which makes telecommunications equipment, both reported disappointing earnings. Shares of Seagate fell 1 9/16 , to 37 1/2, and Pairgain -- the most actively traded issue yesterday -- dropped 111/16 , to 16 9/16 . **********Despite the weakness in technology stocks, the Nasdaq composite index, which contains many such issues, rose slightly yesterday, adding 4.30 points, to 1,490.93. It was the sixth consecutive record close for the index. **********While the Nasdaq continues to underperform the Dow and S.& P. 500 for the year, it has made steady inroads in the last few weeks, as technology stocks have made a comeback. The Dow and S.& P. 500 are up 23 percent this year; the Nasdaq is up 15.5 percent. **********ON THE WEB **********The latest stock and mutual fund quotations, along with news updates, are available on the Internet from The New York Times on the Web: www.nytimes.com

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/29/busin.snippet: Wheat prices fall for third time in four trading sessions as rains replenish dry wheat fields in Europe, easing concern that drought will damage crops there (M)û
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/29/busin.main_headline: Prices for Wheat Slip Again As Rain Aids European Crop
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/29/busin.print_headline: Prices for Wheat Slip Again As Rain Aids European Crop
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/29/busin.body_text: **********Wheat prices fell yesterday for the third time in four trading sessions as rains replenished dry wheat fields in Europe, easing concern that drought would damage crops there. **********On other markets, gold and copper fell. **********As much as an inch of rain fell in southern England and northern and eastern France during the weekend, and more is expected. In the northern Plains of the United States, by contrast, fields have been flooded but drier conditions are predicted for this week, which should let planting of spring wheat get under way. Winter wheat had been damaged last week by a freeze in some areas. **********The rains in Europe helped calm anxiety that drought in Britain and France, where rainfall this year is now just a quarter of normal, would cut wheat output from the European Union, the world's largest producer. Reduced shipments from Europe could increase demand for American wheat, and that prospect had raised wheat prices. **********But yesterday, wheat for July delivery fell 11 cents, to $4.2125 a bushel, on the Chicago Board of Trade. On the Kansas City Board of Trade, it dropped 12 cents, to $4.41 a bushel. **********Also weighing on prices, the Department of Agriculture said that 9.87 million bushels of wheat were inspected for export last week, down from a revised 16.3 million the week before. Traders said that the decline reflected a slowdown in international demand for American grains after a recent surge in prices. **********Gold slumped to a four-year low, in part because members of the Group of Seven leading industrial nations, while signaling concern about the rise of the dollar, did not say specifically that they would act to slow the ascent. The dollar's rally has made gold, for which the dollar is the international currency, more expensive for buyers using other currencies. **********June gold fell $2.50 to settle at $341.40 an ounce on the Comex division of the New York Mercantile Exchange, the lowest close for a most active contract since April 22, 1993. Copper fell after a larger-than-expected decline in American sales of new homes heightened expectations that a slowdown in the housing market will cool demand for copper from builders in coming weeks. **********May copper fell 1.10 cents, to $1.116 a pound, on the Comex.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/25/busin.body_text: **********The Filenet Corporation said yesterday that it would take a $6 million pretax charge in the second quarter to dismiss 10 percent of its workers and close its office in Burlington, Mass. About 150 employees will lose their jobs, the software developer said. Filenet announced plans on April 1 to close the Massachusetts office because of weaker-than-expected new orders. Filenet said the order shortfall led to a first-quarter loss of $9.4 million, or 63 cents a share, about 3 cents more than it had estimated earlier this month. The company's shares dropped 37.5 cents yesterday, to $11.375.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/05/world.snippet: Pres Clinton names Richard C Holbrooke, key figure in negotiating end to Bosnian civil war, special presidential envoy for Cyprus; appointment is sign or renewed American seriousness in trying to reach political settlement in Cyprus, which has bee...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/05/world.main_headline: Clinton Appoints Holbrooke as His Special Envoy for Cyprus
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/05/world.print_headline: Clinton Appoints Holbrooke as His Special Envoy for Cyprus
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/05/world.body_text: **********President Clinton today named Richard C. Holbrooke, who was instrumental in negotiating an end to the Bosnian civil war, as a special presidential envoy for Cyprus. **********There have been repeated efforts, all of them unsuccessful, to reach a political settlement on Cyprus, which has been divided since a 1974 Turkish invasion . But the appointment of Mr. Holbrooke, who will keep his job as an investment banker with Credit Suisse First Boston in New York, is a sign of renewed American seriousness in trying to resolve one of NATO's most potentially destabilizing conflicts as the alliance votes to expand, a senior American official said today. **********Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright has said that Cyprus is one of her priorities. Last year relations between Greece and Turkey, both NATO members, were severely strained over disputed islets in the Aegean, and Mr. Holbrooke, then the Assistant Secretary of State for Europe, was deeply involved in talks to ease the crisis. He resigned in February 1996 to join the investment bank, in which he has not had any business involvement with Cyprus, Greece or Turkey, officials said. **********The appointment of ''our toughest negotiator'' represents ''a rebirth and a renewal'' of ''our commitment to help promote a final political settlement on Cyprus,'' said the State Department spokesman, Nicholas Burns, who is scheduled for nomination as the American Ambassador to Greece. **********Mr. Holbrooke, 55, was a strong candidate for Secretary of State in Mr. Clinton's second administration. He will spend about a week every month on Cyprus issues, and will do so without pay, although with the help of a full-time State Department officer. He replaces Richard Beattie, whom Ms. Albright named last month as her adviser on the reorganization of the State Department. **********Reached by telephone in Copenhagen, Mr. Holbrooke said that Cyprus ''along with Bosnia, is the great unresolved flashpoint in Europe.'' While American efforts to resolve the Cyprus problem date back more than 30 years, ''the difference now is that the cold war is over, so cold war restraints have been loosened,'' he said. ''There is a kind of equilibrium now, but not a long-term one.'' **********Last month the Czech President, Vaclav Havel, said that Greece and Turkey would have gone to war at least twice since 1974 if not for their membership in NATO, and Mr. Holbrooke said he agreed. ''But while they are both NATO members, they have not normalized their relations, the way France and Germany did after the war,'' Mr. Holbrooke said. ''And tensions between them generally have been rising since the restraints of the cold war were removed. So it's absolutely necessary for Europe, the United States and the United Nations to try to settle this issue. It's imperative we try, and I'm honored to be asked.'' **********Both the Greeks and Turks, he said, ''need to realize they both can gain by reaching a settlement of the issue that respects both their communities.'' There is further pressure to settle from the European Union, which takes up Cyprus membership next year. **********But Mr. Holbrooke admitted that ''there is a very real question whether political conditions in Ankara, Athens and Nicosia will allow for a settlement.'' **********Next month, the United Nations Secretary General, Kofi Annan, will bring together the Greek Cypriot leader, Glafcos Clerides, and the Turkish Cypriot leader, Rauf Denktash, for their first meeting in nearly three years. **********No one expects rapid agreement, and Mr. Holbrooke said he would wait to see the results of those talks before traveling to the region.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/06/busin.snippet: H & R Block's new national advertising campaign presents stories that depict how people really feel about filing taxes; this is Young & Rubicam's first campaign for H & R Block since it was awarded contract last spring (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/06/busin.main_headline: H & R Block's spots suggest that a taxpayer's best friend is the one who does the taxes.
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/06/busin.print_headline: H & R Block's spots suggest that a taxpayer's best friend is the one who does the taxes.
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/06/busin.body_text: **********THE year is so young that people have not yet received all their credit card bills for December's holiday shopping, and many are still adhering to their New Year's resolutions. But, H & R Block Inc. wants everyone to start thinking about taxes, and Block is starting a national advertising campaign next week to get people in an April 15th state of mind. **********The campaign, by the Chicago office of Young & Rubicam, comprises four television and seven radio spots that will run through tax day, with a budget of $15 million. The ads are the first by Young & Rubicam for H & R Block since the agency was awarded the contract last spring. Before that, Bernstein-Rein Advertising of Kansas City, Mo., had the account for 12 years. **********This campaign represents a departure from the days when Henry Bloch, who founded the firm with his brother, Richard, was the company spokesman, and from the more recent campaign that emphasized the overall experience of using H & R Block. The new ads present stories that depict how people really feel about filing taxes. **********All of the spots feature ''Someone to Watch Over Me,'' the 1926 classic song by George and Ira Gershwin, as the underlying theme and closing phrase. According to Brad Most, vice president and management supervisor at Young & Rubicam Chicago, clients want a ''trusting relationship'' with their tax preparer in dealing with the sensitive topic of finances. ''The song captures the caring, soothing emotion that Block wants to convey,'' he said. **********Some of the commercials offer common-sense reasons to draw taxpayers into one of Block's 8,308 offices in the United States. In one television commercial, money is the compelling motivation to turn to a Block tax preparer: the I.R.S. average tax refund is $1,223, but the average Block customer gets $1,408. Smiling recipients are shown opening their refund checks, lighted by a soft yellow light as the refrain ''someone to watch over me'' plays behind the company logo. Another television spot reminds people that such  changes in their lives as marriage, divorce, buying a house or having a baby also change their tax status. **********A fuzzy emotional background may infuse the campaign, but most of the ads offer taxpayers a reminder of the many reasons why they find April the cruelest month, including the possibility of mistakes, complicated forms, audits and confusing math. ''There are a lot of buttons to be pushed in the tax business,'' Eric Steinhouse, senior vice president of marketing for H & R Block, said, ''because everybody has to file taxes.'' **********The campaign portrays the company as protector and helper: phrases like ''highest refund possible,'' ''guarantees of accuracy'' and ''having friends in the tax business'' pepper the spots, but so do such comments as ''nearly two million will have to endure an audit'' and ''the dreaded tax deadline of April 15th.'' **********H & R Block has been using focus-group research to plan its marketing strategies for five years, and last year it conducted a tracking study during the tax season to discern the attitudes of Block clients and noncustomers alike. In general, people are resigned to doing their taxes, but they have lingering doubts about missing out on a full refund and find the task frustrating, Mr. Steinhouse said. ''Preparing taxes is a very emotional process and the consumer is going up against a huge bureaucracy,'' he said. **********H & R Block, which is also based in Kansas City, Mo., already prepares one out of every seven income tax returns, and handled 17.3 million clients worldwide in 1996. In the United States, the company prepared returns for 14.8 million customers and dwarfed its closest competitor, Jackson Hewitt Inc., of Virginia Beach, Va. According to Alexander Paris Jr., a senior investment analyst at Barrington Research Associates Inc. in Chicago, Block had revenues of approximately $831 million from tax preparation in its 1996 fiscal year, compared with Jackson Hewitt's $25 million. **********Block's real ''competition'' is from the 50 million self-sufficient taxpayers, and they are the target audience in this campaign. ''The biggest chunk of tax preparers are self-preparers,'' Mr. Steinhouse said, ''and we're trying to attract them.'' **********Analysts say that Block is fine-tuning its business plans. The company, which has flirted with running a temporary-personnel business and a chain of community legal offices, owns Compuserve and the Block Financial Corporation. Compuserve is an Internet access and on-line provider, and Block Financial offers technology-driven services like  home banking and software for taxes and family legal advice. **********H & R Block is currently expanding its tax-related services, with products like tax-return checking for self-preparers; in-home preparation; refund anticipation loans in a partnership with Beneficial National Bank, and a preparation service aimed at higher-income clients. It is also expanding into such nontax businesses as helping fill out college applications and home will kits. **********Mr. Paris sees the neighborhood Block office as an excellent starting point for sales. When the Block preparer is doing taxes, he can ask the customer if he would be interested in a home equity loan to pay off credit cards or in some other service, Mr. Paris said. ''They want to build upon the trust of the H & R Block brand name,'' he said.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/07/busin.body_text: **********Social Security Panel Seeks Investment in Stock Market **********A Federal advisory panel suggested that the nation consider investing part of its Social Security revenue in the stock market to insure the solvency of the retirement program, which now invests solely in Government securities. But panel members disagreed on exactly how to do that. $(Page A1.$) **********Funneling billions into the market through Social Security could prove to be a boon to Wall Street and would conceivably help to send stock prices to new heights. But the shift could raise interest rates. $(A14.$) **********A Better Year for Auto Makers **********The auto industry ended the year with a 4 percent drop in sales, but even with the slowdown, auto makers sold 15.1 million vehicles, slightly better than 1995. $(D4.$) **********Monsanto Agrees to $1 Billion Deal **********Monsanto agreed to buy Holden's Foundation Seeds, a major producer of corn seed, and two Holden seed distributors, for $1.02 billion to capitalize on what it sees as a revolution in agricultural biotechnology. Some analysts viewed the deal as expensive, and Monsanto's stock slipped. Market Place. $(D8.$) **********A Bag of Coal for Toys 'R' Us **********Shares of Toys ''R'' Us tumbled 14.6 percent in active trading, after the big toy retailer said its Christmas sales were flat and that its fourth-quarter earnings would suffer. Sales of popular items like Nintendo 64 and Tickle Me Elmo dolls were insufficient to offset a lack of software titles and a shortened holiday selling season. $(D2.$) **********Apple's Shares Fall Sharply **********Apple Computer's shares fell nearly 18 percent after the company announced on Friday that it would report a loss in what is typically its strongest quarter. $(D2.$) **********The Dow Staggers to Record **********The stock market lurched to a new high, but a broad follow-through to Friday's rally faltered as the bond market continued to sputter. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 23.09 points, to 6,567.18. $(D8.$) **********Prices of Treasury securities sagged, dragged down by a weaker dollar and the higher cost of energy. The yield on the 30-year bond rose to 6.77 percent. $(D15.$) **********Texaco Names Ad Agency **********Texaco named the BBDO Worldwide unit of Omnicom Group as its lead corporate agency, to handle a new assignment centered on burnishing Texaco's tarnished brand image. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. $(D7.$) **********Heinz and Campbell in Feud **********The rivalry between H. J. Heinz and Campbell Soup landed in a courthouse when Heinz hired away a top Campbell executive and Campbell accused the executive of violating a noncompete clause in his contract. $(D4.$) **********Prudential Insurance Is Fined **********A Federal judge fined Prudential Insurance $1 million after several incidents of document destruction in the company's long-running legal dispute concerning deceptive sales practices. $(D3.$) **********Economic Adviser Suits Mainstream **********Four years ago, many top economists criticized President Clinton's choice of Laura D'Andrea Tyson to lead the Council of Economic Advisers. But when he selected Janet Yellen as the council's latest head, the move made barely a ripple among economists, and the shift says a lot about their new attitude toward the Administration. $(D3.$) **********German Developer Is Charged **********Prosecutors in Germany announced fraud charges against Jurgen Schneider, the real estate developer whose empire collapsed nearly three years ago. $(D18.$)

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/21/world.snippet: Article on controversial German filmmaker Leni Riefenstahl, whose films in 1930's celebrated Nazi pageantry; notes that she will be 95 on Aug 22; photo (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/21/world.main_headline: Admire Her Art? (Her Camera Adored Swastikas)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/21/world.print_headline: Admire Her Art? (Her Camera Adored Swastikas)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/21/world.body_text: **********Leni Riefenstahl will be 95 years old on Friday, and if she imagined the years would diminish the stigma she accumulated 60 years ago and more as Hitler's favored movie-maker, then she was -- apparently -- wrong. **********When an exhibit of her work -- the first in postwar Germany -- opened here last week, the focus was on those denouncing her roots in the Third Reich and on a debate about a particularly troubled corollary: can art that grew in such soil ever transcend its origins? **********''The discussion is, in fact, more interesting than the exhibit,'' said Andreas Schluter, who arranged the exhibit of 50 colored postwar photographs and black-and-white prewar film clips at his second-floor gallery  close to Hamburg's main railroad station. **********Ms. Riefenstahl has staked out her own position in the debate. ''Can art be separated from politics?'' she said in a telephone interview from her home on the Starnbergersee in Bavaria. ''If an artist is possessed by his art, then he does not have the possibility to do anything else.'' **********An admiring Adolf Hitler sought  out the filmmaker to direct what has been termed the most notorious documentary ever filmed -- ''Triumph of the Will'' -- a depiction of the Nazi Party rally that became a central motif of Hitler's dictatorship. **********In scenes that have chilled subsequent generations, the documentary shows the massed banners and uplifted faces of Hitler's devoted followers marching by his podium. Yet, Ms. Riefenstahl insisted today, ''it was only a documentary. It could be used for propaganda purposes, but I didn't make it as propaganda.'' Indeed, she recalled, the film won a major award as a documentary in Paris in 1937. **********''Triumph of the Will'' was followed by her renowned documentary coverage of the 1936 Berlin Olympics, ''Olympia,'' cementing her reputation as a documentary-maker entwined with the Nazi ideology of Aryan supremacy. So close was the association that Time magazine, she recalled, once referred to her erroneously as Hitler's girlfriend. **********At the core of the argument over the exhibition, of course, is postwar Germany's unresolved fixation with its history that seems to trip modern Germans at every turn: only last week, two conscripts were discharged from the German Army after an arson attack on a home for foreigners, a development that raised worrisome questions about screening military recruits for right-wing sympathies; and even this week, Government officials are negotiating with Jewish officials over compensation payments to Holocaust survivors in Eastern Europe. **********Almost routinely, the past rears up -- in high-school courses and histories -- with the warning that it should not be repeated. **********But, at Mr. Schluter's gallery here, the discussion is tinged with a further question: is there a statute of limitations, so to speak, for those, like Ms. Riefenstahl, who spent three years after World War II in American and French internment camps and who underwent the process known as denazification, through which Germans were supposed to equip themselves to begin anew? **********''This is really a significant question,'' Mr. Schluter said in an interview during which he acknowledged deep admiration for Ms. Reifenstahl's work, first as a filmmaker in the 1930's and then as a photographer in the postwar era. (Even today, despite her years, she is working on a deep-sea video reflecting her fascination with submarine themes.  She learned to dive more than 20 years ago when she was in her 70's. Three days after her birthday, she plans a diving trip to Hawaii to work on her next film.) **********''For 50 years, Leni Riefenstahl has been working with photography,'' said Mr. Schluter, who is 36.  ''There is a postwar person here and perhaps one can make a distinction'' between that person and the prewar movie-maker. **********Even then, Ms. Riefenstahl challenges the stereotype of herself as what Mr. Schluter described as ''a synonym for the Third Reich.'' **********About the Holocaust, she says: ''I did not know what was going on. I did not know anything about these things.'' Accordingly, she said, referring to the Nazi ideology, ''I distance myself from all that.'' **********Ms. Riefenstahl's rise to pre-eminence among German movie-makers began in 1932 when she directed ''The Blue Light,'' the story of an innocent mountain girl, which reflected the interest in mountain themes she had discovered starring in Arnold Fanck's dramatic movies. It was that film that caught Hitler's eye and led him to ask her to make ''Triumph of the Will.'' **********Ms. Riefenstahl says she had begun to have doubts about Hitler -- whom at first she greatly admired -- in 1937 because his views on art conflicted with hers. **********The war, in effect, ended her movie-making. **********Detained from 1945 to 1948, she said today, she repeatedly insisted to her captors that she had not been a Nazi Party member and had ''never uttered an anti-Semitic phrase and was never a racist.'' **********Nonethless, her past caught up with her: no one would hire her to make movies. And even when she turned to color photography and traveled to the Sudan to take a series of photographs of Nubians, which appeared in book form in the 1970's, she was again accused of pursuing the ''fascist aesthetic'' of glorification of the male body. **********''Absolute nonsense,'' she said today. **********Her work has been exhibited in Japan and Italy -- where it also drew protests in Milan -- but the Hamburg exhibit is the first in Germany. Though she had had other offers, she said, she accepted Mr. Schulter's because she found him agreeable. For his part, the gallery owner said he had conceived the exhibition as a great admirer of Ms. Riefenstahl's work. Pointedly, there are no stills from ''Triumph of the Will'' in the exhibit. **********Critically, the exhibit has inspired a huge surge of interest in Ms. Riefenstahl and her work. She has been interviewed for most of Germany's major weekly publications -- Der Spiegel, Stern and Die Zeit, for instance. But the attention has not always been flattering. Interviewers have again pursued her association and fascination with Hitler, critics have challenged the merit of her photography, which also includes underwater photographs of coral reefs. Other, older Germans, Mr. Schluter said, have left the exhibit in a nostalgic and sympathetic mood. **********None of this amounts to a formal rehabilitation. No public officials attended the exhibit's opening. ''I absolutely cannot imagine that I did something unjust,'' Ms. Riefenstahl said in one published interview. ''What crime did I commit?''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/10/busin.snippet: Fidelity Investments says its flagship Magellan Fund, nation's largest mutual fund, has none of its assets in bonds, for first time this decade; says Magellan had 95.5 percent of its assets invested in stocks at end of February and rest in cash-re...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/10/busin.body_text: **********For the first time this decade, Fidelity Investments' flagship Magellan Fund holds no bonds. **********The Boston-based company, a unit of the FMR Corporation,  said in a report today that Magellan, the nation's largest mutual fund, had none of its assets in bonds on Feb. 28, down from the 19.3 percent it held on May 31 when Robert E. Stansky took control as manager of Magellan from Jeffrey N. Vinik. **********Magellan's investment in bonds hurt its performance last year as the fund ranked among America's worst-performing ''growth'' stock funds. **********This year Magellan ranks No. 396 of 687 growth stock funds tracked by Bloomberg Fund Performance, returning six-tenths of a percent as of Tuesday. By contrast, the Standard & Poor's 500 Index was up 3.43 percent. **********Mr. Stansky has steadily shaved Magellan's investment in bonds over the last nine months. In February, the fund reported the percentage of its assets in finance stocks increased and the percentage of assets allocated to technology and energy-related stocks declined, according to the Fidelity report. **********Fidelity announced last week that beginning in July it would change its policy of disclosing the top 10 holdings of its mutual funds. It said that beginning in July the data would be published quarterly rather than monthly. **********Magellan had 95.5 percent of its assets invested in stocks at the end of February and the rest in cash-related securities, according to Fidelity.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/07/busin.snippet: Justice Dept files suit to block plan by Chancellor Media Corp to acquire four popular Long Island radio stations from SFX Broadcasting, saying it would undercut competition, drive up radio advertising fees and result in higher costs to consumers ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/07/busin.main_headline: U.S. Acts to Bar Chancellor Media's L.I. Radio Deal
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/07/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS; U.S. Acts to Bar Chancellor Media's L.I. Radio Deal
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/07/busin.body_text: **********After approving more than 1,000 radio station mergers since Federal rules were liberalized nearly two years ago, the Justice Department filed suit today to block one for the first time. **********In a civil complaint filed in United States District Court in Brooklyn, the  department said that the plan by the Chancellor Media Corporation to acquire four popular Long Island radio stations would undercut competition, drive up radio advertising fees and result in higher costs to consumers in the area. Chancellor had planned to acquire the stations from SFX Broadcasting Inc., swapping them for two stations in Jacksonville, Fla., and $11 million. **********Chancellor, which now owns two stations on Long Island, said that acquiring the four that SFX owned would help it compete with other media and with larger stations based in New York City. **********But Charles E. Biggio, senior counsel in the Justice Department antitrust division, said the deal ''would end the competitive battle'' for radio advertising in Long Island's Suffolk County. The Justice Department  complaint said the deal would for the first time create a single dominant Long Island radio group, with more than 65 percent of the local radio advertising market. **********Chancellor would acquire SFX's  WBLI-FM, WBAB-FM, WHFM-FM and WGBB-AM. The deal is part of a wave of mergers resulting from the Telecommunications Reform Act of 1996. Congress in effect authorized the rapid consolidation in the radio industry by relaxing Federal Communications Commission restrictions on the number of radio stations held by any one owner. **********Since then, Government officials have said, more than 4,000 of the  11,000 radio stations in the nation have changed hands. There have been more than 1,000 merger deals, including more than 140 large enough to be reported to the Justice Department's antitrust division for review. **********The Justice Department objected to eight previous deals. In five cases, it reached settlements that resolved the competitive concerns, often requiring some stations to be sold off. Three other deals were restructured or abandoned. **********Government and private lawyers in the Long Island dispute seemed to agree that the lawsuit did not represent a hardening of the Justice Department's antitrust approach to the  wave of radio station mergers, but was a fight over competitive position in a superheated market. **********''Our position toward these transactions has been consistent,'' Mr.  Biggio said. ''This is the first case where the parties have been unable to resolve our concerns.'' **********In addition to seeking to halt the deal, the Justice Department action, which resulted in part from complaints by advertisers, is aimed at trying to stop a temporary marketing arrangement in which Chancellor has been operating SFX's Long Island stations. **********The Justice Department focused on three Long Island stations that it said together dominated the ratings  on Long Island among adults 25 to 54 years of age, who are most important to Suffolk County advertisers.  The three are WALK-FM, an adult contemporary station already owned by Chancellor, and two SFX stations: WBLI, another adult contemporary station, and WBAB, an adult-oriented rock station. **********Quoting internal corporate documents, the Justice Department said that a WALK sales director had written that the acquisition would bring an end to the bitter competition between Chancellor and SFX that had afforded advertisers ''fire sale rates.'' The Government said that a Chancellor executive had exulted after the deal was first reached that ''the war is won.'' **********Government lawyers said they had concentrated on the anti-competitive effect of the deal. **********''Allowing Chancellor to buy a dominant position in this concentrated market will result in higher radio advertising prices for Suffolk County businesses that rely on radio to sell their products and services,'' said Joel I. Klein, the Assistant Attorney General in charge of the antitrust division. **********But Chancellor representatives said that the Government erred in failing to acknowledge how the new group of radio stations under one ownership could also offer benefits to advertisers. Edward P. Henneberry, an antitrust lawyer for Chancellor, said that the group of stations would provide a competitive alternative to expensive New York City radio stations, cable television stations or even newspapers. **********''The Government didn't mention the strong pro-competitive benefit that you get from radio consolidation that allows this group to compete more directly with other advertisers,'' Mr. Henneberry said. ''We think this is an overgeneralization and we disagree with it -- a lot of people on Long Island listen to New York radio stations.'' **********Katie Bachman, editor of Radio Business Reports, an industry newsletter, echoed that view, adding that there was no evidence that ad rates had increased since the nationwide consolidation wave began. **********Chancellor, which is based in Irving, Tex., owns 95 radio stations in 21 major American markets, including 12 of the largest markets. SFX is based in New York City and owns or operates 85 radio stations in 23 cities. Chancellor is a recently formed media group consisting of the Evergreen Media Corporation, the Chancellor Broadcasting Company and the former radio group of Viacom International Inc. **********Chancellor's largest shareholder, with an 18 percent stake, is the investment partnership of Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst, a Dallas buyout firm. Hicks, Muse also agreed in August to acquire SFX in a $1.2 billion deal that is unaffected by the  action today by the Justice Department. **********Like Chancellor, other big radio companies like the Westinghouse Broadcasting Corporation and Jacor Communications have embraced consolidation with a vengeance. **********The Telecommunications Act now allows station owners to amass as many as eight stations in a single market, presumably with a greater share of the audience. Several companies are bumping up against that limit in some markets.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/23/busin.snippet: Investors dump Japanese stocks, spurring rumors that Finance Ministry might intervene by buying shares; Nikkei index of 225 shares falls 515.49 points, or 3.37 percent, to 17,799.40 on Mon, 12/22, weakest close since July 1995 (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/23/busin.main_headline: Japan Stocks Fall, Ignoring Stimulus Plan and Intervention Rumors
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/23/busin.print_headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; Japan Stocks Fall, Ignoring Stimulus Plan and Intervention Rumors
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/23/busin.body_text: **********Ignoring Government efforts to revive the economy, strengthen weak banks and defend the yen, investors dumped Japanese stocks today and sent the market to its weakest close in nearly two and a half years. **********It was the second consecutive trading day of relentless selling and aroused rumors that the Finance Ministry might intervene to buy shares in order to provide a floor for the stock market, which has become a daily measure of the economic frailties vexing Japan. **********Officials declined to comment on the rumors. But Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto, asked today about the market's decline, replied, ''I am deeply concerned.'' **********The benchmark Nikkei index of 225 stocks fell 515.49 points, or 3.37 percent, to 14,799.40, its weakest close since July 4, 1995. On Friday, the Nikkei index dropped 5.2 percent. **********Some of the selling today might have reflected efforts by investors to reduce their exposure before a holiday Tuesday, when financial markets here are closed for Emperor Akihito's birthday. But many sellers seemed to have lost confidence. **********''Sentiment is deteriorating quite rapidly,'' said Andrew Shipley, an economist with Schroders Japan Ltd. Government attempts to invigorate the economy that might have seemed adequate before, he said, were ''now not perceived as sufficient at all.'' **********Last week, Mr. Hashimoto, his advisers and the central bank sought to revive confidence in Japan with proposed tax cuts and other stimulants valued at five trillion yen, or more than $38 billion; a plan to inject up to twice that much into debt-plagued banks, and aggressive purchases of yen to keep the currency from weakening further. **********But the efforts were undermined on Friday with news that a leading food commodities trader, Toshoku Ltd., would seek bankruptcy protection, raising fear that more such failures could come without warning. **********Japan is already suffering from the worst spate of business bankruptcies since World War II -- something that has dire implications for weak financial institutions. **********Sakura Bank, one of the weaker of Japan's 20 largest, had been heavily exposed to Toshoku, and its shares, which plummeted last week, dropped nearly 14 percent further today. Moody's Investors Service put the bank on credit watch last week for a possible downgrading. **********Even the mighty Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi was bruised, its shares falling 4.4 percent today. **********The market's weakness also reflected a strong reluctance by consumers to spend money. Hiroshi Okuda, president of the Toyota Motor Corporation, complained today that the auto maker, Japan's largest, was having difficulty luring buyers. ''I felt quite unhappy,'' Mr. Okuda said, when asked what he thought of the market pessimism. **********And Okiharu Yasuoka, a leader of the Liberal Democratic Party committee charged with stabilizing the financial system, described the Nikkei index's fall below 15,000 as ''a crisis.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/07/world.snippet: Television coverage of funeral of Diana, Princess of Wales, was communal event for many New Yorkers, both spiritually and physically (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/07/world.main_headline: As Dark Turned to Dawn, a City Watched History Receive a New Legend
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/07/world.print_headline: As Dark Turned to Dawn, a City Watched History Receive a New Legend
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/07/world.body_text: **********Jean and Daniel Segal, real estate brokers on Manhattan's Upper East Side and the parents of three small children, began yesterday morning by paying Diana, Princess of Wales, the highest tribute they could think to offer: not watching her televised funeral. **********Diana, who lived almost half her life hounded by photographers and who died in Paris a week ago trying to flee them, might have been pleased with the Segals' decision. The Segals also kept the television off last week -- during the intensive coverage of Diana's life and death at 36 -- because, they said, they were so saddened by her death. **********''Her death just broke my heart,'' Mrs. Segal, 42, said. ''I can't bear to watch her children.'' **********But the Segals' decision was unusual, exceptional. In the privacy of their homes, in churches and in hastily arranged memorial services, millions of people from Hong Kong to Atlanta were linked in a common experience yesterday morning. For three hours, in many time zones, they watched Diana's last television appearance, her lifeless body resting inside a coffin covered with the royal flag and three bouquets of white flowers. **********In New York, where the city's pace and crowded conditions often force people to share private moments with strangers in the subway, the park or the streets, Diana's funeral was a communal event for some, not only spiritually, but physically. **********About 40 people, bundled up against the chilly wind of the early morning, congregated in front of the giant television screen at Times Square, some arriving as early as 3:30 Saturday morning. They were there, most said, because Diana was such a good, selfless person, that she deserved a proper farewell. **********Maritza Meyer, a 30-year-old secretary, summed it up this way: ''What is a sleepless night compared to what the world has lost?'' **********Some of the early-morning funeral watchers, like Joseph Gallivan and Spring Gunter, had set their at alarms at 3 A.M., planning to go to Times Square because they did not have a television at home. Others just happened upon the first images of the funeral and decided to stay. **********Still others failed to find any other place with a television and wound up in the Times Square crowd. They included Tom Wayman and Angus MacDougall, tourists from England, who walked the city for two hours looking in vain for an open bar. Intent on watching, they too headed for Times Square. **********Reclining against the street-sign pole on 44th Street, Mr. Wayman explained why watching Diana one last time was so important to him. ''Because I've been saturated with her, and I'm feeling withdrawal symptoms,'' Mr. Wayman, a 23-year-old from Oxford, said with a deep sigh. ''You think you are not addicted to her, but, all of a sudden, she is taken away from you and you realize that, unwillingly, you are.'' **********Others in Times Square, even those who have never lived in or even traveled to England, expressed a similar sentiment. For so long, Diana's name and image have been part of many people's lives that they simply could not let her go without one last look. **********One of those was Constantinos Mavris, a cab driver for 24 of his 54 years, who suddenly put on the brakes on Broadway when he saw the picture of Diana on the giant screen just before the funeral procession began. Technically, he was in the heart of his shift, which ended at 6 A.M., but, he said, Diana's funeral was more important. **********''I was never lucky enough to meet her. I've met Meg Ryan and a couple of Rockettes and Margot Kidder, but I never gave the Princess a ride anywhere. I would have loved to,'' he said. ''I wouldn't have charged her, that's for sure.'' **********By 6 A.M., feet hurting and necks sore from looking up to the screen for hours, some people began to gather in circles and talk to each other. **********''We don't have anything like this in Kansas City, I can tell you that,'' said John P. Soulis, 31, a private detective who came to New York on Friday to accompany a friend on business. ''People watching television in the middle of the street would be a very strange sight in Kansas City.'' **********Mr. Soulis said he had decided to go to Times Square on a whim in the middle of the night to ''soak up in the atmosphere.'' Upon arriving at 1 A.M., he saw a television crew setting up cameras, found out that the funeral would be broadcast and decided to stay. Five hours later, he looked at his wrist watch and realized he had not slept in 26 hours. **********No matter, he said, it was the least he could do for Diana. ''She was a beautiful lady,'' he said in a whisper. ''Besides, now I can say that I was part of history. I saw her funeral in Times Square.'' **********For Mr. Soulis, there was a sweet irony to his happening upon the televised images of Diana. He was an eighth grader when Diana married Prince Charles in 1981. He remembers getting up early in the morning to watch that ceremony. Since then, Diana has fascinated him. **********It was the same for Elia Guzman, an Upper East Side nanny. Ms. Guzman, 55, set her alarm clock early yesterday to make sure she did not miss a minute of the Princess's funeral. She watched it alone, in the darkness of her Washington Heights apartment because her roommate, Maria de los Angeles Alberto, was too sleepy to share the experience with her. **********''I saw the wedding, I have read all the magazines, I have her pictures, I know all about her life,'' Ms. Guzman said. ''I would not miss this for the world. I feel I owe it to her.'' **********Ms. Guzman is so enthralled by Diana that she asked her boss, who is in England on business, to sign her name in the condolence books that people have been standing in line for hours in London to sign. **********''I hope he does,'' Ms. Guzman said. ''It would mean a lot to me.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/19/busin.main_headline: Japan Reports Trade Surplus Soared in April
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/19/busin.print_headline: Japan Reports Trade Surplus Soared in April
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/19/busin.body_text: **********Japan's merchandise trade surplus rose sharply in April as auto makers and others cranked up exports to compensate for slower growth in domestic demand after the Government raised the national consumption tax, economists said today. **********The surplus increased 163.7 percent from the corresponding month a year earlier to 831.48 billion yen, or $7.23 billion, the Finance Ministry said. The rise, which was the second in the last three months, followed nearly three years of declines. Automobile and machine makers that lifted production to meet strong domestic orders before April are now focused on competing for market share overseas. **********Japan's politically sensitive trade surplus with the United States rose for the seventh consecutive month, increasing 174.1 percent, to 468.97 billion yen, or $4.16 billion. **********That could irritate the Big Three American automobile companies, which have seen Japanese auto makers increase their share of the United States market this year. **********The rise in the trade surplus came as the dollar rose sharply against the yen, before slipping this month. A stronger dollar, and thus a weaker yen, makes Japanese goods less expensive overseas. In Tokyo trading, the dollar briefly slipped to less than 115 yen on word of the trade-surplus rise, down from 115.45 just before the release of the numbers, but later recovered. **********If the dollar continues to fall from the highs it reached against the yen earlier this year, it could limit the rise in the Japanese trade surplus by making the country's exports more expensive again. **********Japanese exports in April rose 21.5 percent, to 4.43 trillion yen, the Government said. **********Exports of every major industrial category rose. Auto exports to the United States rose 25.4 percent in April from the corresponding month the previous year, to 230 billion yen. **********Imports to Japan rose 8.1 percent in April, to 3.59 trillion yen. The Government raised the consumption tax by 2 percentage points, to 5 percent, on April 1. **********The stock market had a muted reaction to the report. At midday, the Nikkei index or 225 issues was up 97.91, to 20,422.44, or a half-percent. On Friday, the Nikkei rose 268.42 points.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/12/busin.print_headline: Motorola Wins Phone Contract in India
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/12/busin.body_text: **********Motorola Inc. won a $50 million order from Bharti Telenet Ltd., an Indian telecommunications company, to provide some of the equipment to build a phone network in India. **********Motorola's Cellular Infrastructure Group will help set up the network in the central state of Madhya Pradesh. **********Bharti Telenet is a joint venture involving two companies controlled by the entrepreneur Bharti Mittal and Telecom Italia S.p.A., the Italian telecommunications monopoly. **********Bharti Televentures owns 51 percent of the venture, Telecom Italia holds 30 percent and Bharti Telecom has 19 percent. **********More than half of the equipment for India's cellular phone networks comes from Motorola, the company said. It has helped set up 20 systems in India worth $300 million. **********Motorola, based in Schaumburg, Ill., had 1996 sales of $28 billion.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/01/world.snippet: German politicians acknowledge failure of efforts to streamline burdensome tax system, even as US lawmakers negotiate budget-balancing and tax accord; German business people are gloomy about becoming more competitive in world market; praise pragma...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/01/world.main_headline: As Bonn Fails at Tax Reform, German Businesses Study U.S.
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/01/world.print_headline: As Bonn Fails at Tax Reform, German Businesses Study U.S.
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/01/world.body_text: **********The timing was a coincidence, but no less telling for that: just as United States lawmakers  were preening over legislation to balance the budget and cut taxes, German politicians acknowledged failure early today in negotiations to streamline their land's burdensome system of taxation. **********For people like Ralf Riba, who runs a small design company here that has taken an American cue -- not only by marketing 6 foot tall, 100 pound steel representations of the Empire State Building, but also by downsizing its staff and outsourcing work -- the implications were obvious. **********''Medium-sized companies are still the motor of the German economy,'' he said. ''And this has put the brakes on.'' **********Indeed, across a spectrum from industry representatives to Government ministers, the assessment was gloomy. ''The chance to make Germany more attractive in the international race for investment was frittered away,'' said the Economics Minister, Gunther Rexrodt. **********Neither was the comparison with Washington lost on commentators. **********''Two worlds,'' said the Frankfurter Allgemeine, a conservative daily. ''With pragmatic common sense, the Americans presented themselves with a reduction of capital taxes to keep their economy on the upswing; in Germany, a tax reform that would have offered a realistic chance to the unemployed has collapsed on ideological divisions.'' **********The German tax reform, which Chancellor Helmut Kohl labeled ''the reform of the century,'' centered on a Government proposal to cut $16 billion worth of taxes, in part by lowering the top-end income tax rate from 53 percent to 39 percent and the starting rate from 25.9 percent to 15 percent. The Government proposal also foresaw a reduction of an income tax surcharge for the staggering costs of German reunification from 7.5 to 5.5 percent. **********The aim was to encourage investment and thus stimulate jobs in an economy where unemployment exceeds one million people, or 11 percent of the work force. **********The opposition Social Democrats, with a majority both in the upper house of Parliament and on the mediation committee that met for 15 hours on Wednesday, blocked the package, saying its terms favored the rich. Not only that, the opposition's own counterproposal to lower Germany's prohibitive labor costs in return for increases in the value-added tax and the fuel tax now seems certain to be voted down by the Government majority in the lower house. **********The result: political paralysis and, according to Arnold Willemsen, a spokesman for the Federal Association of Germany Industry, ''catastrophic implications'' for Germany's record-level unemployment and ''a signal to German investors to take their money abroad and to foreign investors to avoid Germany even more.'' **********For Mr. Riba, 29, in his design office in this leafy backwater 25 miles south of Bonn, the tribulations seemed ominously familiar: It was a combination of high costs and global pressures that turned his family's business from a substantial manufacturer of clothing-industry machinery employing 70 workers to a modest studio with just two full-time employees -- a parable of German costs and complacency at a time of global economic change. **********When its American marketing partner pulled out under disputed circumstances two and a half years ago, Mr. Riba said the company, founded in 1947, was left to fend for itself in a world that had changed radically. **********The company's patented machinery designs, it turned out, had been copied in Poland and Greece, Mr. Riba said in an interview. The clothing industry had moved away from Germany because of high labor costs to places where it was cheaper -- Romania, Turkey, the former Yugoslavia and parts of southeast Asia. **********''As Germans, we had been so arrogant,'' Mr. Riba said. ''We ranked No. 2 in the world as exporters. But we lost sight of the world market and realized too late that our competitors had not been sitting still.'' **********When the banks demanded repayment of loans worth some $800,000, the company -- Dipl. Ing. Riba G.m.b.H. -- was left with 26 full-time employees it could not afford to dismiss because of the high severance pay mandated by German law. **********It declared bankruptcy last September, sold off manufacturing plants and office buildings and was reborn this year as Ralf Riba Design, with one small workshop, one rented design studio and two full-time employees -- Mr. Riba and an assistant. Start-up cost: $30,000. **********Although Mr. Riba has never visited the United States, his formula seems a microcosm of American economic restructuring. In a land where social contributions devour 40 percent of gross salaries, he employs a designer and technical staff as freelancers so that he does not have to pay those outlays. Rather than maintain costly work space, Mr. Riba subcontracts labor to four independent shops. **********''We don't want mass markets,'' he said. ''We want niche markets for new ideas.'' Apart from the Empire State Building look-alikes, about 100 of which have been sold as decorative objects or CD racks for around $1,200 each, his company also produces a device to measure the conductivity of building materials, costing roughly $80,000 each. The future, he said, is in high-tech innovation. **********Such thinking might be profitable in the United States. But in Germany, steep taxes and the world's highest labor costs inhibit companies like Mr. Riba's that simply are not big enough to transfer production plants abroad, as many bigger German companies have. **********''It's worse for small companies than big ones,'' said Mr. Willemsen of the Federal Association of German Industry. ''The big firms have made their investments abroad and even the bigger medium-sized firms have begun to move abroad. The smaller firms find this difficult. They stay here and remain under the tax-yoke. For them, there's no relief.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/12/busin.snippet: ING Groep NV offers $4.68 billion for Banque Bruxelles Lambert of Belgium (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/12/busin.main_headline: ING Offers $4.68 Billion for Belgian Bank
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/12/busin.print_headline: ING Offers $4.68 Billion for Belgian Bank
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/12/busin.body_text: **********ING Groep N.V. made a bold move to extend its spree of acquisitions today with a $4.68 billion offer to buy Banque Bruxelles Lambert of Belgium. **********ING, the biggest financial services company in the Netherlands, said it would pay a combination of cash and securities valued at 9,500 Belgian francs a share, or $268 a share, for the 80 percent of Banque Bruxelles it does not own. ING purchased 20 percent of the bank in an early 1990's takeover attempt. **********There was no immediate response from Banque Bruxelles. ING had been cited in the Belgian and Dutch press as a possible buyer since merger talks between the bank and Generale de Banque S.A., Belgium's biggest bank, broke down last year. **********ING has been expanding on both sides of the Atlantic as it tries to create one of the world's largest financial companies. **********Last month, it bought the Equitable of Iowa Companies, an insurer, for $2.6 billion, and Furman Selz Inc., a New York investment bank, for $600 million. Two years earlier, the bank bought Barings P.L.C., Britain's oldest merchant bank, after Barings nearly collapsed in a trading scandal. **********Earlier this year, ING said it had ''at least'' 6 billion guilders, or about $3 billion, to spend, and planned to buy a European bank. **********Wieger Sietsma, a spokesman for ING, said that under terms of the offer to Banque Bruxelles, shareholders would receive six shares of ING, one call warrant and 300 Belgian francs in cash for each Banque Bruxelles share. **********Belgian banks are too small to compete on a European scale, analysts say, and the tangled web of Banque Bruxelles shareholdings made the bank the focus of speculation over mergers and takeovers. **********Royale Belge, a Belgian insurer; Groupe Bruxelles Lambert, a holding company, and Dexia, a lender to local governments, own about 12 percent of Banque Bruxelles apiece. **********Earlier today, ING said nine-month profit rose 27 percent, led by its banking business, to 2.963 billion guilders ($1.54 billion) from 2.337 billion guilders in the period a year earlier. The company said it also expected improved profits for the full year.
