https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/22/your-.main_headline: Credit-Card Protection Gains a High-Tech Edge : What's in the Cards?More Uses and Fraud
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/22/your-.print_headline: Credit-Card Protection Gains a High-Tech Edge : What's in the Cards?More Uses and Fraud
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/22/your-.body_text: **********AN AMERICAN personal-finance guru once advised in his list of top 10 tips for financial success that people should not worry about their credit cards being lost or stolen. His reasoning was that cardholders were liable only for the first $50 of fraudulent use and that there were more important financial matters on which to dwell. **********Cardholders may still have far greater worries, but they probably should be more concerned about fraud and security than when that advice was offered nearly 20 years ago. The number of cards in use and the amount spent on them by consumers has grown substantially. **********Just as important, there are more ways to spend money with cards — at cash machines, over the telephone and the Internet, and soon through electronic wallets that serve as cash surrogates — and fraud techniques are becoming more varied and sophisticated. **********Fraud and theft amount to about 10 cents on every $100 that cardholders charge, but because card use is so pervasive, this adds up to more than $1 billion a year just for cards issued by banks under the two largest brands, Visa and MasterCard. Total card fraud is considerably higher when American Express, Diners Club and the many types of department-store and oil-company cards are included. **********Cardholders are still liable only for nominal amounts charged illegally in their name. But ultimately the money lost to card issuers and the money they spend trying to prevent further thefts comes out of the pockets of their cardholders or, if competition is too steep, their shareholders. **********Theft comes in many guises. There are the most crude forms, such as stealing someone's wallet or reading a cardholder's personal identification number at a cash machine and then taking the card. Some more artful crooks intercept new cards before they can be delivered in the mail. And then there are techno-literate thieves, who try to hack into computer networks to steal the card numbers of on-line shoppers. **********Fortunately, there is a vast, sophisticated arsenal with which to combat such crime. A relatively simple procedure is to print cardholders' photographs on cards, which has proven "very successful in cutting down point-of-sale fraud," said Keith Saunders, chief architect for security and electronic commerce at NCR Corp., which makes cash machines and security systems. **********Including a photo, he said, "increases the risk of getting caught and makes criminals feel uneasy." **********The biggest innovation in anti-theft technology is the smart card, which is also called the chip card because an embedded silicon chip allows far more information to be stored than on a card with a conventional magnetic stripe. **********While a stripe card might contain a PIN and not much else, chip cards are being developed with enough room to store a digitized version of the cardholder's thumbprint. Another advantage is that it is harder to snatch information off a smart card. **********"If you had the right equipment, you could copy a stripe card," Mr. Saunders said. "When you move into smart cards, the equipment is much less available and much more expensive, and the level of expertise is much higher. Remanufacturing a silicon chip is a fairly complex operation. **********"Typically, only big companies and universities have that equipment," he added, "and information is put into a chip that makes it difficult to know what to copy and what to look for. If you don't do it just right, you destroy the chip." **********Smart cards are being introduced gradually around the world. Ciaran Brennan, editor of the industry newsletter Cards International, noted that in countries where it has been in widespread use, such as France, banks "have been able to reduce card fraud quite substantially and now other countries are looking to introduce chip cards." **********He said that they were viewed somewhat as the future of card security. **********Smart-card technology will eventually allow banks to provide cards that can serve both as credit cards and electronic wallets, with stored-up cash that can be used for small purchases and replenished at banks when the cash runs out. The goal, Mr. Brennan said, is "to take cash out of society and bring in electronic payment cards, with the added benefit of reducing fraud." **********In a card security system, Mr. Saunders said, "ideally what you want is something you possess, something you know and something you are." **********The first is a PIN, the second is the card itself and the third could be a thumbprint. **********Cards that read thumbprints are deemed especially useful in emerging economies, where card use is increasing rapidly and fraud is far higher than in traditional markets. Visa reported that card fraud in Latin America last year was six times as great as in Europe and Asia as a percentage of sales and twice as great as in North America. **********Thumbprint identification overcomes the limitations of literacy and familiarity with computers that exist in emerging markets. The system is not foolproof, however. There have been gruesome cases in South Africa where thieves have separated cardholders from their cards as well as from their thumbs. Newer technology requires the thumb connected with a card to have a pulse. **********Another identification procedure being tested and likely to be on the market in a few years involves reading the irises of cardholders' eyes, which are even more idiosyncratic than fingerprints. **********All is not lost once a card is stolen. Credit-scoring agencies, which banks use to decide who should and should not get credit, have developed programs for spotting spending patterns with a high probability of indicating fraudulent use. **********Technology designed by Fair, Isaac & Co., a large credit scorer, looks for such telltale signs as large transactions out of a cardholder's home area soon after an account is open, especially stores that carry expensive merchandise such as electronics and jewelry. **********Cardholders are increasingly making purchases all over the world while they are sitting in their living rooms. A priority of card issuers is to develop technology that keeps hackers from grabbing card information transmitted over the Internet. **********This includes encryption procedures that scramble communications between cardholders and merchants and make use of a "digital signature." That involves the cardholder entering a bit of information, such as a PIN, which unlocks the flow of information to the merchant. **********The next step, being tested in a joint program by Visa and MasterCard, is the use of "secured electronic transactions." A sort of software wallet bundled into Internet browser software on personal computers will allow information to be sent to merchants, who can then send it to cardholders' banks for approval. **********Future models are expected to encode the information on the cards themselves, so that nothing can be gleaned by stealing a cardholder's computer. **********A crucial advantage of secured electronic transactions over other encryption software is that only the banks will be able to read the card information, not the merchants being patronized, Mr. Saunders said. So there will be no need to tear up virtual carbons.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/21/busin.snippet: Advertising column reports on final sessions of 88th annual conference of Assn of National Advertisers; says focus was on daunting challenge posed by getting skeptical shoppers to try the untried--particularly in continuously changing technology m...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/21/busin.main_headline: The challenge of getting shoppers to try the untried is the final focus of an ad conference.
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/21/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; The challenge of getting shoppers to try the untried is the final focus of an ad conference.
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/21/busin.body_text: **********THE daunting challenge posed by getting skeptical shoppers to try the untried -- particularly in the continuously changing technology market -- was the focus of the final sessions of the 88th annual conference of the Association of National Advertisers. **********Attendees at the conference, which ended last night at the Ritz-Carlton Laguna Niguel here, heard impassioned pleas for risk taking and experimentation from marketers in fields ranging from banking and technology to consumer products and telecommunications. **********''Brands will be the short cut'' to woo consumers, said Carl F. Pascarella, president and chief executive of Visa U.S.A. Inc., because ''with a trusted brand, the consumer can cut through the clutter.'' **********''This is going to be more important in the future,'' he added, ''with the growth of new technologies and the explosion of electronic commerce.'' Visa, for instance, is testing so-called smart cards, or cards with computer chips that can store values of money and data, which are intended to supplant cash or checks in retail transactions. **********''Today, your Visa card resides in your wallet,'' Mr. Pascarella said. ''Tomorrow, your Visa card will be your wallet.'' **********As consumer-oriented marketers like Visa become more technologically oriented, technology marketers are becoming more consumer oriented. **********''As our market has broadened we've had to evolve our advertising,'' said Ann Lewnes, worldwide advertising director of the Intel Corporation, to emphasize ''a much more approachable way to talk about technology.'' **********Ms. Lewnes shared a series of television commercials by the Intel agency, the Euro RSCG Dahlin Smith White unit of Havas Advertising, centered on ''bunny people'' -- chip makers in protective suits who in less than a year have become ''pivotal characters,'' she said, symbolizing Intel products like the Pentium II microprocessor. **********A coming commercial shows bunny people dancing to ''Shake Your Groove Thing'' with the Rockettes in Times Square, Ms. Lewnes said, and bean-bag-style dolls based on the bunny people are even being sold on the Intel World Wide Web site. **********The Microsoft Corporation is unlikely any time soon to sell dolls resembling William H. Gates, its chairman and chief executive, particularly to any Federal antitrust enforcers at the Justice Department, which took strong actions against Microsoft yesterday. But Robert J. Herbold, executive vice president and chief operating officer of Microsoft, portrayed the company in his remarks at the conference as struggling as much as any of its competitors to determine how best to peddle its wares. **********''We've done a lot of things that have worked,'' said Mr. Herbold, a former technology and marketing executive at the Procter & Gamble company, ''and some things that haven't.'' **********For instance, Mr. Herbold said, when Microsoft began television advertising aimed at general audiences in 1994, ''it was somewhat disappointing in the beginning'' because the commercials were ''kind of cold and didn't show people using personal computers or the results of using personal computers.'' **********The following year, he added, Microsoft decided it needed ''a brand proposition,'' which would define its software as a product that ''leads the way in providing access to a new world of thinking and communicating.'' The commercials became warmer and more emotional, like a new spot by Wieden & Kennedy, the Microsoft agency, that shows how the truck maker Freightliner uses Microsoft software to custom-build trucks for customers. **********Customization is important, said Scott Bedbury, vice president for marketing at the Starbucks Coffee Company, because all too often ''consumers don't truly believe there's a huge difference between products.'' **********The solution, said Mr. Bedbury, a former worldwide advertising director of Nike Inc., who describes himself as ''a bit of a brand nut,'' is to ''establish emotional ties'' between brands and consumers because ''people's hearts are far more powerful than their brains.'' **********For instance, Mr. Bedbury described how Starbucks coddles ''what we call our early customers, our pre-caffeinated customers,'' who often ''come into our stores in Manhattan at 6:30 before they even shave or shower.'' **********''We have a great product,'' Mr. Bedbury said, ''but we don't stop there. We offer a 'value proposition' based in large part on how it feels when you walk into a store.'' **********To deepen those feelings, Mr. Bedbury said, Starbucks plans a ''major drive'' for the coming holiday season, to seek donations from customers ''to put a book in the hands of a needy child.'' The goal, he added, will be one million books. **********Another marketer agreed with Mr. Bedbury's assessment of the difficulties of tending to newer brands. **********''You have to steward a brand, try to protect it,'' said Tim Kelly, vice president for advertising sponsorship and media of the Sprint Corporation. ''One of the key assets of a long-distance company like ours is to have a national, well perceived brand.'' **********The tumult in the long-distance category -- executive changes at the AT&T Corporation and a takeover battle involving the MCI Communications Corporation -- presents a unique challenge for Sprint. **********''As a marketing person, you've got to stay focused on the business,'' Mr. Kelly said, ''and not allow all that to distract you.'' For example, Sprint is proceeding with a sponsorship of the current Bridges to Babylon tour of the Rolling Stones, for which the company paid an estimated $5 million. **********The conference also featured the presentation of the second annual Casie Awards for effective interactive advertising and marketing. Casie is the Coalition for Advertiser Supported Information and Entertainment, formed by the Association of National Advertisers and the American Association of Advertising Agencies. **********The Betty Crocker Web site of General Mills Inc., was named Best Advertiser Web site for products costing under $100. And the Web site of the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company was named best advertiser Web site for products costing more than $100. The Betty Crocker site was developed by Rare Medium and the Hancock site by Modem Media, part of True North Communications. **********The Station@Sony.com, part of the Sony Web site, won for best interactive campaign. That award was presented to Sony Online Ventures, part of the Sony Corporation, and Kirshenbaum Bond & Partners. **********In a new category, best collaborative effort among advertisers, agencies and Web developers, the award was presented to a promotion of the chess rematch between the I.B.M. Deep Blue computer and Gary Kasparov that featured Warner Brothers cartoon characters and appeared on the Warner Brothers Web site. That award was given to the International Business Machines Corporation, the Ogilvy & Mather Interactive Group unit of WPP Group and the Warner Brothers unit of Time Warner Inc.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/27/world.snippet: Clinton Administration quietly weighs proposals to impose economic sanctions on Mexico's biggest drug traffickers; proposals include freezing suspected traffickers American assets, barring their legitimate commercial ventures from doing business i...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/27/world.main_headline: U.S. IS CONSIDERING CURBS ON MEXICANS TIED TO NARCOTICS
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/27/world.print_headline: U.S. IS CONSIDERING CURBS ON MEXICANS TIED TO NARCOTICS
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/27/world.body_text: **********Searching for a new weapon in the United States' most important drug battle abroad, the Clinton Administration has been quietly debating proposals to impose stringent economic penalties against Mexico's biggest traffickers. **********The measures under consideration include freezing the American assets of suspected drug smugglers and their associates, barring the traffickers' legitimate commercial ventures from doing business in the United States and blocking the traffickers' access to American banks. **********Such sanctions have been imposed in the last 18 months against the most powerful cocaine producers in Colombia and several hundred of their associates. While the effect is only starting to be felt, United States officials have praised the effort as a major new front in the fight against drugs. **********But the Administration has been circumspect about taking similar action against Mexicans, in part because of the extent to which the traffickers have enmeshed themselves in an economy that American officials describe as being of vital strategic importance to the United States. **********There are, the officials said, a growing number of American intelligence reports suggesting that Mexican smugglers have invested some of their booming profits in banks, ports and other enterprises that have been sold off by the Mexican Government in recent years. **********''If you start going after stuff they've privatized, you are going into a minefield,'' an official opposed to the sanctions said. ''You have to weigh how much this would really hurt the traffickers against what it could do to a lot of innocents -- and what it could do to the Mexican economy as a whole.'' **********The continuing debate, as described by officials in Washington involved in the deliberations, has brought the economic and law-enforcement aims of American policies toward Mexico into unusually clear conflict. **********To some officials in the White House, the State Department and the Drug Enforcement Administration, such strong measures could be more effective in Mexico than in Colombia because of the greater importance of the United States for Mexican businesses. **********But Justice Department officials question whether they could defend penalties against the Mexican traffickers in court. And the Treasury Department opposes the idea more strongly, officials said, warning that the sanctions might even undermine investor confidence in the Mexican economy. **********''Mexico is our third-largest trading partner,'' a White House official cautioned. ''Something like this would involve so many businesses, entities and individuals there -- it's just a much more complicated task than with Colombia.'' **********Good for Colombia, But Not for Mexico **********A former senior law-enforcement official who took part in discussions about the sanctions and spoke about them on the condition that he not be identified, explained the Administration's reticence differently. **********''This is one more case of selective application of the rules,'' he said. ''What is fine for Colombia is not O.K. for Mexico.'' **********Other officials gave some weight to both views. As a practical obstacle, they noted that the United States Government had much less specific information about the front companies and legitimate holdings of drug smugglers in Mexico than it did about those of Colombians. **********At the same time, the officials noted that the United States agency responsible for imposing the sanctions, the Treasury Department, had been the most insistent voice within the Government warning that they might pose a danger for legitimate business interests in Mexico. **********President Clinton announced the crackdown on Colombian traffickers with considerable fanfare, in an October 1995 speech marking the 50th anniversary of the United Nations. ''We must not allow them to wash the blood off profits from the sale of drugs,'' he said. **********Since then, the effort has received little public attention in the United States. In Colombia, however, each new development in the program referred to as ''the Clinton list'' and ''the American blockade'' has been front-page news. **********The sanctions were levied under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act, which authorizes penalties in case of an ''unusual and extraordinary threat to national security.'' The same authority was invoked to stop Americans from doing businesses with the Panamanian leadership of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, and to freeze Iranian assets after Americans were taken hostage in Teheran. **********The Practical Results Of Freezing Assets **********The executive order issued for Colombia allows the Government to freeze any assets under United States jurisdiction that belong wholly or in part to four principal figures in the Cali cocaine cartel or to nearly 300 of their relatives and associates who have been named on a list of ''specially designated narcotics traffickers.'' **********Because the traffickers are thought to have few identifiable properties in the United States, the main effect of the program comes from its secondary provisions. Those make it illegal for American citizens and companies to do business with the 126 Colombian companies -- from poultry farms to cosmetics manufacturers -- that have been explicitly linked to the cartel. Violators risk prison terms as long as 10 years and fines of $500,000 for corporations and $250,000 for individuals. **********None of the cases brought against the traffickers have yet been tested in court. But American and Colombian officials pointed to signs that the hundreds of warning letters sent to American companies by the Treasury Department Office of Foreign Assets Control have at least disrupted the traffickers' business empires. **********The sanctions ''have had a profound impact'' on the cartel leaders, the head of the Drug Enforcement Administration, Thomas A. Constantine, told Congress last year, limiting ''their ability to conduct business in both the national and international marketplaces.'' **********Colombian banks, threatened with the loss of access to the United States financial system, have closed some accounts tied to the traffickers and tightened some regulations. The Colombian Attorney General's office and the Colombian equivalent of the Securities and Exchange Commission have opened investigations into some of the businesses cited by the Treasury Department. **********Colombian companies like Drogas La Rebaja, a huge chain of discount drugstores owned by relatives of the jailed cartel leader Miguel Rodriguez Orejuela, have lost both bankers and wholesale suppliers. And though subsidiaries of some American manufacturers have continued to feed the blacklisted companies through intermediaries, the pressure has been sufficient to bring relatives of the traffickers out of the shadows to complain. **********Unbearable Tension In Being a Rodriguez **********''Being a Rodriguez these days is worse than having AIDS,'' Mr. Rodriguez's oldest son, William, told a Colombian newsmagazine last year. **********The executive director of the Colombian-American Chamber of Commerce, Joseph A. Finnin, said in a telephone interview from Bogota that since the sanctions, major Colombian companies, as well as American ones, are being careful about whom they deal with. ''They don't want their names alongside those on the list,'' Mr. Finnin said. **********There is some evidence that the sanctions have essentially become a kind of tax on the traffickers' aboveboard holdings -- an inconvenience rather than a serious threat. **********Greg Passic, a special agent at the Treasury Department's money-laundering intelligence center, the Financial Crimes Enforcement Network, said the threat of sanctions had prompted Cali operatives to get rid of some of their holdings. But he said that with other assets, they had changed their ownership, at least on paper. **********The director of the Treasury's foreign assets office, R. Richard Newcomb, acknowledged as much. ''But those new companies are not mainstream; they are underground,'' he said in an interview. ''It gets more and more raggedy, and as they do that, we will identify the new front companies they set up and put them on the list.'' **********American officials are generally less sanguine in assessing the potential of similar sanctions against major traffickers in Mexico. Mr. Newcomb declined to address the subject at all. Other officials said the problem of intelligence information loomed especially large. **********The actions taken against Colombian traffickers, their associates and their businesses may not have been challenged in court because they have unusually strong evidence backing them up: Law-enforcement officials said the sanctions were largely based on thousands of documents and computer files captured in the long series of raids that landed most of the cartel leaders in prison in the summer of 1995. **********By contrast, officials said, United States law-enforcement and intelligence agencies know far less about the aboveboard holdings of traffickers in Mexico. Much of what the agencies do have, they added, is information that government lawyers would be loath to present in court -- either because it is only partly corroborated or because it could expose the methods used to collect it. **********Scant Data on Mexicans Limit Enforcement **********Miguel Rodriguez and his brother, Gilberto, in particular, also went to great lengths to set up their children and other relatives in legitimate business. Mexican traffickers are often more circumspect about their place in society, hiding their assets in labyrinths of lawyers, front companies and phantom associates. **********The expected nomination of Gov. William F. Weld of Massachusetts, an Assistant Attorney General in charge of the criminal division in the Reagan Administration, as the next Ambassador to Mexico is seen by some analysts as a boost for cooperative investigative operations. **********Nevertheless, ''determining who is inside the circle and who is outside -- through court records, business records and everything else, is a lot tougher in Mexico,'' said a former senior law-enforcement official who has conducted investigations there. ''There are just so many cutouts.'' **********Senior Clinton Administration officials worried recently that even the symbolic refusal to certify Mexico as cooperative in fighting drugs could imperil the Mexican economic recovery, to which President Clinton has committed billions of dollars in credit and considerable political capital. **********Yet some officials predicted that as the Administration focused more closely on the traffickers' growing economic power in Mexico, it would become harder and harder to avoid doing there as it has done in Colombia. **********Mexico's traffickers, they noted, are more dependent on the United States economy and thus potentially more vulnerable. They are more closely tied to the American financial system. They like to keep homes in areas like San Diego and south Texas. **********''There is a lot of evidence out there that these people are extremely wealthy, extremely influential, and enough of a threat to the United States for the President to include them on the list,'' a senior law-enforcement official said. ''It's a natural extension of the policy.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/15/world.main_headline: U.S. Senate Votes to Let Russia Shift Troops
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/15/world.print_headline: U.S. Senate Votes to Let Russia Shift Troops
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/15/world.body_text: **********The Senate unanimously agreed today to amend a 1990 treaty governing conventional forces in Europe to allow Russia to keep more heavy weapons for a longer time around sensitive southern republics like Chechnya. **********The 100-to-0 vote showed the strong bipartisan support for altering the agreement, which has led to the destruction or removal of 53,000 non-nuclear weapons in Europe since the treaty took effect five years ago. Adjusting the agreement suits Moscow's post-cold-war security needs on its northern and southern flanks, and is expected to soothe Russian fears over NATO's planned expansion. **********In a sign of the broad support, Senator Jesse Helms, a North Carolina Republican who heads the Foreign Relations Committee, voted for the pact, the first treaty he has supported since 1992. **********The accord, the Conventional Armed Forces in Europe Treaty, was signed in 1990 by the 22 nations of NATO and the Warsaw Pact, and approved by the Senate in 1991. It places limits on tanks, artillery, armored combat vehicles, attack helicopters and combat aircraft between the Atlantic Ocean and the Urals. **********After the collapse of the Soviet Union and with increasing unrest in the Caucasus, Russia sought changes in the limits assigned to its northern and southern flanks. **********The modified treaty does not change the overall limits on conventional weapons; instead it gives Moscow more flexibility to decide where to put that equipment. It also redraws the boundaries of Russia's northern and southern flanks to reflect the breakup of the Soviet Union, and gives Russia until May 1999 to reduce its forces in those areas. **********Approval was assured only after Senate Democrats and the Administration dropped their opposition to a Republican demand on a separate arms control treaty that raised questions of constitutional prerogatives.  At issue there was the power to decide which countries of the former Soviet Union inherit the Soviet Union's commitments to the Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty of 1972. **********The Administration argued that President Clinton has executive authority to decide that matter, and he did so, designating Russia, Kazakstan, Ukraine and Belarus. But Republican Senators argued that transforming a bilateral treaty into a multilateral treaty required Senate approval. **********Rather than risk damage to the broader treaty on conventional forces, the Administration gave in, but vowed to resume the fight when changes to the missile treaty are submitted to the Senate, perhaps later this year. **********In recent years Republican have stepped up their attacks on the A.B.M. Treaty, arguing that it is an outdated document that constrains the United States' ability to defend against missile attacks and should be abandoned. The Administration considers the treaty a centerpiece of its arms-control policy, but is negotiating with Russia to take account of new short- and medium-range missile defenses the United States wants to deploy.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/04/busin.main_headline: Apple Expects A Big Loss For Quarter
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/04/busin.print_headline: Apple Expects A Big Loss For Quarter
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/04/busin.body_text: **********Apple Computer Inc. said late today that it expected to report a loss of $100 million to $150 million for its most recent quarter, a much sharper loss than analysts had expected. **********Apple cited weakness of demand for its Performa line of consumer-oriented Macintosh computers, and short supply of its Powerbook portable machines. **********The projected loss comes to 80 cents to $1.20 a share. Wall Street  had been expecting a loss of 4 cents a share for the quarter, which ended Dec. 31, according to a survey of analysts by I.B.E.S. International. A year ago, Apple reported a loss of $69 million, or 56 cents a share. **********Apple, which is based in Cupertino, Calif., made its announcement after the stock market closed. Earlier, Apple shares rose 75 cents, to $21.75, in Nasdaq trading. Apple will announce the results for its first fiscal quarter on Jan. 15. **********The loss is the latest sign of trouble for Apple, which is trying to turn itself around after a year of large losses and shrinking market share. And it follows other signs of weakness in consumers' purchases of computers over the holiday season.  On Thursday, CompUSA, a large computer retailer, said that sales for the last three months of the year were far below expectations. **********In the previous quarter, Apple unexpectedly reported a profit of $25 million, partly as a result of an adjustment of restructuring charges, which reduced pretax operating expenses by $28 million. **********Gilbert F. Amelio, Apple's chairman, president and chief executive, has said that the company will not return to sustainable profitability until later this year. **********Tim Bajarin, an analyst with Creative Strategies Inc. in San Jose, Calif., said that the weakness of the Performa line is an indication ''consumers are still concerned about Apple's long-term viability.'' **********''Amelio fixed the holes, but he still has to show Apple has a future.'' **********Apple said that unit sales of its Power Macintosh and Powerbook lines exceeded internal forecasts, but that the weakness in the Performa line and shortages of Powerbooks led to a decline in revenues of 10 percent from the September quarter, for which the company reported revenues of $2.3 billion.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/05/busin.body_text: **********Japan's return to work Tuesday after a weeklong spring vacation may add some zest to the foreign-exchange market, but analysts warn not to count on it. **********The dollar ended last week at 126.595 yen and 1.7295 Deutsche marks, virtually unchanged from the previous week, as a communiqué from the Group of Seven's top finance officials and central bankers was universally derided as saying nothing new. **********U.S. Treasury Secretary Robert Rubin reiterated his support for the G-7 statement on the dollar, saying Sunday that a "strong" U.S. currency had led to lower inflation. **********"What we don't want to have is have currencies get out of synch with fundamentals," Mr. Rubin said. **********But Jim O'Neill of Goldman, Sachs & Co. described the dollar as "boxed in." On the one hand, he said, there is "considerable anxiety that the Bank of Japan will intervene to prevent further weakness of the yen," while on the other, "everyone is on tenterhooks about whether the Federal Reserve will increase U.S. interest rates." **********The Federal Reserve Board's policymakers will meet May 20, and analysts are hedging their earlier bets on a rate increase in view of last week's data showing no significant upward pressure on U.S. prices. **********"There is a chance, but hardly a certainty, that the Fed will follow its quarter-point increase in March with another one this month," said John Llewellyn of Lehman Brothers. But he said there were sound reasons for the Fed to hold back. **********Citing a surge in exports to explain the sharp growth in the final quarter last year and good weather in many areas in the first quarter of this year, Mr. Llewellyn argued that "economies grow above potential rates for extended periods only when there is a strong force pushing it." The possible forces, he said, include an expansionary budget deficit, an aggressively easy monetary policy or strong export growth, "none of which currently apply in the United States." **********Mr. Llewellyn does not rule out the possibility that runaway spending by companies and consumers could give new life to the U.S. boom, but he doubts it. "This U.S. business cycle is different," he said, citing increased world competition that prevents companies from raising prices, frightened workers who are more interested in job security than wage increases and "vastly better" monetary and fiscal policies that are keeping the economy in control. **********In no small part because of the rise in the dollar, which is up 14 percent against the mark and nearly 12 percent against the yen in the past six months, Mr. Llewellyn said, "U.S. growth is set to slow throughout the rest of the year." **********Mr. O'Neill said he expected the dollar to trade cautiously until the Fed meeting. If interest rates are not increased, he expects the dollar to drop below 1.70 DM and to the low 120s against the yen. But if the Fed does raise rates this month, Mr. O'Neill sees the dollar pushing beyond 1.77 DM and 129 yen.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/22/world.snippet: After decades during which Hong Kong provided sanctuary for political and religious refugees from mainland China, its special role as escape route for those fleeing persecution will all but close with withdrawal of British colonial Govt that discr...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/22/world.main_headline: Hong Kong Escape Network Is Driven Into Shadows
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/22/world.print_headline: Hong Kong Escape Network Is Driven Into Shadows
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/22/world.body_text: **********For hundreds of dissidents spirited out of China in a modern-day version of an underground railway, it worked this way: The dissident received a coded message to travel quickly to a fishing pier along China's jagged southern coastline and slip aboard one of the nondescript junks that ply the South China Sea. **********With the dissident hidden below deck, a dark and tense passage across a few dozen miles of rolling swells ensued, as the boat's captain, often a common smuggler, carefully evaded Chinese patrol boats and the pirates who have made the sea lanes near here treacherous. If luck held, the dissident emerged to scramble ashore at a deserted beach an hour's drive from downtown Hong Kong, where British intelligence officers and diplomats provided temporary resident and travel papers -- the equivalent of a passport to freedom. **********Now this escape route, through which nearly 500 dissidents and defectors have passed since the crushing of the Tiananmen Square democracy movement in 1989, is being shut down with the end of British rule on June 30. **********After decades during which Hong Kong provided sanctuary for political and religious refugees from mainland China, its special role as an escape route for those fleeing persecution will all but close with the withdrawal of the colonial government that discreetly tolerated it. **********A small group of determined political activists say they plan to stay on in Hong Kong after China takes over on July 1 in hopes of providing some semblance of the safety net that has rescued so many. **********''We hope a shadow could continue,'' said a senior Western diplomat who has worked with dozens of governments to find homes for political-asylum seekers who have reached the British colony. **********But others fear that Beijing will try to crush the escape route once and for all, if only to stamp out the image of Hong Kong as a ''base of subversion'' against Communist rule on the mainland. **********Publicly, Hong Kong's future leader, Tung Chee-hwa, has shown no sympathy for the fate of political refugees. Anyone who has not entered Hong Kong ''properly and legally,'' he said this month, will ''have to go,'' meaning back to China. **********Robin Munro, director of the Hong Kong office of Human Rights Watch, said, ''We believe there should be some mechanism that allows a valid asylum seeker to leave the territory with the permission of the new Hong Kong government.'' **********He added that ''it could be worked out, if there is a will'' among the foreign governments that will continue to be represented in Hong Kong and if the new Hong Kong government allows it. **********At its peak of activity, in 1989-91, the underground pipeline was known as Operation Yellowbird. But it was really an amalgam of efforts that featured a collaboration of political activists in China and Hong Kong working in alliance with human rights organizations and crime syndicates always willing to smuggle human cargo for profit. **********At the end of the pipeline was always Her Majesty's colonial government working in unspoken complicity with gangsters and spies to provide an escape for those who might otherwise be imprisoned if they remained in China. **********The successes were often spectacular. They frequently bedeviled China's powerful Ministry of State Security, whose hapless agents could never plug all the routes out of the country. **********But there were also betrayals and failures, the most notable of which compromised the escape of two longtime democracy advocates, Chen Ziming and Wang Juntao, in October 1989. Both were captured and sentenced to 13 years in prison. Mr. Wang was allowed to go into exile in the United States in 1995 after the personal intervention of President Clinton and more than 50 senators. Mr. Chen has been living under house arrest in Beijing since receiving a medical parole last fall. **********Some of the most famous student leaders of the Tiananmen movement, like Chai Ling, Li Lu and Wuer Kaixi, escaped through Hong Kong or Macao. But the Yellowbird networks have also assisted scores of other dissidents, labor activists and even Chinese Government officials seeking to defect. **********One of the most recent refugees to pass through the pipeline was Wang Xizhe, a longtime pro-democracy campaigner who fled China last fall after he wrote a public letter criticizing President Jiang Zemin and demanding that the Government enforce freedoms enshrined in the 1982 Constitution. On Oct. 8, he was at his parents' home in Guangzhou in the middle of shaving his invalid father's mustache when his beeper went off and he got word that the co-author of the protest letter, Liu Xiaobo, had been arrested in Beijing. **********''I finished shaving my father's mustache, and then I left,'' Mr. Wang recounted in an interview. ''I told my mother I had something to do.'' He never got word to his wife, whom he left behind. **********''I went to Hong Kong on a smuggler's boat,'' he said by telephone from New York, where he is studying English. ''It was so sad to watch the Chinese coastline disappear.'' **********Once he landed in Hong Kong, British officials quietly issued him travel papers, and the Clinton Administration just as quietly arranged passage for him to the United States. **********Virtually every Western consulate in the territory has confronted the  problem of accepting political refugees from China at the risk of offending Beijing's hypersensitive Communist leaders, who do not like to admit that they imprison their citizens for their political or religious views, or that a significant percentage of Chinese, if given the choice, would emigrate to the West. **********''On the record, it's not something we talk about,'' said Richard Boucher, the United States Consul General here. Over the last year, the British colonial government has stepped up its efforts to clear the final accounts of the 100 or so dissidents who had fled to Hong Kong but had not yet received offers of permanent asylum in other countries. Some countries, fearful of offending Beijing, refused to accept them. France, the United States, Canada and Britain took the bulk. By February, there were 40 left, and in late May more than 20 departed at once. **********A determined remnant of pro-democracy campaigners are left behind. They have vowed to keep helping political refugees escape the mainland, even though the risks will be much greater. **********''Those people have no intention of leaving, and we are very much worried about them,'' said a ranking diplomat, who has worked with a variety of governments to smooth the passage of political refugees out of China. **********Others who are left behind are about 10 mainland dissidents who arrived in Hong Kong and were offered asylum in Western countries, but not the ones of their choice. Last week they called on the international community to come to their rescue. **********Finally, there is always Han Dongfang, the fiery labor activist of the Tiananmen era whom China refuses to allow to come home, but who will achieve his goal on July 1 when Hong Kong will again be part of China. **********In essence, Hong Kong is a colony of refugees from China. The first big wave came in the early 1950's to escape the brutal land reforms imposed by the Communists; the next came during the Great Leap Forward, whose ill-conceived economic schemes touched off a devastating famine. In the 1960's, the chaos and persecution of the Cultural Revolution flushed thousands more across the border. **********''If you look at history, Hong Kong has been a home for people one way or another disaffected from China,'' said John Kamm, an American who has done business in the colony for more than 20 years. ''People have fled political and religious persecution and people have fled famine, and now Hong Kong is being embraced by the very people who caused these refugees to flee.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/13/world.snippet: Overall strategy of ratcheted confrontation with new Government of Laurent Kabila could lead to armed resistance in Congo, formerly Zaire; Joseph Olenghakoy, one of Congo's most outspoken politicians, says his country will not accept dictatorial r...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/13/world.main_headline: In Congo, Many Chafe Under Rule Of Kabila
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/13/world.print_headline: In Congo, Many Chafe Under Rule Of Kabila
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/13/world.body_text: **********Responding to a ban on opposition party politics that was announced along with the creation of this country's new Government in May, one of Congo's most outspoken opposition politicians decided he should move his office. **********But the opposition figure, Joseph Olenghakoy, did not go underground or even adopt a more discreet stance to avoid confrontation with the new Government of Laurent Kabila. Instead, Mr. Olenghakoy, the leader of the Renovating Forces for Union and Solidarity, ordered that his desk be taken out of the quiet back office in his party headquarters and defiantly placed square in the middle of the reception area, where he now sits daily to greet a stream of party members and well-wishers. **********With former Prime Minister Etienne Tshisekedi, the main opposition figure, having been arrested in June and held overnight for making public speeches in defiance of the political ban, Mr. Olenghakoy sees the placement of his desk in full public view as a small symbolic gesture. It is part of an overall strategy of ratcheted confrontation that he and others in Congo, formerly Zaire, are already warning could ultimately lead to armed resistance. **********''Unfortunately, one of the lessons the Congolese people have learned from Kabila's rise to power is that the international community respects violent men,'' said Mr. Olenghakoy, 34. **********Mr. Kabila's forces won power in May from Mobutu Sese Seko, who nearly drove the country into the ground in almost 32 years of dictatorial rule. **********''This country didn't struggle for seven years to get rid of Mobutu to sit back and watch him be replaced by someone who uses the same methods,'' Mr. Olenghakoy added. ''But after having applauded Kabila's army's march across Zaire, the West should not expect us to accept nonviolent opposition indefinitely.'' **********In much of Africa, opposition parties face a choice between peaceful tactics, which have often proven futile in the face of repressive governments, and armed resistance. **********In the new Congo, the choice is even starker. Since sweeping to power on May 17, Mr. Kabila has in effect outlawed organized opposition, saying that his Alliance of Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Congo will rule alone until it organizes national elections -- promised for 1999. **********Complicating matters further, Mr. Kabila's edicts have received only muted criticism from the West, which seems relieved over the end of Mr. Mobutu's long dictatorship, and eager to give the new leader the benefit of the doubt. **********''We haven't tackled that specifically,'' said one Western diplomat, who was asked if protests had been lodged over the ban on political activity here. ''We do attach a lot of importance to the timetable for elections and will try our best to hold them to that.'' **********Mr. Kabila's Government has given almost no public explanations for many of its policies. But opposition leaders say that they have been told  the new leaders feel they should be allowed to work unhindered at getting this country in order again. **********There are growing signs already, however, especially here, that the new restrictions on political freedoms are grating on people's nerves. **********The brief arrest of Mr. Tshisekedi, for example, provoked incidents in several neighborhoods of the city, where opposition activists set fire to cars and trucks and played cat-and-mouse games, taunting the Government soldiers sent into the streets to restore order. **********Responding to protests in the streets carries risks for the Government. Much of Mr. Kabila's army is composed of foreign forces on loan from neighboring countries -- Rwanda, Uganda, Angola and Eritrea -- that supported his revolt. Every appearance of troops in the streets draws people out of their homes to watch and comment, mostly negatively, about what is widely resented here as a foreign occupation. **********Polls indicate that Mr. Kabila has already paid a heavy price for this perception. In one opinion survey by an independent polling agency in June, only 14 percent of those who responded said they admired the new President, while a majority said they regarded him as a ''hostage'' to foreigners. Over 75 percent said they disapproved of the ban on political activity, while 62 percent said they supported Mr. Tshisekedi. **********''There has been a large erosion already in support for this Government, and it seems clear there will be no honeymoon,'' said Olivier Kamitatu, the director of the leading polling agency here, Berci. ''Without a base, and without an army of his own, everything is in place for Kabila to fail. If he doesn't deal with the perception about the Rwandans and arrive at an understanding with the opposition, there is every reason to believe that we will be heading into a new crisis.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/16/world.snippet: Fishing from rocks and cliffs along coast of New South Wales, Australia, remains hazardous pastime, and is perhaps most deadly sport in world; officials say some casualties seem to forget most basic elements of common sense and misjudge tides and ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/16/world.main_headline: Australian Fishermen, Warned of Peril, Remain on the Rocks
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/16/world.print_headline: Australian Fishermen, Warned of Peril, Remain on the Rocks
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/16/world.body_text: **********They have their buckets, lunch packs and bait bags of worms, prawns or bits of mackerel, eel and squid. From Sydney's rocky coastline they ply their long, silvery lines for that magic moment when the bream, whiting, kingfish or anything else from hammerhead to dugong might strike from the pools below. **********It is summer in Australia, time for fishing, and if you don't have a boat, the best places are the rocks and cliffs just above a thundering surf that rolls in across thousands of miles of open Pacific. **********The fishermen come out in wide,  flat-brimmed koala hats or sports caps, sunglasses, shorts and loose, comfortable shirts to relax and think in the long hours between bites. **********But police and surf rescue teams see a flip side -- that fishing from the rocks around Sydney is perhaps the most deadly sport in the world. **********Most of the casualties have misjudged the tides and the power of the waves. A rogue wave hits and dumps them into the churning sea. They are either dashed against rocks or swept out by currents too strong to fight. **********''It's amazing how you can get carried away by fishing and just forget about the basic elements of common sense,'' said Scott Abbott, a senior constable in the Sydney Water Police. ''You've got to check out the tides, the weather conditions, wear the right shoes -- essential ingredients like that.'' **********He said there had been 14 deaths along the New South Wales coast last year, compared with 9 the year before. Most were near Sydney. **********Jeff Williams is a senior lifeguard at Cronulla, one of the south Sydney beaches. ''The worst thing in the world is to stand above with relatives and have a body in the ocean that you can't find,'' he said. **********Compounding rescue difficulties is the urge of fishermen to fish from the most isolated and inaccessible spots. Several days ago, Mr. Williams recalled, a man let himself down on a ledge along a cliff and was unable to get back up. **********From the land he could not be seen, and his cries for help could not be heard. Mr. Williams happened to be passing by in his launch and spotted him. He navigated the launch toward the rocks and had the man jump into the water and swim hard away from the rocks and toward the boat for a successful rescue. **********Police officers and water safety instructors now urge those who fish from the rocks to wear life jackets and shoes with rock-gripping cleats. **********Tom Foulati, 59, a forklift truck driver, was wearing sandals and shorts as he scrambled with his pole and bag of bait over rocks above Cougee beach in south Sydney. **********''I've been fishing for years and know exactly what I'm doing,'' he said. ''I go any place and wear what I want.'' **********The police fence off dangerous places and post warning signs. But as Mr. Abbott, the senior constable, put it, ''There's no way you can put a railing along the whole New South Wales coast, and people would jump over it anyway.'' **********Some local councils are installing emergency telephones so rescue services can be called immediately in case of accidents. **********One of last year's casualties, Soo Hwan Hwang, 33, was the victim of a rogue wave. Another fisherman saw him casting from the rocks at the Royal National Park near Sydney. Ten days later his body was found. **********His widow, Sun Hee Hwang, said in an interview that her husband, a journalist who had reported on Australia for a South Korean weekly, had not known how to swim. She had warned him many times against fishing from the rocks. **********''If I'd known where he was headed,'' she said, ''I would never have let him go.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/21/busin.main_headline: Germany's Tax Plan Seems to Target Everyone
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/21/busin.print_headline: Germany's Tax Plan Seems to Target Everyone
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/21/busin.body_text: **********Just about everyone in the country stands to lose from the comprehensive revision of Germany's bewildering and burdensome tax system being finished this week by a government commission. **********By eliminating an array of write-offs, subsidies and breaks to try to offset lower tax rates, analysts say the plan will offer nearly as much pain as gain, although details will not come out until the panel led by Finance Minister Theo Waigel finishes its work Wednesday. **********The governing coalition is selling the tax plan as a way to reduce unemployment, create jobs and save Germany's taxpayers tens of billions of Deutsche marks. Mr. Waigel has warned that there can be "no taboos" when it comes to eliminating tax breaks. **********"There will be tough discussions and hard decisions," he said. **********There also will be political trench warfare, as the proposals will unleash armies of lobbyists intent on defending tax advantages, raising the prospect that many proposed changes will be weakened. **********Chancellor Helmut Kohl, who is expected to use the new tax plan as the centerpiece of his 1998 re-election campaign, needs the legislation to be finished this year and to take effect in January 1999. **********"It will be extremely difficult to close the loopholes," said Gernot Nerb, senior economist for Salomon Brothers Inc. in Frankfurt. **********Mr. Waigel came under pressure for watering down details of the plan even before it had been completed. Leaders of the top party in the governing coalition, fearing that Mr. Waigel would not deliver meaningful tax relief for the hard-earned marks of their constituents, called over the weekend for his resignation. **********"Our chief task must be to fight unemployment," said Christian Wulff, the Christian Democratic leader in Lower Saxony who has led the call for Mr. Waigel to leave, "and for that we need tax cuts so that our European competitors do not steal business from us." **********Grumbling about taxes has been a national pastime since unification in 1990 pulled rates painfully higher. The top bracket stands at 53 percent of gross salary for anyone earning more than 120,000 Deutsche marks ($74,830) a year. The top rate in Britain is 40 percent, and in the United States it is 33 percent. **********Mr. Waigel's panel aims to reduce the top rate to 39 percent. At the bottom end of the scale, the government aims to move the lowest bracket to no more than 20 percent from its current 25.9 percent. **********But, like the debate on monetary union, tax revision runs the risk of focusing on the disadvantages while overshadowing a raft of economic benefits, said Gerhard Grebe, an economist at Bank Julius Baer in Frankfurt. **********Prospects for consensus are not promising. The government began the year bickering over the unpopular "solidarity" surcharge, a 7.5 percent levy on income tax intended to pay for the reconstruction of Eastern Germany. **********The Free Democrats, the junior coalition partners, insist that the surcharge be eliminated by 2000 and have threatened to topple the government to get their way. The Christian Democrats insist the surcharge be kept into the next century and are standing firm. **********Prime ministers of East German states, which have the most to lose from scrapping the solidarity tax, are pushing to keep it for 10 to 15 years. Most now expect it to linger until 2004 or 2005. In any event, the realization is dawning that the 16 authorities on Mr. Waigel's commission are powerless to take action on the surcharge, the most disliked tax of all. **********Opposition already is out in the open on proposals to raise taxes on government retirement checks for pensioners with additional sources of income. **********If the government tries to close tax breaks on unemployment checks, unions are expected to resist. Unions will act against higher taxes on overtime wages for Sunday and night work, if proposed, bankers can be expected to try to fend off any tax on gains from stock-market profits, and insurers will fight to defend tax breaks on life-insurance policies.
