After pushing up short-term rates by a qu...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/03/busin.main_headline: Wall Street Applauds As Policymakers Find No Inflation Danger : Fed Leaves U.S. Rates Unchanged
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/03/busin.print_headline: Wall Street Applauds As Policymakers Find No Inflation Danger : Fed Leaves U.S. Rates Unchanged
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/03/busin.body_text: **********U.S. central bankers decided to leave interest rates unchanged at their two-day policy meeting that ended Wednesday, after the economy showed few signs of inflation despite strong growth in recent months. **********After pushing up short-term rates by a quarter of a percentage point in March, the Federal Reserve Board's Open Market Committee has opted at its last two meetings to maintain its target for overnight interbank loans, which set a floor for U.S. rates, at 5.50 percent. **********Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, had been warning investors since late in 1996 that the central bank was concerned about rising stock and bond prices, which he said might reflect "irrational exuberance" about the markets' prospects. But although the economy grew at a strong 5.9 percent annual rate in the first quarter of the year, there have been few signs of inflation. **********It is widely believed that economic growth slowed to a rate of about 2 percent in the second quarter, but with unemployment below 5 percent for the first time in two decades, there have been questions as to whether a lack of workers would require wage increases that would kindle significant inflation. **********Stock and bond prices rose after the Fed meeting ended. The Dow Jones industrial average finished just shy of a record, up 73.05 points, at 7,795.38. The broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 13.00 points, to a record 904.03. The Nasdaq composite index, which largely reflects technology stocks, also set a record, rising 17.38 points, to 1,455.63. The yield on the benchmark 30-year bond fell to 6.71 percent from 6.74 percent on Tuesday. **********In recent weeks, the view on Wall Street has been that although the Fed might raise rates later this year, it was unlikely to do so at this meeting. That position gained credence Tuesday when the National Association of Purchasing Management issued its June report, which showed the manufacturing sector expanding but at a reduced pace from May. The government, separately, said construction spending slowed in May. **********Further evidence of moderating growth came Wednesday, when the government said factory orders fell 0.7 percent in May from April. **********Ed Yardeni and Debbie Johnson of Deutsche Morgan Grenfell Inc. said that although overall factory orders fell in May, buying of high-technology goods rose 15 percent. Mr. Yardeni is among a school of economists who say that the widespread use of computers by American industry allows the economy to grow faster than the 2.5 percent annual rate that had been perceived as the maximum that would not lead to inflation. **********These so-called New Age economists say that technological advances have made traditional methods of calculating growth and inflation unreliable. **********One economist who maintains that the economy is growing far faster than the official data show is Leonard Nakamura of the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia. Mr. Nakamura figures that the economy grew at about a 4.5 percent annual rate from 1978 to 1995, compared with official measures of about 2.5 percent. In the past five years, he said, the rate accelerated to 5.0 percent, compared with about 2.6 percent in the government figures. **********If the official data are correct, Mr. Nakamura said, then all the gains in productivity since the late 1970s would have come from workers having more machinery and working increased hours. That means that none of the recorded productivity gains came from technological advances, a situation that seems absurd to anybody who remembers living in a world without fax machines. **********Mr. Nakamura said 1978 was a watershed year. He found that the traditional measures became ineffective because of changes that became apparent around that time. Among these, he said, were the beginning of deregulation and changes in retailing that led to mismeasurements of consumer prices. **********An example of both these effects, he said, was in commercial airline fares. Before the aviation industry was deregulated, most routes had only one round-trip coach fare and most travelers paid it. Since then, he said, the full coach fare has risen at an annual rate of about 9 percent, but discount fares have risen at only about a 2 percent rate. The consumer price index tracks only the full fares, but Mr. Nakamura said that now only about 7 percent of miles flown are at the full rates, so the cost of an average flight is far lower than the inflation data suggest. **********Other changes that began to occur in the late 1970s, he said, were that personal computers "began entering the business community in substantial numbers" along with price scanners in retail stores and the subsequent use of electronic pricing information by retailers. This allowed for a wide variety of prices to be charged, but government price reporters were not equipped to react to the changed environment. **********Mr. Nakamura said his data on stocks were not precise, but technological advances were providing added benefits to the value of corporations beyond the increased sales and profits generated by strong economic growth. Computers, for example, make mundane corporate assets such as archived documents more valuable, he said. **********Another benefit of computers, Mr. Nakamura said, is that as their ease of use rises and they appear on more desktops, workers whose work had been relatively low level are able to accomplish more complex tasks. **********This technological enhancement of corporate assets is one reason U.S. stock prices have scored double-digit percentage advances for each of the last three years, he said, far outpacing even his torrid estimate of economic growth.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/14/busin.snippet: Commerce Department estimates shoppers spent three-tenths of 1 percent less in April than in March; says retail sales--unadjusted for inflation--were 4.9 percent higher than in April 1996, reaching estimated $212.2 billion; graph (L)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/14/busin.body_text: **********The nation's consumers, after spending at a surprisingly strong pace during the first months of the year, have sharply cut back on shopping, with April posting the first monthly decline in retail sales since the start of the Christmas holiday season. **********The Commerce Department estimated today that shoppers spent three-tenths of 1 percent less last month than in March as automotive sales and nearly all other major categories weakened. Moreover, a small March rise vanished through revision. **********The latest sales figures, which were expected to provide a clue to whether the Federal Reserve would raise interest rates again next Tuesday, were widely seen as confirming that the economy had begun to decelerate from first-quarter growth that was the fastest so far of the 1990's -- a 5.6 percent annual pace. **********But in light of several distorting factors this year -- unusual winter weather, income tax season, an early Easter and New York's moratorium on sales taxes -- analysts said they could not clearly distinguish between a new, sustainable trend in retail sales and what might turn out to be simply a breather followed by renewed strong growth. And that left many of them saying that the Fed was still likely to raise interest rates, probably next week but certainly within the next few months, unless clearer signs of a slowdown emerge. **********''You can't tell how much is seasonal impact and how much is a genuinely slower pace of demand,'' said Kathleen Camilli, chief economist at Tucker Anthony in New York. **********Howard Keen Jr., an economist for Conrail, was similarly skeptical. ''It's quite premature to be calling this any kind of a significant downshifting,'' he said. **********Although various other data, including two gauges of inflation, are to be published before the Fed's policy meeting on Tuesday, today's tally of retail sales is probably the last critical figure the Fed will have before the meeting. Retail sales not only account for one-third of economic activity but are one of the most up-to-date indicators available to monetary officials. **********Today's soft sales results were in line with expectations and prompted no clear reaction on Wall Street. Interest rates initially edged lower, helping power the Dow Jones industrial average above 7,300 for the first time, but after a report from the Atlanta Federal Reserve Bank indicated that manufacturing activity in the South had picked up speed, both markets reversed course and ended with losses. **********While analysts generally regarded the sales report as one straw in the wind against Fed action, the dominant view seemed to be that the Fed would probably still raise rates, given an unemployment rate below 5 percent and industry running at a robust pace that is using more than 84 percent of capacity. **********''It gives them a little more opportunity not to tighten next week but it would take a lot more weakness than we've seen so far to forestall it,'' said Chris Varvares, president of Macroeconomic Advisers in St. Louis. **********Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, warned last week of a need for higher rates unless the economy slowed, but it was unclear whether he was expecting immediate confirmation of a slowdown or was prepared to wait for more solid evidence of the longer-term trend. **********William C. Dudley, a senior economist at Goldman, Sachs, dismissed the notion that today's figures represented a significant slowdown in consumer spending. Rather, he contended that the weak sales were merely the ''flip side'' of early-year strength that owed much to such temporary factors as mild shopping weather and income tax refunds that were bigger than in the past and were received earlier than usual. **********Still, Mr. Dudley added, ''this does give Chairman Greenspan one more arrow in his quiver to argue for waiting'' when the Fed deliberates next week. **********James McCormick, an economist at Morgan Guaranty Trust, expressed a common view when he said the Fed faced ''a close call'' but one that ''slightly favors'' a quarter-point rate increase. **********''Supports for consumer spending are still in place,'' he noted, ''including a strong labor market, rising real incomes and increased wealth from financial markets.'' **********The decline in April retail sales, which was the first since November and the biggest since June, included a drop of five-tenths of 1 percent for durable goods. That mainly resulted from automotive sales, which fell nine-tenths of 1 percent. Merchants selling furniture and other home equipment reported receipts were three-tenths of 1 percent below the previous month, while sales were unchanged for those selling building materials, hardware, garden supplies and mobile homes. **********Among nondurables, the biggest drop was a fall of nine-tenths of 1 percent at department stores and other general merchandisers. Other declines were six-tenths of 1 percent in apparel; five-tenths of 1 percent in food, and one-tenth of 1 percent for gasoline stations (where prices fell) and for drugstores. **********The only sales increase -- five-tenths of 1 percent -- was at restaurants and bars. **********In all, retail sales -- unadjusted for inflation -- were 4.9 percent higher than in April 1996, reaching an estimated $212.2 billion.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/30/world.snippet: Israel and Palestinians will resume new peace talks on October 6; announcement follows meeting with US Sec of State Madeleine K Albright in New York (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/30/world.main_headline: Israel and Palestinians to Meet Next Week in New Talks
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/30/world.print_headline: Israel and Palestinians to Meet Next Week in New Talks
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/30/world.body_text: **********After meeting with Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright, Israel and the Palestinians agreed yesterday to resume committee talks that broke down more than six months ago, a modest step that Administration officials said left difficult issues of security and Jewish settlements unresolved. **********The two sides agreed to meet Oct. 6 to discuss issues like safe passage between Gaza and the West Bank and the establishment of an airport and seaport for the Palestinians. But despite efforts by the United States, they failed to agree on how to proceed with more substantive talks, deciding only to meet in Washington on Oct. 13 to discuss an agenda for those negotiations. **********''We have arrested the downward spiral, and we have taken a step forward,'' bringing the Israelis and Palestinians back to the peace effort, Ms. Albright said yesterday. Talks ended in March after Israel resumed building housing for Jews in East Jerusalem. **********She spoke at a news conference at the Waldorf-Astoria in Manhattan, where yesterday's meetings took place. The announcement came a day after Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu welcomed what he called ''preliminary steps'' by the Palestinian Authority to crack down on Islamic militants. Yesterday Palestinians arrested more Islamic militants, including a leader of Hamas. **********Ms. Albright applauded what she called ''some encouraging steps taken in the last several days.'' The State Department's spokesman, James P. Rubin, added that the crackdown was a sign that the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, understands American and Israeli demands for a total commitment to security. **********The Israeli Foreign Minister, David Levy, called yesterday's meeting ''a renewal of the peace process.'' But the Israelis and Palestinians have different priorities for the talks, and deep divisions remain over how to proceed with the most intractable issues that are supposed to be resolved in accelerated ''final status''  talks. **********In talks leading up to yesterday's meeting, the Palestinians had pressed for a written commitment by Israel to respect the ''time out'' in the construction or expansion of settlements that Ms. Albright called for on her trip. Last week, Mr. Netanyahu announced that Israel would build 300 new homes in a settlement on the West Bank, prompting a rebuke from Ms. Albright. **********Instead, the Israelis and Palestinians could agree only to take up the ''definition and content'' of a halt in expanding settlements and other ''unilateral steps'' when they meet. **********Mr. Abbas, who, like Mr. Levy, refused to answer questions, said the Palestinian Authority was ''determined to go forward and not backward'' in the peace effort. But he suggested that Israel had to be prepared to make concessions. **********''The resumption of negotiations will not be viewed as an objective and an end by itself,'' he said. ''Negotiations are a vehicle to achieve substantial results in all aspects so our efforts will not be to no avail.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/09/world.snippet: Interview with new UN Sec Gen Kofi Annan, who has come under criticism for slow and cautious efforts at reform; photo (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/09/world.main_headline: Despite Critics, New U.N. Chief Keeps His Style
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/09/world.print_headline: Despite Critics, New U.N. Chief Keeps His Style
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/09/world.body_text: **********Kofi Annan captivated Capitol Hill. He dazzled financiers and political leaders at Davos. **********The United Nations' new Secretary General impresses nearly everyone he meets as ever so nice, but now they are discovering that he is also ever so cautious. And although  Washington and other capitals are reluctant to pass judgment so early on the man the Clinton Administration promoted as the organization's savior, some of his first moves -- or lack thereof -- have disappointed. **********By Mr. Annan's own admission, the job he assumed last month makes him ''the man in the middle,'' the chief administrative officer -- with very limited authority -- over only part of an unwieldy, decentralized, global system that takes orders from the 185 countries of the world that make up its membership. **********''I'm trying to move the organization to go through with reform at a time when lots of people think that the United States is imposing reform and that the member states are not ready,'' he said in an interview on Friday in his office overlooking the East River. ''You can come with the best blueprint, but if you impose reform, you're never going to go anywhere.'' **********Asked whether he had an impossible job before him, he replied, ''A friend of mine described it as a job from hell.'' **********A career international civil servant from Ghana who is said to have never raised his voice with colleagues, Mr. Annan, 58, whose name is pronounced to rhyme with cannon, has survived and thrived in the labyrinthian United Nations bureaucracy for more than three decades because he prefers quiet, slow-moving consensus-building to dramatic, bold action. **********But it is precisely that quality that may make it hard for him to press the United Nations to change -- the only way the United States will pay more than $1 billion in back dues. **********In its 1998 budget proposal released on Thursday, the Administration proposed spending $100 million next year and $912 million in 1999 to pay its debt. However, the payments are contingent on a level of reform that the Administration and the Congress have yet to define. **********''It's not ideal, but given the history and circumstances it's probably the best we could get,'' Mr. Annan said, acknowledging that he has no choice but to accept the proposal even though the payments are not at all certain and even though the United Nations says the United States owes $300 million more. **********Mr. Annan disagrees that his studied, low-key style is a liability. ''There seems to be a sense out there that unless you are confrontational and get into contentious situations you are not tough, you are not a leader, you are not free,'' he said. ''I've never shared that view in my life and I'm not going to change now. I often tell my colleagues you can even win without fighting so why do I have to go and pick unnecessary fights.'' **********Much to the dismay of the United States and some of the other big donors, Mr. Annan has announced that he will not have a comprehensive reform plan ready until late July at the earliest, after the entire United Nations membership has had an opportunity to weigh in. **********''A good leader must also be a good follower,'' he said of his decision to wait until all the other countries have their say. **********But the delay misses the opportunity to capitalize on the extraordinary goodwill surrounding Mr. Annan in succeeding Boutros Boutros-Ghali, the Egyptian whose ouster was spearheaded by the United States. **********It also gives conservative Republicans in Congress time to preempt Mr. Annan with their own legislation. **********''I was a little surprised,'' said Princeton Lyman, the Assistant Secretary of State for International Organizations, of Mr. Annan's decision to take so much time. ''There are a number of steps we have all been waiting for, and frankly, we hope he takes them before July.'' **********One change the United States and the world's six other largest industrial countries say they want is the merging of the United Nations' three economic departments under a single head, a proposal they formally presented last year. **********Even the departments' titles suggest duplication: the Department for Policy Coordination and Sustainable Development, the Department for Economic and Social Information and Policy Analysis, and the Department for Development Support and Management Services. **********But when Edward W. Gnehm Jr., the acting chief American representative, and Ambassador Alain Dejamet of France met with Mr. Annan on Tuesday to press him for a decision on behalf of the group, he said he was not ready to make a decision, according to diplomats familiar with the meeting. **********In fact, they said, he changed the subject. And when the two envoys tried again, Mr. Annan refused to be pinned down. **********''This is an idea that has been around for a long time,'' said one diplomat. ''Even the Chinese seem to be in favor. It's all, well, a bit disappointing.'' **********Mr. Annan's reappointment of most of the senior bureaucracy at the United Nations -- many on contracts of three to five years -- instead of cleaning house has also dismayed the United States, some of the other members and even some officials inside the bureaucracy. He has even given plum assignments to several senior officials who openly lobbied against him for Mr. Boutros-Ghali. **********''Uninspired,'' is how one senior Administration official described the appointments. **********To that charge, Mr. Annan replied that the right time to make personnel changes is not in the midst of a far-reaching reform process. ''Change is a process; it's not an event,'' he said. **********Still, the way Mr. Annan has decided to organize his reform team is already causing confusion about who will do what. **********Mr. Annan appointed Maurice Strong, a former businessman from Canada who has undertaken a number of United Nations missions, to a newly created post of ''executive coordinator for reform'' at a symbolic salary of $1 a year. But Mr. Strong reports directly to Mr. Annan, not to Joseph E. Connor, the American Under Secretary General in charge of the United Nations' administration and management. **********The two men are said to have a correct relationship at best. **********The Administration has expressed concern that Mr. Strong may usurp or duplicate some of the functions now performed by Mr. Connor, a former chairman and chief executive of Price Waterhouse, whom the Administration hand-picked to lead the reform effort three years ago. **********In addition, Mr. Strong openly campaigned for a second term for Mr. Boutros-Ghali, predicting that efforts by Madeleine K. Albright, then the chief American representative, to oust him would fail. **********When Ms. Albright met with Mr. Annan before she left for Washington as Secretary of State, she had a two-word reaction to Mr. Strong's appointment, according to American officials: ''Why Strong?'' **********Mr. Annan explained that Mr. Connor would continue to deal with making the United Nations more efficient, but that he needed Mr. Strong to reach out to the countries that belong to the United Nations and craft a plan reflecting their larger vision for change. **********''Reform is a full-time activity,'' Mr. Annan said in defending Mr. Strong's appointment. ''It is not something I can tag on to Mr. Connor's functions.'' **********Meanwhile, there is still a third reform apparatus: a handful of committees made up of all the countries in the United Nations, headed by Ismael Rezali of Malaysia, the president of the General Assembly, many with their own specific ideas of what does and does not need to be changed. **********As part of his conciliatory style and his determination to reach out to the United States Congress, Mr. Annan has invited a team from the staffs of several lawmakers, including that of Senator Jesse Helms,  chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee and an outspoken critic of the United Nations, to discuss reform at the organization next week. **********Mark Thiessen, Mr. Helms's spokesman, said the purpose of the meeting is to give Mr. Annan ''some input'' into the specific targets for the United Nations that Mr. Helms will include in legislation he intends to introduce before any taxpayers' money is spent on back dues. **********Mr. Annan said he is ''uncomfortable'' with specific targets dictated by Washington, but his gesture to consult closely with Congress at all has sparked criticism from other delegations that he is America's man at the United Nations. **********''I am a free man,'' he insisted. **********He is a realist as well. **********''Without Congress the payment cannot be made,'' he said. ''To those who say, 'Aren't you setting a bad example and are you going to do the same for all the other 184 Parliaments in the world?' my answer is, 'I will devote the same attention to any country that pays 25 percent of the dues and owes $1.3 billion.' ''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/28/busin.print_headline: Seoul Markets Fall After No Quick Fix
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/28/busin.body_text: **********The South Korean won slid to a record low against the dollar and stocks fell to their lowest level in five years Monday after the government tried but failed to soothe investors spooked by the turmoil sweeping Asian financial markets. **********The latest drop in South Korean and other Asian financial markets underscored the lack of any quick fixes for the region, analysts said. More important, they said, it highlighted the need for long-term policies — probably using taxpayer money — to pull the region's financial institutions back from the brink of collapse. **********"All the governments in the region can do is to address the problems in a way that builds their credibility," Miron Mushkat, chief economist for Lehman Brothers in Asia, said in Hong Kong. "And they must do it and in a manner that is transparent, minimizes ambiguity and is consistent with the problems at hand." **********After the won and stocks plummeted last week, the government scheduled a special meeting of economic advisers for Monday and hinted at emergency measures to stabilize shaky financial markets. **********Indeed, the local media reported over the weekend that Seoul might lend money to local brokerages to support share prices, which have fallen by nearly one-third since the beginning of the year. **********But the meeting disappointed investors, as President Kim Young Sam made only vague pledges to hasten the introduction of previously announced measures to support financial markets. **********"Various steps have been taken to stabilize the market," Mr. Kim told his ministers at the meeting. "But I hope the prime minister will work on the minute details and ensure they are implemented without any setbacks." **********Mr. Kim was referring to the announcement by the government this month that it would let foreigners own larger stakes in listed companies. **********At the meeting, Mr. Kim also urged Kang Kyong Shik, the deputy prime minister and minister of economy and finance, to "come up with measures so that the financial market can quickly recover." **********Following the meeting, the Seoul bourse gave up early gains of more than 1 percent as investors dumped South Korean stocks. The Korea composite index finished down 18 points, or 3.28 percent, at 530.47, its lowest close since September 1992. For every stock that rose, six fell. **********The dollar rose to a record high of 939.50 won from 929.30 on Friday. **********In the first 25 days of October, foreigners investors, who account for about 6 percent of daily trading, sold $635 million more stock in South Korean companies than they bought, according to the exchange. **********Chipmakers and oil refiners led the market lower Monday. **********The electronics subindex fell 6.1 percent, to 325.1 points, after news reports said the price of the benchmark 16-megabit memory chip had fallen below $5. Analysts said the decline would make it almost impossible for the South Korean companies that dominate the memory-chip market to make money. **********Shares in Samsung Electronics Co. fell 7.9 percent at 48,000 won ($51.65). Shares in LG Semicon Co. fell 7.7 percent, to 20,300 won. **********Among oil refiners, Yukong Ltd.'s shares fall most sharply, ending down 7.4 percent at 13,700 won. Like other refiners, the company was hit hard by the won's fall against the dollar. **********LG Research Institute estimates that a 1 percent drop in the won against the dollar reduces the profit-to-sales ratio at South Korean refineries by 2.5 percent. **********Stocks of companies in the bankrupt Kia Group plunged after prosecutors said they might investigate Kim Sun Hong, Kia's chairman, following allegations of embezzlement. **********Shares in Kia Motors Corp., Kia's flagship company and South Korea's third-largest carmaker, tumbled 7.9 percent, to 8,630 won. **********But Ssangyong Paper Co. stock rose 7.8 percent, to 26,300 won, after the announcement that the company would be taken over. Procter & Gamble Co. said it would buy a 25 percent controlling stake in the paper maker for $69 million. The U.S. company said it would bring its stake to 51 percent by the end of the year, to increase its share in South Korea's rapidly growing markets for toilet paper and other sanitary products. **********Analysts have warned that a failure to address the weakness of financial markets with skill, speed and determination could slow economic development across Asia significantly. **********"There are not necessarily any short-term solutions," Mr. Mushkat said. The process of recovery, he added, "could be protracted and involve what one might call creative destruction" to build more efficient financial systems on which to base future economic development.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/20/busin.snippet: Pressure is growing to curb agreements to arbitrate dismissals and other work disputes that increasing number of workers are required to sign; California court recently found one such agreement unfair; employers are turning to mandatory arbitratio...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/20/busin.main_headline: Opposition Builds to Mandatory Arbitration at Work
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/20/busin.print_headline: Opposition Builds to Mandatory Arbitration at Work
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/20/busin.body_text: **********WHEN the Parc Fifty-Five Hotel in San Francisco dismissed Georgina Cheng-Canindin from the benefits department in 1994, she said she had been  wrongly accused of disclosing confidential salary information to other employees. That made her angry enough. But when she heard that managers had told other employees that she was let go for being a problem employee, she wanted to sue. **********''It was not true,'' she said, calling the second accusation insult to injury. But the company said she had no right to sue. In her employee handbook was a requirement that she agree to arbitrate disputes related to her job. The committee that was to resolve any complaint in arbitration would include two hotel managers and two hotel employees picked by the executives who had dismissed her. Moreover, the company's personnel department would determine who could testify on her behalf. If the committee deadlocked, one of the executives who had dismissed her would break the tie. **********But Ms. Cheng-Canindin may have her day in court after all. The California Court of Appeals ruled recently that the hotel's arbitration process was so unfair that it was not binding and that she could sue. A hotel spokesman referred queries on the issue to a lawyer, who said he could not comment while the case was pending. **********The court decision, and others like it, may prove important to an ever-increasing number of American workers who have been required to sign arbitration agreements to win or keep their jobs. Within the last year or so, these agreements appear to have raised more and more questions about fairness, bringing something of a backlash that might well result in curbs. **********Arbitration is a dispute resolution process involving a hearing outside of court. The  arbitrators, who are supposed to be neutral, hear a complaint and determine a resolution, which is final and binding. **********''About a year ago we knew of a couple of dozen companies with mandatory arbitration,'' said Richard Naimark, corporate senior vice president of the American Arbitration Association, a trade group for the arbitrators who hear these cases. ''Now we know of 300.'' The association says it confers with 12 to 15 companies a month that are beginning to use arbitration. **********Arbitration agreements rose in popularity after Congress acted in 1991 to reinforce protections under Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964. Title VII, which allowed employees to sue and collect punitive damages, was aimed primarily at discrimination because of an individual's race, age, sex, religion or national origin. But employers say that employees have used Title VII too broadly, leading to more and more lawsuits and making it difficult for companies to dismiss employees without legal repercussions. ''Anyone can say, 'I am in a protected group,' '' said John W. Robinson 4th, a labor lawyer in Tampa, Fla., who often represents employers. ''A white male can claim reverse discrimination -- not that it is an easy case to make.'' **********Arbitration was seen as a low-cost way to settle disputes. Businesses said they needed to make arbitration mandatory because employees tended to choose jury trials despite the cost to both parties. ''It can commonly take two years to get to trial, and that is very expensive,'' Mr. Robinson said. ''Your bill can easily reach $100,000.'' **********The Supreme Court has upheld the legality of brokerage houses' requirements that new employees agree to have all claims heard by arbitration panels. Yet more and more courts are saying that workers cannot sign away their rights to sue in areas of discrimination. These new decisions may send the issue back to the Supreme Court. **********The National Association of Security Dealers is reconsidering its requirement that industry employees like stockbrokers and traders agree to mandatory arbitration in harassment and discrimination cases. And proposals in Congress that would outlaw mandatory arbitration are gaining momentum. ''We have 42 co-signers,'' said a spokeswoman for Representative Edward J. Markey, the Massachusetts Democrat who sponsored one version of the bill, which previously had no more than 10 co-signers. A similar bill sponsored by Senator Russell D. Feingold, Democrat from Wisconsin, has three co-signers; in previous sessions of Congress, it had none. **********Arbitrators are neither licensed nor regulated. Although trade groups try to impose standards, no particular training is required and companies can choose anyone for the job. Arbitrators are often selected from the ranks of trade associations or companies that have arbitrators for hire. In recent months, the two biggest arbitration associations -- the American Arbitration Association and the National Academy of Arbitrators -- and the biggest dispute-resolution company have said they do not want their members to hear cases in which the odds are stacked. **********''Many employers have adopted arbitration plans,'' said George Nicolau, recent past president of the National Academy of Arbitrators. ''Many are mandatory, and many are quite unfair.'' **********John P. Unroe, president of the nation's biggest dispute-resolution company, Judicial Arbitration and Mediation Services/ EnDispute, based in Irvine, Calif., agreed. ''If an arbitration isn't fair,'' he said, ''not only does the case suffer, the arbitration movement suffers.'' **********The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission enforces Title VII but recently issued a policy statement opposing mandatory arbitration. ''Our view is that 'mandatory' is the problem,'' said Ellen J. Vargyas, a lawyer for the commission. ''We support voluntary forms of dispute resolution, including arbitration.'' **********Judges generally like arbitration because it helps keep dockets clear, although some  think it emphasizes speed over justice. ''Judges come to feel that the expeditious disposition of a case is more important than the quality of the adjudications,'' said Anthony J. Kline, presiding justice of the California Court of Appeals. **********Most experts view fair arbitration as an excellent way to settle disputes. But its effectiveness wanes when employers set rules that obviously favor them. And no matter how lopsided the rules, most people are forced to arbitrate. The main reason is the 1991 Supreme Court decision upholding the brokerage houses' requirement, Gilmer v. Interstate/Johnson Lane Corporation. Before this ruling, Title VII stipulations had been interpreted to mean that a person could not waive the right to sue. **********CONSIDER the case of Michele Peacock, who tried to sue the Great Western Mortgage Corporation for sexual harassment, contending, among other things, that at a trade show in Atlantic City an executive had suggested they share a bed so he could ''get to know you better.'' But because of an arbitration requirement in the employee handbook, she could not sue. Under the rules of the company, she could not seek damages or fees, and she was not allowed to see evidence that might support her case before the hearing, although the company could. **********''In Gilmer, a very large corporation asked a very little person to sign away rights,'' said Neil M. Mullin, who represents Ms. Peacock and plans to file next month to argue the case before the Supreme Court. ''The disparity of bargaining power did not impress the court. The rule became: 'You signed it. Live with it.' '' **********A spokesman for Great Western, Tim McGarry, echoed that interpretation of the rule. ''The key question is if Ms. Peacock should be required to live by a commitment she made,'' he said. ''So far, the courts have said she should.'' **********While one problem with arbitration can be the companies that make it mandatory, another can be with people who work as arbitrators. Even though members of the big arbitration groups will not hear cases they regard as obviously unfair, others apparently have no such qualms. **********''There are still lots of people out there who will,'' said Mr. Unroe of Judicial Arbitration and Mediation Services/EnDispute. ''If you count individuals? Thousands. Thousands.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/25/world.main_headline: Wartime Envoy on Nazi Gold Bristles at Hindsight
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/25/world.print_headline: Wartime Envoy on Nazi Gold Bristles at Hindsight
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/25/world.body_text: **********Seymour J. Rubin, an enduring lawyer who arrived in this city as a Roosevelt-era Wunderkind, gently sipped his martini, deciding how to defend his reputation in a controversy rooted 50 years deep in history. **********''I've been here in Washington since 1939 and seen people come and go, seen people being praised, seen them being condemned,'' the 83-year-old international trade specialist said. He was thinking back to 1946 when he was the Truman Administration's deputy negotiator of what has suddenly become a much criticized accord with Switzerland over the disposition of the gold of Nazi Germany's war machine. **********''There was never any great controversy at all,'' Mr. Rubin said of that treaty's enactment. A new Government study accuses Switzerland of grossly violating the accord and accuses the Truman Administration of having engineered ''a bad bargain'' that covered only a minor amount of the total plunder. **********On a luncheon break from his judicial duties with the Inter-American Development Bank's administrative tribunal, Mr. Rubin noted that in Washington now as ever there was nothing like hindsight. But as a capital survivor who swims daily to keep in trim, he hardly seemed haunted by history as he chose words somewhere between lawyerly precision and personal passion. **********''The accusation now that we pooped out in a basic blunder on the part of Mr. Truman seems to me pandering to Al D'Amato and maybe to the Jewish organizations as well,'' said Mr. Rubin. He referred to the United States Senator from New York and to Jewish leaders who first pressed the indictment -- concurred with now by the Clinton Administration -- that the Swiss Government deliberately failed to return hundreds of millions of dollars in assets that Nazi Germany had looted from European banks and Holocaust victims while the United States stood by. **********''Maybe 'pandering' is too strong a word,'' the lawyer amended in commenting on the critical report and its director, Stuart E. Eizenstat, Under Secretary of Commerce. ''Basically, I think Mr. Eizenstat took a look at what the public pressures are and then decided that one of the things he could do was to fault the U.S. delegation back in 1946.'' **********Mr. Eizenstat responded that the pandering accusation was ''an absurd proposition,'' particularly since critics like Mr. D'Amato had been focusing on the actions of the Swiss, not of the Truman Administration. **********''We had to be willing to look at our position too,'' added Mr. Eizenstat, who emphasized that the report hardly found ''moral equivalence'' between Washington's position and the larger failures of other nations. **********The searing 200-page report, involving 11 Government agencies and thousands of pages of documents, pored over the accord's history and concluded that Swiss bankers had been profiting richly from unreturned booty across decades of ''indifference to the needs of the victims of the Holocaust and their heirs.'' **********Further, the report accused the Truman Administration of a tactical blunder in unfreezing Swiss assets shortly after the war ended and thereby losing the leverage to see that the Swiss properly returned war loot. Some critics in Congress raised objections at the time that the Administration was too easily compromising its bargaining strengths, the report noted. **********Mr. Eizenstat said the findings made clear that the problem was ''not the shortcomings of Mr. Rubin himself.'' Rather, the accord's failure, he said, largely resulted from the ''obdurate posturing'' of the Swiss, the lack of Allies' support for any tougher United States stance, and the postwar shift in Administration priorities to rebuilding Germany and the rest of Europe in the ensuing cold war. **********''Mr. Rubin did the best he could under these limitations,'' Mr. Eizenstat declared, adding that the negotiator lacked the support of ''senior-level people in the Administration'' in seeking a stronger deal. **********As he looks back, Mr. Rubin finds insult mixed with injury, for not only is his mission criticized in hindsight but he has also lately discovered he was the target of private anti-Semitic slurs by a Swiss negotiator. He shrugged at this, emphasizing that his main regret is not the treaty but the trust placed in the Swiss to live up to it. **********''I probably would have done a hell of a lot more to try and make sure that the Swiss carried the thing out in good faith,'' he said, had he known then what he knows now. The Swiss, he noted, eventually rebuffed the heirs of victims by requiring Holocaust death certificates and other elaborate documentation to stake claims on bank holdings. ''We were probably naive on that,''he said. **********But Mr. Rubin firmly rejected the suggestion that the Truman Administration could have applied more pressure for a better deal. He said the possibility of keeping Swiss assets frozen after the war was rendered moot when Britain, eager to move on to recovery, decided to end the wartime blacklist of Swiss companies even before the accord was signed. **********''I never blamed them for that,'' said Mr. Rubin. ''A lot of people in the United States were saying the same thing: the war is over and if we continue blacklisting Swiss companies, we can't do business with them but everybody else in the world will.'' **********The Eizenstat report concluded that President Truman had settled for token reparations for the victims of Nazism because of contrary pressures to focus on the emerging Soviet threat. Mr. Rubin angrily rejects this notion. **********''This leads to a suggestion that poor Mr. Truman, of all the people in the world, was a weakling!'' he said. He conceded there had been a debate within the Truman Administration about applying pressure on the Swiss and ''the Treasury Department was by and large a little more vigorous.'' **********But Mr. Rubin, who worked for the State Department in negotiating the accord, said, ''Nobody ever raised cold war considerations -- with the negotiating delegation, at any rate.'' **********Mr. Rubin said that the fact that the accord had resulted in the Swiss returning more than $30 million of the booty had been overlooked in the current ''hullabaloo.'' The Eizenstat report found that amount to be a scandalously small fraction of the treasure exploited by the Swiss for half a century. **********Looking back as a veteran of a score of counseling positions across six different administrations, Mr. Rubin wished Mr. Eizenstat full speed ahead in his mission for a far better level of accounting and reparations now that fresh pressures were at work. **********The lawyer noted that in his part of history, he had also held positions outside Government representing Jewish organizations on the very same Nazi gold issue that had cycled back upon him. **********''I'm the guy who worked on this more than any person around,'' he said.

Columbia, the largest United States hospital chain, said that it would pay an undisclosed price for Beckley Hospital in Beckley, W.Va., a private, for-profit hospital with a capacity of 135 patients. On Tuesday, Columbia revised its bid for Value Health Inc. of Avon, Conn., to $1.12 billion in cash from an earlier offer of stock. https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/09/busin.snippet: Technology column notes World Wide Web is laden with sites devoted to wit and wisdom of Marshall McLuhan, godfather of new media; photo (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/09/busin.main_headline: McLuhan perferred form to content. So does the Internet -- to its sorrow.
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/09/busin.print_headline: McLuhan perferred form to content. So does the Internet -- to its sorrow.
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/09/busin.body_text: **********IF Marshall McLuhan were alive today -- and it sometimes seems he is -- he might be chuckling over the columns of old-fashioned print he continues to inspire. McLuhan, the godfather of new media, died in 1980, outliving his first wave of cultic fame and dying a decade before his second, but the expiring old media are still paying homage. **********Wired magazine has called him its ''patron saint,'' even publishing an interview with someone in 1995 who pretended to be an incarnation of the techno-prophet ( http://www.wired.com/wired/4.01/features/channeling.html). The magazine's book publishing arm, Hardwired, has also just published two of McLuhan's graphic manifestoes: ''The Medium is the Massage'' and ''War and Peace in the Global Village,'' wrapping them in Wired's trademark neon colors. **********M.I.T. Press has also jumped in with ''On McLuhan: Forward Through the Rearview Mirror,'' a book that with its pastiche of images and quotations by and about McLuhan, screams out for multimedia presentation. One of its editors, Paul Benedetti, did in fact accomplish something like that for Voyager, whose extravagantly rich CD-ROM,  ''Understanding McLuhan,'' includes the complete texts of ''Understanding Media'' and ''The Gutenberg Galaxy,'' video clips, testimonials and search engines (http://www.voyagerco.com/catalog/mcluhan). **********And then, of course, there is the medium that has helped inspire all these reprinted textual messages: the World Wide Web is laden with sites devoted to McLuhan's quips, positions and impact. The University of Toronto, where McLuhan taught, presents its ''McLuhan Program in Culture and Technology'' (http://www.fis.utoronto.ca/mcluhan/program.htm). A media theorist has gathered essays in tribute and criticism (http://www.aber.ac.uk/dgc/influ02.html). And long papers are plentiful (see http://www.ctheory.com/a28-digital--humanism.html). **********What are we to make of all this attention to a dead prophet? Is it because of the ubiquity of McLuhan's suggestive aphorisms (''the medium is the message'') or pungent phrases (''global village,'' ''information age'')? Is it because he gave birth to what is now called media studies and predicted a crisis in print culture? Or maybe it is because of the appeal of his playful provocations (''the future of the book is the blurb'') and extreme proclamations (''political democracy as we know it today is finished''). **********Yes, but it may also be partly because, as he predicted, sound bites like his have inherited the earth. And we are living in the world he outlined 30 years ago. The more the media proliferate the more plausible McLuhan's main thesis becomes: ''Media are so pervasive in their personal, political, economic, esthetic, psychological, moral, ethical and social consequences that they leave no part of us untouched, unaffected, unaltered.'' McLuhan defined media in the broadest sense -- as extensions of the human body, expanding our ears or eyes or nervous systems, changing the ''ratios'' between our senses, and altering the way we think and experience the world. **********The first crucial media event, for McLuhan, was the creation of a phonetic alphabet -- a medium that completely altered the course of history. Written literacy, McLuhan argued, inspired Western notions of order and reason. He believed the alphabet (and movable type) transformed tribal man into modern man. The next transformation is still going on, and oddly enough, goes in just the opposite direction, back to a kind of high-tech tribal culture, in which literacy is irrelevant. The electric media, beginning with the telegraph, shifted the emphasis from the eye to the ear, from systematic order to multiple sensations. Television is the key example, which helped create a world we now call post-modern. **********There are many details to quarrel about but the cultural changes that  McLuhan outlined in the 1960's have indeed continued -- and they are precisely what is being celebrated by Web devotees who refer to new on-line communities, shifting sexual identities in cyberspace, and a world of hot-linked connections rather than sequentially ordered texts. The Web, in McLuhan's categories, might even be considered a form of hyper-television, exaggerating that medium's character. **********The ''cool'' nature of television becomes cold on the Web. There is no ''real,'' high-definition portrait of the world; the entire medium depends on the patience, imagination and involvement of the surfer. **********A Web site generally thrives if it stands out against this background, emphasizing process and not just information. Much-heralded ''cool'' sites (as they are often called) are those that are warmer, more approachable and inviting than their surroundings. They ''do'' something in response to our doing something, making the Web seem more like interactive television (the Microsoft Network has even tried to imitate TV -- so far unsuccessfully -- with its ''channels'' and programming). **********The Internet attracts so many hotheads, with their diatribes, partly because of similar attempts to stand out against the coldness of the medium; exaggerated feelings and expressions strain at breaking bounds. But rather than seeming comical or overwrought as McLuhan thought heated personalities do on television, the medium is so removed, so composed and so cold, the very heat of such extremes has a closet appeal. The hotheads can even seem representative, since they are all a Web surfer tends to remember. **********So there is much in McLuhan's way of looking at technology that is suggestive. But the flaws in McLuhanesque interpretation are also the flaws in the new media. McLuhan turned technology into the primal force of human existence. Everything is seen through a single lens; all social activity is its reflection and all culture is in its service. McLuhan once described as ''idiotic'' anybody who thought that the content of a communication was more relevant than its medium. For him, it really didn't matter what was on television or in the newspaper or on the Web. Their impact as media was far more profound than anything they contain. **********This is a strangely cold and almost nihilistic picture of the world. This message has no middle ground, no medium. Media are powerful but so are what they contain. Without content, media become a mere distraction -- sonic or optical wallpaper. With content, perceptions of the medium itself can change. Look at the impact McLuhan managed to have on new media by using antiquated movable type. And that ancient medium continues to return the compliment.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/06/busin.snippet: Federal Court of Appeals in Denver, Colo, has denied Justice Department petition to rehear case that overturned conviction of Robert Cochran, former municipal-bond executive with Stifel, Nicolaus & Co in Oklahoma City; decision could be serious bl...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/06/busin.body_text: **********In a potentially serious blow to regulators' powers in the municipal bond market, the Federal Court of Appeals in Denver has denied a Justice Department petition to rehear a case that overturned a conviction of Robert Cochran, a former municipal-bond executive with Stifel, Nicolaus & Company in Oklahoma City. **********In a decision on Wednesday, the court denied the Government's petition to rehear the case before the full court. A three-judge panel in late March overturned Mr. Cochran's conviction last spring of wire fraud and related offenses in connection with municipal-bond transactions. Mr. Cochran denied the charges. **********The Securities and Exchange Commission, which has a civil action against Mr. Cochran, filed a brief in support of the petition, saying that the panel's decision, ''if widely accepted, would strike at the heart of the commission's anti-fraud efforts, by calling into question the application of the anti-fraud provisions of the Federal securities laws.'' **********The panel in March found that Mr. Cochran could not be held liable for wire fraud based on false or misleading statements made to an issuer of bonds unless he owed a fiduciary duty of disclosure to the issuer.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/19/busin.snippet: Technology stocks, high fliers of current bull market that many analysts predicted would be hottest sector of 1996, have reversed course as investors begin questioning high share prices and as speculators find other sectors to court; technology-he...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/19/busin.body_text: **********For a time this year, they were the high fliers -- the darlings of a magnificent bull market that was soaring to new heights. **********With leaders like Intel, Oracle and Microsoft, technology stocks bounded ahead, easily outpacing the Dow Jones industrial average and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index. **********But with the approach of spring, the sector that many predicted would be this year's hottest has reversed course as investors began questioning the high share prices and speculators found other sectors to court. **********The technology-heavy Nasdaq composite, which had outperformed every other major index early this year, shooting up nearly 8 percent in a matter of weeks, now finds itself in the unusual position of being -- gasp -- down 1.7 percent for the year, badly trailing the broader market. **********Yesterday, technology stocks once again dragged the market down, with Microsoft and Dell Computer leading the plunge. Microsoft lost 87.5 cents, to $99.625, and Dell fell $3.125, to $64.75. While the Dow fell 58.92 points yesterday, or 0.85 percent, to 6,896.56 -- the Pacific Stock Exchange Technology Index dropped even more, down 1.5 percent. **********Part of the reason is that in recent weeks, an increasing number of investors have been pulling tens of millions of dollars out of technology funds -- those mutual funds that specialize in technology stocks. As a result, technology funds have lost hundreds of millions in value in the last month. **********''Investor sentiment is drying up,'' said Robert Adler, president of AMG Data Services, which tracks mutual fund inflows. ''This is reminiscent of last June,'' he said, recalling withdrawals that preceded July's steep decline in technology stocks, which helped drag down the larger market. ''There is an identical abatement in investor demand for technology mutual funds.'' **********Indeed, as of last Wednesday, technology funds saw their fifth consecutive week of net redemptions, according to AMG, the first time the company has recorded such a flight from technology funds. Since Feb. 6, $229 million more was taken out of technology funds than was put in. (Technology funds are now valued at close to $16 billion.) **********So while the leading technology indexes are down on the year, technology funds are much worse off. **********Last month, 10 of the largest technology funds lost, on average, about 9 percent of their value, through a combination of net outflows and declining stock prices, after big gains in January, according to Lipper Analytical Services. **********T. Rowe Price's Science and Technology Fund, one of the largest, is down about 9 percent this year, and in February it saw its value decline by nearly $400 million because of net outflows and slumping performance. **********The Seligman Communication Technology Funds, with about $3.4 billion in assets, were down nearly 7 percent in February. **********What happened? ''Well, the short answer is: reality set in,'' said Richard A. Shaffer, a principal at Technologic Partners, a New York consulting firm. ''The story of the last year or two is the Internet, and every time we find a new technology we fall in love with it. But the problem is, technology attracts momentum investors who don't always understand the business. So in many ways, it's the herd mentality.'' **********And the herd can swerve suddenly, as it has done, because momentum investors want stocks that are moving higher quickly. So when the stocks fall, the herd moves elsewhere. **********With the price-to-earnings ratio among Nasdaq stocks peaking at a record 50.3 at the end of 1996, investors also began to wonder whether technology stocks had become too expensive. ''In technology, valuations got ridiculous,'' said Roger McNamee, general partner at Integral Capital Partners in Menlo Park, Calif. ''And the same guys who were buying irrationally on the way up are now selling irrationally on the way down.'' **********Among the stocks that have been dumped are networking and communications issues -- shares of companies that help computers talk to one another, using modems, for example. After a sparkling 1996, Cisco Systems is down 21 percent this year; Ascend Communications has lost 23 percent, and the 3Com Corporation has plunged an astounding 54 percent, a loss of about $6.5 billion in its market capitalization. **********While this year's downturn has been significant, several analysts said that last summer the Nasdaq managed to lose about 16 percent over concerns about weakness in the technology sector, before the stocks and the index surged at the end of the year. **********This year, however, there is a whole new set of concerns, including fears about weakening sales overseas, partly because of a strong dollar, and the warning by the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, about ''excessive optimism'' in the financial markets. **********As a result, even some of technology's longtime darlings are being jilted. Intel is down 17 percent since Feb. 4, and Microsoft, while still up 20 percent this year, has lost 4 percent from its high on Feb. 4. **********''It's happens almost every year,'' Mr. Shaffer at Technologic Partners said. ''I've been following technology for 20 years and the stocks are heroes one year and bums the next. It's just like baseball.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/26/busin.snippet: Article by Herbert Barchoff, former member of Council of Economic Advisers, discusses perplexing anomaly of living in most open sexual society ever, while at same time society is expected to adhere to stringent puritancial code of behavior in work...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/26/busin.body_text: **********I HAVE lived for many decades. But instead of feeling as if I've attained a certain measure of insight and wisdom about social interaction, I often find myself responding as did the character originally played by Yul Brynner in ''The King and I'': ''It's a puzzlement.'' **********Under the First Amendment, we can be subjected to movies like ''Leaving Las Vegas'' and plays like ''Sex and Longing,'' both of which border close to the pornographic. And the current film ''The People vs. Larry Flynt'' can cynically hold up a smut publisher to be a champion of civil liberties. **********Yet last March, Bernice Harris, then a 58-year-old cashier in the Senate coffee shop, became the focus of a sexual harassment imbroglio just because a young part-time Senate aide took offense to her calling him ''baby.'' It was a term of endearment she applied to everyone -- from janitors to senators -- whom she had encountered in the 30 years she worked at the Capitol. And last fall, a second grader in Far Rockaway, Queens, was suspended from his public school by an administrator who was going by the sexual harassment rule book because he kissed a classmate and tore a button from her skirt. Only after an outcry of public indignation was he reinstated. **********It all makes for a perplexing anomaly. **********We are living in the most openly sexual society ever. The National Opinion Research Center at the University of Chicago,  in a study published in 1994 titled ''The Social Organization of Sexuality,'' found that among people born after 1963, about two-thirds have lived together before marriage. On our stage and screen and television, we easily accept profanity -- no, egregious vulgarity -- with impunity. **********Yet amid this pervasive permissiveness and libertinism, we're expected to adhere to a stringent puritanical code of behavior in the workplace, where complaints and lawsuits involving sexual harassment can be brought on the most trivial grounds. **********When it comes to morals, the concept clearly varies with the Zeitgeist. In the Colonial Massachusetts of Hawthorne's ''The Scarlet Letter,'' Hester Prynne was made to wear a red ''A'' for her adultery. In Afghanistan only a few short months ago, a couple caught in adultery were stoned to death by the locals while the police looked on. In the TV land of the 1990's, as Murphy Brown found out, having a child out of wedlock puts you atop the ratings. **********What constitutes sexual harassment? Even though I am a lawyer, I've never argued a case in court. But I am confident that if Floria Tosca, the heroine of Puccini's opera, had come to me instead of taking a leap off the Castel Sant'Angelo, I could have beaten the murder rap for her. Be it New York in 1997 or Rome in 1800, Baron Scarpia was clearly out of line. Demanding sex in exchange for sparing a lover's life -- now that's sexual harassment! **********At the other end of the spectrum, a middle-aged friend who was once a low-level manager at a New Jersey company recalls the advice he received about a decade ago at a training session aimed at limiting the concern's vulnerability to sexual harassment complaints. If you're thinking of complimenting a subordinate's appearance or dress, don't! You never know how someone is going to take that sort of thing, the woman conducting the seminar warned. Over the years, I'm sure I have made comments that were greeted with a hearty chuckle then but would get me a slap in the face or a lawsuit today. **********Where does it all end? When you're a defendant in a suit of this sort, it's a no-win situation. Even if you prevail, there is damage to your reputation and potentially huge legal costs. **********IN all the discussion of sexual harassment, an important issue has been overlooked: the necessity for an unambiguous definition of the term. **********In its most significant ruling to date on sexual harassment in the workplace, the Supreme Court in November 1993 unanimously established the ''reasonable person''  standard, allowing workers to pursue and win sexual harassment cases if the workplace ''environment would reasonably be perceived, and is perceived, as hostile or abusive.'' This is a rather vague guideline that begs the question of what is reasonable. **********We sorely need explicit laws. In struggling with the issue of pornography more than three decades ago, Justice Potter Stewart remarked, ''I can't define it, but I know it when I see it.'' When it comes to sexual harassment, we cannot afford anything as ironically amorphous.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/09/busin.snippet: Prof Sumner M Rosen letter on Louis Uchitelle's Feb 16 article on contrasting views of economists Paul Krugman and Lester Thurow, particularly their explanations for growth of income inequality in United States (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/09/busin.main_headline: A Tale of 2 Economists: Sizing Up the Income Gap
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/09/busin.print_headline: A Tale of 2 Economists: Sizing Up the Income Gap
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/09/busin.body_text: **********''Like Oil and Water: A Tale of Two Economists,'' by Louis Uchitelle (Feb. 16), examined the contrasting views of Paul Krugman and Lester Thurow of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, particularly their explanations for the growth of income inequality in the United States. Here are some readers' responses. **********To the Editor: **********In some ways, John Maynard Keynes may be a role model for Paul Krugman, but Mr. Krugman lacks Keynes's crystal-clear dissent from both the policies of governments and the long-established doctrines of the pre-Keynes generation of economists. Lester Thurow correctly sees the global economy as central to the explanation of wage inequality. But neither has helped us see the ways in which today's global economy is a departure from both earlier globalization and the more recent focus on individual national interests. **********What should be considered in this debate is the possession and the exercise of power in the hands of the central banks and a relatively small number of multinational corporations. The nature, exercise, effects and accountability of power is a terrain still foreign to economics, including its most shining lights. **********SUMNER M. ROSEN **********Manhattan, Feb. 16 **********The writer, professor emeritus of social policy at Columbia University, has a Ph.D. in economics from M.I.T.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/26/busin.snippet: Lipper Analytical Services and Salomon Brothers to offer option contracts based on mutual fund performance on Chicago Board Options Exchange; options are based on two new Lipper/Salomon indices (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/26/busin.main_headline: Option Craze Extends to Mutual Funds
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/26/busin.print_headline: INVESTING IT; Option Craze Extends to Mutual Funds
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/26/busin.body_text: **********FOR better or for worse, investors will soon be able to buy options contracts based on mutual fund performance. **********Introduced by Lipper Analytical Services and Salomon Brothers, the options will begin trading on Dec. 3 on the Chicago Board Options Exchange. The options are based on two new indexes, the Lipper/Salomon Growth Mutual Fund Index and the Lipper/Salomon Growth and Income Mutual Fund Index. **********''Options on the Lipper/Salomon indices are the first and only derivatives based on the performance of mutual funds,'' said William J. Brodsky, chairman and chief executive of the Chicago Board Options Exchange. ''Individual investors will now be able to adjust their mutual fund exposure during the trading day without having to actually buy and sell fund shares, while fund managers will be able to more effectively manage risk and cash positions.'' **********Some financial planners also see  advantages. The Lipper/Salomon Growth Index, made up of the 30 largest growth-oriented stock funds, includes eight Fidelity funds, including Magellan and Contrafund, so investors could use the options as a way to bet on Fidelity's mutual fund performance, they said. **********The options also allow some fund managers to change their mutual fund exposure quickly, or for a brief time. ''A portfolio manager who is changing his strategy from value to growth could buy the options as a way to do that,'' said Richard Lee, president of Lee Financial in Dallas. ''The one big advantage is a portfolio manager can make that switch with the options without the tax costs'' of selling major holdings that may incur big capital gains. **********Individual investors, however, may want to be a little more leery. ''These options and these new indexes all come from the yearlong craze of index mania,'' said Lewis Altfest, president of L. J. Alfest & Company, a New York City financial planner. ''If I believed the market was going to decline, I wouldn't recommend my clients buy'' put options on this index, he said. ''There are contrarian funds.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/28/world.snippet: National security officials in United States expel Bosnian general, Brig General Selmo Cikotic, from elite US Army training course this week after hearing unconfirmed accusations that he is a war criminal (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/28/world.main_headline: Allegations Halt Army Training For Bosnian General in the U.S.
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/28/world.print_headline: Allegations Halt Army Training For Bosnian General in the U.S.
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/28/world.body_text: **********National security officials expelled a Bosnian general from an elite United States Army training course this week after hearing unconfirmed accusations that he is a war criminal, Administration officials said today. **********The man in question, Brig. Gen. Selmo Cikotic, is a Bosnian Muslim who came to Washington in December 1994 as the military attache at the Embassy of Bosnia and Herzegovina. The State Department sent him this month to the Army's Command and General Staff College at Fort Leavenworth, Kan., under a program to train and educate foreign military officers. **********The accusations against General Cikotic came from Croatian officials, according to a senior Administration official. They include unconfirmed allegations that he commanded soldiers who killed and tortured people in and around Bugojno, a town of about 40,000 people in central Bosnia, in July 1993, when Muslim and Croatian forces were fighting for the town. **********General Cikotic, 34, is a former Yugoslav Army officer who served as a field commander and as chief of staff of the Bosnia Third Corps during the war. He also served as a senior member of the Muslim delegation that held peace talks with the Croatians in 1993. **********He declined to address the accusations against him during a brief telephone interview. ''This should be handled government-to-government,'' he said. **********The Bosnian Embassy's acting military attache, Maj. Suad Cengic, said his Government was preparing a response. **********The officials who decided to remove General Cikotic from the rolls at the Command and General Staff College did not know whether the charges against him were true, an Administration official said. **********''We have questions about the credibility of the accusation,'' said the official, who refused to be quoted by name. ''We could not come to a definitive conclusion as to whether he might have been involved in war crimes. But in the end it was decided we needed to have a zero-tolerance policy, and because of that we had to hold him to a very, very high standard.'' **********In the only public statement on the general, John Dinger, a State Department spokesman, said, ''Senior officials within the National Security Council, the State Department and the Defense Department decided by consensus not to enroll the general in a longer course.'' **********Officials at the International Criminal Tribunal at the Hague said they could not discuss whether General Cikotic is under investigation for war crimes. The tribunal has indicted 75 suspected war criminals -- 54 Serbs, 18 Croats and 3 Muslims. Only eight suspects are in custody. **********Last month the State Department invited General Cikotic to attend a 10-month course at the college, the Army's most prestigious school for teaching officers tactics in war and leadership in battle. **********But this week, after weighing the accusations against General Cikotic, senior national security officials withdrew the general from the college, Administration officials said. He was informed of the decision at the end of a short orientation course. **********Another official said the Army and the State Department wanted to avoid embroiling the Command and General Staff College in the kind of controversy that has enveloped the Army's School of the Americas. In past years that school has trained, among many other Latin American officers, such notorious figures as Roberto D'Aubuisson, the most prominent leader of death squads in El Salvador in the 1980's.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/30/busin.body_text: **********Air France Group, the parent company of France's state-owned airline, reported yesterday that it posted its first annual profit in seven years in the year that ended on March 31 because of increases in passenger and cargo revenue and a drop in financing costs. **********The company, which includes travel and catering services, earned 394 million French francs ($67 million) in the fiscal year. https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/01/busin.snippet: JP Foodservice Inc agrees to buy Rykoff-Sexton Inc for about $689 million in stock; companies, two of biggest in food service industry, say merged operations would have annual sales of $5.2 billion (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/01/busin.main_headline: Distributors Of Foods Plan Merger Worth $689 Million
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/01/busin.print_headline: Distributors Of Foods Plan Merger Worth $689 Million
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/01/busin.body_text: **********JP Foodservice Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Rykoff-Sexton Inc. for about $689 million in stock. **********The companies, two of the biggest in the food service industry, said the merged operations would have annual sales of $5.2 billion. The combined company would have more than 130,000 customers among restaurants, hotels and institutional buyers. **********The purchase will extend JP Foodservice's reach into the Western United States and into manufacturing. **********It also enables JP Foodservice to compete more directly with the Sysco Corporation, which has dominated the fragmented $135 billion food distribution industry during the last decade. **********Sysco, based in Houston, had 1996 sales of $13.4 billion. **********Under the terms of the agreement, Rykoff-Sexton's shareholders will exchange each of their shares for 0.84 share of JP Foodservice. Based on JP Foodservice's closing price Friday, that values each Rykoff-Sexton share at $25.3125, nearly 29 percent above the company's stock price on Friday. Shareholders of both companies will hold almost equal stakes in the combined company. **********But shares of JP Foodservice fell $1.4375 yesterday, to $28.6875, on the New York Stock Exchange, giving the deal a value of $689 million. Shares of Rykoff-Sexton rose $3.6875, to $23.3125. **********JP Foodservice, based in Columbia, Md., will also assume about $700 million in the debt of Rykoff-Sexton, whose headquarters are in Wilkes-Barre, Pa. **********The sale, while still subject to regulatory and shareholder approvals, has already received the consent of about 36 percent of Rykoff-Sexton's shareholders, the companies said. **********The combined companies will continue under JP Foodservice's name. **********The purchase, while leaving the company far behind Sysco, enables JP Foodservice to accelerate the growth it has pursued since gaining independence from the Sara Lee Corporation in 1989. **********''We view this as the opportunity to leap ahead of the industry, in a No. 2 position,'' said James Miller, JP Foodservice's chairman and chief executive. ''We now have the critical mass.'' **********The food service industry has been consolidating quickly in the last few years as companies hustle to keep old accounts and gain new ones by creating larger economies of scale. **********JP Foodservice bought $350 million in companies last year alone, Mr. Miller said, and Rykoff last year completed the acquisition of US Foodservice Inc. for $614 million.
