https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/16/busin.snippet: Interest rates in Hong Kong surge to their highest levels since 1995 as traders bet that speculative attack on Southeast Asian currencies might cause authorities to allow Hong Kong dollar to float; currency turmoil continues elsewhere in region (M...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/16/busin.main_headline: Monetary Turmoil in Asia Pushes Up Hong Kong Rates
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/16/busin.print_headline: Monetary Turmoil in Asia Pushes Up Hong Kong Rates
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/16/busin.body_text: **********Interest rates in Hong Kong surged to their highest levels since 1995 today as traders bet that the speculative attack on Southeast Asian currencies might cause the authorities to allow the Hong Kong dollar to float. **********Currency turmoil continued elsewhere in the region. Malaysia's currency, the ringgit, fell to a 24-year low against the dollar, declining as much as 1.6 percent, after the central bank failed to mount a significant defense of the currency, traders said. **********Indonesia's currency fell as much as 6 percent against the dollar today, one day after the central bank abandoned efforts to support it, and interest rates surged 4.6 percentage points, to 40 percent, their highest level in more than four years. **********Southeast Asian currencies have been tumbling in the wake of the devaluation of the Thai baht on July 2. Speculators say that the factors that caused Thailand's financial troubles -- including a current account deficit, rapid growth of bank loans and a weak property market -- may be mirrored in other countries. **********In Hong Kong today, investors rushed to buy contracts that locked in future exchange rates. The contracts would help insulate them from losses if the Hong Kong dollar weakens. **********The monetary authorities keep the Hong Kong dollar pegged to its American counterpart. They maintain that they can fend off any attacks on the currency, but speculators are not so sure. **********The one-year forward rate for the Hong Kong dollar, which allows investors to fix an exchange rate one year in advance, was quoted today at $7.90 (Hong Kong) to one United States dollar. On the spot market, the local currency has not been weaker than $7.80 (Hong Kong) during this decade. **********As the forward rates rise, the risk of holding the local currency increases. In turn, local interest rates climb as people holding investments denominated in Hong Kong dollars demand a higher return in exchange for taking on that risk. **********Hong Kong's overnight lending rate rose today to 7.125 percent from 6.4375 percent, and the three-month rate climbed to 9 percent from 7 percent. **********The increased rates hurt Hong Kong stocks, and the benchmark Hang Seng index declined 2.4 percent, to its lowest close since July 30. **********To be sure, Hong Kong does not have the economic troubles of other countries in the region. But those countries gain a competitive advantage over Hong Kong as their currencies weaken, because their exports become less expensive in terms of other currencies. **********In today's dealings in the Malaysian currency, traders said the Malaysian central bank's apparent decision to intervene only lightly in the foreign exchange market indicated a desire to smooth out daily volatility, adding stability to the currency, rather than to mount an outright defense of the ringgit. **********Traders also said the Monetary Authority of Singapore apparently bought that country's currency, which fell slightly against the dollar today. **********Malaysia and Singapore have said they will let market forces determine exchange rates. **********As currencies decline in the region, local companies that hold foreign debts suffer because the cost of buying foreign currency to repay those debts increases. In Indonesia today, P.T. Indocement Tunggal Prakarsa, part of the Salim family's huge group of companies, said that only 20 percent of its $350 million in foreign debt was hedged, meaning it has been hurt by the rupiah's decline.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/01/world.snippet: Japanese people, with their nation facing severe budget deficit, start to object to spending for public works projects that have played outsized role in Japan's economy and political system; questioning is part of broader reassessment of public sp...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/01/world.main_headline: Japan's Road to Deep Deficit Is Paved With Public Works
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/01/world.print_headline: Japan's Road to Deep Deficit Is Paved With Public Works
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/01/world.body_text: **********When the national and local governments built a $4 million ''agricultural airport'' in this small town in northern Japan, they said it would allow local farmers to get higher prices for their vegetables by flying them to market while still fresh instead of sending them by truck, a three-day trip. **********What the officials overlooked was that each flight would cost more than $4,000 but could carry no more than $3,000 in vegetables. Moreover, since the planes are too small to make it all the way to Tokyo or Osaka, trucks are sometimes still needed for part of the journey, and shipping time is cut by only one day. Last year, only 10 flights took off from the airport, and taxpayers are wondering if their money was well spent. **********''It may be good for a children's playground,'' said Kayoko Omiyo, the wife of a farmer. The town government is indeed thinking of turning the runway over for in-line skating, and cross-country skiing in the winter, to make greater use of the site. **********With their nation facing a severe budget deficit, people in Japan are starting to object to the spending for public works projects that have played an outsized role in Japan's economy and political system. The questioning is part of a broader reassessment of public spending policy and of Japan's once-admired bureaucracy, both of which are now being seen as riddled with waste and corruption. **********Japan spends more on public construction, about $300 billion, than the Pentagon spends on defense. Critics call Japan ''doken kokka,'' the ''construction state,'' a reference not only to the magnitude of the activity but also to the cozy relationships between contractors and Government officials that keeps pork-barrel projects coming. Public works have also long been a sore point in trade with the United States, as American companies seeking a share of the huge projects have complained of a bidding system that locks them out of contracts. **********''The construction state is in some respects akin to the military-industrial complex in cold-war America (or the Soviet Union), sucking in the country's wealth, consuming it inefficiently, growing like a cancer and bequeathing both fiscal crisis and environmental devastation,'' Gavan McCormack, a professor of Japanese history at Australia National University, wrote in ''The Emptiness of Japanese Affluence,'' a recent book. **********In the last few years, public works spending has been stepped up even more to stimulate a languid economy. Everywhere you look, roads are being paved or dug up, rivers dammed, bays filled to make new land, and domed arenas erected. Projects range from the $7.6 billion Akashi Straits Bridge, which is being built near Kobe and which will be the longest bridge in the world, to the art museum for the small town of Ono, completed in 1993, which displays only reproductions because there was no money to buy art. **********The statistics alone are staggering. Japan uses as much cement each year as the United States, despite having only half the population and only 4 percent of the land area. Japan's construction industry, with 500,000 companies and 6.6 million workers, accounts for 10 percent of the country's employment compared with 5 to 7 percent in other advanced nations. Public works spending in Japan amounts to about 6.6 percent of gross domestic product compared with 1.6 percent in the United States and 2 to 3 percent for Western European nations, according to the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development. **********But now the Cabinet has formed a task force to cut public construction expenses. Citizens have begun to question Government extravagance in public buildings. And environmentalists have started fighting the construction binge that has left only 3 of Japan's 113 major rivers flowing freely and only 45 percent of the coastline of the four main islands in a natural state. **********The press is having a field day digging up white elephants, like the  pier at Fukui, a port to which ships rarely come, that is called a ''10 billion yen fishing hole'' by local residents. The pier, sitting empty except for fishermen, actually cost 30 billion yen, or $250 million. **********A fiscal crisis is driving Japan's reassessment. After years of lecturing the United States to reduce its Federal budget deficit, Japan has developed a deficit of its own that is far worse proportionately than Washington's. **********In 1996, Japan's central and local budget deficits amounted to 7 percent of gross domestic product, the highest among the Group of Seven major industrial countries. The figure for the United States is less than 2 percent. Some 22 percent of next year's budget will be spent on interest payments on the accumulated debt -- more than on education, science and the military combined. **********''Japan holds a time bomb that is expected to explode in a few years, and the bomb gets bigger every year,'' an advisory committee to the Ministry of Finance said in a recent report. **********The deficit results from several years of a weak economy, which forced the Government to cut taxes and to increase spending to prime the pump. Since 1992, the Government has announced stimulus packages worth $560 billion, with much of it spent on public works. The budgets included $50 billion in 1995 alone for relief and reconstruction after the Kobe earthquake. **********Despite such infusions, the economy still has not fully recovered. Some economists say the public works stimulus is losing its effectiveness, though others say it kept the economy from a deeper recession. **********Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto has suggested that the Government might review a pledge to spend  more than $5 trillion on public works  from 1995 to 2004. The promise was made in response to demands by the United States that Japan stimulate domestic spending to increase imports. **********Critics also label spending for agriculture as wasteful, including $50 billion the Government committed to spend over six years to compensate farmers for the partial opening of the rice market to imports. Takigawa, a town in northern Japan, is building a hot springs resort using agricultural promotion funds, justifying it on the grounds that a shop on the premises will sell local produce. **********But cutting back on public works is proving to be difficult. Those expecting sharp cutbacks next year were outraged that the proposed budget included $10 billion for extensions of bullet train lines that analysts expect to prove uneconomical. **********Too much fiscal tightness could plunge the still-fragile economy into recession. Japan is already planning to raise taxes this year to fight the deficit and the United States is cautioning Japan not to restrict spending too much. **********But a bigger reason is that pork-barrel politics is deeply ingrained. Politicians push for big projects for their districts, not only to satisfy voters but because construction companies have long been among the biggest contributors to the Liberal Democratic Party. The party has governed Japan for most of the post-World War II period and is now back in power after a three-year hiatus.  Ministries also fight any diminution of their budgets. **********Bribery of public officials to win contracts is common. So is bid-rigging, in part because bidding on many projects is open only to designated companies, shutting out foreign firms, among others. Those factors have helped make construction costs in Japan at least 30 to 40 percent higher than in the United States. **********Government officials contend, and many citizens agree, that Japan needs to improve its infrastructure . The war leveled large parts of the country, and Japan has emphasized developing industry over improvements that would have been considered consumer amenities. **********Half of Japan's population lives in homes that are not connected to sewage systems. And Japan has only 4,000 miles of expressways compared with 5,500 in France and 7,000 in Germany. Most of its highways are only two lanes in each direction and are clogged. **********''Japan is still a developing country compared with Western Europe and the United States,'' said Yasuo Mitsuie, a Ministry of Construction official. **********But critics say that politics drives  projects to take on a life of their own, even if the need for them disappears. **********''The construction itself is the purpose,'' said Hirofumi Uzawa, a retired University of Tokyo economics professor. **********There are some signs of change. In a rare move, the Ministry of Construction has canceled plans for four dams -- of 300 being built or planned. The Ministry of Agriculture is reviewing its agricultural airport program because the four that have been completed have been failures. **********But the construction state will not die easily. Indeed, a project to top all others is now being planned -- to move the nation's capital out of Tokyo by the year 2010. **********To reduce the congestion and concentration of power in Tokyo, a new capital city of 600,000 people is to be built. The initial cost estimate is more than $100 billion, but it is likely to cost much more.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/30/world.snippet: Jobless demonstrators occupy nine employment offices across France to demand year-end bonuses of $500; others block trains in Marseilles and Chatellerault; national unemployment averages 12.5 percent (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/30/world.main_headline: French Jobless Seize Unemployment Offices to Press for $500 Bonus
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/30/world.print_headline: French Jobless Seize Unemployment Offices to Press for $500 Bonus
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/30/world.body_text: **********In France, where being unemployed has become a full-time occupation for hundreds of thousands of people, jobless demonstrators occupied nine employment offices today to demand year-end bonuses of $500. **********About 200 unemployed people also blocked trains at the main station in Marseilles, where unemployment is higher than the 12.5 percent national average, and 40 demonstrators occupied tracks on the main rail line between Paris and Bordeaux at Chatellerault for brief periods today, causing delays of several hours for thousands of travelers. **********In Chatellerault, demonstrators had been thrown out of the local employment office after occupying it for several days in support of the demand for a year-end bonus. In Marseilles, demonstrators had been refused admittance to the main office of the regional government headquarters in the Mediterranean port. **********Protests began there and in the economically bleak north of France last month after the Socialist Government elected in June said it would raise welfare payments by 2 percent this year for 500,000 people whose unemployment benefits had run out. **********The increase -- which amounted to about $7.50 a month, bringing the payments to a little over $400 a month -- was described by some demonstrators as ''an insult.'' The Government plans a 1 percent increase next July. Unemployment benefits in France decrease over time and expire, for most people, after two and a half years; the unemployment rate for the last two and a half years has hovered around 12 percent. **********Employer groups and the conservative opposition say that high taxes and employer-paid benefits required by law discourage businesses from hiring. This, they say, explains why it is so much harder for people here to find jobs than it is in the United States, where the jobless rate is about a third of what it is in France. **********The protesters chose the year-end bonus issue as a way of dramatizing the inability of all recent French governments, Socialist or conservative, to reduce unemployment significantly. Year-end bonuses have long been expected by salaried workers in France and Germany, and another month's pay is something most French workers lucky enough to have jobs take for granted. **********The French Minister of Unemployment and Solidarity, Martine Aubry, has urged local officials to be generous in considering applications for additional aid to jobless people in financial distress. But the Government is trying to keep spending down to make sure France qualifies among the European countries that hope to start a common currency in 1999. **********Christophe Aguiton, one of the founders of a group of unemployed workers called Act Together Against Unemployment, said, ''We shouldn't forget that 80 percent of all the unemployed in France receive less than $500 a month in benefits.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/20/busin.snippet: Dreamworks SKG, entertainment company that debuted 26 months ago with much fanfare, is still waiting to make its first big splash; studio will not release its first live-action feature film until next fall; it has three television series on air, b...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/20/busin.main_headline: Despite a Sluggish Beginning, Dreamworks Is Viewed as a Potential Hollywood Power
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/20/busin.print_headline: Despite a Sluggish Beginning, Dreamworks Is Viewed as a Potential Hollywood Power
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/20/busin.body_text: **********It was a holiday party done in typical Hollywood tradition. At the rambling, adobe-style buildings that are the temporary home of Dreamworks, the lawn was covered with tents under which the company's 1,200 employees were helping themselves to a lavish buffet dinner. **********Several tables were spread with items for making personalized decorations; a sled led by two live reindeer for employees to pose with, and wandering amid it all were Dreamworks' three partners -- Jeffrey Katzenberg, Steven Spielberg and David Geffen -- dressed in their trademark jeans and sport shirts. **********The party resonated with the mood of success and stability typical of more established film companies celebrating splashy hits. But 26 months after the much-covered debut of Dreamworks SKG -- the first attempt to begin a major new entertainment company in decades -- the studio is still waiting to make its first big splash. It will not release its first live-action feature film until next fall, when ''The Peacemaker,'' a thriller, reaches theaters in September. It has three television series on the air, but only one, ''Spin City,'' has a strong chance of generating enough episodes to produce profits from rerun sales, several television executives said. And George Michael's new album ''Older,'' Dreamworks' first major record, has had a lackluster reception. **********At any other company, such a record would doom executives to relentless and loud criticism. And in Hollywood there are those who say privately that so far Dreamworks is a disappointment. **********But most acknowledge that even with the daunting risks of starting a new entertainment company, particularly at a difficult time for the industry, the Dreamworks' team has a respectable chance of pulling it off. ''There are only two brand names in the business: Disney and Spielberg, and Dreamworks has one of them,'' said John Tinker, an analyst at Montgomery Securities. ''They have a strong capital base and experienced management. That gives them a tremendous advantage. **********''The question is: Can they survive given the increasing capital costs and risks in the business?'' he said. **********But no one is willing to bet against David Geffen's deal-making skills. Mr. Geffen built one of the biggest personal fortunes in Hollywood by creating and selling his record company to MCA for $550 million in stock in 1990. Within a year, he cashed out for $710 million when Matsushita Electrical Industrial bought MCA. **********Perhaps the greatest reason for caution is that Dreamworks' biggest bet, the business on which its future rises and falls, is animated films. Ron Nelson, the company's chief financial officer, anticipates that 40 percent to 50 percent of Dreamworks' profits will come from animation. **********Three hundred animators are now working on its first release, ''The Prince of Egypt,'' which is not due out until Thanksgiving 1998. Another 100 animators are preparing ''El Dorado: City of Gold,'' for the following year and smaller teams are working on the computer-generated films, ''Ants'' and ''Shrek.'' That means about 40 percent of the staff is at work on animation. **********Animation is Mr. Katzenberg's first love, and where he built his reputation during his 13 years at the Walt Disney Company. Clearly he wants to prove he can do it again. But he also wants to do it differently from Disney. **********At the moment, Mr. Katzenberg does not anticipate Dreamworks' rivaling the Disney machine in marketing and merchandising film-related products. The company is still debating whether product tie-ins, Disney's huge profit machine driven by animated hits, are appropriate for ''Prince of Egypt.'' **********''It's not even a movie that the Disney Company would ever have made,'' Mr. Katzenberg said, during a short work break. ''For them there have to be stores and parks and merchandise.'' **********Mr. Katzenberg, who is suing Disney in a bitter battle over compensation, may be seeking his vindication, but economics also play a role. Successful animated films, even before profits from merchandising, promise a windfall. Moses, like Bugs Bunny, does not demand a huge salary. Disney's film division, fueled by animation hits, averaged 17 percent operating profit margins between 1992 and 1995, compared with about 10 percent at Warner Brothers, the industry's second-most-profitable studio, David Londoner, an analyst at Schroder Wertheim & Company, noted. **********If Mr. Katzenberg is fully immersed in the roughly $60 million production of ''Prince of Egypt,'' his partners played a central role in deciding to adopt the Biblical story as the company's first, defining animation effort. **********As Mr. Katzenberg tells the story, at one of the team's earliest meetings, ''Steven asked me: ''Could you start another animation company,'' Mr. Katzenberg recalled. ''Steven said to me; 'You know the one thing that I looked at as a competitor -- the thing you did at Disney -- was starting with an unbelievably great idea. How did you pick them?' '' **********''I listed what we looked for in picking a subject: a great theme, allegorical: not only does it have to be a good story, but it has to tell you something about humanity. You need a great villain. You need great music that moves you from one place in the story to another. **********''When I finished listing the requirements, Steven said, 'Oh, like the 10 Commandments.' And David said, 'What a great idea.' '' **********But Mr. Spielberg's major role involves live-action films, where operations have been slow to get off the ground. For one thing, Mr. Spielberg has been finishing up films for Amblin Entertainment, including directing ''Lost World,'' the ''Jurassic Park'' sequel. And Walter Parks, who together with his wife, Laurie MacDonald, was brought to Dreamworks from Amblin to head the movie division under Mr. Spielberg, acknowledged, ''We have been pulled between the two endeavors.'' **********There are rumors in Hollywood that neither Mr. Geffen nor Mr. Katzenberg is particularly happy with the progress at the film division. And even Mr. Parks said, ''We have been trying to hire another executive to help.'' **********But both Mr. Geffen and Mr. Katzenberg deny they have any concerns. Mr. Katzenberg said that ''it is complete and utter nonsense; David and I are very pleased with how things are going.'' **********In one scheduling change that will help fill the pipeline faster, Mr. Spielberg, who had not planned to direct his first Dreamworks picture until next summer, will start directing ''Amistad,'' a story of black slaves  put on trial for murder, in February. And the company has recently announced production plans for several new films this year. **********The company's most visible efforts have been in television, where at least one series -- ''Spin City,'' with Michael J. Fox -- is likely to make it to syndication. It now ranks 11th in the Nielsen ratings. **********Two other shows are more problematic -- ''Ink,'' about a newspaperman, ranks 35th and ''High Incident'' survives though it ranks a precarious 85th. A fourth show, ''Champs,'' lasted just six episodes early last year. **********Dreamworks has not been shy about spending money. Not only has it locked up top television talent, but it has hired top executives at other divisions, including Mo Austin, the former Warner Music executive who was eagerly courted by Disney, among others. And it has expanded its initial plans to enter the business of interactive games, a field in which its initial offering, ''Goosebumps'' is  doing well. **********But the company is still physically scattered on several sites. A deal to move to Playa Vista has been bogged down in disputes between the developers and some real estate investors. **********Deamworks does not disclose its finances, but so far, Mr. Nelson contended, the company was ahead of budget in part because it had not ''ramped up its feature film division,'' Mr. Nelson said. But unlike other start-ups, it has a strong capital base. The three partners together hold 67 percent of the company, having put up $33 million each. The two other key investors are the former Microsoft executive, Paul Allen, who committed $492.5 million for an 18 percent stake, while Mie Kyung Lee, a scion of the Samsung Electronics family, invested $300 million for an 11 percent stake. A consortium of banks agreed to put up $1 billion in credit. **********Dreamworks executives say that they are not expecting to show any profits for at least five years. But neither Mr. Allen nor Ms. Lee seem impatient. In a telephone interview from South Korea, Ms. Lee said: ''We're very happy with the relationship with Jeffrey and David. I don't care about getting our money out ASAP.'' Asked what kind of return she anticipated, Ms. Lee said: ''I can't come up with the numbers right now. My brother is a better numbers expert.'' **********An investor could cash out if the company were sold or went public, said Alan Patricof, a longtime venture capitalist who heads his own firm. But several traditional venture capitalists said they doubted that Dreamworks would produce the 35 to 40 percent average annual returns that have characterized the best deals. **********''For an investor to get 35 percent in three years, Dreamworks would have to have at least a $6 billion valuation,'' Mr. Patricof noted. MCA, one of the Hollywood giants, was valued at about $7 billion when it was sold to Seagram in 1995. **********''The game is always to build a pool of assets so that somwhehwere down the road you can sell it to somebody else, go public or sell it back to the company for a big capital gain, '' said Harold Vogel, an analyst at Cowen & Company. **********Mr. Allen, however, does not share the venture capitalist timetable nor does he see Dreamworks as a classical venture-capital bet on a ''bunch of long shots. **********''Here they have a proven track record of working together,'' Mr. Allen said. ''It's like investing with Bill Gates. If you have one Windows or Excel, things could be fantastic.'' Indeed, the value of companies in the entertainment industry has risen steadily. **********From Mr. Geffen's point of view, ''I think what we have accomplished is extraordinary.'' He noted that Dreamworks has been in business with its financing for two years or less. But even he is a realist about  the risks in the movie business. **********Speaking about ''Prince of Egypt'' he said: ''I think it is one of the most fantastic animated movies ever made. Having said that, it will come out and we will see how it does.'' **********After two years, the same can be said of Dreamworks.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/16/busin.snippet: Roundup of feature articles in personal-finance magazines; article in Kiplinger's discusses future of Social Security; article in Money magazine discusses high fees charged on some 401 (k) retirement plans; photo (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/16/busin.main_headline: Dissecting Retirement Programs, and Suggesting Surgery
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/16/busin.print_headline: Dissecting Retirement Programs, and Suggesting Surgery
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/16/busin.body_text: **********IF retirement is on your mind, there is plenty to consider in the April batch of personal-finance magazines. **********''Saving Social Security,'' an article by Melynda Dovel Wilcox in Kiplinger's, is a clear and fairly comprehensive look at the ins and outs of Social Security and the problems it faces, which, the article says, aren't as terrible as some politicians are saying. **********In fact, many experts have said that if nothing is done between now and 2029, when the Social Security trust fund is expected to be ''bankrupt,'' revenue from payroll taxes will still be enough to pay 75 percent of promised benefits. So the trick is figuring out how to make up the other 25 percent. **********Kiplinger's endorses a middle-of-the-road plan -- what one economist calls ''everyone's second choice'' -- promoted by Edward Gramlich, dean of the School of Public Policy at the University of Michigan and chairman of the Advisory Council on Social Security. The plan would create the equivalent of a national 401(k) tax-deferred retirement plan that would work in tandem with Social Security. It would not divert money now flowing into the system, but would be financed with an extra contribution of 1.6 percent of pay. The proposal would then slow the growth of Social Security benefits, mainly for middle-  and high-wage workers, but the gap -- in theory -- would be made up by the extra 1.6 percent in contributions. **********One complaint about the Kiplinger's article is that it makes no mention of the regressive nature of the Social Security tax. Everyone pays the same rate on annual earnings of up to $65,400 for the current year, but no one pays a cent on earnings above that amount. This means that high-income people are paying the tax on only a portion -- in many cases a small portion -- of their incomes, while middle-  and low-income workers are paying the tax on all or most of their earnings. What about raising the cutoff point instead of the rate? **********401(k) WOES Money magazine, in an article by Penelope Wang, contends that ''excessive'' and often ''hidden'' fees on some 401(k) plans are cheating American workers out of an estimated $1.5 billion a year. Some of these fees, Money says, are up to seven times as high as charges by moderately priced mutual funds or institutional investment managers. The magazine says a typical 35-year-old worker who participated in a high-cost plan for 30 years would retire with 25 percent less than he or she would have collected under a low-cost plan -- a shortfall estimated to average $244,000. **********Many companies, Money continues, fail to protect employees' interests, and some small businesses are barely better informed about 401(k) costs than their workers are. The magazine advises that you  find out the cost of your 401(k) plan and pressure your employer to minimize fees, even if it means switching plans. **********MEDICARE PITFALLS The April-May issue of Your Money has some practical advice for dealing with Medicare and so-called Medigap insurance. This is a case in which the devil is in the details, and what you don't know can prove disastrous. **********HOME ALONE Two magazines, Money and PC World, have jointly ranked the best areas for telecommuters. The rankings are based on factors like Internet access and the number of computer-supply stores and copy centers, as well as the economic, educational, cultural and social scenes. **********Over all, the top 10 places are San Francisco; San Jose, Calif.; Los Angeles; San Diego; Seattle; Oakland, Calif.; Tampa-St. Petersburg, Fla.; Orange County, Calif.; Boston, and Atlanta. **********The top 10 midsize areas are Raleigh-Durham-Chapel Hill, N.C.; Sarasota-Bradenton, Fla.; West Palm Beach, Fla.; Santa Barbara, Calif.; Jacksonville, Fla.; Austin, Tex.; Brevard County, Fla.; Ventura, Calif.; Fort Myers-Cape Coral, Fla., and Madison, Wis. **********Ranked highest among small areas are Manchester, N.H.; Gainesville, Fla.; Nashua, N.H.; Bryan-College Station, Tex.; Naples, Fla.; Boulder, Colo.; San Luis Obispo, Calif.; Portsmouth, N.H.; Santa Cruz, Calif., and Olympia, Wash. **********HAPPY BIRTHDAY Smart Money is five years old and celebrates with a follow-up on 10 stocks for the 90's that it recommended in 1992. They have done well. The top pick, Applied Materials, has increased twelvefold; the laggard, La-Z-Boy, is up 38 percent. **********BITS AND PIECES Financial World expects Congress to reduce estate taxes by the end of the year. . . . Individual Investor takes a look at some companies whose earnings have beaten Wall Street estimates, but fails to mention that write-offs in some cases have been inflating earnings growth. . . . Smart Money has several good articles for the business traveler, including rankings of airlines and hotels. . . . Maybe it's premature spring fever, but many magazines and newspapers, including this one, are featuring babies on their covers and display pages; will puppies be next?

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/09/busin.snippet: On-line businesses look to courts to impose law and order and to help protect their content; in one case, Ticketmaster Corp has sued Microsoft Corp, seeking to prevent links to its site from Microsoft content provider; Microsoft contends that esse...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/09/busin.main_headline: Legal Situation Is Confused On Web Content Protections
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/09/busin.print_headline: Legal Situation Is Confused On Web Content Protections
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/09/busin.body_text: **********While the new frontier of the World Wide Web is often compared to the Wild West, on-line businesses now are looking to the courts to impose law and order and to help protect their content. **********As that content becomes more valuable, the on-line entrepreneurs increasingly want to control who links to their sites, how they link and how their content is displayed -- questions that seemed largely insignificant even a year ago. **********However, the first litigation on the matter appears to have raised as many questions as it answered. Last week, Total News Inc. settled a lawsuit with Time Warner's CNN, The Washington Post and four other major media conglomerates by agreeing to stop displaying their Web content with its own ads. **********The Total News case involved a browser function that permits a Web designer to use a simple command to create partitions in a Web page. Total News, a Web company based behind a Lulu's Taco Stand in Gilbert, Ariz., links to 1,350 news sites, wrapping the linked content in a frame of its own advertising. **********Because the closely watched case never made it to trial, legal scholars and people in the on-line industry said it failed to provide any significant precedent. **********At the most, ''it was a warning shot across the bow to people who want to make money using other people's content,'' said Trotter Hardy, professor of law at William and Mary Law School. **********Tom Baker, business director of the Wall Street Interactive Edition of Dow Jones & Company, a plaintiff in the case, said that Internet businesses had to feel that their intellectual property was protected on line or they would have no incentive to post valuable content. **********The settlement ultimately raised questions not only about so-called frames, but about linking in general. In what is believed to be one of the first agreements of its kind, Total News also said it would license the right to link to Web sites of the six plaintiffs, and that the plaintiffs could revoke that right on 15 days' notice. **********In a related case that is still pending, the Ticketmaster Corporation in April sued the Microsoft Corporation in Federal court in California. Ticketmaster wants to prevent links to its site from a Microsoft content provider, called Microsoft Sidewalk. Ticketmaster contends that Microsoft Sidewalk is profiting from the link, and from Ticketmaster's brand name. **********Microsoft counters that the essence of the Web is that it permits largely unrestricted linking and roaming of content. ''If they're successful, the Web will change as we know it,'' said Frank Schott, general manager of Microsoft Sidewalk, which is continuing to link to Ticketmaster over its objections. **********Hank Barry, a partner with Wilson, Sonsini, Goodrich & Rosati in Palo Alto, Calif., said that in the future Web sites were also likely to try to prevent links from sites that they did not want to be associated with. **********Ultimately, the emergence of such intellectual property questions coincides with the increasingly profitable nature of Internet content. ''Advertisers now realize there is value there, and eyes there and eyes that buy things,'' Mr. Barry said. ''In contrast to 18 months ago, it now makes economic sense to control how your content is used.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/02/world.snippet: US officials recently denounced corrupt Mexican officials when they learned that suspected drug trafficker Rigoberto Gaxiola Medina had managed to hold onto tens of millions of dollars that had been ordered frozen in money-laundering investigation...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/02/world.main_headline: The Missing Drug Millions: Just a Misunderstanding?
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/02/world.print_headline: The Missing Drug Millions: Just a Misunderstanding?
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/02/world.body_text: **********When United States officials  learned recently that a suspected  Mexican drug trafficker had managed to hold onto tens of millions of dollars that had been ordered frozen in a money-laundering investigation,  they wasted no time denouncing what they saw as new evidence of corruption south of the border. **********Less than a month later, however, the evidence that Mexican investigators tipped off the suspect is evaporating almost as quickly as his millions had supposedly disappeared. **********Huge sums of money may well have moved in and out of the accounts, but some officials in both countries now acknowledge that what most clearly went awry was the communication between Washington and Mexico City. **********Initially, the Deputy Treasury Secretary, Lawrence H. Summers, assured Congress that the Clinton Administration had delivered a ''strong protest'' to the Government of President Ernesto Zedillo. Justice Department officials said they, too, had confronted the Mexicans over the affair, demanding that the incident be investigated fully. **********Mexican officials have insisted from the start that the uproar over the money-laundering case was a  misunderstanding on the part of the United States. And in interviews over the last week, the Mexican officials  provided some evidence suggesting that if the drug-trafficking suspect,  Rigoberto Gaxiola Medina, got wind of the plan to seize his money, it happened after Mexican authorities moved against his bank accounts. **********According to Mexican officials, money did not flow out of Mr. Gaxiola's accounts in the days after the Mexican Government moved to freeze them. Instead, more than $15 million was deposited. **********''We can see that there was no flight of money,'' said a senior finance official in the Mexican Government, who spoke on the condition that he not be identified. ''There was more money in the accounts when they were seized than there was when we presented the complaint to seize them.'' **********Clinton Administration officials said they originally concluded that Mr. Gaxiola (pronounced ''gah-she-OH-la'') had probably been tipped off to the money laundering investigation because officials of Mexico's Finance Ministry had notified Mexico's Treasury Department on Jan. 8 that they were filing a seizure order that cited 15 of Mr. Gaxiola's accounts and involved more than $183 million. **********According to two confidential chronologies of the affair produced by American officials, agents of Mexico's National Institute for Combating Drugs did not act on the order until Jan. 20. **********Moreover, American officials noted, the Mexican official in charge of actually confiscating the money, Col. Jose Felix Name, the institute's chief of investigations, was himself suspect. The colonel was arrested and charged with allowing a man accused of being one of Mexico's most important money launderers, Humberto Garcia Abrego, to escape from custody. That incident came to light last month just as President Clinton was certifying Mexico's cooperation in the fight against drugs. **********Finally, when the Mexican authorities reported back to the United States Customs Service on the Gaxiola case, they said first that the  accounts in question had been ''depleted,'' and then that only about $16.7 million had been seized. **********In later interviews, Mexican officials said that the Americans had got it wrong from the start: the seizure order was for $183 million, the officials said, because that was all the money that Mr. Gaxiola was suspected of having laundered, the total he had deposited in all of the accounts over 30 months. The $183 million figure took no account of the frequent withdrawals, they said. **********The episode is unlikely to change any American minds about the depth of corruption in Mexican law enforcement. But it has opened a small window on the Clinton Administration's recent struggle to be tougher with Mexico on Capitol Hill while remaining conciliatory with the Mexican Government on its own turf. **********''We can't just beat them up every time something like this comes to light,'' one United States official involved in the case said of his Mexican counterparts. ''Stuff like this happens all the time. We still have to work with these people.'' **********Mexican finance officials did not present their version of events to their Treasury Department counterparts until after the reports of the case appeared in American newspapers. Why the explanation took so long is unclear, but it may have a lot to do with the way in which American ''protests'' were delivered. **********However thunderous the complaints of United States officials like Mr. Summers might have sounded when he related them to the Senate Foreign Relations Committee in an appearance on March 12, three Mexican officials said they interpreted the comments quite differently. **********Clinton Administration officials said an Assistant Attorney General, Mary Lee Warren, had protested the seeming disappearance of the money on March 11 at a meeting of law-enforcement officials of the two countries in Mexico City. But a senior Mexican Justice official who was present said ''in no way'' did the Americans complain about the matter. **********''There was no expression of protest,'' said the Mexican official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. ''They asked for a search for the money. All that was was a request that we work together to find the money.'' **********The same day, the Assistant Treasury Secretary in charge of enforcement matters, James E. Johnson, also telephoned the Mexican Deputy Finance Minister handing the Gaxiola case, Ismael Gomez Gordillo, and protested the matter to him, American officials said. **********But senior Mexican officials familiar with the conversation insisted that, once again, ''protest'' would be far too strong a word for what they said was Mr. Johnson's softly worded expression of concern and his  request that the two governments work together to sort the problem out. **********American officials said two United States Treasury officials, Mr. Summers and one of his aides, did voice displeasure over the incident more sharply. But they did so in telephone conversations with a different Deputy Finance Minister, who apparently knew little about the Gaxiola case. **********The Treasury Department's chief spokesman, Howard M. Schloss, suggested yesterday that United States officials were still not satisfied with the Mexicans' explanations. **********''There have been discussions with Mexican officials about this, but we are still investigating the matter,''  he said in a telephone interview. **********According to information that Mexican officials provided to Washington last week, Mr. Gaxiola's accounts contained only about $393,000 on Dec. 31. On Jan 10, just before the Mexican Government moved to seize the accounts, they contained $1.47 million. But on Jan. 23, after the money was frozen, the combined balance was up to $16.7 million. **********''If there was a tip-off,'' one Mexican official asked, ''why would Gaxiola make all those deposits?'' **********Senior Mexican officials said that in one major transfer, on Oct. 30, Mr. Gaxiola sent $15 million from one of his Mexico accounts to a Chase Manhattan Bank branch in New York, and then on to another bank, apparently in the Cayman Islands. **********But according to an inquiry by Sonora state officials, Mr. Gaxiola's accounts apparently contained more than $110 million at some point in  1996. The Mexican officials said they had no further information about where that money went or when it was withdrawn.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/07/busin.snippet: Treasury bonds with long maturities bounce back from early weakness to finish higher for second day, after Government's quarterly debt refunding concludes with strong demand; 30-year bond rises 17/32, to price of 102 19/32, with yield falling to 6...

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/07/busin.print_headline: CREDIT MARKETS; Price of Long Bond Rises a Bit as Auctions Stir Demand
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/07/busin.body_text: **********Treasury bonds with long maturities bounced back from early weakness yesterday to finish higher for a second day, after the Government's quarterly debt refunding concluded with strong demand. Shorter maturities lagged, however, and ended the session mixed. **********The 30-year bond rose 17/32, to a price of 102 19/32, while its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, fell to 6.18 percent, from 6.22 percent on Wednesday. **********There were two Government auctions yesterday -- one of 52-week bills, the other of 30-year bonds. Dealers first pushed yields higher in the market to make sure that the new securities would be more attactive to investors. Market participants were also cautious before today's employment report for October. **********In the auctions, traders saw decent demand as jitters continued in the equity markets, making Treasuries more attractive because of their relative safety. Small investors were said to be doing much of the buying in the bill auction. **********In the first auction, the Treasury sold $12 billion of new 52-week bills at an average rate of 5.14 percent. In the final leg of the Government's quarterly refunding, $10 billion of a new 30-year issue was priced to yield an average of 6.201 percent. **********Jack Ablin, executive vice president and head of the fixed-income department of Barnett Capital Advisors Inc. in Jacksonville, Fla., considered the auction results strong. ''It's going to pave the way for solid total returns going forward in the bond market,'' he said. **********Greg Jones, an economist with Briefing.com in Menlo Park, Calif.,  said that demand during the auction from domestic accounts was better than expected. **********He noted, however, that the 30-year sale was the better of the two auctions. The bid-to-cover ratio, representing the total number of bids compared with the total amount of the auction, was 2.82 to 1, a very strong level, for the 30-year bond. **********''Over the last 12 long-bond auctions,'' he said, ''the bid-to- cover ratio has averaged 2.42 to 1. Today's ratio was the best in 10 years.'' **********The market is now focused on the release of the October employment report. The consensus among economists is that the number of jobs added to American payrolls last month was about 200,000, with the unemployment rate unchanged at 4.9 percent. But Mr. Jones said he believed that even a relatively strong report might have a muted effect on the market. **********''Until certain issues are resolved about effects of the Asian crisis on the U.S., yields of Government securities are not expected to venture far from where they are now over the short term,'' he said. **********Treasuries with shorter maturities were weighed down yesterday by a surprise interest-rate increase overnight by the Bank of England. The central bank lifted its benchmark rate by a quarter of a percentage point, to 7.25 percent. **********The Treasury market interpreted the move as a reminder that economic growth exceeding long-term trend levels keeps central bankers inclined to tighten monetary policy. **********The following are the results of yesterday's bill and bond auctions: **********(000 omitted in dollar figures) **********Average Price   94.803 **********Discounted Rate   5.14% **********Coupon Yield   5.42% **********High Price   94.803 **********Discounted Rate   5.15% **********Coupon Yield   5.43% **********Low Price   94.793 **********Discounted Rate   5.14% **********Coupon Yield   5.42% **********Accepted at low price   08% **********Total applied for   $85,573,152 **********Accepted   $18,427,542 **********Noncompetitive   $713,142 **********The one-year bills mature Nov. 12, 1998. **********Average Price   98.970 **********Average Yield   6.201% **********Low Price   98.889 **********High Yield   6.207% **********High Price   99.010 **********Low Yield   6.198% **********Accepted at low price   44% **********Total applied for   $29,352,611 **********Accepted   $11,182,711 **********Noncompetitive   $292,611 **********Interest set at   6 1/8% **********The 30-year bonds mature Nov. 15, 2027.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/02/busin.snippet: US economy strengthens in July, adding 316,000 jobs and lowering unemployment rate to 4.8 percent, matching a 23-year low set in May; National Association of Purchasing Management reports that its overall index rose to 58.6 from 55.7 for the month...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/02/busin.main_headline: Report Shows Robust Growth With New Jobs
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/02/busin.print_headline: Report Shows Robust Growth With New Jobs
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/02/busin.body_text: **********The United States economy entered the summer with fresh strength, as an unexpected number of new jobs reduced the nation's unemployment rate to 4.8 percent last month, matching a 23-year low set in May, Government figures showed today. **********While analysts had predicted that the economy would rebound from a spring slowdown, today's data on jobs, combined with a private report on manufacturing, fanned fears that the rebound might be too strong. Some investors, who have been pushing bond and stock prices higher on the belief that growth is moderate and inflation tame, wondered whether the Federal Reserve would now need to apply the brakes with an increase in interest rates. **********''We've kind of shattered the old conviction of no Fed tightening,'' said Richard B. Hoey, chief economist at the Dreyfus Corporation. **********Bond and stock prices tumbled after the report, although stocks later recovered. The Dow Jones industrial average, which earlier fell 1 percent, ended the day down 28.57 points, or less than half a percent. Bond prices, however, continued to slide, driving the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond -- a benchmark for consumer interest rates like mortgages -- to 6.45 percent, from 6.29 percent on Thursday. Bond prices and their yields move in opposite directions. **********While the employment report revived Wall Street's fears of higher interest rates -- which eat into corporate profits and make bonds less attractive -- it confirmed the improved position of job seekers. The unemployment rate for black teen-agers, for example, fell by more than four percentage points, to 28.6 percent, the lowest since 1969. **********Over all, 316,000 jobs were added to the nation's payrolls last month, well above expectations and above a revised 228,000 jobs in June. When combined with a modest increase in the labor force, the jobless ranks contracted by 253,000 and the unemployment rate fell to 4.8 percent, from 5 percent in June -- matching the rate in May and the lowest since November 1973. **********At the same time, however, the average hourly earnings of production workers were unchanged while their weekly earnings fell because of a shorter workweek. **********The Clinton Administration applauded the July jobs report. **********''This morning we have further evidence that the strategy of balancing the budget while investing in our people and selling more American products around the world has helped to produce sustained prosperity for Americans,'' President Clinton said today. ''There is no doubt that the economic strategy we put in place in 1993 created the conditions for the extraordinary private-sector growth.'' **********July's gains in jobs showed that the May report was no fluke, said Nicholas S. Perna, economist for the Fleet Financial Group in Boston. ''The most important thing is that the unemployment rate is clearly below 5 percent again,'' he said. **********Mr. Perna and other economists worry that such low unemployment will soon drive up wages and spur inflation. **********Further signs of economic growth came in a survey today by the National Association of Purchasing Management. The association's report, which covers manufacturing, showed its overall index rising to 58.6 from 55.7, while the production index leaped by 8.4 points, to 64.4. **********Rising for the first time in four months, the group's price index surged to 53.6 from 48.1, with 17 percent of members reporting paying higher prices compared with 13 percent in May and June. The index of supplier deliveries climbed to 55.3 from 54.6, which the association said meant that ''deliveries are slowing at a faster rate.'' **********In other reports, the Commerce Department said that orders placed with factories rose 1.2 percent in June, more than recovering a drop of five-tenths of 1 percent in May. The department also said that Americans' income grew six-tenths of 1 percent in June, while spending rose three-tenths of 1 percent. **********While today's reports raised expectations that Federal Reserve policy makers might increase rates, few analysts expect them to do so at their next meeting on Aug. 19. **********Macroeconomic Advisers, a St. Louis consulting firm, told clients today that ''despite the continued benign behavior of wages, the further tightening of labor markets will be of concern to the Fed and keeps the possibility of a tightening alive, although almost certainly not before'' the Fed's September meeting. **********The 316,000 jump in employer payrolls last month was well above expectations, though the total was swollen by a 48,000 increase in local education that was statistically suspect because of changing seasonal patterns of the school year. Teachers are considered employed year-round, but others, like cafeteria workers and sports referees, move on and off education payrolls and may or may not take unrelated jobs. **********But the report showed a 31,000 advance in health service jobs following an unusually weak June, a 65,000 surge in retail trade -- half in restaurants and bars -- and a 26,000 gain for the finance-insurance-real estate category that was more than twice the monthly average over the last year. **********Factory jobs, however, were flat with 20,000 additional people producing durable goods more than offset by 25,000 fewer producing nondurables. **********The workweek shortened by 18 minutes and factory overtime also fell, suggesting to some that employers were confident enough to add permanent workers, which tends to reduce the need for long hours. The index of aggregate weekly hours fell seven-tenths of a point, to 139.9. **********Another reflection of July strength, analysts said, was the resumed increase in the percentage of the unemployed who voluntary left their latest job, typically because they thought they could readily find another one. This percentage was 12.6 percent in July, up from 12.2 in May and June and 11.2 in April. **********By region, the West showed the most improvement, with its July unemployment rate declining three-tenths of a point, to 5.3 percent. The Northeast and Midwest posted two-tenths of a point declines, to 5.5 percent and 3.6 percent, respectively, while the South edged down to 5 percent from 5.1.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/22/busin.snippet: Survey by Montgomery Asset Management finds investors expect average annual return of 34 percent over next 10 years, figure that shocks many financial advisers because it is so far above historical averages; Dow Jones industrial average rises 139 ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/22/busin.main_headline: Bull Market's Glitter May Be Blinding Investors
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/22/busin.print_headline: Bull Market's Glitter May Be Blinding Investors
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/22/busin.body_text: **********It was less than a week ago that stock investors fretted about the possibility of a huge decline as the 10th anniversary of the Oct. 19, 1987, crash approached. But the real concern may be whether investors have become too giddy. **********A recent survey of mutual fund investors would suggest so, raising the possibility they may be laying the basis for a major disappointment. **********The survey by Montgomery Asset Management in San Francisco found investors expected an average annual return of 34 percent over the next 10 years, a figure that shocked many financial advisers because it is so far above historical averages. **********''People have become completely enamored of the stock market; there's a love affair with it,'' said Raymond DeVoe, a market strategist at Legg Mason. ''There is this total blind belief that the market can do no wrong.'' **********That kind of bullish sentiment was clearly at work yesterday, as the Dow Jones industrial average rose sharply for the second consecutive session, up 139 points, or 1.75 percent, to close at 8,060.44. **********Strong earnings reports from I.B.M. and Microsoft -- technology bellwethers that represent the old breed and the new -- helped touch off a rally that also sent broader measures higher. **********The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index surged 16.67 points, or 1.74 percent, to 972.28, and the Nasdaq composite index jumped 27.09 points, or 1.61 percent, to 1,712.54. **********For the Dow, the gains of yesterday and Monday erased the nearly 200 points lost last week when the market tumbled just as it was nearing the anniversary of the crash a decade ago. Rebounds like that inspire confidence, analysts said. **********But what few investors know is that despite the outsized gains of recent years, the last 30 years have actually produced below-average returns, when adjusted for inflation. In other words, the great bull market that began in 1982 has not yet been powerful enough to undo the damage done in the previous 15 years, which included the bear market of 1973-74. **********For some Wall Street analysts who lived through less exalted times, therein lies a lesson: beware first-time investors. Although these may be extraordinary times, history suggests that long-term stock market returns are much tamer, and so it is unlikely that stocks will continue to rise at this torrid pace. **********In fact, Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, offered just such a warning two weeks ago, when he cautioned investors that it would be ''unrealistic'' to expect stock returns to keep rising at the current rate. **********For the last three years, the market has done little wrong. Few investors have suffered since the sharp increase in prices that helped send the Dow to gains of 33 percent in 1995, 26 percent in 1996 and 25 percent so far this year. **********Never before has the Dow had three consecutive years with gains of 20 percent or more. Logical Information Machines, a research concern in Chicago, said that the current three-year run was one of the greatest of all time. **********Those kinds of returns bolster optimism. Earlier this year, the Montgomery survey showed investors expected annual returns of about 22 percent over the next 10 years, compared with 34 percent in the most recent tally. **********At a 34 percent pace, the Dow average would exceed 120,000 in the year 2007. That is assuming a dividend yield of about 3 percent, which is well above current prices. **********Is such a gain likely? Theodore Aronson at Aronson & Partners, a money management firm based in Philadelphia, said the best 10-year run for the Dow average was 17.1 percent, in the period ending in June 1959. What does Mr. Aronson think of those who are expecting a 34 percent return? ''They must have polled the loony bin,'' he said. **********Jeremy J. Siegel, a professor at the Wharton School at the University of Pennsylvania, is gentler. He cautioned investors not to get too excited. **********His studies show that after inflation, stocks achieve an average annual return of about 7 percent, going all the way back to 1802. In spite of wars, social upheavals and and other bumps on the road of history, stock returns tend to settle at that level. **********''The long-run return is always the same, about 7 percent,'' Mr. Siegel said. ''I've found this remarkable stability over time.'' **********In the last 30 years, however, stock returns have trailed slightly, he said. The average stock return from 1966 to 1997 was about 6.03 percent compounded annually, nearly a percentage point below the historical average of 6.99 percent, after inflation. **********In mid-1967, for instance, the Dow stood at 860.25. And 15 years later, in mid-1982, it stood at 811.94 -- a loss of nearly 6 percent, but much more when inflation is factored in. **********Why take note of such figures? Because many investors are too optimistic, analysts say, and the higher the expectation, the greater the possibility that some will be scared out of the market during a sudden downturn. **********''We have a stock market that's full of virgins,'' said Ron Chernow, a financial historian and author of ''The Death of the Banker.'' **********''They've had a very atypical experience in the market; it's had this very pleasant attitude of going up all the time,'' he said. ''So we don't know how they'll behave during downturns.'' **********Because so many of the nation's financial assets are locked up in the stock market, almost automatically, through 401(k) retirement plans, Mr. Chernow said he believed the market might be secure from a huge collapse. **********But like other analysts and historians, he worries that the kind of crowd psychology that has driven prices ever higher could reverse course and depress a whole generation of first-time investors. **********ON THE WEB **********The latest stock and mutual fund quotations, along with news updates, are available on the Internet from The New York Times on the Web: www.nytimes.com

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/25/world.snippet: Mohammed Khatami, who campaigned on platform of tolerance and social reform, has been elected President of Iran in landslide, defeating Ali Akbar Nategh-Nouri, candidate favored by ruling Islamic clerics; photo (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/25/world.main_headline: MODERATE LEADER IS ELECTED IN IRAN BY A WIDE MARGIN
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/25/world.print_headline: MODERATE LEADER IS ELECTED IN IRAN BY A WIDE MARGIN
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/25/world.body_text: **********In a surprising political upset, a candidate who campaigned on a platform of tolerance and social reform has been elected President of Iran in a landslide, defeating the candidate favored by the ruling Islamic clerics, according to results announced today. **********The winner, Mohammed Khatami, who was forced out of the Government five years ago after conservatives accused him of being too permissive, was supported by millions of Iranian voters who are increasingly opposed to the controls on private and public life imposed by the 18-year-old Islamic Government. **********Although the power of the Iranian President is limited, and no major foreign policy changes are expected, Mr. Khatami will be at the head of a new Government that he will appoint and his election marks the first time since the Islamic revolution of 1979 that a figure associated with moderation has won a broad mandate. **********$(Mr. Khatami won 20.5 million votes, or 69 percent of the 29.1 million ballots cast in the election on Friday, Iranian radio and televison reported early Sunday after the final tally. His closest rival, the Speaker of the Parliament, had 25 percent. About 90 percent of the eligible voters went to the polls, the radio said.$) **********The four candidates who ran for President were handpicked by the Council of Guardians, the country's highest religious body, and the fact that the council approved Mr. Khatami's candidacy signifies that he is considered well within the ideological boundaries that it considers acceptable. But he is the first Iranian leader since the revolution that overthrew Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi who has dared to say that many revolutionary policies need to be reappraised. **********Mr. Khatami did not issue a victory statement, but his principal opponent, Ali Akbar Nategh-Nouri, conceded defeat this afternoon. **********''I hope that you will prove able to comply with the Constitution and all our laws,'' Mr. Nategh-Nouri said in a statement addressed to his rival. ''I wish you luck and success, and will cooperate fully with you.'' **********The results showed that Mr. Khatami did well not only in cities and towns, where intellectuals are concentrated and where people are more resentful of the Government's social and economic policies, but also in villages and rural outposts. **********It was an almost unimaginable triumph for a candidate who had been considered an outsider since beginning his campaign in January and who had been attacked in the pro-Government press as a liberal with weak Islamic credentials. **********There were signs all week that Mr. Khatami was attracting wide public support. But many Iranians, accustomed to a form of politics in which the religious leaders always seemed able to impose their will, doubted that he could win. Leading clerics, including Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, Iran's supreme leader, had made clear that they favored the candidacy of Mr. Nategh-Nouri. **********There is no modern tradition in Iran of street demonstrations to cheer election results, and Teheran was quiet today. But in some offices and homes, there were broad smiles that reflected a sense of satisfaction and wonder at what the electorate had managed to achieve. **********The vote showed Iranians that they have the power to influence their political structure, something many had come to doubt after generations of autocratic rule, first under the Shah and now under the Islamic Government. It also showed that people here no longer feel obligated to follow the direction of their political and religious leaders, a change that could have profound implications. **********Mr. Khatami will not take office until August. He is expected to name an entirely new Cabinet, replacing among other people Foreign Minister Ali Akbar Velayati, who has been the Government's most recognized international spokesman since the days when he defended the takeover of the United States Embassy and seizure of hostages here in 1979. **********$(A White House spokesman said: ''We're watching the situation carefully and have no opposition to the Iranian people or an Islamic government. We need to see if there will be actual change in behavior in those issues which have concerned us in the past such as terrorism, proliferation of weapons of mass destruction and human rights.''$) **********The new Government is likely to include more technocrats and fewer religious figures. The departing President, Ali Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani, who was barred by law from seeking re-election and who obliquely supported Mr. Khatami during the campaign, will probably be one of his leading allies. **********Mr. Rafsanjani has been viewed as a moderate, though he was stymied at many points by religious forces. He will continue to hold considerable power as head of the Expediency Council, a powerful body charged with mediating between political and religious leaders. **********In an interview today as the results were being announced, Ahmad Borghani, a close aide and spokesman for the President-elect, said Mr. Khatami would ''try to make changes as best he can.'' **********He said one of the first priorities would be legalizing political parties, which have been effectively outlawed since the revolution. **********''Of course Mr. Khatami will not continue the present restrictions on the press and media,'' Mr. Borghani said. ''He will have an open policy toward them.'' **********Mr. Borghani also suggested that the new Government would seek to curb the police and religious militia whose members patrol streets and neighborhoods in search of people who are having parties, listening to forbidden music, watching imported videos or satellite television, playing cards or otherwise violating the social code. **********''We have heard Mr. Khatami say that people should not investigate other people's private lives,'' Mr. Borghani said. ''If people want to listen to music, they should turn it down so it does not disturb their neighbors. Otherwise it is fine.'' **********In a document last week outlining his principles, Mr. Khatami said he was dedicated to ''countering superstition and fanaticism'' and ''assuring civil rights and freedoms of citizens.'' He pledged to curb censorship, to recognize the ''variety and diversity of attitudes'' and to combat the view ''that politics should be monopolized by a specific group.'' **********Young people formed the backbone of Mr. Khatami's political campaign. Throughout the country they volunteered with an enthusiasm many had never before shown for a political candidate. In a country where 70 percent of the population is said to be under the age of 25, they form a key constituency that does not feel bound by the ideology that brought the revolutionary Government to power when they were young or even before they were born. **********To satisfy them, Mr. Khatami will not only have to give them more personal freedom but also make economic changes that will cut the power of state-backed monopolies and end what he has called ''unfair economic concessions.'' **********The other group that gave especially strong support to Mr. Khatami was women. Because they played an important role in the 1979 revolutionary movement and because many of them supported the eight-year war with Iraq, women here have great political power. **********Although under Islamic law introduced following the revolution they must still cover themselves in public, they have more rights than women in some other Muslim countries. But many are assertive and unsatisfied, and complain about laws that discriminate against them. **********In addition to facing a possibly unhappy group of clerics who were dubious about his candidacy to begin with, Mr. Khatami will find the 275-member Parliament less than friendly. Most members supported his rival, and many are deeply suspicious of all reformist thought.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/29/busin.snippet: Cie Financiere Richemont of Switzerland plans to buy 30 percent of Vendome Luxury Group of Britain that it does not own for 1.036 billion pounds ($1.73 billion) (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/29/busin.main_headline: Richemont to Buy The Rest of Vendome
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/29/busin.print_headline: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS; Richemont to Buy The Rest of Vendome
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/29/busin.body_text: **********Cie. Financiere Richemont of Switzerland said yesterday that it planned to buy the 30 percent of the Vendome Luxury Group of Britain that it did not own for $:1.036 billion ($1.73 billion), consolidating its hold on the group's global luxury brands like Cartier and Piaget watches and Montblanc pens. The South African- controlled Richemont said it would offer 495 pence in cash for each Vendome share it did not already own, which put a value on the company of $:3.454 billion. **********Vendome shares, which fell 27 percent in the four weeks through Nov. 20, when they reached a four-year low, closed yesterday at 472.5 pence, up 79 pence. Vendome's board needs to approve the offer. Richemont's chief executive, Johann Rupert, said he was confident that Vendome would accept his company's offer.
