https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/22/busin.body_text: **********Fujitsu Ltd., which already owns 42 percent of the Amdahl Corporation, raised its bid for the remainder by 3.3 percent, to $878 million, in an effort to settle shareholder lawsuits against the proposed purchase. The two companies said Fujitsu would raise the offer for Amdahl, a mainframe computer maker in Sunnyvale, Calif., to $12.40 a share from $12. Amdahl's shareholders have filed at least a dozen lawsuits seeking to stop the acquisition. The suits contend that Amdahl's directors failed to protect the interests of smaller shareholders. Amdahl's shares rose 37.5 cents, to $12.25, on the American Stock Exchange.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/23/world.snippet: Turkey, secular Islamic country which straddles East and West and has adopted mostly Western-syle values, is suffering from worsening identity crisis as it remains refubbed by European Union in attempts to attain membership; accuses Europeans of b...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/23/world.main_headline: Turkey Finds European Union Door Slow to Open
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/23/world.print_headline: Turkey Finds European Union Door Slow to Open
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/23/world.body_text: **********Nowhere in the world is the divide between Europe and Asia as palpable as in this majestic city. Only here can one sit in a European cafe and gaze across a narrow waterway to Asia. Behind are Vienna, Berlin and Paris; on the other side lies a vast,  unbroken expanse that stretches to Baghdad, Tashkent and Beijing. **********This geography has bequeathed to Turks an eternal identity crisis. For centuries they have been asking themselves where they truly belong. **********Today the question is more urgent than ever. Turkey is demanding entry into the European Union but cannot pry the door open. Turks are beginning to feel that Europe does not want them, and to wonder if they should look for friends elsewhere. **********European leaders insist that before Turkey can be considered for membership, it must improve its human rights record, end its war against Kurdish rebels and resolve its disputes with Greece. Many Turks consider these to be hypocritical arguments behind which Europeans hide their prejudice against Muslims. **********''At every turn, Turkey is being snubbed by Europe,'' said Baran Tuncer, an economist and former World Bank official. ''Countries like Bulgaria are being considered for membership ahead of us, countries which over the years have had no relation whatsoever with European political or economic values. The subtext is fear of what we represent religiously and culturally. People here are beginning to resent this attitude quite strongly, and anti-Western politicians are exploiting the resentment and fueling it.'' **********Membership in the European Union promises a host of benefits for Turkey, mostly economic but also psychological, and would hold out the prospect of steady progress toward greater democracy and prosperity here. Prime Minister Necmettin Erbakan, modern Turkey's first Islamist leader, says he is as committed to European Union membership as any of his predecessors. But some militants in his party would, in the words of one adviser to the Government, ''love an excuse to throw up their hands, say 'Europe doesn't want us' and turn in another direction.'' **********This impulse was shown in December, when Mr. Erbakan refused to go to a European Union summit meeting in Dublin. He said the union  was insulting Turkey because the dinner to which he was invited was scheduled after the meeting's official end, when not all heads of government would be present. **********Many Turks applauded Mr. Erbakan's gesture, but European leaders took it as a signal that Turkey was not really serious about joining the union, or did not know how to press its case. As further evidence that Mr. Erbakan's Government does not understand the ground rules of diplomacy, Europeans have pointed to the threat by Turkey, a NATO member, to veto NATO expansion if it does not receive better treatment from the European Union. **********European ambivalence toward Turkey is hardly a new phenomenon. It dates back hundreds of years to an era when ''the Turk'' was a European archetype, a symbol of ''the other'' and even the antichrist. **********Ottoman armies nearly took Vienna in 1683, and for a time the central question of Europe was whether the Ottomans would sweep into France and Germany, turning the continent into a vassal of the Sultan. **********Today, Europe's treatment of Turkey is a sensitive subject not only here but also in the broad band of Turkic nations that stretches across the Caucasus and Central Asia. The success or failure of Turkish efforts is likely to affect perceptions of Europe across this region. **********In January 1996, Turkey entered into a customs union with the Europeans under which both sides dropped most tariffs and other trade restrictions. But rather than bringing Turkey closer to Europe, the agreement has been a source of new discord. **********''The customs union created misconceptions on both sides,'' said Michael Lake, the European Union envoy in Ankara. ''The European side felt that Turkey would be preoccupied with making it work and not press for full membership for some time. Turkey had the misperception that the customs union was a stepping stone toward full membership in the next year or two. This led to a drifting apart, which both sides are now determined to reverse. **********''I do not feel that if the membership of Turkey arises naturally in the fullness of time, the E. U. can sustain a veto on the basis of religion or culture. That would undermine the importance we place on democracy. Turkey is the only fully democratic Muslim country in the world. To keep Turkey out on this basis would send the wrong signal to the whole Mediterranean basin and the world at large.'' **********Not every European official is so sure. In an unusually frank statement this month, Hans van Mierlo, Foreign Minister of the Netherlands, said it was ''time for us in Europe to be honest'' about the religious aspect of the issue. **********''There is a problem of a large Muslim state,'' Mr. van Mierlo told a committee of the European Parliament. ''Do we want that in Europe? It is an unspoken question.'' **********Other obstacles to Turkey's membership are clearer. Certainly the most emotional is human rights. A host of reports by groups that have investigated conditions here say that torture is regularly practiced in Turkish jails. In addition, laws restrict freedom of expression, and dozens of writers and journalists are in jail. Army tactics in the war against Kurdish separatists often seem at least as brutal as those used by the separatists themselves. **********''The human rights situation is a disaster,'' said a European Ambassador in Ankara. ''Turkey is far, far away from what the European Parliament will insist on.'' **********Government officials acknowledge this problem, although they insist that it is not as serious as some outsiders say. They are considering a series of measures ranging from repeal of laws that restrict free speech to creation of a judicial police force that would monitor conditions in detention centers. **********On other issues that have been raised as obstacles to Turkish membership, Turkish negotiators have in recent months shown a new flexibility that contrasts with, or complements, the more militant position taken by Prime Minister Erbakan. **********They are offering to prevent a flood of low-wage Turkish laborers into Western Europe and to refrain from claiming the large sums of aid that would be necessary to bring rural Turkey up to European standards of development. **********In recent weeks, another concern was added to the list as officials in several European countries suggested that Turkish officials were protecting heroin smugglers. **********The diplomat who is leading the Turkish bid to join the European Union, Onur Oymen, secretary general of the Foreign Ministry, acknowledges that he faces ''an uphill battle.'' **********''If the E. U. presents objective criteria and says that the first countries which fulfill them will be the first to be admitted, we can accept that,'' Mr. Oymen said. ''Let talks begin with all applicants, see which ones reach the targets, and then admit them in that order. What is really unacceptable to us is if different standards, different criteria are applied to us than are applied to other countries. **********''It would be a very great mistake to make the E. U. a religious or cultural entity. It would be against everything we have learned about European values. We do not want a cultural or religious iron curtain to replace the political iron curtain that we fought for 50 years to remove.'' **********Many foreigners here believe that although well-organized anti-Turkish lobbies are hard at work in Europe, Turkey could do much more to counter them. They say that Turkish governments have not tried hard enough to present their country's positive side. **********''Behind us are 600 years as masters of the Ottoman Empire,'' said Yilidrim Akturk, an American-trained economist who is a member of Parliament. ''We are children of the Ottoman experience. We don't believe in bending over, even if it's to pick up a big check. We want to preserve our pride.'' **********Turkish diplomats who are waging the campaign for European Union membership believe they are engaged in a historic effort crucial to their country's future, and cannot imagine that they will be kept out forever. **********''Even in the worst of times,'' observed Omer Akbel, the chief Foreign Ministry spokesman, ''we were the sick man of Europe, not Asia.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/02/busin.snippet: Airlines' new stress on profitability over market share has helped them smooth out industry's historically wide-swinging business cycle and raise fares; industry is expected to report record 1996 profits; big new plane orders raise prospects that ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/02/busin.main_headline: Expansion Control Helps Smooth Airlines' Wild Earnings Ride
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/02/busin.print_headline: Expansion Control Helps Smooth Airlines' Wild Earnings Ride
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/02/busin.body_text: **********The airline industry has made remarkable progress in recent years in smoothing out its historically wide-swinging business cycle. For a lot of consumers, that is too bad. **********After all, it has long been one of the industry's failings that in good times, the airlines as a group would order far more aircraft than they really needed. By the time the planes were delivered, traffic growth had typically fallen off, leaving too many planes for too few passengers. And because an empty seat is worthless to the airlines, they would start bruising fare wars -- to the cheers of travelers -- to fill their seats. **********The most recent such bonanza occurred in the summer of 1992, when airlines cut fares as much as 50 percent on many routes. **********That fare sale and the effects of the Persian Gulf war on oil prices and travel were some of the many problems that contributed to the American airline industry's cumulative losses of more than $13 billion between 1990 and 1994. **********These losses apparently taught the industry a lesson about overexpansion: Profits are more important than market share. It was an obvious lesson in hindsight, but required the airlines to discard a long-cherished notion that size and market share were the paths to profits. **********After a couple of years with a good economy and the tight control maintained by airlines over the number of seats in the market, the industry is expected to report record profits for 1996. This discipline has given the airlines a rare ability to set fares at profitable levels. **********This means that fares have been going up. Tom Parsons, editor of Best Fares magazine, keeps a running tally of fare increases, and said that the industry had raised fares more than 35 times since 1992. Now, those same round-trip tickets for flights between New York and the West Coast that sold for less than $200 in 1992 cost at least twice that much, even at sale prices. **********Mr. Parsons said that fare increases could be attributed to more than tighter airline capacity and a healthy economy. Airlines now have a more sophisticated understanding of traffic patterns on their routes, and know more precisely what travelers are willing to pay. **********''When the airlines are doing well, consumers are going to have to work harder to get the big savings,'' Mr. Parsons said. **********However, consumers still hoping for the industry to return to its self-defeating ways were given new reasons to be optimistic about fares recently. Shortly after the industry appeared to be on its way to an unusual run of sustained profitability, it resumed the old habits that had led to excess capacity and had exaggerated the effects of the broader economic cycles. **********The USAir Group, for example, placed an order in early November for up to 400 aircraft from Airbus Industrie. That order, however, is contingent upon USAir management's getting an agreement from its labor groups to lower its costs, currently the highest in the industry. **********Two weeks later, American Airlines, a unit of the AMR Corporation, placed a firm order for 103 new jets from the Boeing Company, and said that it might order several hundred more planes from Boeing as part of a deal in which it committed itself to making Boeing its sole supplier of aircraft for the next 20 years. **********But the new planes do not necessarily mean more capacity. Because of tough Federal noise standards that go into effect in 2000, many of the new planes will simply replace older models that will be sold outside the United States because the cost of modifying them to meet the tougher standards is too great. And despite the large orders from American and USAir, aircraft orders and scheduled deliveries for the industry last year still remain below earlier peaks. **********Even so, the new orders are prompting many industry analysts on Wall Street to re-evaluate their estimates of capacity growth. **********Samuel C. Buttrick, an airline analyst at Paine Webber, said that his estimate for the airlines' total capacity growth for 1997 is 4.3 percent. Two years ago, he had projected 3.5 percent. The capacity growth, he said, suggests that airline executives are losing some sense of self-discipline. ''There is no question they are losing their religion,'' Mr. Buttrick said. **********Will that mean a return to the kind of fare wars that prompted so many spontaneous trips in 1992? With the airline industry's notorious unpredictability, no one is willing to guess. But for now, the industry is enjoying the rare thrill of profitability. **********''There is nothing more exciting,'' David A. Swierenga, chief economist at the Air Transport Association, said, ''than making money.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/06/world.snippet: Swiss Government proposes setting up $4.7 billion fund and using interest on money to help victims of Holocaust and other calamities; under proposal, Switzerland would increase stated value of its gold reserves to correspond to current world marke...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/06/world.main_headline: Swiss to Use Gold for a Holocaust Fund
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/06/world.print_headline: Swiss to Use Gold for a Holocaust Fund
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/06/world.body_text: **********The Swiss Government today proposed setting up a $4.7 billion fund and using the interest on the money to help victims of the Holocaust and other calamities. **********Under the proposal, Switzerland would increase the stated value of its gold reserves to correspond to current world market prices, and use the difference as the principal for the new fund. **********The plan represents the boldest financial maneuver yet by the Swiss to gain moral high ground in the dispute over the country's dealings with Nazi Germany in World War II. **********At the same time, the Swiss National Bank offered to donate about $70 million to a separate fund set up last week for short-term help to Holocaust survivors, doubling the value of that fund. **********Both proposals require the Swiss Parliament's approval to take effect, and they could face major opposition if right-wing Swiss politicians decide to campaign against them. **********The Government's proposal today, announced at an unusual breakfast-time session of Parliament by President Arnold Koller, represented not only a far greater commitment of money than previously discussed but also an attempt to walk the thin line between international pressure and domestic reluctance to use taxpayers' money for what many Swiss regard as an unjustified acknowledgment of wartime guilt. **********The plan would not involve extra spending by the Government. **********Switzerland, which has been under increasing pressure from the World Jewish Congress and its political allies in New York and Washington to atone for both its wartime dealings with Nazi Germany and the resistance of its private banks to helping relatives gain access to bank accounts and other assets belonging to Holocaust victims. **********Last month the Swiss Government finally agreed to share with Jewish organizations the administration of a separate fund, financed principally by Swiss private banks and, as of today, the Swiss National Bank, to compensate Holocaust survivors living in Eastern Europe, Israel, the United States and elsewhere. **********But the proposal today went much further, offering, as President Koller told a meeting of the upper and lower houses of Parliament here, to create a ''Swiss Foundation for Solidarity'' drawn from funds accruing from the increased estimate of the value of its gold deposits. **********Switzerland has kept the value of its gold low by estimating the worth of its deposits at about one-third of the price they would bring on world markets. **********The interest from the new fund would ''be destined for victims of poverty and catastrophes, of genocide and other severe breaches of human rights, such as of course victims of the Holocaust,'' Mr. Koller said. He did not specify other likely beneficiaries from the proposed foundation. **********Mr. Koller said the foundation could be created by next year, the 150th anniversary of Switzerland's foundation as a modern state, and would be used ''half in Switzerland, half abroad.'' **********He put the overall value of the proposed fund at ''about seven billion Swiss francs,'' or $4.7 billion at current exchange rates, yielding several hundred million dollars a year in interest. **********''This shows us that the Swiss people have finally got it,'' Israel Singer, the secretary general of the World Jewish Congress, said in a telephone interview from New York, reflecting a broadly positive response by Jewish groups in the United States, Israel and Switzerland. **********But the proposal could further deepen a rift in Swiss society, particularly between younger people who believe that their country played an ambiguous, if not collaborationist, role toward Nazi Germany and older Swiss who see outside pressure for atonement as a Jewish conspiracy. **********''The Federal Council has lost its head,'' said Christoph Blocher, a leading rightist. ''These are public assets, not just any money.'' **********Swiss Government officials say they fear that Mr. Blocher could try to organize a referendum to block the entire proposal. **********Until today, the Swiss Government and the Swiss National Bank had held back from committing themselves financially. **********But President Koller's largely conciliatory speech sought to defend Switzerland against its critics and acknowledge that Switzerland's wartime neutrality had ''its bright sides and its dark sides.'' **********''Today we do not have to feel ashamed that we escaped the war,'' Mr. Koller said today. ''Every country defended primarily its own interests. And we, too, were entitled to this right. We had the right to survive. **********''But nevertheless the question arises as to whether and to what extent all Swiss citizens managed to satisfy the high moral demands during the war period,'' he said. ''That means that we have to publicly admit self-criticism and admit the dark sides of that difficult period.'' **********The announcement coincided with the opening session here of a commission of foreign and Swiss historians, appointed by the Government, to investigate Switzerland's dealings with Nazi Germany. **********In addition, a separate commission led by Paul A. Volcker, the former chairman of the United States Federal Reserve, is investigating the question of dormant accounts left by people killed in the Holocaust. And a third inquiry into the affair is being conducted by an interagency group in Washington led by Stuart E. Eisenstat, Deputy Commerce Secretary for International Trade. **********That group is set to publish a report of its findings this month, leading to speculation that one reason for the timing of today's announcement was to pre-empt further criticism from Washington of Switzerland's wartime behavior. **********''None of this would have happened without outside pressure,'' said an American Jewish official with close knowledge of the negotiations leading to the Swiss reversal. **********According to Hans Meyer, the chairman of the Swiss National Bank, Switzerland's gold deposits are calculated for central bank bookkeeping purposes at a fixed price equivalent to $117 an ounce, compared to the current market price of about $350. **********By calculating its gold deposits at the free market price, Mr. Meyer said, ''several billion francs could be transferred in gold'' to the proposed foundation. **********''This would permit investments yielding annual income of several hundred million francs which would be available for fulfilling the foundation's objectives,'' he said. ''It is envisioned that the foundation would sell the gold transferred to it in the market of a period of approximately 10 years and invest the proceeds in interest-bearing assets.'' **********Those sales, he said, should not affect the market price of either gold or the Swiss franc. Dealers reported, however, that the gold price dipped today after the announcement. **********Werner Abegg, a spokesman for the National Bank in Zurich, said the Swiss bookkeeping price of gold deposits predated agreements in the 1970's that created a floating open market for gold. **********While the Swiss gold deposits are currently valued overall at 11.9 billion Swiss francs, he said, their market value is much higher. But, he said, the process of changing the Constitution to permit a revaluation of gold assets would take time and could require a referendum among the Swiss people. **********Swiss Government and banking officials, and American Jewish officials, said that while the previous fund established by private Swiss banks and the National Bank would provide short-term help for needy Holocaust survivors, the latest proposal offered the prospect of long-term commitments. **********In addition, said Mr. Abegg at the Swiss National Bank, the proposed foundation would mean that only interest on investments -- not the principal -- left Switzerland.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/26/busin.snippet: Toyota Motor Corporation, largest Japanese automobile manufacturer, says it will become first company to sell low-polluting hybrid vehicle, with both electric motor and gasoline engine, to mass market; will begin selling compact hybrid car with 1....
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/26/busin.main_headline: Toyota to Sell Hybrid-Power Car in Japan
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/26/busin.print_headline: Toyota to Sell Hybrid-Power Car in Japan
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/03/26/busin.body_text: **********The Toyota Motor Corporation said today that it would become the first company to sell a low-polluting hybrid vehicle, with both an electric motor and a gasoline engine, to a mass market. **********The company, the largest Japanese auto maker, said it would begin selling a compact hybrid car with a 1.5-liter engine in Japan this year. Executives said they had no immediate plans to sell the vehicles in the United States, though that is a possibility later. ''We are very confident about what this offers,'' said Akihiro Wada, an executive vice president of Toyota, ''but we would like to get reaction and criticism by testing it in the Japanese market first.'' **********Hybrid vehicles significantly reduce emissions compared with gasoline-powered cars but are far more practical than fully electric cars. They cannot achieve the zero-emission level of the fully electric car, which California regulators have been seeking. But many auto engineers believe that the hybrid approach represents a reasonable compromise. **********Toyota estimates that its hybrid car will get 66 miles a gallon of gasoline in Japanese fuel-economy tests, twice the efficiency of a similar-size Corolla. Emissions of carbon dioxide would be cut in half, and those of carbon monoxide, hydrocarbons and nitrogen oxides reduced 90 percent. **********Many other companies are working on hybrid vehicles. Detroit's Big Three -- General Motors, Ford and Chrysler -- are pursuing them, in an effort partly financed by the Department of Energy, to develop a high-efficiency supercar. Audi, a division of Volkswagen, is said to have a hybrid car using a diesel engine ready for sale later this year, and Renault has also announced hybrid technology. **********Until recently, much of the emphasis in cutting automotive air pollution had focused on fully electric vehicles, because California was requiring that 2 percent of the cars sold there beginning in the 1998 model year have zero-emission levels. **********But last year, with auto makers insisting that it would be a long time until it was possible to make an electric vehicle that would satisfy consumers, California dropped that deadline, though it is still aiming for 10 percent of vehicles sold in 2003 to have no emissions. **********Takehisa Yaegashi, chief engineer for Toyota's hybrid system, said the company hoped that California might further relax its requirements and accept hybrid vehicles instead of electric ones. **********General Motors in December began offering an electric vehicle in California and Arizona, but has sold only a few dozen a month. The Honda Motor Company, Toyota and possibly others are expected to begin sales of electric vehicles in California this year. **********The hybrid vehicles could avoid a major shortcoming of fully electric ones -- the limited range of the batteries. G.M.'s electric vehicle goes only about 90 miles before the battery must be recharged, a process that takes about three hours. **********But the hybrid vehicle can also travel farther because it uses gasoline. And energy from the gasoline engine can recharge the battery while the car is in motion, so that no external recharging is needed. **********Hybrids can achieve high efficiency and low pollution because of the way they combine dissimilar propulsion systems. Gasoline systems are good for quick refueling, but get zero miles a gallon when the car is idling; in a hybrid, that energy can be converted to current for the batteries. And if the engine runs at a constant speed, the antipollution system can operate at most efficient levels for that speed. **********Electric systems are clean and powerful but rely on slow recharging, which is cumbersome if the car has to stand still. And the gasoline engines used in hybrids can be small and light, because they do not have to be big enough to meet peak demand -- acceleration to highway speeds; for that, they can get help from the electric motor. **********Because hybrid cars can get by with smaller batteries, they also should cost significantly less than fully electric cars, Toyota executives said. They would not disclose the price of their new car, but said they aimed to keep it no more than about $4,000 more expensive than a similar-size conventional car, implying a price of less than $20,000 for a compact model. By contrast, the G.M. electric vehicle, which seats only two people, has a price of $34,000. **********Toyota officials suggested that they expected to sell significantly more hybrid vehicles than the several hundred a year electric cars that most makers expect to sell. But they would not announce a sales target and conceded that the hybrid car's higher price compared with conventional cars would limit sales. **********In Toyota's hybrid vehicle, power from the gasoline engine is split into two paths -- one directly turning the wheels and the other operating an electric generator. The generator's electricity output can be used to turn a motor that drives the wheels, or to charge the battery. The proportion of power allocated to each path is automatically adjusted to achieve maximum efficiency. **********When the car is started and moving slowly, only the electric motor is used because gasoline engines operate inefficiently at such low speeds. In normal driving the gasoline engine is used, perhaps assisted by the electric motor during acceleration. When the car is slowed, the gasoline engine is shut off and the momentum of revolving wheels helps recharge the nickel-metal hydride battery. **********Toyota is not banking solely on hybrids but is pursuing many different technologies for increasing fuel efficiency and lowering emissions, such as lean-burning gasoline engines, electric vehicles and cars that use other kinds of fuel.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/05/busin.snippet: Discount shops that sell little but cigarettes are rapidly opening in urban and suburban areas; such outlets now account for 11 percent of cigarette sales, up from about 1 percent in 1992; outlets divert sales from stores frequented by children, b...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/05/busin.main_headline: Catering to Adults Only Is Becoming Bigger Plus
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/05/busin.print_headline: Catering to Adults Only Is Becoming Bigger Plus
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/05/busin.body_text: **********When Mildred Lockhart ran out of Salems, she used to pay $3.10 for a new pack at a newsstand in the Loop skyscraper where she works as an accountant. These days, though, Ms. Lockhart walks half a block in this city's central business district to the new Cigarettes Cheaper shop, where her Salems cost just $2.39. **********''It's even less than at the convenience store near my home on the South Side,'' she said. ''It would be great if there were more places like this.'' **********Chances are good there will be. Even though the nation is preparing to restrict cigarette retailing, shops that sell little but cigarettes at discount prices -- once found mainly just over the borders of cities and states with high tobacco taxes -- have been rapidly colonizing urban storefronts and suburban strip malls. Tobacco is anything but a growth industry in America, but the cigarette stores are betting that the harsher climate will stoke demand for specialized retailing, just as ''category killer'' vendors have emerged for things like toys and books. **********Cigarette shops serve one goal of tobacco foes by diverting sales of cigarettes from stores frequented by children. But health authorities fret that they also give smokers a way to dodge the impact of the price increases envisioned in the tentative $368 billion settlement with tobacco manufacturers. **********In 1992, there were only about 400 such stores, handling a little more than 1 percent of cigarettes sold. By last year that had jumped to around 4,500 outlets, accounting for 11 percent of sales, according to the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company, the nation's second-largest tobacco company, after the Philip Morris Companies. **********''This is the way cigarettes should be sold everywhere,'' said Ned Roscoe, vice president of the family-owned Premium Tobacco Stores Inc., which owns the three-year-old Cigarettes Cheaper chain. The company, based in Benicia, Calif., has 390 stores in eight states in the West and Midwest. **********Although such specialty stores have for the most part shied away from states like New York that have high state cigarette taxes, Mr. Roscoe says he plans to be in the top 20 metropolitan markets, including the New York area, in the next year and a half. **********But Mr. Roscoe and other industry insiders say new cigarette stores are opening at a slower pace this year, amid the uncertainty about tobacco regulation. Cigarettes Cheaper, which has expanded most aggressively, has been unable to agree with potential investors on terms for financing more growth. And some supermarkets and convenience stores are providing tougher competition by building ''stores within stores'' featuring tobacco. **********The future of the $45 billion domestic tobacco industry, however, clearly includes tougher restrictions on marketing and higher prices. And both trends could give the cigarette stores a new leg up on less focused competitors like grocers -- and even on convenience stores, which have doubled their share of tobacco sales to nearly half the market since 1984. **********''The cigarette stores are on the launching pad,'' said Kenneth Harris, a consultant who follows tobacco retailing for Cannondale Associates of Evanston, Ill. One of their main advantages, he said, is that they are typically adult-only enterprises with better-than-average track records on avoiding sales to minors. **********''It may ultimately make licensing and preventing youth access easier,'' said Dr. David Burns, a researcher at the University of California at San Diego, who has been an adviser to plaintiffs' lawyers in tobacco litigation. **********But there is concern about the health impact of the cigarette stores' low prices. Analysts figure the tobacco pact would drive average prices up anywhere from 20 percent to 40 percent as the industry passed along the settlement costs. Some smokers would respond by switching to cheaper brands, but health officials hope millions of others will smoke less or quit, as they did after past price increases. **********They worry that the proliferation of cigarette stores promoting bargain prices on premium brands like Marlboro and Camel may offer many smokers a deadly alternative -- avoiding some or all of any price increase by switching where they shop. **********Tobacco manufacturers will not comment on any possible impact of the settlement, including this one. **********But other vendors will have a lot to say about whether cigarette stores continue to grow rapidly, said Brian Stockdale, vice president for wholesale and retail trade marketing at R. J. Reynolds in Winston-Salem, N.C., a unit of RJR Nabisco Holdings. **********''Most of the outlets are in the same shopping strips and malls as grocery stores because grocers aren't pushing the category,'' Mr. Stockdale said. **********Indeed, many grocers have pulled the plug on tobacco promotions to avoid offending nonsmokers. They have also kept prices up to maintain traditional tobacco profit margins of more than 20 percent and have cut back on easy customer access to tobacco to control theft and sales to minors. **********Cigarette stores say that any restrictions on marketing will be easier for them to adapt to because nothing they sell is meant for minors; if they successfully keep minors out, for instance, they will not have to take down signs and additional tobacco-company promotional materials that other stores will no longer be able to display. **********The grocery share of tobacco sales fell from 36 percent in 1988 to 18 percent last year as first convenience stores and then the new tobacco shops stole business. Unlike convenience stores, which usually sell a pack at a time, cigarette stores appeal more directly to grocery store customers, who tend to purchase cigarettes by the carton. **********Many drugstores have become even more reluctant than grocers to push tobacco, in part because they have frequently been attacked as hypocrites for selling such a deadly product along with medicine. **********At the Walgreen drugstore just half a block from Cigarettes Cheaper's Madison Street outlet here, Marlboros cost $2.85 a pack, compared with $2.15 at the tobacco shop. **********Tobacco sales at that Walgreen are off noticeably since Cigarettes Cheaper moved in, said Michael Polzin, a spokesman for the Walgreen Company. But Walgreen, the nation's largest drug chain, is sticking with its premium pricing, limited display racks, ban on tobacco advertising and promotion and a standard layout that allows only cashiers to reach the cigarettes. **********''We carry cigarettes strictly as a convenience for our customers,'' Mr. Polzin said. **********Convenience stores are expected to fight much harder to retain their share of the market. ''It's 25 percent to 30 percent of their merchandise revenue,'' said Hugh Houghton, director of the National Advisory Group, a Florida trade group for independent convenience stores. ''They can't afford to let that go.'' **********Many convenience stores will simply cut prices to the bone to hang on to customers, but other convenience stores, like some grocers, are building ''stores within a store'' to attract smokers and keep minors away. ''At the end of this reshuffling, I think convenience stores will gain market share,'' said Gus Olympidis, president of the Family Express Corporation, a chain of 26 convenience stores based in Valparaiso, Ind., that in a test is building glass-enclosed tobacco shops in two of its stores. **********Cigarette stores typically sell cigars, chewing and pipe tobacco and tobacco-related books and magazines as well as cigarettes; most also carry a limited selection of gum, candy and drinks. But the business is driven by the nicotine cravings of the nation's 46 million cigarette smokers. **********Stores like Cigarettes Cheaper keep prices low in part by selling an average of about 1,000 cartons a week, more than five times the volume of the average convenience store. Many keep operating costs to a minimum by relying on a single employee working a 10-  or 11-hour day to run an entire store. And they live with tobacco profit margins of less than 10 percent. **********But low prices are just part of their strategy. Cigarette stores also have a broader range of brands and packaging than most other retailers, a more regular diet of promotions and, store operators say, a welcoming attitude to smokers that is increasingly rare. **********''We have a philosophy of being very courteous and giving smokers the dignity they deserve,'' said David Bershof, a Denver entrepreneur, who has organized a consortium of nine tobacco distributors called Smoker Friendly International that operates 125 outlets from California to Pennsylvania. **********The Cigarette Store, a 25-store California chain based in Modesto, advertises its friendliness by doling out dog biscuits to customers who show up with a canine companion. **********Cigarettes Cheaper is the industry's brash enfant terrible. The Roscoe family, operators of a discount grocery business, opened its first cigarette store in October 1994. John Roscoe, the family patriarch and an outspoken libertarian, has used the stores as a platform to rail against Government interference with the rights of adults to pursue private vices. That has not stopped the company from also publicizing a ''model ordinance'' that would restrict tobacco sales to shops like Cigarettes Cheaper as a way of regulating sales to minors. **********What grabbed attention in the industry, though, is not such public relations high jinks but Cigarettes Cheaper's decision to go for rapid expansion based on exclusive marketing agreements with Philip Morris. That move defrayed some initial development costs and now assures the chain unbeatable prices on Marlboro, by far the nation's best-selling cigarette, and other Philip Morris brands. **********All the cigarette signs in its stores and on its fixtures feature Philip Morris brands, even those on racks carrying rival brands, like the Salems favored by Ms. Lockhart, which are made by R. J. Reynolds. In the Loop store visited by Ms. Lockhart, Marlboro gear and Virginia Slims clothing provide both decoration and prizes for drawings. **********Philip Morris, with more than half the market, says that the same arrangements have been offered to any retailer that wants to emphasize its brands. Most balk, though, because such deals require them to forgo some promotional support from the other manufacturers. **********''If we participate in all the Philip Morris promotions outside the exclusivity, we can match Cigarettes Cheaper on Marlboro about eight months of the year and be cheaper on everything else,'' said James Reed, president and owner of Patton Vending Machines Inc., which owns the Cigarette Store chain in California. (An unrelated, larger chain based in Boulder, Colo., operates under the same name in other areas, including the Midwest and the Rocky Mountain states.) **********The rapid expansion of Cigarettes Cheaper has had its drawbacks. It has led to missteps that have already forced it to close more than 20 stores. **********Ned Roscoe conceded that some problems existed, such as the fact that pay, which includes a share of operating profits above certain levels, was low at new stores. But managers in stores open two years or more in California earn as much as $45,000, he said. He readily agreed with the criticism that the growth rate had outpaced the company's management skills. Growth has slowed sharply, though, following the failure to work out financing for an expansion to 500 stores by the end of last year. **********Mr. Roscoe and other entrepreneurs in the field agree that future rapid expansion is far from a given. ''The low-margin, high-volume tobacco business is much more difficult than it appears,'' Mr. Roscoe said. ''It's extremely competitive.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/06/busin.snippet: Signs of trouble at Nine West Group, leading shoe manufacturer, discussed; include Securities and Exchange Commission probe of possible accounting irregularities, which led to sharp drop in stock price; company warns fourth-quarter earnings will b...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/06/busin.main_headline: A Good Fit Is Starting to Pinch; Nine West Tries to Fend Off Investigations and Debt
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/06/busin.print_headline: A Good Fit Is Starting to Pinch; Nine West Tries to Fend Off Investigations and Debt
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/06/busin.body_text: **********Jerome Fisher and Vincent Camuto founded their shoe company in 1977 on a simple but brilliant idea: spot the hottest designs on the fashion runways and quickly make the shoes affordable for the middle-class masses by manufacturing them in Brazil. **********The strategy seems to have paid off handsomely for the two men and their company, which was named for its first location, at 9 West 57th Street in Manhattan. The company, now known as Nine West Group, says that one of every five pairs of shoes that American women buy comes from Nine West. In shopping malls across the nation, women with $50 to $80 to spend on a pair of shoes can hardly miss one of the company's 13 brands, from the classy Enzo Angiolini to the comfortable Easy Spirit. **********But now there are signs of trouble -- everything from investigations by two Government agencies to mounting debts and slower sales. The company's stock, recently a darling among Wall Street's retail stocks, has fallen 45 percent in price from this year's high of $52.75. It closed yesterday at $29 a share, up 50 cents. Much of the drop came after management said in May that the Securities and Exchange Commission had been inquiring for at least six months about possible accounting irregularities concerning its wholesale revenues. Company officials first disclosed the inquiry in a paragraph deep inside a routine public filing. Stunned shareholders wondered why the company had not been more up front about the investigation. **********Just when stockholders were beginning to believe management's repeated assurances that the S.E.C. would find little amiss, the shoe company announced last month that the agency  was widening its investigation to look at the company's imports from Brazil. The company also reported that customs officials were making a separate inquiry into the Brazilian imports. **********Even before the investigations hit, there were problems. Company officials had publicly boasted of double-digit gains in sales. Most of that growth, however, comes from acquisitions and new stores. Take those figures out of the picture, and sales at stores that have been open for several months are falling. For the third quarter, those same-store sales were down 3 percent from a year ago. **********The Oppenheimer Total Return Fund decided to sell its 5 percent stake in Nine West about six months ago, after the company's storerooms were left filled with boxes of open-toe shoes that had languished during the snowy spring, said Bruce Bartlett, who manages the fund. **********''It looks like an inexpensive stock,'' Mr. Bartlett said, noting that shares now sell for about 11 times this year's earnings. ''But we question the direction of the earnings.'' **********The company, nearly debt free in 1994, borrowed deeply in 1995 when it paid $600 million for the footwear divisions of the U.S. Shoe Corporation. Now it must warn investors in S.E.C. filings that interest expense is eating into its cash and that the high debt could upset its expansion plans. **********If anything, the company should be sitting pretty, with 60 percent of its goods coming from Brazil, whose currency has weakened against the dollar. Instead, management warned yesterday that fourth-quarter earnings would be 40 percent lower than expected. **********The two founders declined to be interviewed for this article. But in a  statement to shareholders, Mr. Fisher, the chairman, blamed fashion faux pas in part for the disappointing year. He said the company was also facing ''shipping challenges'' in its accessories division. **********''We have taken action by critically evaluating every aspect of our business,'' Mr. Fisher's statement added. For one thing, the company vowed this week to lower the price of certain shoes by as much as 5 to 8 percent. **********Despite selling most of the company to the public in 1993, Mr. Fisher and Mr. Camuto -- who describe  themselves as experts in shoes, rather than finance -- are still very much in charge, judging from comments by people inside and outside the company. **********Some experts on corporate practice question whether some things would be different if outside shareholders had more sway. Specifically, they find fault with the company's small board, with a chief financial officer who comes straight out of the company's accounting firm and with the company's leasing office space from its two founders. **********Mr. Fisher and Mr. Camuto, the chief executive officer, occupy two seats on the company's five-member board. John C. Coffee Jr., a securities law professor at Columbia University, said that public companies similar to the billion-dollar Nine West  often had boards of 12 directors or more, with 80 percent of the members coming from outside. **********The other three directors are C. Gerald Goldsmith, an investment consultant from Palm Beach, Fla.; Henry W. Pascarella, a lawyer in Greenwich, Conn., and Salvatore M. Salibello, a partner at the small accounting firm of Salibello & Broder in New York. **********The board, which ordinarily meets only four times a year, has been kind to top management. Mr. Fisher and Mr. Camuto each received $1.8 million in salary and bonus last year. The two have also found another way to make money from Nine West: by sharing a 15.5 percent stake in a partnership that owns the company's headquarters in Stamford, Conn. The company is relocating to White Plains but must continue to pay rent -- now more than $2 million a year --  on the Stamford building until 2002, unless it can find someone to sublet  it. **********At least two family members also work for the company. Mr. Fisher's son, Marc, earned $982,808 last year  as president of a division that sells shoes under other companies' names. The chairman's daughter, Jodi, also works at the company, fielding calls from reporters. **********Mr. Galvin, the chief financial officer, is a former partner in Deloitte & Touche, the accounting firm, which has long audited the company's books. He was hired after he advised Mr. Fisher and Mr. Camuto on the U.S. Shoe acquisition. **********It is legal for companies to hire former auditors. But Mr. Galvin's prior employment at Deloitte raises ticklish questions about the independence of the accounting firm before and after he was hired, and about whether a pending job offer could have influenced Deloitte's  reading of the Nine West books. Even now, his intimate knowledge of Deloitte's auditing procedures and his relationship with various professionals could make it harder for the firm to conduct its audit. **********A Deloitte spokeswoman said the firm would not comment on a client matter. **********Mr. Coffee, the law professor, said, ''All of this company's watchdogs look a bit tame.'' He added that the small corporate board and the founders' ownership in the real estate partnership, which would likely be unacceptable at other public companies, seemed to be characteristic of ''a somewhat dysfunctional company that has not yet made the leap from a private company to truly public company.'' **********But Mr. Galvin said the company believed that the board was large enough to give its public shareholders a strong voice. He said outside consultants with expertise in corporate compensation had determined that Marc Fisher's salary was appropriate. And he said that while he had worked on the audit of the company while he was at Deloitte, he was not the partner in charge of the audit. He said the entire board -- not just Mr. Fisher and Mr. Camuto -- had approved his hiring. **********In an interview, Mr. Pascarella, the board member from Greenwich, said he was comfortable with the company's management and its response to the investigations. In addition to holding a special board meeting with management this fall, he said the three outside directors had met privately with their own counsel and with representatives of Deloitte to discuss the S.E.C. inquiry. He also said he was confident with management's assurances that the problems were not material. **********That said, the scrutiny is proving painful for a company that was always at its best taking on the industry. Now, it has grown so much that it is the industry. **********''The founders were very great entrepreneurs,'' said Faye I. Landes, an analyst at Smith Barney Inc. ''But this is now a very big and complicated company.'' She is not recommending the stock to clients. **********The company became more complex with the U.S. Shoe purchase, which doubled the number of its retail stores. Some U.S. Shoe brands were losing money, but Nine West management thought it could turn them around by manufacturing overseas. This year, it closed three Midwest shoe factories that had been operated by U.S. Shoe, so that it could buy even more shoes from Brazil. The company laid off more than 1,000  workers in Kentucky and Indiana, including 300 in Vanceburg, Ky.,  where the unemployment rate was already more than 10 percent. **********Now, S.E.C. investigators are looking at the way Nine West recorded wholesale revenues at some of the former U.S. Shoe divisions, in the seven months from the acquisition through the fiscal year ending Feb. 1, 1996, according to Nine West news releases. The company says it records revenues when the shoes are shipped to wholesale customers, who resell the shoes through noncompany outlets like department stores. **********The S.E.C., as is its policy, will not confirm an inquiry or comment on whether one has begun. While it is not clear what the S.E.C. may suspect, some other companies have run into problems with the agency when they overstated sales by shipping products that they knew would be quickly returned or by parking goods marked ''sold'' in warehouses. **********Given management's assurances that the problems were confined to certain brands and involved a limited period, investors were rolling with the punches until the company disclosed on Nov. 6 that the S.E.C. had widened its investigation to look at the way the company was importing shoes from Brazil. ''Many people felt misled,'' said one analyst, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. ''Management said this was very narrow and confined, but it's not.'' **********The company said in its Nov. 6 salvo that it had received an S.E.C. subpoena on Oct. 29 for documents relating to shoes bought from Brazil since 1994, including information on the prices and customs duties paid for those shoes. **********Mr. Galvin said he continued to believe that any findings by the investigators would not hurt Nine West financially. He also said that he thought the accounting policies were appropriate and that the company had made no changes to policies or practices since the S.E.C. began asking questions last fall. But such assurances ring hollow to some analysts, who say revisions by the company have forced them to lower their  earnings estimates time and again. **********''It is still unclear why they are having such a hard time making these estimates,'' said Ms. Landes of Smith Barney. ''It is hard for me not to think that they are sitting in meetings with lawyers much of the time.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/31/busin.snippet: Stephen Shulman, trained accountant himself, relates bizarre saga of 37-cent New York tax bill that grew to hundreds of dollars, through convoluted reasoning of state's computer system; photo (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/31/busin.main_headline: The 37-Cent Tax Bill That Grew and Grew
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/31/busin.print_headline: The 37-Cent Tax Bill That Grew and Grew
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/31/busin.body_text: **********STEPHEN SHULMAN felt a twinge of anxiety in 1992 when he picked up an envelope from the New York State Department of Taxation and Finance. But his mood turned to bemusement as he read that the thousands of dollars that he and his wife, Linda, had paid in income taxes for 1990 were not enough. **********The state wanted 37 more cents. **********''I thought the notice was a silly mistake,'' said Mr. Shulman, a former accountant with a major firm who now sells insurance as an independent broker from a midtown Manhattan office. ''The state rounds to the nearest dollar so I wrote them a letter saying the notice must be a mistake and asking them to waive it, and about $70 in penalties and interest, which I thought was absurd, and when they didn't reply I forgot about it.'' **********The state didn't forget. More than two years later a computer churned out a notice demanding the 37 cents plus a penalty that had grown to $216.92 and interest of $53.83. **********Soon the state added a demand for 1994. The Shulmans did not owe any additional tax for 1994, the notice said, but they owed a penalty of $110.80 and interest of $48.82. The notice did not explain why they would owe penalties and interest on no additional tax. **********The amounts grew until earlier this year, when the state wanted $544.53. Plus the 37 cents. **********The tiny tax bill that the state pursued with such vigor illustrates how even a minor tax dispute can turn into a war of correspondence for people who question the authorities rather than just paying up. **********Tax relief was a theme of the elected officials who championed tax bills passed this summer in Albany and Washington. But Mr. Shulman said he would have welcomed a law that eliminated petty rules and provided quick, easy remedies for taxpayers disputing a penalty. **********''It would have been nice if I just could have gotten an explanation from the state of the penalty and how they figured that interest,'' he said. **********Tax penalties are commonplace. Last year more than 20 million penalties were assessed against individuals and couples by the Internal Revenue Service, affecting more than one of every six taxpayers. Those penalties totaled $3.4 billion, equal to more than one-half of 1 percent of all individual income taxes. The I.R.S. has no data on penalties actually paid, only those assessed, said a spokesman, Steve Pyrek. **********New York State has data on penalties actually paid, which totaled $15.1 million in 1995, or less than one-tenth of 1 percent of the nearly $17 billion in state income taxes paid that year. **********In New York State, only the Commissioner of Taxation and Finance or his deputies  can waive a tax, even of a dollar, said Kevin Quinn, a spokesman for the tax agency. However, he added, because no tax bill for less than a dollar is supposed to be sent, low-level tax officials can waive such bills on the theory that the tax does not exist. **********Mr. Quinn said policy changes intended to ease disputes over penalties were on the way, a result of focus group interviews to determine which tax policies irritated people the most. **********Mr. Shulman's battle produced an inch-thick stack of correspondence, much of it his requests for an explanation of the penalty and interest that elicited boilerplate replies from the state reciting the amounts demanded, but without explanation. **********The state later granted Mr. Shulman and his wife amnesty under a program to clean up old tax bills and told the couple to send in a check for $69 to settle the case. But the state sent the same sum back last December, leaving the Shulmans totally perplexed. Then came the $545 bill. **********JAMES W. WETZLER, a former state tax commissioner who is tax group director at Deloitte & Touche, the accounting firm, said the state should apply ''reasonable tolerance levels'' in determining the accuracy of tax returns and overlook amounts that are not worth the state's time. **********Penalties, Mr. Wetzler said, are typically imposed by computer programs and ''are designed to improve voluntary compliance'' with the tax laws. **********A taxpayer like Mr. Shulman could end up owing penalties and interest, but no tax, if he applied for an extension to file a tax return and then discovered that more money was  due when the return was filed, Mr. Wetzler said. ''The state takes the position that to have a valid extension you had to have paid 100 percent of the tax due before the extension would have begun,'' he said. ''So if you fell 37 cents short, the state would say your extension is invalidated and you would owe a nonfiling penalty plus interest on the tax that was paid late and interest on the penalty.'' **********Mr. Shulman said he now believed that this was what happened in his case. But, he asked, ''does it make sense for the state to spend thousands of dollars trying to collect 37 cents or even $100?'' **********''The state should also explain the reasons for its penalties and interest so that anyone can understand,'' he said. ''I'm a certified public accountant and I couldn't figure it out.'' **********In July, after a reporter inquired about the Shulmans' bill, the state advised the couple that it was withdrawing its demand for the 37 cents and penalties and interest, but not taking into account $112 it withheld from his refund in 1995 as partial payment on what started as a 37-cent tax bill. **********Will he try to get back the $112? ''No,'' Mr. Shulman said, breaking into a pained grin. ''I've learned that it's just not worth it.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/12/busin.snippet: Centennial Technologies Inc dismisses chairman and chief executive Emmanuel Pinez; begins inquiry into accuracy of company's financial statements (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/12/busin.main_headline: Chief Is Dismissed at Centennial Technologies
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/12/busin.print_headline: Chief Is Dismissed at Centennial Technologies
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/12/busin.body_text: **********Centennial Technologies Inc., a maker of personal computer equipment whose stock soared last year, said yesterday that it had dismissed its chairman and chief executive, Emanuel Pinez, and had begun an investigation into the accuracy of its financial statements. **********Centennial stock never opened for trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. **********Centennial's investigation will probably require past earnings to be lowered, said J. P. Luc Beaubien, a Centennial director. The company also got in touch with the Securities and Exchange Commission to inform it of the investigation, he said. **********''I would be surprised if the results of the inquiry were to be to restate upwards'' previously announced results, Mr. Beaubien said. Along with another director, William Kinch, Mr. Beaubien will assist the company's president, John McDonald, in running the company. **********Centennial's chief financial officer, James Murphy, was relieved of his duties and is assisting in the inquiry, the company said. **********Yesterday's developments represented another blow for Centennial, whose stock rose 451 percent last year. The company's shares have fallen precipitously this year, from a peak of $55.50 a share to $16.50 on Monday, driven down in part by speculation that sales would slow and profit margins would narrow. **********Centennial's woes spilled over to  Websecure Inc., in which Centennial owns a stake of 8.7 percent. Shares in Websecure, which provides Internet service to corporate customers, fell $2.50, to $5.50, after a brief trading halt. Robert Kuzara, Websecure's president and chief executive, is a former director of Centennial and still owns 250,000 shares. **********''It's been a devastating day,'' Mr. Kuzara said, adding that he bought 10,000 Centennial shares just last month, at $32, on the open market. **********Centennial, which makes adapter cards for personal computers, said it was looking into the accuracy of its posted earnings for the fiscal year 1997 second quarter that ended Dec. 31, as well as for earlier periods. The company formed a committee to oversee the inquiry. **********Last month, the company, which is based in Billerica, Mass., said that second-quarter earnings rose to $3.46 million, or 19 cents a share, from $996,000, or 7 cents, a year earlier.  The company's outside auditor is Coopers & Lybrand L.L.P. **********The dismissal of Mr. Pinez is related to the inquiry, said Mr. Beaubien, who declined to say in what way misstatements might have occurred, or by how much.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/27/busin.main_headline: Firms Discover Limits of India's Middle Class
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/27/busin.print_headline: Firms Discover Limits of India's Middle Class
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/27/busin.body_text: **********Daewoo Motor Co. Ltd. gives away 200 sedans for an 18-month "test drive." Whirlpool Corp. offers buyers of refrigerators and washers the chance to win an apartment and a car. Akai Electric Co. Ltd. lures customers for its color televisions by paying handsomely for their old sets. **********A nationwide clearance sale is on in India. **********Lured by estimates that India's middle class is the size of the population of the United States or several European countries combined, makers of everything from corn flakes to cars flocked here after free-market reforms in l99l began to transform the economy. **********Now, with inventories mounting, multinationals are discovering that "the middle class of India is not the middle class of the West, by a long shot," said K.B. Dadiseth, chairman of Hindustan Lever, the Indian subsidiary of the Anglo-Dutch consumer giant Unilever PLC. **********In much of the West, a middle class family has a mortgage, car, personal computer and enough savings for an annual vacation. In India, "middle class is a family that can afford to eat a balanced diet, send the children well-clothed to school and buy a black and white television," Mr. Dadiseth said. **********A 1996 Gallup poll found that the average Indian household earns $780 a year. Half that income goes to food and clothing, the survey determined. **********What is more, when they do spend on consumer goods, Indians have a number of local brands to choose from. These realities are prompting many multinationals to review their break-even dates and market strategies. **********Nothing illustrates the disappointment more than the accumulation of midsize American, European and South Korean cars, priced at $15,000 or more. Total car sales rose 19 percent, to 411,000, for the year ended March 1997, but the market was dominated by an Indian subcompact that cost $6,000. The Association of Indian Automobile Manufacturers has scaled back its projection for car sales by the year 2000 to 700,000 from 850,000. **********Daewoo Motors' plant outside New Delhi operated at one-third its capacity last year. The company sold less than 16,000 Cielo sedans, half what it had anticipated. "We were very surprised," said S.G. Awasthi, managing director of Daewoo in India. To get Indians into its showrooms, Daewoo offered 200 Cielos for 18-month test drives. Some 350,000 Indians have applied for the lucky draw. **********"Companies wishfully overestimated the size of the middle class," said Amit Roy, President of ORG/MARG, a leading market research firm. **********In New Delhi, the nation's richest city, home-theater and stereo televisions are languishing on store shelves. "The income of Indians is too low to justify buying such products," said Ravi Chhadra, owner of a home appliance store in a middle class neighborhood. He noted that most of his customers buy 20-inch (51-centimeter) color sets, priced at $250, in installments **********Annual sales of color television sets stagnated at 1.9 million sets in 1996, and the Consumer Electronics & Television Manufacturers Association now expects Indians to have bought 5 million sets by 2000, five years later than forecast. Akai, Sony Corp., Daewoo and Samsung Electronics Co. Ltd. are just some of the foreign entrants into the saturated market. **********"Sony is working on reducing its prices to have better results," said Y. Kubo, who heads Sony's wholly owned Indian subsidiary. **********The battle for market share in India has driven some of the world's leading brands to craft audacious sales promotions, while competitors are quick to cry foul. **********Early this year, General Electric Co. and its Indian partner, Godrej, took Whirlpool's Indian unit to court to stop it from offering refrigerator and washing machine buyers the chance to win prizes that included an apartment in New Delhi. Invoking an Indian unfair-trade act, Godrej/GE Appliances accused Whirlpool of "luring gullible consumers" to buy a refrigerator or washer "without concern for quality," according to a lawyer for Godrej/GE Appliances. The court forced Whirlpool to suspend the plan. **********Meanwhile, judging from refrigerator sales, consumers are not that interested in quality when it comes to having the latest technology available. Only 10 out of every 100 sold has so-called frost-free technology, a standard feature for decades in Western fridges. In a country of 950 million people, only 2.9 million refrigerators were sold last year, most of them only slightly larger than a mini-bar fridge in a hotel room. **********So, how big is the Indian middle class? **********Whirlpool currently estimates that 65 million people can afford to buy a refrigerator. But only 35 million are potential buyers. "You can't expect someone to buy a refrigerator if he still doesn't own a radio," said Garrick D'Silva, managing director of Whirlpool India. **********Reebok International Ltd. reckons that 50 million Indians can afford its sports shoes and apparel. **********Still, "to capture that 50 million, you need a very good distribution network," cautioned Muktesh Pant, managing director of Reebok India. **********The country's buying power is scattered, and much of it lies untapped in medium-sized towns made remote by potholed roads. **********"Nobody doubts that India will be one of the world's biggest markets," Mr. Pant said. "The question is how long will it take to get there."
