https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/16/busin.body_text: **********Envirodyne Industries said today that it would retain a financial adviser to assist it in possibly selling the food packaging and supplies company or some of its units. **********The move follows a request Wednesday by the Zapata Corporation, which owns 40 percent of Envirodyne, that Envirodyne hire an adviser to value it. It came four days after Michael Heisley, an Envirodyne director, effectively raised his $650 million offer for the company by promising to include part of the$102.4 million won last year by Envirodyne in a patent-infringement suit. **********Envirodyne, which is based in Oak Brook, makes plastic films and containers used in food packaging, as well as disposable silverware. **********Mr. Heisley offered on June 11 to buy Envirodyne for $8.50 a share, or $125 million, and assume $525 million of debt. An independent committee of Envirodyne's board rejected the offer June 23.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/22/busin.snippet: Interview with Ralph Roberts, 77-year-old founder and chairman of family-run Comcast Corp; he will soon turn over control of company to son Brian, who is president; photos; graph (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/22/busin.main_headline: The Heir Is Clearly Apparent at Comcast
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/22/busin.print_headline: The Heir Is Clearly Apparent at Comcast
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/22/busin.body_text: **********RALPH ROBERTS, the dapper 77-year-old founder of the Comcast Corporation, loves to follow the ups and downs of other family businesses and try to figure out what makes some thrive and others implode. ''There are the families that destroy each other as soon as the father or  mother dies,'' Mr. Roberts said. ''They come in and tear each other apart. The Gettys or that family in Texas,'' he continued, referring to Harold Simmons, the Texas investor who is at war with his daughters. ''They are all billionaires, and they're fighting like crazy over another billion.'' **********Mr. Roberts has reason to track the way family-run companies pass the baton from one generation to next. He has five children, aged 36 to 47. Only his fourth child, Brian, is at Comcast, the nation's fourth-largest cable television operator with $4 billion in revenue last year. And by the end of this year, the elder Mr. Roberts will increase Brian's control over the company's special class of 8.8 million shares that represent nearly 82 percent of Comcast's vote. It is only natural for the world to wonder: How will Brian's siblings react to all this? **********The potential for conflict is obvious. The Roberts clan's equity stake in Comcast, based in Philadelphia, is worth at least $470 million without a premium, and once the patriarch and his wife pass from the scene, there is no guarantee the heirs won't hurl themselves into a fierce battle for the spoils. **********But the elder Mr. Roberts has probably come as close as any company founder can to setting the stage for an orderly succession. His plan is to turn over the votes to Brian but make sure to divide the financial pie fairly among all the offspring. Though many aging entrepreneurs resist relinquishing power despite all their promises to do so, Comcast has begun notifying local cable commissions of the pending change of control, which Ralph Roberts said would be no later than early next year. **********And experts say the odds of a successful transition are greater at Comcast than at most family businesses. Mr. Roberts has by all accounts done a skillful job of grooming Brian to fill his shoes so that he is both respected by his peers and supported by his siblings. While no one doubts that the father still calls a lot of the shots, he has eased his son into high-profile positions both at the bargaining table and in the public eye. In a family business, even the strongest allegiances can crack under the strain of a mismanaged transition at the top, but people familiar with Comcast say the younger Mr. Roberts is proving his mettle. **********That was evident earlier this month when Brian Roberts and the founder of Microsoft, Bill Gates, struck a deal in which Microsoft agreed to pay $1 billion for an 11.5 percent stake in Comcast. The deal put the cable company on a far larger corporate map. ''We had 650 analysts on the conference call to discuss the deal,'' recalled Brian Roberts, who handled the call for Comcast. ''Usually we have about 200.'' **********Even as he is promoting his son, the elder Mr. Roberts is looking after the financial interests of his other children. He never pressured any of them to join the family company -- and none besides Brian showed any interest in doing so. Today, Ralph Jr. is a professor of psychology at the University of Denver, and the other three all live near their parents in Philadelphia, where Lisa has a design business, Cathy is involved in philanthropy and Douglas is an assistant District Attorney. **********And all of them are rich. The elder Mr. Roberts has made sure that each of Brian's  siblings will retain an economic stake in Comcast equal their brother's. The five children and their parents jointly own the holding company that owns Comcast's supervoting shares. And to prevent his other heirs  from putting pressure on Brian to sell Comcast -- an issue that has torn many families apart -- Mr. Roberts is struggling with a way to give them nonvoting stock that they could cash in without disturbing their brother's grip on the company. **********''The children -- the family -- have continual discussions,'' he said during an interview in which he was joined by Brian, dressed like his father in a gray suit, black loafers, a white button-down shirt and red print tie. ''It's a pretty close family. Our activities are so public. If you have a small private business, and the old man has stashed away something under the floor, then it's very different.'' **********A few weeks ago, the five Roberts children -- leaving behind both mates and children -- spent a day with their parents for freewheeling talks on everything from personal concerns to financial matters. **********Family-business experts say the family is something of an anomaly in devising a smooth transfer between generations. ''This is a relatively unusual situation,'' said Leon Danco, president of the Center for Family Studies. ''The father is open. Many entrepreneurs are very secretive. It is a sign of a man who has given considerable thought to the future and has spoken to his other children. What is more common is that this kind of agreement does not happen. To make it work, you have to have motivated, competent successors as well as accommodating heirs. If a family has to go to law court to determine what is fair, the issue is what's the law, not what is fair.'' **********IT helps, of course, that only one of the children desperately wanted to follow in  Dad's footsteps. ''I think we have known that Brian would take over the company since he was about 8 years old,'' said Julian Brodsky, Comcast's vice chairman and Mr. Roberts's alter ego for the last 34 years. **********When Brian was 8, Comcast was a fledgling cable operator that Ralph Roberts had founded after jumping in and out of a handful of other businesses. His main goal at the time was to make a lot of money. He had been born into an affluent home, the son of the owner of a small drugstore chain in  Westchester County, N.Y. For a time, the family even had a chauffeur. But during the Depression, Mr. Roberts recalled, ''my father died, and we lost all our money. People who never had a financial problem in their lives can never understand what terror there is in that.'' **********He credits his mother for pulling the family through hard times. ''She had a lot of friends, and she decided to go into the insurance business, and everybody she knew bought a policy from her the first year to keep us going,'' he said. ''We moved into an apartment with my aunt in Philadelphia. I went to the University of Pennsylvania. I lived at home.'' To support himself at college, he took on a variety of odd jobs, including selling milk. **********Once Mr. Roberts began building Comcast, Brian, alone of his brood, frequented the company premises. Luckily, the youngster had business smarts as well as enthusiasm. If he hadn't, his father confesses, ''I probably would have sold the company.'' **********That would have been a wrenching decision, as it almost invariably is for the founder of a company. ''There is something about wanting to pass things on,'' he said. ''It is the same thing as giving birth -- or having another generation. But if Brian were not up to it, he would not have stood a chance because you can't sacrifice all the people in the place for a poor manager.'' **********Or an arrogant one. ''The most dangerous thing is a son or daughter coming into a business where they think they get special treatment,'' Mr. Roberts said. ''They drag the business down because it kills the morale of everybody in the company.'' **********After Brian received an undergraduate business degree from the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania in 1981, Ralph Roberts tried to steer him to another company, where he would have to fight his own battles. But the son wanted to stay in the family business, so Mr. Roberts started him off in the trenches, stringing cable in New Kensington, Pa. ''We were lucky because the cable business was growing and growing, '' Mr. Roberts recalled. There was plenty of room to give the son a shot. **********But as Brian Roberts worked his way up the ladder, the halcyon 1980's came to an end. The 1990's have been far tougher, as regulation and skepticism about the industry's future in the face of rival technologies hurt cable stocks. Like many other cable companies, Comcast peaked in late 1993, at $28.17 a share. It bottomed out at $16.375 last March and has recovered slightly, closing at $21.375 on Friday on Nasdaq. **********ALL along, however, Mr. Roberts has drawn his son closer to the center of action inside Comcast and pushed him into the spotlight outside the company. ''I thought if he was so young, you really have to be helped to be promoted to make it appear that you really are your own person,'' the elder Mr. Roberts recalled. ''Every chance I get I step back and say, 'Here is Brian.' I didn't want it to appear that he was just his father's son.'' **********For example, it was Brian Roberts who was on the board of Turner Broadcasting before Time Warner bought it in 1996, and it was Brian who was president of the National Cable Television Association's board in 1995. **********Promoting an heir apparent may have been easier for the elder Mr. Roberts than for other entrepreneurs. Investors who know him say he always prefers to remain in the background and let others like Mr.Brodsky, the vice chairman, take the limelight. ''I used to talk to Julian all the time,'' recalled Gordon Crawford, a senior vice president at the Capital Group, whose funds hold 8.1 percent of Comcast's class A stock. ''I would see Ralph about once a year.'' **********Brian Roberts, on the other hand, seems to relish his public role. ''He gives more speeches than anyone who is asked,'' said one media executive, who spoke on condition of anonymity. ''But if it were not for self-promotion, how would a guy like Bill Gates take him seriously?'' **********Brian Roberts came to know Mr. Gates when a contingent of Comcast executives visited Microsoft on a fact-finding tour several years ago. They have met at the investment bank Allen & Company's annual Sun Valley Conference for media heavyweights, and they got together last summer when Mr. Gates came to speak at a United Way fund-raising event in Philadelphia. **********The recent deal was begun when the executive committee of Cablelabs, the cable industry's research and development arm that included Brian Roberts and John Malone, chairman of Tele-Communications Inc., the country's largest cable operator, visited Microsoft in late April. **********Mr. Gates told the group he believed the cable industry had been slow to upgrade its systems. Brian Roberts countered that other companies, including Comcast, were aggressively upgrading. Later, the two men found themselves in the same restaurant, and Mr. Roberts suggested that Microsoft consider investing in cable. Mr. Gates was warm to the idea. A result was Microsoft's $1 billion investment in Comcast. **********As Gregory B. Maffei, Microsoft's treasurer, sees it, the younger Mr. Roberts is no pawn of his father. On the contrary, he says, ''Brian takes the lead and is the one forging ahead and trying to figure out where they are going,'' Mr. Maffei said. ''Brian is the more active participant.'' **********And Peter Barton, the former president of Liberty Media, recalled that Brian Roberts played the key role in a complicated deal with Liberty involving the purchase of Time Warner's stake in E Entertainment, a cable-service company, for $321 million. Brian brought in the Walt Disney Company to put up most of the funds for the acquisition, even though Comcast management gained effective control of E Entertainment. **********''Deals like Microsoft and QVC would not have happened without Brian,'' said Steven Rattner, deputy chief executive of Lazard Freres & Company, who has worked with the family for about a decade. ''Ralph and Julian have been intimately involved, but Ralph doesn't sit there until 4 A.M. in the lawyers' offices anymore. Now Brian typically takes the lead.'' **********To be sure, he adds, ''At an important fork in the road, Brian will go off to his father'' to get the older man's stamp of approval. **********The company is clearly planning for the day that Ralph Roberts will no longer be running the show. Over the last five years, it has brought in a younger team of senior executives to work with Brian, including the executive vice president, Larry Smith, 49; the senior treasurer, John Alchin, 49, and  the president of the cable division, Tom Baxter, 50. **********The son, meanwhile, remains an understudy of the father -- and the father is impressing upon the son the need to play hardball when the occasion demands it. **********In 1994, for example, Ralph Roberts scuttled a bid by Barry Diller, then the chairman of QVC, the home-shopping cable channel, to acquire CBS. The deal would have relegated Comcast, the biggest QVC shareholder, to be a minor, and passive, investor in CBS, and the elder Mr. Roberts wanted no part of that. So he made his own bid for QVC, with TCI as a partner, effectively killing the CBS deal. **********The memory of the fiasco still rankles Mr. Diller. ''Ralph is tough,'' he says ruefully. ''Under that bow tie and courtly manner beats the heart of one tough man. He is steel.'' **********Ralph Roberts acknowledges that he was the heavy. ''I was probably the one to pull the curtain,'' he said. ''Barry is very charismatic and hypnotic, but we were not going to lose our business and become a nonvoting stockholder of CBS to provide Barry with an entree to CBS.'' Then, chuckling, he added, ''It was probably a very good lesson for Brian -- no question about it.'' **********The son got the point. His father's greatest skill, he said, ''is the ability to make the hard decision at the crucial moment.'' **********Once the elder Mr. Roberts is out of the picture at Comcast, Wall Street will be watching closely to see whether the son can be as tough and decisive as his father. It is a skill that Brian Roberts knows he has yet to prove and that is rare among the sons of powerful men, who are often overwhelmed by their fathers. **********''It has been wonderful to share those tense moments with your father,'' Brian Roberts said, ''and hopefully, it has prepared me for the future.'' **********Brian Roberts acknowledges that decision making, what he calls ''pulling the trigger,'' is something you learn. ''Hopefully, I have had more experience than most people,'' he said, ''but you never know.'' **********At least Comcast has the financial flexibility to make the transition work. Like many media entrepreneurs, Ralph Roberts created several classes of stock, enabling him to issue equity without losing control. In 1963, the year he founded the company, he created Comcast class B shares, of which there are 8.8 million, each with 15 votes. The company also has 33 million shares of common stock with one vote each and 284 million K shares with no votes. The family holding company owns all the supervoting shares, as well as 1.8 million of the class A shares and 5.3 million of the nonvoting shares. In addition, Ralph Roberts personally owns another 5.2 million nonvoting shares, as well as 319,00 class A shares. **********JUST as important, family-business experts say the apparent harmony within the Roberts family bodes well for the chances of a smooth transition. Mr. Roberts has been married to his wife, Suzanne, for 54 years. And the other children, who declined to be interviewed, are said to be knowledgeable about the plan and favorable to it. **********''All this would never have happened in the arms of a second wife,'' according to Mr. Danco. ''When some guy decides that he is so important that he dismisses Mama for some 35-year-old trophy, then I don't know what is fair. There are too many other combatants, and it becomes another deal. This has a pretty good chance of working. It is the mother who will make it work.'' **********Both parents said that in bringing up their brood, they worked hard to see that the children connected with one another. ''We never emphasized that they should make a lot of money, or have the biggest car,'' Mrs. Roberts recalled. And her husband reminisced about family trips. ''We used to take the children away with us every year to climb the Pyramids or something memorable to keep their attention,'' he said. ''We would have discussions about our lives. They were like mass therapy sessions with the children.'' **********That was hardly a coincidence. When she was 60 years old, Mrs. Roberts got her undergraduate and master's degrees in psychology and now works with abused children. **********Without being asked, Mrs. Roberts volunteered her opinion that Ralph and Brian clicked as few business partners do. ''I have never seen a relationship that could surpass the two of them,'' she said. ''I don't think Ralph knows any more about Brian's personal life than he knows about the others. But they talk all the time. It is always business. And if there is any disagreement, they can always talk it out. It is amazing.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/04/08/busin.body_text: **********Stocks Rise, Led by Rally In Technology Shares **********Stocks began this week on a far more upbeat note than the last. The Nasdaq composite index, which is heavily weighted with technology stocks, surged 14.62 points, or 1.18 percent, to close at 1,251.35. **********It was the third straight session in which the Nasdaq rose more than 1 percent, and the rally extended to other indexes. The Dow industrials were up 29.84 points, to 6,555.91. $(Page D10.$) **********Treasury prices recovered from Friday's sharp fall, bolstered by a strong dollar and by thin trading. The yield on the 30-year bond fell to 7.06 percent from 7.12. $(D17.$) **********2 Chip Makers' Results Strong **********Two big semiconductor makers, Advanced Micro Devices and Motorola, posted surprisingly strong financial results after the market closed. The strong reports could help the fledgling rally in technology stocks, which had slumped broadly earlier this year. $(D4.$) **********2 Stocks Plummet on Merger Plan **********Rational Software, a maker of programs used to manage computer software development, agreed to acquire a rival, Pure Atria, in a stock swap initially valued at about $890 million. But the shares of both companies plunged because of concern that the two would cannibalize each other's sales, and by the end of the day the value of the deal was only about $525 million. $(D4.$) **********Skepticism on Talk of On-Line Deal **********The shares of America Online and Compuserve fell sharply as both companies declined to confirm continuing reports that America Online was negotiating to buy Compuserve, its biggest rival in computer on-line services. $(D4.$) **********Pharmacia AIDS Drug Approved **********The F.D.A. has approved a new AIDS drug -- delavirdine from Pharmacia & Upjohn -- for patients to add to their complex medication cocktails, despite conflicting evidence on how well it works. $(B8.$) **********Growth in Consumer Credit Slows **********Growth in consumer debt slowed in February, rising at a 6.7 percent seasonally adjusted annual rate, to $1.21 trillion, after increasing at a 10.3 percent rate in January. $(D2.$) **********Mesa Agrees to Merger **********Mesa, from which T. Boone Pickens staged many takeover attempts, has agreed to merge with Parker & Parsley Petroleum in a deal that would create the nation's third-largest independent oil and gas exploration and production company. $(D5.$) **********Health Care Deal Is Called Off **********Integrated Health Services, a big nursing home and home health care company, called off its offer to buy Coram Healthcare, a financially troubled provider of intravenous care for patients at home. $(D2.$) **********Brinkmanship by PC Executives **********Leaders of the personal computer industry proposed their vision for the future of TV, setting them on a collision course with broadcasters. Executives spelled out the technical format for the digital televisions that some PC makers plan to include in personal computers -- a format incompatible with the digital technology that broadcasters plan to introduce next year. $(D8.$) **********Commerce Secretary Plans Trip **********Commerce Secretary William M. Daley will lead a trade mission to Latin America next month, his first and the first under new rules intended to eliminate politics from the process of selecting businesses that take part, the Commerce Department said. $(D20.$) **********Office Supply Giants to Keep Trying **********Staples and Office Depot vowed to ''vigorously contest'' the F.T.C.'s decision to challenge their proposed $4 billion merger, asserting that Federal antitrust officials did not understand the office supply business. $(D20.$)

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/15/busin.body_text: **********Federated Department Stores Inc. reported robust first-quarter earnings yesterday, helped by higher sales of store-brand clothing and lower expenses. **********The company, which operates Macy's, Bloomingdale's and other department store chains, earned  $24.1 million, or 12 cents a share, compared with a loss of $37.9 million, or 18 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier. **********In the 1996 quarter, Federated took a pretax charge of $77 million for integrating the Broadway retail chain into its operations and adjusting inventory. Before the charge, Federated earned $9.3 million, or 4 cents a share. **********The most recent results exceeded Wall Street estimates of 9 cents a share, according to a survey of analysts by I.B.E.S. International Inc. **********Earnings were bolstered by increased sales of private-label clothes, which carry higher profits. Also, Federated cut costs by changing how it distributes merchandise and orders inventory; the changes reduced sales, general and administrative expenses to 34.5 percent of sales from 36.2 percent a year earlier. **********Sales for the quarter ended May 3 rose 3.3 percent, to $3.41 billion from $3.30 billion. Sales at stores open at least a year, a key retailing barometer, rose 2.5 percent. Federated operates more than 400 department stores.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/31/world.main_headline: Gandhi's Ashes Rest, but Not His Message
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/31/world.print_headline: Gandhi's Ashes Rest, but Not His Message
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/31/world.body_text: **********In a mood of reproachful retrospection, India turned the clock back nearly half a century today with an emotional ceremony at a sacred Ganges site to scatter some of Mohandas K. Gandhi's ashes, long left forgotten in a provincial bank vault. **********For a few hours, this city was host to events that seemed borrowed from the days after a Hindu nationalist assassinated Gandhi in New Delhi on Jan. 30, 1948. **********Sealed in the wooden coffin where they had been placed after being scooped from Gandhi's funeral pyre, the ashes were taken from a special railroad car, honored by crowds of young and old shouting, ''Long Live the Mahatma!'' and poured from an urn into the Ganges to the sound of ancient Hindu death chants. **********The ceremony on the river came at a time of intense Indian debate over Gandhi. Among the thousands who lined the streets and the riverbank here today, and millions of other Indians, he is still revered. But many say that his legacy has been mocked by events in India since he died, and that the country urgently needs to look anew at his vision for the country he led to nationhood. **********As India approaches the 50th anniversary of its independence from Britain on Aug. 15, many have been unhappily scrutinizing the country they live in for evidence of Gandhi's ideals -- among others, nonviolence, religious harmony, concern for those trapped by poverty and caste, and a life free of materialism. **********These people point to India's covert nuclear weapons program, to soaring rates of crime and corruption, to political parties that appeal to divisions of religion, region and caste, and above all to the 350 million Indians who still live in poverty and conditions of endemic disease. **********''We invoke Gandhi today as the Mahatma, the Father of the Nation,'' said Vandita Mishra, a columnist writing last weekend in The Pioneer, a leading newspaper. ''But the politician and social philosopher who articulated an alternative model of society is, by a curious sleight of memory and imagination, transformed into the presiding deity of a system that negates every conviction he stood for.'' **********Ms. Mishra's article was one of a torrent in Indian papers recently deploring what has been described as the country's passion for celebrating Gandhi in speeches, statues and books, and ignoring almost everything he taught. Many of these articles have also condemned some of the more radical figures among India's new generation of political leaders for using Gandhi as a political football, often denigrating him and, his followers say, distorting his ideas. **********One of India's most vociferous politicians, a woman who uses the single name Mayawati, has condemned him as ''the biggest enemy'' of the 150 million people who belong to the dalit, or untouchable, caste. **********Gandhi's prescription for untouchables -- that untouchability should be abolished, but that dalits should unite with Hindus of other castes in working for broad reform -- was strongly contested in his lifetime by untouchable leaders who believed dalits should band together as a separate political force. But the arguments of Gandhi's day rarely had the venom of the recent ones. **********Arousing just as much controversy have been the attacks on Gandhi by Hindu nationalists. Although never fully recovered politically from the fact that one of their followers, Nathuram Godse, killed Gandhi, they seem to have felt freer in recent years to challenge his legacy. **********Balasaheb Thackeray, a nationalist who is the most powerful political leader in Bombay, suggested this month that Gandhi's habit of testing his asceticism by sleeping in the same bed with naked young women may not have been as innocent as Gandhi said. He also challenged the habit of referring to Gandhi as Father of the Nation. ''At the most,'' Mr. Thackeray said, ''he could be India's son.'' **********Some leaders have even suggested that Gandhi erred by pressing for independence too soon. One of India's foremost Islamic scholars, Maulana Wahiduddin Khan, has said independence should have waited until India -- whose current literacy rate is about 60 percent -- had a better-educated electorate. **********''Gandhi and his followers perceived the British as the source of all evil,'' Mr. Khan said. ''They believed if they threw the British out, they could usher in an evil-free society. But people of my generation will agree that the India of 1947 was a better India. There was peace, prosperity and brotherhood.'' **********Partly, the ceremony today was a matter of unfinished family business, organized by a descendant of India's independence leader, Tushar Gandhi, 36, a graphic designer in Bombay. He learned from a report in The Times of India three years ago that a wooden coffin said to contain some of the ashes of his great-grandfather had been discovered in a branch of the State Bank of India in Cuttack, on the eastern coast. **********After months of hearings last year, the Supreme Court authenticated the ashes as having come from the division that was made at the funeral pyre of Gandhi, who was cremated atop a pile of sandalwood beside the Yamuna River in New Delhi. **********At least a score of urns were filled from the ashes and distributed across India for immersion in the country's rivers, but the urn sent to Orissa state, for reasons that remain obscure, ended up in the bank at Cuttack, which was Orissa's state capital at the time of Gandhi's assassination. **********In the absence of any explanation from government or bank officials in Orissa, several theories have been advanced to explain why the ashes were left in the bank. One is that the Orissa government at the time planned to build a memorial to Gandhi, then forgot about the ashes when the memorial project was dropped. Another is that the ashes were simply overlooked in the confusion that developed in 1950 when the state capital of Orissa was moved from Cuttack to Bubaneshwar, on the Bay of Bengal coast. **********As much as the Gandhi family -- which is not related to the Gandhi political dynasty -- wanted to give its famous forebear ''a final measure of peace,'' as Tushar Gandhi put it today, the ceremony in Allahabad, an ancient holy site, also made a political statement. **********Many Indians who revere Gandhi believe that the neglect of his ashes merely reflects the decline in his relevance since independence. **********The sense of alienation from his ideals was not eased when today's ceremonies were held without any of the country's best-known figures. Prime Minister H. D. Deve Gowda stayed in New Delhi, an hour's flight away, and instead sent a Communist Party leader, Chaturanan Mishra, who is Agriculture Minister in the 14-party coalition Government. The top leadership of the Congress Party, which Gandhi led for three decades, was also absent, represented by a local leader from Uttar Pradesh state, where Allahabad is situated. **********As he greeted local dignitaries visiting a tented enclosure in Allahabad where the ashes lay in state today, Tushar Gandhi said politicians in New Delhi had shown their pettiness by staying away. **********''The political atmosphere in India is so vitiated these days that our leaders calculate everything according to a narrow scale of gain,'' he said, adding that he thought leaders feared Gandhi. ''His very memory is a reproach to lack of leadership and vision.'' **********Among ordinary Indians, matters seemed different. Thousands lined up in the morning sun to throw marigold and rose petals on the coffin, or to cheer as it passed by. **********Government officials, citing a Supreme Court ruling in November that the ashes be disposed of ''with dignity and honor,'' had blocked Tushar Gandhi's plan to display the urn on a road tour through north Indian states. Instead, they had ordered the ashes to be taken from the Cuttack bank to a train, guarded by a heavily armed contingent of the army's Rapid Action Force and carried directly to Allahabad. **********When a launch bearing the coffin reached a floating platform at the point where the Ganges converges with the Yamuna, there were moments that captured some of the hope Gandhi engendered as he crisscrossed India. A large crowd of pilgrims, breaking away from the soul-cleansing dips that draw millions of Hindus to Allahabad, waded waist-deep into the water and burst into a chant. **********''As long as the sun and the moon rise,'' they cried, ''so will your name live, Mahatma!'' **********A lone Hindu holy man, naked except for a saffron-colored wrap, stood silent in the water hoisting a sign demanding an end to one of the practices Gandhi condemned. **********''Dowry-giving is a sin!'' the sign read, referring to the habit, common despite constitutional proscription, of grooms' families' demanding payment from brides. **********A middle-aged woman, serene on a sandbar with her royal blue bathing wrap blowing in the breeze, waved a lonely farewell. **********Whether the ceremony would have pleased Gandhi is a matter of dispute. Although he was an ardent Hindu, he asked that his death ceremonies be kept to a minimum. But Tushar Gandhi thought he might have accepted the rite as a means of stirring debate in India about his ideals. **********''What would the Mahatma have disapproved of in today's India?'' Tushar Gandhi asked. ''What would he not have disapproved of? The caste-ism, the religious divide, the materialism, the aping of the West -- all this he would have found reprehensible. He would be a very disappointed man.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/14/busin.print_headline: Chairman Resigns at Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/14/busin.body_text: **********The chairman of Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank Ltd. stepped down today after he ''suddenly remembered'' knowing that the scandal-ridden bank had made loans to a suspected racketeer, the company said. **********He is the latest executive to lose his job in a scandal over loans to corporate blackmailers that has left the president of the Nomura Securities Company under arrest and has forced the resignations of top executives of Dai-Ichi Kangyo. **********A Dai-Ichi Kangyo vice president and an executive managing director were arrested today, the most senior of 10 officers and former employees who have been arrested in the last two weeks. **********Katsuyuki Sugita, who will become the bank's president as part of an effort to restore its tarnished image, announced at a late night news conference that the bank's chairman, Tadashi Okuda, had resigned. **********Mr. Sugita said he asked Mr. Okuda to leave after the chairman said he remembered knowing that the bank had lent money to Rikiya Kijima, a suspected racketeer. Mr. Okuda had previously denied knowing of any bank ties to Mr. Kijima. **********Dai-Ichi Kangyo also said an internal investigation had discovered loans to other suspected racketeers. **********The bank executives have been arrested on suspicion that they were involved in 8.8 billion yen ($77 million) of loans to a suspected gangster, Ryuichi Koike. The loans, which investigators say were in reality payoffs, have not been fully repaid.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/03/busin.snippet: Credit Markets column; Treasury bonds rally on news that Pres Clinton and Republican Congressional leaders agreed on balanced budget plan; tables show prices of Treasury bills, bonds and notes (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/03/busin.main_headline: Budget Agreement Gives Treasuries a Lift
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/03/busin.print_headline: Budget Agreement Gives Treasuries a Lift
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/03/busin.body_text: **********It was a clean sweep for the bulls in the Treasury market this week. Although prices slipped early yesterday in response to the mixed labor report, after posting significant gains through the week on data that suggested the economy might be slowing, they rallied again in the afternoon on news that President Clinton and Republican Congressional leaders agreed on a balanced budget plan. **********A balanced budget would shrink the deficit, meaning the Government would have to sell fewer bonds. That, in turn, would make existing securities scarcer, sending prices higher and yields lower. **********The 30-year bond rose 16/32 yesterday, to 96 29/32, yielding 6.88 percent, down from 6.91 percent on Thursday and down 26 basis points, or more than a quarter of a percentage point, for the week. **********Traders noted, however, that the market was limited on the upside ahead of the Government's quarterly refunding next week, as the Treasury prepared to sell $29 billion of three-year notes on Tuesday and 10-year notes on Wednesday. **********Some investors were beginning to suggest that the Fed might not need to raise short-term rates much further, while others said the odds in favor of a rate had improved from 70 percent to even. **********One thing that clouded the outlook for Fed monetary policy was yesterday's report that the unemployment rate fell to 4.9 percent last month, the lowest since 1973, from 5.2 percent in March. But the economy added only 142,000 nonfarm jobs, and average hourly earnings fell unexpectedly by 1 cent. **********''While the slower pace of job creations was greatly heralded by credit market investors, everyone is keenly aware of the fact that nothing in this report truly signaled a complete easing of tight labor market conditions,'' said Anthony Chan, vice president and chief economist at Banc One Investment Advisors in Columbus, Ohio. ''If the Fed expressed concern when the unemployment rate equaled 5.2 percent, one can be sure that the new 4.9 percent figure is definitely not going to unleash any new resurgence of complacency.'' **********Discussing the outlook for Fed action, Mr. Chan added, ''It's clear that their apparent intention to raise short-term rates one or even two more times in 25-basis-point increments before the end of the year is very much alive.'' **********He added that with the latest three-month moving average of nonfarm payrolls still hovering near 200,000, it was still pointing in the direction of higher-than-expected growth. ''And when one realizes that labor unrest and weather problems may have understated actual conditions,'' Mr. Chan said, ''one can understand why the market was able to deliver only a lukewarm response to the overall report.'' **********Kenneth J. McCarthy, founder of the Economic Intelligence Company, a research analysis firm, said the economy was slowing as expected, but low unemployment would keep the Fed wary and make market participants cautious. **********''For the Fed, this morning's report was a mixed bag'' Mr. McCarthy said. ''On one hand, slower growth in employment and declining wage pressures indicate an economy that is not in danger of overheating.'' **********On the other hand, he said, the lowest unemployment rate in 24 years has to be a cause for concern because in 1973, when unemployment was below 5 percent for most of the year, the inflation rate soared from 3 percent to 8 percent. **********Mr. McCarthy pointed out, however, that there was an Arab oil embargo in 1973, and average hourly earnings were rising by 6.5 percent. **********In when-issued trading late yesterday, the yet-to-be-sold three-year note was offered at a price to yield 6.40 percent, and the 10-year note, 6.67 percent.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/12/busin.snippet: Broad equity indexes in US end mixed despite overnight gains among Asian markets; Dow Jones industrial average closes at 7,558.73, up 6.14 points, after trading up as much as 47.15 points; table (L)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/12/busin.main_headline: Stocks End Mixed in Moderate Trading as the Dow Rises 6.14
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/12/busin.print_headline: Stocks End Mixed in Moderate Trading as the Dow Rises 6.14
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/12/busin.body_text: **********Despite overnight gains among  Asian markets, broad equity indexes in the United States ended mixed yesterday, as stocks meandered for a second consecutive session characterized by moderate trading volume. **********Indeed, even though markets in Japan and Hong Kong firmed and South Korea's sustained only minimal losses earlier in the day, the United States market failed to retain most of the gains it made at the start of its session. **********With the bond market closed in observance of Veterans Day, stocks also lacked a barometer on interest-rate trends. **********Caterpillar was a victim of the market's malaise. Shares of the company, a maker of heavy equipment, fell 2, or nearly 4 percent, to 48 3/16 on concern that events in Asia and Latin America create uncertainty about the company's overseas business. In addition, President Clinton's failure to win expedited trade negotiating authority may have hurt the stock, analysts said. **********The Dow Jones industrial average closed at 7,558.73, up 6.14 points, after trading up as much as 47.15 points. Shares of large multinational companies like DuPont, Procter & Gamble, Johnson & Johnson and Coca-Cola led the advance. **********Despite its positive finish, the average of 30 blue-chip stocks was undermined not only by Caterpillar but negative financial news from Eastman Kodak and General Motors as well. **********Among broader market gauges, Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks gained 2.65 points, to 923.78. The Nasdaq composite index, heavily weighted with technology stocks, fell 5.86 points, to 1,584.86. **********Declining issues outpaced advancers, 1,486 to 1,336, on the New York Stock Exchange. **********''The downward bias is not a great sign,'' said Alan Bond, chief investment officer at Bond Procope Capital Management in New York. ''With the improvement in Asia, it's not quite as firm as I would have liked to see.'' **********In fact, the stock market's inability to strengthen more on such a light trading day could portend further declines, said Jim Benning, a vice president at Bankers Trust New York. **********''I think people are just concerned that the problems in Southeast Asia are spreading slowly,'' Mr. Benning said. ''At the moment, the U.S. economy looks fine, but that could change. And stocks were up so high. Prices were based on a rosy scenario till the end of time and that's not realistic.'' **********Traders and analysts said that the market was largely unconcerned about today's meeting by the Federal Reserve's policy-making committee because an interest-rate increase is seen as unlikely. **********In addition, little new information is expected to be disclosed tomorrow when the Fed's chairman, Alan Greenspan, and Deputy Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers are scheduled to testify before Congress about Asia's financial turmoil and its impact on the United States economy. **********Shares of MCI Communications and Worldcom were the two most actively traded issues yesterday following Monday's announcement that the two companies would merge in a deal valued at $36.5 billion. **********But questions about the merger -- including those about the stringent regulatory scrutiny it is expected to draw and worries that Worldcom's growth could slow as it raises its debt burden to finance the deal -- weighed on the stocks. **********Worldcom closed at 30 1/4, off 11/16, with nearly 23.5 million shares traded. MCI closed unchanged at 41 1/2, on 19.8 million shares traded, after gaining more than 4 on Monday. **********Kansas City Power and Light shares fell 1 1/4, to 27 13/16 on concern that Western Resources might renegotiate its agreement to buy the utility for about $2.7 billion in stock and assumed debt. Western Resources shares rose 1 5/16, to 37 11/16. **********ON THE WEB **********The latest stock and mutual fund quotations, along with news updates, are available on the Internet from The New York Times on the Web: www.nytimes.com

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/20/busin.snippet: Golfer Tiger Woods signs five-year contract to become spokesman for American Express Co; American Express will not disclose deal's financial details; Brandweek magazine reports that Woods will be paid $13 million over five years, including $5 mill...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/20/busin.main_headline: Tiger Woods Signs Pact With American Express
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/20/busin.print_headline: Tiger Woods Signs Pact With American Express
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/05/20/busin.body_text: **********Now that he has more than enough money to qualify for credit cards and to require a staff of financial advisers, the golfer Tiger Woods has signed a five-year contract to become a spokesman for one of the biggest providers of such services, American Express. **********Mr. Woods, who is 21, will join Jerry Seinfeld as an American Express spokesman, the latest in a line of celebrity endorsers dating to the 1970's, when Senator Sam Ervin asked, ''Do you know me?'' in the company's commercials. **********Clearly American Express expects that Mr. Woods, whose visibility has been surging as a result of several high-profile tournament victories, will not have to ask a similar question. **********Though American Express would not disclose the deal's financial details, Brandweek magazine reported that Mr. Woods would be paid $13 million over five years, including a $5 million up-front fee. Brandweek also reported that American Express would spend $30 million on advertising and promotion to back its commitment to Mr. Woods. But a person familiar with the details of the contract characterized the $30 million sum as too high. **********The only financial element divulged by the company was its donation of $1 million to Mr. Woods's charitable foundation, to benefit junior golf for minorities. **********''That touched my heart,'' Mr. Woods said during a conference call. **********Aligning with American Express catapults Mr. Woods from the hard-core sports business into a broader role as a corporate spokesman. He currently has five-year endorsement contracts, with Nike, for $40 million, and Titleist, the leading golf ball maker, for $20 million. Both were signed shortly after Mr. Woods turned professional last August. **********''In Tiger Woods, we have a representative who has captured the imagination of many different kinds of people,'' Kenneth I. Chenault, the president of American Express, said during the conference call. He said the traits that characterized Mr. Woods -- ''discipline, hard work and preparation'' -- are the pillars of our business.'' **********American Express intends to associate its card, traveler's checks and financial services with the many allures of Mr. Woods: a wealthy, successful young man, with a multi-ethnic background and the longest drives on the P.G.A. Tour. **********''It's hard to visualize anyone he wouldn't appeal to,'' Mr. Chenault said. **********H. Spencer Nilson, the publisher of the Nilson Report, which tracks the credit and charge card industry, agreed, saying: ''This is a coup. There is no one in the world entirely like him.'' **********Not even Michael Jordan, Mr. Woods's sibling as a Nike endorser? ''He's older, he's fading,'' Mr. Nilson said. ''Here's a young, popular person you can use for years. It's positioning yourself with a leader.'' **********Peter Lucas, a senior editor of Card Marketing magazine, said Mr. Woods gave American Express ''an icon to market to potential card holders.'' He also said that Mr. Woods was already a global personality who could be used to market American Express's products in South America and Asia, where growth exists in golf and credit cards. **********Currently, Visa is the leader in the  card market, holding a 46.6 percent market share in total spending, with $308.7 billion in 1996, according to the Nilson Report. Mastercard's $172.6 billion gave it a 26.1 percent market share. American Express's $129.6 billion gave it a 19.6 percent share. **********Mr. Woods and American Express have discussed their affiliation since last December, but they announced the agreement one day after Mr. Woods won the GTE Byron Nelson Classic by two strokes and one month after he won the Masters by a stunning 12. After only 16 tournaments as a professional, and five triumphs, he has won $2.08 million. **********Mr. Chenault said the initial thrust of American Express's marketing with Mr. Woods would involve the company's financial advisory services. (Mr. Woods will add an American Express adviser to a cadre of people tending to his money.) **********Mr. Wood's role will subsequently embrace the credit-card business, which the company is best known for and which has been most widely advertised. The first spot in the Woods campaign is scheduled to go on the air in the third quarter of the year. **********Mr. Woods said that the American Express endorsement was part of a well-defined vision, developed with the help of his father, Earl, and his agent, Hughes Norton of the International Management Group, for how to market himself. ''We had already developed a brand plan that encompasses who I am,'' Mr. Woods said. ''American Express isn't going to branch off into areas where we're in conflict. So I'm going to be promoted in the way I hope to be perceived.''  Other card companies made offers, Mr. Woods said, but he felt at ease with American Express. Brandweek reported that Mastercard had made a bid that included $2.3 million upfront. **********Mr. Lucas said that losing the Tiger sweepstakes to American Express might crimp Mastercard's efforts to further market and promote its golf sponsorship interests. **********Ed Dixon, a Mastercard spokesman, said he would not discuss any talks with Mr. Woods. Kelly Presta, a Visa spokesman, said that company had not pursued Mr. Woods.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/07/busin.snippet: Dow Jones industrial average soars 130.49 points, or 1.8 percent, to close at record 7,435.78 on June 6; graph (M)ÿ
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/07/busin.main_headline: Dow Adds 130, Putting 1997 Gain Near 1,000 Points
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/07/busin.print_headline: Dow Adds 130, Putting 1997 Gain Near 1,000 Points
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/07/busin.body_text: **********In yet another display of the market's seemingly bottomless store of euphoria, stock prices surged again yesterday, lifting most of the major indexes to new records. **********Heavy demand for blue-chip stocks and fresh signs that the economy remains robust, but with few signs of inflation, have buoyed a stock market that continues to baffle even seasoned analysts. **********The Dow Jones industrial average soared 130.49 points, or 1.8 percent, to close at a record 7,435.78 -- leaving the index just 13 points shy of a 1,000-point gain this year. **********In fact, in just over five months, the Dow  has climbed more than 15 percent, giving investors and Wall Street a great deal to cheer about. **********''It's been one heck of a year,'' said A. Marshall Acuff, a market analyst at Smith Barney. ''There were many years in history when people would have been glad to take 15 percent.'' **********The rally yesterday was fueled in part by the bond market, where prices jumped and yields plunged after the Government released data showing that payrolls rose less than had been expected last month, even as the unemployment rate fell to a 23-year low. The yield on the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond fell to 6.77 percent, its lowest level since late February, from 6.88 percent on Thursday. **********Bond prices initially slipped yesterday morning on concerns that the unemployment data would be ominous for debt securities. But bond prices soared later, sending the market to one of its best one-day performances this year, partly because just 138,000 jobs were created last month, down from 323,000 in April. **********The financial markets were also buoyed by reports that European monetary union might be delayed, primarily because of weakness in Germany, where new data show a surge in unemployment. The dollar hit its highest level against the German mark in nearly three and a half years -- 1.7423 marks -- before settling back in New York at 1.7258 marks, down from 1.7288 Thursday. The dollar also ended down against the Japanese yen at 114.60, compared with 115.72 on Thursday. **********But longer term, analysts said, uncertainty in Europe could create stronger demand for the dollar, which is considered a highly stable currency; in contrast, the foreign-exchange market has grown increasingly skeptical that the planned European currency, the euro, will be strong. All of these factors should mean greater foreign demand for American securities, according to analysts. **********While investors viewed the European developments favorably and the payroll data as benign, some analysts said yesterday's rally had less to do with such particular events and more to do with investors' seemingly boundless desire for stocks. **********''Confidence is running high, mutual fund inflows are strong and investors want to own stocks,'' said Joseph V. Battipaglia, chief equity strategist at Gruntal & Company. ''That's because the economy is strong enough to yield better-than-expected earnings but not enough for the Fed to raise rates.'' **********Among the indexes setting records yesterday was the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks, which rose 14.58 points, to 858.01. The Russell 2000 index of small-capitalization stocks also peaked, up 2.15 points, to 387.14. **********It has been that kind of year for the stock market. After two years in which the Dow gained more than 20 percent, few analysts expected stocks to play an encore. **********But the market has foiled most bearish soothsayers. Despite a nearly 10 percent drop that ended in mid-April, blue-chip issues have racked up enviable returns. For example, shares of Wal-Mart are up 38 percent for the year; Coca-Cola, 29 percent, and Microsoft, 50 percent. **********One reason large-capitalization stocks keep sizzling is that investors, continuing to see the global companies as safe bets, ride the wave of momentum buying out of fear that they will miss out on a big rally. **********''There's pressure for performance,'' said Richard E. Cripps, a market strategist at Legg Mason in Baltimore. ''We have more capital that wants to get into the market, and we have few good stock ideas.'' **********Among the strong sectors, financial issues, like banks and brokerage houses, are booming, with the S.& P. financials index up 20 percent this year. And drug stocks are doing even better; the Amex pharmaceuticals index has gained 25 percent. **********More impressive, though, are the broad market gains that have taken place in recent weeks. Small-  and mid-capitalization stocks are now in growing demand. **********Yesterday, advancing issues outnumbered those declining by more than 2 to 1 on the New York Stock Exchange. And program trading, often a sizable factor when the Dow gains more than 100 points, played a smaller role yesterday, according to Birinyi Associates, a market research firm in Greenwich, Conn. **********Still, yesterday's performance was dominated by blue-chip issues. Within the Dow, 29 of the average's 30-component stocks rose yesterday, led by Procter & Gamble, up 3, to 136 1/4; Merck up 3, to 92 1/4, and J. P. Morgan, which gained 2 3/4, to 111 1/2. **********Yesterday's run-up was the ninth time this year that the Dow has gained more than 100 points in a day. Recently, however, the Dow has been less volatile. For the week, the Dow gained 104.74 points, or 1.4 percent. **********The technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index also rose yesterday, climbing 14.79 points, or 1.1 percent, to close at 1,404.84. The index has gained 8.8 percent this year but has lagged behind recently, partly because of Intel's announcement that second-quarter earnings would be disappointing. **********Despite the market's spectacular gains this year, many analysts continue to caution investors that a significant slump could lie ahead. The ''wolf'' is not at the door, Mr. Acuff at Smith Barney said, but that is of little solace to a longtime market watcher. **********''The market, to put it mildly, is historically high,'' he said. ''Some people say it's different this time, but I heard that in the 60's.'' **********ON THE WEB **********The latest stock and mutual fund quotations, along with news updates, are available on the Internet from The New York Times on the Web: www.nytimes.com

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/29/world.snippet: Article focuses on wide range of reactions to Chinese Pres Jiang Zemin's visit to US among Washington's large and diverse Chinese-American community (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/29/world.main_headline: Pride and Censure Mix With a Dash of Apathy
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/29/world.print_headline: SUMMIT IN WASHINGTON: THE CHINESE-AMERICANS; Pride and Censure Mix With a Dash of Apathy
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/29/world.body_text: **********If President Jiang Zemin of China studies the official receptions here this week and the disparate throngs protesting or quietly watching beyond, he will be able to sample a range of Chinese-American concerns as wide as China itself. **********Kung-Lee Wang, an economist and business consultant who co-founded the influential Committee of 100 Chinese-American leaders, says he will be at the reception for President Jiang on Wednesday because he yearns to see a fuller opening of China's vast economic and cultural marketplace to America. **********''We are not there,'' Mr. Wang warned. ''The Europeans and the Japanese are there.'' Counseling creative patience on human rights matters, he said, ''I would not let that one issue become the veto issue.'' **********But half a block from Mr. Jiang's meeting with Mr. Wang and 30 other local Chinese-American leaders at Blair House, vocal dissidents will mass in Lafayette Park to focus on human rights, not economic opportunity, as the prime issue of the China leader's visit with President Clinton. **********''We have been stripped of our nationality and forced to become stateless international refugees,'' Liu Binyan, a celebrated victim of Beijing's intolerance, said on the eve of a protest that will echo with the grievances of the brutal crackdown on the Tiananmen Square democracy protest eight years ago. **********Daphne Kwok is one Chinese-American activist who will be studiously ignoring human rights and economic issues as her focal point. ''I'm monitoring how the visit may or may not play into the campaign finance issue,'' said Ms. Kwok, devoted in her role as director of the Organization of Chinese Americans. **********She says her group has 10,000 members and a sense of absolute outrage at the ''systematic stereotyping'' of Asian-American citizens in the investigations into alleged political fund-raising abuses by foreign-born donors. **********''This is the real issue for Chinese-Americans,'' she said. ''Here we are in 1997 with a major feeling, tolerated among the American public, that it is O.K. to make fun and stereotype Americans who have Chinese features.'' **********Darting somewhere between Blair House and the park protest will be Norman Fu, United States correspondent for China Times, a Taiwan newspaper, taking notes as a reporter fascinated by President Jiang's presence here as ''a paradoxical figure'' who has had a classical education but a ''callous'' rise to power. **********''What is no less interesting is my impression that there may be more Americans than Chinese-Americans opposed to his visit because of the human rights issue.'' **********Beyond these individuals, the mood among the 1.7 million Americans of Chinese ancestry about President Jiang's arrival can be found ranging from the blase to the prideful. **********''I'm kind of ambivalent,'' said Wu-Lang Lee, a Federal economist unstirred by the media drumbeat. **********''It's a routine matter to me,'' said Mr. Lee, a Taiwan-born American who cares deeply about the security of Taiwan but expects President Clinton to win no great reassurances in that regard. **********And pride? Shu-Ping Chan, a community relations specialist with the government of Maryland, insisted: ''Listen, even among my friends who work for the Taiwan Government I'm finding political differences put aside. There's a bit of lingering pride that the Chinese Government is being recognized as a coequal. This is a chance for China to shine -- that's what I'm sensing.'' **********Studying these facets and more, American scholars like Marshall Bouton, vice president of the Asia Society, find Chinese-Americans feeling ''whipsawed,'' as he put it, by the Chinese leader's visit. There is a distinct sense of welcome, but wariness, too, that the visit might somehow redound negatively on them by feeding controversies like the foreign-money campaign inquiry. **********''The visit is and ought to be a very welcome development in putting U.S-China relations back on an even keel after the very traumatic Tiananmen events,'' Mr. Bouton said. ''Many in the community felt the trauma personally. But there was also that sort of shudder, if you will, at the tendency in our history for the Chinese community to be victimized when state relations turn sour.'' **********Just a mile from all the toasting and protesting about President Jiang, Duane Wang, Shanghai-born and an American for four decades, intends to stay busy all week at his lumberyard in Washington's Chinatown. **********''It all depends on where you're from and when you got here,'' was his summary of Chinese-American views. ''I speak as an American. I find the visit a good thing because China is a very old country, and since Nixon opened it up, it has changed tremendously, even in human rights.'' **********''Think of it this way: if it hadn't been opened up, there would have been no Tiananmen Square,'' said Mr. Wang, his faith in time and China strong. ''President Jiang will learn. He will find out our system is good, and he will go home with a different attitude.'' **********Others are not so sure. **********''Personally, I think business will be foremost with President Clinton in the visit, not human rights, and I don't agree with that,'' said the Rev. Samuel Yau, pastor of the Chinese Christian Church of Greater Washington, which serves 350 Americans from China, Taiwan and Hong Kong in nearby Silver Spring, Md. **********Mr. Yau finds no special discussion or protest this week among his hard-working parishioners. He speaks of the campaign inquiry issue not as an outraged Chinese-American, but as as an American with faith in the political system. ''I don't worry about the fund-raising charges,'' he said. ''The system is very much stable in our country.'' **********G. Greg Chen, a worker here in the Mayor's office, earns his living tracking and celebrating the grand disparity of views about China within Chinatown, but also fathoming the relative ignorance of non-Chinese Americans about his birthplace. He hopes the visit will ease both the simplistic ''Communist dragon'' image of China and local anxiety over racist stereotyping. **********''We have lots of people contributing to their new country,'' Mr. Chen said. ''You cannot treat Asian-Americans this way.''
