https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/13/busin.body_text: **********Rallye S.A. made a bid yesterday for Casino Guichard-Perrachon S.A. to shore up its control of France's No. 3 supermarket operator in the face of a hostile $4.6 billion bid from Promodes S.A. The offer from Rallye, which owns 33.2 percent of Casino, involves convertible bonds, cash and other guarantees. If Casino's founding family accepts the offer, it would be impossible for Promodes to gain control. **********The counteroffer comes one week after Promodes made its bid for both Rallye and Casino in an effort to become the biggest supermarket operator in France.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/02/busin.snippet: The Association of South East Asian Nations said Monday that it would begin monitoring Southeast Asia's domestic economies in order to prevent future financial crises, modifying its 30-year legacy of staying out of members' affairs..Finance minist...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/02/busin.main_headline: ASEAN Adopts 'Peer Surveillance' to Monitor Risk
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/02/busin.print_headline: ASEAN Adopts 'Peer Surveillance' to Monitor Risk
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/02/busin.body_text: **********The Association of South East Asian Nations said Monday that it would begin monitoring Southeast Asia's domestic economies in order to prevent future financial crises, modifying its 30-year legacy of staying out of members' affairs. **********Finance ministers from the nine members of ASEAN decided on a system of "peer surveillance" that would evaluate "potential economic and financial risks of member countries, highlighting policy options and implications and encouraging early action to minimize such risks." **********ASEAN also endorsed a decision made in Manila last week for a separate rescue fund for the region. **********Although the notion of peer surveillance may seem far from revolutionary elsewhere, it would be a big step for ASEAN members, which have prided themselves on keeping out of their neighbors' business. The group's mantra has been so deeply rooted that, several months ago, as choking smog blanketed many parts of Southeast Asia, neighboring governments were loath to publicly criticize Indonesia, the source of the fires causing the pollution. **********"The present circumstances and the contagion and systemic risks facing the region [make] it necessary to move forward to develop a regional surveillance mechanism within ASEAN," the ministers said in a statement. **********Coming just a few weeks before ASEAN's 30th anniversary — which until recent months was slated to be a celebration of the members' economic success stories — the meeting Monday allowed the group's finance ministers to discuss the causes of the regional financial crises and possible solutions. **********Malaysia's finance minister, Anwar Ibrahim, said the meeting was "positive, open and frank." It was Mr. Anwar who suggested in a magazine article in July that ASEAN take on a policy of "constructive intervention" and evolve from its historic role as a reactive grouping. The idea was quickly dismissed by Mr. Anwar's boss, Prime Minister Mahathir bin Mohamad. **********Also skeptical of a more proactive ASEAN is the region's other prominent statesman, Lee Kuan Yew, Singapore's senior minister. Mr. Lee said last week that ASEAN members could have a hard time pressuring others into action. **********"Let me put it in a very succinct way," he said. "I'd rather the IMF tell the Thais what they have to do than me and my ASEAN neighbors clubbing together, putting up $17 billion, and telling the Thais 'If you don't do this, we won't give you $17 billion.' We won't be friends for a very long time." **********The ASEAN finance ministers seemed to take Mr. Lee's advice to heart Monday when they recommended that a rescue fund for troubled economies in the region be provided "in consultation with the IMF." **********This contrasted with earlier efforts to create an Asia-based fund that would have been outside the purview of the International Monetary Fund. The issue of the IMF's involvement is important because of the strict conditions usually attached to IMF money. **********Mr. Mahathir said Monday that IMF packages resulted in "a lot of difficulties for the countries concerned and their economies." **********Mr. Mahathir also seemed to contradict the statement issued by the finance ministers earlier in the day when he said the Asian standby fund was "not necessarily a supplementary fund that will be subject to the same conditionalities as the IMF." **********Richard Hu, Singapore's finance minister, asked to clarify the point, said: "It is a facility to supplement the IMF and it will only be invoked if the country signs up with an IMF program."

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/08/world.snippet: US jet fighters step up their patrols over US-enforced no-flight zone in southern Iraq after Iraqi planes breach zone several times (M)
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/08/world.main_headline: U.S. Steps Up Patrols in Iraqi No-Flight Zone
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/08/world.print_headline: U.S. Steps Up Patrols in Iraqi No-Flight Zone
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/10/08/world.body_text: **********The Pentagon announced today that American jet fighters had stepped up their patrols over the American-enforced no-flight zone in southern Iraq after Iraqi planes breached the zone several times during the last week. **********Defense Department officials said two Iraqi fighters had violated the area today, apparently to test American resolve to enforce the no-flight zone and to offer at least a symbolic response to Iranian air attacks last week on military camps used by Iranian opposition groups in southern Iraq. **********Iraqi and Iranian pilots have been put on notice by the Pentagon in recent days that they risk attack if they continue their incursions into the no-flight zone, which was established by the United States and its allies after the Persian Gulf war in 1991. And the warning to the Iraqis was repeated today at a Defense Department news conference. **********''If they carry out flight operations, they risk getting shot down,'' said Capt. Michael Doubleday, a Pentagon spokesman. ''We've done that in the past. We stand ready to do it in the future. But I'm not in a position to predict if and when that will occur.'' **********Last week the Pentagon announced that Defense Secretary William S. Cohen had ordered the aircraft carrier Nimitz to skip a port call in Singapore and hurry from the South China Sea to the Persian Gulf on a previously scheduled deployment. The carrier is expected to arrive in the Persian Gulf four or five days ahead of schedule. **********In what may be a reflection of the Clinton Administration's hopes for improved relations with the Iranian Government, Mr. Cohen said that the show of strength with the Nimitz was meant as a warning to Iraq, not Iran, and his spokesmen said today that the Pentagon was far more concerned about Iraqi violations of the no-flight zone than Iranian violations. **********''I think you need to go back and take a look at what the purpose of the no-fly zone is, and the no-fly zone is designed to keep Iraqi aircraft in check,'' Captain Doubleday said. **********''I think the signal of the aircraft carrier going to the region, the constancy of our flights over there, make it very clear that the Iraqis are very restricted in their ability to carry out air operations.'' **********The American aircraft carrier is to join several other American ships in the gulf, including five destroyers and three guided-missile frigates. **********The Pentagon refused to say exactly how many times the Iraqi military had violated the American-patrolled area during the last week, nor would it explain why the Iraqi MIG fighters had not been shot down. **********Captain Doubleday said that there had been ''several'' violations by the Iraqis, most of them in daylight, and that American fighters based in Saudi Arabia and Bahrain had stepped up their patrol flights as a result. **********''I will describe them as being primarily just skirting the no-fly zone,'' he said of the Iraqi moves. ''I'm not going to get into a play-by-play on where and when they occurred. I don't think that is productive.'' British and French fighters also enforce the no-flight zone. **********On Monday, Iraq warned that it would hit back at Iran ''blow for blow'' if it mounted new attacks on the bases in southern Iraq used by the Iranian opposition. Several Iranian jet fighters bombed two of the bases near the Iran-Iraq border on Sept. 29.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/09/world.snippet: Article on plight of albinos in Africa, notably Zimbabwe, where they are shunned and feared as products of witchcraft; far more than on any other continent, albinism is lifelong curse on African continent, where most albinos languish at home witho...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/09/world.main_headline: Black, Yet White: A Hated Color in Zimbabwe
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/09/world.print_headline: Black, Yet White: A Hated Color in Zimbabwe
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/09/world.body_text: **********John M. Makumbe is a professor of political science. Richard Nyathi is chief librarian for a Government ministry. Stanley S. Gunda is a senior financial officer in another ministry. Not so long ago, they might have been killed at birth. **********Even today, pregnant women refuse to shake their hands. On crowded buses they sit apart. On the street they see mothers point and warn their children, ''If you don't behave, I'll let that monkey get you.'' **********Messrs. Makumbe, Nyathi and Gunda are albinos. In Africa, far more than on any other continent, that is a lifelong curse. They lack the gene that codes the skin pigment melanin, and they are very nearsighted. As white-skinned men in a black society, they are shunned and feared as the products of witchcraft, taunted by children and drunks as ''peeled potatoes,'' ''monkeys'' and ''ghosts.'' **********There is a stereotype that all albinos are intelligent and accomplished, as these three men are. But Professor Makumbe said successful albinos were ''a teeny-weeny minute number.'' Most, he added, languish at home without education because they cannot see the blackboard at school or because their parents, told such children die young, will not pay for their schooling. **********In parts of Africa, albinos rarely live beyond 40. Mr. Nyathi has already lost a 30-year-old brother to skin cancer. And Professor Makumbe said he thought ''many just die of frustration -- of broken hearts.'' **********With a handful of other albinos, Professor Makumbe has founded the Zimbabwe Albino Trust. He dreams of a powerful human rights organization that battles prejudice on albinos' behalf. But his first goals are almost pathetically humble: to raise enough money to buy sunscreen lotion and spectacles for albinos who cannot afford them, and to raise $20,000 for a survey to count albinos in Zimbabwe and see what they need most. **********In the United States, about 1 person in 20,000 is an albino, according to doctors at the University of Minnesota Medical Center, which has a clinic that studies the genetics of albinism. The condition is more common among blacks than among whites, and almost unknown among Asians. **********In parts of Nigeria, as many as 1 in 1,100 are albino; in parts of South Africa the incidence is 1 in 1,800. It varies sharply from country to country and tribe to tribe, said Jennifer Kromberg, an expert on albinism at the South African Institute for Medical Research. For instance, in South Africa it is twice as high among Tswana as among Zulu, she said, because Tswana encourage marriage between cousins while Zulu forbid it. **********Estimates for Zimbabwe vary. One done early last year found that 1 schoolchild in 4,700 was albino. An earlier one found nearly twice that rate in Harare. **********Albinism comes from a recessive gene and must be inherited from both parents. Not all children in affected families are albino. Mr. Nyathi, for example, has two albino siblings, while his parents and eight other siblings are black. **********The condition may skip generations, reappearing to cause confusion and ruin marriages. **********Lloyd Thuchila, a pipe fitter, said his father had left his mother shortly after he was born. ''He said, 'Why do I have to be the one with an albino child?' '' Mr. Thuchila said. '' 'No one in my family has an albino.' '' **********Professor Makumbe, who is married to a black woman and has three black children, said that when his first child was born, one of his colleagues at the University of Zimbabwe asked if the baby was ''black, white or colored.'' **********''He's a physicist,'' Mr. Makumbe said. ''He should know better.'' **********Many men accuse their wives of infidelity when albinos are born. Some even accuse them of having had sex with a tokolosh, a devil's imp who is said to be produced by witchcraft from a tree root and to live under beds. **********Superstitions are strong in rural Zimbabwe. The practice of killing suspected witches survives, and albino children were once smothered at birth. The belief that adult albinos do not die, but simply vanish, is still widely held. **********There is also a lingering belief that albinism is somehow contagious. Many Africans admit to spitting when they see an albino, to ward off the ''spell.'' At parties, Mr. Gunda said, people hesitate to shake his hand. Some albinos say they bring their own food on group outings to avoid embarrassing incidents. **********''When my nephew got a rash when he was 18,'' Professor Makumbe recalled, ''my own sister said, 'You must have got this from your Uncle John.' '' **********Professor Kromberg said surveys she had done among young albino adults in Soweto, South Africa, found that they were rarely shunned on buses or in the classroom but did have much lower marriage rates and believed that they would have difficulty finding work. She said she had come across anecdotal evidence that black children were reluctant to share food with albino classmates. **********More disturbingly, she said studies she had done in the 1980's found that mothers of albino children took about nine months to accept them fully.  ''They keep a distance that's not normal between mother and child, and talk to them less,'' she said. **********She conceded that discrimination might be worse in other African countries. For 25 years she and a social worker have been visiting clinics and reminding nurses to explain to people that the condition is genetic ''and not caused by witchcraft or by the mother drinking orange Fanta during pregnancy or by laughing at an albino or other things people believe,'' she said. **********Many albinos have developed a bitter humor about their lot. Twice in the 1970's during the war against the old white regime, Mr. Nyathi was almost shot by guerrillas who took him for a white man. He was very funny as he described walking home from a rural bus stop and seeing three soldiers leap up from behind a bush, pulling back their rifle bolts, then halting in astonishment when he started shouting at them in Ndebele, the language of southern Zimbabwe. ''Oh, look, he's an African,'' they said. ''Sorry, brother, sorry!'' **********Sibongile Chitiyo, a 27-year-old albino studying social work at the University of Zimbabwe, said she could judge a man's feelings for her by his behavior in public. ''If people ask who I am, and he says 'Oh, she's my sister,' then I know he's ashamed,'' she said. **********Mr. Nyathi, 36, Mr. Gunda, 33, and Mr. Thuchila, 24, met in the library of the Ministry of Industry and Commerce recently and talked about the difficulties of doing ordinary things like dating and looking for jobs. The day-to-day discrimination that albinos face sounded hauntingly like that suffered by black Americans. **********Mr. Gunda recalled how the mother of ''the first girl I wanted to marry'' declared, ''I will commit suicide if I have an albino son-in-law.'' **********All three men mentioned having co-workers who were friendly at work but avoided them socially. **********Mr. Nyathi described job interviews he had set up by phone, and the shock and confusion of the interviewers when he walked in. ''You know you have failed before you start talking,'' he said. **********Several times as the men spoke, ministry employees came around the bookshelves that hid Mr. Nyathi's desk. Each one started at the sight of several white-skinned men, and retreated, apologizing. **********Mr. Nyathi smiled ruefully and reflected on the peculiar shame that discrimination creates in those who must face it. ''Albinos tend to unconsciously avoid each other,'' he said. ''If I see another albino on a bus, I won't go stand next to him. Other people will assume he's my brother or something. But you look at each other, and you both have this sense of, 'They're on to us.' '' **********All three men did well in school, despite vision problems. The genetic differences that cause albinism also change the connections between the optic nerves and the brain. Many albinos have nystagmus -- ''dancing eyeballs'' -- and myopia that, even with thick glasses, can only be corrected to about 20-200. **********''Albinos seem more intelligent because they try harder,'' Mr. Nyathi said. ''You have to get out of your seat, go up to the board, squint, write two sentences, go back, and still finish the test in the same time as the others.'' **********Dr. Kromberg said her intelligence studies had confirmed that. ''Albinos have normal I.Q.'s but a higher capability,'' she said. ''I think it's because they don't play in the sun all day. They stay inside and do their homework.'' **********But poverty and discrimination often hold them back. **********Mr. Thuchila was a good student but could not afford glasses. He became a pipe fitter in a Government motor depot but had to give up the job because the oils on the lathes he used damaged his fragile skin. His bosses, he said, would not give him a different job, or one he could do with gloves on. **********For those who do poorly in school, there is even less hope. ''It's pretty common to see an albino with a little bowl, begging on the street,'' Professor Makumbe said. **********His trust is seeking outside money, but without much success. ''Foreign embassies usually say, 'Give us a development project, not charity,' '' Mr. Thuchila said. **********At Christmas the Mayor's office gave $500, an anonymous donor, $300. Johnson & Johnson's local subsidiary donated 50 small bottles of sunscreen lotion and some toothbrushes. **********John Chinyandura, a 48-year-old unemployed albino who asked Professor Makumbe to pull together the rights group, knows what he would do if there was more money. **********He said he would go on speaking trips throughout Zimbabwe, ''to tell people that we are the same blood -- that we are people.''

The deal would expand Dylex's retail clothing business in Canada to 920 stores. Dylex offered $1.65 (Canadian), equivalent to $1.19 (United States), in cash and one-quarter Dylex share for each Mark's share. https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/04/busin.snippet: Daewoo Corp., South Korea's manufacturing giant, is poised to become the largest automaker in Eastern Europe, with billions of dollars already invested in local automakers.. The company is racing to catch up with regional leaders such as Volkswage...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/04/busin.body_text: **********Daewoo Corp., South Korea's manufacturing giant, is poised to become the largest automaker in Eastern Europe, with billions of dollars already invested in local automakers. **********The company is racing to catch up with regional leaders such as Volkswagen AG, Fiat SpA, Dacia RA of Romania and Avtovaz of Russia, according to recent research reports. **********"Daewoo is obviously taking over," said Elaine Hardy, director of a new regional study by Harbour Wade Brown, British auto-industry analysts. "They're really going places, and the automakers from Japan and Western Europe are losing out." **********Analysts say Daewoo is using low-paid, highly skilled workers to target Western Europe's car markets as well as the growing economies of Eastern Europe. If it meets sales targets, it could become one of the world's top 10 carmakers. **********"I think they are using Eastern Europe as a launch pad to attack West European markets," said Tim Armstrong, an automotive analyst with DRI/McGraw Hill. **********Daewoo executives said recently that the company planned to produce about 2.5 million cars a year — 1.5 million overseas and 1 million in Korea. As wages and living standards rise at home, the company has been building up capacity in Eastern Europe. **********Daewoo already makes cars, light trucks and parts in Poland, Romania, the Czech Republic, Hungary, Slovakia, Russia and Ukraine. It has also said it would consider projects in Bulgaria and Croatia. **********By 2000, Daewoo wants to build 1 million cars annually in Eastern Europe, Ms. Hardy said. **********A report by DRI/Plan-Econ rates Daewoo as Eastern Europe's fourth-largest car maker, behind Volkswagen, Fiat and Dacia. But some analysts say Daewoo's plans are too ambitious. **********"I think they are overestimating the capacity of the market to absorb their production," Mr. Armstrong of DRI said. For now, much of Daewoo's production consists of assembling kits from Korean-made parts. That has left it vulnerable to the vagaries of transition economies. At the Daewoo plant in Craiova, Romania, 10,000 unsold cars fill the fields around the factory after a collapse in the local currency, the leu, effectively tripled the price of a new Daewoo. **********Daewoo says it has sold fewer than 400 cars in Romania this year. **********Dacia, the local rival, uses mostly Romanian parts and saw production rise 20 percent in the first two months of the year, to 16,294 vehicles, as the cost of a new Dacia fell in dollar terms. **********But in Poland, the region's largest market, with 373,542 new-car sales last year, Daewoo's sales of both South Korean and Polish models rose 494 percent in the first three months of 1997, to 28,228 vehicles, according to DRI/Plan-Econ. **********Rather than build all-new factories, Daewoo has been buying state-owned automakers from governments eager to privatize. **********Eastern Europe is one of the world's fastest-growing car markets. DRI reports that 1.9 million cars were sold in 1996, up from 1.6 million in 1995. By 2000, Mr. Armstrong said, the region's consumers will be buying more than 2.5 million new cars a year.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/12/busin.snippet: France's Socialist government said Friday night it would halt plans to sell off its majority stake in Thomson-CSF, Europe's leading defense electronics company, casting doubts on projects to restructure the European defense industry to meet intens...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/12/busin.main_headline: Industry's Restructure Is in Doubt : France Says It Won't Privatize Thomson
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/12/busin.print_headline: Industry's Restructure Is in Doubt : France Says It Won't Privatize Thomson
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/07/12/busin.body_text: **********France's Socialist government said Friday night it would halt plans to sell off its majority stake in Thomson-CSF, Europe's leading defense electronics company, casting doubts on projects to restructure the European defense industry to meet intensifying American competition. **********But Prime Minister Lionel Jospin insisted that in preparing the company's future, the government would take into account "the prospect of mergers aimed at strengthening the defense industry in Europe." **********The privatization of Thomson-CSF had been set by the previous conservative government of Prime Minister Alain Juppe. **********The prospect of privatization had seemed likely to touch off a major realignment of the European defense industry, with rival bids from the missile-making conglomerate, Lagardere SA, and the engineering concern, Alcatel Alsthom SA, in an alliance with the state-owned plane-maker Aerospatiale. **********The vast restructuring of the U.S. aerospace industry — with proposed mergers between Boeing Co. and McDonnell Douglas Corp. and between Lockheed Martin Corp. and Northrop Grumman Corp. — has forced Europeans to consider a Continent-wide makeover of their own. **********Thomson-CSF's chief executive, Marcel Roulet, warned in the National Assembly earlier this week that the company would be in jeopardy if it remained in state hands and stood aloof from the wave of consolidation happening or about to happen in Europe. **********Mr. Roulet said Thomson-CSF must be able to participate in the restructuring for the benefit of France's defense industry as a whole. **********The government's refusal to sell the company raises the same questions as those surrounding Aerospatiale in its relationship with its German, British and Spanish partners in the Airbus Industrie consortium: How can a state-owned or state-controlled company, not fully exposed to market forces, join European conglomerates dominated by private entities? And how can state-owned companies form global partnerships with privatized industries in the United States and elsewhere? **********In its communiqué Friday night after the French financial markets closed, the government did not answer those questions. It said it sought an industrial solution for the company aimed at creating "a French professional electronics and defense sector endowed with a decisive public capital structure." **********It said it had decided to end the privatization process because this failed to "preserve the interest of the state, the company and its employees." **********The statement said that in creating a "professional and defense electronics pillar with a determining public share-holding," the government would ensure that Thomson would be among the "alliances destined to reinforce the European defense industry." **********It added that guidelines for the Thomson restructuring would be implemented in the next few weeks. **********The prospect of several more weeks of indecision was a chilling one for defense and aerospace leaders, who lobbied Parliament this week to call for quick action on consolidating their industries. Several warned that unless the government sold its stake in Thomson-CSF France's industry would be left behind as the rest of the Continent consolidated.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/07/busin.snippet: Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corp, facing wide-ranging criminal probe, plans to drastically alter or abandon many of business practices that helped make it world's largest health care company; internal company documents outline plan for culture shift, ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/07/busin.main_headline: Hospital Giant, Under Attack, Sets Shake-Up
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/07/busin.print_headline: Hospital Giant, Under Attack, Sets Shake-Up
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/08/07/busin.body_text: **********The Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation, responding to a wide-ranging criminal investigation, plans to drastically alter or abandon many of the business practices that helped make it the world's largest health care company and a leading advocate of medical care for profit. **********The changes, described in internal company documents obtained by The New York Times, are a strong break with Columbia's past. They address virtually every policy and practice that has attracted the interest of Federal investigators or drawn public criticism in recent months. **********According to the internal documents, the plan would involve ''a total change in the culture'' of Columbia. The company would take these steps: ***********Sell its home health care business, which along with Columbia's hospitals is being examined to determine whether its expenses were fraudulently inflated in reports filed for Government reimbursement. ***********Eliminate all cash-bonus programs, which were designed to encourage employees to meet financial targets and other corporate goals but which were criticized as an incentive to cut corners. ***********Adopt new programs to insure that employees comply with all laws and regulations, and significantly increase its enforcement staff. ***********Abandon its practice of selling interests in hospitals to its doctors and buy out those who already hold such investments; these stakes have been widely criticized for creating conflicts of interest for doctors. **********Some changes address even small details of the company's culture. For example, according to the internal documents, Columbia will eliminate the use of ''scorecards'' that have been annually distributed to all employees, pinpointing the amounts of revenue in various categories that Columbia's senior executives wanted the hospital managers to obtain. That change is part of an effort to end the company's ''short-term profit orientation,'' the documents say. **********Parts of the plan, which has not yet been publicly announced, were said to have been presented yesterday by lawyers for Columbia to Justice Department officials involved in the investigation of the company. **********Indeed, many of the plan's elements are apparently intended to smooth Columbia's relationship with Federal authorities. In an effort to be viewed as more cooperative, under the new plan Columbia would open its files to Federal law enforcement agents, giving the Government access to all compliance programs, as well as to reports of expenses filed to the Government, laboratory billing records and other documents that are at the center of the growing criminal investigation. The company has been fighting Government efforts to obtain some documents. **********Going forward, the company would also inform Medicare of differences between reports of expenses it submits to the Government for reimbursement, and other cost reports it keeps for accounting reasons. The discrepancies between those two sets of reports are being used as crucial evidence of possible fraud in the criminal investigation. **********The plan also calls for Columbia to grant broad powers to outside lawyers and accountants who would be charged with investigating its current practices, recommending additional new policies and working to resolve the Government inquiries. **********Columbia officials declined to comment on the documents obtained by The Times or on any plans the company has prepared. ''I have not seen the documents you are referring to and cannot comment on them,'' said Victor L. Campbell, a Columbia senior vice president. **********Mr. Campbell also declined to comment on whether the company had adopted the strategies described in the documents. **********The plan comes just 12 days after the appointment of Dr. Thomas Frist Jr. as chairman and chief executive of the embattled company, replacing Richard L. Scott, Columbia's hard-charging founder. Health care experts who were told of certain details of the plan described them as symbolic of a new era for the company, which under Mr. Scott developed a reputation in just nine years as one of the most aggressive -- and profitable -- companies in the business. **********''The extent of these reforms, I think, is a measure of the seriousness of the problems that the company has gotten itself into,'' said Dr. Arnold Relman, former editor of The New England Journal of Medicine. ''We are going to see a softer company that is not going to make as much money as it did before.'' **********Indeed, the changes are the most striking shift in strategy since Columbia was formed in 1987 by Mr. Scott, a lawyer who never managed a hospital, and Richard Rainwater, the Texas investor. Starting with less than $300,000, Columbia built itself from just two hospitals in El Paso to a corporate behemoth with $20 billion in revenues coming from roughly 350 hospitals, 550 home-health-care offices and scores of other medical businesses in 38 states. **********Columbia has been scrambling since last month, when teams of Federal agents began a seven-state raid of its hospitals and offices, seizing hundreds of boxes of documents in a multifaceted investigation that is focusing on whether Columbia hospitals overstated expenses to increase Federal reimbursement. **********In the weeks since, Mr. Scott and his top lieutenant have been forced out by the company's directors, and three Columbia executives responsible for reimbursement for certain Florida hospitals have been indicted on charges of conspiracy and fraud. **********Columbia's decision in the wake of those events to cooperate with the Government is a departure from its previous tactics. For example, according to people who are parties to the investigation, in secret court proceedings in the last year the company has fought Government requests for certain information relating to cost reports. Under the new plan those documents will be made available to investigators. **********The company also plans to be more open about its practices. For example, many Columbia hospitals maintained a secret, second set of cost reports that often differed dramatically from the reports submitted to Medicare. Those second reports estimated how much money a hospital might have to return to Medicare if it was audited. Some Columbia employees had been directed not to discuss the second reports with Medicare officials or to show them the documents. Under the new plan, Columbia hospitals will inform Medicare of differences between the two sets of reports. **********Many changes address problems at the company that were described in articles in The Times beginning in March. Those articles, the result of a yearlong investigation into Columbia's business practices, addressed the company's home care operations, bonus programs for executives who met financial targets, aggressive billing practices and investment opportunities for doctors. **********By deciding to sell the home-health-care business, Columbia is abandoning an area that has become a lightning rod for Federal investigators examining possible fraud in cost reports filed to receive Government reimbursement. Under Medicare rules, outpatient treatments like home care are reimbursed on a formula based on cost. Prosecutors are investigating whether Columbia improperly shifted hospital costs onto its home care agencies and misrepresented the costs of those agencies to increase its total reimbursement. **********A computer analysis by The New York Times conducted as part of its investigation found sharp differences between Columbia and its rivals in the amount Medicare paid for outpatient services like home care. Investigators are said to believe that at least some discrepancies may be the result of hospitals inflating their reported outpatient costs. **********For example, the Times analysis of Medicare data from Texas showed that care provided after hospitalization -- such as home care -- cost Medicare 23 percent more at Columbia hospitals than the state average, even after adjusting for severity of illness. As a result, the report found, the course of care at Columbia hospitals in Texas cost Medicare $48 million more than if the care had been billed at the state average. **********All told, according to Columbia's financial records, the home care business represented the largest component in the growth of its outpatient services, bringing in $1 billion in revenue last year, compared with $547 million in 1995. **********By eliminating cash incentive compensation, Columbia would be addressing what some critics have contended has been a flash point for abuse. Under its current compensation system, hospital administrators and other executives have been able to almost double their salaries through bonuses based almost entirely on meeting financial targets. But decisions about how to meet those targets have been left in the administrators' hands; doctors, nurses and some hospital executives contend that the incentives led to staff cuts that compromised care. **********Dr. Frist, Columbia's new chairman, was not available for comment last night, Mr. Campbell said. But associates said that he had long expressed discomfort with Columbia's policies of selling interests in its hospitals to doctors, concerned about possible conflicts of interest. They said that he also became deeply disenchanted with the home-health-care business, believing that it was too difficult to make money in it. **********Unlike Mr. Scott, Dr. Frist is a physician. As the former head of the Hospital Corporation of America before it was acquired by Columbia in 1994, he earned a reputation as a sharp businessman willing to transform his company to meet market demands. But he is no stranger to cost-reporting controversies: in a 1993 General Accounting Office report, his company was accused of including improper expenses in the cost reports of its headquarters.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/05/busin.print_headline: Factory Orders Rose in July; Analysts Had Expected Drop
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/09/05/busin.body_text: **********Orders placed with factories unexpectedly increased in July to a record level, a sign that manufacturing could be poised for faster growth. **********The Commerce Department said today that factory orders rose two-tenths of 1 percent in July, to a record seasonally adjusted $330.28 billion, after a revised gain of 1.7 percent in June. Analysts had expected the July report to show a decline of one-tenth of 1 percent. **********In a separate report, the Labor Department said the number of workers filing for unemployment benefits rose by 2,000 in the week ended last Saturday, to a seasonally adjusted 326,000. The increase was close to analysts' expectations. **********Stronger demand for vehicles and parts, metals, food, textiles and plastics led July's gain in orders. Orders for aircraft, electronics and communications gear declined. **********Factory inventories increased half a percent in July after having risen three-tenths of 1 percent in June. Analysts have warned that a buildup in inventories could lead to slower factory orders as companies attempt to empty their warehouses and stores of merchandise. **********In the months ahead, strength in manufacturing will come from auto makers, said Kevin Flanagan, an economist at Dean Witter Securities in New York. They will be stepping up output because strikes hampered production of cars and trucks earlier this year, he said. The Ford Motor Company and the General Motors Corporation this week reported vehicle sales for August that were stronger than expected. **********Aerospace, too, will be a source of strength. This week, the Boeing Company announced it had won a $4.5 billion order to build 61 jetliners for the aviation-leasing arm of the American International Group. Additionally, consumer spending remains healthy, with major retail chains reporting today that August sales met or topped expectations. **********Many economists caution that it is difficult to discern trends from month-to-month shifts in factory orders, which are heavily influenced by large changes in orders for commercial jetliners and military weapons. **********Excluding aircraft and other transportation equipment, factory orders rose eight-tenths of 1 percent in July. Excluding the military industry, orders increased three-tenths of 1 percent. **********Orders for durable goods, which are made to last three or more years, fell three-tenths of 1 percent in July. In an advance report on Aug. 26, the Commerce Department said durable goods orders unexpectedly declined six-tenths of 1 percent in July. **********Orders for nondurable goods, including food and clothing, increased nine-tenths of 1 percent. **********Factory shipments, a gauge of current demand, rose 1.4 percent during July. Unfilled factory orders, a measure of pent-up demand, decreased half a percent. **********The jobless claims data for last week were distorted by the effects of retooling of auto assembly lines and by the strike against United Parcel Service, David Shabelman, an economist at MMS International in Belmont, Calif., said. **********The four-week average for new jobless claims, a less volatile measure of employment conditions, rose to 326,500 in the latest week from 321,000 in the previous week.

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/15/busin.snippet: Mark E Whitacre, former Archer Daniels Midland Co executive and chief informant in sweeping criminal antitrust investigation, concedes he fabricated some documents to support his allegations of wrongdoing by Federal Bureau of Investigation, which ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/15/busin.main_headline: Archer Daniels Informer Admits Recent Deception
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/15/busin.print_headline: Archer Daniels Informer Admits Recent Deception
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/01/15/busin.body_text: **********The chief informant in a sweeping criminal antitrust investigation has conceded that he fabricated some documents to support his allegations of wrongdoing by the Federal Bureau of Investigation, and sought hospitalization yesterday for his poorly controlled manic depression. **********The informant, Mark E. Whitacre, a former executive at the Archer Daniels Midland Company, sued an F.B.I. agent on Monday. But he had only used the fabricated documents in recent weeks to buttress his claims about government wrongdoing to reporters. In a lengthy article concerning his allegations, Fortune magazine this week cited a document that Mr. Whitacre now says is not real. **********The developments will likely have little impact on the investigation that has brought Mr. Whitacre fame; rather, they may well highlight a once high-flying executive's struggle with mental illness. **********Mr. Whitacre has been at the nexus of the criminal investigation of price-fixing at Archer Daniels since 1992, when he agreed to use his position as a company executive to work undercover for the F.B.I. **********Since then, the case has experienced twists and turns that bordered on the bizarre. After his role as informant was disclosed, Mr. Whitacre admitted improperly obtaining money from Archer Daniels in overseas bank accounts; after negotiating a plea agreement with prosecutors, he switched gears and proclaimed his intent to fight the Government; after a year in which he publicly praised Brian Shepard, the F.B.I. agent who handled the case, Mr. Whitacre accused him in his lawsuit of ordering the destruction of tapes potentially beneficial to Archer Daniels. **********To back up those claims, Mr. Whitacre provided some news organizations, including The New York Times, with documents ostensibly showing that he had discussed F.B.I. wrongdoing with his psychiatrist and lawyer as early as July 1995. **********It is those documents that Mr. Whitacre admitted on Monday night were fabricated -- a legal act, since none of the records were submitted to a court or Government agency. He maintains that his underlying allegations are true. He added that tape recordings exist that could prove it, though he said they were not in his possession. **********Medical experts said at least some of Mr. Whitacre's behavior in recent years might be indicative of his mental illness. People with manic depression, also known as bipolar disorder, often gain a sense of invincibility that leads to self-destructive decisions. **********During the last few months, according to medical records verified by The Times, Mr. Whitacre's blood levels of lithium, the medication used to treat manic depression, have been too low to offer much -- if any -- medical benefit. **********While declining to comment specifically on any patient's case, Dr. Derek Miller, a Chicago-area psychiatrist who has treated Mr. Whitacre, said that uncontrolled bipolar patients experiencing mania can tell falsehoods while believing that they are speaking the truth. **********''A real crook or a real liar does it very well, but these people don't do it well at all,'' Dr. Miller said. ''They think they are being honest.'' **********Legal experts said that they expected that the latest twist in the Archer Daniels case would have little impact on the investigation. Three senior Archer Daniels executives, including Mr. Whitacre, have been indicted on price-fixing charges. Three executives with Asian companies pleaded guilty to price-fixing yesterday. **********By indicting Mr. Whitacre, ''the Government has already made the decision not to rely on him as a witness,'' said John C. Coffee Jr., a  Columbia University law professor. ''Ninety percent of what he brought to the table were the tapes, and they still remain valid evidence.'' **********Among the documents Mr. Whitacre provided reporters was one purporting to be a letter to Mr. Whitacre from Dr. Miller, which appears to show Dr. Miller's concern in November 1995 about Mr. Whitacre's allegations against the F.B.I. **********There were numerous indications the document was not real: among them, the type and style did not match another letter by Dr. Miller, but were identical to other letters written by Mr. Whitacre, and the letterhead listed a telephone area code that did not exist when the letter was supposedly written. **********On Monday night at his office in Chapel Hill, N.C., at a meeting with a reporter from The Times attended by his wife, Mr. Whitacre first maintained that the document was real. But soon, with tears brimming in his eyes, he conceded it was fake. **********A second document purported to be a fax that he sent in July 1995 to his former lawyer, James Epstein, discussing F.B.I. wrongdoing. It was that document that was quoted in Fortune. Told Monday that Mr. Epstein was available by telephone to discuss the fax if Mr. Whitacre agreed to allow him, Mr. Whitacre conceded that it was also a fake. **********''It's not a fax that was sent at that time,'' he said, adding that he had created the document recently. **********After the meeting, Mr. Whitacre and his wife spoke with his psychiatrist, and he agreed to seek aggressive treatment. **********In a statement yesterday, John Huey, the managing editor of Fortune, said that the main points in its article -- that Mr. Whitacre planned to sue the F.B.I. and that he had a mental illness -- remained true. **********''Mark Whitacre, as we have warned our readers repeatedly, has a big credibility problem,'' he said. ''We have no way of knowing whether what he told The New York Times is indeed true or false.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/26/busin.main_headline: Justice Dept. Deals Setback To Ameritech Long Distance
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/26/busin.print_headline: Justice Dept. Deals Setback To Ameritech Long Distance
https://www.nytimes.com/1997/06/26/busin.body_text: **********In a major setback to expansion-minded local phone companies, the Justice Department recommended yesterday that the Ameritech Corporation be barred from offering long-distance service in Michigan. **********The department said Ameritech had failed to adequately open its existing local market to justify being allowed into a new one, though Joel I. Klein, the chief of the antitrust division, noted approvingly that ''local competition is beginning to take root in Michigan.'' **********The Federal Communications Commission will make the final decision by Aug. 19 on whether to allow Ameritech into the long-distance market in Michigan. While the Justice Department's recommendation is not binding, most experts said the F.C.C. would be likely to go along with it. **********''The process for the Bells getting into long distance is going to be one of knocking on the door until they break it down,'' said William Deatherage, an analyst at Bear, Stearns & Company. ''It will take multiple applications for a company to have a reasonable chance.'' **********Ameritech, which offers local phone service in five Midwestern states, had already withdrawn and resubmitted its application, after the F.C.C. told the company it was likely to be rebuffed. **********The Justice Department has also recommended against allowing another Bell company, SBC Communications, which was formerly called Southwestern Bell, into the long-distance market in Oklahoma. And F.C.C. officials said yesterday that the commission was likely to formally reject that company in a few days. **********But the recommendation against Ameritech carries more weight because it is perceived as more open to competition than SBC. In Oklahoma, barely a handful of customers are getting local phone service from a company other than SBC. In Michigan, the largest competitor, Brooks Fiber Properties, serves more than 5,000 local customers in Grand Rapids. **********Still, regulators in Michigan said Ameritech controlled 86 percent of the residential and business lines in the state. And the Justice Department said the company had not yet created systems that would allow a new competitor to connect its customers into Ameritech's network. **********A spokesman for Ameritech said the company would not comment on the decision until it had reviewed the complete decision. **********The Justice Department's recommendation comes at a time of intensifying debate in Washington over the dearth of competition in the telecommunications industry. With the AT&T Corporation and SBC reportedly weighing a $50 billion merger, some lawmakers and regulators are fearful that the industry is rapidly consolidating into a handful of giants. **********Last Thursday, the chairman of the F.C.C., Reed E. Hundt, assailed a potential AT&T-SBC merger -- saying in a speech that it would be ''unthinkable'' under antitrust laws. And yesterday, Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska introduced a bill in Congress intended to tighten the Government's scrutiny of mammoth mergers in telecommunications. **********In a speech in the Senate, Mr. Kerrey said, ''the urge to compete should not be replaced by the urge to merge.'' **********Despite the mounting criticism, AT&T and SBC are still laboring to reach an agreement, according to executives involved in the talks. Indeed, AT&T has begun waging an aggressive lobbying campaign in Washington -- even though the company has not confirmed the talks. **********In meetings with F.C.C. officials, lawyers for AT&T have suggested ways to structure a Bell merger that they contend would promote, rather than impede, competition. One proposal would be to split SBC into separate wholesale and retail operations. The wholesale company would then sell access to SBC and other competitors on equal terms. **********AT&T has also retained high-powered lobbyists like Robert S. Strauss, a former Democratic Party chairman who is a partner at the Washington law firm of Akin, Gump, Strauss, Hauer & Feld. **********So far, though, the campaign seems to be falling on deaf ears. Officials at the F.C.C. said Mr. Hundt would not change his opposition to an AT&T-Bell deal if SBC were to spin off its local network. **********One senior official, speaking on condition of anonymity, pointed out that AT&T itself had vociferously opposed such an arrangement when the Southern New England Telecommunications Company recently proposed it as part of an application to be deregulated in its home state of Connecticut. **********The debate over AT&T and SBC has become so all-consuming in Washington that executives at other telephone companies said they were worried that it could paralyze the regulatory process. **********Bell Atlantic and Nynex, for example, had hoped to close their $22 billion merger in mid-May, shortly after receiving approval from the Justice Department. But the F.C.C. has yet to sign off on it, and frustrated executives at the companies said yesterday that they probably would not be able to close the deal until the end of July. **********''I do think the AT&T-SBC hysteria has brought out the worst, not only in the F.C.C., but in people on the Hill,'' said one high-level executive at Bell Atlantic, who declined to be identified. **********Another executive at Bell Atlantic estimated the companies were forgoing $5 million in revenue for each day they could not combine their operations. That sum represents both the cost savings and potential synergies the companies could realize by merging. **********Officials at the commission denied that the decision on the Bell Atlantic-Nynex merger had been held up by the AT&T and SBC debate. But they acknowledged that one other piece of business might have been delayed: the F.C.C.'s decision on allowing SBC into the long-distance market, which was ready to be released last Thursday. **********The commission decided to hold off on releasing it, according to one official, because that day Mr. Hundt was speaking out against a potential merger of AT&T and a Bell. This official said the F.C.C. did not want to mix a formal commission ruling on SBC with a speech by Mr. Hundt about a hypothetical merger involving the same company.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/21/techn.snippet: Letter from David Shayt, regarding May 14 article, says it was not David Letterman but Edmund Carpenter, cultural anthropologist, who first noted that people in public places will answer ringing pay telephone even though they know it is not for th...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/21/techn.body_text: **********To the Editor: **********Your May 14 piece dates this pay phone phenomenon (''If a Pay Phone Rings, Who Will Answer,'' May 14) to David Letterman. **********Not so! He cobbed it from the esteemed & brilliant cultural anthropologist Edmund Carpenter, who in his 1973 book, ''Oh, What a Blow That Phantom Gave Me!'' states, ''I copied down the numbers of several phones in Grand Central Station and  Kennedy Airport and called these numbers. Almost always someone answered. When I asked why they had answered, they said, ''Because it rang.'' **********Carpenter also recalled ''a Californian who read his poetry aloud at parties until his friends learned to silence him. But when he played his recordings of these same poems, everyone listened.'' In our brave new world, the electronic voice trumps the real person. You think our new baby is cute? Wait until you see her picture! **********DAVID  SHAYT **********Washington, D.C., May 19, 1998 **********The writer is a specialist in the history of crafts and trades in the Division of Cultural History at the Smithsonian's National Museum of American History.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/06/world.main_headline: ISRAEL AT 50: Many Voices, Not All in Unison, in the Spirited Israel of the 1990's; THE ISRAELI ARABS: Too Israeli an Arab, and Vice Versa
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/06/world.print_headline: ISRAEL AT 50: Many Voices, Not All in Unison, in the Spirited Israel of the 1990's; THE ISRAELI ARABS: Too Israeli an Arab, and Vice Versa
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/04/06/world.body_text: **********Half a century after its creation, Israel comprises a multitude of ethnic and religious groups whose diversity and divisions might surprise the country's Zionist founders. Here are glimpses into some of the lives that make up this very modern nation in an ancient land. **********Salwa Nakkara remembers the first time she went to Egypt. An Arab born and raised in Israel, she was excited at the notion that all the signs would be in Arabic and all the people would be speaking her language. **********The trip proved a disappointment. ''I visited the museums and pyramids, and felt myself in touch with ancient Egypt,'' she said. ''But I discovered that modern Egypt didn't say anything to me.'' **********Soon after that she went to Jordan, and the disenchantment deepened. ''They treated me as an Israeli,'' she said, adding with a smile, ''like I'd be rude or steal the faucet.'' **********For Mrs. Nakkara, an actress, the trips brought home a central reality for many of the million Arabs who are Israeli citizens: fate has left them between two worlds. They are second-class citizens among the Jews, and Israelis among the Arabs. **********''I have both sides,'' she said, gazing out over the sea from her hillside apartment in Haifa. ''I'm Israeli in daily life, but emotionally I'm very Palestinian.'' **********''I'm Israeli when I push at the bus stop, when I never relax, when I wear a bikini on the beach and feel free as a woman.'' **********She probably would not have become an actress in an Arab society, as she has in Israel -- one of the few Israeli Arabs to graduate from the theater school in Tel Aviv and to act in many Israeli productions, often in Jewish roles. **********''But if I see a Jewish child crying and a Palestinian child crying,'' she said, ''I cry with the Palestinian.'' **********Mrs. Nakkara, 39, recalled her elation on the day in 1993 when Yitzhak Rabin, then Prime Minister, shook hands with the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, at the White House, raising the hope that being an Israeli Arab would no longer be a contradiction. **********But for her as for many Palestinians in the region, what followed was disillusionment. ''Today I feel tired of all this,'' Mrs. Nakkara said of the fighting that characterizes Israeli-Palestinian relations. **********''We always dreamed that the Jews would stop changing the street names, that we'd become equal citizens, but nothing happened,'' she said. **********''The Arabs in Israel just want to continue living, not to make trouble, not to shout, not to scream, to keep a low, low profile. I say to my kids, don't dream too much.'' **********She concedes that her life has been comfortable. Her husband is an accountant in Nazareth; they have two sons, and she has plenty of work as an actress. **********At 18, when she enrolled in theater school and plunged into Jewish society, she was the only Arab student. She said: ''Most of them came after the army. That was the main subject of conversation -- all their adventures and feats. I couldn't be part of this talk. I looked at the army as my enemy.'' **********''I realized the Jews knew nothing about Arabs,'' she added. ''Jewish people don't feel the need to know Arabs. We feel we have to know them.'' **********As for the 50th anniversary, she said, ''It's a very sad day.'' Her family's tradition on this day is to visit the site of a former Arab village.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/09/world.snippet: National security adviser Samuel R Berger, in remarks prepared for speech at Stanford University, appeals for Arab support in Clinton Administration's campaign to overthrow Iraqi Pres Saddam Hussein; says recent US preoccupation with overthrow of ...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/09/world.main_headline: Pressing for Iraqi's Overthrow, U.S. Appeals for Arab Support
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/09/world.print_headline: Pressing for Iraqi's Overthrow, U.S. Appeals for Arab Support
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/12/09/world.body_text: **********The Clinton Administration made an open appeal yesterday for Arab support in its campaign to overthrow President Saddam Hussein of Iraq. **********The national security adviser, Samuel R. Berger, said in remarks prepared for a speech at Stanford University, ''Saddam's continued misrule of Iraq is harmful to the Middle East as a whole.'' He laid out economic and political reasons why the region should welcome a new Iraqi Government. **********''The sooner the situation is Iraq is normalized,'' he said, ''the sooner the people of the Middle East can get on with the business of building a more stable region and the more likely we are to realize our goal of seeing the region integrated, with consent of its people, into the international system.'' **********His address was for an event to honor a former Secretary of State, Warren Christopher, on the publication of his new book, ''In the Stream of History.'' **********Mr. Berger acknowledged that the recent American preoccupation with the overthrow of President Hussein was linked to a realization that Washington's long-term policy of containment of Iraq was under serious challenge. **********''Through constant confrontation, our policy of containing Iraq has been successful,'' he said. ''But that does not mean that by itself it is sustainable over the long run.'' **********He also conceded that sanctions, imposed in 1990 after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, might not be viable indefinitely. Russia and France are likely to renew pressure in coming weeks to lift at least the oil embargo on Iraq if arms inspections now being resumed there go relatively smoothly. **********Other members of the United Nations Security Council are lukewarm at best in supporting the embargo. **********''The longer this standoff continues,'' Mr. Berger said, ''the harder it will be to maintain the international support we have built for our policy. Even the toughest of all sanctions regimes in history becomes harder to sustain over time.'' **********Mr. Berger's speech followed one on Thursday by Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright at Emory University. She said the American policy of containment of Iraq had changed to one of ''containment plus regime change.'' **********Ms. Albright also said the United States was working with Iraqi opposition groups. President Clinton first announced that policy publicly on Nov. 15, when he withdrew the threat of American bombing of Iraq after Mr. Hussein ended a ban on arms inspections. **********Even officials in the Administration have doubts about the efficacy of supporting the splintered Iraqi opposition. But exiles say that there has been a notable increase in American activity along those lines as Washington looks for allies in a broader range of groups than in the past. **********Abbas Mehdi, chairman of the Union of Independent Iraqis, which links dozens of small groups based in the United States, said in an interview yesterday that exile organizations had been told by American officials and officials in the region that the American Government had made overtures to opposition groups. **********One is a Shiite Muslim organization led by Mohammed Bakir al-Hakim, based in Iran and apparently operating with the knowledge of that country's Government. Others include Kurdish parties or parties led by members of Iraq's Kurdish minority. **********Senator Richard Lugar, Republican of Indiana, said in Washington recently that the open appeal to opposition groups was ''a very fundamental change'' in American policy, but that it was still in its fledgling stages. **********Mr. Berger, who acknowledged that ''change will take time,'' offered some general incentives to Mr. Hussein's opponents. ''We will also stand ready to help a new government in Iraq that respects the rights of its people and meets its obligations to the world,'' he said. ''We would work to ease economic sanctions against such a new Iraq as quickly as possible. We would work to relieve Iraq's massive economic debts.'' **********But Mr. Berger's broadest appeal was to Iraq's neighbors. **********''At stake is the stability of Arab and Muslim states, our future relationship with them and our fundamental strategic and economic interests in the Middle East,'' he said. ''At stake is our ability to fight terror, avert regional conflict, promote peace and protect the security of our friends and allies.'' **********--------------------        New Inspections in Iraq **********BAGHDAD, Iraq, Dec. 8 (AP) -- United Nations arms inspection teams initiated a series of surprise searches in Iraq today for banned weapons despite angry assertions from the Government that the searches amounted to harassment. **********The official Iraqi News Agency said the inspectors made 32 surprise visits, the highest since they returned to Baghdad last month. **********State-run newspapers quoted Deputy Prime Minister Tariq Aziz, on a visit to Moscow, as saying there was a limit to Iraq's compliance.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/29/busin.snippet: DuPont Co's board approves plan to sell up to 20 percent of Conoco in initial public offering (S)
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/29/busin.main_headline: DuPont Approves a Stock Issue for Conoco
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/29/busin.print_headline: DuPont Approves a Stock Issue for Conoco
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/09/29/busin.body_text: **********The DuPont Company's board approved a plan today to sell up to 20 percent of Conoco, the nation's ninth-largest oil company, in an initial public offering. **********Under the plan, DuPont would offer the company's remaining Conoco shares to DuPont shareholders in a tax-free transaction. **********The sale of an estimated 10 percent to 20 percent of the company, expected to occur by the end of this year, would complete DuPont's exit from the energy business and position Conoco for a possible merger. **********Conoco, which in 1997 accounted for almost half of DuPont's $45 billion in revenues and had $1.0 billion in earnings, filed to sell 150 million shares this year, plus an additional 22.5 million if demand is strong enough. **********With British Petroleum's recent $48 billion acquisition of Amoco, other large energy companies are seeking potential partners -- and Conoco is seen as one of the best candidates. Analysts value Conoco at $20 billion to $25 billion. **********The sale would help DuPont, based here, to speed up efforts to increase its life-sciences businesses. It made $7 billion in life-sciences acquisitions in 1997, including paying $1.5 billion for the Ralston Purina Company's Protein Technologies International soy foods unit and $1.7 billion for a 20 percent stake in Pioneer Hi-Bred International Inc. Last May, it agreed to buy the 50 percent stake of DuPont Merck Pharmaceuticals it did not own for $2.6 billion. **********A Conoco sale could also help restore some credibility to DuPont management, which failed to detect a 16 percent decline in second-quarter earnings until after the quarter ended. The company blamed woes in Asia, low oil prices and difficulties with its agricultural chemicals business.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/05/23/busin.body_text: **********The Radio Unica Corporation said yesterday that it would buy the radio station KBLA-AM in Los Angeles from Sinclair Broadcast Group Inc. for $21 million, bolstering the Spanish-language radio network's presence in the nation's largest Hispanic market. If regulators approve the purchase, the closely held Radio Unica, based in Miami, will own or operate six radio stations, all in the nation's top 10 Hispanic markets, along with a network of satellite affiliates. The Baltimore-based Sinclair Broadcast owns television and radio stations and provides programming services across the country.

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/23/busin.snippet: One of hottest topics for media in New York is the media; both of city's general-interest tabloids have bolstered their media business coverage over last year with daily sections focused on industry; John Polich, newspaper consultant and professor...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/23/busin.main_headline: How the New York Media Cover the New York Media: Intently
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/23/busin.print_headline: How the New York Media Cover the New York Media: Intently
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/23/busin.body_text: **********In a city where books merge into screenplays, where the news jumps from headlines onto the Broadway stage and magazines appear in cyberspace before they make it to the newsstand, it should come as no surprise that one of the hottest topics for the media in New York is, well, the media. **********''So many of our readers on both coasts are in the entertainment and media industries that it is part of our responsibility to give it special coverage,'' said Peter Bart, editor of the weekly and daily editions of Variety, which last week began printing an East Coast edition, Daily Variety Gotham, with an East Coast media writer with the headline-ready name of Jessica Nix. ''The media and the entertainment industries have become so completely intertwined, even in terms of ownership, that this has become an important focus for us,'' Mr. Bart said. **********Both of the city's general-interest tabloids have bolstered their media business coverage over the last year with daily sections focused on the industry. Both papers have covered deals in the industry for years, but the new sections are their attempts to better package coverage for their readers. **********The New York Post has Media City, whose main reporter, Michael Shain, writes a twice-weekly column on the industry. At The Daily News, the section is called Media Business, where Phyllis Furman leads the coverage. **********The New York Times has devoted its Monday business section to media and information in the broadest sense -- telephones and newspapers, movies and microchips -- since May 1995. **********The Daily News began running Media Business about a year ago, said Debbie Krenek, the paper's executive editor, after recognizing the media's role in New York and the public's interest. ''The section covers everything from books to film and magazines -- the whole media world,'' Ms. Krenek said. ''It's a big industry in the city, and we focus on it as a business.'' **********The Post, owned by Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation, has been famous for its gossip about New York's heavy hitters. It got into media coverage years ago with a weekly review, invariably disapproving, of the way The New York Times went about its business. The column was written by Hilton Kramer, a former Times art critic, and has since been discontinued as the paper broadened its coverage of all media, said Ken Chandler, The Post's editor. **********''I think people forget that New York is the capital for foreign correspondents who are covering America from here,'' Mr. Chandler said. ''Their agenda is very much driven by what they see in the papers and on TV in this city.'' **********All this media self-absorption in New York City draws a dissent from John Polich, a newspaper consultant and professor of media business management at Fordham University. **********''Rupert Murdoch was one of the first to viscerally grasp that the geo-synchronous satellite was going to take the media industry global, and that media as an institution were no longer going to be grounded anywhere anymore,'' Mr. Polich said. **********After all, the television networks' corporate headquarters may be in New York City, and their evening news broadcasts may originate from Manhattan, but the rest of television has fallen into the hands of independent producers and distributors across the country, Mr. Polich said. **********''I think the era when Dave Garroway or Walter Cronkite sat in New York and you just knew that New York was the center of the news business in the United States is long gone,'' Mr. Polich continued. ''The networks don't have the dominant place in the country's life anymore, while CNBC and MSNBC are doing some of the best work in TV news from New Jersey, while CNN is in Atlanta.'' **********Mr. Bart, the editor of Variety, who sits in Los Angeles most of the time, says that New Yorkers get a little self-involved. **********''There is a degree of narcissism about the way we cover each other,'' he said, ''because we do like to read about ourselves, even if we are being a little self-referential.''

https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/16/busin.snippet: Ad agency Weiss, Whitten, Stagliano is being renamed Weiss Whitten Stagliano Partners as nine creative, account, production and administrative executives are given stock in agency; new partners are gaining undisclosed minority interest in agency f...
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/16/busin.main_headline: Seeking growth, Weiss, Whitten, Stagliano changes its name and adds nine partners.
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/16/busin.print_headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; Seeking growth, Weiss, Whitten, Stagliano changes its name and adds nine partners.
https://www.nytimes.com/1998/10/16/busin.body_text: **********A CREATIVELY focused New York agency is reorganizing as the principals seek to spark new growth. **********The agency, Weiss, Whitten, Stagliano, which creates campaigns for clients like Allied Domecq, The Economist, Ferrari and Guinness, is being renamed Weiss Stagliano Partners as nine creative, account, production and administrative executives are given stock in the downtown shop. The new partners are gaining the undisclosed minority interest in the agency from Marty Weiss and Adam Stagliano, who will hold the majority of the equity and voting shares. **********Weiss Stagliano was formed seven years ago as Weiss, Whitten, Carroll, Stagliano with the merger of two small shops that opened in 1989. Of the four principals who joined forces in 1991, the two who remain are Mr. Weiss, creative director, and Mr. Stagliano, president and account planning director. **********As for the other two, Tom Carroll, who left in 1993, is a partner at Messner Vetere Berger McNamee Schmetterer Euro RSCG, a unit of Havas Advertising in New York. And Nat Whitten, who left in November, started his own agency, Nat Whitten Inc. in New York. **********Weiss Stagliano is part of a new generation of agencies that were founded in the late 1980's and early 1990's by entrepreneurial talents who broke away from such hot shops as Chiat/Day; Fallon McElligott; Goodby, Silverstein & Partners, and Wieden & Kennedy. Though many of the newcomers are thriving, there is a widespread perception, as Warren Berger wrote in an article in the July-August issue of the trade publication Creativity, that they ''have not evolved all that far'' and ''have yet to hit the kind of early home run that promises future greatness.'' **********Progress for Weiss Stagliano, which estimates its billings at $85 million to $90 million, has been impeded by two recent setbacks. The Barnes & Noble Inc. retail and on-line accounts, with billings estimated at more than $40 million, left after less than a year for the New York office of TBWA/Chiat/Day, part of the TBWA Worldwide unit of Omnicom Group. **********And the estimated $35 million Guerlain fragrance account, once shared by Weiss Stagliano with WSP/Australie, part of the Euro RSCG unit of Havas in Paris, was consolidated at the French agency by the French perfumer, which is owned by LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton. Weiss Stagliano does, however, continue to maintain ties with WSP/Australie. **********''Do I think we had an aspiration 10 years ago to be bigger?'' Mr. Stagliano, 43, said in an interview. ''Absolutely.'' **********''I don't think we're quite as brash as we were,'' he added. ''But we still believe in our vision.'' **********Mr. Weiss, 44, who joined Mr. Stagliano for the interview, agreed. **********''We didn't lose a lot of sleep over what seemed like 'hits' to the outside world,'' Mr. Weiss said, because ''we've never felt more solid.'' **********''We have more focus and we have more management,'' he added. ''It's all coming together.'' **********One reason Mr. Stagliano gave for describing himself as a ''psychopathic optimist'' is that, he said, the agency ''has never been as busy new-business-wise.'' He listed a new $5 million account from American Skandia, a unit of the Skandia Insurance Company Ltd., and additional assignments from such clients as Allied Domecq Spirits and the Guinness Import Company. **********Weiss Stagliano is also taking part in account reviews, Mr. Stagliano said, that include the Chupa Chups lollipops sold by Chupa Chups USA and the Concord watch brand sold by Movado Group. **********''We've weathered partners leaving,'' he added, ''and the leaving of some fairly highly visible clients. We are not the new kids on the block; we have a certain maturity.'' **********The naming of the new partners is meant to encourage their efforts in the Weiss Stagliano advertising operation as well as at units that specialize in film and music, Internet marketing and brand design. **********''We wanted to come up with an incentive scheme,'' Mr. Stagliano said, ''and at agencies that can mean only one thing: giving out equity.'' **********The new partners are: Paul Budd, 35, studio director; Jeff Compton, 33, creative supervisor; Neil Cotton, 32, group account director; Louise Fischer, 31, group account director; Todd Gallentine, 34, creative supervisor; Jeff Greenberg, 41, production services director; Gay Holmes, 32, group account planning director; William Livolsi Jr., 39, chief financial officer, and Mark Mendelis, 30, creative supervisor.
